name: Christmas pie
description: Combine a few key Christmas flavours here to make a pie that both children and adults will adore
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2 tsp chopped fresh or 1tsp dried thyme
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Heat 1 tbsp oil and the butter in a frying pan, then add the onion and fry for 5 mins until softened. Cool slightly. Tip the sausagemeat, lemon zest, breadcrumbs, apricots, chestnuts and thyme into a bowl. Add the onion and cranberries, and mix everything together with your hands, adding plenty of pepper and a little salt.

Cut each chicken breast into three fillets lengthwise and season all over with salt and pepper. Heat the remaining oil in the frying pan, and fry the chicken fillets quickly until browned, about 6-8 mins.

Roll out two-thirds of the pastry to line a 20-23cm springform or deep loose-based tart tin. Press in half the sausage mix and spread to level. Then add the chicken pieces in one layer and cover with the rest of the sausage. Press down lightly.

Roll out the remaining pastry. Brush the edges of the pastry with beaten egg and cover with the pastry lid. Pinch the edges to seal, then trim. Brush the top of the pie with egg, then roll out the trimmings to make holly leaf shapes and berries. Decorate the pie and brush again with egg.
Set the tin on a baking sheet and bake for 50-60 mins, then cool in the tin for 15 mins. Remove and leave to cool completely. Serve with a winter salad and pickles.
chief_review: This Christmas pie is a festive delight, beautifully balancing the savoury richness of sausagemeat and chicken with bursts of sweet dried apricots and tangy cranberries. The addition of chestnuts gives a pleasing texture and echoes traditional holiday ingredients, while fresh thyme and lemon zest add aromatic complexity. The use of ready-made shortcrust pastry simplifies preparation without sacrificing flavour, and a golden egg glaze gives the pie a lovely, inviting finish. This recipe would particularly suit those on a nut-free diet (as it uses chestnuts, which are technically a seed and rarely trigger nut allergies), but is not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or those requiring gluten- or dairy-free options. The result is a crowd-pleasing dish that graces the festive table with both comfort and flair—an excellent centerpiece for a holiday gathering.

name: Simmer-&-stir Christmas cake
description: An easy-to-make alternative to traditional Christmas cakes which requires no beating
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 750g luxury mixed dried fruit (one that includes mixed peel and glacé cherries)
finely grated zest and juice of 1 orange
100ml/3½ fl oz cherry brandy or brandy plus 4tbsp more
directions: Put the butter, sugar, fruit, zests, juice and 100ml/3½fl oz brandy in a large pan. Bring slowly to the boil, stirring until the butter has melted. Reduce the heat and bubble for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Remove the pan from the heat and leave to cool for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 150C/gas 2/ fan 130C and line a 20cm round cake tin. Toast the nuts in a dry frying pan, tossing them until evenly browned, or in the oven for 8-10 minutes - keep an eye on them as they burn easily. When they are cool, chop roughly. Stir the eggs, nuts and ground almonds into the fruit mixture and mix well. Sift the flour, baking powder and spices into the pan. Stir in gently, until there are no traces of flour left.
Spoon the mixture into the tin and smooth it down evenly - you will find this is easiest with the back of a metal spoon which has been dipped into boiling water.

Bake for 45 minutes, then turn down the heat to 140C/gas 1/ fan120C and cook for a further 1-1¼ hours (about a further 1¾ hours if you have a gas oven) until the cake is dark golden in appearance and firm to the touch. Cover the top of the cake with foil if it starts to darken too much. To check the cake is done, insert a fine skewer into the centre - if it comes out clean, the cake is cooked.

Make holes all over the warm cake with a fine skewer and spoon the extra 4tbsp brandy over the holes until it has all soaked in. Leave the cake to cool in the tin. When it's cold, remove it from the tin, peel off the lining paper, then wrap first in baking parchment and then in foil. The cake will keep in a cupboard for up to three months or you can freeze it for six months.
chief_review:
This alternative Christmas cake presents a sumptuous array of festive flavors, highlighted by rich muscovado sugar, mixed dried fruit, zesty citrus, and aromatic spices. The use of macadamia nuts and ground almonds adds both texture and depth, while cherry brandy infuses a delicate warmth evocative of the season. The recipe’s simplicity—no beating required—makes it accessible even for novice bakers, yet it sacrifices nothing in taste or moistness.

The inclusion of ground almonds and macadamia nuts makes this cake a delightful option for those who appreciate nutty undertones, but it is unsuitable for anyone with nut allergies. The cake contains both eggs and butter, meaning it is not appropriate for vegan or dairy-free diets. With its reliance on plain flour, it is also unsuitable for those with gluten sensitivities. Nonetheless, for lovers of traditional fruitcakes, this festive treat is a wonderfully easy and flavorful choice.

name: Christmas cupcakes
description: These beautiful and classy little cakes make lovely gifts, and kids will enjoy decorating them too
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 100ml dark rum, brandy or orange juice
400g pack ready-rolled marzipan(we used Dr Oetker)
4 tbsp warm apricotjam or shredless marmalade
directions: Tip the sugar, butter, dried fruit, whole cherries, ginger, orange zest and juice into a large pan. Pour over the rum, brandy or juice, then put on the heat and slowly bring to the boil, stirring frequently to melt the butter. Reduce the heat and bubble gently, uncovered for 10 mins, stirring every now and again to make sure the mixture doesn’t catch on the bottom of the pan. Set aside for 30 mins to cool.
Stir the nuts, eggs and ground almonds into the fruit, then sift in the flour, baking powder and spices. Stir everything together gently but thoroughly. Your batter is ready.

Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Scoop the cake mix into 12 deep muffin cases (an ice-cream scoop works well), then level tops with a spoon dipped in hot water. Bake for 35-45 mins until golden and just firm to touch. A skewer inserted should come out clean. Cool on a wire rack.
Unravel the marzipan onto a work surface lightly dusted with icing sugar. Stamp out 12 rounds, 6cm across. Brush the cake tops with apricot jam, top with a marzipan round and press down lightly.
Make up the fondant icing to a spreading consistency, then swirl on top of each cupcake. Decorate with sugared almonds and snowflakes, then leave to set. Will keep in a tin for 3 weeks.
chief_review: This recipe produces elegant, festive cakes that are perfect for gifting or a fun decorating activity with kids. With its rich mix of dried fruit, pecans, warm spices, and a decadent marzipan and fondant topping, each bite is an explosion of flavors and textures, reminiscent of classic holiday fruit cake but in a charming individual portion. The addition of either rum, brandy, or orange juice allows for a non-alcoholic adaptation, making it versatile for all ages. Notably, the recipe is wheat-based but incorporates ground almonds and plenty of fruit, offering a delicious option for those following a vegetarian diet. However, due to the presence of eggs, butter, and marzipan, it's not suitable for vegans. Nut and gluten allergies should also be noted given the pecans and flour. It's a luxurious treat for festive occasions with a sophisticated presentation.

name: Christmas buns
description: Paul Hollywood's fruit rolls can be made ahead then heated up before adding a glossy glaze and citrus icing
author: Paul Hollywood
ingredients: 500g strong white flour, plus extra for dusting
40g unsalted butter, softened at room temperature
directions: Put the flour and 1 tsp salt into a large bowl. Make a well in the centre and add the yeast. Meanwhile, warm the milk and butter in a pan until the butter melts and the mixture is lukewarm. Add the milk mixture and egg to the flour mixture and stir until the contents come together as a soft dough (add extra flour if you need to).
Tip the dough onto a well-floured surface. Knead for 5 mins, adding more flour if necessary, until the dough is smooth, elastic and no longer sticky.

Lightly oil a bowl with the vegetable oil. Place the dough in the bowl and turn until covered in oil. Cover the bowl with cling film and set aside in a warm place for 1 hr or until doubled in size. Lightly grease a baking sheet and set aside.

For the filling, knock the dough back to its original size and turn out onto a lightly floured surface. Roll it into a 1cm-thick rectangle. Brush all over with the melted butter, then sprinkle over the sugar, cinnamon and fruit.
Roll up the dough into a tight cylinder, cut into 9 x 4cm slices and position on the prepared baking sheet, leaving a little space between. Cover with a tea towel and set aside to rise for 30 mins.
Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Bake the buns for 20-25 mins or until risen and golden brown. Meanwhile, melt the glaze sugar with 4 tbsp water until syrupy.
Remove from oven and glaze. Set aside to cool on a wire rack. Once cool, mix the zest and icing sugar with about 2 tbsp water to drizzle over the buns. Serve.
chief_review:
Paul Hollywood’s fruit rolls exhibit classic baking craftsmanship, featuring a pillowy enriched dough swirled with warm cinnamon, vibrant cranberries, and apricots. The balance of soft brown sugar and citrus zest creates a beautiful aroma and appealing sweetness, while the final glaze and lemon-infused icing lend a professional, glossy finish. These rolls are ideal for breakfast or an indulgent brunch, made all the more convenient by their make-ahead design.

This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat, fish, or animal-derived rennet. However, it does include dairy and eggs, so it’s not vegan. Be mindful of those with gluten intolerance or dairy allergies due to the flour, butter, and milk. Overall, these fruit rolls deliver a delightful combination of texture and fruity flavor, sure to impress for any special occasion or cozy gathering.

name: Christmas cupcakes
description: Made these for the second time today, and I have to say they turned out great! I've got large muffin tins and the mixture made 15 muffins, will definetely make these again at christmas time and decorate festively.
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: natural green food colouring(for Christmas trees), sweets, sprinkles and white chocolate stars
milk and white chocolatebuttons and natural colouring icing pens, available at Asda
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170 fan/gas 5 and line a 12-hole muffin tin with cake cases. Put all the cake ingredients into a bowl and mix with a whisk until smooth. Spoon the mix into the cases, bake for 25 mins until golden and risen and a skewer comes out clean. Cool on a wire rack.

For the frosting, beat the butter, vanilla extract and icing sugar until pale and creamy and completely combined. To make snowmen, reindeer and Christmas puddings, first spread the icing over the top of each cake. Then lay the chocolate buttons on top, slicing some buttons into quarters to make ears and hats. Finally, use icing pens for the details. For the Christmas tree, colour the icing with green food colouring and pipe onto the cakes using a star-shaped nozzle, decorate with sweets, sprinkles and white chocolate stars.
chief_review:
This festive muffin recipe offers a lovely, moist crumb and buttery flavor—ideal for creative Christmas decorating with its playful use of food coloring, sprinkles, and assorted sweets. The inclusion of self-raising flour and eggs gives the muffins an excellent rise. As a chef, I appreciate the combination of natural yogurt and butter, resulting in a tender, rich base without being overly heavy. 

This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin. However, those with dairy allergies or lactose intolerance will need to seek alternatives due to the presence of butter and yogurt. The versatility in decoration invites personalization, making these muffins a fun centerpiece for holiday gatherings.

name: Christmas slaw
description: A nutty winter salad which is superhealthy, quick to prepare and finished with a light maple syrup dressing
author: Good Food
directions: Peel strips from the carrots using a vegetable peeler, then mix with the other salad ingredients in a large bowl. Combine all the dressing ingredients in a jam jar, season, then put the lid on and shake well. Toss through the salad when you’re ready to eat it. The salad and dressing will keep separately in the fridge for up to four days.
chief_review:
This vibrant winter salad delivers a delightful medley of textures and flavors—crunchy pecans, crisp vegetables, and a tangy-sweet maple mustard dressing. The carrots, white cabbage, and red peppers shine with freshness, while spring onions add a gentle bite. The maple syrup and Dijon mustard blend beautifully with cider vinegar and olive oil, resulting in a light yet flavorful coating for the vegetables. 

As a chef, I appreciate its versatility and speed; it can stand alone as a light meal or complement heartier winter mains. The use of pecans provides healthy fats and protein, making the salad both nourishing and satisfying. This recipe is particularly well-suited for vegan and gluten-free diets, with all components plant-based and free from gluten-containing grains. A smart choice for health-conscious diners and those with dietary restrictions seeking a festive, fuss-free dish.

name: Christmas mess
description: Delicious and a synch to make! Have made this a couple of times as a dinner party dessert, very pretty as a winter alternative to Eton mess. The fact you use frozen fruits is great, I just used a bog standard pack of frozen mixed berries and added some home made blackberry liqueur. Like other people, I added more cinnamon. Thumbs up!
author: Caroline Hire
ingredients: 1 x 500g bag frozen mixed berries(we used Sainsbury's Black Forest fruits)
directions: In a small saucepan gently heat the frozen berries, icing sugar and cinnamon until the sugar has dissolved. Remove from the heat, stir in the cassis, if using, and set aside to cool completely.

Whip the double cream and Greek yogurt until just holding it’s shape, ripple through the lemon curd. Break the meringue nests into a glass bowl, or 8 individual glasses. Spoon over half the cream, then half the berries. Repeat with the remaining cream and berries. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This dessert recipe offers a luxurious, crowd-pleasing finish to any dinner party, brilliantly combining the richness of double cream and Greek yoghurt with the tartness of mixed berries. The use of frozen fruit not only adds convenience but also ensures vibrant flavours year-round. Adding homemade liqueur or cassis infuses an elegant depth, while a touch of cinnamon brings lovely warmth—especially fitting for winter gatherings. The meringue nests provide delightful crunch, balancing the creamy and tangy layers. This is an ideal recipe for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatine. However, note that traditional meringue is made with egg whites, and there is dairy throughout, so it isn’t suitable for vegans or those avoiding eggs or lactose. Overall, visually stunning and fabulously indulgent, this dessert deserves frequent encores at festive tables.

name: Christmas brownies
description: can I made these the day before
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 200g unsalted buttercut into cubes, plus extra for greasing
directions: Grease and line a 20cm x 20cm brownie tin. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the butter and both types of chocolate in a heat proof bowl and either melt in the microwave (in 30 second bursts, stirring after each) or set over a pan of barely simmering water, stirring every now and then until the chocolate has melted.

Leave the chocolate and butter mixture to cool a little while you whisk the eggs and caster sugar in a large bowl using electric beaters. Once the mixture is pale, fluffy and looks like it’s roughly doubled in volume, whisk in the melted chocolate. Fold in the flour, cocoa powder and mixed spice until no pockets of flour remain then pour into your prepared tin. Level the top with a spatula and bake for 20-25 mins. The top should look set and shiny but should be a little wobbly if you gently jostle the tin.

Leave the brownie to cool completely in the tin then chill in the fridge until set. While the brownie cools brush the rosemary sprigs and glacé cherries with egg white, dab off the excess with kitchen paper then dredge in caster sugar until well coated. Leave to dry on a wire rack. Put the chocolate truffles onto a sheet of baking paper or foil then spray with the edible gold lustre.

Dust the chilled brownie with icing sugar to create a snowy surface and top with amaretti biscuit pieces then poke the crystalised rosemary sprigs into the surface at random intervals (cut the brownie into pieces and dust on icing sugar first, if you like). Nestle a glacé cherry or gold truffle alongside the rosemary sprig then add the buttons and silver balls.
chief_review: This festive, decadent bake is perfect for serving at a special occasion, and the clever layering of chocolates, truffles, amaretti biscuits, and aromatic rosemary create a sophisticated treat. The addition of glacé cherries and mixed spice infuse a subtly fruity, wintry note. From a dietary perspective, this recipe is not suitable for gluten-free or nut-free diets (due to the plain flour and amaretti biscuits, which often contain almonds). It is also not suitable for vegans or dairy-free diets due to butter, milk, and eggs. However, it works for a vegetarian audience since no meat or gelatin is present. Making these a day ahead is actually ideal, as the flavors have time to meld and the texture settles beautifully. Expect a rich, fudgy, elaborate dessert sure to impress.

name: Christmas cosmopolitan
description: How many servings have you gotten using the above measures?
author: Good Food
ingredients: juice 5 limes, keep zest for garnish
directions: Mix the vodka and ginger wine in a jug. Stir in the cranberry juice, lime juice and some sliced stem ginger. Garnish with lime zest, if you like.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail is a lively blend of vodka, ginger wine, cranberry juice, and fresh lime juice, finished with zesty lime and stem ginger. With 2 liters of spirits and juice, you can expect about 10-12 servings if poured over ice, making it ideal for a festive gathering. The harmonious balance between sweet, tart, and warming ginger notes creates a truly crowd-pleasing drink. Since the ingredients are all plant-based and free from animal products, this recipe is suitable for vegans and vegetarians. Additionally, as long as you ensure the ginger wine and vodka are produced without gluten-containing grains, the cocktail can be gluten-free—though always check brand-specific labels if serving guests with allergies. For best presentation, serve in chilled glasses with a curl of lime zest and a slice of stem ginger for that extra flourish.

name: Christmas pizza
description: Use up leftover roast turkey and sausagemeat stuffing in this new spin on an Italian classic
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: large handful (about 100g) leftover stuffing(a sausage stuffing works well for this)
large handful (about 100g) leftover cooked turkey, shredded
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Prepare the pizza base mix following pack instructions. Once rolled out, leave to rest for 10 mins, then top with the pasta sauce.

Scatter over the stuffing and turkey, then top with the mozzarella. Toss the sage leaves with the oil, then scatter over the pizza, drizzling over any remaining oil. Bake for 10-12 mins until the crust is crisp and the cheese has melted.
chief_review: This inventive twist on an Italian classic makes excellent use of holiday leftovers, transforming roast turkey and sausagemeat stuffing into a hearty, flavor-packed pizza. The sausage stuffing adds a robust, savory character that pairs beautifully with the mellow mozzarella and punchy tomato sauce, while fresh sage contributes an aromatic finish. The pizza basemix ensures a crisp, sturdy foundation that holds up well to the generous toppings. For best results, crack the base thin and bake in a very hot oven for a golden, bubbly crust. This recipe is ideal for those who enjoy rich, comforting flavors and want to minimize food waste, all while creating a meal that’s both satisfying and novel.

name: Christmas poussin
description: Prepare ahead and pop in the oven when your guests arrive. Perfect if you don't want to be tied to the kitchen
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 230C/fan 210C/gas 8. Smear the butter all over the poussins, season inside and out, then criss-cross the bacon over each one. Sit the poussins in a roasting tin and cook for 40 mins until the birds are golden and the bacon is crisp. Remove from the tin, leave to rest and set the tin aside until you’re ready to make the gravy.

About 5 mins before you sit down to eat, make the gravy. Place the tin on a medium heat, then stir in the flour and splash in the Worcestershire sauce. Bubble together, then drain the veg over the roasting tin and stir in the vegetable stock. Bring the gravy to the boil, taste for seasoning, adding more Worcestershire sauce if needed, then pour into a warm gravy jug.
chief_review: This recipe offers a classic combination of tender poussin and smoky bacon, finished with a rich, flavorful sauce thickened with flour and elevated by Worcestershire sauce. The use of butter lends depth and silkiness, making the final dish wonderfully comforting. Its make-ahead nature is a highlight for entertaining—allowing for effortless oven finishing when guests arrive. Given the ingredients, this dish is well-suited for those following a gluten-containing and omnivorous diet but would not be appropriate for anyone seeking gluten-free, dairy-free, vegetarian, or vegan fare. The recipe’s reliance on simple, high-quality ingredients ensures a robust flavor profile—just take care to season well and not overcook the delicate poultry. It promises to be a crowd-pleaser at any dinner gathering.

name: Mary Berry's Christmas chutney
description: A perfect match for cheese and cold meats, and delicious in turkey sandwiches
author: Mary Berry
ingredients: 3 red peppers, 1 large aubergine and 1 green pepper (total weight of about 900g/2lb)
700g onion, peeled and fairly finely chopped, by hand or in a food processor
300ml/½pint white wine vinegar or distilled malt vinegar
directions: Peel the tomatoes - prick them with a sharp knife, place in a bowl and cover with boiling water. Leave for a few seconds then drain and cover with cold water. The skins will now come away easily.

Chop the tomatoes and aubergine and seed and chop the peppers. Put in a large heavy-based pan with the onions and garlic and bring to the boil. Cover with a lid, lower the heat and gently simmer for about one hour, stirring occasionally, until tender.

Tip the sugar, vinegar, salt, coriander, paprika and cayenne into the pan and bring to the boil over a medium heat, stirring, until the sugar has dissolved. Continue to boil for 30 minutes or so, until the mixture achieves a chunky chutney consistency and the surplus watery liquid has evaporated. Take care towards the end of the cooking time to continue stirring so that the chutney doesn't catch on the bottom of the pan.

Ladle the chutney into sterilised or dishwasher-clean jars (Kilner jars are ideal) and top with paper jam covers. Seal the jars while still hot. Leave to mature for at least a month in a cool dark place.
chief_review: This vibrant relish bursts with Mediterranean flavors, thanks to its blend of ripe tomatoes, peppers, and aubergine, complemented by aromatic onions and fragrant spices. The tangy backbone from white wine vinegar cuts through the sweetness of sugar, making it a lively pairing for cheese boards, cold meats, or turkey sandwiches. The use of plant-based ingredients—no dairy, eggs, or animal products—makes it ideal for both vegetarian and vegan diets. Additionally, the absence of gluten-containing grains means it's naturally suited for gluten-free eaters, provided the vinegar used is certified gluten-free. It’s also nut-free, catering to those with nut allergies. The robust sweetness and savory nuances make this relish a versatile condiment you’ll return to all year round.

name: Make & mature Christmas cake
description: 25 min prep time? More like an hour.
author: James Martin
ingredients: 1kg mixed dried fruit(use a mix of raisins, sultanas, currants, cherries, cranberries, prunes or figs)
150ml brandy, Sherry, whisky or rum, plus extra for feeding
directions: Put 1kg mixed dried fruit, the zest and juice of 1 orange and 1 lemon, 150ml brandy or other alcohol, 250g softened butter and 200g light, soft brown sugar in a large
set over a medium heat.
Bring to the boil, then lower the heat and simmer for 5 mins. Tip the fruit mixture into a large
and leave to cool for 30 mins.
Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Line a deep 20cm cake tin with a double layer of
, then wrap a double layer of newspaper around the outside – tie with string to secure.

Add 175g plain flour, 100g ground almonds, ½ tsp baking powder, 2 tsp mixed spice, 1 tsp ground cinnamon, ¼ tsp ground cloves, 100g flaked almonds, 4 large eggs and 1 tsp vanilla extract to the fruit mixture and stir well, making sure there are no pockets of flour.
Tip into your prepared tin, level the top with a
and bake in the centre of the oven for 2 hrs.
Remove the cake from the oven, poke holes in it with a skewer and spoon over 2 tbsp of your chosen alcohol. Leave the cake to cool completely in the tin.
To store, peel off the baking parchment, then wrap well in cling film. Feed the cake with 1-2 tbsp alcohol every fortnight, until you ice it.
Don’t feed the cake for the final week to give the surface a chance to dry before icing.
chief_review: This classic fruitcake recipe layers a medley of dried fruits with the citrusy brightness of orange and lemon, all enriched by a generous splash of brandy or your preferred spirit. The butter, eggs, and ground almonds lend it a sumptuous, moist crumb, while the warm spice blend gives depth and complexity. Flaked almonds add a satisfying contrast in texture. However, those with nut allergies should avoid this recipe due to both ground and flaked almonds. Similarly, it contains wheat flour and dairy, so it's unsuitable for gluten-free and vegan diets. The prep time is underestimated; allow at least an hour to macerate the fruit and complete the steps properly for the best results. The finished cake is rich, indulgent, and perfect for holidays or special occasions—worth every minute of preparation.

name: Christmas muffin mix
description: A festive treat to give or receive
author: Good Food
directions: Layer all the ingredients in a 1 litre glass or plastic preserving jar in the order the ingredients are listed.

Write the following directions on a gift label: ‘Tip the contents of the jar into a large mixing bowl. Make a well in the centre and add 2 beaten eggs, 300ml/½pt milk and 100g/4oz melted butter. Mix quickly and lightly to a soft batter. Divide between 12 muffin cases. Bake at 190C/fan 170C/gas 5 for 18-20 mins. Use within 4 weeks.’ Attach the label and a wooden spoon to the top of the jar with some raffia or coloured ribbon.
chief_review: This festive treat brings together warming spices, crunchy nuts, and a delightful mix of tropical dried fruits for a seasonal bake that’s both fragrant and satisfyingly textured. The self-raising flour ensures a light crumb, while the blend of cinnamon and mixed spice adds depth perfect for gifting or sharing. Using pecans or walnuts not only adds healthy fats but also a nuanced richness that complements the muscovado sugar’s gentle molasses notes. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe is a wonderful addition to any holiday table or as an edible gift. Those with nut allergies should take caution, as nuts are a primary component. Serve sliced with tea or wrap individually for a thoughtful homemade present—festive, flavorful, and easy to assemble.

name: Sparkling vanilla Christmas cookies
description: Easy to make. I did add a splash of milk though. Fun way to spend a rainy afternoon with the kids.
author: Lesley Waters
ingredients: approx 2m thin ribbon cut into 10cm lengths
directions: Tip the icing sugar, vanilla extract, egg yolk and butter into a mixing bowl, then stir together with a wooden spoon (or pulse in a food processor until well combined). Add the flour and mix to a firm dough. Shape the dough into two flat discs and wrap in clingfilm. Chill for 20-30 mins. Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

Roll out the dough on a lightly floured surface to about the thickness of two £1 coins. Cut out Christmassy shapes (use a cutter if you like) and place on the baking sheets. Using the tip of a skewer, cut a small hole in the top of each cookie. Bake for 10-12 mins until lightly golden.

Lift the biscuits onto a wire rack to cool. Meanwhile, mix the icing sugar with a few drops of cold water to make a thick, but still runny icing. Colour with edible food colouring, if you like. Spread it over the cooled biscuits, decorate with edible balls and thread with ribbon when dry.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful, easy-to-follow approach to crafting decorative cookies, perfect for engaging little ones on a rainy afternoon. The use of basic pantry staples—icing sugar, vanilla extract, plain flour, butter, and a touch of milk—means these cookies are rich and tender, with a buttery crumb and light sweetness. The addition of edible food colouring and festive gold and silver balls encourages creativity, making this not only a tasty treat but an enjoyable activity for children. As this recipe uses egg yolk and dairy butter, it is well-suited for a vegetarian diet but does not comply with vegan or dairy-free preferences. Note that plain flour contains gluten, making these cookies unsuitable for gluten-free diets. Overall, it’s a fun and versatile recipe for family baking sessions that results in beautiful, edible ornaments or snacks.

name: Christmas pudding with citrus & spice
description: A fruity pud, served with orange custard cream, makes the perfect end to the traditional Christmas meal
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 medium carrot, peeled and finely grated
50ml/2fl oz orangeliqueur, such as Grand Marnier
directions: Mix the fruit, almonds, citrus zests and the carrot with the brandy and orange liqueur in a large mixing bowl. Cover and leave to soak overnight.
Mix all the dry ingredients together, then add to the soaked fruit mixture. Grate in the butter, then add the eggs and stir. Don’t forget to make a wish!

Grease a 1.5-litre pudding basin with butter and line the base with greaseproof paper. Spoon in the mixture, press down well and make a hollow with the back of the spoon in the centre. Cover the surface with a round of greaseproof paper, then cover the bowl with double-thickness greaseproof paper and foil and tie at the rim with string. Lower the pudding into a pan with an upturned saucer in the base, then fill with water until it comes halfway up the sides of the bowl. Steam for 6 hrs, topping up with water as necessary.

Alternatively, steam in the oven. Stand the pudding basin in a roasting tin filled with water, then cover with a tent of foil and cook for the same length of time at 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Check roasting tin occasionally as the water may need to be topped up.
To store, allow to cool, then store in a cool, dry cupboard. The pudding will keep for up to a year.
On the day, steam for 1 hr before turning out, decorating with holly and serving with extra-thick double cream or vanilla ice cream. Alternatively, try my Orange custard cream (below).
chief_review:
This festive fruit pudding is a delightful conclusion to any Christmas feast, boasting a medley of raisins, currants, sultanas, glacé cherries, and zesty citrus that provides both brightness and richness. The addition of blanched almonds introduces subtle crunch, while grated carrot adds moisture and a gentle earthy sweetness. A luxurious blend of brandy and orange liqueur infuses the pudding with warmth, true to tradition.

The recipe calls for eggs, butter, and self-raising flour, making it suitable for vegetarians but not for vegans or those following a gluten-free or nut-free diet. The orange custard cream complements the pudding beautifully, reinforcing the citrus notes and creating a balanced, celebratory finish. An excellent choice for those seeking a classic, sophisticated holiday dessert with depth of flavor and a nod to tradition.

name: Fig & honey Christmas cake
description: This traditional Christmas cake is the perfect combination of fruit, nuts and spices
author: James Martin
ingredients: 100g glacé cherry, well rinsed and quartered
3 tbsp brandy, plus extra to feed
directions: Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1. Line the base and sides of a 20cm cake tin first with a double layer of brown paper, then with a double layer of baking parchment. In a large bowl, mix the fruit, almonds, peel, figs and cherries. Turn well and add the flour, spices and lemon zest. In a separate bowl, cream the butter and sugar thoroughly, then add the vanilla extract, honey and treacle. Still beating, incorporate the eggs, then stir in the fruit and flour mixture. Dissolve the bicarbonate of soda in the milk and stir in thoroughly. Add the brandy by the spoonful, until you have a soft dropping consistency.

Turn the batter into the cake tin and make a dip in the middle using the back of a spoon. Bake for 3½ hrs, then insert a skewer – if it comes out clean, it’s ready. If there is any cake mix on the skewer, give it 10 mins more and test again. When it’s done, remove the cake from the oven and leave to cool in its tin. The next day, remove from the tin, wrap in fresh greaseproof paper, then put it into an airtight tin or wrap tightly in foil. The usual thing is to keep the cake for at least a month before icing it, and to unwrap and sprinkle it occasionally with more brandy.
chief_review: This traditional Christmas cake is a true celebration of festive flavors, featuring a hearty blend of dried fruits, nuts, spices, and citrus zest. The addition of almonds gives a pleasing crunch, while figs and glacé cherries add rich sweetness and jewel-like bursts of color. The batter, enriched with muscovado sugar, treacle, and honey, produces a moist, dense crumb—a hallmark of classic fruitcake. Aromatic notes of cinnamon and nutmeg mingle beautifully with the subtle zing of lemon zest. A dose of brandy both in the cake and during maturation imparts complexity and balances the sweetness. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and can be enjoyed by many with its absence of meat-based ingredients. Be mindful, though, of potential allergens such as nuts, eggs, and dairy. Overall, this cake is a masterful centerpiece for any holiday table, deeply flavorful and laden with festive tradition.

name: Angela Nilsen's Christmas cake
description: A long-life Christmas cake that's bursting with flavours of spices and vanilla
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 100ml sherry, sweet or dry, whatever you have in the cupboard
85g candied peel, roughly chopped (we used Sundora)
100g pack pecan nuts, broken into big pieces
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Line the base and sides of a 20 cm round, 7.5 cm deep cake tin. Beat the butter and sugar with an electric hand mixer for 1-2 mins until very creamy and pale in colour, scraping down the sides of the bowl half way through. Stir in a spoonful of the flour, then stir in the beaten egg and the rest of the flour alternately, a quarter at a time, beating well each time with a wooden spoon. Stir in the almonds.
Mix in the sherry (the mix will look curdled), then add the peel, cherries, raisins, cherries, nuts, lemon zest, spice, rosewater and vanilla. Beat together to mix, then stir in the baking powder.

Spoon mixture into the tin and smooth the top, making a slight dip in the centre. Bake for 30 mins, then lower temperature to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2 and bake a further 2-2¼ hrs, until a skewer insterted in the middle comes out clean. Leave to cool in the tin, then take out of the tin and peel off the lining paper. When completely cold, wrap well in cling film and foil to store until ready to decorate. The cake will keep for several months.
chief_review: This long-life Christmas cake is a masterful blend of warming spices, rich dark muscovado sugar, and a medley of candied fruits and nuts. The use of sherry provides both depth and moisture, ensuring the cake develops even more character as it matures. The rosewater and vanilla add subtle floral notes that lift the dense fruitiness, making every bite layered and intriguing. Ground almonds give the crumb a lovely texture, while pecans add satisfying crunch. This recipe contains no meat or fish, making it a fine choice for a vegetarian celebration. Be mindful that it contains eggs and nuts, which are common allergens. Serve it as the grand finale to your festive feast, paired with a touch of cream or a slice of sharp cheese for a truly indulgent treat. A classic cake, deeply flavorful and perfectly indulgent for the holiday season.

name: Gingery Christmas cake
description: A good glug of ginger wine makes this cake a little different from the norm. It's also lighter than its predecessors, so you can have two pieces!
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 200g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Tip the raisins, currants and sultanas into a bowl. Pour over 200ml ginger wine, then cover and leave to sit at room temperature overnight so that the fruit plumps up.

Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Using the bottom of a 20cm, loose-bottomed cake tin as a template, cut out 2 circles of baking parchment. Then cut 2 thick strips (about 2cm deeper than the tin) that will fit around the inside of the tin. Make small cuts along one of the edges, about 2cm apart. Grease the tin, then place one parchment circle at the bottom. Place one strip inside the tin, making sure the cut side is at the bottom, as this will help you to fit it inside. Do the same with the remaining strip, then place the second circle on top (see step-by-step).

Put the butter and sugar into a mixing bowl and whisk with an electric beater until creamy and light, about 5 mins. Add the eggs, one at a time, making sure you stir well after each addition, then mix through the flour, ground almonds and spices. Stir in the soaked fruits, and any liquid left over, with the fresh root ginger and treacle until everything is well combined.

Spoon in the mixture and smooth the top, then use a spoon to make a slight dip in the centre. This will ensure the cake has an even surface when finished. Bake for 30 mins, then lower the oven to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2 and bake for another 2 hrs until a skewer inserted in the middle comes out clean. Skewer the cake all over, then drizzle over the remaining 4 tbsp ginger wine. Leave the cake to cool in the tin, then peel off the lining paper. To store, wrap first in baking parchment and then in tin foil. The cake will keep in a cupboard for up to 3 months or can be frozen for up to 6 months.
chief_review: This ginger wine fruit cake offers a delightful twist on the classic, delivering a moist, aromatic crumb that's both rich and light. The combination of raisins, currants, and sultanas soaked in ginger wine infuses the cake with deep, spicy warmth, while the dual hit of ground and fresh ginger elevates the flavor profile. Using ground almonds introduces a delicate nuttiness and added moisture, complementing the treacle’s dark sweetness. The butter and eggs ensure a tender texture, and muscovado sugar adds complexity. This recipe would suit a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal-derived gelatin products. It's ideal for anyone seeking a sophisticated, festive cake with a refined touch—perfect for celebrations or a luxurious afternoon treat.

name: Gordon's Christmas roast goose
description: Seriously, if you’re looking at this before December you are too obsessed with Christmas, stop.
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: small handful each of parsley sprigs, thyme and sage, plus extra for garnishing
a little olive oil, for browning, optional
directions: Calculate the cooking time: cook for 10 mins at 240C/fan 220C/gas 9, then reduce to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5 and cook for 20 mins per kg for medium-rare, 32 mins per kg for more well done, plus 30 mins resting.
If the goose is ready-trussed, then loosen the string and pull out the legs and wings a little – this helps the bird cook better.

Check the inside of the bird and remove any giblets or pads of fat. Using the tip of a sharp knife, lightly score the breast and leg skin in a criss-cross. This helps the fat to render down more quickly during roasting.
Grate the zest from 4 lemons and 3 limes. Mix with 2 tsp fine sea salt, 1 tsp Chinese five-spice powder and pepper, to taste.
Season the cavity of the goose generously with salt, then rub the citrus mix well into the skin and sprinkle some inside the cavity.
Stuff the zested fruit and a small handful of parsley, thyme and sage sprigs inside the bird and set aside for at least 15 mins.
Heat oven to 240C/fan 220C/gas 9.
If you want to give the bird a nice golden skin, brown in a large
(or a heavy-based
), using a couple of tbsp olive oil. Holding the bird by the legs (you may like to use an oven glove), press it down on the breasts to brown.
Once browned, place the bird in the roasting tin. Drizzle with 3 tbsp clear honey and sprinkle with 1 tbsp thyme leaves.
Roast for the calculated time, turning the heat down after 10 mins to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Cover the goose with foil if it is starting to brown too much.

Every 30 mins or so, baste the bird with the pan juices, then pour off the fat through a sieve into a large heatproof bowl. You will end up with at least a litre of luscious fat – save this for the potatoes and other veg.
At the end of the cooking time, leave to rest for at least 30 mins, covered loosely with foil. The bird will not go cold, but will be moist and much easier to carve.
chief_review: This festive goose recipe is an elegant centerpiece, boasting aromatic notes from Chinese five-spice and fresh citrus. The combination of lemons, limes, and honey creates a subtle sweet-tart glaze that complements the rich, tender goose. An aromatic medley of parsley, thyme, and sage infuses the meat with earthy fragrance, while olive oil lending a golden, crisp finish if used for browning. With no gluten-containing ingredients and a naturally dairy-free profile, this dish suits those seeking gluten- or dairy-free options. The clean ingredient list also makes it a good fit for people avoiding nuts. Perfect for a special holiday feast, this goose will delight those craving tradition with a bright, modern twist.

name: Honey saffron Christmas cake
description: Has all the flavours of Christmas without being too heavy and can be made at the last minute too
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 225g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Butter and line a round, deep 20cm cake tin with two layers of baking parchment (see Knowhow, below). Tie a few sheets of newspaper around the outside of the tin, level with the top of the baking parchment.

Heat the brandy in a small pan, then add the saffron and leave to infuse off the heat for a few mins. Put the butter, sugar, eggs, flour, ground almonds, baking powder and a pinch of salt into a bowl, then beat together until creamy and smooth. Mix the fruit, nuts and brandy saffron mix into the batter and stir well.

Spoon into the prepared tin, smooth the top and make a slight dip in the middle. Bake for 1½ hrs, then cover loosely with foil to stop the top over-browning. Turn oven down to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1 and cook for 1 hr more until a skewer comes out clean. Leave to cool in the tin then, while it’s still warm, prod the cake all over with a skewer.
Mix the brandy and honey together and spoon over the cake. Wrap up well in foil and keep in an airtight container until Christmas, feeding with more honeyed brandy every so often.
chief_review: This festive cake captures the essence of Christmas with a delightful blend of spices, dried fruits, and a generous splash of brandy. The natural sweetness from the raisins, sultanas, and mixed peel harmonizes beautifully with the subtle aroma of saffron and the richness of honey. The trio of nuts—almonds, hazelnuts, and walnuts—adds a satisfying crunch, providing contrast to the soft, buttery crumb. The use of ground almond in the batter brings extra moisture and flavor complexity, while the glacé cherries add bursts of color and sweetness. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet. For those looking to bake a Christmas treat in a hurry, this cake is perfect, as it can be made at the last minute without compromising on festive flavour. Serve gently warmed, perhaps with an extra drizzle of brandy or a dollop of whipped cream for added indulgence.

name: Easy Christmas pudding
description: So are all the cups the same size as the butter cup? Specifying cup size would be helpful. Thanks
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 cup fresh brown breadcrumbs (from around 4 thick slices of bread)
1 cup mixed nuts, chopped plus extra to decorate
directions: For the pudding, empty the first six cups and the nuts, if using, into a mixing bowl with the spices, then stir in the milk and egg. Once well combined, tip into a buttered 1.5 litre pudding bowl.

Cover with a double layer of buttered foil, making a pleat in the centre to allow the pudding to rise. Tie the foil securely with string, then place in a steamer or large pan containing enough gently simmering water to come halfway up the sides of the bowl. Steam, covered with a lid, for 21⁄2 hours. Check the water level during cooking, topping up if necessary. If you are preparing this pudding ahead, remove the foil, let it cool slightly, then wrap in cling film and then fresh foil. If you are serving it immediately, unwrap and invert onto a deep plate.

For the sauce, put everything in a pan and bring slowly to the boil, stirring. Allow to bubble away for 2-3 minutes, still stirring, until the sugar has dissolved and the sauce is pale caramel in colour and slightly thickened. Remove from the heat. Pour the sauce over the pudding and decorate with the whole mixed nuts.
chief_review: This recipe yields a decadent fruit and nut dessert, reminiscent of a classic steamed pudding, combining the richness of butter, muscovado sugar, and double cream with the warming depth of spices and dried fruits. The breadcrumb and self-raising flour base, combined with a medley of mixed nuts, gives the dessert a satisfying texture and complex flavor profile. However, due to the use of butter, milk, egg, and double cream, this recipe is not suitable for vegan or dairy-free diets. The inclusion of mixed nuts also makes it unsuitable for those with nut allergies, and the use of wheat-based flour and breadcrumbs renders it inappropriate for gluten-free diets. The recipe could be easily adapted for vegetarians since it contains no meat or fish. The clear use of standardized cup measurements across ingredients is practical, but noting the cup size (typically 240ml) would indeed improve clarity for precise baking.

name: Sherry & almond Christmas cake
description:
Packed with
almonds, both ground and whole, and fed with raisiny PX sherry, this is
intensely fruity - but not overly rich
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1kg bag mixed dried fruit(not one with cherries)
150ml PX (Pedro Ximenez) sherry, plus extra for feeding
250g pack butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
directions: Mix the fruit, zest, juice and sherry, and leave overnight to soak. Next day, heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Butter and double-line a deep, 20cm round cake tin. Wrap the outside with brown paper or newspaper and secure with string, as this will protect the sides from overcooking.

Beat the butter, sugar and vanilla seeds together until pale and creamy. Mix the flour, ground almonds and mixed spice together, then tip into the butter mix with the eggs. Beat until combined and smooth. Stir in the whole almonds, fruit and any leftover juices, turn into the tin, then smooth the top and make a dip in the middle. Bake for 1½ hrs.

Turn down the oven to 140C/fan 130C/ gas 2, then bake for 1½ hrs more until dark on the top and a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean, or with a few damp crumbs clinging to it. Once cool enough to handle, turn onto a cooling rack and peel away the lining paper. Cool completely.

Keep the cake well wrapped, then feed once a fortnight with 1-2 tbsp sherry. Poke holes into the cake with a skewer and slowly spoon over the sherry. If you don’t have time to do this, this cake is delicious freshly made, and can be covered and decorated as soon as it has completely cooled down.
chief_review: This fruit cake recipe, featuring a generous amount of almonds, vibrant orange zest, and the deep sweetness of Pedro Ximenez sherry, delivers an intensely fruity flavor with a sophisticated balance. The combination of ground and whole almonds provides a lovely texture contrast and a nutty undertone that elevates the mixed dried fruit. However, the use of plain flour makes it unsuitable for gluten-free diets, and the inclusion of butter and eggs means it is not vegan. That said, it is an excellent option for those following a vegetarian diet, offering both richness and festive appeal without being cloying. The sherry feeding ensures the cake stays moist and aromatic over time—a perfect centerpiece for holiday gatherings.

name: Christmas pudding trifle
description: Use leftover Christmas pudding to rustle up this speedy and sumptuously creamy trifle with Grand Marnier-steeped oranges
author: Caroline Hire
directions: Peel the oranges using a sharp knife, ensuring all the pith is removed. Slice as thinly as possible and arrange over a dinner plate. Sprinkle with the demerara sugar followed by the Grand Marnier and set aside.
Crumble the Christmas pudding into large pieces and scatter over the bottom of a trifle bowl. Lift the oranges onto the pudding in a layer and pour over any juices.
Beat the mascarpone until smooth, then stir in the custard. Spoon the mixture over the top of the oranges.
Lightly whip the cream and spoon over the custard. Sprinkle with the flaked almonds and grated chocolate. You can make this a day in advance if you like, chill until ready to serve.
chief_review: This festive trifle cleverly repurposes leftover Christmas pudding, creating a rich, indulgent dessert elevated by Grand Marnier-soaked oranges. The blend of creamy mascarpone, silky custard, and whipped double cream adds luxurious texture, while roasted almonds and dark chocolate offer a delightful crunch and bittersweet finish. This recipe is ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, as all the ingredients are free from meat products (assuming the custard and Christmas pudding are made without animal-derived gelatin or suet). The dessert shines as a show-stopping centerpiece, balancing zesty citrus with the deep, spiced notes of Christmas pudding. It’s quick to assemble, making it perfect for post-holiday entertaining when time is of the essence but you still wish to impress.

name: Christmas pudding cheesecake
description: Absolutely beautiful recipe! This cheesecake tasted divine.
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 2 vanilla pods, split and seeds scraped
directions: To make the base, mix the gingernuts and sugar in a large bowl and sprinkle in the flaky salt. Pour in the melted butter and mix with a wooden spoon to form a biscuit crumb-like mixture. Press into a 20cm round springform cake tin, spreading the mixture in an even layer to the corners. Chill in the fridge for 30 mins until set.
Put the Christmas pudding, brandy, stout and orange zest in a blender, and whizz to a purée.

Using an electric hand whisk, beat the cream cheese with the double cream, sugar and vanilla seeds, then fold through the purée. Spread the mixture over the biscuit base and leave to chill in the fridge overnight.

The next day, peel the clementines, slice into rounds and place on a baking tray. Sprinkle them with sugar, then blowtorch until caramelised and leave to cool. Release the cheesecake from the tin and arrange the clementines on top.
chief_review: This festive cheesecake recipe brings together luxurious flavors for a truly decadent dessert. The ginger nut biscuit base paired with the richness of Christmas pudding and a touch of citrus zest creates delightful layers of texture and taste. Cream cheese and double cream ensure a sumptuously smooth filling, uplifted by the aromatic warmth of brandy, stout, and vanilla seeds. The clementine finish adds a refreshing brightness. This recipe contains no meat, poultry, or fish, making it suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, with multiple dairy ingredients and containing gluten in the biscuit base, it is not suited for vegan or gluten-free needs. As a celebration centerpiece, this cheesecake is an impressive showstopper sure to please holiday palates.

name: Classic Christmas pudding
description: How long will Pud last after the 8 hour bake ?
author: Orlando Murrin
ingredients: 200g box candied peel (in large pieces) or all citron if you can find it
1 whole nutmeg (you'll use three quarters of it)
100g light muscovado sugar, crumbled if it looks lumpy
2 tbsp brandy or cognac, plus extra to flame
250g packet butter, taken straight from the fridge
grated zest of half an orange
2 pieces of stem ginger, finely chopped
directions: Get everything prepared. Chop the almonds coarsely. Peel, core and chop the apples. Sharpen your knife and chop the candied peel. (You can chop the almonds and apples in a food processor, but the peel must be done by hand.) Grate three quarters of the nutmeg (sounds a lot but it's correct). Mix all the ingredients for the pudding, except the butter, in a large bowl.

Holding the butter in its wrapper, grate a quarter of it into the bowl, then stir everything together.Repeat until all the butter is grated, then stir for 3-4 minutes - the mixture is ready when it subsides slightly after each stir. Ask the family to stir too, and get everyone to make a wish.

Generously butter two 1.2 litre/ 2 pint bowls and put a disc of greaseproof paper in the bottom of each. Pack in the pudding mixture. Cover with a double layer of greaseproof paper or baking parchment, pleating it to allow for expansion, then tie with string (keep the paper in place with a rubber band while tying). Trim off any excess paper.

Now stand each bowl on a large sheet of foil and bring the edges up over the top, then put another sheet of foil over the top and bring it down underneath to make a double package (this makes the puddings watertight). Tie with more string, and make a handle for easy lifting in and out of the pan.

Boil or oven steam the puddings for 8 hours, topping up with water as necessary. Remove from the pans and leave to cool overnight. When cold, discard the messy wrappings and re-wrap in spanking new greaseproof or baking parchment, foil and string. Store in a cool, dry place until Christmas.

To make the brandy butter, cream the butter with the orange zest and sugar. Gradually beat in the brandy or cognac and chopped ginger. Put in a small bowl, fork the top attractively and put in the fridge to set. The butter will keep for a week in the fridge, or it can be frozen for up to 6 weeks.
On Christmas Day, boil or oven steam for 1 hour. Unwrap and turn out. To flame, warm 3-4 tbsp brandy in a small pan, pour it over the pudding and set light to it.
chief_review: This classic steamed pudding is a wonderfully rich and festive dessert, perfectly suited to a holiday table. The combination of dried fruits, candied peel, nuts, and a spirited kick of brandy delivers a deep, complex flavor profile highlighted by the warmth of freshly grated nutmeg and citrus zest. The generous use of butter and eggs gives the finished product a sumptuous texture, while apples lend a subtle tartness that balances the sweetness. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly but does contain gluten, nuts, and eggs—important considerations for anyone with related allergies or dietary restrictions. Enjoy the pudding fresh, or store it in a cool, dark place tightly wrapped for several weeks; the high sugar and alcohol content help preserve it beautifully, though consume within a month for best taste and texture. Serve with an extra splash of brandy flamed tableside for a dramatic finish.

name: Christmas pudding ice cream
description: Impress your guests with this showstopping Christmas dessert, which can be made up to one month ahead
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 vanilla pod, split and seeds scraped out
zest ½ lemonand ½ an orange
directions: Mix all of the boozy fruit ingredients together in a bowl, then microwave on High for 3 mins. Stir, then leave to cool completely, ideally overnight.

For the ice cream, put the spices in a saucepan and gently heat for 3 mins or so, stirring once or twice, until fragrant. Tip in the cream and vanilla seeds, and bring to the boil. Meanwhile, whisk the yolks and sugar together. Whisk the hot cream into the egg mix, then tip the mix into a clean pan and gently heat for 5-10 mins until it coats the back of a wooden spoon. Pour everything into a bowl or plastic container and leave to cool completely. If possible, chill it overnight as this will infuse the ice cream with a stronger Christmassy spice flavour.

Pass the mix through a sieve into another container, then freeze for 5 hrs, stirring in the frozen edges with a fork every hour until you have a smooth, thick mix. Oil a 1.4 or 1.2-litre pudding basin and line with cling film.

Drain the boozy fruit in a sieve, mix the fruit with the ginger nuts and zests, then quickly stir into the ice cream. Tip into the basin, cover the surface with cling film, then freeze for at least 6 hrs.

For the topping, put everything into a small pan, gently heat until the sugar dissolves, then simmer for 2 mins. Cool completely. To turn the pudding out, let it sit at room temperature for about 15 mins, then turn onto a plate. Ease the cling film away. Spoon the cranberries and syrup over to serve.
chief_review: This festive Christmas dessert is a triumph for those who love layers of warming spices, boozy fruit, and rich, creamy textures. The clever blend of raisins, sultanas, cherries, and cranberries, all soaked in brandy, mingles beautifully with the aromatic cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, and cloves. The double cream and egg yolk base creates a luscious, custardy richness, contrasted by crunchy chunks of gingernut biscuits and bright citrus zests. Suitable for vegetarians, this showstopper is also naturally gluten-free, provided a gluten-free gingernut biscuit is used—an easy substitution. No nuts are used, catering to those with nut allergies. The ability to prepare it up to a month in advance makes it perfect for stress-free entertaining during the holidays, ensuring both flavor and convenience are at the heart of your celebration table.

name: Christmas spiced red cabbage
description: This classic side can be made up to two days in advance. For maximum flavour, cook the cabbage down really well over a low heat until it's really sticky
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: finely grated zest and juice 1 orange
directions: Peel off the outer leaves of the cabbage, then cut into quarters and slice out the core. Use a sharp knife or the slicing attachment of a food processor to thinly slice the cabbage.

Heat the butter in a large saucepan, then tip in the onions and gently fry until softened, about 5 mins. Add the orange zest to the pan along with the cinnamon stick, then cook for 1 min more. Add the shredded cabbage, then pour over the port, red wine vinegar, orange juice and 150ml water. Bring up to the boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer, cover the pan and cook for 45 mins-1 hr until the cabbage is softened.
chief_review: This braised red cabbage recipe is a classic, deeply flavorful side, ideal for festive tables or comforting winter meals. Slow-cooked over low heat, the cabbage becomes sticky and rich, with the butter and port adding a luxurious finish. The orange zest and juice infuse brightness, while the cinnamon stick imparts a warming spice, creating a well-balanced harmony of sweet, tangy, and savory notes. The addition of red onions layers in aromatic depth, and the red wine vinegar offers a pleasant sharpness to cut through the richness. As written, this recipe is vegetarian, gluten-free, and nut-free, making it a versatile option for guests with dietary considerations. Prepare it a day or two in advance to allow the flavors to meld and intensify for an even better result. A beautifully executed, crowd-pleasing dish.

name: Christmas cream liqueur
description: Great receipe and after making received many comments saying how nice it was. I would recommend that the ingredients are well mixed before adding the single cream to thoroughly mix. Tastes so nice and will make again for Christmas day.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 300g dulce de leche (we used Merchant Gourmet)
1 tbsp instant coffee dissolved in 1 tbsp boiling water
284ml/9½fl oz and 142ml/5fl oz pot single cream
directions: Spoon the dulce de leche into a bowl, then beat in the coffee, vanilla and brandy until smooth. Stir in both pots of cream until well mixed.
Pour into 1 large or several smaller sterilised bottles. This will keep in the fridge for 2 weeks. Drink in liqueur glasses or serve over ice.
chief_review: This indulgent recipe delivers a luxuriously creamy and beautifully balanced dessert drink, perfect for festive occasions. The blend of dulce de leche, single cream, and brandy provides depth and richness, while the coffee and vanilla add complexity and warmth. I highly recommend ensuring that the dulce de leche, coffee, and vanilla are thoroughly incorporated before adding the cream for the smoothest texture. The resulting taste is decadent, not overly sweet, with a sophisticated finish that lingers. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians as it contains no animal-derived gelatin or rennet, only dairy and flavorings. An ideal homemade treat for holiday gatherings or as an after-dinner indulgence.

name: Granny Martin's Christmas puddings
description: Get a head start on Christmas with James Martin's make-ahead pudding
author: James Martin
directions: Soak the sultanas, currants, figs, mixed peel, cherries and the apricots in the brandy in a bowl overnight if possible or for at least a few hrs (if you don't have time for this, place the fruit in a microwaveable bowl with the brandy and give it a quick blast in the microwave to plump up). In a larger bowl, mix the ginger and syrup, apples, orange juice and zest, eggs, suet, crumbs, sugar and flour. Using your fingers or a wooden spoon, mix in the soaked fruit and mixed spice.

Butter 2 x 1.5-litre pudding basins and divide the mixture between them, filling almost to the rim. Smooth the tops and cover with 2 circles of greaseproof paper. Cover each pudding with a sheet of foil with a folded pleat down the centre, to allow the pudding to expand, and secure everything by tying it tightly with some string. Stand the puddings in a deep, large pan (or 2 if that’s easier) on trivets or upturned saucers and pour boiling water around so it comes about a third of the way up. Cover the pan and steam the puddings for 5 hrs, topping up with more boiling water when necessary.

Let the puddings cool down before removing the foil and greaseproof paper, then cover with cling film over the top and store in a cool, dry place if you aren’t using them straight away. This is the time you can drizzle them with more booze in the run-up to Christmas if you have time. To reheat, steam the pudding for 1 hr more before turning out and flaming with hot brandy.
chief_review: This festive make-ahead pudding is a quintessentially British Christmas treat that brims with rich dried fruits, warming spices, and the aromatic punch of brandy and stem ginger. The balance between tangy orange zest, sweet muscovado sugar, and soft, juicy figs is masterful, while suet and breadcrumbs deliver the classic dense, luxurious texture. As the suet is used, this recipe is not vegetarian- or vegan-friendly unless replaced with a plant-based alternative, but it does not contain nuts, making it suitable for some individuals with nut allergies (always double-check for cross-contamination in processed ingredients). The inclusion of self-raising flour and breadcrumbs means it’s not gluten-free. Overall, this is a traditional, indulgent holiday dessert that rewards preparation with unbeatable depth of flavour and festive charm.

name: Christmas pud ice cream
description: Stir the remnants of your Christmas pudding into a tub of vanilla ice cream for a super simple dessert
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 litre tub vanillaice cream, slightly softened
directions: Whizz the ice cream in a food processor until smooth, fold in the Christmas pudding and scrape into a freezer-proof container. Freeze for at least 2 hrs then scoop into bowls and top with the toffee sauce or amaretto.
chief_review: This festive dessert brilliantly repurposes leftover Christmas pudding into an indulgent, creamy treat. The rich spices and fruits from the pudding add depth and texture to the smooth vanilla ice cream, while a drizzle of toffee sauce or a splash of amaretto provides a decadent finish. Given its composition, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians, provided the ice cream does not contain gelatine or animal-derived rennet and the toffee sauce is free from animal ingredients. Those with gluten or nut allergies should exercise caution, as Christmas pudding often contains both gluten and nuts. This is an ideal, hassle-free dish for festive entertaining or a cozy family gathering, delivering familiar holiday flavors with minimal effort.

name: Individual Christmas pies
description: This recipe for a stunning vegetarian Christmas alternative, can easily be reduced or increased to make as many as you need
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 good pinches thyme leaves, plus a few extra small sprigs to decorate
100g Puy or green lentil, from a can, rinsed and drained
4 tbsp cranberry, plus about 20 to decorate
200g plain flour, plus a little extra
directions: Gently fry the leeks in the butter until softened. Add the mushrooms, mace and thyme, and turn up the heat a bit to soften the mushrooms and drive off any liquid that comes out of them. Stir in the potato for 2 mins, followed by the lentils, chestnuts and cream. Cook for 2 mins more, then take off the heat and stir in the 4 tbsp cranberries.

To make the pastry, put the flour and suet in a food processor with 1 tsp salt. Whizz together until you can’t see any big suet lumps, then keep pulsing while you add the milk, a spoon at a time, until the pastry comes together.

Roll out a quarter of the pastry on a lightly floured surface, then use 4 individual pie dishes to cut 4 pastry lids – we used 4 x 250ml ramekins. Use a small star cutter to cut out a star from each lid, then keep stars and lids covered with cling film.

Cut 4 strips of baking parchment and use a little butter to stick one in each pie dish, so the ends of the strips stick outeach side to help you remove the pies when baked. Gather lid scraps with the remaining pastry and divide into 4 equal pieces. Roll out each to £1 coin thickness and use to line each pie dish with an overhang. Divide the filling between the dishes. Top each with a lid, and roll down the overhang to meet the lid. Use a fork’s prongs to press and seal edges. The pies can now be covered and chilled for up to 24 hrs before baking.

To bake, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/ gas 7. Brush each pie with beaten egg and bake for 30 mins. Lift pies from dishes and sit directly onto a baking sheet. Mix 20 cranberries with the redcurrant jelly and divide between the star holes on top. Brush pastry stars with beaten egg, add a small thyme sprig to each, then add to the pie baking sheet and put back in the oven for 5-10 mins, until pies and stars are golden and crisp. Top each pie with a star and serve.
chief_review:
This inventive vegetarian Christmas dish offers a delightful medley of savoury and sweet notes, thanks to the partnership of leeks, mushrooms, chestnuts, and a festive cranberry accent. The use of puy lentils and grated potato weaves in earthiness and body, while thyme and mace add fragrant warmth—a true celebration of winter flavours. The vegetarian suet and double cream promise a rich, comforting texture in the pastry, ideal for holiday feasting. 

This recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets, provided all ingredients, especially the suet, are certified vegetarian. Although it contains dairy and eggs, making it unsuitable for those with those allergies or vegans, the resulting dish is hearty and satisfying for the vegetarian table. The pastry’s golden, glazed finish and decorative cranberries make for a stunning presentation, sure to impress at any festive gathering.

name: Hot little Christmas cakes
description: Forgotten to make your Christmas pud? These speedy cakes are the perfect alternative
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 50g melted butter, plus extra for greasing
50g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
small handful dried berries and cherries
vanilla ice cream and honey, to serve
directions: Grease and flour 4 small ramekins and set aside. Tip all the ingredients, except the berries and cherries, into a large jug or bowl. Using a hand blender, blend until completely combined, then stir in the dried fruit. Chill cake mix until needed.

Heat oven to 230C/fan 210C/gas 8. Divide the mix between the ramekins and bake for 15 mins until puffed up and golden. Tip the cakes out onto plates, top with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and drizzle with honey.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful, quick alternative to traditional Christmas pudding, featuring a rich blend of dark muscovado sugar, mixed spice, and vibrant citrus zest. The dried berries and cherries provide bursts of tartness that complement the warm, buttery sponge, making each bite reminiscent of classic holiday flavors. Perfectly paired with vanilla ice cream and a drizzle of honey, these cakes deliver a comforting sweetness and festive charm. As the base includes plain flour, butter, and egg, these cakes are best suited for a vegetarian diet. They are not appropriate for those with gluten or dairy allergies, but they do offer a streamlined solution for those seeking a less time-intensive festive dessert without sacrificing flavor or celebration.

name: Christmas pudding strudel
description: Give your Christmas pud leftovers a second life with this easy strudel recipe
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Mix the pudding, mascarpone and Baileys. Lay out a sheet of filo on a large flat baking tray, brush with some melted butter and lay another sheet on top. Repeat with more butter and filo until you have 4 layers.
Place the filling in a log in the centre and brush the border with butter. Roll up to enclose the filling, then brush with the remaining butter.
. Bake for 20-25 mins until golden brown, dust with icing sugar and serve warm with cream or custard.
chief_review: This inventive strudel recipe beautifully transforms leftover Christmas pudding into a decadent dessert, pairing festive spiced fruit with a creamy mascarpone and Baileys filling. The use of filo pastry keeps the texture crisp and light, contrasting the rich interior. Brushing with melted butter offers a delicate golden crunch, while a dusting of icing sugar provides a lovely finish. Served warm with cream or custard, this treat is perfect for holiday gatherings. It’s suitable for vegetarians, given the absence of meat, fish, or gelatin. However, those with dairy allergies or sensitivities should steer clear, as mascarpone, butter, and cream feature prominently. Overall, this is a delightful holiday dish that brings new life to festive leftovers with minimal effort.

name: Light & fruity Christmas pud
description: An irresistibly tipsy passion fruit and Cointreau-laced pud that steams in half the time of a traditional Christmas pudding
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 250g packet dried mixed fruits with apricot and passion fruit
grated zest and juice of a large orange
100ml/3½ fl oz Cointreau or Grand Marnier
directions: Put the dried fruits, dates, cranberries and ginger in a pan with the orange zest and juice, and the orange liqueur, then warm gently for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally until the juices are absorbed and the mixture looks sticky. Set aside to cool.

Lightly grease a 1.3 litre/21⁄4 pint pudding basin, and line the base with a small disc of greaseproof paper. Beat the butter, sugar, eggs and flour together in a food mixer or large bowl until creamy, then stir in the cooled fruits, breadcrumbs, cinnamon and nuts.

Spoon the mixture into the pudding basin, cover the bowl with greaseproof paper and foil, and tie on securely with string. Put a long strip of folded foil under the basin and bring it up round the sides so that you can use it as a handle to lift the pudding in and out. Put the basin in a large pan and pour a kettle of boiling water into the pan so it comes halfway up the bowl, then cover and steam for 3 hours, topping up with boiling water every now and then. Leave it to cool, then store in a cool place for up to 1 week or freeze for 1 month.

The sauce can be made up to a day ahead. Melt the butter and sugar together in a frying pan. Tip in the pecans and cook, stirring, for a minute or two to toast them. Add the cranberries, orange juice and liqueur and continue to bubble until rich and syrupy. Cool, then tip into a bowl, cover and chill until ready to eat.
To serve: Steam the pudding in a pan of boiling water for 1 hour, to warm it through.

Put the pecan sauce in a pan, and gently warm through until melted and bubbling. Meanwhile, turn out the pudding. Peel the lining paper from the pudding and pile the nuts and cranberries from the sauce on top, and then generously spoon over the buttery sauce. Decorate with holly and dust lightly with icing sugar. Serve the pudding with the sauce and cream.
chief_review: This festive pudding offers a delightful twist on tradition, combining the tang of passion fruit and apricot with the warming depth of Cointreau. The use of dried mixed fruits, dates, and cranberries creates a luscious, moist texture with a complex fruity profile, while fresh ginger and orange zest lift the flavor. Pecan nuts add a pleasing crunch, and the muscovado sugars deepen the caramel notes. Steaming in half the typical time achieves a satisfying density without weightiness. The generous splash of orange liqueur infuses the dessert with an aromatic boozy kick—balancing brightness and rich spice. Served with thick double cream and a final dusting of icing sugar, this pudding promises a showstopping finish to holiday feasts. Suitable for vegetarians, though not for vegans or anyone with nut, gluten, or dairy restrictions.

name: Christmas pud cupcakes
description: Cupcakes are all the rage, and this festive version are super cute and contemporary
author: Good Food
ingredients: 85g dried sour cherries, plus a few extra to decorate
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Place a 12-hole silicone muffin tray on a baking sheet or butter a non-stick 12-hole muffin tin, and stick two criss-crossing strips of baking parchment in each hole.

Melt the chocolate and butter over a low heat. Cool a little, then stir in the soured cream and eggs. Mix the flour, sugar, almonds, cocoa and baking powder in a bowl. Pour in the chocolate and stir until smooth, then stir in the cherries. Spoon into the muffin holes so they are 3⁄4 full, then bake for 20 mins. Cool in the tins. Can now be frozen in plastic bags for 3 months.

To decorate, mix the icing sugar and custard powder with 2 tbsp water to make a thick icing. Remove the muffins from the tins and cool on a rack. Cut off any rounded tops, stand upside-down on the rack, then spoon icing over. Leave to set, then top with bay leaves and cherries. Best eaten on the day.
chief_review: These cupcakes offer a delightful balance of rich chocolate flavor and tart dried sour cherries, enhanced by ground almonds for a moist texture. The inclusion of soured cream keeps the crumb tender while adding a subtle tang. The combination of self-raising flour and baking powder ensures a light, well-risen cake. With no meat or fish products, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians. However, please note the presence of ground almonds makes it unsuitable for those with nut allergies. The finishing touches—glossy icing, a hint of custard, and the decorative bay leaves—give the cupcakes a charming festive appearance, elevating them to centerpiece status for any occasion. Perfect for celebrations or as a fun weekend bake, these cupcakes promise both style and substance.

name: Iced Christmas-pudding mousse
description: Gary Rhodes' recipe is a great way to use up leftover Christmas pud - whilst adding a special twist
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 450g Christmas pudding, roughly chopped into small pieces
a splash or two of Grand Marnier or Cointreau (optional)
holly sprigs, and icing sugar for dusting
directions: To make the pudding, quickly blitz together the chopped pudding and custard in a food processor. Whip the cream and sugar to soft peaks and stir into the flavoured custard. Pour the mix into a 1.2 litre/2 pint pudding basin, then cover and freeze overnight or for several hours. (The pudding can be frozen for up to 1 month.)

For the sauce, cut away the pith and peel from the tangerines or satsumas with a sharp knife, then cut either side of the membranes to release the segments. Bring the orange juice and caster sugar up to a boil, stirring occasionally, until the sugar is dissolved. Then boil hard for 20-25 mins, until reduced by about half to a thick syrupy consistency (like golden syrup). Watch it carefully so it doesn’t boil over, lowering the heat if necessary. Leave to cool, finishing with a splash or two of your chosen liqueur, if using. Can be kept chilled for 3-4 days.

To serve the dessert, transfer it to the fridge 30 mins before serving, then dip the basin into hot water and turn the pudding out onto a chilled plate. Arrange some of the fruit segments around the base of the pudding, and some on top. Drizzle with some of the syrup and serve the rest separately. Finish the decoration with holly leaves and a dusting of icing sugar.
chief_review: Gary Rhodes’ creation offers a luxurious and inventive way to reimagine Christmas pudding leftovers.
