The use of plain flour in the sauce does mean this recipe isn’t gluten free, and it’s a classic meat-forward dish, so it's not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. Still, for lovers of a traditional roast, the method shines, especially when care is taken to bring the beef to room temperature before cooking. The flavors are beautifully balanced, and the sauce elevates the dish to something truly special—perfect for a celebratory meal.

name: Perfect pancetta & roast shallot-stuffed turkey
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 5-5½ kg oven-ready turkey, neck and giblets removed (save them to make stock, if you like)
1 pack smoked sliced pancettaor streaky bacon (about 14 rashers)
bay leavesand chopped thyme, for scattering over (optional)
directions: Up to two days ahead, season the bird all over with flaky sea salt – inside and out and under the skin. Leave the turkey in the tin, breast-side up, and put in the fridge for up to two days; the longer you salt it, the more succulent it will be. Weigh the turkey and calculate the cooking time by allowing 40 mins per kg for the first 4kg, then 45 mins for every additional kg. As a guide, a turkey of this size should take 3½-4 hrs plus 30-45 mins resting.
To make the butter, mash the garlic with the thyme, lemon zest and a pinch of salt using a
, then beat in the butter until well mixed.

Gently push your fingers under the skin of the turkey, starting from the neck, until you can push your whole hand down the length of the breast – take care not to tear the skin. Spread the butter under the skin so that it covers the breast meat. Lay the pancetta (or bacon) on your work surface in two rectangles of six overlapping slices. Carefully push each rectangle under the skin to cover and protect each breast. This can be done the night before; take the turkey out of the fridge 1 hr before roasting to bring it back to room temperature.
On the day, heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tip the whole shallots into a bowl with the thyme, bay and garlic butter, then season and toss to coat. Lift the turkey into a

, massage the olive oil into the skin and season well if you haven’t already seasoned ahead. Tip the shallots into the roasting tin, around the turkey, and stuff the lemon halves into the cavity. Cover the tin loosely with foil and roast for the calculated cooking time.

For the final 30 mins, remove the foil and pour off all of the cooking juices (reserve them for the gravy). Spoon the shallots into the cavity and increase the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Roast for the final 30 mins until the turkey is golden and the thigh juices run clear when pierced with a skewer, or until a

reads over 70C. Leave the turkey to rest on a warm platter covered with foil – it will stay warm for about 1 hr. If you want to make turkey gravy, pour the fat off the juices and add the gravy to the roasting tin. Bring to the boil, then pour into a gravy jug. To serve, bring the whole turkey to the table, along with the herbs, if using. Carve onto a hot platter with a little of the hot gravy poured over. Any leftover meat can be frozen in the gravy, or used in leftovers.
chief_review:
This turkey recipe is a classic festive centerpiece, combining succulent roasted turkey with aromatic herbs, zesty lemon, and the rich depth of smoked pancetta or streaky bacon. The butter and olive oil ensure a moist, flavorful bird, while the shallots and fresh thyme add a beautiful aromatic foundation. The citrus notes from the lemon zest and halves cut through the richness and brighten the overall flavor profile.

This dish is naturally gluten-free and does not contain common allergens like nuts or shellfish. However, it is not suitable for vegetarian or vegan diets. The technique of layering pancetta over the turkey adds both moisture and a savory, smoky finish to the crisp skin. Perfectly balanced between tradition and flavor enhancement, this recipe is ideal for celebratory gatherings where a moist, flavorful roast is essential.

name: Sprouts with crispy prosciutto
description: Dress simply steamed or boiled Brussels sprouts with butter, lemon and crispy prosciutto for a gluten-free side dish for a festive dinner
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 750g medium sprouts, trimmed and outer leaves removed
directions: Heat a large frying pan and cook the prosciutto in batches, laying the slices flat in the pan until brown and crispy. Remove from the pan and set aside.

Steam or boil the sprouts for 7-8 mins until just tender, drain and return to the pan with the butter, lemon zest and some seasoning. Turn the sprouts until well coated, then tip into a serving bowl, tear over the crispy prosciutto and season with freshly ground black pepper.
chief_review: This recipe elevates Brussels sprouts with a luxurious combination of butter, lemon zest, and crispy prosciutto, resulting in a vibrant and deeply savory side dish. The use of prosciutto infuses the sprouts with a delicate saltiness and crunch, while butter adds indulgent richness offset by the brightness of lemon zest. The preparation is straightforward, allowing the natural sweetness of the sprouts to shine. Notably, this recipe is entirely gluten-free, making it a smart, crowd-pleasing option for festive dinners where dietary considerations matter. The balance between buttery, zesty, and umami flavors is masterful, and the texture contrast is irresistible. A sophisticated yet approachable dish, perfect for elevating any celebratory table.

name: Vanilla shortbread dough
description: Use this dough as the base for biscuits, to eat yourself, or to make as a Christmas gift
author: Good Food
directions: Tip the flour into a food processor. Cut the butter into small pieces and drop them into the bowl, then whizz until the mixture looks like breadcrumbs.
Add the sugar, vanilla and egg yolks and whizz to a small dough.
chief_review: This classic biscuit dough yields a buttery, tender crumb and a lovely hint of vanilla that elevates it beyond the ordinary. The use of salted butter brings depth and balance to the sweetness from the golden caster sugar, ensuring a well-rounded flavor. The inclusion of egg yolks contributes to the richness and a pleasing texture—perfect for biscuits destined to impress, whether served simply or adorned for festive gifting. This recipe is an excellent choice for those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish products. The dough handles easily and bakes to a beautiful golden finish, making it a reliable base for creative shapes or flavor variations. Ideal for home bakers looking for a dependable classic with just the right amount of indulgence.

name: Smoked salmon & avocado terrines
description: A light, elegant make-ahead starter to ease you into the Christmas Day blow-out, or to kick off a dinner party menu
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 300g and 150g pack thinly sliced smoked salmon
100g pack Chevre or other mild goat's cheese, broken into small pieces
3 large ripe avocados, peeled, stoned and finely chopped
directions: Lightly oil 8 small ramekins. Line with cling film, then the salmon (either 1 large or 2 smaller slices), allowing plenty of overhang.

Gently mix together the cheese, chives and avocado with the lemon juice and plenty of seasoning. Spoon into the salmon-lined ramekins, press down, fold over the overlapping salmon, then cling film to seal in the mixture. Can be made the night before, but if making on the day they should be chilled for at least 4 hrs.

On the day, gently lift the terrines out of the ramekins using the cling film, then remove the film. Place the terrines on plates with some baby salad leaves tossed in a little vinaigrette. Drizzle the terrine and plate with sweet chilli sauce. Serve on their own or with toast.
chief_review: This smoked salmon and goat's cheese starter is a refined, fresh way to begin a festive meal or impress at any dinner party. The combination of creamy Chevre, velvety avocado, and delicately smoky salmon offers a rich contrast of flavors and textures. Chives and lemon juice add brightness, while a drizzle of sweet chili sauce brings a subtle heat that lifts the entire dish. Presented atop crisp salad leaves with vinaigrette, this make-ahead recipe not only saves time but also promises a restaurant-quality start to your menu. The dish is well-suited to pescatarian diets and is naturally gluten-free, making it a versatile option for guests with various dietary preferences. Overall, it’s an elegant, crowd-pleasing starter that highlights quality ingredients in a harmonious way.

name: Chestnut & cranberry roll
description: Forget fiddly stuffing balls, this clever roll tastes delicious, plus its practical shape makes it ultra-simple to slice
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 2 x 200g/7oz packs vacuum-packed chestnuts, roughly chopped
small bunch parsley, leaves roughly chopped
small bunch sage, leaves roughly chopped
directions: Heat the oil in a large frying pan, then gently fry the onion for 5 mins until softened. Finely chop the apples either by hand or in a food processor.

Squeeze the sausagemeat from the sausages into a large bowl, then add all the other ingredients, except the cranberries and streaky bacon. Season generously, then get your hands in and mix well. Weigh out 450g of the stuffing and mix a handful of the cranberries into it. Use to stuff the neck of the turkey (see 'Goes well with').

To assemble, butter and season a large sheet of foil. Stretch out the bacon rashers slightly with the back of a kitchen knife, then overlap 12 rashers on the foil. Spoon half of the stuffing mix evenly over the bacon, leaving a border of about 3cm. Scatter with half the cranberries, then pat them in. Tuck the long edges of the bacon over the stuffing; then, using the foil to help, roll the stuffing up into a log shape. Repeat to make a second roll.
Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Put the foil-wrapped rolls onto a roasting tin and roast for 45 mins. Unwrap, draining off any juice, then finish roasting for 15 mins until the bacon is crisp.
chief_review: This rolled stuffing recipe is a wonderfully practical and flavorful take on classic stuffing. The blend of pork sausage, chestnuts, tart Bramley apples, and fresh herbs infuses the roll with a balanced combination of savory, sweet, and herby notes, while the cranberries add bursts of bright acidity. Wrapping everything in streaky bacon not only locks in moisture but also ensures a crispy exterior, making each slice visually appealing and deliciously moreish. The inclusion of egg and breadcrumbs binds the mixture nicely, resulting in a firm yet tender texture that slices beautifully. This recipe is ideally suited to those seeking a festive showstopper for a traditional roast, and is a great choice for dairy-free diets, as it does not contain milk or cheese (use a plant-based butter for greasing to avoid dairy completely). Overall, it’s a smart, crowd-pleasing centerpiece.

name: Hot toddy fruitcake
description:
This fabulous Christmas cake can be made and decorated in four very different ways. Just choose your
favourite
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 200ml hot, strong black tea (use any type)
3 tbsp good-quality orange marmalade, thin or medium shred
1 tbsp whisky(or use orange juice if you prefer)
directions: Mix the hot tea, whisky and marmalade in a large bowl until the marmalade melts. Stir in all of the dried fruit, peel and cherries, then cover and leave to soak overnight.

Next day, heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3 and grease and double-line a 20cm round, deep cake tin with non-stick baking paper. Using electric beaters, cream together the butter and sugar until fluffy. Add the eggs a little at a time, beating well after each addition, then fold in the flour and spices, followed by the lemon zest and soaked fruit. Add any liquid that hasn’t been absorbed by the fruit, too. Spoon into the prepared tin, level the top, then bake for 1½ hrs. Turn the oven down to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1 and bake for another 1½ hrs or until a skewer inserted into the centre of the cake comes out clean. Cool on a wire rack in the tin.

While the cake is still warm, use the skewer to pepper the cake with holes, poking it all the way down. Dissolve the sugar in the tea, add the whisky or orange juice, then spoon over the surface. If you’re making the cake ahead of time, feed it with a fresh swig of hot toddy every week, but take care not to make the cake soggy. Can be kept for a month well-wrapped in an airtight container in a cool, dry place. If short on time, the cake can be made the same day that you decorate it.
chief_review: This Christmas cake is a classic, richly fruited centerpiece, brimming with festive aroma from mixed spices, whisky, marmalade, and citrus zest. The use of strong black tea adds depth and balance to the sweetness, while the inclusion of both mixed dried fruits and glacé cherries creates a succulent, moist crumb. Butter provides a luxurious texture, and the option to substitute orange juice for whisky in the finishing syrup makes this cake family-friendly if desired. Ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, the recipe contains no meat or animal-derived gelatine. However, it does contain eggs, making it unsuitable for vegans. While the cake is bursting with traditional holiday flavors, attention should be given to allergens such as gluten (from the flour), eggs, and potential traces of nuts in dried fruit mixes. Overall, a delectable centerpiece for festive gatherings.

name: Creamy parsnip & squash bake
description: i made this just now but my own way....i put the veggies in a deep dish, and mixed in salt, pepper and chilli powder into the double cream, mixing real well. poured that on top, but lo and behold, it wasnt enough. so i beat some Philly cheese with milk till smooth n creamy, and poured that in too. sprinkled tons of chopped chives and spring onions in, then covered the whole thing with a generous sprinkle of cheddar cheese. really delicious, but it definitely needs baking for 1 hour as the parsnip cooks slower than butternut squash. cover with foil if need be, and next time i'll even mix in garlic into the cream.
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 284ml pot and a 142ml pot double cream
1 small onion or shallot, finely chopped
500g butternut squash (about ½ a large one)
directions: Place the cream, onion or shallot and the thyme sprig into a small pan. Slowly heat to just below boiling point, then remove from the heat and leave to cool. Strain, discarding the onion and thyme.

Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 4. Rub the bottom and sides of a gratin dish measuring about 20cm x 30cm with butter. Peel the parsnips and trim the ends. Peel and scoop the seeds out of the squash. Thinly slice the vegetables.
Layer the parsnip and squash in the dish, pour over the infused cream, then scatter with the thyme leaves and gruyère. Bake for 1 hr until golden and a fork slides easily into the veg.
chief_review: This hearty vegetable bake is indulgently creamy, with layers of parsnip and butternut squash bathed in double cream and topped with a rich cheddar crust. The addition of chives and spring onions brings freshness, while the use of Philly cheese blended with milk adds a decadent, tangy depth to the sauce. Gruyère lends a subtle nuttiness to the final dish. For best results, be sure to bake for a full hour to allow the parsnip to soften completely, covering with foil to prevent over-browning. Incorporating garlic into the cream is an excellent suggestion for even more flavor. This recipe is ideal for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish—just be sure to use vegetarian-friendly cheeses if necessary. It pairs beautifully as a main or a rich side dish for festive or comforting dinners.

name: Winter root mash with buttery crumbs
description: A little bit of this winter root mash goes a long way - make it a day ahead and cut the stress on Christmas Day
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 650g swede, cut into same size chunks as the parsnips
1 rounded tbsp hot horseradish(English Provender is good)
a small handful thyme leaves, plus extra for scattering
directions: In a large pan of boiling salted water, cook the parsnips and swede, covered, for about 20 minutes until tender. Drain well, then mash them together using a masher or food processor until reasonably smooth but still with a bit of texture. Stir in the soured cream, horseradish and thyme and season with salt and pepper.
Spoon into a buttered shallow ovenproof dish and put to one side.

Make the topping. Melt the butter in a frying pan and cook the onion for 5-6 minutes, until gorgeously golden. Mix in the breadcrumbs and stir to brown and crisp a little. Season with salt and pepper and add the thyme. Take the pan off the heat. Spoon the mixture casually over the top of the mash. Scatter over the parmesan. (Can be made ahead to this point and kept covered in the fridge for up to a day. Or can be frozen for up to a month.)

Bake with the turkey (190C/gas 5/ fan 170C) for 35-40 minutes if doing from cold, 25-30 minutes if not, or 11⁄2-13⁄4 hours from frozen (put foil on top, and remove it for the last 10 minutes) – until golden and crisp on top. Serve scattered with a few more thyme sprigs and leaves.
chief_review: This winter root mash brilliantly marries the sweetness of parsnips and swede with the warming kick of horseradish and the creaminess of soured cream. The fresh thyme adds aromatic depth, while the breadcrumb and Parmesan topping bakes to irresistibly golden crispness. It's an excellent make-ahead dish, easing holiday meal prep. Suitable for vegetarians, it delivers a comfortingly rich note as a side or main event for non-meat eaters. Do note the presence of dairy and gluten, so it's ideal for those without specific allergies or intolerances. Whether for Christmas or a winter gathering, this dish is sure to bring both flavor and festive spirit to the table.

name: White chocolate chip fudge
description: Such a good recipe I have made it so many times. Only thing I would say is not to use any white chocolate that is softer in the middle as it meant the fudge didn't set properly
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 3 tbsp liquid glucose(available in most supermarkets and chemists)
140g white chocolate, cut into chunks (not too small or they'll melt completely)
directions: Line a 22cm square non-stick tin with baking parchment. Put the caster sugar, double cream and liquid glucose in a pan. Slowly heat together, stirring continually, until the sugar melts and stops feeling grainy on the bottom of the pan. Turn up the heat and fast boil until a small amount of the mixture dropped into a glass of cold water sets into a soft ball that you can pick up on a teaspoon. By this time the bubbles in the mixture will look small and even.

Turn off the heat and keep stirring for 5 mins or until the mix starts to thicken a little. Sprinkle in the white chocolate and swirl it through the mixture once using a spatula or the handle of a wooden spoon. Pour into a tin and leave the fudge overnight to set, then turn out and cut into squares.
chief_review: This recipe produces a decadent white chocolate fudge with a rich, creamy texture thanks to the generous use of double cream and golden caster sugar. The clever addition of liquid glucose ensures smoothness and helps prevent crystallization. When choosing white chocolate, opt for a solid variety to guarantee the fudge sets properly—avoid filled or soft-centered chocolates that may compromise the final texture. This treat is indulgent and remarkably sweet, making it perfect for special occasions or as a gift. The absence of eggs and nuts makes this suitable for vegetarians and for those avoiding common allergens like nuts and eggs. However, this recipe does contain dairy, so it's not suitable for lactose-intolerant individuals or vegans. Overall, a classic confectionery delight with a smooth finish, provided quality chocolate is used.

name: Sticky Port gravy
description: This full-flavoured, festive gravy can be made in advance - our secret ingredients of soy sauce and dried mushrooms add a deep hit of 'umami', or savouriness, to complement a roast
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 chicken wings, chopped into pieces (or 8 chicken wings if you don’t have the turkey neck and giblets)
small handful dried mushrooms(optional – but nice)
1 tbsp red wine vinegaror Sherry vinegar
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Tip the turkey bits and/or chicken wings into a sturdy roasting tin with the onions, carrot, celery and garlic. Toss in the oil and spread out into a single layer. Place in the oven for 40 mins undisturbed – you want them the right side of just burnt, as this will give you lots of flavour.

Remove the tin from the oven and mix in the honey, soy sauce and tomato purée. Toss everything together until all the bits are completely coated, then return to the oven for 10 mins until sticky and caramelised. Remove the tin from the oven again, sprinkle over the flour and dried mushrooms (if using) and return to the oven for a final 10 mins.

If your roasting tin is flameproof, put it on a low flame, add the vinegar and sizzle for a moment. Pour in the Port and cook until you have a thick, glutinous paste mixed in with all the ingredients – it will look quite messy! Add the stock and herbs, bring to the boil and cook for 10 mins. (If your tin isn’t flameproof, add the vinegar, stir to loosen all the burnt bits from the tin, then tip into a saucepan to continue.)

Turn off the heat and use a potato masher to mash everything to extract as much flavour out of it as you can. Carefully pass the contents through a sieve over another saucepan, pushing down on the contents of the sieve. Simmer the gravy until thick and glossy, then leave to cool. Can be chilled for up to 3 days or frozen for up to 2 months. Reheat the gravy and serve as it is, or add to the turkey roasting juices for even more flavour.
chief_review: This rich, deeply savoury gravy is a triumph of balanced flavours and technique, embodying the essence of festive cooking. The combination of turkey neck, giblets, and chicken wings forms a robust base, while soy sauce and dried mushrooms elevate the umami, enhancing its depth—perfect for pairing with any roast. The inclusion of red wine or port adds a luxurious backbone, and the aromatic backbone of onions, garlic, thyme, and bay leaf rounds it out beautifully. The flour ensures a silky texture, and the blend of sweet (honey) and sour (vinegar) notes showcases a chef's attention to the classic sweet-sour balance in great gravies. This recipe is particularly suitable for those seeking nut-free dishes or wishing to prepare ahead for seamless entertaining. In summary, a show-stopping gravy—complex, comforting, and cleverly crafted for festive occasions.

name: Eggnog
description:
Add cinnamon, and please please please don't serve it over ice. Just chill it
Dark spiced rum preferred to brandy
directions: Put the sugar in a saucepan with 75ml water. Simmer until the sugar has dissolved, then cool and chill.
Beat the yolks with the vanilla until smooth. Add the condensed milk, brandy and cooled sugar syrup, mixing well.
Pour into a jug and chill for at least 2 hrs. Serve within 24 hrs, over ice.
chief_review:
This recipe creates a rich and decadent drink, reminiscent of a festive eggnog but with a delightful twist from spiced rum (if you opt for it over brandy). The combination of egg yolks, condensed milk, and vanilla delivers a silky, luxurious texture, perfectly complemented by the warming depth of the chosen spirit. The hint of cinnamon heightens the aromatic profile, making each chilled sip comforting and indulgent. It’s important to serve it well-chilled—not over ice—to preserve the luscious consistency. 

Given the presence of egg yolks and condensed milk, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet but not for vegans or those avoiding dairy or egg-based products. The ingredients are naturally gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for those with gluten sensitivities. Enjoy this as a festive treat for special occasions.

name: Rocky robin cake
description: Get creative with your Christmas cake icing - these robins are super cute and really easy to model
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 x 20cm round or 18cm square Christmas cake(see 'Goes well with', below)
4 tbsp raspberryor apricot jam, warmed and sieved
brown, green and red food colouring
directions: Sit the cake on a large board or flat serving plate. Brush a little of the jam over the cake. Dust a clean surface with a little icing sugar, then roll out the marzipan until big enough to cover the cake (use string to help you measure). Carefully lift the marzipan onto the cake, pat down to cover smoothly and trim any excess off the bottom. Brush all over again with more jam.

Knead 1kg white icing until smooth, then roll out on an icing sugar-dusted surface until a little bigger than the marzipan size. Carefully lift onto the cake, partially pat down the sides to smooth and stick, allow the rest to stick in folds, or tease into shape with your fingers (step A). Trim any ragged edges.

For the robins, roll 3 walnut-size balls from some of the remaining white icing. Halve the icing that is left. Knead brown colouring into 1 half to give a rich colour, wrap well – this will be the branch. Divide the other half into 3 pieces, and colour 1 red, 1 pale brown and 1 green.

Re-dust the work surface, pinch off 3 marble-size balls of red icing and roll each into a teardrop shape for the breast. Use a cocktail stick to add texture, then stick 1 onto each robin – brush a little water onto the icing to help it stick. As you stick it, flatten the base of the ball slightly so that the robins stand up.

Divide the pale brown icing into 3 balls and roll each into an oval shape, then pinch 1 end of each into a gentle point (step B). Stick onto the robins so that the point is the head, and trim the tail if you need to. Poke a clove into each brown tip to make a little beak. Pull the round bit off the end of 6 cloves to leave spiky ends, and poke into robins to make feet. Use black writing icing to add eyes (step C).

Roll most of the dark brown icing into a long branch and attach to the cake with a little more water or jam. Roll smaller branches from the remaining dark brown icing. Pinch leaves from the green icing and attach. Add the robins and enjoy.
chief_review: This festive Christmas cake icing recipe is a delightful invitation to creativity, transforming a classic holiday centerpiece into an adorable tableau of robin decorations. Working with ready-to-roll icing and marzipan makes the process approachable for both beginners and experienced bakers. The use of fruit jam as a glaze adds a subtle, tart layer beneath the rich marzipan and sweet icing, balancing flavors beautifully. A touch of food coloring brings the robins to life, while cloves and black icing provide characterful detail. The result is a visually stunning, crowd-pleasing cake—ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, as all listed ingredients are plant-based. Remember that marzipan may contain nuts, so this recipe naturally suits nut-lovers but is not appropriate for those with nut allergies. Overall, it’s an inviting and playful technique to brighten your holiday table.

name: Gingerbread pancakes
description: Hi I would like to make these Christmas morning but wondered if you can freeze them then heat them through on the day? Thanks so much in advance.
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: ½ tbsp maple syrup, plus extra to serve
directions: Put the flour, baking powder, ginger, cinnamon and sugar in a large bowl with a pinch of salt. Combine the egg, maple syrup and milk in a jug. Gradually add to the dry ingredients, whisking until a smooth, silky batter forms.

Heat a drizzle of oil in a large, non-stick pan over a medium heat and ladle 2-3 small rounds into the pan. Cook for 1-2 mins until bubbles start to appear on the surface, then flip over and cook for a further 1 min until fluffy. Do this in batches until you have 10 pancakes.
Serve in a stack, with extra maple syrup, a blob of crème fraîche and dates scattered over.
chief_review: This recipe creates festive pancakes with warming spices and a lovely sweetness from dates and maple syrup—a perfect choice for Christmas morning. The batter’s use of self-raising flour and cow's milk means it’s not gluten-free or dairy-free but would suit a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish products. The combination of ground ginger, cinnamon, and maple syrup provides delightful holiday flavors, while the crème fraîche and chopped dates bring a luxurious finish. Freezing the pancakes after cooking is a practical option—simply reheat them in the oven or toaster on the day for a fresh, delicious breakfast. Overall, a comforting and crowd-pleasing recipe for those looking for an indulgent yet simple vegetarian treat.

name: Pigs in puff pastry blankets
description: Serve these irresistibly buttery pastry-wrapped chipolatas as a Christmas dinner side dish - they're perfect as party canapés too
author: Good Food
ingredients: ½ tbsp vegetable oil, for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and grease a large baking tray. Unroll the puff pastry into an A4 sheet and cut 16 x 10cm-long strips.
Wrap each chipolata in a strip of pastry, winding it round like a corkscrew. Place on the baking sheet and chill in the fridge for 15 mins. Can be chilled overnight or frozen for up to 2 weeks.

Mix the egg yolk with 1 tsp water and use to glaze the top of each pastry spiral. Sprinkle with the sesame seeds, then bake for 25-30 mins until the pastry is puffed up and golden, and the sausages are cooked.
chief_review: This festive recipe turns classic chipolatas into a show-stopping side or canapé by wrapping them in golden, buttery puff pastry. The chipolatas remain juicy inside, while the pastry offers a crisp, flaky texture that’s deeply satisfying. Brushing with egg yolk provides a beautiful, glossy finish, and the sprinkle of sesame seeds adds a subtle nutty crunch that rounds out the dish. The use of ready-rolled pastry ensures the process is simple and approachable, yet the result feels indulgent and celebratory—ideal for both Christmas dinner and elegant parties. As the recipe relies on pork sausages and egg, it’s best suited for those following a traditional diet, but its rich flavors and textures are sure to be a crowd-pleaser. Serve them hot from the oven for maximum impact.

name: Creamed sprouts with chestnuts
description: Double cream, nutmeg and chestnuts make a luscious addition to traditional Brussels sprouts - just watch this extra-ingulgent side dish disappear on Christmas Day
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tsp freshly grated nutmeg, plus extra to serve
directions: Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, add the sprouts and cook for 3-4 mins until slightly tender. Drain and rinse under cold water.

Meanwhile, very gently fry the onions in the oil and half the butter for about 10 mins until soft. Add the garlic and stock cube and cook for 2 mins, stirring, until everything is combined. Remove from the heat.

Roughly chop the sprouts by hand or in a food processor, then stir them in with the onions and the rest of the butter, along with the double cream and nutmeg. Put back on the heat and cook until the cream is bubbling. Season to taste. Toss in the chestnuts and sprinkle over a little extra nutmeg to serve.
chief_review: This festive Brussels sprouts dish elevates the humble green with layers of flavor and sumptuous texture. Sautéed onions and garlic create a rich base, while the addition of double cream and butter yields a wonderfully decadent sauce that clings to each sprout. The warmth of freshly grated nutmeg ties in perfectly with the earthiness of chestnuts, lending a soft, wintry sweetness. It's an ideal, crowd-pleasing side for a holiday feast, especially for those seeking a luxurious, vegetarian-friendly option. Using vacuum-packed chestnuts ensures both convenience and consistent flavor. The creaminess contrasts beautifully with the bright, slightly bitter sprouts, resulting in a dish that is both comforting and celebratory. A sprinkle of freshly grated nutmeg at the end heightens the aroma, making this recipe a true standout for special occasions.

name: Gingerbread Bûche de Noël
description: Give the classic chocolate Bûche a makeover with festive flavours of ginger, cinnamon, treacle and golden syrup and creamy butter icing
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 balls stem ginger, finely grated, plus 2 tbsp of the syrup
100g dark muscovado sugar, plus extra for dusting
3 tbsp gingersyrup, from the stem ginger jar
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Grease and line a 20 x 30cm Swiss roll tin with baking parchment, then grease the parchment a little too. Put the treacle, syrup, butter and stem ginger in a pan, heat until melted and stir to combine, then set aside to cool a little.

Put the eggs and sugar in a bowl and whisk using an electric hand whisk until light, mousse-like and doubled in size – this will take about 10 mins. The mixture is ready when it holds a ribbon trail from the beaters for 3 secs. Sift over the flour, baking powder and spices, then pour the melted butter mixture around the sides of the bowl so that it trickles down into the whisked eggs. Very gently fold everything together with a large metal spoon. When just combined, pour the mixture into the Swiss roll tin and ease it into the corners. Bake for 12 mins until just cooked.

While the sponge is cooking, lay a sheet of baking parchment, big enough to fit the cake, on your work surface and dust with a little sugar. Once cooked, tip the cake directly onto the parchment. Use a small serrated knife to score a line about 2cm from one of the shorter ends, making sure you don’t cut all the way through – this will help to get a tight roll. Gently roll up from this end, rolling the parchment between the layers. Leave to cool like this on a wire rack to help set the shape.

To make the icing, put the ingredients in a bowl and whisk until smooth. Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a large round nozzle, or use a plastic sandwich bag and snip off one corner to make a hole about 1cm wide. Unroll the sponge and drizzle the surface with 2 tbsp ginger syrup. Pipe a layer of ginger buttercream over the inside of the roll, then use the paper underneath to help tightly re-roll into a roulade. Slice off both ends for a neat finish. The Bûche can be frozen at this point – simply re-roll in the parchment, then in foil, and freeze. Defrost at room temperature before continuing.

Place the Bûche on a serving plate or board. Use the remaining icing to pipe a thick layer over the top of the sponge, zigzagging backwards and forwards to create a tight concertina pattern. Decorate with white pearl sprinkles, if you like. The Bûche will keep in a sealed container for up to 5 days, or can be frozen for up to two months.
chief_review: This festive twist on the classic chocolate Bûche impresses with its harmonious blend of ginger, cinnamon, treacle, and golden syrup, perfect for those who love spicy warmth in their desserts. The use of both stem ginger and ground ginger delivers layered, aromatic heat, balanced by the earthiness of muscovado sugar. The sponge is delightfully moist, while the creamy butter icing pairs smoothly with the sweet spice profile. The golden syrup and treacle add depth and a slight stickiness, reminiscent of classic gingerbread. This recipe suits an ovo-lacto vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin. It is not suitable for those seeking dairy-free, gluten-free, or vegan options, but for a traditional holiday treat, it absolutely delights. The white pearl sprinkles provide a festive finish, making this an eye-catching centerpiece for any celebration.

name: Pecan toffee cake
description: Indulge in this gorgeously nutty cake for dessert, then serve the leftovers as you would Christmas cake to whoever pops by
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 200g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Tip 100g pecans into a processor and whizz until fine, then tip into a bowl. Put the dates into a small pan with enough water to cover, boil for 5 mins until very soft. Drain, discarding the liquid, then whizz in the processor until smooth. Leave to cool.

Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Butter and line the base of a 23cm cake tin. Beat the butter, sugar and spice together until lighter and creamy, then tip in the dates, ground pecans, eggs and a pinch of salt and beat briefly until smooth.

Fold in the flour with a metal spoon, then spoon into the tin and level the top. Sprinkle the remaining nuts over the top (don’t press them in), then bake for 40 mins or until risen and golden and a skewer comes out clean. Serve warm, with generous drizzles of maple syrup and scoops of Maple crunch ice cream (see 'goes well with').
chief_review: This pecan and date cake is a rich, decadent treat bursting with warm spice and a deep, nutty sweetness from the pecans and dates. The use of muscovado sugar and mixed spice contributes a lovely depth of flavor, making it perfect for festive occasions or as an indulgent dessert. The cake’s texture is exceptionally moist, thanks to both the butter and dates, while the maple syrup drizzle adds an extra touch of luxury. With no dairy alternatives or flour substitutions, this recipe is not suitable for gluten-free or vegan diets, but it does cater well to vegetarians. The inclusion of plenty of nuts also makes it a good pick for those wanting a dessert with natural, wholesome ingredients—though those with nut allergies should avoid it. Serve it in slender slices, just as you would a classic fruitcake, to savor every bite.

name: Coconut & vanilla milk bottle cocktail
author: Chelsie Collins
directions: Put a few ice cubes in a cocktail shaker with the vanilla vodka, coconut cream, crème de cacao and grated nutmeg. Shake and strain into two mini milk bottles (see tip). Pop a rolled chocolate wafer in each.
chief_review: This decadent cocktail is a delightful fusion of vanilla vodka, coconut cream, and crème de cacao, delivering a richly indulgent yet balanced flavor with a hint of tropical sweetness. The grated nutmeg adds a warming spice note, while chocolate wafers provide a playful, textural element to the experience. With no animal-derived ingredients aside from possibly the chocolate wafers and crème de cacao (which may require label checks for strict dietary needs), the cocktail leans toward being vegetarian-friendly. However, those with dairy or nut allergies should note potential allergens in the coconut cream, crème de cacao, and wafers. The creamy texture and harmonious blend of chocolate and coconut create an ideal after-dinner treat or show-stopping party drink, best enjoyed chilled.

name: Brandy butter ice cream
description: Throw a fresh spin on a favourite, festive sauce by serving as a sweet and creamy frozen dessert or accompaniment
author: Good Food
directions: Heat the butter in a small pan until just starting to take on a nutty brown colour – remove from the heat straight away as it will continue to colour. Stir in the brandy, then leave to cool.

Heat the milk in a saucepan but don’t let it boil. Whisk the egg yolks and sugar in a bowl until pale. Pour over the hot milk, whisking continuously, then return to the saucepan set over a low heat. Cook for 3-4 mins, stirring the whole time with a wooden spoon, until the custard thickens enough to coat the back of your spoon. Leave to cool.
Whisk the cream until it forms soft, billowy peaks. Fold in the brandy butter and the custard mixture. Churn in an ice-cream machine until set, then keep in the freezer for up to 2 months.
chief_review: This inventive recipe transforms a classic festive sauce into an indulgent frozen dessert, offering a rich combination of butter, double cream, egg yolks, and brandy. The deep sweetness of light soft brown sugar and the warmth of brandy pair beautifully, creating a luxurious, grown-up treat with a creamy texture and a hint of sophistication. The result is an elegant, velvety dessert that could serve as a memorable accompaniment to holiday cakes or fruit, or stand alone as a decadent final course. While this recipe is not suitable for those with dairy, egg allergies, or those avoiding alcohol, it is a delightful choice for those seeking an extravagant twist on classic flavors.

name: Burnt sprouts with pomegranate & sesame
description: Add a deliciously different side dish to your Christmas dinner spread with these pan-fried Brussels sprouts and juicy pomegranate seeds, drizzled with pomegranate molasses
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat the oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat. Put the sprouts in the pan, cut-side down, and leave them to sizzle away happily for 10 mins without disturbing them.

Halfway through cooking, dot over the butter and leave it to sizzle and brown – the sprouts need to be really crispy and dark brown. If they are just lightly brown, carry on cooking for another 5-10 mins.

Scatter over the sesame seeds and stir-fry everything until the seeds are toasted. Off the heat, toss through the pomegranate seeds, then season the sprouts with salt and tip into a serving dish. Drizzle with the pomegranate molasses before serving.
chief_review: This festive pan-fried Brussels sprouts dish delivers a vibrant contrast of textures and flavors—crispy, caramelized sprouts paired with succulent pomegranate seeds and a tangy touch of pomegranate molasses. The addition of sesame seeds gives a subtle nuttiness, while butter adds richness to balance the acidity from the fruit. Using rapeseed or sunflower oil keeps the flavors light and lets the freshness of the ingredients shine. This side is an excellent vegetarian option, and since it contains no gluten or common allergens (except for sesame and dairy), it's broadly suitable for those with dietary restrictions. Simple to prepare yet visually stunning, it’s a sophisticated addition to any Christmas spread.

name: Cranberry sours
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: big bag of crushed ice, to serve
directions: Put the cranberries, liqueurs, orange and lime juices and the maple syrup into a food processor or blender. Blitz until the berries are as finely chopped as possible.

Strain through a fine sieve, working the cranberry pulp against the mesh with a spatula or small ladle until you have extracted all of the liquid. Chill until needed. When ready to serve, fill small glasses with crushed ice, then pour over the almost fluorescent pink cocktail.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail blends the tartness of cranberries with the citrusy punch of orange juice and liqueur, offering a refreshing and sophisticated drink. The addition of Disaronno provides subtle almond notes, while maple syrup balances the acidity, letting you adjust sweetness to taste. Served over crushed ice, it’s perfect for festive occasions or summer gatherings. With all plant-based ingredients and no animal products, this recipe is suitable for a vegan diet. Additionally, the absence of gluten-containing ingredients makes this beverage ideal for those following a gluten-free lifestyle. Simple to prepare, visually appealing, and bursting with flavor, this cocktail is sure to impress.

name: Pomegranate rosemary spritzer
author: Chelsie Collins
directions: Put the pomegranate juice in a small saucepan with a sprig of rosemary. Bring to the boil and reduce for a few mins until syrupy. Leave to cool, then chill until ready to use.
Fill four Champagne flutes with 1 part pomegranate syrup and top up with 3 parts Prosecco. Garnish each glass with a rosemary sprig, if you like.
chief_review:
This refreshing cocktail elegantly combines the tart vibrancy of pomegranate juice with the lively effervescence of prosecco, subtly accented by the aromatic hint of rosemary. Its preparation is minimal, yet the final result is sophisticated—a perfect aperitif or celebratory drink. The use of fruit juice as a base enhances the drink’s bright notes without overwhelming sweetness. The rosemary adds an earthy punch that complements the sparkling wine.

This recipe is naturally suitable for a vegetarian diet and vegan-friendly, as it does not contain any animal products. It’s also gluten-free, as prosecco is a wine and wheat or gluten-containing ingredients are absent. Additionally, the ingredient list steers clear of common allergens like dairy, nuts, and eggs, making it an inclusive option for gatherings where guests may have various dietary requirements. Serve well-chilled and garnish generously with rosemary for maximum visual and aromatic appeal.

name: Scallop & apple salad with hazelnut dressing
description: Fat, juicy scallops are always a treat- the secret is not to overcook them and to team with contrasting sweet flavours
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2 tbsp finely chopped toasted hazelnut(see dressing)
2 tsp extra-virgin rapeseed oil, plus extra for drizzling
175g hazelnut(a 200g bag will give you enough for the scallops, too)
directions: To make the dressing, tip the hazelnuts into a frying pan, toast until golden, then transfer to the small bowl of a food processor. Whizz for 5-10 mins until they make a smooth paste – the nuts will start to release some of their oil and the paste should look like smooth peanut butter. Add the vinegar, maple syrup, season and blend to combine. With the motor running, pour in 150ml water and continue blending until smooth. Can be kept in the fridge for up to 1 week.
Cut the apple into really fine matchsticks using a mandolin or sharp knife. Toss in a little of the lemon juice as you go to prevent the apple from turning brown.

Put the hazelnuts in a shallow dish. Heat the butter in a frying pan until foaming and nut brown. Add the scallops and cook for 1 min on each side, or to your liking, seasoning as they cook. Remove from the pan and roll each scallop in hazelnuts. If cooking for larger numbers, cook the scallops in batches so that you don’t overcrowd the pan.

To serve, spoon a dollop of the hazelnut dressing in the centre of each plate; use the back of the spoon to spread out the dressing slightly. Toss the watercress in the remaining lemon juice and oil, season and place a pile in the centre of each dressing dollop. Arrange the scallops around the watercress and place piles of apple between each scallop. Drizzle with a little oil and serve immediately.
chief_review: This scallop recipe beautifully balances sweetness from maple syrup and apple with the rich nuttiness of toasted hazelnuts. The addition of cider vinegar and lemon juice brings a welcome brightness, cutting through the buttery texture of the scallops. The watercress adds freshness, making this dish not only vibrant but also elegantly layered in flavor. The method highlights the importance of not overcooking the scallops, preserving their delicate, juicy texture. Overall, this recipe is an excellent choice for pescatarians. It also caters to those seeking a gluten-free option, provided all condiments used are verified gluten-free. The nut component means it’s not suitable for nut allergies, but the thoughtful pairing of ingredients exemplifies modern seafood cookery.

name: Stuffing baubles
description: These bacon and onion-wrapped balls of sausagemeat and cranberry stuffing make a sensational side for Christmas dinner with all the traditional trimmings
author: Good Food
ingredients: drizzle of vegetable oil, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and grease a large baking tray. Halve the onions through the root and peel off the papery skin. Cut off any stringy roots but leave the base of the root intact. Slice a little off the rounded side of each onion half, so they will sit on the tray. Cut away the centre of the onions, reserving the offcuts, to leave a hollow – once you’ve cut away a little, you can use your fingers to pull out the layers until you’re left with a shell of 2 or 3 layers. Arrange the halves on a baking tray, season and bake for 10 mins until just softened. Set aside to cool.

Weigh the onion offcuts and place 140g/5oz in a food processor (save any remaining onions for another recipe). Blitz until finely chopped but still with a little texture – or finely chop by hand. Heat a drizzle of oil in a frying pan and add the onions. Cook for 5 mins until softened, then set aside to cool.

Tip the sausagemeat, cranberries, thyme and breadcrumbs into a bowl. Add the fried onions and a little seasoning. Mix well. Roll the stuffing mixture into 12 balls and use to fill the onion halves. Wrap a slice of pancetta around each ‘bauble’, ensuring the ends meet underneath the onions. Can now be covered with cling film and chilled for up to 2 days or frozen for up to a month.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Unwrap the stuffing baubles (if chilled) and bake for 25 mins until cooked through and the bacon is starting to crisp. If you’re cooking from frozen, bake for 35 mins. (If you have a full oven, it may be too steamy to crisp up the bacon, so finish with a blast under a hot grill until nicely browned and crispy.)
chief_review: This festive recipe delivers impressive flavor and presentation—juicy sausagemeat and sweet cranberries wrapped in smoky pancetta and tender red onion. The breadcrumbs lend a pleasant texture, while fresh thyme infuses a hint of aromatic depth. These stuffing balls make a standout accompaniment for a traditional Christmas feast, balancing savory richness with sweet, tangy bursts from the cranberries. Be mindful: the presence of sausagemeat and pancetta means the dish is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. Additionally, wheat-based breadcrumbs make it unsuitable for gluten-free diets, though a gluten-free alternative could be used. For those with egg or dairy allergies, this recipe is a safe bet, as neither ingredient is present. Overall, a well-balanced, crowd-pleasing side dish that’s sure to enhance any holiday spread.

name: Sticky spiced red cabbage
description:
This colourful dish will complement any
festive main course. Toss any leftovers with a drizzle
of olive oil and serve with
cold cuts, pâté or cheese
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 medium-size red cabbage, quartered, cored and shredded
1 finger-size piece fresh root ginger, finely chopped
directions: Heat oil in a large saucepan, add cabbage, ginger, onions, allspice and mustard seeds, then cook for 5 mins until just starting to wilt.

Scatter over the sugar and pour in the vinegar. Cover pan, gently cook for 10 mins, then remove lid and turn up the heat to medium. Simmer the liquid in the cabbage for about 20 mins, stirring occasionally, then stir continuously for the last few mins until all the liquid has evaporated and becomes sticky on the bottom of the pan. Tip cabbage into a large bowl and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant red cabbage dish is a standout accompaniment, bringing both color and complexity to festive tables. The interplay of sweet golden caster sugar and tangy red wine vinegar provides a pleasant balance, while the aromatic kick from fresh ginger and mustard seeds elevates the flavor profile. Olive oil adds richness, and the gentle spice of allspice rounds out the finish. Leftovers are just as delightful, tossed with a bit more olive oil and paired with cold cuts, pâté, or cheese. The recipe is naturally vegan and gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for those with dietary preferences or restrictions. Its simplicity and adaptability are commendable, and it works seamlessly alongside a variety of main courses. An impressive addition to any celebratory spread.

name: Lebkuchen
description: A German biscuit similar to gingerbread, lebkuchen is easy to make and a great Christmas treat
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: pinch each ground cloves, grated nutmeg and black pepper
directions: Tip the dry ingredients into a large bowl. Heat the honey and butter in a pan over a low heat until the butter melts, then pour into the flour mixture along with the lemon zest. Mix well until the dough is combined and fairly solid. Cover and leave to cool.

Heat oven to 180C/fan160C/gas 4. Using your hands, roll dough into about 30 balls, each 3cm wide, then flatten each one slightly into a disk. Divide the biscuits between two baking trays lined with baking parchment, leaving room for them to expand. Bake for 15 mins, then cool on a wire rack.

To ice the biscuits, mix together the icing sugar, egg white and 1-2 tbsp water to form a smooth, runny icing. Dip the top of each biscuit in the icing and spread with the back of a knife. Leave to dry out in a warm
chief_review: This lebkuchen recipe offers a festive and aromatic take on traditional German gingerbread, with a lovely balance of warming spices like ginger, cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg. The addition of ground almonds imparts a soft texture, while honey provides a gentle sweetness and moisture. The lemon zest brightens the overall flavor, cutting through the richness of the butter and spices. This recipe is naturally suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients apart from egg white, which may be swapped for an aquafaba-based icing for a vegan twist. The recipe does include wheat flour and egg white, so it is not gluten-free or vegan as written. The simple icing sugar glaze adds a pleasing finish to these festive treats, making them perfect for holiday gatherings or gifting.

name: Fragrant mango & apple chutney
description: Really delicious - one to make when you find some nice ripe cheap mangoes. I added a bit of garlic. Use your judgement with the water. And as another reviewer has mentioned don't be too alarmed if it tastes really spicy at first - it will mellow!
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: thumb-sized piece fresh root ginger, peeled and cut into thin shreds
½ tsp coriander seed, lightly crushed
¼ tsp black onion seeds (Nigella or Kalonji are good)
2 Bramley apples, about 500g/1lb 2oz, peeled, cored and chopped
1 large red chilli, deseeded and finely sliced
directions: Cut each mango in half down the sides of the flat stone that runs through the centre of the fruit, so that you end up with 2 fleshy halves. Now take each mango half and cut into the flesh, making quite chunky diagonal pieces – take care not to cut through the skin. Turn each half inside out, then slice away the chunks of mango that stand proud from the skin. Cut the flesh from around the stones, trim off the skin and chop the flesh.

Heat the oil in a large, deep sauté pan, add the onion and fry for a few mins until starting to soften. Stir in the ginger and cook, stirring frequently, for about 8-10 mins until the onion is golden. Stir in all of the spices, except the turmeric, and fry until toasted.

Stir in the turmeric, add the apple and pour in 500ml water, then cover the pan and cook for 10 mins. Stir in the mango and chilli, then cover and cook for 20 mins more until the apple is pulpy and the mango is tender.

Pour in the vinegar, stir in the sugar and salt, then leave to simmer uncovered for 30 mins, stirring frequently (especially towards the end of the cooking time so that it doesn’t stick) until the mixture is pulpy rather than watery. Spoon into sterilised jars.
chief_review:
This mango chutney recipe skillfully balances sweet, spicy, and aromatic notes, thanks to the medley of ripe mangoes, apples, and a beautifully layered spice mix. The technique of blooming cumin, coriander, and cardamom in sunflower oil enhances the depth, while ginger and red chilli provide a gentle warmth that mellows over time. The result is a glossy, tangy condiment that pairs excellently with curries, roasted vegetables, and cheeses.

With no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, this chutney is both vegan and gluten-free, making it a versatile addition to diverse dietary tables. As always, adjust water and spices to your taste and enjoy this vibrant celebration of mango season.

name: Sausage, sage & onion stuffing
description: So easy to make and devine to eat. Had loads left over as well for sandwiches and nibbles for Boxing Day.
ingredients: 1 small Bramley apple, peeled, cored and diced
2 x 400g packs meaty Cumberland sausages, removed from their skins
handful sage, leaves chopped, plus extra for topping
directions: Fry 2 sliced onions in 25g butter for 5 mins, then add 1 small diced Bramley apple and cook briefly.
Cool, then mix with 800g Cumberland sausages, skins removed, the chopped handful of sage, 140g granary breadcrumbs and seasoning.
Use to stuff the neck end of the bird, then roll any leftovers into balls. Or, pack the whole mixture into a 1kg loaf tin and top with extra sage leaves.
Bake with turkey for 30-40 mins. Drain off any fat and serve sliced.
chief_review: This recipe is a true showcase of comforting British flavors, bringing together sweet Bramley apple, aromatic sage, and hearty Cumberland sausages. The sautéed onions and buttery breadcrumbs add a depth and richness, while the rustic granary crumbs ensure a satisfying texture. It’s a versatile dish, perfect for festive spreads and delicious as leftovers in sandwiches, as the recipe suggests. This dish contains both gluten (from granary breadcrumbs) and dairy (from butter), and is not suitable for those with these allergies or intolerances. The recipe is also not vegetarian or vegan due to the inclusion of meaty sausages and butter. Overall, this is a crowd-pleaser for meat lovers and makes a comforting centerpiece for a festive meal or a cozy family dinner.

name: Chestnut, spinach & blue cheese en croûte
description:
This is, honestly, one of the most delicious things I've every made. I can't recommend it highly enough. It has become a staple at our Christmas table, and it pleases veggies and meat eaters alike. It also tastes great cold as part of a salad platter or to go with leftovers on Boxing Day.
A few hints:
Try swapping out the whole chestnuts for cashews. This adds a little bite and some more creaminess.
Being designed for the Christmas table, this dish is ENORMOUS! Halving the ingredients will serve 3-4.
We love blue cheese in our house, so we add a little extra. If you're not a fan of blue, mature cheddar also works well.
Chestnut puree can be a little tricky to find out of season, but our local Morrisons stock it all year round. A 200g pack of chestnut puree (instead of the 415g tin the recipe suggests) is actually plenty for the full recipe.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 200g pack vacuum-packed whole cooked chestnuts, halved
220g pack blue Shropshire cheese, rind trimmed, diced
directions: Melt the butter in a large frying pan. Add the leeks and garlic, stir well, cover and cook for 10 mins until the leeks are soft, stirring a few times to check that they don’t catch. Tip into a large bowl. Put the spinach in the pan and allow it to wilt. Leave to cool and, when cold, squeeze out as much liquid from it as you possibly can.

Tip the chestnut purée into the bowl with the leeks and add the 3 eggs, the nutmeg, chestnuts, spinach, breadcrumbs, cheese and seasoning, and stir until well mixed. Chill for at least 1 hr until the mixture firms up.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. On a lightly floured work surface, roll out the pastry to a rectangle large enough to completely enclose the filling. Carefully lift onto a large, long baking tray that has been lined with baking parchment, then brush round all the edges of the pastry with the remaining egg. Spoon the filling down the centre of the length of the pastry, leaving the ends clear. Tuck the ends over the filling, then firmly lift up the sides to wrap them round, trimming away any excess pastry as you go. Brush with more egg to glaze, then make a few holes in the top so steam can escape as it cooks. Bake for 40 mins until golden and the filling is firm. Remove from the oven, brush with more glaze and bake for 10 mins more.

To make the sauce, heat the stock in a medium pan, add the leeks, boil for 5 mins, then take off the heat and scoop out 2 tbsp of the leeks. Blitz the rest in the pan with the cornflour using a hand blender, then cook, stirring, until thickened. Pour in the cream and reserved leeks and warm through. Can be made 2 days ahead and chilled. Serve the pastry in thick slices with the sauce.
chief_review: This festive centerpiece hits all the right notes for a celebratory meal: luxurious, robustly flavored, and visually stunning. The combination of leeks, spinach, chestnuts, and creamy blue cheese wrapped in all-butter puff pastry delivers a magnificent balance between richness and vegetal freshness. The dish’s use of eggs, butter, and double cream makes it indulgent and satisfying—ideal for vegetarians looking for a hearty main course over the holidays. Its size thoughtfully considers large gatherings, but it scales down gracefully for intimate feasts. The suggestion to swap chestnuts for cashews brings textural variation and enhances its creamy notes. With bold, savory undertones from the blue cheese, this recipe speaks to those who appreciate assertive flavors in their holiday fare. Serve hot or cold; either way, it remains irresistibly moreish—a new classic for a vegetarian Christmas spread.

name: Chestnut, bacon & cranberry stuffing
description: This festive stuffing brings together all the trimmings in one gorgeous mass
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 rashers unsmoked back bacon, cut into strips
½ tsp chopped fresh thyme leaves
directions: Soak the cranberries in the port for an hour. Fry the onion and bacon gently in the butter, until the onion is tender and the bacon is cooked. Add the garlic and fry for another minute or so.

Cool slightly, then mix with all the remaining ingredients, including the cranberries and port, adding enough egg to bind – I find it easiest to use my hands. Fry a knob of stuffing in a little butter, taste and adjust the seasoning if necessary.

To Cook: This stuffing can be baked in a dish, or rolled into balls that will be crisp on the outside and moist inside. To bake, press the stuffing into a greased ovenproof dish in a layer that is around 4cm thick. Bake at 190C/gas 5/fan 170C for about 40 minutes, until browned and, in the case of sausagemeat stuffing, cooked right through. Alternatively, roll into balls that are about 4cm in diameter. Roast the stuffing balls in hot fat (they can be tucked around the turkey or done in a roasting tin of their own) for 30-40 minutes, until crisp and nicely browned on the outside.
chief_review: This festive stuffing is a true celebration of classic holiday flavors, marrying sweetness from cranberries and port with the savoriness of bacon and sausagemeat. The addition of chestnuts brings both texture and earthy richness, while fresh herbs elevate the recipe's aroma. The breadcrumbs ensure a satisfying, moist consistency, and the egg binds it all together beautifully. Note that this dish is not suitable for gluten-free, vegetarian, or vegan diets due to the sausagemeat, bacon, butter, egg, and breadcrumbs. It's perfect for a traditional feast where indulgent, comforting sides are the order of the day. A stellar contribution to any celebratory table!

name: Zesty orange marzipan
description: Homemade marzipan out does shop-bought every time, if orange isn't your thing try ginger or cinnamon - it's simple too
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Sift the sugars and ground almonds together, then stir through the orange zest. Beat together the egg and egg yolk, then add to the sugar mixture, stirring well.
Knead briefly to ensure the marzipan is completely mixed and pliable, adding a little orange juice if the mix is too dry, or icing sugar if too wet.

Place the cake on a cake board and use small balls of marzipan to plug any holes in the cake. Now glaze the cake with a thin layer of marmalade. Dust your work surface with a little icing sugar, then roll out the marzipan in one direction, keeping the pressure even and turning a ¼ turn every few rolls.

When large enough (about 40cm in diameter for a 20cm cake), roll the marzipan onto the rolling pin and lift onto the cake. Smooth the top with your palms and continue down over the sides of the cake, smoothing out any folds as you go. Trim with a knife where the marzipan meets the board, then leave to dry overnight.

Although homemade marzipan contains raw eggs, the amount of sugar, and lack of moisture, prevents bacteria growing when left at room temperature, so your cake should last for 1-2 months iced. The most important thing is that you don't scrimp on drying time – once you’ve covered your cake in marzipan it should be left to completely dry out for up to 3 days, before you then cover it with icing. If you want to make marzipan before you are ready to cover your cake, then wrap it well in cling film and keep in a fridge for up to a week – as wrapped in a ball it will still contain a little moisture. As it contains raw eggs it shouldn’t be given to anyone in an at-risk group, including pregnant women, the elderly, the unwell and the very young. You can make a cooked marzipan, which carries no risks. It is a little softer, and harder to work with, but a good substitute if you are at all worried.
chief_review: This homemade marzipan recipe delivers a wonderfully fragrant and flavorful result, thanks to the fresh orange zest and juice. The texture is smooth with just the right amount of sweetness and a gentle, zesty brightness. Substituting orange with ginger or cinnamon offers creative versatility, allowing for playful customization. The inclusion of ground almonds gives it a nutty richness, while the marmalade adds a pleasant, subtle tang. While it contains eggs and ground almonds—both common allergens—it is suitable for a vegetarian diet, making it a delightful homemade treat for vegetarians looking to elevate desserts or festive bakes. The process is straightforward and the end result is a moist, aromatic marzipan far superior to any store-bought version.

name: Sugar-dusted snowflake cake
description: Give your Christmas cake a stylish and professional finish this year with this sparkling decoration idea
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 x 20cm round or 18cm square Christmas cake(see 'Goes well with', below)
4 tbsp raspberryor apricot jam, warmed and sieved
1 egg white, frothed with a fork, or a little thin, runny icing made with icing sugar and water
a little edible glitter, if you have it
directions: Sit the cake on a cake board or flat plate. Brush all over with a little of the jam. Roll out the marzipan on an icing sugar-dusted surface until large enough to cover the sides and top of the cake – use string to help you measure. Cover the cake and trim the excess marzipan from the bottom. Brush with jam again, knead 850g of the white icing until smooth and pliable, then roll out as you did you for the marzipan ensuring it is large enough to cover the top and sides. Lift onto the cake. Smooth the icing down and around the sides, trimming excess from the bottom, as before. Smooth out any marks with the flats of your hand, rubbing the icing to buff it to a shine.

Roll out the rest of the white icing and cut out a few snowflakes. Brush one side with a little egg white or runny icing, then dip this side into the preserving or granulated sugar to coat. Sprinkle on glitter, if using, then use more egg white or icing to stick randomly onto the cake. Leave to set for a few hrs before cutting.
chief_review:
This Christmas cake decoration recipe delivers a visually stunning and festive finish perfect for holiday celebrations. The use of marzipan and ready-to-roll white icing ensures a professional appearance, while raspberry or apricot jam adds a subtle fruitiness that complements the rich cake beneath. The technique of layering, dusting, and using snowflake cutters gives the cake an elegant, sparkling look, elevated further by the optional edible glitter.

This recipe is ideal for vegetarians, as all listed ingredients are free from meat-derived products. However, it does contain common allergens like nuts (marzipan) and eggs, so attention should be paid for those with such allergies. 

Overall, this decorative approach not only makes the cake the centerpiece of your holiday table but also provides a delightful, sweet exterior that enhances the classic Christmas cake experience.

name: Mini sausage rolls
description: I made this last year at Christmas and they went down a treat & will repeat this year too. I added some chorizo sausagemeat in with the regular sausage meat and they were so yummy!! Going to also make a batch this year with gluten-free puff pastry.
author: John Torode
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6.

Crush ½ small garlic clove and a little salt to a paste using a pestle and mortar, or use the flat of your knife on a chopping board. Mix together with a handful of chopped parsley and stir in 50ml cold water.
Place 400g sausagemeat in a food processor (if using sausages, peel away the skins), turn on to a high speed, pour the garlic-flavoured water into the mixture, then season with pepper.
Unroll 375g ready-rolled puff pastry onto a board and cut in half lengthways.
Divide the sausage mixture in two and spread along the length of each pastry strip in a cylinder shape, leaving a 1cm edge.
Tightly roll the pastry around the sausagemeat and brush the ends with 1 beaten egg to secure.
Use a sharp knife to cut each roll into 10 pieces, each about 2.5cm long, and place on a baking sheet.
Can be made up to this point 1 month in advance and frozen. To cook from frozen, simply add 10 mins to cooking time below.

Brush more beaten egg all over the pastry. Place in the oven and cook for 25-35 mins until the pastry is puffed and crisp and the meat has cooked through. Remove and eat hot or cold with tomato ketchup if you like.
chief_review: This festive sausage roll recipe delivers on both flavor and texture, thanks to the aromatic addition of garlic and parsley paired with rich sausage meat and buttery puff pastry. The inclusion of chorizo in the filling offers a delightful, mildly smoky twist, adding depth that elevates the classic recipe. For anyone needing gluten-free options, the suggestion to use gluten-free puff pastry makes this treat more widely accessible—just ensure the sausages are gluten-free as well. These sausage rolls are a crowd-pleaser, perfect for holiday gatherings or any special occasion, with simple techniques that yield impressive results. The glossy egg wash gives them an appealing finish, making them just as inviting visually as they are to eat.

name: Snow globe hot chocolate
description: Marshmallows and strawberry laces transform into a snowman in this cute edible gift idea - a hot chocolate kit in a jam jar - perfect family fun
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 chocolate- a mini Reese's peanut butter cup or other domed chocolate is perfect
1 cookie(small enough to fit in a jam jar)
directions: First make the marshmallow snowman. Skewer the marshmallows together with a cocktail stick - cut off any of the stick that protrudes from the top. Use a little of the icing pen to stick a chocolate button and peanut butter cup to the top of each marshmallow stack, then draw on a face and 3 dots for buttons. Plait 3 strawberry laces and tie around the neck for a scarf. Stick the snowman to a cookie with a little more icing, then set aside to dry for a few mins.

Mix the cocoa and Horlicks together in the bottom of your jar. Put the snowman on top, then scatter around the mini marshmallows. Screw on the lid, tie with a ribbon and a gift tag with the following instructions: Warm 300ml milk in a pan. Remove the snowman from the jar and add the milk. Stir until smooth and chocolatey, then enjoy, with your marshmallow snowman for dunking.
chief_review: This whimsical hot chocolate kit is a delightful edible gift that brings creativity into the kitchen. The combination of marshmallows, a chocolate button, a mini Reese’s peanut butter cup, and strawberry laces creatively forms an adorable snowman, making it a treat for both the eyes and the palate. The dual addition of cocoa and Horlicks powder ensures a rich, malty base for your hot chocolate, while the mini marshmallows and cookie add playful texture. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or animal-derived gelatin, relying on commonly available marshmallows and chocolates (though check brands if strict). However, those with nut allergies should exercise caution due to the inclusion of Reese’s, and anyone wishing to avoid gluten or dairy may need to substitute certain ingredients. Overall, it’s perfect for family-friendly gifting and festive fun.

name: Stollen mince pies
description: These are delicious! Pretty easy to make but just need a bit more preparation . I make mine to the size in the recipe but bake in a deep tray really for muffins. The cakey stollen mixture spreads out and sits neatly atop the mince pie bit which looks good. I have put chopped pistachios on top prior to the bake ... this works well ... or put dried cranberries and/or juicy yellow raisins in the cake mixture as well as marzipan but they will burn if you just put them on top. I have also put lemon zest on top of the blob of mincemeat .. also nice :)
author: Good Food
directions: Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface and stamp out 12 roughly 8cm circles – you might need to re-roll the trimmings. Press into the holes of a 12-hole bun tin. Add a few tsp of the mincemeat to each pastry case.

Whizz the cake, ground almonds, caster sugar, butter and egg in a food processor until smooth. Transfer to a bowl, then stir in the candied peel and marzipan. Divide between the tarts and scatter over the flaked almonds. You can cover and chill the unbaked tarts for up to a day, or freeze for up to 3 months.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bake the pies for 20-25 mins until golden. Remove from the oven and dust with icing sugar. When cool enough, lift from the tin.
chief_review:
This inventive take on mince pies marries classic flavors with a delightful cakey twist. The combination of sweet shortcrust pastry, mincemeat, and a pillowy stollen-inspired cake topping yields a festive bake that is both visually appealing and deeply satisfying. The incorporation of ground almonds, marzipan, and candied peel enriches the texture and aroma, while the optional additions of pistachios, cranberries, or lemon zest allow for personal customisation and extra bursts of flavour.

This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it contains no meat, fish, or gelatine-based products. However, those with nut allergies should exercise caution due to the use of almonds, marzipan, and optional pistachios. Ideal for holiday gatherings, these stollen mince pies are a sumptuous treat that balance tradition and creativity with each bite.

name: Macadamia & cranberry American cookies
description: These freezable biscuits are completely irresistible and make a great gift for kids to give to teachers or grandparents
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Melt 170g of the chocolate, then allow to cool. Beat in the butter, eggs, sugars and vanilla, preferably with an electric hand whisk, until creamy. Stir in the flour, baking powder, cinnamon and cranberries with two-thirds of the remaining chocolate and macadamias, to make a stiff dough.

Using a tablespoon measure or a small ice-cream scoop, drop small mounds onto a large baking dish, spacing them well apart, then poke in the reserved chocolate, nuts and berries. Bake in batches for 12 mins until pale golden, leave to harden for 1-2 mins, then cool on a wire rack.

To freeze, open-freeze the raw cookie dough scoops on baking trays; when solid, pack them into a freezer container, interleaving the layers with baking parchment. Use within 3 months. Bake from frozen for 15-20 mins.
chief_review: These freezable biscuits are a delightful treat featuring chunks of creamy white chocolate, tart dried cranberries, and buttery macadamia nuts. The combination of golden caster and muscovado sugars creates a beautifully chewy texture, while cinnamon adds a hint of warmth. They bake up with a crisp edge and soft middle, making them utterly moreish. Perfect for gifting, these biscuits also freeze well, so you can make them ahead for festive occasions or unexpected visitors. The use of macadamia nuts provides a crunchy contrast and depth of flavor, while the cranberries add both color and tang. This recipe contains nuts, eggs, gluten, and dairy, making it suitable for most but not specific restrictive diets. Overall, an indulgent and crowd-pleasing biscuit that’s both versatile and delicious.

name: Chocolate orange & cranberry red velvet bombe
description: This stunning festive dessert makes a great alternative to Christmas pudding, with a hidden cream cheese and cranberry filling
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 175g butter, very soft, plus extra for greasing
200g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
2 x 10g tubes red food colouring(make sure it’s a bake-safe variety – we used Dr. Oetker)
50g dried cranberries, plus extra to serve
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease 2 x 16cm hemisphere cake tins, then dust with flour and shake out the excess. Stand the tins on two ramekins placed on a baking tray to hold them steady. Put the cake ingredients in a large mixing bowl, add a pinch of salt and whisk together until smooth and evenly coloured bright red. Divide the mixture between the two tins and bake for 45 mins. Remove from the oven, cool in the tins for 10 mins, then tip onto a wire rack and leave until completely cold.

Meanwhile, make the chocolate-orange ganache and the filling. Pour the cream into a saucepan, add the orange zest and heat until just steaming. Put half the white chocolate in a bowl, and the dark and milk chocolates in another bowl. Pour 50ml of the hot cream over the white chocolate (strain it if the orange zest is in big strands), and the remaining cream over the dark and milk mixture. Leave the bowls for 1-2 mins, then stir until smooth and glossy. Set aside to cool for 10 mins.
Put the cream cheese in a bowl and whisk lightly to loosen. Add the icing sugar and the cooled white chocolate and cream mixture, then blend until smooth. Stir through the cranberries, then chill.

When the cakes are cold, you can start assembling. With the cakes flat-side up, use a 7cm biscuit cutter to mark a circle in the centre of each. Use a spoon to gently scoop a dip in each cake, about 4cm deep (save the crumbs for cake truffles – see tip, left.) Remove the cream cheese mixture from the fridge and use to fill the cavities in the cakes, spreading a little onto the flat surfaces too, to help them stick together. Invert 1 cake onto the other to create a sphere, and place on a wire rack set over a baking tray (this will catch any chocolate drips).

To ice the cake, the chocolate ganache needs to be the right consistency – pourable but not too runny. If it has set a little too much, place in the microwave for 10-20 secs, then mix until smooth; if it is too runny, chill until it has firmed up a little. Pour half the ganache over the cake, letting it cover the sides and run into the tray below (use the chocolate drips for cake truffles, see Tip). Cover the whole surface using a palette knife. This is just the first coating, so won’t fill the gap between the sponges. Chill the cake for 20 mins or until the ganache has firmed up a little.
