Serve the fritters topped with a spoonful of coconut yogurt followed by the warm pears.
chief_review: This recipe for dense, nutty griddle cakes is a delightful option for brunch enthusiasts seeking a dairy-free treat. Employing almond milk and coconut butter instead of traditional dairy, the recipe achieves a rich flavor profile enhanced by warming spices—cloves, nutmeg, and cinnamon. The inclusion of rolled oats adds a wholesome texture, while the fresh pears offer a sweet, fruity contrast. Coconut yogurt as a serving accompaniment wraps it all together with a creamy, tangy finish. Using only plant-based milks and butters, this dish is well-suited for those with lactose intolerance or following a dairy-free diet. However, with eggs included, it’s not entirely vegan. These griddle cakes are a wonderful choice for anyone looking to indulge in a cozy, aromatic, and allergy-friendly (dairy-free) brunch.

name: Spicy satay wings with peanut sauce
description: These chicken wings are marinated, then baked until crisp and golden, served with a fiery, crunchy peanut sauce - the ultimate party buffet food
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 cucumber, deseeded and cut into sticks, to serve
1 Thai chilli, pricked all over with the tip of a knife (see tip, top left)
directions: Using a sharp knife or kitchen shears, snip the wing tips from the wings at the first knuckle. Discard the tips or use to make stock (see above left). Cut the remaining wing through the joint. Put the wings in a large non-metallic bowl or a food bag. Mix together the marinade ingredients and pour over the wings, toss well to coat, then chill for at least 4 hrs or overnight.

For the sauce, heat the oil in a pan, then add the garlic, ginger, lemongrass and chilli, and fry for 30 secs until aromatic. Stir in the cumin, toast for a few secs, then stir in the remaining ingredients. Simmer just long enough to make a slightly thickened sauce. Spoon into a bowl, cover and leave to cool. Can be made up to 3 days ahead and chilled.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Spread the wings over a large baking tray, sprinkle with a little salt and roast for 40-45 mins, turning halfway, until crisped and golden. If a large amount of juice has collected in the tray at the halfway point, pour it away before continuing to roast. Just before serving, warm the peanut sauce gently and remove the lemongrass and chilli. Serve with the wings, sweet chilli sauce and cucumber sticks.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a bold combination of textures and flavors, perfect for entertaining a crowd. The marinade infuses the chicken wings with depth from turmeric, cumin, soy, and aromatics, ensuring juicy, flavorful meat under a crisp, golden skin. The accompanying peanut sauce—rich with coconut cream, ginger, lemongrass, and Thai chilli—adds a spicy, creamy crunch, creating a satisfying contrast to the wings. The addition of cucumber sticks provides a refreshing, cooling element to balance the heat. This dish is an excellent choice for party buffets and social gatherings. With both the wings and sauce containing no gluten-based ingredients, this recipe is suitable for those seeking a gluten-free option, provided verified gluten-free soy sauce is used. The peanut butter and coconut cream also make this a vibrant riff on classic satay flavors. Serve fresh, and let the flavors shine!

name: Potted salmon rillette
description: This delicious starter is similar to a pâté, made with smoked salmon, cream cheese and horseradish for a kick - serve on crackers or toast
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g crème fraîche, soured cream, double or whipping cream – or a mixture of all your leftovers
100g smoked salmontrimmings, half diced, plus extra to decorate (optional)
melba toast, crackers or toasted rye bread, and a few leaves, to serve
directions: Put the cream cheese, the leftover creams, 50g salmon, 2 tsp horseradish and a small squeeze of lemon juice in a food processor or blender. Whizz until smooth, then scrape into a mixing bowl. Fold in the remaining salmon, then taste – add another tsp horseradish if you like, plus seasoning if needed. Divide the mixture between 4 small ramekins and chill for at least 2 hrs.
Before serving, decorate the rillettes with a spiral of salmon or a few dill sprigs, if you like. Add a pot to a plate with a few leaves and some crunchy Melba toast, or similar, and serve.
chief_review: This smoked salmon pâté is a delightful, indulgent starter with a luxuriously creamy texture from the blend of cream cheese, crème fraîche, and a touch of double or whipping cream. The smoked salmon provides a satisfying depth of flavor, complemented perfectly by the gentle heat of creamed horseradish and a splash of lemon for brightness. Garnishing with dill and extra salmon not only elevates the presentation but also adds a fresh herbal note. Served atop crisp melba toast, crackers, or rye bread, this pâté shines at both casual gatherings and formal occasions. Suitable for pescatarians, it can be enjoyed by those looking for a protein-rich, elegant appetizer that’s quick to prepare—ideal for entertaining or a luxurious snack.

name: Rich nutmeg ice cream
description: This rich ice cream is the perfect way to complement your Christmas pudding
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat the double cream and the full-cream milk in a pan until just starting to boil.
Meanwhile whisk the egg yolks and sugar in a large bowl. When milk and cream mix is ready, steadily pour it over the yolks, whisking continuously.

Pour back into a clean pan, then heat gently, stirring, for about 10 mins until the mix thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon. Strain custard through a sieve into another large bowl, stir in the freshly-grated nutmeg, then cool.

Churn in an ice cream machine or pour into a freezer-proof container, then freeze for about 1½ hrs until frozen around the edges. Stir the frozen edges into the mix, then repeat this twice more or until the ice cream is smooth and thick. Leave for at least 4 hrs to freeze before serving with Sticky orange & marsala pudding (see link, right).
chief_review: This ice cream delivers a truly indulgent experience, making it an excellent companion for Christmas pudding. The combination of double cream and full-cream milk gives it a sumptuous, velvety texture, while the freshly grated nutmeg infuses a beautifully aromatic warmth that feels festive and comforting. The custard base, made from egg yolks and sugar, results in a rich and creamy consistency that's both decadent and satisfying. The recipe uses no gluten-containing ingredients, making it a suitable choice for those following a gluten-free diet. However, it does include eggs and dairy. Overall, if you're seeking a classic, luxurious ice cream to crown your holiday table, this recipe is a standout choice, balancing both elegance and festive flair.

name: Herby slashed roasties
description: A much-less-fiddly version of classic Hasselback potatoes which are healthy yet totally tasty too
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 2¼kg floury potatoes, such as Maris Piper, unpeeled
directions: Bring a large saucepan of water to the boil and heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Cut the potatoes into halves or quarters depending on their size. Tip into the pan, allow the heat to come back up, then boil for 6-10 mins until just starting to soften around the edges. Drain in a colander and return to the pan. With the lid on, shake the potatoes until the edges fluff up.
Leave the potatoes until cool enough to handle. Slash half the chunks once with a small knife and stuff alternately with bay or thyme.

Heat the butter and oil in a large roasting pan either in the oven or on the hob until the butter turns golden. Carefully tip in the potatoes and gently turn in the fat (tongs are best for this). Sprinkle with sea salt and black pepper to taste and roast for 1-1¼ hrs until crisp and golden, turning halfway through.
chief_review: This simplified take on Hasselback potatoes offers a delightful blend of texture and flavor, with the floury Maris Piper variety ensuring a fluffy interior and crisped edges. The addition of bay leaves and thyme imparts subtle aromatic notes, elevating the potatoes without overpowering their natural taste. Butter and light olive oil add richness, balancing healthfulness with indulgence. This recipe is a solid match for a vegetarian diet, and can also accommodate gluten-free needs, as no wheat-based ingredients are involved. The minimal prep and reliance on unpeeled potatoes make this accessible yet impressive, perfect as a side for both casual dinners and festive occasions. A clever twist on a classic that’s sure to become a regular feature at the table.

name: Coconut bauble truffles
description: Make these colourful truffles from leftover Madeira cake, dried apricots and desiccated coconut - perfect as an edible gift to make with kids
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: different food colourings, we used yellow, pink, blue and purple
directions: In a big mixing bowl, crumble the cake with your fingers – try to get the bits as small as possible.

Tip in the apricots and coconut. Using your hands again, mix together with the cake crumbs. Use a wooden spoon to stir in the condensed milk. After you’ve mixed it in a bit, use your fingers to pull off any bits stuck to the spoon. Squidge everything together with your hands until it is well mixed and all the cake crumbs are sticky. Rub your hands together over the bowl so any bits that are stuck drop off.

Line some trays that fit in your fridge with baking parchment. Roll the sticky cake mixture into small balls (about the size of a conker or gobstopper) between your hands. Line them up on the trays, then put them in the fridge while you get the decorations ready.

Decide on how many different food colourings you are going to use, then split the coconut into the same number of piles. Put each pile of coconut into a plastic sandwich bag, add a few drops of food colouring to each, and tie a knot in the top. Shake the bags and scrunch between your fingers until all the coconut is coloured – if it’s not bright enough, open the bag and add a few more drops of colouring.

Open all the bags of coloured coconut and take the truffles from the fridge. Put 1 tbsp of water in a small bowl and lightly coat each truffle in it so the coconut can stick to the outside of each bauble.

One by one, drop each truffle into one of your bags. Shake it and roll it around until the outside is covered in coconut. Carefully put each truffle back onto the trays and chill for at least another 2 hrs until they are really cold and firm.
If you like, put some of the truffles in gift bags or boxes and tie with ribbons to give as presents. Will keep in the fridge for up to 1 week.
chief_review: This playful truffle recipe transforms humble Madeira cake and sweet dried apricots into vibrant, bite-sized treats. The use of condensed milk binds everything together for a sweet, rich base, while a double dose of desiccated coconut provides both texture and decorative flair. The colourful coconut coatings make these truffles visually appealing and fun, perfect for engaging kids in the kitchen or presenting as edible gifts. As the recipe contains no nuts, it's a promising option for those with nut allergies. However, due to the use of Madeira cake and condensed milk, it’s not suitable for vegan or gluten-free diets. Overall, this is a simple, creative recipe that brings a delightful burst of flavour and colour to any occasion.

name: Mustard butter-basted roast turkey with bacon
description: Ensure juicy meat by inserting streaky bacon under the skin of your big bird. A tangy mustard baste creates an extra tasty gravy
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 5-5½ kg oven-ready turkey, neck and giblets removed (save them to make stock, if you like)
250g pack dry-cured smoked streaky bacon(about 12 rashers)
bay leaves and chopped thyme, for scattering
directions: Weigh your turkey and calculate the cooking time by allowing 40 mins per kg for the first 4kg, then 45 mins for every kg of turkey over that weight. As a guide, a turkey this size should take 3½-4 hrs plus 30-45 mins resting time.
To make the mustard butter, beat the butter with the mustards, thyme and some ground black pepper until soft and well mixed.

Gently push your fingers under the skin of the turkey, starting from the neck, until you can push your whole hand in down the length of the breast – take care not to tear the skin. Spread the butter under the skin so that it covers the breasts. Lay the streaky bacon on your work surface in 2 rectangles of 6 overlapping rashers (for extra flavour, you can brush the bacon with a little wholegrain or English mustard first), and carefully push each rectangle of bacon under the skin to cover and protect each breast. This can be done the night before, but take out of the fridge for 1 hr before roasting so that it comes back to room temperature.

On the day, heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Lift the turkey into a roasting tin, massage the olive oil into the skin and season well with flaky salt and pepper. Put the onion, thyme and bay inside the cavity of the turkey, then pour in the wine. Cover the tin loosely with foil and roast for the calculated cooking time. For the final 30 mins, remove the foil and pour off all of the cooking juices (use for the gravy; recipe in 'goes well with'). Increase the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and roast for 30 mins more until the turkey is golden and the juices that run out of the thigh are clear, with no sign of pink, when pierced with a skewer. Leave to rest on a warm platter covered with foil and tea towels – it will keep like this for up to 45 mins.

To serve, carve the turkey and arrange the meat on a hot platter with a little of the hot gravy poured over, or bring the whole turkey to the table garnished with herbs. To fill the platter, you could surround the turkey with potatoes, if you like. Any leftover meat can be frozen in the gravy.
chief_review: This recipe elevates the traditional roast turkey with the ingenious addition of streaky bacon under the skin, which ensures beautifully juicy results and imparts a subtle smokiness to the meat. The combination of wholegrain and English mustard in the baste introduces a tangy note that complements the natural flavors of the turkey, enhancing both the texture and taste of the resulting gravy. Aromatic herbs like thyme and bay leaves add complexity, while a splash of dry white wine gives depth and sharpness to the finished dish. This roast turkey suits a gluten-free diet, provided the mustard and other condiments are certified gluten-free. Not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, this is a festive centerpiece designed for meat lovers who appreciate layered flavors and moist, tender poultry. Pair with classic sides for an unforgettable feast.

name: Lobster muffins with poached egg, caviar, spinach & hollandaise
description: Turn Eggs Benedict into a gourmet treat, perfect for a celebration breakfast or indulgent brunch - use shop bought muffins to save time
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: ½ lobster, about 300g meat (see tip, top right)
fine polenta or semolina, for dusting
directions: First make the muffins. Mix together the flour, yeast and 3/4 tsp salt in a food mixer with the dough hook, or in a large bowl if making by hand. Add the milk and egg, and mix to a dough. Leave the mixture in the machine with the motor running and knead the mix for 5-6 mins until it becomes elastic and smooth, or for 10-15 mins by hand. Place the dough in a bowl, cover with cling film and place in a warm spot to prove.

When it has doubled in size, punch the dough down with your hand and turn out. Dust your work surface and a baking tray with the polenta or semolina. Roll out the dough until 2.5cm thick and cut out muffins using a 9cm straight-edged cutter – you should have about 4 muffins. Transfer them to the tray, cover with cling film and leave to prove for 20-25 mins or until doubled in size.

Put a piece of baking parchment in a non-stick frying pan and put the pan on a low heat. Gently transfer the muffins to the pan and cook them in batches for 5-6 mins each side until they are toasted and brown. Remove from the pan and leave to cool on a wire rack. When cool, these freeze very well in freezer bags – then simply toast them from frozen. Keep 2 out for your lobster.

To make the hollandaise, put the wine, vinegar, shallot, tarragon and peppercorns in a small pan and bring to the boil. Simmer for 8-10 mins or until the mix is reduced to one-third of its original volume. Remove from the heat and leave to cool. Meanwhile, fill a pan one-third with water, bring to the boil, then reduce to a simmer. Strain the infused vinegar mixture into a mixing bowl, add the egg yolk and a large splash of water. Place the bowl over the top of the pan of simmering water (but not touching the water) and whisk. The sauce will lighten in colour and fluff up – this is called a sabayon. Do not overcook or it will look like scrambled eggs. When it is fluffy but firm, add the splash of double cream, then slowly pour in the melted butter – not too quickly – imagine you are making mayonnaise, drizzling in a small amount at a time. When all the butter has been incorporated, season with salt, cayenne and lemon juice. Pass the hollandaise through a fine sieve into a bowl. Cover with cling film and keep warm until needed.

Prepare the lobster. Twist the claws and pull the tail off the lobster, then bash the claws with a rolling pin to crack the shell and reveal the meat. Remove the shell from the tail, then cut the tail in half lengthways and remove the intestine. You should now have half a tail and a claw per person. Remove the meat from the shell. To reheat the meat, melt the butter with 2 tbsp water in a medium saucepan. Add the lobster meat and warm over a gentle heat.

To poach the eggs, bring a small pan of water to the boil and add a splash of white wine vinegar. Spin the water around with a slotted spoon and crack in the eggs – they must be very fresh. Turn off the heat and leave them to poach for 2-3 mins until set but still soft.

Meanwhile, melt the knob of butter in a pan. Add the spinach and stir until it starts to wilt. Season and grate over a little nutmeg. Remove from the heat and drain the spinach on kitchen paper. To serve, halve 1 muffin and lightly toast to warm through. Put half a muffin on each plate and top with the spinach, then add the portioned warm lobster. Place a poached egg on top, then spoon over the hollandaise and a dollop of caviar.
chief_review: This elevated Eggs Benedict brilliantly combines the richness of lobster, the silkiness of homemade hollandaise, and the elegance of Avruga caviar. The use of homemade English muffins provides a delightful base, while baby spinach adds a fresh, vegetal note to balance the decadence. This recipe shines at any celebration brunch, impressing diners with technique, flavor layering, and visual appeal. It is best suited for those who include seafood and dairy in their diet. Due to the presence of wheat flour and dairy, it isn’t suitable for gluten-free or dairy-free diets. The addition of caviar and lobster offers both luxury and umami, ensuring a sophisticated, memorable dish. Although there are several steps, attention to detail in poaching eggs and emulsion for the hollandaise will make all the difference for a truly gourmet experience.

name: Ham & watercress salad with clementine dressing
description: Use up leftover festive ingredients such as ham, hazelnuts, cranberries and clementines in this light salad - perfect after a week of indulgence
author: Emily Kydd
ingredients: 280g leftover ham, shredded or cut into chunks
directions: For the dressing, put all the ingredients in a jar, along with some seasoning, pop on the lid and give it a really good shake.

Tip the grains into a large bowl and toss through the ham, watercress, fennel, hazelnuts and parsley. Just before serving, pour over the dressing and gently toss to combine. Transfer to a serving platter and scatter over the dried cranberries.
chief_review: This post-festive salad impresses with its balanced combination of refreshing and hearty elements, cleverly transforming leftover ham, grains, and seasonal garnishes into a vibrant dish. The zing of clementine zest and juice cuts through the richness of the ham, while fennel and watercress add a crisp, peppery freshness. The toasted hazelnuts provide welcome crunch, and cranberries offer a sweet-tart pop. The Dijon mustard and honey dressing is well-judged, harmonizing the varied ingredients without overpowering them. This salad is a great option for those looking to lighten up without sacrificing flavor or substance—it would be an excellent choice for people on a gluten-free diet, provided the mixed grains are gluten-free. However, with ham and honey, it’s not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, nor for those with nut allergies. Overall, it’s a delightful, nutrient-dense way to embrace holiday leftovers.

name: Fig & pancetta American stuffing
author: Emma Freud
ingredients: 150g ciabattaor sourdough bread, cut into small cubes
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4 and grease a large baking tray. Fry the pancetta in a large, dry frying pan until crisp and golden, then transfer to a large bowl with a slotted spoon. In the same pan, fry the sausages until lightly browned, then add to bowl with the pancetta. Melt all the butter in the same pan and fry the onion, celery, rosemary and garlic for about 15 mins until very soft
Meanwhile, put the cubes of bread on a baking tray and toast in the oven until pale golden. Cool, then blitz half the cubes in a food processor. Beat the eggs with the chicken stock.

Add the figs, parsley and chestnuts to the pan with the onion mixture. Stir for a few mins, then transfer to the bowl with the pancetta and sausage. Add all the bread and a really generous sprinkling of seasoning. Using your hands, toss all the ingredients gently together, then add the egg and stock mixture.

Divide the mixture into 16 balls and place on the prepared baking tray. Bake, covered with some greased foil, for 30 mins, then remove the foil and bake for another 10 mins until golden and crispy. Once you’ve taken the stuffing out of the oven, season again and serve.
chief_review: This recipe offers a rich and hearty blend of savory and sweet flavors, with pancetta, Italian sausage, and chicken stock providing a robust, umami base. The addition of dried figs and chestnuts introduces pleasant earthy and fruity notes, beautifully offset by the freshness of parsley and the aromatic touch of rosemary. The use of ciabatta or sourdough bread ensures a satisfying texture, while eggs tie the mixture together for a cohesive bake. This dish, though indulgent, is well-balanced and thoughtfully layered. It would be well-suited to a classic holiday table or as a comforting autumn centerpiece. Given the inclusion of meat, dairy, and bread, it is best enjoyed by those without specific dietary restrictions. A must-try for lovers of traditional, rustic flavors.

name: Vegan gingerbread people
description: Very yummy-my family didn't know it was vegan until I told them! Next time I would reduce the sugar content by 50g or so as they are very sweet, and I will add some more ginger too as they weren't quite spicy enough for me. Also I think the recipe may need to be clearer with regards to the coconut oil. I added it straight from the jar and it was far too solid to be rubbed into the flour so next time it will need to be at least softened, if not melted completely.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 400g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
100ml aquafaba(water from a can of chickpeas)
directions: Put the chia seeds in a small bowl and stir in 3 tbsp water. Leave to soak for 5-10 mins until gloopy. Meanwhile put the flour into a large mixing bowl and rub in the coconut oil until it’s almost disappeared into the flour. Stir in the spices.

In another bowl mix together the sugar, maple syrup, chia mixture and 2 tbsp water until smooth then pour over the flour. Stir until well combined then knead together to make a soft dough. Wrap in cling film until ready to use.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 6. Roll out the dough on a lightly floured surface then cut into gingerbread people (or whatever shape you like) and bake for 10-12 mins on baking sheets lined with baking parchment until just starting to darken at the edges. Let them cool for a couple of minutes on the tray then transfer to a wire rack to cool.

While the gingerbread cools whip the aquafaba in a bowl using electric beaters until really foamy. Add 3/4 of the icing sugar and whisk until smooth and thick, then whisk in the rest of the icing sugar and the lemon juice. Whisk again until the mixture forms stiff peaks. Transfer to a piping bag until ready to use. Snip a little off the end of the piping bag and use to create designs and faces on your gingerbread.
chief_review: This vegan gingerbread recipe is a true crowd-pleaser—rich in spice, with a delightful depth from dark muscovado sugar and the warming flavors of ginger and cinnamon. The use of chia seeds and aquafaba successfully replaces eggs, making these treats entirely plant-based and suitable for vegans. The coconut oil not only adds subtle flavor but also keeps the texture moist (just be sure to melt or soften it for easier mixing). While the sweetness level is high, a reduction in sugar would help balance the flavors and allow the spices to shine. These gingerbreads are also dairy-free and suitable for those avoiding eggs. A terrific holiday bake with a little tweak on the sugar and spice, it stands out for both taste and dietary inclusivity.

name: Hazelnut crunch mince pies
description: Jazz up your homemade mince pies by adding grated apple and orange zest - try a pretty star shaped lid, finished with a crisp nutty topping
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 250g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
75g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Put the flour, half the hazelnuts, the icing sugar and butter in a food processor and blitz to a sandy texture. Add the egg yolk and 1-2 tbsp water, and blitz briefly until the dough clumps together. Tip out onto a work surface and knead the dough a little until smooth. Flatten to a puck shape, wrap in cling film, then chill for 30 mins.

Mix the mincemeat, apple and orange zest in a bowl. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Unwrap the pastry and roll out on a lightly floured surface to the thickness of a £1 coin. Stamp out 12 circles with a 10cm fluted biscuit cutter and use them to line a 12-hole muffin tin.

Fill each pie with the mincemeat mixture. Scrunch up the pastry trimmings and re-roll to the same thickness as before. Stamp out 6 circles using an 8cm cutter, and 6 stars. Put the remaining hazelnuts in a dish and lightly whisk the egg white in another. Brush a little egg white around the inner rim of each pie, then brush one side of each pastry lid, and the stars. Press each lid into the hazelnuts, egg-side down, so they stick, then lightly press on top of the pies, nutty-side up. Repeat with the stars and place these on the remaining pies.

Bake for 20 mins or until golden and crisp. Leave to cool in the tin for 5 mins, then scoop out and cool on a wire rack. Dust with icing sugar before serving. Will keep in a sealed container for 3 days.
chief_review: This festive mince pie recipe stands out with the inclusion of grated apple and orange zest, which lend a wonderfully fresh and vibrant twist to the classic filling. The pastry is enriched with butter and a hint of sweetness from icing sugar, and finished with a unique nutty crunch courtesy of chopped hazelnuts—a clever addition that adds both texture and flavor. The use of egg to bring the dough together ensures a rich, tender crust, while the mincemeat, brightened by fruit, avoids overpowering sweetness. The playful star-shaped lid makes these pies as pleasing to the eye as they are to the palate. This recipe is especially suitable for vegetarians and is a great addition to any festive table, providing both tradition and a touch of creative flair.

name: Rudolph shortbread
description: These simple shortbread triangles are a great edible gift for kids to make over Christmas - decorate with Smarties or other sweets and wrap up with pipe cleaner 'reindeer' antlers
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 225g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
16 white sweetsor white chocolate buttons, for the eyes (we used Waitrose Cooks' Homebaking Meringue pieces)
8 cellophane bags(15 x 25cm) or 8 x 40cm cellophane squares
22-23cm round plate, cake tinor cardboard template
directions: Put the butter, vanilla and sugar in a big mixing bowl and stir together with a wooden spoon until really smooth. Stir in the ground rice first, then the flour. If it starts to get dry, you might need to use your hands to squish everything together to make a smooth dough.

Put a piece of baking parchment on a baking sheet. Make the dough into a round ball in the middle of the parchment, then use your hands to push it down and flatten it. Get a rolling pin and dust it with some flour so it doesn’t stick to the dough. Use the rolling pin to roll the dough out to a big circle.

Get your 22-23cm round plate, cake tin or cardboard template and place on top of the dough when you’ve rolled it big enough. Use a cutlery knife to trim round the edges to make a neat circle and throw away the trimmings.

Use a knife to mark the giant biscuit into 8 smaller wedge-shaped biscuits – pretend you are cutting a pizza into slices but don't actually cut it. Prick lines from the edge to the centre of the dough. Use the back of a fork to press all around the top of the circle along the edge to make a line pattern (it’s going to be hair for your reindeer!)

Cover with cling film and put the tray in the fridge for 30 mins to get cold. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Cook the chilled shortbread for 25 mins until golden. Cool completely on the tray, then use a sharp knife to follow the lines you made with a fork and cut into 8 wedges.

Mix the icing sugar with 1-2 tsp of water to make a thickish icing. Dunk each Smartie in and use like glue to stick one on the pointy end of each biscuit to make red noses. Dunk in your white sweets or chocolate buttons and stick them 2cm in from the edge at the other end to be eyes. Use the black writing icing tube to add dots to the white eyes, then let all the icing dry and go hard.

Carefully wrap each biscuit in a square of cellophane or put in a cellophane bag. Twist the middle of a pipe cleaner in a loop around the top of the bag or gathered cellophane to enclose the biscuit. Now twist each end of the pipe cleaner so it looks like the reindeer’s antlers. Add labels and give to your friends and family, or hang on the tree. Will keep for up to 3 days in a cool, dry place.
chief_review: This festive shortbread recipe produces delightfully buttery, crumbly treats that are not only fun for kids to decorate, but also reliably delicious. The use of ground rice lends an extra tender texture, while vanilla adds aromatic warmth. Decorating with Smarties and sweets elevates the visual appeal, making them perfect as handmade holiday gifts. With no eggs or nuts in the ingredient list, these shortbread triangles may suit some people with common allergies. However, as the recipe uses wheat flour and dairy butter, it is not gluten-free or vegan. For vegetarians, the ingredients are suitable, provided the sweets chosen do not contain animal-derived gelatin or carmine. Overall, this is a playful and accessible recipe ideal for family baking sessions around Christmas.

name: Festive red cabbage
description: Serve this spiced and sticky side dish alongside all the classic Christmas trimmings - it's richly flavoured with red wine, cinnamon, star anise and apples
author: Good Food
directions: Heat the oil in a large flameproof casserole dish, add the onions and cook on a medium heat for 8-10 mins, then add the star anise and cinnamon stick.
Pour in the wine and let it simmer until slightly reduced. Add the cabbage, sugar and apples, and stir well. Season well, cover and simmer on a low heat for 3 hrs, stirring every now and again.

Once the cabbage is tender, check the seasoning. Serve in a bowl with the star anise and cinnamon stick on top. Can be made 1-2 days in advance or frozen for up to 4 months – simply reheat on the hob before serving.
chief_review: This spiced and sticky side dish is a festive delight, bringing together the warmth of cinnamon and star anise with the sweet tang of Bramley apples and deep richness of red wine. The red cabbage melds beautifully with caramelized onions, creating a balance of sweet, tart, and savory notes. The use of vegetable oil and absence of animal products make it an excellent choice for those following a vegan or vegetarian diet. Additionally, it’s naturally gluten-free, given the selection of ingredients. This dish pairs exceptionally well with classic Christmas mains, adding both vibrant color and a complex flavor profile to your holiday table. The careful layering of spices and seasonal produce creates a memorable side that celebrates the spirit of the season.

name: Cashew caramels
description: These delicious homemade sweets, with toasted cashews and vanilla bean paste, make a great party nibble or edible gift
author: Jennifer Joyce
directions: Line a 20cm square tin with foil and rub generously with vegetable oil. Add half the cashews to the tin. In a saucepan, bring the butter, cream and vanilla to the boil, then remove from the heat.

In a large heavy-based saucepan, heat the sugar and syrup on a medium-low heat until it reaches 155C on a sugar thermometer. Do not stir or the sugar will crystallise. Turn off the heat and very carefully add to the cream mixture. Stir together and heat again until it reaches 125C on the thermometer. Remove from the heat and pour in the remaining nuts. Quickly pour into the tin, sprinkle over the salt and leave to cool.
When firm (after 3-4 hrs), cut into pieces –use a knife that has been dipped into boiling water. Wrap in baking parchment until ready to eat. Will keep for 2 weeks in an airtight tin.
chief_review: This indulgent recipe masterfully combines toasted cashews, golden caster sugar, and a touch of sea salt for a luxurious homemade sweet. The inclusion of vanilla bean paste adds a sophisticated aromatic note, while the double cream and butter give these treats a delectably rich, creamy texture. Perfect as an elegant party snack or a thoughtful edible gift, these sweets are sure to impress with their balance of nutty depth and caramel sweetness, finished by just a whisper of salt. This recipe is naturally suitable for a vegetarian diet and is also gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for guests with those dietary preferences. The flavors are classic yet elevated, and the texture offers both crunch and melt-in-the-mouth creaminess—a delightful treat for any festive table or special occasion.

name: Turkey ramen
description: Made with leftover goose gravy and meat and also added some celery. My fiance emptied his bowl and that rarely happens when it has veg!
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: thumb-sized piece ginger, sliced, plus a few slices cut into fine matchsticks to serve
1 tbsp goma(white sesame paste) or tahini
700g leftover turkey gravy, or good-quality chicken stock
150g ramen noodles(egg, rice or udon noodles will all work too)
2 spring onions, finely sliced, white and green parts kept separate
sesame oil, sriracha, chopped coriander, crushed peanuts, crumbled sheets of nori or dried chilli threads (silgochu), to serve (optional)
directions: Crush the garlic with the back of a big knife, then put it in a saucepan with the ginger, miso, goma, mushrooms, gravy and soy. Bring to a gentle simmer, cover and bubble for 5 mins until the ginger is soft. Strain into a clean pan and discard the aromatics and mushrooms.

Meanwhile, cook the eggs in a pan of boiling water for 7 mins. Plunge straight into a bowl of cold water and set aside to cool. Cook the noodles for 1 min less than instructed on the pack, so they retain a little bite. Drain and leave in the pan with a little cooking water so they don’t stick together. Add the turkey and whites of the spring onions to the broth and gently reheat for 1-2 mins.

Divide the noodles between two deep bowls, ladle over the broth and top with a squeeze of lime, the beansprouts, ginger matchsticks, green spring onion and a drizzle of sesame oil, plus the other toppings, if you like. Peel and halve the eggs and place these on top too.
chief_review: This recipe ingeniously transforms leftover turkey and gravy into a vibrant, umami-rich bowl reminiscent of a Japanese-inspired ramen. The use of white miso and goma or tahini provides a lovely depth, complemented by shiitake for earthiness. Fresh aromatics like ginger, garlic, and spring onions lend brightness, while soy sauce adds seasoning and body. The bowl is packed with texture from beansprouts, crushed peanuts, and nori, making every spoonful interesting. Sriracha and lime deliver a punch of heat and acidity, lifting the savory broth. For those following a nut-free or soy-free diet, minor tweaks would be required. As written, the dish is suitable for dairy-free diets, and, using rice noodles, can be made gluten-free. With its balanced flavors, variety of garnishes, and clever use of leftovers, this is a rewarding, heartwarming meal that's both resourceful and restaurant-worthy.

name: Sunday morning baked eggs
description: These creamy, indulgent eggs are baked in individual ramekins with cream, cheese and tarragon - perfect for a lazy weekend brunch
author: Marcus Wareing
ingredients: Brummie bacon cakes (see 'Goes well with') or toast, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3 and bring a kettleful of water to the boil. Pour 1 tbsp oil into 4 shallow ramekins and crack 2 eggs into each. Season with sea salt and coarse black pepper, sprinkle with the tarragon and cheese, then spoon over the cream.

Set the ramekins in a roasting tin, then quarter-fill the tin with water from the kettle. Carefully transfer to the oven and bake for 6-8 mins or until the egg whites are softly set and the yolks are runny. Serve immediately with the watercress on the side and Brummie bacon cakes (see 'Goes well with', right), toast, or gluten-free alternative.
chief_review: This recipe for creamy baked eggs in individual ramekins is a true weekend indulgence, balancing the rich decadence of double cream and Gruyère cheese with the aromatic freshness of tarragon. The eggs are perfectly set but lusciously soft, their richness gently offset by a peppery bed of fresh watercress. The olive oil lends a subtle depth, and the option of a vegetarian cheese alternative makes this dish well-suited for lacto-vegetarian diets when combined with the right toast or bread. Serve with crisp Brummie bacon cakes or sourdough soldiers for a textural contrast. The straightforward preparation makes this recipe accessible, while the result feels restaurant-worthy—ideal for elevating a leisurely brunch at home.

name: Mini elf doughnuts
description: Don't let Santa's elves get left out this Christmas! Kids will love to help bake and decorate these tiny treats and leave them by their stockings - and you can add some carrots for Rudolph too
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 2 tbsp melted butter, plus an extra 1 tbsp for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Brush some melted butter in the holes of a 24-hole mini muffin tin.
Put the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg and sugar in a big bowl and mix together with your hands.
Pour the melted butter into a jug with the egg, vanilla, maple syrup and buttermilk, and mix together with a fork.
Pour the wet ingredients over the dry ones and use a big wooden spoon to mix until there are no lumps.
Use teaspoons to divide the mixture between the holes in the tin. Bake in the oven for 8-10 mins, then cool in the tin.
Now it's time to turn them into doughnuts. Once cool, carefully tip the cakes out. Sit each on a chopping board and push an apple corer into the centre to cut the middle out so you have a ring.

Put the icing sugar and milk in a saucepan over a low heat. Whisk until runny and smooth. Divide the icing between three bowls, and mix a little green food colouring into one bowl, and a little red colouring into another.

Sit the doughnuts on a wire rack (so the drips can fall off), then spoon a little icing onto each. Decorate with sprinkles and writing icing, if you like. As this glaze dries quickly, finish decorating one colour, then start the next colour. If the icing is not runny enough, put in the microwave for 10 secs and stir well. Will keep for 2 days.
chief_review: This playful and festive recipe is perfect for getting little hands involved in the kitchen during the holidays. The combination of cinnamon, nutmeg, and maple syrup promises a warm, fragrant bite, while the icing and colorful decorations add a fun, artistic touch kids will love. The addition of buttermilk yields a tender crumb, and the use of both vanilla extract and golden caster sugar brings a rich sweetness. Please note, this recipe contains wheat (gluten), dairy, and eggs, so it's best suited for those without allergies to these ingredients. With its cheerful presentation and kid-friendly flavors, these tiny treats are sure to charm Santa’s elves and bring joy to any Christmas gathering!

name: Parsnip croquettes
description: This show-stealing side dish of roasted parsnips and creamy béchamel is breadcrumbed and deep-fried for crisp, golden bites
author: Marcus Wareing
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Put the parsnips in a roasting tin with the oil and roast for 1 hr 30 mins. Remove from the oven and cut into chunks.

Meanwhile, make the béchamel. Melt the butter in a saucepan over a low heat, then add the flour and whisk. Remove from the heat and add the milk gradually, whisking after each addition until combined. Return to a low heat and cook, stirring, until thick. Stir in the remaining ingredients, except the Gruyère, add 1/2 tsp salt and take off the heat. Add the Gruyère and mix well.

Once the parsnips are cool enough to handle, purée in a food processor and set aside. Heat the butter in a pan. Add the shallots and cook for 10 mins or until soft and golden. Tip into a large bowl with the parsnip purée, béchamel and horseradish. Season to taste, cover and cool. When almost cold, spoon into a piping bag and pipe into 3cm-thick lengths onto a baking parchment-lined tray. Freeze for 1 hr until firm but not completely frozen. Remove from the freezer and cut into 5cm lengths. Coat the croquettes in the flour, dip in the egg, roll in the panko breadcrumbs, then place on a parchment-lined tray. Chill until needed. Can be made up to this stage up to 24 hrs in advance.

To fry your croquettes, use a deep-fat fryer or half-fill a heavy-based medium saucepan with vegetable oil and heat to 180C. Cook in small batches for 2-3 mins until golden and cooked through. Lift the croquettes from the oil with a slotted spoon and drain on kitchen paper. Put on a warmed plate and cover with foil until ready to serve.
chief_review: This indulgent side dish transforms humble parsnips into a truly decadent treat. Roasted until sweet and tender, the parsnips are enveloped in a rich, cheesy béchamel, then breaded and deep-fried to golden perfection—resulting in a luxurious combination of creamy interior and crunchy exterior. The blend of cheddar and gruyère lends depth, while the creamed horseradish and Dijon mustard provide subtle warmth and complexity. The addition of panko breadcrumbs ensures a shatteringly crisp crust. This recipe contains eggs, dairy, and wheat and is best suited for vegetarians, provided the cheese and Worcestershire sauce are free from animal rennet and anchovies, respectively. A crowd-pleasing side that’s sure to impress at festive gatherings or special dinners.

name: Panettone
description: Prove your baking skills this Christmas with a fluffy, lighter-than-air classic Italian sweetbread, packed with festive flavours and candied fruit
author: Good Food
ingredients: 500g strong white bread flour, plus extra for dusting
100g good-quality candied lemon and orange peel, finely chopped
directions: Grease a panettone tin (see Tip) or a 20cm deep cake tin, or use a panettone case.
Place the warm milk in a bowl and add the yeast and 1 tsp of sugar and leave for a few minutes.
Put the remaining sugar in a large bowl and beat together with the butter and vanilla extract until really light, creamy and pale.
Stir in the lemon and orange zest. Add the eggs a little at a time until all are well incorporated. Spoon in a tablespoon of the flour if the mixture starts to curdle and beat this in with the eggs.

Place the flour in a large bowl and mix with a good pinch of salt and make a well in the centre. Add the yeast mixture then the butter and egg mixture, folding in with a large spoon to make a soft dough. Knead for 5 mins in the bowl until it all starts to come together. It will be a pretty sticky dough at this stage.

Turn out the dough onto a floured surface and knead for a further 10 mins, until everything has come together and you have a very soft and stretchy dough. Add a light sprinkling of flour to the surface and your hands as you go to stop the mixture sticking, but try not to add too much. Place in a lightly greased bowl and cover with cling film. Leave in a warm place for 2 hrs until doubled in size.
Place the raisins and sultanas in a small saucepan with the rum and heat gently for 5 – 7 mins until the fruit has absorbed the liquid and is plump and juicy. Set aside to cool.

When the dough is risen, tip it out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for another 5 mins. Gradually knead in the soaked raisins, sultanas and chopped candied peel. Shape the dough into a ball and pop into the prepared tin. If using a 20cm cake tin, wrap a layer of baking parchment around the outside of the tin, to come up about 5cm above the rim, and secure the paper with string. This will help contain the dough as it rises. Cover lightly with cling film and leave to rise for another hour until it has risen to the top of the tin or paper.

Preheat the oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Adjust the oven shelf to the right height. Mix together the almonds, caster sugar and egg white for the topping and gently brush over the top of the panettone. Place in the oven and bake for 40 - 50 mins until golden and risen and a skewer comes out clean when inserted into the middle of the cake. Leave to cool in the tin for 10 mins before turning out onto a wire rack. Leave to cool completely before dusting lightly with icing sugar and cutting into wedges to serve.
chief_review:
This classic Italian sweetbread is a true showstopper for the festive season, offering a pillowy crumb punctuated by citrus zest, rum-soaked raisins, and aromatic candied fruits. The blend of strong white bread flour and generous butter creates an airy yet rich texture, elevated by the gentle sweetness of vanilla and two types of sugar. The addition of whole blanched almonds brings a satisfying crunch to each slice, while the glossy, delicate icing finishes it with characteristic elegance.

Given its foundation of eggs, butter, and milk, this panettone is ideal for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish. However, those with gluten or nut sensitivities, as well as vegans or individuals with egg or dairy allergies, should take note of the ingredients. Flavors are beautifully balanced, making this a festive centerpiece worth the effort for any home baker seeking an authentic, crowd-pleasing bake.

name: Panforte
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 300g nuts, toasted and chopped (we used pistachios and hazelnuts)
250g dried fruit, chopped (we used dates and apricots)
2 tsp spices(we used 1 tsp cinnamon, ¾ tsp ginger and ¼ tsp cardamom)
3 tbsp fortified wineor liqueur (we used Marsala)
directions: Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Grease and line the base of a 20cm springform cake tin with edible rice paper or baking parchment. Tip the nuts, candied peel and dried fruit into a bowl. Sift over the flour and spices, and mix together.

Heat the honey, sugar and wine in a medium saucepan over a medium heat. Bubble for 3-4 mins until the sugar has melted. Pour the hot liquid over the fruit and nuts, then mix. Scrape the mixture into the tin and use the back of a wet metal spoon to flatten it. Bake for 35-40 mins until the surface is still soft but not sticky – it will firm up as it cools.

Leave to cool in the tin for 10 mins, then remove using a palette knife to release any sticky edges. If using baking parchment, peel it off and discard it; the edible rice paper can be left on. Cool completely on a wire rack, then dust generously with icing sugar, rubbing the sugar gently into the surface. Cut into wedges to serve. Will keep wrapped in baking parchment in an airtight tin for one month.
chief_review:
This recipe yields a delightful, nut-studded treat with complex notes from toasted pistachios and hazelnuts, balanced by sweet candied peel and dried fruits like dates and apricots. The warming spice mix of cinnamon, ginger, and cardamom provides an aromatic undercurrent, beautifully complemented by the rich, slightly fruity depth of Marsala wine. The honey and golden caster sugar create a luscious, cohesive base, allowing the filling to set and meld flavors without overpowering sweetness. Rice paper and a light icing sugar dusting add visual and textural appeal.

Due to its composition, this recipe will appeal to vegetarians and can be made gluten free with a suitable flour substitute, as well as being naturally dairy free. However, it contains tree nuts and is not suitable for those with nut allergies. This is a festive, sophisticated confection, equally enjoyable with coffee or dessert wine.

name: Lobster & celeriac remoulade
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 small, whole cooked lobster(about 400g, defrosted if frozen)
½ small pack dill, chopped, reserving a few fronds to finish
toasted sourdoughor your favourite bread, to serve (optional)
directions: To prepare the lobster, remove the roe if there is any (if you want to include it in the remoulade, set it aside). Twist off and peel the tail, halve lengthways, slice thickly and set aside. Crack the claws and try to remove the meat whole, setting it aside with the tail. Winkle out the rest of the meat from the knuckles and the legs, and keep separate.

Pour the lemon juice into a bowl. Finely cut the celeriac into matchsticks, or coarsely grate or spiralize it. Tip it straight into the lemon juice and toss to prevent it browning. Add the mayo, mustard and Tabasco, season and mix well. Now stir in the broken bits of lobster meat, most of the roe (if using) and the chopped dill.

Neatly spoon the celeriac in the middle of two small plates. Arrange the lobster claw on one side and the tail meat on top and scatter with the dill fronds and the rest of the roe. Serve with toast, if you like.
chief_review: This lobster and celeriac salad is a refined dish that balances the sweetness of tender lobster meat with earthy, crisp celeriac. The lemon juice adds brightness, while the Dijon mustard and Tabasco give the mayonnaise dressing a subtle kick. Fresh dill brings aromatic notes that lift the whole plate. Served atop toasted sourdough or your preferred bread, it makes a luxurious starter or light meal. This recipe suits pescatarian diets and, with gluten-free bread, can be adapted for those avoiding gluten. For anyone with a shellfish allergy, take note that lobster is a primary ingredient. It's an elegant take on classic seafood salads, with a modern, vibrant finish from the herbs and citrus.

name: Vanilla fudge
description: This is the best fudge recipe. I now, after making a lot of times, I add a bit more salt and once set I dip in dark and milk chocolate to make it even more special.
author: Cassie Best
directions: Line a 20 x 20cm cake tin with baking parchment. Tip the sugar, cream, butter and glucose syrup into a medium to large saucepan. Heat to dissolve the sugar and melt the butter, stirring now and again.

Once dissolved, put a sugar thermometer in the pan, making sure the end is completely covered by the syrup – if not, transfer the mixture to a smaller pan (with enough space for the syrup to bubble up). Increase the heat and bring the syrup to a steady boil. Keep bubbling, stirring occasionally to stop the sugar from catching, until the mixture reaches 116C – this is known as the soft ball stage.
Remove the pan from the heat and leave to sit, undisturbed, for 5 mins, until the temperature drops to 110C. Stir in the vanilla and a good pinch of salt.

Keep the sugar thermometer in the pan and begin beating the mixture with a wooden spoon, quite vigorously, until the temperature cools to about 60C. By this time the fudge will be really thick and will have lost it glossy shine. Remove the thermometer and continue beating for a few mins more. This process is very important when making fudge, as it creates small sugar crystals, which give the fudge its lovely smooth and creamy texture (see 'fudge know-how', below).

Before it sets completely, quickly pour the fudge into your prepared tin and smooth over the surface. Leave to cool at room temperature overnight – don’t put the fudge in the fridge as it will become sticky and won’t set properly. Cut into bite-sized pieces and pop in a box to give as a present.
chief_review: This fudge recipe is delightfully rich and creamy, striking a perfect balance between sweetness and a subtle touch of salt. The use of double cream and butter gives a luxurious mouthfeel, while the golden caster sugar and vanilla bean paste add depth and aromatic complexity. Dipping the set fudge in dark and milk chocolate elevates both texture and flavor, creating a decadent treat with a pleasing contrast. Suitable for vegetarians, as no gelatine or animal-derived ingredients other than dairy are used. This recipe is a crowd-pleaser and an indulgent gift for any occasion.

name: Mulled pomegranate juice
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour the pomegranate juice into a large saucepan. Add the rosemary, sumac, cinnamon stick, coriander seeds, and orange. Bring to a simmer then pour through a sieve into a jug. Stir in the orange blossom water and pour into heatproof glasses or cups.
chief_review: This recipe offers a vibrant fusion of flavors, highlighting the sweet-tart notes of pomegranate juice enhanced by aromatic spices and citrus. The infusion of sumac and coriander seeds brings a subtle earthiness, while rosemary and cinnamon add depth and warmth. The orange slices and a hint of orange blossom water provide a fragrant, floral twist, tying all the elements together. This drink is naturally vegan and gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for those following plant-based or gluten-restricted diets. Its fresh, spice-laced profile would make a refreshing standalone beverage or a sophisticated non-alcoholic cocktail base. With its minimal, whole-food ingredients and free of common allergens such as dairy, nuts, and eggs, this recipe is both accessible and health-conscious, perfect for gatherings or a unique personal treat.

name: Bellini
description:
Aspertame-free Cherry Soda Serves:About 8 8-ounce servings,9
CarbsPerServing:Zero! Prep Time:5 min.
Effort:Easy
ingredients:
2-liter bottle Club Soda
1 tbsp. Cherry Extract 1/4 c. bulk Splenda -OR- 9 packets Splenda
How to Prepare:
I prefer this to commercial sugar-free soda because I avoid
aspertame.
Mix the Splenda and cherry extract together in a measuring cup until
dissolved, adding a splash of the club soda if necessary. If you add
soda, this will foam a lot until mixing is complete. Pour the
mixture slowly back into the 2-liter bottle. http://www.weightlosseasy.tips/beverages.html
author: Good Food
directions: Put the peach puree in a Champagne flute up to about 1/3 full and slowly top up with Prosecco.
chief_review: This aspartame-free cherry soda is a refreshing, carb-free alternative to commercial sugar-free sodas, perfect for those watching their carbohydrate or calorie intake. Utilizing club soda, cherry extract, and Splenda, it’s quick to prepare and free from both sugar and artificial sweeteners like aspartame. The recipe is suitable for individuals with diabetes or anyone following a low-carb, ketogenic, or sugar-free diet. As none of the ingredients are derived from animal products, this soda can also be enjoyed on a vegan diet. Additionally, its ingredients are gluten-free and unlikely to trigger common food allergies, making it a broadly accessible and inclusive beverage choice. The homemade approach also allows for customization in flavor intensity and sweetness, offering a crisp, natural cherry flavor without any chemical aftertaste. A simple, satisfying drink ideal for warm days or festive gatherings.

name: Ham, turkey & sprout pie
description: Just served this to the family with the leftovers from Christmas and the pie dish has been scraped clean. Delicious. Easy to change ingredients to suit what you've got. Tempted to over cater with future roasts to allow me to make this pie again.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 500ml turkey or chicken stock(or 100ml/3½ fl oz leftover gravy mixed with 400ml/14fl oz water)
175ml single, double, whipping or soured cream, or crème fraîche – or a mixture
100g mature cheddaror Stilton, grated, plus 25g/1oz extra to sprinkle on top
400g turkeyor chicken, cut into bite-sized chunks
200g ham, diced slightly smaller than the turkey/chicken
splash of milk or beaten egg, to glaze
chief_review: This hearty post-Christmas pie is a true comfort dish, perfectly suited for making good use of festive leftovers. The creamy sauce—enriched with cheese and a touch of mustard—brings together turkey, ham, and Brussels sprouts within a golden, crisp shortcrust pastry shell. The balance between tangy crème fraîche or cream and savory stock creates a luxurious filling, while the extra sprinkling of cheese on top gives a pleasing crust. However, with its inclusion of both wheat-based pastry and dairy products, this pie is best suited for those following a traditional omnivore's diet. The simple adaptability of the ingredients allows for easy tweaking based on what you have on hand, making it a versatile and family-friendly classic. Serve with mashed potatoes and greens for the ultimate comforting meal.

name: Yummy chocolate log
description:
It looked better than the photo when I made it, but the taste was not as good as expected.
The recipe could have been better. It says bake for 10 minutes but it came out a bit too dry. I think 7 minutes would have been better. I saw the winner of the Bake Off Christmas Special do something similar and she baked it for 7 minutes iirc. Also you have to be careful when you whip the double cream because it only takes a few seconds of whipping for it to get too stiff. A warning in the recipe would have been nice for inexperienced bakers like myself.
The cream may have benefitted from a little sugar added to it, but I guess that's why they say to add mint to it because something is definitely missing from the cream if you don't add either sugar or mint.
Next time I will try Delia's recipe as I hear that one is better.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: icing sugarand holly sprigs to decorate - ensure you remove the berries before serving
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6.
Grease and line a 23 x 32cm Swiss roll tin with baking parchment.
Beat 3 eggs and 85g golden caster sugar together with an electric whisk for about 8 mins until thick and creamy.
Mix 85g plain flour (less 2 tbsp), 2 tbsp cocoa powder and ½ tsp baking powder together, then sift onto the egg mixture. Fold in very carefully, then pour into the tin.
Now tip the tin from side to side to spread the mixture into the corners. Bake for 10 mins.

Lay a sheet of baking parchment on the work surface. When the cake is ready, tip it onto the parchment, peel off the lining paper, then roll the cake up from its longest edge with the paper inside. Leave to cool.

To make the icing, melt 50g butter and 140g dark chocolate together in a bowl over a pan of hot water. Take from the heat and stir in 1 tbsp golden syrup and 5 tbsp double cream from a 284ml pot. Beat in 200g sifted icing sugar until smooth.
Whisk the remaining double cream from the 284ml pot until it holds its shape.
Unravel the cake, spread the cream over the top, scatter over 2-3 crushed extra strong mints, if using, then carefully roll up again into a log.
Cut a thick diagonal slice from one end of the log. Lift the log on to a plate, then arrange the slice on the side with the diagonal cut against the cake to make a branch.

Spread the icing over the log and branch (don’t cover the ends), then use a fork to mark the icing to give the effect of tree bark. Scatter with unsifted icing sugar to resemble snow, and decorate with holly.
chief_review: This is a classic chocolate dessert with a festive touch, featuring a light sponge, a rich chocolate filling, and a whipped cream topping. The technique requires careful attention—especially when whipping the double cream, as it quickly can become overbeaten and overly stiff. The bake time suggested in the recipe may be excessive; reducing to around 7 minutes may yield a moister result closer to a professional standard. The filling benefits from the balance of dark chocolate and butter, but the cream would be improved with either a touch of sugar or the refreshing lift of mint, as the current recipe risks blandness. This dessert suits a vegetarian diet but contains dairy, eggs, gluten, and may not be safe for those with nut or wheat allergies. With some minor tweaks, it could be an excellent centerpiece for a festive table.

name: Naan, spinach & halloumi bites
description: Such a brilliantly simple and clever idea. Fast, easy and very tasty. Everyone I have served this too has asked for the recipe. Thanks Miriam!
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Warm the butter in a large pan with the crushed garlic cloves and garam masala. Roughly chop the washed baby spinach and add to the melted butter and spices. Cook until the spinach has wilted, then season to taste.
Cut the halloumi into cubes and grill the tops until golden. Heat the naan breads under the grill – just to warm through – then spread with the spinach mixture.
Evenly distribute the grilled halloumi over the bread, then cut the bread to fit the cheese, and secure with cocktail sticks. Serve warm.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful fusion of flavors, combining the rich nuttiness of halloumi with the aromatic warmth of garam masala and garlic-infused spinach. The preparation is straightforward, making it a reliable choice for a quick yet impressive meal. Butter brings a silky finish, while naan offers the perfect accompaniment to soak up the savory juices. Notably, the use of halloumi and dairy-based butter makes this dish suitable for lacto-vegetarians, and the absence of meat or fish will appeal to those seeking a satisfying vegetarian main. The combination of fresh spinach and flavorful spices ensures each bite is both nutritious and memorable. In summary, this recipe is an excellent addition to any vegetarian repertoire, delivering vibrant taste and comfort with minimal effort.

name: Reverse espresso martini
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Freeze the espresso in an ice cube tray until frozen solid. Pour the vodka and baileys into a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Stir together for about 1 min then strain into a tumbler. Put 4-5 coffee ice cubes into the drink to serve.
chief_review: This cocktail blends the robust intensity of freshly brewed espresso with the smoothness of vodka and the creamy sweetness of Baileys, resulting in a rich, indulgent drink perfect for after-dinner enjoyment. The smooth mouthfeel from the Baileys pairs beautifully with the espresso’s bitterness, creating a sophisticated yet approachable flavor profile. Note that Baileys contains both dairy and gluten, so this recipe is not suitable for those with lactose intolerance, milk allergies, or those following a vegan or gluten-free diet. Overall, it’s a refined, flavorful cocktail best served chilled in a martini glass with a few coffee beans for garnish.

name: Deep-fried olives
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Crush the breadcrumbs in a bag using a
or in a

. Tip into a shallow dish with the berries, then season and set aside. Toss the olives in the flour. Put the beaten egg in a large bowl, add the coated olives and move them around to coat. Turn them one by one in the breadcrumb mixture, then put on a plate until ready to fry.
Heat the oil in a large pan to 180C, then fry the olives for 1-2 mins, or until golden and sizzling. Drain on kitchen paper and leave to cool for a few mins as they'll be very hot inside.
To make the lemon and vermouth mayo, mix the vermouth with the mayonnaise and lemon juice. Serve the warm, deep-fried olives alongside the mayo.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a delightful twist on classic snacks: feta-stuffed olives encased in crispy panko breadcrumbs and served with a zesty vermouth-lemon mayonnaise. The use of panko ensures a satisfying crunch, while the juniper berries add an enticing aromatic depth. The olives provide a briny, creamy center that contrasts beautifully with the golden coating. The sauce, elevated by the subtle herbal notes of vermouth and a splash of lemon juice, is a perfect dipping companion. With no meat involved, this dish is suitable for a vegetarian diet, and it can be a standout at any party or as a gourmet appetizer. This clever combination of flavors and textures demonstrates thoughtful balance and makes for an impressive, crowd-pleasing treat.

name: Apple pie cookie kit
description: A lovely gift - I followed the receipe to the letter and ended up with delicious cookies. Mine were quite fat, not a traditional flat crisp cookie but still lovely with a slight muffin type texture.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 50g malted milk biscuits, broken into small chunks
1 big jam jaror small Kilner jar (about 750ml capacity)
1 sticky labelfor the jar (or tag to tie to the top) and a pen
directions: Wash the jar, then dry very well.

Mix the flour with the spices and bicarb, then tip into the jar. Use your fingers to remove any lumps from the sugar, then pour into the jar. Add each of the remaining ingredients, one by one, following the list, until you’ve added the biscuit bits.
When all the ingredients are in the jar, put the lid on tightly. Sit the apple on top of the lid and tie to the jar with ribbon. The mixture and apple will keep for 4 days.

Download our printable label (see tip), or write out the following instructions on a sticky label (or tag) and attach to the jar: Tip everything in the jar into a big mixing bowl and grate in the peeled apple. Melt 50g/2oz butter with 2 tbsp golden syrup and stir into the bowl with 1 egg. Space 10 spoonfuls on greased trays and bake for 15-18 mins at 180C/160C fan/gas 4 until golden and chewy. The cookies will firm up as they cool.
chief_review: This cookie recipe yields a delightful treat with a soft, almost muffin-like texture—perfect for those who prefer a thick, chewy bite over a crisp snap. The combination of warm spices, raisins or sultanas, and apple gives each bite a comforting, autumnal feel, while the oats add heartiness and the malted milk biscuit chunks contribute a hint of nostalgic sweetness. Presented as a gift in a well-decorated jar, these cookies make a thoughtful homemade present. The inclusion of rolled oats and fruits suits those seeking a wholesome snack, but the recipe is also vegetarian-friendly, ideal for those who exclude meat and fish from their diet. Overall, it’s a creative, tasty bake that delivers on both flavor and charm, especially for homemade gifting occasions.

name: Roast guinea fowl with chestnut, sage & lemon stuffing
description: This festive game bird makes an ideal Christmas dinner for two. The portions are generous so you'll have leftovers to enjoy
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: cranberry sauce, roast potatoes and vegetables, to serve
1 medium egg, beaten with a fork
directions: First make the stuffing. Soften the onion in the butter very gently, then stir in the sage and cook for 2 mins more. Scrape into a bowl with the chopped walnuts, breadcrumbs, lemon zest, mace, chestnuts and egg and mix together well. Season generously.

For the guinea fowl, wash and wipe out the inside cavity. Mix the butter with some seasoning, then push and spread some under the skin over the breasts, and rub the rest over the legs. Lay the bacon across the breasts, smoothing over, and season with some more pepper. Push the stuffing into the cavity (any extra can be rolled into balls and baked in the oven for the last 20 mins cooking time). You can cover and chill the guinea fowl now for up to 24 hours.

To roast, bring the bird out of the fridge 30 mins before. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Sit the bird in a snug roasting tin with the sliced onion underneath. Roast for 15 mins, then lower the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and roast for a further 35-45 mins for a 1kg bird (or longer if bigger – use the timings for a roast chicken). Check the bird is done by piercing the inside of the thigh with a knife and making sure the juices are clear, not bloody. Lift the guinea fowl off the onions, onto a platter. Loosely cover with foil, top with a towel (to keep it warm), and rest while you make the gravy.

Pour off the juices from the roasting tray into a jug or bowl, and allow to settle. Spoon a tbsp of the fat on top back into the roasting tray, pop on the hob over a low heat (make sure your roasting tray is suitable or transfer contents to a pan), and stir in the flour until it isn’t dusty anymore. Gradually stir in the stock, plus any meat juices after you’ve discarded the rest of the fat, and bubble gently until thickened. Season with salt, pepper, and pinches of sugar if it needs it, then strain into a gravy jug and discard the onions. Serve with the guinea fowl, spooning out the stuffing as you carve, plus cranberry sauce and plenty of vegetables.
chief_review: This festive guinea fowl recipe presents a beautifully balanced main for an intimate Christmas dinner. The tenderness of the game bird is enhanced by a wrapping of streaky bacon, ensuring juiciness and depth of flavor. The stuffing—a combination of walnuts, chestnuts, lemon zest, and sage—offers wonderful earthiness with appealing texture. This dish is particularly suitable for those following a nut-friendly diet, though it does include nuts and gluten, so it may not suit individuals with nut or gluten allergies. The integration of butter and egg enriches the stuffing, complementing the bird's savory-sweet notes when paired with cranberry sauce. Served with roast potatoes and your favorite vegetables, this recipe delivers both comfort and elegance for a festive meal, with leftovers promising delicious follow-up dishes. The generous quantities also make it ideal for festive occasions when a traditional whole bird would be too much.

name: Roasted gnocchi, sundried tomato & olive stacks
description: Ready made gnocchi make a perfect base for a bite-sized canapé that's easy to make and perfect for a party platter or casual nibble with drinks
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Tip the fresh gnocchi in a roasting tin and drizzle with olive oil. Roast for 25-30 mins or until golden, stirring occasionally. Thread the roasted gnocchi onto cocktail sticks with pitted green olives, sundried tomatoes and basil leaves. Serve while the gnocchi is still warm.
chief_review: This fun and flavorful canapé recipe is perfect for entertaining, making use of ready-made gnocchi as a unique and satisfying base. The crispy, pan-fried gnocchi pair beautifully with the briny green olives, sweet-tart sundried tomatoes, and aromatic basil, resulting in a vibrant medley of Mediterranean flavors. Ideal for serving as cocktail bites or at casual gatherings, the assembly is as effortless as it is impressive. With its reliance on olive oil and an entirely plant-based ingredient list, this recipe is well-suited for vegetarian diets. Additionally, if the store-bought gnocchi is marked gluten-free (as some varieties are made with potato and rice flour), this dish can easily accommodate gluten-free needs. A delightful, crowd-pleasing appetizer that's simple, stylish, and packed with flavor.

name: Spiced arancello
description: I'm making this for the first time today, having made lemoncello and creme de cassis before. The recipe states that it makes 2.5 litres of arancello. Speaking as a chemist, from 1L of vodka and 500ml of sugar syrup this is IMPOSSIBLE!
author: Good Food
ingredients: a few extra oranges, cinnamon sticks, cardamom and vanilla pods, to bottle
directions: Pare the zest from the oranges using a peeler, making sure that none of the bitter white pith is left on the peel. Put the zest, spices and vanilla pod in one large or several smaller clean jars, then tip in the vodka. Seal and leave for a week, shaking the jar each day.

After one week, you’re ready for the next stage. Boil a kettle of water. Put the sugar in a heatproof bowl, then pour over 500ml boiling water, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Add to the vodka mix, then leave for another week, shaking the jar regularly. Strain into decorative bottles, discarding the peel and spices, and store in a cool place until Christmas. Before giving, drop some fresh spices and peel into each bottle to decorate. Will keep bottled for 6 months.
chief_review: This arancello recipe offers a delightful twist on traditional citrus liqueurs, blending the warmth of cinnamon, the floral notes of cardamom, and aromatic vanilla with the bright zest of oranges. The infusion of whole spices with fresh citrus promises depth and complexity beyond classic lemon or cassis versions. As a homemade infused spirit, this recipe is suitable for those following a vegetarian or vegan diet, given the absence of animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, it is naturally gluten-free, provided the vodka is distilled from gluten-free sources (such as corn or potatoes). The technique requires patience for flavor development but rewards with a sophisticated, aromatic liqueur. This arancello would make for an impressive homemade gift or a vibrant digestif to finish a meal. The recipe's measurements are accurate for a yield just under the sum of its parts—something to note for bottling plans.

name: Mince pie martini
description: Plus, Martini Rosso will work better than Dubonnet if you have any in the cupboard.
author: Good Food
directions: To make a mincemeat syrup, put 100ml water, the golden caster sugar and mincemeat in a pan and bring to the boil. Cool and strain though muslin into a sieve. Separately, mix the caster sugar and mixed spice, then dampen the rims of 4 martini glasses and dip in the sugar and spice mixture.

Muddle the mincemeat in a cocktail shaker (you may need to make in 2 batches), then add the gin, sweet red vermouth, dark rum, 80ml mincemeat syrup and ice. Shake well and strain into your prepared glass.
chief_review:
This unique recipe fuses the festive depth of mincemeat with the botanical brightness of gin, enhanced by the rich undertones of sweet red vermouth and dark rum. The mixed spice, combined with golden and caster sugars, creates a warming complexity that recalls holiday desserts in liquid form. Using Martini Rosso as the vermouth base beautifully complements the spiced, fruity notes of the mincemeat. The substantial use of both mincemeat and alcohol suggests a clever twist on classic winter cocktails—perfect as an after-dinner indulgence. 

Note that mincemeat can sometimes contain suet or other animal-derived ingredients, so if you are catering for vegetarians or vegans, ensure you use a suitable version. Additionally, this recipe is inherently gluten-free, as all ingredients are naturally free from gluten-containing grains. This cocktail is an inventive, festive crowd-pleaser, ideal for winter celebrations.

name: Hot chocolate set
description: Present this chocolate and cinnamon stirrer in a festive mug and give as an edible Christmas gift to be enjoyed during a cosy night in
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 4 empty 47g fromage frais pots, washed and dried
cellophane and twine or string, for wrapping
directions: Very lightly grease the fromage frais pots with oil and set aside until needed.

Melt the milk chocolate in a bowl set over a pan of just-simmering water, stirring occasionally, then divide between the prepared pots. Place in the fridge or a cold place for around 30 mins or until set.

Once the milk chocolate layer is firm, melt the dark chocolate in a bowl as before, then pour it over the milk chocolate. Leave the pots to set for 15 mins, then sprinkle a pinch of flaky sea salt onto each.

Cut a hole in the bottom of each paper cake case and push a cinnamon stick through. Push the end of the stick into the middle of each pot so that the paper case is upside down – it will help to hold the cinnamon stick in place while it sets.

Leave to set overnight, then turn out and discard the pot and paper case. Wrap each in cellophane tied with twine. Tie each stick to a mug, or simply place inside the mug, and write a tag to read ‘Just add hot milk’.
chief_review: This charming chocolate and cinnamon stirrer recipe is a delightful way to give a homemade Christmas treat that will warm hands and hearts alike. The base of quality milk and dark chocolate, accented with flaky sea salt, promises a rich and balanced flavor, while the cinnamon sticks impart a festive, gently spicy aroma. Presented in individual fromage frais pots and cleverly wrapped, these stirrers are both visually appealing and practical for gift-giving. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, making it an inclusive option for many on your gift list. The preparation is straightforward, and the result is a luxurious, aromatic experience—perfect for cozy evenings. A thoughtful, edible present that showcases both care and creativity.

name: Celeriac & potato gratin
description: In this indulgent side dish, vegetables are layered up with a creamy sauce, caramelised onions, and flavours of nutmeg, garlic and thyme
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 large onions, halved and thinly sliced
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and grease a shallow ovenproof dish about 35 x 24cm. Melt the butter in a non-stick frying pan, add the onions and fry for 10 mins, stirring frequently, until soft and starting to turn golden. Sprinkle over some seasoning and the sugar, stir again, then cook 5-10 mins more until golden. Meanwhile, heat the milk with the nutmeg, garlic, thyme and seasoning. When the mixture starts to boil, pour in the cream and turn off the heat.

Quarter the celeriac and thinly slice, then arrange in the base of the dish. Pour over half the milk mixture, then spoon over the golden onions. Thinly slice the ends of the potatoes, reserving the middles. Pile the sliced potatoes into the dish, then thinly slice the reserved middle sections and arrange neatly on top. (By cutting the potatoes this way, you should have neat slices roughly all the same size for the top of the gratin.)
