Pour over the remaining milk mixture, scatter over the Parmesan and bake for 1 hr 30 mins until a knife easily cuts through the layers. Allow to rest for 10 mins before serving to allow the creamy sauce to soak into the potatoes.
chief_review:
This vegetable gratin offers a luxurious blend of tender celeriac and potatoes layered with rich double cream, aromatic garlic, thyme, and a hint of nutmeg. The slow-caramelised onions, enhanced with a touch of sugar, add a subtle sweetness that perfectly balances the dish’s savoury profile. A crisp top of grated parmesan (with a vegetarian alternative available) crowns each bite with umami depth. 

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet when using a vegetarian parmesan substitute. The absence of wheat or flour gives this dish broad appeal for those avoiding gluten. However, it does include dairy and would not suit vegan or lactose-intolerant diets. Overall, it’s a crowd-pleasing, comforting side perfect for holiday tables or special occasions.

name: Roast sweet potato & onion tart with goat’s cheese
description: Top buttery puff pastry with caramelised onions and melted cheese for a festive buffet or dinner party winner that you can make ahead and freeze
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 1kg sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into small chunks
3 x 100g soft goat's cheesewith rind, broken into large chunks
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Heat 2 tbsp of the oil in a large non-stick frying pan and cook the onions over a low heat for 20-25 mins or until well softened and lightly browned. Add the vinegar and cranberry sauce, and simmer for 5-10 mins more, stirring until almost all the liquid has disappeared. Leave to cool.

Meanwhile, put the sweet potatoes in a bowl and toss with the remaining oil, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper and the chilli flakes. Arrange on a baking tray and cook for 20 mins, turning halfway, until softened and lightly browned. Leave to cool.

Reduce oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line two large baking trays with baking parchment and unroll the pastry sheets on top – trimming the edges neatly at this point will encourage a good rise. Leaving a 2cm gap around the edge, spread the onions over the pastry, then top with the sweet potatoes and goat’s cheese. Brush the beaten egg around the border of the pastry and bake in the oven for 35-40 mins or until the pastry is golden and crisp, swapping the shelves after 20 mins.
Scatter over the thyme, then cut each tart into quarters (or smaller pieces if serving more). Serve with a large leafy salad.
chief_review: This festive tart brings together layers of flavor: sweet caramelized onions, tangy cranberry, chili-spiced sweet potatoes, and luscious rounds of goat's cheese atop golden, buttery puff pastry. The combination of sweet and savory is exceptionally well-balanced, with thyme adding an aromatic finish. Ideal for a buffet or as a striking vegetarian centerpiece, this recipe is suitable for lacto-vegetarians and works wonderfully as part of a festive spread. It’s make-ahead friendly—simply assemble, freeze, and bake off when guests arrive. Pair with a crisp salad for freshness.

name: Favourite biscuit cupcakes
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 12 mini Oreos, 12 mini Jammy Dodgers, 12 mini gingerbread
few drops vanilla extract, 1 tbsp cocoa and a pinch each of powdered ginger and cinnamon
12 cupcake cases(3 different colours if using 3 types of biscuits)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line a 12-hole muffin tin with three different coloured paper cases. Tip the flour, baking powder, unsalted butter, eggs, sugar, milk, vanilla and almonds into a large bowl and beat with an

until smooth. Put a spoonful of batter into each paper case. Crumble a biscuit into each case – use one type of biscuit for each case colour, so you remember what’s in each one. Divide the remaining batter between the cases (they should be about half full), and bake for 20-25 mins or until golden and just firm. Leave to cool on a wire rack.

Make the icing by beating the butter until soft, then beat in the icing sugar. Divide the icing into three. Add the vanilla to one batch, the cocoa and a splash of milk to another, and the ginger and cinnamon to the third. Mix them all well.

Spoon each batch of icing into a bag fitted with a star nozzle (or use one batch at a time) and pipe icing onto the cakes, matching the icing flavour with the biscuit inside. Add two of the same biscuit to the top as a decoration. Will keep for up to two days in an airtight container.
chief_review:
This cupcake recipe is a playful fusion of classic flavors, featuring a buttery, tender crumb with ground almonds adding a subtle richness. The use of mini Oreos, Jammy Dodgers, and gingerbread biscuits gives each cupcake its own unique personality, ideal for a whimsical afternoon tea or party treat. The buttercream is light, sweet, and easily customizable with hints of vanilla, cocoa, ginger, and cinnamon, elevating the overall experience. 

Designed for those who enjoy classic baking, this recipe contains wheat, eggs, milk, nuts (almonds), and gluten. It is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as all ingredients are free from animal-derived gelatin or meat products. The visual appeal—using colored cases and assorted biscuits—adds an inviting touch. A delightful choice for anyone seeking a charming, nostalgic bake with playful variety.

name: Fruitcake with apricot butter icing
description: Having made my Christmas cake already I decided to try this as a cake to eat with a cup off tea. I used Brandy and orange juice from half an orange in the buttercream. This worked really well with the overall taste of the cake. I just found the cake rather dry as there didn't seem to be much sponge compared to my Christmas cake. or is it just me ?? Easy recipe to make.
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease a deep 20cm round cake tin with a little bit of the butter, then line with greaseproof paper or baking parchment. Wrap a couple of sheets of newspaper around the outside of the tin, then secure with string.

In a food processor, whizz the almonds with the flour until the mix resembles crumbs. Beat the butter and icing sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs, one by one, then fold in the flour and almonds, dried fruit and brandy. Scrape into the tin, level the surface and bake for 1 hr 15 mins, until a skewer poked in comes out clean. Cool in the tin.

When the cake is completely cold, make the icing quickly by beating the butter, jam and icing sugar until pale. Don’t allow the butter to get too warm or overbeat as the icing might split. Swirl all over the cake, then leave in a cool place to set (but not the fridge).
chief_review: This fruit-laden cake offers a delightful mix of flavors, highlighted by the addition of brandy and fresh orange juice in the buttercream, which brings brightness and depth. The whole almonds provide a pleasant crunch, contrasting nicely with the succulent mixed dried fruit. While the recipe is straightforward and fuss-free, the sponge can be on the drier side, likely due to the high proportion of fruit to batter—consider reducing the fruit slightly or adding a splash more liquid for a moister crumb next time. The use of plain flour and no animal gelatins makes this cake a fine choice for vegetarians, but not for those with nut allergies or those requiring gluten-free baking. Overall, this cake is perfect with afternoon tea, especially for those who appreciate rich, festive flavors outside the holiday season.

name: Goat’s cheese & olive tapenade spirals
description: Fill tortilla wraps with tangy soft cheese and black olives, then roll and slice for bite-sized canapés on cocktail sticks
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Spread the black olive tapenade over the tortilla wraps, then crumble over the soft goat’s cheese and scatter with the olives. Tightly roll up the wraps – neaten them by cutting off the ends. Can be made a few hours ahead and wrapped in cling film. To serve, slice each one into 10 portions. Secure the spirals with cocktail sticks and serve.
chief_review: This recipe presents a delightful marriage of Mediterranean flavors, using tangy soft goat’s cheese and robust black olives spread generously across supple tortilla wraps. Rolled and sliced into elegant bite-sized canapés, the layers offer a creamy, salty complexity accentuated by the olive tapenade. The dish is vegetarian-friendly and can easily be adapted for gluten-free diets by using gluten-free tortilla wraps. Its simple assembly makes it ideal for entertaining, ensuring each slice is uniform and visually appealing atop a cocktail stick. The combination of rich cheese and briny olives provides a pleasing balance, making these canapés a sophisticated addition to any canapé platter.

name: Mincemeat, apple & cranberry lattice tart
description: Not using fresh puff pastry very often I found it hard to move the rolled out sheet from the work surface onto the baking parchment as it had got too thin. I think it's easier to roll it out on the parchment ( and you can roughly mark on it in pencil the size you want the pastry to be too). Made a nice change from mince pies.
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: 2 Granny Smithsapples, peeled, cored and diced
1 tbsp golden caster sugar, plus extra for sprinkling
whipped creamor brandy cream, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and put a baking sheet in to heat up. Lightly flour a work surface, roll out the puff pastry to a 30 x 45cm rectangle, then put on a sheet of baking parchment. Mix together the apples and cranberries, then add the cinnamon, mixed spice, sugar, lemon zest and mincemeat, and mix again.
Arrange the pastry in front of you with a short edge nearest to you. Spread the mincemeat mixture in a line down the centre, about 12cm wide, leaving 2cm of pastry at the top and bottom.

To create the lattice pattern, start at the top of the pastry and cut a 1.5–2cm-wide horizontal strip of pastry on both sides of the mincemeat filling (so it is still attached next to the filling). About 1.5cm in from the filling, cut out a 0.5cm strip of pastry and remove this, then cut another 1.5–2cm strip (you’re creating a pattern like the teeth of a comb). Repeat this directions until you get to the bottom of the pastry. You’ll need to cut out the final strip and remove this. Fold the top and bottom flaps of pastry up and over the filling. Fold the strips of pastry diagonally over the filling, starting from the top until you reach the bottom, creating a lattice pattern. You can now chill the tart for up to 2 days, or freeze for up to 2 months.

Brush the tart with the egg and sprinkle with the extra sugar. Using the baking parchment, transfer the tart to the hot baking tray. Bake for 20–25 mins or until golden brown on top (add an extra 10-15 mins if baking from frozen). Leave to cool for 5 mins before serving with whipped cream or brandy cream.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers a festive twist on traditional mince pies, combining tart Granny Smith apples and fresh cranberries with classic mincemeat for a vibrant flavor. The use of ready-made puff pastry offers both convenience and a satisfyingly flaky texture—rolling it directly on baking parchment is an excellent tip for effortless handling. The combination of cinnamon, mixed spice, and lemon zest adds aromatic depth, while a sprinkle of golden caster sugar creates a lovely finish. Served with whipped or brandy cream, this treat feels indulgent yet balanced.

This bake is suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, as most shop-bought mincemeat today contains vegetable suet, but it’s wise to double-check the mincemeat label to confirm. Those with egg or gluten allergies should be cautious, given the egg wash and wheat-based pastry. Overall, this is an enjoyable seasonal upgrade sure to please at any winter gathering.

name: Sugar charms
description: Add sparkle to your Christmas tree with these festive edible decorations made from melted sweets
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 7-8 fruit-flavoured boiled sweets, unwrapped and sorted by colour
400g bag clear mint sweets(I used Fox’s glacier mints)
2 metres of coloured thread or thin ribbon, for hanging
directions: Grease two large baking trays with the oil. Crush the fruit-flavoured sweets by colour and put into separate bowls. Arrange small clumps of coloured sweets onto the trays.

Put the mints in a saucepan over a medium heat. Cook gently until melted, stirring occasionally with a metal spoon. Once melted completely, remove from the heat immediately, otherwise the mixture will burn and discolour.

Working quickly, design your charm shapes (making sure they have a hole for threading the ribbon) by drizzling spoonfuls of the melted mints over the clumps of coloured sweets on the trays – they will melt into your shape and add interest to your design.

If the mixture hardens while you are working, return it to a low heat to soften, but try to make as many as you can in one go – the more you heat the mixture, the less clear the final charms will be. Leave to set for about 10 mins until hard and cool enough to handle, then remove from the tray by hand – be careful as they will be quite brittle. Tie a length of ribbon through each charm for hanging on the tree. Pack in a box between sheets of baking parchment so they don’t stick together. Eat within 3-4 days, or keep as a decoration for up to 4 weeks.
chief_review: This playful recipe transforms classic boiled and mint sweets into charming edible Christmas tree decorations. The use of sunflower oil ensures easy release from molds, and the clear mint sweets (such as Fox’s glacier mints) provide a beautiful glass-like effect when melted. These decorations work wonderfully for a fun, hands-on holiday activity with children or as a whimsical edibles-on-display treat. The recipe contains no animal products, so it is suitable for vegetarians, and it is also free from gluten and dairy, catering to those with such dietary requirements. However, check the sweet packaging for any additional allergens, particularly gelatin or trace amounts of milk if catering to strict dietary needs. Overall, this recipe adds both charm and festivity to the holiday table or tree, offering an inclusive, creative experience.

name: Winter whiskey sour
author: Chelsie Collins
directions: Using a small paintbrush (or your finger), brush some honey around the rim of two tumblers and use another small paintbrush to stick edible gold glitter around each.

Fill each glass with crushed ice. Put the bourbon into a cocktail shaker with the lemon juice, orange juice and sugar syrup. Shake and strain into each glass, and serve with an orange slice and short straws.
chief_review: This cocktail recipe is a delightful twist on a classic whiskey sour, blending bourbon with fresh citrus juices and just a hint of honey sweetness, finished with a dash of glamorous gold edible glitter. The crushed ice and fresh fruit slices uplift the drink, making it both refreshing and visually impressive—perfect for celebratory occasions or as a showstopper at your next gathering. The use of sugar syrup and honey ensures the citrus isn't overpowering, balancing the flavors beautifully. This drink is naturally gluten free, free of dairy, and suitable for vegetarians, as no animal-derived ingredients are included. The recipe’s simplicity allows the quality of the bourbon and brightness of the citrus to shine through. For best results, use freshly squeezed juices and premium bourbon. Serve immediately to enjoy the sparkle and the chill.

name: Orange & cardamom tree biscuits
description: Mary's Cadogan's crisp citrus cookies make perfect decorations - just stamp them with the celebration motif of your choice
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 100g icing sugar, plus extra to decorate
Christmas rubber stamps (see tip below) and thin ribbonor string
directions: Split the cardamom pods and tip the seeds into a mortar, then grind to a powder with the pestle. Tip the flour, rice flour and cardamom powder into a food processor. Chop the butter into small pieces and add to the food processor with the orange zest. Pulse to a fine breadcrumb texture. Add the icing sugar and mix briefly, then add the egg yolk and 1-2 tsp cold water and pulse to a firm dough. Wrap in cling film and chill for 15 mins.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line 2 baking sheets with baking parchment. Roll out half the dough at a time and stamp out 8cm rounds or squares and transfer to the baking sheets. Gather up the trimmings and roll out again to make more biscuits. Use a cocktail stick to make a hole in each biscuit for hanging from the tree. Press a festive rubber stamp into the surface of each biscuit. Chill for 30 mins.
Bake for 8-10 mins until just golden and crisp. Transfer to a wire rack and leave to cool.
Dust each biscuit liberally with icing sugar, then brush off the excess from the surface, leaving a white imprint on each biscuit. Tie up with pretty ribbon or string and hang from your tree.
chief_review: These crisp citrus cookies by Mary Cadogan offer a delightful balance of buttery richness and vibrant orange zest, accented with aromatic cardamom. The use of rice flour alongside plain flour gives them a uniquely tender, crumbly texture—ideal for festive, decorative treats. The dough handles beautifully for stamping and shaping, making it perfect for creative celebrations. As there are no nuts and only an egg yolk, these cookies can suit some with mild nut allergies, but are not vegan or gluten-free given the use of butter, egg, and traditional wheat flour. The ingredient blend yields a sophisticated yet familiar flavor profile, perfect for holiday gatherings or as edible gifts. Dusting with icing sugar completes the festive touch, and the cookies hold their shape well, retaining crispness for several days when stored properly.

name: Chicory cups with prawns & mango
description: Juicy prawns pair beautifully with sweet mango and crunchy leaves in this simple canapé, finished with lemon juice and coriander
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 2 x 150g packs cooked and peeled king prawns
a few sprigs of salad cress
directions: Separate the chicory heads into leaves, then divide the king prawns, mango pieces and a few sprigs of salad cress between them.
Assemble a few hours ahead and chill. Whisk together the olive oil, lemon juice and finely chopped coriander and drizzle a little over each filled chicory leaf.
chief_review: This canapé is a refreshing and vibrant choice, perfectly balancing the juicy sweetness of mango with succulent king prawns and the crisp bite of chicory. The recipe’s lightness is enhanced by the zingy lemon-coriander dressing, while salad cress adds a delicate peppery touch. Impressively simple yet elegant, this dish is naturally gluten-free and dairy-free, making it suitable for those with sensitivities to these ingredients. Additionally, the absence of bread or grains keeps the canapé low in carbohydrates. The use of olive oil further highlights its suitability for Mediterranean-style diets. Serve these at your next gathering for a sophisticated and allergen-friendly appetizer that doesn’t compromise on flavor.

name: Mini croque monsieurs
description: Turn a comfort food classic into a cute canapé with these mini melted cheese and ham toasties on cocktail sticks - perfect for a party or buffet
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 10 thick slices of white bread(crusts removed)
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Mix together 100g of the grated Gruyère, crème fraîche and Dijon mustard. Season with salt, black pepper and a pinch of nutmeg and spread half the mixture over 5 slices of white bread. Top with a layer of cooked sliced ham and another slice of bread.

Spread softened butter over one side of the sandwich and place on a baking sheet, butter-side down. Top the unbuttered side with the rest of the cheese mixture the remaining 50g grated Gruyère. Can be assembled the day before and chilled. To serve, bake in the oven for 20 mins or until golden, then slice the sandwiches into bite-sized pieces and serve straight away.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a delightful bite-sized twist on the classic ham and cheese toastie, making these mini treats perfect for entertaining. The combination of rich Gruyère and creamy crème fraîche yields a melty, flavorful filling, perfectly complemented by the tang of Dijon mustard and a hint of nutmeg. The buttered, crustless white bread toasts up golden and crisp, providing the ideal vehicle for the savory ham and cheese mixture. These canapés are particularly suited for those who include pork and dairy in their diet but may cater to some family-friendly dietary requirements: they’re nut-free, making them a thoughtful choice for guests with nut allergies (barring any cross-contamination). Serve freshly toasted for optimal texture and flavor – a crowd-pleaser that turns humble ingredients into party showstoppers.

name: Gingerbread trees
description: Enjoy this recipe for golden gingerbread trees - make them to eat on their own, or to decorate your Christmas cake
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Beat together the softened butter with the caster sugar until creamy. Stir in bicarbonate of soda, golden syrup and the egg yolks. Sift in the plain flour and ground cinnamon and ground ginger then bring together with a wooden spoon. Shape into two balls, knead until the dough comes together, then chill for 30 mins. Roll out one ball at a time, to about 2 x £1 coin thickness. Stamp out trees with a 7cm cutter, then re-roll the trimmings. Lift dough onto greased baking sheets and bake for 10-12 mins until slightly risen and golden brown. Cool on a wire rack. Will keep in an airtight container up to a week.
chief_review: These golden gingerbread trees offer a delightful balance of spice and sweetness, with the warmth of cinnamon and ginger perfectly rounded by golden syrup. The use of butter and egg yolks results in a beautifully tender crumb, making them as enjoyable to eat on their own as they are charming additions to festive cakes. The recipe contains no nuts, which is ideal for nut-free diets, and there are no ingredients containing gluten alternatives or dairy substitutes. The preparation is straightforward, making it an excellent option for holiday baking with children or for impressing guests with edible decorations. A festive treat that captures the essence of the season!

name: White chocolate & ricotta cheesecake
description: This mouthwatering cheesecake is the perfect way to finish a large Sunday lunch, as it's incredibly light despite being made with chocolate
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Melt the butter in a pan or microwave. Very finely crush the biscuits together, stir with the butter, then press very firmly into the base of a 20cm round loosebottomed cake tin. Bake for 6 mins. Cool, then wipe around the inside of the tin with a little oil on kitchen paper.

Soak the gelatine in water while you make the filling. Tip the chocolate into a bowl over a pan of simmering water, then add the milk. Gently heat until melted, then stir together. Squeeze the gelatine dry, add to the chocolate mixture and stir to dissolve.
Beat the ricotta, cream, sugar and egg yolks together. In a separate bowl, whisk the egg whites.

Stir the chocolate and ricotta mixtures together, then gently fold in the egg whites. Carefully pour onto the cooled biscuit base. Cover the tin with cling film, then chill until firm, preferably overnight.
To decorate, very generously top the cheesecake with the white chocolate curls, then remove from the tin, scatter with the pomegranate seeds and dust all over with icing sugar, if you like.
chief_review: This cheesecake delights with its airy texture and elegant white chocolate profile, making it a fitting finale for a Sunday feast. The blend of digestive and amaretti biscuits in the base provides a subtle nutty crunch, while the ricotta and double cream ensure a rich, yet surprisingly light filling. The pomegranate seeds add a welcome burst of freshness, balancing the sweetness of the white chocolate. However, those with nut allergies should note the presence of amaretti biscuits. This dessert is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no gelatine of animal origin, and no meat or fish by-products. The refined finish of chocolate curls and a dusting of icing sugar elevates its presentation, making it a showstopper on any dessert table.

name: Coconut cupcakes
description:
I used the folllowing ingredients and it tasted great, having also considerably less calories per muffin, respectively 206.
100 ml walnut oil, 150 g brown sugar, 25 g desiccated coconut, 100 g icing sugar, 100 ml milk,200 g spelt flour.
author: Edd Kimber
ingredients: 400g can full-fat coconut milk(must not contain stabilisers)
200g gluten-free self-raising flour(the mix should include xanthan gum – I used Doves Farm)
directions: Chill the can of coconut milk overnight. The next day, make the cakes. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and line a 12-hole muffin tin with muffin cases. Put the coconut oil and sugar in a large bowl and use an electric whisk to beat together for about 5 mins until light and creamy. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating until fully combined before adding more. Working in three additions, add the flour, alternating with the coconut milk, then add the vanilla extract.

Scoop the batter into the prepared muffin tin using an ice cream scoop, then bake for 20-22 mins or until the cakes are golden and a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean. Remove the cupcakes from the tin and cool on a wire rack.

The whipped cream is best made within a few hours of serving. Open the can of coconut milk upside down and pour off the thin liquid. Scoop the thick coconut milk into a large bowl, add the icing sugar and the vanilla, and whisk for 2-3 mins until soft and fluffy. Spread or scoop the whipped cream onto the cupcakes and sprinkle with the desiccated coconut. Best stored in the fridge and eaten within a couple of days.
chief_review: This coconut muffin recipe shines with its rich coconut flavor and moist crumb, achieved through the use of both coconut oil and full-fat coconut milk. The incorporation of gluten-free self-raising flour (with xanthan gum) makes it a suitable choice for those following a gluten-free diet, while the recipe’s absence of dairy, thanks to coconut milk and oil, caters to those who are lactose intolerant or require dairy-free options. The natural flavors of vanilla and desiccated coconut are well balanced by the sweetness of golden caster and icing sugars. Using walnut oil in the preparation contributes to a subtly nutty undertone, enhancing the overall taste. Perfect for anyone looking to indulge while adhering to specific dietary needs, this muffin manages to deliver indulgence with fewer calories per serving.

name: Spiced salmon coulibiac
description: This make-ahead main of pastry-wrapped fish and rice is an extra-special way to serve seafood for a dinner party, spiced with cardamom, cloves and chilli
author: Mark Sargeant
ingredients: thumb-sized piece ginger, cut into large chunks
140g basmati rice, soaked in cold water for 30 mins, then drained
1 red chilli, seeds kept in, finely chopped
2 x 500g whole salmon fillets, skin removed and pin-boned
directions: Heat the oil in a frying pan and add the onion, garlic, cardamom, cinnamon, fennel, star anise, fenugreek, cloves, ginger and 1 tsp garam masala. Cook over a medium heat until the onion is a deep golden brown. Add the rice with 250ml water and the bay leaf, and season with salt. Bring to the boil, then turn down to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook for 15 mins or until the liquid has been absorbed and the rice is light and fluffy. Remove from the heat, tip into a bowl and leave to cool. Once cooled, remove the cardamom, cinnamon stick, star anise, cloves, ginger and bay leaf. Add the coriander, chilli, mango chutney and lemon juice. Check the seasoning, cover and chill until needed.

Take the pastry out of the fridge and leave at room temperature for 10 mins. Unroll the pastry sheets, roll out to make a little wider and put each on a non-stick baking sheet. Cover with cling film and place in the fridge to re-chill for 30 mins. Season the salmon on both sides with a little salt and pepper and the rest of the garam masala, then place one piece of salmon on one piece of pastry and cover with half of the rice mixture. Top with the other piece of salmon, then brush around the pastry edges with beaten egg. Cover with the second piece of pastry, pushing down well, then roll the edges over, crimp with a fork to seal and decorate as you like. Can be made ahead and chilled for 1 day. Brush all over with beaten egg and chill for 30 mins.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Bake in the oven for 10 mins, then turn the oven down to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and continue to bake for about 30 mins until the pastry is golden brown. Set aside in a warm place to rest for 10 mins. Serve with the rest of the rice mix (heated or cold) and the Raita (see goes well with).
chief_review: A true showpiece for a celebratory table, this pastry-wrapped salmon and spiced rice dish marries fragrant aromatics—cardamom, cinnamon, star anise—with the richness of perfectly cooked fish. The rice, enlivened by garam masala, chilli, fresh coriander, and a hint of mango chutney, offers lovely contrast to the delicate salmon. Encased in golden puff pastry, each slice reveals a visually stunning centerpiece. This recipe is ideal for pescatarians or those seeking a special, make-ahead main course. Take note that it contains gluten and egg, so it’s not suitable for those avoiding these ingredients. With a harmony of textures and layers of spice, this dish will impress at any dinner gathering. Serve with a simple leafy salad or seasonal greens to let the bold flavours shine.

name: Chorizo with celeriac remoulade
description: These elegant meaty canapés combine salty slices of chorizo with a creamy celeriac and mayonnaise filling - great for parties
author: Good Food
directions: Peel and coarsely grate the celeriac and mix with the mayonnaise, lemon juice and Dijon mustard. This can be made a day ahead and chilled. To serve, put 1 tsp of the celeriac mixture onto individual thin slices of chorizo, making 40 in total. Fold the chorizo over to encase the remoulade and secure with a cocktail stick.
chief_review: This canapé recipe creatively pairs the robust savoriness of chorizo with a smooth, zesty celeriac and mayonnaise filling, making it a standout choice for party platters. The earthiness of celeriac is balanced beautifully with the acidity from lemon juice and a touch of heat from Dijon mustard, all enveloped in creamy mayonnaise. The salty, spicy bite of chorizo slices provides the perfect vehicle for the filling, resulting in a harmonious flavor combination that will impress meat lovers and adventurous foodies alike. Since this recipe contains both meat and mayonnaise (traditionally made with eggs), it is not appropriate for vegan or vegetarian diets, nor would it be suitable for those avoiding eggs. However, the absence of bread or wheat keeps it naturally gluten-free, making it a delicious option for guests with gluten sensitivities.

name: Raymond’s roast goose
description: Raymond Blanc's recipe for this classic Christmas bird yields perfectly tender leg and breast meat and crisp, golden skin
author: Raymond Blanc
ingredients: 4½ -5kg free-range organic goose, excess fat trimmed and discarded, legs removed; wings, neck and excess carcass removed and chopped into 2cm/¾ in pieces (about 600g/1lb 5oz)
sprigs of fresh herbssuch as bay, rosemary and thyme, to serve
directions: Take the goose out of the fridge 2 hrs before roasting. Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Chop 1 bay leaf and the leaves from 2 thyme sprigs together. Mix with the garlic, 1/2 tsp coarse sea salt and 2 pinches of white pepper, then rub into the flesh of the goose legs.

Heat the goose fat in a large flameproof roasting tin on a medium heat. Add the wings, neck and excess carcass and cook for 5 mins until lightly golden. Do not colour the bones too much, or the resulting jus will taste bitter. Add the onion, carrot and celery, and continue to brown for 3 mins.
Place the goose legs, skin-side up, in the roasting tin with the bones and vegetables. Cover the tin tightly with foil and roast for 1 hr.

Rub the goose crown with the butter and season well with sea salt and freshly ground white pepper. Remove the tin from the oven and increase the temperature to 230C/210C fan/gas 8. Remove the foil from the tin and sit the goose crown on top of the legs and bones, which will help the heat to circulate the crown, cooking it more evenly. Roast for 30 mins until the crown is golden.

Reduce oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Add the remaining bay leaf, 3 thyme sprigs and 300ml hot water to the tin to lift the caramelised juices from the pan and the bones. (It will also keep the goose moist.) Continue to cook for 30-35 mins, basting every 10 mins with the juices, until a probe thermometer inserted into the breast reads 55C.

Remove the crown from the oven and wrap tightly in foil. Rest for 30 mins to allow the meat to become tender. Continue to cook the goose legs during this time. Meanwhile, heat the Port and Madeira in a small pan and simmer to reduce by half. Remove the goose legs from the oven, then place on a tray, wrap in foil and leave to rest in a warm place.

Pour off the excess fat from the roasting tin and reserve (see tip, below). Remove the bones and veg from the tin and place the tin on a medium heat. Bring to the boil and stir to lift the juices. Add the reduced alcohol. Taste and adjust the seasoning if required, then pour the resting juices which have collected under the goose into the jus. If the sauce is a little thin, mix the arrowroot with 1 tsp cold water, then add a little at a time to ensure that it does not become too thick. Sieve into a warmed gravy boat. Scatter herbs over a serving platter, loosely reassemble the goose on top and serve with the sauce.
chief_review: Raymond Blanc’s goose recipe is a celebration of traditional festive flavors, executed with precision to ensure tender meat and crisp, golden skin—an ideal centerpiece for Christmas. The layering of aromatics such as bay, thyme, and garlic imparts wonderful depth, while the use of goose fat and unsalted butter yields a rich, silky finish in both meat and vegetables. The juggle of port and madeira reduces to a luscious sauce, complementing the gamey notes of goose beautifully. This recipe is naturally gluten-free, as it relies on arrowroot for optional thickening and contains no wheat products. Additionally, the absence of nuts makes it suitable for those with nut allergies. A timeless and elegant dish, this goose will undoubtedly impress discerning palates at any holiday table.

name: Spanish skewers
description: A nod to traditional tapas, these freezable party canapés of potatoes, red pepper and chorizo can be made in advance
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 200g waxy potatoes, such as Charlotte, peeled and cut into 24 x 2cm/¾ in chunks
1 tbsp mild olive oilor sunflower oil
2 tsp finely chopped fresh rosemaryor ½ tsp dried rosemary
1 large red pepper, deseeded and cut into 24 x 2cm/¾ in chunks
1 large yellow pepper, deseeded and cut into 24 x 2cm/¾ in chunks
½ small pack flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Half-fill a large pan with water and bring to the boil. Add the potatoes and return to the boil. Cook for 1 min, then drain in a colander and tip into a bowl. Pour over the olive oil, sprinkle with the rosemary and season. Toss together.
Scatter the potatoes over a large baking tray and cook for 5 mins. Turn the potatoes, add the peppers and cook for a further 10 mins or until just beginning to soften. Set aside to cool.

Thread a chunk of yellow pepper, a chunk of potato and a chunk of red pepper onto bamboo skewers, finishing with a piece of chorizo. Place on a parchment-lined baking tray, cover and chill (up to 8 hrs). To make the dip, mix all the ingredients in a bowl, cover and chill.

When ready to serve, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bake the skewers for 10 mins or until the vegetables are softened and nicely browned, and the chorizo slices are cooked through. Serve with the dip.
chief_review: This festive canapé recipe skillfully combines the vibrant flavors of potatoes, roasted peppers, and smoky chorizo, all presented conveniently on bamboo skewers. The addition of rosemary infuses the potatoes with a herby depth, while the garlicky, herbed crème fraîche dip delivers a creamy, tangy counterpoint—balancing the spice of the chorizo beautifully. These skewers are an excellent choice for party settings, especially as they can be made ahead and frozen, streamlining event preparations. However, with chorizo and crème fraîche featured prominently, the dish is tailored for omnivores rather than vegetarians or those avoiding dairy. Great texture contrasts and bold Spanish-inspired flavors make these canapés a reliable crowd-pleaser.

name: Gingerbread Bellini
description: We were quite excited about this Bellini as it sounded perfect as a welcome drink to serve at our upcoming Christmas party. Luckily we decided to test it first. I should mention that we used gingerbread syrup instead of ginger cordial. The result was a strange greasy tasting mix of clashing flavours. Unfortunately it was so unpleasant we couldn't even finish it.
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put 4 Champagne flutes in the fridge for 15 mins. When you’re ready to serve, mix together the lemon juice, ginger cordial and hazelnut liqueur in a small jug. Take the Champagne flutes out of the fridge, pour in the mixture, then top up each glass with Prosecco.
Roll the icing into 4 small balls, then gently press them onto the rims to help you secure the mini gingerbread men. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This festive Bellini offers an inventive twist on the classic bubbly aperitif, blending lemon juice, ginger cordial, hazelnut liqueur, and prosecco, garnished with whimsical marzipan or icing and mini gingerbread men. The flavor profile attempts a marriage between vibrant citrus, spicy warmth, and nutty richness, capped with the effervescence of prosecco. However, the combination struggles for harmony, with the hazelnut liqueur and ginger introducing a heaviness that can clash rather than complement, especially when accented by sweet decorations. While playful in presentation and perfect for holiday gatherings, this recipe includes nuts (hazelnut liqueur and marzipan/icing may contain almonds or other allergens), making it unsuitable for those with nut allergies. Additionally, it is vegetarian-friendly, as there are no animal-derived ingredients. For best results, careful selection of syrup and liqueur, and possible tweaks to balance flavors are recommended.

name: Ham & stem ginger thins
description: This simple canapé is easy to assemble and has only three ingredients, yet looks great as part of a party platter or buffet
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 2 x 130g boxes of biscuitsfor cheese (we used charcoal wafers)
thin slices of stem gingerin syrup
directions: Assemble the canapés by topping the biscuits with thin slices of the stem ginger in syrup and spoonfuls of shredded ham. Can be made up to 1 hr ahead.
chief_review: This canapé offers a delightful balance of flavors with the earthy crunch of charcoal wafers, sweet warmth from stem ginger in syrup, and the savory depth of shredded ham. Its assembly is refreshingly simple, making it ideal for entertaining when time is short but presentation still matters. The combination of ingredients ensures each bite delivers textural contrast and a subtly adventurous twist, perfect for guests seeking something beyond the ordinary cheese platter. Thanks to its wheat-based biscuit component, this recipe is not suitable for those following gluten-free diets. Additionally, due to the inclusion of ham, it is not compatible with vegetarian, vegan, or pork-free dietary preferences. For a classic yet intriguing party bite, this canapé is sure to impress those with no dietary restrictions.

name: Fruitcake with cheese & apples
description: The classic combination of apples and cheese is given a lift with thin slices of sweet fruitcake - a great festive party canapé or buffet treat
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: a little lemon juice(if not eating immediately)
directions: Cut the fruitcakes into thin pieces and top each with a slice of Lancashire cheese and a piece of apple, tossed in a little lemon juice if not eating immediately. Can be made up to 1 hr ahead.
chief_review: This inventive canapé brilliantly balances sweet and savory notes, pairing the rich, spiced density of fruitcake with the crumbly tang of Lancashire cheese and the crisp freshness of apple. The fruitcake serves as an unexpected, festive base that stands up to the robust cheese, while the apple slices offer a refreshing, juicy counterpoint. A touch of lemon juice is not only practical for keeping the apples fresh but also adds a subtle brightness. This recipe is ideal for vegetarian guests, as it features no meat or fish. Use vegetarian Lancashire cheese to ensure it's entirely vegetarian-friendly. As an elegant addition to any party platter, this canapé delivers both flavor and sophistication in every bite—perfect for elevating a holiday spread.

name: Mini venison & blueberry dogs
description: These cute mini hotdog canapés, using brioche rolls and venison sausages, are perfect for a festive party or buffet
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Roast the venison sausages following pack instructions, then cut into thick slices. Mix the blueberry conserve with the balsamic vinegar. Toast the brioche rolls, cut each one into 4, then slice the tops down the middle.
Arrange a piece of cooked sausage in each and top with a little blueberry mixture and a sprig of thyme, if wanted. Serve warm.
chief_review: This inventive canapé recipe brings a sophisticated twist to the classic mini hotdog. The combination of venison sausages and sweet blueberry conserve, accented with a splash of balsamic vinegar, sets a refined tone—perfect for a festive party spread. The soft, buttery brioche adds richness and a touch of indulgence, while thyme offers a subtle herbal note if desired. Notably, the use of venison provides a leaner alternative to traditional pork or beef sausages, making this appealing to guests seeking a slightly healthier option without sacrificing flavor. This recipe is well-suited for those without gluten or meat restrictions, and will delight anyone looking for an elegant, flavorful bite at their next gathering.

name: Pancetta & sage-wrapped chipolatas
description: Update your pigs in blankets by swapping streaky bacon for pancetta - they can still be easily assembled the day before
author: Jenny White
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Lay a slice of pancetta on a board and place a sage leaf lengthways on top. Roll a chipolata up in the pancetta and sage, and transfer to a roasting tin with the end of the pancetta underneath. Repeat with the remaining pancetta, sage and chipolatas, and roast for 30-35 mins.
chief_review: This updated take on pigs in blankets elevates the classic appetizer by using pancetta instead of streaky bacon, wrapping each chipolata with a fragrant sage leaf for an aromatic touch. The saltiness of the pancetta pairs beautifully with the herby freshness of sage, creating a well-rounded flavor profile that is both savory and subtly earthy. Assembly is fuss-free and can be prepared ahead, making it convenient for entertaining. This recipe is ideal for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the chipolatas used are certified gluten-free, as there are no bread-based fillers among the ingredients. The result is a crowd-pleasing, flavorful bite that brings sophistication to a familiar favorite—perfect for festive gatherings or as a delicious side at any dinner table.

name: Salted maple-roasted parsnips
description: Roast root vegetables with maple syrup and thyme leaves until soft and sticky, then serve as a side dish to your traditional festive feast
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the parsnips in a large roasting tin with the oil, maple syrup, thyme leaves and some sea salt flakes. Roast for 35-40 mins until soft and sticky. Scatter over a few more sea salt flakes before serving.
chief_review: This roast root vegetable dish makes a stunning side, delivering sweet and earthy parsnip flavors elevated by maple syrup and fresh thyme. Roasting brings out a caramelized stickiness, with the thyme adding an aromatic depth that complements festive mains beautifully. The use of vegetable oil and maple syrup ensures the recipe is suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets, and it’s naturally gluten-free, making it versatile for a range of guests. With its short ingredient list and straightforward preparation, this is a reliable choice for adding seasonal warmth to your table—crisp on the edges, tender in the center, and simply delicious.

name: Red wine jelly
description: This rich preserve is delicious in baking, spread on toast or served with cold meats over the festive season
author: Alex Hollywood
ingredients: ½ split vanilla pod, seeds scraped out
directions: Put the red wine, sugar, star anise, clove, cinnamon stick, allspice, vanilla pod and seeds in a medium saucepan. Stir together, then heat gently to dissolve the sugar. Turn up the heat and boil for 20 mins until reduced and syrupy. Strain into a small, sterilised jam jar and leave to cool completely. Will keep in the fridge for up to 1 month.
chief_review: An elegant and aromatic preserve, this recipe masterfully balances warming spices with the robust character of red wine. The inclusion of star anise, clove, and cinnamon offers depth and festive flair, while the vanilla pod adds a gentle sweetness. The use of jam sugar ensures a reliable set, making it ideal for baking or as a luxurious spread on toast. This preserve is vegetarian-friendly, appealing to those seeking a unique addition to cheese boards or cold meats. Its spirited, spiced profile lends itself perfectly to celebratory occasions, offering versatility and gourmet charm.

name: Brioche French toast with bacon, banana & maple syrup
description: So tasty and filling, favourite new Brioche brunch recipe!
author: Joanna Brennan
ingredients: 4 thick, generous slices or 8 thin slices of day-old brioche
directions: In a large bowl, whisk the eggs vigorously, then add the single cream, vanilla and sugar, and whisk again.

When you’re ready to cook, heat the oven to its lowest setting, pop a baking tray inside and pour the cream mixture into a shallow dish or tub that will allow space for the brioche to lay flat. Heat a griddle or a frying pan to a medium heat, and melt the butter and the oil together.
Place the brioche slices in the cream mixture for 1 min, then turn each slice and gently press all over, allowing them to soak up the liquid for another 1 min or so until fully soaked.

Remove the brioche from the mixture and place onto the hot griddle or pan (you may need to do this in batches). Cook for a few mins on either side until the inside is tender and moist (but not wet). To check this, make a small cut in the middle with a knife – the inside should be like cooked bread pudding. Keep warm in the oven while you cook the remaining slices.
In the meantime, fry the bacon in a pan for 5 mins until crispy. Serve the French toast topped with bacon, bananas and a drizzle of maple syrup.
chief_review: This indulgent brunch recipe delivers a luxurious take on classic French toast, using rich brioche soaked in a creamy, eggy mixture with a hint of vanilla. The combination of crispy bacon, caramelized banana, and the sweetness of maple syrup creates a harmonious balance of flavors and textures. The use of butter and cream further elevates the dish, giving it a satisfying, decadent mouthfeel. This recipe is ideal for those following a vegetarian diet that includes eggs and dairy, though it is not suitable for vegans or those with dairy or egg allergies. Pair with freshly brewed coffee for a truly special brunch experience—hearty, comforting, and sure to please.

name: Comté cheese soufflé
description: The soufflé is good but really needs longer in the oven. At least another 15 minutes. It is actually better cooked individually. Very disappointed that M. blanc has not checked his own recipe for errors. I followed the directions to the letter for a dinner party as I trusted his recipes, I guess I should have tried it beforehand.
author: Raymond Blanc
directions: Using a pastry brush, thoroughly grease a 25-30cm oval or round earthenware dish with a thin, even layer of butter. Coat with the breadcrumbs, shaking out the excess, then set the dish aside. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and place a baking tray on the middle shelf to heat up.

To prepare the soufflé base, melt the butter in a small saucepan over a medium heat. Add the flour, whisk until smooth and cook to a nutty blond roux. Lower the heat, then gradually add the warm milk, little by little, whisking to keep the consistency smooth. Add the cheese and mustard, and continue to cook, stirring from time to time, for 3-5 mins. Remove from the heat and allow to cool a little. Add the egg yolks and stir until the mixture is silky and smooth. Season with white pepper (see tip) and keep warm. Can be made ahead up to this point (see tip).
In a large, clean, dry bowl, whisk the egg whites with the lemon juice to medium peaks.

Transfer the warm soufflé base to a large bowl and briefly whisk in a third of the whipped egg whites to lighten the base. Carefully fold in the remaining egg whites with a spatula or large metal spoon, delicately cutting and lifting the mixture to ensure minimum loss of volume and lightness. Taste and adjust the seasoning if necessary. Pour the soufflé mixture into the prepared dish so it is three-quarters full.
Slide the dish onto the hot baking tray and bake for 20 mins. Meanwhile, make the cheese sauce.

Bring the cream to the boil and add the cheese and some freshly ground white pepper, stirring continuously. Once the cheese has melted, remove from the heat and taste for seasoning. Add a dash of kirsch (if using), then pour the sauce into a warmed small jug.
Sprinkle the grated cheese over the soufflé and bake for a further 5 mins. Serve immediately, placing the soufflé and sauce in the middle of the table so everyone can help themselves.
chief_review: This classic cheese soufflé recipe boasts rich flavors from comté and a hint of Dijon, delivering a luxurious texture and notable depth. The technique is traditional, using a roux and whipped egg whites for lift. However, the bake time as written is insufficient—be sure to extend by at least 15 minutes or portion into individual ramekins for better rise and even edges. The double cream and butter create a decadent, melt-in-the-mouth result when properly cooked. This dish is an excellent vegetarian option, provided the comté is made with vegetarian rennet. Those with gluten or dairy allergies must avoid it due to the flour, milk, cream, butter, and cheese content. For best results, trial the recipe ahead of entertaining to fine-tune baking time and achieve the perfect soufflé rise.

name: Sherried turkey & ham bake
description: This warming bake, rich with sherry and mustard, will use up the Christmas leftovers
author: Good Food
ingredients: 140g thickly sliced cooked ham, cut into strips
50g butter, plus a little extra for greasing the dish
50g chopped mixed nut, such as hazelnuts, almonds, and walnuts
directions: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6/fan oven 180C. Mix the turkey, ham and frozen peas in a buttered ovenproof dish.

To make the sauce, put the butter, flour and milk in a saucepan and bring to the boil, whisking all the time, until the sauce is thickened and smooth. Stir in the sherry and mustard, season to taste and simmer for 1 minute. Remove from the heat and stir in half the cheese.

To finish the dish, pour the sauce over the ingredients in the dish. Mix the remaining cheese with the nuts and sprinkle on top. At this point, you can keep the bake in the fridge up to 5 hours, or freeze it. When ready, bake for 25-35 minutes until the topping is golden and the sauce is bubbling.
chief_review: This hearty bake is a delightful way to transform Christmas leftovers into a comforting dish. The blend of turkey and ham delivers a satisfying protein base, complemented by the freshness of peas. The sherry and wholegrain mustard add depth and a pleasant tang to the creamy sauce, while the cheddar brings a rich, savory element. Topping with mixed nuts adds a crunchy texture and a nutty flavor, elevating the dish. This recipe is ideal for those following a nut-inclusive diet and is suitable for individuals without gluten or dairy restrictions. It’s a wonderful, family-friendly meal perfect for busy post-holiday days.

name: Ginger beer & tangerine glazed ham
description: This warming ginger beer-spiced ham is great for Christmas entertaining as it's simple to prepare ahead of time
author: Maria Elia
ingredients: 3 tangerines, zest removed with a vegetable peeler
directions: Put the gammon, onion, tangerine zest and star anise in a large pan. Pour over all but 100ml of the ginger beer and, if necessary, top up with water so the gammon is just covered. Bring to the boil, skim the surface to remove any fat, reduce to a simmer, then cover and cook for 3-3½ hrs or until the meat is tender. When the gammon is cooked, remove it from the pan. Reserve the cooking liquor and use to cook lentils (see 'Goes well with').

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Carefully cut the skin off the gammon, making sure to leave a layer of fat, then lightly score the fat into diamond shapes. Place in a roasting tin lined with foil. Warm the honey, mustard and reserved 100ml ginger beer in a pan and boil until it thickens. Spoon over the fat, then stud a clove into the middle of each diamond. Bake for 20-25 mins or until the glaze has caramelised.
. Slice and eat warm or cold.
chief_review: This ginger beer-spiced ham is a showstopper for festive entertaining, delivering wonderful depth of flavor with minimal fuss. The gammon is infused with aromatic tangerine zest, star anise, and the gentle heat of ginger beer, creating a beautifully balanced sweetness that’s perfect for a holiday centerpiece. Glazing with honey and wholegrain mustard brings a glossy, sticky finish, while cloves add classic warmth. The simplicity of the preparation allows for advance cooking, freeing up valuable time during busy celebrations. This recipe is ideal for those seeking a standout main that appeals to a broad range of tastes, though it is not suitable for vegetarian or vegan diets, or those with certain dietary restrictions. Serve this delicious ham with your favorite sides to impress your guests and enjoy a bit of festive cheer with every bite.

name: Really easy roasties
description: The secret to really great roast potatoes, fluffy parboiled potatoes and hot oil - simple!
author: Lucy Netherton
ingredients: 2kg potato, such as King Edward or Maris Piper
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Heat the oil in a large roasting tin in the oven. Cut any larger potatoes in half. Cover the potatoes in cold salted water, bring up to the boil and cook for 2 mins. Drain and steam-dry in a colander for 5 mins, then shake to ruffle up the outsides.

Remove the roasting tin – be really careful as the oil will be hot. Tip in the potatoes and garlic (if using), and use a spoon to turn them so they are all coated in the oil. Sprinkle with sea salt and pepper, and roast for 1 hr 45 mins, turning every 30 mins or so, until really crisp and golden.
chief_review: This roast potatoes recipe is a straightforward classic, relying on the tried-and-true technique of parboiling for perfectly fluffy insides while hot sunflower oil ensures a crisp, golden exterior. The optional addition of halved garlic bulb subtly perfumes the dish, adding depth without overpowering the natural potato flavor. King Edward or Maris Piper potatoes are excellent choices; their starchy texture is ideal for roasting. The simplicity of the recipe, using only potatoes, oil, and optional garlic, makes it naturally vegan and gluten-free, perfect for those with such dietary considerations. With no dairy, eggs, or common allergens, it’s a safe and delicious side for large gatherings, easily paired with a variety of mains. A wonderful, reliable technique that’s sure to become a favorite for holiday tables or Sunday roasts.

name: Cherry & coconut Florentines
description: Cute chewy bites. Make one giant version, then stamp out the star shapes - leaving lots of bits to nibble!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 250g dark, milk or white chocolate, or a mix
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the sugar, honey and butter in a large pan and gently melt together. When all the sugar has dissolved stir in the coconut, flaked almonds, sliced cherries and flour.

Line a large baking tray with greaseproof paper (about 40 x 30cm), and roughly spread the Florentine mixture out to a thin layer – don’t worry if you have small gaps, it should melt together in the oven. Bake for 10-12 mins until a rich golden colour, then set aside to cool and firm up.

Melt the chocolate(s) all in separate heatproof bowls over gently simmering water. Line a second large tray or board with greaseproof paper and carefully flip the cooled Florentine bake onto it. Peel off the greaseproof paper. Spread the melted chocolate over, if you’re using a few types just leave a gap between each.

Leave aside until set, then stamp out shapes using cookie star cutters - if the cutter is digging into your hands (as the Florentine mix may be a little hard), rest a small plate or pan on top of it and push down on this instead.
chief_review: This whimsical recipe for star-shaped chewy bites delights both the eyes and palate. The combination of muscovado sugar, honey, and butter creates a rich, chewy base, while desiccated coconut and flaked almonds add texture and depth. Glacé cherries provide jewel-like pops of sweetness, and the flexibility in chocolate choice lets you tailor the flavor to your preference. Making a single sheet and stamping out shapes is clever and practical, ensuring minimal waste and extra nibbles for the chef. With no eggs involved, this sweet treat is suitable for ovo-free vegetarians but contains dairy and gluten, making it a fun and flavorful option for gatherings or gifts for those without specific dietary restrictions. Each bite offers a delightful blend of chewy, crunchy, and chocolatey notes—a recipe sure to win smiles.

name: Creamed spinach
description: I can’t rate this recipe as I made changes along the way, but it’s super easy and delicious! I used a leek instead of onion as I had one that needed using up, and Philadelphia cream cheese with herbs and garlic instead of the cream, as it was also getting near the use by date. It worked really well and I would do it again this way, but will also try the original recipe as that sounds lovely too.
author: Good Food
directions: Heat 25g butter in a saucepan, then add 1 finely chopped small onion and cook for 5 mins until softened.
Stir in 2 tbsp plain flour and cook for 2 mins, then slowly start to whisk in 200ml full-fat milk. When it has all been incorporated, gently cook for 5 mins until the sauce has thickened.
Meanwhile, place two 200g bags spinach in a large colander. Pour over a kettle full of boiling water until the leaves have wilted (you may have to do this twice).
Place the spinach in a clean dishcloth, squeeze out any excess liquid, then roughly chop.
Stir into the sauce with 100ml single cream, gently heat, then finely grate over some fresh nutmeg and season well.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers a classic and comforting spinach dish with a creamy, velvety texture. The use of butter, cream, and milk ensures depth and richness, while fresh nutmeg adds aromatic warmth. Swapping in leeks for onions brings a gentle sweetness that pairs beautifully with spinach. Incorporating herbed cream cheese, as mentioned, offers a garlic-infused tang and a more decadent body to the sauce.

The dish is vegetarian-friendly, fitting neatly into a lacto-vegetarian diet as all dairy ingredients are used. For those seeking a versatile, crowd-pleasing side, this recipe is both approachable and adaptable, with simple changes yielding inviting new flavors. Serve it alongside roasted mains or as a standalone comfort meal with crusty bread.

name: Pineapple, fig & ginger chutney
description: The pineapple flavour really comes through in this tangy chutney, making it a perfect accompaniment for ham and all your festive cold meats and cheeses
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 1 large pineapple, about 1kg, or 400g prepared pinapple, roughly chopped
500g Bramley apple, peeled, cored and finely chopped
5cm piece fresh root ginger, finely chopped
directions: Tip the pineapple into a food processor, then pulse until finely chopped. Tip into a large, wide pan with the apples, ginger, onion, figs, spices, vinegar and 2 tsp salt. Bring to the boil, stirring, then boil for 10 mins until the apples are softened.
Add the sugar, then stir to dissolve. Simmer for 20-30 mins, stirring occasionally, until the chutney is thickened. Pot into warm sterilised jars, seal and label. Will keep for 6 months.
chief_review:
This pineapple chutney is a bright and vibrant condiment, where the tropical sharpness of pineapple melds with the warm spice of ginger, mustard seeds, and nutmeg. The Bramley apples lend a lovely tart body, while dried figs and muscovado sugar provide complexity and depth. Its tangy-sweet balance perfectly complements ham, festive cold cuts, and robust cheeses, bringing an invigorating freshness to traditional fare.

With its use of plant-based ingredients and absence of animal products, this chutney is entirely suitable for a vegan or vegetarian diet. Additionally, it is naturally gluten-free, provided all packaged ingredients (such as vinegar) are confirmed so. Bursting with fruit and spice, this chutney is a celebration of festive flavors and will elevate any holiday table.

name: Eggs Benedict with smoked salmon & chives
description: Get your poaching technique honed and serve up this brunch classic- it's easily-doubled to feed a family or crowd
author: James Martin
directions: First make the Hollandaise sauce. Put the lemon juice and vinegar in a small bowl, add the egg yolks and whisk with a balloon whisk until light and frothy. Place the bowl over a pan of simmering water and whisk until mixture thickens. Gradually add the butter, whisking constantly until thick – if it looks like it might be splitting, then whisk off the heat for a few mins. Season and keep warm.

To poach the eggs, bring a large pan of water to the boil and add the vinegar. Lower the heat so that the water is simmering gently. Stir the water so you have a slight whirlpool, then slide in the eggs one by one. Cook each for about 4 mins, then remove with a slotted spoon.
Lightly toast and butter the muffins, then put a couple of slices of salmon on each half. Top each with an egg, spoon over some Hollandaise and garnish with chopped chives.
chief_review: A beautifully executed brunch staple, this recipe blends poached eggs with smoked salmon atop toasted English muffins, all lavishly crowned with homemade hollandaise and a sprinkle of chives. The step-by-step method encourages mastery of classic techniques: delicate egg poaching and emulsifying a rich, tangy hollandaise. The combination of lemon juice and white wine vinegar in the sauce adds a lively acidity that cuts through the richness of butter and yolk, perfectly complementing the smoky salmon. Suited for pescatarians, this dish avoids meat yet retains indulgent flavor. Note that it contains gluten (in the muffins), eggs, and dairy, making it ideal for those without related allergies or intolerances. This brunch is both elegant and satisfying, perfect for impressing guests or treating the family to a restaurant-quality meal at home.

name: Braised red cabbage with cider & apples
description: I had to post as I have just made this and it is fabulous. I wasn't going to bother trying red cabbage again after so many disasters but I decided to have one more go and to use a straight forward recipe with great reviews. I halved the quantities of everything and used dark sugar rather than light but it came out perfectly. I was worried that halving the quantities would cause the mixture to dry out and burn so after about an hour I added half a cup of water. I am thrilled with the results and now wish I had made the full quantity. I will definitely make another batch for Christmas.
author: Cathryn Evans
ingredients: 4 Granny Smiths apples, peeled and cored and chopped
directions: Peel off the outer leaves from the cabbage and discard. Quarter the cabbage, removing the tough stem, then thinly slice. Arrange a layer of the cabbage on the bottom of a large saucepan, followed by some of the onions, apples, zest, mixed spice, sugar and seasoning. Continue to create layers until you have used up the ingredients.

Pour over the vinegar and cider and dot the butter on top. Bring to the boil then simmer with a lid on over low heat for 1½ hrs, until tender. The cabbage will keep for 2 days, covered, in the fridge or freeze for up to 1 month. Reheat in either a pan or in the microwave.
chief_review:
This braised red cabbage recipe is a delightful balance of sweet, tangy, and spiced notes—perfect as a festive side or a comforting winter dish. The combination of red cabbage, apples, citrus zest, and mixed spice creates depth, while brown sugar and cider provide subtle caramelized sweetness. The cider vinegar nicely brightens the overall flavor, keeping the dish vibrant. The instructions suggest careful attention to moisture, ensuring a soft, almost jammy consistency.

For those following a vegetarian diet, this recipe fits beautifully—simply ensure the butter is true dairy and not mixed with animal fats. Additionally, swap the butter for a plant-based alternative to cater for vegan diets. The absence of wheat or gluten-containing ingredients also makes it a solid option for gluten-free diners, provided all packaged ingredients are checked for cross-contamination. An easy, festive, and adaptable dish for many dietary needs!

name: Easy wreath cake
description: Make your Christmas cake extra special this year with this easy and speedy decoration
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 x 18cm square or 20cm round Christmas cake(see 'Goes well with', below)
1 egg white, frothed with a fork
3 tbsp apricotor raspberry jam, warmed and sieved
directions: Dip the cranberries in the egg white, then roll in caster sugar a few times until well coated. Leave to set (or use glacé cherries instead, even easier and no need to frost with egg white). Brush just the top of the cake with a little jam. Roll out the marzipan to slightly larger than the top of the cake, lay on top of the cake, press down and trim flush to the edges of the cake.

Mix a dribble of water at a time into the fondant icing sugar, until it’s a smooth, stiff consistency that won’t run. Pile on the top of the cake. Push to the edges with a palette knife so it eases down the sides a little. Make a wreath from the sage and bay, then add a few of the frosted cranberries (or glacé cherries if using instead).
chief_review: This festive Christmas cake decoration recipe is both elegant and accessible, transforming a classic holiday cake into a true centerpiece. The use of marzipan and fondant icing brings a delightful almond sweetness and smooth finish, while the fresh cranberries dusted with sugar add a vibrant, frosted charm. Brushing the fruit and herbs (sage and bay leaves) with frothed egg white before coating with sugar creates an impressive "snowy" effect, making it perfect for a wintry aesthetic. The apricot or raspberry jam provides a subtle fruity layer, helping the marzipan adhere to the cake. This recipe contains no gluten ingredients (assuming your cake base is gluten-free) and is suitable for vegetarians, but it does include nuts (marzipan) and egg white, so those with nut or egg allergies should take note. Overall, this is a stunning, creative decoration method that requires minimal skill but delivers maximum visual impact.

name: Stollen wreath
description: BBC Good Food's show-stealing December 08 cover recipe - perfect if you fancy a change from the usual Christmas cake
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 50g dried cranberry, plus extra to decorate
1 egg, beaten, plus extra beaten egg to glaze
50g pistachio, peeled and chopped, plus extra, sliced, to decorate
directions: Mix the raisins, cranberries and mixed peel in a bowl, pour over the rum, then leave to soak while you make the dough. Tip the flour into a large bowl and stir in ½ tsp salt, the yeast, sugar, nutmeg and lemon zest. Rub the butter in until the mix is like fine crumbs. Warm the milk to hand-hot, then mix into the egg. Pour the milk into the flour mix, then stir with a round-bladed knife to make a soft dough, adding a drop more milk if needed to mop up any dry crumbs in the bottom of the bowl. Gather the dough into a ball, then knead for 3-4 mins on a lightly floured surface. Put the dough into a lightly oiled bowl, cover with cling film and leave until the dough has risen to double the size (about 45 mins-1 hr).

Knead the dough 2 or 3 times, then roll out to a rectangle about 37cm x 17cm. Stir the chopped pistachios into the soaked fruits, then spread one-third of the fruit mix down the centre of the dough, leaving all the edges uncovered. Fold each side into the centre to overlap slightly. Press the edges with the rolling pin to seal, turn the dough, then repeat the rolling out and spreading of the fruit twice more. Roll out to a final rectangle that is 55cm x 16cm. Roll the marzipan into a sausage shape, so it’s slightly shorter than the length of the dough. Place it down the centre. Roll the dough over the marzipan, then turn the dough over so the join is underneath. Lift onto a buttered baking sheet, then curl the dough round a buttered 12cm round cake tin (see tip, below), brushing the ends with a little beaten egg and pinching them well together to seal.

Cover and leave to rise for 30-45 mins or until puffy and doubled in size. Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/ gas 5. When the dough has doubled, brush with beaten egg and bake for about 25 mins until golden. Cool on the baking sheet briefly, then transfer to a wire rack.
Make up the icing. Stir 2-3 tsp water into the fondant icing sugar and, when the stollen has cooled, drizzle the icing over. Scatter over the extra cranberries and pistachios and decorate with holly.
chief_review:
This festive centerpiece offers a delightful twist on tradition with a fruit-packed, marzipan-filled bread that’s beautifully decorated for the holidays. The inclusion of dried cranberries, raisins, mixed peel, and pistachios creates a pleasing balance of sweet and nutty flavors, enhanced by aromatic rum, nutmeg, and lemon zest. The bread dough, enriched with butter and milk, is tender and fragrant, providing a soft structure that envelops the rich marzipan core.

As a chef, I appreciate the careful layering of textures—chewy fruit, buttery crumb, and soft marzipan, all topped with a delicate fondant icing. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, it is not vegan-friendly due to eggs, butter, and milk, nor is it suitable for those with nut or gluten allergies. Overall, a visually stunning and flavorful alternative to classic Christmas cake.

name: Little Eccles mince pies
description: From freezer to oven, these cheeky Eccles mince pies are perfect mid-afternoon with an equally cheeky glass of mulled wine. It is Christmas after all!
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Roll the pastry out to about the thickness of a 50p piece on to a floured surface, and cut out 10cm circles, then continue to re-roll and cut out until you have about 18 circles.
Place 1 tsp of mincemeat in the centre of each circle, brush the edges with egg white, then gather together tightly to completely encase the mincemeat.
Flip the pies over so the sealed edges are underneath, then squash them with your hand so you have a small puck-shaped pie.

Cut two small slits in the top of each pie, brush generously with egg white and scatter with sugar. The pies can now be frozen for up to 2 months. Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and bake for 15 mins from raw or 25-30 mins from frozen.
chief_review: These Eccles mince pies truly capture the festive spirit, offering a delightful balance of crisp, buttery pastry and rich mincemeat filling. The use of all-butter puff pastry ensures a flaky, indulgent crust with a deliciously golden finish, while the sweet and fruity mincemeat brims with seasonal flavors. The simple process—straight from the freezer to oven—makes this recipe both convenient and impressive for entertaining. They pair exquisitely with mulled wine, enhancing their holiday charm. Note, this recipe contains dairy and egg, making it unsuitable for those with allergies to these ingredients and for vegans. The recipe is otherwise a classic crowd-pleaser, perfect for a celebratory treat.

name: White mulled wine
description: Delicious way to warm the cockles (and use up some bottle ends). Added diluted elderflower juice and a little more sugar than in the recipe having read Jo's comments.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 bottles cheap-ish white wine, medium-dry is good
zest 2 lemons(pared into strips using a vegetable peeler)
directions: Put all the ingredients into a pan and heat until steaming but not boiling. Ladle into mugs or glasses to serve, while you keep the rest warm on a low heat.
chief_review: This festive mulled wine variation is a delightful twist on the traditional, with elderflower cordial lending a floral depth that beautifully complements the bright notes of lemon zest and delicate spices. The addition of cider lightens the body and adds gentle apple undertones, making it both refreshing and comforting. Its use of only plant-based ingredients makes this an excellent option for vegetarians and vegans. There’s no gluten-containing ingredients, so it can also suit a gluten-free diet if the cider is confirmed gluten-free. The drink is easy to prepare and perfect for gatherings, serving as a spirited centerpiece to warm up any winter evening. Adjusting the sugar based on personal taste, as suggested, ensures a versatile, crowd-pleasing result.

name: Sugar-dusted vanilla thins
description: Great for keeping the biscuit tin topped up over Christmas, these sweet thins make a perfect treat
author: Good Food
directions: With your hands, roll the dough on a lightly floured surface into a sausage shape about 25cm/9in long and 5cm/2½in in diameter. Wrap the roll and chill for at least 1 hour. (The roll can be frozen for up to 6 weeks. To use, remove from the freezer and allow to thaw for one hour at room temperature so that the dough is soft enough to be sliced into biscuits.)

Preheat the oven to 180C/gas 4/fan 160C and lightly grease 2 large baking sheets. Using a sharp knife, cut the dough into slices, each a generous 5mm/¼in thick, then arrange them on the greased baking sheets, spacing the biscuits slightly apart so they have a bit of room to spread as they cook.

Bake for 20 minutes until the biscuits are just turning pale golden around the edges, then transfer to a wire rack to cool. Dust generously with icing sugar. The biscuits will keep fresh for up to one week stored in an airtight tin.
chief_review: These vanilla shortbread thins are a festive delight, perfect for filling your biscuit tin during the holiday season. The use of a classic vanilla shortbread dough results in a melt-in-the-mouth texture with a comforting, buttery richness and a subtle hint of vanilla. A simple dusting of icing sugar adds a snowy finish, making them visually appealing as well as delicious. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe does not include meat or animal-derived rennet, and is ideal for those seeking a simple, sweet treat with minimal ingredients. If you wish to add a touch of elegance, pair with tea or coffee for an elevating afternoon snack.

name: Thai mango, chilli & lime cups
description: Sainsburys and Waitrose do the croustade cups. This was delicious. We also do them with duck, hoi sin and spring onions. Also pop some caramelised red onion and soft goat's cheese in them - then add a mix of egg and cream and bake - awesome!
author: Good Food
directions: Mix the mango, red chilli, red onion and a handful coriander leaves, then mix with the lime juice and sweet chilli sauce. Season.
Divide between 32 mini croustade cups (in the supermarket bakery area) and serve within 1 hr so they’ll be firm.
chief_review: This vibrant recipe offers a delightful burst of sweet, spicy, and tangy flavors, perfect as a canapé or light starter. The combination of ripe mango, red chilli, red onion, coriander, and lime juice creates a refreshing salsa with a pleasant heat, balanced by the sweetness of the fruit and chilli sauce. The use of mini croustade cups provides an appealing, crisp base that makes for an elegant presentation. With all plant-based ingredients, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and is also gluten-free if you select gluten-free croustade cups. The absence of dairy, eggs, and nuts makes it friendly for those with common food allergies as well. An easy yet impressive option for entertaining, this dish is sure to please a crowd looking for bright, fresh flavors.

name: Coconut, raspberry & lime meringue slice
description: Making one large meringue is much less fiddly than doing individual ones, and you can prepare all the elements ahead
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1. Line baking sheets with baking parchment and draw 3 rectangles, roughly 25cm x 12cm. Whisk whites to stiff. Gradually whisk in sugar to stiff again, then whisk in the cornflour and vinegar. Fold in the desiccated coconut and pipe, or spread, the meringue mix into 3 even rectangles. Scatter flaked coconut over one of the meringues and bake for 1 hr, then turn off oven and leave in there with the door shut for 1 hr. Leave to cool.

Whisk cream, icing sugar and lime zest and juice to a thick consistency. Spread half over one meringue base (not the one with flaked coconut on top – save that for the top), and scatter over half the raspberries. Sit second meringue base on top, spread with remaining cream and scatter with remaining raspberries. Top with coconut-covered meringue and serve.
chief_review: This impressive large meringue brings simplicity and elegance to dessert preparation, ideal for entertaining or family gatherings. The meringue itself achieves a delightful balance of crisp exterior with a soft, marshmallow-like center, enhanced by the addition of desiccated coconut for a subtle, nutty richness. The lime zest and juice add a bright, zesty contrast that complements the sweetness of the meringue and raspberries beautifully, while the whipped cream provides a lush, creamy layer.
