The flaked coconut topping gives a lovely textural finish. This dessert is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those avoiding gluten. However, it does contain eggs and dairy. Prepare ahead for a stress-free, show-stopping centerpiece that will appeal to fans of classic pavlova with a tropical twist.

name: Ponche de crème bread pudding
description: Inspired by a traditional Caribbean spiced drink, this comforting pud is the perfect dessert to bring to a festive dinner party
author: Shivi Ramoutar
ingredients: 50g unsalted butter, plus extra for greasing
400g brioche(slightly stale, if possible), thickly sliced
large pinch of freshly grated nutmeg
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and lightly grease a 20 x 30cm baking dish with a little of the butter.

First, make the ponche de crème. In a large bowl, using an electric hand whisk, beat the eggs and lime zest for 1-2 mins until light and frothy. Gradually beat in the evaporated milk and rum, then add the vanilla, nutmeg and bitters, and mix well. Stir in the condensed milk and set aside.

Butter the brioche slices on one side and cut each in half diagonally. Layer half the slices across the base of the baking dish, butter-side down. Pour over half the ponche de crème. Scatter over the coconut flakes, raisins and half the nutmeg, and leave for 15 mins.

Sprinkle over the pecans and layer the remaining slices of brioche, butter-side up, on top. Pour over the remaining ponche de crème, ensuring it soaks all the bread. Sprinkle over the remaining nutmeg and the demerara sugar.

Put the baking dish into a roasting tin and pour boiling water into the tin to come halfway up the outside of the baking dish. Carefully put the tin in the oven and bake for 40-45 mins until the custard is set and the pudding is golden brown. Scatter over pecans and coconut flakes and serve with ice cream or cream.
chief_review: This Caribbean-inspired pudding delivers a luscious blend of rich coconut, warming spice, and citrusy brightness, all elevated by a generous splash of dark rum. Using stale brioche ensures a silky, soak-up-the-custard texture, while the combination of coconut flakes, pecans, and raisins gives delightful layers of flavor and crunch. Evaporated and condensed milk create a luxurious, ultra-creamy base, beautifully complemented by lime zest and a double hit of nutmeg. The dessert finishes perfectly with a scoop of coconut ice cream or a drizzle of double cream for extra indulgence. Note that the use of eggs, butter, brioche (contains wheat), and dairy makes this pudding unsuitable for vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, and dairy-free diets, and it may not be suitable for those with nut allergies due to pecans. Overall, a showstopping centerpiece for festive occasions, delivering classic comfort with tropical flair.

name: Truffled parsnip & brioche pudding with hazelnut & thyme butter
description: This decadent, savoury take on the classic bread & butter pudding can be served as a vegetarian centrepiece, or an indulgent side dish
author: Ben Tish
ingredients: 300g parsnips, peeled and cut into small chunks
1 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
1 tbsp picked thyme leaves, plus extra to serve
2 tbsp good-quality white truffle oil, plus extra to drizzle
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the parsnips on a baking tray, drizzle with the olive oil, season well and roast for 30 mins or until tender and nicely caramelised. Reduce the temperature to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
In a large bowl, whisk together the cream, eggs, half the butter, half the cheese and half the thyme. Season well, then add the truffle oil, brioche and parsnips, and leave for 10 mins.

Lightly oil a medium baking dish and tip in the soaked brioche mixture. Heat the remaining butter in a shallow pan and cook until the butter turns brown. Add the hazelnuts and remaining thyme and cook for 2 mins before spooning over the top of the pudding. Cover the dish with foil, and cook in the oven for around 50 mins until puffed up and starting to caramelise. Remove the foil, sprinkle with the remaining cheese and place back in the oven for 15 mins to brown fully. Scatter over the black truffle, if using, add an extra drizzle of truffle oil, the extra thyme and serve.
chief_review: This sumptuous savoury bread & butter pudding is an impressive vegetarian showstopper, ideal as either a centerpiece or a luxurious side. The golden brioche, infused with double cream and eggs, bakes into a perfectly rich and custardy base, while roasted parsnips and earthy thyme add warmth and depth. Vegetarian-style parmesan brings savoury umami, while truffle oil elevates the dish with its intoxicating aroma. The addition of blanched hazelnuts gives a delightful crunch, and fresh black truffle (if using) is a lavish finishing touch. Carefully chosen ingredients make this recipe suitable for a vegetarian diet. For best results, ensure the parmesan is truly vegetarian, as some varieties may contain animal rennet. Paired with a crisp salad or served as part of a festive spread, this dish is a true celebration of flavor and texture.

name: Golden roast potatoes
description: Don't spend Christmas morning peeling potatoes, make our freeze ahead roasties
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 2½ kg Desirée or King Edward potato
5 tbsp goose fat or sunflower oil
directions: Peel the potatoes, then cut into halves, or quarters if large. Bring a large pan of water to the boil, add a little salt, then tip the potatoes into the pan. Bring back to the boil and cook for 7 mins. Drain really well, then return to the pan and sprinkle over the flour. Place a lid on top of the pan, then pick up the pan using oven gloves or a tea towel and give it a few really hard shakes so the potatoes get bashed around (this will make them nice and crisp).

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Spoon the goose fat or sunflower oil onto a large, lipped baking tray and leave to heat on the top shelf of the oven for 5 mins. Carefully pull out the tray, make sure its surface is evenly coated with the fat, then tip on the potatoes. Roast for 20 mins, then turn up the oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7 and roast for another 30 mins, turning the potatoes once, until golden and crisp. Sprinkle with a little salt and serve straight away.
chief_review: This recipe for freeze-ahead roast potatoes is a classic choice for a festive meal, offering crispy exteriors and fluffy interiors, thanks to the combination of Desirée or King Edward potatoes and a generous coating of flour. The goose fat adds incredible flavor and a golden crunch, while sunflower oil provides a plant-based alternative for those preferring to avoid animal products. The straightforward method streamlines Christmas preparations, freeing up valuable time on the day itself. As the recipe is naturally free from gluten-containing ingredients (relying on plain flour, which can be swapped for a gluten-free blend if needed), it suits a gluten-free diet. When prepared with sunflower oil, these roasties can also be enjoyed by vegetarians or vegans looking for a luxurious, no-fuss side dish. A dependable, crowd-pleasing addition to any special occasion spread.

name: Orange & ginger stained glass biscuits
description: Kids will love to make these magical Christmas biscuits and hang them with pretty ribbon
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Grease 2 large non-stick baking sheets with oil. Whizz the flour, ginger, zest and butter with 1⁄2 tsp salt to fine crumbs in a food processor. Pulse in the sugar and milk, then turn out and knead briefly on a floured surface until smooth. Wrap in cling film, then chill for about 30 mins.

Flour the work surface again, then roll out the dough to the thickness of a £1 coin. Use 7cm cutters to cut out shapes, then use 4cm cutters to cut out the middles. Re-roll leftover pieces. Make a hole in the top of each biscuit, then carefully lift onto the baking sheets.

Crush the sweets in their wrappers with a rolling pin, then put the pieces into the middles of the biscuits – the sweets should be level with the top of the dough. Bake for 15-20 mins or until the biscuits are golden brown and the middles have melted.
Leave to harden, then transfer to a rack to cool. Thread with ribbon, then dust with icing sugar. Will keep for a month, but best eaten within 3 days.
chief_review: These magical Christmas biscuits are a delightful treat, perfect for festive baking with kids. The combination of ground ginger and orange zest imparts a bright, aromatic flavor, while the cold butter ensures a crisp, buttery texture. The real showstopper is the use of fruit-flavored boiled sweets, which melt to create jewel-like stained glass centers—both visually stunning and fun to eat or display. The dough is easy to handle, making it ideal for little hands to help cut shapes. Designed with a light dusting of icing sugar and finished with a ribbon for hanging, these biscuits are as decorative as they are delicious. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet and can be adapted for nut-free needs, making it an inclusive option for holiday gatherings with children. A festive, hands-on activity that delivers both joy and flavor!

name: Turkey, thyme & leek meatloaf
description: A yummy meatloaf that is perfect for a midweek meal
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 rashers lean back bacon, fat trimmed, chopped
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Heat the oil in a frying pan, then soften the leeks for 5 mins. Line the base of a 28 x 18cm baking tin with greaseproof paper.

Mix the mince, thyme, two-thirds of the breadcrumbs, leeks and egg together with a little seasoning, then tip into the tin. Press the mixture firmly into the tin, then ruffle the surface with a fork. Mix the remaining breadcrumbs and bacon together and scatter over the top. Cook for 15 mins, then finish under the grill until golden and crisp on top. Serve with boiled potatoes and carrots.
chief_review: This turkey and leek meatloaf is a lighter twist on a classic comfort dish, ideal for a midweek family dinner. The use of turkey mince and lean back bacon keeps it relatively low in fat without sacrificing flavor, while the addition of leeks provides a pleasant sweetness and moisture. Thyme brings a subtle herbal aroma, and fresh breadcrumbs help bind everything together seamlessly with the beaten egg. The recipe is suitable for those avoiding red meat and suits a high-protein diet. However, it is not suitable for gluten-free diets due to the inclusion of breadcrumbs, and does not accommodate vegetarian or vegan preferences. Pair it with steamed vegetables or a side salad for a well-rounded meal. Overall, the dish is homely, satisfying, and straightforward to prepare, making it a great option for busy evenings.

name: Boozy mincemeat
description: A staple of Christmas, this mincemeat will make the perfect addition to all your seasonal baking
author: Ruth Watson
ingredients: 500g muscatel or Californian raisin (or a mixture)
500g Bramley apple, peeled, cored and chopped fairly small
250g whole mixed peel, chopped into small dice
directions: Wash the dried fruit thoroughly in a colander under the cold tap (you may find it easier to do this in batches) - whatever it says on the packet, washing the fruit is something I've (Ruth Watson) always done. Tip the fruit on to clean tea towels and dry by patting in the cloths.
Put the dried fruit in a very large bowl with the apples, suet, almonds, sugars and spices. Grate the zest of the lemon into the bowl, then squeeze in the juice. Tip in the peel and the alcohol.
Mix all the ingredients very thoroughly - it's easiest to do this with your (very clean) hands.
Cover and leave to stand for 24 hours, asking the family to stop and give it a good stir with a spoon when they pass by.

Pack the mincemeat into sterilised or dishwasher-clean jars (Kilner jars are ideal) and top with greaseproof paper jam covers. Seal the jars tightly and store in a cool place. The mincemeat will last from one year to the next, but's best used within 6 months.
chief_review: This traditional mincemeat recipe combines a rich medley of dried fruits, apples, and aromatic spices with an indulgent blend of dark spirits for depth and complexity. The inclusion of shredded beef suet makes this mincemeat particularly lush and classic, lending a luxurious mouthfeel. Crunch from blanched almonds and brightness from fresh lemon elevate the overall texture and flavor profile, while both demerara and muscovado sugars contribute robust caramel notes. This mincemeat is ideal for bakers seeking authenticity in their holiday pies and tarts. Since it contains only fruit, almonds, and suet, it is naturally suitable for gluten-free diets, assuming your suet is gluten-free. However, it is not vegan or vegetarian due to the beef suet, and may not be nut allergy friendly because of the almonds. For those looking for a time-honored, festive filling, this recipe delivers exceptional depth and seasonal spirit.

name: Brussels sprouts with pancetta
description: Spruce up your sprouts this Christmas - Gordon Ramsay's recipe creates a really rich flavour
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 100g thinly sliced pancetta, cut into 2cm strips
directions: Blanch the Brussels sprouts in a pan of boiling salted water for 3 mins, then drain and tip into a bowl of iced water to cool quickly. Drain well again and set aside until nearly ready to serve. Sauté the pancetta in the hot goose fat until crisp. Toss in the sprouts and stir-fry for 2-3 mins, adding the sage to serve.
chief_review: This festive Brussels sprouts recipe by Gordon Ramsay is an indulgent upgrade perfect for the holiday table. The smoky pancetta pairs beautifully with the earthy sprouts, while a generous hit of hot goose fat imparts deep, luxurious flavor and rich texture. Shredded sage adds a subtle aromatic note, lifting the dish and complementing the savoriness of the pancetta. This savory side is ideal for those following a gluten-free diet, as it relies entirely on naturally gluten-free ingredients. However, the inclusion of pancetta and goose fat makes it unsuitable for vegetarians or vegans. Serve this alongside roasted meats or as a decadent twist to your classic Christmas spread—it's sure to convert even sprout-skeptics.

name: Pea & ham soup
description: Cooked for lunch today using ham stock from the weekend. Very quick and easy. A little thin I thought, so I just boiled up another couple of potatoes, added to the soup and re-blitzed - which did the trick.
ingredients: 300g thickly sliced ham, trimmed of any fat and diced
directions: Heat a knob of butter in a saucepan and when lightly foaming gently cook 1 chopped onion until softened, but not coloured.
Tip in 1 peeled and diced medium potato and stir to coat in butter, then pour over 1l ham or pork stock. Simmer until softened.
Tip in 500g frozen petit pois and bring back to the boil. Cook for a couple of mins.
Remove from the heat and
until smooth. Stir in 300g diced ham and serve.
chief_review:
This hearty soup is a fantastic option for a quick and satisfying lunch, showcasing classic flavors with ham, peas, and potato. The use of ham or pork stock imparts a rich depth, which pairs beautifully with the sweetness of petit pois. Chopped onions and potatoes provide an earthy balance and a thicker texture after blending, as mentioned in the recipe tweak. The addition of diced ham ensures a substantial, protein-packed bowl.

This recipe is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as long as the stock and ham chosen are certified gluten-free, making it accessible to those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. The soup is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the use of pork-based stock and ham. Simple, rustic, and full of flavor, it’s a comforting classic for cooler days.

name: Smoked salmon with beetroot & vodka crème fraîche
description: A hit of vodka gives this classic a new edge. Serve with a shot of vodka for full effect
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 250g pack small, cooked beetroot (not in vinegar), thinly sliced, then shredded
directions: Beat the crème fraîche with the vodka and a little seasoning until it holds its shape, then stir in the horseradish. Chill in the fridge.

Lay the slices of salmon over plates, then top with the beetroot and a spoonful of the crème fraîche. Top with the salmon caviar, if using, then scatter with the dill. Grind over some black pepper and serve.
chief_review: This recipe offers a sophisticated twist on the classic smoked salmon platter, infusing crème fraîche with vodka and horseradish for a lively kick that pairs elegantly with tender beetroot and the smoky richness of salmon. The addition of salmon caviar and sprigs of dill elevates it further, making it an impressive starter for dinner parties or festive gatherings. The use of smoked salmon and crème fraîche means this dish is suitable for pescatarians, and it is naturally gluten-free, provided the toppings and sauces used are free from gluten-containing additives. The flavors are bold yet balanced, and the textural interplay of creamy, silky, and crisp components makes each bite a delight. Pairing with a chilled shot of vodka, as suggested, adds a touch of Nordic tradition and a celebratory flair.

name: Roast fillet of beef with mushroom stuffing
description: Serve up a spectacular centrepiece of roast beef with a rich stuffing, and a clever twist on Yorkshire puddings
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: knob of butter, plus extra for roasting
directions: Tip the porcini into a bowl and pour over 250ml boiling water. Leave for 20 mins to soften and plump up, scoop out the mushrooms with a slotted spoon and finely chop, then strain the liquid (leaving behind the last drop as it might contain grit) and set aside.

Set aside about half the wild mushrooms, choosing those with the best shape, then finely chop the remainder. Chop 1 shallot very finely. Heat a large frying pan, add the butter and 1 tbsp olive oil, then cook the chopped shallot and garlic over a medium heat for 3-5 mins until softened. Tip in the chopped porcini and stir around the pan for 2 mins. Add the chopped mushrooms to the frying pan along with the thyme sprigs. Cook for 10 mins until lightly browned and any liquid has evaporated. Leave to cool.

Place the beef on a board. Take a sharp knife and make a slice lengthways along the fillet, about one-third of the way down, so it folds out like a book. One side of the beef should now be thicker than the other. Make another lengthways slice along the thick half of beef so the beef unfolds to a flat, evenly thick piece of meat, about the size of an A4 page. Spread the mushroom mixture all over the beef and season really well. Tightly roll up the beef to reform into a log and tie about 8 pieces of string around to secure well.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Place a large heavy-based roasting tin over a high heat on the hob (ensure that it will fit in your oven beforehand). Heat some more butter and the other 1 tbsp oil in the tin, then fry the beef, turning every couple of mins, until well browned all over. This will take about 10 mins.

Tip the whole shallots into the tin around the beef and toss them in the oil. Roast for 20-25 mins for rare, 35 mins for medium and 45 mins for well done. If you have a thick piece of meat, it may take a little longer. Ten mins before the end of cooking, stir the whole mushrooms around the pan, coating well in the oil and juices, then leave to roast alongside the meat and shallots. Leave the meat to rest on a board for 10-15 mins and keep the vegetables warm in a serving dish while you make the sauce.

Place the tin back on the hob. Stir in the flour, mixing well into any oil in the pan, then very carefully pour over the brandy, making sure you don’t pour straight from the bottle. Use a small whisk to stir in the brandy, scraping up all the lovely browned bits from the tin. When the brandy has nearly boiled away, pour over the strained mushroom liquid and beef stock. Cook for about 5 mins until the liquid just coats the back of a spoon, then stir in the mustard and crème fraîche. Season, sprinkle with parsley and pour into a gravy boat. Cut the beef into thick slices and serve with the vegetables, gravy and some Parmesan puffs, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe creates a stunning roast beef centerpiece enriched with a luxurious wild mushroom stuffing and a refined take on traditional Yorkshire puddings. The combination of dried porcini and wild mushrooms with shallots, garlic, and fresh thyme brings earthy, aromatic depth to the dish, complementing the succulent beef fillet. The sauce, crafted with brandy, beef stock, wholegrain mustard, and crème fraîche, adds a creamy, tangy richness that elevates every bite. The use of butter and olive oil ensures the mushrooms are beautifully sautéed and intensely flavorful. Ideal for festive occasions, this dish would suit a gluten-free diet if the plain flour is substituted appropriately—for instance, with a certified gluten-free flour. The rich flavors and elegant presentation will certainly impress any dinner guest, making it perfect for special gatherings and holiday feasts.

name: Chocolate fruitcake
description: If anyone in your family isn't keen on traditional fruitcake, this might be the compromise you've been looking for
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 100g dark chocolate(we used 80%) broken into chunks
directions: Put the butter, sugar, chocolate, brandy, vanilla and dried fruits into a large saucepan. Heat gently, stirring occasionally until everything has melted together. Remove from the heat.
Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Line a deep cake tin, 20cm round or 18cm square, with a double layer of baking parchment. Wrap a few layers of newspaper around the outside and secure with string.

Mix the flour, almonds, cocoa and spice together. Stir the eggs into the slightly cooled chocolate mixture in the saucepan, followed by the flour mixture. Scrape into your prepared tin and bake for 1½ hrs- 1 hr 45 mins or until a skewer poked in comes out clean. Cool in the tin, then decorate (see 'Goes well with', right, for decoration ideas).
chief_review:
This modern twist on the classic fruitcake masterfully balances rich chocolate notes with the tang of dried fruits and a touch of brandy warmth. The dark chocolate (80%) lends depth and a slight bitterness, cutting the sweetness of the currants, raisins, and cherries, while ground almonds offer a gentle nuttiness and moist crumb. The cocoa and mixed spice unite the flavours, making each slice aromatic and festive. It's a decadent, moist cake that appeals even to those wary of traditional fruitcake's density.

This recipe is a delightful option for those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal rennet products. However, it does include eggs and dairy, so it’s not suitable for vegans. The inclusion of almonds may also appeal to fans of nutty undertones in baked goods. This fruitcake is sure to win over even the most reluctant festive dessert eaters.

name: Shortbread recipe
description: Make these a lot..lovely light crumbly shortbread.
author: Emma Lewis
directions: Place the butter and 140g sugar in a
and whizz until smooth.
Tip in both the flours and a pinch of salt, then whizz until mixture comes together.

Using your hands, roughly spread the mixture out in a 20 x 30 x 4cm baking tray. Cover with cling film and smooth over until there are no wrinkles. Place in the fridge, uncooked, for at least 30 mins and up to 2 days.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Remove cling film, then lightly mark the shortbread all over with a fork.
Sprinkle with the remaining sugar, then bake for 20-25 mins.
Leave to cool in the tin, then cut into 24 thin slices. Shortbread will keep in an airtight container for up to 1 week.
chief_review: This shortbread recipe yields a delightfully light and crumbly texture, true to traditional Scottish roots. The use of both plain and rice flour ensures a delicate bite and tender crumb, while the high butter content imparts a rich, melt-in-the-mouth finish. Golden caster sugar brings a gentle caramel undertone, elevating the overall flavor profile. With no eggs or dairy alternatives, this shortbread is suitable for a vegetarian diet but not vegan. It's a lovely companion for afternoon tea or as a base for dessert innovation. Simplicity in the ingredient list means the technique is key—be gentle with the dough to maintain the crumbly texture. Highly recommended for those who appreciate classic, buttery biscuits.

name: Baileys banana trifles
description: Easy to make but note if you are a novice like me you need to whip the cream and baileys together otherwise it goes like single cream! Also whilst it can be made ahead of time if you add the toffee sauce too early it will just sink to the bottom of the trip so worthwhile adding just before presentation. Otherwise absolutely delicious!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 chocolate brownies(about 250g/9oz), broken up, or use crumbled chocolate biscuits or loaf cake
directions: Mix the cream with 1 tbsp Baileys, and set aside. Divide the brownie pieces between 6 glasses, then drizzle each with 1 tbsp Baileys. Top with the sliced bananas, custard and Baileys cream, dividing equally, then drizzle with toffee sauce and finish with grated chocolate. Can be made a few hours ahead.
chief_review: This indulgent dessert layers rich brownies (or cake), bananas, vanilla custard, whipped Baileys-infused cream, and a generous drizzle of toffee sauce, finished with grated chocolate. The instructions wisely highlight the importance of properly whipping the cream with Baileys for a stable texture and advise delaying the toffee sauce until serving for best presentation. This recipe is wonderfully suited to a vegetarian diet, given its lack of animal-derived gelatin or meat products. However, it does contain dairy, gluten, and eggs (in typical brownies or cake), so those with lactose intolerance, gluten sensitivity, or an egg allergy should take note. Its decadent nature makes it a showstopping dessert for gatherings. The flavor combination is classic yet elevated by the added Baileys, creating a creamy, adults-only treat that’s both easy and impressive.

name: Mincemeat custard pies
description: If you find the classic mince pies a bit dry and crumbly, try these moist mouthfuls, with an indulgent dollop of creamy custard
author: Angela Nilsen
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Stir the custard and almonds together. Unroll the pastry, then cut out circles using a 7cm plain round cutter. Gather up the pastry trimmings, re-roll, then cut out more circles – you should get 16-18. Use to line a couple of bun tins.

Spoon a heaped tsp of the custard mix into each tart case, then top with a scant tsp of mincemeat. Scatter over some flaked almonds, then bake for about 10 mins until puffy and golden. Cool briefly in the tin, then dust with icing sugar and serve slightly warm.
chief_review: This inventive twist on classic mince pies brings a lusciously moist texture, thanks to the addition of creamy Devon custard and ground almonds blended into the filling. The ready-rolled puff pastry ensures a light, golden shell that crisps beautifully in the oven, while flaked almonds provide a pleasant crunch and the icing sugar dusting adds just the right touch of sweetness. These pies offer a delightful balance of sweet, spiced mincemeat and velvety custard, making each bite rich and festive. Suitable for vegetarians, as none of the listed ingredients is derived from meat or fish, and the custard is typically egg and milk-based. However, they do contain gluten, nuts, and dairy, so do be mindful of those with relevant allergies. Overall, a deliciously indulgent upgrade to the traditional mince pie, perfect for anyone wanting something softer and more decadent this holiday season.

name: Limoncello & raspberry semi-freddo
description: Limoncello lends a lively kick to both the semi-freddo and the sauce - a perfect chance to use up that bottle you brought back from holiday
author: Angela Nilsen
directions: Line the base of a 1kg loaf tin (19cm x 12cm x 9cm deep) with baking parchment. For the semi-freddo, mash the raspberries and half the sugar in a bowl with a fork. Whisk the cream, the rest of the sugar and the limoncello to soft peaks. Beat the crème fraîche briefly so it is in soft peaks like the cream. Gently fold the cream mixture and crème fraîche together.
Pour the mashed raspberries into the cream and give a few stirs only - just enough to swirl it through the creamy mix. Pour the mixture into the loaf tin and smooth the top.
For the coulis, mash the raspberries, sugar and limoncello with a fork, then push through a sieve.
Open-freeze (see 'Try' below) the semi-freddo then cover with cling film and foil and freeze for up to 1 month. Pour the sieved coulis into a rigid container and freeze for up to 1 month.

To serve, thaw the coulis in the fridge overnight. Thaw the semi-freddo in the fridge for 1 hr. Remove it from the tin and peel off the lining paper. Drizzle with a little of the coulis and scatter some raspberries over the top. Serve in slices with the rest of the coulis.
chief_review: This Limoncello Raspberry Semifreddo is a vibrant and indulgent Italian-inspired dessert that perfectly balances the zesty punch of limoncello with tart raspberries and rich, creamy layers. The combination of double cream and crème fraîche creates a luxuriously smooth texture, while the limoncello infuses a lively citrus brightness that lifts the whole dish. Using both fresh and frozen raspberries ensures a consistent, fruity flavor throughout. This recipe is a delicious treat for those seeking a vegetarian dessert, as it contains no gelatine or animal-based thickeners. It makes an elegant end to a summer meal and provides an inventive way to enjoy limoncello beyond a simple digestif.

name: Baked mincemeat doughnuts
description: Get into the Christmas spirit and enjoy the pure pleasure of baking these mincemeat filled doughnuts
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Tip the flour, sugar and a good pinch of salt into a large bowl. Add the butter and rub into the flour with your fingertips. Stir in the yeast.

Warm the milk to hand hot. Make a well in the centre of the flour and add the milk and egg. Mix everything together to make a soft dough. Tip onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 5 mins until the dough is smooth, elastic and no longer sticky. Put the dough back in the bowl, cover with a tea towel and leave to rise for about 1 hr or until doubled in size.

Knead the dough again briefly, then divide into 12 equal pieces. Roll out each piece to a 9cm round and put 1 tsp mincemeat in the centre. Gather up the edges of the dough to enclose the filling, pinching it well to seal. Shape into a ball between your hands and put on a baking sheet lined with baking paper, sealed side down, allowing space for the dough to rise. Cover with a tea towel and leave for about 30 mins. Heat the oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5.

Bake the doughnuts for 10-12 mins until risen and golden. Mix the icing sugar with 2 tbsp cold water in a shallow bowl. Mix the caster sugar and cinnamon in another bowl. Roll each doughnut first in the sugar syrup, then into the caster sugar to coat all over. Leave to cool.
chief_review: These mincemeat filled doughnuts are a delightful festive treat, balancing a soft, pillowy bread dough with the rich, spiced depth of mincemeat. The enriched dough—made with strong white bread flour, butter, and egg—yields a wonderfully tender crumb and is further elevated by a cinnamon sugar coating, bringing seasonal warmth to every bite. The method is straightforward for home bakers, relying on easy-blend dried yeast and pantry staples. While not suited for vegan or dairy-free diets due to the inclusion of butter, milk, and egg, this recipe can be enjoyed by vegetarians, provided the mincemeat is suet-free or made with vegetarian suet. Perfect for a holiday gathering, these doughnuts encapsulate the nostalgic flavors of Christmas with a playful twist. Enjoy them warm, dusted generously with cinnamon sugar for maximum cheer.

name: Brussels sprouts with hazelnut & orange butter
description: Wonderful recipe, made it for Christmas Day and everyone loved it, including the self-proclaimed sprout haters! Will definitely be using this recipe again in the future!
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: finely grated zest of 1 small orange
50g chopped toasted hazelnuts(you can buy these in a packet)
directions: Mix the butter, orange zest and hazelnuts in a small bowl with some freshly ground black pepper. (This can be done 2-3 days ahead and kept covered in the fridge.)

Put the sprouts into a pan of boiling salted water, bring back to the boil, cover and cook for 4-5 minutes. Pour in the peas and cook for a further 2 minutes. The sprouts should be only just cooked. Drain.
Put the sprouts and peas back into the pan and toss with the flavoured butter so it melts in. Season with salt and pepper and tip into a warmed serving dish.
chief_review: This festive Brussels sprouts recipe is a delightful surprise, skillfully transforming a divisive vegetable into the star of the table. The combination of softened butter and bright orange zest elevates the flavor profile, while the toasted hazelnuts introduce an appealing crunch and nutty depth. The addition of petits pois imparts a sweet contrast, balancing the sprouts’ earthiness beautifully. This recipe is an excellent choice for a vegetarian diet, as it avoids the use of meat or fish while delivering full-bodied flavor. It's also suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided that all packaged ingredients, including the frozen petits pois, are confirmed gluten-free. With its simple yet thoughtful ingredient list, this dish is ideal for special occasions but easy enough to enjoy year-round. Highly recommended for anyone looking to enliven classic holiday fare.

name: Snow-topped holly cakes
description: This square Christmas cake is cut into two loaf-shaped cakes, so you can give one to a friend
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 100ml dark rum, brandy or orange juice
directions: Tip the sugar, butter, dried fruit, whole cherries, ginger, orange zest and juice into a large pan. Pour over the rum, brandy or juice, then put on the heat and slowly bring to the boil, stirring frequently to melt the butter. Reduce the heat and bubble gently, uncovered for 10 mins, stirring every now and again to make sure the mixture doesn’t catch on the bottom of the pan. Set aside for 30 mins to cool.
Stir the nuts, eggs and ground almonds into the fruit, then sift in the flour, baking powder and spices. Stir everything together gently but thoroughly. Your batter is ready.

Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Butter and line the base and sides of a 18cm square tin with baking paper. Spoon the cake mix into the tin and level the top with a spoon dipped into boiling water. Bake for 45 mins, then turn oven down to 140C/120C fan/gas 1 and cook for 1 hr more or until a skewer inserted comes out clean. Cool on a wire rack. Will keep well-wrapped in foil for 2 months or freeze for 1 year.

Carefully cut the square cake in half and trim the edges so that you see the texture of the cake on all sides. Roll out each piece of marzipan on a surface dusted with icing sugar until the size of the top of each cake.
Generously brush the top of the cakes with jam, place jam-side down on top of the marzipan, then trim away the excess marzipan with a sharp knife.

Make up the fondant icing to a spreading consistency, then spread on top of the cakes so that it slightly runs over the edges. Top with cherries and holly, then leave to set. Will keep in a plastic container in a cool place for 4-7 days.
chief_review: This festive Christmas cake is a true celebration of classic holiday flavors, boasting rich muscovado sugar, a generous mix of dried fruit, warm spices, and a spirited hint of dark rum or brandy. The inclusion of pecans and ground almonds infuses depth and texture, while the marzipan and fondant icing add that signature luxurious finish. Ideal for sharing, as the cake cleverly splits into two loaves—perfect for gifting. This recipe is best suited for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, those with nut allergies or gluten sensitivities should be aware of the presence of nuts and wheat flour. The cake's moist crumb and aromatic profile make it irresistible and festive, especially with decorative holly sprigs crowning the loaf. A delightful centerpiece for any Christmas table, and a wonderful homemade gift to spread seasonal joy.

name: Salmon, dill & potato tart
description: This delicious smoked salmon tart makes a light alternative for lunch
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 3 tbsp chopped dill, extra for sprinkling
200g pack smoked salmon, torn into strips
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Roll out the pastry and line a shallow 28cm flan tin. Trim off the edges, then line with baking paper and beans. Put on a baking sheet, bake for 10 mins. Remove the paper and beans, then bake for 5 mins more.

Cook the potatoes in boiling salted water for 6-8 mins until tender, then drain. Beat together the cream, eggs, dill, lime zest, salt and pepper. Scatter half the potatoes over the bottom of the pastry case, then put half the salmon strips in the gaps. Pour over half the egg mix, then arrange the remaining potatoes over the salmon pieces and put the remaining salmon in the gaps between. Pour over the rest of the egg mix.
Bake for 25 mins until the top is lightly coloured and firm to the touch. Cool for 10 mins before removing from the tin, then serve warm or at room temperature sprinkled with extra dill.
chief_review:
This smoked salmon tart offers a delightful balance of creamy and fresh flavors, making it an excellent choice for a light yet satisfying lunch. The rich base of single cream and eggs creates a custardy texture that pairs beautifully with the salty smoked salmon and herbaceous dill. The addition of lime zest lifts the dish, providing a subtle, refreshing zing. Sliced new potatoes add heartiness without overpowering the delicate proteins.

Vegetarians who consume fish (pescatarians) and those seeking a luxurious, special-occasion brunch will particularly enjoy this tart. The ready-made shortcrust pastry saves time, while still delivering a flaky, tender crust. Sprinkle fresh dill just before serving to intensify the aromas. For best results, serve slightly warm with a simple green salad.

name: Festive fruit & nut cake
description: This fabulously moist and nutty Christmas cake is baked with a syrup and nut topping - a bit like a Florentine biscuit
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 700g luxury mixed fruit (including raisins, currants, sultanas, mixed peel and glace cherries)
50g each whole skinned hazelnut and blanched almonds
85g each Brazil nuts and flaked almonds
directions: Preheat the oven to 180C/gas 4/fan 160C and lightly grease and line the base and sides of a deep 22-23cm round loose-based cake tin with Bake-o-Glide or baking parchment (see overleaf). Beat the butter, sugar, eggs, flour, ground almonds and spices until thoroughly mixed and creamy, preferably with an electric beater or in a food mixer.

Measure off 100g/4oz of the cake mixture, put in a bowl and set aside. Fold the fruit and rum into the remaining mixture, then gently stir in the marzipan. Spoon this mixture into the prepared cake tin and flatten with a spatula to make a smooth even surface, then make a slight dip in the centre of the cake. This simple trick will give the finished cake a nice flat top. Bake for 11⁄4 hours.

While the cake is in the oven, make the fruit and nut topping. Mix all the nuts, cherries and syrup into the remaining cake mixture (see tip overleaf). Spoon the mixture on top of the part-cooked cake (once it has had its 11⁄4 hours), evenly distributing the mixture of nuts and cherries across the surface of the cake. Loosely cover the top of the tin with foil.

Return to the oven for 40 minutes more, then take off the foil and bake for another 10-15 minutes, so the nuts can turn golden. Keep an eye on them, so they don’t get too dark. To test the cake mixture is cooked, insert a fine skewer into the cake – if it comes out clean then it's ready. Cool in the tin then turn out, keeping the lining on, and wrap with foil. (The cake will keep for up to 2 weeks or can be frozen for up to 2 months.)
To serve, remove the cake from the foil and strip away the lining. Place on a board or serving plate and tie with a decorative ribbon.
chief_review: This Christmas cake delivers a delightful fusion of classic festive flavors and an indulgent twist reminiscent of a Florentine biscuit. The combination of ground almonds, marzipan, and a medley of nuts brings a rich, nutty depth, while the mixed fruit and glacé cherries impart bursts of sweetness. Ground ginger and cinnamon add subtle warmth, making it truly evocative of the season. The syrup and nut topping lends a glossy, textured finish, ensuring both visual appeal and a pleasing crunch. This cake is ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no gelatine or animal fats beyond dairy and eggs. However, do note that it contains both nuts and gluten, which may not suit all dietary needs. The result is a luxurious, showstopping centrepiece—perfect for holiday gatherings and sure to impress with both flavor and presentation.

name: Creamy cheese & potato bake
description: A comforting cheesy potato bake is the perfect accompaniment to a hearty meat dish in winter
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 1½ kg King Edward potato, Desiree, or similar, peeled
knob of butter, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Boil the potatoes for 3 mins to soften a little, then drain. When cool enough to handle, slice into 5mm pieces. Cook the onion in the butter in a pan until softened, about 5 mins, then pour over the wine, milk and cream and heat through. Place the potato slices into a large bowl, pour over the cream mixture, sage leaves and half the cheese. Carefully stir until the potato slices are coated.

Grease a large baking dish (about 20 x 30cm) with a little butter, then tip the potatoes in. Smooth over the top, scatter over the remaining cheese and season with black pepper. Cover with foil and cook for 30 mins, then uncover and cook 30-40 mins more until a fork slides in easily and the top is golden brown.
chief_review: This cheesy potato bake is an exquisite side dish, boasting layers of tender King Edward potatoes, subtly sweet onion, and aromatic sage. The interplay of white wine, milk, and double cream infuses the bake with a luxurious richness, while Gruyère adds the essential nutty depth and perfect golden crust. The recipe is naturally vegetarian-friendly, making it suitable for those abstaining from meat. With its creamy texture and soothing flavors, it’s an ideal companion to robust winter mains. However, cooks should be mindful of common allergens present—namely dairy (milk, cream, cheese, and butter). Serve piping hot for maximum comfort and indulgence.

name: Devil’s food cupcakes
description: These sponges with a cream cheese topping are light yet wonderfully chocolatey
author: Good Food
ingredients: small handful silver balls or sprinkles, for decoration
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line 2 muffin tins with 16 paper muffin cases. Whisk together 175ml boiling water with the cocoa powder in a medium-sized bowl until smooth. Allow the mixture to cool until it reaches room temperature (put it in the freezer to speed it up), then whisk it with the eggs and vanilla.

In an electric mixer, combine the flour, salt, bicarbonate of soda and sugar. Mix on a low speed for 30 secs, then add one-third of the cocoa liquid and softened butter. Keep mixing on a low speed, then turn up to medium high and beat for 1 min. Add the remaining liquid in 3 batches, beating each one for 30 secs. Scrape the sides and bottom of the bowl with a spatula and mix one more time. Fill the cupcake liners three-quarters full and bake for 20 mins, then remove and let them cool in the tin.

To make the frosting, beat the butter and cream cheese for 2-3 mins until creamy, then add the vanilla. While still mixing, pour in the sugar in 4 batches, beating each time to fully combine. Beat for a further min, then chill for 2 hrs.
Swirl the frosting over the cooled cupcakes and decorate with silver balls or whatever you like.
chief_review:
This recipe produces delightfully light chocolate sponge cakes crowned with a rich cream cheese frosting. The use of cocoa powder and a generous amount of butter creates a tender crumb with intense chocolate notes, balanced beautifully by the tang of cream cheese in the topping. The eggs contribute structure and moisture, elevating the airy texture, while the vanilla adds a fragrant backdrop without overpowering the chocolate. The silver balls or sprinkles provide a festive finish, perfect for celebratory occasions.

This recipe contains both eggs and dairy, and uses wheat flour, making it suitable for a standard vegetarian diet but not for those requiring vegan or gluten-free options. It is also unsuitable for those with dairy or egg allergies. For best results, ensure ingredients are at room temperature before starting, and take care not to overmix the batter to preserve the cake's lightness.

name: Duck & pork terrine with cranberries & pistachios
description: Set aside a couple of hours and enjoy every minute of making this impressive terrine
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2 duck breasts, about 300g/10oz each, skin removed and reserved
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Put the duck breasts and skin in a shallow dish, then place in the hot oven for 20 mins. Discard the shrivelled bit of skin that remains, then pour the duck fat into a bowl to cool. Reserve 6 bacon rashers, then roughly chop the remainder. Roughly chop the cooked duck meat.

In a food processor, blend the chopped bacon, pork and duck in batches to a coarse texture, then tip into a large bowl. Tear up the bread and soak in the milk for 5 mins. Squeeze out the bread and put in the food processor with the shallots, garlic and livers. Process to a coarse texture, then add to the bowl, mixing well.

Grind the peppercorns, coriander seeds and cloves to a coarse powder using a pestle and mortar. Stir in the cinnamon. Add the spices to the meat along with 4 tbsp reserved duck fat, the Cognac, eggs and 2 tsp salt. Mix together very thoroughly – the best way is to use your hands.

Press half the mixture into a 1.5-litre baking dish or similar. Scatter over the pistachios and cranberries, then cover with the remaining meat mixture. Arrange the reserved bacon rashers over the top, tucking in the ends. Cover the dish tightly with foil, then put in a roasting tin. Pour boiling water into the tin to come halfway up the sides of the dish.

Bake for 2 hrs, remove foil, then bake for 15 mins more to brown the top. Cool completely, then wrap in fresh foil and chill. For the best flavour, let the terrine chill and mature for at least 2 days before eating.
TO FREEZE Make the terrine as stated, cool and then freeze. Defrost in the fridge before serving.
chief_review: This luxurious terrine is a tour de force of classic French charcuterie, boasting duck breasts, pork shoulder, bacon, and enriched with duck or chicken livers for a deeply savory profile. Aromatics like shallots, garlic, and an array of warm spices add complexity, while Cognac lends a refined finish. The addition of milk-soaked bread ensures a tender texture, and the contrast of pistachios and dried cranberries brings both crunch and subtle sweetness. Although time intensive, the layering and careful seasoning make for a show-stopping centerpiece, ideal for special occasions or festive gatherings. This recipe does contain eggs, nuts (pistachio), dairy (milk), and gluten (bread), so it may not suit all dietary needs. However, for those seeking an indulgent charcuterie experience with traditional flair, this terrine offers textural nuance, bold flavors, and impressive presentation.

name: Date & red wine sauce
description: This red wine sauce from Gordon Ramsay makes the perfect accompaniment to a Christmas goose
author: Gordon Ramsay
directions: Boil down the chicken stock, red wine, port and balsamic vinegar by two-thirds. Meanwhile, cover the dates with boiling water, leave for 5 mins and then drain. Strain the reduced stock and return to the pan with the soaked dates. Simmer sauce for 3-5 mins, then check seasoning and keep warm.
chief_review: This red wine sauce delivers a rich, complex accompaniment perfect for elevating the flavors of Christmas goose. The combination of chicken stock, red wine, and port provides depth, while balsamic vinegar adds a striking acidity that balances the sweetness from the dates. The result is a harmonious sauce with a glossy finish and an appealing mix of sweet, savory, and tangy notes. This recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those avoiding gluten. Additionally, it's an excellent choice for those following a dairy-free diet, as no milk or cream is included. The sauce’s luxurious texture and sophisticated flavor profile would also pair beautifully with other roasted meats or root vegetables, making it a versatile addition to any festive table.

name: Millionaire’s ice cream bombe
description: Made this for Xmas day 2017, only just getting round to posting. It turned out really well and looked amazing!
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 200g dulce de leche or Carnation caramel
300g caramel or vanilla ice cream(not soft-serve)
directions: Line a 1.2-litre pudding bowl with a double layer of cling film, leaving plenty overhanging, and make a space for the bowl in the freezer. Put the biscuits in a food processor and blitz until they resemble fine crumbs. Add the butter and 2 tbsp caramel, and blend until well mixed. Save about 3 tbsp for the top and tip the rest into the lined pudding bowl. Use the back of a spoon to press evenly over the base and up the sides of the bowl. Freeze for 30 mins.

Remove the chocolate ice cream from the freezer and allow it to soften at room temperature for 10 mins. Remove the pudding bowl from the freezer too (the biscuits should be firm by now.) Spoon the ice cream into the biscuit- lined bowl, packing it into the base. Spoon over the remaining caramel, spreading it to the biscuit walls. Return to the freezer for 30 mins.

Remove the caramel ice cream and allow it to soften for 10 mins. Meanwhile, tip 75g Maltesers into a bowl and lighty crush with the end of a rolling pin, leaving some chunky bits. Add the ice cream to the bowl and stir through the Malteser pieces – work quickly so the ice cream doesn’t melt too much. Remove the pudding bowl from the freezer and tip in the Malteser ice cream, spreading it to completely fill the bowl, then level the top. Scatter with the remaining biscuit crumbs. Return to the freezer for at least 4 hrs (or for up to 2 weeks).

Put the cream in a pan and heat until steaming hot but not boiling. Put the chocolate in a large bowl and pour over the cream. Leave to stand for 1-2 mins, then stir to make a smooth ganache. Set aside to cool until the sauce thickens to a spreadable consistency (you can speed this up by putting it in the fridge, but remember to stir it every 5-10 mins or it will set around the edges).

Remove the pudding bowl from the freezer. Turn it onto a plate and remove the bowl and cling film. Spread half the chocolate ganache all over the pudding and, as quickly as you can, stick the remaining Maltesers all over the surface – this is easiest if you start around the bottom and work your way up in layers. The chocolate ganache will start to set, so use a little more from the bowl to make the Maltesers stick. Once covered, return to the freezer for at least a further 4 hrs (or for up to 3 days), removing it 10 mins before serving. Top with a dusting of icing sugar and a sprig of holly, if you like.
chief_review: This indulgent dessert is a true showstopper, perfect for festive occasions. The combination of a buttery digestive biscuit base, rich caramel, layers of creamy chocolate and caramel (or vanilla) ice cream, and the delightful crunch of Maltesers creates an irresistible medley of textures and flavors. Topping it off with double cream and dark chocolate adds a luscious finish, while optional holly and a dusting of icing sugar provide an elegant holiday touch. The recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat, fish, or gelatin-based ingredients. Keep in mind, however, that it includes dairy, gluten, and possibly nuts (depending on the brand of the ingredients used), so it may not be appropriate for those with related allergies or dietary restrictions. Overall, a visually stunning and crowd-pleasing treat, sure to impress your guests.

name: Mustard chicken with winter vegetables
description: This is a great way to make a chicken go further, and the mustard gives it that little kick
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 3 small turnips, peeled and cut into wedges
directions: Put the chicken in a large pot. Halve 1 onion, 1 celery stick and 1 carrot. Add to the pot with the herbs, peppercorns and a sprinkling of salt. Add water to come halfway up the chicken, bring to the boil, then cover tightly and simmer for 1½ hrs. Cool slightly, remove the chicken to a dish, then strain the stock into a bowl.
When the chicken is cool enough to handle, strip the meat from the bones and tear into pieces with your hands.

Chop the remaining onion, and cut the celery and carrots into thick slices. Heat the butter in the same pot, add the onion and lardons, then gently fry for 5 mins until just starting to brown. Add the remaining veg, then fry for 2 mins. Stir in the flour, then cook for 1 min. Measure 900ml stock (if you don’t have enough, make it up with water), then gradually add to the pan, stirring. Cover, then simmer for 20-25 mins until vegetables are tender.
Return the chicken to the pan with the mustard and crème fraîche, then return to a simmer, stirring gently. Season and sprinkle with parsley.
chief_review: This recipe is a rustic, family-style dish that brilliantly stretches a whole chicken into a hearty, flavor-packed meal. The addition of smoked bacon lardons deepens the savory base, while the medley of vegetables provides natural sweetness and earthiness. Wholegrain mustard and crème fraîche lend a creamy tang, elevating the sauce and balancing the richness. As a chef, I appreciate the layered aromatics from fresh thyme, bay leaves, and parsley—these herbs impart freshness to the finished dish. With its inclusion of flour and dairy, this recipe is best suited to those without gluten or lactose sensitivities. It’s a fantastic choice for a comforting weekend meal, easy to serve at the table for communal enjoyment. The technique is straightforward, ensuring robust flavors with minimal fuss. A classic, well-executed chicken dish.

name: Bread sauce
description: Super easy and very tasty. It freezes fine. Easily makes enough for 8 people. Mascarpone cheese option is super rich and delicious, have not tried the cream version.
author: Good Food
directions: Simmer the milk, butter, onion, cloves, peppercorns, garlic and herbs in a pan for 20 mins. Strain and return the liquid to the pan. Add the breadcrumbs and simmer for 3-4 mins. Stir in the cream or mascarpone. Add nutmeg, season and serve. Can be made up to 3 days in advance and heated up on the hob or microwave on Medium for 3 mins.
chief_review: This recipe is a classic, comforting bread sauce, elevated by aromatic infusions of clove, peppercorn, bay, and thyme. The method of steeping milk with whole spices and aromatics ensures deep flavor, while the richness from butter, cream, or mascarpone brings a luxurious finish. Opting for mascarpone creates an especially luscious texture—perfect for those who enjoy a decadent side. The use of white breadcrumbs to thicken the sauce makes this dish suitable for a vegetarian diet. It also caters to nut allergies, barring any cross-contamination in the kitchen. This bread sauce pairs wonderfully with roasted vegetables or as a traditional accompaniment to a celebratory main course and can be made ahead and frozen, making it a superb choice for stress-free entertaining. A warming hint of nutmeg rounds out the seasoning beautifully—a simple yet sophisticated addition to any meal.

name: Sticky ginger pear pudding
description: A great last-minute alternative to a traditional Christmas pudding - plus it reheats in only five minutes
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 175g dark muscovado sugar, plus 1 tsp extra
100g butter, plus lots extra for greasing
directions: Put the syrup, sugar and milk into a saucepan, then bring to a simmer to dissolve. Leave to cool almost completely while you get on with everything else. Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4.

Put the butter, flour, bicarb, ground ginger and cinnamon into a food processor, then pulse until it forms fine crumbs. Generously butter a 1.4-litre pudding basin and sprinkle 1 tsp sugar into the bottom. Cut 3 of the ginger balls in half and put 5 halves, rounded-side down, into the bottom, like the points of a star. Cut one cheek from a pear, then slice through about 10 times, without cutting through the stalk end. Put this into the bottom of the bowl amongst the ginger, then press gently so that the pear fans out. Core, then thinly slice the remaining pear. Finely chop the rest of the ginger.

Tip the cooled syrup mix and egg into a food processor, then quickly whizz with the dry ingredients to a batter. Take out the blade, then stir in the chopped ginger and sliced pear. Scrape the mix into the basin, then bake for 1 hr 20 mins until risen and dark golden, and a skewer comes out clean. Whatever you do, don’t open the oven before 45 mins is up.

To finish, gently melt the syrup ingredients in a pan together until the sugar dissolves, then boil briefly. Turn the pudding out of its basin just before serving, spoon over the syrup and serve with custard.
chief_review: This quick ginger and pear pudding is a delightful twist on the classic Christmas dessert. The blend of golden syrup, dark muscovado sugar, and stem ginger creates a rich, warming sweetness, while the addition of ripe pears adds a tender, fruity note. Aromatic spices like ginger and cinnamon evoke festive comfort with every bite, and the final touch of ginger syrup and brandy gives the dish a luxurious, grown-up finish. Served with custard, this pudding is decadently moist and comforting. It's a great choice for vegetarians and can be enjoyed by those seeking a nut-free dessert option, provided all processed ingredients are confirmed nut-free. With its quick reheating time, it’s ideal for busy holiday meals without compromising on flavor or texture.

name: Layered squash, barley & spinach pie
description: A spectacular veggie Christmas centrepiece - when sliced, it looks stunning, and the flavours go brilliantly with all your favourite trimmings
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 small butternut squash(about 1kg/2lb 4oz), peeled and cubed
3 tbsp olive oil, plus a little extra for brushing
½ x 20g/1oz pack sage, leaves picked and chopped
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and roast the butternut squash with 1 tbsp oil for 25-30 mins until tender, then set aside.

Meanwhile, heat remaining oil in a large pan and cook the onions and garlic for 10 mins until soft. Remove two-thirds, then add the mushrooms, chestnuts and pearl barley to the pan. Sizzle for a few mins, pour in the stock, then bring to the boil. Bubble fiercely for 30 mins until the barley is tender and sticky and there is no liquid left. Stir in the soy sauce, season and set aside.

While the barley layer is cooking, make the other layers. Stir the zest, ricotta, soft cheese and a good amount of seasoning into the reserved onions until smooth. Take a third of the mixture and gently fold with the sage and roasted squash. For the final layer, boil the kettle, then tip half the spinach into a large colander. Pour over the boiling water to wilt, then repeat with the rest of the spinach. Tip the spinach onto a clean tea towel and squeeze out all the moisture you can. Roughly chop, then mix into the remaining ricotta mixture with the parsley.

To make the pie, brush a 900g loaf tin with a little oil. Make 3 long triplelayer strips of foil and lay these across the width of the tin to help you lift out the pie to serve. Tip flour and 3 tsp salt into the largest bowl you have and gently melt the butter, shortening and milk with 200ml water in a pan. Once melted, increase heat until bubbling fiercely, tip onto the flour, then quickly beat with a wooden spoon until combined. Don’t worry if some powdery bits remain. Once cool enough to handle, knead until it comes together, then tip onto your work surface. Set aside a third and roll the rest into a large rectangle – big enough to line the tin with a little overhanging.

Ease into the tin, pressing evenly into the corners and sides – you can be rough with it. Spoon in the spinach layer, smooth the surface, then repeat with the barley and finally the squash layer. Dome the squash mix slightly to give a rounded top. Roll out the remaining pastry to fit, brush the edges with some egg, then press the lid over the top. Trim the excess and crimp or pinch to seal, then decorate with pastry trimmings cut into leaves (add bay leaves, if using, when the pie has 30 mins left in the oven). Can be covered and chilled overnight.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and put a large baking sheet inside. Brush the surface of the pie with egg, lift onto the heated baking tray and bake for 30 mins, then reduce the heat to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4 and bake for a further 1 hr 30 mins until the pastry is golden brown and feels hard. Stand for 15-20 mins while you get the rest of the meal ready – the pie will stay warm. Gently tip out the pie, or use the foil strips to lift out carefully. Carry to the table and slice thickly to serve.
chief_review: This vegetable centrepiece is a true festive showstopper, showcasing vibrant flavours and a beautiful layered presentation. The combination of butternut squash, mushrooms, chestnuts, and pearl barley creates a hearty, satisfying filling with lovely earthy notes, perfectly balanced by lemon zest and fresh herbs. Ricotta and full-fat soft cheese bring creaminess, while the homemade pastry adds a deliciously tender, golden crust. This dish is ideal for vegetarians, making it a standout main for Christmas or any special occasion. Additionally, it’s nut-free (with chestnuts generally considered safe for common nut allergies, but always check individual sensitivities) and can be adapted for lacto-vegetarians. Featuring wholesome vegetables and aromatic herbs, it pairs seamlessly with classic holiday sides. A wonderful centrepiece that will impress both in taste and appearance.

name: Turkey crown with roast garlic & pancetta
description: Just made it for Easter. It was a huge success, but i needed a good extra 1/2 hour on the oven. Love the roasted lemons on the side of the turkey.
author: Good Food
ingredients: about 10 thin slices streaky bacon or pancetta
4 tbsp olive oil, plus extra to drizzle
1 small loaf ciabatta, to give 280g/10oz breadcrumbs
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Rinse the turkey then pat dry with kitchen paper. Weigh it to calculate the cooking time, allowing 20 mins per kg, plus 70 mins (or 90 mins when roasting a crown over 4kg). Sit the turkey on a board, very lightly rub all over with olive oil and season with pepper. Lay the pancetta or streaky bacon over the top of the turkey, slightly overlapping to cover it. Tuck the slices under the bird to secure at the bottom. Insert small rosemary sprigs haphazardly between the slices. Season with pepper. Tie the crown across in 2-3 places with butcher’s string, to hold the shape together. Put the onion wedges in the middle of a large roasting tin and sit the crown on top. Cover the turkey with a loose tent of foil, then roast following your calculated time.

Make the stuffing. Heat 3 tbsp of the oil in a large frying pan. Tip in the onions and garlic, and fry for 5-8 mins until softened and starting to turn golden. Push the onions to one side of the pan, then add the pine nuts and continue to fry for 1 min more, stirring the nuts until golden. Remove from the heat and cool slightly. Stir in the remaining oil, all but a small handful of the Parmesan and the remaining stuffing ingredients. Season with salt and pepper. Loosely spoon stuffing mixture (don’t pack it down) into an oiled ovenproof dish, drizzle with a little extra olive oil, sprinkle with remaining Parmesan, then lay a sheet of baking parchment on top. Set aside. Can be made 1 day ahead and chilled.

Thirty mins before the end of the cooking time, remove the turkey and increase oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. If you are roasting potatoes put them in now. Roast the garlic. Remove the foil, place the garlic halves and lemon wedges around the turkey, then baste them and the turkey with the cooking juices. Return the tin to the oven and continue to roast for the final 30 mins. To test if cooked, pierce the fattest part of the crown with a skewer – the juices should run clear, not pink. If they are pink, continue to roast, checking at 10 min intervals.

Remove the turkey, garlic and lemon from the oven, transfer to a warm serving platter and rest, covered loosely with foil, for 30 mins before carving. Meanwhile, increase oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the stuffing in the oven and bake for 20 mins, then remove the paper and bake for a further 5 mins until the stuffing is golden.

Make the gravy. Pour off any excess fat from the roasting tin but leave the juices and onions. Stir all the sticky bits from the bottom of the tin into the juices. Set tin over a medium heat, add the flour and cook, stirring continuously, for 2 mins. Pour in the Marsala and simmer for 2 mins. Pour in the stock, bring to the boil, then simmer for 5-10 mins or until reduced to your liking. Season with pepper if needed. Strain the gravy into a pan, warm through, then pour into a jug. Serve the turkey garnished with rosemary sprigs, surrounded with the roasted garlic and lemon, and accompanied by the gravy and stuffing.
chief_review: This turkey crown recipe embraces traditional flavors with a Mediterranean twist, thanks to the pancetta, fresh herbs, and the savory touch of roasted lemons. The use of olive oil, pine nuts, and ciabatta breadcrumbs in the stuffing brings a lovely depth and texture, while grated Parmesan enhances the richness. The inclusion of Marsala wine elevates the gravy, complementing the succulent bird perfectly. As a chef, I appreciate the additional aromatics—whole bulbs of garlic and plenty of rosemary—that permeate the turkey and ensure a fragrant result. For those following a nut-free or gluten-free diet, modifications would be needed due to the pine nuts and ciabatta. Similarly, vegetarians and vegans would need significant substitutions. Overall, it’s an impressive and flavor-forward centerpiece perfect for festive occasions, especially when given a generous oven time to achieve proper doneness.

name: Traditional mincemeat
description: Try making your mincemeat well in advance of Christmas to give the flavours maximum time to mature
author: James Martin
ingredients: zest of 1 lemon, juice of ½
1 large Bramley apple, peeled and grated
directions: Soak the raisins and currants in the brandy and lemon juice for 1 hr until plumped up, then drain and set the brandy aside. Mix all the ingredients together in the order given, then pour in the brandy when everything else is well mixed. Spoon and press into sterilised jars, to exclude any air (the easiest way to sterilise jars is to run them through a dishwasher on its hottest setting). Cover and leave for at least a fortnight. Will keep in the fridge for up to 6 months.
chief_review: This traditional mincemeat recipe is a classic, brimming with rich dried fruits, warming spices, and the deep aroma of brandy. Allowing the mixture to mature before Christmas truly intensifies the flavors, creating a complex and fragrant preserve ideal for festive baking. Using shredded suet gives the mixture an authentic texture and richness; however, note that most suet contains beef fat, making it unsuitable for vegans and vegetarians unless a vegetarian suet is substituted. The ingredient list is naturally free of gluten, dairy, nuts, and eggs, making it a versatile choice for those with common allergies or intolerance concerns (do verify ingredient sources, especially mixed peel and suet, for hidden allergens). A winning recipe for holiday preparations, this mincemeat delivers on both tradition and flavor.

name: Potage Dubarry with crisp chorizo (Creamy cauliflower soup)
description: Crisp little florets and salty, spicy chorizo contrast wonderfully with this creamy cauliflower soup
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Set aside two handfuls of small cauliflower florets. Heat the butter in a large pan, add the shallots and gently fry until soft but not brown. Add the cauliflower, potatoes, milk and stock. Season and bring to the boil, then reduce the heat, cover and gently simmer for 15-20 mins until the vegetables are tender. Purée until smooth either with a stick blender or in a food processor (you will need to do this in batches). Return to the pan and add the cream. Warm through and add more seasoning if necessary.

Heat the oil in a pan, add the reserved cauliflower florets and fry until brown and starting to soften. Add a splash of water, cover and cook for a further 1-2 mins until just tender. Tip the cauliflower into a bowl. Add the chorizo to the pan and fry quickly on each side until crisp. Drain on kitchen paper.
Serve the soup in bowls with a small pile of crisp cauliflower in the centre, topped with a couple of slices of chorizo and scattered with coriander.
chief_review: This cauliflower soup strikes a beautiful balance between velvety creaminess and robust flavor. The gentle sweetness of shallots and potatoes blends seamlessly with the cauliflower base, while a duet of milk and double cream provides a luxurious texture. Chorizo adds a smoky, spicy punch, delivering savory depth and a satisfying contrast to the delicate soup. A drizzle of olive oil and fresh coriander offer bright finishing touches. This dish suits a gluten-free diet, as well as being nut-free, given the listed ingredients. It's an excellent example of how simple, well-chosen ingredients create harmonious layers of taste and texture. Perfect as a comforting starter or a light main, especially on cooler days.

name: Lemon meringue cupcakes
description: These mini meringues will bring a touch of zing to your party, and can be made one day ahead for extra ease
author: Good Food
ingredients: zest 2 lemons, plus 2-3 tbsp lemon juice
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Beat half the sugar and all the butter until pale, then add whole eggs, one by one, beating in well each time. Stir in the zest and a squeeze of lemon juice, then fold in flour. Check the batter’s consistency; it should softly drop off the end of a spoon. Add more lemon juice if it’s a bit stiff.

Line a 12-hole bun tin with cake cases and put 1 large tbsp mix in each. Smooth then make a little dip in the centre. Spoon 1 tsp lemon curd into each dip and cover with 1 tbsp cake mix. Bake for 10 mins.

Meanwhile, place the egg whites into a clean bowl, whisk until stiff peaks form, then whisk in the rest of the sugar a tbsp at a time. Keep whisking until the mixture looks glossy and has thickened a little, like shaving foam. Spoon the mixture into a freezer bag and snip off the end to leave a hole with a 1.5cm diameter.

Take the cakes out of the oven – tops should be very pale and just firm – then pipe meringue all over the cakes. Return to the oven for 10-15 mins until the cakes are cooked through and meringue lightly browned. Can be made 1 day ahead.
chief_review:
These mini meringues are a delightful fusion of crisp, airy sweetness and bright, zesty lemon flavor—perfect for enlivening any party table. The recipe cleverly layers soft, buttery sponge with tangy lemon curd and crisp meringue, offering a satisfying contrast in textures. Preparation is straightforward and convenient, as these can be made ahead of time without compromising taste or texture. 

Vegetarians will appreciate that this recipe is free of meat and gelatin, relying solely on eggs for structure and lift. However, as the inclusion of both wheat flour and eggs precludes those with gluten or egg allergies, it’s best suited for those without dietary restrictions in these areas. The generous use of lemon juice and zest elevates these bites, making them a refreshing and memorable treat for citrus lovers.

name: Olive oil-baked potatoes
description: Crispy, moreish baked potatoes cooked with just olive oil and salt, by Gary Rhodes
author: Gary Rhodes
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Scrub the baking potatoes, then pat dry. Slice lengthways into three. Drizzle olive oil over a large baking sheet. Place the potatoes on the baking sheet, drizzle with olive oil, rub all over, then generously sprinkle with sea salt. Bake for 40-45 mins (longer for extra crispiness) turning halfway, until golden brown and tender.
chief_review: Gary Rhodes’ take on baked potatoes is a masterclass in simplicity, highlighting the naturally earthy flavor of good potatoes. Olive oil and sea salt work in tandem to create a thin, gorgeously crispy skin, while the interior remains perfectly fluffy. The technique is straightforward, making it accessible even for novice cooks, and the recipe relies on pantry staples rather than dairy or animal products. These potatoes are inherently vegan, gluten-free, and nut-free, accommodating a wide range of dietary needs. For best results, ensure each potato is generously coated with olive oil and salt before baking, elevating both taste and texture. Ideal as a side or a base for creative toppings, these baked potatoes embody comfort—pure and uncomplicated.

name: Maple crunch ice cream
description: A super-simple ice cream which goes gorgeously with warm puddings and cake
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 4 tbsp maple syrup (strength 2, if you have the option)
directions: Stir the vanilla into the condensed milk in a large bowl. Lightly whip the cream until it just holds its shape, then fold into the condensed milk using a metal spoon. Spoon into a 1-litre freezer-proof container and freeze for about 3 hrs, until softly frozen. This mix won’t crystallise at the edges like most ice creams.

Working quickly, ruffle up the mix, pour over the syrup and the crushed caramels, then give another quick swirl. Freeze for another 4 hrs or ideally overnight until firm. Will freeze for up to 1 month.
chief_review: This ice cream recipe is a delightful indulgence, perfect for pairing with warm desserts. The combination of vanilla, maple syrup, and crushed Werther’s Originals gives it a rich, caramel flavor with a smooth, creamy base from the double cream and condensed milk. It’s extremely easy to assemble, requiring no churning, making it ideal for novice home cooks or those short on time. The texture is luxuriously soft and the sweetness is well-balanced by the salted caramel notes from the Werther’s. Since it doesn't require eggs, it's suitable for those avoiding eggs in their diet, but not suitable for vegans or anyone with dairy allergies. Serve it atop a warm brownie or apple crumble for an unforgettable dessert experience.

name: Bramley apple sauce
description: A great accompaniment to rich meats such as goose or pork
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 3 Bramley apples, peeled, cored and sliced
directions: Tip all the ingredients into a pan, then cover with a lid. Place the pan on a low heat, stirring occasionally, for about 15 mins until the apples break down into a purée. Stir to knock out any lumps, then tip into a serving dish.
chief_review: This simple apple sauce recipe is a classic complement for rich meats like goose or pork, balancing out their savory depth with a bright touch of acidity and sweetness. The Bramley apples, renowned for their tartness, break down beautifully during cooking, resulting in a velvety-smooth texture. The addition of caster sugar elevates the apples’ natural sweetness, while butter adds a luxurious mouthfeel and richness. This dish is naturally vegetarian and gluten-free, making it accessible for guests with these dietary preferences. For best results, cook the apples gently to preserve their flavor and achieve a silky sauce. An excellent staple for autumnal roasts or festive gatherings.

name: Raspberry cranachan trifle
description: A twist on the Scottish classic, with crunchy flapjack-style toasted oats
author: Good Food
directions: First, make the crunchy oats. Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Melt the butter and honey in a large saucepan, then stir in the other ingredients until everything is well coated. Spread out on a baking sheet, then bake for 20 mins until crisp. Cool, crumble into pieces, then set aside. Can be stored in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

For the whisky cream, beat both pots of double cream with the mascarpone, icing sugar and whisky until it is smooth and holds soft peaks. In a separate bowl, stir a couple tbsps icing sugar into the raspberries to taste.

To assemble, spoon some raspberries in the bottom of a glass bowl, followed by a layer of cream and a layer of oats. Repeat 2-3 times, depending on your bowl size, saving the final layer of oats to scatter over before serving with a dusting of icing sugar.
chief_review:
This innovative take on the Scottish classic Cranachan offers a charming blend of creamy mascarpone, sharp whisky-soaked raspberries, and crunchy flapjack-style oats elevated by toasted hazelnuts. The rich double cream and mascarpone provide an indulgent texture, balancing beautifully against tart raspberries and fragrant honey. The addition of hazelnuts adds delightful depth and crunch, enhancing the oaty layer.

With its absence of meat, this dessert is ideal for a vegetarian audience, provided the honey aligns with individual dietary preferences. However, those with nut allergies or gluten intolerance should be aware of the inclusion of hazelnuts and plain flour. Overall, the dish achieves a sophisticated harmony between creamy, crunchy, and fruity elements, making it a standout dessert for special occasions or festive gatherings. The whisky infusion rounds out the flavors with a quintessentially Scottish note.

name: Squidgy chocolate pear pudding
description: When you don't have much time, but you want (need) something sweet.
author: Justine Pattison
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Lightly grease a roughly 20 x 30cm shallow ovenproof dish. Put the butter in a large saucepan and place over a low heat until just melted. Remove the butter from the heat and stir in the sugar until well combined.

Whisk the eggs together in a large bowl. Gradually add the eggs to the butter and sugar, beating well with a wooden spoon in between each addition. Sift the flour and cocoa powder on top of the egg mixture, then beat hard with a wooden spoon until thoroughly combined.
