This recipe combines classic shortbread with a decadent, crunchy topping of golden syrup, flaked almonds, glacé cherries, and dark chocolate—an irresistible combination for lovers of British baking. The halved cherries add vibrance and visual appeal, while the cinnamon in the base lends subtle warmth, perfectly complementing the buttery, crumbly texture.

Vegetarians will appreciate that the recipe contains no gelatine or animal-derived fats besides dairy. However, those with nut allergies should steer clear due to the flaked almonds, and the use of wheat flour means it’s not gluten free. The recommendation to triple the topping underscores its appeal—its gooey, almond-studded richness is the true star here. Finishing with generous shards of dark chocolate provides a lovely bittersweet edge, balancing the sweetness of the syrup and cherries. This treat is perfect for afternoon tea or a showstopping dessert platter.

name: Peppered mackerel & pink pickled onion salad
description: Made this as a starter over the Christmas period and it was absolutely gorgeous. Wouldn't change the recipe one bit.
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 240g pack peppered smoked mackerel, torn into pieces
1 small red onion, very thinly sliced
directions: Mix together the onion, vinegar, sugar and a pinch of salt. Leave to pickle while you dice the beetroot and roughly chop the nuts.

Divide the watercress and smoked mackerel between six plates. Scatter over the beetroot and nuts, then top with a cluster of the pickled onions. Whisk the oil into the pickling vinegar, then drizzle the dressing around the outside of each plate.
chief_review: This festive starter impresses both in flavor and presentation. The peppered smoked mackerel provides a punchy, rich base, complemented by earthy beetroot and the fresh, peppery bite of watercress. Honey-roasted mixed nuts lend welcome crunch and a subtle sweetness, balancing the fish's intensity. The sherry vinegar dressing, brightened with a pinch of sugar, harmonizes the dish beautifully, while thin red onion slices add just the right sharpness. All components come together for a lively, well-composed starter that excites the palate—perfect for kickstarting a celebratory meal. This salad is ideal for pescatarians and is gluten free, provided the nuts are not processed with gluten-containing ingredients. Simple but impressive, it’s a dish that showcases how quality ingredients can deliver maximum flavor with minimal effort.

name: Beetroot blinis with smoked salmon
description: Top light, homemade blinis with cream cheese and smoked fish for a pretty and elegant canapé - a perfect party nibble
author: Miriam Nice
directions: To make the blini batter, blend the cooked beetroot and Greek yogurt with a stick blender until smooth. Whisk in the eggs, bicarbonate of soda and self-raising flour.

Drop teaspoonfuls of the mixture into a hot non-stick pan. Turn over when small bubbles start to form on the surface of each, then cook for about 30 secs and transfer to a wire rack. Repeat until all the batter is used up. Can be made a day ahead and kept in an airtight container.
Spread each blini with a little cream cheese and season with salt and black pepper. Top with smoked salmon trimmings and sprigs of dill.
chief_review: This recipe creates vibrant, tender beetroot blinis topped with luscious cream cheese, smoky salmon, and fresh dill—a classic combination that shines as a sophisticated canapé. The blinis, enriched with Greek yogurt and eggs, deliver a moist, fluffy bite with an appealing earthiness from the beetroot. Cream cheese adds rich contrast, while the smoked salmon brings a pleasing depth; dill ties the flavors with a herbal freshness. Vegetarian adaptations could substitute the smoked salmon with grilled vegetables or a vegan smoked alternative, and gluten-free self-raising flour can replace the standard variety for coeliacs. Lactose-intolerant diners may use dairy-free yogurt and cream cheese. Overall, this elegant bite is sure to impress at gatherings, balancing taste, texture, and visual appeal beautifully.

name: Leftover turkey casserole
description: This one pot stew uses up all your roast dinner leftovers in one go and has a great honey mustard tang
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 tsp dried sage, or 5 sage leaves, chopped
about 350g leftover roasted vegetables like roast potatoes, parsnips, celeriacs and carrots, chunkily diced
directions: Fry the onion and apple in the oil until softened in a casserole or deep pan. Stir in the sage for 1 min, then stir in the flour. Gradually stir in the stock followed by the mustard and honey.
Bring up to a simmer and stir in the turkey and roast veg. Cover and gently simmer for 15 mins until turkey is piping hot. Season and eat with mash or jacket potatoes.
chief_review: This leftover roast dinner stew is a clever and sustainable solution for using up post-holiday ingredients. The blend of honey and wholegrain mustard delivers a vibrant tang that enhances the naturally sweet and aromatic notes of onions, sage, and apple. The use of turkey and roasted root vegetables offers depth and familiar comfort, while olive oil and a well-chosen stock provide satisfying body. With its one-pot approach, this dish is straightforward yet full of character, making it ideal for a cozy meal. The recipe is well-suited for those following a dairy-free diet, as there are no milk-based products used. However, those with gluten sensitivities should note that plain flour is an ingredient—this could easily be substituted for a gluten-free flour if needed. Overall, an efficient and flavorful way to reimagine leftovers into a nourishing new dish.

name: Festive spice
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Combine all ingredients in a bowl and mix.
Now you can use the spice mix in other recipes, including our
, or a fluffy
for frosting your cakes with.
chief_review: This aromatic spice blend delivers a warm, complex profile balanced by bright citrus notes from fresh orange and lemon zest. The combination of cinnamon, coriander, nutmeg, ginger, and cloves offers depth and a hint of sweetness, making it perfect for both sweet and savory dishes. A touch of light brown sugar and sea salt enhances the overall flavor harmony. This versatile mix suits vegetarian and vegan diets, as it contains no animal products. Additionally, with all ingredients being naturally gluten-free, this blend is safe for gluten-sensitive individuals. There are no common food allergens present, making it suitable for most dietary needs. Ideal as a rub for roasted vegetables, a flavor boost for oatmeal, or an enhancement to baked goods, this spice mix is a pantry must-have for adventurous cooks seeking vibrant, well-rounded flavors.

name: Healthy roast turkey crown
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 3 oranges, 1 cut into wedges, ½ sliced, 1 ½ juiced
1 tbsp runny honey, plus extra for drizzling
handful thyme sprigs, leaves picked from one, two left whole, plus sprigs to serve (optional)
500g carrots, peeled and cut into long batons
500g parsnips, peeled and cut into long batons
directions: Take your turkey crown out of the fridge 1-2 hrs before you want to cook it. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut 4 slices from one of the oranges. Juice the rest of it along with another of the oranges. In a small bowl, stir the orange juice together with the honey and the picked thyme leaves, the soy sauce and a good grinding of black pepper.

Loosen the skin over the turkey breast. Place two slices of orange, a bay leaf and thyme sprig under the skin, on both sides of the breast, then spoon in some of the juice mix and smooth the skin back over. Tip the orange wedges into a roomy roasting tin with the carrots and parsnips. Nestle the crown amongst the vegetables and oranges. Drizzle over about a third of the remaining orange juice mix and roast everything in the oven for 30 mins. Remove, give the veg a stir and drizzle over another third of the juice mix, then return to the oven and do that again one more time, roasting the turkey for a total of 1hr 30 mins (covering with foil halfway through if it begins to colour too much).

Remove the turkey from the roasting tin and place on a board covered with foil, then turn the oven up to 220C/200C fan/gas 8. Toss the veg in a drizzle of honey and put the tin back in the oven to caramelise the veg for 25-30 mins, leaving the turkey crown to rest. Serve the crown on a platter surrounded by the glazed roots, orange wedges and extra thyme sprigs, if you like. Remove the sticky skin from the breast before
to serve as a side.
chief_review:
This roasted turkey crown recipe marries citrus brightness with earthy root vegetables, making it a wonderful centerpiece for festive occasions. The orange juice and honey create a sweet, tangy glaze that caramelizes beautifully in the oven, complimented by fresh thyme and bay for aromatic depth. The addition of soy sauce brings a subtle umami note, enhancing the savory richness of the turkey. Carrots and parsnips roast alongside, absorbing the flavors from the drippings and providing a naturally sweet, tender accompaniment.

The absence of dairy and gluten-containing ingredients makes this dish suitable for gluten-free diets when a certified gluten-free soy sauce is used. It's also well-suited for those following a dairy-free diet. However, always check ingredient labels in case of sensitivity or allergies, particularly with soy sauce. In sum, this recipe offers a balanced, flavorful roast, perfect for a gathering or celebratory meal.

name: Sausage nut stuffing cake
description: This basic stuffing recipe is really versatile, you can shape into small balls and cook around the bird or make one fabulous looking cake
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 50g roughly chopped walnuts, plus extra to serve
1 tbsp chopped sage leaves, or 1 tsp dried
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Have ready an 18-20cm springform cake tin. Heat the oil and butter and gently fry the shallots and celery for 5 mins without colouring them. Tip into a bowl and add the breadcrumbs, sausagemeat, walnuts, orange zest and sage. Add plenty of pepper and a little salt, if using, and mix together with your hands. Add the egg, then mix well.

Arrange the bacon slices in the tin, leaving 5cm strip on the base, then lay them up around the sides of the tin and let the excess hang over the edge. Carefully fill the tin with the stuffing mix, levelling it on top. Fold the bacon over the top of the stuffing, gathering and twisting the ends loosely in the centre. Scatter over the remaining walnuts, pressing them in slightly.

Set the tin on a baking sheet to catch any juices that escape, then bake for 40-45 mins until the top is golden. Cool in the tin for 10 mins, then remove onto a serving plate and scatter with parsley. Cut into wedges to serve.
chief_review: This stuffing recipe impresses with its balance of savory sausagemeat, aromatic herbs, and a hint of citrus zest. The addition of walnuts introduces a pleasant crunch and depth, while the bacon wrapping ensures each portion remains succulent. Using olive oil and butter lends a rich mouthfeel, elevated by the freshness of chopped parsley just before serving. The versatility to shape into balls or bake as a 'cake' adapts well to your presentation needs. This recipe suits those following a nut-enriched, protein-forward diet and is a delightful choice for festive or special occasion meals. However, note the inclusion of gluten (breadcrumbs) and animal products, making it unsuitable for gluten-free, vegetarian, or vegan diets, and it may not be appropriate for those with nut allergies. Overall, it’s a classic, flavorful stuffing that delivers both in taste and texture.

name: Braised chestnuts, apples & Brussels sprouts
description: This is a huge hit with the kids, and they often ask for it when are having sausages. I have to say I was sceptical about the apples with the sprouts but it works
author: Raymond Blanc
ingredients: 400g raw peeled chestnut(or frozen raw peeled chestnuts, defrosted)
1 celery stick, cut into 1cm/½ in slices
1 Braeburn apple(about 100g/4oz), skin on, cored and cut into 8 segments
directions: Heat the butter in a medium saucepan on a low heat. Add the chestnuts, celery and apple, and cook gently for 4 mins. Pour in the stock, bring to the boil and season with 1 tsp fine sea salt, 2 pinches freshly ground white pepper, the sugar and lemon juice. Cover and cook on a low heat (so that the bubbles are just breaking the surface) for 20-25 mins until soft and melting.
Meanwhile, blanch the sprouts in boiling salted water for 6 mins, then drain well. Add the sprouts to the chestnut pan, sizzle for 5 mins, then tip into a serving dish.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful medley, bringing together the earthy sweetness of chestnuts and apples with the robust bite of Brussels sprouts. The addition of unsalted butter ensures a rich, indulgent finish, while celery and a touch of golden caster sugar add freshness and just enough sweetness to balance any bitterness from the sprouts. The apple is a surprising but successful element, lending a subtle fruitiness that harmonizes well with sausages—a perfect accompaniment. The use of chicken stock as an option makes the dish flexible, but it’s easily made vegetarian by choosing water as the liquid. This side is suitable for vegetarian diets (when water is used) and is naturally gluten-free, making it an inclusive addition to festive tables or family dinners. The combination of texture and flavor elevates the humble sprout, creating a dish even skeptics will enjoy.

name: Creamy lemon, pancetta & rosemary turkey
description: For a perfectly moist and succulent turkey, follow Emma Lewis's tips for a creamy mascarpone stuffing
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 4½ -5kg oven-ready turkey, thawed if frozen, giblets removed
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Wash the turkey and pat dry. Strip the leaves from half the rosemary and thyme stalks and finely chop. In a bowl, combine the lemon zest, chopped herbs, pancetta and mascarpone. Season well.

Halve the zested lemons and stuff into the cavity, along with the remaining herb sprigs. Use your hand to loosen the skin lying over the breast of the turkey, to create a pocket. Push the mascarpone mixture under the breast skin to create a thick, even layer.

Put the onion slices into a large, flameproof roasting tin, place the turkey on top and cover loosely with foil. Cook for 3-3¾ hrs, until the juices of the bird run clear. Baste every 30 mins and uncover for the last 30 mins if needed, to brown the bird. When cooked, take the turkey from the oven, remove from the tin and leave to rest on a platter, covered loosely with foil, for 30 mins.

To make the gravy, pour away any excess fat from the roasting tin and discard the onion slices. Set the tin over a medium heat, then sprinkle over the flour. Stir through and cook for 2 mins. Slowly whisk in the wine and stock. Bring to a boil, scraping the bits from the bottom, then simmer over a low heat for 15 mins. Serve the gravy with the turkey.
chief_review: Emma Lewis’s stuffed turkey recipe elevates holiday dining with its sophisticated mascarpone filling and aromatic herbs. The creamy mascarpone blends seamlessly with pancetta, lemon zest, rosemary, and thyme, infusing the turkey with both moisture and nuanced flavors. The addition of white wine and turkey stock, used to create a rich gravy over a bed of onions, intensifies the dish’s complexity. The recipe’s reliance on whole, unprocessed ingredients makes it a strong choice for those seeking festive fare with classic, comforting elements. While it’s not suited for vegetarians, the absence of gluten-containing ingredients makes it a clever option for those following a gluten-free diet (provided care is taken to select gluten-free stock and check wine labels). This is a recipe sure to impress at any celebratory table, marrying technique with indulgent flavors and inviting aromas.

name: Reindeer cake pops
description: These chocolate cake lollipops are decorated in true festive fashion - have fun making them with the kids this Christmas.
author: Valerie Barrett
ingredients: small pretzels, broken into large 'antler' shape pieces
8 small jelly sweets, red chocolatebeans or Smarties
2 tbsp royal icingcoloured black or purchased black writing icing
8 cake pop sticksand a polystyrene block to stand up the cake pops
directions: Crumble the cake into fine crumbs using your hands or in a food processor. Put into a bowl. In another bowl, beat together the butter and icing sugar until creamy.

Melt the plain chocolate in the microwave or in a bowl over a pan of barely simmering water. Add the melted chocolate to the butter mixture and combine well. Add this to the cake crumbs and mix thoroughly using your hands, until it sticks together. Divide the mixture into eight and shape each one into a smooth ball. Insert a cake pop stick, place on a tray lined with baking parchment and chill for at least 2 hours.

Melt the milk chocolate in the microwave or in a bowl over a pan of barely simmering water. Take a cake pop and dip in the chocolate. Shake gently until the excess has drained off. Push into a polystyrene block.

Make two holes in the top of the head and insert a pretzel 'antler' in each one. Press a sweetie nose onto the front and hold for a few seconds until attached. Repeat with all the other cake pops. Leave to set for about 20 mins and then using black icing, pipe on eyes and a mouth.
chief_review: A playful treat, these chocolate cake lollipops are as delightful to make as they are to eat—perfect for a festive family kitchen. The rich combination of chocolate cake, butter, and icing sugar provides a scrumptiously moist base, while the milk and plain chocolate coating delivers a decadent finish. Creative decorations, such as pretzel antlers and vibrant red Smarties, add a whimsical touch reminiscent of Rudolph himself. Ideal for getting children involved, the step-by-step assembly encourages hands-on fun and festive cheer. Please note, these cake pops contain gluten, dairy, and eggs, with potential for nut traces in some candies; thus, they are not suitable for gluten-free, vegan, or allergy-restricted diets. The playful presentation, coupled with layers of chocolatey flavor, ensures these cake pops will become a cherished holiday tradition in any household.

name: Cranberry margarita
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: finely grated zest and juice 1 orange
directions: Using a fine, clean paintbrush, paint a thin layer of honey around the rim of 4 margarita or martini glasses. In a saucer, combine the orange zest, salt and sugar, then turn the glasses upside down and dip them into the mixture. Put the glasses in the fridge to chill.

In a cocktail shaker, combine the orange juice, tequila, lime juice, cranberry juice, triple sec and ice, and shake to combine. When the outside of the shaker feels cold, strain the mixture into your prepared glasses and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail recipe harmonizes fresh citrus zest and juices with the bold spirit of tequila and the tartness of cranberry, creating a balanced and refreshing drink. The use of honey and sugar adds a delicate sweetness, while the coarse sea salt, likely intended for rimming the glass with a paintbrush, introduces a sophisticated contrast on the palate. Triple sec rounds out the orange notes, tying the flavors together in a classic, festive style. Notably, the recipe is gluten-free and suitable for vegetarians, given its focus on spirits, juices, and natural sweeteners. This cocktail stands as an excellent choice for lively gatherings or as a celebratory treat, appealing to those who appreciate layered, citrus-forward flavors. Serve well chilled over ice for optimal enjoyment.

name: Mince tart with crumble topping
description: A portion of this tart is practically ONE THOUSAND calories! Why spend all that money on lovely ingredients only to be bashed over the head with a bag of sugar?
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 2 Bramley apples, peeled, cored and diced
50g quick frosted walnuts, roughly chopped (see goes well with)
directions: First, make the pastry. Using a tabletop mixer or an electric hand whisk, cream together the butter and sugar with a pinch of salt until soft and fluffy. Add the yolks, then fold in the flour until the pastry just comes together, being careful not to overwork. Wrap in cling film and leave to rest in the fridge for 1 hr.

Meanwhile, make the filling. Cook the butter, sugar, orange zest, apple and cinnamon over a medium heat for 15 mins or until you have a thick purée. Add the dried fruit and mixed peel for the final 1-2 mins, then remove from the heat. Once cool, remove the cinnamon stick, and stir in the brandy and suet.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the pastry to the thickness of a £1 coin, then use to line a 25cm loose-bottomed tart case. Return to the fridge for 30 mins until well chilled.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Prick the base of the tart case with a fork, line with baking parchment and fill with baking beans or uncooked rice. Bake for 12 mins, then remove the baking beans and parchment and cook for 3 mins more.
Meanwhile, put the flour, sugar and butter for the crumble in a bowl. Rub together with your fingertips until it resembles coarse breadcrumbs, then mix in the frosted walnuts.

Spoon the mincemeat filling into the pastry case and cover with the crumble. Return to the oven for 30 mins until bubbling at the edges and the topping is golden and gooey. Serve warm or cool with custard or clotted cream.
chief_review:
This tart is a rich, indulgent dessert that brings together a medley of dried fruits, apples, warming cinnamon, and the zesty brightness of orange, all enveloped in a buttery, crumbly pastry. The addition of brandy and suet (offering an option for either beef or vegetable suet) gives the filling a classic richness reminiscent of traditional mincemeat tarts—perfect for festive occasions.

Choosing vegetable suet allows this tart to cater to vegetarian diets, making it more inclusive. While the pastry is classic and delicious, it's important to note that it is made with wheat-based flour. The tart is beautifully fragrant, packed with texture from walnuts and a pleasant chewiness from the fruit. It pairs exquisitely with a dollop of custard or clotted cream, providing a comforting finish. Perfect for special celebrations where indulgence is encouraged!

name: Sourdough starter kit
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Put 200g flour in the Kilner jar with 200ml cool water. Mix well, then cover with the muslin, leaving the lid off. Leave the mixture somewhere warm but away from direct sunlight for 2-3 days until it has swelled and is frothing with bubbles.

To ‘feed’ the starter, throw half of it away, then top up with 100g flour and 100ml cool water. Mix well and leave for two to three days more. Once the starter is puffy and foamy again, it is ready to use.
When making sourdough bread, use as much of the starter as your recipe calls for, then keep it in the fridge, ‘feeding’ it 100g flour and 100ml cool water every week.
chief_review: This recipe, utilizing organic rye flour, is perfect for crafting a classic rye sourdough starter. As such, it’s a fantastic choice for those following a vegan or vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal products. Rye flour is also a great option for individuals with wheat sensitivities, though it does contain gluten and is not suitable for those with celiac disease. The simplicity of the ingredients—just rye flour and water—makes for a pure, unadulterated foundation for homemade bread. Using a glass Kilner jar and muslin supports proper fermentation and airflow, essential for a healthy starter. This method is a staple in artisan baking, cultivating deep, tangy flavors that elevate any rustic loaf.

name: Cauliflower, chestnut & sage cake
description: I made this for christmas dinner as it looked fab, and was a bit worried because of the previous comment, so I did it as a second dish and froze it ahead of time. I defrosted it the night before and reheated it in the oven for 20mins at 160, and it was yummy. A perfect subtle tasting accompaniment to all the other rich trimmings on christmas day. Highly recommended!
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1 medium cauliflower(about 500g chopped weight), leaves trimmed and cut into florets
1 small pack sage, half the leaves picked, largest ones left whole, remaining, finely chopped
180g pack cooked chestnuts, 2/3 roughly chopped, the rest halved
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Drop in the cauliflower florets and cook for 10 mins until soft but holding their shape. Drain and allow to steam-dry.

Meanwhile, heat the oil and butter in a frying pan over a medium heat. Add the onion and a pinch of salt, then cook for 8 mins until softened and caramelising. Stir in the garlic, chopped sage leaves and chopped chestnuts, and cook for 2 mins or until fragrant. Remove the pan from the heat and leave to cool slightly.

Grease and line the base of a 23cm springform cake tin with baking parchment. Put the flour, polenta, baking powder and cheese in a large bowl. Whisk in the eggs so that you have a smooth batter, then carefully fold in the cooked onion mixture and cauliflower.
Tip the mixture into the prepared tin and arrange the remaining sage leaves and chestnuts on top. Bake for 40 mins until golden brown. Serve warm as a main course with a big green salad, if you like.
chief_review: This cauliflower, chestnut, and sage bake delivers a delightful balance of earthy, nutty flavors complemented by aromatic herbs. The dish’s creamy texture, enriched with polenta and a golden crust of parmesan, makes it a standout side—especially against the often heavy flavors typical of festive feasts. Its reliance on cauliflower, chestnuts, and eggs not only adds depth but also offers a satisfying, protein-rich vegetarian option. The flexibility to use a vegetarian parmesan alternative ensures it is entirely suitable for vegetarians, making it an inclusive centerpiece for mixed dietary gatherings. The ability to prepare ahead and successfully reheat without compromising quality is a chef’s dream for holiday entertaining. Serve with a crisp green salad to further lift its freshness.

name: Chocolate truffle star cake
description: Glamorous enough to serve as a dessert, this makes a stunning centrepiece. And the bonus is you can make the whole thing ahead and freeze until you need it
author: Good Food
ingredients: 140g dark chocolate, 70% cocoa solids, broken into pieces
directions: The cake and stars are best made a day ahead (the cake is easier to slice and fill, and the stars have time to set). Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Butter and base-line a deep loaf tin (22 x 11 x 6cm). Put the chocolate and butter for the cake in a saucepan. Mix the coffee with 50ml water, then pour into the pan. Warm through over a low heat, just to melt – be careful not to overheat.

While the chocolate melts, mix both flours with the bicarbonate of soda, both sugars and the cocoa. Break down any lumps in the sugar with your fingers. Beat the eggs, then stir in the soured cream. Pour this and the melted chocolate over the flour mixture, then stir everything together – the mix will be very soft. Pour it into the tin, then bake for about 1½ hrs, or until firm on top. Let the cake cool in the tin (it may crack if you turn it out too soon), then loosen the sides and carefully turn it out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

To make the stars, line a baking sheet with baking parchment. Melt both chocolates separately. Pour and spread the white chocolate thinly into a rectangle on the parchment. Drizzle the dark chocolate off the end of a teaspoon in bold squiggles over the top. Leave in a cool, dry place (not the fridge) until almost set but not hard, then lightly press down with a star cutter, about 5.5cm across, to make at least 6 star outlines. (Make a few extra in case of breakages and wipe the cutter each time you press a star shape.) When completely set, cut through the star outlines with a small sharp knife, then carefully lift them off onto baking parchment.

For the white chocolate icing, heat the cream just to boiling. Remove from the heat, tip in the chocolate and swirl so it starts to melt, then pour in the boiling water and stir to melt completely. Pour into a small bowl and chill in the fridge for about 1 hr to cool and thicken slightly. Beat with an electric hand mixer until thick and glossy.

When the cake is completely cold, place it into the fridge to chill (this makes it easier to slice). Take the cake out of the fridge and turn it over so the flat base becomes the top of the cake. Slice the cake horizontally into three. Sandwich back together with the white chocolate icing, not quite up to the edges. (This can be done a day ahead and chilled.)

For the dark chocolate icing, heat the cream with the sugar just to boiling. Remove from the heat, tip in the chocolate, then stir in the boiling water. Leave to cool and thicken a little. Put the cake on a wire rack with parchment paper underneath (to catch any drips). Pour and spread the icing all over the cake. Leave to set slightly, then arrange the truffles down the centre and prop 5 or 6 of your best stars against them.
chief_review:
This decadent chocolate dessert is a showstopper, both in appearance and taste. The use of high-quality dark and white chocolates creates a rich, layered flavor profile, beautifully balanced by light muscovado and golden caster sugars for depth and subtle caramel notes. Adding coffee granules intensifies the chocolate, while the interplay of self-raising and plain flour ensures a satisfying texture—moist yet structured. The soured cream keeps the cake tender, and the double cream topping adds a luscious, creamy finish. The creative garnish of chocolate truffles makes this an eye-catching centerpiece—perfect for entertaining. 

This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, it incorporates dairy (butter, cream, soured cream) and eggs, so it is not vegan. The inclusion of both plain and self-raising flours means it is not gluten-free, and there are multiple chocolate elements that could include potential allergens.

name: Mixed greens with walnuts
description: A delicious nutty side dish to complement your Christmas meal
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g Brussels sprout, trimmed and thickly sliced
250g Savoy or green cabbage, sliced or shredded
300ml vegetable or chicken stock(use vegetable if you have any vegetarian guests over for Christmas)
directions: Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, add your sliced sprouts and cabbage, then boil for 2 mins. Drain, rinse in cold water to cool, then drain well again. Soften the sliced shallots in a frying pan with the butter and oil until meltingly soft. Cover the veg separately with cling film and chill for up to 24 hrs, until just before serving.

While your turkey is resting, tip shallots back into your largest frying pan with the stock and heat until simmering. Stir in the blanched sprouts, cabbage and frozen peas and cook for 2-3 mins until all the veg is tender and stock reduced. Season and stir in the walnuts just before serving
chief_review: This Brussels sprout and cabbage side dish is a vibrant, textural triumph that will shine alongside any festive main. The pairing of sprouts and cabbage delivers robust winter flavors, while shallots add a gentle sweetness. Butter and olive oil create a silky base, binding the vegetables beautifully. Walnuts contribute a delightful crunch and nutty depth that elevates each bite. Peas not only bring a bright pop of color but also a natural sweetness to balance the dish. Opting for vegetable stock makes this recipe entirely vegetarian, and it’s naturally gluten-free—a boon for guests with dietary restrictions. However, given the presence of butter, it’s not suitable for vegans or those with dairy allergies without substitution. All told, this is a well-balanced, nutritious, and crowd-pleasing side—perfect for a festive table.

name: Honey-roast beetroot
description: This is lovely hot or cold, and even better a day later when flavours have developed
author: Good Food
ingredients: 670g large cooked beetroot, unvinegared (we used 3 x 250g packs of organic beetroot from Waitrose)
directions: Heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Cut each beetroot into 4-6 wedges and arrange in a large roasting tin. Mix together the remaining ingredients and pour over the beetroot. Season well, and toss together so all the beetroot is thoroughly coated in the dressing. Roast for 25 mins until the beetroot is sticky and glazed.
chief_review: This beetroot dish is a celebration of earthy sweetness, elevated by aromatic thyme and the tang of balsamic vinegar. Using oven-roasted or pre-cooked unvinegared beetroot preserves a pure, mellow flavor, while the olive oil creates a luxurious mouthfeel. The fresh thyme infuses a herbal brightness that balances the richness, and the honey ties everything together with a delicate glaze. It’s especially enjoyable served the next day as the flavors meld further. This recipe is an excellent option for vegetarians and those seeking gluten-free fare. With minimal ingredients, it provides a nutritious side or main for picnics and gatherings, offering both versatility and elegance.

name: Mini gingerbread houses
description: Everyone can decorate their own gingerbread house this Christmas, with Sarah Cook's cute mini versions
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1kg plain flour, plus a little extra for dusting
few ping-pong-size balls of regal icing, wrapped in cling film
directions: Put about half the flour in a food processor with the butter and whizz until you can’t see any lumps of butter remaining. Mix the remaining flour, spices and bicarb together with a pinch of salt. Tip both the floury mixtures into your largest mixing bowl and stir in the sugar. (If you don’t have a food processor, rub the butter into all of the flour until it resembles fine crumbs. Then stir in the spices, bicarb and sugar.) Whisk the eggs with the golden syrup and stir into the flour mixture with a wooden spoon. Using your hands, knead together into a smooth dough.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Roll a quarter of the dough out at a time on a sheet of baking parchment, to the thickness of 2 x £1 coins. Use a small, sharp knife to cut around the house templates (see tips, below)– remember that each time you’ll need 2 x A, 2 x B and 2 x C for one house. Remove trimmings and lift the gingerbread, on its parchment, onto baking trays. Re-roll trimmings to cut out all the shapes you need.

Bake the gingerbread one tray at a time on a high shelf in the oven for 8-10 mins, until a lovely, rich brown and firm to the touch. As soon as each tray is baked, carefully sit the templates back onto the relevant shapes and trim any edges to neaten. Use a cutter to stamp out any windows or cut away any doors with a small, sharp knife. Let all the biscuits cool completely.

Sieve the royal icing sugar into a bowl and stir in dribbles of water until you have a stiff icing. Spoon some into a food bag (cover the rest), snip the tiniest bit off the corner and pipe any icing decorations you want onto the gingerbread. Leave to dry.

Arrange the wall biscuits as you are going to assemble them, then pipe icing along the side edges and stick the walls together. Pipe extra icing where the walls join each other on the inside of the house, and support the sides using your icing balls. Leave for a few hrs until set.

Once dry, stick on the roofs, as above – you may need to hold the biscuits on firmly for a few mins until the icing starts to set – or shape your icing balls to support the edges of the roof. Set overnight, then use any remaining royal icing to help you decorate your houses with sweets and sprinkles.
chief_review: A festive highlight, these mini gingerbread houses by Sarah Cook deliver classic holiday charm and delicious, aromatic spice. The combination of mixed spice and ground ginger infuses the dough with deep warmth, while a generous amount of golden syrup and brown sugar gives a beautifully rich, caramelized finish. The dough handles well, yielding crisp yet tender walls—essential for construction and delightful to eat. The royal icing provides sturdy “glue” for assembly and decoration, enabling creative expression for all ages. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe contains no meat, fish, or gelatin. However, those seeking gluten-free or eggless options would need to adapt the ingredients. In summary, this recipe excels as an interactive and flavorful project for festive gatherings, producing charming, edible centerpieces sure to wow guests and satisfy sweet cravings.

name: Slow cooker turkey breasts with wine & bacon
description: Easy enough to make, but not very exciting. Don't think I would make it again.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 turkeybreast fillets, approx 800-900g each. Or buy 1 small turkey crown, approx 1.9k and remove the breast fillets (your butcher will do this for you if you're unsure how to prepare)
2 tbsp fresh thyme leaves, plus extra to serve if you like
500ml chicken stock(we used a Knorr chicken stock pot)
directions: Lay a length of string twice the length of the turkey fillet on a chopping board. Arrange 4 more lengths of string large enough to tie around the width of the fillet at intervals across your first string, winding each one around the main string once so they don't move around too much. Lay 8 rashers of bacon, across the main string and running in the same direction as the 4 strings, overlap the rashers slightly so they don’t pull apart when you wrap the turkey. Scatter with 1 tbsp of the thyme and grind over some black pepper.

Place a turkey fillet on top of the bacon then wrap the bacon around it and tie the strings around the middle and around the length to hold everything in place, it should be snug but not too tight Snip off any excess string with scissors.

Heat the oil in a large frying pan and fry the fillet on all sides until browned then remove from the pan. While browning the first fillet wrap and tie the other one then brown that too. Set aside with the other breast.

Add the onion and carrots to the pan and cook until starting to colour. Tip the vegetables into the slow cooker and add the bay leaves and mushrooms then arrange the turkey fillets on top. Pour the wine and stock into the frying pan, bring to a rapid boil then pour in to the slow cooker, cover and cook on LOW for 3-4 hours until a skewer poked into the centre comes out feeling very hot or a meat thermometer reads 75C.

Lift the turkey breasts onto a plate and cover with foil. Mix the flour with 4 tbsp water to make a smooth liquid. Strain the cooking juices from the slow cooker into a pan, whisk in the flour mixture and keep whisking over the heat while bringing to a simmer to make a thin gravy. Serve with the sliced turkey breasts and traditional vegetables and accompaniments. If taking the turkey to the table on a platter, scatter with a little thyme and grind over some black pepper.
chief_review: This turkey breast recipe is a straightforward roast, enriched with the smoky depth of bacon, fresh thyme, and the earthy notes of dried porcini mushrooms. The combination of white wine and chicken stock delivers a moist, flavorful result, while the inclusion of carrots and onions enhances the base of the dish. However, overall, it lacks inventive flair and may not particularly excite seasoned home cooks seeking something memorable. The use of wheat flour and bacon means it is not suitable for gluten-free or vegetarian diets, while the mushrooms do add an interesting umami undertone. This hearty preparation serves best as a comforting, reliable centerpiece for a casual family meal, rather than a show-stopping dinner. For more impact, consider adding bolder herbs or a bright citrus finish.

name: Salted caramel pecan sour
author: Josh Ramsay
ingredients: 18 drops chocolate bitters(we used Fee brothers Aztec chocolate bitters)
good grating of nutmeg, to serve
directions: Toast the pecans in a dry saucepan for 1-2 mins, then take off the heat. Quickly add the sugar and 80ml water, stir rapidly to dissolve the sugar, add the salt, then leave the mixture to cool completely. Pour through a sieve to remove the pecans.

Pour the pecan salted caramel syrup, vodka, egg whites, clementine juice and bitters into a cocktail shaker. Shake hard for 30 secs to add volume to the egg white. Add some ice and shake again for a further 15 secs, then strain into rocks or coupe glasses. Garnish each with a dehydrated orange slice and grate fresh nutmeg over, to taste. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe is an inventive cocktail with a holiday twist, combining the richness of pecans, the brightness of fresh clementine juice, and a smooth base of Reyka vodka. The aromatic complexity of chocolate bitters, a touch of sea salt, and a dusting of nutmeg offer wonderful layers of flavor. Using egg whites creates a luxuriously silky texture and a frothy finish, making this beverage feel indulgent yet fresh. The dehydrated orange slices provide an elegant garnish enhancing the citrus notes. Please note, this recipe contains nuts (pecans) and egg whites, making it unsuitable for nut and egg allergies, but it is otherwise vegetarian-friendly and naturally gluten-free if standard vodka is used. This well-balanced cocktail is both festive and refined, ideal for impressing guests at winter gatherings.

name: Gingerbread star tree
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 350g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
a set of star cookie cutters (8-10), ranging from 12cm-2cm, or make templates from paper and cut them out yourself
directions: Put the sugar, syrup and butter in a
. Bring to a simmer, then bubble for 1-2 mins, stirring. Set aside to cool for 10 mins.
Tip the flour, bicarb and spices into a large

. Add the syrup mixture and the egg, stir to bring everything together, then gently knead in the bowl until smooth. The dough will feel a little soft, but will firm up once cooled. Wrap and chill for at least 30 mins.
Remove the dough from the fridge and leave at room temperature until softened. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line two baking trays with baking parchment.

Working with half the dough at a time (keeping the remaining dough well wrapped), roll out to the thickness of a £1 coin. Cut out 10-12 stars in descending size, re-rolling the offcuts if you need to. Arrange over the trays and bake for 8 mins until a few shades darker and puffed up a little. Cool on the trays for 5 mins, then transfer to a
to cool completely.
Mix the icing sugar with enough water to make a thick, pipeable icing. Transfer to a
and decorate. Pipe a blob of icing in the middle of each biscuit and stack them to make a tree, sticking the smallest star on top, standing upright.
chief_review: This recipe yields classic spiced biscuits with lovely warmth from ground ginger and cinnamon, beautifully balanced by the richness of dark muscovado sugar and golden syrup. The dough is easy to handle and holds its shape well for precision cut-outs—ideal for festive star cookies or creative shapes. The royal icing adds a crisp finish for decoration. As it contains butter and egg, it is suitable for vegetarians but not for vegans. Additionally, it includes wheat flour, so it is not gluten-free, and those with egg or dairy allergies should avoid it. Perfect for holiday baking projects, these cookies are deliciously aromatic and offer a delightful snap, especially paired with tea or coffee. The recipe’s clear ingredient list and simple method make it accessible for bakers of all skill levels.

name: Spice 75
description: Very Chistmassy but also incredibly strong!! I have lots of the syrup left so will have to continue using it up until Christmas.
author: Kyle Wilkinson
directions: Gently warm 60g golden caster sugar in a pan with 30ml water and 1 tbsp allspice. Cook gently until the sugar has dissolved, then leave the mixture to cool. Strain through a sieve lined with a coffee filter (or a double layer of kitchen paper).

Pour 60ml of the spiced syrup into a cocktail shaker along with 200ml rum and 90ml lime juice. Shake with ice and strain between six flute glasses. Top up with 600ml champagne and garnish each with an orange twist.
chief_review: This festive cocktail is the epitome of holiday cheer, with its robust flavors and vibrant presentation. The homemade syrup of golden caster sugar and allspice infuses the drink with warmth and spice, beautifully complementing the tartness of fresh lime juice. The combination of rum and champagne delivers both depth and effervescence—ideal for celebrations, though notably potent. The orange twist adds a citrusy aroma, lifting the drink’s profile. With no animal products or dairy present, this recipe is suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets. Additionally, it is free from gluten-containing ingredients, making it appropriate for a gluten-free lifestyle. For those who enjoy their cocktails bold and memorable, this recipe is sure to become a holiday favorite—just be prepared for its strength and abundance of delicious spiced syrup!

name: Jamaican ginger beer & pineapple bundt cake
description: Super easy and tremendously delicious. It is a wet mixture but bare with it for a great weekend bake.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 225ml vegetable oil, plus extra for greasing
227g can pineapple ringsin juice, drained and chopped into small chunks (reserve the juice for the glaze)
5 rings of dried or glacé pineapple
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and brush with oil the inside of a 2.4 -litre non-stick bundt tin. Make sure you get into any corners to ensure the cake doesn’t stick. Pour the milk and molasses into a pan and heat gently, whisking until the molasses has melted, then set aside to cool a little. Combine the flour, baking powder, bicarb, sugar, spices and 1/2 tsp salt in a large bowl. Shake the bowl a few times so any lumps of sugar come to the surface and squeeze through your fingers.

In a jug, mix the oil, buttermilk, ginger beer and eggs. Add the cooled molasses mixture and whisk again, then pour into the dry ingredients, along with the chopped pineapple. Stir everything to combine, then scrape into the tin. Bake for 1 hr until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean. If not, return to the oven for another 10 mins and check again. Leave to cool in the tin for 15 mins, then very carefully turn out onto a wire rack.

For the glaze, combine the molasses, icing sugar and pineapple juice in a saucepan and set over a low heat. Whisk until smooth and glossy, then brush generously all over the cooling cake, allowing it to soak in. To serve, top with the glacé pineapple ( hold in place with halved cocktail sticks, if you like), and crystallised ginger. Will keep well in an airtight container for five days.
chief_review:
This recipe offers a wonderfully moist and rich cake, with the deep warmth of ginger, molasses, and muscovado sugar perfectly complemented by the tartness of pineapple. The wet batter yields an exceptionally tender crumb, making this a standout treat for weekend baking. The use of vegetable oil imparts a delicate texture, while the ginger beer infuses the cake with extra spice notes and moisture. Topping with crystallized ginger and glacé pineapple adds both eye-catching appeal and bursts of flavor.

Given its ingredients—particularly the absence of any meat or animal gelatin—this bake is suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians. However, it does contain eggs, milk, and buttermilk, so it is not vegan or dairy-free. The recipe also uses wheat flour, making it unsuitable for gluten-free diets. Overall, this is an indulgent, crowd-pleasing cake for those seeking bold spiced flavors.

name: Festive frozen chocolate parfait
author: Tom Kerridge
directions: Put all the dried fruit in a bowl and pour over the brandy. Leave to soak while you line a 900g loaf tin with cling film.
Melt the chocolate in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of barely simmering water, then set aside to cool a little.

the egg yolks with the sugar and honey in a separate bowl until light, then fold into the melted chocolate. Place the mixture back over the pan of hot water and whisk for a couple of minutes until thickened.

Melt the butter with the cocoa in a pan, leave to cool to room temperature, then whisk into the chocolate mixture. Whip the cream to soft peaks, then fold that into the chocolate too. Finally, fold in the fruit and the ginger nuts. Scrape everything into the prepared loaf tin, then freeze overnight, or for up to one month. To serve, turn out of the tin and cut into slices using a hot knife. The parfait is delicious on its own but also works well with a spoonful of crème fraîche.
chief_review: This decadent dessert recipe showcases a luxurious blend of dark chocolate, dried fruits soaked in brandy, and the warming spice of crumbled ginger nuts. The multiple egg yolks, double cream, and butter yield a rich, silky texture, reminiscent of a classic chocolate torte. Golden caster sugar and honey enhance the sweetness, balanced by the bittersweet cocoa and the tang of cranberries and sultanas. Pairing it with crème fraîche offers a delightful contrast to the dense chocolate base. Notably, the absence of flour makes this recipe suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided the ginger nuts used are gluten-free. The dish is ideal as a festive treat or an elegant finale to a dinner party, delivering both complexity and indulgence in every bite.

name: Smashed sprouts mash with chestnuts
description: This veggie side is perfect for those who love the taste of Brussels sprouts but don't like the texture
author: Good Food
directions: Put the sprouts in a large pan, cover with boiling water and cook for 8-10 mins or until very tender. Drain, and leave to steam-dry for a few mins. Tip back into a saucepan and mash to a chunky texture with a potato masher. Add the butter, cream and nutmeg, and season well. Cook for a further 2 mins. Mix in half the chestnuts, then sprinkle over the remaining chestnuts to serve.
chief_review: This recipe transforms Brussels sprouts into a silky, decadent side dish, ideal for those seeking a new twist on the classic vegetable. Halving and pairing the sprouts with rich double cream and butter creates a luscious texture, far removed from the usual crunch. The addition of chestnuts brings delicate sweetness and a gentle bite, enriching each mouthful. A hint of grated nutmeg weaves warmth throughout, perfectly complementing the earthiness of the sprouts. Notably, this dish is well-suited for a vegetarian diet and is also gluten-free, accommodating those with gluten sensitivities. Prepare this recipe as a sophisticated accompaniment to festive roasts or as a stand-alone indulgence for Brussels sprouts aficionados.

name: White chocolate unicorn bark
description:
It looks so special!
I put shards of it on top of cupcakes and also am going to box some up as a gift!
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: food colouring gelof your choice (we used pink, purple, blue, yellow and green)
directions: Measure all your ingredients into separate bowls. Heat the chocolate in a microwave-safe bowl in 30-sec bursts until melted, stirring each time. Or put it in a heatproof bowl set over (but not touching) a pan of simmering water (an adult should help with this bit). Stir frequently until the chocolate has melted smoothly.

Pour the melted chocolate into four or five small bowls. Use the food colouring to dye the chocolate in the colours you like best. Food colouring can be very strong, so start by adding a tiny amount, mixing well, then add more if you like.

Line a large tray or board with baking parchment and spoon the different coloured chocolates onto the parchment in puddles, in any order you like. The different colours should start to join up and become one big puddle.

Use a skewer or a cocktail stick to swirl the colours together, but don’t swirl too much, otherwise the colours will blend into one. Gently shake the tray from side to side to help the chocolate sit in an even layer and fill in any gaps.

Decorate with your sprinkles, sweets and marshmallows. Leave the chocolate to set in a cool place, or overnight, until set hard. Then break it into pieces and place in gift boxes lined with baking parchment. Will keep in the fridge for up to a week.
chief_review: This recipe yields an eye-catching creation, perfect for adding a decorative flair to cupcakes or gifting in attractive boxes. The white chocolate provides a rich, creamy base that's beautifully complemented by eye-popping swirls of food colouring gel. The addition of hundreds and thousands, jelly sweets, and mini marshmallows adds playful texture and bursts of sweetness, making each shard fun and visually enticing. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, provided the marshmallows and jelly sweets are chosen with vegetarian-friendly ingredients. The process is straightforward and excellent for creative customization, allowing limitless combinations of colours and toppings. Overall, a festive, versatile treat that’s as delightful to look at as it is to eat.

name: Mont Blanc-tini
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 50ml chestnut liqueur (we used Briotett) or amaretto
directions: Start by making the meringue topping. Whisk the egg whites to stiff peaks, then set aside. Put the sugar and 3 tbsp water in a saucepan and set over a low heat. Cook until the sugar has dissolved, then continue to heat, stirring occasionally, until the syrup reaches 120C on a sugar thermometer. While whisking the egg whites with an electric whisk, slowly add the hot syrup in a steady stream, being careful to pour the syrup into the eggs and not onto the sides of the bowl or the whisk, as it may stick. Once all the syrup has been incorporated, continue whisking until the mixture is glossy and stiff – about 5 mins. Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a wide round nozzle until needed. Can be made 1hr ahead–store in a cool place.

Now make the base of the cocktails. Pour the vodka, coffee liqueur, espresso, crème de cacao and chestnut liqueur into a cocktail shaker and add a handful of ice. Shake well, then strain into 4 Champagne saucers or small Margarita glasses.

Carefully pipe your meringue topping onto the surface of the glasses, starting on the outside edge and building it up so that it doesn’t sink. Using a blowtorch, very carefully caramelise the top, then add a marron glacé to each. Serve immediately with a spoon.
chief_review:
This recipe presents a sophisticated and indulgent cocktail, artfully blending vodka, coffee liqueur, crème de cacao, and chestnut liqueur for a rich, complex flavor profile. The use of cold espresso coffee introduces a bold bitterness, expertly balanced by the sweetness of marrons glacés as a garnish. Granulated sugar and egg whites are shaken to create a silky, frothy texture reminiscent of classic sours, elevating the drinking experience. 

Egg whites contribute a creamy mouthfeel but mean the drink isn’t suitable for those with egg allergies or on a vegan diet. The absence of wheat-based ingredients makes it a strong choice for gluten-free diets, provided all the liqueurs (especially amaretto or chestnut liqueur) are verified as gluten-free. Ideal as an after-dinner treat, this cocktail is sure to impress with its luxurious flavors and elegant presentation.

name: Crisp-topped sprouts
description: Spruce up your usual sprouts and add crunch and crispiness with a bread and almond-based topping
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 2 tbsp olive oil, plus extra to serve
directions: Remove any tough leaves and trim sprouts, then steam or boil for 10 mins until tender.

Tear the bread into crumbs. Heat a large frying pan and pour in the olive oil. Add the bread and fry until just crisp. Tip in the flaked almonds, garlic and lemon zest, then cook gently until everything is golden. Place the sprouts in a serving dish, season, then toss with the crumbs and a little extra olive oil to finish.
chief_review: This inventive Brussels sprout recipe brings a delightful crunch and aromatic layer by finishing the dish with a topping of crumbled ciabatta and toasted flaked almonds. The olive oil and lemon zest work beautifully to lift and brighten the earthy profile of the sprouts, while the garlic infuses a savory depth. The use of ciabatta makes the topping light yet satisfyingly crisp, as opposed to heavier breadcrumbs. This dish elegantly balances texture and flavor, making it a standout side. With only plant-based ingredients and no dairy or eggs, it’s perfectly suited to a vegetarian or vegan diet. Additionally, the use of nuts offers a protein boost, though cooks should be mindful if serving those with nut allergies. Altogether, this recipe is a refreshing update to a classic, ideal for festive tables or simple weeknight meals.

name: Classic pigs in blankets
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Cut the bacon rashers in half. Wrap a piece of bacon around each of the chipolatas.
Place on a baking tray and cook for 30-35 mins until golden.
chief_review: This recipe is indulgently focused on savory, smoky flavors, thanks to the combination of smoked streaky bacon and succulent chipolatas. The method likely delivers a crisp, caramelized finish to the bacon, enhancing the juiciness of the sausages for a mouthwatering bite. This dish is ideal for those who enjoy hearty, protein-rich fare, and makes a fantastic centerpiece for a brunch or festive breakfast spread. The simple, two-ingredient profile makes for quick preparation with maximum impact. However, note that the use of pork-based ingredients means it is not suitable for vegetarian, vegan, or certain religious diets. For those following a gluten-free diet, ensure the chipolatas are certified gluten free, as some sausages contain fillers or breadcrumbs. Overall, this recipe promises robust flavors and satisfying texture in every mouthful.

name: St Nick's flip
description: A mellow smooth creamy drink with a fiery kick and an ideal accompaniment to a good sofa film. Also, a superior alternative to those 'off the shelf'cream based seasonal drinks. Worth the extra effort, try it. Cheers.
author: Birds and Bats Wines
ingredients: 60ml simple syrup(we used Funkin Sugar Cane Syrup)
directions: Pour a third of all the ingredients (except the pared orange, cloves and cinammon) into a cocktail shaker with a handful of ice.

Shake hard for 1 min, then strain into two wine glasses. Repeat twice more with the remaining ingredients using fresh ice each time. Stud each piece of pared orange with a clove, then use to garnish each glass along with a pinch of cinnamon.
chief_review: This homemade creamy Cognac and muscat wine cocktail delivers a luxurious, velvety texture with a lovely interplay between the rich double cream, egg whites, and warming spices. The muscat wine adds a delicate sweetness, while pared orange peel and ground cinnamon bring aromatic depth, finished by the clove’s subtle fire. The use of Funkin Sugar Cane Syrup ensures a smooth, integrated sweetness that elevates the drink far above mass-produced alternatives, making each sip indulgent and complex. Perfect for cozy evenings and festive moments, this recipe is well-suited to vegetarian diets, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, note the presence of egg and dairy for those with allergies. Serve chilled, and enjoy the sophisticated balance—a true treat for cocktail enthusiasts willing to invest in a little extra preparation.

name: Celeriac, hazelnut & truffle soup
description: Made this for lunch though I did use chicken stock and single cream. Utterly delicious.
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1l veg stock(check the label to ensure it’s vegan – we used Marigold)
50g blanched hazelnuts, toasted and roughly chopped
1 tbsp truffle oil, plus an extra drizzle to serve
directions: In a large saucepan, heat the oil over a low heat. Tie the thyme sprigs and bay leaves together with a piece of string and add them to the pan with the onion and a pinch of salt. Cook for about 10 mins until softened but not coloured.

Stir in the garlic and cook for 1 min more, then tip in the celeriac and potato. Give everything a good stir and season with a big pinch of salt and white pepper. Pour in the stock, bring to the boil, then simmer for around 30 mins until the vegetables are completely soft.

Discard the herbs, then stir through the cream, remove from the heat and blitz until completely smooth. Stir through 1/2 tbsp truffle oil at a time and taste for seasoning – the strength of the oil will vary, so it’s better to start with less oil and add a little at a time.
To serve, reheat the soup until piping hot, then ladle into bowls and top with the hazelnuts, some black pepper and an extra drizzle of truffle oil.
chief_review: This celeriac and potato soup boasts a beautiful depth of flavor, combining aromatic thyme, bay leaves, and toasted hazelnuts with the earthiness of celeriac. The addition of soya cream lends a silky texture without the heaviness of dairy, and the truffle oil finish makes the dish restaurant-worthy. The recipe cleverly uses vegetable stock and omits animal-based ingredients, making it fully suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets (if you use a vegan-certified stock and check the soya cream brand). Naturally gluten-free, provided the stock is as well, and free from common allergens like dairy and eggs. The toasted hazelnuts add character—though those with nut allergies should omit or replace them. Ideal as a comforting lunch or an elegant starter.

name: Winter wonderland cake
description:
I am planning to make this cake next week and would like to know what units of icing sugar is required for the frosting.... 30? Icing sugar.
Many thanks
Lizzie2901
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 175g unsalted butter, softened, plus more for the tin
100g dark chocolate, melted and cooled a little
mini white meringuesand jelly sweets, to decorate
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter and line three 18cm (or two 20cm) cake tins. Beat the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy. Add the eggs, beating them in one at a time. Fold in the flour, baking powder and a pinch of salt, then fold in the crème fraîche and chocolate and 100ml boiling water.

Divide the cake mixture between the tins and level the tops of the batter. Bake for 25-30 mins or until a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean. Leave to cool for 10 mins in the tin, then tip out onto a cooling rack and peel off the parchment. Set aside to cool completely.

To make the angel frosting, put the sugar, vanilla and liquid glucose in a pan with 125ml water. Bring to the boil and cook until the sugar has melted – the syrup turns clear and the mixture hits 130C on a sugar thermometer (be very careful with hot sugar). Take off the heat. Meanwhile, beat the egg whites until stiff then, while still beating, gradually pour in the hot sugar syrup in a steady stream. Keep beating until the mixture is fluffy and thick enough to spread – this might take a few mins as the mixture cools. Beat in the icing sugar.

Spread two of the sponges with jam and some of the icing mixture, then sandwich the cakes together with the plain one on top. Use a little of the frosting to ice the whole cake (don’t worry about crumbs at this stage). Use the remaining icing to ice the cake again, smoothing the side, and swirling it on top. Crush four of the candy canes and sprinkle over the cake, then add the remaining whole candy canes, meringues and sweets.
chief_review:
This cake recipe combines classic baking essentials with festive decorative touches. The use of butter, eggs, and plain flour creates a rich, tender crumb, while the addition of crème fraîche adds a slight tang and moistness. The dark chocolate and strawberry jam bring layers of flavor, and the playful finish with candy canes, meringues, and jelly sweets makes it visually delightful—perfect for celebrations. The frosting, indicated by the use of egg whites, liquid glucose, and a generous amount of icing sugar (30g), suggests a marshmallowy or royal icing, offering a smooth, sweet finish.

This recipe contains wheat, eggs, and dairy, making it suitable for vegetarians but not for a vegan or gluten-free diet. If food allergies are a concern, especially related to eggs, wheat, or dairy, substitutes would be needed. Overall, a deliciously festive treat with a fun decorative flair.

name: Red cabbage with Bramley apple & walnuts
description: A sweet, crunchy cabbage dish with a superhealthy boost of vitamin C
author: Good Food
directions: Put the cabbage in a wide shallow pan with the butter, apple, bay leaf and cloves. Cook, stirring, until the cabbage starts to wilt. Add the vinegar (stand back and don’t breathe in until the steam subsides), then continue to stir and cook until the vinegar has almost all disappeared. Add the sugar and stir until it has completely dissolved – be careful not to let it burn. Sprinkle with walnuts to serve.
chief_review: This vibrant red cabbage dish delivers both visual appeal and a satisfying balance of flavors. The sweetness of the Bramley apple and light muscovado sugar contrasts beautifully with the tanginess of cider vinegar, creating a well-rounded profile. The butter adds a subtle richness, while the toasted walnuts provide an appealing crunch and depth. Spices like bay leaf and cloves offer fragrant warmth, elevating the humble cabbage. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and is naturally gluten-free, provided you confirm the provenance of your vinegar. Ideal as a holiday side or a nutritious weekday addition, the dish is packed with vitamin C and antioxidants, making it as wholesome as it is flavorful.

name: Snowball dippers
description: Make a batch of these to dip in warm milk or hot chocolate for a festive party or gathering, or wrap up and give as Christmas gifts
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 150g bar dark chocolate, broken into chunks
10 lollipopsor cake pop sticks, to serve
directions: Bring a pan of water to a simmer over a low heat. Put the chocolate in a heatproof bowl and sit it on top of the pan, making sure that the water doesn’t touch the bottom of the bowl, and gently melt the chocolate.

Push a lollipop or cake pop stick into each marshmallow. Check the chocolate is melted completely by giving it a stir, then scrape it into a smaller bowl. Tip the white sprinkles into another small bowl. Put a wire rack next to the bowl of chocolate and a sheet of baking parchment next to the bowl of sprinkles.

Holding the end of a stick, dip a marshmallow into the chocolate so that it is completely coated. Lift it out, but hold it over the bowl to allow the extra chocolate to drip back in, then put it on the wire rack. Dunk the marshmallows, one by one, then line them up on the wire rack in the order that you dunked them.

Pick up the first marshmallow you dunked and dip into the sprinkles to completely coat. Sit the snowball marshmallow on the baking parchment. Continue to dip and coat the marshmallows, working along the line so that you cover them in sprinkles in the same order that you dunked them in chocolate. When all the marshmallows are covered, leave them on the baking parchment until they are set.

You can now wrap the marshmallows in cellophane and tie with ribbons if you’re giving them as a present. Alternatively, if you want to enjoy them right away, warm 1 mug of milk – in a microwave or saucepan – per snowball. Use your snowball as a stirrer in each mug of milk and keep stirring until all the sprinkles, chocolate and most of the marshmallow have melted. Check the milk is not too hot, then drink up. Will keep for up to 2 weeks in cellophane bags.
chief_review: This delightful recipe transforms simple ingredients into festive chocolate-dipped marshmallow pops—perfect for parties or holiday gifting. The robust flavor of dark chocolate pairs beautifully with the soft, pillowy marshmallow center, and a sprinkle of hundreds and thousands adds a colorful crunch. These treats are designed to be slowly dipped and melted into cups of hot milk or cocoa, creating a luscious drink with each swirl. As the recipe contains no nuts or gluten ingredients, it can be suitable for some gluten-free diets, though always check the ingredient labels to be certain. Additionally, with no eggs or flour present, this is a handy choice for certain allergy-conscious gatherings. The assembly is straightforward, making it suitable for little helpers in the kitchen. These festive pops are both fun to make and irresistible to enjoy—guaranteed to bring joy to any holiday celebration.

name: Gingerbread wreath
description: Turn delicately spiced, iced biscuits into an edible Christmas decoration - a gorgeous gift to give to someone special over the festive season
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 350g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
ribbonand cellophane (if giving as a gift)
directions: Put the sugar, golden syrup and butter in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer, then bubble for 1-2 mins, stirring until well combined. Set aside to cool for 10 mins.

Tip the flour, bicarbonate of soda and spices into a large bowl. Add the warm syrup mixture and the egg, stir to bring everything together, then gently knead in the bowl until smooth and streak-free. The dough will feel a little soft now, but will firm up once cooled. Wrap the dough in cling film and chill for at least 30 mins.
Remove the dough from the fridge and and leave at room temperature until softened. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line two baking trays with baking parchment.

Cut off half the dough and keep the rest wrapped in cling film. Roll out the dough to the thickness of a £1 coin, then use a plate or the base of a cake tin as a template to cut out a 20cm circle. Transfer to one of the baking trays, then use a 7cm cutter to stamp out and remove a circle in the middle. Roll out the remaining dough and cut out a variety of other shapes to decorate the wreath (you’ll need about 20-25 pieces – we used stars and angels) and arrange these over the trays too.

Bake the biscuits for 10-12 mins, swapping the trays over halfway through cooking. Stamp a hole in the top of the ring using a small cutter, or the end of a piping nozzle, as soon as it comes out the oven – you can tie a pretty ribbon through this later. Leave to cool on the trays, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

Mix the icing sugar with enough water to make a thick icing. Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a small nozzle, then decorate the biscuits as you wish, using a little edible glitter, if you like. We flooded some of the biscuits with pale blue icing (see tip) and piped white details on the others. Leave the icing to dry for 1-2 hrs, then use a little more icing to stick the biscuits to the wreath. Thread a ribbon through the hole and wrap up in cellophane, if giving as a gift (the ribbon is just for show and may not support a hung wreath). Will keep for 2 weeks.
chief_review: These delicately spiced, iced Christmas biscuits deliver both flavor and festive elegance, making them perfect as edible decorations or thoughtful gifts. With muscovado sugar, golden syrup, and a duo of warming spices—ginger and cinnamon—each biscuit offers rich, comforting depth. The combination of plain flour and bicarbonate of soda ensures a tender crumb, while fondant icing invites creative, decorative flourishes, especially when paired with optional food coloring and edible glitter. Though the inclusion of egg means these are not vegan, vegetarians can certainly enjoy them. This recipe is also nut-free, making it a good option for those with nut allergies. Overall, these biscuits strike a delightful balance between taste and presentation—a joyful project for holiday baking and gifting.

name: Apricot & ginger ham
description: Glaze your gammon joint with fruit, bay leaves, allspice and cloves then slow-roast and serve in thick slices
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4-5kg raw smoked hamon the bone (ask your butcher if your ham needs to be soaked before cooking- some are pre-soaked to save you time)
directions: If your ham needs soaking, do this the day before cooking. Put it in a large pan (a preserving pan is great for this). Cover the ham with cold water and leave to soak in the fridge for 24 hrs, changing the water twice.

Pour away the soaking water and rinse the pan. Return the ham to the pan and add the ginger beer, bay leaves, allspice, peppercorns and 6 of the cloves. Top up the liquid with enough water to cover the ham. If the bone sticks out of the liquid, don’t worry – just rotate the ham halfway through cooking. Put over a medium heat and bring to a gentle simmer, then cover with a lid or a piece of foil. Leave to cook for 2½ hrs, topping up with water as it cooks.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. When the ham is cool enough to handle, discard the cooking liquid and pat the ham dry. Use a small, sharp knife to pare the rind away from the ham, leaving a layer of fat attached to the meat. Score the fat in a diamond pattern and stud all over with the remaining cloves. Put the ham in a roasting tin. Mix together the ginger and jam and brush the mixture over the ham. Roast for 1 hr until golden and glistening. Serve hot or cold.
chief_review: This gammon joint recipe is a showstopper, pairing the rich, salty depth of smoked ham with a vibrant, aromatic fruit glaze. The use of ginger beer and apricot jam brings a sweet and tangy complexity, while whole spices and bay leaves infuse the meat during its slow-roasting journey. The cloves not only add fragrance but also create a classic visual appeal. This recipe is perfect for festive occasions or a hearty family gathering. While deliciously indulgent, it's important to note that this dish is not suitable for vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free diets, and those with sensitivity to pork or certain spices should take care. The resulting ham is succulent, aromatic, and beautifully glazed—a centerpiece worth celebrating. Serve in generous slices with your choice of sides for an unforgettable meal.

name: Hedgerow royale
description: Made this for a dinner party at the weekend, minus the cherry brandy as we didn't have any! Called it a Bramble Fizz, (drank too many) and it went down a treat. The bottle of sloe gin is ready with the magnum of prosecco for christmas day tipples!!
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Fill a coupe glass with crushed ice and pour over the Prosecco. Hold the rosemary sprig in the palm of your hand and clap the other hand sharply over it to lightly bruise the leaves before dropping it into the glass. Slowly pour the sloe gin and cherry brandy into the glass so that they sink to the bottom. Serve immediately.
chief_review: The Bramble Fizz is a vibrant, festive cocktail perfect for celebrations, offering a delightful balance between the herbal notes of rosemary and the deep berry flavors of sloe gin and cherry brandy. The prosecco adds a welcome effervescence, making the drink light and refreshing, while the crushed ice chills it beautifully. Omitting the cherry brandy tones down the sweetness but allows the sloe gin to shine. This cocktail is vegetarian and gluten free, suitable for guests with those dietary preferences. However, those with tree nut allergies should confirm the gin and other spirits are free from allergens. Its inviting appearance and lively taste make it an impressive choice for dinner parties or holiday gatherings. Garnishing with a rosemary sprig adds aromatic flair, elevating the overall experience. Cheers to a well-balanced, crowd-pleasing fizz!

name: Sherry, almond & orange pandoro
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 2 tbsp icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: In a large bowl, whisk together the cream, mascarpone, half the sherry, 3/ 4 of the zest and the icing sugar until the mixture is floppy and just holds its shape.

Cut the pandoro horizontally into five slices. Put the bottom piece on a serving plate or cake stand and drizzle over a little of the remaining sherry. Spoon over a quarter of the cream mixture and top with a handful of the almonds (saving enough for each layer and to decorate the top). Add the next layer of pandoro and continue to sandwich the layers together, rotating each at a different angle so that you create the shape of a Christmas tree.
Dust with icing sugar, then dot over the gold leaf (if using) along with the remaining almonds and orange zest.
chief_review: This indulgent dessert combines the luscious richness of double cream and mascarpone with the fragrant notes of Pedro Ximénez sherry and fresh orange zest. The use of Pandoro as a base adds a light, buttery texture, perfectly complemented by the crunch of toasted almonds. The addition of icing sugar brings the components together with just the right amount of sweetness, while edible gold leaf provides a festive and eye-catching finish. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin-based ingredients. The balance of creamy, citrusy, and nutty flavors creates an elegant treat – ideal for special occasions or holiday gatherings. For the best presentation, dust with extra icing sugar just before serving.

name: Grapefruit spritz
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Pour the grapefruit juice and Aperol into a chilled coupe glass. Add ice and gently stir to combine. Top up with the Prosecco, garnish with a twist of grapefruit zest and serve immediately.
chief_review: This refreshing cocktail combines the bright, bittersweet notes of Aperol with the zesty tang of grapefruit juice and the delicate fizz of prosecco, finished with a fragrant twist of grapefruit zest. The balance between citrusy sharpness and Aperol's herbal complexity creates a lively, elegant drink—perfect for sunny afternoons or as an aperitif. With no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, this cocktail is well-suited for both vegetarian and vegan diets, as well as for those seeking gluten-free options. The simplicity and harmonious flavors make it an impeccable choice for entertaining or relaxing with a light, sophisticated beverage.

name: Passion fruit, chocolate & coconut roulade
description:
Made this on the weekend and it was FAB!!
I made the sponge in the evening thinking that I could leave it rolled up. BAD IDEA. I'm not sure whether the rolling is actually needed because I baked it twice and on both occasions the swiss roll broke. The first time, I left it overnight and as it cooled it stuck to the parchment paper. Second attempt, I unrolled it while warm and it was more flexible this way. Maybe next time, I will not bother rolling at all and sprinkle some much needed Malibu over the sponge to keep it moist and hopefully flexible.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 150g gluten-free dark chocolate, chopped into small pieces
3 ripe passion fruits, flesh scooped out
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a 33 x 23cm Swiss roll tin and line with baking parchment, then grease the parchment too. Tip the chocolate into a heatproof bowl and place it over a pan of gently simmering water. Leave to melt, stirring occasionally, then remove from the heat and allow to cool a little (alternatively, melt it in short bursts in the microwave).
