Put the egg whites in a large, clean bowl, and the yolks and sugar in another. With very clean beaters, whisk the whites until they are just holding soft peaks. Transfer the beaters to the yolks bowl (no need to wash them) and beat until the sugar has dissolved and the mixture is thick and pale.
Add a large spoonful of whites to the yolks and mix with a large metal spoon to loosen the yolks a little. Add the remaining whites and gently fold into the yolks, avoiding knocking out too much air.

When nearly all incorporated, sieve the cocoa over the surface, scatter over the almonds and pour in the melted chocolate. Continue folding until the mixture is well combined, then scrape into your tin. Spread the mixture to the edges and level the surface. Bake for 15-18 mins on the middle shelf of the oven until the surface is crisp and the cake feels springy.

While still warm, turn the roulade out onto a large piece of baking parchment, removing the parchment you used to bake the roulade on. With a small serrated knife, make a shallow incision about 1cm in from one of the shorter edges, making sure that you don’t cut all the way thorough. Starting from this end, roll up as tightly as you can, bending the cut piece inwards to get the centre of the roll tight, using the baking parchment to help you and stop the layers sticking. Leave to set and cool.

Tip the mascarpone, cream, Malibu (if using) and icing sugar into a bowl and whisk until softly whipped. Carefully unroll the roulade – it will crack in places, but don’t worry. Spread a third of the cream all over the surface, leaving a border of about 1.5cm all the way around. Drizzle the passion fruit curd all over the surface and top evenly with the passion fruit flesh.

Starting from the end that you used before, re-roll the roulade as tightly as you can, bending the cut piece into the cream to get the centre of the roll tight. Place the roulade, seam-side down, on a serving plate or board and spread the remaining cream all over the outside. Press the coconut flakes all over the top and sides, and dust with a little gold glitter, if you like.
chief_review: This Swiss roll recipe is an indulgent dessert perfect for those following a gluten-free diet, as it uses ground almonds and gluten-free dark chocolate in place of traditional flour. The combination of rich chocolate sponge, luscious mascarpone and double cream filling, and the tangy brightness of passion fruit curd create a beautifully balanced flavor profile. Toasted coconut flakes add both texture and a tropical flair. The optional Malibu and gold glitter elevate the dish’s festive appeal. Chef’s tip: Roll the sponge while still warm to maintain flexibility and prevent cracks—a key technique in cake-making. All in all, this dessert delivers on decadence and sophistication, making it an impressive centerpiece for any celebration.

name: Prosciutto-wrapped turkey roll
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 2 x 150g packs garlic and herb cream cheese
directions: Beat the cream cheese, mustard and lemon juice together in a bowl, then season with a little salt and pepper and set aside.
Butterfly the turkey breast by cutting into one side of it so you can open it like a book. Cover with cling film and use a meat mallet or
to gently bash it out to a rectangle about 3cm thick, trimming the edges to neaten it up. You can reserve this trimmings to use in another recipe, such as a turkey curry.

Lay a large sheet of baking parchment on your work surface. Lay the prosciutto over it, overlapping the slices to make a rectangular shape larger than the turkey, then place 8 sage leaves all the way down the centre of the prosciutto in a line, lengthways. Lay the turkey, skinned-side down, on the prosciutto and spread liberally with the cheese mixture. Use the edge of the baking parchment to lift and roll the prosciutto and turkey, tucking and rolling it as you would a roulade, to form a long log. Tie at intervals with string. If chilling, wrap well in cling film and put in the fridge.
To cook, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the cling film and put the turkey roll seam-side down on a
. Brush with a little oil and roast for 1 hr, or until the prosciutto has crisped up and the meat is cooked all the way through (a
should read at least 70C). Scatter over additional sage leaves, if you like, and leave to rest for at least 15 mins before carving.
chief_review:
This recipe combines succulent boneless, skinless turkey breast with the creamy tang of garlic and herb cream cheese, accented by a hint of lemon and wholegrain mustard. The richness of the prosciutto wraps the turkey, helping lock in moisture and adding a pleasantly salty, savory dimension. Fresh sage leaves impart a delicate herbal aroma, while a drizzle of olive oil aids in crisping the prosciutto to an appealing finish. 

This dish is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as all ingredients listed are naturally gluten free—care should be taken to verify the specific cream cheese and prosciutto brands to confirm there are no hidden gluten-containing additives. In terms of flavor, the simple preparation allows the turkey’s natural taste to shine, enlivened by aromatic notes and creamy filling, making this an elegant centerpiece fit for special occasions or festive gatherings.

name: Cider roast turkey
description: Succulent, cider-roasted turkey, with tender glazed apples and pear makes the ultimate centrepiece for your Christmas table
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Wash and dry the turkey, removing any feathers. Pull out the giblets and the neck, then set aside. Lift up the skin that covers the neck opening, then stuff the stuffing up and under the skin, securing it tightly underneath with a skewer or two cocktail sticks. Weigh the stuffed turkey, then calculate the cooking time, allowing 40 mins per kg (20 mins per lb).

Put the leeks and carrots along the bottom of a roasting tin in a single layer – this will make a trivet for the turkey to sit on and add flavour to the gravy. Add the neck to the tin. Sit the turkey on top and coat the breast all over with butter. Pour in the cider, cover with foil, then roast according to your timings. Keep checking the tin – if the vegetables look like they’re burning, add a splash of water or cider. At 30 mins before the end of cooking, remove the foil and season generously.

To test that the turkey is ready, pierce the thigh through its thickest part; the juices should run clear. Take the turkey out and leave to rest, covered with a clean tea towel. Can leave to rest for up to 1 hr. Now make the gravy. Drain the fat and juices from the tin into a jug, discarding the veg and the neck. Place the tin over a flame, then pour in the cider, scraping up the flavour-filled crusty bits with a wooden spoon. Reduce the cider by half, then strain into a saucepan (this will save you hob space later).
chief_review: This cider-roasted turkey delivers a festive feast with beautifully moist meat and a subtly fruity glaze, thanks to the dry cider and aromatic quince or redcurrant jelly. The pairing of tart apples and pears alongside tender turkey creates layers of sweet and savory that feel both classic and contemporary. The bed of leeks and carrots not only infuses the bird with gentle flavor but also makes for a stunning presentation. Ideal for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the stuffing and stock are chosen accordingly. With its elegant balance and rich, appealing jus, this recipe is a celebration of winter produce and traditional flavors—perfect for any holiday gathering.

name: Stollen babka wreath
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 600g strong white bread flour, plus extra for dusting
50g salted butter, melted, plus extra for greasing and to serve
25g pistachiosor almonds, or a mixture roughly chopped
directions: Mix the yeast, flour, mixed spice, sugar and 1 tsp salt in a big bowl.

together the milk, melted butter and egg, then tip into the flour mixture and stir until it forms a sticky dough. Tip onto a work surface and knead for about 8 mins until the dough feels soft and stretchy. Clean the bowl, then butter it. Return the dough to the bowl, cover with buttered cling film and set aside for about 1-2 hrs, or until doubled in size, or chill for up to 24 hrs. In a small pan, simmer the cranberries, mixed dried fruit, zests and orange juice until the fruit looks plump. Leave to cool.

When you’re ready to shape the stollen, heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tip the dough onto a surface lightly dusted with flour. Roll out to a 50 x 30cm rectangle. Grate the marzipan over the surface of the dough (this is easier to do if the marzipan is cold). Scatter the soaked fruit and half the nuts evenly over the top, then press down lightly with your hands so they stick into the dough a bit.
With a long side facing you, roll up the dough as tightly as you’re able to, like a Swiss roll (see step 1 of our step-by-step guide). Pinch the dough together to seal the open edge, then use a large

to cut the sausage of dough in half along its length, leaving one end intact by about 5cm (see step 2). You should now have two long strips of dough to work with. Move the dough onto a large baking sheet, oiled and lined with parchment. Twist the two pieces together, turning the cut edges outwards to expose the marzipan and fruit filling (see step 3). Once twisted, connect the two ends to make a wreath shape about 26cm in diameter with a 12cm hole in the middle. Tuck one end under the other to hide the uncut piece of dough (see step 4). Cover loosely with oiled cling film and leave the bread to prove for 30-40 mins until risen by roughly a third.
Uncover the bread and bake for 40-45 mins until the dough is golden all over. You may want to rotate the tray halfway through cooking to get even results. Leave to cool on the tray for 20 mins.
Meanwhile, mix the icing sugar with enough lemon juice to make a thick but pourable icing. Drizzle over the wreath, then scatter with the rest of the nuts.
chief_review:
This festive bread recipe combines classic holiday flavors with a luxurious twist, thanks to golden marzipan and a generous mix of dried fruit and citrus zest. The use of strong white bread flour and fast-action yeast ensures a superbly airy crumb, while the mixed spice and citrus create warmth and brightness in every bite. The addition of cranberries and mixed fruit lends a pleasant chewiness and natural sweetness, perfectly complemented by the rich, nutty marzipan core.

This recipe contains both dairy (milk, butter) and egg, making it suitable for vegetarians but not for those seeking a vegan option. There’s also wheat flour, so it isn’t gluten-free, and nuts are present, which is important for those with nut allergies. Serve warm with extra butter for a decadent treat—ideal for special occasions or a luxurious brunch.

name: Cranberry & orange Chelsea bun tree
description: this is a favorite in my family and it just says Christmas, but sometimes I make it though out the year as everyone loves it so much :)
author: Cassie Best
directions: Warm the milk in a saucepan until steaming but not boiling. Remove from the heat and add the butter, swirling to help it melt, then set aside to cool a little. Meanwhile, mix the flour, yeast, 50g sugar, the cinnamon and 1 tsp salt in a large bowl, or the bowl of a tabletop mixer. When the milk is warm, add it to the dry ingredients and combine to make a sticky dough. Tip onto your work surface and knead for 10 mins by hand, or for 5 mins in the mixe r until the dough is smooth and stretchy. Return to a clean oiled bowl, cover with oiled cling film and leave somewhere warm to rise for 1-2 hrs until doubled in size.

Line your largest baking sheet with baking parchment. Tip the dough onto a lightly floured work surface and roll to a rectangle about 30 x 40cm. Grate the marzipan over the surface and scatter over the orange zest, fresh cranberries, 75g dried cranberries, 25g pistachios and 3 tbsp caster sugar. From one of the longer sides, tightly roll up the dough into a sausage, pinching the dough together at the other end to seal the open edge.

Use a large, sharp knife to divide the sausage of dough first in half, then into quarters, then cut each quarter into three pieces, so you’re left with 12 equal pieces of dough. Turn them all cut -side up and arrange on the baking sheet in a tree shape, using one piece for a trunk and leaving space between each bun for them to expand. Make sure the pinched edge on the outside of each bun is facing towards the centre of the tree, otherwise it may come unstuck and unravel as it cooks. You should have one bun left over – bake this alongside (treat for the cook!) . Cover the sheet in one or two pieces of oiled cling film and leave to prove for 30 -40 mins, or until doubled in size and just touching

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4. Bake in the middle of the oven for 20-22 mins until golden brown. While the buns cook, heat the apricot jam with 2 tsp water until runny, then set aside to cool a little. Mix the icing sugar with enough orange juice to make a thick icing and transfer it to a small disposable piping bag or plastic sandwich bag. You can spray the pistachios with gold spray at this point, if you like.

When the buns are cooked, leave to cool for 15 mins, then brush all over with the apricot glaze. Snip the corner off the piping bag and drizzle icing over the top of the buns in random lines. Scatter over the remaining pistachios and dried cranberries and leave the icing to set for 10 mins before serving. Will keep in an airtight container for up to three days.
chief_review: This festive bread recipe is a delightful celebration of seasonal flavors, boasting a rich, buttery dough laced with orange zest and warm cinnamon. The inclusion of both fresh and dried cranberries adds a pleasing tartness, balanced by sugary marzipan pockets and crunchy pistachios. The glossy apricot glaze topped with a drizzle of icing sugar (and a touch of edible gold spray if desired) delivers a bakery-style finish. For vegetarians, this recipe ticks all the boxes, as it contains no meat or gelatine. However, those with nut or dairy allergies should exercise caution, given the pistachios, marzipan (almond-based), butter, and milk. This bread is best enjoyed fresh, perhaps as a breakfast centerpiece or an afternoon treat alongside tea. Its nostalgic, Christmas-inspired flavors could easily charm at any time of year.

name: Turkish lamb flatbread
description: We really love this recipe. I have made it as per the recipe including the flat bread. I have also bought a flat bread dough from the supermarket and used that when I didn't have so much time to prepare it. The home made flat bread was tastier but if you need to save time the supermarket dough is good.
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 400g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
500g lean lambleg meat, finely chopped (or lean mince)
2 tsp Turkish chilli flakesor 1tsp chilli flakes
4 tbsp pomegranate molasses, plus extra for drizzling
2 small red onions, thinly sliced into half moons
directions: Mix the yeast and 250ml warm water in a small bowl, and leave to stand for 5-10 mins until foamy – this means the yeast is working. Put the flour and salt in a large mixing bowl (or use a tabletop mixer fitted with a dough hook and set at a low speed). Add the yeast mixture and mix by hand or machine until the dough comes together into a ball. If the mixture is too sticky to form a ball, add 2 tbsp flour and mix again. Knead for 12 mins by hand, or 8-10 mins on a high speed in the mixer, until smooth, then put in a lightly oiled bowl. Turn to coat the dough in the oil, cover with cling film and leave in a warm place for 2-4 hrs until doubled in size. (You can also put it in the fridge overnight, punch down and let it rise again at room temperature.)

Heat the oven to 240C/220C/gas 9. Put a baking sheet or pizza stone on the middle shelf. If you’re using lamb leg meat, blitz it in a food processor until it’s finely minced. Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan over a medium-high heat until hot. Add the onion and garlic, and cook for 10 mins until golden. Add the lamb and cook for 5 mins or until brown, breaking up any lumps with a spoon, then pour off any excess oil. Add the spices, some seasoning, tomato purée, tomatoes and the pomegranate molasses, and cook for 5 mins more, mixing everything together well and breaking down the tomatoes with a spoon. Remove from the heat and leave to cool completely. Can be done one or two days ahead.

Roll out the dough on a floured surface into a large rectangle about 30 x 40cm. Sprinkle 1 tsp or so of the semolina on a baking sheet. Put the dough on top and make sure it can move around. Add the spicy lamb first, then top with the red onions, pine nuts and feta. Slide onto the heated baking sheet or pizza stone and cook for 10-15 mins until crisp on the bottom.
Remove and drizzle with a little extra pomegranate molasses, then scatter over the parsley and pomegranate seeds. Transfer to a large board and cut into diamonds to serve.
chief_review: A beautifully balanced recipe that brings together the robustness of lamb, the warmth from Turkish spices, and the sweet tang of pomegranate molasses. The homemade flatbread is a delightful touch, lending authenticity and an excellent texture; however, a ready-made dough also delivers good results for busy cooks. The topping’s mixture of lamb, spices, tomato, and molasses strikes an ideal harmony between savory, spicy, and sweet. Crumbled feta adds creaminess, while pine nuts provide a lovely crunch. Pomegranate seeds and fresh parsley add a burst of freshness at the end. This recipe suits those following a nut-free and vegetarian-excluded diet, as it contains lamb and pine nuts. For dairy-free needs, skipping the feta would suffice, but the dish, as written, includes cheese. An excellent centerpiece for a Mediterranean-inspired meal, it’s both satisfying and impressive for gatherings.

name: Rudolph pancakes
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: ½ tbsp maple syrup, plus extra to serve
a few drops red food colouring
directions: Mix the dry ingredients in a bowl with a pinch of salt. Combine the wet ingredients in a jug and gradually pour into the dry ingredients, whisking until a smooth batter forms.
Put 2 tbsp of the batter in a small bowl and mix in a few drops of red food colouring. Transfer to a squeezy bottle.
Put 1/3 of the remaining batter into the other squeezy bottle, and the remaining 2/3 into a jug.

Gently heat a drizzle of oil in a non-stick pan. Squeeze some batter into an outline of Rudolph, drawing two holes for eyes. Fill the rest with batter from the jug. Make a nose using the coloured batter. Cook for 1-2 mins, flip and cook for 1 min more. Repeat to make four pancakes. Serve with icing sugar and maple syrup.
chief_review: This playful recipe yields delightfully fluffy pancakes with a vibrant twist, thanks to the splash of red food colouring. The combination of self-raising flour and baking powder ensures a light texture, while the golden caster sugar and maple syrup bring just the right amount of sweetness. The use of milk and egg adds richness and structure, resulting in pancakes that hold together well in the pan. The icing sugar dusting and extra maple syrup make for a delightful finish. This recipe suits vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish products. A touch of creativity with squeezy bottles allows for fun shapes or patterns, making it appealing for breakfast gatherings or a kid’s treat. Overall, it is a well-balanced, easy-to-follow pancake recipe that guarantees excellent results with a visually charming presentation.

name: Gravadlax kit
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: a fishmonger gift voucher(to buy a 500g boneless piece of salmon)
directions: To make the cure for your gravadlax, zest the orange and roughly chop a large bunch of dill. Using a pestle and mortar, grind 1 /2 tbsp peppercorns, then stir in 50g sea salt, 75g sugar, 1 tsp each coriander seeds and caraway seeds, and the zest.

Put half the dill on a large piece of cling film and place your salmon on top. Cover with all the cure and the remaining dill, then wrap tightly. Place in a dish with something heavy on top to weigh it down.
Leave to cure for 24-48 hrs, turning the salmon once, then rinse well and pat dry before serving. Will keep in the fridge for up to three days.
chief_review: This recipe is a classic blend for making home-cured gravlax, bringing together fresh dill, spices, citrus, salt, and demerara sugar to create a beautifully balanced cure for a 500g side of salmon. The mixture of coriander and caraway seeds adds a fragrant, earthy depth, while orange zest brightens the flavor profile. The use of sugar and sea salt ensures both sweetness and the proper curing effect, transforming raw salmon into a silky, flavor-packed delicacy. This preparation is well-suited for pescatarians and those following a gluten-free diet, as all ingredients are naturally free of gluten. Additionally, it avoids common allergens such as nuts and dairy, making it broadly accessible. Perfect served thinly sliced on rye bread or blinis with a touch of mustard sauce, this gravlax recipe delivers elegance and Nordic charm to any occasion.

name: Bespoke martini kit
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: small pod of green cardamom pods
small pot of dried rose petals
directions: Open the bottle of vodka and add 2 tbsp juniper berries, 6 cardamom pods, a pinch of dried rose petals, 1 tsp coriander seeds and a strip of lemon peel. Put the lid back on and leave in a cool dark place for 24 hrs.
Strain the infused mixture through the coffee filter paper into a jug, then pour back into the bottle to store.

To make a martini, chill 2 martini glasses in the fridge for 30 mins. Put 50ml vermouth in a tall glass, add 150ml infused vodka and a large handful of ice. Stir well until the outside of the glass feels cold, then strain into the chilled glasses. Garnish with an olive.
chief_review: This recipe creatively infuses rye vodka with botanicals like juniper berries, green cardamom, dried rose petals, and coriander seeds, echoing a floral, artisanal twist on the classic martini. The process is simple but delivers depth—subtle fragrance from rose petals, citrus brightness from lemon, and complexity from the spices. Finishing with vermouth and green olives adds balance and a savory touch. The ingredients are naturally free from common allergens, gluten, and any animal-derived products, making this cocktail vegan and gluten-free. A sophisticated serve for those wanting a unique, elegant martini experience.

name: Mulled tea
description:
just as Gerald implied I am in shock that a person able to earn $7711 in 1 month on the computer.................................................................
see more,,,,,,,, www.moneyboastfast7.tk ..............................................
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour 1 litre of water into a large saucepan then add the dried rose petals, cloves, bay leaf, cinnamon stick, frozen mixed berries, cranberry sauce and orange. Bring the mixture to the boil, stirring occasionally then take off the heat. Drop in the tea bag then leave to steep for 2-3 mins. Strain through a sieve into a heatproof jug and serve warm.
chief_review:
This recipe offers a fragrant and colorful infusion, blending dried rose petals, cloves, bay leaf, cinnamon stick, mixed berries, cranberry sauce, orange, and green tea. The result is a vibrant, aromatic beverage with floral top notes, warming spice, tartness from berries, and a subtle citrus lift. The use of frozen berries and cranberry sauce contributes additional natural sweetness and depth, making it perfect for a cozy afternoon drink.

Given that all the ingredients are plant-based and free from common allergens, this recipe is suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets, as well as being naturally gluten-free and dairy-free. It’s an excellent option for those seeking a caffeine boost with a twist, or anyone looking for a unique, healthful tea experience. Serve hot or iced for a refreshing, antioxidant-rich brew.

name: Easy smoked turkey crown
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 tsp dried herbs such as rosemary, thyme or oregano
a handful of wood chips(applewood are delicious)
directions: Up to two days ahead, mix the paprika, dried herbs and lots of ground pepper with 1 tbsp flaky sea salt. Season the turkey crown with half of the herby salt mixture, then cover. Mix the remaining herby salt mixture with the butter and chill.
To cook, heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Smear the herby butter all over the crown, working it under the skin. Sit the crown on a rack in a large
, skin-side up, and roast for 1 hr 30 mins, basting with the buttery juices every 30 mins until the skin is crisp and the turkey is cooked all the way through.
Remove the turkey from the oven and set aside. Use a small sheet of foil to make an open package of the wood chips. Place the package in a dry
and heat until smoking, then transfer to the roasting tin. Cover everything in a large tent of foil to trap the smoke and leave the turkey to rest for 20 mins before unwrapping and
. Save the juices from the tin to make a smoky gravy.
chief_review:
This recipe brings together classic, earthy flavors with a rich, smoky undertone. The blend of smoked paprika and dried herbs like thyme, rosemary, or oregano creates a wonderfully aromatic seasoning for the turkey crown. Rubbing the turkey with soft butter ensures a juicy, golden finish, and the use of wood chips—particularly applewood—adds a delicate sweetness that elevates the bird’s natural flavor. 

As it relies solely on turkey, herbs, paprika, and butter, this recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. The absence of nuts and other common allergens ensures broad compatibility with standard dietary requirements, except for those who avoid dairy or animal products. 

Overall, this approach results in a festive centerpiece that expertly balances smokiness, savoriness, and tenderness. Perfect for special occasions or a hearty family meal.

name: Festive filled brioche centrepiece with baked camembert
description: I made this for a Christmas party and it was fabulous. Need to be organised in terms of starting the day before, however is on the party food list.
author: Kimberley Wilson
ingredients: 1 egg, beaten with a pinch of salt
1 whole 250g camembertin a wooden, stapled carton
½ tbsp dried, chopped cranberrymixed with ½ tbsp cranberry sauce
directions: whisk together the eggs and milk in a jug. Put the flour, yeast, sugar, salt and spice in the bowl of a kitchen mixer fitted with a dough hook. Stir to combine.

On a medium setting, slowly pour in the egg mixture in a steady stream, continuing to stir until incorporated into a very soft, wet dough. Add the butter and increase the speed, kneading for 8-10 minutes. The dough will be ready when it clings around the dough hook. At this stage it will look more like a thick cake batter than bread dough. Cover with cling film and refrigerate overnight.

heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Line a baking sheet with foil. Remove any loose outer skins from the garlic bulbs. With a sharp knife, cut off the stem and uppermost part of the cloves. Place on the foil, drizzle over a little olive oil and season. Bring up the edges of the foil and seal to form a fairly tight parcel. Bake in the top of the oven for 35-45 minutes. Remove from the oven and leave the parcel sealed until the garlic is cool enough to handle. Remove the cloves by either squeezing the bulb upwards from the base or by teasing them out with a toothpick. Mash the garlic with a fork. Wrap well (to avoid the garlic smell transferring to other foods) and refrigerate.
line a baking tray with baking parchment. Remove the cheese from its wooden carton and put the cheese back in the fridge until later. Put the carton in the centre of the lined tray.
Tip the dough out onto a well-floured surface. Divide into 5 large equal-sized pieces - it can help to roll the dough into an even sausage shape and mark with a knife first to get equal pieces.

Take one piece and divide into 5 again. One at a time, roll each of these 5 pieces gently into a ball, flour your index finger and make a small, deep indent in the middle. Fill with half a teaspoon of the roasted garlic, pinching the dough over the top to seal and placing the sealed side down onto the floured surface. Cup your hand over the bun and rotate a little to get an even shape. Repeat until you have filled all 5.
Repeat step 6 using the remaining 4 fillings.

Arrange the buns around the wooden carton, you’ll need 10 for the inner ring and 15 for the outer ring. Leave around 0.5cm between each bun, giving them room to rise. Cover with oiled cling film and leave in a warm place for 30-40 minutes or until nearly doubled in size.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Remove any plastic wrapping or stickers from the cheese. With a small knife, make an incision in the top rim and remove the top layer of rind. Sprinkle with thyme leaves and place in the carton, cut side up. Brush the buns with the beaten egg and scatter with poppy seeds. Bake for 15-20 minutes until golden brown. Slide onto a serving platter. Decorate with the herbs and fresh cranberries. Serve the extra cheese alongside if using.
chief_review:
This recipe is an impressive centerpiece, perfect for a festive celebration like Christmas. The enriched bread dough, redolent with mixed spice and enriched with butter, pairs beautifully with the baked Camembert and its aromatic thyme and garlic undertones. The inclusion of quince paste, chestnuts, and cranberries brings sweet and earthy notes, complementing the creamy cheese. A scattering of poppy seeds adds visual appeal and crunch.

This dish is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish and focuses on dairy and eggs alongside plant-based flavors. People with nut or gluten allergies should exercise caution due to chestnuts and wheat flour. The make-ahead aspect is ideal for party planning, and the flavors truly come together for a festive and memorable treat.

name: Spiced apple cheesecake
description: I made this yesterday for a late Christmas get together. Following the comments and the rush I was in I changed the ricotta for mascarpone, only added 100g sugar to the cheese mix (I think 80g would be even better), and added lemon juice as well as zest. The result was great very popular even the kids including those who don't like cheese!
author: John Torode
ingredients: 100g butter, melted, plus extra for tin
100g stem gingerin syrup, drained and chopped
3 Granny Smith apples, peeled and cored
directions: Butter and line the base of a 23cm loose-bottomed cake tin. Whizz the biscuits to a rough crumb in a
, or put them in a sandwich bag and crush with a

. Tip the crumbs into a bowl with the melted butter, stem ginger and spices, and stir well. Press the mixture into the tin, pushing up the sides a little (putting your hand in a food bag makes this easier). Leave the base to set for 30 mins in the fridge.
For the cheese layer, whisk all the ingredients together until smooth, then pour over the base. Chill in the fridge overnight.

The next day, make the topping. Mix the cinnamon, ginger and mixed spice in a large bowl. Cut each apple into 12 wedges, then toss the wedges in the spice mixture. Heat the sugar and 4 tbsp water in a saucepan and bubble to a caramel. As soon as the sugar becomes a dark caramel, take off the heat and carefully toss through the apples. Pour in the brandy, and the whole lot will bubble and seize. Return the pan to the heat and simmer gently to re-dissolve the caramel and cook the apples in the syrup. Remove from the heat and set the apples aside to cool in the syrup.
Ease the cheesecake out of the tin. Spoon the apples over the top with a slotted spoon. Serve the sticky brandy syrup on the side as a sauce.
chief_review: This festive dessert is a decadent treat, perfect for special occasions. The use of ginger nuts and stem ginger gives the base a warming, spicy depth that pairs beautifully with the creamy filling. Swapping ricotta for mascarpone lends extra richness, while reducing the sugar and incorporating both lemon zest and juice brightens the flavor, balancing the sweetness. The vanilla seeds and array of spices add aromatic complexity, and the addition of caramelized apples with a splash of brandy provides a luxurious finish. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, though it includes dairy and eggs, so not vegan or dairy-free friendly. The flavors are well-rounded and crowd-pleasing—even for hesitant young eaters. For those who enjoy bold spice and creamy textures, this is an excellent, indulgent choice for your next gathering.

name: Super-simple fruitcake
description: The olive oil is wrong for this recipe; it has far too strong and wrong a taste and is too heavy. A soft butter may have been better but wasn’t prepared to risk wasting another set of ingredients.
ingredients: 175ml olive oil, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/ gas 3. Grease and line the base of two 20cm springform cake tins with baking parchment.

Stir together the oil and sugar, add the eggs, flour, baking powder, spices and juices, and mix thoroughly with a wooden spoon until pourable and reasonably runny. Gently fold in the fruit, then divide the batter evenly between the tins. Bake for 20-25 mins or until a skewer inserted in the centre comes out clean, then leave to cool.
When cool, remove from the tins and sandwich the cakes together with jam. Sieve some icing sugar on top to serve.
chief_review: This recipe attempts a rich, spiced fruit cake, but the choice of olive oil over a neutral oil or soft butter unfortunately overshadows the balanced flavors expected in such a bake. Olive oil’s pronounced, grassy notes compete with the spices and fruit, resulting in a heavy crumb and muddied taste. A switch to unsalted butter would not only lighten the texture but also harmonize better with the citrus and dried fruit, letting their subtleties shine. On the positive side, the recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or animal-derived gelatin. However, with eggs and wheat flour, it does not cater to vegan or gluten-free diets. Overall, with a minor fat substitution, it has the potential to be a fragrant, festive loaf for vegetarian-friendly occasions.

name: Mincemeat, apple & marzipan wreath
description: Great way to use up leftover mincemeat. Served warm with brandy cream.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: ½ dessert apple, chopped into small pieces
directions: Unravel the pastry, cut off a 4cm strip along the width and chill this piece until later. Cut the remaining pastry in half lengthways. Place the pastry pieces end to end, so you have one long rectangle, squashing the cut ends together to seal. Scatter over the marzipan and orange zest, leaving a border of about 1cm free along one side. Spoon the mincemeat along the centre, like you’re making sausage rolls, then top with the apple.

Brush a little beaten egg over the exposed pastry edge. Starting from the other side, roll into a long sausage, sealing with the eggwashed edge. Use a sharp knife or a pair of scissors to snip almost all the way into the pastry at a slight angle at 5cm intervals, keeping all the pieces attached along one edge. Coil into a ring, with the cut pieces on the outside to help it bend, and tuck one end into the other to give a neat finish. Brush the wreath with egg, then use the trimmings from earlier to make decorations, such as stars or holly leaves, and brush these with egg too. Transfer to a baking sheet lined with baking parchment and chill for 30 mins.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bake the wreath for 20 mins or until golden brown. Dust with icing sugar and serve warm for dessert, or cold as an alternative to mince pies.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful treat for those seeking to transform leftover mincemeat into something indulgent. The combination of crisp, buttery puff pastry with sweet marzipan and zesty orange creates a fragrant base, perfectly complemented by the rich mincemeat and tart apple pieces. Serving it warm with brandy cream elevates the festive flavors, making it ideal for holiday gatherings or dessert trays. However, those with nut allergies should take caution due to the marzipan, and the presence of egg and dairy (in the cream) may require consideration for some diets. The use of ready-rolled puff pastry streamlines preparation without compromising on taste or texture—a true testament to smart yet sophisticated home baking.

name: Roast turkey with citrus butter
description: Used this recipe for Xmas and it was a hit. Very simple and delicious recipe. Bird was moist and the best bit was the gravy I made from the roast which had a lovely sweet taste to it thanks to the oranges.
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Pat the turkey dry all over with kitchen paper. Now weigh the bird and calculate the cooking time at 40 mins per kg.

Mix the butter with the zests and herbs, and season well. Gently push your fingers under the turkey’s skin, starting from the neck end of the bird, easing the skin away from the flesh over both the breasts and the tops of the drumsticks. Spread the butter under the skin, pushing it in as far as you can, then smooth the skin back into place. Halve the lemon and orange and put in the turkey cavity along with 2 onion halves and the bay leaves.

Rub turkey all over with oil and sprinkle with salt. Arrange remaining onions in the bottom of a large roasting tin to act as a trivet for the bird. Sit the turkey on top and completely cover both bird and tin with foil to make a tent. Roast according to your calculated cooking times.
Thirty mins before the end of the cooking time, take out the turkey and turn up the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the foil and return to the oven for a further 30 mins until golden.

To test whether your turkey is cooked, pierce the fattest part of the thigh with a skewer – the juices that run out should be clear and not pink. Keep cooking if the juices are pink and re-check at 10-min intervals. If you like your turkey meat almost falling off the bone, then wiggle the leg – it should give slightly if the meat is ready. Keep cooking and basting until it does.
Rest the turkey, covered loosely with foil, for at least 30 mins and up to 1 hr before serving. Strain and reserve the cooking juices and keep the onions in the tin for
chief_review: This holiday turkey recipe is a true celebration of classic flavors, elevated by the refreshing zest of lemon and orange, which infuse both the meat and gravy with a subtle, sweet brightness. The butter rub, enhanced with fresh thyme and rosemary, ensures the turkey remains wonderfully moist, while the generous use of onions and bay leaves creates a deeply aromatic base. The method is delightfully simple, making it accessible even for less experienced cooks. This dish is naturally gluten free, provided the side accompaniments are chosen carefully. It’s also a great option for those following a nut-free diet. Ideal for centerpiece holiday feasting, the sweet citrus undertones in the gravy truly set this recipe apart.

name: Vegetarian red wine gravy
description: Going meat-free doesn't mean missing out on a sumptuous sauce for roast dinners - mushroom ketchup adds depth to this version
author: Good Food
directions: Heat the oil in a saucepan. When hot, add the onions, carrots, celery and bay, and cook gently for 10-15 mins until soft. Remove the bay leaves.

Add the flour and cook for 3-4 mins until brown. Add the wine little by little, stirring constantly, then add the stock. Once fully incorporated, simmer for 5-10 mins until the gravy has thickened. Strain through a sieve, stir through the mushroom ketchup and season to taste.
chief_review: This meat-free gravy delights with a rich, complex depth thanks to mushroom ketchup, making it an impeccable companion for any roast dinner. The combination of caramelized onions, aromatic bay leaves, and a harmonious medley of vegetables provides a hearty backbone. Red wine and mushroom ketchup layer in umami and acidity, resulting in a sauce that feels both luxurious and comforting. The use of vegetable stock keeps it suitable for vegetarians, and with no use of animal-derived ingredients, vegans can also enjoy this delightful sauce. Be sure to check the mushroom ketchup and stock for gluten if serving those with gluten sensitivities. Overall, this recipe provides a remarkably robust flavor profile that will please even the most ardent lovers of traditional meaty gravies—no compromise required.

name: Posh spice cake
description: A fruit cake for those who like theirs light, spicy, fruity and moist, with a tart cranberry topping
author: Angela Nilsen
directions: Butter and base-line a deep 18cm round, loose-bottomed cake tin. Heat oven to 170C/fan 150C/gas 3. For the cake, stir together the flours, baking powder and sugar. Slit open the cardamom pods and remove the tiny seeds (discard the pods). Grind the seeds to a powder using a pestle and mortar, then stir into the flour mixture with the orange zest and all the other spices.

Rub the butter into the mix until it looks like coarse crumbs. Coarsely chop half the pecans and stir into the mix with the raisins, sultanas and cranberries. Beat the egg, pour in the milk and stir into the cake mixture. Spoon the mixture into the tin, level the top and scatter over the remaining pecan halves. Bake for 45 mins, then lower the heat to 150C/fan 130C/ gas 2 and bake for another 45 mins.

While the cake bakes, prepare the topping. Pat the cranberries dry on kitchen paper, then toss with the sugar in a small bowl. After the second 45 mins of baking, spoon the sugared cranberries over the top of the cake. Return to the oven for another 15-20 mins, or until the cranberries are sticky and a skewer inserted into the cake comes out clean.

Leave the cake to cool in the tin, then turn out onto a wire rack. Decorate with ribbon. The cake is best kept overnight for the flavours to mellow before slicing. Will keep in an airtight tin for up to 2 weeks.
chief_review: This fruit cake is a delightful twist on the classic, achieving a lovely balance of lightness, robust spice, and vibrant fruitiness. The tart cranberry topping elevates the cake, adding freshness and contrasting beautifully with the warm spices and sweet dried fruits inside. The use of wholemeal flour and pecans brings a hearty texture, while orange zest brightens the flavor profile. It’s great for those who prefer a moist, less dense fruit cake. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe avoids animal gelatin or fats beyond butter and egg. However, it does contain nuts (pecans), eggs, dairy, and gluten, so it’s not suited for those with related allergies or dietary restrictions. Overall, it’s a festive and memorable centerpiece ideal for gatherings, particularly appealing to fans of spiced baked goods and fruit-forward desserts.

name: Stollen spirals
description: Bake a batch of these sweet German buns over Christmas and enjoy at breakfast or teatime... or both
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 550g strong white bread flour, plus extra for kneading
85g butter, plus extra for the tin
melted butter and icing sugar, or icing sugarmixed with a little water, plus chopped pistachios, if you like
directions: Stir together the zest and juice, Cointreau, cranberries and mixed fruit in a small bowl and leave to soak.

Meanwhile, mix the flour, yeast, caster sugar and nutmeg in a large bowl. Add ½ tsp salt and rub in the butter. Beat the egg with the warm milk, then pour onto the flour mix. Stir with a round-bladed knife, then use your hands to bring the mixture together as a soft dough.

Tip onto a work surface and knead for a couple of mins, adding a little flour only if you need to stop it sticking. Oil the bowl, return the dough and cover with cling film. Leave to rise for 45 mins-1 hr in a warm place until doubled in size.

Line and butter a large roasting tin with baking parchment. Roll the risen dough out firmly to a long strip about 70 x 18cm. Add the pistachios to the soaked fruit, then scatter the mix along the dough. Roll the marzipan into a sausage the same length as the longest side of the dough, then place it down the centre of the dough and roll up together firmly, a bit like making a sausage roll. Trim the ends, then cut the rest into even lengths and arrange, cut side up, in the tin. Cover with cling film and leave to rise for 45 mins-1 hr until really well risen.
Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Bake for 15-20 mins until golden.
. Brush with melted butter and dredge with icing sugar, or mix a little water into the icing sugar, drizzle over the buns and scatter over the nuts. Eat within 2 days.
chief_review:
These German festive buns are a delightful treat, exemplifying the sweet, aromatic flavors of Christmas. The combination of orange zest, Cointreau-soaked dried cranberries, and mixed fruit provides a lovely citrusy lift and holiday warmth, balanced with a hint of nutmeg. Toasted pistachios add a pleasant crunch, while the golden marzipan running through the buttery dough brings a rich almond sweetness in every bite. 

This recipe is a wonderful choice for vegetarians, with no meat or gelatine involved, and can easily be enjoyed at breakfast or paired with afternoon tea. However, it does contain nuts, dairy, eggs, and gluten, so it's essential to keep this in mind for those with specific food allergies. The finishing touch—melted butter and icing sugar—gives these buns an irresistible, festive glaze, making them a crowd-pleaser for any holiday gathering.

name: Cranberry-topped raised pie
description: I made this for a Boxing Day buffet and it went down a storm! It does take a bit of time but it's definitely worth the effort. Fed a party of 25 people well as part of a buffet and had the added bonus for us of also happening to be naturally dairy free. I don't have a meat thermometer so I tested whether it was cooked using the spoon directions the recipe suggests and it worked perfectly. I also was worried that I couldn't fit all that much stock into the pie but I need not have worried as it came out with lots of jelly. My pie did spring a bit of a leak but I patched that with a bit of spare pastry I had until it was cool, when the jelly had set and it no longer leaked. I also made the cranberry topping which was simple, although I did get lots of juice left. But no matter; seeing as the juice was just a mix of sugar, cranberry and sherry I used it to make Christmas cocktails by mixing it with gin and soda water!
author: John Torode
ingredients: 500g boneless pork shoulder, skin removed, chopped into 2cm/¾ in pieces (ask your butcher for 300g/11oz pork bones if you want to make your own stock)
250g pork belly, skin removed, chopped into 2cm/¾ in pieces
650g chicken drumsticksand thighs, skin and bones removed, chopped into 2cm/¾ in pieces – you should have about 375g/13oz (save the bones to make stock, if you like)
100g smoked streaky bacon, cut into small pieces
1 fresh bay leaf, very finely chopped
directions: If you want to make your own stock: put the chicken and pork bones in a pan, add 600ml water (or enough to just cover) and bring to a gentle simmer. Cover with a lid and cook for 30 mins, then strain and continue cooking to reduce the liquid to about 300ml. The bones will add natural gelatine to the stock so it should set without additional gelatine. But if you want to make sure, add 1 leaf following the directions in step 10.

Mix together all the filling ingredients in a large bowl and season with 1½ tsp salt. Now make the pastry. Pour 150ml water into a saucepan, add the lard and ½ tsp salt, and bring to the boil. Once the lard has melted, remove from the heat.
Meanwhile, sift the flour and 1 tsp salt together into a large bowl. Pour over the hot liquid and stir vigorously to form a dough.
Tip onto your work surface and knead for a couple of mins to develop the gluten slightly and create an even-textured pastry. (Once made, keep covered with cling film.)

Remove roughly one-third of the pastry and set aside to make the lid later. Roll the remaining pastry to the thickness of a £1 coin. You’ll need a 20cm-deep springform cake tin to assemble the pie in.
Line the cake tin with the pastry, pushing it well into the corners and up the sides of the tin (use a small ball of dough to do this). Leave any excess hanging over the top of the tin.
Add the filling to the pie, packing it tightly – this will expel any air pockets and create a nice flat top for the cranberries to sit on later.

Roll out the reserved pastry to the same thickness and lift it onto the pie to create a lid. Press into the pastry around the edges and trim off any excess. Crimp with 2 fingers if you like. Brush the top of the pie with beaten egg. Cut a hole in the centre to let the steam out as it cooks. You can now chill it for up to 24 hrs or cook straight away. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.

Bake for 30 mins, then reduce heat to 150C/130C fan/gas 2 and bake for another 1 hr 45 mins. If you have a meat thermometer, the internal temperature of the pie should be 75C. If not, insert the end of a spoon into the centre of the pie and hold it there for 10 secs – it should be hot to the touch.

Place the tin on a wire rack to cool, then remove the pie. If you have a blowtorch, blast it around the outside of the tin before removing the pie – this melts the fat sticking the pastry to the tin, making it release more easily. Alternatively, leave the pie at room temperature for 20 mins before removing the tin. Warm the stock and put the gelatine in a bowl of cold water to soften for 5 mins. Squeeze out any drops of water, then add the gelatine to the stock, stir in until dissolved, and season well. Transfer to a jug.

If there is no gap between the pastry and meat, you'll need to poke a skewer into the hole and wiggle it around to create space for the stock. Pour two-thirds of the stock into the central hole (use a piping nozzle as a funnel, if you have one), or as much as you can, but reserve about 4 tbsp for the topping. Chill for at least 2 hrs.

Dissolve the sugar with the sherry over a low heat. Once dissolved, bring to the boil and add the cranberries. Cook for 1-2 mins, but remove from the heat before the cranberries burst. Leave to cool. Once the stock in the pie has set to a jelly, top with the cranberries. Melt your remaining jellied stock in a saucepan over a low heat, then use it to brush the cranberries generously. Return to the fridge for 1 hr to set the topping. Enjoy within 3 days.
chief_review:
This festive Boxing Day pie is a true showstopper—rich, savoury, and packed with nuanced flavour from pork shoulder, belly, chicken, and smoked bacon. The blend of mace, nutmeg, thyme, sage, and parsley provides excellent depth, while the cranberry topping adds a sweet-tart finish that complements the hearty meats beautifully. The jelly, set with gelatine and sherry, imparts a traditional touch and impressive texture. The lard-based hot water crust delivers perfect sturdiness and flavour, crucial for feeding a crowd. Clever use of leftover cranberry syrup for cocktails proves resourceful and delicious.

Notably, this pie is dairy free, catering well to those with lactose intolerance or cow’s milk allergies. However, it includes both gluten (flour) and animal products, so is not suitable for gluten-free, vegetarian, or vegan diets. Allow time for preparation—the result is more than worth the effort for a celebratory buffet.

name: Spiced cranberry & pear relish
description: A Christmassy relish which will keep in the cupboard for up to six months, making it perfect for make-ahead gifts
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 2½ cm/1in piece ginger, peeled and grated
1 dried red chilli, crumbled, seeds removed if you prefer
4 pears, cored and cubed, peel left on
directions: Put all the ingredients except the pear in a non-reactive saucepan with a large pinch of salt. Bring it slowly to a simmer, stirring to make sure all the sugar has dissolved. Add the pear and continue cooking until the mixture has the consistency of thick jam.
Sterilise your jars and lids by washing them in hot soapy water, rinsing well and drying them in a warm oven. Spoon the hot relish into the hot jars and seal. Leave to cool.
chief_review: This festive relish is a beautifully balanced blend of sweet, tart, and warming spice notes—perfect for elevating holiday cheese boards or roasted meats. The combination of dried cranberries and pears lends both richness and texture, while the ginger, allspice, and chili offer depth and a gentle heat. Its shelf life of up to six months makes it an excellent candidate for make-ahead gifts. With no eggs, dairy, or animal products, this recipe is naturally vegan and suitable for vegetarians. Additionally, it's gluten-free, as all the listed ingredients are free from gluten-containing grains. Its thoughtful use of natural fruit and spices is ideal for those seeking festive flavors without artificial additives. An impressive, versatile relish—ideal for thoughtful gifting or enhancing your own holiday spread.

name: Jolly marshmallow snowmen
description: Young children will love making these marshmallow treats with liquorice, chocolate and icing decorations.
author: Valerie Barrett
directions: Take one cake pop stick and thread on a marshmallow, narrow end on first. Thread on a second marshmallow, wide end on first so the the two wide ends meet in the middle. Thread a third marshmallow on sideways so the narrow round end makes the snowman's face.
Knead the white fondant icing and divide into 6. Shape each one into a rough mound and stick the snowmen into these bases.
Take three strawberry laces and twist together. Tie around a snowman's neck and then trim off the excess with scissors. Repeat for the other snowmen.
Using a little royal icing stick a Pontefract cake on each head. Using a little black writing icing, stick a Liquorice Allsort on top of each Pontefract cake.
Pipe on two eyes using black writing icing. Using royal icing, stick a Tic Tac on each face for a carrot nose. Stick mini chocolate beans on the bodies as buttons.

Using royal icing, stick four mini marshmallows on each snowman to represent arms. Stick a candy cane or pretzel stick to the end of one of each of the snowmen's arms, attaching the bottom end to the icing mound.
Take a little royal icing and thin with a few drops of water. Brush or dab on the base and sprinkle over the crushed sugar cubes. Leave to set.
chief_review: This playful and visually delightful marshmallow treat recipe is sure to capture the imagination of young children, making for a fun and interactive kitchen activity. The combination of white marshmallows, fondant, royal icing, liquorice, and a medley of candies brings together sweetness and creative flair. The recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, provided the marshmallows and fondant are confirmed to use no animal-derived gelatin. However, always check labels for hidden animal products or additives, especially in sweets like marshmallows and fondant. The treats’ variety of candies may also cater to egg-free diets, but again, ingredient verification is key. The preparation process encourages creativity, and the finished product is perfect for parties or festive occasions. Overall, this is a delightful recipe for holiday fun and edible crafting.

name: Perky penguins
description: Children will love creating these chocolate penguins - the fruit pastilles and icing decorations add a fun wintery finish
author: Valerie Barrett
ingredients: 3 red fruit pastilles(we used Tesco as they look like wooly hats)
directions: Cut the jumbo chocolate buttons in half and place together in pairs, rounded sides touching, to make feet. Snap the walnut off the top of the walnut whip and discard. Put a little royal icing on each pair of feet and stick a walnut whip on top.

Divide the fondant icing in three. Take one piece and roll out into a sausage that is fat in the middle and thin at both ends. Flatten the ends to make flippers. Place the sausage on top of the walnut whip and shape the fat middle section into a head. Leave the flippers to hang free at the sides.

To decorate, put the remaining royal icing into a piping or plastic bag and snip a tiny bit off the end. Pipe a circle on the front of each penguin. Pipe two dots for eyes. Pipe a circle on top of each head and stick on a fruit pastille. Pipe a blob on top for a bobble.
Carefully cut three triangular pieces from the orange fruit pastille and stick on the face. Using the black writing icing pipe black dots in the centre of each eye. Leave to set.
chief_review: This playful chocolate penguin recipe is a delightful treat for children, inviting creativity with a whimsical wintery finish. The combination of walnut whips, jumbo chocolate buttons, and fondant icing offers a pleasing variety of textures, while fruit pastilles bring vibrant pops of color and a touch of tartness. The use of royal icing sugar ensures smooth, workable icing, ideal for assembling and detailing. Since all key components are vegetarian, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, it is important to note the presence of nuts (from the walnut whips) and potential allergens in the ready-to-roll fondant and candies. Overall, this charming confection is perfect for festive family activities and is sure to delight both in taste and presentation.

name: Chocolate meringue Mont Blanc cake
description: This towering cake has layers of chocolate sponge, meringue and chestnut cream - a stunning centrepiece for a festive dinner party
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 200g chestnut puréefrom a 415g can (reserve the rest for the filling, below)
100g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Grease 2 deep 20cm loose-bottomed cake tins and line the base and sides with baking parchment. Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/ gas 3. Melt the chocolate and butter in a bowl over a pan of gently simmering water, then set aside to cool a little.

In a large bowl, whisk the whole eggs, yolks and sugars with an electric whisk until doubled in size – this will take about 5 mins. Sieve in the flour, cocoa and baking power with a pinch of salt. Fold the chestnut purée into the chocolate butter mixture, then add to the other bowl and gently fold everything together. Divide evenly between the tins.

Working quickly, clean the whisks and your large bowl, put the egg whites in the bowl and whisk until stiff. Add the sugar, a spoonful at a time, whisking continuously, until thick and able to hold stiff peaks. Use a spoon to dot the meringue on top of the cake mixture in both tins, then use the back of the spoon to spread the mixture. Fill the gaps to touch the edges of the tins – make nice swirly dips and peaks as you spread. Bake for 1 hr 15 mins until a skewer inserted into the middle of the cake comes out with moist but set crumbs. Cool completely.

When you’re ready to serve, make the filling. Put the cream, chestnut purée and icing sugar in a bowl and whisk until softly whipped. Remove the cakes from their tins and place 1 on a cake stand or plate (save the one with the prettiest top for the final layer). Dollop on the cream and swirl out towards the edges (don’t worry if you crush the meringue a bit). Place the next sponge on top, dust with icing sugar, then top with chocolate shavings, if using. Best served straight away, but will keep in the fridge for 2 days.
chief_review: This impressive dessert layers moist chocolate sponge, crisp meringue, and luscious chestnut cream for an indulgent showstopper—ideal for festive occasions. The combination of rich dark chocolate and earthy chestnut purée offers depth, while the double cream and sugar create a decadent, melt-in-the-mouth experience. The meringue adds texture and a delightful sweetness, balancing the bittersweet chocolate. This recipe is perfect for those seeking a luxurious, memorable centerpiece for a dinner party. As it contains wheat flour, dairy, eggs, and chestnut purée, it’s well-suited to vegetarians, but not for dairy-free, vegan, or gluten-free diets. The elegant finish with chocolate shavings and icing sugar dusting makes this cake visually stunning and ready to impress guests both in appearance and flavor.

name: Custard & crumble mince pies
description: Holy moly! These are awesome they look so good that i am making them again again.
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 125g unsalted butter, cold from the fridge
185g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put a baking sheet in the oven on the middle shelf.
Cut the butter into small cubes. Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl and add a pinch of salt.
Tip the butter into the flour and use your fingers to rub the two together until it resembles breadcrumbs.
Stir in 2 tbsp of the sugar. Scoop a heaped half cup (85g) of the crumbs into a smaller bowl and set aside.

Have two small bowls ready. Crack the egg on the side of one bowl, then carefully pull the shell apart in two halves, letting the yolk nestle into one side. Let the white drain away from the yolk into one bowl and put the yolk into the other bowl.
Beat the egg yolk with a fork, then add it to the bigger bowl of butter and flour mix. Use a cutlery knife to stir the yolk into the crumbs.
Put your hand in the bowl and squeeze the crumbs together to make a ball. Knead the pastry a few times until smooth.
Sprinkle some flour over your work surface. Sprinkle a little more over the pastry and roll it out to the thickness of two £1 coins.
Stamp the pastry with an 8cm cutter, re-rolling the trimmings to make 12 rounds.
Gently push the rounds of pastry into the bun tin. Spoon 1 heaped tsp of the custard into each pastry case, followed by the mincemeat on top.
Add the final 1 tbsp sugar to the smaller bowl of crumb mix. Pinch it together to make bigger clumps and mound it on top of the mincemeat.
Slide the bun tin on top of the baking sheet and bake for 15 mins until golden brown and the custard and mincemeat are starting to bubble.
Cool in the tin for 15 mins, then carefully lift the pies onto a rack and leave to cool. Will keep for 2 days in an airtight tin.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a delightful take on a classic dessert, balancing the richness of unsalted butter with the sweet tang of golden caster sugar and mincemeat. The shortcrust pastry is tender thanks to the cold butter, while the inclusion of custard adds a creamy, indulgent twist to each bite. This treat is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it avoids gelatine or animal rennet, relying on egg for structure and mincemeat (assuming it’s the commonly available vegetarian version). The preparation is straightforward, and the flavors feel festive and nostalgic—a perfect bake for gatherings or a cozy weekend treat.

name: Mint-choc mousse
description: So disappointed with this recipe. No warning that the chocolate can go rock hard if too cool when the rest of the ingredients are added - be warned before ££s of ingredients end up in the bin!
author: Cassie Best
directions: With the chocolate bar flat-side up, scrape a large kitchen knife over the surface to create chocolate curls (you only need enough to decorate the mousses before serving). Transfer to a plate and chill. Finely chop the remaining chocolate and put in a bowl set over a pan of gently simmering water, stirring every now and then, until melted. Alternatively, melt in the microwave in short bursts, to ensure it doesn’t burn. Set aside to cool for 10 mins.

Put the cream and peppermint extract in a bowl. Put the egg whites in another bowl with a small pinch of salt. Using very clean beaters, whisk the egg whites until they hold stiff peaks, add the sugar and briefly whisk again. Transfer the beaters to the cream and whisk until just holding its shape, then fold in 200g of the yogurt. Stir the egg yolks into the melted chocolate.

Add a large spoonful of egg white to the chocolate mix and stir to loosen the consistency. Add the remaining egg whites and the whipped cream. Gently fold everything together with a large metal spoon, trying to keep as much air in the mixture as possible. When there are no more visible streaks, transfer to eight serving glasses and chill for 2 hrs, or cover with cling film and chill for up to 24 hrs.
Before serving, top each mousse with a spoonful of yogurt, pomegranate seeds, chocolate shavings and mint leaves.
chief_review: This recipe creates a rich, decadent dessert that beautifully balances bittersweet dark chocolate with the refreshing lift of peppermint and pomegranate. As a chef, I appreciate the luxurious mouthfeel from the combination of double cream and Greek yogurt, while the egg yolks and whites provide body and lightness. However, the technique here is critical: if the chocolate cools too much before blending with other ingredients, it will seize and become unworkable, so swift mixing is essential—temper the ingredients carefully to avoid this. This dessert is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it doesn't contain gelatin or animal rennet. Note, however, that it is not suitable for those with dairy or egg allergies. Presented with fresh mint and pomegranate, it’s elegant and festive—just mind your timings for a smooth, airy finish.

name: Faux gras with toast & pickles
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 300g organic chickenor duck livers, trimmed, cleaned and patted dry
directions: Heat 50g butter in a frying pan until sizzling, add the livers and fry for 4 mins until coloured on the outside and slightly pink in the middle. Leave to cool, then tip the contents of the pan into a food processor or a smoothie
. Season generously with salt and add the remaining butter. Blitz until you have a smooth purée, then scrape into a container, smooth over the top and place in the fridge to chill for at least 2 hrs.

To serve, griddle slices of brioche or sourdough, and tip some cornichons and chutney into small pots. Put a large spoon in a cup of hot water. As if serving ice cream, scoop a spoonful of the faux gras onto each plate, dipping the spoon into the water after each scoop. Sprinkle a few salt flakes over each scoop and serve with the toasts, cornichons and chutney.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a classic and indulgent pâté experience, marrying the richness of organic chicken or duck livers with the velvety mouthfeel of softened butter. Served atop toasted brioche or sourdough, its creamy texture contrasts beautifully with the crunch of cornichons and the sweet tang of chutney. A finishing touch of sea salt flakes heightens the flavors. This dish is inherently suitable for gluten-free diets if served with gluten-free bread instead of brioche or sourdough, and aligns well with a low-carb approach by omitting the bread. Those following a vegetarian or vegan diet will need to look elsewhere, as the base of this spread relies on animal products. Overall, this recipe shines as a luxurious appetizer or starter—perfect for entertaining and highlighting simple, high-quality ingredients.

name: Peppermint creams
description:
Hi. I would like to make these as presents.
Could you give me the shelf life please?
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Sieve the icing sugar into a large bowl. Add a little of the egg white and a few drops of the peppermint essence and mix really well. You want the mixture to come together as a soft dough, so keep adding a little egg white until this starts to happen (you might not need to use all of it). Taste the mixture and add more peppermint essence if desired.
Divide the mixture into 20 small balls, then flatten them gently with your fingertips into discs.

Place baking parchment on a large board or tray and space out the discs. Meanwhile, tip the chocolate into a microwavable bowl and heat in 30 second intervals in the microwave until melted, stirring after each blast. Once melted, leave the chocolate to cool for 5-10 mins then carefully dip the peppermint creams in the melted chocolate until they are half coated. Lay them back on the baking parchment to set for 3-4 hours or overnight.
chief_review: This recipe yields a classic peppermint fondant, a delightful confection perfect for gifting. The use of icing sugar, egg white, and peppermint essence creates a smooth, refreshing sweet, and the optional dark chocolate coating adds a contrasting richness. Suitable for vegetarians, this treat can also cater to gluten-free diets, as the listed ingredients contain no gluten-based components. Those with dairy intolerances will appreciate the absence of milk products, provided the chosen dark chocolate is also dairy-free. However, the inclusion of raw egg white necessitates cautious handling and storage—these should be kept refrigerated and consumed within a week for safety. Overall, it's a charming, elegant sweet with clean flavors and a pleasing texture.

name: Gravadlax with celeriac & fennel salad
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 7 tbsp extra virgin olive oil(a fruity one, not a bitter Tuscan one)
juice 1 lemon(you may not need it at all)
15g bunch dill, leaves only, roughly chopped
directions: Make the dressing first. Put the mustard, honey, garlic, vinegar and some seasoning in a cup, and whisk in the oil in a steady stream. Stir in the cream, then check the seasoning – it should be sweet-sour.
Put some of the lemon juice in a mixing bowl. Peel the celeriac and cut the flesh into matchsticks, tossing these in the lemon juice as you go to stop the flesh discolouring.

Quarter the fennel and remove any coarse outer leaves. Trim the tips, reserving any tufty fronds. Cut out the core from each piece. Using a very sharp knife or a mandolin, slice the fennel lengthways – the slices should be almost transparent. Toss with the celeriac and add some more lemon juice.

Cut the onion as finely as possible (it’s best to do this on a mandolin too). Halve the apples, core and cut into matchsticks (there’s no need to peel them). Add to the bowl with the onions, and add a little more lemon juice (to keep the apple from turning brown). Chop any fennel fronds and add along with the dill. Toss with the dressing.
Divide the salad between eight plates with some gravadlax alongside, or serve the gravadlax and offer the salad in a large bowl.
chief_review:
This dish is a vibrant, Scandi-inspired salad that elegantly balances earthy celeriac, crisp apples, and delicately sweet fennel with the luxurious, silky gravadlax or smoked salmon. The dressing—a lively blend of wholegrain mustard, honey, cider vinegar, olive oil, and a touch of cream—lifts the flavors, while aromatic dill lends a bright, herbal finish. The combination is texturally appealing and visually stunning, perfect as a refined starter or light main. 

With its focus on fresh vegetables, fruits, and high-quality fish, this recipe is ideal for pescatarians and suits a gluten-free diet, provided that your mustard is gluten-free. It’s also free from common allergens like nuts and soy. A balanced, seasonal plate for those who appreciate nuanced flavors and a modern approach to classic Nordic ingredients.

name: One-pot partridge with drunken potatoes
description: I made this on xmas eve using the recommended substitute of poussin. Very quick and easy to prepare and cook, will definitely be making this one again. Recommended.
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: buttered cavolo neroor shredded sprout tops, to serve
directions: Season the partridges (including the cavity) generously. Put a juniper berry, a thyme sprig, a bay leaf and a garlic clove in each cavity. Chop the bacon into chunky pieces and slice the potato lengthways into six thick slices, discarding the ends.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Heat half the duck fat or butter in a flameproof casserole dish until just sizzling, then brown the birds on all sides for 10 mins. Remove them from the dish and set aside. Add the rest of the fat to the dish and gently fry the potato slices until very brown and crisp on each side. Add the bacon and sizzle with the potatoes until starting to brown. Sit the birds on top of the potatoes and pour over the wine. Put in the oven, uncovered, for 15 mins.
Remove the birds from the dish and leave somewhere warm to rest for 10 mins. Baste the potatoes, return to the oven until cooked through, then scatter over the parsley.
To serve, sit the birds back in the pan and bring to the table or plate up with the potatoes. Serve with cavolo nero or sprout tops.
chief_review: This festive partridge recipe is a delightful showcase of classic flavors, highlighted by aromatic juniper, thyme, and rich red wine. The use of smoked streaky bacon and a choice of duck fat or butter imparts a satisfyingly deep savoriness, while the tender Maris Piper potatoes offer a hearty base. It’s a straightforward preparation—perfect for an elegant dinner with minimal fuss. Though not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the poultry, bacon, and fat, it can be adapted for gluten-free diets as the ingredients listed are naturally gluten-free. The final touch of fresh parsley and buttered cavolo nero or sprout tops lends color and brightness, elevating the dish from homely comfort to festive centerpiece. An excellent option for those seeking a classic, robust winter meal, and sure to impress at any special occasion.

name: Sloe royales
author: James Martin
directions: Divide the gin between 2 Champagne flutes and top up each with 150ml Champagne or Prosecco. For an extra sparkle, add a sprinkle of edible glitter to each flute before filling.
chief_review: This festive cocktail elegantly combines the rich, fruity notes of sloe gin with the effervescent sparkle of Champagne or prosecco, resulting in a drink that's both sophisticated and celebratory. The optional addition of edible glitter adds a whimsical touch, perfect for special occasions or to elevate any gathering. Crafted without any animal-derived or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is naturally suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, as well as for those following a gluten-free lifestyle—provided the sloe gin and sparkling wine are confirmed as vegan and gluten-free brands. The method is straightforward: simply pour chilled sloe gin into a flute, top with your sparkling of choice, and finish with a dusting of glitter if desired. Enjoy this cocktail as a delightful aperitif or toast.

name: Icy kir
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: a scoop of blackcurrant or raspberry sorbet
directions: Pour the vodka into the bottom of a coupe glass. Chill for 30 mins, then top with the blackcurrant or raspberry sorbet and pour the Prosecco around it. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail is a delightful blend, with vodka adding a crisp kick, tangy sorbet offering elegance and fruity depth, and prosecco delivering a refreshing effervescence. The recipe’s playful use of sorbet ensures a chilled, dessert-like texture, perfect as a palate cleanser or celebratory treat. Since it contains no animal-derived ingredients, this concoction is well-suited for a vegetarian diet. However, those observing a vegan diet should ensure their prosecco is labeled vegan, and that the sorbet is free from dairy or honey. Additionally, this recipe is naturally gluten-free, provided the vodka is distilled from gluten-free sources. Overall, this drink is visually striking and sophisticated, ideal for special occasions or as a creative dinner party offering.

name: Sticky pear tarts with Roquefort cream
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Unravel the pastry and cut out two 15cm diameter circles using a saucer or small plate as a guide. Put them on a tray and prick all over with a fork. Peel, core and halve the pears lengthways. Finely slice each half and arrange in a neat overlapping circle in the middle of the pastry, leaving a 2cm border. Roll up and crimp the edges of the pastry to tuck the pears neatly into the tart.
To make the cream, whisk the cream and honey together to form soft peaks, add the cheese and continue to whisk. Scrape into a small container and chill until needed.

Put a baking tray in the oven and heat to 200C/180C/gas 6. For the glaze, put the sugar in a pan over a medium heat until it melts and caramelises. Pour this over the pears, then put the tarts on the hot baking tray and cook for 15 mins until they’re puffed up and golden. Lift the tarts onto warmed plates and serve with a spoonful of the Roquefort cream so it melts on top.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful combination of sweet and savory, featuring ripe pear and rich Roquefort atop buttery, crisp puff pastry. The gentle tang of the blue cheese melds beautifully with the honeyed pears, bringing a sophisticated balance of flavors. The golden caster sugar and cream add lusciousness and a mildly caramelized finish. With its mix of fruit and cheese, this recipe shines as an elegant starter or a unique dessert for those who appreciate complex tastes. Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, as all ingredients are plant-based or derived from milk, it also avoids nuts, making it an appealing option for nut allergy concerns. Use gluten-free puff pastry if a gluten-free version is needed, though the standard recipe includes wheat. Overall, a simple yet impressive dish with a gourmet touch.

name: Coco fizz
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put the coconut rum, coconut water and lime juice into a cocktail shaker, add ice and shake until the outside of the shaker is icy-cold to the touch. Strain into a chilled coupe glass, top with the Prosecco and serve.
chief_review: A refreshing and tropical-inspired cocktail, this recipe artfully balances the sweetness of coconut rum with the subtle, natural flavor of coconut water and a bright touch from fresh lime juice, all lifted by the effervescent prosecco. The drink is light on the palate, making it an ideal aperitif or a vibrant addition to any summer gathering. Its ingredients are free from dairy, eggs, and animal-derived products, making it suitable for a vegan diet. Additionally, it does not contain common allergens such as nuts or gluten, suiting gluten-free requirements when using prosecco that’s certified gluten-free. The preparation is straightforward—simply shake or stir the base with ice, strain, and top with prosecco for a lively, sophisticated finish. This cocktail is a delightful option for those seeking a simple yet elegant beverage that feels like a brief escape to the tropics.

name: Slow-cooked goose with cranberry salsa
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 1 whole goose(about 6kg), giblets removed, trimmed or excess fat
directions: Take the goose out of the fridge 1 hr before cooking. Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. In a frying pan, toast the whole spices over a medium heat until aromatic. Use a pestle and mortar (or spice grinder) to grind to a fine powder. Mix in the crumbled stock cubes, orange zest, 1 tsp salt and cinnamon.

Lay the goose in a high-sided roasting tin, score the skin all over with a sharp knife and rub in the spice mix, making sure you press into all the cut marks. Loosely cover the tin with foil and roast for 2 hrs, then remove the foil and roast for a further 2 hrs. Once cooked, rest for at least 20 mins, loosely covered with foil. Reserving the fat to roast your cabbage (see goes well with).
