While the goose cooks, make the salsa. Fry the onions in the oil over a medium heat for 10-15 mins until golden brown. Add the cranberries, cook for a few more mins, then remove from the heat. Mix in the remaining salsa ingredients and keep in a warm place to allow the flavours to infuse. Carve the goose and serve with the salsa.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a succulent whole goose, elevated by aromatic spices like star anise, cloves, and cinnamon, which beautifully infuse the meat. The use of orange, lime, and cranberries brings a lively citrus tang and a hint of natural sweetness, balancing the richness of the goose. The addition of green chillies and fresh thyme adds depth and a gentle heat, while the cranberry sauce melds the fruit flavours with savoury undertones. The inclusion of chicken stock cubes means this dish is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, but it can cater to those seeking a festive, flavour-forward main course that celebrates both spice and fruit. If serving at a gathering, pair this goose with simple sides to let the complex flavours shine. Overall, this is an impressive centerpiece for those looking to enjoy a sophisticated and aromatic roast.

name: Whisky & pink peppercorn marmalade kit
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 500g mix of oranges, clementines and lemons
directions: Halve the fruits and squeeze the juices into a large saucepan. Remove all the peel and set aside. Put the flesh in the pan with 1 litre water and boil for 15 mins. Push through a sieve lined with muslin and return the liquid to the pan.

Shred the peel and tip into a heatproof bowl. Add enough water to just cover and microwave for 3-4 mins until soft. Add the peel to the pan, then add the sugar. Boil for 35-45 mins until the marmalade has reached setting point (keep an eye on it so it doesn’t bubble over).
Remove from the heat and add 1 tsp pink peppercorns. Allow the mixture to cool a little, then stir in 50ml whisky. Ladle into sterilised jars and seal. Will keep for up to one year.
chief_review: This vibrant citrus jam recipe brings together the lively flavors of oranges, clementines, and lemons, balanced with the warmth of demerara sugar and spiced subtlety of pink peppercorns. A generous splash of whisky lends complexity, making this preserve truly unique—perfect for elevating anything from morning toast to gourmet cheeseboards. The preparation relies on classic jam-making techniques, so set aside time for gentle simmering and careful straining through muslin. With no animal-derived ingredients, the jam is suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets. There are no obvious gluten sources, making this a potential treat for those avoiding gluten, though anyone with severe allergies should always check labels on whisky. Store the richly colored jam in sterilized jars, and don’t forget to label each one—this special preserve makes a thoughtful homemade gift as well as a lively addition to your pantry.

name: Fresh & smoked salmon rillettes
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 2 tbsp lemon juice, plus a squeeze
small bunch parsley, stalks only (use the leaves below)
125g smoked salmon, cut into small shreds
1 tbsp chopped chervil(or chives if you can't get chervil)
rye breadand chicory leaves, to serve (optional)
2 tbsp capers, rinsed of salt or brine
directions: Put the vermouth, onion, lemon juice, parsley stalks and peppercorns in a saucepan with 150ml water and bring to the boil. Simmer for 10 mins. Turn the heat down to a very gentle simmer, add the salmon fillet and poach for 4 mins. Let the salmon sit and cool in the liquid.

Lift the salmon out of its poaching liquid, remove the skin and flake the flesh roughly. Mix the flesh with the smoked salmon, a good squeeze of lemon, the butter, chervil and some pepper. Tip into a bowl, cover and put in the fridge (be sure to bring it back to room temperature to serve).

Mix the crème fraîche with the herbs, capers, shallot, oil and lemon juice to taste. Serve the rillettes with leaves of chicory – its bitterness is very good against the richness of the salmon – the caper crème fraîche and some rye bread, if you like.
chief_review:
This recipe features the gentle poaching of fresh salmon in an aromatic bath of vermouth, onion, parsley stalks, and peppercorns, layered with the decadent addition of smoked salmon. The amalgamation of crème fraîche, capers, herbs, and shallots creates a refreshing yet rich spread or topping, enhanced by a touch of lemon and olive oil. The key accompaniments—rye bread and chicory leaves—provide a pleasing balance of earthy and bitter notes.

This dish is beautifully suited for pescatarian diets and is free from nuts, making it appropriate for nut-free needs. However, it contains dairy (crème fraîche and butter) and fish, which may be allergens for some. The optional serving suggestions give flexibility, and the overall preparation guarantees a harmonious blend of textures and bright, savory flavors—a refined starter or sophisticated addition to a brunch.

name: Mulled mead
description: I just made a take on this! I substitute fennel seed for the clove and cherry bitters in place of apple juice. A splash of grenadine turns the cherry around quite nicely. All in all a very well cocktail.
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour the mead (or cider) into a saucepan and add the brandy, apple juice, lemon peel, cloves, cinnamon stick and ginger. Gently warm through until simmering then remove the spices and lemon zest with tongs or strain through a sieve before serving.
chief_review: This inventive cocktail combines the florality of mead or cider with warming spices and a hint of citrus. The addition of brandy deepens the flavor, while cloves, cinnamon, and ginger offer complexity and a gentle heat. Swapping fennel seed for clove invites a subtle anise note, and the use of cherry bitters and grenadine adds a lush, fruity depth that balances the apple and ties all the elements together. This recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients. However, vegans should take care, as some meads and ciders may use animal-based clarifying agents during production. Those with gluten sensitivities can enjoy the cocktail, provided they choose a gluten-free mead or cider. Overall, it’s an aromatic, layered drink perfect for festive gatherings or a cozy night in.

name: Spiced lemon & ginger biscuits
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: ½ tsp coarsely ground black pepper
50g candied lemon peel(or a mix of lemon and orange)
50g stem ginger, chopped into small chunks
directions: Mix the butter and sugar with a wooden spoon. Stir in the spices, lemon zest and flour, then tip in the candied lemon peel and stem ginger – you might need to get your hands in to bring the mix together as a dough. Divide the dough in two and shape each half into a log about 5cm across. Wrap in cling film, then chill for 1 hr.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Slice the logs into 1cm-thick rounds, place on two
lined with baking parchment and bake for 12-15 mins. Leave to cool completely on the tray.
Mix the lemon juice with the icing sugar to make a thin glaze. Brush over the biscuits and leave to set.
chief_review: This recipe yields a rich, aromatic biscuit with a pronounced ginger and citrus profile, balanced by the warmth of cinnamon and the subtle heat of black pepper. The combined use of muscovado sugar and stem ginger lends a deep, complex sweetness, while the candied peel and fresh lemon zest provide a bright, zesty contrast. The texture promises to be tender, thanks to the butter and plain flour. A simple icing finishes these biscuits with an extra layer of sweetness that complements the spices beautifully. Suitable for vegetarians, these biscuits would make an excellent addition to a festive tea or dessert platter.

name: Mince pie brownies
description: It wasn’t cooked after 30 minutes, family still ate them but I will be interested in anyone else cooking these to know if there’s were cooked okay. Not sure what went wrong.
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Melt the butter and chocolate in a medium bowl, either in a

– cooking for 1 min on High, then stirring and continuing to heat in 20-second blasts – or by setting the bowl over a pan of simmering water and stirring occasionally. Once melted, leave the mixture to cool.

Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line the base of a shallow 20cm square tin with non-stick baking parchment. Sieve the flour and cocoa into a medium bowl. Whisk the eggs and sugar with an electric
on maximum speed until thick and creamy, about 3-8 mins, or when the mixture runs off the beaters and leaves a trail for a second or two.
Pour in the cooled chocolate mixture, then fold together with a rubber
in a figure of eight, moving the bowl round until the mixture is a mottled dark brown. Be gentle so you don’t knock out the air.
Sift in the cocoa and flour mixture and continue gently folding. The mixture will look dry and dusty, then fudgy. Stop just before you feel you should, as you don’t want to overmix it.

Spoon a little mixture into the prepared tin, then add the mince pies, leaving them whole. Scrape over the rest of the mixture, gently easing it between and over the pies. Level the top. Put in the oven for 25 mins. If the brownie mixture is very wobbly in the middle, it’s not quite done, so bake for another 5 mins until the top has a shiny, papery crust and the sides are just beginning to come away from the tin. Take out of the oven and leave to cool in the tin. Dust with icing sugar. Cut into quarters, then cut each quarter into four squares.
chief_review: This recipe promises a decadent twist on traditional brownies by incorporating mince pies, offering a festive richness and complexity of flavor. The use of high-quality dark chocolate and cocoa powder delivers a deep, chocolatey intensity, while golden caster sugar adds a subtle caramel sweetness. Be sure to thoroughly check for doneness—brownies should have set edges with a slightly fudgy center, as indicated by a skewer coming out with some moist crumbs. Attention to baking time is key, especially with the extra moisture from the mince pies, which can slow the cooking process. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, these brownies do not contain meat or gelatine, but are not vegan or gluten-free. Dusting with icing sugar adds a refined finish. A wonderful treat for those seeking a holiday-inspired chocolate dessert!

name: Mini jackfruit tacos with charred sweetcorn & gochujang mayo
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: ½ bunch fresh coriander, finely chopped
1 red chilli(deseeded if you don’t like it too hot), finely chopped
directions: Mix the gochujang with the mayonnaise, then season and set aside. Boil the corn cob for 5 mins, then drain, cool and pat dry. Grill on high for 10 mins until starting to blacken, turning frequently. Leave to cool. Cut each of the tortillas into four smaller circles using a 9cm cutter. Shred the off-cuts, then fry in the oil for about 1 min, or until crisp. Drain on kitchen paper.

Warm the tortilla rounds in the microwave for 1 min, then put on a serving plate. Drain the jackfruit and mix with the gochujang mayo, then divide between the tortillas. Scatter the pineapple, coriander and chilli over the jackfruit, then squeeze over the lime wedges. Cut the kernels off the sweetcorn cob and spoon onto the tacos, then top with the fried tortilla pieces.
chief_review: This jackfruit and pineapple tortilla recipe brings together vibrant flavors and textures, making it a standout for those seeking a plant-based meal. The jackfruit provides a satisfying, meaty bite, while the sweetness of pineapple and fresh coriander create a refreshing balance, complemented by the subtle heat of gochujang and red chilli. A tangy squeeze of lime and creamy gochujang mayo elevate each bite, contrasting beautifully against the charred corn and tortillas. This dish is ideal for vegetarians and can be easily adapted for a vegan diet by substituting vegan mayonnaise. While the flour tortillas are typically not gluten-free, swapping in gluten-free tortillas extends its versatility. A crowd-pleaser, this recipe impresses both in taste and presentation, making it suitable for casual dinners or dynamic gatherings.

name: Croque madame traybake
author: Dan Doherty
ingredients: 6 slices gruyèreor any other hard, melty cheese you have
directions: To make the sauce, heat the milk in a
with the onion, cloves and bay leaf. When boiling, turn off the heat and leave to infuse for 30 mins, then strain.
Melt the butter in another pan and add the flour. Cook for 4-5 mins until sandy. Gradually
in the milk, then cook over a medium heat, stirring, until you have a thick sauce. Stir in the mustard and season. Set aside to cool.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter a

large enough to fit 3 slices of bread, then butter and toast the bread, and make 3 sandwiches with 2 slices of ham and cheese in each. Spread the white sauce on top, and make a small well in the sauce on each sandwich. Crack the eggs into the wells, then scatter over the parmesan. Bake for 20 mins or until the whites are just set.
chief_review: This recipe masterfully combines classic flavors—smoked ham, gruyère, and a robust mustard-infused béchamel—for what appears to be an elevated take on the French croque-monsieur or a decadent ham and cheese bake. The preparation highlights the careful use of infusing milk with onion, cloves, and bay leaf, adding depth to the creamy sauce enveloping each layer. The generous topping of Parmesan before baking ensures a golden, savory crust. Ideal for those seeking a comforting, indulgent dish, especially at brunch. Please note that, with its focus on dairy, wheat flour, and ham, this recipe is suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians, who allow eggs and dairy but abstain from meat, may not use this recipe; however, it’s perfect for anyone without specific dietary restrictions or allergies to gluten or dairy. The method and ingredient selection showcase a commitment to both tradition and hearty satisfaction.

name: Mini turkey & cranberry pies
description: These dinky pies are so versatile – try them with chopped ham and mustard, too
author: Good Food
directions: Roll out the pastry on a floured surface so that it’s just thinner than a £1 coin. Cut out 8 x 10cm circles using a pastry cutter or small saucer, then cut 8 x 9cm circles for the lids – you may need to re-roll the trimmings. Push the larger circles into 8 holes of a muffin tin, then divide the turkey, cream and cranberry sauce between them. Season well and brush the edges with a little egg. Place a lid on top of each and pinch the sides together to seal. Chill for 15-20 mins.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Brush the tops with more egg, then bake for 25 mins until the pastry is crisp and golden. Serve warm, or leave to cool and enjoy cold.
chief_review: This mini pie recipe offers a delightful way to use up leftover turkey, pairing succulent shredded meat with a touch of decadent double cream or crème fraîche and a sweet tang of cranberry sauce—all enveloped in a golden, flaky shortcrust pastry. The simple ingredients maintain a lovely balance of creamy and savory notes, with the cranberry sauce cutting through richness for a festive pop. For those with dietary requirements, the pies are suitable for a nut-free diet, and, using standard shortcrust pastry and dairy, they can be enjoyed by vegetarians who consume eggs and dairy if the filling is adapted (swap turkey for roasted vegetables or cheese). Quick to assemble and easy to customize, they make an excellent addition to a holiday table or lunchbox.

name: Leftover veg & orange cake
description: A novel way to use up root vegetables is to bake up a sweet, moist sponge with citrus flavours
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 200g butter, melted, plus extra for greasing
zest and juice 2 oranges, or 4 clementines
4 large eggs, beaten with a fork
300g carrots, parsnips, pumpkin, butternut squash or swede, or a mixture, grated
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease and line a 30 x 20cm baking or roasting tin with baking parchment. Mix the sultanas and zest and juice from 1 orange (or 2 clementines), and microwave on High for 2 mins.

Mix the flour, caster sugar, spices, bicarb and pinch of salt into a large bowl. Mix the eggs with the melted butter and sultana mixture, then tip into the dry ingredients and stir in with a wooden spoon. Stir in the grated veg, and scrape into the tin. Bake for 35 - 40 mins, or until a skewer poked in the centre comes out clean. Cool in the tin.

Once cool sift the icing sugar into a bowl and stir in remaining orange zest plus enough juice to make a runny icing. Drizzle all over the cake and scatter with the crushed sugar cubes. Leave to set, then slice into 15 squares to serve.
chief_review:
This inventive sponge cake is a delightful homage to root vegetables, seamlessly blending their natural sweetness with a lively citrus punch from oranges or clementines. The mixture of grated carrots, parsnips, and squash imparts moisture and subtle earthiness, while sultanas or raisins add bursts of chewy fruitiness. Richly spiced with ginger and mixed spice, the cake is aromatic and warming, perfect for cooler months. A light, zesty glaze and a scattering of sugar cubes create an appealing finish. Using self-raising flour gives the sponge a pleasing lift and tenderness. 

Notably, this bake is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, relying solely on plant-derived ingredients (aside from eggs and dairy butter). However, some ingredients (eggs, butter) mean it isn’t vegan. For those seeking nut-free treats, this recipe is a great option, as it contains no nuts by default. This cake is an inspired, crowd-pleasing way to utilize surplus root vegetables.

name: Sticky treacle-glazed ham
description: James uses the steam-roast directions to cook his Christmas ham, so you don't need an enormous pan to boil it in
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2 oranges, 1 cut into wedges and finely grated zest and juice of the other
big bunch bay leavesand orange segments, to serve (optional)
directions: If you need to soak the ham, do so the night before. Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Place the ham, skin-side up, in a deep roasting tin, then add enough water to cover the base of the tin. Scatter the orange wedges and cinnamon stick around. Cover the pan with a tight tent of foil, then cook the ham for about 2½ hrs. (If using a different weight of ham, you want 20 mins per 450g.)
While the ham is cooking, mix the mustard, treacle and orange zest together with enough orange juice to make a mixture loose enough to paint over the ham.

When the ham has had its time, remove the roasting tin from the oven and turn up the heat to 220C/ fan 200C/gas 7. Remove the foil, leave the ham until cool enough to handle, then pour away any liquid in the tin. Using a sharp knife, carefully cut away the skin to leave an even layer of fat. Use the tip of the knife to score the ham fat diagonally at 3cm intervals – first in one direction, then the other, to produce a diamond pattern. Liberally paint the glaze over the fat, then stud with the cloves at the points of the diamond shapes.

Roast the ham for 30 mins until glazed and just beginning to char around the edges. Leave to cool and serve warm or cold, decorated with the bay and orange wedges, if you like, along with my delicious green bean salad and your favourite chutney.
chief_review: James’s steam-roast method for Christmas ham is a wonderfully practical approach, especially for smaller kitchens. The ham is infused with warming aromatics from bay leaves, cinnamon, and oranges, with black treacle and English mustard adding depth and a sweet, peppery glaze. The liberal use of citrus balances the richness of the meat, while whole cloves give the ham a festive, spiced finish. This recipe is perfect for those following a gluten-free diet, provided you verify your mustard and treacle products, as it contains no wheat-based ingredients. However, it is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, as the main ingredient is ham. Allergy-wise, if mustard allergy is a concern, caution is advised. Overall, it’s a classic centrepiece with a harmonious balance of sweet, savoury, and fragrant notes, bringing festive spirit to any holiday table.

name: Almond-topped mince pies
description: These festive favourites are encased in a rich, sweet shortcrust pastry and finished off with a frangipane topping that livens up every bite
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 450g shop-bought mincemeator Quick-to-mix homemade mincemeat (see 'Goes well with' below, right)
280g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
140g cold unsalted butter, cut into small cubes
directions: Put the flour in a large bowl with 1/4 tsp salt. Add the butter and rub it in with your fingertips until the mix looks like fine crumbs.

Stir in the sugar, then slowly pour in the egg, stirring with a cutlery knife as you go to avoid any overly wet or dry patches. Scrunch to a dough with your hands, then knead briefly until smooth. Alternatively, pulse together the butter, flour and salt in a processor, then add the sugar and egg. Shape into 2 discs, wrap in cling film and chill for 30 mins (if you have time).

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Mix the prunes and Armagnac into the mincemeat and set aside. Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured work surface until 3mm thick, cut into circles with a 7.5cm or 8cm round plain cutter and gently press into 2 x 12-hole shallow, non-stick bun tins.
For the topping, beat together the butter and sugar with a wooden spoon, then add the flour, ground almonds, eggs, almond extract and a pinch of salt, and beat until smooth.

Spoon the mincemeat into the tin (about 1 dessertspoon into each). Spoon over the topping, then smooth it to the edges of the pastry with a palette knife. Scatter over the flaked almonds. Can now be frozen for up to 1 month.

Bake for 25 mins from room temperature (or 30 mins from frozen) until the pies are golden, risen and the pastry feels firm at the sides. Leave to cool in the tin for 10 mins before transferring to a cooling rack. Dust with icing sugar to serve. Can be stored in an airtight tin for up to 3 days once cold.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on the traditional mince pie with its luscious frangipane topping and a beautifully rich, sweet shortcrust pastry. The use of ground almonds in the frangipane creates a lovely, nutty aroma and a moist, tender crumb that contrasts well with the fruity mincemeat. Including prunes soaked in Armagnac or brandy elevates the filling, adding a subtle depth and festive warmth to each bite. The combination of both plain and self-raising flours in the pastry and topping results in an excellent texture—crisp yet tender. This recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, as it is free of meat and gelatine, relying on butter and eggs for richness. A festive, crowd-pleasing treat perfect for any holiday spread.

name: 10-minute mincemeat
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Put the peeled and grated Bramley apples, light muscovado sugar and the zest and juice of the orange and lemon into a large bowl with the ground cinnamon, ground nutmeg, allspice, mixed dried fruit and brandy. Stir in the grated unsalted butter or shredded suet and ground almonds. Transfer to jars or containers.
chief_review:
This recipe brings together the tartness of Bramley apples with a deep, spiced sweetness from muscovado sugar, dried fruits, and a subtle kick of brandy. The citrus zests and juices add freshness, while the trio of spices—cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice—create a warming aromatic base. Using either butter or suet for richness alongside ground almonds for texture, the end result will be a luxurious, festive fruit mix that works well in desserts like mincemeat tarts or puddings.

Vegetarians can enjoy this recipe if unsalted butter is chosen over suet, as traditional suet is animal fat. The absence of flour makes the recipe naturally gluten-free, though it's wise to check dried fruit packaging for cross-contamination. Those with nut allergies should avoid the ground almonds or seek a substitute. This recipe is not vegan due to the use of butter (unless a plant-based alternative is used).

name: Barney's roly-poly mince pies
description: These aren't really pies - they're more like Catherine wheels or miniature Danish pastries and are great fun for Christmas
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Preheat the oven to 200C/gas 6/ fan 180C. Scatter the sugar over the worktop, unravel the pastry, then roll it out so it’s a quarter bigger, but keeps its rectangular shape.

Spoon and spread the mincemeat evenly over the pastry leaving a 2cm border along the longest edges. Fold one of the longest edges over the mincemeat then roll the pastry tightly into a sausage shape while gently pressing the pastry into the mincemeat. When you get to the other edge, brush it with milk and press down to seal in the mincemeat. Press both ends in gently to plump up the roll and chill for at least 30 minutes to firm it. (The mince pie roll may now be frozen whole or as portioned slices, see below, for up to 1 month.)

Cut the roll into 12 rounds, about 3cm thick. Lay them evenly spaced on a large baking sheet and flatten them with your hand so they look like squashed Chelsea buns. Scatter the almonds on top and bake for 20-30 minutes until golden brown and the mincemeat sizzles. Leave to cool for 5 minutes – keep them separate so they don’t stick together. Eat hot with vanilla ice cream, or just as they are.
chief_review: This festive recipe offers a delightful twist on traditional mince pies, presenting them as spiral pastries reminiscent of Danish treats. The ready-rolled puff pastry creates a crisp, buttery base that pairs wonderfully with the rich, fruity mincemeat. A sprinkle of golden caster sugar caramelizes in the oven, adding a pleasing sweetness, while the flaked almonds provide a toasty crunch on top. The recipe is suitable for vegetarians, assuming the mincemeat is suet-free or uses vegetarian suet. It's a straightforward bake, perfect for beginner or experienced bakers seeking a playful addition to Christmas spreads. Serve slightly warm for maximum enjoyment.

name: Sticky clementine cake with cheesecake cream
description: This golden, citrus-packed pud will bring a little ray of sunshine to your table this Christmas
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
zest 1 lemon, plus a squeeze of juice
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 180C/gas 4. Boil the kettle and thinly slice 5 of the clementines horizontally, discarding the ends. In a small pan, melt 250g of the sugar with 300ml boiling water, then increase the heat until the syrup is simmering. Add the clementine slices, then cover and cook for 20 mins until the slices are tender. Meanwhile, grease and line the base of a 25cm springform tin.

Use a slotted spoon to lift out the clementine slices, then arrange over the bottom of the tin. Grate the zest from the remaining 7 clementines and set aside. Squeeze the juice from 4, then stir this into the syrup. Boil for 10 mins until thick. Cool and set aside.

For the cake, beat 200g of the remaining sugar with the butter, lemon zest and half of the clementine zest until pale. Beat in the egg yolks one by one. Peel the three remaining zested clementines, then break the segments into a food processor and whizz until pulpy. Stir this into the butter mixture along with the almonds, polenta and one pot of yogurt. Whisk the egg whites to stiff peaks, then gently fold into the cake mix. Carefully spoon the mixture into the prepared tin, then bake for 1 hr until a skewer inserted comes out clean. Cool the cake in the tin.

For the cheesecake cream, mix the remaining clementine zest with the mascarpone, the remaining pot of yogurt, 50g sugar and a good squeeze of lemon juice. Turn the cake out upside down onto a serving plate , then pour over some of the sticky syrup. Serve in wedges topped with a spoonful of the cheesecake cream, and a little more syrup on the side.
chief_review: This vibrant citrus pudding is a showstopper, balancing the sweet brightness of clementines with subtle lemon zest. The use of ground almonds and polenta instead of wheat flour makes it an excellent gluten-free dessert, satisfying those with gluten sensitivities without compromising on texture—expect a light, moist crumb with a gentle crunch. Creamy mascarpone and tangy yogurt sit atop, providing luscious contrast. The pudding is rich, aromatic, and perfect for the festive season, sure to enliven your table with both flavour and a gorgeous golden hue. Suitable for vegetarians, the absence of flour and the inclusion of natural yogurt and mascarpone give this dish a lovely Mediterranean touch. An impressive festive indulgence!

name: Brandy & vanilla butter
description: Not just for Christmas pud, this brandy butter goes perfectly with mince pies or spread over toasted panettone
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tsp vanillapaste, or seeds scraped from 1 vanilla pod
directions: Beat the butter, sugar and vanilla together until pale, then whisk in the brandy, one tbsp at a time, until you are pleased with the taste.
chief_review: This classic brandy butter recipe offers a luscious, festive accompaniment to mince pies and panettone alike. The salted butter provides a rich, creamy foundation, while the icing sugar balances it with just the right sweetness. A hint of vanilla adds aromatic depth, and the generous splash of brandy imparts a warming, sophisticated finish. This spread is suitable for a vegetarian diet. Its smooth, airy texture comes together beautifully, perfect for dolloping onto desserts or spreading over toasted treats. Truly, an indulgent finishing touch for your holiday table or any occasion that calls for a little extra decadence.

name: Gooey toffee puddings
description: Indulgent yet wonderfully light, these individual caramel sponges are baked with a sticky toffee sauce - keep in the freezer for a last-minute pud
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 140g softened butter, plus extra for greasing
directions: Lightly grease 8 mini metal pudding basins that each hold around 200ml. Place a small disc of baking parchment in the base of each one.

To make the sauce, put the sugars and butter in a small saucepan and cook over a low heat until the butter melts and the sauce is glossy, stirring regularly. Add the cream and bring to a simmer. Cook for 1 min, stirring constantly. Remove from the heat and divide between the pudding basins. Leave to cool for 30 mins.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Beat the butter, sugar, eggs and flour together in a large bowl with a wooden spoon or electric whisk until pale and thick. Spoon the mixture into the pudding basins and place them in a small roasting tin.
Add cold water to the roasting tin until it rises just 1cm up the sides of the basins. Place the tin in the oven and bake for about 25 mins or until well risen and a skewer inserted comes out clean.

Take the tin out of the oven and, one at a time and holding firmly with a dry tea towel, loosen the sides of each pudding with a round-bladed knife. Turn out onto 8 warmed dessert plates, or arrange on a platter. Serve hot with cream or ice cream, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe delivers an elegant twist on the classic sticky toffee pudding, offering individual caramel sponges that strike a harmonious balance between rich flavor and airy texture. The use of both light and dark muscovado sugars imparts a deep, molasses-like complexity to the toffee sauce, while the double cream and generous butter content ensure a luxuriously smooth finish. Serving with cream or ice cream is a delightful, optional indulgence. Notably, this dessert is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatine. The freezable nature of these sponges also makes them a convenient solution for entertaining or a spontaneous sweet craving—simply reheat for an impressive, decadent treat on short notice.

name: Savoury party bites
description: Impressive, quick and easy nibbles to serve at parties or with drinks
author: Good Food
ingredients: Goat's cheeseon toast (all ingredients for recipes below)
directions: 3 limes, 1 tbsp grated ginger, 1 crushed garlic clove, 1 chopped and deseeded red chilli and 1 tbsp chopped coriander. Cut a large mango into 20 chunks. Thread each onto a small skewer with a large cooked prawn (20 prawns will be about 250g/9oz). Marinate the skewers in the lime dressing for 1 hr (makes 20).

Put 20 small new potatoes on a baking tray. Drizzle with olive oil and season. Roast for 25 mins at 200C/180C fan/gas 6, then cool to room temp. Cut a small cross in the top of each one, push open a little and top with 1 tsp crème fraîche and some caviar (makes 20).

Peel a large butternut squash. Cut into 20 x 3cm squares, then mix with 1 tbsp each of soy sauce, sesame oil and honey. Arrange the chunks on a large baking tray lined with baking parchment. Sprinkle with 2 tbsp sesame seeds, season and bake for 20-25 mins at 200C/180C fan/ gas 6 until crisp. Put a cocktail stick in each chunk to serve (makes 20).

Use a pastry cutter to cut out 20 x 6cm circles from a pack of soft Middle Eastern flatbread or wraps. Grate 75g/2.5oz Manchego and chop 75g/2.5oz chorizo and ½ a red chilli. Scatter over the bread bases, then bake at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 10 mins (makes 20).

Roughly mash 250g/9oz goat’s cheese with 2 finely chopped shallots. Toast 5-6 slices of sourdough and stamp out 20 small circles. Spread each circle with some cheese, top with a small blob of chilli jam (you’ll need about 3 tbsp) and scatter with chives, snipped from a small packet (makes 20).
chief_review: This platter of party nibbles is a vibrant medley designed to impress your guests with both flavor and presentation. The mango & prawn skewers offer a refreshing, tropical touch balanced by succulent seafood. Little caviar jackets provide sophistication and a briny pop, ideal for more refined palates. Sticky squash with sesame seeds delivers a delightful sweet and nutty counterpoint, and will appeal to vegetarians in the crowd. The chorizo & chilli mini pizzas introduce a spicy, smoky note with their robust toppings, while the goat’s cheese on toast gives a creamy, tangy option that’s crowd-pleasing and satisfying. With each bite, there’s a clear attention to texture and contrast—a sign of thoughtful planning. This selection is perfect for cocktail parties, ensuring a dynamic range of flavors that encourages guests to graze and mingle. The inclusion of vegetarian options enhances the appeal for mixed dietary preferences.

name: Boxing Day scones
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 450g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
100g leftover cooked gammon or ham, chopped into rough cubes
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the flour and baking powder in a large bowl and rub in the butter using your fingertips until the mixture looks like fresh breadcrumbs. Mix the mustard, egg and milk together in a jug then pour into the flour mixture along with the Stilton and ham. Knead the dough briefly, you want to make sure all the ingredients are evenly dispersed through the mix but try not to overwork the dough.

Dust your work surface with flour then shape the dough into a flat disc around 4-5cm thick. Cut out 9 or 10 scones using a 7.5cm fluted cutter then transfer to a baking sheet lined with baking parchment. Brush the tops with milk then bake for 12-15 mins or until risen and golden. Serve warm with butter, cheese and pickles.
chief_review: This savory bake masterfully combines the robust flavors of Stilton and hearty gammon, balanced by the gentle warmth of wholegrain mustard. The use of plain flour and baking powder promises a light, tender crumb, while butter ensures a rich, satisfying texture. Incorporating egg and milk adds depth and contributes to a lovely golden finish when glazed. The recipe will particularly appeal to cheese lovers, as the Stilton retains delightful pockets of creaminess throughout. This dish is best enjoyed fresh and warm, making it an excellent centerpiece for brunch or afternoon tea. Because the main protein is gammon or ham, it’s suited to those who enjoy pork and strong cheeses, and it makes clever use of leftovers for minimizing waste. This recipe contains gluten and dairy, so it's not suitable for those with related dietary restrictions.

name: Turkey noodle soup
description: I make this a lot. I usually add in other veg, bok choi is nice, mange tout, sliced ceps or courgetter. Good base recipe for playing about with.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 bunch spring onions, sliced, white and green parts separated
directions: Bring the stock to the boil and throw in the carrots. Boil for 4 mins, then add the noodles and simmer for 3 mins. Stir in the turkey, peas and the white part of the spring onions, heat for 1 min or until everything is hot through. Ladle into bowls, scatter with the green part of the onions to serve.
chief_review:
This recipe is a versatile, comforting noodle soup brimming with protein and fresh vegetables. The base of low-sodium chicken stock and cooked turkey or chicken delivers depth of flavor, while the medley of carrots, frozen peas, and spring onions ensures a satisfying mix of textures and nutrients. The medium egg noodles provide heartiness, making this dish suitable for those looking for a quick yet nourishing meal. 

Its flexibility is a standout feature—swap or add vegetables like bok choy or courgette to suit seasonal produce or personal preferences. This recipe caters well to those following dairy-free diets and is suitable for individuals looking to avoid nuts or soy. While it contains gluten and eggs due to the noodles, an easy adaptation with gluten-free or egg-free noodles enhances its inclusivity. Ideal for light dinners or hearty lunches, this soup encourages creativity in the kitchen.

name: Mushroom, shallot & squash pie
description: A hearty vegetarian main dish that will keep in the freezer for up to two months
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 butternut squash, peeled, deseeded and diced
250g fresh mushrooms(such as Portobello or chestnut), sliced
50g plain flour, plus a little extra for dusting
directions: Soak the dried mushrooms in 250ml boiling water. Meanwhile, soften the shallots in the olive oil and a third of the butter for 10 mins. Add the squash and cook for a further 10 mins until softening, then add the garlic and herbs and cook for 2 mins more. Set aside.

In another pan, fry the fresh mushrooms in another third of butter until softened. Strain the porcini, reserving the soaking liquid, then roughly chop and add to the cooked mushrooms. Fry for 2 mins, then remove from the pan and set aside.

Melt the remaining butter in the same pan, stir in the flour for 2 mins, then gradually stir in the stock and mushroom soaking liquid. Bring to the boil, stirring, and cook for 2-3 mins until thickened. Combine the sauce with all the veg, then transfer the mixture to a 2-litre rectangular pie dish and cool.
Roll out the pastry on a floured surface until big enough to cover the pie dish. Cover the pie, trimming the excess pastry, then wrap well in cling film.
To cook, defrost the pie thoroughly in the fridge overnight if frozen. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6, glaze the pastry with a little egg and bake for 30-40 mins or until golden and hot through.
chief_review: This vegetarian main dish showcases deep, earthy flavors from both dried porcini and fresh mushrooms, rounded out by sweet butternut squash and aromatic herbs. The dish’s generous use of shallots adds a natural sweetness, while the combination of olive oil and butter imparts a luxurious mouthfeel. Wrapping the filling in puff pastry results in a golden, indulgent crust, perfect for gatherings or batch-cooking sessions, as it freezes well for up to two months. As it’s prepared with only plant-based ingredients (aside from butter and egg), this recipe caters to vegetarian diets. However, please note that it is not suitable for a vegan or gluten-free diet due to the inclusion of butter, egg, plain flour, and conventional puff pastry.

name: Pecan-stuffed dates
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 2 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for brushing
directions: Heat the oil in a frying pan. Add the shallot and a generous pinch of salt and cook for 2-3 mins until softened, then add the garlic, breadcrumbs, pecans and thyme and cook for 1 min more. Add a splash of vegetable stock to bring the mixture together, then set aside.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Cut the dates in half lengthways (but don’t cut all the way through). Take small balls of the stuffing and push inside the dates, then push the sides of the dates back together. Put a sage leaf on top of each date, then put the dates on a baking tray lined with baking parchment. Get ahead by prepping your dates up to this point – they will keep in the fridge overnight ready to be baked.
Brush the outside of the dates liberally with olive oil, then bake for 15-20 mins until the sage leaf is crisp. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe showcases an enticing medley of textures and flavors—crisp olive oil-toasted breadcrumbs, aromatic shallot and garlic, and the earthiness of chopped pecans. The sweetness of medjool dates contrasts beautifully with savory thyme and sage, creating a well-balanced filling that feels both elegant and comforting. It's thoughtfully crafted for vegan and vegetarian diets, relying on plant-based ingredients and vegan vegetable stock in place of animal products. The use of olive oil and gluten-free breadcrumbs allows the recipe to be adapted for gluten-free needs as well. Allergens like nuts are present, so take note for those with sensitivities. This versatile dish would make an exceptional addition to festive spreads or as a creative starter.

name: Brie wrapped in prosciutto & brioche
description: I don't understand how the directions can create results as shown in the photo
author: Paul Hollywood
ingredients: 3 large eggs, plus 2 beaten eggs for glazing
directions: Mix the flour, 1 tsp salt, caster sugar, yeast, milk and eggs together in a mixer using the dough attachment for 5 mins until the dough is smooth. Add the butter and mix for a further 4 mins on medium speed. Scrape the dough bowl and mix again for 1 min. Place the dough in a container, cover with cling film and leave in the fridge for at least 6 hrs before using.

Wrap the brie in the prosciutto and set aside. Turn out the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Roll into a 25cm circle. Place the wrapped brie in the middle of the circle and fold the edges in neatly. Put the parcel onto a baking tray lined with baking parchment and brush with beaten egg. Chill in the fridge for 30 mins, then brush again with beaten egg and chill for a further 30 mins. Leave to rise for 1 hr at room temperature. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6, then bake for 22 mins. Serve warm.
chief_review: This recipe brings together the richness of a classic enriched bread dough with a decadent brie and prosciutto filling—a show-stopping centerpiece. The high ratio of eggs and butter signals a brioche-style bread, promising a tender crumb and sumptuous flavor. The use of strong white bread flour and fast-action yeast ensures a good rise, but ensuring proper kneading and proofing will be key to replicating the lofty, golden loaf seen in many photos. The milk and eggs in the dough give additional structure and richness. The melting brie and salty prosciutto create a luxurious, savoury filling—ideal for an impressive brunch or appetizer. Suitable for vegetarians who consume dairy and eggs, this recipe should be avoided by those with gluten, egg, or dairy allergies. Presentation is impressive, and the balance of textures and flavors is sophisticated. Careful attention to dough development will yield excellent results.

name: Deep-filled mince pies
description: These deep, decadent mince pies with a layer of almond frangipane cook brilliantly from frozen
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 400g butter, very cold, cut into cubes
700g plain flour, plus extra for rolling out
1 egg, beaten, to seal and glaze
directions: Make the pastry by rubbing the butter and flour together with your fingertips until the mix resembles fine crumbs or whizz in a food processor. Stir in the sugar and a good pinch of salt, then add the egg yolks and water or milk and work into the mix with a knife until the dough starts to clump together. Press the dough together with your hands to form a ball, split in two and knead each half briefly until smooth. Shape into a flat disc. Wrap in cling film then chill while you make the topping.
Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Beat the almonds, sugar, egg whites and almond extract together to a rough paste.

Roll out one of the discs of pastry on a lightly floured surface and cut 12 x 9cm circles (or 10 x 10cm circles, depending on the depth of your muffin tin) with a round cutter. Push into the wells of a 12-hole muffin tin. Re-roll the leftover pastry and cut out enough 7cm circles to cover the tops.

Spoon a heaped tbsp mincemeat into each case, followed by 1 tbsp almond mix. Brush the edges of the cases with egg and press the tops on, then brush with egg. If you’re making ahead, ‘open’ freeze at this point, in the tin, uncovered. Once frozen, cover with cling film and use within a month. Bake for 20-25 mins until golden from fresh or for 25-30 mins from frozen. Leave to cool almost completely in the tin before lifting out. Serve dusted with a little icing sugar if you like. Repeat with remaining mix to make a second batch.
chief_review: These mince pies elevate the classic festive treat with a sumptuous almond frangipane topping. The rich shortcrust pastry, enriched by cold cubed butter, provides a wonderfully crisp base that contrasts beautifully with the silky mincemeat filling. The frangipane layer adds not only depth of flavor but an irresistible moistness, making each bite luxurious. Preparation is straightforward, and the pies freeze excellently, allowing for easy, fresh bakes during the busy holiday season. This recipe suits those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal rennet, assuming the mincemeat used is suet-free or uses vegetarian suet and all other ingredients align. Overall, these pies are a decadent, make-ahead showstopper for festive gatherings, combining traditional warmth with an elegant almond twist.

name: Gingerbread cookie cottage
description: Here's a gingerbread recipe sure to delight youngsters and enchant adults alike; a genuine house of gingerbread
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 650g self-raising flour, plus extra to dust
200g icing sugar, sifted, plus extra for dusting
directions: Place the flour, ginger, cinnamon and butter in a food processor and pulse until they resemble breadcrumbs (do this in two batches if the bowl is small). Combine the sugar, treacle and egg in a large mixing bowl. Tip in the flour mix and stir, then bring the dough together with your hands. Turn onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth. Cover and chill for at least 1 hr.

Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Line three baking sheets with non-stick paper. Divide the dough into three and roll out on a floured surface to the thickness of two £1 coins. Using the templates, cut out two each for the roof, sides and two pointed end walls. Lift them onto the baking sheets. Re-roll scraps of dough, then cut out the small trees. Bake for 12 mins or until just firm. Leave to firm up for 5 mins, then transfer to a wire rack to cool.

To assemble the house, pipe a door on an end wall and a window on a side wall, using the squeezy icing. Pipe icing generously along one long edge of one side wall and stick it to the board. Repeat with an end wall, join the corners with a line of icing, then fix a flake bar to the base as a 'foundation'. Stick the remaining walls together. Use another flake bar to support the other end wall. Fix on the roof pieces, then leave overnight to set.

Stick the marshmallows all over the roof, using the decorating icing as glue. Fix chocolate buttons around the door and to cover the corner joins. Pipe icicles along the front edge of the roof using the squeezy icing – start each one with a small pea-sized blob of icing. Pull the icing nozzle downwards and away from the blob – the icing will break off in a jagged 'icicle'. Alternatively, decorate with a line of white chocolate buttons.

Mix the icing sugar with drops of water until you have a thick but spreadable icing. Spread this over the board and decorate with the lollipops (fastened to soft sweets), sweets, chocolate buttons and gingerbread trees. Dust lightly with icing sugar for a snowy effect.

NOTE: To make the templates draw each shape on card or paper, using the following measurements. Side walls: 16cm x 10cm. Roof walls: 19cm x 12cm. End walls: Total height 18cm to the apex. 10cm tall to the top of the box. Angled line 11cm long.
chief_review: This gingerbread house recipe is a festive masterpiece, combining aromatic spices—ginger and cinnamon—with rich black treacle for a robust flavor and deep color. The method uses self-raising flour for a subtle lift, ensuring the structure remains sturdy yet pleasantly tender. Decorating with white icing, marshmallows, and candies makes the experience interactive and visually stunning. This recipe is ideal for aspiring bakers wanting to involve children in holiday baking projects. Notably, it’s suitable for vegetarians, but not vegans or those with gluten or dairy allergies. The inclusion of chocolate, sweets, and marshmallows provides ample creative scope for decoration, while the overall sweetness is well-balanced by the warming spice profile. This is a classic gingerbread house sure to become a holiday tradition.

name: Pineapple chutney
description: Give this tangy fruit pickle away as a gift or keep in your cupboard for a colourful household condiment
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 pineapplespeeled, cored and chopped into small chunks
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Heat the oil in a large heavy-based pan. Tip in the onions and spices and cook for 5 mins until fragrant. add the rest of the ingredients plus 1 tsp salt and simmer for 1 hr until dark golden and thick. Pour into sterilised jars and allow to cool before covering.
chief_review:
This vibrant fruit pickle is a delightful blend of sweet, tangy, and spicy notes, making it a standout condiment for any table or a thoughtful homemade gift. The combination of pineapple, ginger, and chilli creates a punchy tropical flavor, beautifully enhanced by the aromatic warmth of mustard seeds, nigella, and turmeric. The use of cider vinegar and brown sugar provides a harmonious balance of acidity and sweetness, essential for a well-structured pickle.

This recipe is suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets, as it contains no animal products. Additionally, it is naturally gluten-free, provided the cider vinegar is certified gluten-free. The clever layering of flavors and appealing color make it a versatile complement to everything from curries to cheese boards—a real testament to the flavorsome world of homemade preserves.

name: Triple choc hot chocolate
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Whip the double cream until it holds its shape then set aside until needed.

Put the milk in a small saucepan and heat gently until simmering. Add the milk chocolate and dark chocolate, then stir until melted. Pour into a mug and top with a dollop of the double cream and scatter over a few mini white chocolate buttons to decorate.
chief_review: This indulgent recipe brings together a creamy dairy base with a trio of chocolates—milk, dark, and white—creating a luxurious and deeply satisfying dessert experience. The balance between double cream and whole milk provides a velvety texture that allows the chocolate flavors to shine, making this rich treat perfect for chocolate lovers. Thanks to the absence of eggs and nuts in the ingredient list, it may be suitable for some individuals with those specific allergies. However, it relies heavily on dairy and chocolate products, so it's best suited for those following a standard diet without restrictions. As always, check chocolate ingredient labels for traces of common allergens if allergies are a concern.

name: Caraway oatcakes with stilton & damson jam
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 60g light spelt flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Gently melt the butter. Combine the oats, spelt flour, salt, baking powder, sugar and seeds in a bowl. Pour in the melted butter and stir to combine, coating all of the oats. Add up to 80ml boiling water, a little at a time, until you have a dough that holds together.

Lightly dust a work surface with flour and turn out the dough, rolling out to 0.5cm thickness. Using a 5cm round cutter, cut out your biscuits and place on a lined baking tray. Bake for 20-25 mins until crisp and golden, then remove from the oven and cool on a wire rack. Can be made one day ahead and kept in an airtight container. To serve, spread with butter and top with stilton and a dollop of damson jam.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a delightful blend of textures and flavors, with the mix of jumbo and regular oats providing a hearty, rustic bite. The presence of butter ensures a rich, tender crumb, while spelt flour offers a nutty depth that pairs beautifully with the aromatic lift of caraway seeds. The subtle sweetness from golden caster sugar balances the savory notes, and the touch of sea salt sharpens the flavors. Baking powder gives the dough a lightness that prevents heaviness often found in oat-based bakes. Served with stilton and damson jam, this creation becomes a sophisticated treat suited to those who appreciate robust, contrasting tastes. With its use of oats and spelt, it may appeal to those seeking alternatives to wheat flour, but the recipe is not gluten-free or vegan. It is highly recommended for a gourmet snack or as part of a luxurious cheese board.

name: Creamy parsnip & mustard gratin
description: This luxuriously creamy bake is the perfect partner to Sarah's veggie pie
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 4 tbsp grated Twineham Grange cheese(see Know-how, below)
directions: Slice enough parsnips thinly lengthways to cover the surface of a small ovenproof dish, then slice the rest thinly into rounds. Combine the milk, cream, stock, mustard and half the cheese in a large, lidded saucepan and bring to the boil. Add a good grating of nutmeg and some seasoning – the sweet parsnips can take a bit of salt – then tip in the parsnips. When the cream is simmering again, cover and cook for 6 mins.

Using tongs, fish out the long slices of parsnip and set aside. Tip the rest into your dish, then arrange the long slices over the top. Scatter with the rest of the cheese and another grating of nutmeg. Can be chilled for up to 24 hrs.
To serve, heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4 and bake for 1 hr, then turn up to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and brown for 15 mins more – you can do this while the pie is resting.
chief_review: This creamy parsnip bake is a masterclass in comfort food, pairing sweet, earthy parsnips with a luscious blend of milk, double cream, and savory vegetable stock. The addition of wholegrain mustard cuts through the richness, lending tang and warmth, while Twineham Grange cheese brings a sharp, nutty depth that melds beautifully with the dish. A hint of freshly grated nutmeg rounds out the flavors and elevates the aroma. Suited for vegetarian diets, this bake is hearty, satisfying, and makes an excellent partner to any vegetable pie or as a standout side at a festive table. The texture is sumptuously smooth, yet the rustic mustard seeds provide a pleasing contrast. Ideal for those looking to indulge in a meat-free, flavor-packed dish.

name: Mincemeat & shortbread squares
description: Love these, have been making them for several years. Great alternative to mince pies. Great for gifts. Will also keep in the freezer for a few weeks so can make ahead.
author: Good Food
directions: Halve the dough and press one half evenly into the base of the tin. Spread the mincemeat over the top, leaving a 1cm border around the edge. Roll out the remaining dough between 2 sheets of baking parchment to a 20cm square, then slide onto the mincemeat. Seal around the edge with your fingers gently press all over until dimpled, then prick all over the top with a fork.
Bake for 25-30 mins until lightly golden. Mix the granulated sugar with the remaining 1/4 tsp cinnamon and sprinkle over the top. Cool in the tin before cutting into squares.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on traditional mince pies, presenting a spiced, buttery treat perfect for the festive season or as edible gifts. Featuring warming spices like cinnamon and cloves, combined with rich mincemeat and a tender shortbread dough, the result is both aromatic and satisfyingly crumbly. The use of ground rice maintains a light texture, preventing heaviness. Prepared ahead and freezer-friendly, these are practical for busy bakers. Given the absence of eggs and the omission of any explicit animal-derived gelatine in the mincemeat, this recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, assuming the mincemeat used follows vegetarian guidelines. However, it contains wheat (gluten) and dairy, which are important considerations for those with allergies. Overall, these treats are a festive, fragrant alternative to classic mince pies, with great potential for advance preparation and gifting.

name: Cranberry ripple cheese-cupcakes
description: These one-portion puds have a sharp ripple of cranberry to cut through the sweetness
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 100g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: First make the ripple by putting the cranberries and icing sugar into a shallow pan and cooking down over a mediumhigh heat for 10 mins until the berries collapse into a thick and sticky sauce. Turn off the heat and leave to cool.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line a 12-hole muffin tin with 12 muffin cases. Crush the biscuits in a plastic bag or whizz in a food processor, then mix with the melted butter. Divide between the muffin cases and press down with your fingers. In a separate bowl, mix the soft cheese with the flour, sugar and vanilla extract, then gradually beat in the eggs and yolk until smooth. Ripple the berry mix through the cheese, being careful not to over-mix. Spoon the mix into the cases and smooth the tops with the back of the spoon. Bake for 30 mins, leave to cool, then chill in the fridge until completely cold.
To serve, peel the cases off the cakes, if you like, then dust with icing sugar. Serve piled up on a nice dish for everyone to help themselves.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a delightful balance of creamy richness from the soft cheese and a vibrant, tart lift from the cranberry ripple. The biscuit base provides a buttery crunch, perfectly contrasting the silky cheesecake topping. With classic ingredients like flour, dairy, and eggs, the texture is smooth and the flavor profile well-rounded—highlighted by the subtle touch of vanilla. While the cranberries add a welcome sharpness, the dusting of icing sugar offers a sweet finish. Overall, these single-serve puddings are an elegant and satisfying dessert, ideal for those seeking an impressive yet approachable treat. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe accommodates guests seeking a meat-free indulgence.

name: Easy vanilla marzipan
description: It's worth having a go at making your own marzipan to cover your Christmas cake - and you can experiment with adding different flavours
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 280g icing sugar, sifted, plus extra for kneading and rolling out
½ tsp orange or lemon juice
3 tbsp apricot jam, warmed then sieved
directions: Mix the sugars and almonds in a large bowl, then rub in the vanilla seeds until even. Make a well in the middle, then tip in the eggs and citrus juice. Cut the wet ingredients into the dry with a cutlery knife. Dust the surface with icing sugar, then knead the marzipan briefly with your hands to a smooth dough. Don’t overdo it as the paste can get greasy. Add a bit more icing sugar if it seems too wet. Shape into a ball, then wrap and keep in a cool place until ready to cover the cake. Can be made up to 2 days in advance.

Lift the cake onto a cake board or plate, then use a pastry brush to cover evenly with a thin layer of jam. Dust the work surface with more icing sugar, then roll the marzipan into a circle about 40cm across, dusting underneath the marzipan with more icing sugar and turning it a quarter turn after every few pushes of the rolling pin.

Flip the top of the circle back over your rolling pin so you can see the underside of the marzipan, then lift the pin up and lift the marzipan over the cake. Stop once you can see that the edge of the marzipan nearest you is about level with the bottom of the cake. Flop the front of the marzipan down. Smooth the paste over the cake using the palms of your hands, then trim with a sharp knife. If any cracks appear, simply pinch the paste back together and smooth. Leave to dry for at least 24 hrs, or up to 3 days, before covering with icing.

Although homemade marzipan contains raw eggs, the amount of sugar, and lack of moisture, prevents bacteria growing when left at room temperature, so your cake should last for 1-2 months iced. The most important thing is that you don't scrimp on drying time – once you’ve covered your cake in marzipan it should be left to completely dry out, before you then cover it with icing. If you want to make marzipan before you are ready to cover your cake, then wrap it well in cling film and keep in a fridge for up to a week – as wrapped in a ball it will still contain a little moisture. As it contains raw eggs it shouldn’t be given to anyone in an at-risk group, including pregnant women, the elderly, the unwell and the very young. You can make a cooked marzipan, which carries no risks. It is a little softer, and harder to work with, but a good substitute if you are at all worried.
chief_review: This homemade marzipan recipe is a delightful way to elevate your Christmas cake, offering a fresher, richer almond flavor than store-bought varieties. The addition of vanilla seeds and citrus juice adds complexity and balance to the sweetness. Using golden caster sugar lends a subtle caramel depth, while the apricot jam ensures a smooth adhesion to the cake. This marzipan is naturally gluten-free, making it a great choice for those with gluten sensitivities, and it’s suitable for vegetarian diets. For a twist, try infusing the marzipan with a touch of almond extract, rose water, or even cocoa. The recipe’s simplicity and flexibility make it an excellent canvas for creative flavor experimentation, and the homemade touch will impress at any festive gathering.

name: Orange, cranberry & almond mince pies
description: Stirring zingy cranberries into bought mincemeat and making your own simple almond pastry really brings these mince pies to life
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Whizz the butter, flour and ground almonds in a food processor until the butter has disappeared. Pulse in the sugar and half the orange zest. Add the milk and keep whizzing until a rough dough comes together. Tip onto the work surface, press together and shape into a smooth disc, kneading once or twice if you need to. Chill for 15 mins. Can be made up to 3 days ahead and chilled, or frozen for up to 1 month.
Scatter a little flour onto the work surface. Roll out the dough to about the thickness of a £1 coin. Using an 8cm cutter, stamp out 24 circles and use to line the holes of 2 x 12-hole bun tins.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Mix cranberries and mincemeat, then spoon into cases. Scatter each pie with flaked almonds. Can be frozen for up to 1 month. Bake the pies for 18-20 mins until the pastry and almonds are golden. When ready to serve, dust with the tiniest bit of icing sugar. Stir 2 tsp icing sugar and remaining zest into the crème fraîche, then dollop onto each pie to serve.
chief_review:
This recipe elevates classic mince pies by incorporating zingy cranberries into jarred mincemeat and crafting a fragrant almond pastry with orange zest. The rich, buttery crust gains depth from ground almonds, complementing the festive filling’s tanginess. Flaked almonds on top add a delightful crunch, while a dusting of icing sugar and a dollop of crème fraîche provide elegance and balance. 

Vegetarians will appreciate that all ingredients are plant-based, provided the mincemeat and crème fraîche are vegetarian-friendly. However, as the pastry uses wheat flour, it’s not gluten-free, and the inclusion of ground and flaked almonds makes this recipe unsuitable for those with nut allergies. Overall, the recipe is straightforward but sophisticated, perfect for holiday gatherings where you want to impress with both flavor and presentation.

name: Red wine risotto with duck & garlicky mushrooms
description: A great way to use up leftover duck in a rich, luxurious supper dish
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat 1 tbsp butter in a wide saucepan, then add the onion, carrots and celery. Cover, then gently cook for 10 mins until soft. Tip in two-thirds of the garlic, fry for 1 min, turn up the heat, then add the thyme and rice. Stir for a few mins, then add the wine and let it reduce to almost nothing.

Stir in the stock over a medium heat, ladle by ladle, waiting for each addition to absorb before adding the next. Keep the heat on medium – too hot and the stock will evaporate rather than be absorbed by the rice. When the rice is creamy and justcooked, take off the heat, add the duck, then cover for 5 mins to heat through.

Melt the remaining butter in another wide pan, add the mushrooms, then fry them on a high heat for about 3 mins until golden. Add the remaining garlic, fry for 1 min more, then season. Stir the mushrooms into the risotto, then scatter with parsley and serve.
chief_review: This duck risotto recipe is a decadent and flavorful way to transform leftovers into an elegant supper. The classic combination of finely chopped onion, carrot, celery, and garlic delivers a delicious sofrito base, while the earthy chestnut mushrooms and aromatic thyme complement the shredded duck. Using red wine intensifies the rich flavors, and the addition of hot chicken stock ensures a creamy, glossy risotto. Finished with fresh parsley, the dish is beautifully balanced, both hearty and refined. This recipe is well-suited to gluten-free diets, provided the stock and wine used are certified gluten free. It’s also nut-free and could be an excellent option for those looking for an indulgent, satisfying one-pan meal.

name: Bourbon-glazed pork belly chunks
description: Your guests will snap up these cubes of crispy belly pork in sticky, sweet whiskey marinade with soy, anise and honey flavours
author: Good Food
ingredients: chives and soured cream, to serve (optional)
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Pour 100ml of the bourbon into a small, shallow roasting tin and add the star anise. Season the pork belly, put in the tin and cover tightly with foil. Bake for 3 hrs. Remove from the oven and leave to cool for at least 1 hr. You can chill the pork for up to 2 days at this stage.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the pork from the tin. Using a small, sharp knife, pare away the rind from the meat, leaving a small layer of fat. Cut the meat into 2cm chunks and return to the tin. Roast for 20 mins until crisp and sizzling, turning regularly.

Meanwhile, tip the ketchup, soy sauce, honey and remaining bourbon into a small pan. Set over a high heat and bubble for 5 mins until thick and syrupy. Pour over the chunks of pork and toss to coat. Roast for 10 mins more until sticky.
Snip the chives into the sour cream, if you like, and serve alongside the pork chunks with cocktail sticks.
chief_review: This recipe for crispy belly pork glazed in a sticky, sweet whiskey marinade is a true celebration of rich flavors and bold textures. The tender pork belly, marinated and caramelized with bourbon, soy, honey, and star anise, delivers a balanced combination of smokiness, sweetness, and umami. The addition of tomato ketchup adds subtle tang, while optional chives and soured cream bring brightness and a creamy finish. Perfect as a decadent party appetizer or a standout main, this dish is best suited for omnivores and makes a striking impression at any table. Note that the inclusion of soy sauce (containing wheat) means it's not gluten-free, and the recipe is naturally unsuitable for those avoiding pork or seeking a vegetarian or vegan option.

name: Salted caramel sauce
description: Add a little salt to your caramel sauce before pouring liberally on sponge puddings, ice cream and any sweet treat you fancy
author: Good Food
directions: Combine all the ingredients in a saucepan set over a low heat, and stir until the sugar has dissolved. Turn the heat up and bubble the sauce for 2-3 mins until golden and syrupy. Leave to cool for 10 mins before serving.
chief_review: This salted caramel sauce is a decadent, silky addition to any dessert repertoire. The balance between the rich double cream, buttery undertones, and a hint of salt transforms plain puddings and ice cream into luxurious treats. It’s an excellent recipe for those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal rennet or gelatine. The simplicity—just sugar, cream, butter, and salt—means minimal prep, but the outcome is restaurant-quality. The salt elevates the sweetness, ensuring the sauce isn’t cloying but rather complex and irresistible. Highly recommended as a quick yet impressive finish for both classic and modern desserts.

name: Classic roast turkey
description: Worked really well
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: fresh bay leaves, to flavour and serve
glass red wine, such as Merlot
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Put the onion and a large sprig of bay in the cavity between the legs. Now pack half the stuffing into the neck end, pushing it towards the breast. Secure the neck skin in position with skewers and tie the turkey legs together at the top of the drumsticks to give a neat shape.
Weigh the turkey and calculate cooking time at 20 mins per kilo, plus 90 mins. (You may need to use your bathroom scales.)

Put a large sheet of extra-wide foil in a large roasting tin, then put the turkey on top. Smear the breast with the butter, grate over half the nutmeg and season well. Cover the breast with bacon, pour over the wine, then loosely bring up the foil and seal well to make a parcel.

Roast in the oven, then 90 mins before the end of cooking, open the foil, discard the bacon, and drain off excess fat from the tin. Leaving the foil open, return the turkey to the oven to brown, basting with the juices several times. Then 30 mins before the end of cooking, place pigs-in-blankets and stuffing of your choice around the turkey, or cook in a separate lightly oiled tin.
To test whether the turkey is cooked, push a skewer into the thickest part of the thigh – the juices should run clear. If they are pinkish, cook for 15 mins more, then test again.

Transfer the turkey, stuffings and pigs-in-blankets to a platter, cover with foil, then a couple of tea towels and allow to rest for up to 30 mins before carving. This gives the juices time to settle back into the meat, ensuring that the turkey will be juicy. Garnish with sprigs of bay.
chief_review: This classic roast turkey recipe delivers a succulent centerpiece, enhanced with aromatic bay leaves and a generous rub of softened butter. The addition of nutmeg imparts subtle warmth, perfectly complementing the savoury depth from bacon and red wine. Stuffing and pigs-in-blankets provide robust flavour and texture contrasts, making the dish festive and richly satisfying. Suitable for traditional omnivorous diets, it pairs beautifully with seasonal vegetables and gravy. The inclusion of dairy (butter) and pork may not be suitable for certain dietary preferences, but as a celebration dish, it’s sure to be a hit at any holiday table.

name: Caramel panettone pud
description: This sweet, rich and fragrant pudding will have you fighting over the last portion
author: Ruth Watson
ingredients: 284ml carton double cream, plus more double cream to serve
directions: To make the caramel, put the sugar and hot water into a small, heavy pan over a low-medium heat. Stir occasionally until the sugar has dissolved then raise the heat and boil, without stirring, until the caramel is golden brown.
Immediately remove the pan from the heat and quickly pour the caramel into a wide, fairly deep, 1.5 litre/2¾ pint ovenproof dish, swirling it around to cover the base. Set aside.

Preheat the oven to 160C/Gas 3/fan oven 140C. Cut the panettone into 1cm/½in thick slices then remove the dark brown, bottom crust. Butter one side of the slices generously. Put in a single layer, butter-side-up, in the dish.

Using an electric whisk or food mixer, beat the sugar and eggs in a large bowl for 2 minutes, or until thickened. Heat the milk and cream in a saucepan to just below simmering point, then pour on to the egg mixture and stir to combine.
Pour this custard over the panettone, pressing the slices into the liquid. Soak for 10 minutes.

Put the dish on to the middle shelf of the preheated oven, and bake for 55-60 minutes. The pudding is ready when the top is pale gold and dry-looking and the custard set to a just-firm shiver – it should not be completely solid as the custard continues to set as it cools. Leave it to rest for 30 minutes before serving with cream.
chief_review: This decadent pudding boasts a gorgeous caramelized top and truly indulgent flavors thanks to the panettone base and rich custard. The combination of eggs, double cream, and milk results in an exceptionally silky texture, while the panettone adds subtle notes of citrus and spice, making every bite unique. The recipe is best suited for those with a sweet tooth and pairs perfectly with a drizzle of extra cream. While the panettone and double cream elevate the dish, the overall process remains approachable for a home cook. Gluten and dairy are key components, so it is ideal for traditional dessert lovers. Serve warm for the best flavor and aroma.

name: Mojito recipe
description:
Italian Cream Soda Serves:1
CarbsPerServing:1 gram Prep Time:About 2 min.
Effort:Easy
ingredients:
One Tall Glass Full of Ice
1 Table Spoon Cream or Half and HalfOne Can Club Soda Chilled if You
Want
Your Choice Torani Sugar Free Syrup
How to Prepare:
Put ice into glass. Mix cream and syrup in small glass before
pouring into tall glass( do this or the cream will get a weird
texture.) Pour cream mixture into glas, then add club soda, mix.
Ta-daa, now you have a very grubbinesque soda. http://www.weightlosseasy.tips/beverages.html
author: Good Food
ingredients: small handful mintleaves, plus extra sprig to serve
directions: Muddle the lime juice, sugar and mint leaves in a small jug, crushing the mint as you go – you can use the end of a rolling pin for this. Pour into a tall glass and add a handful of ice.
Pour over the rum, stirring with a long-handled spoon. Top up with soda water, garnish with mint and serve.
chief_review: This Italian Cream Soda recipe is an indulgent yet refreshing beverage, perfect for those who enjoy a creamy twist on classic sodas. The use of club soda and sugar-free flavored syrup makes it an excellent low-carb, keto-friendly choice, particularly appealing to those limiting carbohydrate intake. With dairy as the only potential allergen (cream or half and half), it's important to note for lactose-sensitive diners. The recipe is also gluten-free, as no wheat-based ingredients are present. Preparation is quick and simple, requiring minimal culinary effort—just mix the cream and syrup first for best texture, followed by the club soda. The customization possibilities with various sugar-free syrups make this drink a versatile treat for any flavor preference.

name: Damson gin
author: Lulu Grimes
directions: Rinse and pick over the damsons to remove any leaves and stalks, then pat dry, tip into a freezer bag and freeze overnight. The next day, bash the bag of damsons a couple of times with a rolling pin and then tip the lot into a 2-litre Kilner jar, or divide between 2 smaller jars.

Pour in the sugar and gin, and put the lid on. Shake well. Each day for a week, give the jar a good shake until all the sugar has dissolved, then put it in a cool, dark place and leave for 2-3 months.

Line a plastic sieve with a square of muslin (or use a coffee filter in a cone for a really refined gin) and strain the damson gin through it. Decant into clean, dry bottles, seal and label. The gin is now ready to drink, but will improve and mature over time – it will keep for over a year, if you can wait that long.
chief_review: This damson gin (or vodka) recipe is a celebration of seasonal fruit and simplicity. Using only damsons, golden caster sugar, and your choice of clear spirit, it delivers a beautifully flavoured liqueur with minimal effort. By excluding any animal-derived products and gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is well-suited for both vegan and gluten-free diets. The absence of common allergens like nuts, dairy, or eggs adds further versatility, accommodating a range of dietary needs. The process extracts the vibrant tartness of the damsons, balancing it with just the right amount of sweetness. Perfect for gifting or as a festive homemade treat, this recipe is as adaptable as it is delicious—enjoy it sipped neat, poured over ice, or as a base for creative cocktails.

name: Zimtsterne (Cinnamon stars)
description: Edd Kimber creates a version of these German spiced cookies- they're chewy, crisp and similar to an almond macaroon
author: Edd Kimber
ingredients: 1 tsp lemon juice, plus zest 1 lemon
200g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2 and line a large baking tray (or 2 smaller) with baking parchment. Place the egg whites in a large bowl and use an electric mixer to whisk until foamy. Add the lemon juice and whisk again until they hold soft peaks.

Slowly mix in the icing sugar and continue whisking until the mixture is stiff. Remove about a quarter of the meringue mixture and set aside to use for the topping. Put the almonds, cinnamon, ginger and lemon zest in the bowl with the meringue and mix to form a stiff, slightly sticky dough.

To form the stars, put the dough on a piece of baking parchment lightly dusted with icing sugar and dust the top of the dough with sugar, too. Place a second sheet of parchment on top of the dough and roll out to about 0.5cm thick (the dough is a little sticky, so the parchment makes it easier to roll). Peel off the top sheet of parchment and use a 5cm star-shaped cutter to cut out as many cookies as possible. Place them on your prepared baking tray.

Using the reserved meringue mixture, spread a small amount onto the top of each cookie, covering the entire top – you may need to add a few drops of water to make the meringue a little easier to spread. Put the tray in the oven and bake for 12-15 mins until meringue is set but not browned.
