chief_review: This recipe for German spiced cookies captures the delicate balance of chewy and crisp textures, reminiscent of classic almond macaroons. The blend of ground almonds, cinnamon, and ginger delivers a fragrant warmth, while the zest and juice of lemon provide a bright, zesty contrast to the sweetness of icing sugar. These cookies use no flour, making them naturally gluten-free—an excellent treat for anyone following a gluten-free diet. Additionally, there are no dairy ingredients, so they’re suitable for those avoiding lactose. However, the presence of egg whites means they're not vegan-friendly. Their simplicity and lack of wheat allow the warm spice and nut flavors to shine. These cookies would be a delightful addition to a holiday spread or enjoyed with a cup of tea any time of year.

name: St Clements carrots
description: Use some of the heap of clementines lying around over the Christmas period to make these sticky, citrussy roasted carrots
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: zest 3 clementines, plus a few slices
zest 2 lemons, plus a few slices
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and bring a large pan of water to the boil. Cut the carrots lengthways into halves or quarters, depending on their size. Tip the carrots into the pan, wait for the water to simmer again, then cook for 4 mins. Drain well, then tip into a large roasting tin.

While the carrots are still hot, gently toss them with all the zest, oil, butter, seasoning and the lemon and clementine slices. Poke the slices in among the carrots, so they’re not left on the edges of the tray. Roast for 40 mins until the carrots are golden and tender.
chief_review: This roasted carrot recipe elevates the humble root vegetable with a vibrant blend of clementine and lemon zest, perfect for showcasing seasonal citrus over the festive period. The olive oil provides a subtle richness while the butter contributes a satisfying, glossy finish, allowing the carrots to become tender and sticky as they roast. The citrus slices not only infuse the dish with fragrance but also add visual appeal, making this an attractive side for holiday tables. Suitable for vegetarians, this dish is ideal for those seeking to add a burst of bright flavor and color to meat-free meals. The straightforward ingredient list also minimizes potential allergens, making it a versatile choice for entertaining. Serve warm for the best balance of sweet, tangy, and earthy flavors.

name: Carrot & star anise purée
description: If you fancy adding something a little different to the table on Christmas Day, this seasonal purée could be just the thing
author: Good Food
directions: Melt the butter in a large, shallow pan. Add the carrots, tarragon and star anise. Slowly cook for 10 mins until the carrots are glazed and starting to soften. Pour in the stock and bring to the boil, then simmer everything for 20 mins until cooked and the stock has reduced.

Pour in the cream, bring back to the boil and simmer for 1 min more. Remove from the heat, take out the star anise and stir through the lemon juice. Season to taste, then blitz with a hand blender until as smooth as possible.
chief_review: This seasonal carrot purée offers a delightful twist for the Christmas table, marrying the natural sweetness of carrots with aromatic tarragon and star anise. The use of double cream and butter results in a velvety, luxurious texture, while a splash of lemon juice adds a bright lift to the dish. The optional choice of vegetable or chicken stock provides flexibility for both vegetarians and meat-eaters. This recipe is particularly suitable for a vegetarian diet (when using vegetable stock) and caters to those looking for a comforting, elegant side. The flavors are well-balanced, with subtle aniseed notes complementing the earthy carrots and fresh tarragon. A refined, festive dish that’s sure to impress your guests.

name: Old fashioned
description:
This is the style from outdated to the new school, that is the thing that everybody needs to include it up! Thanks for sharing it.
The Flash drama series Jackets
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tsp sugarsyrup or 1 tsp granulated sugar
directions: Put the sugar, bitters and water in a small tumbler. Mix until the sugar dissolves if using granulated. Fill your glass with ice and stir in the whisky. Add a splash of soda water if you like and mix. Garnish with the orange and cherry.
chief_review: A true nod to cocktail tradition, this recipe delivers a beautifully balanced Old Fashioned that allows the deep character of Scotch or bourbon to shine through, subtly enhanced by sugar and Angostura bitters. The orange slice and maraschino cherry garnish add a touch of brightness and nostalgia, making this drink both visually appealing and aromatic. With simple ingredients and a straightforward method, it’s a classic choice well-suited for home bartenders looking to master foundational techniques. For those with gluten sensitivities, most distilled whiskies and bourbons are considered gluten-free, making this an excellent option. Vegans too will find this recipe generally suitable, provided the maraschino cherries are free from animal-derived dyes or additives. This drink remains a timeless staple, tastefully reimagined for any cocktail enthusiast’s repertoire.

name: Baby buttermilk pancakes with sticky bananas & Brazils
description: Pile 'em high - these scrumptious pancakes are guaranteed to be a real crowd pleaser
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2 ripe bananas, thickly sliced into chunks
200ml maple syrup, plus extra on the side
directions: Place the flour, salt, baking powder, bicarbonate of soda, sugar and vanilla seeds in a food processor and pulse briefly to blend. Add the egg yolks, butter, buttermilk and milk, then whizz to a smooth batter, scraping down the sides of the bowl once or twice. Whisk the egg whites in another bowl to soft, floppy peaks, then fold into the batter.

Heat a heavy-bottomed frying pan until you can feel a good heat rising, then lightly oil the pan. Using a small ladle, pour in the batter to make pancakes about 10cm in diameter. Cook for about 1 min until the tops are set and little holes appear in the surface. Flip the pancakes over, brown lightly on the other side, then transfer to a tea towel placed on a wire rack and keep warm in a low oven. Repeat with the remaining batter, stacking the pancakes as they are cooked.

To serve, pour the sugar into a mixing bowl and toss the Brazil nuts and bananas through it. Tip into a pan, heat through to melt the sugar, then toss together as everything begins to caramelise. When the nuts and bananas are golden brown, remove from the heat and stir in the maple syrup. Arrange the pancakes on a serving dish and spoon over the nut and banana mix, then serve with extra syrup and a dollop of yogurt or crème fraîche.
chief_review: This pancake recipe delivers on its promise—fluffy, vanilla-scented stacks topped with caramelized bananas, crunchy Brazil nuts, and plenty of maple syrup. The use of buttermilk adds a lovely tang and keeps the crumb moist, while the separated eggs contribute to excellent rise and featherlight texture. The caramelized topping is truly crowd-pleasing, with just the right contrast of sweetness and crunch. For those following a vegetarian diet, this recipe is well-suited, as it contains no meat or fish. However, it includes gluten (flour), dairy (butter, milk, buttermilk, yogurt or crème fraîche), eggs, and nuts (Brazil nuts), so considerations are necessary for anyone with related allergies. Overall, a delightful brunch treat with a gourmet edge that is sure to impress both kids and adults alike.

name: Cauliflower cakes with green yogurt sauce
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 1 small cauliflower(600g), trimmed and finely chopped
1 lemon, zested (save the juice for the sauce)
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Boil the cauliflower in salted water for 5 mins until soft. Drain, put back in the pan to steam off the excess water, then tip into a bowl to cool. Add the garlic, spring onions, chilli, parmesan, lemon zest, 50g of the toasted breadcrumbs, the flour, egg, and some seasoning. Shape into 16 cakes, then roll in the remaining breadcrumbs. Put on a plate and chill for at least 1 hr, or overnight, before cooking.
To make the sauce, put all the ingredients in a food processor or blender. Add some seasoning and blend until smooth. Pour into a serving bowl and set aside. Can be made a day ahead.
Liberally spray a large baking sheet with the oil. Put the cauliflower cakes on top and spray well again. Bake for 25 mins until golden and crisp. Serve with the sauce and some rocket salad.
chief_review:
This inventive cauliflower recipe offers a delightful blend of flavors and textures, pairing finely chopped cauliflower with the gentle heat of red chilli and the sharpness of parmesan. The inclusion of fresh breadcrumbs and a touch of flour allows for a pleasing crunch, while the aromatic addition of lemon zest brightens every bite. Anchovy, parsley, and Worcestershire sauce round out the tangy yogurt-mayo sauce, making it an addictive accompaniment.

The dish is well-suited for vegetarians when a vegetarian parmesan alternative is used and the anchovy is omitted, or replaced with a plant-based umami element like capers. However, it is not suitable for vegans due to the presence of cheese, yogurt, and egg. The use of wheat flour and breadcrumbs makes it unsuitable for gluten-free diets. This would be a standout appetizer or a light lunch alongside a peppery rocket salad.

name: Cauliflower cheese rolls
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Chop or
the cauliflower into rice-sized pieces. Cover loosely and
for 5 mins, or until tender, stirring halfway. Pour the milk into a saucepan with the plain flour and 1tbsp butter.

together and slowly bring to the boil, mixing all the time, until smooth and thick. Mix in the cooked cauliflower, cheddar and parmesan, then season. Leave to cool in the pan. Once cold, transfer to a piping bag or food bag and chill.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line a baking sheet with baking parchment. Unfold the pastry sheets and slice into three pieces widthways, cutting through all the sheets at once. Take out three strips and keep the rest covered.

Melt the remaining butter, then use to lightly brush the pastry strips. Fold the strips in half lengthways, then brush again with the melted butter. Pipe or spread 1 tbsp of the cauliflower mixture onto the buttered pastry strips. Fold the short ends in, then loosely roll to form a cigar. Brush the end with a little butter to help seal in place. Place on the baking sheet, spacing them a little apart, then repeat with the remaining pastry strips. Brush the tops with butter, then sprinkle with the za’atar and sesame seeds. Bake for 15-18 mins until golden and crisp. Serve warm.
chief_review:
This recipe brings together the mild, nutty flavors of cauliflower with a luxurious cheese sauce, encased in crisply baked filo pastry. The use of cheddar and parmesan adds depth, while za’atar and sesame seeds provide a fragrant, Middle Eastern-inspired finish. A touch of butter contributes richness, and the technique of layering filo results in a delightfully textural contrast. 

This dish suits a lacto-vegetarian diet when a vegetarian parmesan alternative is used, ensuring no animal rennet is present. The recipe does contain gluten (from both the flour and the filo pastry), dairy, and sesame seeds, so it’s important for diners with specific allergies to take note. Overall, this is a beautifully textured and flavorful dish, ideal for a special starter or a light main course.

name: Triple chocolate cupcake kit
description: The perfect Christmas gift for someone who loves to bake - the ingredients for delectable chocolate cupcakes
author: Good Food
ingredients: large glass jarwith a clip or screw lid
cellophane, ribbon, gift bag or box, new spatula or wooden spoon and large label
directions: Tip the caster sugar into the jar, followed by the flour, then finally the cocoa, so the ingredients sit in layers. Seal the jar.
Wrap the chocolate drops and bar up in cellophane. Tie the spatula or spoon onto the jar with ribbon and pack in a gift bag or box with the chocolates, sprinkles and cupcake cases.

Hand-write a label with the following instructions and attach it to the gift: ‘Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put 100g very soft butter in a bowl with 2 eggs, add the contents of the jar and beat well. Add a drop of milk to the mix if it is too stiff. Stir in the white chocolate drops. Divide between the cake cases. Bake for 15 mins. Cool. Melt the milk chocolate, spoon a little over each cake and then decorate with sprinkles.’
chief_review: This chocolate cupcake gift jar is a thoughtful and delightful present for enthusiastic bakers. The careful layering of caster sugar, self-raising flour, cocoa powder, white and milk chocolate drops not only creates visual appeal but promises cupcakes with rich chocolate flavor and a moist crumb. Thoughtful extras like a new spatula or wooden spoon, cupcake cases, and decorative gift packaging make it a complete, ready-to-bake experience. This recipe can be enjoyed by vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin-based ingredients. However, those with dairy allergies or lactose intolerance should be cautious, as both white and milk chocolate drops are included. It's a clever and elegant gift idea that brings festive joy and homemade treats to any Christmas celebration.

name: Cranberry sauce with port & star anise
description: Star anise gives this classic sauce a really Christmassy flavour, and a contemporary update
author: Tony Tobin
ingredients: grated zest of 1 orange and the juice of 2 oranges
2 tbsp golden caster sugar, or more to taste
directions: Tip the cranberries into a saucepan, grate in the orange zest then squeeze in the juice. Add the redcurrant jelly, port and star anise and slowly bring to the simmer.

Cook gently over a low heat for about 15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until all the cranberries have burst and the sauce thickens and looks glossy. You want to end up with a saucy texture rather than a jammy one – you will find fresh cranberries thicken the sauce more readily whereas the frozen cranberries will take a little longer.

Stir in the sugar and taste. Chef Tony Tobin likes the sauce to have enough tartness to make you suck in your cheeks, but add more sugar if you prefer. Cool and then fish out the star anise. The sauce will keep in the fridge in a covered container for 1 week or for 2 months in the freezer.
To serve, take out of the fridge an hour or so before the meal so that it returns to room temperature, then spoon into a serving dish.
chief_review: This cranberry sauce offers a bright and festive twist with the addition of star anise, which imparts an aromatic, Christmassy note to the classic citrusy base. The orange zest and juice lend a lively freshness, while redcurrant jelly brings an extra depth of flavor and smoothness. Port adds a luxurious touch, balancing tartness with warmth. Sweetness is adjustable with golden caster sugar, allowing for perfect control over the final taste. As the recipe contains only fruit, sugar, jelly, port, and spices, it's naturally suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, assuming you select a vegan-friendly redcurrant jelly and sugar. It’s also naturally gluten-free, ideal for those avoiding gluten. This sauce would make a vibrant complement to holiday roasts, plant-based mains, or as a tangy counterpoint to rich seasonal dishes—a delightful update on tradition.

name: Freeze-ahead roasties
description: Save precious time when planning a group meal by prepping and freezing your potatoes in advance
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2½ kg/5lb 8 oz Maris Piper, red-skinned or King Edward potatoes, peeled
directions: Leave small and medium potatoes whole, but halve large potatoes. Tip the potatoes into a large pan of cold salted water and bring to the boil. Boil for 6 mins exactly, then drain in a colander and leave to steam-dry for a few mins. Toss in the colander to rough up the sides.

Transfer to a large bowl. Shake over the flour, some salt and a little pepper, and toss well to combine. Spoon over 100g of the fat and toss to coat evenly. Lay the potatoes on a tray lined with baking parchment and freeze. Once frozen, the potatoes can be transferred to a freezer bag for easy storage. Can be frozen for up to 3 months.

When ready to cook, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Pour remaining fat and the oil into a baking tray and put in the oven. When the fat is sizzling, carefully add the potatoes, then roast for 25 mins. Remove tray, then increase oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Turn over the potatoes and return to the oven for a further 40 mins until golden and crisp.
chief_review: This recipe is a wonderful time-saver for group meals, delivering classic, crispy roasted potatoes with minimal fuss on the day of serving. The choice of Maris Piper, red-skinned, or King Edward potatoes guarantees a fluffy interior and crisp exterior, elevated by dusting with plain flour before roasting. The combination of duck or goose fat and sunflower oil adds a rich, savory depth and promotes even browning. This dish is ideal for those following a gluten-free diet if you substitute the plain flour with a gluten-free alternative. Note that the use of animal fats means this recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. The freezing method outlined ensures you’ll have beautifully roasted potatoes on demand—perfect for festive gatherings or roast dinners.

name: Stilton & poppy seed sablés
description: Sablé is French for sandy, which explains the crumbly texture of these pastries - given extra crunch by the addition of polenta
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 tbsp polenta (this is optional but does add extra crunchiness)
100g stilton, crumbled (it's easier to use if taken straight from the fridge)
extra stilton to top the biscuits
directions: In a large bowl, rub together the flour, butter, mustard powder, cayenne, polenta (if using), poppy seeds, stilton and a pinch of salt, using your fingers and hands, until the mixture forms a pastry dough. Knead the dough briefly until it really sticks together and is very lightly speckled with tiny bits of cheese. You can be quite heavy-handed.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a sausage shape with your hands, about 25cm long and 4cm in diameter, then wrap in cling film and chill for at least 1 hour. (The pastry can now be chilled for up to 1 week or frozen for up to 1 month. The pastry can be sliced and cooked from frozen but you need to cut it slightly thicker.)

To bake the biscuits, preheat the oven to 190C/gas 5/ fan 170C. Slice the dough into rounds just under 1cm thick. Lay the rounds a couple of centimetres apart on a baking sheet (or two, if you are cooking all the biscuits at the same time). Put a very small piece of stilton in the middle of each biscuit, then bake for 10-15 minutes, until the edges are starting to go golden and the cheese is bubbling. Leave to cool slightly before serving. The biscuits will keep for 2-3 days in an airtight tin.
chief_review: This sablé recipe is a delightful tribute to French pastry, offering a savory twist with the inclusion of Stilton cheese and poppy seeds. The crumbly, tender texture is skillfully enhanced by optional polenta, lending a subtle crunch that contrasts beautifully with the richness of butter and pungency of blue cheese. The mustard powder and cayenne pepper add a gentle kick, deepening the overall flavor complexity without overwhelming the palate. These savory biscuits are well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as they contain no meat or animal-derived rennet—assuming the Stilton used is vegetarian-friendly. Perfect for serving at a cheese board, as an appetizer, or alongside a crisp salad, these sablés capture the elegance of French baking with a bold, British cheese flourish.

name: Polenta & goat's cheese stacks
description: This show-stopping vegetarian main will dazzle dinner party guests and it's special enough to serve on Christmas Day
author: Good Food
ingredients: 5 medium beetroot, peeled using rubber gloves
12 shallots, soaked in hot water for 5 mins, then peeled and halved
2 thymeand rosemary sprigs, plus 2 bay leaves, all scrunched with your hands to release their scent
1½ l vegetable stock(we made this with 4 tsp bouillon powder)
2 x 100g log of goat's cheese- the kind with rind
2 tbsp each olive oil and extra-virgin olive oil, plus extra
small handful flat-leaf parsley, roughly chopped
directions: For the spinach, boil a kettle and put half the spinach into a colander. Pour over the hot water until it wilts, then cool completely under cold water. Tip into a clean tea towel, then wring out every last drop of water you can. Repeat with the other half.

For the polenta, bring the stock to the boil in a large pan, then stir in the polenta in a fine, steady stream, so to avoid any lumps. Keep cooking for 5 mins, stirring all the time, until thick. Stir in the butter, Parmesan, half of the spinach, the nutmeg and plenty of seasoning, then leave to cool for a few mins.

Meanwhile, slice each cheese into three rounds. Tear off six pieces of cling film, about 30cm across, then, while the polenta is still soft, spoon a sixth onto each square. Nestle the slices of cheese on top, then draw the edges of the cling film around and twist, to make burgershaped polenta cakes with the cheese completely sealed in the middle. Cool and chill for up to 2 days.

Cut the squash and beetroot veg into finger-tip-wide chunks. Keeping the beetroot separate, put the squash, shallots, 2 tbsp extra virgin oil and half of the garlic and herbs into a large bowl, then rub well and leave to marinate for 1 hr. Do the same with the beetroot, remaining herbs and garlic and 1 tbsp oil.

Heat a small knob of butter in a large non-stick frying pan, then fry the beetroot, herbs and garlic, for 10 mins on a medium heat, stirring often till starting to colour. Tip into one end of a large roasting tin. Wipe out pan, then repeat with the squash and shallots in a little more butter, browning one-third at a time for 5 mins, until tinged golden. Tip into the other end of the tin. Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Transfer the roasting tin to the oven and roast for 40 mins. The veg can be cooled to room temperature at this stage, then covered for up to 24 hrs and crisped up in a hot oven for 15 mins on the day.

After 40 mins scatter the sesame seeds over the roasted veg, then tip the veg into a large bowl and keep warm. With the roasting tin over a low heat, splash in the Madeira, bubble it down to 2 tbsp, then stir in the honey, balsamic, soy sauce and a little butter. Simmer until just starting to make a syrupy sauce, then stir in the olive oils. Can be made ahead and re-heated.

Fifteen mins before serving, heat a little oil and remaining butter in a large non-stick frying pan. Once sizzling, add the polenta cakes and fry on both sides for 5 mins until golden. Fry in 2 batches and keep warm. Re-heat the remaining spinach in a pan for a few secs, with a grating more nutmeg and a good pinch of seasoning.

Sit the polenta cakes on warmed plates, and top with some spinach. Stir parsley into the dressing. Toss the roasted veg with a few tsp, then pile the veg on top of the polenta. Drizzle a little more dressing over and around, then serve.
chief_review: This vegetarian main is an impressive centerpiece, perfect for festive occasions or dinner parties. The medley of squash, beetroot, and shallots, roasted with aromatic herbs, delivers depth and comfort, while the layers of vibrant spinach and creamy polenta add harmony and substance. The inclusion of goat’s cheese and vegetarian-style Parmesan offers tangy richness, beautifully offset by a sweet, glossy Madeira, honey, and balsamic glaze. The use of tamari ensures a gluten-free alternative to regular soy sauce, making this dish suitable for a gluten-free diet. Extra points for being nut-free and utilising only plant-based stocks, so it works for ovo-lacto vegetarians. The textures—crisped sesame seeds, velvety polenta, roasted roots—are wonderfully executed. Overall, this is a well-balanced, flavour-packed dish that honours seasonal vegetables with sophistication and flair.

name: Slow cooker ham with sticky ginger glaze
description: We cooked this yesterday as a test run for our Christmas ham and I can't begin to describe how good it is. The ham is very tender and the ginger flavour is beautiful. When it was cooking it smelt like Christmas in my kitchen. Would definitely recommend this as one to try.
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Put the onion and 10 cloves in the base of the

then nestle in the gammon joint. Pour over the ginger beer then cover and cook on LOW for 7 hours until the gammon is tender, but still holding its shape. You can cool then chill the gammon at this stage if you prefer.

Heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Carefully remove the skin from the gammon leaving a layer of fat behind. Score the fat in a diamond pattern with a sharp knife, making sure you don't cut into the meat, then stud the centre of each diamond with cloves.
Mix the mustard and ginger preserve in a bowl, spoon or brush over the gammon then bake for 20 mins until golden and sticky.
chief_review: This recipe transforms a classic gammon joint into a festive centerpiece, beautifully infused with the sweet spice of ginger beer and preserve. The method, utilizing both simmering and gentle roasting, ensures the ham stays moist and tender, while the cloves and mustard create a fragrant, Christmassy aroma and a subtle warmth. The balance of sweet and spice is masterfully handled, making this dish both comforting and vibrant—perfect for holiday feasts. This dish is well-suited for those looking for gluten-free options, as none of the listed ingredients commonly contain gluten (though always check specific product labels). It’s an excellent choice for festive celebrations, delivering a standout balance of flavor and impressive tenderness in the ham.

name: Stem ginger & treacle tart
description: James Martin gives the traditional treacle tart a Christmassy twist
author: James Martin
ingredients: vanilla ice cream or custard, to serve
directions: Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface until big enough to line a 23cm fluted tart case, about 3cm deep. Line the tin with the pastry and fold the overhang over the sides. Chill for 30 mins.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line the tart with greaseproof paper and baking beans. Bake blind for 20 mins. Remove the beans and paper and bake for 10 mins more until the pastry is pale golden and sandy.

Meanwhile, mix the golden syrup, breadcrumbs, lemon zest and juice, ground ginger and eggs together. Once the pastry is ready, lower the oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Using a small serrated knife, carefully trim the edges, then tip in the treacle mixture and bake for 55 mins-1 hr until the filling is golden and crisp, and feels set to the touch.

When the tart comes out of the oven, arrange the ginger slices over the top. Drizzle with some syrup from the ginger jar, then lift from the tin to a serving plate and serve warm with vanilla ice cream or custard.
chief_review: James Martin's festive treacle tart elevates a classic British dessert with a delightful Christmassy flair. The addition of ground and stem ginger introduces a warming spice, which beautifully balances the indulgent sweetness of golden syrup. Lemon zest and juice impart a refreshing brightness, ensuring the tart remains vibrant on the palate. The use of ready-made shortcrust pastry streamlines the process without sacrificing texture—crisp and flaky beneath a rich breadcrumb filling. This recipe contains eggs, wheat, and gluten, making it unsuitable for gluten-free or vegan diets, but it’s a strong vegetarian option. Served warm with vanilla ice cream or custard, this tart is perfect for holiday gatherings, offering both nostalgia and seasonal charm.

name: Oven-baked rösti cake
description: Grate potatoes into a hash brown-style patty and cook in the oven for a convenient and tasty side dish
author: Emma Lewis
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Dry-fry the bacon in a pan for 5 mins until crisp, then chop into small pieces. Boil the whole potatoes for 5 mins, drain, then place in a bowl of chilled water.

When cool enough to handle, pat the potatoes dry and roughly grate into a large bowl. Toss with the oil as you go, to stop them from sticking. Roughly grate the onion and squeeze out any excess juice, then stir into the potatoes along with the bacon.

Place a baking sheet in the oven for 5 mins to warm through. Liberally grease a 23cm loose-bottomed cake tin with butter. Scatter the potato over the tin, trying not to pack it down, then dot all over the top with butter. Place on the hot baking sheet and bake in the oven for 1 hr 20 mins until the potatoes are cooked through and crisp on top.
chief_review: This oven-baked potato hash brown recipe offers a delicious combination of crispy bacon, tender potatoes, and sweet onions, all bound by a hint of olive oil. The choice of Maris Piper potatoes ensures a light, fluffy texture at the center, crisply edged by oven roasting. Bacon brings a savory, smoky note that balances wonderfully with the subtle onion. The method is simple and fuss-free—ideal for a hearty breakfast side or a comforting dinner addition. This recipe is suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided that all processed ingredients, such as bacon, are checked for hidden gluten. The use of olive oil instead of other fats keeps the flavor fresh and contemporary. A definite crowd-pleaser that feels both homely and thoughtfully put together.

name: Caramelised apple & walnut strudel
description: Have made this several times - really easy and quite impressive. Today I couldn't get filo pastry (small town supermarket) so tried it with puff pastry. Interesting, but still delicious!!
author: James Martin
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Heat 75g of the sugar and the vanilla seeds in a medium, heavy-based frying pan over a medium-low heat for 5-8 mins, or until golden brown and caramelised. Add the apples, currants, sultanas, allspice, nutmeg and walnuts, then cook for 10 mins or until the apple is tender. Remove the apple mix from the pan with a slotted spoon and cool to room temperature.

Line 2 baking trays with baking paper. Place a sheet of filo on one of the trays, then brush lightly with the melted butter. Sprinkle over 1 tsp sugar. Repeat the process until there are 3 layers of filo. Repeat with the remaining sheets of filo on the second tray.

Divide the apple mix along the shorter edge of both pastry sheets and gently roll into 2 logs, tucking in the ends as you go. Brush with melted butter and sprinkle over 1 tbsp sugar. Can be made up to 1 day ahead, kept chilled. Bake for 25 mins, or until the pastry is golden brown and crisp. Let cool slightly, then cut each strudel into 6 diagonal slices. Serve two slices each with a dollop of crème fraîche on the side.
chief_review: This apple and nut strudel is a delightful dessert, combining the tartness of Granny Smith apples with the warmth of allspice and nutmeg. The addition of currants, sultanas, and chopped walnuts creates a lovely texture and depth of flavor, all encased in delicate, flaky filo pastry. The use of crème fraîche on the side adds a rich, tangy creaminess that balances the sweetness perfectly. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarian diets, as it contains no meat, poultry, or fish. However, do note the inclusion of butter and crème fraîche, so it is not vegan. The walnuts bring a pleasant crunch, but those with nut allergies should avoid it. Overall, this dessert is both easy to prepare and impressive for entertaining. Enjoy warm for the best experience.

name: Pickled red cabbage
description: A colourful accompaniment to cheese or meat, this infused pickle can also be jarred and given as a gift
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Place the shredded cabbage in a colander over the sink and sprinkle with salt. Leave for 2-3 hours, then drain and wash away the salt. Pay dry with a clean tea towel.
Put the vinegar, wine, sugar, peppercorns and bay leaves into a big, wide saucepan and simmer until the liquid has reduced by about half. Set aside for 10 mins to infuse.

Strain through a fine sieve into a jug or bowl, and discard the peppercorns and bay leaves. Put the cabbage and mustard seeds into a big bowl, and then pour the strained liquid over. Transfer the cabbage and pickling liquid into sterilised jars and seal. Will last for a month in the fridge.
chief_review: This vibrant red cabbage pickle offers a balance of tang, spice, and sweetness, making it a versatile companion for cheese boards and charcuterie platters alike. The use of cider vinegar and red wine builds a robust acidity, while the mustard seeds, bay leaves, and peppercorns lend aromatic complexity. Sugar softens the sharpness, allowing the cabbage’s natural flavor to shine through. The preparation is straightforward, and the result is both visually appealing and deliciously piquant. Suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, this pickle is also naturally gluten-free—ideal for a wide range of guests. Its shelf-stability makes it perfect for batch-making and gifting. A thoughtful addition to festive spreads or everyday sandwiches.

name: Garland sausage roll slice
description: This party recipe adds a touch of sophistication to traditional sausage rolls, and can be made one day ahead for minimum stress
author: Good Food
ingredients: small bunch flat-leaf parsley, leaves chopped
1cm thick slice of ham, cut into small chunks
directions: Boil eggs for 2½ mins, then cool slightly before peeling and trimming each end.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. In a bowl, mix together the sausagemeat grated onion, apple, parsley, Tabasco, ham and breadcrumbs. Roll the pastry out to a rectangle about 25 x 35cm, carefully lift onto a baking sheet and brush all over with beaten egg.

Press two-thirds of the sausage mix along one of the long sides of the pastry, leaving 2cm pastry free on one side for sealing, and half of the pastry empty on the other side for folding over later. Press a line down the middle of the meat with your finger, then lay the eggs along it, trimmed end to trimmed end. Press over the rest of the sausagemeat. Fold the pastry over the sausage and press the edges together, before trimming with a knife and sealing well by pressing the edges with a fork.
Brush all over with more egg and bake for 40 mins until golden. Leave to cool, then slice and serve with mustard. Can be made 1 day ahead.
chief_review: This recipe is an elevated twist on the classic sausage roll, offering balanced flavors and a refined bite for any gathering. The use of quail eggs adds a delicate richness, while the seasoned sausage mixture—enhanced by grated apple and parsley—brings freshness and depth. The addition of ham and a shake of Tabasco introduces subtle complexity, making each bite memorable. Wrapping the filling in all-butter puff pastry ensures a flaky, golden exterior, perfectly complemented by the gentle tang of wholegrain mustard. Suitable for preparation a day in advance, this dish is ideal for hosts who appreciate flavorful, make-ahead options. Notably, with its combination of meat, egg, and dairy, this recipe is not suitable for vegetarian or vegan diets, nor is it gluten-free due to the puff pastry and breadcrumbs.

name: Cranberry jewelled mincemeat
description: Cooking up batches of this festive, fruity mincemeat will fill your kitchen with the smell of Christmas
author: James Martin
ingredients: 500g mixture of raisins, currants and sultana(use jumbo or golden sultanas if you can get them)
100g fresh or frozen cranberry, roughly chopped
directions: Tip the dried fruits and mixed peel into a large bowl. Pour over the brandy, zests and juices. Stir, then cover and leave to soak for 24 hrs.

Tip the mixture into a large saucepan with the remaining ingredients and stir well. Set over a medium heat and, once the suet has melted, turn up the heat and bubble for a few mins. Pack while hot into sterilised jars (see tip, below). Leave in a cool, dark cupboard for at least a fortnight, or for up to 6 months.
chief_review: A beautifully festive mincemeat, this recipe bursts with the aromas of dried fruits, citrus, and warming spices. The combination of raisins, currants, sultanas, apricots, cranberries, mixed peel and brandy ensures a rich, complex depth of flavour that fills your kitchen with the essence of Christmas. The addition of both dried and fresh/frozen cranberries brightens the mixture and balances the sweetness, while cinnamon and nutmeg provide a comforting spice base. Using suet in the mix contributes a traditional, luxurious texture. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians if you opt for vegetarian suet, making it accessible to a wider range of festive tables. The mincemeat’s make-ahead nature allows flavours to meld beautifully. Overall, a classic yet vibrant take on mincemeat, perfect for pies, tarts, or even spooned over vanilla ice cream for a holiday treat.

name: Classic roast goose with cider gravy
description: A foolproof guide to cooking this festive favourite with a simple gravy
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 4-5kg/9-11lb 4 oz oven-ready goose, trussed for roasting
gooseneck, chopped into a few pieces
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Remove all the fat from inside the bird and use a skewer to prick the skin all over, especially under the wings. Season the inside and stuff the goose with the onions and herbs. Rub the breast and legs with the oil; season generously with salt. Sit the bird, the right way up, in a large roasting tin. Cover with a large piece of foil, scrunching it up at the sides so it’s a tight fit. Place the goose in the oven (leaving a shelf above free for the Roasted roots, see page 62) for 1 hr 30 mins.

Take the goose out of the oven, then remove the foil, carefully ladle all the fat out of the tin (or use a baster to suck it out) into a bowl, then lightly baste the goose. Re-cover with foil, then roast for another 1 hr 30 mins. Pour all the fat from the tin again, baste, then return to the oven without any foil to brown for a final 30-40 mins until golden brown. Don’t worry about whether it’s done – the goose will be cooked all the way through. Transfer the goose to a large board or platter to rest in a warmish place for 30 mins. Keep the tin to finish the gravy in.

To make the gravy, while the goose is roasting, heat the oil in a sauté pan until very hot, add the pieces of goose neck, then fry until browned and caramelised. Add the veg to the pan, then fry for about 10 mins until brown and just starting to burn slightly. Throw in the herbs, then pour over the cider and boil down by about two-thirds, skimming off any froth that comes to the top. Pour in the chicken stock, reduce by half, then strain into a large jug and set aside. The stock can be made the day before.

Once the goose has come out of the tin, pour all but about 2 tbsp of fat from it, keeping in any brown juices. Place the tin on the heat, scatter in the flour and stir to make a brown paste the texture of wet sand. Slowly pour in the cider stock and stir to make a smooth gravy. Season to taste, then strain again into a gravy jug.
Serve the goose on a platter with the herby onions from the cavity scattered around.
chief_review: This festive goose recipe is a classic centrepiece for any holiday table, offering crisp, golden skin and tender, flavourful meat. The method is thoughtfully detailed, ensuring even novice cooks can achieve an impressive result. Roasting over aromatic onions, bay, and thyme infuses the bird with delicate herbal notes, while the inclusion of simple, natural ingredients keeps the focus on the goose's rich flavour. The cider- and stock-based gravy is a delightful accompaniment, providing depth and a pleasant tang that elevates the dish. While best suited to traditional eaters, this recipe would be appropriate for those following a dairy-free diet. The dish is substantial, warming, and ideal for celebratory occasions. For extra finesse, skim and reserve the rendered goose fat for glorious roast potatoes or vegetables—no chef would let that go to waste!

name: Festive gammon
description: I made this for the firs time this year, to take along for Christmas lunch with my family. I used a 3kg ham and adjusted the recipe accordingly. It was really tasty, tender and everyone loved it, there were 7 of us and there was still plenty left over. Great as sandwiches with chutney! Really loved the recipe will be making it again.
author: Richard Corrigan
directions: For the brining, take all the spices for the glaze and toast them in a frying pan until they begin to release their fragrance. Grind using a pestle and mortar, then tip into a food processor with the sugar and blitz everything together to make a spice mix. Tip two-thirds of the mix (reserving the rest in a sealed plastic container) into a large pan with the salt and 5 litres of water and bring to the boil, then turn off the heat. When the mix has cooled, pour it over the ham and leave in the fridge to brine for 24 hrs.

After 24 hrs, wash off the brine. Place the ham in a large pan with the stock veg, herbs and vinegar. Cover with water and bring to the boil. Lower the heat to a gentle simmer and cook, uncovered, for 3 hrs, topping up with water as necessary. Turn off the heat and leave the ham to cool in the stock.

Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Remove the ham from the stock and cut away the top layer of fat and skin. Score the fat in a criss-cross and brush with the mustard, then pack on the reserved spiced sugar. Roast for 35-40 mins until the glaze has completely caramelised and become sticky. Allow the ham to rest for at least 10 mins before carving.
chief_review: This festive ham recipe is a showstopper, perfect for a special occasion like Christmas lunch. The use of whole spices such as coriander, fennel, cloves, and star anise infuses the meat with deeply aromatic, warming flavors, while the generous sugar and Dijon mustard create a sweet, tangy glaze that caramelizes beautifully. The aromatic vegetables and herbs add layers of subtlety, rendering the ham exceptionally moist and tender. Leftovers are a bonus—sliced ham with chutney makes an unbeatable sandwich. This recipe is particularly suitable for a gluten-free diet, as none of the listed ingredients contain gluten. However, always check your mustard and vinegar for cross-contamination or hidden gluten if cooking for someone with celiac disease. Overall, a delicious, crowd-pleasing centerpiece you’ll want to make again.

name: Chocolate, cranberry & macadamia brownies
description: Leftover cranberry sauce? Use it as an excuse to make these delicious chocolate, nutty cake squares
author: Caroline Hire
directions: Heat the oven to 180C/ 160C fan/ gas 4 and line a 20cm x 20cm baking tin with baking parchment. Melt the dark chocolate with the butter in the microwave or in a heatproof bowl over just simmering water.

Mix together the sugar, flour and cocoa powder and stir in the melted chocolate and butter mixture, followed by the eggs. Stir through the dried cranberries and macadamia nuts, then swirl through the cranberry sauce.
Pour into the tin and smooth the surface. Bake for 25 - 30 mins. Allow to cool before slicing.
chief_review: This inventive recipe cleverly repurposes leftover cranberry sauce into rich, chocolatey cake squares layered with bursts of dried cranberries and crunchy macadamia nuts. The combination of dark chocolate and cocoa delivers deep, robust flavor, balanced by the tartness of cranberry and the buttery crunch of the nuts. Using self-raising flour means the cake bakes up with a tender, moist crumb, while the soft brown sugar adds comforting warmth. Perfect for serving as a seasonal dessert or as an indulgent snack with coffee. Suitable for vegetarian diets, as it contains no meat or gelatin, but does include eggs and dairy. Those with nut allergies should be aware of the inclusion of macadamia nuts. The recipe brings together pantry staples in a creative way, offering a satisfying treat that makes the most of your holiday leftovers.

name: Chocolate, ginger & praline bombe
description: A frozen pud with real star quality – and you don’t need an ice-cream machine to make it
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Take a large food bag, cut down one side and along the base, then open out. Use to line a 1-litre pudding basin. Tip the contents of the jar of conserve into a large bowl, then stir to break it down. Using a large sharp knife, shave 50g of the chocolate into shards, then reserve. Measure 450ml of the cream into a bowl, then whip until it just holds its shape. Fold the cream into the ginger conserve using a large spoon until the cream is evenly flecked with ginger, then gently fold in the shaved chocolate.

Spoon the cream mixture into the lined bowl and smooth the top. Freeze for at least 4 hrs, or overnight is better, until the ice cream is firm. Line a wooden board with foil, then lightly oil the foil. Tip the sugar into a heavy based pan, then gently heat, without stirring, until the sugar is melted and a golden caramel. You can swirl the pan gently to help it melt evenly if necessary. Remove from the heat, then stir in the almonds. Tip onto the foil, spread out with the back of an oiled metal spoon, then leave to set.
Pour the reserved cream into a small pan. Break up the remaining chocolate, then add to the pan, stirring over a low heat until the chocolate has dissolved. Set aside to cool and thicken.
When the almond caramel has set, break it up into small pieces using a rolling pin. You are aiming for a mix of larger and smaller pieces.

When the chocolate sauce has cooled and is thick enough for spreading, turn the ice-cream bombe out onto a serving plate, remove the bowl, then peel off the plastic. Spread the chocolate over the top and sides of the bombe as evenly as possible. Add more as the first layer starts to set until you have used it all up. Scatter over the almond caramel, then return to the freezer until firm. To store the bombe, wrap in freezer film until ready to serve.
To serve, transfer the bombe to the fridge 45 mins before serving. Dust with a little icing sugar and cut into thick wedges.
chief_review: This frozen dessert impresses with a delightful balance of warming ginger and rich dark chocolate, elevated by the contrasting crunch of flaked almonds. The absence of eggs keeps the recipe straightforward and smooth in texture, while the cream ensures a velvety, indulgent finish. Sweetness is expertly managed, allowing the spicy-sweet ginger notes to shine. With no ice-cream machine required, this pud is accessible for home cooks seeking a sophisticated end to a meal. The use of dark chocolate may also appeal to those seeking a slightly less sweet dessert. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe is a treat at festive gatherings or summer soirées alike. The sprinkling of icing sugar and almonds adds visual appeal and a pleasing bite, making each serving both elegant and satisfying.

name: Boxing Day soup
description: Use up your leftover Christmas Day vegetables in this comforting winter soup
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 medium potatoes, about 350g/12oz total weight, peeled and cut into small chunks
1.2l vegetable stock, made from a stock cube
550g leftover roasted or boiled vegetables, such as Brussels sprout, carrots, parsnips and squash, roughly chopped
natural yogurt or crème fraîche, to serve
directions: To fry the vegetables, heat the oil in a large saucepan and fry the onion for 5 minutes until golden. Stir in the celery and fry for 5 minutes, then tip in the potatoes and fry for a further 1-2 minutes, stirring often.
Stir in the curry paste, let it cook for a minute or so, then pour in the stock. Bring to the boil and stir well. Lower the heat, cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes until the potatoes are tender.

To serve, tip the leftover veg into the pan and warm through for a few minutes. Pour the soup into a food processor or blender and blitz to a smooth purée. Thin down to the consistency you like with hot water or stock (we added 300ml) then taste for seasoning. Cool and freeze, or serve in bowls with spoonfuls of yogurt or crème fraîche swirled on top.
chief_review: This vibrant winter soup is a clever and resourceful way to give new life to leftover Christmas vegetables. The combination of onion, celery, potatoes, and a medley of roasted or boiled veg creates a robust and hearty base, while a spoonful of curry paste layers in subtle warmth and spice. The use of vegetable stock keeps it light yet flavorful, and finishing with natural yogurt or crème fraîche adds a welcome creamy tang. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians and can easily be made vegan by swapping the dairy garnish for a plant-based alternative. Additionally, it’s gluten-free if you ensure your stock cube is certified gluten-free. Perfect for a nourishing post-holiday meal, this soup is both comforting and versatile, encouraging creativity with whatever vegetables are on hand.

name: Creamy celery gratin
description:
Let celery take centre stage in this delicious side dish. The
wine and stock make an intense sauce,
while the nutty breadcrumbs provide
a satisfying crunch
author: Good Food
directions: Cut any thick celery stalks in half, trim all of it into thumb-size lengths, then wash and leave wet. Melt half the butter in a large frying pan, then add the celery, onion and bay leaves. Season, cover, then cook over a medium heat for about 30 mins, stirring occasionally to stop the onions catching.
Meanwhile, prepare the breadcrumbs. Melt the remaining butter in a separate pan, then toss in the crumbs and walnuts, stirring often until lightly golden and toasted. Set aside.

Heat grill to medium. When the celery is tender, turn the heat right up, pour in the wine and stock, then reduce by two-thirds. Pour in the cream, then reduce for a final few mins until you have a syrupy sauce. Check seasoning, tip into an ovenproof dish, then scatter with the breadcrumbs and Parmesan. Grill for 2-3 mins, until the sauce bubbles. Let it sit for 5 mins before serving.
chief_review: This celery-forward side dish showcases the vegetable’s subtle, earthy flavor paired beautifully with the richness of butter, double cream, and wine-infused stock. The use of nutty walnuts and crisp breadcrumbs adds delightful texture, while the parmesan lends a savory depth. Using vegetable stock and a vegetarian Parmesan alternative, this recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet. It’s also ideal for those seeking a hearty, comforting accompaniment with layered flavors and contrasting textures. Pair it alongside roast meats or as part of a robust vegetarian spread for a sophisticated, seasonal touch.

name: Apricot & almond fruitcake
description: This bake is lighter than the traditional rich fruitcake and is a blank canvas to ice and decorate as you wish
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 250g pack butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Mix the sultanas and sherry and set aside for 1 hr to soak.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease a deep, 23cm loose-bottomed cake tin, and line the base and sides with a double layer of baking parchment that comes about 2.5cm above the sides of the tin. In your largest mixing bowl, beat the butter, sugar and vanilla together until pale and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one by one.

Stir in the flour, baking powder, and the ground and flaked almonds. Next, add the soaked sultanas with any remaining sherry, the dried apricots, the mixed peel, and all the zest and juice. Scrape into the cake tin, smoothing out the surface.

Bake on the middle shelf of the oven for 1 hr 25 mins. Poke with a skewer in the centre to check it is cooked – if the skewer comes out with any uncooked mixture stuck to it, bake for 10 mins more before checking again. Cool in the tin. Decorated, or wrapped in greaseproof paper and foil, the cake will keep for up to a month.
chief_review: This bake offers a refreshing take on the classic fruitcake, delivering a lighter, pleasantly moist crumb thanks to the inclusion of sherry-soaked sultanas, ground almonds, and citrus zest. The blend of toasted flaked almonds and dried apricots gives a lovely texture and tartness that balances well with the gentle sweetness of light brown sugar. Its versatile, subtly flavored base makes it ideal for creative icing and decoration, perfect for celebratory occasions. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe can be enjoyed by many looking for a festive cake without overly dense richness. The use of ground and flaked almonds adds not only flavor but also a delicate nuttiness, making each bite more nuanced. A thoughtfully crafted bake, this cake is sure to be a charming centerpiece for both casual gatherings and formal celebrations.

name: Squash & nigella seed soup
description: Perfect recipe for a frosty day! Used one of our home grown squashes, left out the nigella seeds, & added a big spoon of curry powder instead of the chilli. Crusty rolls & you're well away!
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 800g squash, peeled, deseeded and cut into chunks
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan, add the onion, then fry until lightly coloured. Add the nigella seeds and chilli, then fry for 1 min. Tip in the squash, potato and stock, then bring to the boil. Stir well, cover, then simmer for 20 mins, or until the vegetables are tender.
Purée the soup in batches, adding a handful of parsley with each batch. Return the soup to the pan, then reheat. The soup can be frozen for up to 1 month.
chief_review: This hearty squash soup is a warming, flavorful bowl perfect for chilly days. The sweetness of homegrown squash pairs beautifully with a hint of spice from the curry powder and a subtle earthiness from the olive oil. The addition of potato gives a creamy texture, while fresh parsley brightens the dish just before serving. The recipe is entirely plant-based, making it an excellent choice for vegetarians and vegans alike. Using low-sodium vegetable stock keeps it heart-healthy without compromising flavor. Serve it with crusty rolls for a satisfying meal. Overall, this soup is wholesome, comforting, and easy to adapt—ideal for anyone seeking a nourishing, meat-free option.

name: Wild mushroom, potato & pancetta gratin
description: Bake layers of vegetables and Italian bacon with thyme, nutmeg and double cream for a rich, warming one-pot - the ultimate comfort food
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 3 thyme sprigs, plus a sprinkle of leaves
250g wild mushrooms, roughly chopped after cleaning
directions: Put the garlic cloves, onion, bay leaves, thyme, double cream and milk in a pan. Bring slowly to the boil over a low heat, partially cover with a lid and cook for 20-30 mins until the onion is tender and the cream mixture slightly thickened. Turn off and leave everything to infuse for 1 hr.

Strain the cream mixture into a jug (or bowl) and discard the herbs. Put the garlic cloves and onion in a food processor or blender and whizz until smooth – add a drop of the cream if it helps. Stir the paste back into the rest of the cream and season with 2 tsp salt.

Put the pancetta in a cold frying pan and cook gently, over a low-medium heat so the fat melts into the pan, until the pancetta is really crispy. Lift out with a slotted spoon, add the butter and mushrooms and turn up the heat, frying the mushrooms, until golden and dry.

Leave the skins on the potatoes and slice as thinly as possible. Grease a large baking dish with a little more butter. Layer up the potato slices, scattering over some of the cooked pancetta, the mushrooms and a little freshly grated nutmeg and pepper as you go. Finish by slowly pouring over the cream so that it settles among all the layers, then scatter over a few more thyme leaves. Cover with foil.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Bake the gratin for 1 hr, then remove the foil and bake for 35-45 mins more until golden and crispy on top. Poke a knife in to check the potatoes are tender, then leave for 10-15 mins to settle, before serving with a salad, if you like.
chief_review: This baked vegetable and pancetta gratin is a sublime comfort dish, rich with layers of earthy wild mushrooms, tender potatoes, and savory Italian pancetta, all enveloped in a luxurious thyme- and nutmeg-infused double cream sauce. The extended use of garlic, bay leaves, and fresh thyme creates an aromatic base that deepens the flavors, while the crispy topping from a final oven bake adds textural allure. The dish would particularly appeal to those following a gluten-free diet, as it contains no wheat-based ingredients; just ensure that your pancetta is gluten-free, as some processed meats may contain additives. Pairing with a simple green salad balances the dish’s decadence and ensures a well-rounded meal. This recipe delivers hearty, classic flavors perfect for a cozy gathering.

name: Pine nut & honey tart
description: This make-ahead tart is the ultimate finale for a festive buffet - just make sure you have enough as guests may well want seconds
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 50g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
2 tbsp clear honey, plus extra for drizzling
directions: Put the raisins and glacé fruit in a bowl with the rum or juice, then soak for 1 hr.
Roll out the pastry on a surface lightly dusted with flour, then use it to line a deep 23cm loose-bottomed tart tin. Leave the pastry overhanging the edges, prick the base, then chill for 1 hr.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Fill the pastry case with baking paper and baking beans, then blind-bake for 8 mins. Remove paper and beans, then bake for about 5 mins more. Allow to cool a little.
Beat the butter, sugar, almonds, flour and eggs. Stir in the fruit, then pour into the case. Scatter over the pine nuts, press lightly into the surface, then drizzle with honey.

Return the tart to the oven, turn down heat to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and bake for 40-50 mins until firm to the touch. If the top browns too quickly, cover with foil. Cool in the tin. Will keep in a cool place for 2 days and will freeze for 3 months. Thaw at room temperature for 5 hrs. Drizzle with honey to serve.
chief_review: This festive tart is a delightful blend of luxurious textures and flavors, with glacé fruits and raisins steeped in rum or orange juice for a fragrant depth. The frangipane base—rich with ground almonds and softened butter—delivers a moist, tender crumb, contrasted beautifully by sweet, crunchy pine nuts and a glistening honey glaze. Its make-ahead nature makes it perfect for entertaining, ensuring a stress-free, show-stopping finale to any buffet. This recipe is an excellent option for vegetarians and, if you opt for orange juice, for those preferring alcohol-free desserts. However, the presence of eggs, dairy, nuts, and wheat flour excludes it from vegan, gluten-free, and nut-free diets. Overall, this tart shines with seasonal richness and is sure to impress your guests.

name: Appleberry mulled wine
description: Very nice- Much better than any other mulled wine recipe I have tried, so fruity!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 x 75cl bottles red wine(such as Merlot; better quality wine makes all the difference)
1 long cinnamon stick, snapped in half
a handful or so (about 100g/4oz) frozen mulled fruitor fruits of the forest or Black Forest fruits
3 small red-skinned apples, sliced into rings
directions: Pour the wine and apple juice into a large saucepan and add the sugar, cinnamon stick and star anise. Heat gently, stirring once or twice, until the sugar has dissolved, then continue heating gently for another 15 minutes.
Just before serving, swirl in the Curaçao or Cointreau, throw in the frozen fruits and add the apple slices.
chief_review: This mulled wine recipe is a standout, thanks to its generous fruitiness and refined balance of sweetness and spice. The combination of good-quality red wine and cloudy apple juice creates a rich base, while cinnamon and star anise infuse warming aromatic notes. The use of orange liqueur adds citrus complexity, and the addition of Black Forest fruits and fresh apple slices give both depth and freshness. Suitable for vegetarians and naturally gluten-free, this recipe also accommodates a dairy-free diet. Perfect for festive gatherings, the outcome is an aromatic, crowd-pleasing winter warmer—deliciously better than standard mulled wine preparations.

name: Caramelised nuts
description: A moreish treat that can be a little addictive. These nuts are so yummy you'll need to make double
author: Tana Ramsay
ingredients: 200g mixed nut, try pecans, almonds, hazlenuts, pistachios
directions: Mix together all the ingredients in a pan and place over a moderate heat. Stir constantly, allowing the mix to caramelise and turn brown and making sure all the nuts are well coated.
Pour the nuts onto some greaseproof paper. Don't worry if they are stuck together, as they can be separated when cool. Store in an airtight container for up to 1 week.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers an irresistible combination of crunchy, toasted mixed nuts enrobed in a delicately sweet, citrus-kissed coating thanks to the Grand Marnier. The use of pecans, almonds, hazelnuts, and pistachios ensures a pleasing variety of texture and flavor in every bite. The icing sugar provides a satisfying sweetness that pairs elegantly with the orange notes of the liqueur. 

This treat is naturally gluten-free, provided the icing sugar is certified gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. Additionally, as it contains only nuts, sugar, and liqueur, it's appropriate for a vegetarian diet. However, be mindful of nut allergies. Perfect for festive gatherings or as an indulgent snack, this recipe is as simple as it is addictive—just as a proper chef’s snack should be.

name: Salmon & prawns with dill & lime aïoli
description: For a simple, smart starter, just mix mayo with garlic, herbs and a squeeze of lime and serve with seafood and brown bread
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g cooked king prawns, shelled apart from the tail
2 tbsp chopped fresh dill, plus extra leaves to garnish
juice ½ lime, plus 1 wedged to serve
granary breadand butter, to serve, if you like
directions: Arrange the prawns and salmon on plates. Mix the mayo, garlic and chopped dill, and add lime juice to taste. Put a spoonful on each plate, scatter over dill leaves add a wedge of lime and a grinding of pepper.
chief_review: This seafood starter impresses with its elegant simplicity and fresh flavor combinations. The rich mix of mayonnaise with garlic, dill, and lime provides a zesty, aromatic lift that pairs beautifully with the sweet, briny prawns and smoky salmon. Presentation is quick and refined, making it perfect for entertaining. The use of fresh dill and lime not only cuts through the richness of the seafood but adds vibrancy to every bite. Accompanied by granary bread, this dish is satisfying yet light—ideal as a prelude to a summer meal. Suitable for pescatarians, this recipe is also free from nuts. Those with dairy or gluten sensitivities should note the butter and bread, which can be easily substituted if needed. A stylish, flavor-packed starter that’s effortlessly sophisticated.

name: Creamy potato & shallot gratin
description: How will you serve your potatoes this Christmas? If rich and creamy is your thing, try this indulgent gratin recipe
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1kg Desirée potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced
directions: Heat most of the butter in a shallow pan. Add the shallots, bay leaf and thyme, and cook for 10 mins until soft, golden and sticky. Pour in the cream and bring to the boil. Turn off the heat, season with nutmeg and cayenne and leave to infuse.

Meanwhile, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Place the potatoes in a pan of cold water, bring to the boil, then drain. Butter a large gratin dish, then layer it up with potatoes and cream, finishing with a good ladle of cream and shallots. Use a fish slice to press everything down.
. Bake for 40 mins or until golden and the shallots are starting to crisp.
chief_review: This potato gratin is a classic festive indulgence, rich in both flavor and texture. The combination of caramelized shallots, fragrant bay leaf, and thyme infuses the cream with aromatic notes, while nutmeg and cayenne add depth and gentle warmth. Layered thinly sliced Desirée potatoes absorb the creamy mixture beautifully, resulting in luscious, tender layers and a golden, buttery finish. This recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it ideal for those with gluten sensitivities. However, it contains dairy, so it's best-suited for those who can enjoy butter and cream. Serve this gratin as a decadent side dish to complement your holiday centerpiece—its silky, savory richness is guaranteed to impress your guests and elevate any celebration.

name: Venison & wild mushroom Wellington
description: A stunning centrepiece for any dinner party - how about trying it as an alternative to turkey at Christmas?
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 1 trimmed loin of venisonweighing about 1kg, cut into 2 equal pieces. Ask for the loin or the loin fillet off the bone, well-trimmed
300g mixed wild mushroom, trimmed and cleaned
2-4 thin herb pancakes, see directions, below
directions: Heat half the oil in a frying pan and quickly seal the venison for about 2 mins on each side until browned. Remove the meat from the pan, brush all over with the mustard and leave to cool.

Mince the mushrooms in a food processor. Place the pan back on the heat with the rest of the oil and add the mushrooms. Season with salt and pepper and fry over a high heat for 5 mins until the excess moisture has evaporated and you have a thick paste. Season, transfer the mushrooms to a bowl and leave to cool.

Lay 2-3 large sheets of cling film overlapping each other on a clean surface. Lay the slices of prosciutto overlapping lengthways in 2 rows of 3. Sit one of the pieces of venison in the middle of the prosciutto. Press the mushrooms over the venison and sandwich with the other piece of venison. Roll into a tight package (see step-by-step images above) and leave to chill in the fridge.

Lay out another couple of pieces of cling film. Trim the pancakes into squares and lay them overlapping on the cling film. Remove the cling film from the prosciuttowrapped meat and place the meat on top of the pancakes. Roll up tightly again in cling film, then place in the fridge to hold its shape.

Roll the pastry out to a large rectangle big enough to easily wrap the meat in, then brush all over with egg yolk. Unwrap the cling film from the pancake-wrapped venison and roll to completely encase in the pastry. Tuck the ends in and trim any excess. Lay out more cling film and finally roll into a tight package to get an evenly thick log. Tie the ends of cling film to keep the package tight and leave in the fridge overnight or in the freezer for an hour. Can be made to this point up to a day in advance.

When ready to cook, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Remove the cling film and brush the Wellington all over with egg yolk. Sit it on a baking tray lined with baking paper and lightly score in a feathered fashion. Bake for 50 mins for medium rare, dropping to 200C/180C fan/ gas 7 if the pastry becomes too brown. Remove from the oven to rest for 20 mins. If you prefer the meat well done, turn oven off after 40 mins and leave to rest inside. Trim the end of the pastry, carefully carve in slices about 3-4cm thick and serve.

for the Wellingtons, tip 100g plain flour into a bowl. Beat 1 egg with 250ml milk and gradually whisk into the flour until smooth. Stir in some snipped chives and a handful of chopped flat-leaf parsley just before cooking, then heat a drop of oil in a large non-stick frying pan and swirl around some of the batter to make a thin pancake. When the pancake is done, make another 3 and set aside. The pancakes can be made 2 days in advance.

, chunk 1kg floury potatoes. Place in a pan of cold salted water and bring to the boil. Simmer for about 15 mins until completely tender, then drain and return to the pan over a low heat for a few mins to dry out. Press the potatoes through a ricer and gradually add 150ml warm double cream and 50g butter. Season to taste and serve, or leave to cool and reheat in a pan or microwave with a touch more cream and butter. The mash can be made a day in advance.

, peel and trim 24 baby carrots (a mix of white and orange if you can find them) but keep them whole. Boil for 2-3 mins in salted water until just tender, then drain. Heat a large knob of butter in a frying pan and sizzle the carrots for 8-10 mins until golden. Serve the carrots or cool and reheat in a pan with a touch more butter or in the microwave. The carrots can be made a day in advance.

, sweat 1 finely chopped shallot in a little butter with a thyme sprig. Pour in 300ml port and reduce by two-thirds, then add 600ml fresh chicken stock and reduce again by two-thirds until syrupy. Strain into another saucepan ready to be reheated. The sauce can be made 2 days in advance and reheated in the saucepan, adding a splash more stock if too thick.
chief_review:
This venison Wellington is an impressive dish worthy of any festive table, distinguished by tender venison loin wrapped in a savoury blend of wild mushrooms, prosciutto, herb pancakes, and buttery puff pastry—delivering luxurious texture and bold, earthy flavours. The port and chicken stock reduction elevates the dish with a rich, elegant sauce, while creamy mash and buttery carrots complete the classic presentation. 

It is well-suited for those following a diet without gluten or dairy restrictions; as written, it contains wheat (in the pancakes, pastry, and flour) and dairy from butter and cream, plus eggs and prosciutto. The generous use of wild mushrooms, fresh herbs, and venison makes it a refined alternative to traditional roasts, especially for a gathering where a show-stopping centrepiece is desired. Ideal for those seeking a sophisticated twist on holiday fare.

name: Pancetta-wrapped turkey breast with herby lemon & pine nut stuffing
description: No need for impressive carving skills with this easy-to-serve dish with creamy gravy
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 20 rashers pancetta (2 x 70g/2oz packs) or thinly sliced streaky bacon
140g pack pancetta cubes or bacon lardons
25g pack sage, leaves only, roughly chopped
2 x 20g/1oz packs flat-leaf parsley, roughly chopped
directions: First prepare the stuffing. Heat the butter and oil in a large frying pan, then soften the onion without colouring for 10 mins. Tip into a bowl. Add the pancetta or bacon to the pan, fry for 5 mins until golden, then add the pine nuts, garlic, sage and lemon zest. Fry for 1 min more until fragrant and the pine nuts are starting to brown. Stir in the chopped parsley. Tip into the bowl with the onions, then bind with the crumbs, egg and seasoning.

Butter and season a sheet of turkey foil or use 2 sheets of foil crimped together to make a sheet about 50 x 60cm. Lay five long pieces of string over the foil like rungs of a ladder, ready to tie the breast together. Arrange the pancetta or bacon in a lattice over the middle of the foil, on top of the string.

Open out the butterflied breast, skin-side down, and slash each side several times. Cover with cling film and bash with a rolling pin until the meat is about 5cm thick all over. Trim the sides so that you have a roughly rectangular shape (but be careful not to cut the skin). Lift onto the pancetta, then fill any gaps with the trimmings. Season, then press the stuffing along the middle of the joint. Pull up the sides at one end, tucking in the short end, then tie the string tightly so that the stuffing is encased. Repeat with all the strings. Wrap up tightly in the foil, then turn the roll over so that the pancetta is on the top. Can be left in the fridge for up to 2 days.

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Sit the joint in a roasting tin and roast for 40 mins per kg or until a skewer inserted into the middle comes out very hot and the juices run clear. Unwrap for the last 10 mins of cooking.

Lift the joint onto a board and leave to rest, covered, for at least 10 mins. For the gravy, heat the tin on the hob, then splash in the wine and any juices. Reduce by half, then add the stock and repeat. Pour in the cream and bubble to a slightly reduced sauce. Season to taste, then stir in the parsley.
chief_review:
This festive turkey breast recipe is a showstopper with its aromatic herb stuffing and rich, creamy gravy. The combination of pancetta, sage, lemon zest, and pine nuts delivers layers of savory flavor, and the butterflied turkey keeps serving effortless and elegant. The double cream and chicken stock-based gravy ensures everyone will want seconds. 

Thanks to ingredients like turkey, bacon, egg, and cream, this dish is well-suited to traditional eaters and those looking for a hearty, protein-rich centerpiece. However, it is not suitable for guests with dairy or nut allergies, nor for vegetarians. The use of breadcrumbs means this recipe does contain gluten. Serve with simple greens and roast potatoes for a classic, comforting holiday meal.

name: Roast duck two ways with spiced clementine sauce
description: Christmas dinner for two? Forget having to carve a whole duck and enjoy this meltingly soft, crispy skinned leg and breast meat version instead
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 6 or so thyme sprigs, left whole
1 large duck breast with skin on
directions: Mix the spices, thyme and zest. Slash the skin of the breast, cutting through the fat but not into the meat, then rub the spice mix over the breast and legs. Leave for at least 2 hrs, or for up to 24 hrs in the fridge.

Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Put the legs into an ovenproof frying pan or smallish roasting tin, season well, then roast for 1½ hrs until deep golden and crisp. Sit the legs on a plate, then keep warm in a low oven or let cool. Spoon off excess fat from the pan juices and keep it for the next time you make roasties. Pull the meat and skin from the legs, shred using 2 forks, then mix together. Keep warm or, if making ahead, reheat in a hot oven for 10 mins before serving.

Put the pan back on the hob, add the sugar for the sauce and let it melt and turn dark golden. Add the vinegar (the sugar might turn hard at this point but don’t worry as it will dissolve again), then reduce by about half. Tip in the clementine juice and almost all the stock and bubble again until reduced and syrupy. Whisk in the butter, then season to taste.

Heat a frying pan, then cook the breast, skin-side down, for 10-12 mins until very crisp and the fat has run out. Turn over, fry for another 5 mins for just pink (or longer if you prefer), then lift onto a plate and rest, uncovered, for 10 mins. Spoon off remaining fat, add the leftover stock to the pan, then stir to dissolve any tasty, meaty bits. Add to the sauce.

Slice the breast on the diagonal, then divide half of the leg meat between 2 warm plates in small piles (you can use a cutter or ring if you like, to make it neater). Top with slices of breast. Spoon the sauce over the meat and serve with glazed veg and potatoes.
chief_review: This festive duck recipe impresses with its harmonious pairing of spices, citrus, and sherry vinegar, delivering both succulent meat and a beautifully crispy skin. The use of both breast and leg provides a pleasing textural contrast while the muscovado sugar balances the tangy clementine and vinegar reduction, resulting in a sauce that’s rich yet bright. Fresh thyme and warming spices evoke a seasonal aroma, elevating this dish for a special occasion like Christmas. As the recipe centers on poultry and includes both butter and chicken stock, it is well suited for omnivores. The ingredient list avoids common allergens such as gluten, nuts, or dairy (aside from a minimal amount of butter, which could be swapped for dairy-free margarine if needed), making it friendly for those with such sensitivities. Overall, it's an elegant, manageable alternative to whole roast duck, ideal for an intimate holiday meal.

name: Feta & cucumber bites
description: These decorative canapés look impressive when laid out - flavour your ricotta cheese filling with dill and garlic
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 tbsp chopped dill, plus extra fronds, to garnish
1 large cucumber, halved lengthways, seeds scooped out and discarded
directions: Add the garlic, feta, ricotta and dill to a food processor and whizz until smooth but thick.
Fill the middle of the cucumber with the cheese mix and smooth over. Cut into 3cm-thick slices. Sprinkle with cracked pepper and garnish with the dill fronds.
chief_review: This canapé recipe is a delightful showcase of fresh flavors and elegant presentation. The creamy blend of ricotta and feta, enhanced with aromatic dill and a hint of garlic, creates a rich, herbaceous filling that pairs beautifully with crisp cucumber. Using cucumber as a vessel not only adds freshness but also makes this dish suitable for gluten-free diets, as no bread or crackers are involved. The vegetarian ingredients appeal to a broad audience, making these canapés a great choice for meatless gatherings. Garnished with dill fronds and a sprinkle of cracked black pepper, they are visually appealing and deliver a bright, tangy bite, perfect for summer entertaining or as a refined starter.

name: Creamy potato gratin with caramelised onions
description: The sweetness of the caramelised onions cuts through the rich creaminess of this dauphinoise-style bake
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 thymesprigs, leaves picked, plus extra to serve
1¼kg/2lb 12oz large potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced
directions: Up to 2 days before serving, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Heat the oil in a large frying pan. Add the onions and thyme, cover, and cook over a gentle heat for 10-15 mins until softened and caramelised. Pour the cream and milk into a large bowl and season well. Add the potatoes and mix to combine.

Butter a 23 x 28cm ovenproof dish, then layer in half the potatoes. Spread the onion mixture on top, then layer on the remaining potatoes. Press down with your hands. Pour over the milk mixture, which should come just level with the potatoes. If not, add a little more milk until it does. Cover with foil, then bake for 11⁄2 hrs until tender. Remove from the oven and leave to cool. Cover and store in the fridge.

On the day, heat the oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Uncover the gratin, spread the crème fraîche on top, then sprinkle over the Parmesan. Put in the oven and cook for 30 mins until the cheese is melted, the top crisp and golden brown, and the gratin piping hot. Serve garnished with extra thyme.
chief_review: This dauphinoise-style bake is a beautifully rich and comforting dish, elevated by caramelised onions that impart a subtle sweetness, balancing the creamy layers of potato and dairy. Fresh thyme adds a welcome herbal note, enhancing both aroma and flavor complexity. The blend of double cream, milk, and crème fraîche yields a luscious texture, while the crust of grated parmesan creates a golden, savory finish. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet and can be a superb centerpiece or luxurious side for any gathering.
