Those looking for gluten-free options will also appreciate its lack of wheat-based ingredients. Overall, it’s an indulgent and thoughtfully constructed bake—perfect for elevating a cozy meal.

name: Yule chocolate log
description: Mary Cadogan’s festive chocolate log will go down a treat with everyone - it's a lighter recipe than most
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 25g good quality cocoa powder such as Green & Black's or Oxfam Fairtrade
450g fondant chocolate, such as Lindt Lindor
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Butter and line the base and sides of a 30 x 35cm Swiss roll tin with baking parchment.

Separate the eggs, putting them into two large mixing bowls. Add the sugar and 2 tbsp water to the egg yolks. Using an electric whisk or tabletop mixer, whisk the sugar and yolks for about 5 mins until the mixture is light in colour and thick enough to leave a trail when the whisk blades are lifted. Sift in the flour and cocoa, then fold in lightly, using the whisk blades or a large metal spoon.
Using a clean whisk, beat the egg whites until they are stiff, then fold into the cake mixture in three batches, again using the blades to preserve as much air as possible.

Pour the mixture evenly over the prepared tin, then carefully spread to the edges. Bake for 10-12 mins, or until the cake feels firm to the touch. Put a large sheet of baking parchment on the work surface and sprinkle lightly with caster sugar. Turn the cake out onto the parchment and peel off the lining paper. Cover with a clean tea towel, then leave to cool completely. Trim a little cake from all the edges, then score along the edge of one of the long sides of the cake and roll up from there, using the paper to help you, rolling the paper inside the cake.

To make the icing and filling, bring the cream to the boil in a small pan, remove from the heat, then break in 400g of the chocolate. Stir until it is melted and smooth. Leave to cool, then chill until it is spreadable, about 1 hr. Chop the remaining chocolate, spoon a third of the icing into a bowl, then stir them together to make the filling.
Carefully unroll the cake, then spread all the filling over to within 2cm of the edges. Roll up the cake again using the paper to help you, then set on a board.

Cut a thick diagonal slice off one end of the cake. Transfer the larger piece of cake to a board or flat serving plate. Spread a little icing over cut side of the small piece of cake and fix it to the large roll to make a stump (as photo). Spread remaining icing over the cake, then dust with icing sugar to serve.
chief_review: Mary Cadogan’s festive chocolate log is a delightful take on a holiday classic, crafted with a lighter touch thanks to the use of light muscovado sugar and careful balance of cream and chocolate. The airy sponge, enriched by quality cocoa powder and kept moist with a generous filling of whipped double cream, rolls perfectly under a decadent fondant chocolate topping. The dusting of caster and icing sugars adds a delicate finish. While the recipe is indulgent with eggs, cream, and fondant chocolate, it is naturally suited for vegetarians and makes an elegant centerpiece for festive gatherings. Attention to detail in the rolling and assembly is key for both appearance and texture, rewarding careful technique with a cake that’s as impressive visually as it is delicious on the palate.

name: Swede & parsnip bake
description: A mixed mash of favourite winter root veg with a crispy herb topping, which can be chilled or frozen ahead
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 medium swede(about 600g), peeled and cut into chunks
500g parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks
directions: Bring a large pan of water to the boil, and add the swede chunks. Boil for 3 mins, then add the parsnips and boil the lot for 12 mins more or until tender. Drain well, then tip both together into a pan or bowl and mash well with the butter. Stir in the golden syrup, three-quarters of the breadcrumbs and the eggs with plenty of seasoning. Transfer to a baking dish and smooth the surface. Toss the remaining breadcrumbs with the oil, seasoning and thyme leaves, then scatter over the mash. Dot with a few knobs of butter.
To serve, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6 and bake for 40 mins or until piping hot and the crumbs are crisp.
chief_review: This winter root vegetable mash is a comforting dish that showcases the natural sweetness of swede and parsnip, elevated by a golden, herby breadcrumb topping. The addition of golden syrup lends a subtle caramelized note, balancing the earthy roots beautifully. The fresh thyme brings a pleasant aromatic lift, while the crispy topping provides a satisfying contrast to the creamy mash. Prepared with olive oil and butter, the texture is rich without being heavy. This dish is vegetarian-friendly and a delightful accompaniment or a standalone centerpiece for any hearty cold-weather meal. The recipe’s make-ahead feature is especially convenient for busy schedules, allowing for chilling or freezing in advance. Ideal for gatherings or meal prep, it offers both comfort and versatility on the winter table.

name: Spinach with onions & pine nuts
description: Jazz up a bag of spinach with caramelised onions and the crunch of pine nuts
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat the oil in a large, deep pan. Add the onions, cover, then gently fry for 15 mins until soft and almost transparent. Add the butter and pine nuts, turn up the heat, then fry for 5 mins more or until the onions are dark golden. Stir in the garlic, grate in a little nutmeg, then fry for 1 min. Splash in vinegar.

Meanwhile, heat the largest pan you have until very hot. Throw in half the spinach, cover for 20 secs, then stir until just wilted. Tip into a colander set over a bowl, then repeat with the second bag of spinach.
To serve, toss the cooked spinach into onion mix and season generously.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful way to elevate spinach, delivering rich flavor with caramelised onions, fragrant garlic, and the nutty crunch of pine nuts. The addition of sherry vinegar brings just the right touch of acidity, while a grating of nutmeg adds depth and warmth to the greens. The use of olive oil and butter ensures a luxurious mouthfeel and an aromatic base. This dish is naturally vegetarian, making it an excellent side or main for meat-free tables. For those with gluten sensitivities, the recipe is entirely gluten-free as presented. Thanks to the plant-based ingredients (with the exception of butter), it's easy to adapt for vegan diets by simply swapping the butter for a vegan alternative. Overall, this is a flavourful, nutrient-dense option that turns simple spinach into a memorable dish.

name: Aubergine timbales with goat's cheese
description: These vegetarian dishes, from Gordon Ramsay, are great for a party as they can be made ahead, and look stunning
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 1 red pepper, deseeded and finely chopped
1 large courgette, yellow or green (or 1 small one of each colour), ends trimmed and finely chopped
80g vegetarian parmesan-style cheese, 25g grated, the rest in shavings
directions: Put oil in a large frying pan to cover the base, and heat. Fry the aubergine until softened, 2-3 mins . Season, then drain on paper towel. You may have to do this in batches.

For the filling, add 2-3 tbsp oil to the pan and fry the pepper, courgette, shallots and garlic over a high heat until they have a good colour, 3-5 mins. Stir in the balsamic vinegar and cook until evaporated. Add the tomatoes and season, then cook for 3 more mins stirring occasionally until the mixture is softened, but not too saucy. Remove from the heat, then mix in the olives, capers, half the shredded basil and the grated parmesan. Set aside to cool.

Grease the moulds and line the bases with aubergine slices to fit. Top with veg mixture, more aubergine slices (cut to fit if needed) and a slices of cheese. Repeat the layers, finishing with aubergine. Press lightly to firm. Can be covered with cling film and chilled for up to 1 day.

To cook and serve: heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Chilled cups will need to come to room temperature first. Place the cups on a tray, uncovered, and bake for 12-15 mins until bubbling. Allow to stand for 10 mins while you toss the spinach and remaining basil with vinaigrette and seasoning and divide between six dinner plates. Scatter over the nuts.
Loosen the tops of the timbales with a table knife and up-end into the centre of the salad on the plates, shaking the cups to help demould. Top with the parmesan shavings and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant vegetarian dish from Gordon Ramsay offers a delightful medley of Mediterranean flavors and textures—perfect for entertaining. The centerpiece is thinly sliced, sautéed aubergine layered with peppers, courgette, and shallots, all brightened by tomatoes, olives, capers, and fresh basil. The generous use of both vegetarian parmesan-style cheese and creamy chèvre ensures a satisfying umami depth, while toasted pine nuts and a vinaigrette-dressed spinach salad add crunch and freshness. Because it uses only vegetarian cheeses, this recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets. It’s also an excellent option for those seeking crowd-pleasing, make-ahead party fare that delivers both on presentation and taste.

name: Salmon, cranberry & couscous parcels
description: Whip up some fruity couscous then place with fish into parchment to be baked in a pouch
author: Good Food
ingredients: small handful mint leaves, roughly chopped
small handful basil leaves, roughly chopped
directions: Boil the kettle. Put the couscous, cranberries and spices in a large bowl. Dot with the butter and pour over 350ml boiling water. Cover immediately with cling film and leave for 5 mins to steam. Remove the film and fluff with a fork to loosen the couscous grains. Cool, stir in the pine nuts and herbs, then season to taste. Cut 6 squares of baking parchment about 30 x 30cm.

Season the salmon fillets, spoon the couscous in mounds in the centre of the parchment squares, then dot with a little butter. Top each with a piece of salmon, scatter with a little orange zest and drizzle with a little juice. Fold the sides of the paper over, then fold up the ends to make a parcel. Tie with string and secure with a bow. Stir together the cranberry sauce, orange zest and juice, then set aside in a serving bowl. The parcels can be chilled for up to 1 day. Be sure to remove them from the fridge 20 mins before cooking.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the parcels on a baking sheet in the middle of the oven and cook for 15 mins, or 20 mins if you prefer your salmon well done. Pop the parcels onto plates and let your guests unwrap their own supper. Serve with Garlic & feta broccoli and the cranberry & orange sauce.
chief_review:
This inventive recipe brings together the tender richness of baked salmon with a vibrant, fruity couscous. The use of dried cranberries, orange zest, and juice lends a fresh, sweet-tart accent, while the fragrant blend of cinnamon and allspice provides warmth and depth. Toasted pine nuts contribute a satisfying crunch, and the addition of fresh mint and basil elevates the dish with herbal brightness. Butter creates a silky texture, enriching both the couscous and the salmon. 

With its emphasis on wholesome grains, nuts, and fish, this recipe is well-suited for pescatarian diets. It is also a great fit for those seeking a dairy-containing, nut-inclusive, protein-rich meal that celebrates Mediterranean-inspired flavors. The parchment pouch technique ensures the salmon remains moist and aromatic, making this an attractive main course for both weeknight dinners and special gatherings.

name: Fruity turkey tagine
description: Freshen up Christmas leftovers of turkey, carrots and parsnips with ras el hanout in this sweet and spicy Moroccan stew
author: Emily Kydd
ingredients: 3 carrots, thickly sliced on the diagonal
3 parsnips, thickly sliced on the diagonal
140g mixture of dried apricots and prunes, roughly chopped
½ small bunch coriander, roughly chopped
directions: Heat the oil in a large saucepan, add the onion and cook gently for 8 mins or until softened. Add the carrots and parsnips, and cook for 8 mins until starting to soften and brown a little. Stir in the garlic and ras el hanout, and cook for a further 30 secs. Tip in the stock, tomatoes, chickpeas, dried fruit and 150ml water. Season, bring to a simmer and cook for 25-30 mins until the vegetables are tender.
Add the turkey and simmer for 5 mins to warm through. Stir in the honey, then scatter over the coriander and almonds just before serving with couscous and Greek yogurt.
chief_review:
This Moroccan-inspired stew offers a vibrant way to reinvent Christmas leftovers, infusing them with the warming complexity of ras el hanout. The medley of carrots, parsnips, and chickpeas adds hearty substance, while chopped apricots and prunes lend a beautifully sweet undertone that balances the mild heat of the spice blend. The addition of turkey gives the dish satisfying protein, and flaked almonds provide a pleasant crunch. Finished with fresh coriander, this stew is aromatic and inviting. 

It’s especially suitable for those following a dairy-free diet if served without Greek yogurt, and works well for those seeking high-protein, fiber-rich meals. The recipe can also be gluten-free when paired with rice or quinoa instead of couscous. Overall, this dish is a delicious, resourceful way to transform holiday leftovers with North African flair.

name: Sweet & spicy nuts
description: Roast almonds, Brazil nuts and cashews with spiced flavours then pack up into bags as a homemade gift
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g mixed nut, try almonds, Brazil nuts and cashews
directions: Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1. Mix the oil with the spices, then stir in the nuts and drizzle over half the honey. Spread over a baking sheet and cook for 10 mins.
Remove from the oven and drizzle over the remaining honey, then return to the oven and cook for a further 10 mins. Allow to cool completely.
chief_review: This Roast Spiced Nut mix offers wonderful depth—warm cinnamon and mixed spice elevate the natural richness of almonds, Brazil nuts, and cashews. The roasting process highlights a satisfying crunch, while a light glaze of honey provides subtle sweetness, well balanced by the hint of earthy spice. Sunflower oil ensures the nuts toast evenly, achieving a perfect golden finish without overpowering the spices. This recipe is a superb choice for those seeking a homemade, protein-rich snack, and it’s naturally gluten-free. However, be mindful that the honey makes it unsuitable for a strict vegan diet. Perfectly packaged, these spiced nuts are ideal as a thoughtful homemade food gift, or as an elegant nibble with drinks.

name: Chocolate & apricot pud with glossy chocolate sauce
description: Traditional Christmas pud is not universally popular, especially with children - this wonderfully moist chocolate version could be the answer
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Butter a 1.2 litre/2 pint pudding basin and put a circle of greaseproof paper in the base. Put the apricots in a small pan and add the brandy. Bring slowly to the boil, then simmer, turning the apricots occasionally until all the brandy has soaked in. Leave until cool enough to handle.
Tip the ground almonds into a bowl, then sift over the cocoa, flour and baking powder and mix everything together.
In another bowl, beat the butter and sugar together for 2-3 minutes until light and fluffy.Gradually beat in the eggs and milk.
Chop half the apricots into small pieces. Chop the chocolate into large chunks. Lightly stir the flour mixture into the cake mix, followed by the apricots and chocolate.

Put the remaining whole apricots into the bowl and spoon over the honey. Add the pudding mixture and smooth the top. Cover with double thickness buttered greaseproof paper and tie down. Trim off the excess paper, then overwrap in foil, tucking the ends under the edges of the paper.

Put the basin into a large pan and pour boiling water into the pan, to come halfway up the sides of the basin. Cover and steam for 21⁄2 hours, until it feels firm. (The pudding can be made to this stage up to 2 days ahead. Reheat by steaming for 1 hour, or microwave on medium for 6-8 minutes.)
Towards the end of the cooking time, make the sauce. Break up the chocolate and put in a small pan with the cream and brandy if using. Warm gently, stirring lightly until smooth and glossy.
Cool the pudding in the bowl for 10 minutes, then turn out and serve with the chocolate sauce and cream or good vanilla ice cream.
chief_review:
This chocolate twist on traditional Christmas pudding offers a rich, moist texture and an indulgent balance of flavors. The use of dried apricots and brandy adds a festive note, while ground almonds contribute to a pleasant density that pairs beautifully with cocoa and dark chocolate. Topped with a luscious double cream and honey-laced chocolate sauce, this dessert is sure to win over those who typically pass on classic pud—especially children.

Suitable for vegetarians, thanks to the absence of gelatine or animal fats, and it meets a gluten-free diet if swapped with a gluten-free self-raising flour blend. However, those with nut or dairy allergies should take care due to the inclusion of ground almonds, butter, and cream.

The decadent combination of chocolate and fruit makes this an impressive and crowd-pleasing finale to a holiday meal.

name: Four & twenty chicken & ham pie
description: There aren't any blackbirds baked into it, but this stunning centrepiece will impress with its layers of nuts, fruit, chicken and gammon
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp butter, plus extra for greasing
1kg cooked ham, trimmed of fat and thickly sliced
700g skinless chicken breast, halved to thin
directions: Soften the onion in the butter with the sage and mace. Cool for a few mins while you whizz the chicken thighs and 300g of the ham in a food processor until minced. Scrape into a large bowl and stir in the softened onion, pistachios, cranberries, apricots and parsley. Season with nutmeg, lots of black pepper and some salt.

Grease a deep, 20cm round springform or loose-bottomed tin, then line with baking parchment. To make the pastry, mix together the flours and 2 tsp salt in a large bowl, then make a well in the centre. Put the butter and lard into a small pan with 200ml water and very gently melt. Once melted, turn up the heat and when just bubbling, pour into the well and stir with a wooden spoon to a dough – don’t worry if some powdery bits remain.

Once cool enough to handle, knead in the bowl until the dough comes together, then tip onto your work surface. Set aside a third, wrapped in a clean tea towel to keep it as warm and pliable as possible, while you quickly roll the remaining dough into a large circle – big enough to line the tin with a little overhanging.

Ease the circle into the tin, pressing evenly into the corners and side – you can be rough with it. Evenly cover the base with half the remaining sliced ham, followed by half the chicken breasts and half the mince mixture, pressing firmly to pack. Repeat with the remaining ham and chicken, then a rounded dome of mince. Put a pie funnel, if you have one, on the top.

Roll the reserved dough to a circle large enough to easily cover the pie, cutting out a hole (if using a pie funnel). Brush the edge of the pie with some beaten egg and top with the pastry lid. Press to seal the edges before trimming the excess. Crimp the edges between your thumb and forefinger to seal thoroughly, then make a small hole in the middle to let steam escape (if not using a pie funnel). Brush the top of the pie with more beaten egg.

Heat oven to 200C/180 fan/gas 6. Bake the pie for 1 hr. Very, very carefully remove the pie from its tin, brush the top and side with more egg and bake for another 30 mins until browned and crisp. Leave to cool completely before chilling.

To make the jelly, soak the gelatine in cold water for 5-10 mins until soft. Squeeze out any excess water from the gelatine, then dissolve in the hot stock. Once cooled, carefully pour into your chilled pie through the small hole, using a funnel, until full – you may not need all the stock. Chill the pie for a few hrs. Serve with chutney and salad, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe is a true showstopper, perfect for a festive occasion or special family gathering. The combination of succulent chicken, richly flavored ham, toasted pistachios, tangy cranberries, and sweet apricots layered within a delicately spiced hot water crust is both traditional and inventive. Sage, parsley, and mace add aromatic depth, while the gelatine and chicken stock ensure a beautifully set filling reminiscent of a classic English raised pie. This recipe is a delight for fans of traditional British charcuterie, and suits those following a nut-inclusive or high-protein diet. However, allergens such as nuts (pistachio), eggs, and gluten (from the flour) are present, so mindful adaptation is necessary if serving to guests with specific dietary requirements. Serve with a tangy chutney and fresh salad for a balanced, memorable meal.

name: Polar bear peppermint creams
description: Needed a fair bit more icing sugar but in the end were lovely.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 15 chocolate sweets(we used Waitrose blue and green chocolate beans)
directions: Sieve the icing sugar into a large bowl. Mix in the egg white, a little at a time – stop adding it when you have a soft dough that feels like plasticine.
Add 3 drops of the peppermint essence, mix well and taste. Add another drop if it isn’t minty enough.
Roll half the mixture into 15 balls, about the size of cherry tomatoes, then flatten them with your hand to make the bear heads.

Place on sheets of baking parchment on a large board or tray. Using half the remaining mixture, make blueberry-sized balls and flatten them out onto the heads to make snouts. Add chocolate sweets for the noses.
Use the rest of the mixture to make the ears. Shape them into tiny balls and press them gently into the top of the heads with your fingertips. Use a cocktail stick to shape the eyes.
Leave the polar bears to dry for 3-4 hrs, or overnight. Eat within 1 month.
chief_review: This recipe creates delightful peppermint treats, perfect for indulging your sweet tooth. The combination of icing sugar, egg white, and peppermint essence forms a classic, melt-in-the-mouth peppermint paste, while the chocolate sweets add a playful and colourful touch. The result is reminiscent of after-dinner mints, both refreshing and satisfyingly sweet. With no gluten-containing ingredients, these are suitable for those following a gluten-free diet (provided the chocolate sweets themselves are gluten-free—always double-check packaging). They are also suitable for vegetarians, as the recipe contains no meat, fish, or animal rennet. The straightforward preparation makes these an ideal choice for festive occasions or as a charming homemade gift. For best results, ensure you beat the egg white until frothy and add sufficient icing sugar to achieve a pliable, non-sticky dough. A cool set in the fridge will help the mints keep their shape and flavour.

name: Sticky pork & pineapple hotpot
description: Give a warming winter stew an Asian-inspired twist with coriander, chilli and star anise, sweetened with chunks of juicy, fresh pineapple
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1½ kg (about 8) pork shouldersteaks, each cut into 4 thick strips
small bunch coriander, stalks finely chopped, leaves reserved
3 Thai red chillies, 2 sliced, 1 left whole and pricked
directions: Heat the oil in a large, flameproof casserole dish. Season the pork, and brown it in 2 or 3 batches until golden, about 5 mins per batch. Set aside in a bowl. Stir the onions into the remaining fat, cover and soften for 5 mins – they will take on the browned colour of the meat. Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3.

Add the garlic, coriander stalks, chillies and anise to the dish, sizzle for 1 min, stirring often, then mix in the sugar and tomato purée. When these have melted and it looks a bit like barbecue sauce, return the pork and its resting juices to the dish, along with the fish sauce and stock. Tuck in the pineapple chunks here and there.

Once simmering, cover the hotpot, leaving a small gap for steam to escape, and transfer to the oven for 2 hrs. With 30 mins to go, skim some of the fat from the top (this tends to seal the liquid in, making it more difficult for the sauce to reduce), then return to the oven. The pork will be meltingly soft when ready. If the sauce is thin, lift the pork into a warmed serving dish, put the casserole dish on the hob and simmer until the sauce has slightly thickened. Leave to cool for 5 mins, taste for seasoning, pour over the pork and sprinkle over the coriander leaves.
chief_review: This vibrant, Asian-inspired pork stew showcases a masterful balance of sweet, spicy, and aromatic flavors. The interplay of juicy pineapple, earthy coriander, and warming star anise brings a refreshing twist to the traditional winter comfort dish. Pork shoulder stews to melt-in-the-mouth tenderness, while fish sauce and tomato purée provide a deep, umami-rich base. Thai red chillies add controlled heat that lifts the palate, while brown sugar harmonizes the flavors with a delicate sweetness. Finished with fresh coriander leaves, this recipe is ideal for those following a dairy-free diet. However, those with soy or fish allergies should note the inclusion of fish sauce, and the dish is naturally unsuitable for vegetarians and vegans due to its pork content. Overall, an impressive stew that will warm you up and transport you with its bold, Southeast Asian notes.

name: Spinach, cheese & onion rice torte
description: Risotto rice cooks in the filling to give it a creamy texture, which binds the vegetarian ingredients together beautifully
author: Angela Nilsen
directions: Wash the spinach and put it in a large saucepan with just the water that clings to its leaves. Heat for 1-2 mins until gently wilted, then tip into a colander and allow to cool. Once cool, squeeze out the excess water and chop finely.

Heat the oil in a frying pan and gently cook the onion for about 5 mins until softened. Stir in the garlic and chilli flakes, and cook for 1 min more. Tip into a bowl, add the spinach, courgettes, rice and cheese, and toss together.

Beat the 2 large eggs with the mustard, a pinch of salt and a good grinding of black pepper. Add to the spinach mixture and mix well. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put a baking sheet in the oven to preheat. Cut the pastry in half and roll 1 piece out on a lightly floured work surface until you have a sheet that measures 32 x 17cm. Place in a 30 x 15cm tin and prick it well all over the base. Roll out the remaining piece of pastry to the same size.

Spoon the spinach mixture into the pastry base. Beat together the milk and remaining medium egg, then brush the edges of the pastry with it. Lay the other sheet of pastry over the top and press down gently to seal. Brush the top with a little more beaten egg and sprinkle with the sesame seeds.

Place the tin on the preheated baking tray and bake for 10 mins, then reduce the temperature to 160C/140C fan/gas 4 and bake for a further 30 mins until the pastry is golden. Leave to cool for 10 mins before cutting into squares.
chief_review: This savory risotto and vegetable tart is a delightful centerpiece bursting with layers of flavor and texture. The use of risotto rice creates a creamy, unified filling that complements the fresh spinach and tender courgette perfectly. The mature cheddar brings a robust, nutty sharpness, while a hint of mustard and a pinch of chilli flakes add subtle warmth and complexity. The sesame-studded, golden shortcrust pastry delivers an appealing crunch. This recipe is a fantastic choice for vegetarians and easily stands out on a buffet table or as a satisfying main course. Just note: with eggs, dairy, and wheat, it’s not suited for those avoiding these ingredients. Serve warm or at room temperature for best results.

name: Cranberry & red wine sauce
description: Keep this Christmas-spiced cranberry sauce in the fridge for up to a week before the big day
author: Good Food
directions: Put the wine, sugar, cloves, star anise and cinnamon stick into a large, shallow pan. Bring to a simmer and cook until the liquid has reduced by half. Add the cranberries and cook for 5 mins or until the cranberries burst and start to look jammy. Set aside to cool.
chief_review:
This Christmas-spiced cranberry sauce is a festive standout, elevated by the warmth of red wine and whole spices. The combination of cloves, star anise, and cinnamon stick infuses the cranberries with aromatic complexity, balancing the tartness with a refined sweetness from caster sugar. The sauce simmers to a glossy, jewel-toned finish—perfect for accompanying roast dishes or cheese boards. 

With no dairy, eggs, gluten, or animal-derived products in the ingredient list, this recipe is ideally suited for vegan and vegetarian diets, as well as those needing a dairy-free or egg-free option. It’s naturally gluten-free, making it broadly versatile for holiday gatherings where guests may have varied dietary needs. The make-ahead aspect is an added chef’s bonus, allowing flavors to deepen and simplifying your holiday preparations.

name: Peppermint hot chocolate
description: Delicious! I did this with 100g plain and 100g milk chocolate (and no sugar) and everyone loved it. Was worried it wouldn't serve 6, but you only need a small cup each! Looked great in simple white tea cups with saucers. I managed to get mini candy canes from a sweet shop, which were perfect.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g bar plain chocolate, broken into chunks
directions: Put the chocolate in a pan with the milk. Gently heat, stirring until all the chocolate has melted. Continue heating until the milk is steaming, then remove from the heat and stir in the cream.

Divide the hot chocolate between 6 mugs, add sugar to taste and hang a candy cane on the edge of each. Pass the mugs round and let everyone stir their hot chocolate with their candy cane – letting as much of the sweet peppermint dissolve as they fancy.
chief_review: This indulgent chocolate drink recipe marries the richness of plain and milk chocolate with the creaminess of milk and cream, delivering a decadent dessert perfect for festive gatherings. The use of mini peppermint candy canes as a garnish adds a charming seasonal flair and a fresh contrast to the deep chocolate notes. Presented in white tea cups, it achieves an elegant yet cozy appearance. With easily adjustable sweetness and portion size, it’s a crowd-pleaser suitable for vegetarians—there are no animal-derived gelatins or rennets present; just ensure the chocolates selected use vegetarian-friendly emulsifiers. The richness means a little goes a long way, making each serving satisfyingly luxurious.

name: Ham hock & mustard terrine
description: Cured slow-cooked pork is a great foundation for a coarse pâté style starter and can be made in advance
author: Good Food
ingredients: caper berries and toasted bread, to serve
directions: Put the ham hocks in a large pan with the stock ingredients. Cover with cold water. Set pan over a high heat and bring to the boil. Reduce heat to a simmer, cook for 2 and a half to 3 hrs or until the meat falls from the bone. Leave to cool in the pan.
Grease a 1-litre terrine mould or loaf tin with the oil, then line with cling film. Remove the hocks, then strain the stock through a fine sieve into a pan. Set aside.
Shred the ham, leaving some large chunks, removing as much fat and sinew as possible. In a large bowl, mix the ham with the mustard and parsley. Press the mixture into the prepared terrine.

Bring the reserved stock back to a rapid boil and reduce by half. You should have about 600ml/1pt liquid remaining. Remove from the heat. Meanwhile, soak the gelatine in cold water for 5 mins to soften. Remove from the water, then squeeze out any excess liquid. Add the gelatine to the hot stock and stir well.

Pour enough of the stock over the ham to just cover. Tap terrine firmly on a hard surface to knock out air pockets, then cover with cling film. Chill for 3-4 hrs or overnight. To serve, remove from the mould and carve into chunky slices. Serve with caper berries and toast.
chief_review: This rustic cured slow-cooked pork pâté offers deeply savory flavors, skillfully balanced by the aromatic undertones of star anise, thyme, and cider. The addition of wholegrain mustard and chopped parsley lifts the richness, while caperberries provide an appealing briny contrast. With the inclusion of gelatine, this recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, but will delight those seeking a robust, make-ahead starter centered on pork. Serve with toasted bread to enjoy textural contrast and to soak up the fragrant aspic. The thoughtful seasoning and careful cooking of ham hocks ensure a moist, toothsome pâté—a classic charcuterie item fit for festive gatherings or elegant dinners.

name: Iced berry pud
description: This pudding is so simple, you almost feel you've cheated - it looks like a Christmas pud but is altogether different
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 100ml/3½ fl oz dark rum, plus 1 tbsp extra
170g packet dried berries and cherries (or same weight mix of dried cranberries, cherries, blueberries and raisins)
sprigs of sugar-frosted bay leaves and little bunches of sugar-frosted red and green grapes, to decorate
directions: Whip the cream in a big bowl so it is softly whipped, then stir in the custard. Put this in the freezer for about an hour and a half, until it is starting to freeze around the edges.

Meanwhile, put the sugar in a pan with 100ml/31⁄2fl oz rum. Heat slowly until the sugar has dissolved, tip in the fruits, and simmer gently for one minute to plump up the fruit. Pour everything into a wide bowl (so it cools as quickly as possible), and leave until cold (about an hour). Add the extra tablespoon of rum for a bit more kick.

Stir the cream and custard with a balloon whisk to break it all up, then stir in the cooled fruit. Pour the mixture into a 1.2 litre/ 2 pint pudding basin, cover and freeze overnight until firm (or for up to 1 month).

To serve, dip the basin quickly into boiling water to loosen the pudding, go round the sides with a round-bladed knife, then turn the pudding out onto a serving plate. Decorate with clusters of frosted bay leaves and grapes (see 'how to make the decorations') around the base.
chief_review: This festive pudding offers indulgence with minimal effort, relying on creamy double cream and ready-made custard for a rich, velvety base. Steeped in dark rum and studded with jewel-like dried berries and cherries, each spoonful is deeply aromatic and evocative of the holiday season. The addition of golden caster sugar ensures a smooth sweetness that complements the tartness from the fruit. Sugar-frosted bay leaves and clusters of grapes lend an elegant, wintry finish that's visually striking. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no gelatine or animal rennet. However, it is not suitable for vegans or those with dairy allergies, due to the cream and custard. This dessert will shine as a show-stopping finale to any festive meal – impressively simple yet sumptuously satisfying.

name: Guinness, treacle & ginger pudding
description: Rich, dark and spicy - prepare enough mixture for two basins, one for Christmas day and the other to give as a gift
author: James Martin
ingredients: 100g stem ginger, drained and chopped, plus 2 tbsp syrup
directions: Mix together the dried fruit, ginger, orange zest and juice, and Guinness in a bowl. Cover and leave to soak overnight.

Grease 2 x 1.2-litre pudding basins. Boil a kettle of water. To prepare your steamers, put a snug-fitting upturned bowl or plate in the base of 2 large, deep saucepans, big enough to hold your pudding basins. Add the remaining ingredients (except brandy) to the fruit mixture and stir well, making sure there are no pockets of flour. Divide between your prepared basins and cover with buttered baking parchment and a foil lid. Tie with string to secure and make a handle for easy lifting.

Stand the puddings on the upturned bowls or plates in your saucepans. Pour in enough boiling water to come halfway up the sides of the basins, cover with a tight-fitting lid and steam for 6 hrs, topping up with water if necessary. If your lids start to rattle as the puddings cook, place a couple of heavy cans on top to hold them down. Once cooked, the puddings can mature for up to 1 year in a cool dark place, so if you only eat one this year, that’s fine.
To serve, reheat in a steamer for 1 hr until piping hot all the way through. Flame with brandy, if you like, as you bring it to the table.
chief_review: This decadent Christmas pudding boasts deep, complex flavors with the richness of Guinness, a generous blend of dried fruits, and the spicy kick of stem ginger. The inclusion of both whole and ground almonds adds a pleasant nutty texture, while grated apple and date or prunes lend natural sweetness and moisture. The suet imparts a traditional richness prized in classic puddings, and the warm spices harmonize beautifully with the dark muscovado sugar and treacle. This recipe is particularly suitable for those following a vegetarian diet, as it utilizes vegetarian suet, and it also appears nut-friendly for those who enjoy almond-based bakes. Serve with a splash of brandy for a festive flourish. A true showstopper for the holiday table and a thoughtful edible gift.

name: Gingered rich fruit cake
description: This traditional cake has been jazzed up with lots of ginger - you'd never know it's gluten-free and dairy-free. Perfect for weddings and Christmas
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g each dried currant, sultanas and raisins
225g each semi-dried fig and prunes, roughly chopped
100g stem ginger, from a jar, chopped
1 tsp each ground ginger and mixed spice
450g mixed fruit, including figs, prunes, date and apricots
directions: Heat oven to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1. Lightly oil a 71⁄2cm deep, 25cm round cake tin, and line it with a double layer of baking parchment.

Mix the dried fruits, ginger and syrup, Cointreau, spices and lemon zest. Put the olive oil, sugar and eggs in a bowl, whisk together until light and fluffy. Sift the flour and baking powder into the mixture and tip in the fruit. Fold and stir together well.

Spoon the mixture into the cake tin. Bake in the centre of the oven for 2-21⁄2 hrs, or until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean. Cover with foil if the cake begins to over-brown. Take from the oven and leave to cool in the tin. Remove, leaving the baking parchment in place until you decorate.
For the topping: warm the jam and Cointreau together until the jam is liquid, allow to cool. Arrange the fruit on the cake and brush with the jam.
chief_review: This vibrant twist on a classic fruit cake is a celebration of ginger, both crystallised and stem, delivering pronounced warmth and a lively aroma throughout each bite. Generously studded with a medley of dried fruits, the texture is rich and satisfying without feeling heavy. Using olive oil in place of butter ensures a moist crumb and keeps the recipe dairy-free, while gluten-free flour and baking powder make it accessible to those with gluten intolerance or celiac disease. Each component is carefully balanced, from the zesty infusion of lemon to the subtle boozy lift from Cointreau. Perfect for wedding celebrations and Christmas tables alike, this cake is a thoughtful choice for guests with dietary needs—without ever compromising on taste, texture, or festive flair.

name: Sausage & cranberry stuffing
description: Make stuffing balls to serve alongside your Christmas turkey, or cook the mix in a baking dish if you prefer
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 slices white bread, whizzed to chunky breadcrumbs
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cook the onion in the butter until soft but not browned. Add the breadcrumbs and stir so they soak up all the excess butter and fat. Let the mixture cool. Tip into a bowl with the sausagemeat, apple, cranberries, pistachios, sage and mixed spice. Mix well, then roll into balls.
To cook, place in a roasting tin and bake for 40 mins, turning a few times, or until browned all over. Add the bay leaves, if using, for the final ten minutes of cooking.
chief_review: This festive stuffing ball recipe offers a delightful mix of textures and flavors, with sweet cranberries and apple balanced by savory sausagemeat and aromatic sage. The addition of pistachios introduces a pleasant crunch, elevating this classic Christmas side dish. Butter and white bread lend moisture and richness, ensuring the stuffing remains tender inside while crisping up on the outside. This recipe contains both gluten (white bread) and nuts (pistachios), making it unsuitable for gluten-free and nut-free diets. It's also not vegetarian, due to the use of sausagemeat. Serve as individual stuffing balls or bake the mix in a dish for a more traditional presentation. This stuffing promises to complement roast turkey beautifully, adding both color and festive flair to your holiday table.

name: Chilli vodka
description: I prefer to add some other hottest pepper from this list. Can I ask why my comment isn't visible?
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 fat red chillies, plus extra for bottling
directions: Slice the chillies and mix with the vodka in a large bottle or jug. Leave for 4-5 hrs. Strain out the chillies and pour back into a bottle to store until needed. Just before giving away, decant into smaller glass bottles, pop a whole chilli in each and label.
chief_review: A bold and simple infusion, this recipe spotlights the fiery heat of fresh red chillies blended seamlessly into smooth vodka. It’s a versatile concoction, perfect for elevating cocktails with a punch of spice or creating a unique sipping experience for the adventurous palate. As the preparation is purely based on chillies and vodka, it aligns well with vegan and gluten-free dietary preferences, provided you choose a certified gluten-free vodka. This infusion would also be free from common allergens, making it broadly accessible. Just ensure the chillies are thoroughly cleaned, and consider straining the vodka according to personal preference for heat and clarity. The minimal ingredients allow the heat and flavor to shine, making it a favorite for lovers of spice and innovative spirits alike.

name: Honey-roasted parsnips
description: These are lovely, tried today for Sunday roast, will definitely make again.
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Top and tail 500g parsnips, cutting any larger ones in half lengthways, then put in a large saucepan, cover with salted water, bring to the boil and cook for 5 mins.
Drain in a colander and let them steam-dry for a few mins.
Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/ gas 5.
Sprinkle 1 tbsp flour and 1 tbsp honey over the parsnips and toss to coat.
Put the parsnips in a
with 2 tbsp sunflower oil, 2 tbsp butter and seasoning.
Roast for 40 mins, turning halfway, until golden.
chief_review: A delightful addition to any Sunday roast, these honey-roasted parsnips strike a perfect balance between sweet and savory with a golden, caramelized finish. The combination of sunflower oil and butter enriches the earthiness of the parsnips, while the subtle sweetness from honey complements their natural flavor. The light dusting of flour ensures a crisp texture. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet; however, it is not suitable for vegans due to the inclusion of butter and honey, and it is not gluten-free because of the flour. Overall, a simple yet elegant dish that elevates classic roast vegetables with minimal effort and maximum flavor.

name: The ultimate makeover: Chocolate log
description: The lighter version of this much-loved festive treat keeps all of the chocolatey richness
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 85g golden caster sugar, plus extra for rolling
50g plain chocolate, 70% cocoa solids or more, very finely chopped
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Lightly oil and line a 23 x 32cm Swiss roll tin with baking paper. Mix the coffee with 1 tbsp warm water. Beat the eggs, both sugars and the coffee mix together in a large mixing bowl with an electric whisk for about 8 mins or until the mixture is thick and airy like meringue and holds a trail when you lift up the beaters.

Sift the flour and cocoa powder over the fluffy egg mix, then fold in very gently using a large metal spoon. Pour the mixture evenly into the lined tin and carefully tip it so it spreads evenly without being deflated. Use a knife if necessary to very gently tease it into the corners. Bake for 12-15 mins or until the cake feels spongy but firm when touched.

Lay a sheet of baking paper on the work surface and sprinkle with a little caster sugar. Tip the tin upside-down onto the paper and let the cake fall out. Carefully peel off the paper. Roll up the cake lengthways from one of the short ends with the help of the paper, rolling it inside so the cake doesn’t stick. Cool. The cake becomes even more moist if left overnight wrapped up, then iced the next day.

For the chocolate icing, put the chopped chocolate in a medium bowl. Heat a small pan of water (one-third full) until boiling, remove it from the heat, then sit the bowl of chocolate over the top. Leave for a few mins off the heat until melted. Remove the bowl from the pan, then leave the chocolate until it is cool to the touch. Beat the mascarpone and quark together, then sift and stir in the icing sugar and cocoa powder. Stir in the cooled melted chocolate (keeping a couple of tsp back for drizzling), then the coffee mixed with the vanilla extract.

Carefully unroll the cake, don’t worry if it cracks a bit, and discard the paper. Spread half the icing over the unrolled cake, then re-roll it, finishing with the join underneath. Place the cake on a serving plate. Swirl the rest of the icing all over the cake to cover it, then drizzle over the reserved melted chocolate. Decorate with a sprig of holly.
chief_review: This lighter festive chocolate roulade impresses with its intense cocoa flavor while offering a tender crumb and rich, creamy filling. The blend of mascarpone and quark gives the dessert a delectable lightness, balancing the chocolate's depth without feeling overly heavy—a thoughtful touch for those seeking a less-indulgent treat. The inclusion of self-raising flour and eggs means it isn’t gluten-free or vegan, but it fits well for a vegetarian diet. Coffee granules and finely chopped plain chocolate enhance the sophistication, making this roulade ideal for special occasions. The recipe's simplicity respects the original's spirit while modernizing it with lighter, fresher elements.

name: Vegan pie
description:
I made this for my "pie club" so they wouldn't disown me for becoming vegan, and a room full of meat-lovers were totally won over by it. We ate it cold as part of a picnic. Defnitely going to make it again and try it hot.
The recipe has a lot of steps but I didn't find any of it challenging (it just takes time and lots of washing up!) and I'd call myself a mediocre cook. The pastry was really slimy and strange to work with and I was very pleasantly surprised when it came out crisp and quite tasty. And the filling held its shape perfectly when cut, making it a great centrepiece!
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 80ml olive oil, plus extra for brushing
1 tbsp vegan red wine vinegar(we used Aspall)
3 beetroots(about 400g), peeled and sliced into rounds about ½ cm thick
1 small celeriac(about 750g), peeled, cut into quarters and then sliced into triangles about 1 cm thick
3 large sweet potatoes(about 600g), peeled and sliced into rounds about ½ cm thick
250g Swiss chard, leaves only (save the stalks to add to soups, stews and risottos)
150g coconut oil, plus extra for the tin
directions: First, make the filling. Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Mix together 1½ tbsp oil with the cumin, cinnamon and vinegar, and rub the mixture all over the beetroot. Put the beetroot into a small roasting tin, season well, then cover with foil and roast for 20 mins.

Meanwhile, toss the celeriac with 2½ tbsp oil, the thyme, garlic and some seasoning in a second roasting tin. Separate out the slices so they cook evenly, then cover the tin in foil. In a third roasting tin, mix the sweet potato with the remaining oil, the smoked paprika and some seasoning, and cover with foil. Once the beets have cooked for 20 mins, add the celeriac and sweet potato to the oven alongside them, and roast all the veg for 40 mins further or until tender. Remove the thyme sprigs, squeeze the garlic cloves out of their skins and mash them in with the celeriac, then leave all the veg to cool. All the veg can be cooked the day before and kept in the fridge.

For the pastry, boil the kettle and use some coconut oil to grease a deep 20cm springform cake tin. Pour the flour into a bowl and add 1 tsp salt. Mix the coconut oil with 200ml boiling water, stir until melted (put it in the microwave if need be), then pour into the flour and mix with a wooden spoon to form a dough. Working as quickly as you can (it’s best to roll the pastry when it’s warm), cut off a ¼ of the dough and set aside under a tea towel. Roll out the rest to 0.5cm thick, then use it to line the cake tin, pressing the dough into the corners and leaving any excess pastry overhanging the sides. Don’t worry if the pastry breaks – it’s very forgiving, so you can patch it up as you go. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

Now build the pie. Cover the base with chard leaves, then scatter over the semolina (which will absorb the beet juices), press in the beetroot, and season. Add another layer of chard, followed by the sweet potato, and season. Add a final layer of chard leaves, then top with the celeriac and season again.

Roll out the pastry you set aside to a thickness of 0.5cm to use as the lid. Put the lid on top of the pie and, using a fork, press together the overhanging pastry to create a crimped edge. Make a steam hole, then brush the top with a little almond milk mixed with a spoonful of oil (this will help to colour the pastry). Bake in the centre of the oven for 45 mins until the pastry is a deep golden brown. Leave to cool for 15 mins, then remove from the tin and serve in the middle of the table. Will keep for up to three days in the fridge (the pie is also delicious cold).
chief_review: This vibrant pie is an impressive vegan creation that showcases seasonal root vegetables with aromatic spices and herbs. The use of coconut oil and spelt flour results in a surprisingly crisp, flavorful pastry—no butter or eggs in sight—making it an excellent choice for those following a vegan diet. Almond milk replaces dairy for brushing, and the filling of beetroot, celeriac, sweet potato, and Swiss chard delivers both stunning color and satisfying texture. The careful layering and seasoning elevate every bite, and the pie holds its shape beautifully, making it an ideal centerpiece for gatherings. Though the recipe requires multiple steps and liberal use of bowls and trays, none are technically difficult, suiting even less experienced cooks. Served hot or cold, this pie is a testament to how creative, hearty, and delicious plant-based baking can be.

name: Chicken liver parfait with sultanas & raisins
description: Making your own paté is an extra-special touch- this version is flavoured with wine, cream, garlic and sage
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Put the dried fruit and dessert wine in a bowl. Cover and microwave on High for 3 mins. Meanwhile, gently melt the butter in a large pan and fry the livers with the garlic, sage and plenty of black pepper for about 5 mins until browned.
Tip the mixture into a food processor, scraping in all of the buttery juices and blend until smooth. Pour in the cream and 2 tbsp of the wine from the dried fruit, season with salt, then blend again.

Generously oil the insides of 8 x 100ml ramekins. Spoon some wine-soaked raisins into the base of each ramekin, then top with the parfait. Cover and chill. They will keep for 2 days in the fridge or 1 month in the freezer. Thaw overnight in the fridge.
To serve, run a knife round the inside of the ramekins and turn the parfait out onto plates. Accompany with toasted brioche and a few salad leaves.
chief_review: This homemade chicken liver paté recipe delivers a rich and indulgent spread, perfect for an elegant starter or special occasion. The use of sweet dessert wine and plump sultanas and raisins adds a delightful burst of sweetness that balances the savory depth of the livers. Double cream and butter provide a luscious, silky texture, while garlic and fresh sage lend aromatic complexity. Served on tender slices of brioche with a side of crisp salad leaves, this paté shines as both a rustic and refined dish. Suitable for a gluten-free diet if served with gluten-free bread, and an option for those who eat poultry but avoid red meat. This recipe is not suitable for dairy-free diets or vegetarians, but will please lovers of rich, traditional charcuterie flavors.

name: Apricot & marzipan twist
description: Paul Hollywood's almond and apricot 'couronne' is crammed with fruit and nuts and is a great alternative to stollen
author: Paul Hollywood
ingredients: 200g icing sugar, mixed with enough water to make a runny icing
directions: The night before, put apricots and orange juice in a bowl and set aside.
To make the dough, put flour, 1 tsp salt, butter, milk, yeast and egg in a bowl, and mix together to form a dough. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 6 mins.
Transfer dough to a mixing bowl. Cover, then set aside to rise in a warm place for 1 hr.
Meanwhile, drain the apricots. In a mixing bowl, cream the butter and muscovado sugar until fluffy. Mix in the apricots, flour, raisins, walnuts and orange zest.

Turn the risen dough out onto a lightly floured surface. Roll it out to a rectangle, about 25 x 33cm. Evenly spread over the apricot mix, then roll out the marzipan and lay it on top. Roll up the rectangle tightly so it looks like a Swiss roll. Roll slightly, then cut lengthways along the roll, leaving 1 end joined. Twist 2 lengths together, then shape into a ring on a baking sheet lined with baking parchment. Set aside to rise for 1 hr.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bake the twist for 30 mins until risen and dark golden. Towards the end of the baking time, gently warm the apricot jam in a small pan. Brush the freshly baked loaf with the warm jam to glaze it, then set it aside to cool. Once cooled, drizzle the twist heavily with the runny icing.
chief_review: Paul Hollywood’s almond and apricot couronne is a delightful, festive bake that showcases rich layers of flavor and texture. The bread itself is soft and enriched, carrying the subtle tang of whole milk and the aroma of orange zest. The filling, with its buttery marzipan, bursts of apricot, and crunchy walnuts, provides a satisfying contrast, further elevated by the fruity sweetness of raisins soaked in orange juice. Topping it all is a glossy apricot glaze and a delicate, sweet icing that adds the perfect finish. The recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, making it an excellent centerpiece for holiday gatherings or special occasions. This couronne is both visually stunning and deeply flavorful—a true testament to Paul Hollywood’s bakery prowess.

name: Winter pilaf
description: A quick midweek meal that will help you use up leftover turkey, goose or duck, nuts and even a dollop of cranberry sauce
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g mixed brown and wild rice(or basmati)
handful leftover cooked turkey, goose or duck, shredded
directions: Heat the oil in a pan and gently fry the onions and garlic until softened, about 5 mins. Add the spices and rice, then stir-fry for 1-2 mins. Pour in the hot stock and simmer until the stock is nearly all absorbed, about 20-25 mins. Stir in the turkey, add seasoning, then continue cooking until warmed through. Scatter over the nuts and coriander. Divide between two bowls and serve with a dollop of cranberry sauce.
chief_review: This clever recipe transforms leftovers into a fragrant, satisfying dish, full of warm spice and texture. The blend of cardamom, cumin, and cinnamon lifts the flavor of the rice and poultry, creating a subtle nod to Middle Eastern pilafs. Toasted nuts add a delightful crunch, and the fresh coriander brightens the dish. A spoonful of cranberry sauce on the side provides a pleasing tang and balance. Using vegetable stock makes the base suitable for those avoiding meat broths, and using rice ensures the meal is naturally gluten-free. This dish is ideal for anyone following a gluten-free diet, and even dairy-free (as long as the cranberry sauce contains no allergens). Additionally, you can swap in any preferred nuts to accommodate nut allergies, or omit them entirely. A smart, flexible, and flavorful way to make leftovers feel new.

name: Buttered peas & leeks
description: A simple side for your roast dinner, which counts towards your five-a-day
author: Good Food
directions: Gently soften the leeks in butter and oil in your largest pan for 15-20 mins until almost meltingly soft.

Stir in the stock, bring to a simmer and cook, stirring occasionally, for 5 mins. Stir in the peas and spring onions for 3-5 mins more until the peas are defrosted and cooked through, then season and serve.
chief_review: This recipe offers a vibrant and comforting side that effortlessly elevates any roast dinner. The combination of leeks, spring onions, and peas provides a fresh, subtly sweet flavor, while the blend of butter and olive oil adds richness without overpowering the vegetables. Using either vegetable or chicken stock gives flexibility for different preferences. It suits vegetarian diets when prepared with vegetable stock, and is naturally gluten-free, making it versatile for a range of diners. The reliance on fresh, green ingredients makes it a nutritious option, and a quick sauté ensures the vegetables retain their vibrant color and tender texture. This dish is a delightful, wholesome way to add more vegetables to your meal.

name: Sausage & Bramley stuffing
description: This recipe will give you enough to stuff the Christmas turkey and also make a tasty stuffing loaf
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 5 tbsp chopped fresh parsley, plus extra to serve (optional)
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan, add the celery and onion, and cook for about 5 mins until starting to soften. Tip into a bowl to cool while you remove the sausagemeat from the skins. Add the apple, sausagemeat, breadcrumbs, herbs, egg and seasoning. Mix well – the easiest way is to knead it together in the bowl with your hands. Use 1/4 to stuff the neck cavity of the turkey (see 'Goes well with')

For the remainder, line a 900g loaf tin with 8 rashers of streaky bacon, spoon in the stuffing, lift the bacon over and cover with the last 2 rashers. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and bake the stuffing for 40-50 mins. Can be made ahead up to this point and chilled for 2-3 days. Turn out onto a baking-parchment-lined baking tray and return to the oven (once the turkey has come out) at 220C/200C fan/gas 7 for 15-20 mins more to brown the bacon. If chilled, reheat at the lower temperature for 45 mins, covered in foil, then turn out for the extra 15 mins at the higher temperature. Allow to stand, then scatter with parsley (if you like), slice and serve.
chief_review: This festive stuffing recipe beautifully balances savory Cumberland sausages, tart Bramley apple, and aromatic fresh herbs, resulting in a flavorful complement to roast turkey or as a standalone loaf. The addition of sautéed celery and onion lends depth, while the breadcrumbs provide the classic light, yet satisfying texture. Wrapping the loaf in streaky bacon adds smoky richness and ensures the stuffing remains moist throughout baking. This dish is ideal for those who appreciate traditional Christmas flavors. It is suitable for individuals without dietary restrictions related to gluten, dairy, eggs, or pork, and it’s not appropriate for vegetarian or vegan diets. Serve with extra parsley for a fresh finishing touch.

name: Truffled parsnip & Parmesan bruschetta
description: Scented truffle oil and fresh Parmesan make humble parsnips the star in this tasty Christmas canapé
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 mini ciabatta or panini roll, cut into 12 x ½cm slices
3 large parsnips, halved and quartered, cored and cut into 1cm cubes
1 tsp truffle oil, plus more to serve if you like
2 tbsp olive oil, plus more to serve
directions: Heat a griddle pan and toast the bread for about 2 mins on each side until golden and marked. Rub the cut side of the garlic clove over each piece.

Heat the butter in a large frying pan. Add the parsnips, season with sea salt and freshly ground black pepper, then cook over a medium heat, shaking regularly until golden and softened, about 20 mins. Add a splash of water if you need to. Remove from the heat and whizz to a purée in a food processor with both of the oils. Season to taste. Set aside at room temperature if serving on the day. Can be chilled up to 2 days ahead.
To serve, top the toasts with the truffled parsnip mix (it should be room temperature), scatter with rocket leaves and Parmesan shavings, then drizzle with a little more olive oil or truffle oil.
chief_review: This canapé is a delightful fusion of earthy truffle oil and nutty Parmesan, elevating roasted parsnips to festive heights. The recipe’s use of ciabatta, butter, and Parmesan delivers rich flavors and pleasing textures, while the rocket adds a peppery freshness for balance. For vegetarians, opting for a vegetarian Parmesan alternative ensures the dish remains suitable. The simplicity of the preparation allows the natural sweetness of parsnips to shine, making these bites both sophisticated and comforting. Serve as an impressive appetizer at holiday gatherings—this recipe is sure to win over guests with its elegant presentation and complex flavors.

name: Sweet snowballs
description: An alternative to truffles, these chocolatey bitesize treats contain Maltesers, coconut, marshmallow, cranberries and rich tea biscuits - perfect for making with kids
author: Good Food
directions: Melt the chocolate in a bowl over a pan of simmering water. Meanwhile, crush the biscuits and Maltesers in a large bowl with a rolling pin.

Add mini marshmallows, dried cranberries and cake crumbs, then the chocolate and golden syrup. Mix well. Tip desiccated coconut onto a plate. Drop large spoonfuls of mixture onto the plate, then roll them around, coating in coconut and shaping into balls. Place on a baking tray and chill for 30 mins before serving. Sprinkle with edible glitter if you like.
chief_review: This playful recipe offers irresistible, bite-sized confections, perfect for family-friendly gatherings or afternoon treats. The fusion of white chocolate with crunchy Maltesers and rich tea biscuits creates a delightful texture, while cranberries add a tangy lift and mini marshmallows lend a chewy contrast. The inclusion of desiccated coconut and golden syrup ties together sweetness and subtle nuttiness. Given the ingredient list, vegetarians can enjoy these treats, provided the marshmallows are made without gelatine and the cake crumbs are gelatine-free. For those with nut allergies, this recipe is suitable, as none of the ingredients are nut-based, but always check for cross-contamination. Be aware that it contains gluten and dairy, so it's not suitable for gluten-free or vegan diets. Overall, a creative, crowd-pleasing sweet that's easy to prepare and fun for kids to help with decorating and shaping.

name: Apple flapjack trifle
description: Buttery apple flapjack trifle with crispy nuggets of of sugared and spiced oats - perfect for sharing
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 7-8 Cox's or russet apples, depending on size
2 tbsp blackcurrant coulis (you will find it in small bottles in the chiller cabinet alongside the creams, or by the canned fruit)
directions: Mix the oats, spice and sugar. Melt the butter in a frying pan, add the oats and fry for about 5 minutes, stirring all the time, until they are lightly toasted and crisp (they become crispier still on cooling). Tip into a bowl and leave to cool.

Peel, core and thickly slice the apples. Melt the butter in the frying pan until it is foaming, add the apples and fry quickly over a fairly high heat, flipping them over when they start to colour. Sprinkle over the sugar and cook for a further 2-3 minutes, until the apples are slightly softened. Leave to cool.

Layer half the apples and almost half the oats in a glass serving dish, repeat, setting aside a few oats. Drizzle over the coulis, then spoon over the custard. Whip the cream until stiff, then spoon over the custard. Scatter over the remaining oats. Serve straight away or chill for up to 6 hours.
chief_review: This buttery apple flapjack trifle is a delightfully indulgent dessert, blending the comforting warmth of sugared and spiced oats with the tartness of Cox’s or russet apples. The oats, toasted with muscovado sugar and butter, provide an irresistible crunch that perfectly contrasts the luscious, creamy custard and double cream layers. The blackcurrant coulis introduces a welcome burst of sharpness, balancing the dessert’s sweetness. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatine, and is versatile enough for an impressive dinner party centrepiece or a cozy family treat. The use of fresh custard and real cream elevates the trifle, while the spiced apple compote keeps it comfortingly familiar. Serve in a large glass bowl to show off the beautiful layers—each spoonful offers buttery, fruity, and creamy bliss. A truly outstanding sharer’s dessert for autumn gatherings.

name: Chocolate & clementine log
description: This fudgy, fruity alternative to a classic Christmas pudding can be prepared on Christmas Eve to save time on the big day
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g bar dark chocolate(a standard supermarket own brand is fine)
3 tbsp cocoa, plus extra for dusting
100g caster sugar, plus a little extra
silver ballsand white stars, if you like
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line a roughly 37 x 25cm tin with baking parchment. Melt the chocolate over a pan of barely simmering water. Set aside to cool while you get everything else ready. Whisk the yolks and brown sugar until pale and thick enough to hold a trail. Whisk in the cocoa, chocolate, clementine zest and juice. Whisk whites until stiff, whisk a third into chocolate mixture, then fold in the rest. Transfer to tin, gently spread to corners and bake for 16 mins until firm to touch.

Meanwhile, dust a large sheet of baking parchment with a little cocoa. When the cake is done, turn it out onto the parchment. Don’t remove the paper stuck to the bottom of the cake – just roll the cake up with the paper inside from one of its longer sides. Leave to cool.

For the frosting, melt the chocolate, cream and icing sugar together in a bowl over a pan of barely simmering water. Cool and chill until spreadable. Or chill for up to 24 hrs, then leave at room temp until spreadable again.
For the clementine cream, whisk the cream, crème fraîche, icing sugar, clementine zest and juice until thick. Chill for up to 24 hrs.

To make the decoration, melt the caster sugar with 100ml water in a small pan and gently bubble. Peel the zest from the clementine with a vegetable peeler. Thinly shred into strips, then drop into the bubbling syrup. Simmer for 2 mins, then turn off and leave for another 2 mins. Scatter a little extra sugar onto a plate. Lift out the shreds with a slotted spoon and toss in the sugar. Set aside to dry.

To assemble, gently unroll the sponge and peel off the paper. Squeeze over juice from final peeled clementine. Thinly spread with a tiny bit of the chocolate frosting, then spread with half to two-thirds of the clementine cream. Carefully roll back up and trim each end. Transfer to a serving plate and cover with the rest of the chocolate frosting, using a round-bladed knife to stripe the surface. Scatter with the sugared clementine peel and silver balls and/or stars, if you like. Serve with remaining clementine cream.
chief_review: This festive dessert is a decadent, rich alternative to the traditional Christmas pudding, featuring layers of dark chocolate, light brown sugar, cocoa, and the bright, aromatic notes of clementine. Its preparation the night before is a boon for busy hosts. The texture is wonderfully fudgy, offering a luxurious mouthfeel complemented by the citrus zest and subtle bitterness from the chocolate. The whipped double cream and crème fraîche bring a delightful creaminess, while the decorative silver balls and white stars add a whimsical, celebratory touch. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this dessert avoids gelatin and meat products, relying on eggs for structure and richness. However, it contains both eggs and dairy, so not suitable for those with related allergies. Overall, an indulgent and visually striking centerpiece for the holiday table, with balanced flavors of chocolate and fruit.

name: Rudolph cupcakes
description: Get the kids into the kitchen to decorate these individual chocolate sponges with frosting and sweets
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 12 large milk chocolate buttons(we used Cadbury Dairy Milk Giant Buttons)
mini pretzels, carefully cut in half horizontally
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Line a 12-hole muffin tin with paper cases. Gently melt the butter, chocolate, sugar and 100ml hot water together in a large saucepan, stirring occasionally. Set aside to cool a little while you weigh the other ingredients.

Stir the eggs and vanilla into the chocolate mixture. Put the flour in a large mixing bowl, and stir in the chocolate mixture until smooth. Spoon into the cases until just over three-quarters full. Bake on a low shelf in the oven for 20-22 mins. Leave to cool.

To make the icing, melt the chocolate in a heatproof bowl over a pan of barely simmering water. Once melted, turn off the heat, stir in the double cream, sift in the icing sugar and mix well. When spreadable, top each cake with some icing.

Position a milk chocolate button on top of each cake, then 2 white chocolate buttons above it. Use a little icing as glue to stick a red Smartie onto the milk chocolate button for a nose. Then use your icing pens to draw black dots on the white buttons for eyes. Stick 2 pretzel top halves into the top of each cake for antlers, and stick the bottom half of a pretzel under the Smartie for a mouth.
chief_review: This playful recipe for individual chocolate sponges is a delightful project for children and adults alike, encouraging creativity in both baking and decorating. The sponge is rich and moist, thanks to the combination of butter, light brown sugar, and a generous amount of chocolate, while the double cream and icing sugar create a smooth, luscious frosting. Decorating with chocolate buttons, Smarties, and pretzels adds both visual appeal and texture, making these cakes as fun to eat as they are to make. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe does not use gelatin or animal-based rennet, though dairy and eggs make it unsuitable for vegans. Additionally, the absence of nuts may appeal to some with allergies, but always check chocolate and decoration labels for potential traces. This is an excellent recipe for festive occasions or a rainy day activity with kids.

name: Fig & blue cheese tart
description: This extra special tart with crumbly walnut pastry makes a fabulous vegetarian dinner
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 200g plain flour, plus a little extra for rolling pastry
100g walnut, roughly chopped in a food processor
1 tbsp fresh thymeleaves, plus extra to decorate
140g blue cheese- Danish Blue is a good vegetarian one
3-4 figs, halved, cut sides brushed with a little oil
directions: First make the pastry. Tip the flours into a food processor with ½ tsp salt and the diced butter. Pulse until you can’t feel any lumps, then tip in the walnuts. Mix the egg yolks with 3 tbsp cold water, then dribble this into the machine while you pulse again until the pastry comes together. Tip the pastry out onto a floured surface, lightly bring it together into a ball, then roll out and line a deep 20-23cm tart tin with overhang. The pastry may crack, but just patch it back together, then cover and chill for 1 hr.

To make the filling, melt the remaining butter in a large pan, then add the shallots and soften for 10-15 mins, until golden and squishy. Stir in the thyme for 1 min, then remove from the heat. Beat the eggs in a jug with the crème fraîche and cream. Crumble in the cheese and season with pepper and a small amount of salt.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Blind bake the pastry for 20 mins, remove the baking beans and paper, then bake for a further 15-20 mins until golden and sandy. Reduce the oven temp to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Add the cooled onions to the cream mixture and pour into the case. Sit the fig halves on top, cut side up, sprinkle with some more thyme and bake on the middle shelf for 1 hr-1hr 10 mins until the tart is browning and has a slight wobble – the cheese middle will firm up on sitting. Cool for about 15-20 mins, then remove from tin and serve with a green salad.
chief_review: This luxurious tart truly shines as a centerpiece for a vegetarian dinner. The walnut-enhanced pastry adds a toasty richness and crumbly texture that beautifully complements the creamy, tangy filling. The use of Danish Blue cheese—a known vegetarian-friendly blue cheese—ensures excellent depth of flavor without compromising on dietary ethics. Luscious double cream and crème fraîche yield an indulgent custard, studded with sweet caramelized shallots and aromatic thyme. Halved figs roasted on top add a burst of fruity acidity and visual flair. This tart is ideal for vegetarians, and its ingredient list suggests it is nut-rich, making it unsuitable for those with nut allergies. Overall, a masterful, well-balanced creation—perfect for entertaining or an elevated weeknight meal.

name: Turkish delight vodka
description: This turned out really lovely. I can live with a bit of cloudiness. It goes really well with strawberry Lambrini.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g Turkish delight, chopped, plus a little extra for packaging
directions: Pour 100ml out of the vodka bottle – you can keep this in the freezer for Christmas cocktails. Mix the rose water and caster sugar together until the sugar dissolves, then pour into the vodka bottle using a funnel.

Wash any sugar off the Turkish delight, then put it in the bottle. Screw on the lid and leave to stand for up to a month, swirling occasionally until the Turkish delight dissolves. Serve with soda water and ice, or drizzle neat over vanilla ice cream for a boozy treat.
chief_review:
A delightful infusion, this recipe combines vodka with aromatic rosewater and the distinctive sweet chew of Turkish delight. The result is a playful, floral liqueur that balances the spirit’s intensity with delicate, fragrant notes, and just a hint of sugar. While the cloudiness may indicate a modest suspension of Turkish delight, this brings a charming, hand-crafted touch. Served alongside strawberry Lambrini, the pairing expertly highlights the rose and berry profiles, delivering a unique and indulgent treat with a Middle Eastern twist.

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as Turkish delight is typically gelatin-free when made to traditional standards and the remaining ingredients are plant-based. However, those with nut allergies should check the Turkish delight's ingredients, as pistachio or hazelnut varieties are common. This homemade liqueur is a true testament to creative infusions and thoughtful flavor pairings.

name: Prawn & chorizo skewers with gremolata
description: Entice your guests to the buffet table with the flavourful combination of prawn and chorizo
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Fry the chorizo until crisp on both sides. Skewer the cooked, peeled king prawns onto cocktail sticks and add a slice of chorizo to each, then transfer to a baking sheet and bake for 5 mins until warmed through.
To make the gremolata, mix lemon zest with some parsley and garlic. Sprinkle over the prawn and chorizo skewers to serve.
chief_review: This prawn and chorizo appetizer offers a delicious interplay between smoky, spicy chorizo and the sweet brininess of king prawns. The lemon zest adds a bright, refreshing note, while parsley and garlic bring aromatic depth, making each bite vibrant and balanced. This dish is well-suited for those on a gluten-free diet, as none of the core ingredients contain gluten. However, always verify the chorizo is gluten-free, as some brands use fillers. Its simplicity allows for quick assembly, letting the protein-rich prawns shine alongside the robust sausage. Perfect for entertaining, its bold flavors and eye-catching presentation will undoubtedly draw attention at any gathering.

name: Sweet potato & sprout hash with poached eggs
description: This quick and easy pan-fried dish uses up leftover Brussels sprouts for a delicious Boxing day brunch, or a low fat, low calorie weeknight dinner
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 large sweet potatoes, cut into chunks
directions: Put the sweet potatoes in a bowl, cover with cling film and microwave on high for 5 mins until tender but still holding their shape. Uncover the bowl and leave to cool a little.

Meanwhile, heat the oil in a wide non-stick frying pan and add the onions. Cook for 5-8 mins until starting to caramelise. Add the sprouts and stir-fry over a high heat until softened. Push the sprouts and onions to one side of the pan and add the sweet potatoes, squashing them down in the pan with the back of a spatula. Leave undisturbed for 5 mins until starting to crisp on the underside. Season, add the nutmeg, mix in the sprouts and onions, and flip the potato over, trying not to break it up too much. Cook for a further 5 mins until really crispy.
Meanwhile, poach 3 eggs in a pan of barely simmering water. Serve the hash topped with poached eggs.
chief_review: This vibrant pan-fried dish transforms humble leftovers into a hearty, flavorful meal. The combination of sweet potatoes, caramelized red onions, and Brussels sprouts delivers a satisfying medley of textures and subtle sweetness, lifted with a hint of nutmeg. Pan-frying in olive oil keeps the dish light while enhancing the vegetables' natural flavors. Topping with eggs adds protein, making this a balanced choice for brunch or a light, nutritious dinner. It's ideal for those seeking vegetarian options and fits well into a low-calorie, low-fat eating plan. Simple, seasonal, and easily adjustable to taste, this recipe is both practical and delicious.

name: Sprout & chorizo carbonara
description: Pan fry cubed chorizo and Brussels sprouts, then toss with egg yolks, spaghetti and Parmesan for an indulgently creamy weeknight dinner
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 25g grated parmesan, plus extra, to serve
directions: Heat a large frying pan with the olive oil and boil a large pan of salted water.
