Add the cubed chorizo to the frying pan and cook for 5 minutes, stirring, until the oils are released into the pan. Halve and finely slice the Brussels sprouts. Add these to the frying pan, season and cook for 10 mins, stirring now and then, until tender.
Cook the spaghetti following pack instructions. Whisk the egg yolks, single cream and milk with the grated Parmesan and a good grind of black pepper.

When the pasta is cooked, drain, reserving a cup of the cooking water, and add the pasta to the frying pan. Turn the heat to very low and add the egg mixture. Toss everything together for 2-3 mins until the sauce has thickened, adding a splash more water if it looks to dry. Serve with extra Parmesan.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers a rich and satisfying fusion of flavors—the smokiness of chorizo pairs beautifully with the slightly bitter bite of pan-fried Brussels sprouts. The creamy sauce, crafted from egg yolks, single cream, and Parmesan, clings luxuriously to the spaghetti, making each bite indulgent and comforting. A dash of black pepper finishes the dish with just the right amount of heat and balance.

Ideal for those following a traditional vegetarian-free diet, this dish also works well for individuals avoiding nut allergies, as none are present in the ingredient list. However, note that it contains dairy and egg products, making it unsuitable for vegans. For vegetarians, swapping the chorizo for a meat-free alternative would make this dish more inclusive without sacrificing the creamy, savory essence that makes it so appealing. Serve with extra Parmesan for maximum enjoyment.

name: Snowman in the garden cake
description: Surprise the kids with something irresistible, or get them involved - either way, they'll love this magical cake.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 5 tbsp apricot jam, warmed and sieved
small black writing icing tube (Supercook, available from tesco)
small orange sweet, such as a Tic-Tac or an orange hundred and thousand, for the nose
directions: Cover the cake with jam, marzipan and ready-to-roll icing), taking the icing to the edge of the board.

To decorate, roll out several marble-sized balls of the 100g ready-to-roll icing to make snowballs, then set aside. Roll two larger balls, one a little bigger than the other, to make the head and body of the snowman, then leave to dry for at least 30 mins.

Meanwhile, ice the gingerbread trees. Beat the egg white with the icing sugar to make a smooth paste. Put about one-third of the icing into another bowl, then mix in a speck of green colouring and a few drops water so that it’s fairly runny and very pale green. Spread this over three of the gingerbread trees and leave to dry. Spoon another third of the icing into a piping bag fitted with a fine writing nozzle. Pipe rough fir-tree-like branches over the remaining trees. Once the green iced trees have dried to the touch, pipe branches over those, too.

When the icing has set, fix the trees onto the cake and around the edge using spots of the remaining thick royal icing. Put the smaller snowballs around and on top of the cake. Pipe eyes and a mouth onto the head of the snowman and insert the nose. Fix the snowman’s head on with a spot more icing, position him on the cake, then carefully tie a ribbon scarf with the shorter length of ribbon. This is easiest if you start with too much ribbon, tie it, then trim with scissors. To finish, attach ribbon around the base and secure woth a double-sided tape.
chief_review: This playful recipe creates a show-stopping centerpiece that captures the imagination—perfect for involving children in the kitchen. The combination of rich fruitcake, natural marzipan, and ready-to-roll icing delivers classic flavors and festive charm. Green food coloring and gingerbread trees enhance the magical theme, while careful attention to apricot jam and sieved icing ensures a professional finish. The use of egg white in the icing means it suits vegetarians, provided the marzipan and icing are free from animal-based additives. However, those with nut allergies or egg allergies should take caution, as marzipan is almond-based and egg white is present in the icing. This recipe’s whimsical design and vibrant presentation make it ideal for celebrations, blending fun, creativity, and tradition.

name: Rosemary-spiked cabbage
description: This was "ok", I found it to be a bit ordinary and I love cabbage so new ways to cook it are always welcome. Maybe adding the bacon would help, I'll try that next time!
author: Gordon Ramsay
directions: Quarter the cabbage, remove the core and shred the leaves. Blanch in a pan of boiling salted water for 3 mins, then hold under a cold tap to cool. Drain well. Heat the goose fat in a pan and sauté the shallots, rosemary sprig and garlic cloves for 5 mins, until golden. Discard the garlic and rosemary, toss in the cabbage, stir-frying until reheated. Season and serve.
chief_review: This recipe features Savoy cabbage braised with goose fat, shallots, rosemary, and garlic—a true celebration of simple, classic flavors. The use of goose fat gives the dish a deliciously rich depth, beautifully complementing the aromatic shallots and rosemary. For those following a gluten-free diet, this recipe is a safe choice, as it contains no wheat or gluten-based ingredients. Additionally, it's free from common allergens like nuts and dairy. The potential addition of bacon, as suggested, would introduce a smoky layer and elevate the umami profile; however, even as written, the dish stands as a comforting, rustic side perfect for hearty winter meals. Consider seasoning generously and sautéing the cabbage to achieve a golden edge, which would add appealing texture and help the main ingredients shine.

name: Whipped brie salad with dates & candied walnuts
description: Had this Christmas day, it was lovely, but it won't whip unless your brie is really soft. I put mine in the microwave for 15 seconds and it whipped up beautifully!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 85g stoned dates, cut into small pieces
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. To make the candied walnuts, shake the walnut halves in 2 tbsp water, then toss in the sugar. Scatter over a baking sheet and bake in the oven for 6-8 mins until golden brown. Remove from the oven and allow to cool.

Carefully peel the rind off the brie and discard. Put the gooey inside in a medium-sized bowl. Using a spoon or small whisk, whip the brie until pale and spoonable. To make the dressing, whisk the oil and vinegar together, then season.

In a large bowl, combine the walnuts, dates and rocket, then mix with some of the dressing. Place a spoonful of whipped brie in the middle of each serving plate and arrange the salad around it. Scatter over the croutons, drizzle with a little extra dressing and serve.
chief_review: This festive brie salad cleverly balances textures and flavors—creamy whipped brie, sweet dates, crunchy walnuts, peppery rocket, and crisp croûtons. The technique of briefly microwaving the brie ensures it whips perfectly for a luxurious, spreadable texture. Walnut oil and balsamic vinegar together make a nuanced dressing that elevates the dish. The recipe is vegetarian-friendly and excludes meat or fish, making it ideal for a festive meat-free table. However, those following gluten-free diets should note the use of croûtons unless suitably substituted. The dates add a lovely, natural sweetness that harmonizes with the richness of the cheese, while the walnuts provide depth. Overall, this dish is a sophisticated and festive starter or side—simple in assembly but impressive in presentation and taste.

name: Orange frosted panettone cake
description:
If you’ve been given a panettone over
Christmas but you’re not sure what to do
with it, try this superfast,
special stacked cake
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 500g boxed fruity panettone(or try a chocolate version)
directions: Make the syrup first. Gently heat all the ingredients together until the sugar dissolves, then boil for 1 min or until just thickened. Leave to cool.

Meanwhile, trim the rounded top off the panettone (this is cook’s perks for later!), then cut the rest into 4 horizontal slices using a serrated knife. Beat the mascarpone, orange zest and caster sugar together.

Stack up the slices, drizzling a little of the orange syrup over each piece as you go, and using about 2 tbsp of the mascarpone to sandwich each layer together. Once you’ve finished stacking, cover with the rest of the mascarpone in swirls and whirls – a palette knife is the best tool for the job. Scatter with a few silver balls if you like, then serve straight away, or chill for up to 2 hrs, then scatter with the balls at the last minute.
chief_review:
This festive stacked cake transforms traditional panettone into an elegant dessert in minutes. Slices of panettone—either fruity or chocolate—are layered with a decadent mascarpone cream, delicately sweetened and brightened by fresh orange zest. An orange syrup laced with Grand Marnier keeps the cake moist, adding a sophisticated citrus note. The finishing touch of silver balls gives the cake a celebratory sparkle, perfect for special occasions.

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, it does contain gluten from the panettone and dairy from the mascarpone, so it’s not appropriate for those with dairy or gluten allergies. The use of Grand Marnier can be omitted for those avoiding alcohol, though it adds depth to the flavor. Overall, this dessert is a delightful and quick showpiece for holiday gatherings or to reinvigorate leftover panettone.

name: Squash & sage pithivier
description: This simple pie for one makes a great veggie option for Christmas Day - make as many as you need and freeze ahead
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 sageleaves, chopped, plus a few extra to decorate
1 garlic clove, finely grated to a paste
½ the top end of a butternut squash(about 250g), thinly sliced into rounds
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Roughly halve the pastry, but make one half a tiny bit bigger. Roll the slightly smaller half out on a floured surface to a circle about 15cm in diameter. Spread over the mustard, leaving about a 2cm gap around the edge. Mix the mascarpone, breadcrumbs, chopped sage and garlic together and season generously.

Arrange a few squash slices, overlapping, to cover the mustard. Spread with some of the mascarpone mixture. Repeat, making slightly smaller circles with the squash each time, and spreading mascarpone between each layer until the top is just one slice of squash and you have made a rough dome shape on the pastry.
Thinly roll out remaining pastry. Use to cover the squash dome, gently pressing down on the veg to push out as much air as you can. Press the pastry edges to seal.

Brush with beaten egg, then poke a tiny steam hole in the top and gently score patterns over the surface. Dip a few sage leaves in the remaining egg and stick on top. Transfer to a baking sheet and bake for 35-40 mins until a skewer poked through the steam hole goes through the veg easily.
chief_review: This individual pie is a delightful vegetarian choice, perfect for festive occasions like Christmas. The combination of creamy mascarpone, aromatic sage, and sweet butternut squash wrapped in flaky puff pastry delivers both comfort and elegance. The subtle kick of wholegrain mustard complements the earthiness of the squash beautifully. With no meat, fish, or animal rennet-derived cheese, it caters well to ovo-lacto vegetarian diets. However, it does contain gluten (from the pastry and breadcrumbs) and dairy, making it unsuitable for those with gluten or dairy intolerances. The inclusion of egg also means it’s not vegan-friendly. Preparation is straightforward, and the option to freeze ahead adds convenience for holiday planning. Overall, this pie is sure to please anyone seeking satisfying, seasonal vegetarian fare.

name: Roasted Brussels sprouts with bacon & chestnuts
description: Great recipe, super-easy to make and very tasty indeed. Would go with any type of roast dinner but we particularly like it to accompany Venison Wellington.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g vacuum-packed chestnuts, roughly chopped in half
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Bring a large pan of water to the boil, add the sprouts and cook for 5 mins. Drain and refresh in cold water.

Toss the sprouts with all the other ingredients in a bowl and season with a pinch of salt and a good grinding of black pepper. Tip onto a large baking tray in a single layer. Put in the oven and roast for 30 mins, tossing halfway through, until the bacon is crispy and the sprouts are golden and tender.
chief_review:
This is a classic, robust dish perfect for the colder months, bringing together the earthiness of Brussels sprouts and sweetness of chestnuts with the savory punch of smoked bacon lardons. The simplicity of the recipe highlights the natural flavors—lightly roasting brings out a subtle caramelization, while the chestnuts offer textural contrast. The combination works wonders alongside hearty mains like Venison Wellington, as well as with any traditional roast.

From a dietary standpoint, the recipe is naturally gluten-free, provided the bacon and chestnuts are sourced without additives containing gluten. While not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to bacon, the use of simple, whole ingredients may appeal to those who value clean eating. For the best results, take care not to overcook the sprouts; a bit of bite preserves their vibrant color and appealing texture. This dish is sure to become a staple at any festive table.

name: Quick & easy party nibbles
description: Ten stunning ideas for your Christmas drinks party, all suitable for vegetarians
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: See recipe directions, below, for all the ingredientsyou'll need for your canapés
directions: For 10 shots mix 700ml tomato juice with 50ml vodka, juice from 1 lemon and a good splash of Tabasco and vegetarian Worcestershire sauce in a jug. Season then chill. To serve, pour into 10 shot glasses, add a thin cucumber stick to each as a stirrer, and top with a small spoon of creamed horseradish.

Toast 1 tbsp each of cumin and coriander seeds and 85g hazelnuts, then whizz in a food processor until finely chopped. Mix with 50g sesame seeds and salt to taste, then serve in small bowls with 24-36 hard-boiled quails’ eggs, halved, alongside for dipping.

Buy mini croustade cases from the supermarket, then put a small spoonful of sour cream in each case. Finely dice ripe avocados and mix with a little lime juice, some poppy seeds and finely snipped chives, then pile on top of the sour cream.

Peel a parsnip per person, then cut into chunky chips and roast with sunflower oil and seasoning at 220C/200C fan/gas 7 for 20-30 mins until crispy and golden. Mix a 200ml tub crème fraîche with 2 tbsp grainy mustard, 2 tbsp maple syrup and some seasoning and serve the hot parsnip chips alongside for dipping.

For the salsa, finely dice 200g fresh or canned pineapple and mix with 1 finely chopped red onion, 1 finely chopped red chilli and juice of 1-2 limes to taste. Use a 250g pack halloumi per 5-6 people, slice into chunky strips, thread onto small soaked wooden skewers and grill, turning, until crispy. Serve with the salsa.
Cook and cool bought falafel, then skewer each one with a chunk of cucumber, small cube of feta and a cherry tomato. Serve with pots of houmous and tzatziki on the side.

To feed a crowd, finely shred 3 peeled carrots, dice ½ a cucumber and finely slice 4 spring onions. Mix together with a squeeze of lemon juice and 1 tbsp toasted mustard seeds. To serve, pile into bought mini poppadom crisps, top with a small dollop of mango chutney and scatter with coriander leaves.
Skewer wedges of fig and cubes of blue cheese onto small cocktail sticks or skewers, then drizzle with a little runny honey and scatter with thyme leaves to serve.

Melt together 200g dark chocolate and 200ml double cream, then crumble in 100g leftover cooked Christmas pud (buy a vegetarian one), then chill. When firm enough, use a melon baller or roll into balls, then dip the tops in some melted white chocolate, scatter with edible decorations, then chill to firm.

Knock up a batch of scone dough (from a packet or find recipe on bbcgoodfood.com), adding some dried cranberries and orange zest into the mix before stamping out 4cm rounds and baking. When cool, split and spread generously with orange or jaffa curd (we used Waitrose) and top with a small dollop of clotted or thick double cream.
chief_review: This compilation of ten Christmas drinks party canapés showcases creativity and vibrant flavors, all while adhering to a vegetarian-friendly approach. With ingredients and methods tailored to festive gatherings, each canapé offers a thoughtful balance of seasonal produce and elegant presentation. The assortment not only appeals to vegetarians but also ensures a variety of textures and tastes to delight all guests—perfect for pairing with sparkling holiday beverages. Ideal for hosts accommodating meat-free diets, this recipe selection manages to be both impressive and inclusive, elevating the standard of holiday entertaining.

name: Choc-cherry fudge torte with cherry sorbet
description: This divine, squidgy chocolate cake is dairy and wheat-free, so vegans can dig in!
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 300g gluten- and wheat-free plain flour(we used Doves Farm)
a little icing sugar, for dusting
directions: For the sorbet, whizz the compote with the sugar until smooth-ish, then tip into a freezer-proof container. Freeze until solid.
Mix the cherries and the brandy and leave to soak for a few hrs.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Line the base of a round, 20cm loosebottomed tin with baking parchment. Mix the flour, cocoa, brown sugar, baking powder, bicarb and xanthan gum in a big bowl. Whisk the oil, rice milk and agave syrup, then add to the dry ingredients and stir in with a wooden spoon. Add the cherries and any brandy, then scrape into the tin. Bake for 35-45 mins until crisp on top but fudgy in the centre. Cool in the tin.
Carefully lift the torte onto a serving plate. Dust with cocoa and icing sugar, and serve with the cherry sorbet.
chief_review: This recipe is a masterclass in inclusive baking, producing a rich, moist chocolate cake that caters beautifully to vegan and gluten-free diets. The use of gluten- and wheat-free flour blends, alongside baking powder, bicarbonate of soda, and xanthan gum, ensures a light yet structured crumb without any compromise in texture. Rice milk and sunflower oil provide a clean, neutral base, while agave syrup and dried sour cherries add nuanced sweetness and tartness. The cherry compote and a dusting of cocoa finish the cake with flourish. This dessert is well-suited to those with dairy, egg, or gluten intolerances, and its clever ingredient swaps make it a strong contender for allergy-conscious gatherings without sacrificing indulgence. A thoughtful treat that doesn’t alienate anyone at the table.

name: Beef fillet with horseradish & prosciutto
description: This was easy to make beforehand and pop into the fridge, then take out half an hour before putting in the oven. I cooked this for a dinner party for 6, so the portions were generous. Definitely needed a meat thermometer to get right temperature as it needed an extra 10 minutes in the oven. I'm not keen on horseradish, but it works really well with this recipe and the procuitto gave it lovely a crispy edge - much better than heavy pastry with a beef Wellington. Highly recommended!
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 900g beef fillet, cut from the middle so it is an even thickness
400g bag banana shallots, halved and thinly sliced
1 tbsp fresh thyme leaves, plus extra to serve (optional)
directions: Heat the butter in a large frying pan and fry the beef fillet for 5 mins, turning it to seal and brown it all over. Remove from the pan and leave to cool. Add the shallots to the buttery meat juices and cook, stirring, until softened and golden. Turn off the heat and tip out two-thirds of the shallots into a bowl. Add the horseradish and some black pepper to the bowl, then blitz with a hand blender to make a coarse purée.

Meanwhile, pour the red wine and stock into the pan with the remaining shallots. Blend the cornflour with 3 tbsp water, add to the pan with the redcurrant jelly, and stir until thickened. Season to taste and allow to bubble for at least 5 mins until it has become a sauce. Cool and chill until ready to serve.

Lay 8 slices of prosciutto in 2 overlapping rows. Spread the horseradish mixture on top and scatter evenly with the herbs. Place the fillet on top, cover the ends with the last 2 slices, and tightly wrap the prosciutto around the beef. Chill until ready to cook.
Remove the beef from the fridge at least 30 mins before you are ready to cook it. Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the meat on a baking-parchment-lined

and roast for 30-40 mins, depending on how well done you like it. (To test how done the beef is, insert a digital thermometer into the centre – it should read 50C for rare, 55C for medium rare and 60C for medium.) Leave to rest for 10-15 mins, then carefully slice with a very sharp knife and serve with the wine sauce. Scatter with extra thyme, if you like.
chief_review: This beef fillet recipe is a sophisticated yet approachable alternative to the traditional beef Wellington, replacing pastry with a savory prosciutto wrap that ensures a pleasingly crispy edge and added depth of flavor. Preparing the dish in advance makes it perfect for entertaining, while the combination of horseradish sauce, fresh herbs, and a rich red wine and beef stock reduction infuses the tender fillet with layers of complexity. Using a meat thermometer is advisable to achieve optimal doneness, especially for larger cuts. With its reliance on fresh meat, dairy, and a cornflour-based sauce, this recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for those with gluten intolerance. However, the use of beef and prosciutto makes it unsuitable for vegetarians or vegans. Overall, a showstopper for any meat lover seeking a hearty and elegant main course.

name: Sprouts with chestnuts & crisp pancetta
description: If you struggle to get the family to eat their sprouts, try adding some chestnuts and pancetta to make an irresistible side dish
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g cooked chestnuts, broken into large pieces
directions: Boil the sprouts for 3 mins until starting to soften slightly, then drain. Fry the pancetta until crisp, then remove from the pan and set aside. Add the chestnuts and sugar, tossing in the pan, then add the stock and reduce by half. Add the sprouts and pancetta back to the pan and warm through to serve.
chief_review: This festive Brussels sprouts dish cleverly balances flavors and textures by pairing earthy sprouts with sweet, nutty chestnuts and savory, crisped pancetta. The addition of muscovado sugar introduces a subtle hint of caramel that complements both the chestnuts and the pancetta’s smokiness. Briefly simmering the ingredients in a splash of vegetable stock allows the flavors to meld while keeping the sprouts vibrant and tender. This is a delightful side that elevates classic Brussels sprouts far beyond the ordinary, ideal for holiday gatherings or special occasions. The chestnuts provide a satisfying bite, rounding out the richness of the pancetta, making this a crowd-pleasing, well-rounded vegetable dish.

name: Creamy baked cauliflower
description: Think of this as a creamier, richer take on traditional family bake, cauliflower cheese
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 bay leaves(fresh if you have), scrunched in your hand
directions: Put the milk, quartered onion, mace and bay leaves in a pan, and bring to a simmer. Turn off the heat, set aside for 1 hr to infuse, then strain.
Meanwhile, bring a large pan of water to the boil. Tip in the cauliflower and cook for 5 mins until just tender. Drain and set aside, uncovered, in a colander to steam-dry.
Put the pan back on the heat, then add the knob of butter and the chopped onion. Gently soften onion for 10 mins until really soft but not coloured.

In a medium-sized pan, melt the butter, then stir in the flour to form a paste. Cook for 2 mins, then gradually stir in the strained milk to form a smooth sauce. Bring to the boil and simmer, stirring often, until thickened and smooth. Stir in the softened onion and season well with salt and nutmeg.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Tip the cauliflower into an ovenproof dish and pour over the sauce. Can be covered and chilled for up to 2 days at this stage or frozen. Scatter the cauliflower with the breadcrumbs, then bake for 30 mins until the sauce is bubbling and the top is golden and crisp.
chief_review: This recipe elevates the classic cauliflower cheese by amplifying its richness and creaminess, making it an indulgent centerpiece or side. The infusion of whole milk with aromatic bay leaves, mace, and onions imparts a layered depth to the béchamel. Cauliflower remains tender yet substantial, enveloped in a velvety sauce bound with a butter-flour roux and highlighted by a touch of nutmeg. The breadcrumb topping adds a welcomed textural contrast. With no meat in sight, this dish is suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, the use of dairy means it is not vegan-friendly. Perfect for a comforting family dinner or as an impressive addition to a festive spread, this recipe honors tradition while delivering extra decadence.

name: Cranberry & pear pies
description: These cute and festive pies make a good warm dessert or a tangy alternative to mince pies
author: Good Food
ingredients: 140g caster sugar, plus extra to decorate
325g jar orange curd(we used Waitrose Jaffa orange curd)
450g just-ripe pears, peeled, cored and chopped
directions: To make the pastry, tip the flour, almonds and sugar into a food processor then pulse in the butter until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Pulse in up to 5 tbsp cold water until mixture comes together as a dough. Wrap in cling film and chill for 1 hr.

To make the filling, tip the cranberries into a pan with the sugar and cornflour and stir well. Stir in the orange curd, then cook for a few mins until thickened. Add the pears and cook a few mins more, stirring frequently. Cool.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5 with a large baking sheet inside. Roll out the pastry and use to line 8 x 10cm individual Yorkshire pudding tins (or 10cm individual tart tins). Spoon in the cooled filling. Roll out the rest of the dough and stamp out 4 x 9cm rounds to make lids. Cut out the centres with a medium star cutter.

Carefully cover half the pies with the pastry lids and place the stars on a baking tray. Crimp the edges of each pie (if using straight edged tins) with your finger and thumb, brush the pies and stars with the egg then dredge with sugar. Bake the stars for 8-10 mins and the pies for 15-20 mins until golden. Dredge with more sugar once out of the oven. Place a star on the open pies and serve with cream or ice cream.
chief_review:
This festive pie recipe brings together the bright tartness of cranberries and the subtle sweetness of orange curd and pears, all encased in a rich pastry featuring both plain flour and ground almonds. The pastry's inclusion of ground almonds imparts a delicate nuttiness, while butter provides the classic shortcrust texture. The fruit filling is nicely balanced: the acidity of cranberries and fragrant pear complement the citrus notes of the orange curd, resulting in a refreshing twist on traditional mince pies.

This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, relying on butter and egg for richness and structure. However, it contains key allergens such as gluten, nuts (almonds), eggs, and dairy, so it's important to consider guests' dietary needs. Perfect served warm with cream or custard, these pies make a delightful winter dessert with a memorable flavor profile.

name: Salt & pepper turkey
description: A finishing touch of a lattice of bacon makes this turkey a Christmas dinner centre-stage star
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 4½ -5.6kg/10-12lb turkey, thawed if frozen, giblets removed
a few bay leaves, plus extra sprigs to garnish
4 tbsp lingonberry preserve or cranberry sauce
directions: Preheat the oven to 190C/gas 5/ fan 170C.Wash the turkey inside and out and dry well with kitchen paper. Season inside the bird with salt and pepper.

Coarsely crush the peppercorns with a pestle and mortar and add the sea salt. Finely grate the lemon rind on top and mix together. Quarter the lemon and put inside the body cavity along with a few bay leaves.

If you are stuffing the turkey, stuff the neck end only, pushing it towards the breast. Don’t overfill, as the stuffing will expand on cooking. Any leftover stuffing can be shaped into walnut-sized balls and cooked around the turkey for the last half-hour. Secure the neck end flap with a small metal or wooden skewer.
Tie the turkey legs together with kitchen string to give it a good shape.Weigh the turkey and calculate the cooking time at 18 minutes per 450g/1lb.
Set the turkey in a large roasting tin. Brush liberally all over with melted butter. Sprinkle the salt and pepper mix evenly over the breast and legs.

Cover the turkey loosely with a large square of foil and roast for the calculated cooking time, basting with the pan juices every hour. Half an hour before the end of the cooking time, remove the foil and string.Re-tie the legs with a rasher of bacon and arrange the rest in a lattice over the breast. Place any stuffing balls around the turkey. Spoon or siphon off 6 tbsp of pan juices into a saucepan for the gravy, then return the turkey to the oven.
At the end of the cooking time, transfer the turkey to a serving platter. Cover tightly with foil and leave to rest for 15-45 minutes.

Meanwhile, make the gravy. Heat the 6 tbsp of pan juices in the saucepan. Whisk in the flour and cook for 3 minutes until golden. Gradually whisk in the turkey or chicken stock and port, cooking until the gravy is no longer lumpy. Stir in the lingonberry preserve (or cranberry sauce) and mustard and simmer for 5 minutes. Then taste the gravy and season if necessary. Skim off the fat from the juices in the roasting tin, then add about 150ml/1⁄4 pint of the pan juices to the gravy. Heat through then transfer to a warmed gravy boat.
Carve the turkey and serve.
chief_review: This turkey recipe is a classic, show-stopping main perfect for festive occasions. The bacon lattice adds both moisture and a visually appealing finish, while the use of lemon and bay leaves infuses the bird with fresh, aromatic flavors. The accompanying gravy, enriched with port and lingonberry preserve, beautifully balances sweetness and acidity, complementing the richness of the turkey and bacon. The butter basting ensures succulent meat and a golden, crisp skin. This recipe suits those following a gluten-containing diet due to the plain flour used in the gravy—an easy swap to gluten-free flour could accommodate other needs. The dish is best enjoyed by meat-eaters—especially those looking to impress at holiday gatherings with a harmonious blend of classic flavors and festive flair.

name: Pepper-crusted salmon with garlic chickpeas
description:
I didn't do the chickpeas.
I found the topping very easy but it overpowered the fish.
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Put the salmon fillets in a shallow ovenproof dish in a single layer. Roughly crush the peppercorns with a pestle and mortar, or tip into a cup and crush with the end of a rolling pin. Mix with the paprika, lime zest and a little sea salt. Brush the salmon lightly with oil, then sprinkle over the pepper mix. Bake for 12-15 mins until the salmon is just cooked.

Meanwhile, tip the chickpeas into a colander, rinse well under cold running water, then drain. Heat the oil in a pan, add the garlic, then gently cook for 5 mins without browning. Add the chickpeas and stock, then warm through. Crush the chickpeas lightly with a potato masher, then add the spinach and stir well until the leaves are wilted. Add the lime juice and some salt and pepper, then heat through. Serve with the salmon.
chief_review: This salmon recipe showcases bold flavors with black peppercorns, paprika, and a lively burst of lime zest and juice. While the chickpeas were omitted, the combination of salmon, spinach, and aromatic garlic provides a nutrient-rich meal with an appealing balance of textures. The topping, though easy to prepare, can easily overshadow the natural delicacy of the fish, so I recommend adjusting the quantity to suit your palate. This dish is gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities, and relies solely on fish and vegetable components, which makes it ideal for pescatarians. Overall, it’s a healthy, protein-rich option with bright citrus flavors and a peppery kick—just tune the spicing to your desired intensity for the best experience.

name: Iced chestnut ripple cheesecake
description: With a dark chocolate digestive base and nutty cream cheese topping, this frozen dessert has a winter twist
author: Good Food
ingredients: 300g tub soft cheese, beaten until smooth
directions: For the base, blitz the biscuits in a food processor or bash in a bag to make crumbs. Stir in the butter, then press into the base of a 22cm springform cake tin. Chill.

For the praline, line a tray with baking parchment and lightly oil it. Tip the caster sugar into a frying pan and place over a high heat. Cook for 5 mins, without stirring, until dissolved and you have a dark amber caramel. Throw in the chestnut pieces, then quickly tip onto the baking parchment and leave to harden. Break or chop into small pieces and set aside.

For the filling, blitz the chestnut purée in a food processor with the icing sugar and 1 tbsp of the rum. Set 3 tbsp of the mix aside. In a large bowl, whisk the cream with the caster sugar and vanilla until it holds its shape, then whisk in the soft cheese. Beat in the pieces of praline, then gently fold through the chestnut purée so that it ripples the cream. Spoon onto the biscuit base. Bang the cake tin gently on the work surface to level and smooth over the top. Cover with cling film and freeze for at least 12 hrs or up to 1 month.

For the drizzle, mix the remaining rum with the reserved chestnut purée and enough water to make it just runny. If serving the cake within 2 days, chill the drizzle; if keeping for longer, freeze and defrost when needed.

Put the cheesecake in the fridge to thaw a little 30 mins before serving. Using a sandwich bag with a corner tip cut off, pipe the drizzle over the top of the cake in a zig-zag pattern. Carefully remove from the tin and serve in small wedges – with a glass of rum if you fancy it.
chief_review: This decadent frozen dessert combines the deep, slightly bitter flavor of dark chocolate digestive biscuits with a luscious, nutty cream cheese and chestnut topping. The use of both chestnut pieces and chestnut purée provides wonderful texture and a wintery earthiness, while the double dose of sugar and a splash of dark rum add sweetness and complexity. The double cream and soft cheese base result in a sumptuously smooth consistency that contrasts beautifully with the crunchy biscuit foundation. As a chef, I appreciate the balance of rich, festive flavors, making it a perfect treat for colder months. **Vegetarians** will find this dessert suitable, provided the soft cheese and biscuits are free from animal rennet. However, those with dairy or nut allergies should avoid it, and it does contain gluten due to the digestive biscuits. Overall, it's an indulgent, crowd-pleasing showstopper for special occasions.

name: Gingerbread syrup
description: This simple syrup makes a lovely homemade gift and adds a festive flavour to drinks and desserts - stir into hot chocolate, warm apple juice or Prosecco, or drizzle over ice cream
author: Cassie Best
directions: Put the golden caster sugar, 200ml water and ground ginger into a saucepan. Add the cinnamon stick and bring to a gentle boil. Simmer for 5 mins until the sugar has dissolved, then stir in a little edible gold glitter, if you like. Pour into a 500ml sterilised bottle (see tip below).
To decorate, tie a cinnamon stick around the neck with a pretty ribbon, if you like. Will keep for up to 1 year.
chief_review: This ginger and cinnamon simple syrup is a festive delight, ideal for elevating beverages and desserts with aromatic warmth. The use of golden caster sugar pairs beautifully with pungent ground ginger and the spicy depth of cinnamon, creating a well-balanced syrup that’s both comforting and versatile. Its preparation is straightforward and quick, making it an excellent homemade gift when dressed up with a touch of edible gold glitter and ribbon. The syrup is naturally vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free, suiting a wide range of dietary needs. It’s perfect drizzled over ice cream, stirred into hot drinks, or splashed into sparkling wine for a celebratory twist. Both its flavor and presentation make it a standout addition to the holiday pantry, and its adaptability ensures it will quickly become a favorite in a variety of festive recipes.

name: Rum & raisin puddings
description: These individual desserts are deliciously naughty, so make plenty or you might have a fight on your hands when it comes to seconds
author: Good Food
ingredients: 150ml sunflower oil, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Mix the dates with the hot milk and set aside for 20 mins. Mix the raisins with the rum and do the same. Grease 9 dariole or small pudding moulds and sit them in a deep roasting tin or baking dish. Put the kettle on.

Whizz the dates and milk together in a food processor until you have a smooth purée, then scrape into a large bowl and mix with the oil and eggs, before stirring in the bicarbonate of soda, flour and sugar. Finally fold in the rum-soaked raisins and any rum left in the bowl. Divide between the darioles, then carefully pour boiling water into the tin or dish so it comes two-thirds to halfway up the sides of the darioles. Bake for 20-25 mins on a low shelf in the oven.

Check the puds are done with a skewer, then lift out and cool a little. For the sauce melt the butter, sugar and cream together, then turn up the heat until it bubbles and comes together into a smooth, shiny sauce. Stir in the rum and raisins and cool. Turn out the puddings from the moulds, scraping around the sides of each with a blunt cutlery knife first. Line up in a shallow baking dish and cover with cling film. Keep the puds and sauce somewhere cool for up to 24 hrs.

To serve spoon a little sauce and raisins over each pud, then pour the rest around (if the sauce has separated a little just gently reheat and stir back together). Cover the whole dish with a tent of foil. When the Christmas dinner is ready turn the oven down to 120C/100C fan/gas ¼ and reheat puddings for about 30-40 mins until hot. Serve with crème fraîche.
chief_review: This dessert boasts deep, caramelized flavors from muscovado sugar and dates, complemented by rich rum-soaked raisins. The double-layered approach—moist sponges drenched in buttery, creamy sauce—offers a classic indulgence that’s as memorable as it is decadent. The presence of eggs and dairy makes it suitable for vegetarian diets, while the absence of gelatine or animal-derived thickeners extends its appeal. However, it contains gluten and is unsuitable for those with dairy or egg allergies. The lush finish of crème fraîche adds an irresistible tang to balance the sweetness. A perfect celebration dessert best served warm, where the interplay of fruit, rum, and cream can truly shine.

name: Traditional bread sauce
description: Every Christmas lunch needs a big bowl of bread sauce on the table
author: Good Food
directions: Pop the onion in a pan with the milk, cream, peppercorns and bay leaves. Bring to a simmer, then turn off the heat and leave to infuse for 30 mins. Pour the milk through a sieve into a jug, then return it to a cleaned pan.

Stir in the breadcrumbs, bring back to the simmer and cook for a few mins (add a splash more milk if you like your sauce thinner). Stir in the butter, season with salt, white pepper and nutmeg, then pour into a warm serving jug or bowl.
chief_review: This classic bread sauce recipe offers a rich, creamy accompaniment perfect for festive roasts. The infusion of clove-studded onion, bay leaves, and black peppercorns in milk and cream adds layers of aromatic warmth, while the fresh breadcrumbs and butter create a satisfying, velvety texture. The finish of freshly grated nutmeg elevates the sauce with a subtle, nutty spice. This dish is ideal for vegetarian diets when served alongside roasted vegetables or nut loaf, as it contains no meat or meat-derived ingredients. Note that the sauce includes both gluten (breadcrumbs) and dairy (milk, cream, butter), so it is not suitable for those with gluten or dairy sensitivities. Traditionally served at Christmas, this bread sauce is comforting, aromatic, and brings a nostalgic touch to holiday meals.

name: Espresso, chocolate & chilli cake with coffee cream
description: The warmth of coffee and chilli combine beautifully with chocolate in this impressive dinner party dessert, finish with double cream
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 3 tbsp plain flour, plus extra for the tin
250g salted butter, softened and chopped, plus extra for greasing
2 red bird's-eye chillies, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a 22cm springform cake tin with soft butter and line the bottom with baking parchment. Shake a little flour around the buttered edges.

Melt the chocolate and butter together over a pan of simmering water, or in a microwave. Once melted, whisk together until smooth and add the espresso powder and chillies and chilli powder, if using. Whisk the egg yolks with the brown sugar and caster sugar, either in an electric mixer or with an electric hand whisk, for 5-10 mins until thick and pale. In a separate bowl, using a clean whisk, beat the egg whites and cream of tartar until soft rounded peaks form.

Pour the chocolate mixture onto the beaten yolks and sugar, and gently mix until smooth. Add the almonds and flour and mix again. Spoon the egg whites into the chocolate mixture and gently fold together. Pour the batter into the prepared tin and bake for 40-45 mins until the cake is set but with a slight jiggle in the centre. (If the cake is starting to brown too quickly, cover with a piece of baking parchment.)

Leave to cool in the tin – it will sink a little as it cools. Run a knife around the inside of the cake tin to loosen. Remove the baking parchment and place on a cake stand. Whisk the cream and espresso powder until soft peaks form. Serve on the side or spoon on top of the cake dusted with a little cocoa powder.
chief_review: A sophisticated fusion of coffee, chilli, and chocolate, this dessert offers rich, layered flavors perfect for a dinner party finale. The addition of espresso and chilli both intensifies and deepens the chocolate, while cream lends richness and balance. The use of ground almonds adds a subtle, nutty undertone. This recipe is suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided you substitute plain flour with a gluten-free flour blend and ensure all other ingredients are certified gluten free. However, it contains eggs, dairy, nuts, and possible caffeine, so is not suitable for those with related allergies or restrictions. Overall, this dessert is sure to impress with its complexity, warmth, and velvety finish. Serve with a dusting of cocoa powder and double cream for an indulgent experience.

name: Festive red salad
description: Cabbage, red onion, apple and beetroot - all the brightest purple fruit and veg makes up this winter salad with sweet vinaigrette
author: Good Food
directions: Quarter the cabbage, then cut out the white core at the bottom and discard. Finely shred the cabbage and tip into a large mixing bowl with the onions, apples, beetroot and walnuts. Finely grate over the zest from the oranges.

Cut a little from the top and bottom of each orange, so they sit flat on your work surface. Use a small, serrated knife to cut away the peel and pith in strips down the orange. Holding each orange over a bowl, cut away the segments, letting them and any juice drop into the bowl. Squeeze any juice left in the membranes into the bowl, too. Fish out the segments, roughly chop and add to the salad.
Whisk the red wine vinegar, redcurrant jelly, honey and oil into the orange juice with some seasoning, then stir into the salad.
chief_review:
This vibrant winter salad is a celebration of bold colours and fresh, seasonal flavours. The crunchy red cabbage pairs beautifully with earthy beetroot and sweet, tangy red apples, while red onion adds a subtle bite. The orange segments and their juice lend a zesty brightness, perfectly complemented by a sweet vinaigrette of red wine vinegar, redcurrant jelly, and honey. Toasted walnut pieces provide a satisfying crunch and a touch of richness that elevates the dish.

Perfect for vegetarians and those seeking a gluten-free option, this salad offers a harmonious balance of sweet, tart, and savoury notes, making it an excellent side or light main course throughout the colder months. As a chef, I appreciate the thoughtful combination of ingredients for both flavour and texture, and the minimal use of processed elements, resulting in a dish that is as nutritious as it is visually stunning.

name: Decorative stars
description: Leave the tinsel and bling for the Christmas tree and keep it simple with this tasteful finishing touch to your homemade cake
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: icing sugar, for rolling and dusting
directions: Once the marzipan is dry on your cake, brush it all over with water just to dampen the surface. Cut off 750g of the icing, re-wrap the rest, then dust the worktop with icing sugar. Knead the icing until pliable and smooth, then roll out and lay over the cake in the same way as you did with the marzipan (see 'Goes well with' recipe). Leave to dry completely overnight.

For the stars, cut the remaining icing in half. Knead a small spot of icing colour (you can always add more later) into one half until evenly pale blue. Cut in half, then work a little more colour into one piece to make it darker.

Piece by piece, roll out the white and blue icings a little thicker than a £1 coin. Stamp out about 40 stars, re-rolling any trimmings, then push the piping nozzle or straw through the middles to make holes. Lift onto a rack, then dry in a cool, dry place for 24 hrs, or longer if you can. Once dry, knot an 80cm length of ribbon loosely at one end, then thread with stars. Untie the knot, then tie the ribbon in a bow, making sure that the stars are slanting in the same direction.
Once the cake is dry, pick up the wreath of stars carefully, then lay it on top of the cake. Fix the remaining ribbon around the bottom of the cake using a little tape or glue.
chief_review: This recipe offers a classic and elegant approach to cake decorating, using white ready-to-roll icing with optional blue coloring for visual flair. The simplicity of the ingredients—ready-to-roll icing and icing sugar—makes it approachable for home bakers seeking a clean, professional look. The decorative elements, such as precision-cut stars and a colored ribbon, add a festive yet understated touch. Notably, the recipe is well-suited for vegetarian and gluten-free diets, as most ready-to-roll icings are free from animal products and gluten; however, it's essential to check specific brands to confirm. The absence of common allergens like nuts, dairy, or eggs in the listed ingredients further enhances its versatility. Overall, this finishing touch lets the beauty of your cake shine without overwhelming your palate or effort.

name: Mushroom butter on toast
description: This make-ahead starter delivers all the flavour of mushrooms on toast without any last-minute frying
author: Good Food
ingredients: 30g pack dried porcinimushrooms, soaked, drained and finely chopped
small handful each parsleyand tarragon, finely chopped
toasted breadand salad leaves, to serve
directions: Melt 50g butter in a pan and gently fry the onion until softened. Add the garlic and thyme and fry for 1 min more. Tip in all the mushrooms and toss to coat in the butter. Cook on a high heat for 5-8 mins until soft. Pour over the brandy and lemon juice, then cook for 2-3 mins more or until all the liquid has evaporated. Turn off the heat, add the herbs and seasoning, then allow to cool.

Once cooled, remove the thyme. Mix the mushrooms with the remaining butter, then divide between 4 ramekins. Chill until firm, or for up to 2 days, then serve a ramekin, topped with a thyme sprig, between 2 to share with toasted bread and dressed salad leaves.
chief_review: This make-ahead mushroom starter is a delightful twist on the classic mushrooms on toast, delivering deep, umami-rich flavors with minimal last-minute effort. The combination of chestnut and porcini mushrooms, enhanced by aromatic herbs, creates a complex, earthy spread with well-balanced acidity from the splash of lemon. The use of butter adds luxurious creaminess, while brandy provides a subtle lift. This dish is ideally suited to vegetarian diets, making it an excellent choice for dinner parties where guests may have diverse dietary preferences. Serve atop freshly toasted bread with crisp salad leaves for a harmonious starter that highlights the best of mushroom cookery.

name: Sticky carrots with thyme & honey
description: Give your carrots some flavour with this easy idea using small Chantenay carrots and just three other ingredients
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1kg Chantenay carrots, unpeeled, larger ones halved
directions: Tip the carrots into a deep frying pan with the butter, thyme and honey. Cook for 5 mins until starting to brown. Pour in 250ml water, bring to the boil and cook until the water has evaporated and the carrots are tender. Turn down the heat and cook the carrots slowly, stirring, until glazed.
chief_review: This simple recipe elevates Chantenay carrots with the aromatics of fresh thyme and a subtle sweetness from honey, all brought together by the richness of butter. The technique allows the carrots’ natural flavour to shine, resulting in a side dish that is both vibrant and rustic. With only four ingredients, preparation is quick, making this dish an excellent addition to a weeknight meal or an elegant dinner. The use of honey and butter makes it suitable for vegetarians, but not for vegans or those with dairy allergies. For best results, aim to caramelise the carrots lightly to achieve a lovely texture with deep, earthy notes from the thyme. A beautifully balanced classic, this recipe celebrates the carrot at its best.

name: Fig & walnut slice
description: Looking for something new to go with your favourite cheese? This makes a perfect accompaniment, or a lovely gift
author: Good Food
ingredients: 250g dried figs, hard stalk removed, chopped
directions: Pulse the almonds in a food processor until most are finely chopped. Remove and transfer to a bowl. Whizz the figs until they form a sticky paste, then add this to the almonds with the remaining ingredients. Mix well, then shape into a sausage and allow to dry, uncovered, in the fridge or a cool, dry place for a week.
Wrap and tie in baking parchment if giving away, then slice and serve alongside your favourite cheeses. Will keep in a cool place for up to 2 months.
chief_review: This fig and nut accompaniment is a delightful addition to any cheese board, offering layers of sweet, nutty, and subtly spiced flavors. Toasted almonds and walnuts give satisfying crunch, which pairs well with the chewy dried figs and apricots. The hint of brandy and honey rounds out the mixture with a touch of warmth and sweetness, while a pinch of ground cloves adds fragrant complexity. This recipe is naturally gluten-free and suitable for vegetarians, making it accessible for a variety of guests. Serve alongside a selection of cheeses and crackers for an impressive appetizer or package it as a thoughtful homemade gift.

name: Gingerbread people
description: The sugar makes these rather dark and the muscovado flavour dominates. I'd recommend mixing half of the dark sugar with a lighter one and using more ginger or adding some stem ginger to the mix
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 350g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Melt the sugar, golden syrup and butter in a saucepan, then bubble for 1-2 mins. Leave to cool for about 10 mins.

Tip the flour, bicarbonate of soda and spices into a large bowl.  Add the warm syrup mixture and the egg, stir everything together, then gently knead in the bowl until smooth and streak-free. The dough will firm up once cooled. Wrap in cling film and chill for at least 30 mins.
Remove the dough from the fridge, leave at room temperature until softened. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line two baking trays with baking parchment.
Roll out the dough to the thickness of a £1 coin, then cut out gingerbread people with a cutter. Re-roll the excess dough and keep cutting until it’s all used up.

Lift the biscuits onto the trays and bake for 10-12 mins, swapping the trays over halfway through cooking. Leave to cool on the trays for 5 mins, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. Use the icing to decorate the biscuits as you wish, and stick on sweets for buttons. Leave to dry for 1-2 hrs. Will keep for up to three days in an airtight container.
chief_review: This recipe delivers cookies with a deep, rich flavor profile, courtesy of dark muscovado sugar, complemented by the warmth of ginger and cinnamon. The suggestion to lighten the sugar and boost the ginger is excellent—it will balance sweetness and emphasize those spicy notes. The dough is workable and yields a soft yet sturdy texture, ideal for decorating with writing icing and sweets. Since it contains wheat flour, dairy (butter), and egg, these cookies aren’t suitable for gluten-free, vegan, or dairy- and egg-free diets. However, they are perfect for vegetarians and make a delightful choice for festive gatherings or as a treat with tea. For a spicier kick, adding stem ginger is highly recommended. Overall, a classic, reliable bake that’s elevated by careful adjustments to sugar and spice.

name: Little almond cookies
description: These delicate snow-dusted Mexican cookies are rich, crumbly and melt in the mouth
author: Thomasina Miers
ingredients: 140g-175g plain flour, plus extra for rolling out
directions: Heat oven to 170C/150C fan/gas 3 and roast the almonds for 5-10 mins until they are a pale golden colour. Cream together the butter, sugar, rum and a pinch of salt, then add the flour until the dough just comes together – it will be soft. Roughly chop the almonds and add them to the dough. Carefully roll out the dough on a well-floured surface to a 4-5mm thickness and cut out small cookies roughly 3-4cm across. Freeze the cookies on a baking sheet for 20 mins to harden.

Bake the cookies in the oven for about 20 mins until just set – they will still be very pale. Lay out on a wire rack and dust icing sugar on both sides while they are still warm, being careful not to break them as you turn them. The icing sugar will melt. When they are cool, sprinkle them extremely generously with more icing sugar so that they are completely white. Store in an airtight container for up to 2 days, or freeze for up to 2 months.
chief_review: This recipe for Mexican cookies delivers a sublime texture—crumbly, buttery, and wonderfully rich, with the subtle crunch of ground whole almonds. The addition of dark rum gives a gentle warmth and depth, balancing the sweetness that blooms with the finishing dusting of icing sugar. These cookies are ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, as they contain no meat or animal-derived rennet. However, be mindful that they do include dairy (butter) and nuts (almonds), which may be allergens. The precise use of caster sugar and careful ratio of flour ensure a light, melt-in-the-mouth consistency. Perfect served with coffee or as a festive treat, these cookies highlight simple, quality ingredients with finesse.

name: Bacon, sausage & prune rolls
description: Securing these bites with a cocktail stick keeps everything together while cooking and makes them simple to serve
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the sausages in a bowl with the honey until all are well coated. Wrap each sausage and prune in a piece of bacon, then skewer with a cocktail stick. Put on a baking sheet and cook for 30 mins.
chief_review: This recipe presents a classic combination of sweet and savory flavors, featuring prunes and cocktail sausages wrapped in streaky bacon and glazed with honey. The use of cocktail sticks ensures the bites stay intact during cooking and makes for easy serving, perfect for parties or as an appetizer. The contrast between the sticky prunes, the honey’s caramelized sweetness, and the salty richness of bacon delivers a complex flavor profile in each bite. This recipe suits those who enjoy indulgent, crowd-pleasing snacks, though it’s worth noting the inclusion of both bacon and sausages, which means it is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. Additionally, only check the sausage and bacon ingredients for potential allergens or gluten if serving to guests with dietary restrictions. Overall, these bites are a sure-fire hit for any festive gathering, offering bold flavors and effortless presentation.

name: Baked ham with brown sugar & mustard glaze
description: Served hot or cold, this delicious cut of pork with a sugar glaze is best sliced into thick pieces
author: Good Food
ingredients: dark rye bread, sweet sliced pickles and bay leaves, to serve
directions: Place the raw ham in a large, clean bucket. Add enough water to cover and soak overnight, or up to 24 hrs ahead, changing the water twice.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Drain and place the ham in a large roasting tin, cover tightly with foil and bake for 3 hrs.

Remove the ham from the oven and turn the heat up to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.Using a sharp knife, carefully slice the rind off the ham, leaving about 1-2 cm of fat; cut a diamond-shaped pattern into this. In a small bowl, mix together the sugar and mustard, then rub all over the ham. Roast for 30 mins until the ham is tender and the outside nice and sticky.

Bring to the table on a large platter lined with bay leaves. To serve, cut 1cm-thick slices off the ham to go alongside the rye bread, pickles and mustard sauce (Make your own sauce with our recipe below).
chief_review: This glazed smoked ham recipe is a classic showstopper, ideal for festive gatherings or casual buffets. The combination of soft brown sugar and wholegrain mustard creates a rich, tangy-sweet crust that accentuates the juicy, smoky flavor of the bone-in ham. Serving suggestions of dark rye bread and sweet pickles provide a lovely contrast in both taste and texture. For those following a gluten-free diet, note that traditional rye bread contains gluten, but you can easily substitute with gluten-free bread without compromising the overall experience. The dish is also nut-free and dairy-free as presented, making it approachable for many guests with common food allergies. Whether served hot or cold, this ham is beautifully versatile and crowd-pleasing, elevating any occasion with minimal effort.

name: Sparkling lemon & amaretti ice
description: This decadent dessert with its creamy cheesecake flavour can be frozen complete with its topping, leaving you more time to spend with friends during the festive season
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: grated zest and juice of 2 lemons
directions: Line the base and sides of a 20cm cake tin with a round and two or three strips of plastic cut from two A4 clear plastic folders. Crush the amaretti biscuits fairly finely and mix into the melted butter, stirring well. Press into the base of the tin, smoothing with the back of a metal spoon.
Tip the cheese into a large bowl, beat briefly to soften, then beat in the sugar, lemon zest and juice. Whip the cream until it just holds its shape, then fold into the mixture.

Pour the lemon mixture into the tin and smooth the top. Freeze for 4 hours. For the topping, slice the lemons as thinly as possible. Put in a pan, cover with water and bring to the boil, reduce the heat and simmer for 20 minutes. Drain well.

Tip the sugar into a small pan and add 3 tbsp water. Heat gently to melt the sugar, then add the lemon slices, increase the heat and cook until the lemons are caramelised (about 4-5 minutes). Cool to room temperature, then arrange in overlapping circles over the top. Drizzle over any syrup, then return to the freezer. (Can be frozen for up to 2 months.)

Remove the dessert from the freezer 2-3 hours before serving, peel off the plastic and set on a serving plate. (Timing is not too critical, as it won’t collapse, just become softer.) Tuck it away in the fridge until you are ready to serve.
chief_review: This dessert masterfully balances the rich, creamy notes of ricotta with the bright acidity of lemons, delivering a cheesecake that’s as refreshing as it is indulgent. The amaretti biscuit base adds a delightful crunch and subtle almond essence, elevating the overall flavour profile. The preparation allows for freezing, making it an excellent make-ahead option for entertaining during the festive season. With no wheat flour in the crust, this recipe is well-suited for a gluten-free diet, provided you select certified gluten-free amaretti biscuits. It’s also a great fit for vegetarians, given the use of ricotta and absence of gelatin. The layering of citrus zing with creamy sweetness and biscuit crunch creates a memorable dessert experience—perfect for special occasions or a luxurious treat with friends.

name: Boozy chocolate bombes
description: Showstopping individual coffee sponges with hidden mousse, and a Baileys and white chocolate topping - stunning!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g white chocolate(use cheaper chocolate, it will melt better), broken into pieces
real or artificial holly, to decorate
2 tsp instant coffee, mixed with 1 tbsp boiling water
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter 6 x 150ml ovenproof pudding moulds and put a disc of baking parchment in the base of each.

To make the sponge, put the butter, chocolate and coffee in a bowl over a pan of simmering water. Gently heat until melted, add the vanilla and stir to combine. Set aside to cool a little. Sift the flour, cocoa and bicarb into another bowl, then scatter in the sugar, breaking up any clumps of sugar with your fingers. Mix the eggs and yogurt in a jug. Add the chocolate mixture and the egg mixture to the flour, and stir everything with a spatula until there are no visible lumps of flour. Divide the mixture between the 6 moulds, put on a baking tray and cook in the centre of the oven for 30 mins or until a skewer pushed into the cakes comes out clean. Leave to cool for 10 mins, then turn out onto a wire rack and cool completely. Can be made up to 5 days ahead, wrapped well in cling film and stored in a sealed container; or freeze for up to 6 weeks.

While the cakes cool, make the chocolate mousse. Melt the chocolate in a small bowl over a pan of simmering water. Leave to cool for 5 mins, then stir in the egg yolk. Whisk the egg white in another bowl until stiff, add the sugar and continue to whisk until glossy and thick. Pour the cream into a third bowl and lightly whisk until thick. Tip the cream into the chocolate and stir to combine. Add the beaten egg white and, using a metal spoon, fold together until there are no streaks of egg white remaining. Chill until needed.

Line each pudding mould with cling film. Remove the tops of the cakes with a small serrated knife to create a flat surface. Carefully split the cakes into 2 or 3 layers through their middles. Reassemble the cakes in the pudding moulds, soaking each layer of sponge with the liqueur and layering with chocolate mousse. Cover the cakes with any overhanging cling film and press down gently. Chill the cakes for at least 3 hrs or for up to 2 days before serving.

Melt the white chocolate in a small bowl over a pan of barely simmering water. Turn each cake out and unwrap. Drizzle the top of each with a little white chocolate, letting it drizzle down the sides. Decorate using a small sprig of real or artificial holly. Leave the white chocolate to set for 20 mins before serving.
chief_review: These individual coffee sponges deliver both visual drama and complex flavor, with a luscious hidden mousse core and a decadent Baileys-infused white chocolate topping. The pairing of rich dark chocolate with the subtle bitterness of coffee creates depth, while the Irish cream elevates the dessert to something undeniably festive. The texture contrast between moist sponge and silky mousse is delightful. This recipe is best suited to those without dietary restrictions, as it contains gluten, dairy, eggs, and alcohol. The addition of real or artificial holly garnishes makes each serving truly showstopping—perfect for impressing guests at a special gathering. The method rewards those willing to give a little extra care to their baking; the result is a sophisticated, bakery-quality dessert with layers of flavor and a presentation sure to be remembered.

name: Chilli-charred Brussels sprouts
description: Far too much chilli in this recipe. Try 1/2 or even 1/4 tsp of chilli flakes if you want to be able to taste the other flavours.
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 600g Brussels sprouts, trimmed at the base
directions: Bring a pan of salted water to the boil. Add the Brussels sprouts and cook for 4-5 mins until just tender, then drain and leave to cool a little before slicing in half vertically.

Meanwhile, heat 3 tbsp olive oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat, add the garlic and cook until golden but not burnt, around 4 mins. Use a slotted spoon to remove the garlic and discard. Add the chilli flakes and a big pinch of salt to the oil, then put the sprouts cut-side down in the pan, and leave them to cook for around 10 mins. Don’t be tempted to move them – this ensures that they get some colour. Add the remaining olive oil and the lemon juice, then cook for a few mins more.
Tip onto a large serving platter, top with lemon zest and season. These will hold in a low oven for 20 mins while you get everything else ready.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts recipe boldly leans into heat, but the suggestion to reduce the chilli flakes is well-advised—the smaller quantities allow the nutty, earthy sprouts and aromatic garlic to truly shine, balanced beautifully by the brightness from lemon zest and juice. The roasting method delivers a crisp exterior and tender bite, complemented by the olive oil’s richness. This dish is naturally vegan, gluten-free, and suitable for those avoiding common allergens like dairy, eggs, and nuts. Its straightforward preparation makes it accessible, while the lively interplay of flavours ensures it stands out as a side or main for plant-based gatherings. A smart, simple update to the classic roasted sprout.

name: All-the-trimmings traybake
description: I love the idea of this recipe but my biggest mistake was to stick to it exactly! Even though I used a lower than suggested oven temperature, the onions and sprouts became somewhat burnt! As well as reducing the cooking time for many of the ingredients, next time I would use more olive oil, as the mix with the chutney was not runny enough - everything seemed to stick! Nevertheless, whilst not looking great, the end product was quite tasty.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 2 small red onions, cut into wedges
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Mix the oil and chutney together and season well. Divide everything except the sausages and herbs between two large roasting tins, pour over the oil and chutney mixture and toss together. Put both trays in the oven for 25 mins.

Add the sausages and herbs to the trays and bake, stirring halfway through, for 30-35 mins more or until the vegetables are soft and the sausages are cooked through. If one tray is browning more than the other, swap them round.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a flavorful and hearty traybake perfect for a comforting meal, showcasing root vegetables elevated by caramelised onion chutney and fresh herbs. The inclusion of parsnips, carrots, potatoes, sprouts, and red onions brings robust autumnal notes. The olive oil and chutney mixture add sweetness and depth, but care must be taken with oven temperature and time to prevent burning and ensure the veggies remain tender. Increasing the olive oil and reducing the cooking time—as suggested—will create better caramelisation and cohesion. The wrapped cocktail sausages contribute a traditional savory punch, making the dish especially suited for those enjoying festive or family-style meals. Notably, this recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the presence of bacon-wrapped sausages. Additionally, it is not gluten-free, as some commercial cocktail sausages and chutneys may contain gluten; always check ingredient labels if required.

name: Mulled wine
description: Needed something to keep the cold out and this did the trick. Enjoyed the addition of sloe gin.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 large cinnamon stick, or 2 small ones
2 strips lemonzest, pared using a vegetable peeler
directions: Put the red wine, cinnamon, star anise, cloves, lemon zest and sugar in a large pan. Cook on a low heat for 10 mins.
Remove from the heat and cool, leaving to infuse for about 30 mins.
To serve, heat without boiling, stir in the sloe gin (if using) and pour into mugs or heatproof glasses.
chief_review: This mulled wine recipe is a classic winter warmer, beautifully enhanced by the inclusion of sloe gin, which adds depth and a subtle fruity note to the spiced red wine base. The infusion of cinnamon, star anise, and cloves provides a comforting, aromatic character, balanced with the citrus brightness of lemon zest. The measured sweetness from caster sugar harmonizes perfectly with the spices rather than overpowering them. This recipe is suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets, as it contains no animal products. It’s also nut-free, which is beneficial for those managing nut allergies. Serve this aromatic mulled wine at holiday gatherings or cozy evenings in; it’s a delightful way to keep the cold at bay.

name: Bramley & walnut chutney
description: Studded with walnuts and stem ginger, this pickle is delicious on a cheeseboard or with cold meats, plus it makes a great gift
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1.6kg Bramley apple, peeled, cored and chopped
500g eating apple, peeled, cored and sliced
1 large red chilli, deseeded and chopped
directions: Tip all the ingredients, except the walnuts, into a preserving pan. Warm over a low heat, stirring occasionally, until the sugar dissolves. Turn up the heat a little, then let the mixture boil until the Bramley apples have broken down to a pulp, but the eating apples still hold their shape. This can take from 45 mins to 1 hr. You can tell that it is ready by running your wooden spoon through the mixture. Your spoon should briefly leave a channel in the mixture, and there shouldn’t be liquid pooling into the space.
Meanwhile, tip the walnuts into a small pan and cook over a low heat until they are lightly toasted, stirring frequently to ensure that they don’t burn. Sterilise your jars.
When the chutney is ready, stir in the walnuts and cook briefly, then pot the mixture into the jars. Will keep for at least a year.
chief_review: This vibrant apple, walnut, and stem ginger pickle offers a delightful balance of sweet, tangy, and warmly spiced flavors. The use of Bramley and eating apples ensures both a soft texture and nuanced taste, while walnuts contribute a satisfying crunch. Stem ginger and cinnamon add aromatic depth, complemented by pops of heat from red chilli. The cider vinegar provides a lively acidity, making this pickle an excellent companion for strong cheeses or charcuterie. Ideal for gifting, its ingredient list is free from animal products, making it suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets. Additionally, the absence of wheat or gluten-containing products means it’s naturally gluten free. An impressive homemade addition to festive spreads or food hampers.

name: Golden-glazed carrot, mushroom & hazelnut tart
description: This looks good
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 carrots, peeled and cut in half lengthways, or about 10 baby carrots left whole
15 x 12cm rectangle of all-butter puff pastryfrom a 320g roll
1 banana shallotor 2 normal shallots, very finely diced
1 tbsp chopped roasted hazelnut, plus a little extra to garnish
a few tarragonleaves, chopped, plus a few leaves to garnish
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Pop the carrots in a pan of boiling water and cook for 4-5 mins until tender. Spread the carrots out in one layer on a baking tray. Carefully toss with olive oil, seasoning and half the maple syrup. Bake for 20 mins, turning once.
Next, place the pastry rectangle on a baking parchment-lined baking sheet. Score a 1cm border. Prick the centre area with a fork and put in the oven for 12 mins with the carrots.

Fry the shallot in butter until totally soft, then stir through the mushrooms. Fry for several mins until mushrooms are tender and the mixture is dry. Spread out on a plate to cool. Whizz a third of the mushroom mixture with the nuts, cream cheese, tarragon and seasoning, so you have a coarse texture. Tip into a bowl and stir through the remaining mushroom mix.

Remove the pastry base from the oven and gently press down the centre area with the back of a spoon. Spread the mushroom mix inside and lay the glazed carrots on top. You may need to tuck the ends round to fit the carrots in. Drizzle over the remaining maple syrup and bake for a further 12-15 mins until the pastry is golden. Sprinkle with a few tarragon leaves and some more chopped nuts to serve.
chief_review: This recipe presents a delightful balance of flavors and textures, pairing the natural sweetness of carrots and maple syrup with earthy chestnut mushrooms and roasted hazelnuts. The all-butter puff pastry yields a beautifully crisp base, while the addition of shallots and tarragon infuses aromatic notes fitting for a refined starter or light main course. The use of low-fat cream cheese ensures a creamy richness without overwhelming the dish. This recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish. The hazelnuts add a satisfying crunch, though those with nut allergies should take note. Overall, it's a well-executed and creative dish, ideal for a dinner party or a special lunch.

name: Roasted root vegetables
description: Root veg is a must with Sunday lunch and Christmas dinner, and this easy recipe is low-fat, superhealthy and high in fibre to boot
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 celeriac, peeled and cut into 2cm cubes
½ a swede, peeled, cut into 2cm cubes
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss all the veg with the oil and garlic in a large roasting tin, then roast for 40 mins until starting to soften and turn golden. Remove the tin from the oven, drizzle the veg with honey and return to the oven for 10-20 mins more until golden.
chief_review: This root vegetable medley is a celebration of earthy flavors and vibrant colors, ideal for a festive Sunday lunch or Christmas dinner. The combination of carrots, parsnips, celeriac, and swede creates a delightful harmony of sweet and nutty notes, while roasting elevates their natural sugars and adds a lovely caramelized finish. The use of olive oil keeps the dish heart-healthy and low in saturated fat, and the addition of garlic infuses a subtle aromatic depth. A drizzle of clear honey rounds off the vegetables with just the right touch of sweetness, without overwhelming the palate. This recipe is naturally gluten-free and vegetarian, making it an excellent choice for those with specific dietary preferences. Additionally, it's high in fibre and suitable for a low-fat diet. A simple yet elegant side dish that suits both everyday and special occasions.

name: Stollen buns
description: These sticky buns really capture the taste of Christmas and are great for sharing with friends and neighbours
author: Good Food
ingredients: 50g icing sugar, plus more to dust
directions: Put the first 5 ingredients into a large bowl and mix. Rub in the butter. Or you can do this in a food processor. Put 200ml milk, treacle and brandy into a pan and warm until the treacle melts. Stir well.

Beat one of the eggs and the oil into the liquid, then add the whole lot to the dry ingredients and mix to a smooth dough. Let it sit for 10 mins, then knead for 1 min on a lightly floured surface until smooth and springy. Put into an oiled bowl, cover with oiled cling film and leave to rise in a warm place until doubled in size. Leave it overnight in the fridge instead if you have time – bring the dough back up to room temperature before step 3.

Lightly flour the work surface. Tip the dough from its bowl and press out into a rectangle about A4 size. Scatter over the fruit and zest, knead in until even, then roll out the dough to a rectangle approximately 50 x 15cm. Squash the marzipan into a cylinder, then roll into a thick sausage the same length as the dough. Sit it in the middle of the dough, wet the dough a little around the edges and roll it around the marzipan.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line 3 baking sheets with baking parchment. Dip a large sharp knife into some flour and slice into 14 rounds, discarding the very end bits. Flatten each bun and its marzipan middle a little with your hand. You can freeze them at this stage. Put onto the sheets well spaced, then cover with oiled cling film and leave to rise until about half their size again. Beat the second egg with 1 tbsp milk and brush it all over the buns. Sprinkle with almonds.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and bake for 15 mins or until risen and golden. After a few mins cooling, lift onto a cooling rack. Melt the icing sugar with 4 tbsp just-boiled water, then brush the syrup all over the buns – be generous with it. Dust with a little more sugar to serve. Best eaten within 48 hrs.
chief_review: These festive sticky buns are a masterful showcase of holiday flavors—mixed spice, orange and lemon zest, sultanas, raisins, and a hint of brandy create a beautifully aromatic dough, while the marzipan swirl and glacé cherries give every bite an indulgent texture and sweetness. The addition of flaked almonds adds a satisfying crunch to contrast the soft crumb. These buns are suitable for vegetarians, as they contain no meat or gelatin. However, they do include dairy, eggs, wheat (gluten), and nuts, so be mindful for those with allergies. Their rich, spiced aroma and inviting appearance make them perfect for sharing at festive gatherings. Serve warm, dusted with a touch of icing sugar, for a truly celebratory treat that’s as delightful with coffee as it is with mulled wine.

name: Rosemary & garlic roast potatoes with chipolatas
description: Give your roasties a little style and originality with rosemary, garlic and chipolatas
author: Good Food
