ingredients: 2kg King Edward potatoes, cut into large pieces
1 bulb garlic, separated into unpeeled cloves
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Put the potatoes in a pan of cold water, bring to the boil and simmer for 5 mins. Meanwhile, put the butter and oil into a large, shallow roasting tray and heat in the oven. Drain the potatoes in a colander, giving them a good shake to fluff the edges up a little. Toss in the hot oil in the tray and roast for 20 mins.
Add the garlic, rosemary and chipolatas to the tray, toss well together and roast for a further 50 mins until the potatoes are crunchy and golden brown and the sausages are cooked through.
chief_review: This recipe elevates traditional roast potatoes with the aromatic pairing of garlic and rosemary, while the addition of pork chipolatas turns a simple side into an indulgent centerpiece. The use of King Edward potatoes ensures a fluffy interior and crispy exterior, especially when combined with butter and olive oil. Roasting whole, unpeeled garlic cloves imparts a mellow sweetness that balances the bold, savory notes of rosemary and sausage. It's a hearty, satisfying dish—ideal for festive occasions or Sunday lunches. This recipe is best suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as all the ingredients listed are naturally gluten free (ensure the chipolatas are certified gluten-free). The rustic simplicity and depth of flavor will please both home cooks and guests alike.

name: Pickled onions
description: Preserved shallots in malt vinegar make a classic condiment that will never get old. Beautiful with cheese and cold meats
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Place the onions in a large heatproof bowl and pour over boiling water to cover. Leave to cool. Once cool, trim roots and tops and peel. Sprinkle the salt over the peeled onions, stir and leave overnight.
Next day rinse the onions well and dry with kitchen towel. Place the vinegar and honey into a large pan and gently heat just to dissolve the honey into the vinegar, but do not boil.

Pack the onions into clean, sterilized jars. Pour over the hot vinegar mixture to fill the jars, and check there are no air pockets. Seal the jars and leave to cool. The onions will be ready to eat after about 1 month or better if kept for 2. Once opened store in the fridge.
chief_review: This preserved shallots recipe offers a delightful balance of sweet and sharp flavors, thanks to the clear honey and malt vinegar. The shallots are gently pickled, resulting in a classic condiment that brings vibrancy to cheese boards and charcuterie alike. The use of honey gives these pickles a nuanced sweetness that complements stronger cheeses and cold meats beautifully. With no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and those following a gluten-free diet, provided the malt vinegar used is confirmed gluten free. The method is straightforward, yielding a homemade preserve far superior to most store-bought versions. Serve these shallots alongside mature cheddar, pâtés, or even in salads to add depth and interest. A timeless recipe, perfect for those who enjoy elevating their table with well-crafted, flavourful condiments.

name: Roast potato, turkey, sausage & stuffing pie
description: Made this on Boxing Day and so tasty! I did add all the leftover veg as well. Really satisfying
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 6 sausagesor 8 chipolatas (leftover pigs in blankets are fine too)
directions: Heat the oil and butter in a large, shallow ovenproof casserole dish. Add the onion and cook for 10 mins until really soft. Push the onion to one side of the dish and add the sausages, browning them all over (skip this step if you’re using cooked leftovers).

Remove the sausages from the dish and set aside to cool a little. Stir the mustard powder, flour and stock cube into the oil and butter for 1-2 mins, then add the white wine. Bubble for 1 min, scraping the bottom of the dish to release any tasty bits, then add the stock. Stir to make a smooth sauce, season and bubble for 5 mins. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

Cut the sausages and stuffing into bite-sized chunks, add to the sauce with the turkey, mustard, crème fraîche and parsley. When bubbling, remove from the heat. Crumble the potatoes in your hands over the top of the filling, so you have some larger and smaller chunks. Scatter with cheese and bake for 40 mins until the potatoes are crisp and the filling is bubbling around the edges.
chief_review: This recipe is a fantastic way to transform Boxing Day leftovers into a comforting, flavor-packed dish. The use of leftover turkey, sausages, stuffing, and roast potatoes captures all the essence of a festive meal, elevated by the depth of wholegrain mustard and fresh parsley. The addition of low-fat crème fraîche creates a luscious, creamy sauce without making it overly rich, and the touch of mature cheddar adds a golden finish. The flexibility to incorporate any leftover vegetables makes it an ideal option for reducing food waste. This dish is not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or those seeking gluten-free or dairy-free options due to the sausages, turkey, flour, butter, and cheese. It’s a true celebration of classic British comfort food, perfect for sharing with family and friends during the holidays.

name: Serrano-wrapped pear with goat’s cheese
description: These canapés look fancy, but are incredibly easy to assemble, and look lovely as part of a sharing platter or party nibble
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: a small log (125g) of goat's cheese(you won't use it all)
½ a packet of rocket leaf
directions: Tear 6 slices of Serrano ham in half. Core a pear and cut into 12 slices. Place a piece of pear at the bottom of the ham slice. Add a 3cm piece of goat's cheese and a few rocket leaves. Roll up and secure with a cocktail stick.
chief_review: This canapé recipe delivers an elegant combination of flavors—salty Serrano ham, sweet pear, creamy goat's cheese, and peppery rocket. The ingredients balance beautifully, resulting in a sophisticated bite that's as pleasing to the eye as the palate. The recipe cleverly uses minimal ingredients to achieve maximum impact, making it perfect for entertaining. Its assembly is simple, making it accessible for all skill levels, yet the presentation remains refined. This dish is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, assuming care is taken with any accompaniments. The absence of nuts makes it friendly for guests with nut allergies, though always verify the goat's cheese is nut-free. Overall, this is an impressive and versatile addition to any sharing platter or cocktail party.

name: Baked camembert pie for sharing
description: This is amazing! Easiest thing to make so you can't possibly go wrong, and all the guests loved it! I use different jellies every time - crabapple, cranberry, quince, redcurrant, blackcurrant - anything works. Served it with new potatoes and salad for a light main dinner course too.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 5 tbsp quincejelly, or cranberry sauce or jelly
250g whole round camembert, brie or other similar whole cheese
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Halve the pastry, then roll out each half on a lightly floured surface to about the thickness of a £1 coin. In the centre of 1 pastry sheet, spread the jelly into a circle roughly the same size as the cheese. Sit the cheese on top.

Brush the pastry around the cheese with some beaten egg. Lift the second sheet of pastry on top and gently press over the cheese, squeezing out the air as you go, then seal it all the way around – press down with your fingers over all the excess pastry to seal really well. Use scissors to cut away excess pastry, leaving about a 4cm border around the cheese. Use the prongs of a fork to press the edges – this looks pretty and seals the pastry even more. Lift onto a baking tray lined with baking parchment. Brush all over with egg, then add a sesame-seed star, if you like.

Bake for 20-25 mins until the pastry is brown, crisp and well risen around the edges – if your star is getting too dark, cover with a square of foil after 20 mins. Sit for 5 mins before cutting and catching the cheesy centre as it oozes out.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful showstopper—warm, gooey cheese encased in flaky, buttery puff pastry with a touch of sweet, fruity jelly. The choice of jelly adds a beautiful flexibility, complementing the creamy camembert or brie with a bright, tangy note. It’s straightforward to assemble, making it a perfect centerpiece for both casual gatherings and more formal affairs. For vegetarians, this dish is an excellent choice, provided the cheese is made with vegetarian rennet. The crispy pastry, melty cheese, and jewel-like jelly create a harmonious flavor and texture combination. Serve with new potatoes and salad for a fresh, balanced meal.

name: Pecan tassies
description: These are a favourite with American families and make a great alternative to mince pies
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 50g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. To make the pastry, whizz the pecans in a food processor until finely ground, then pulse in the remaining ingredients with a pinch of salt until the dough just comes together. Lightly flour your hands to prevent sticking, then roll the dough into 12 small balls. Use your fingers to gently press them into the bottom and up the sides of a 12-hole mini muffin tin. Chill in the fridge while you make the filling.

Toast the pecans in a dry frying pan for 3-5 mins until lightly toasted and smelling aromatic. Cool a little, reserve 12 of them, then roughly chop the rest. Whisk the remaining ingredients with a pinch of salt, then stir in the chopped pecans.

Bake the pastry cases for 5 mins, then remove from the oven. If the pastry has puffed up a little, gently press it down with a teaspoon or your fingers. Spoon 1-2 tsps of the filling into each of the pastry cases, then top each with a whole pecan. Bake for 15-20 mins or until the crust turns golden and the filling is set. Leave to cool a little in the tin. Eat warm on their own, or with some cream whipped up with maple syrup.
chief_review:
This recipe yields a delightful variation on traditional holiday treats, perfect for those seeking an alternative to mince pies. The rich combination of buttery pastry and pecans offers a satisfyingly nutty flavor, and the hint of maple syrup lends an irresistible sweetness. The use of soft cheese in the pastry adds a pleasing slight tang and a tender texture. 

Notably, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin. However, it includes dairy, eggs, wheat flour, and nuts, so it's important for hosts to be mindful of guests with allergies. The straightforward ingredient list and simple method make these treats accessible to bakers of all skill levels. Serve warmed with a dusting of icing sugar for a truly festive finish.

name: All-in-one roast bubble & squeak
description: Fab recipe, I make it every Christmas to feed a crowd. It goes well with a turkey and cranberry pie. Easy to make and stress free. There's never much leftover but if there is this year I might try it with a fried egg! Thanks for the idea Kimkap.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1¼kg/2lb 12oz floury potatoes, peeled and cut into 3cm chunks
200g lardons or smoked bacon, cut into pieces
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Bring a pan of water to the boil, then tip in the potatoes. Cook for 4-5 mins, drain well, then return to the pan. Put on the lid and shake a couple times.
Set a heavy-bottomed roasting tin on the hob over a medium heat and add the oil. When it’s really hot, add the potatoes and fry for a few mins.
Add the bacon and sprouts, mix everything together, then put in the oven and bake for 30 mins until the bacon is crisp and the sprouts are tender.
chief_review: This hearty holiday recipe is a classic crowd-pleaser, perfect for festive gatherings thanks to its simple execution and satisfying flavors. The combination of floury potatoes, crispy lardons or smoked bacon, and Brussels sprouts brings together comforting textures and a savory depth that pairs beautifully with Christmas mains like turkey and cranberry pie. The use of rapeseed oil keeps the dish light, while the bacon adds a smoky richness. It's stress-free to prepare in large batches and versatile enough for leftovers—try it topped with a fried egg for a delicious breakfast twist. The recipe is suitable for gluten-free diets, provided all ingredients (especially bacon) are certified gluten-free, making it a great option for gatherings with diverse dietary needs. A reliable, adaptable side dish for any festive table.

name: Honey-roasted duck with creamed cauliflower
description: If you're making Christmas lunch or dinner for a small group of people, Curtis Stone's duck is just right – it's full of flavour and so much easier to cook than a big bird
author: Curtis Stone
ingredients: 1 head cauliflower, broken into small florets
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Dry the duck with kitchen paper and liberally season all over with coarse salt. Put the thyme and bay leaves inside the cavity, then place the duck on a rack over a roasting tray.

Cook for 10 mins or until the skin begins to turn golden, then reduce the heat to 180C/fan 160C/ gas 4. Cook for a further 45 mins, basting the bird with honey every 5 mins or so for the final 20 mins of cooking. Your bird will now be roasted to medium – cook 10 mins more, if you like your duck well done. Set aside to rest, uncovered, for 10 mins.

Meanwhile, make the creamed cauliflower. In a pan, cook the caulifl ower and shallots in the butter over a low heat for 20 mins until softened and any liquid has evaporated. Spoon into a liquidiser with the cream and whizz to a purée. Season and keep warm.
For the garlic crisps, thinly slice the garlic cloves using a really sharp knife or a mandolin. Place the slices in a pan along with the milk and slowly bring to the boil.

Remove from the heat and strain the garlic slices, discarding the milk (or save it for mashed potato). Leave the garlic to drain on kitchen paper. Cover the bottom of a frying pan with the oil and heat. Fry the slices, a couple at a time, until golden and crisp, then remove with a slotted spoon.
To serve, carve the duck and serve alongside the creamed caulifl ower and sprigs of watercress, sprinkled with the crisp garlic slices.
chief_review: Curtis Stone’s duck recipe is a delightful choice for an intimate Christmas gathering, showcasing tender, flavourful meat elevated by aromatic thyme, bay leaves, and a luscious honey glaze. The bed of fresh watercress provides a peppery balance, while the creamy cauliflower purée offers a luxurious, silky accompaniment. The inclusion of double cream and butter in the purée adds richness and depth, perfectly complementing the savoury notes of the duck. Garlic and shallots deepen the flavour profile, rounding out this elegant yet approachable dish. The recipe is naturally gluten free, making it suitable for guests with gluten sensitivities. Overall, this dish combines festive indulgence with thoughtful technique, ensuring an impressive centrepiece for your holiday table.

name: Plum pudding
description: A traditional, long-life Christmas plum pudding that's deliciously dark, rich and fruity
author: Jeni Wright
ingredients: finely grated zest and juice of 1 small orange
finely grated zest and juice of 1 small lemon
directions: Stir the flour, spice, suet, breadcrumbs and sugar in a large bowl. Tip in the fruit, peel, cherries (if using) and carrot, then stir well to mix. Add the remaining ingredients and beat until thoroughly combined.

Spoon the mixture into a buttered 1.2 litre pudding bowl (with a buttered disc of greaseproof paper in the bottom) and press down well, leaving room for the pudding to rise a little during steaming. Cover with a circle of buttered greaseproof paper, then cover with pudding cloth or foil and tie securely with string.
Stand the bowl on an upturned saucer in a saucepan and half fill with boiling water. Cover tightly and steam for 8 hours, topping up the water as necessary. Leave to cool in the pan.

Remove the pudding from the pan and discard the cloth or foil and paper. Then cover with fresh greaseproof paper and cloth. Store your pudding in a cool, dry place until required - you can feed it with a few tablespoons of brandy once in a while. Before serving, steam again for 2-3 hours.
chief_review: This traditional Christmas plum pudding is a classic festive centerpiece, boasting a beautifully dark, rich, and deeply fruity flavor profile. The combination of dried fruits, mixed spice, and muscovado sugar delivers a complex sweetness, while the addition of black treacle and stout introduces delightful depth and subtle bitterness for balance. The inclusion of both citrus and grated carrot creates a nuanced, moist texture. The use of suet and eggs, along with self-raising flour and fresh breadcrumbs, makes this pudding unsuitable for vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free diets, as well as those with egg, dairy, or wheat sensitivities. Feeding the pudding with brandy not only develops mature flavors but also ensures its celebrated long-life quality, enhancing the experience for weeks to come. This recipe excels as a nostalgic, luxurious dessert, perfect for sharing during the holiday season.

name: Lime & coconut dhal
description: A vegetarian dip with a fresh zesty flavour, your party guests will hover around this one
author: Good Food
ingredients: zest of 1 lime, plus a squeeze of juice
handful chopped coriander, plus extra to serve
2 warmed naan bread, cut into fingers
directions: Heat the curry paste in a pan for 1 min. Pour in the coconut cream and stir to combine. Add the lime zest, brown sugar and lentils. Bring to a simmer and cook for 10 mins, adding a squeeze of lime juice and seasoning. Stir through a handful chopped coriander and serve with warmed naan breads. Sprinkle extra coriander on the dhal if you like. Great warm or at room temperature.
chief_review: This vibrant vegetarian dip masterfully balances the warmth of mild curry paste with the fresh zing of lime and the creamy texture of coconut cream. The lentils provide a wholesome, protein-rich base while the brown sugar adds a subtle hint of sweetness, complementing the aromatic coriander garnish. Served with toasted naan fingers, it’s an inviting and crowd-pleasing option for gatherings. The recipe is entirely plant-based, making it ideal for both vegetarians and vegans. Additionally, with no nuts or common allergens in sight (except possibly gluten in naan), it suits many dietary needs, though gluten-free options can be considered for the bread. This dip’s bold, fresh flavors and creamy-smooth texture are sure to become a centerpiece at any party table.

name: Mini sage & onion scones
description: These mini savoury scones are quick to make and are cute canapés for your Christmas party
author: Good Food
ingredients: 225g self-raising flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Heat the oil in a pan and cook the onion for 5 mins until soft, then set aside to cool. In a food processor, pulse the flour and butter together until the mixture looks like crumbs, then add the sage, cooled onion and enough milk to make a soft but not sticky dough. Tip out onto a floured surface, knead briefly, then roll out to 1cm thickness. Using a 1.5cm cutter, stamp out mini scones. Brush tops with egg, put onto a baking sheet and bake for 8-10 mins until risen and golden.
To serve, split the scones, spread each side with cranberry sauce, then sandwich together with the turkey.
chief_review: These mini savoury scones bring festive flair to any party platter. The combination of buttery, herb-infused scones layered with cranberry sauce and turkey creates a delightful balance of savoury and sweet. The addition of sage lifts the flavour profile, complementing the classic Christmas notes. The use of self-raising flour and a light touch with butter ensures a soft crumb, while a brush of egg gives the scones a lovely sheen. These make excellent finger food for those who include poultry in their diet. However, be aware that this recipe contains gluten (from flour), dairy (from butter and milk), and eggs, so it is not suitable for those with related allergies or dietary restrictions. Overall, these festive mini scones are a charming and flavour-packed canapé for holiday gatherings.

name: Hot chocolate stirrers
description: Brilliant! I topped mine with chocolate buttons and mini marshmallows. I didn't need to bother with the fiddly cupcase idea to keep the lolly sticks upright - they stood in the chocolate just fine and I put them all on a little tray in the fridge to set. Lovely as little gifts for neighbours and they would make fab little 'teacher presents' for younger children to make themselves.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 300g dark, milk or white chocolate(or a mixture), broken into squares
selection of chocolate buttons, hundreds and thousands, mini fudge pieces or chopped peppermint candy canes
directions: Push a small hole in the middle of the cupcake cases with a pencil and put aside for later.
Dip the pastry brush in the sunflower oil and paint a very thin layer of oil over the insides of the fromage frais pots.

Put the chocolate in a bowl and heat in the microwave in 30-sec bursts until runny, stirring after each blast. Or melt it in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of simmering water (get an adult to help you). If you’re using different types of chocolate, you should melt them separately.
Carefully pour the melted chocolate into the pots. Put a lolly stick in the middle of each and sprinkle your chosen decorations around it.
Sit a cake case on top of each pot so that it covers the chocolate and the stick pokes through the hole. Put them in the fridge to set overnight.
The next day, carefully pull the chocolates out of the pots and throw away the paper cases. Wrap each in cellophane tied with string and write a tag to read: ‘Simply stir into hot milk.’
chief_review:
This delightful recipe offers a creative way to make personalized chocolate treats, perfect for gifting or as hands-on activities for children. The process is simplified by letting the chocolate lollies set directly on a tray, making it accessible even for novice cooks. Using a mix of dark, milk, or white chocolate allows for flavor variety and customization, while the array of toppings—from chocolate buttons to peppermint candy canes—adds visual interest and texture. 

The basic recipe is naturally gluten-free, provided that all toppings (including hundreds and thousands and mini fudge pieces) are verified gluten-free. It's also suitable for a vegetarian diet, assuming the marshmallows do not contain gelatin derived from animals. For dairy-free or vegan adaptations, simply opt for vegan chocolate, plant-based toppings, and vegan marshmallows. Altogether, a fun and flexible treat perfect for special occasions or handmade gifts.

name: Snowman friends cake decoration
description: Icing and decorating a Christmas cake may take time but this sweet snowy scene will be a hit with kids
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 100g sifted icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
blue, brown, orange and green food colouring
directions: ICE THE CAKE: Melt the apricot jam, then sieve and brush a little all over a 23cm cake (see Apricot & almond fruitcake recipe to the right of this recipe). On a clean surface lightly dusted with a little sifted icing sugar, roll out the marzipan to a circle large enough to cover the cake – use a piece of kitchen string to help you check. Lift up the marzipan by hanging it over your rolling pin, then drape over the cake. Gently pat and smooth the marzipan down the sides of the cake, then trim any excess from the bottom.

Colour the regal icing with a little blue food colouring, then cover the marzipan using the same directions as you covered the cake, firstly brushing the marzipan with more apricot jam. Trim the base.

ADD SOME SNOW: Use your hands to roll two-thirds of the remaining regal icing into a long, thin sausage on an icing sugar-dusted surface. It should be long enough to go round the cake – use a piece of kitchen string to help you measure it. Use a rolling pin to roll the sausage into a strip about 5cm wide. Use a small, sharp knife to straighten one edge, and trim the other into a wiggly edge.

Keep all the trimmings, and squash half into 2 wobbly circles for the snowmen to sit on. Brush the strip, circles and the very bottom edge of the cake with a little runny icing made with 100g sifted icing sugar and a splash of water. Scatter the desiccated coconut over the strip and circles, gently pressing to stick and cover. Starting with one end of the strip, stick it round the base of the cake. This can be a bit fiddly, so if you’re nervous, simply halve the icing from the start and do in 2 half-length strips, using a little more coconut to hide the joins on the cake.

SHAPE THE SNOWMEN: Roll the remaining third of regal icing into 2 large balls, 2 medium balls and 2 small balls. Stick together, squashing slightly, into 2 snowmen. Brush 4 cocktail sticks with a little brown food colouring and stick into the snowmen for arms.

ADD BUTTONS AND NOSES: Push a few whole cloves into one snowman as buttons. Use a little orange food colouring to dye a little of the strip trimmings, and shape a little around the pointy end of 2 cloves to look like carrot noses. Use another clove to make little holes where the noses will go, dab a bit of runny icing into the holes and stick on the noses, pushing them into the holes to help hold them.

SMILEY FACES: Use a black or brown writing icing pen to dot on smiley mouths and eyes – I find it helps to mark tiny holes with the end of a cocktail stick first. It stops you making mistakes and helps the icing stay in place.

MAKE THE HAT: Dye another lump of regal icing trimmings with food colouring (we used green). Shape most into a woolly hat shape, pressing a slight dip into the bottom with your thumb where it will sit on the snowman’s head. Roll a little ball to stick on top of the hat; attach it with more runny icing. Then roll and cut a thin strip to stick round the base of the hat. Use a cocktail stick to make markings like a woolly hat and rough up the ball on top. A little more runny icing will help it stick onto your snowman’s head.

AND LASTLY, THE SCARF: Knot the strawberry laces together at one end. Tightly plait a 10cm length and knot at the end again. Using scissors, snip the ends, leaving about 1cm for tassels after the knot, then wrap around the neck of the other snowman. Sit the wobbly snowy islands on top of the cake and a snowman on each one.
chief_review: This festive Christmas cake decorating recipe is a delightful and creative project, perfect for baking with children. The combination of marzipan and regal icing creates a smooth, professional finish, while desiccated coconut offers a convincing snowy effect. The use of food colouring allows for vibrant, playful details and adds to the whimsical charm. The apricot jam adds shine and helps the marzipan adhere to the cake, ensuring a polished look and subtle flavour. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and does not contain animal-derived ingredients, making it a wonderful choice for meat-free celebrations. Be aware of the presence of tree nuts (marzipan contains almonds) and gluten, depending on the cake base used. Overall, this decorating method is a fun, festive way to engage children and impress guests with your holiday baking skills.

name: Mashed parsnip & sprout colcannon
description: This is a delicious accompaniment to Christmas dinner, but is also a great way to use up those leftover cooked sprouts
author: Good Food
directions: Chop the parsnips into large chunks. Boil for 15 mins or until really soft, then use a slotted spoon to drain into a colander. Blanch the sprouts in the same pan.
In a bowl, mash the parsnips with the butter and milk, then stir through the sprouts and spring onions. Serve with a knob more butter.
chief_review: This festive side dish cleverly combines the earthy sweetness of parsnips with the mild bitterness of Brussels sprouts, creating a mash that’s both comforting and vibrant. The addition of butter and milk lends a creamy texture, while spring onions provide a fresh, subtle crunch that lifts the overall flavor profile. It’s a wonderful choice for those following a vegetarian diet, and can easily be adapted for lacto-vegetarians. The recipe is practical for holiday gatherings or as an inventive way to repurpose leftover sprouts, ensuring minimal kitchen waste. Overall, this dish is hearty, flavorful, and a pleasing complement to any festive or everyday meal.

name: Smoked salmon with lentil salad
description: A simply stylish salad that will make an impressive dinner party starter this Christmas
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2 tbsp dill, chopped, plus extra fronds to garnish
directions: Rinse the lentils, then put them in a pan and cover generously with water. Bring to the boil, then turn down the heat and simmer for 25-30 mins until tender. Drain well and leave to cool. Put the shallot in a bowl with the mustard, vinegar and seasoning. Mix well and whisk in the oil.

Put the eggs into a small pan and cover with water. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 3 mins. Cool quickly under running cold water and peel off the shells. Put in a bowl of cold water until ready to serve.

Stir the dill into the dressing and pour it over the lentils. Spoon onto 6 plates, then halve the eggs and put one half on each plate with two slices of smoked salmon. Sprinkle with black pepper, scatter over a few dill fronds and serve.
chief_review: This salad is a beautifully composed and elegant holiday starter, balancing earthy Puy lentils with velvety smoked salmon and zesty mustard-dill vinaigrette. The shallot offers subtle sharpness, while the dill adds freshness and festive color. Soft-boiled eggs lend richness, making the dish hearty yet refined. Notably, this recipe is gluten-free and pescatarian-friendly, accommodating a range of dietary preferences. It’s a smart choice for dinner parties, as the components can be prepared ahead and assembled just before serving. Each bite offers a harmonious mix of textures and seasonal flavors, sure to delight guests at your Christmas table.

name: Parsnip, mushroom & barley wreath
description:
Followed the recipe exactly, except followed the comment below and added two eggs instead of the seed mixture. Worked out really well and got compliments on it, however I felt that the end result was a little bland. All the individual components smelled and tasted wonderful but when added together nothing really stood out. Made sure to season everything more than indicated in the recipe but it didn't help the flavours stand out.
The previous day I had made the Squash and blue cheese wellington from this site, much less work and was absolutely divine.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 330g parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks
2 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
1 rosemarysprig, leaves stripped, plus extra to decorate if you like
small pack flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
handful parsnip crispswith sea salt & black pepper, or similar
directions: Cook the pearl barley with the stock cube according to pack instructions. Reserve 4 tbsp of the cooking stock, then drain the grains well. Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, then add the parsnips, and cook until really soft. Drain well, tip back into the pan to steam dry for a few minutes, then roughly mash. Mix the ground flax or linseeds with the reserved stock water, and leave to go gluey.

Put the butter and oil in your largest frying pan with the onions and garlic. Fry gently until soft and golden, then stir in the mushrooms, rosemary and sage. Fry the mushrooms until golden too, and any liquid that comes out has evaporated. Scrape into a big mixing bowl and set aside to cool.

Grease a 22-24cm savarin or ring tin generously with butter, then line with thin strips of overlapping baking parchment if it’s not a non-stick tin. Add the mashed parsnip, cooked pearl barley, gluey seed mix, grated hard cheese, chopped parsley and whole hazelnuts to the fried mushroom mixture. Season generously with salt and nutmeg, then mix everything together really well. Spoon the filling into the tin, and press down firmly to fill the tin and flatten the top. Keep in the fridge for up to 24 hrs before baking.

Heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and cover the tin with foil. Bake for 45 mins, until a skewer poked into the centre of the mixture comes out piping hot. Use a small palette or cutlery knife to release the filling all the way around, then sit a serving plate on top and flip over. Carefully lift off the tin, and top the wreath with some parsnip crisps and whole pumpkin seeds to serve – plus some extra rosemary sprigs if you like. Slice into wedges and enjoy.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a hearty and textured dish with a wholesome base of pearl barley, roasted parsnips, and mixed mushrooms. The addition of toasted hazelnuts and pumpkin seeds provides lovely crunch and earthy undertones, while fresh sage, rosemary, and parsley bring aromatic freshness. The inclusion of eggs (in place of the linseed mixture) transitions this from vegan to vegetarian, and the vegetarian Italian-style hard cheese adds a rich, umami note. However, as noted, the combined flavors can flatten out—I'd recommend amplifying herbs and increasing the cheese or incorporating lemon zest for brightness. This well-constructed recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet and could cater to those seeking nut-rich, high-fiber meals. It does, however, contain gluten and nuts, so is not appropriate for gluten- or nut-free diets. A satisfying centrepiece, though it benefits from punchier seasoning.

name: Clementine & vodka-baked salmon with beetroot crème fraîche sauce
description: Divide a whole side of salmon into fillets, cover with a sticky citrus glaze, then bake for a festive dinner party crowd-pleaser
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: zest and juice 4 clementineor 2 oranges (about 175ml/6fl oz), plus 2 clementines, unpeeled and cut into thin slices
250g pack cooked beetroot(not in vinegar), drained and grated
directions: Put the clementine zest and juice, vodka and honey in a pan, season and bring to a simmer. Bubble for 10 mins until reduced by half. Add the clementine slices and simmer for a further 5 mins until the clementines are softened and a little sticky. Remove them from the liquid and transfer to a plate. Bubble the liquid until thickened to a glossy glaze.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line a baking tray with foil or baking parchment and place the salmon in the middle – or on an angle to help it fit if you need to. Using a sharp knife, cut the salmon into 8 fillets, cutting through the flesh but not the skin, as this will hold the whole thing together. Cut the thinner end into slighter wider fillets, so everyone gets a similar portion. Brush the salmon with the glaze, making sure you get in between the gaps, and save a little for brushing on at the end. Lay the candied clementine on top, down the centre, and bake for 20 mins.

While the salmon is cooking, make the beetroot crème fraîche by mixing all the ingredients together in a bowl with plenty of black pepper and a little salt – save a few chives to sprinkle on top. When the salmon is cooked, reheat the remaining glaze, adding a splash of water if it is too thick, and dab it over the top (wash the brush first as it will have come into contact with the raw salmon). Serve the salmon and sauce as part of a buffet, and let everyone dig in.
chief_review: This salmon recipe is a striking centerpiece for a festive dinner, balancing delicate citrus flavors with the richness of the fish. The sticky glaze of clementine and honey, accented by vodka, infuses the salmon with bright, aromatic notes while keeping the fillets moist and succulent. Serving it atop grated beetroot adds earthy sweetness and a vibrant color contrast, making the dish visually appealing. The horseradish and crème fraîche sauce cuts through the richness, delivering a creamy, tangy kick with fresh chives adding a touch of herbal freshness. This recipe is well-suited to pescatarians and is gluten-free, provided all packaged ingredients (like horseradish cream) are checked for hidden gluten. It does, however, contain dairy, so it’s not appropriate for those who are lactose intolerant or follow a vegan or dairy-free diet. Overall, a refined and balanced dish for special occasions.

name: Lemon meringue fridge cake
description: A very, very rich "cake". Nowhere near Lemony enough in my opinion - needs a really zingy Lemon curd and more mixed through the cream
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 1 ½ packs (about 300g) buttery biscuits(we used Fox's Crinkle Crunch Butter)
2 lemons, 1 zested and juiced, 1 sliced to serve
directions: Grease and line a 900g loaf tin with baking parchment. Line the base with a row of biscuits. In a bowl, whisk the lemon zest and juice, mascarpone, cream, sugar and 50g lemon curd until thick and holding its shape. Transfer roughly 1 /4 of the mixture to a bowl and chill in the fridge for later.

Layer the mascarpone and biscuits into the tin, and add the remaining lemon curd in spoonfuls between the layers. Break some biscuits to fill any gaps. You should have about four layers of biscuits, finishing with a layer of cream. Wrap the tin in cling film and chill for at least 8 hrs, or up to 48 hrs.

When you’re ready to serve, unwrap the tin and turn the pudding out onto a platter or board. Peel off the parchment. Crush 4 of the mini meringues to a rubble texture and stir through the reserved mascarpone mix. Spread across the top of the pudding, then press the remaining mini meringues and lemon slices on top. Leftovers will keep for one day.
chief_review: This cake presents an indulgent, creamy texture with a notable richness from the mascarpone and double cream. The biscuit base delivers satisfying crunch, though the lemon element is rather subdued—upping the lemon curd and incorporating more zest would bolster its brightness and create a truly zingy finish. The addition of mini meringues offers playful sweetness and visual appeal. Suitable for vegetarians, this cake does not rely on gelatin or animal products beyond dairy and eggs found in the meringues. However, as the recipe includes wheat-based biscuits and dairy, it’s not gluten-free or vegan. Overall, a decadent treat that could benefit from a bolder citrus punch.

name: Sugar-dusted mince pie parcels
description:
Super fast, super easy AND super tasty!
We've got a keeper!
:)
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 x 375g sheets ready-rolled shortcrust pastry(bring them out of fridge about 15 mins before you want to use them)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Unroll one of the pastry sheets onto a lightly floured surface, and spoon on teaspoonfuls of mincemeat, spaced about 2.5cm apart. Brush round the mincemeat with a little egg. Unroll the second sheet of pastry, keeping it on its wrapper, then roll out just a touch bigger. Using the wrapper to help you, flip onto the mincemeat-dotted sheet.

Press and shape the pastry around each dollop of mincemeat, squeezing out as much air as you can. Slice up the sheet into individual parcels using a sharp knife or pizza cutter. Prick each with a fork, then seal the edges around each one by pressing with a fork. Lift onto baking trays, brush with a little more beaten egg and bake for 18-20 mins until golden and crisp.
While the pies are baking, mix sugar and cinnamon on a plate. When done lift the pies, a few at a time, carefully into the sugar and gently turn to coat.
chief_review: This recipe delivers on its promise of speed and ease, using ready-rolled shortcrust pastry and classic mincemeat for a fuss-free, flavorful result. The combination of warm cinnamon and a crisp sugar topping adds depth to the sweet filling, making each bite comforting and festive. The use of egg wash ensures a golden, flaky finish, while a light dusting of flour helps manage the pastry effortlessly. As written, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians—most commercial mincemeat is now made without suet, but do check the label to be sure. It is not gluten-free due to the pastry, and not vegan because of the egg. Overall, this quick treat is perfect for a last-minute holiday bake or an indulgent snack with tea.

name: Maple mustard roots
description: The sweetness of this side dish makes it the ideal accompaniment to roast turkey
author: Good Food
ingredients: 800g small carrots, peeled and halved or quartered lengthways if large
800g parsnip, peeled and cut into long wedges
directions: Bring a large pan of salted boiling water to the boil. Tip in the roots, bring back to the boil and cook for 3 mins. Drain well, then tip onto a large, lipped roasting tin. Whisk together the syrup, mustard and oil with some seasoning, then gently toss with the veg. Cover with cling film for up to 24 hrs.
Bring to room temp before cooking. After the turkey comes out, roast at 220C/200C fan/gas 7 for 30 mins until golden and sticky.
chief_review: This vibrant side dish masterfully balances the earthy flavors of carrots and parsnips with the rich sweetness of maple syrup and the tang of wholegrain mustard. Roasting the vegetables brings out their natural sugars, resulting in a caramelized exterior and tender bite. The addition of rapeseed or sunflower oil provides a light, clean base, allowing the vegetables’ flavors to shine through. This recipe is well-suited for both vegetarian and vegan diets, as it relies solely on plant-based ingredients. Its gluten-free nature also makes it accessible to those with gluten sensitivities. Simple yet elegant, this dish is a stellar partner to roast turkey or a festive plant-based main, delivering a delightful medley of sweet and savory notes in every bite.

name: Vegan mince pies
description: These end up being quite expensive to make but they are SO good! The pastry turned out so crispy and the hazelnuts in the mince meat made it extra lovely. Would recommend
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 100g skinless hazelnuts, roasted and roughly chopped
200g coconut oil, straight from the fridge (as solid as possible)
20g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tip all the mincemeat ingredients into a casserole dish or roasting tray – be sure to include half the kirsch from the jar of cherries. Mix everything together, then cover with a lid or a sheet of foil. Bake for 35-40 mins until all the sugar has melted, the mixture is bubbling slightly at the edges and the liquid has reduced (the mixture firms a bit as it cools, so be careful not to over-reduce). Set aside to cool completely. Can be made up to three days in advance and chilled in the fridge.
To make the pastry: tip the flour and coconut oil to a

and pulse until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Add the sugar and pulse to just combine, then pour in the vodka and 2 tbsp ice-cold water and pulse until the pastry is just coming together. Add another 2 tbsp water if a little dry, then tip the dough onto a clean surface and pat into a disc with your hands. Wrap in cling film and chill in the fridge for at least 30 mins.

Take the pastry out of the fridge. Cut off one-third of the pastry and keep covered under a tea towel. Cut the rest into five chunks and, one chunk at a time, squeeze with your hands until malleable, then roll out on a well-floured surface to a thickness of 0.5cm. Cut out circles using a 9cm cookie cutter and line 18 holes of two 12-hole cupcake tins. Repeat with the rest of the pastry chunks, re-rolling off-cuts where necessary.

Put a heaped spoonful of mincemeat in the middle of each circle, then put the pies in the fridge. Take the remaining pastry from under the tea towel and roll out to 0.5cm thickness. Transfer to a baking sheet lined with baking parchment. Chill for 15 mins to firm up.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Remove the pastry sheet from the fridge and use an 8cm cookie cutter to cut out nine circles, then use a star cutter to cut out the middles. Bring the mince pies out of the fridge and top half of them with the stars and the other half with the stamped-out circles. Use your fingers to seal the tops and bases, then brush the tops with milk. Bake for 30 mins until the pastry is crisp and the tops are golden. Cool a little, then dust with a little icing sugar to serve.
chief_review: This recipe offers a wonderfully indulgent twist on classic mince pies, with the addition of hazelnuts and black cherries in kirsch lending depth and a touch of sophistication. The pastry, made with coconut oil, delivers an impressively crisp texture and light flavor, cleverly accommodating dairy-free diets and making this suitable for vegans. Using non-dairy milk for brushing further cements its vegan suitability. It’s packed with fruit and aromatic spices, providing excellent flavor balance and a beautifully festive aroma. The inclusion of hazelnuts adds a satisfying crunch and a lovely toasted note. The vodka in the pastry ensures tenderness without adding weight. Though the ingredients list hints at a premium price, the taste and texture justify the expense for a special occasion. An excellent choice for those seeking a vegan treat that doesn’t compromise on flavor or texture.

name: Roasted stuffed cauliflower
description: Cut out the center and lo and behold...the whole thing fell apart. Tried it with two cauliflowers and the only cavity i could make without it falling to bits was a cylindrical tube in the middle of the stalk leaving a hollow about 2" round?!?! How can you stuff it when the florets fall apart?? In your picture were they glued back together??
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: ½ small pack sage, leaves chopped
½ small pack rosemary, leaves chopped
150g cooked chestnuts, finely chopped, plus 30g for the topping
directions: Trim and discard the cauliflower leaves. Turn the cauliflower upside-down on a chopping board and use your knife to carefully cut out the stalk and core, leaving a cavity – the florets should still be holding together.

Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Submerge the cauliflower and cook for 7 mins, then remove with two slotted spoons and set aside to steam dry. Add the kale to the pan and cook for a min or so until wilted. Drain, then run under cold water to cool. Squeeze out the excess liquid and roughly chop.

To make a linseed ‘egg’ (this will bind the stuffing together), mix the ground linseed with 3 tbsp water and set aside for 5-10 mins until gluey. Meanwhile, heat 2 tbsp oil in a frying pan, add the onion and a pinch of salt, and cook until softened, then stir in the remaining stuffing ingredients, including the kale, and cook for a min or so more. Remove from the heat and season, then put in a
with 150ml water and the linseed egg and blitz to a thick purée. Transfer to a piping bag.

Pipe the stuffing mixture into every nook and cranny of the cauliflower, getting in as much of the purée as you can – see our tip below. Transfer to a baking tray lined with parchment. Can be made up to this point in the morning and kept in the fridge.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Mix the remaining chestnuts with the breadcrumbs and some seasoning. Spoon the remaining oil all over the cauliflower, then pat on the breadcrumb chestnut mix. Roast for 45 mins until golden brown and tender (place under a hot grill for the last part of cooking time if it needs to crisp-up). Serve with any crisp bits that have fallen onto the baking tray.
chief_review:
This inventive cauliflower centerpiece promises a creative plant-based option, perfect for vegetarians and even vegans if the breadcrumbs used are egg- and dairy-free. The mixture of roasted cauliflower with a hearty kale, chestnut, and herb stuffing delivers plenty of flavor and texture. The chestnuts add a pleasant earthiness while sage, rosemary, nutmeg, and lemon zest provide aromatic notes.

However, as highlighted by the recipe experience, the structural integrity of the cauliflower may be tricky—removing the core can easily lead to loose florets. To alleviate this, consider parboiling the cauliflower to soften it slightly before hollowing, or opt for a gentle coring technique, ensuring an even cavity without breaching the cluster of florets.

Overall, it's a stunning, festive dish suitable for those with vegetarian, vegan, and nut-free diets, provided ingredient labels are checked.

name: Artichoke & wild mushroom pie
description: This rustic savoury pie shows just how modern vegetarian dishes can excite and thrill all appetites
author: Lesley Waters
ingredients: 1 egg, a pinch of salt and 1 tbsp water, beaten together to glaze
large handful flat leaf parsley leaves, very roughly chopped
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Heat half the oil in a medium frying pan, then gently fry the onions for 12-15 mins until softened and lightly browned. Tip the onions into a bowl and mix with the artichoke hearts, season if you like and set aside. Heat the remaining oil in the same pan (there’s no need to clean it) over a high-ish heat. Add the mushrooms, then stir-fry for 2-3 mins until soft, throw in the garlic and thyme and continue to cook for a minute. Remove from the heat, season well and allow to cool.
On a floured surface, roll out the pastry into a rough circle about 40cm in diameter and drape over a large baking sheet.
Pile the onions and artichokes into the middle of the pastry and spread them out evenly, leaving a 10cm border around the edge, then pile the mushrooms on top.

Bring the edges of the pastry up over the filling. Brush the exposed pastry edge with the egg glaze. Bake for 20-25 mins until the pastry is crisp and golden brown. Sprinkle with parsley and serve immediately with the sour cream and relish.
chief_review: This rustic savoury pie is a celebration of earthy, Mediterranean flavours, pairing grilled artichoke hearts and mixed mushrooms with sweetly caramelized onions and fresh thyme. The olive oil-based sauté ensures a depth of taste while maintaining a lighter touch. The use of ready-made shortcrust pastry makes this an accessible recipe for home cooks seeking both comfort and sophistication. Finishing with parsley brightens the dish, and a dollop of soured cream adds luscious tang. This pie is an inspired option for vegetarians, satisfying and complex enough to please even committed meat-eaters. It isn’t gluten-free due to the pastry, but the ingredients otherwise avoid common allergens like nuts. Overall, an impressive, modern vegetarian main—hearty enough for a festive centerpiece, yet straightforward for weeknight dining.

name: Clementine, feta & winter leaf salad
description: This wonderfully light salad is packed with easy-to-find seasonal ingredients and makes a great Christmas starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 fennel bulb, halved, cored and very finely sliced
1 red onion, halved and finely sliced
directions: Whisk the dressing ingredients in a jug, season with salt and set aside.

To make the salad, peel the clementines and slice whole. In a bowl, gently toss the chicory and watercress with the fennel and onion. Place slices of clementine on opposite sides of each plate, mound a pile of leaves in the middle, then scatter over the feta. Stir the parsley through the dressing and drizzle over the salad.
chief_review: This vibrant salad is a refreshing celebration of winter produce, perfect as a festive Christmas starter. The combination of juicy clementines with crisp chicory, fennel, and watercress brings a pleasing interplay of sweetness and bitterness, harmonized further by the tang of lemon juice and the gentle sharpness of red onion. Crumbled feta adds a creamy, salty depth, while parsley lends a fresh herbal lift. The olive oil and citrus dressing, subtly sweetened with sugar, ties the dish together with finesse. This recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians and is gluten-free, provided attention is paid to the feta (some varieties may contain animal rennet). The preparation is straightforward yet yields a sophisticated result—a lively salad that enlivens the palate and brightens any festive table with both colour and flavour.

name: Peppers filled with corn, chilli & cheese
description: A veggie main, perfect for a satisfying meal
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 peppers, any colour, tops removed and deseeded
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped or 1 tsp cayenne pepper
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Bring a large pan of water to the boil, then cook the peppers for 5 mins. Remove and drain, cut side down, on some kitchen paper.

Heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a frying pan and cook the onion for 3 mins until tender. Add the cumin and chilli or cayenne pepper and cook for a further 2-3 mins. Add the courgette, then cook for 4 mins until tender.

Remove from the heat, then stir in the sweetcorn, avocado, cheese, coriander and seasoning. Spoon the filling into the peppers, then stand them in a baking dish. Drizzle with remaining oil, then bake for 30-35 mins until the peppers are very soft.
Leave to stand for about 5 mins, then serve warm with soured cream, a chilli bean salad and corn chips.
chief_review: This vibrant stuffed pepper recipe is a true celebration of fresh vegetables and bold flavors—a fantastic option for a wholesome vegetarian main. The pairing of red onion, courgette, sweetcorn, and creamy avocado delivers both color and texture, while the cumin and chilli bring a warm, gentle spice that balances the sweetness of the peppers. Vegetarian cheddar adds richness without overpowering the freshness of the dish, and the coriander offers a bright finish. Using olive oil keeps the preparation light, and the absence of animal products beside the cheese means this meal is suitable for a vegetarian diet. By omitting gluten ingredients, it’s also naturally gluten-free. With a focus on seasonal produce and a straightforward method, this recipe shines as a nutritious, crowd-pleasing centerpiece for any vegetarian table.

name: Homemade gingerbread cottage
description: A step-by-step guide to making and assembling a beautiful gingerbread house complete with snow-capped roof and pretty piping - a great family project
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1kg plain flour, plus extra for dusting
200g ready-to-roll fondant icing, plus a few ping-pong sized balls, wrapped in cling film, ready for assembling
directions: : Put about half the flour in a food processor with the butter. Whizz until you can’t see any lumps of butter remaining (if you don’t have a food processor, rub the butter into all of the flour with your fingertips, until it resembles fine crumbs). Tip the buttery flour into your largest mixing bowl and mix in the remaining flour, spices and bicarbonate of soda with a pinch of salt. Stir in the sugar.

Whisk the eggs with the golden syrup and stir into the flour mixture with a wooden spoon. Using your hands, knead together into a smooth dough. Use straight away, or chill or freeze until ready to bake.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Roll out a quarter of the dough at a time on a sheet of baking parchment, to the thickness of 2 x £1 coins. Use a small, sharp knife to cut around the cottage templates (see the 'try' section below to print off the template) – remember that each time you’ll need 2 x ROOF, 2 x END and 2 x SIDE for one cottage. Remove the trimmings and lift the gingerbread, on its parchment, onto baking trays. Re-roll trimmings to cut out all the shapes you need.

Bake the gingerbread one tray at a time (so it cooks evenly), on a high shelf in the oven for 8-12 mins, until rich brown and firm to the touch. Give each tray 3-5 mins to cool, then carefully sit the templates back onto the relevant shapes and trim any edges to neaten

. Keep these trimmings for nibbles. Use a small knife, or heart-shaped cutters, to cut out any doors and windows you want to have. If you want to fill your cottage with lights, use the end of one of the SIDE templates to cut out a little door in the back END of the cottage.

For a roof like ours, roll out remaining gingerbread to about half the thickness of the walls. Use a 3-4cm cutter to stamp out rounds – to fully cover the roofs, you will need about 75 round biscuit tiles. Bake as above, but for 6-9 mins – as they are thinner, they will bake quicker. Let all the biscuits cool completely.

Sift 250g of the icing sugar into a bowl, dribble in water, stirring in until you have a thick-ish icing. Tip the preserving sugar or pearl sugar into a shallow bowl and get a couple of cooling racks ready. Dip the round roof tile biscuits into the icing, one by one – covering about a quarter of the biscuit in icing
. It looks nice if they’re all a bit higgledy-piggledy. Dip into the preserving sugar to stick, then sit on the cooling racks and leave to dry.

Put the egg whites in a large bowl, sift in the remaining 500g of icing sugar, then stir to make a thick, smooth icing. Spoon a little into a piping bag with a very small nozzle. Spoon half of the rest into a piping bag that has a slightly larger nozzle (or spoon into large food bags and, when ready to ice, snip off the corner to turn into a piping bag). Keep the rest covered in the bowl. Use the small piping bag to pipe any icing decorations you want onto the END that is going to be the front of your cottage. Leave to dry.
Arrange the wall biscuits as you are going to assemble them. Swap to the big bag of icing with a medium nozzle to pipe generous snakes of icing along the SIDE edges
and stick the walls together. Pipe extra icing where the walls join each other on the inside of the cottage, and support the sides using your icing balls

To decorate the roof, scrape any excess icing and sugar from the underside of the roof tiles with a small knife, so they can lie flat. Start at the bottom of one and work along in a row, using the icing in the bowl, spread good-sized blobs of icing on the underside of the top of each tile biscuit to stick

. Let the bottom row overhang the edge of the ROOF. Continue working up, sticking a row at a time, sitting the row above in the gaps of the row below, so the tiles sit in a diamond pattern rather than straight lines down the ROOF

. You’ll need to cut some of the tiles on the edges to fit – just use a big sharp knife and be brave (you should have a few spares available in case you have any accidents). Repeat to cover the second ROOF, then leave the completed ROOFS with the half-built cottage for a few hrs at least, or preferably overnight, until set.
When ready, remove the supports from the cottage and stick on the ROOFS
. This bit can be fiddly, so you may need an extra pair of hands. Shape your icing balls to support the bottoms of the ROOFS. Hold the biscuits on firmly for a few mins until the icing starts to set
. Set again for a few hrs, or overnight.

To finish decorating like ours, roll marble-sized balls of the ready-to-roll icing and stick them along the ROOF top – this is perfect for hiding the join. To make the icicles, start with the nozzle at a 90-degree angle to the ROOF and squeeze out a pea-sized blob of icing. Keeping the pressure on, pull the nozzle down and then off – the icing will pull away, leaving a pointy trail. Repeat all around the front of the cottage, covering the gap between the ROOF and roof tiles too, if you like.
chief_review:
This gingerbread house recipe is a delightful, classic project perfect for family gatherings, combining aromatic spices and rich golden syrup for a flavorful, sturdy dough. The structure benefits from a high flour-to-butter ratio, ensuring crisp edges and a reliable base for construction. The decorating elements—royal icing, fondant, and pearl sugar—offer ample creative freedom, while the assembly process encourages collaborative fun. 

As the recipe is free from nuts, it’s a good choice for nut-free diets, provided all decorations are checked for possible nut traces. However, it contains wheat flour and eggs, making it unsuitable for gluten-free and vegan requirements. The use of freshly mixed royal icing and a well-spiced dough results in both visual charm and classic festive taste. Overall, this project is well-balanced between flavor and tradition, producing a showstopping centerpiece for any holiday table.

name: Sausage & kale hash
description: Added turmeric and chilli powder about half teaspoon each to add a little spice was a delicious brunch
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: 4 Cumberland sausages(about 250g), meat squeezed out of the skins
directions: Put the potatoes in a pan of cold water with a little salt. Bring to the boil, cook for 3-4 mins until nearly tender, then drain and set aside.

Meanwhile, heat 1/2 tbsp oil in a large, non-stick frying pan. Cook the onion for 8-10 mins over a low heat until soft. Add the potatoes and sausagemeat, turn the heat up to medium and brown everything for 5-6 mins. Scatter the kale over and wilt for 2 mins, then stir in the sage.
Pour in the remaining oil and push the hash to one side of the pan to make room for the eggs. Crack the eggs in and fry to your liking. Divide the hash between two bowls and top with a fried egg.
chief_review: This brunch recipe delivers robust flavors and a satisfying texture, thanks to the combination of tender white potatoes and savory Cumberland sausage. The addition of turmeric and chilli powder introduces subtle heat and earthy depth, complementing the sweetness of the sautéed onion and the slight bitterness of kale. Sage brings aromatic freshness, while eggs add rich creaminess for a well-balanced dish. This recipe is protein-packed and suitable for those following a traditional diet. However, it contains gluten (in sausage and possibly brown sauce) and is not vegetarian or vegan due to the use of eggs and meat. Overall, it’s a delicious, hearty option that’s ideal for a weekend brunch, offering a good dose of greens and a satisfying blend of spices.

name: After-dinner mint cream
description: This creamy syllabub is a spin on classic mint choc chip and a great way to use up leftover chocolates
author: Silvana Franco
ingredients: 2-3 tbsp cream sherry(we used Harvey's Bristol Cream)
200g thin after-dinner mints, plus 6 extra to serve
directions: Put the mascarpone, double cream, caster sugar and sherry in a bowl and whisk until thick enough to hold its shape. Break 200g of the after-dinner mints into small pieces, then beat these into the cream mixture. Spoon into tiny glasses or bowls and chill until needed. Add 1 more thin after-dinner mint to each dessert before serving
chief_review: This creamy mint choc chip syllabub is a delight for dessert lovers, masterfully marrying mascarpone and double cream for sumptuous richness. The touch of cream sherry adds subtle depth, while the crushed after-dinner mints bring a refreshing burst and a touch of nostalgia—perfect for using up leftovers. The texture is luxurious yet light, making it a lovely way to finish a meal. Vegetarian-friendly, this dessert excludes gelatin or eggs, relying on dairy for its structure. Those seeking nut-free options will also find this recipe accommodating, given the absence of common allergens except for dairy. Overall, it’s an elegant, low-effort showstopper ideal for entertaining or indulging in a sweet moment at home.

name: Hasselback roasties
description: Don't be put off by the preparation. Slice the spuds on Christmas eve and keep in a bowl of water overnight - they're well worth the effort
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2½ kg small-ish potato, such as Desirée, peeled
5 tbsp duck or goose fator sunflower oil
directions: Using a sharp knife, thinly slice each potato about two-thirds through, so the bottom of the potato holds the slices together. One way of doing this is to insert a metal skewer through the length of each potato, close to the base, before slicing. Sit the potato on a chopping board with the skewer nearest the board, then thinly slice down. Pull out the skewer and move on to the next spud.

Heat the fat in a large roasting tin in the oven for 5 mins, then carefully roll in the potatoes with some sea salt. Roast at 200C/180C fan/ gas 6 along with the turkey for its final 30 mins. When you take the turkey out to rest, increase heat to 220C/200C fan/ gas 7, give the tin a good shake and roast potatoes for a further 30 mins until crisp and cooked through.
chief_review: This festive potato recipe showcases classic technique and rich flavor, perfect for holiday tables. Slicing the potatoes a day in advance and soaking them ensures an appealing texture—crispy edges and creamy centers after roasting. Duck or goose fat imbues the potatoes with deep, savory notes and hints of luxury, elevated by aromatic thyme. This side dish would particularly suit those following a gluten-free diet, as it contains no wheat or related allergens, and it’s straightforward enough for cooks of all skill levels. The option to use sunflower oil allows adaptation for individuals avoiding animal fats or seeking a dairy-free alternative. Overall, it's an indulgent, crowd-pleasing accompaniment that rewards careful preparation with restaurant-quality results.

name: Vegan tiffin
description: I have used this recipe a couple of times. Really simple and quick to make. Today I made a cheaper version... swapping ginger nuts for own brand digestives, cranberries for currants and pistachios for sliced almonds.
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 75g coconut oil, plus extra for the tin
200g vegan dark chocolate(at least 70%), roughly chopped
directions: Lightly oil a 20cm square brownie tin with coconut oil and line the base with baking parchment. Melt the chocolate with the coconut oil and golden syrup in the microwave in 30-second bursts until smooth and glossy.

Break the ginger nuts into small pieces in a bowl, then add the dried cranberries and pistachios. Scrape in the chocolate mixture and give everything a good mix to combine, then spoon the tiffin into the tin. Use the back of the spoon to smooth out the top and press it down, then chill in the fridge for 2 hrs or until set hard. Once set, cut into 25 mini squares. Will keep for a week in the fridge.
chief_review: This recipe is a stellar choice for anyone seeking a quick, fuss-free sweet treat that doesn't compromise on flavor. The combination of vegan dark chocolate, vegan ginger nuts, coconut oil, and golden syrup forms a rich, velvety base, punctuated by the tartness of dried cranberries and the crunch of pistachios. Using all plant-based ingredients, this dessert is ideally suited for a vegan diet. Additionally, the absence of dairy and eggs makes it friendly for those with common food allergies like lactose intolerance or egg allergies. The flexibility in swapping nuts and fruits also enhances its wide appeal. A delightful, easy-to-customize recipe perfect for parties or an indulgent snack.

name: Cherry & pistachio stuffing
description: Try a new flavour combo in sausagemeat stuffing balls - sweet fruit, crunchy nuts and fresh parsley are a perfect match
author: Good Food
ingredients: 450g sausagemeat(or sausages removed from their skins)
directions: Melt the butter in a small pan, add the onion and cook until soft, about 8 mins. Leave to cool.
Mix the onion with the remaining ingredients, apart from the oil – the best way to do this is with your hands. Roll the stuffing mixture into 24 walnut-sized balls and put on a baking tray.

When the turkey comes out of the oven, turn the heat up to 220C/200C fan/ gas 7. Drizzle the stuffing with oil and cook on a middle shelf for 30 mins. Swap to the top shelf for the final 10 mins if they need browning.
chief_review: This sausagemeat stuffing ball recipe brings a delightful blend of flavors and textures to the table. The combination of sweet dried cherries or cranberries, zesty citrus, and crunchy pistachios complements the savory richness of sausagemeat beautifully. Fresh parsley brightens the profile, while breadcrumbs help bind everything together for a classic, hearty bite. This dish is ideal for adding a festive twist to your roast dinners or holiday spreads. It does contain eggs and nuts, so those with allergies should note these ingredients. The recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the use of sausagemeat and egg. Overall, a thoughtfully balanced and crowd-pleasing choice for anyone seeking a flavorful accompaniment to their meal.

name: Herb-roast turkey
description: Whether you're cooking your first or your fifteenth Christmas dinner, this herb-scented turkey is foolproof and has loads of flavour
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 3 onions, cut into thick rounds with the skins left on
generous handful thyme and bay leaves, plus more herbs to put around the bird, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Wash and dry the turkey, removing any feathers. Lift up the skin that covers the neck opening, then push the stuffing up and under the skin, securing it tightly underneath with a skewer or 2 cocktail sticks. Weigh stuffed turkey, then calculate cooking time, allowing 40 mins per kg (20 mins per lb). Put a few pieces of onion and a few herbs into the cavity, then tie the legs together with string.

Put the remaining onions in a single layer in the tin, then add a good bed of herbs. Add the neck and all of the other giblets, except for the liver, to the tin, then sit the turkey on top of the herby onions. Coat the breast all over with butter. Pour the wine into the tin, cover with foil, then roast according to your timings. Keep checking the tin – if it looks a little dry, add a splash of water. While the bird cooks, mix the salt, crushed green peppercorns and thyme leaves.

Thirty mins before the end of cooking, remove the foil. Brush the turkey again with butter, then scatter over and press in the salt, pepper and thyme mix. Roast for the remaining cooking time, uncovered, until golden. To be reassured that the turkey is ready, pierce thigh through its thickest part; the juices should run clear. If not, give it 15 mins more and test again. Remove the turkey from the tin and leave to rest without covering (this will keep skin crisp). The turkey will stay hot for up to an hour, so there’s no need to panic.

Now make the gravy. Drain the fat and juices from the tin into a jug, keeping the onions but discarding the neck and giblets. Place the tin on the hob, then pour in the wine, scraping up the flavour-filled crusty bits with a wooden spoon. Reduce until the wine has almost all disappeared. Spoon the fat from the juices and discard, then add the juices, onions and stock to the tin. Boil down for about 5 mins until reduced and a little syrupy, stir in redcurrant jelly, then season. Strain into a jug; any resting juices should go in now, too. Lift the turkey onto a platter with the Bacon-wrapped sausages (see recipe below), dotting herb sprigs around to decorate. Serve with cranberry and bread sauces.
chief_review: This herb-scented turkey recipe is a classic and reliable choice for a festive centerpiece. The combination of fresh thyme, bay leaves, and a touch of redcurrant jelly delivers aromatic depth and a subtle sweetness, beautifully complementing the succulent turkey. The use of white wine in both the roasting and gravy stages ensures a moist bird and a well-rounded, flavourful sauce. With onions forming a makeshift rack, the turkey stays juicy, while the butter rub aids in a crisp, golden skin. This recipe comfortably serves a large gathering and offers flexibility in stuffing choice. Notably, with a suitable gluten-free stuffing, it can be enjoyed by those following a gluten-free diet, and using dairy-free butter substitutes can make it work for some lactose-intolerant guests. All in all, it’s a foolproof method for an impressive celebratory meal with broad appeal.

name: Bitter orange & cardamom martinis
description: will try this Christmas eve and let you know cant wait
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 tbsp Seville orange marmalade, plus more to serve
directions: Bash 6 cardamom pods in a pestle and mortar until they split.
Melt the marmalade in a pan, then whisk in the vodka. Add the crushed pods. Don’t boil the mix, simply warm it for a few mins. Leave to infuse off the heat for 20 mins, then strain.
Add the Cointreau and lemon juice and chill (or keep in the freezer). Serve in glasses with a little more marmalade in the bottom, ice and a cardamom pod floating on top.
chief_review: This festive cocktail recipe is a delightful fusion of aromatic cardamom, zesty Seville orange marmalade, and citrusy Cointreau, balanced with a splash of lemon juice and vodka for a sophisticated finish. The distinct notes of marmalade carry both sweetness and a slight bitterness, pairing beautifully with the warmth of cardamom. Served over ice, this drink is refreshingly bright—ideal for holiday gatherings or as a celebratory aperitif. Notably, with no animal products in the ingredient list, it’s suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Additionally, the absence of gluten-containing ingredients makes it a friendly option for those following a gluten-free lifestyle, assuming the spirits used are gluten-free. The simplicity and vibrant flavor profile make this cocktail a standout—perfect for impressing guests or adding a festive flair to your evening.

name: Chinese roast duck
description: John Torode's whole crispy duck with oriental marinade makes for an impressive and alternative Christmas centrepiece
author: John Torode
ingredients: small bunch spring onions, roughly chopped
2 tbsp maltsyrup or maltose (available in most Chinese supermarkets)
directions: The day before, soak 4 wooden skewers in water for 20 mins. Wash the ducks inside and out with cold water, drain and pat dry with kitchen paper. Mix together the sugar, star anise, ginger, spring onions and a few good pinches of salt, then use this to fill the cavities. Close the cavities with wooden skewers and set aside.

In a small bowl, mix the maltose and 2 tbsp of the vinegar. Add the remaining vinegar to a jug of boiling water and pour over the ducks. (The boiling water opens up the pores, while the vinegar helps to strip some of the waxiness from the skin, so it will be more receptive to the maltose, which adds sweetness and a lacquered caramel colour.) Smear the maltose mixture over the ducks, then place them in a large plastic container and put in the fridge overnight, uncovered.

To cook, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/ gas 7. (Fan ovens are particularly effective for roasting duck.) Put a little water in the bottom of a large roasting tin, place the ducks on a rack over the top and cover with foil. Roast for about 45 mins. Take off the foil and roast for another 45 mins – the duck must be well done, there is no such thing as a rare Chinese roast duck! Take the duck out of the oven and let it rest for a good 20 mins before carving.
chief_review: John Torode’s whole crispy duck with oriental marinade is a stunning showpiece for festive occasions, delivering both bold flavors and a dramatic presentation. The combination of star anise, ginger, and malt syrup infuses the duck with aromatic depth, while the sugar and red wine vinegar help create an irresistibly lacquered, crispy skin. Spring onions add a fresh edge to the savory, slightly sweet marinade. This dish would suit those following a dairy-free diet, as there are no dairy products in the recipe; it’s also nut-free, which may be helpful for certain allergies. For a Christmas meal that's a little out of the ordinary, this recipe offers impressive results and complex, warming flavors.

name: Roast turkey with chestnut stuffing
description:
I use this stuffing every year and it really intensifies the gravy and brings a wow to the dinner. Its the best stuffing and everyone loves it even the children.
16lb Bronze turkey cooked 2.5hrs and was moist and perfect.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 15g pack thyme, use the leaves and reserve the stalks
2 x 454g packs Cumberland sausages, skins removed
200g pack whole cooked chestnut(I used Merchant Gourmet)
zest 1 lemon(halve and reserve the rest to use for the turkey)
4½ -5.6kg/10-12lb bronze turkey, giblets removed (to use in stock)
directions: First make the stuffing. Pour the madeira or wine into a bowl, then crumble in the mushrooms. Fry the onions in the butter for 10 mins, until golden. Cool, then mix with the thyme leaves, the mushrooms and their soaking liquid, and all remaining ingredients, apart from 8 of the chestnuts and the bacon. Season well.

Set aside half of the stuffing. Line a greased 500g loaf tin with bacon. Pack the rest of the stuffing into the tin, then bring the rashers round over the top and secure in place with cocktail sticks. Use the reserved chestnuts to fill the spaces where the bacon meets. Chill until ready to cook. This will keep in the fridge uncooked for 2 days or can be frozen for up to a month.

Prepare the turkey. The night before, put the onion quarters, reserved lemon halves and thyme sprigs in the cavity between the legs. Pack the reserved stuffing into the neck end. Secure the neck skin with skewers and tie the legs together. Weigh the turkey. Calculate the cooking time at 40 mins per kilo, plus 20 mins.

Put a large sheet of extra-wide foil in a large roasting tin and put the turkey on top. Smear the breast with the butter, then grate over half of the nutmeg and season well. Cover with bacon, then pour over the glass of madeira or wine. Seal the foil well to make a parcel. Chill overnight.

On the day, take the turkey out of the fridge 1 hr before roasting. Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Put the turkey in the oven; then, 90 mins before the end of cooking, remove foil and bacon, and drain off the juices from the tin to use in the gravy. To test whether the turkey is cooked, push a skewer into the thickest part of the thigh – the juices should run clear. If they are pinkish, cook for 15 mins more, then test again.

Transfer the turkey to a platter, cover with foil, then a couple of tea towels, and allow to rest for at least 30 mins before carving. Meanwhile, cook the stuffing loaf for 30 mins and reheat the bacon. Garnish with watercress and serve the stuffing loaf separately.
chief_review:
This festive stuffing recipe is a true celebration of rich, earthy flavors, thanks to the addition of porcinis, chestnuts, and the aromatic blend of fresh thyme and parsley. Using Cumberland sausages provides a deep, savory base, complemented beautifully by the subtle sweetness of Madeira or white wine. The lemon zest and nutmeg add brightness and warmth, elevating the stuffing from traditional to exceptional. The streaky bacon adds irresistible smokiness and helps keep everything moist inside the turkey. 

With bread crumbs and sausages, this stuffing is best suited for those without gluten or meat restrictions, but it could be partially adapted for other preferences. Overall, this is a crowd-pleasing recipe, perfect for those classic holiday gatherings, delivering both robust flavor and comfort. Chef’s tip: Don’t skip the Madeira—it really ties all the complex flavors together.

name: Mini panettone
description: Perfect for an indulgent brunch over the Christmas holidays, these little Italian treats are rich and devilishly buttery
author: Sara Buenfeld
