directions: Beat the eggs and yolk with the vanilla. In a large bowl, mix the flour, yeast, sugar and ½ tsp salt. Add the warm milk and egg mixture, then beat to a very soft, sticky dough with a wooden spoon. Cover with cling film and leave in a warm place until the dough has doubled in size.
Drop large muffin wraps into 10 clean, 200g size cans (or use a muffin tray), or line them carefully with baking parchment so that the paper comes well above the cans to make a collar.

Blend the butter, fruit and peel into the risen dough, preferably with your hands. Cut into 10 equal pieces and drop a piece into each prepared can. Cover again and leave until they are very well risen.
Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Gently brush the panettone with milk, scatter over the almonds and bake for 25-30 mins until golden.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful nod to classic Italian holiday baking, delivering wonderfully rich and buttery treats ideal for a festive brunch. The use of eggs, butter, and warm milk contributes to a tender, indulgent crumb, while mixed dried fruit and candied peel provide bursts of sweetness and lively texture. The addition of flaked almonds on top adds both visual appeal and a subtle, nutty crunch. With plain flour as the base and a generous helping of sugar, these treats are perfectly balanced—neither too dense nor overly sweet. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe can be appreciated by those seeking a luxurious, home-baked decadence to share during the holidays. Serve warm with a dusting of powdered sugar for extra festive flair.

name: Buttered sprouts with pancetta
description: A great way to jazz up Brussels sprouts for an extra special occasion
author: Good Food
directions: Fry the pancetta in a large non-stick frying pan for 4-5 mins until crispy and golden, then add the Brussels sprouts and cook for a further min. Pour in the chicken stock and simmer for 15-20 mins until the sprouts are tender and the stock has reduced. Melt in the butter, season well and serve.
chief_review: This dish is a delightful twist on classic Brussels sprouts, infusing them with the savory depth of pancetta and the richness of chicken stock and butter. The pancetta renders its fat, coating the sprouts and imparting a smoky, salty flavor, while the chicken stock ensures that each bite is moist, tender, and infused with layered umami. Finishing with butter creates a glossy, luxurious texture. Ideal for an indulgent side at festive meals, this recipe pairs brilliantly with roasted meats and hearty mains. It’s suitable for gluten-free diets, provided the chicken stock contains no added gluten. Perfect for those looking to elevate their vegetable sides while maintaining robust, crowd-pleasing flavors.

name: Chocolate tree cake
description: An easy yet stunning decorative idea which will put those surplus Christmas chocolates to good use
author: Good Food
directions: Beat the butter with sifted icing sugar and a little green food colouring. Spread the mixture on an 18-20cm square sponge or chocolate cake. Use matchstick chocolates or black liquorice laces to mark the branches of a Christmas tree, then dot on assorted chocolates to look like decorations.
chief_review: This recipe brilliantly transforms surplus Christmas chocolates into an eye-catching and indulgent centerpiece, making excellent use of seasonal leftovers. The combination of a soft buttercream—achieved by blending very soft butter with sifted icing sugar and a touch of green food colouring—creates a lush and visually striking frosting, perfect for decorative piping. The base of sponge or chocolate cake provides a moist, tender foundation, while matchstick chocolates or black liquorice laces introduce playful texture and contrast. The assorted chocolates on top add a festive, decadent flair, sure to delight guests and children alike. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat-based ingredients, though it’s essential to check individual chocolate brands for hidden animal-derived additives. Overall, an imaginative and resourceful showpiece that promises both visual appeal and festive flavor.

name: Butter-roasted supreme of chicken with wild mushroom & potato gratin
description: I only had skinless breasts which turned out a bit dry, so definitely use ones with skin, but otherwise it was really amazing, and very decadent!
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: thymesprigs, plus a few extra thyme leaves for sprinkling
300g mixed wild mushrooms, cleaned and roughly sliced if large
bunch flat-leaf parsley, leaves very roughly chopped
4 large chicken breasts, preferably supremes with the wing bone still attached
24 baby leeks, trimmed to the same size, boiled for 3 mins, then refreshed in iced water
directions: To make the gratin, peel and slice the potatoes no thicker than a 50p piece using a mandolin, if you have one. Bring the milk, cream, garlic, herbs and some seasoning to the boil in a large saucepan, then turn down the heat and simmer for a few mins.

Slip the potatoes into the hot milk mixture and simmer for 10 mins until just cooked. Drain the potatoes in a colander over a bowl to catch the liquid – reserve the milk. While the potatoes are simmering, heat half the butter in a frying pan until foaming. Fry the mushrooms for 2 mins until just wilted, season with salt and pepper and set aside.

Rub 2 small gratin dishes (or 1 medium) with the remaining butter, sprinkle over the thyme leaves and grate over some of the cheese. Fill the dishes halfway with potato slices, moisten with a little milk and grate over more cheese. Fill up the dishes with potato slices, add enough milk to cover, then top with the mushrooms and the rest of the cheese.

For the chicken, mix about two-thirds of the butter with the lemon zest and half the juice, the parsley, paprika and some salt and pepper. Lift the skin slightly away from each breast, spread or pipe the flavoured butter under the skin, then stretch the skin back over. Chill up to a day in advance, if you like.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Heat the remaining butter in an ovenproof frying pan until foaming. Pan-fry the chicken, basting constantly with the butter until starting to brown. Add the shallot, garlic, thyme and stock. Place the chicken, skin-side up in its pan, on the higher shelf of the oven, and the gratins on the lower shelf. Roast both for 25-30 mins, then remove the chicken and rest for 15 mins, while the gratins continue to cook.

To finish, remove the chicken from the pan. Place the pan back on the heat, squeeze over the remaining lemon juice and bring everything to a hard boil. Pass the sauce through a sieve, pressing down firmly on all the soft shallot and garlic. Heat a drizzle of olive oil in another frying pan and reheat the leeks until they start to colour. With the gratins cooked, you are now ready to plate up.

Line six leeks up in a row in the middle of each plate. Carve the chicken on a slant into five thick slices. Neatly fan out each chicken breast over the leeks. Spoon the sauce over the chicken and around the leeks, and serve with the potato gratin.
chief_review:
This recipe is a celebration of rich, comforting flavors—a true showcase of classic French techniques. The gratin-style potatoes, enriched with full-fat milk, double cream, and Gruyère or Comté, deliver a luxurious backdrop to the main event: tender chicken supremes, ideally roasted with skin for maximum succulence. Wild mushrooms add a gorgeous earthiness, while a lemon and parsley butter infuses the dish with freshness and aromatic brightness. The delicate baby leeks complete the plate with their gentle sweetness.

For vegetarians or vegans, this dish isn’t suitable since it features chicken, dairy, and chicken stock. However, it can be enjoyed by those on a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain wheat or gluten components, making it a safe and indulgent option for gluten-sensitive diners. A proper chef’s comfort dish—decadent, satisfying, and beautifully balanced.

name: Parsnip gnocchi
description: Would it be possible to make these in advance and freeze them? At what stage? Before frying or after and then just pop in the oven to crisp up on the day?
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 400g parsnip, peeled and cut into chunks
600g potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
60ml olive oil, plus a drizzle to serve
½ small pack thyme, leaves picked, to serve
30g walnuts, toasted and chopped, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Toss the parsnips and potatoes in 2 tbsp of the olive oil and tip into a roasting tin along with the garlic cloves. Roast for 40 mins or until the veg is completely soft. Remove from the oven and leave to cool a little. Squeeze the garlic from their skins, then discard the skins. Tip everything into a
, along with the nutmeg, flour and nutritional yeast, season well, then pulse until well combined and holding together as a dough.

Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Tip the dough onto a floured surface, cut into four chunks and roll each into a sausage about 35cm long and 2.5cm wide. Use the back of a table knife to cut each sausage into small pillow-shaped gnocchi, each around 2cm long. Cook the gnocchi in batches for 1 min or until they float to the surface. Remove from the water with a slotted spoon and drain on kitchen paper.

In a frying pan, heat the rest of the oil over a medium heat until shimmering. Add half the gnocchi and fry until lightly golden on each side, around 3-4 mins. Transfer them to a tray using a slotted spoon while you cook the second batch. When all the gnocchi are golden, return them all to the pan to warm through before dividing between four plates. Sprinkle over some black pepper, then top with the thyme leaves, toasted walnuts and a drizzle of olive oil, if you like.
chief_review:
This recipe is a delightful blend of hearty root vegetables and aromatic herbs, resulting in a dish with lovely texture and depth. The use of parsnips and potatoes provides a naturally sweet and earthy base, while nutritional yeast adds a welcome umami note that’s often sought after in plant-based cooking. The addition of walnuts and thyme gives a nice finish with both crunch and freshness.

This dish is well-suited for both vegan and vegetarian diets, as it excludes animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, the recipe is free from common allergens like dairy and eggs, making it suitable for those with such restrictions. However, note that ‘00’ flour contains gluten, so it is not suitable for gluten-free diets.

For freezing, it’s best to do so after forming the patties but before frying—this will preserve texture and flavor. Simply defrost and fry or bake to crisp up when ready to serve.

name: Baby potato fondants
description: This sumptuous side dish uses small new potatoes cooked until buttery-soft inside with crispy skins on the outside
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 garlic clove, left whole but smashed once
directions: Put the potatoes, garlic and bay leaves in a large lidded sauté pan. Pour over the wine, add the butter and put the lid on the pan. Set over a medium heat and simmer for 1 hr until the wine has completely evaporated and the potatoes are coated in the buttery juices.

Reduce heat to low, then sizzle the potatoes in the buttery mixture, shaking the pan and turning the potatoes occasionally until they are completely cooked through, and the skins are brown and crisp. Serve scooped straight from the pan with a sprinkling of sea salt.
chief_review: This recipe delivers beautifully textured baby potatoes—crisp and golden on the outside, tender within—enhanced by the aromatic complexity of garlic, bay leaves, and dry white wine. The addition of butter creates a rich, luscious finish and deepens the overall flavor profile, making it a crowd-pleasing accompaniment to roasts or grilled dishes. The technique of simmering with wine imparts a sophisticated note, elevating a simple side to restaurant-quality fare. This dish is ideal for vegetarian diets, though not suitable for vegans due to the use of butter. It steers clear of common allergens like nuts and soy, but those avoiding alcohol may need to adapt the recipe. Perfect for festive meals or everyday excellence, these potatoes showcase how humble ingredients can be transformed by careful technique and thoughtful seasoning.

name: Cherry choc muffins
description: Expert baker Paul Hollywood takes this classic flavour combination and creates cute individual cakes
author: Paul Hollywood
ingredients: 200g dark chocolate, chopped into small pieces
directions: In a mixer using the blade attachment, cream together the butter and sugar. Add the eggs, one at a time, and mix for 4 mins. Add the flour, baking powder and milk, and mix for a further 4 mins on slow, then mix in the chocolate.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut 16 squares of baking parchment big enough to act as cases for the holes of your muffin tins. Using a piping bag or a spoon, fill the muffin cases with the mixture. When all the cases are filled, share the cherries equally between the muffins, pushing them into the mixture as you go. Bake for 25 mins, then serve warm or cold.
chief_review: Paul Hollywood’s individual cakes masterfully showcase the timeless union of dark chocolate and Morello cherry. The butter and eggs contribute richness and a delicate crumb, while the plain flour, leavened gently with baking powder, yields a beautifully tender base. Chopped dark chocolate throughout each portion ensures bursts of deep cocoa flavor, perfectly offset by the tartness of the cherries. The splash of milk softens the batter, keeping the cakes moist and light. This recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat products. The use of high-quality ingredients and precise technique elevates a familiar combination into a sophisticated treat, ideal for afternoon tea or as an elegant dessert. These individual cakes balance flavor and texture—an irresistible bake for chocolate and cherry lovers alike.

name: Fennel & chestnut loaf with cranberry relish
description: Good Food reader Barbara Keen shares her vegetarian loaf recipe with seasonal chestnut and cranberry
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp sunflower oil, plus extra for greasing
directions: Place the chestnuts and berries in a small pan, pour over enough water to just cover. Bring to the boil then remove from the heat, cover and leave to infuse until cool. Once cool, drain chestnuts and discard berries. Meanwhile, heat the oil in a medium-size pan and fry the onion until soft. Add the fennel and cook for 3-4 mins.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a 1lb loaf tin with oil. Transfer mixture to a mixing bowl and stir in the chestnuts and remaining ingredients with some seasoning. Put into the tin, smooth the top a bit, and cook for 35-40 mins until light golden. Leave to cool for a few mins in the tin before removing.

While it’s cooking make the cranberry relish. Place the cranberries in a small pan and pour over 150ml of water. Bring to the boil and cook until they’re soft. Reduce the heat and add the sugar. Simmer until the mixture has thickened. Remove from the heat and allow to cool. Add the orange and serve with the loaf.
chief_review: Barbara Keen's chestnut and cranberry vegetarian loaf is a vibrant celebration of seasonal ingredients perfectly balanced between earthy and bright flavors. The chestnuts and ground almonds provide a nutty richness, complemented beautifully by the tang and fragrance of fresh cranberries and orange zest. Fennel and thyme add depth, while the juniper berries introduce a subtle, aromatic hint reminiscent of festive dishes. The addition of wholemeal breadcrumbs offers structure and a satisfying texture. This recipe is an excellent fit for a vegetarian diet, and its thoughtful use of fresh produce makes it both wholesome and hearty. While it does contain nuts and eggs, it cleverly avoids meat and integrates festive flavors, making it an ideal centerpiece for holiday tables or special gatherings. Serve with a light salad or steamed greens for a well-rounded meal.

name: Mince pie trees
description: Love mince pies? They you'll love these little tree-shaped Danish pastry-like bites, with their layers of buttery pastry bonded with fruity, gooey mincemeat
author: Good Food
ingredients: 425g pack ready-rolled puff pastry (2 sheets in each pack)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Line two baking sheets with baking parchment. Unroll one of the pastry sheets onto a lightly floured surface, with the long edge nearest you. Spread with mincemeat, top with the second sheet of pastry, then cut in half, widthways, down the middle.

For each piece, cut into 4 strips down, measuring 6cm, 4cm, 2cm, and 1cm in width. Next, cut across evenly to make 12 ‘ladders’ of pastry. Dip the knife in flour if it sticks. Brush with egg. Chill for 10 mins.

Build the trees on the baking sheets. Stack the strips, mincemeat middles facing up, starting with the longest and finishing with the smallest. It helps them look more tree- like if you fold them a little in the middle, too. Once stacked, squash with your hand to flatten into a tree shape. Can be frozen for up to a month. Bake for 20 mins (25 mins from frozen) or until the pastry is golden and the mincemeat bubbling. Leave to cool on the tray for 5 mins, then lift onto a wire rack with a palette knife and let cool completely. Dust with icing sugar to serve.
chief_review: These festive, tree-shaped Danish pastry bites capture the essence of classic mince pies but offer a delightful twist with crisp, flaky puff pastry and rich, fruity mincemeat. The recipe cleverly uses ready-rolled puff pastry for convenience, making it ideal for quick holiday entertaining. A light dusting of flour ensures the pastries don’t stick, while the beaten egg wash gives them a beautiful golden sheen. Finished with a whisper of icing sugar, they’re as visually appealing as they are delicious. Suitable for vegetarian diets (provided the mincemeat is suet-free or made with vegetarian suet) and nut-free preparations (as long as the mincemeat and pastry are nut-free), these bites are a crowd-pleasing treat for your next seasonal gathering.

name: Madeira gravy
description: A good gravy is an essential accompaniment for the festive meal. This one's enriched with Madeira (fortified wine)
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 600ml turkey or chicken stock, fresh or made with cubes
200ml/7fl oz turkeyjuices, skimmed of all fat (make up with stock if you don't have enough; add it all if you have more)
directions: Gradually mix the Madeira into the flour until smooth. Heat the stock in a pan, then pour in the flour mixture and mustard, stirring until thickened. Chill until ready to serve, covering the surface with cling film to stop a skin forming. On the day, reheat in a pan with the turkey juices until bubbling.
chief_review: This Madeira-enriched gravy is a classic complement to festive poultry, delivering deep, layered flavors with the addition of turkey or chicken stock and rich roasting juices. The use of wholegrain mustard adds a gentle piquancy, balancing the sweetness of the fortified wine. The plain flour provides reliable thickening, resulting in a glossy, velvety sauce. This recipe is naturally suitable for gluten-free diets if you simply swap the plain flour for a gluten-free alternative. Additionally, using a good-quality stock cube allows for quick adaptation, though homemade will always yield the best results. This gravy is a truly luxurious finishing touch for your holiday roast.

name: Braised red cabbage
author: Cassie Best
directions: Quarter the red cabbage and remove the core, then finely shred. Tip into a large pan with the red onion, brown sugar, cider vinegar, red wine, butter and cinnamon stick and season well. Bring to a simmer, then cover with a lid, lower the heat and cook for 1 1/ 2 hrs, stirring every so often. Remove the lid and continue cooking for 30 mins until tender.
chief_review:
This braised red cabbage recipe is a beautifully balanced side dish, layering sweet, tangy, and earthy flavors. The combination of red cabbage, red onion, brown sugar, and cider vinegar yields a deliciously tender result, while the addition of red wine and a cinnamon stick adds depth and subtle warmth. The butter rounds out the dish, imparting a rich silkiness to the final texture. 

Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe can also be enjoyed by those seeking gluten-free options, as none of the listed ingredients contain gluten. However, individuals with dairy allergies or lactose intolerance should note the inclusion of butter, though it can easily be substituted with a plant-based alternative for a vegan version. This simple yet elegant side pairs wonderfully with roasted meats, festive mains, or as part of a hearty winter meal.

name: Winter spice jelly
description: This spiced jam can be stored to eat with meat or cheese or presented as a homemade gift
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 blade mace, or ¼ tsp ground mace
directions: Wash and cut up the apples into small chunks, leaving the peel and cores in. Tip the apple into a large pan with the spices, orange peel and bay leaves, reserving 2 star anise, 4 cloves and 2 bay leaves for the jars. Cover with 600ml water. Bring to the boil, then turn down the heat and simmer with a lid on for 1 1⁄2 hrs.

Pour the apple mixture into a jelly bag or a sieve lined with muslin or a J-cloth, suspended over a large bowl. Leave to drip for 2 hrs (until it stops dripping) or overnight. Do not be tempted to push the liquid though the sieve or your jelly will become cloudy.
Measure the juice – you should have about 600ml. Pour the liquid into a large pan along with the jam sugar and vinegar.

Set over a low heat to dissolve the sugar, stirring constantly. Once dissolved, turn up the heat and bring to the boil. Boil rapidly for 15 mins, or until setting point is reached, skimming away any scum that rises to the surface.
Pour jelly into hot sterilised jars and place a star anise, bay leaf and 2 cloves into each jar. Chill for 3-4 hrs or overnight until set.
chief_review:
This spiced apple jam is a masterful blend of warming spices and tart apples, delivering depth and complexity ideal for pairing with both meat and cheese platters. The use of cinnamon, star anise, and orange peel brings a festive note, while the cider vinegar provides balance to the natural sweetness, making the preserve nuanced rather than cloying. The inclusion of jam sugar ensures a set texture and glossy finish.

Vegetarians will appreciate its suitability, as there are no animal-derived ingredients. Furthermore, the absence of common allergens like nuts, dairy, or eggs makes it widely accessible. This recipe avoids gluten-containing ingredients, making it a suitable treat for those following a gluten-free diet when served with appropriate accompaniments. Presented in jars, this jam makes an elegant and thoughtful homemade gift, sure to impress with its aromatic profile and versatility.

name: Cranberry, pineapple & date chutney
description: Perk up cold ham and turkey with this tangy chutney. Or, make a batch, put into pretty jars, and give as Christmas gifts
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Peel, core and roughly chop the apples and pineapple. Peel and roughly chop the onions. Mix together the apples, pineapple, onions, cranberries, dates, raisins, garlic and ginger.
Put the mix of fruit and vegetables in batches through the food processor until finely chopped. Tip into a large wide pan or preserving pan.

Add the spices, salt and vinegar and bring to the boil. Simmer for 20 mins until the apple is pulpy, then add the sugar and stir to dissolve. Bring to theboil, then simmer for about 40-45 mins, until the chutney is thick and pulpy.
Pot into warm, sterilised jars. Seal, label and store for at least a month in a cool dry place.
chief_review:
This festive chutney is a vibrant addition to any holiday table, bursting with fruity sweetness from apples, pineapple, cranberries, dates, and raisins, balanced by warming spices and a touch of heat from chilli flakes. The spiced vinegar and muscovado sugar offer depth and a glossy finish. Its richness is ideal for pairing with roast meats like ham and turkey, but it also shines as an accompaniment for cheese boards. 

Vegetarians will appreciate the absence of animal products in this recipe, making it a versatile pantry staple or a thoughtful homemade gift. There’s no gluten or dairy among the listed ingredients, so it caters to those dietary needs as well. The process is straightforward for novice and experienced cooks alike, yet the flavors develop into something truly celebratory and complex.

name: Mushroom & chestnut rotolo
description:
Oh how I laughed as the slippery pasta sheets and slippery mushroom sauce failed to roll, or cut without all the musrooms sliding out the sides of the pasta.. In the end, I made lots of pasta rolls stood them up and poured the sauce in from the top.... Whereupon it slumped during cooking leaving the lasagne sheets one notch crunchier than a bag of walkers Crisps.
The end result tasted OK, however it would be far easier to simply layer it as a lasagne.
In conclusion, unless you are Harry Potter, or have him at hand, don't try rolling it up. As for doing it on a clean towel? You could maybe cut the middle man out and just eat the towel for a nutritious vegan meal instead. P. S. - Save the rest of the White wine.. You will need it to ease the pain.
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 500g fresh wild mushrooms, brushed clean and roughly chopped
½ small pack sage, leaves picked
directions: Soak the dried mushrooms in 350ml boiling water and set aside until needed. Blitz ¾ of the chestnuts with 150ml water until creamy. Roughly chop the remaining chestnuts.
Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a large

. Fry the shallots with a pinch of salt until softened, then add the garlic, chopped chestnuts and rosemary, and fry for 2 mins more. Add the wild mushrooms, 2 tbsp oil and some seasoning. Cook for 3 mins until they begin to soften. Drain and roughly chop the dried mushrooms (reserve the soaking liquid), then add those too, along with the soy sauce, and fry for 2 mins more.

the wine, reserved mushroom liquid and chestnut cream together to create a sauce. Season, then add half to the mushroom mixture in the pan and cook for 1 min until the sauce becomes glossy. Remove and discard the rosemary sprigs, then set the mixture aside.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil and get a large bowl of ice water ready. Drop the lasagne sheets into the boiling water for 2 mins or until pliable and a little cooked, then immediately plunge them into the cold water. Using your fingers, carefully separate the sheets and transfer to a clean tea towel. Spread a good spoonful of the sauce on the bottom two thirds of each sheet, then, rolling away from yourself, roll up the shorter ends. Cut each roll in half, then position the rolls of pasta cut-side up in a pie dish that you are happy to serve from at the table. If you have any mushroom sauce remaining after you’ve rolled up all the sheets, simply push it into some of the exposed rolls of pasta.
Pour the rest of the sauce over the top of the pasta, then bake for 10 mins or until the pasta no longer has any resistance when tested with a skewer.

Meanwhile, put the breadcrumbs, the last 2 tbsp olive oil, sage leaves and some seasoning in a bowl, and toss everything together. Scatter the rotolo with the crumbs and sage, then bake for another 10 mins, until the top is golden and the sage leaves are crispy. Leave to cool for 10 mins to allow the pasta to absorb the sauce, then drizzle with a little truffle oil, if you like, before taking your dish to the table.
chief_review:
An ingenious attempt at reimagining classic lasagne, this recipe showcases a medley of mushrooms and chestnuts bound by aromatic herbs. The use of vegan wine, soy sauce, and olive oil ensures the entire dish is plant-based, making it perfectly suited for vegans and vegetarians. The combination of dried and fresh mushrooms deepens the umami, and the chestnuts add a delightful earthiness.

However, the ambitious rolling technique proves tricky, often resulting in a compromised texture. As the reviewer notes, layering the lasagne sheets traditionally is not only easier but likely yields a more cohesive dish. 

A notable bonus: this recipe contains no dairy or eggs, and with gluten-free lasagne sheets and panko, it could be made suitable for gluten-free diets as well. Overall, it promises rich, hearty flavors—best enjoyed with a glass of that reserved white wine!

name: Gingerbread jumpers
description: Cover these cute gingerbread biscuits with icing and sprinkles in Christmas jumper patterns for a fantastically festive bake
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 350g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
food colouringpaste in various colours, or use coloured icing tubes (and you won’t need the fondant icing sugar)
directions: Put the sugar, golden syrup and butter in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer, then bubble for 1-2 mins, stirring until well combined. Set aside to cool for 10 mins.

Tip the flour, bicarbonate of soda and spices into a large bowl. Add the warm syrup mixture and the egg, stir to bring everything together, then gently knead in the bowl until smooth and streak-free. The dough will feel a little soft now, but will firm up once cooled. Wrap the dough in cling film and chill for at least 30 mins.
Remove the dough from the fridge and and leave at room temperature until softened. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line two baking trays with baking parchment.

Working with half the dough at a time (keeping the remaining dough well wrapped), roll out to the thickness of a £1 coin, keeping the dough in a rough rectangle shape. Cut the dough into long strips, roughly 8cm wide, then cut each strip into ‘jumpers’ (see step-by-step). Cut out a V-neck for the collar and trim slim triangular pieces from either side to create sleeves (see step-by-step). Continue rolling and shaping the dough until you have about 20 jumper shapes. Arrange over the trays and bake for 8 mins until a few shades darker and puffed up a little. Cool on the trays for 5 mins, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. Un-iced, the biscuits will keep in a sealed container for up to 2 weeks.

For ‘flooded’ biscuits, mix 100g fondant icing sugar with enough water to make a thick but pipeable icing – it should hold its shape when piped. Transfer the icing to a piping bag fitted with a fine round nozzle and pipe a line around the edge of each biscuit. If you have any icing left, tip it back into a bowl and add the remaining icing sugar, then add enough water to make an icing a little looser than the first batch, but not too runny. Divide the icing between as many bowls as the number of colours you’d like to use, then add a tiny bit of colouring to each and mix well until you have a vivid colour.
If you have disposable piping bags, transfer the icings to different bags and secure the open ends (see tip).

To pipe your jumpers using the 'flooding' directions, pipe the runnier icing onto the biscuit, then use a cocktail stick to encourage it to fill every corner up to the piped border. Once dry, you can add details like fluffy collars and cuffs or spots and stripes with the thicker icing.

To pipe your jumpers with a cable knit effect, pipe lines of coloured icing (we used white) vertically across the jumper. Use a toothpick to drag up and down through the icing to create a wave effect.
Finish off with sugar sprinkles if desired - we used mini gingerbread men, snowflakes, white ‘mimosa’ balls and gold polka dot sprinkles (see tip).
chief_review: These charming gingerbread biscuits are a festive delight, bringing classic holiday flavors together with playful, decorative flair. The use of dark muscovado sugar and golden syrup imparts a deep, rich sweetness, while ground ginger and cinnamon lend the perfect spicy warmth. The dough is easy to work with and holds its shape beautifully—ideal for crafting those whimsical Christmas jumper patterns. The finishing touch of fondant icing and colourful sprinkles invites creative expression, making this a great project for families or holiday gatherings. Additionally, the recipe is vegetarian-friendly, as all ingredients used are plant-based or derived from dairy and eggs, with no gelatin or meat products involved. For those mindful of allergens, be aware that it contains wheat, butter, and eggs. Overall, this recipe is as delicious as it is festive, promising both fun in the kitchen and on the holiday table.

name: Coffee lover's kit
description: Ginger biscuits wrapped up with a tin of coffee and a pair or espresso cups make a very cute Christmas gift set
author: Good Food
ingredients: 300g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
pack or tin of ground coffee
directions: Heat oven to 170C/150C fan/gas 3-4. Line 2 baking trays with baking parchment. Melt butter, sugar and syrup in a pan, stirring until the sugar melts. Take off the heat. Sieve the flour, bicarb and ground ginger into a bowl, pour in the wet ingredients and add the stem ginger. Stir to make a stiff dough.

Roll the warm dough out on a surface dusted with flour until about ½cm thick. Stamp out biscuits using a cutter, lift onto the baking trays and cook for 10 mins or until golden. Cool completely, then lift off parchment.
Pack the biscuits in an airtight box, bag or jar, then put in a gift box with the cups and coffee and tie with a ribbon.
chief_review: These ginger biscuits are a delightful treat, perfectly spiced with both ground and stem ginger, creating a rich depth of flavour and a lovely chewy texture. The use of dark muscovado sugar and golden syrup adds warmth and a subtle molasses undertone, enhancing the biscuits’ festive charm. Assembling them with a tin of quality ground coffee and a pair of espresso cups transforms this bake into a thoughtful and beautifully presented Christmas gift. This recipe suits a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients except dairy. For best results, ensure your dough is well chilled before rolling, allowing you to cut crisp, uniform shapes. Pack the finished biscuits in an airtight container to preserve freshness, and enjoy the spicy-sweet aroma when each box is opened. An impressively simple yet elegant homemade gift.

name: Fennel & poppy seed cracker wreath
description: Arrange savoury biscuits in a pretty circle around your chosen cheese for a decorative centrepiece and alternative cheeseboard
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 300g plain flour, plus extra for rolling
2 tsp fennel seed, plus extra to sprinkle
2 tsp poppy seed, plus extra to sprinkle
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line one baking sheet with parchment. Place the flour, baking powder, butter, fennel and poppy seeds with ½ tsp salt in a food processor, then whizz for a minute until the butter is completely mixed with the flour. Add 100ml water and pulse until the mixture comes together to a firm dough that’s not sticky – you may need another tbsp or so of water, if it still feels.

Roll out dough on a lightly floured surface as thinly as you can. Stamp out lots of different sized circles using a selection of round and fluted biscuit cutters of 4cm, 5cm and 6cm diameter. Brush a little milk over the surface of the biscuits, and prick all over with a fork. Start to arrange in a circle on the baking sheet, overlapping each other. If you want to serve a cheese in the centre, check that it will fit. Scatter over a few more fennel and poppy seeds and bake for 15 - 20 mins until the biscuits feel dry and sandy with a slightly golden colour around the edges - they may still feel soft but will harden up when cooling. Cool on the baking sheet. Serve with cheese & chutney. Will keep in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on the traditional cheeseboard by featuring homemade savoury biscuits arranged artfully around your favorite cheese. The use of fennel and poppy seeds brings a nuanced flavour, lending both aroma and a satisfying crunch. The buttery dough, enriched with baking powder, bakes up tender yet crisp—an ideal vehicle for cheeses of all kinds. The preparation is straightforward, making it accessible to both beginner and experienced cooks. This recipe suits a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients apart from dairy. Additionally, its reliance on basic pantry staples means it’s both affordable and easy to adapt for various herbs or spices. Serve these biscuits warm or cooled, and enjoy their subtle sophistication as part of any elegant spread.

name: Sticky date & raisin pudding
description: Keep everyone happy with this sticky toffee-like steamed basin pudding packed with dried fruit
author: Good Food
ingredients: 140g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Put the dates, raisins, milk and brandy or rum in a small saucepan and bring to the boil. Simmer for 5 mins until the fruit is soft and the liquid has been absorbed – don’t worry if it looks a little curdled. Leave to cool. Meanwhile, generously butter a 1.2-litre pudding basin.

To prepare your steamer, place a snugly fitting upturned bowl or saucer in the base of a large, deep saucepan, big enough to hold your pudding basin. Cut out a large circle of baking parchment and one of foil, both 5cm wider than the rim of your pudding basin. Make a sharp pleat down the centre of both, then butter one side of the parchment – this will be your lid. Set aside. Boil the kettle for the steamer.

In a mixing bowl, beat the butter and sugar with an electric whisk until pale and fluffy. Add the eggs, beating again until well combined. Finally, add the flour, mixed spice, orange zest, date mixture and a pinch of salt, and stir everything well with a spatula until there are no visible lumps of flour. Tip the cake mixture into your pudding basin. Cover the bowl with the parchment, butter-side down and pleat on top, then the foil. Push the sides of the lid down, then tie a piece of string securely under the lip of the basin. Use any overhanging string to create a handle to help you lift the pudding.

Stand the pudding basin on top of the upturned bowl or saucer in the saucepan and fill the pan with enough boiling water to come halfway up the side of the basin. Bring to a gentle simmer, then cover the pan with a lid and leave to steam for 2½ hrs, topping up with boiling water if the level gets low. Check the pudding is cooked by inserting a skewer into the centre. If the skewer has any uncooked mixture on it, return it to the pan to steam for another 15 mins, then check again. Once cooked, you can cover the pudding with clean baking parchment and foil and keep for up to a week. Re-steam the pudding for 1 hr before serving.
chief_review: This steamed basin pudding is a comforting dessert redolent of classic British sticky toffee, yet with an added burst of flavor from generous amounts of dried dates, raisins, and a lively touch of orange zest. The soft brown sugar and butter create a rich, moist crumb, while the brandy or rum infuses a subtle warmth, making it a true celebration pudding. The use of self-raising flour, butter, and eggs means it’s best enjoyed by those without dairy, gluten, or egg sensitivities. However, it's an excellent choice for vegetarians, as no meat or animal-derived gelatins are used. Perfect for festive occasions, this pudding will delight with its deep, fruity sweetness and aromatic spices. Serve warm with a spoonful of cream or custard for the ultimate treat.

name: Clementine custard
description: This take on a traditional accompaniment has zesty citrus flavours and you can make it ahead to save time
author: Good Food
directions: Put the cream and milk into a large pan and gently bring to just below boiling point. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, whisk together the yolks, cornflour, sugar, clementine zest and juice. Gradually pour on the hot milk mixture, whisking the sugar mixture constantly.
Wipe out the saucepan and pour the custard mixture back into it. Heat gently, stirring with a wooden spoon, until the custard is thickened, coating the spoon. Eat hot or cold.
chief_review: This citrus-infused take on a classic custard strikes a perfect balance between creamy richness and fresh, zesty flavor. The combination of double cream and whole milk delivers a luxurious texture, while the clementine zest and juice provide a bright, fragrant lift, making it an excellent complement to fruit-based desserts or simple cakes. Preparation ahead of time allows the flavors to meld harmoniously and saves you precious moments during a busy service. Thanks to the use of cornflour as a thickener, this recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the cornflour is certified gluten-free. The pronounced citrus profile brings a delightful twist to a traditional accompaniment, elevating it with both elegance and freshness. This custard is sure to impress guests seeking something familiar yet exciting.

name: Cranberry, maple & pecan pudding
description: Dairy-free, wheat-free and gluten-free - this Christmas pudding is moist and has a real zing. A less rich, more refreshing way to round off Christmas dinner
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g each semi-dried prunes and date, stoned and chopped
grated zest and juice of 2 oranges
directions: Put all the ingredients for the pudding into a big bowl and stir together until well mixed. Don’t be put off by the consistency of the mixture – it is quite wet. Lightly oil a 1.5 litre pudding basin. Tip the mixture into this and press down. Make a cover for the pudding basin using a double layer each of oiled greaseproof paper and aluminium foil. Make a pleat in the middle of these sheets to allow for expansion of the pudding. Press it over the top of the pudding basin and secure it well with a double piece of string. Use a little extra string to make a handle for ease of lifting in and out of the boiling water.

Cook the pudding in a large pan with a well-fitting lid. There should be enough boiling water to come two-thirds up the sides of the basin at all times – so keep an eye on it. Cook the pudding for 3 hrs.

To make the topping, cook the cranberries in the maple syrup until they burst open and become syrupy. Once the pudding is cooked, remove the cover and carefully tip it onto a large serving plate. Spoon the hot cranberry and maple syrup over the top and serve straight away.
chief_review: This Christmas pudding is a refreshing twist on the classic, beautifully balancing sweet and tangy notes from prunes, dates, and cranberries with the zesty brightness of fresh orange. The use of gluten-free flour and baking powder ensures that those with gluten sensitivities can enjoy this festive treat, and its dairy-free composition makes it suitable for those with lactose intolerance or a dairy-free diet. The addition of pecans introduces a lovely crunch and depth of flavor, while the maple syrup and dark muscovado sugar provide a natural, rich sweetness. The result is a pudding that is moist, aromatic, and far less heavy than traditional versions—a perfect, lighter finale to your holiday meal.

name: Reindeer cupcakes
description: Kids will love making these cute Christmas cupcakes from Planet Cake
author: Good Food
ingredients: 500g fondant icingcoloured brown, 100g/4oz of it a paler brown
twigs or wire for the antlers and spaghettifor attaching the ears
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line the holes of a 12-hole muffin tin with paper cases.
Beat the butter, sugar and vanilla in a medium bowl using an electric mixer until light and fluffy.
Beat the eggs into the butter mixture one at a time. Add half the sifted flours and half the buttermilk, and mix on low speed until just combined. Mix in the remaining flours and buttermilk.
Divide the mix evenly among the paper cases. Gently smooth the tops (this will help the cupcakes to rise evenly).
Bake for 25-30 mins or until lightly golden and cooked when tested with a skewer. Allow to stand for 5 mins in the tin before transferring to a wire rack to cool.
To make the ganache, put the chocolate in a bowl, bring the cream to a simmer and pour it over the chocolate. Stir until smooth. Cool until firm.

Ice the cupcakes with ganache, then with brown fondant icing. Use the rest of the colours for the ears, eye and nose. Attach ears to the head by pushing a 3cm piece of spaghetti a little way into the ear, then pushing the other end into the head. See below to download more detailed instructions. Remember to warn people that not every element of the decoration is edible!
chief_review: These Christmas cupcakes from Planet Cake are a whimsical festive treat, perfect for engaging kids in holiday baking. The sponge itself is beautifully soft, thanks to the combination of butter, buttermilk, and eggs, producing a moist and tender crumb. The dual use of self-raising and plain flour yields a light yet stable base for creative decorating. The fondant icings allow for fun, customizable decorations with a smooth, professional finish, while the chocolate and double cream contribute a rich, luscious element. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no animal-derived gelatine or meat products. However, note that it contains common allergens such as eggs, dairy, and gluten. For families and young bakers, this is a delightful project that promises both fun in the making and joy in the eating—a wonderful holiday experience.

name: Cauliflower & carrot salad
description: Keep this healthy salad in the fridge to serve with cold meats or cheese
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Break cauliflower into florets, cutting any larger ones into thin slices. Mix with carrots, red onion, capers and chopped parsley. Whisk white wine vinegar with Dijon mustard, season, then whisk in olive oil and mayonnaise.
Pour over the salad and mix well. Can be stored in the fridge for up to 3 days.
chief_review: This vibrant salad combines crisp cauliflower, sweet grated carrot, and tangy capers, all brought together with a delicate white wine vinaigrette. The addition of parsley and red onion gives it a refreshing bite, while the touch of Dijon mustard and mayonnaise adds creaminess without being heavy. This recipe is perfect for vegetarians and those on a gluten-free diet, as all ingredients are plant-based and free from wheat-derived products. Additionally, it features a colorful medley of raw vegetables, making it both nutritious and satisfying. The salad’s light acidity pairs exceptionally well with both cold meats and cheeses, as suggested, but it’s just as delicious as a standalone dish or picnic staple. Easy to prepare and packed with flavor, this is a versatile, wholesome choice for a range of dietary preferences.

name: Chocolate fudge cake with angel frosting
description: The ultimate in indulgence, this chocolate fudge cake looks like a star with American-style frosting and bakes in just one tin
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 250g dark chocolate, broken into chunks - standard supermarket chocolate is fine
300g light, soft brown sugar, plus 2 tbsp
200ml sunflower oil, plus a little extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 4 and grease and line a deep, 20cm round cake tin. Whizz the chocolate in a food processor until crumbs. Tip the flour, sugar, cocoa, oil, 150ml soured cream, eggs, vanilla and 150ml water into the largest mixing bowl you have. Whisk with an electric whisk until smooth, then quickly stir in 150g of your whizzed-up chocolate bits. Scrape into a tin, and bake on the middle shelf for 1 hr 20-1 hr 30 mins, or until a skewer inserted in the centre comes out clean. Cool in the tin.

While the cake is baking, make the icing. Combine remaining chocolate bits and soured cream with 2 tbsp soft brown sugar in a small saucepan and heat, stirring, until the chocolate is melted and you have a smooth icing. Leave to cool.
When the cake is cool, slice it into 3 even layers. Spread 2 layers with chocolate icing.

To make the angel frosting, put the sugar, vanilla and liquid glucose in a pan with 125ml water. Bring to the boil and cook just until the sugar has melted and the syrup turns clear. Take off the heat. Meanwhile, beat the egg whites until stiff, then continue beating, gradually pouring in the hot sugar syrup in a steady stream, until the mixture is fluffy and thick enough to spread – this might take a few mins as the mixture cools. Beat in the icing sugar. Work quickly and spread a tiny bit over each chocolate-covered layer. Assemble cake and swirl remaining frosting over entire cake.
chief_review: This chocolate fudge cake is a showstopper—moist, dense, and exceptionally rich thanks to a generous use of dark chocolate and cocoa. The cake benefits from sunflower oil and soured cream, which ensure a tender crumb and balanced richness without tasting heavy. American-style frosting made with egg whites and glucose creates a luxuriously glossy finish, striking the perfect contrast against the dark cake layers. The use of self-raising flour makes for a light rise, and the brown sugar imparts a subtle caramel depth. Suitable for vegetarians, this cake caters to those avoiding gelatine, but do note that it contains eggs and dairy. Overall, it’s a celebration-worthy treat—ideal for birthdays or special occasions—offering both visual appeal and an indulgent, melt-in-the-mouth experience.

name: Cranberry meringue roulade
description: Work on your meringue skills to roll up this sensational dessert with tangy fruit, toasted almonds and vanilla cream filling
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 250ml fresh pomegranate juice(not pomegranate juice drink), or use orange juice
100g white caster sugar, plus 1-2 tbsp to taste (optional)
¼ tsp arrowrootmixed with 1 tsp cold water
3 tbsp icing sugar, sifted, plus extra for dusting
½ tsp vanillapaste, or seeds from ½ vanilla pod
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease then line a 23 x 32cm shallow baking tray. Using electric hand beaters, whisk the egg whites, lemon juice and a pinch of salt until stiff but not dry.

Add 1 tbsp of the caster sugar, then whisk until the mixture thickens again to make stiff peaks. Repeat with the rest of the sugar, spoon by spoon, until the mix resembles thick shiny shaving foam. Spread the mixture into the tin, scatter with almonds, then bake for 15 mins or until risen, firm and golden. Cool completely. (It will deflate.)

Simmer the cranberries in the pomegranate juice for 10 mins until tender. Add the sugar and cinnamon, and simmer for 5 mins or until syrupy. Taste and add more sugar if you need to. Stir in the arrowroot until the juices thicken, then leave to cool.

To assemble, sift plenty of icing sugar over a large piece of parchment, then carefully flip the meringue onto it. Remove the tin and the baking parchment. With a short end facing you, score a line 2cm into meringue. Whip all the cream ingredients until thick but not stiff, then spread over the meringue. Spoon over about 1/3 of the cranberry sauce. Roll up the roulade, starting with the scored short end and using the paper underneath to help. Carefully lift onto a serving plate and serve with the remaining saucy cranberries.
chief_review:
This festive roulade beautifully showcases classic meringue technique, pairing the crisp, marshmallow-like texture with a decadent vanilla cream filling. The tartness from cranberries and pomegranate juice provides a refreshing counterpoint to the sweetness, while toasted flaked almonds add a delightful crunch. Using Greek yogurt in the filling lends a gentle tang and lightness, complementing the whipped cream. 

This recipe is ideal for those following a gluten-free diet, as it contains no wheat or gluten-derived ingredients. Its focus on dairy means it isn’t suitable for vegans or the lactose-intolerant, but it is an excellent choice for those seeking an elegant, crowd-pleasing, gluten-free dessert. Overall, the roulade is a sophisticated finish for any special occasion, rewarding the baker with both skill-honing and stunning results.

name: Stuffed pumpkin
description: I thought the fennel was a bit overpowering and really detracted from the delicious pumpkin. Pomegranate seeds made this dish sing though, so don't be tempted to leave them out!
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut the top off the pumpkin or squash and use a metal spoon to scoop out the seeds. Get rid of any pithy bits but keep the seeds for another time (see our
). Put the pumpkin on a baking tray, rub with 2 tbsp of the oil inside and out, and season well. Roast in the centre of the oven for 45 mins or until tender, with the ‘lid’ on the side.

Meanwhile, rinse the wild rice well and cook following pack instructions, then spread out on a baking tray to cool. Thinly slice the fennel bulb and apple, then squeeze over ½ the lemon juice to stop them discolouring.

Heat the remaining 2 tbsp oil in a frying pan. Fry the fennel seeds and chilli flakes, then, once the seeds begin to pop, stir in ½ the garlic and the fennel. Cook for 5 mins until softened, then mix through the apple, pecans and lemon zest. Remove from the heat. Add the mixture to the the cooked rice, then stir in the chopped parsley and taste for seasoning.
Pack the mixture into the cooked pumpkin and return to the oven for 10-15 mins until everything is piping hot. Meanwhile,
the remaining lemon juice with the tahini, the rest of the garlic and enough water to make a dressing. Serve the pumpkin in the middle of the table, topped with pomegranate seeds and the dressing.
chief_review:
This vibrant dish showcases autumnal flavors with roasted pumpkin and a medley of textures from wild rice, toasted pecans, and zesty pomegranate seeds. The fennel, both bulb and seed, brings a bold anise note that could overshadow the delicate sweetness of the pumpkin, so I’d suggest moderating its quantity or slicing it thinly for balance. The pomegranate seeds truly elevate the dish, lending bursts of freshness and color—an essential finishing touch. The use of olive oil, tahini, and fresh parsley rounds out the flavors with a Mediterranean flair.

With no animal-derived ingredients or gluten-containing grains, this recipe is well-suited for both vegan and gluten-free diets. It is also appropriate for those seeking a dairy-free or egg-free option. Carefully check wild rice sources for cross-contamination if preparing for someone with celiac disease. Overall, a beautiful, nourishing salad best enjoyed as a centerpiece or hearty side.

name: Mashed carrots with Pernod
description: This recipe from chef John Tovey sounds like an odd combination, but Sara wouldn't be without it for her Christmas lunch
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Boil the carrots for 20 mins until tender, then drain and return to the pan. Mash with the butter, Pernod and plenty of seasoning until fairly smooth and most of the moisture has evaporated. Tip in a bowl and cover. This will keep in the fridge for 2 days. On the day, heat in the microwave on High for 7 mins, or in the oven for 20 mins, until piping hot.
chief_review: Chef John Tovey’s carrot dish is a surprising yet elegant addition to a festive table, combining classic ingredients with a novel twist. The sweetness of the carrots finds a sophisticated partner in Pernod, which infuses gentle notes of anise and elevates the humble root vegetable far beyond its everyday character. The butter rounds out the palate with richness, creating a luxe texture that complements the aromatic undertones. This preparation is perfect for vegetarians, providing a flavorful side that brings both tradition and innovation to the holiday meal. The simplicity of the ingredients also makes it naturally gluten-free. A distinctive and memorable accompaniment, this recipe is sure to delight guests looking for something a little out of the ordinary.

name: Sausage, pancetta & rosemary pinwheels
description: Skewering chipolatas with rosemary not only infuses them with flavour but makes a stylish alternative to pigs in blankets
author: Good Food
ingredients: 18 rosemarysprigs, leaves picked and stalks cut into 7½ cm/3in skewers
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Cut the sausages in pairs (so you have 2 sausages still connected by skin). Unwrap the twist between each pair and squeeze into one long, uniform sausage. Place a rasher of pancetta along the length of a sausage, stretching it a little to reach. Roll up the sausage in a pinwheel and secure with a rosemary skewer. Repeat with remaining sausages, pancetta and skewers. Put pinwheels on a greased baking tray and cook for 30 mins until golden.
chief_review: This inventive recipe elevates the classic pigs in blankets by threading chipolatas and pancetta onto rosemary sprigs, adding both fragrance and visual appeal. The rosemary skewers subtly infuse the meat with herbal notes during roasting, resulting in a beautifully aromatic finish. Wrapping the chipolatas in pancetta or streaky bacon brings a pleasant depth of flavour and a satisfying salty crispness. The minimal use of sunflower oil keeps the dish light, allowing the natural flavours of the pork and rosemary to shine. This recipe is ideal for meat-lovers and makes an attractive, crowd-pleasing addition to any holiday spread or canapé selection.

name: Malted milk melting snowman cake
description: Can someone with lots of ambition and time please make this delightful cake for me and ship it to New York? LOL! ;-)
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: 500g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
4 tbsp malt extract(or 2 tbsp vanilla paste)
1 tbsp full-fat milk(or 2 tbsp if using vanilla paste)
2 tbsp malt extract(or 1 tbsp vanilla paste)
1 wooden dowel, cut the same length as the nose
2 white chocolate Mikado sticks, for the arms
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease two 20cm round cake tins and line with baking parchment. Heavily grease a 16cm hemisphere cake tin and stand on a ramekin on a baking sheet to hold it steady.

First, make the sponges. Using electric beaters or a tabletop mixer, beat the butter and sugar together until pale and fluffy. Pour the eggs in, one at a time, giving the mix a thorough beating before adding the next. If the mix starts to look curdled, add 2 tbsp of the plain flour. Beat in the yogurt.

Mix both the flours together, adding ½ tsp salt, and slowly beat into the batter, followed by the malt extract (or vanilla paste) and milk. Spoon half the mixture into one of the 20cm tins, and split the remaining half between the other 20cm tin and the 16cm hemisphere. Bake the smaller amount of cake batter in the 20cm tin and the 16cm tin for 1 hr, and the larger amount for 1 hr 20 mins or until a skewer comes out clean when inserted into the middle of the cakes. Cool in the tin for 10 mins before turning out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

Meanwhile, make the buttercream by beating all the butter and half the icing sugar together using an electric whisk or tabletop mixer. Add the rest of the icing sugar once incorporated, followed by the malt extract (or vanilla paste) and milk. Set aside until ready to use.

To assemble, halve the largest 20cm cake horizontally so you are left with two equal-sized sponges the same size as the remaining 20cm cake. Put a blob of buttercream onto a 23cm cake board (or cake stand) and spread using a palette knife. Stick one of the sponges to the board. Spread a thick layer of buttercream on top of the cake and sandwich another sponge on top. Spread over another thick layer and sit the final sponge on top. Using a palette knife, coat the entire cake in a thin layer of buttercream and smooth the sides and top carefully, working around the whole cake, scraping off any excess icing. Chill in the freezer for 10 mins or in the fridge for 1 hr until set.

Meanwhile, put the hemisphere sponge on the smaller cake board and halve horizontally. Fill the middle with some buttercream, sandwich with the top and coat the entire cake in a thin layer of buttercream. Chill in the freezer for 5 mins or in the fridge for 30 mins.

Take the larger cake out of the fridge/ freezer and coat in another layer of buttercream. Take care when covering this time, as you want a smooth finish to the cake. Running the palette knife under hot water helps smooth over the sides once it is coated completely. Chill again for 5 mins in the freezer.

Cover the hemisphere sponge with buttercream and smooth over with the palette knife. Carefully lift the hemisphere onto the centre of the cake (as the sponge has been frozen you shouldn’t leave finger marks). Press down lightly to set on the buttercream. If there is a gap around the rim, use a small palette knife to fill in with any remaining buttercream. Chill for 10-15 mins.

Meanwhile, make the eyes and nose using coloured fondant. Roll the black fondant into two balls for the eyes, and five smaller balls for the mouth. Roll the orange fondant into a carrot shape. Leave to set and harden slightly while you make the drippy ganache.

Make the drippy ganache by mixing the chocolate and oil and microwaving for 30 secs, stirring and then giving it another 30 secs until melted. Transfer to a squeezy bottle, then pour down the edges of the round cake to create the melting snow effect.

To finish the cake, stick the eyes to the head using a little remaining buttercream. Poke the wooden dowel into the carrot nose, leaving some poking out to stick it to the face. Stick the five small black fondant balls for the mouth and the chocolate buttons down the front of the cake for buttons. Insert the Mikado sticks on either side for the arms. Bring the cake to room temperature before serving.
chief_review:
This indulgent, multi-tiered cake is a showstopper, perfect for ambitious bakers seeking an extravagant centerpiece. With a rich blend of unsalted butter, yogurt, and malt extract (or vanilla), the sponge promises a moist, flavorful crumb, beautifully complemented by a smooth, malty buttercream. Decorative touches like fondant details, chocolate buttons, and Mikado sticks add playful, textural elements, making this cake not just delicious but visually stunning.

Suitable for vegetarians, thanks to the absence of gelatine or animal-derived additives, the recipe also allows a choice between malt extract and vanilla, catering to different flavor profiles. Be aware of potential allergens, as the recipe is heavy on dairy, gluten, and eggs. This cake is an ambitious bake, best suited for celebrations, ensuring both a delicious and impressive result.

name: Mulled Port & lemon
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 cinnamon sticks, plus more to serve (optional)
directions: Using a peeler, pare thin strips of zest from the orange and lemon. Squeeze the juice. Put the zests and juice into a large saucepan, then add the Port and remaining ingredients. Simmer very gently for 20 mins, then leave to cool completely. Can be made up to 1 week ahead and chilled. To serve, 'frost' the glasses if desired (see 'Tip', below left), put ice and slices of orange and lemon in each glass, then carefully pour in equal quantities of the Port and lemonade.
chief_review: This festive punch recipe brilliantly marries the richness of ruby port with the zesty brightness of orange and lemon. The addition of whole spices—star anise, cloves, and cinnamon sticks—imparts a warming complexity that complements the citrus notes. Served over plenty of ice and topped with lemonade, it's refreshingly balanced and perfect for entertaining. Garnishing with extra citrus slices and cinnamon sticks adds a beautiful aromatic appeal. As the recipe contains no animal products, dairy, or eggs, it is suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets. With no gluten-containing ingredients, it's also a safe bet for those seeking a naturally gluten-free option. Perfect for gatherings, this punch offers a sophisticated twist on classic party drinks.

name: Starry mincemeat slices
description: Get creative with your mincemeat this Christmas and try this simple traybake version of mince pies
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: a little butter, for the tin
175g grated Bramley apple, squeezed to remove excess juice
directions: Butter a 30 x 20 x 2.5cm tray tin. Mix the mincemeat and grated apple. Unroll the pastry sheets. Lift one sheet into the tin so that the pastry lines it and the excess hangs over the sides. Spread the mincemeat mix over evenly.

Leave the other sheet on its wrapping, but lightly mark the size of the tin onto it. Stamp out stars, spaced apart – don’t go outside the markings. Carefully invert on top of the mincemeat, pastry side down, and peel off the wrapping. Press the edges together around the edge of the tin, trim the excess, then randomly place the cut-out stars over the pastry.

Chill for 20 mins. Meanwhile, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 with a large baking sheet inside it. Dredge the pastry with sugar and bake on the hot baking sheet for 30 mins until golden. Remove and dredge with more sugar.
chief_review: This festive traybake puts a creative twist on classic mince pies, offering a fuss-free method for making a crowd-pleasing holiday treat. The use of buttery ready-rolled shortcrust pastry ensures a crisp, golden base and top, while the mixture of mincemeat and fresh, tart Bramley apple adds depth and a pleasant contrast to the sweet, spiced filling. Dredging with caster sugar gives a delicate crunch that finishes each bite beautifully. Suitable for vegetarians, provided the mincemeat and pastry are made without animal-derived fats or additives. This recipe is perfect for sharing, easy to portion, and ideal for serving at seasonal gatherings.

name: Cinnamon shortbread
description: We would try most of these once more, but My spouse and i would not help to make one particular smooth biscuit, because the features journeyed splendid along with crispy along with brownish even so the middle has been nevertheless quite doughy. Much more denseness to the previously really thick cranberry fools. Furthermore, the particular quantitiy associated with glucose to be able to cover has been extreme. You would like 1 / 2 that sum. catba resort
author: James Martin
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Mix the butter with 50g of the sugar and the vanilla. Mix the flour, ground rice and ½ tsp cinnamon, then mix this into the butter mixture – you may need to finish with your hands. Roll out to just under 1cm thick between 2 sheets of baking parchment, then lift the bottom sheet of baking parchment onto a baking tray. Bake for 10-15 mins until golden and crisp looking.

Meanwhile, mix the remaining sugar with the remaining cinnamon. Remove the shortbread and leave to firm up for 1-2 mins, then slice into long shard shapes with a knife. Discard trimmings (or nibble them!), and scatter the biscuits with the cinnamon sugar while still warm. Gently toss to coat, then set aside until cool. Cover until ready to serve.
chief_review: This recipe yields a biscuit with a wonderful crispy exterior and deep brown color, thanks to the butter and the caramelizing sugar, while the use of ground rice provides a pleasingly dense, crumbly texture. However, the original sugar quantity can overshadow the subtle warmth brought by the cinnamon and vanilla; halving the sugar brings better balance. The simplicity of the ingredient list means this is suitable for a vegetarian diet. It does contain both butter and wheat flour, so it is not vegan or gluten free, and those with dairy or gluten allergies should avoid it. Perfect as a classic accompaniment to tea, these biscuits shine when allowed to brown fully while ensuring the centers are just cooked through.

name: Bacon & citrus crumb stuffing
description: Add a citrus zing to your Christmas turkey this year with this easy stuffing recipe
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g cubetti di pancetta, bacon lardons or chopped bacon
directions: Dry-fry the lardons until crisp in a non-stick frying pan, then lift out with a slotted spoon and tip in the onions. Gently cook for 15-20 mins until really soft. Tip into a bowl with the lardons, herbs, breadcrumbs, zests, mace, eggs and plenty of seasoning, then mix well.

Set aside about 450g of the stuffing for your turkey, then roll the rest to the size of golf balls. When the turkey comes out of the oven, roll the stuffing balls in the oil in a small roasting tin, then roast underneath the veg at 220C/200C fan/ gas 7, for 20 mins until golden and crisp.
chief_review: This citrus stuffing recipe offers a fresh twist to classic holiday fare, pairing the richness of pancetta or bacon with the bright zest of orange and lemon. The aromatic combination of parsley, thyme, and mace provides depth and warmth, balancing the savory flavors beautifully. The use of abundant breadcrumbs and eggs binds the mixture while imparting a lovely, hearty texture—perfect for complementing succulent Christmas turkey. Though rich and flavorful, the dish is not suitable for those seeking gluten-free or vegetarian options due to the breadcrumbs and pork elements. The preparation is simple yet results in a stuffing that feels special and seasonal, with just the right balance between traditional comfort and vibrant, zesty lift. The recipe’s ingredient list also allows for easy prep and adaptability to suit your preferred type of bacon, making it a practical as well as a delicious addition to your festive table.

name: Citrus & thyme turkey
description: Try this traditional based turkey with its easy citrus twist that transforms it into a Christmas Day showstopper
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 4½ -5.6kg/10-12lb turkey, thawed if frozen, giblets removed
2x 20g bunches of lemon or regular thyme
Lightly spiced Christmas stuffing(see 'Goes well with' below)
4 carrots, halved lengthways and cut into chunks
10 small red onions, peeled and quartered lengthways but still attached at the root
2 onion squash or 2 small butternut squash (total weight about 500g/1lb 2oz), cut into thin wedges and peeled
directions: Chop the leafy tops of the thyme but not the hard, woody branch ends (save these for the cavity). Finely grate the orange and lemon zest into a small bowl and mix with the chopped thyme, olive oil and seasoning. Mash the mix into the oil with the back of a metal spoon (or use a pestle and mortar) to release its flavour. Set aside to infuse.
Preheat the oven to fan 170C/conventional 190C/gas 5. Wash the turkey inside and out and dry well with kitchen paper. To make carving easier, you can now cut out the wishbone, but it’s not essential.

Put the reserved third of the stuffing in the neck end of the turkey and push it towards the breast. Don’t overfill, as the stuffing will expand during cooking. Secure the neck end flap with a small metal skewer. Weigh the stuffed turkey and calculate the cooking time – allow 18 minutes per 450g/1lb.

Season the turkey generously with salt and pepper inside and out. Halve the orange and lemon and put in the cavity (squeezing the fruit as it goes in) with the thyme branches and two of the bay leaves. Tie the turkey legs together to give the bird a good shape.

Throw the chopped carrots and onion and remaining bay leaves into a large roasting tin. Sit the turkey on top of the vegetables, smear the butter over the skin and cover with a loose tent of foil. Roast the turkey for the calculated time, basting with the pan juices every hour.
Meanwhile, tip the red onions and squash into a shallow roasting tray and toss in half of the thyme oil, making sure you get it right into the cuts in the onions. Set the tray aside.
Half an hour before the end of the turkey’s cooking time, whip off the foil and leave the bird to brown. After 15 minutes, drizzle the turkey with the remaining thyme oil.

To test if the turkey is cooked, insert a skewer into the thickest part of a thigh – the juices should run clear. If they are still pink, cook for a further 20-30 minutes and test again. Remove the turkey from the oven and turn the oven up to fan 180C/conventional 200C/gas 6. Transfer theturkey to a serving platter, cover tightly with foil and leave to rest while you finish off the vegetables and trimmings.

Put the red onions and squash in the oven and roast for 30-40 minutes. At the same time, roast the bacon-wrapped sausages (see Lightly spiced Christmas stuffing, right) for 30 minutes. Now make the gravy. Discard any fat from the roasting tin. Stir the wine and redcurrant jelly into the carrots and onion in the tin. Bring to the boil and boil rapidly for 8-10 minutes to reduce by half. Scrape the sticky bits off the bottom of the tin with a wooden spoon as the gravy boils. Pour in the stock and simmer for 10 minutes until you have a dark, tasty gravy, adding salt and pepper to taste. Strain the gravy into a pan (discard the vegetables), bring back to the boil and serve in a warm jug.
chief_review: This citrus-infused roast turkey recipe is an elegant twist on a holiday classic. The marriage of orange, lemon, and thyme with the succulent turkey elevates the flavor profile, offering a wonderfully aromatic and zesty touch—perfect for a festive showpiece. The addition of squash and red onions provides a natural sweetness that balances the tangy citrus and earthy herbs. Roasting in olive oil and butter ensures a moist and flavorful bird, while the red wine and redcurrant jelly bring depth to the accompanying sauce. The recipe, as presented, is suitable for gluten-free diets, provided the stuffing used is also gluten-free, and it caters to those who avoid nuts and soy. It’s a crowd-pleaser that celebrates tradition with an innovative flair, making it a delightful centerpiece for any special occasion.

name: Frosty forest cake
description: You can make this Christmas cake right at the last minute. The decorating makes a fun holiday project for the kids
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 50g each almond, cashews and Brazil nuts, chunkily chopped
directions: To make the cake, soak the apricots in the brandy while you get everything prepared. Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Butter then line the sides and base of a deep 20cm round cake tin with greaseproof paper. Mix together the figs, raisins, cherries, nuts and lemon zest.

Combine the flour with the baking powder, mixed spice and ground almonds. Beat the butter and sugar in a large bowl until creamy, about 2 mins. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Gently fold the flour mixture into the cake mixture in two goes, then fold in the fruits and nuts, followed by the apricots and brandy.

Spoon the mixture into the tin, then smooth the top, making a slight dip in the middle. Bake for 30 mins, then lower the temperature to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2 and bake for another 1 hr 45 mins, laying a sheet of foil loosely over the top for the final 15 mins if it starts to brown too quickly. The cake is done when a skewer inserted in the centre comes out clean. Leave the cake in the tin to cool, then remove the lining paper and wrap well in cling film and foil until ready to decorate (see below or turn the page for another idea).

To create the frosty forest cake: colour the marzipan pale green with a little of the food colouring. Cut off 250g, then make this a shade darker with more food colouring for the trees. To make the trees, roll out the darker green marzipan on a surface lightly dusted with icing sugar. Make pointed triangular cardboard tree templates in 3 different sizes (roughly 7.5 x 4cm/6.5 x 3.5cm/5.5 x 3cm). Using these as guides, cut out the tree shapes (see tip, above right). Brush one side lightly with honey, then scatter over silver and coloured dragees, pressing them down lightly to stick. Lay the trees on baking parchment to firm up. This is best done a day or two ahead.

When ready to decorate, sit the cake on a board or plate. On a surface lightly dusted with icing sugar, roll the paler green marzipan into a circle wide enough to cover the cake completely. Brush the cake all over with honey. Using a rolling pin, lift and lower the marzipan onto the cake. Smooth the surface of the marzipan with your palms, then trim off any excess from the bottom with a sharp knife.

Cut off two-thirds of the ready-to-roll icing, then roll out a strip about 8cm wide and long enough to go over the top and down the sides of the cake. Cut a wavy line down either side to resemble a path. Brush the marzipan with honey where you want the path to go, then lay the path on top. Trim to neaten the ends.

Take two-thirds of the remaining icing, then roll out 2 long, narrow ropes the same length as the path and about 5mm wide. Dampen the path edges with water and lay the ropes in position. Cut off and roll small pieces from the rest of the icing (and any trimmings), then shape into small snow drifts for the trees to stand in. When the trees are firm, make an indent in the top of each snowdrift with the back of a knife and put each tree into position. Sit the trees on the cake, securing with a little honey underneath. If necessary, cut off some of the rope along the edge of the path to make a flatter surface for the trees. Finally, scatter edible glitter onto the marzipanned cake.
chief_review: This festive Christmas cake delivers a delightful balance of dried fruits, nuts, and a gentle hint of citrus from lemon zest, creating a flavor profile both rich and aromatic. The inclusion of brandy-soaked fruits adds depth, while the marzipan and ready-to-roll icing provide a classic, sweet finish—ideal for celebratory decorating with children. Texture is thoughtfully considered, with both whole and ground nuts offering contrast to the soft, moist crumb. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no gelatin or animal fats, but relies on eggs and dairy for structure and richness. Be mindful of potential nut allergies and the presence of gluten in the plain flour. Overall, this cake is a joyful centerpiece for the holiday table, marrying traditional flavors with a family-friendly decorating activity.

name: Lemon star biscuits
description: Gorgeous, edible decorations for the Christmas tree which will delight your children
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 quantity vanilla shortbread dough (see below), with the finely grated zest of 1 lemon added to the flour
100g tropical dried fruits, such as mango, pineapple and papaya, chopped
ribbon, for hanging on the tree
directions: Preheat the oven to 180C/ gas 4/fan 160C and grease 2 large baking sheets. Roll out the dough to a thickness of about 5mm/¼in and cut out star biscuits using a 10cm cutter. Re-roll the trimmings make more biscuits.

With a skewer, make a small hole 1cm/½in from a point on each star - this is for hanging the biscuits. Bake for 18-20 minutes until turning pale golden around the edges, then transfer to a wire rack to cool. (If the holes have filled in during baking, re-make them with the skewer while the biscuits are still hot.)
Put the egg white and lemon juice in a bowl and beat in the icing sugar to make a smooth icing. Using a small palette knife, spread it generously over the biscuits to about 5mm/¼in from the edges.

Mix the fruits, then scatter them in the middle of the icing with some silver balls. Leave for at least 2 hours to set. Thread with ribbon just before you hang them and eat within 24 hours. They will keep fresh for up to 1 week stored in an airtight tin.
