chief_review: This festive recipe transforms simple vanilla shortbread into delightful, edible Christmas tree decorations, perfect for involving children in the holiday spirit. The addition of lemon zest brightens the classic dough, adding a fresh, zesty note that balances the sweetness of the icing. The combination of tropical dried fruits and cranberries not only brings vibrant color but also a pleasing chewiness and tartness to each bite, elevating the texture. The glossy lemon icing provides both a tangy finish and helps the decorative silver balls adhere, making these ornaments as beautiful as they are tasty. Note that this recipe contains wheat and egg, so it is not gluten-free or suitable for egg allergies. This charming project is ideal for parties or a family kitchen activity, and the result both decorates and delights as a holiday treat.

name: Wild rice, chestnut & squash stuffing
description: Add a colourful and healthy dish to your Christmas lunch table with this vegetarian stuffing
author: Good Food
ingredients: bottom half of 1 butternut squash, peeled and cut into small cubes
4 sageleaves, chopped plus extra sage leaves, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Tip the onion, squash and chestnuts into a roasting tin with the oil, chopped sage and seasoning, then toss well with your hands. Roast for 20 mins or until the edges of the squash start to tinge brown. If your oven is full, you can simply fry the lot together in a large frying pan.

Add the rice and stir to coat it, then tip the lot into a saucepan. Add the stock and stir well. Bring to a simmer and cook for 20-25 mins or until the rice is tender and the stock absorbed. Add cheese, if using, and tip into a baking dish.
To finish, heat grill to high, then cook until the top is browned and crisp and the stuffing is hot through.
chief_review: This vibrant vegetarian stuffing is a festive and hearty addition to any Christmas spread. The blend of sweet butternut squash, earthy chestnuts, and aromatic sage pairs beautifully with the nutty wild and basmati rice base. Using olive oil elevates the dish with healthy fats, while the optional parmesan—or a vegetarian alternative—allows for full vegetarian-friendly enjoyment. For those seeking gluten-free options, every listed ingredient naturally fits, provided the stock is gluten-free. The absence of common allergens like eggs and dairy (if using a plant-based parmesan) also increases its suitability for dairy-free diets. This stuffing is not only colourful and flavourful but also thoughtful in accommodating various dietary preferences, making it an inclusive and delicious centrepiece.

name: Peppermint candy cane Battenberg
description: This checkerboard cake, with alternating red peppermint and vanilla sponges, makes a stunning Christmas gift or party centrepiece - why not get older children to have a go with this fun, festive project?
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 350g unsalted butter, very soft (take it out of the fridge in the morning), plus a little for greasing the tin
red food colouringpaste (we used 2 Dr Oetker tubes)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a 20cm square tin with a little butter and line the base with baking parchment. To make the white (un-dyed) sponge, put 175g of the butter, 175g of the sugar, 175g of the flour, 3 eggs, the vanilla extract and a pinch of salt in a big mixing bowl. Beat with an electric whisk until smooth and not streaky.

Spoon into the tin and spread right into the corners. Bake for 25-30 mins – when you poke a skewer into the middle it should come out clean. Cool in the tin for 10 mins, then transfer to a wire rack to finish cooling. Wash the tin so it’s ready to use again.

Now make the red sponge. Grease and line the tin as in step 1. Mix the same ingredients in a big bowl, but use the peppermint extract instead of the vanilla. When the mixture is smooth and not streaky, squeeze in a little red food colouring and whisk in, adding more until you get a strong red colour.
Repeat step 2. Once cooked, cool the red sponge in the tin for 10 mins before placing on a wire rack to finish cooling.
To make the buttercream, beat all the ingredients and a pinch of salt with an electric whisk until completely smooth.
Knead 1 tsp of the peppermint extract into each of the fondant icings, keeping them separate.
Using a long knife (adults might want to help) or a ruler, cut off the crusts of each sponge (sides only, not the top and bottom). Now cut each sponge into 4 long fingers.

Use a sieve to dust a clean work surface with a little icing sugar. Roll out one block of your peppermint icing to a big rectangle – it needs to be 22cm wide and 45cm long. Turn the icing so one of the short sides is nearest to you.

Brush the top of a white and red sponge finger with a thin layer of buttercream. Using the buttercream as a glue, stick the white sponge finger along the edge of the icing nearest to you. Now trim the icing along the near edge of the sponge so it’s neat. Brush some buttercream on top of the white sponge and on the side furthest away from you. Stick the red sponge finger next to this far side of the white finger, so there is no gap between the two. Brush the top of the red sponge with more buttercream.

Sit a second red sponge finger on top of the white sponge you’ve already stuck to the icing. Now stick another white sponge on top of your first red one – again spreading buttercream in between the second layer of sponges to stick. Brush buttercream over any cake you can still see. Now roll over your cake, as if you’re wrapping a present in paper, to surround it in the icing. When the sponge is covered, you should have an edge where the two icing ends meet – trim off any extra icing.
Use a knife to trim the ends to make it neat. Put one candy cane in a plastic sandwich bag and use a rolling pin to break it into little bits on a chopping board. Sprinkle over your cake to decorate.
To make your second cake, repeat the recipe from step 8. Cakes will keep in an airtight container for 2 days.
chief_review:
This checkerboard cake is a showstopper with its vibrant layers of red peppermint and vanilla, perfect for festive gatherings. The recipe brings together classic baking staples––butter, eggs, flour, and sugar––with a holiday twist, thanks to peppermint extract and decorative candy canes. The fondant finish and buttercream offer a professional touch and a creamy counterpoint to the sponge's sweetness.

Its straightforward ingredients make it ideal for family projects or letting older children join in. The cake is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no gelatin or animal-based food colorings. However, it's not gluten-free or vegan due to the self-raising flour, eggs, and butter. Those with nut allergies are safe here, as there are no nuts involved, but always check candy cane packaging for traces of nuts. An inviting recipe for those seeking festive flair with a classic cake structure.

name: Turkey tonnato salad
description: Tuna mayo on turkey may sound like an odd combination, but trust us! This Italian-style light lunch dish is the perfect remedy for Christmas excesses
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 100g mayonnaise(an olive oil one works best)
2 anchoviesfrom a can, 1 cut into thin slices
80g tunain oil (a good-quality one will make all the difference here), drained
400g/14oz or thereabouts leftover turkey- white and/or brown meat
directions: Put the mayo, most of the capers, 1 whole anchovy, the tuna and most of the lemon juice into a food processor. Whizz until the tuna is completely mixed into the mayo. Season with pepper first, then taste, and add salt and more lemon juice, if you need to. If your sauce seems a bit thick, whizz in a drop of water. Can be made up to a day ahead.
Spread the turkey and rocket over a large serving plate, then spoon over the dressing and scatter with the remaining capers and sliced anchovy. Serve straight away with crusty bread.
chief_review:
This Italian-inspired Tuna Mayo on Turkey is a clever, light post-holiday lunch, bringing together rich protein from turkey and tuna, lifted by capers, anchovies, and fresh lemon juice. The olive oil mayonnaise adds a creamy element without overwhelming the palate, while the rocket gives a peppery freshness that balances the dish. The flavors nod to classic tonnato, optimizing leftovers in an elegant way.

Those following a gluten-free diet will appreciate the absence of bread or wheat-based ingredients, making it a safe option. The reliance on quality canned tuna and anchovy provides both umami and healthy fats, perfect for a satiating, flavor-forward meal. An accessible recipe for anyone looking to reinvent holiday remnants into a refined yet simple plate.

name: Mushroom rice stuffing
description: Make Christmas veggie-friendly with this recipe for vegetarian stuffing
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Oil a non-stick 12-hole bun tin and line holes with two strips baking parchment, to form a cross. Put the mushrooms in a bowl and pour over hot vegetable stock. Leave for 20 mins, then strain, reserve the stock and chop the mushrooms, if large.
Heat oil in a pan, add onion and fry for 5 mins until softened. Add the pine nuts and fry until lightly toasted. Add the garlic, rice and cook for 2 mins.

Tip in wine, let it bubble, then add the reserved stock, mushrooms and bring to the boil. Reduce heat, cover and simmer for 10 mins, until the rice is just cooked. Remove from heat and cool, then stir in the egg, basil, pepper, and salt, if using.

Fill the tins with stuffing, sprinkle over parmesan. Bake for 20-25 mins, until golden on top. Cool in the tins, or for 5 mins if serving straight away. Remove by pulling up the parchment crosses. Make up to two days ahead. Reheat on an oiled baking sheet, at 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 for 10 mins.
chief_review: This vegetarian stuffing is a delightful alternative for Christmas, featuring aromatic porcini mushrooms, risotto rice, and a medley of fresh herbs. The umami of porcini blends well with the nuttiness of pine nuts, while white wine adds depth and brightness. Olive oil and parmesan bring richness, and the beaten egg helps bind the mixture for a cohesive texture. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and could suit gluten-free diets if you ensure your stock and parmesan are GF-certified. The stuffing’s flavors are elevated by the basil and garlic, creating a robust dish perfect for your holiday table.

name: Mont Blanc ice-cream squares
description: This Christmas dessert, based on the French classic, can be made several weeks ahead, saving you from the usual stress of the season
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 435g can chestnut purée (we used Merchant Gourmet)
2 x 1-litre tubs good-quality vanilla icecream (we used Waitrose Seriously Creamy)
5 marrons glaces or candied chestnuts, halved
directions: For the meringue, heat oven to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1. Line the base of a loose-bottom 20cm square tin. Tip 25g of the walnuts into a food processor and blitz until ground as finely as possible, add the rest of the walnuts, then pulse to chop roughly. Tip the egg whites into a clean bowl, whisk until peaks have formed, then gradually add the sugar a third at a time, beating between each addition until stiff. Fold in the walnuts. Tip the meringue into the tin, then spread over the base. Bake for 2 hrs until crisp, then leave to cool. This can be done 1 day in advance and covered in cling film.

While the meringue is cooking, make the sweetened purée by mixing the chestnut purée with the sugar until smooth. This can be done 1 day in advance and covered in cling film. Put a couple of large bowls to chill in the fridge.

To assemble, leave the ice cream to soften slightly so it’s pliable, but not melted. Working quickly, in one of the bowls mix half of the ice cream with half of the purée to make chestnut ice cream. If it’s too soft once you have mixed it, place the bowl in the freezer to firm up. Once all the ice cream is the same consistency, quickly ripple the vanilla and chestnut ice creams and half the remaining purée together. Spread over the meringue and smooth the top, then place in the freezer until frozen solid. This can be done 1 month in advance and frozen, covered in cling film. You can also freeze the rest of the purée.

To serve, defrost the purée, remove the cake from the freezer, then place in the fridge for 40 mins. Meanwhile, make a thin piping bag from greaseproof paper and whip the cream until stiff. Mix in the rest of the purée, continue to beat until it becomes stiff again, then tip the cream into the piping bag. Using a large knife dipped into hot water, cut the cake into 9 squares. Working quickly, pipe a ‘crazy-string’ nest of chestnut cream in the centre of each square. Top the cream with half a marron glacé or candied chestnut and serve straight away.
chief_review:
This festive dessert ingeniously marries the elegance of a French classic with holiday convenience. The combination of walnuts, chestnut purée, and marrons glacés lends a rich, nutty depth, perfectly complemented by creamy vanilla ice cream and a touch of double cream. The meringue, made from whipped egg whites and sugar, creates a light yet crunchy texture that contrasts delightfully with the ice cream’s smoothness. Preparation ahead of time is a boon for busy hosts.

This recipe is particularly well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatine. However, it does include nuts and dairy, so those with related allergies should be cautious. The balanced sweetness and luxurious textures make this showstopper a worthy addition to any Christmas table, offering both tradition and modern ease.

name: All in-one bread sauce
description: Christmas isn't complete without creamy bread sauce and this recipe is super-easy to make
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 bay leaf, plus extra to serve
½ tsp ground mace, plus extra to serve
directions: Put all of the ingredients into a small saucepan. Cover and simmer for 15 mins, then whizz to a smooth or chunky sauce – whichever is your favourite. Top with extra bay leaves or more nutmeg to serve. Can be made 3-4 hrs ahead, then reheated in a microwave to serve.
chief_review: This classic creamy bread sauce delivers traditional holiday comfort with minimal effort. The combination of crust-less bread and milk achieves a luxuriously smooth texture, while subtle aromatics from bay leaf, mace, and freshly grated nutmeg elevate its flavor profile. The absence of butter or cream makes this version lighter than many traditional recipes, yet it retains all the richness expected from this festive side. Suitable for vegetarians, given that only plant-derived ingredients are used, this bread sauce pairs perfectly with roast dishes or vegetables, providing a gentle, warming spice and a creamy backdrop to sharper flavors. A must-have for any Christmas table seeking that nostalgic touch.

name: Chicken liver & mushroom nests
description: The rich earthy taste of mushroom pâté powers through these delicious little Christmas stuffing treats
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g pack chicken liver, trimmed of any sinewy bits
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Heat the oil in a large frying pan, then soften the onions for 10 mins with the pan covered. Turn up the heat, add the mushrooms and fry for about 10 mins until golden and all their liquid has evaporated. Stir in the garlic and cook for 1 min more. Tip everything onto a plate.

Pat the livers dry, then add a little more oil to the pan. Sizzle in batches for about 20 secs on each side until just golden but not cooked through. Set aside on a plate as you go. Tip in the brandy and let it reduce to 1 tbsp. Roughly chop the livers once cooled, then mix with the oniony mushrooms, brandy, bread and almost all the parsley and nuts.

To cook, wind bacon rashers into the wells of a 12-hole bun tin, like little nests. Spoon in the stuffing (reserving 250g for your turkey), scatter with remaining nuts, then bake, covered with foil, for 20 mins. Uncover and cook for 25 mins more until the bacon is gold. Scatter with remaining chopped parsley to serve.
chief_review: This mushroom and chicken liver pâté stuffing delivers a deep, earthy flavor, elevated by the addition of brandy and completed with the crunch of walnuts. The use of both mushrooms and chicken livers provides a fantastic umami depth, while onions and parsley bring brightness to the mix. The smoked, dry-cured bacon not only adds savory notes but also ensures a satisfying texture on the outside. With breadcrumbs binding the mixture, each bite is moist yet substantial. This recipe is a festive favorite but contains common allergens such as nuts (walnuts), gluten (white breadcrumbs), and eggs (if present in the breadcrumbs). It’s not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to chicken livers and bacon. Ideal for those seeking rich, meaty Christmas appetizers that will stand out on any holiday table.

name: Bay & bacon roast turkey with make-ahead gravy
description: Try this delicious way to prepare the Christmas bird, with bay leaves, lemon and stuffing - perfect flavours to compliment your festive dinner
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 5-5½ kg oven-ready turkey, neck and giblets removed
¼ quantity Sausage & Bramley stuffing(see recipe, 'Goes well with')
300ml strong chicken stock, plus extra if necessary
directions: First make the gravy – you can do this several days ahead. Heat the oil in a non- stick pan and fry the onion and carrot with the bay leaf for 10 mins, stirring frequently, until softened and golden. Meanwhile, blend the flour with 300ml cold water to make a smooth paste.

Remove the bay leaf from the pan and pour in the stock, closely followed by the flour mixture, stirring all the time until thickened. Leave to bubble for 5-10 mins, stirring frequently, then blitz with a hand blender until completely smooth. Pour into a bowl and cover the surface of the gravy with cling film or baking parchment to prevent a skin forming as it cools. Chill.

Weigh the turkey (you may need to use bathroom scales) and calculate the cooking time by allowing 40 mins per kg for a 4.5-6.5kg turkey, then 35 mins for every kg of turkey over that weight. As a guide, a turkey this size should take 3 hrs 20 mins-3 hrs 40 mins, plus 30-45 mins resting time.

Pack the stuffing into the neck end of the turkey, smoothing down the skin and tucking it under the bird for a neat finish. Put the onion and lemon, with some bay leaves, inside the cavity. Spread the butter over the skin that covers the breasts and lay the streaky bacon on top, to cover and protect each breast and seal in the butter. Can be done the night before, but take out of the fridge 1 hr before roasting so that it comes back to room temperature.

On the day, heat oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4. Lay the turkey on a large sheet of double-thickness foil, long enough to completely cover it, then lift into a roasting tin and season well. Pour the wine inside the cavity, then bring the foil up over the top of the turkey and seal it well. Roast for the calculated cooking time. For the final 40 mins, open the foil and remove the bacon (serve alongside the turkey or save it for a turkey sandwich). Pour off all of the cooking juices and use a little of the buttery oil that rises to the top to baste the bird. Roast until the turkey is golden and the juices that run out of the thigh are clear, with no sign of pink, when pierced with a skewer. (If you are using a digital thermometer, the thigh should be cooked to 80C and the breast to 75C.) Leave to rest on a warm platter, covered with foil and tea towels, for up to 45 mins.

While the turkey is roasting for the final 40 mins, skim the fat from the pan juices and pour into a jug. The amount of juices you get is dependent on the type of turkey that you are cooking, as speciality bronze turkeys will give you less juice than a white turkey – so make up to 600ml with chicken stock if you need to. Tip the gravy base into a pan, gently heat it with a little of the turkey juices to loosen the consistency, then gradually blend in the remainder and cook until bubbling. Season.
To serve, carve the turkey in the kitchen and arrange on a hot platter with a little of the hot gravy poured over, or bring the whole bird to the table. Any leftover meat can be frozen in the gravy.
chief_review:
This festive turkey recipe is a classic Christmas centerpiece, rich in aromatic flavors from bay leaves, lemon, and a savory Sausage & Bramley stuffing. The streaky bacon provides a wonderful smokiness and keeps the breast moist, while the butter enhances succulence throughout the meat. A base of wine, chicken stock, and vegetables for the gravy delivers deep, comforting notes that pair beautifully with the tender turkey. 

This recipe is ideal for those following a traditional omnivore diet. It is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the turkey, sausage stuffing, and bacon. Guests with gluten sensitivities should note the inclusion of plain flour and potentially gluten-containing sausage or stock. Overall, this dish excels in creating a warm, familiar holiday atmosphere and promises to impress at any festive gathering.

name: Double chocolate & orange biscotti
description: I made these yesterday,they were a little crumbly to cut, I think next time I will let them cool slightly before cutting to see if this helps. I will also add some nuts next time
author: Claire Thomson
ingredients: 1 large eggand one egg yolk, beaten
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the flour, cocoa, ground almonds, sugar, chocolate chips, candied peel, orange zest and a pinch of salt into a large bowl, and mix well. Make a well in the centre, then add the nutmeg (if using), egg and vanilla extract. Use your hands to bring the mix together, kneading it firmly.

Shape the biscotti dough into a log approximately 15cm x 5cm x 2.5cm deep. Transfer to a baking tray lined with baking parchment, then bake for 30 mins until firm to the touch (the log will split and crack a little on the top).
Remove from the oven and cool for at least 10 mins. Use a sharp serrated knife to cut the log into slices 1-1.5cm thick.

Put the biscotti back on the baking tray and reduce oven to 150C/130C fan/ gas 2. Bake for 30 mins or until the biscotti are completely hard to touch. Cool completely, then wrap in baking parchment or store in an airtight container.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful and aromatic treat, with the combination of orange zest, dark chocolate chips, and candied peel providing both freshness and richness. The inclusion of ground almonds adds texture and a subtle nutty undertone, though the baker mentions the intention to add even more nuts next time for enhanced crunch and flavor. The mixture can be slightly crumbly, so allowing it to cool before slicing is a wise adjustment. The recipe is well-suited for vegetarians and could also appeal to those looking for desserts with a reduced reliance on wheat flour, thanks to the significant use of almonds. Overall, this is an inviting bake with a pleasant balance of chocolate, citrus, and warm spice—ideal for an afternoon treat or as a homemade gift.

name: Marzipan Eccles tarts
description: This fun spin on the traditional Lancashire fruit cakes uses leftover marzipan to make irresistible individual pies
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 300g leftover dried fruit, like raisins, sultanas, currants
2 eating applesor pears, cored and grated
50g demerara sugar, plus a little extra to decorate
directions: Mix the dried fruit, grated apple or pear, Demerara sugar, marzipan, cloves and cinnamon.

Divide the pastry into 6. Then assemble tarts one by one. Halve a chunk of pastry and roll out each halve to a circle about the thickness of a 50p piece on a floured surface. Spoon a sixth of the filling into the centre of one circle in a pile. Brush edges with egg, and lift the second pastry circle on top. Gently press down on the fruit to push out as much air as you can. Press the pastry edges to seal. Use an appropriate sized bowl, glass etc to help you trim the edges to a neat circle. At this stage, you can cover and chill the tarts overnight, or freeze for 1 month. Defrost before continuing. Brush with beaten egg, then make three small slashes with a knife in a row. Repeat with remaining pastry and filling.

Pop the tarts in the fridge while you heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. When the oven is nice and hot, brush tarts all over with egg and sprinkle each with a little more sugar. Bake for 20 - 25 mins, until golden, then eat warm with ice cream or custard.
chief_review: This creative take on Lancashire fruit cakes results in charming individual pies bursting with the sweetness of dried fruit and a hint of spice from cloves and cinnamon. The inclusion of grated marzipan adds a delightful almond richness, perfectly complementing the fruit filling. Using puff pastry yields a crisp, buttery exterior that contrasts beautifully with the moist, fragrant interior. While this recipe incorporates eggs and pastry (which likely contains gluten and dairy), it's a flavor-packed treat ideally enjoyed with a cup of tea. The grated apple or pear brings a fresh, juicy note, balancing the sweetness of the marzipan and dried fruits. An excellent way to use up leftover ingredients, these pies are sure to be a hit at festive gatherings or as an indulgent snack.

name: Cointreau custard
description: A boozy custard made for grown-up puds. It's divine with Christmas pudding...
author: Good Food
directions: Splash a little milk into the cornflour until you have a smooth paste. Gradually stir in a little more milk until quite runny, then scrape into a large saucepan. Whisk in the remaining milk, cream, egg, yolks, vanilla and sugar. Put over a low-medium heat and, stirring or whisking constantly, bring just to the boil until thickened. Sieve into a jug and stir in the Cointreau.
chief_review: This boozy custard delivers a luxurious, velvety texture and a wonderful depth from the Cointreau, making it a beautiful accompaniment to rich desserts like Christmas pudding. The egg-rich base, enriched further with double cream, creates a custard that's both incredibly smooth and indulgently creamy. The subtle orange notes from the Cointreau wonderfully complement the warmth of vanilla, while the balanced sweetness ties everything together. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it avoids any animal-derived gelatin and uses only dairy and eggs for richness. Those seeking a festive, sophisticated custard will find this recipe a delightful addition to their holiday repertoire.

name: Baileys custard tart
description: Really fantastic recipe, I made it with gluten free pastry and it was delicious. The rest of the family loved it. Making it again for New Year's Eve dinner party.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 125g caster sugar, plus 1 ½ tbsp for topping
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and put a baking sheet on the middle shelf to heat up. Unroll the pastry, then use to line a 22cm fluted tart tin. Leave about 1cm of pastry overhanging and trim the rest. Line the case with baking parchment (scrunch it up first to make it more pliable) and baking beans. Place on the hot baking sheet and bake for 15 mins, then remove the beans and parchment and return to the oven for another 5 mins or until biscuity brown. Trim the sides of the pastry case with a serrated knife and discard the trimmings.

Pour the cream into a saucepan, scrape out the seeds from the vanilla, add these along with the pod and heat until steaming. Meanwhile, whisk the whole eggs, yolks and sugar in a large bowl until smooth. Pour the Baileys into the cream, then the cream mixture onto the eggs and mix well. Strain the mixture through a sieve and into a jug.

With the tart case still on the baking sheet, carefully pour the custard into the tart. Reduce the temperature to 150C/130C fan/ gas 2 and bake for 30 mins until the filling has just set but still has a slight wobble in the middle (the tart will continue to set a little once out of the oven ). Cool to room temperature, then chill in the fridge for at least 2 hrs.

Whip the remaining cream, sugar and Baileys until it just holds its shape. Pile into the centre of the tart, leaving a border of custard exposed around the edges. Scatter with crumbled honeycomb, if you like, and serve immediately.
chief_review: This celebratory dessert is a decadent treat, perfect for special occasions. The combination of silky Baileys-infused custard and the crisp sweetness of shortcrust pastry delivers an indulgent flavor profile, elevated further by the subtle warmth of vanilla. Using gluten-free pastry, as indicated, makes this recipe suitable for those following a gluten-free diet—just ensure the dusting flour is also gluten free. The optional honeycomb crumbles add a pleasing crunch and touch of playful sophistication. Rich double cream and a generous splash of Baileys ensure a smooth, luxurious mouthfeel that pairs beautifully with the gentle caramelization of the sugar topping. Altogether, this is a showstopper dessert that will impress guests and delight the home baker.

name: Reindeer food
description: Kids at the park love these but I have a problem that you cant hide ruffes
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: mixture of sweets(we used silver balls, chocolate beans, jelly sweets and hundreds and thousands)
directions: Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1. Put all the ingredients (except the apricots, sultanas and sweets) in a large bowl. Stir everything well, then spread out onto two baking trays in an even layer. Put the tray in the oven for 40 mins.
Leave the granola to cool on the tray, then break it up into small chunks and stir in the sultanas and apricots.
Put the granola in a jar ready for breakfast. To make it suitable for magic reindeer, put a few spoonfuls into a small paper bag and mix in some sweets.
Tie with string or a ribbon and add a fun label for Father Christmas to find.
chief_review: This playful, park-friendly snack blends hearty oats, crunchy nuts and seeds, fragrant spices, and a generous helping of dried fruit for natural sweetness. The addition of mixed sweets makes it a colorful treat that’s sure to entice kids, though it does add a burst of sugar and whimsy. The use of sunflower oil and maple syrup offers a lighter alternative to butter and honey, making this recipe naturally dairy-free and vegan-friendly, provided the chosen sweets are gelatin-free and not made with animal-derived ingredients. Note that the inclusion of nuts and potential gluten in oats makes this recipe unsuitable for those with nut or gluten allergies. The combination of wholesome and fun ingredients creates a satisfying, chewy snack, perfect for an energy boost at the park.

name: Laxpudding
description: Simply and delicious!
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 1.2kg potatoes(I like Maris Piper), peeled and finely sliced
green saladwith a sharp dressing, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160 fan/gas 4. In a large saucepan, mix together the creams and the milk, and bring to just under the boil. Add the potatoes and cook gently for 5 mins, carefully turning the potatoes over from time to time.

Season well and spoon one-third of the potatoes into a greased deep dish. Put half the gravadlax and dill on top, then add another one-third of the potatoes, then the rest of the gravadlax and dill. Finish with a final layer of potatoes.

Bake for 1 hr 10 mins or until the vegetables are completely tender. You may need to cover the top with foil after 1 hr to stop it becoming too dark. Serve with a green salad with a sharp dressing (the laxpudding will benefit from something clean to contrast with the richness of this dish).
chief_review: This recipe elegantly layers finely sliced Maris Piper potatoes with rich double and soured cream, complemented by luxurious gravadlax and fresh dill. The result is a decadent, Scandinavian-inspired gratin—creamy, aromatic, and generously seasoned by the buttery gravadlax. The potatoes turn meltingly tender, soaking up the dairy for a satisfying texture, while the dill brightens every bite. Served with a crisp green salad and sharp dressing, it offers a welcome counterpoint to the richness. Suitable for pescatarians and gluten-free diets (provided the gravadlax is verified gluten-free), this dish is perfect for a special occasion or hearty family meal.

name: Smoked cheese in blankets
description: Used the round Austrian smoked cheese that looks like a sausage from Sainsburys. Cut into 4 lengthways then into 3 across to make 12 pieces. For bite size pieces cut into 4 both ways. Tip.....wrap the pancetta lengthways first, then around the cheese this will stop the cheese from oozing out of the ends. Great little Christmas treats, good for canapes or as part of a sharing starter board. Make the cranberry and chestnut falafels to go onto the starter board also on BBC good food. To complete make cream cheese and smoked salmon blinis, I used the ready made blinis from Sainsburys. Makes a nice sharing board for a starter.
author: Gizzi Erskine
ingredients: 150g Bavarian smoked cheese, trimmed and cut into 24 pieces
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180 fan/gas 6. Carefully wrap the pancetta around the cheese pieces (you may not need a full slice of pancetta for each piece of cheese, depending on the size). Can be done two days ahead and kept covered in the fridge.

Put the rosemary sprigs on a baking tray and place the cheese in blankets on top. Roast in the oven for 15 mins until golden and crispy. Serve immediately but be careful, as they will be molten hot inside.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful fusion of savory and smoky flavors, ideal for festive gatherings or as an elegant canapé. The use of Austrian smoked cheese wrapped in pancetta creates a harmonious blend—the creamy, melting cheese perfectly balanced by the salty, crisp pancetta. Cutting the cheese into bite-sized pieces ensures uniform cooking and easy serving, while the rosemary sprigs lend an aromatic depth that elevates the entire board. Serve alongside cranberry and chestnut falafels and smoked salmon blinis for a varied and visually appealing starter. This dish is particularly suitable for low-carb and ketogenic diets, as both cheese and pancetta are inherently low in carbohydrates. It’s a guaranteed crowd-pleaser that’s simple to prepare yet feels celebratory and indulgent—perfect for holiday entertaining.

name: Seared venison with sprout & apple slaw
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 2 rosemary sprigs, leaves picked and chopped
1 tbsp rapeseed oil, plus extra for frying
crème fraîchemixed with horseradish and 1 tbsp pumpkin seeds, toasted (optional), to serve
directions: Mix the marinade ingredients together and marinate the venison for a couple of hours in the fridge. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

For the slaw, put the sprouts in a bowl and pour over the orange juice. Season with salt and drizzle over some rapeseed oil. Using your hands, scrunch the sprouts in the dressing for a few minutes to tenderise them. Grate in the apple, allowing the juice to also dress the sprouts, then toss with the remaining ingredients. Check for seasoning and add more rapeseed oil if you think it needs it. It wants to be perfectly dressed, rather than greasy.

Heat a little rapeseed oil in a heavy-bottomed skillet or frying pan until smoking hot, then add the venison and cook for 2-3 mins until a caramelised crust has formed on the underside. Flip it over and cook for another couple of mins, making sure it's sealed all over. Place on a baking sheet and put in the oven for 5-6 mins, depending on how rare you like it. Remove from the oven and allow to rest for at least 5 mins, then slice. Spread some crème fraîche and horseradish over each plate and top with then venison. Serve the slaw on the side and scatter over the seeds, if you like.
chief_review: This venison loin recipe is a refined, autumnal dish that balances the rich, gamey notes of the meat with vibrant, fresh accompaniments. The marinade—featuring juniper, rosemary, and Worcestershire sauce—draws out complex flavors, while the use of rapeseed oil keeps it light. The Brussels sprouts salad with green apple, orange zest, parsley, and pomegranate seeds adds color, crunch, and a burst of acidity to cut through the venison’s richness. The crème fraîche with horseradish brings a creamy, tangy element, and toasted pumpkin seeds offer textural contrast. This dish suits gluten-free diets, provided the Worcestershire sauce used is certified gluten-free, making it accessible to those with gluten sensitivities. It’s a show-stopping main course that highlights seasonal produce and thoughtful pairings—a modern, elegant twist on classic wild game.

name: Pear, chocolate & marzipan strudel
description: Prepare ahead and freeze this rich filo pastry pud, then cook from frozen for the perfect fuss-free seasonal dessert
author: Good Food
ingredients: 85g butter, melted, plus a little extra
4 tbsp light muscovado sugar, plus extra for sprinkling
icing sugar and cream, to serve
directions: Melt a knob of butter in a large frying pan, add the pears and 1 tbsp sugar, and cook for 5 mins. Tip into a bowl and leave to cool. Then add the Disaronno (if using), biscuits, cinnamon, chocolate, marzipan, and 2 tbsp sugar and mix well.

Line a tray with baking parchment. Lay a sheet of filo on it, brush with melted butter and sprinkle with a little sugar. Top with a second sheet of filo and keep going until you’ve used all the pastry. Pile the filling down one of the long sides of the pastry, then roll it up to form a sausage. Make sure it is seam-side down, then tuck the ends under tightly. Roll up in the parchment, wrap tightly in foil and freeze.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put a tray in the oven to heat. Unwrap the strudel and place, seam-side down and still on its parchment, onto the tray. Brush with melted butter and sprinkle over 1 tbsp sugar. Bake for 35-40 mins, or until golden and crisp. Leave to cool for 10 mins, then dust with icing sugar.
chief_review: This cleverly prepped filo pastry dessert delivers a wonderful contrast of crisp, flaky layers with a warm, aromatic pear and ginger chocolate filling. The sweet spiced pears are elevated by the crunch of ginger biscuits and rich notes from dark chocolate and marzipan, while the option of Disaronno is an inspired touch for those who enjoy a hint of liqueur. The recipe’s use of butter and marzipan means it’s best for vegetarians, and with a simple swap to dairy-free margarine, it could suit a broader vegetarian audience. Filo pastry’s lightness prevents the pud from feeling heavy, making it an ideal centerpiece for the holidays. Prepare ahead and bake straight from the freezer for a stress-free, impressive dessert with a gorgeous texture and festive flavors.

name: Cinnamon butter rum
description: A brilliant, festive and comforting tipple. Added a bit more sugar and butter though, to make it extra decadent ;)
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Gently heat the butter, golden caster sugar and cinnamon sticks in a saucepan until the butter has melted and the sugar has dissolved.
Stir in the spiced rum, then pour into four small heatproof glasses to serve.
chief_review:
This indulgent, festive tipple combines the rich flavors of butter, spiced rum, and warming cinnamon with just the right touch of sweetness from golden caster sugar. The addition of extra butter and sugar elevates the drink to a truly decadent treat, perfect for a cozy winter evening by the fire or as a show-stopping drinks course at a holiday gathering. 

With no dairy alternatives or egg-based ingredients, this recipe is suitable for lacto-vegetarians. However, those with lactose or milk allergies should be aware of the butter. The simplicity of the recipe allows for easy adaptation—swap out the butter for a plant-based alternative to create a vegan version. Overall, this is a luxurious, easy-to-make drink that delights with its deep flavors and silky texture.

name: Cranberry & hazelnut cake
description: A versatile and light fruitcake with a hint of spice and plenty of juicy cranberries and cherries - ice as you wish!
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 200g butter, softened, plus a little extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. grease a deep 20cm cake tin and line with baking parchment – high enough to come 2.5cm above the top of the tin. Put the raisins, cherries, all the cranberries, orange zest and juice, and alcohol into a small pan. Bring to the boil and leave to simmer for 3 mins, until the cranberries have softened a little and most of the liquid has evaporated. Set aside to cool.

Put the sugar, butter and vanilla in a bowl and beat with an electric mixer until pale and fluffy. Add the eggs, flour, almonds, hazelnuts and mixed spice. Whisk again until just combined, then stir through the soaked fruit and any remaining juices. Tip the cake mixture into the tin and level the top, then bake for 1 hr 20 mins, until a skewer pushed into the centre of the cake comes out clean. If the skewer has any uncooked cake mixture on it, return it to the oven for 10 mins, then check again. Leave in the tin to cool.
chief_review:
This fruitcake recipe stands out for its vibrant mix of dried and fresh fruits, balanced by citrus zest and a subtle kick from your spirit of choice, be it sherry or a nutty liqueur. The light, moist crumb is achieved with a blend of self-raising flour and ground almonds, while toasted hazelnuts add depth and crunch. A generous tablespoon of mixed spice lends aromatic warmth, making this cake perfect for festive gatherings. 

With a substantial amount of almonds and hazelnuts, this cake is inherently gluten-containing but can be enjoyed by vegetarians, as it contains no meat or animal-based gelatin. However, it's not suitable for those with nut allergies. The versatility in icing and choice of alcohol allows for customization without compromising its essential flavors. Overall, an elegant, well-balanced fruitcake with ample room for creative finishing touches.

name: Caramel & whisky sauce
description: This thick and boozy toffee sauce can be put into jars and given as a gift, or serve a dollop with warming desserts
author: Good Food
directions: Put the butter, sugar, condensed milk, caramel and ginger in a pan. Heat gently until the butter melts – make sure you don’t boil the sauce. Remove from the heat, then stir in the whisky until smooth. Pour into sterilised jars and allow to cool before sealing.
chief_review: This toffee sauce recipe is rich and indulgent, with the deep notes of brown sugar and a delightful warmth from ground ginger and whisky. The combination of butter, condensed milk, and caramel creates a lusciously thick texture ideal for drizzling—or dolloping—over winter desserts. The generous measure of whisky elevates the sauce with a sophisticated, boozy aroma, making it especially suitable for adult palates. Its bold, buttery flavor profile makes it an excellent companion to sticky puddings or even a scoop of vanilla ice cream. Owing to the use of condensed milk and butter, this sauce is vegetarian, though not suitable for vegan or dairy-free diets. Presented in jars, it makes a thoughtful and decadent homemade gift, capturing the essence of classic comfort desserts with a spirited twist.

name: Cranberry & chestnut falafel
description: Add a bit of seasonal spirit to your chickpea bites with fruit and nuts. Serve with a creamy yogurt dip and fresh coriander
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1 sweet potato, peeled and cut into big chunks
small pack coriander, roughly chopped, plus a little more to serve
85g cranberry, defrosted if frozen and halved if you have time
150g pot creamy Greek-style yogurt, to serve
directions: Put the sweet potato into a microwave-proof bowl, add 1 tsp water and cook on High for 2 mins. Mash in a large bowl.

Put the chickpeas and chestnuts into a food processor and pulse until well chopped but not pasty. Tip on top of the sweet potato, then add the egg, spices, garlic and coriander. Season generously and mix well with your hands. Add the cranberries. Shape dessertspoon-sized balls of the mix into 20 or so patties. Can be made ahead and chilled for up to 3 days.

Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large non-stick frying pan. Fry half of the falafels for 2 mins on each side until golden. Lift onto kitchen paper to drain. Repeat with the second batch. Can be made up to 2 days ahead and reheated. Let the falafel cool for a few mins before serving with the yogurt, plus a scattering of coriander.
chief_review:
These chickpea bites blend comforting seasonal flavors—sweet potato, chestnuts, and cranberries—with the robust earthiness of cumin and a gentle heat from chilli flakes. The addition of chickpeas gives a pleasingly hearty texture, while fresh coriander infuses brightness throughout. Paired with a creamy Greek-style yogurt dip, this dish offers a wonderful balance of sweetness, spice, and tang.

This recipe is well-suited to both vegetarian and gluten-free diets, containing no meat or gluten-based ingredients. It's also rich in plant-based protein and fiber, making it both satisfying and nourishing. The inclusion of eggs and yogurt means it’s not vegan, but those who enjoy dairy and eggs will appreciate its wholesome flavors and wholesome seasonal twist. These festive bites are perfect as appetizers or a light meal when paired with a crisp salad.

name: Stir-fried sprouts with green beans, lemon & pine nuts
description: This fresh idea for your Christmas sprouts is a good source of both vitamin C and folic acid
author: Good Food
directions: Cook the sprouts and beans in a pan of boiling salted water for 3 mins, then drain well. Heat the oil in a large wok or frying pan. When hot, add the lemon zest and pine nuts. Cook for a couple of seconds, then add the vegetables and stir-fry for 3-4 mins until the sprouts colour a little. Add a squeeze of lemon juice and salt and pepper to taste.
chief_review: This vibrant dish elegantly brings together Brussels sprouts and green beans, delivering a delightful crunch with each bite. The use of olive oil, lemon zest, and juice offers a bright, refreshing lift, while toasted pine nuts add a pleasing nuttiness and subtle depth. It's an excellent choice for those seeking a healthy, plant-based side that celebrates the natural flavors of winter vegetables. Notably, the recipe is both vegan and gluten-free, making it suitable for a variety of dietary preferences and requirements. Effortlessly simple yet impressively flavorful, this dish is a prime example of how minimal ingredients can yield maximum impact on the festive table.

name: Melting snowman biscuits
description: Get little ones in the kitchen to assemble these cute festive biscuits - sticky fun for a wintry afternoon.
author: Valerie Barrett
directions: Put the icing sugar into a bowl and add cold water a teaspoon at a time until the mixture is runny but thick enough to coat a spoon.
Ask an adult to snip the marshmallows in half using wetted scissors.
Spoon a little icing onto each cookie and attach half a marshmallow. Using a little icing, stick the other half on top at an angle. Drizzle a little more icing onto the cookie to make melting snow.
Break the pretzel sticks in half and place on the cookie for arms. Stick orange chocolate beans on for the noses. Stick three chocolate beans on each cookie to represent buttons.
Using the writing icing, pipe small blobs for the eyes and mouth. Leave to set.
chief_review: This playful recipe makes for a delightful, hands-on activity with children and results in eye-catching festive biscuits sure to bring joy to any winter gathering. The assembly is straightforward—marshmallows and fondant icing create a snowman effect atop large cookies, while mini chocolate beans form buttons and eyes, and pretzel sticks serve as whimsical arms. The use of fondant icing sugar for the “snow” is clever, providing a smooth and sweet finish. While not suitable for those seeking a vegan, vegetarian, or gluten-free treat due to the inclusion of marshmallows, pretzels, and cookies, this recipe does shine as a fun, interactive dessert. The ingredients are easy to find and adaptable for creative variation, though care should be taken with young children if allergies are a consideration. Overall, an engaging bake that prioritizes festive fun and a charming presentation.

name: Mustard & clementine glazed ham hocks
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 4 ham hock, smoked or unsmoked, rind removed (you can ask a butcher to do this)
directions: The day before, soak the ham hocks in water overnight in the fridge, to draw out some of the salt (they may have already been soaked by the butcher, so check first).

The next day, drain the hocks and pat them dry. Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Mix the allspice, nutmeg and 1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper together and rub into the hocks. Put them in a deep roasting tin with the clementines, cut-side up . Tuck the star anise and bay around the hocks, and pour in 200ml water. Cover the tin in foil and roast for 3 hrs.

Remove the tin from the oven and increase the heat to 180C/ 160C fan/gas 4. Unwrap the tin and drain off the liquid. Squeeze the juice from the clementines over the hocks and return the juiced halves to the tin. Mix the Dijon, treacle and sugar in a bowl and paint half the glaze all over the hocks. Return to the oven for 15-20 mins, turning and brushing with the remaining glaze every 5 mins until the hocks are burnished and caramelised in places. Shred or slice the meat and eat warm or cold.
chief_review: This ham hock recipe is a celebration of robust, warming flavors. The combination of clementines, allspice, nutmeg, and star anise produces an aromatic base that beautifully complements the richness of the pork. Using black treacle and brown sugar creates a deep, caramelized glaze, while the Dijon mustard adds a welcome tang and complexity. The inclusion of bay leaves brings a subtle herbal note, elevating the dish’s savory dimension. This recipe would be a hit at festive gatherings or as a stunning centerpiece for Sunday lunch. It’s especially suitable for those on a gluten-free diet, since all listed ingredients are naturally free from gluten (always check mustard and treacle brands for certainty). The method promises tender, flavorful meat with a sticky, fragrant glaze—a dish that balances sweet, spicy, and savory notes with finesse.

name: Frosted candy cake
description: Give your cake a personal touch this Christmas with this cute and simple design
author: Good Food
ingredients: 15-20 small candy canes(we used striped canes from Waitrose)
directions: Tie the small candy canes into groups with ribbon. Put the white caster sugar, liquid glucose and water in a pan. Heat until sugar is just melted and syrup turns clear. Take off heat and whisk the egg whites until stiff, then carry on whisking while steadily pouring in hot syrup in a stream. Keep beating until thick enough to spread, then beat in the sifted icing sugar.
Quickly spread the icing over an 18-23cm square or round cake (marzipan covered, if you wish), swirling roughly. Stick on the candy canes and leave for 1 hr to set.
chief_review: This festive cake design is delightfully creative and sure to impress at any Christmas gathering. The use of small candy canes creates a charming holiday border, while the homemade icing—crafted from caster sugar, liquid glucose, water, egg whites, and icing sugar—delivers a smooth, glossy finish perfect for decorating. The recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, it includes egg whites and may not cater to those with egg allergies or vegan dietary needs. The instructions are straightforward, making this an accessible and enjoyable project for novice and experienced bakers alike. The final touch of a decorative ribbon ensures your cake will be the centerpiece of your holiday table.

name: Chunky chocolate nut bars
description: Adding cinnamon to basic vanilla shortbread lends these bars an extra Christmassy fragrance
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 quantity vanilla shortbread dough (see below), with 2 tsp ground cinnamon added to the flour
directions: Preheat the oven to 180C/gas 4/fan 160C. Grease the base and sides of 2 shallow 28cm x 18cm baking tins and line each with a single sheet of greaseproof paper to come well above the rim of the tin (this makes it easy to lift out). Grease the paper.
Pack half the dough into the base of each tin, pressing it into the corners. Scatter with the whole nuts, making sure they are evenly distributed. Press them deeply into the dough to secure.
Bake for 40 minutes until the nuts and edges of the biscuits are golden. Carefully lift out of the tins, still on the paper, and transfer to a wire rack to cool.

Melt the plain and milk chocolates in separate bowls set over pans of simmering water. Leaving the slabs of biscuit on the paper, carefully cut each slab widthways into 2cm/¾in slices (don't worry if the nuts seem to be loose - they will be kept in place by the melted chocolate).

Spread the slices so they are 1-2cm apart and drizzle diagonal lines of melted plain chocolate over them, using a dessert spoon. Then drizzle the milk chocolate over the plain and leave in a cool place to set. Cut each biscuit in half widthways. They will keep fresh for up to a week stored in an airtight tin.
chief_review: This festive take on classic vanilla shortbread is elevated by the warm addition of cinnamon, imparting a delightful seasonal aroma. The luxury mixed nuts bring texture and a satisfying crunch, beautifully contrasted by the decadence of both plain and milk chocolate. Thoughtfully layered, these bars offer a sophisticated balance of buttery, spiced shortbread and rich chocolate coatings, making them ideal for holiday gatherings. Suitable for vegetarian diets, as no meat or gelatin is included. Those with nut allergies or dairy sensitivities should take note, but for lovers of bold, festive flavors, this recipe is a real treat. Perfect with a hot cup of tea or coffee.

name: Roast lamb stuffed with apricot & mint
author: Aidan McGee
ingredients: 1 leg of lamb(about 2kg), boned (ask your butcher to do this for you)
½ bulb of garlic, broken into cloves and lightly crushed
½ pack mint, leaves picked and finely chopped
150-200g breadcrumbs(using 200g gives you more solid stuffing, which is easier to carve; 150g is softer and more spoonable)
directions: Lay the lamb, skin-side down, on a board – if the joint you bought is tied up, then snip the strings and unroll it. Cut several pieces of string long enough to tie around the lamb, then slide them under the joint so they’re regularly spaced out. Mix the stuffing ingredients together, and season well. Spread the stuffing out along the middle of the lamb, then fold the meat over to form a roll. Tie the string so the roll stays together, but don’t make it too tight or it will cut into the meat. Tie some string lengthways too, if necessary.

Heat oven to 170C/150C fan/gas 3. Season the lamb evenly all over. Heat a little oil in a large frying pan, then brown the lamb all over. Start with the side where the seam meets, as this will stop the lamb breaking up when you carve it.

Tip the veg, garlic and rosemary into a roasting tin and put the lamb on top, seam-side down. Cook the lamb until the core temperature reaches 60C on a meat thermometer – this should take around 1 hr for a 2kg leg. As you rest the lamb, the temperature will continue to rise so don’t overcook it.

Lift the lamb out of the tin and, keeping it warm, rest for up to an hour. Put the roasting tin on the hob. Add the stock, bring to a simmer, then tip the lot into a saucepan, scraping up any bits. Add 500ml water and then simmer again until reduced by half. Pour through a fine sieve and serve with the lamb.
chief_review:
This stuffed leg of lamb recipe is a true celebration of robust flavors and artful technique. The choice of aromatics—leek, carrot, celery, and garlic—beautifully elevates the lamb, infusing the meat with depth while it roasts. Adding dried apricots lends delightful sweetness that harmonizes with classic rosemary and fresh mint, making each bite fragrant and layered.

The stuffing, prepared with breadcrumbs and egg, brings a tender yet substantial texture, allowing for precise carving and a visually appealing result. Using either lamb or chicken stock as the braising liquid ensures rich, savory undertones.

Given the ingredients, this recipe is ideal for festive gatherings or a special Sunday meal. While substantial and hearty, it does cater to those following a nut-free diet, provided care is taken with the breadcrumbs. Serve with seasonal vegetables or a crisp salad to balance the luscious richness of the dish.

name: Silky chicken liver parfait tart
description: If you're not a confident pastry-maker, you can use shop-bought pastry - you'll find it easier to handle and the result will still be delicious
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 tbsp caramelised onion from a jar
6 tbsp walnut oil or olive oil
directions: At least an hour before you want to make the tart, make the pastry. Tip the flour, thyme, butter and ½ tsp salt into a food processor and pulse to the texture of breadcrumbs. Add the egg yolk and milk and pulse again until it all starts to come together. Tip out and press into a ball of pastry. Wrap, then chill for at least 1 hr. Can be prepared up to 2 days ahead.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the pastry out and line an 11 x 33cm rectangular, fluted tart tin. (The pastry may break up as you work it, so patch over any broken bits.) Keep any excess trimmings. Chill the tart case in the fridge or freezer for 20 mins.

While the tart case is chilling, tip all the ingredients for the parfait into a clean food processor with a generous pinch of salt and a good grinding of pepper. Blitz until the mix is as smooth as it’s going to get, then push through a sieve into a jug and set aside.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Line the tart case with greaseproof paper and baking beans, then bake on a baking tray for 15 mins. Remove from the oven and remove the paper and beans. Check for any small holes or cracks in the pastry and patch up with the reserved trimmings. Place back in the oven for 15 mins, until golden. Remove from the oven and lower the oven to 120C/fan 100C/ gas ½. When the oven has cooled suitably, slide the tart case back into it, then fill as far as you can with the parfait mix. Bake the tart for 20 mins until just set. Leave to cool, trim any untidy edges, then remove from tin.

To serve, cut the tart into 6 slices. Place on plates, then place small blobs of caramelised onions and a scattering of hazelnuts around the tart. Neatly place a few salad leaves around and drizzle everything with oil and vinegar. Arrange 2 fig quarters on top of each slice and serve.
chief_review: This recipe is a beautiful example of a classic pâté tart, blending delicate chicken livers with double cream, a touch of brandy and port, aromatics, and the sweetness of caramelised onion. The addition of toasted hazelnuts brings wonderful texture, while the fig and salad leaf garnish lifts the richness perfectly. Using shop-bought pastry makes this more approachable without compromising on quality. The pastry and filling both contain butter and egg yolk, making this unsuitable for vegans or those with dairy or egg allergies. The presence of flour, nuts, and the use of chicken livers means it’s also not suitable for gluten-free, nut-free, or vegetarian diets. A wonderful option for an elegant lunch or as a showstopping starter at a dinner party, with well-balanced flavors and a satisfyingly complex finish.

name: Sticky sprouts with grapes & walnuts
description: Want to spruce up your sprouts? Our inventive recipe with sweet grapes, Greek yogurt mint dressing and crunchy nuts won't disappoint
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 2 tbsp chopped mint, plus a few small leaves to garnish
directions: Boil a large pan of water and add the sprouts. Boil for 8 mins, or until just cooked through but not soggy. Drain, cool, then halve. Can be chilled for up to 24 hrs.

Melt the fig jam and balsamic vinegar together in a big frying pan or wok. When bubbling, add the sprouts and fry until they start to caramelise. Lower the heat and add the grapes, then cook for a few mins more until the grapes are hot and softening. Add the walnuts and seasoning, then tip into a serving dish. Mix the yogurt and chopped mint, and dollop over the hot sprouts. Garnish with a few extra mint leaves.
chief_review: This creative Brussels sprout recipe is a delightful twist on a classic veg, marrying the earthiness of sprouts with the sweet burst of grapes and fig jam. The toasted walnuts provide an unexpected crunch that elevates the texture, while the Greek yogurt and mint dressing adds a refreshing, creamy tang. Using Greek yogurt makes the dressing rich yet bright, and the balsamic vinegar balances the sweetness. This dish suits a vegetarian diet and is packed with fiber, healthy fats, and probiotics. Its vibrant flavors and contrasting textures make it an appealing side or a light main for festive tables. A simple, sophisticated way to liven up humble sprouts.

name: Sprouts with sticky shallots
description: Spruce up the humble sprout by serving al denté with sweet onions and crunchy nuts
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 tbsp red wine or sherry vinegar
directions: Heat the oil in a large frying pan and sizzle the shallots for 5 mins until starting to colour. Sprinkle over the sugar, stir well, then add the raisins and vinegar. Simmer for 5 mins to make a sticky mix, then set aside.

Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, then tip in the sprouts. Cook for 5 mins, then drain well, add to the shallot pan and toss everything together. Serve scattered with flaked almonds and a sprinkling of paprika, if you like.
chief_review: This vibrant Brussels sprouts recipe elevates a classic vegetable with layers of sweetness and texture. The caramelized shallots, accented by golden caster sugar, create a subtle depth, while plump raisins add a welcome burst of sweetness. The red wine or sherry vinegar provides a harmonious tang that balances the dish. Toasted flaked almonds lend a delightful crunch and nutty aroma, and the optional pinch of paprika can bring a gentle smokiness for those who like a touch of spice. Prepared with olive oil rather than butter, and without any dairy or animal products, this dish is not only vegetarian but also vegan-friendly. It's also gluten-free, making it appealing for guests with dietary sensitivities. Ideal for festive occasions or as a sophisticated side, this recipe transforms Brussels sprouts into a dish worthy of a chef’s table.

name: Santa's stocking cake
description: This fun and festive cake is popular with kids and adults alike
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 18-23cm fruit cake covered with marzipan and ready-to-roll white icing
pink, green and orange food colouring (or use colours of your choice)
orange, green and pink Smarties, plus 3 small gift boxes
directions: Knead the ready-to-roll icing until smooth, then split into three equal pieces and colour each with colouring. Roll out to approx ½cm thickness and, using a template, cut out eight stocking shapes. Set aside.

Make the royal icing and colour as before. With the end of a skewer, dot small 'spots' all over the stocking shapes (or use a piping bag). Set aside to dry. Keep the coloured icing covered with cling film until later.

Fix the ribbon around the top edge of the cake, using a thin line of icing to help it stick. Using a little leftover coloured icing, ‘hang’ the stockings on the cake, just underneath the ribbon, in alternating colours. Top the cake with Smartie-filled boxes and scatter Smarties over the cake and cake board.
chief_review: This playful, decoratively iced fruit cake delights both children and adults with its vibrant colors and whimsical presentation, complete with Smarties and festive gift boxes. The marzipan and ready-to-roll icing provide a smooth, sweet cover that complements the dense, rich fruitcake underneath. The cake is best suited for vegetarians, provided that the food colorings and Smarties used are free from animal-derived ingredients—always check labels to be sure. With its creative use of royal icing and easy customization through colored decorations, this recipe is ideal for those wishing to create an eye-catching centerpiece for birthday parties or celebrations. However, note that marzipan and Smarties may contain nuts and dairy, so be mindful of guests with allergies. Overall, it’s a crowd-pleaser sure to tempt guests with both its looks and flavor.

name: Roasted roots
description: Still no celeriac but this time I added some red onions, increased the carrots and parsnips and cut down the number of potatoes and served them with a slow cooked shoulder of lamb out in the garden...
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1½ kg floury potatoes, such as Maris Piper or King Edward, peeled and chopped into large chunks
3 large carrots, peeled and chopped into very large chunks
3 parsnips, peeled and chopped into large chunks
directions: While the goose is roasting, tip all the vegetables into a pan of cold salted water, then bring to the boil. Boil for exactly 3 mins, then drain well. Scatter the flour over the veg in the colander, then toss well to coat.

Ladle a good layer of goose fat into a large roasting tin, then place above the goose while it is having its final 10 mins with the foil on. When you open the oven to remove the foil from the goose, remove the tin for the veg. Carefully lay the vegetables in the hot fat, then use a fish slice to turn them until completely coated. Place the veg above the goose for the final 30 mins, turn them over, then return to the oven while the goose rests for 30 mins. Cook until golden and crisp, turning the oven up slightly at the end if needed.
chief_review: This robust side dish offers a hearty mix of root vegetables—potatoes, carrots, and parsnips—expertly complemented by the rich flavor of goose fat. The inclusion of plain flour helps achieve a gorgeously crisp finish when roasting. While the absence of celeriac shifts the balance, the increased carrots and parsnips bring welcome sweetness and earthiness. This recipe is ideal for those following a classic British or rustic cuisine tradition, especially when served alongside slow-cooked lamb. It is naturally gluten-containing due to the plain flour, and the use of goose fat aligns it more closely with traditional omnivorous diets. The result is a beautifully textured, deeply flavorful side dish that elevates any festive or comforting meal enjoyed outdoors or inside.

name: Red cabbage salad
description: This vibrant salad with bacon and blue cheese has contrasting textures and flavours and is a fab way to use up leftovers
author: Caroline Hire
ingredients: 150g stiltonor other hard blue cheese, crumbled
directions: Cook the bacon in a frying pan until crispy. You shouldn’t need any oil as the fat will run from the bacon.
Heat the vinegar in a large saucepan until just simmering. Tip in the sugar and stir to dissolve, then add the red cabbage. Cook for a further 3 – 5 minutes, tossing the cabbage through the vinegar.
Spoon the cabbage into bowl, stir through the bacon, sultanas and season with black pepper and a little salt. Allow to cool.
Toss in the blue cheese to serve.
chief_review: This salad brilliantly combines salty bacon, tangy blue cheese, and sweet sultanas for a complex flavor profile with plenty of crunch and creaminess. The shredded red cabbage serves as a crisp, refreshing base, while the red wine vinegar and brown sugar dressing brings a balanced, zesty-sweet punch that ties the dish together. The addition of stilton amplifies the richness without overwhelming the freshness of the cabbage. Sautéing the bacon until golden ensures a pleasing textural contrast. This recipe is ideal for those on a low-carb diet due to its minimal carbohydrate content and high protein from the bacon and cheese. It's a vibrant, indulgent salad that feels both satisfying and inventive—a perfect way to transform simple leftovers into something special.

name: Scandi smoked salmon
description: Try a Scandinavian approach to your smoked fish by adding dill, horseradish, lemon and red onion - great as part of a sharing platter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 small red onion, very finely chopped
small bunch dill, most roughly chopped
directions: Tip the onion and chopped dill into a bowl with the horseradish and lemon juice. Stir through the soured cream, season with a pinch of salt and generous grinding of pepper, and mix well.
Arrange the salmon on a board or plate, scatter with the remaining dill fronds and serve with a grinding of black pepper and the sauce alongside.
chief_review: This Scandinavian-inspired smoked salmon dish elegantly balances the punchy flavors of horseradish, dill, and lemon with the richness of soured cream and the gentle bite of red onion. The combination is both refreshing and indulgent, making it an excellent centerpiece for a sharing platter. The recipe is naturally gluten-free and pescatarian-friendly, relying solely on smoked salmon for its protein, with no wheat-based ingredients. The freshness of dill and acidity from lemon elevate the smoked fish beautifully, while a touch of horseradish brings just the right level of heat. Serve with rye crisps or cucumber slices for a delightful texture contrast. Overall, it’s a simple yet sophisticated dish, perfect for entertaining.

name: Chewy cranberry choc-nut cookie kit
description: Fill a glass jar with the ingredients for fruity macadamia and white chocolate chip biscuits and present as a gift
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 large (1 litre approx) jar- Kilner or with a good screw lid
100g white chocolate chip, buttons, or roughly chopped chunks
directions: Clean the jar and dry well. Layer in the ingredients, starting with the caster sugar, followed by the muscovado, flour, nuts, cranberries and finally finishing with the white chocolate. Close the jar, then add a label with baking instructions, plus a ribbon or pretty cover if you like.
chief_review: This fruity macadamia and white chocolate chip biscuit jar mix is a delightful, thoughtful gift that balances sweetness and texture beautifully. The combination of muscovado and caster sugars gives depth to the flavor, while macadamia nuts and tart dried cranberries add crunch and zing, perfectly offset by creamy white chocolate. Packed attractively in a good-quality jar, it makes for a charming homemade present. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin-based products. However, it does include nuts and gluten, so do consider the recipient’s dietary needs if gifting. The ingredients are well-measured for easy baking—recipients only need to add their wet ingredients and bake to enjoy fresh, chewy biscuits with a satisfying mix of flavors and textures. An inviting, festive option for holiday gifting or an anytime treat!

name: Buttery sage & onion sprouts
description: How do you serve your Brussels? We like ours in plenty of butter, sweet roasted onion and peas for added vibrancy
author: Lucy Netherton
directions: Heat half the butter in a large frying pan and soften the onions over a low heat for about 15 mins until really soft – but don’t let it brown. Add most of the sage. Meanwhile, cook the sprouts in a pan of boiling water for about 4 mins, add the peas and cook for 1 min more until just tender.

Drain, reserving a splash of the water, then add the sprouts and peas to the onions, along with the rest of the butter, stirring well so that all the veg gets coated in the butter. Add the reserved cooking water if it looks a bit dry.
Season with lots of black pepper and some salt. Serve with the reserved sage on top.
chief_review: This recipe transforms Brussels sprouts with rich, buttery flavors and the sweetness of roasted onions, highlighted by fresh sage and tender peas. The combination of butter and onion elevates the Brussels, making them decadently soft, while peas add a burst of color and a slight crunch. It's a side dish that brings warmth, aroma, and depth to any meal. Notably, this recipe is vegetarian-friendly, as it contains no meat or animal rennet products. For those looking to impress at a holiday table or elevate a weekday meal, these Brussels sprouts are sure to please. Serve immediately for the best texture and flavor.

name: Chocolate gingerbread Advent calendar
description: Great recipe, good to find a gingerbread recipe suitable for my 4 year old to help with because it did not involve melting the butter and syrup. Really easy to make, if the recipe does not make a dough add a tiny bit extra syrup, I did this by mistake as I orginally used 120g like for the other ingredients, realised it was wrong so just added another spoonful and it made a perfect dough. Rolling between the paper is perfect for kids as they dont get flour all over the kitchen. You dont need to leave 2 cm between, they dont spread that much. Taste great too, just a subtle gingerness and not too chocolaty.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: cookie cuttersor cardboard to make templates
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the flour, cocoa, ginger, butter and sugar in a processor, and whizz until you can’t see any lumps of butter. Dribble in the syrup and pulse to a smooth dough.

Take about a quarter of the dough at a time and roll out between 2 sheets of baking parchment to the thickness of a £1 coin. Peel away the top layer of parchment and use cookie cutters to make shapes – leaving about 2cm between each shape as they will spread as they cook. Peel away the dough trimmings and lift the parchment with the shapes onto a baking tray. Bake for 12-15 mins until firm. Remove from the oven and use a plastic straw to make a hole for hanging. Work quickly – if the biscuits cool and harden too much, the holes won’t be as neat – then pop the tray back in the oven for 1 min to re-warm.

Continue rolling and shaping all the remaining dough and trimmings while you bake a tray at a time, until all the dough is used up and you have at least 24 biscuits. Cool completely, then decorate and string up as you wish.

Cut your biscuits into triangles using a template – ours was 7cm on each side. After baking, cut two hanging holes in the middle of one side. Use number cutters (or cut out with a small sharp knife like we did) to stamp out 1 to 24 from a sheet of ready-rolled icing. Make runny icing by mixing some sifted icing sugar with a dribble of water. Use small paintbrushes to paint the tops of the icing numbers with some runny icing before dunking in their favourite coloured sprinkles and edible glitters. Leave the numbers to dry for 10 mins, then use more runny icing painted on the bottom of the numbers to stick them to the biscuits.

Stamp your biscuits out using different snowflake cutters – cakescookiesandcraftsshop.co.uk have pretty ones. Decorate each biscuit differently by painting some with runny icing (see instructions above), then dunking into edible glitters and sprinkles – it’s easiest if you tip them onto a small, flat saucer first. Add more icing sugar to your runny icing to make a stiffer consistency, spoon into a piping bag and pipe on pretty details. You can pipe a number onto each with this icing too, if you want.

Make a stiff-ish icing using fondant icing sugar this time (this results in a shinier finish). Then thinly pipe around the outsides and holes of each biscuit. You’re making a ‘wall’ to hold in the other icing, so make sure you don’t leave any gaps. Leave to set for 30 mins until hard. Make more icing of a slightly runnier consistency. Pipe or spoon the icing onto the biscuits, ‘flooding’ the area inside your icing ‘walls’. Shake a little to evenly spread the runny icing, then immediately use the remaining stiffer icing to pipe on a number. These biscuits will need at least a day to harden before hanging. For step-by-step instructions on ‘flooding’ icing, see Edd Kimber’s Fancy iced biscuits (see 'goes well with')
chief_review: This gingerbread recipe is wonderfully approachable for baking with young children, thanks to its no-melt method for incorporating butter and syrup and the clever use of baking parchment to minimize kitchen mess. The dough is forgiving, coming together nicely with a slight adjustment to the syrup if needed. The flavor balance is mild—delicate ginger notes and restrained chocolate make these biscuits appealing for all ages. Ingredient-wise, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no animal products apart from butter (which is acceptable in a vegetarian diet). Since plain flour is used, it’s not gluten-free, but it’s a solid choice for families wanting a festive, fun, and tasty baking activity that little hands can manage from start to finish. Decorating with icing and sprinkles adds extra creative flair—perfect for the holiday season.

name: Mincemeat samosas
description: Give mince pies a makeover with this alternative recipe - all the festive flavour wrapped up in sheets of filo pastry and baked until crisp
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 cooking apple, peeled, cored and finely chopped
directions: Mix together the fruit, dried fruit, nuts, spices and brandy. Leave the mixture in the fridge for 30 mins to allow the flavours to develop, then stir in the honey. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Arrange the filo sheets with the short side facing you and, using scissors, cut the stack in 3 vertically, to make long strips. Brush the top 3 strips with melted butter.

Working quickly, put 1 heaped spoonful of mincemeat at the top of the first strip. Fold one corner of the pastry over it to form a triangle, then continue folding alternately left and right to form a triangular package, until you’ve used up all the strip. Repeat with the other strips, brushing with butter before folding.
Place on a baking sheet and brush each one with more melted butter. Bake for 15-20 mins until crisp and golden. Dust with icing sugar and serve warm (reheat later in a low oven if necessary).
chief_review: This inventive mince pie recipe delivers all the cozy spices and fruits of the season, wrapped in a delicately crisp filo pastry shell. The filling, packed with apple, orange zest, apricots, cranberries, sultanas, and pistachios, offers a layered sweetness and pleasant chew, complemented by cinnamon and nutmeg for classic festive warmth. Brandy and honey brighten the mixture, while the filo pastry keeps each parcel light and flaky, making for an elegant twist on tradition. Notably, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and contains no eggs. However, it does include nuts (pistachios), butter, and gluten (filo pastry), so those with related dietary needs should take care. Overall, an inspired choice for holiday gatherings or a refined afternoon treat, sure to impress with both flavor and presentation.

name: Sole goujons with mango & lime dip
description: Coat strips of white fish fillets with breadcrumbs, then bake for a delicious make-ahead canapé, perfect for entertaining or a party buffet
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 4 skinless sole or plaicefillets, each about 85g
small pack coriander, leaves only, finely chopped
