directions: Put the fish on a board and cut each fillet on the diagonal into about 12 slivers. You should end up with around 48 finger-sized pieces of fish. Put the flour in a bowl and season.

Beat the eggs in a medium bowl. Sprinkle half the breadcrumbs into a large bowl and stir in half the curry powder. Toss the fish pieces with the seasoned flour, then take one at a time and dip into the beaten egg, then coat in breadcrumbs evenly.

Put on a tray lined with baking parchment while the rest are prepared, adding the reserved breadcrumbs and remaining curry powder to the large bowl after coating roughly half the fish pieces. Spray all the fish generously with oil and season again. Can be covered with cling film at this stage and kept in the fridge for up to 8 hrs before baking (or to freeze, see tips below, left.
Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Bake the goujons for 8-10 mins until golden and crisp. To make the dipping sauce, mix all the ingredients in a bowl, then soon into a serving dish or dishes.
chief_review:
This baked white fish canapé recipe boasts a crunchy panko crust with a subtle kick from curry powder, paired with a zesty, creamy dip. The use of skinless sole or plaice keeps the dish light and delicate, while the half-fat crème fraîche and mayonnaise give the dip a luscious texture without excessive richness. The addition of mango chutney and lime infuses a vibrant, tangy sweetness that complements the mild fish perfectly.

This recipe is ideal for those seeking a make-ahead appetizer that doesn’t compromise on flavor or elegance—perfect for gatherings. It suits a pescatarian diet and could cater to those seeking lower-fat options, thanks to the use of half-fat crème fraîche. However, as it contains eggs, wheat, and dairy, those with these specific allergies should avoid it. An excellent choice for a sophisticated yet approachable party platter.

name: Stuffed porchetta
description:
This was our Christmas day 2015 meal and we were not disappointed and neither were our guests here in France. 5***** (the rater's not working!)
It was gorgeous and even though I had a piece of pork the same size it was cooked after 2 hours & 20 mins so watch the timing to prevent the meat drying out.
I'd cook it again for a special occasion as the prepping doesn't make it a sunday roast type meal and I would, thanit more bread, apricots & herbs to the stuffing to add to the flavour
Brilliant special meal that's worth the effort, thanks Good Food & Rosie Birkett!!
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: ½ fennel bulb, hard core cut out and discarded, the rest finely chopped
1 slice sourdoughbread, torn into small pieces
directions: Score the pork belly skin with a sharp knife in a cross pattern. Score down to just before where the skin meets the fat, rather than the fat itself. Bring a large saucepan of water to a simmer and add the bicarbonate of soda. Lower the pork into the water, poach gently for 5 mins, then remove it from the water and leave to cool to room temperature.

Meanwhile, toast the fennel seeds and chilli flakes in a dry frying pan over a high heat for 1-2 mins, then tip into a bowl and leave to cool. Grind the spices in a spice grinder or with a pestle and mortar, then mix with 1 tbsp fine sea salt.

Once the pork has cooled, turn it skin-side down and pierce the underside of the meat all over with a knife. Rub the meat with the spiced salt rub, cover and put it in the fridge for at least 8 hrs or overnight. Can be prepared 24 hours ahead.

The next day, make your stuffing. Heat the olive oil in a non-stick frying pan and add the onion and fennel. Season and cook gently over a low heat for 10 mins. Add the coriander seeds and garlic, and cook for another 2 mins, then add the mince. Cook for 8-10 mins until the mince is browned. Set aside and leave to cool.

Transfer the mince and onion mix to a bowl and add the sourdough, pine nuts, orange zest, apricots, herbs, lemon juice and nutmeg. Season well, then mix together thoroughly with your hands. Add the egg and mix again.

Lie the pork belly on a board, skin-side down. Form the stuffing into a sausage shape running all the way down the middle of the belly. Wrap the sides of the belly around the stuffing and tie with butcher’s string. Place seam-side down in a roasting tin, uncovered, and chill for at least 2 hrs, preferably overnight. You want the skin to dry out completely so that it crisps up when you roast it.

To cook the pork, remove it from the fridge and leave it for at least 1 hr to come to room temperature before you cook it. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4 and cook the pork for about 2 hrs, turning the tin every 30 mins or so. After 2 hrs, turn the heat up to 220C/ 200C fan/gas 7 and cook for another 20 mins. When the pork is done, a thermometer pushed into its centre should read 77C. If the skin looks in danger of burning, cover it with foil – but only do this once it has crackled.
Once the pork has cooked, remove from the oven and leave to rest for 30 mins. When you’re ready to carve, put the pork on a big chopping board. Using a sharp knife, slice the meat into rounds.
chief_review:
This festive pork belly roast is an elegant centrepiece, ideal for special occasions. The stuffing, enriched with apricots, toasted pine nuts, herbs, and orange zest, adds sweetness and complexity, perfectly complementing the savoury meat. The use of fennel seeds, coriander, and garlic in both meat and stuffing imparts a subtle aromatic warmth, while the touch of chilli lends just enough heat.

This recipe contains eggs, nuts (pine nuts), and gluten (sourdough bread), so it is not suitable for vegan, vegetarian, nut-free, or gluten-free diets. However, it caters wonderfully to non-restrictive diets seeking a show-stopping meal. Preparation is a little involved but worthwhile for the depth of flavour and the impressive results. My only suggestion would be to increase the apricots and bread as the reviewer noted—doing so would make the stuffing even more luscious and balanced. A memorable, indulgent dish for any celebratory table.

name: Pistachio & cranberry pork pie
description: A very Christmassy tasting pie! Cranberry sauce is beautiful & the pistachios add a nice crunch. Pastry is so simple to make & makes a delicious pie to feed a crowd. Also tastes nice cold the next day. I forgot to add the nutmeg to the pork which I think it could of done with. 5*
author: Good Food
directions: Put the cranberries in a pan with the sugar and orange juice. Bring to a simmer, then cook until the berries start to burst and the sauce thickens. Set aside to cool.

Heat the oil in a small pan and fry the onion until soft. Add the bacon and garlic, and cook until the bacon starts to brown, then stir through the thyme, sage and some seasoning. Allow it to cool slightly, then mix with the pork and pistachios. Season with salt, pepper and freshly grated nutmeg. Set aside.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Tip the flour into a bowl with 2 tsp salt. Put lard and milk into a pan with 150ml water, then heat until the lard has completely melted. Pour into the flour and beat with a wooden spoon until a ball of dough is formed. Knead briefly on a lightly floured surface until smooth.

Take two-thirds of the pastry and roll out between two sheets of baking parchment into a circle large enough to line the base and sides of a 20cm cake tin (about 4-6cm high with a slight overhang. Press the pastry into the tin making sure to push it into the corners. Pile half the filling into the pastry and flatten into an even layer. Spread over two-thirds of the cranberry sauce, then finish with remaining pork and roughly smooth the top. Keep the rest of the cranberry sauce in the fridge to serve with the pie.

Roll out remaining pastry between baking parchment and cut to a 20cm round. Place onto the pie and glaze the edge with some beaten egg. Fold up the overhanging pastry and press down to seal. Make a steam hole with the tip of a knife, then glaze the pie with more beaten egg. Cook for 30 mins, then reduce the heat to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Continue cooking for 40 mins until the pastry is golden and a skewer inserted into the centre of the pie and left for 10 secs feels very hot. Cool on a wire rack. Serve with the reserved cranberry sauce.
Watch our
for extra tips.
chief_review: This festive pie delivers delightful Christmassy flavors, marrying tart cranberry sauce with a savory pork and bacon filling, all spiked with fresh herbs and the subtle crunch of pistachios. The homemade lard pastry is simple yet reliably crisp, and the pie is as satisfying cold as it is warm—an excellent make-ahead option for entertaining. The omission of nutmeg in the pork is a minor miss, as its warmth would complement the filling well. While this pie isn’t suitable for vegetarians or those avoiding gluten, eggs, or nuts, it’s a true crowd-pleaser for meat lovers seeking a centerpiece with both sweet and savory appeal. The balance of textures—from juicy fruit to hearty pork and buttery pastry—makes each bite memorable and festive.

name: Thyme roasted vegetables
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 450g parsnips, peeled and cut into finger-length pieces, tough cores removed
1½ tbsp good-quality vegan white wine vinegar
handful thyme, leaves picked and chopped
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the parsnips and carrots with the oil, maple syrup, white wine vinegar, thyme and some seasoning in a large roasting tin.

Cover tightly with foil and roast for 20 mins. Remove the foil and give everything a good shake, then roast for a further 30 mins on the top shelf of the oven or until the vegetables are tender and caramelised.
chief_review: This roasted root vegetable dish is a delightful showcase of parsnips and baby carrots, enhanced by the subtle sweetness of maple syrup and the bright acidity of vegan white wine vinegar. The olive oil lends a rich finish while fresh thyme amplifies the earthy flavors. With its entirely plant-based and gluten-free ingredients, this recipe is well-suited to both vegan and vegetarian diets, and works perfectly for those avoiding gluten. The absence of common allergens like nuts, dairy, and eggs makes it a versatile and crowd-pleasing side. Serve this dish as a vibrant accompaniment to a main course or as part of a festive spread—either way, its balance of sweet, savory, and tangy elements will impress.

name: Black Forest loaf cake
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 1 jar or tin of pitted cherries(about 600g), syrup reserved
directions: Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter and line a 1.5kg loaf tin.
Melt the butter and chocolate together in the
until smooth. Sieve the flour into a bowl, then stir in the sugar and cocoa. Add the chocolate mixture, eggs, milk and 200g yogurt and blend until smooth.

Spoon the mixture into the loaf tin and make eight dips in the surface. Top each dip with 1 tsp yogurt and a cherry. Put the loaf in the oven and bake for 1 hr, or until a skewer inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean. Cool in the tin for 20 mins, then transfer to a
and leave to cool completely.
Just before serving, use a balloon whisk or electric
to beat the cream until stiff. Spoon the cream onto the cake in dollops, top with the remaining cherries and drizzle over some of the cherry syrup. Serve straightaway.
chief_review: This decadent dessert brings together the rich flavors of dark chocolate, tangy yogurt, and sweet, juicy cherries, creating a show-stopping treat with lovely textural contrast. The use of natural yogurt and milk produces a tender crumb, while the addition of double cream adds indulgent richness, making it perfectly suited for celebrations or special occasions. The pronounced chocolate notes from both cocoa and dark chocolate are well-balanced by bursts of cherry throughout. As it contains both wheat flour and dairy, this recipe is not suitable for gluten-free or dairy-free diets. However, it's a luxurious choice for those seeking a classic, indulgent chocolate cherry dessert. Perfect for vegetarians, this recipe does not contain any meat, fish, or animal-derived gelatine.

name: Bubble & squeak Boxing Day brunch
description: Big thumbs up for taste but these looked nothing like they did in the picture!! Mashing the potatoes was a bit of a challenge and the patties didn't stick together too well. But we really enjoyed them though!!!
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 4 paprika roasties, or about 200g, left over from Christmas Day (see the recipe)
2 large spoonfuls coriander seed cabbage, about 150g, left over from Christmas Day (see the recipe)
directions: Roughly mash your cold
with a fork, then add the
, cumin seeds, garlic and some seasoning, and mix together. Use your hands to shape the mixture into two patties.

Heat the oil in a large frying pan. Fry the patties for 3-4 mins each side until crisp. Pour the lemon juice over the avocado. To serve, get two plates, put a patty on each and serve with the avocado, a sprinkling of chilli flakes and a good pinch of flaky sea salt.
chief_review: This inventive recipe makes excellent use of festive leftovers, transforming paprika roast potatoes and coriander seed cabbage into flavorful patties with cumin and garlic. The addition of fresh avocado and a zing of lemon juice brings a light, modern touch, while chilli flakes add just the right amount of heat. While the texture could be improved by adding a binder like flour or breadcrumbs (especially if patties don’t hold), the overall flavor profile is vibrant and satisfying. This dish is naturally vegetarian and, with the ingredients listed, gluten-free—ideal for those seeking hearty, plant-based options. A smart, resourceful use of what you have on hand, and perfect for anyone looking to minimize food waste without sacrificing taste.

name: Festive baked Alaska
description: This gloriously squidgy hot and cold ice cream bombe with meringue uses up leftover Christmas cake
author: Silvana Franco
directions: Line a 900ml pudding basin or deep cereal bowl with a double layer of cling film. Scoop the caramel ice cream into the bowl, patting it down well. Top with the conserve, followed by the vanilla ice cream. Pat down firmly, cover with cling film and freeze for at least 2 hrs or, better still, overnight.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Whisk egg whites until stiff, then slowly whisk in the sugar until firm and glossy. Slice the cake and arrange on a baking parchmentlined baking sheet, to make a round the same size as the top of the ice-cream bowl. Press together well to make sure there aren’t any gaps.

Lift ice cream out of bowl, remove cling film and turn onto the cake. Spread the meringue evenly over the ice cream and cake, making sure there are no gaps. Bake for 4-5 mins until nicely coloured. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This festive ice cream bombe is a delightful exploration of contrasting textures and temperatures. The pairing of smooth caramel and vanilla ice creams with rich black cherry conserve guarantees bursts of flavor in every spoonful. The base of leftover Christmas cake adds welcome depth and a moist crumb, while the crisp, pillowy meringue exterior elevates the dessert to indulgent heights. Notably, this recipe contains neither nuts nor gluten in its main ingredients, provided you use a gluten-free Christmas cake base, and is suitable for vegetarians. The dramatic presentation and effective use of leftovers make this a show-stopping finale for a holiday meal. Serve immediately after torching the meringue for the most satisfying hot-cold contrast.

name: Poached & smoked salmon pâté with bagel toasts
description: A chunky fish terrine that's easy to make and delicious with toasted sweet bagels
author: Lucy Netherton
ingredients: olive oil, for greasing and brushing
small bunch dill, chopped, a few fronds left whole
2 x 170g packs steamed or poached salmon fillets, flaked into chunks
directions: Grease and line a loaf or terrine tin (about 650g) with cling film – if you only have a standard 900g tin it will still be fine, just a bit flatter. Arrange the whole dill fronds and a few nice slivers of the smoked salmon on the bottom (this will be the top of the terrine so you want it to look quite neat).

In a food processor, pulse half the cooked salmon fillets, half the remaining smoked salmon trimmings and the cream cheese with some seasoning. Don’t overmix as you want it to have a bit of texture. Fold in half the dill, all the spring onions and the rest of the poached and smoked salmon so that you have some nice flakes of fish running through the pâté. Scrape into the tin, smooth the surface and chill for at least 2 hrs or up to 2 days in advance.

To serve, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Arrange the bagel halves in a single layer on a baking tray and brush each one with some oil. Sprinkle on a little of the dill and some sea salt, then bake for about 10-12 mins, until crisp and light golden. (If the oven is full, these can be done earlier and served at room temp.) Turn the terrine tin upside down and use the cling film to remove it. Unwrap and serve on a platter with the bagel toasts.
chief_review: This chunky fish terrine is a delightful and visually striking dish—ideal for a brunch spread or a light appetizer. The combination of smoked and poached salmon delivers a balanced complexity, complemented by the brightness of fresh dill and spring onion. Binding it all together, the light cream cheese provides a creamy texture without overpowering the delicate seafood flavors. Served atop toasted mini bagels, each bite offers satisfying contrasts of creamy, smoky, and crunchy. This recipe is gluten-free adaptable if served without bagels or with gluten-free alternatives, and, with its absence of meat and poultry, it’s suitable for pescatarians. The ease of preparation makes it approachable for cooks of all levels, while its elegant appearance ensures it will impress guests at any gathering.

name: Creamy smoked haddock & saffron kedgeree
description: Use good quality un-dyed fish in this creamy brunch rice pot with hard boiled eggs and saffron
author: James Martin
ingredients: 1 lemon, cut into wedges, to serve
directions: Cook basmati rice, leave to cool. Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease a large ovenproof dish with some of the butter. Push the egg yolks through a sieve and roughly chop the whites.

Gently heat the cream in a frying pan until just below boiling point, then add the fish. Cover and poach for 4 mins. Place the wine in a pan with the saffron and warm to infuse. In a large bowl, mix together the rice, cayenne, curry powder, nutmeg, seasoning, chopped egg whites and saffron-infused wine. Lift the fish out of the cream and flake into the bowl – removing any bones as you find them. Scrape in the cream and gently mix together once more.

Tip everything into the buttered dish and dot the top with the remaining butter. Bake to heat through for 20 mins, then serve scattered with the parsley and sieved egg yolk, with lemon wedges on the side.
chief_review: This creamy brunch rice pot is a luxurious take on a classic kedgeree, showcasing delicate, un-dyed smoked haddock and warming spices like saffron, curry powder, and cayenne. The buttery basmati rice is enriched with double cream, bringing a rich silkiness that pairs beautifully with the flaky fish and tender hard-boiled eggs. Fresh parsley and a vibrant squeeze of lemon add balance and freshness to each bite. This dish is particularly well-suited for a gluten-free diet, as all the ingredients are naturally gluten-free. It’s also a celebratory brunch choice for pescatarians, offering satisfying protein from both seafood and eggs. The use of simple, high-quality ingredients and the gentle layering of flavors make this a standout dish—a comforting, elegant centerpiece perfect for a special weekend breakfast or brunch.

name: Creamy bread & onion sauce
description: A delicious necessity for any turkey roast
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 140g crustless, soft, open-textured white bread, cubed
directions: In a covered, non-stick pan, gently fry the onions and bay leaves in the butter for 10 mins, until soft. Add the milk and cloves and simmer for 30 mins, stirring now and then.
Take out the bay and cloves, then blitz in a food processor until smooth. This will keep for 2 days in the fridge.
On the day, tip the cream into a pan, add the onion sauce, then mix well. Add the bread and stir until soft but still textured. Add milk to thin if necessary. Season and serve warm.
chief_review: This bread sauce recipe is a quintessential accompaniment for a traditional turkey roast. The combination of gently simmered onions, aromatic bay leaves, and cloves creates a warmly spiced, creamy sauce that envelopes the palate in comfort. Grated nutmeg lifts the richness of butter and double cream, while the soft white bread lends ideal body and texture. Notably vegetarian, provided the bread contains no animal-based additives, this sauce accommodates meat-free diets and pairs well with vegetable mains too. It’s best served hot, generously ladled beside roasted meats or plant-based alternatives.

name: Persimmon & membrillo galette
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: a little plain flour, for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line a baking sheet with baking parchment. Put another baking sheet in the oven to heat up. Put the membrillo, 50g butter, 50g sugar, the cinnamon and nutmeg in a saucepan, and heat until the ingredients have melted together, mashing the membrillo with the back of a spoon to break it up. Set aside to cool while you prepare the pastry and persimmon.

On a flour-dusted work surface, roll the pastry to the thickness of a £1 coin. Use a sharp knife to cut out a circle, about 30cm in diameter (use an upturned mixing bowl as a guide, if you like). Transfer the pastry to the parchment-lined baking sheet. Slice each persimmon into thin circles, showing off the central star.

When the membrillo mixture has cooled, stir in the egg yolks, then spread over the pastry, leaving 1.5cm clear around the edges. Layer the persimmon slices over the membrillo base. Grate over a little more nutmeg, dot with the remaining butter and scatter with sugar. Fold in the edges of the pastry to create a border and brush with the remaining egg yolk. Open the oven and carefully slide the galette onto the hot baking sheet. Bake for 40-45 mins until the pastry is crisp and golden, and the persimmons are soft. Cool for 10 mins before serving with ice cream, or serve cold at teatime.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful interplay between the aromatic warmth of cinnamon and nutmeg and the rich, caramel notes of membrillo and persimmons—all wrapped in the decadence of all-butter puff pastry. The buttery base ensures a crisp, flaky texture that contrasts beautifully with the sweet, slightly tangy filling. The addition of golden caster sugar enhances the persimmons' natural sweetness without overwhelming the palate. The use of egg yolks contributes to a luscious, glossy finish, making the tart both visually appealing and texturally satisfying. Served warm with a scoop of ice cream, it transforms into a comforting, elegant dessert, ideal for autumn or winter entertaining. This recipe is especially well-suited for a vegetarian diet, thoughtfully omitting any meat or gelatin-based ingredients, making it a crowd-pleaser for those seeking a refined, meatless dessert option.

name: Eastern breeze
author: Sabrina Ghayour
ingredients: seedsfrom 1 pomegranate (about 1 heaped tsp per glass)
directions: Fill six highball or big wine glasses with ice and divide 300ml vodka between them. Add 24 mint leaves, seeds from 1 pomegranate (about 1 heaped tsp per glass) and 600ml apple juice, then stir with a straw or chopstick to muddle.
chief_review:
This refreshing cocktail is a harmonious blend of crisp apple juice, bright pomegranate seeds, and aromatic mint, with vodka providing the spirited base. The simplicity of the ingredients allows the natural flavors to shine through, while the pomegranate seeds add a delightful burst of texture and color. Served over ice, it’s an ideal choice for festive gatherings or a summer evening aperitif. 

Given its composition of fruit juices, herbs, and clear spirit, this recipe aligns well with a vegan and vegetarian diet. It also contains no gluten or common allergens such as dairy, nuts, or soy, making it broadly accessible. The use of whole pomegranate seeds adds a touch of elegance as well as nutritional value, complementing the gentle sweetness of the apple juice and the cool, herbal lift of the mint.

name: Easy-peasy fruitcake
description: Swap the candied toppings for fresh fruit
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 600g mixed dried fruit(sultanas, raisins, apricots, cherries, cranberries)
100g pecan nutsor whole skinned almonds, chopped
apricot jam(warmed and sieved) or apricot glaze
candied pineapple, candied angelica, glacé cherries (a mixture of red, green and yellow if you can find them), crystallised ginger
directions: Put the rum (or brandy), orange zest and juice and mixed dried fruit in a bowl and stir. Leave to soak overnight.
Heat oven to 170C/150C fan/gas 3½. Double line a 20cm tin with baking parchment. Beat the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy.

in the eggs one by one, then fold in the almonds and flour. Add a pinch of salt and fold in the soaked fruit mixture (and any remaining liquid in the bowl), along with the nuts, candied peel and ginger. Spoon the mixture into the tin and level the surface.

Bake for 1 hr, then turn the oven down to 150C/130C fan/gas 2 and bake for a further 2 hrs. Check the cake to see if it's pulling away from the sides of the tin and feels firm on top. If you need to, keep cooking for a further 15 mins. Cool in the tin. If storing in the tin, wrap the cake tightly first.
To decorate, brush the cake with the apricot jam (or glaze) and arrange your choice of candied fruit on top.
chief_review: A delightful twist on the classic fruitcake, this recipe replaces the traditional candied toppings with a vibrant medley of fresh fruit. The blend of mixed dried fruits, citrus zest, and a generous splash of brandy delivers a rich, aromatic base, while the chopped nuts and crystallised ginger add both texture and zing. Using ground almonds in the batter introduces a subtle nuttiness and helps keep the crumb moist and tender. This cake is alcohol-infused and contains eggs, butter, nuts, and wheat flour, making it a no-go for strict vegetarians, vegans, gluten-free, nut, or dairy-allergic diets. The final touch of fresh fruit lifts the presentation, balancing the cake’s deep flavors with brightness and natural sweetness. Perfect for festive occasions or an elegant afternoon tea, this fruitcake offers a beautiful balance between tradition and innovation.

name: Golden stuffed goose
description: This mix of the traditional and the trendy makes a glorious family lunch and a magnificent centrepiece
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1¼kg floury potato, such as King Edward, peeled and cut into chunks
8 leeks, trimmed, chopped into long slices and rinsed, trimmings reserved
2 tbsp fresh thyme leaves, stalks reserved
2x 20g packs parsley, leaves chopped, stalks reserved, plus a few sprigs for serving
finely grated zest of 2 unwaxed lemons
1 tbsp vegetable oil or sunflower oil
goose neck and gizzard, roughly chopped
directions: Make the stuffing. Boil the potatoes for 10-15 minutes until soft enough to mash, then drain. Meanwhile, heat the butter in a large pan and fry the leeks, garlic and thyme leaves, stirring occasionally, for 8-10 minutes until soft. Mash the leeks and potatoes together with the parsley, lemon zest and salt and pepper. (This can be prepared up to a day ahead and kept in the fridge until needed.)

Preheat the oven to fan 200C/ conventional 220C/gas 7. Pull out the two big lumps of fat from inside the cavity of the goose. Use a skewer to prick the skin all over, especially on the legs – try not to pierce the flesh. Rub lots of salt over the skin and in the cavity. Pack the cavity with stuffing, then loosely tie the legs together with string.

Lift the goose onto a roasting rack in a large roasting tin. Roast for 30 minutes. Reduce the oven to fan 160C/conventional 180C/gas 4 and roast for another 2⁄2½hours. Meanwhile, make the gravy and stuff the apples (see steps 4 and 5). Check during roasting that the fat released from the goose hasn’t risen to touch the bird – if it’s close, carefully pour it into a bowl. At the end of the roasting time, check the bird is cooked by inserting a skewer into the thickest part of the thigh to see if the juices run clear; if not, give it another 15 minutes and check again.Remove from the oven when ready and increase the heat to fan 180C/conventional 200C/gas 6, for the apples. Allow the goose to rest for 20 minutes before carving.

For the gravy, heat the oil in a heavy-based pan over a highish heat. Fry the goose neck, gizzard and carrots for 10 minutes until brown. Add the onion, leek trimmings and herb stalks and cook for 5 minutes. Pour over the wine and port and boil for 5 minutes until reduced and syrupy. Pour in the stock, stir well and simmer for about 20 minutes until you have a mahogany gravy. Strain into a small pan, ready to reheat before serving.

For the apples, mix the cranberry sauce and cranberries in a bowl. Cut a thin slice off the bottom of the apples. Score the skin all round their middles, then tunnel out the stalks and cores. Stand the apples on a shallow baking tray. Pile the cranberry mix into the cavities, top with a dot of butter and scatter over the sugar.While the goose is resting, increase the oven to fan 180C/conventional 200C/gas 6. Bake the apples for 20-30 minutes until soft and starting to split and the cranberries are oozing juice.

Reheat the gravy. Put the goose on a large platter, surrounded by the apples and sprigs of parsley. Serve with the potato stuffing, Quick braised celery and carrots and the gravy. And what to do with all the goose fat? Use it to make the duck confit and the roast potatoes.
chief_review: This dish is a beautiful fusion of classic and contemporary, ideal for a family feast. The oven-roasted goose serves as a luxurious centerpiece, its richness perfectly offset by the tang of fresh cranberries and apples. The use of butter and poultry makes it best suited to an omnivorous palate and provides wholesome, robust flavors. Floury potatoes and aromatic leeks add hearty, comforting texture, complemented by the brightness of lemon zest and the depth of red wine and port sauce. Fresh herbs bring vitality and balance, while the fruit elements keep the dish lively and seasonal. Every element feels thoughtfully curated, resulting in a meal that is as visually impressive as it is satisfying. This recipe would fit well into a festive gathering, offering both indulgence and a harmonious blend of sweet, tart, and savory notes.

name: Sloe gin & fruit sponge puddings with custard
description: This was lovely and I made it for my husband and I and we had two puddings left over. I left them in the fridge for two days and then reheated them for 25 minutes and they were as good as when we'd had them fresh from the oven. This is on our Favourites list now!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g mixed dried fruit, such as raisins, currants and sultanas
200g butter, at room temperature, plus extra for the moulds
zest of ½ an orangeor 1 clementine
directions: Soak the dried fruit in the sherry overnight, or for as long as you can – even a 10-min soak will help. Butter six 200ml pudding moulds or dariole moulds.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Beat the butter and sugar together until pale and fluffy. Beat the eggs, then slowly add them to the butter and sugar using an electric whisk or mixer. Sift the flour and baking powder together, then carefully fold into the egg, butter and sugar mix using a large metal spoon. Drain the fruit and fold into the mix with the mixed spice, orange or clementine zest and 4 tbsp of the sloe gin.

Mix the jam and the remaining sloe gin, then divide between the moulds. Spoon in the batter, filling the moulds two-thirds full. Fill another mould with any leftover mix. Cover each mould with a large square of foil with a pleat in the centre to allow room, as the sponges will rise a lot. Secure with string. Place the moulds in a baking or roasting dish, then fill the dish with water to come one-third up the side of the moulds. Bake for about 1 hr or until the sponges have risen and are cooked.
To serve, remove the foil. Gently loosen the puddings with a knife and upturn them onto plates. Serve with homemade or bought custard.
chief_review: This rich, festive pudding brings together mixed dried fruits, aromatic spices, and a beautiful hint of citrus, all elevated by the luxurious notes of sherry and sloe gin. The self-raising flour gives the desserts a perfect rise, while the generous use of butter ensures a moist, indulgent crumb. The apricot jam glaze provides a glossy, tangy finish, perfectly balanced by a serving of classic vanilla custard. Thanks to the use of eggs, dairy, and wheat flour, this recipe is suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians but not for those following a vegan or gluten-free diet, or people with egg, dairy, or gluten allergies. Impressively, these puddings also reheat beautifully, maintaining their texture and flavor even after a couple of days in the fridge—making them ideal for preparing ahead during the busy entertaining season. A truly delightful addition to any dessert repertoire!

name: Carrot, apple & celeriac mash
description: A superhealthy side, ideal for making the day before and reheating in the microwave
author: Good Food
directions: Put the celeriac, carrots and apples in a large pan of water, bring to the boil and simmer for 20 mins until tender. Drain, tip back into the pan and mash roughly. Stir in the rest of the ingredients. Cover and keep warm until ready to serve.
chief_review: This vibrant side dish is a beautifully balanced medley of root vegetables and apples, offering a comforting, lightly sweet flavor profile with a creamy finish from the crème fraîche and butter. The generous use of fresh parsley brings brightness and color, making it ideal for both everyday meals and festive occasions. Its make-ahead nature is highly practical for dinner planning. This recipe is excellent for a vegetarian diet, provided the crème fraîche and butter used are vegetarian-friendly. It’s also nut-free and soy-free, making it suitable for those with these common allergies. The absence of gluten-containing ingredients makes it naturally gluten-free, offering a hearty option for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. Overall, it’s a nourishing, versatile side that’s both healthy and crowd-pleasing.

name: Nutty, fruity, festive muffin tarts
description: The perfect sweet offering for the Christmas holidays, these tarts are a delicious cross between mince pies and muffins
author: Good Food
ingredients: 250g salted butter, cut into small pieces
1 lemon, finely grated zest and juice
1 orange, finely grated zest and juice
directions: First make the pastry. Sift the flour into a large bowl, add the butter and, using your fingertips, rub it into the flour so the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Measure 150ml/¼ pint cold water into a jug. Stir the ground almonds and sugar into the flour mixture, then add the egg yolk and a little of the water, stirring with a knife. Gradually work in the rest of the water, stirring until you have a soft pastry ball. Wrap it in cling film and chill for 20-30 minutes.

Meanwhile, make the filling. Preheat the oven to fan 180C/conventional 200C/gas 6. Tip the ground almonds, sugar, currants, sultanas, almonds and spices into a large bowl and stir. Melt the butter (use the microwave for speed) and add to the dry ingredients with the beaten eggs and the lemon and orange zest and juice. Mix together really well.

Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface (working with half at a time is easiest) to about 5mm thickness. Cut out about 24 rounds using a 10cm round cutter. Use each round to line a muffin tin (use two trays, or bake in batches). Spoon the filling into each pastry-lined tart, so it is just shy of the top of the pastry.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until pale golden, then turn each tart out on to a wire rack and dust with icing sugar. Lovely served warm or cold.
chief_review: These festive tarts beautifully blend the comfort of mince pies with the lightness of muffins, yielding a rich, aromatic treat ideal for the holiday season. The pastry is tender and subtly nutty, thanks to the incorporation of ground almonds, while the filling is luxuriously moist, generously studded with currants, sultanas, and flaked almonds, enhanced by the fragrant warmth of cinnamon, nutmeg, and mixed spice. The citrus zest and juice provide a zippy brightness that cuts through the sweetness, balancing each bite. Finished with a delicate dusting of icing sugar, these tarts are sure to delight at any holiday gathering. With no gluten-free substitutes in the base and the presence of dairy, nuts, and eggs, these are particularly well-suited for traditional vegetarian diets but must be avoided by anyone with allergies to gluten, nuts, or eggs. Serve slightly warm with a touch of cream for ultimate indulgence.

name: Pear & manchego salad
description: Really great! There was no manchego at my local deli so I used pecorino instead which worked really well. Simple to make but smart enough for a dinner party
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tsp olive oil, plus a drizzle for toasting the nuts
75g mixed leaf(we used red chicory, watercress and rocket)
1 ripe pear, halved, cored and thinly sliced
directions: Heat the honey and rosemary in a small pan with 1 tbsp boiling water. Bring to a simmer and let it bubble for around 30 secs. Remove from the heat and allow to infuse.

Heat a frying pan and drizzle in a little oil. Add the hazelnuts and toast until golden and starting to char a little here and there. Remove from the pan, allow to cool, then chop roughly to make a rustic crumb. Mix with the lemon zest and some seasoning.

To make a dressing, combine the olive oil and balsamic vinegar with some seasoning. Toss the salad leaves in most of the dressing, then arrange on serving plates or a platter, layering the leaves with the pear slices. Top with shavings of manchego and the hazelnut crumb, then drizzle over some of the rosemary honey and the remaining dressing. Serve with prosciutto twists (see tip, below) for the meat-eaters.
chief_review: This vibrant salad cleverly balances sweet, nutty, and peppery flavors with minimal fuss—making it a perfect starter for a dinner party. Substituting manchego with pecorino demonstrates the recipe’s versatility, and both cheeses pair beautifully with honey, rosemary, and the freshness of pear. Toasted hazelnuts give a delightful crunch, while lemon zest and a touch of balsamic vinegar bring brightness and acidity. The mixed leaves provide a subtle bitterness, contrasting elegantly with the creamy cheese and sweet fruit. Notably, this dish is ideal for vegetarians if you select a vegetarian hard cheese in place of manchego or pecorino. The simple technique and thoughtful ingredient layering make this salad both refined and approachable, sure to impress guests with its sophisticated yet comforting flavor profile.

name: Crispy hedgehog spuds with sage
description: Give your roasties a crispy finish and prepare ahead of time for the ultimate of ease
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2kg small potato, such as Charlotte, scrubbed
6 tbsp duck fat or sunflower oil
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Make 3-4 deep slashes length- and widthways in each potato, to make a criss-cross pattern. Sprinkle over a little sea salt and insert a sage leaf into slits of each hedgehog. Put in a roasting tin, add the fat or oil and roast for 45 mins. You can do this up to a day ahead; keep in fridge until ready to cook. Increase oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Roast for 30 mins until crisp and golden.
chief_review: This recipe showcases classic roasted potatoes with a beautiful crispy finish—perfect for a comforting side dish. Using small potatoes like Charlotte ensures a creamy interior, while sage leaves add aromatic depth. Opting for duck fat will give the potatoes an exquisitely rich flavor, but for those seeking a plant-based or vegetarian option, sunflower oil is an excellent substitute, retaining crispiness and making the dish suitable for vegetarians and vegans. Additionally, with only potatoes, sage, and oil, the recipe is gluten-free, making it broadly accessible for those with gluten sensitivities. Preparing the potatoes in advance maximizes ease without compromising texture or taste. This straightforward yet refined recipe is ideal for Sunday roasts or festive feasts, offering both convenience and crowd-pleasing appeal.

name: Best ever roast potatoes
description: This recipe is very similar to the way I've been roasting potatoes for some years. I don't place them in the fridge once boiled but return them to the empty pan over a low heat and steam them off for a few minutes whilst moving them around with a wooden spatula. This in an effort to remove as much water as possible. It seems to me that water is the sworn enemy of crusty roast potatoes. Then roast for perhaps just under the hour but take a look after 35 minutes. I agree on the Maris Pipers....
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3kg Maris Piper potatoes(we’ve tried lots of potatoes over the years and these are truly the best)
directions: A day or two before roasting, prepare the potatoes. You need chunks or whole potatoes roughly the size of a clementine, so peel and leave whole, halve or quarter accordingly. Place the potatoes in a large pan of cold, salted water – salting is important, so don’t skip it. Bring the water to the boil and simmer gently for about 15 mins until the potatoes are cooked all the way through but not on the brink of collapse. Gently drain the potatoes in a colander, but do not shake them or ruffle them up – just leave them to drain and cool. Once there is no more steam coming off them, place on a tray in a single layer and put them in the fridge, uncovered, until ready to roast.

Heat oven to 200C/180C/gas 6 (or put them in when you turn it up for the turkey). Pour oil into a deep roasting tin to give an even layer of about 0.5cm. Place the tin in the oven for 5 mins to heat the oil, then remove from the oven. One at a time and working directionsically (starting at one corner of the roasting tin and lining them up as you go) place each potato in the oil and use a spoon to turn it so it’s completely coated. Don’t worry about the oil cooling down too much. Once all the potatoes are in the tin in a single layer, not touching, place the tin in the oven and cook for 40 mins, undisturbed.

Remove from the oven and – again, meticulously – turn each potato. Return to the oven for 20 mins, then repeat the potato-turning process again. If, at this stage, your other side dishes allow you to, turn the oven up to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and give the potatoes a final 20 mins. By now you should have potatoes that are everything a roastie should be: deep, golden and crunchy on the outside with an extra-fluffy middle – just sprinkle with a little sea salt to serve.
chief_review: This roast potato recipe showcases a classic technique for achieving a beautifully crisp exterior and fluffy interior. The method of steaming off excess moisture in the pan is a chef’s trick that maximizes the coveted crunchy crust. Using Maris Piper potatoes—renowned for their texture—ensures consistent golden results. Sunflower oil provides a neutral flavor and high smoke point, ideal for roasting at high temperatures. With only potatoes and oil, this recipe is naturally suitable for vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free diets, as well as those avoiding common allergens like dairy and eggs. It’s a versatile, crowd-pleasing side dish that pairs seamlessly with a wide array of mains. An excellent staple for any home cook seeking perfect roast potatoes.

name: Turkey minestrone
description: I used this recipe as a guide and made a few changes based on my leftovers: my turkey breast was already wrapped in bacon, so skipped the first step; used a couple of spoons of onion chutney to finish that off (from my cheese board) and the left over celery and carrot crudites chopped up for step 2. Only root veg left in the house was sweet potato, so used this instead of celeriac and real potato and also skipped the beans (only baked left in the cupboard, but i reckon they could work). Also used left over gravy to boost the chicken stock. Added in the turkey wrapped bacon. Then I had no Orzo, but I did have thin noodles so added these with the sliced savoy cabbage (instead of kale) at the end. Worked perfectly, would make again and edit again based on what is left in the fridge :)
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 300g celeriac(or any other root veg), cut into cubes
400g can borlotti beans, drained and rinsed
1½ l chicken stockor turkey stock, (fresh is best)
directions: Heat 1 tsp of oil in a large saucepan. Add the bacon and fry over a medium-to-high heat for 4-5 mins or until golden, then set aside.

Put the remaining oil, the onion, carrot, celery and a pinch of salt in the pan. Cook gently over a low heat for 8-10 mins, stirring occasionally, until the veg is soft but not coloured. Add the garlic and herbs, and cook for 2 mins more
Tip in the celeriac, potato, borlotti beans and chicken stock. Bring to the boil, then simmer, uncovered, for 10-15 mins. Add the cooked turkey, orzo and the bacon, and cook for 10 mins.
Just before serving, tip in the kale, give everything a good stir and return to the heat for about 2 mins or until the kale has wilted.
chief_review:
This hearty recipe is a fantastic way to transform roast dinner leftovers into a nourishing, flavorful soup. The balance of protein from turkey and bacon pairs beautifully with the earthy sweetness of root vegetables and the robustness of beans. Adding orzo creates a satisfying texture, and the handful of kale brings a welcome bitterness, rounding off the flavors nicely. The flexibility in vegetable and meat choice makes this dish perfect for using up whatever is in your fridge. 

The recipe, however, is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the inclusion of turkey and bacon, and would not meet gluten-free needs because of the orzo. However, this dish is ideal for anyone following a high-protein, comforting diet using whole ingredients—perfect for a post-holiday meal revival. A chef’s tip: try varying the herbs or throw in some lemon zest for an extra lift.

name: Orange blossom cakes
description: Bake these zesty little cakes in a snowflake mould and dust with icing sugar for a festive feel
author: Good Food
ingredients: 120g softened butter, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line 10 holes of a muffin tin with cases (or grease some individual cake moulds). Beat the butter, flour, sugar, baking powder, eggs, yogurt, zest and 2 tbsp orange blossom water in a large bowl with an electric whisk until lump-free. Spoon into the cases (or fill cake moulds three-quarters full), and bake for 18-22 mins until golden and risen – a skewer poked in should come out clean (check cake moulds after 15 mins).
Drizzle with remaining orange blossom water while warm, then cool. Dust with icing sugar to serve.
chief_review: These zesty cakes are a delightful festive treat, boasting bright citrus notes from clementine zest and fragrant orange blossom water. The use of self-raising flour and baking powder ensures a light, tender crumb, while natural yogurt adds moistness and a subtle tang. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish products. The golden caster sugar provides a gentle sweetness, balanced perfectly by the aromatic citrus flavors. Baking the mixture in a snowflake mould adds a seasonal flair, and a simple dusting of icing sugar finishes them beautifully. Ideal for holiday gatherings, these cakes are both eye-catching and delicious, offering a sophisticated twist on traditional party bakes.

name: Cauliflower cheese with walnuts & crumbs
description: Chunks of cauliflower are smothered in creamy cheese sauce, scattered with bread and walnuts, then crisped in the oven in this classic side dish
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 3 fresh bay leaves, folded to break the spines
25g coarse textured white bread, torn into chunky crumbs
directions: Separate the cauliflower into even-sized florets, cutting round the core, then bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Add the cauliflower and boil for 8 mins or until just tender. Drain in a colander and allow to steam-dry. Shake the cauliflower if necessary to remove as much water from the crevices as you can. Arrange in a large casserole dish.

To make the sauce, pour the milk into a pan with the butter, bay leaves and cornflour, and heat gently, stirring all the time, until it thickens into a smooth, creamy sauce. Remove the bay leaves, add 100g of the cheese and season to taste. Pour over the cauliflower and scatter with the remaining cheese. If cooking now, go straight to step 3; alternatively, cover and chill. Can be made a day ahead.
Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Scatter the bread and walnuts over the cauliflower and bake for 25 mins until golden.
chief_review: This cauliflower gratin is a comfort-filled classic, marrying the mellow earthiness of cauliflower with the richness of a homemade cheese sauce. The use of cornflour thickens the milk without traditional wheat flour, making it a suitable gluten-free option—assuming the bread used is gluten-free. The addition of walnuts lends welcome crunch and a nutty depth to the dish, elevating it beyond the usual gratin. Mature cheddar brings sharpness, balancing the creamy texture of the sauce. The bay leaves subtly perfume the base, enhancing flavor complexity. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and for those seeking a hearty, gluten-free side dish with satisfying texture contrasts. Serve alongside roasted meats or a robust vegetarian main for a crowd-pleasing accompaniment.

name: Make-ahead mince pies
description: It wouldn't be Christmas without mince pies, and you just can't beat homemade - these can be cooked from frozen for extra ease
author: James Martin
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Roll the pastry out on a lightly floured surface a little thinner than a £1 coin. Stamp out 12 circles about 8cm wide, keeping all the trimmings. Use the circles to line a 12-hole, non-stick bun tin. Put a small spoonful of mincemeat in each one, but be careful not to put too much, as the suet will melt and bubble out if it has no room to spare. Re-roll the pastry trimmings and cut out another 12 circles a little smaller than the last. Brush the edges of the pastry with beaten egg, then add pastry lids, pinching the two edges together. Make a small cross with a knife in the centre of each pie. The pies can now be frozen in the trays for up to 3 months and either defrosted and cooked as stated or cooked from frozen.
Brush the lids with a little more egg, sprinkle with sugar and bake for 15-20 mins until golden brown. Leave to cool slightly and serve warm.
chief_review: Homemade mince pies are a true seasonal indulgence, and this recipe delivers on both tradition and simplicity. The use of store-bought shortcrust pastry saves time without compromising on that buttery, crumbly texture, while the rich, spiced mincemeat filling bursts with festive flavors. The pies bake beautifully straight from the freezer, making them a perfect make-ahead treat for busy holiday gatherings. A brush of beaten egg and a sprinkle of granulated sugar provide a lovely golden finish and delicate crunch. This classic bake is ideal for vegetarians, assuming the mincemeat used is suet-free or made with vegetarian suet. Overall, these mince pies are a superb, crowd-pleasing addition to any Christmas table, embodying comfort, convenience, and festive cheer in every bite.

name: Funky fudge
description: Don't stick to standard flavours for homemade fudge - try these combinations of sweet with salty and zesty with fiery black pepper
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 rashers smoked streaky bacon, grilled until crispy, then very finely shredded
directions: Line two 19 x 9 x 6cm loaf tins with baking parchment. Tip the sugar, cream, butter and glucose syrup into a medium to large saucepan. Heat to dissolve the sugar and melt the butter, stirring now and again.

Once dissolved, put a sugar thermometer in the pan, making sure the measuring tip is completely immersed in the syrup – if not, transfer the mixture to a smaller pan, but be aware the syrup will bubble up. Increase the heat and bring the syrup to a steady boil. Keep bubbling, stirring occasionally to stop the sugar from catching, until the mixture reaches 116C – this is known as the soft-ball stage.
Remove the pan from the heat and leave to sit undisturbed for 5 mins until the temperature drops to 110C. Stir in a good pinch of salt.

Keep the sugar thermometer in the pan and begin beating the mixture with a wooden spoon, quite vigorously, until the temperature cools to about 60C. By this time the fudge will be really thick and will have lost its glossy shine. Remove the thermometer and continue beating for a few mins more. This process is important when making fudge, as it creates small sugar crystals, which give the fudge its lovely smooth and creamy texture.
Working quickly, divide the mixture into 2 heatproof bowls. In one bowl, stir in the mashed banana. In the other, stir in the clementine zest, juice and 1/4 tsp of freshly ground black pepper.

Before it sets, quickly pour the fudge mixes into your prepared tins and smooth over the surface. Sprinkle the cooked bacon over the top of the banana fudge. Leave both to cool at room temperature overnight – don’t put the fudge in the fridge as it will become sticky and won’t set properly. Cut into bite-sized pieces and put in a box to give as a present. Banana fudge keeps in a sealed container for up to 1 week, clementine fudge for 2 weeks.
chief_review: This inventive fudge recipe delights with playful contrasts, balancing the richness of double cream and butter with vibrant clementine and a subtle hint of banana. The true surprise comes from the addition of crispy smoked bacon, lending a savory edge that pairs beautifully with the sweet and creamy base. The glaze of clementine zest and juice brightens each bite, while the black pepper introduces a gentle warmth, rounding out the flavor profile. This recipe is ideal for those seeking a gourmet twist on traditional fudge, especially fans of sweet-salty combinations. The inclusion of bacon makes it unsuitable for vegetarians and vegans but should delight adventurous omnivores. While decadent, this fudge demonstrates a thoughtful blend of textures and tastes, transforming a classic treat into a conversation-worthy delicacy.

name: Brandy pudding
description: This pud is impressive, delicious and makes a great light alternative dessert to a traditional Christmas pudding
author: Good Food
ingredients: 125g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the dates in a bowl, pour over 250ml boiling water and set aside. Butter a 1.5-litre pudding basin and put a disc of baking parchment in the base.
Put the butter, sugar, flour, baking powder and eggs in a large bowl, then beat with an electric hand whisk until well blended. Add the cooled date mix and beat again to make a sloppy batter

Stir in the fruits, pecans and ginger, then pour into the pudding basin and cover the basin with pleated baking paper and foil (see tips, below). Put the basin in a roasting tin half-filled with boiling water, then steam in the oven for 3 hrs until a skewer inserted into the pudding comes out clean.

Meanwhile, make the brandy syrup. Put the sugar and 75ml water in a pan and stir over the heat until syrupy. Stir in the brandy and remove from the heat. When the pudding is ready, remove from the oven, take off the foil and paper, and push a skewer into the centre – it should come out clean. Pour over the brandy syrup so it soaks into the pudding, then cover until ready to serve. Will keep in the fridge for a week.

To serve, warm the pudding in the turned-off oven once you have taken out the potatoes, or microwave on High, covered with cling film, for 5 mins. Warm the butterscotch sauce (see related recipes) in a pan or in the microwave on Medium for 2 mins. Turn out the pudding onto a plate, pour over some of the sauce and serve the rest in a jug. Top with the holly sprig and serve with good-quality vanilla ice cream
chief_review: This festive pudding offers a delightful mix of textures and flavors, with dates, raisins, and dark glacé cherries providing natural sweetness, balanced by the gentle warmth of stem ginger and a hint of brandy. The pecans add a pleasant crunch that complements the rich, buttery crumb. It’s a lighter, fruit-forward alternative to traditional Christmas pudding, making it perfect for those who crave something a little less dense after a big meal. The butterscotch sauce takes it to another level, adding a luscious finish. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it does not contain any meat or gelatine-based ingredients. However, it does contain eggs, butter, and pecans, so it's not vegan or nut-free, and relies on wheat flour for structure. Overall, an impressive and approachable dessert for a festive table.

name: Spiced roast beef with red wine gravy
description: Marinade your fillet with peppercorn, fennel and mustard seeds then roast until rare - the gravy is gluten-free too!
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 2 tbsp mustard seed, yellow or black, or 1 tbsp of each
1 tbsp wholegrain or English mustard(check the brand is gluten-free)
3 red onions, skins left on, thickly sliced into rounds
a few thyme leaves, to serve (optional)
2 gluten- and wheat-free beef stock cubes(check the label)
directions: Up to 2 days before, crush together the peppercorns and seeds using a pestle and mortar, or in a saucepan with the end of a rolling pin or similar. Brush the beef fillet all over with the mustard, then roll in the peppercorn mix to coat. Cover and chill.
Two hours before you are ready to start cooking, take the beef out of the fridge to come to room temperature.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Heat the oil in a pan big enough to hold the beef, and brown the beef all over, seasoning with salt. In a roasting tin, use the onions as a bed to sit the beef on – pat on any spices that have fallen off. Roast for 20 mins for rare, 25 mins for medium, and 35 mins for well-done beef.

Lift the beef from the tin and rest on a platter, covered with foil to keep it hot, for about 30 mins. Set the tin with the onions and roasting juices over the hob and stir in the oil, cornflour and crumbled stock cubes. Mix in the jelly, then gradually stir in the wine and 400ml boiling water, scraping up any stuck bits from the bottom. Simmer for 15 mins until reduced a little. Season, then sieve into a clean pan to keep warm, discarding the onions. Slice the beef, scatter over the thyme, if you like, and serve with the gravy.
chief_review: A robust dish that lets the character of beef shine, elevated by a well-balanced crust of peppercorn, fennel, and mustard seeds. The marinade punches with aromatic heat, nicely complemented by the sweetness of slow-roasted onions, while the redcurrant jelly and wine gravy adds depth and a touch of brightness. The use of cornflour and specifically gluten- and wheat-free beef stock cubes ensures the entire recipe remains suitable for gluten-free diets, a thoughtful touch allowing broader enjoyment. The recipe is naturally free from common allergens like nuts and dairy, but those with mustard sensitivity should be cautious. For best results, don’t skimp on quality beef and let it rest well after roasting for a tender finish. An impressive centerpiece perfect for special gatherings, especially when catering to gluten-free needs without sacrificing any flavor or texture.

name: Ruby cranberry sauce
author: Cassie Best
directions: Tip all the ingredients into a saucepan. Bring to a simmer and cook for 5 mins (or a little longer if the berries are frozen ). Cool, then chill for up to four days or freeze for two months. Serve at room temperature.
chief_review: This cranberry sauce recipe beautifully balances tart cranberries with the citrus brightness of fresh orange and a delicate sweetness from light brown sugar and ruby port. The simplicity highlights each ingredient’s integrity, making it a sophisticated accompaniment for festive roasts or cheese boards. Notably, the absence of animal products and gluten-containing ingredients makes this recipe suitable for both vegan and gluten-free diets, as long as the port used is certified vegan and gluten-free. The vibrant flavors and ease of preparation will elevate any holiday table while catering to a wide range of dietary preferences.

name: Chorizo & almond Brussels
description: I love brussels one of the best things about Christmas dinner! Not tried it with almond and chorizo so might have to give that a go! :)
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Cook the Brussels sprouts for 2 mins, then drain and leave to steam-dry. Meanwhile, put the butter and chorizo in a large frying pan over a medium heat for 5 mins until the butter caramelises and smells nutty, and the chorizo begins to brown. Tip in the sprouts and fry for 5-6 mins over a high heat until they’re tender, starting to crisp and are coated in the browned butter. Once the sprouts are cooked, toss in the blanched almonds.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts dish, enhanced with the smoky richness of chorizo and the crunchy texture of blanched almonds, brings a robust twist to the classic Christmas side. The butter imparts a silky finish, melding the flavors beautifully, while the chorizo offers a bold, savory depth balanced by the subtle nuttiness of almonds. Perfect for those seeking a festive dish with a combination of earthy, meaty, and nutty elements, this recipe is a standout addition to any holiday spread. Given the absence of gluten-containing ingredients, this dish is also naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. The use of almonds provides added protein and texture, making every bite satisfying and memorable.

name: Stir-fried red cabbage with mulled wine dressing
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 1 small red cabbage, cut into wedges and core removed
4 tbsp goose fat(or use rapeseed oil to make to vegetarian)
directions: For the dressing, put the wine, vinegar, cloves and cinnamon in a saucepan. Cook for 15-20 mins until the liquid has reduced by 3/ 4 (to about 75ml ). Add the orange zest and juice to the pan with the crème de cassis, and set aside to keep warm.

Next, shred the cabbage as finely as possible. Heat a wok until very hot, then add the goose fat and fry the cabbage and ginger for 10 mins. Toss through the dressing and cook for 5 mins more until the cabbage is softened but retains a good bite, serving sprinkled with sea salt.
chief_review: This braised red cabbage recipe is a vibrant, aromatic side dish that's perfect for showcasing seasonal produce. The slow cooking in red wine, spices, and citrus yields tender cabbage with a rich, subtly sweet-tart flavor profile, complemented by notes of ginger and orange. The use of goose fat imparts a deep savory character, but swapping in rapeseed oil makes it entirely vegetarian. With no reliance on gluten or dairy, and by excluding goose fat, the dish also becomes suitable for vegan diets. The addition of Crème de Cassis lends a unique fruitiness that sets it apart from traditional preparations. Ideal alongside roasted meats or as a festive vegetarian main, this dish beautifully balances warmth and freshness on the plate, and the fragrance wafting from the kitchen is simply irresistible.

name: Mulled white wine
description:
as Don replied I am amazed that a student can make $7195 in one month on the computer _______________________
see more___ www.moneyboastfast7.tk ________________
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Start by pouring the white wine and Madeira into a large saucepan. Add the lemon, dried apricots, cardamom pods, star anise, vanilla pod and honey. Bring to a simmer then strain into a jug through a fine sieve. Stir in the rosewater before serving.
chief_review: This recipe presents an aromatic infusion of white wine enriched with madeira, accented by subtle floral and fruity notes from dried apricots, lemon, cardamom, star anise, vanilla, honey, and a touch of rosewater. The combination of spices creates a beautifully balanced and elegant beverage with sweet, citrus, and spice notes—perfect as a sophisticated aperitif or a dessert pairing. Vegetarian-friendly, this recipe is also suitable for a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain wheat or related grains. The use of honey may not cater to strict vegans, but it provides a gentle sweetness that pairs well with the aromatic spices. Overall, this recipe stands out for its depth of flavor and would impress anyone seeking an inventive, wine-based concoction.

name: Roast potatoes with paprika
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1½ kg floury potatoes (such as Maris Piper, King Edward or Desirée), peeled and cut into halves or quarters, depending on size
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Add the potatoes to a pan of cold salted water, bring to a boil, then simmer for 5 mins until partly tender. Drain and steam dry for a few mins in a colander.

Return the potatoes to the saucepan, and add the oil, paprika and plenty of salt and pepper. Cover with a lid, then shake the pan around to roughen the edges of the potatoes and thoroughly coat them in the paprika and oil. Tip the potatoes into a large roasting tin, making sure they are evenly spaced apart. Scrape in all the fluffy potato mess – these make the best crispy bits!
Roast the potatoes for 1 hr 15 mins, turning halfway, until extremely fluffy and crisp.
chief_review: This recipe for roasted potatoes showcases classic comfort with a twist, using olive oil and smoked paprika to elevate simple floury potatoes. The end result is a golden, crispy exterior with a smoky flavor—perfect for a hearty side dish. With its short ingredient list and straightforward approach, this recipe is wonderfully accessible for home cooks. Notably, the absence of animal products makes it suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Since no gluten-containing ingredients are present, it’s also naturally gluten-free, which broadens its appeal for guests with dietary restrictions. Perfect as an accompaniment to both robust and light mains, these potatoes promise to be a crowd-pleaser at any table.

name: Easy mulled wine
description: Not very nice
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour the red wine into a large saucepan. Add the clementine, cinnamon stick, star anise, dried figs, cloves and black peppercorns. Heat very gently until simmering, then turn off the heat.
Fish out the whole spices and peppercorns with a spoon, then stir in the brandy. Ladle into mugs, or heatproof glasses to serve. You could drop in a slice of clementine to each.
chief_review: This warming winter recipe brings together a fragrant blend of red wine, brandy, and traditional spices, resulting in a festive mulled drink. With the aromatic notes of cinnamon, star anise, and cloves, complemented by the subtle sweetness of dried figs and citrus zing from clementine, the beverage captures the essence of classic holiday flavors. The addition of peppercorn adds a gentle heat on the finish. As there are no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is suitable for vegan and gluten-free diets, provided the wine and brandy used are certified accordingly. However, always check for additives in spirits that may not align with strict dietary needs. Ideal for cozy gatherings, this mulled drink is best served warm and garnished with extra spices for a festive touch.

name: Vegan eggnog
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Soak the dates, cashews, apricots and mixed spice in the brandy overnight.
The next day, tip the mixture into a
and add the seeds from the vanilla pod and the almond milk. Blitz until smooth, then pour into eight tall glasses (use a sieve, if you like) with ice and grate some nutmeg on top.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful blend of natural sweetness from dates and apricots, balanced by the subtle nuttiness of cashew nuts and almond milk. The addition of brandy adds a warming depth, while vanilla seeds and mixed spice bring aromatic complexity. The use of sweetened almond milk, along with the other ingredients, ensures the recipe remains entirely plant-based and dairy-free, making it suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Additionally, with no gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is a good fit for those following a gluten-free regimen. The use of whole, minimally processed elements also suggests a focus on wholesome indulgence. Serve it chilled over ice, finished with freshly grated nutmeg, for a festive and refreshing treat that caters to a variety of dietary preferences.

name: Lamb & cranberry tagine
description: I halved the recipe but used a whole can of tomatoes. Turned out just nice. Very tasty.
ingredients: 1½ kg lamb shoulder, trimmed of excess fat, then cubed
2 large red onions, sliced into half moons
50g shelled pistachios, toasted and roughly chopped, to serve
natural yogurt, handful mint leaves and couscous, to serve
directions: At least 3 hrs before (or preferably a day), toss the lamb with half the cumin, coriander, sweet and hot paprika in a large bowl. Cover and leave in the fridge to infuse.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a large flameproof casserole dish over a high heat and season the spiced lamb well. Working in batches, fry until completely brown, then set aside. Add more of the oil as you need it and get some deep colour on the meat – this will add to the flavour of the tagine.

Once the lamb is browned, pour any remaining oil into the dish,reduce the heat to medium and add the onions, garlic and remaining ground spices. Cook for 5 mins until softened, then stir in the cinnamon sticks and cardamom pods. Return the lamb to the dish along with the tomatoes, plus 1 /2 a can of water and the honey. Bring to the boil, season, cover with a lid and put in the oven for 2 hrs 15 mins.
Bring the tagine out of the oven, give it a good stir and tip in the cranberries. Return to the oven, with the lid off, for a further 15 mins until the lamb is completely tender.
Taste the tagine for seasoning and remove the cinnamon sticks and cardamom pods. Scatter over the pistachios, yogurt and mint leaves, then serve out of the dish at the table with couscous.
chief_review:
This lamb stew recipe is an aromatic celebration of Middle Eastern flavors, blending cumin, coriander, sweet and hot paprika with the warmth of cinnamon and cardamom. The thoughtful inclusion of cranberries and honey brings a beautiful balance of tartness and sweetness, enhancing the succulent lamb. The canned tomatoes provide a bright, tangy base, and the garnish of pistachios adds a delightful crunch. Serving with natural yogurt and mint offers freshness, while couscous soaks up the rich sauce perfectly.

This dish is naturally gluten-free if the couscous is substituted with a gluten-free grain such as quinoa or rice, and it fits a nut-free diet if pistachios are omitted. The use of dairy yogurt as a garnish makes the recipe unsuitable for those with dairy allergies, but a dairy-free alternative could be used. Overall, a deeply flavorful and well-balanced dish ideal for family gatherings or festive occasions.

name: Spiced apple syrup with clementine & cloves
description: Once this is made how long will in keep?
author: Claire Thomson
ingredients: 1 clementine, zest finely peeled with a vegetable peeler
directions: Heat the apple juice with the whole spices, ginger, zest and sugar. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 10 mins.
Remove from the heat and leave to cool, then strain the syrup into small bottles.
chief_review: This recipe creates a fragrant, spiced apple syrup with warm notes from cinnamon, allspice, mace, cloves, and fresh ginger, beautifully complemented by clementine zest. The golden caster sugar ensures a smooth, pourable texture and adds subtle caramel undertones. Thanks to its entirely plant-based ingredient list and absence of common allergens like dairy, eggs, or nuts, this syrup is well-suited to both vegetarian and vegan diets. It also contains no gluten-containing ingredients, making it a welcome addition for gluten-free consumers, provided the caster sugar is certified gluten-free. Store the syrup in a sterilized, airtight container in the refrigerator—under these conditions, it should maintain its flavor and quality for up to two weeks. Use it to flavor hot drinks or drizzle over desserts for a seasonal twist.

name: Spiced red cabbage with prunes
description: Braised red cabbage with Christmassy flavours - a lovely addition to the festive table
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 150ml stock, made with 1 vegetable or chicken stock cube
directions: Fry the onion in the oil until beginning to soften. Tip in the mixed spice, then fry a few seconds more.
Add the remaining ingredients. Season, then stir well. Cover and simmer for 20 mins, stirring every now and then, until tender.
On the day, reheat in a pan.
chief_review: This braised red cabbage recipe delivers a beautifully balanced side dish filled with festive warmth and depth. The sweetness of prunes and redcurrant jelly harmonizes with the earthy cabbage, while mixed spice imparts a subtle, Christmassy aroma. The choice of stock can make the dish vegetarian-friendly if a vegetable stock cube is used. There’s no dairy, eggs, or gluten-containing ingredients, so it also fits a vegan or gluten-free diet when the proper stock is chosen. The olive oil and low-sugar content help keep it heart-healthy. Pair this vibrant, tangy-sweet cabbage alongside roasted mains for a stunning upgrade to your holiday spread.

name: Beetroot & horseradish purée
description: This is both a condiment and a side dish, and goes brilliantly with Christmas lunch, or even roast beef on a Sunday
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan and gently cook the onion and garlic for 10 mins until soft. Add the beetroot and vinegar to the pan and cook down until sticky. Take the pan off the heat, then stir in the crème fraîche. Blitz with a hand blender, or tip into a food processor and blitz to a purée. Stir in the grated horseradish and serve. The purée can be made up to a day ahead and heated in a pan or in the microwave.
chief_review: This recipe shines as a vibrant condiment or side, pairing exceptionally well with festive meals or classic roast beef. The earthy beetroot is elevated by the tang of balsamic vinegar and sharpness of fresh horseradish, while the crème fraîche adds a luscious creaminess. Onions and garlic provide an aromatic base, and olive oil ties the flavors together elegantly. It’s well-suited for a vegetarian diet, offering a satisfying richness without meat. Gluten-free by nature, it serves as an inclusive dish for those avoiding wheat. Perfect for anyone seeking a zesty, colorful accent to heartier mains.

name: Carrot & tarragon purée
description: This super simple, yet delicious, side dish has just three ingredients - perfect for no-fuss entertaining or with a laid-back Sunday roast
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Boil the carrots in salted water for 20-25 mins until tender. Drain in a colander and leave to steam-dry for 1-2 mins. Return to the pan with the butter and roughly mash if you would like a little texture in them, or blitz with a hand blender for a silky-smooth purée. Season well and stir in the tarragon. Will keep in the fridge for 3 days. Reheat in the microwave for 2-3 mins, or in a pan.
chief_review: This three-ingredient carrot side dish beautifully highlights the natural sweetness of organic carrots, subtly enhanced by the fresh, aniseed notes of tarragon. Finishing with a generous pat of butter lends a rich silkiness, making it an irresistible accompaniment for a Sunday roast or any casual gathering. The recipe’s simplicity allows the quality of the produce to shine, with minimal preparation required, ensuring it’s both quick and elegant. Vegetarian-friendly, this dish caters well to those seeking hearty vegetable options, and can easily become a staple at any table thanks to its versatile flavor profile.

name: Cranberry & kumquat relish
description: This relish goes perfectly with ham or turkey, making it a perfect accompaniment for your Christmas dishes
author: Good Food
ingredients: 8 kumquats, thickly sliced and any pips discarded, plus extra for garnish
100g light muscovado sugar, plus extra if needed
3 pieces preserved stem ginger in syrup, cut into matchstick-size strips
directions: Put the cranberries and kumquats in a pan with 300ml/⁄½ pint water. Bring to the boil and simmer very gently for 5-6 minutes, or until the skins start to pop.

Stir in sugar until dissolved, simmer for 4-5 minutes until thick and jam-like. Add stem ginger and more sugar if you like. Cool before serving. Relish can be stored in a covered container in the fridge for up to 5 days.
chief_review: This vibrant cranberry and kumquat relish brings a delightful balance of tartness, citrus brightness, and gentle warmth from stem ginger—an excellent complement to rich holiday meats like ham or turkey. The freshness of cranberries pairs beautifully with the tangy kumquats and subtle spice, while light muscovado sugar adds depth and roundness to the flavor profile. The use of preserved stem ginger in syrup elevates the relish with a nuanced sweetness. The recipe makes a visually appealing and refreshing side, perfect for festive occasions. Thanks to its plant-based ingredients, it’s a standout option for both vegan and vegetarian diners, and it’s naturally gluten-free, making it inclusive for gluten-sensitive guests. Its simple preparation and bold flavors make this relish a must-have on the holiday table.

name: Roast goose with potato & stuffing
description: As a Christmas turkey alternative, roast goose - free-range and oozing with flavour - is hard to resist
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4½ kg oven-ready goose, neck, giblets and wishbone removed and saved for the stock
1 bouquet garni (a sprig of thyme; 3-4 parsley stalks; 1 celery stick, sliced; and 6-7 peppercorns - all in a muslin bag)
2 tsp thyme or lemon thyme leaves
directions: Make the stock. Put the neck, giblets and wishbone from the goose into a large saucepan with the vegetables and bouquet garni. Cover with cold water and bring to the boil then simmer, half covered, for 11⁄2-2 hours. Strain the stock when it is ready. (You can make and strain the stock up to 24 hours ahead, and keep it in a covered container in the fridge.)
