Make the stuffing. Melt the butter in a heavy saucepan, add the onions, cover and sweat on a gentle heat for about 5 minutes. Tip in the apples, thyme and orange juice and cook, covered, until the apples are soft and fluffy – about 10 minutes.

Boil the potatoes in their skins for about 20 minutes until tender. Drain and peel when cool enough to handle, then mash and add to the fruit and onion mixture with the zest and seasoning. Allow to get quite cold before stuffing the goose.

Preheat the oven to 180C/gas 4/fan 160C. Season the cavity of the goose with salt and freshly ground pepper and rub a little salt into the skin. Stuff the cavity loosely and roast for about 2 hours. To test if it’s done, prick a thigh at the thickest part: the juices that run out should be clear. If they are still pink, the goose needs a little longer.

Put the goose on a serving platter and put it in a very low oven while you make the gravy. Spoon the fat from the roasting tin and save it in a covered container in the fridge – it will keep for months and is great for roast potatoes. Pour about 600ml/1 pint of the strained stock into the tin and bring to the boil on the hob. Using a small whisk, scrape the tin well to dislodge the flavourful meaty deposits. Taste, then strain and serve in a hot gravy boat. Serve the goose garnished with bay leaves and hand the gravy and apple sauce separately.
chief_review: This roast goose recipe is an exceptional Christmas centerpiece, offering a rich, gamey alternative to turkey. The use of free-range goose ensures a depth of flavor, while the aromatic bouquet garni, orange zest, and bay leaves add brightness and complexity. The stuffing of apples, onions, and thyme provides a classic pairing that beautifully complements the robust meat, while the Bramley apple sauce brings the ideal balance of tartness. The inclusion of floury potatoes completes the meal with comforting simplicity. This dish is well-suited to those following a gluten-free diet, as there are no wheat-based ingredients present. Additionally, its focus on whole foods and fresh ingredients will appeal to those prioritizing clean eating. Overall, this recipe promises a festive, elegant dining experience with flavor and texture at every turn.

name: Devil pigs on horseback
description: Pigs in blankets meet Devils on horseback in this combo - perfect as a side with Christmas dinner or Sunday roast, or as a party canapé
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Soak the prunes and apricots in the wine or juice, preferably for 3 hrs or more. Smear a piece of bacon with a little mustard, then use it to wrap round a prune or apricot and a sausage. Repeat with the remaining ingredients to make 24 and arrange on a baking tray.
Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7, brush with a little oil and bake for 18-20 mins until cooked and golden.
chief_review: This inventive recipe combines the fruity sweetness of prunes and apricots with savoury chipolatas and smoky bacon, delivering a crowd-pleasing bite ideal for festive gatherings or as a standout canapé. Soaking the dried fruit in white wine or orange juice enriches their flavour, while a swipe of piquant English mustard adds a welcome kick. Crisped in the oven with a light brush of olive oil, each parcel marries textures and tastes beautifully—juicy, tangy, savoury, and smoky all at once. The combination of both prunes and apricots offers an appealing contrast, balancing meaty richness with bursts of natural sugar. The recipe, laden with pork sausage and bacon, is best suited for omnivores and isn’t appropriate for vegetarian or vegan diets, nor is it gluten-free depending on the sausages used. This festive twist on classic appetizers is sure to be a hit at any holiday table.

name: Clementine & Port spiced cranberry sauce
description: Complete your Christmas dinner with this punchy cranberry sauce, made extra special with clementines, cinnamon and a touch of Port
author: Jenny White
directions: Put all the ingredients in a saucepan and stir over a gentle heat until the sugar has dissolved. Increase the heat, cover and simmer for 5 mins until the cranberries have burst and the sauce has thickened. Transfer to a bowl and leave to cool, then remove the cinnamon and cardamom.
chief_review: This festive cranberry sauce offers a vibrant burst of tartness, beautifully balanced by the citrusy brightness of clementines and an aromatic lift from cinnamon and cardamom. The addition of port lends a nuanced depth, elevating the sauce to a perfect companion for rich holiday roasts. With its reliance solely on fruit, spices, and a dash of fortified wine, this recipe is naturally suitable for vegetarians and vegans alike. Free from gluten, dairy, nuts, and eggs, it can be enjoyed by those with many common food allergies or dietary needs. The preparation is straightforward, yielding a sauce that’s both rustic and refined—a must-have on the Christmas table.

name: White forest meringue roulade
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 100g white chocolate, 50g grated, 50g melted and cooled a little
300g frozen black cherries, saving a few whole ones to decorate
½ tsp vanilla bean pasteor extract
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter, then line a 23 x 32cm baking tray. Using an electric hand
, beat the egg whites, lemon juice and a pinch of salt until stiff.

Add 1 tbsp of the caster sugar, then whisk until the mixture makes stiff peaks. Repeat with the rest of the sugar, spoon by spoon, until the mix is thick and shiny. Spread into the tin, then bake for 15 mins or until crisp to the touch and lightly golden in places. Leave to cool.

Simmer the cherries, orange juice, sugar and cloves for 10 mins, or until the cherries are soft but still holding their shape. Mix the cornflour with 2-3 tsp cold water to make a paste, stir into the cherries and cook for a couple mins more until the juices thicken. Leave to cool.
To assemble, sift icing sugar over a large piece of parchment, then carefully flip the meringue onto it. Remove the tin and parchment. With a short end facing you, score a line 2cm into the meringue.

Whip the cream, icing sugar and vanilla until thick but not stiff, then spread over the meringue. Spoon over about half of the cherry sauce and scatter with the grated chocolate. Roll up the roulade, starting with the scored short end and using the paper underneath to help.
Freeze by setting on a parchment-lined tray then, once firm, wrap the parchment around it and cover with cling film.
To serve, drizzle with the melted white chocolate. Top with a few of the whole cherries and serve the remaining sauce on the side.
chief_review: This recipe showcases an indulgent marriage of rich white chocolate and vibrant black cherries, masterfully balanced with airy meringue and lush whipped cream. The tartness of cherries harmonizes beautifully with the sweetness of the chocolate and the subtle warmth of ground cloves, while the orange juice adds a refreshing citrus twist. It’s an elegant dessert, perfect for special occasions, where both flavor and presentation shine—especially with those reserved whole cherries for a final flourish. Suitable for gluten-free diets, as it contains no wheat or gluten-based ingredients, but do ensure your cornflour is certified gluten-free. The texture contrast between the crispy meringue and velvety cream is irresistible. For best results, use high-quality white chocolate and fresh vanilla bean paste if available. Dusting with icing sugar just before serving adds a delightful finish. A truly memorable sweet treat for those who crave luxurious, fruit-forward desserts.

name: Red cabbage with mulled Port & pears
description: This braised cabbage side is a super healthy and versatile dish with a rich, deep-red colour enhanced by the addition of the Port
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 large red cabbage, quartered, cored and thinly sliced
directions: Put all the ingredients except the pears in a large pan and cover with a tight- fitting lid. Cook on a low heat for 1 hr, then stir through the pears. Cover and cook for 1 hr more until the cabbage is really tender. If at any point the cabbage looks dry, add a splash of water. If there is still liquid in the pan at the end, turn the heat right up to evaporate it. Season with a little salt and serve. The cabbage can be prepared ahead and either chilled or frozen. Then reheat in the pan or in a microwave.
chief_review:
This braised cabbage side dish is a standout for its balance of flavors and striking hue. The slow-cooked red cabbage melds beautifully with aromatic spices—cinnamon, cloves, and star anise—while the addition of port provides a rich depth and subtle sweetness. Pear offers freshness and texture, complementing the savory base with light fruitiness. Brown sugar and red wine vinegar round out the dish with sweet-and-sour notes.

Vegetarians and vegans will appreciate the absence of animal products, and the use of naturally gluten-free ingredients means it works well for those avoiding gluten. It’s also nut-free and dairy-free, catering to common allergies. The versatility of flavors makes this recipe an excellent companion for a variety of mains, particularly festive or hearty roasts. Highly recommended for anyone seeking a vibrant, flavorful side that caters to multiple dietary needs.

name: Chocolate Tia Maria nuggets
description: Gorgeously tempting chocolate treats with an added kick of Tia Maria
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: icing sugar and cocoa powder, to coat
directions: Bring the cream to the boil in a small pan. Remove from the heat and stir in the chocolate until it has melted. Stir in the liqueur and pour into a bowl. Cool, then chill until firm, about 4 hrs, or overnight.

Sprinkle a sheet of greaseproof paper with icing sugar and another with cocoa powder. Take a teaspoon and scoop nuggets of truffle mix out of the bowl and onto either the paper with cocoa powder or icing sugar. Use two teaspoons to coat the nuggets then transfer them to paper sweet cases. Pack into paper sweet cases in boxes and chill. Store for up to 2 weeks.
chief_review:
This decadent recipe delivers rich, velvety chocolate truffles with a sultry depth from Tia Maria, making for an irresistible after-dinner treat. The double cream and dark chocolate blend beautifully, resulting in a luscious, smooth center that melts in the mouth. Rolling the truffles in icing sugar and cocoa powder provides a pleasant contrast—sweet and bitter notes that balance the overall flavor profile.

Suitable for a vegetarian diet, these truffles cleverly showcase how a few quality ingredients can deliver maximum indulgence. The use of Tia Maria introduces a sophisticated twist, ideal for adult palates seeking something beyond the norm. For best results, use a high-quality dark chocolate to ensure a robust cocoa presence. These truffles are perfect for gifting or as an elegant conclusion to a special meal.

name: Twisty cheese straws
description: Puff pastry is ideal for canapés. Try twisted with cream cheese and pesto then baked until crispy
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Tip the cream cheese and pesto into a bowl and mix well.

Unroll the pastry on a lightly floured surface and cut in half lengthways. Spread the pesto mix over one half, pop the other piece of pastry on top to create a sandwich, then cut in half lengthways to create 2 long rectangles. Divide each rectangle into short strips, about 1cm thick. Twist each pastry strip and place on a baking tray lined with parchment.
Brush with egg and bake for 20-25 mins until risen and golden brown.
chief_review: This recipe offers delightful and elegant canapés with minimal fuss—perfect for entertaining. The combination of creamy cheese and vibrant pesto wrapped in flaky puff pastry provides a beautiful balance of texture and flavor. The steps are straightforward, and results are visually appealing as well as delicious: crisp twists with a tender, savory filling. Notably, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, provided the pesto is made without animal rennet. The use of ready-rolled puff pastry and basic ingredients makes it easy to prepare, though mindful bakers should verify ingredient labels for any hidden allergens, especially in the puff pastry and pesto. These canapés are versatile—ideal as starters or snacks—and are sure to impress guests with their enticing aroma and satisfying bite. Serve warm for the best experience.

name: Cranberry sea breeze punch
author: Jennifer Joyce
directions: Using two ice cube trays, put one or two cranberries in each square, fill with water and freeze until solid. Can be done a week ahead.

Pour the cranberry juice, vodka and grapefruit juice into a punch bowl or large pouring jug and add the lime slices. Add some ice and half the cranberry ice cubes. Divide the remaining cranberry ice cubes between the glasses, then pour in the punch.
chief_review: This vibrant cranberry punch is a refreshing cocktail with a tart, fruity profile enhanced by the brightness of lime and grapefruit. The sharpness of cranberry is balanced beautifully with the smoothness of vodka, making this an ideal party drink. The use of fresh juice and real cranberries adds both depth of flavor and a festive touch. This recipe is suitable for a vegan diet, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, as it is free from wheat, rye, barley, or oats, it can be enjoyed by those following a gluten-free lifestyle, provided the vodka is confirmed gluten-free. This punch’s sharp citrus notes and bold berry flavor make it a versatile and crowd-pleasing choice for gatherings where dietary preferences are considered. Serve well-chilled over plenty of ice for the best experience.

name: Roast turkey & cranberry Wellington
description: A festive twist on the classic British dish of beef Wellington, rich with chestnuts and stuffing
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 2-3 tbsp cooking oil, plus extra for greasing
25g butter, plus extra for the shallots
300ml water or chicken stock made with 1/8 stock cube
directions: Trim the turkey breast. Its natural shape does not suit the rolled and wrapped Wellington. The thicker neck end can first be trimmed to establish a more cylindrical shape. Trimmings from 2kg/4lb 8oz breasts and upwards, will be enough for the 350g/12oz needed for stuffing. Once trimmed, tie the breast with a 2cm/1in gap between each loop of string, to give a rounded shape.

Heat 2-3 tablespoons of cooking oil in a large frying pan or roasting tray. Season the turkey before pan frying until golden brown all over. Remove from the pan and cool. The breast can now be refrigerated to firm up before removing the string.

Make the stuffing: cook the onions in a knob of butter for a few minutes until softened. Remove from the heat and leave to cool. Roughly chop the turkey trimmings before blitzing in a food processor until smooth. Add sausages and continue to blitz for 30-40 seconds until mixed in. Season and add the eggs. These can be blitzed into the meat for a further minute until the texture thickens.

Spoon the stuffing into a large bowl. Mix in the onions and remaining stuffing ingredients along with extra seasoning, if desired. The stuffing can now be chilled while the bacon and pastry are prepared.

The streaky bacon needs to be rolled thinner. This extends the length of the rashers helping them to wrap around the turkey and stuffing. The easiest directions to follow is to lay 3-5 rashers between two sheets of cling film and press with a rolling pin as if rolling pastry. The rashers will easily thin and extend this way. Peel away the top layer of film and remove the rashers and put on a tray. Repeat until all rashers are pressed. Chill until needed.

Roll the puff pastry on a lightly floured surface to a rectangle approximately 45 x 35cm/18 x 14in. The rashers of bacon can be laid on top of the pastry, leaving a 3-4cm/1½in border all round. Slightly overlap the rashers as they are laid on the pastry (you'll need about 14-15 rashers).

Spread the cranberry stuffing over the bacon, first mixing it well if it is chilled and set. Keep back a few heaped tablespoons. Remove the string from the turkey and lay the breast lengthwise and presentation side down on top of the stuffing. The reserved stuffing can now be spread along the centre top of the turkey. Lift 4-5 rashers at a time and press them against the breast. Continue until all the rashers on both sides have been lifted and pressed. The remaining rashers can now be laid lengthwise along the top, covering the stuffing that was spread there.

Bring one long side of the pastry up and over the turkey. Brush the other long side with beaten egg, along the 3-4cm/1½in border, then seal. Brush both ends with beaten egg and fold up to seal in all the ingredients. Turn the Wellington so that the presentation side is up and put on a lightly oiled baking tray, or one covered with greased parchment. Chill.

To cook the Wellington: preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6/170C in a fan assisted convection oven and bake for 1 hour 15 minutes to 1 hour 25 minutes maximum. After 45 minutes, brush the Wellington with egg to help colour the pastry. For the most golden of finishes, brush again before the last 15-20 minutes. Once cooked, remove from the oven and rest for 15-20 minutes before lifting carefully on to a carving board with two large fish slices.

While the Wellington is baking the sauce can be made: melt a knob of butter in a pan, once bubbling add the shallots or onions and cook on a medium high heat until a rich deep golden colour. Add the honey and continue to cook for a few minutes until bubbling and almost caramelising. At this point add the red wine vinegar and red wine. Bring to the boil and reduce by half. Add the water or stock and return to simmer. Mix the flour with 25g/1oz butter. Whisk into the sauce a little at a time until completely whisked in. Return the sauce to the boil before reducing to a simmer and cooking for a few minutes. Strain through a sieve and season. Slice the Wellington and serve with Noisette potatoes and buttered Brussels sprouts.
chief_review: This festive take on the classic beef Wellington impresses with its succulent turkey breast, stuffing, and a beautifully crisp puff pastry. The inclusion of chestnut purée and cranberries adds both texture and a subtle sweetness, harmonizing well with the savory sausage and turkey. Bacon wraps the whole ensemble, imparting an extra depth of flavor and ensuring a juicy result. The red wine and honey sauce balances richness with tangy sweetness for an elegant finish. This recipe is ideal for those following a traditional Christmas or celebratory menu and would work beautifully for large gatherings. Notably, it is suitable for anyone managing nut allergies, as chestnut is generally safe for those with tree nut allergies, though caution is always advisable and individual responses may vary. Note the use of wheat and egg for those with dietary sensitives. Overall, an impressive, crowd-pleasing centerpiece rich in flavor and festivity.

name: Passion fruit pots with coconut stars
description: Perfect party puddings - you can pop them all on a tray and pass them round
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 350g caster sugar, plus a tbsp extra for decorating the stars
8 ripe passion fruit(look for wrinkly ones)
140g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Combine 125g sugar with all the cream in a heavy-based saucepan. Heat gently, stirring occasionally, until all the sugar has dissolved, then bring to the boil. Boil fiercely for 3 mins, stirring to prevent the mixture bubbling over the pan or sticking, then immediately remove from the heat.

Whizz the pulp from 7 of the passion fruits in a food processor to separate the seeds from the juice. Sieve and stir this juice into the cream along with the lime juice – the mixture should visibly thicken. Leave to cool for 10 mins, then pour into 10 small pots or cups. Arrange the cups on a tray (make sure it fits in your fridge) and, when cool, cover the whole tray with cling film – be careful not to let it touch the surface of the cream. Chill for 3 hrs to set, or up to a day ahead.

Meanwhile, make the shortbread. Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. In a large bowl, use a wooden spoon to mix the butter, flour, ground rice, 50g of the coconut, the egg yolks, vanilla and remaining 225g sugar until the dough comes together. Roll out on a lightly floured surface and, using starshaped cutters, stamp out biscuits. Spread over baking parchment-lined baking trays, sprinkle with the remaining coconut and sugar, then bake for 8-10 mins. Leave to cool.
To serve, scoop the pulp from the last passion fruit and drizzle a little over each pot. Arrange the coconut stars on the side.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers wonderfully festive, individual puddings—ideal for parties and easy to serve en masse. The combination of passion fruit and lime offers bright acidity to balance the richness of double cream, with subtle coconut and vanilla notes enhancing the crumbly, buttery base. The use of ground rice alongside flour provides a satisfying texture, elevating this dessert above standard fare.

The inclusion of eggs, dairy, wheat flour, and coconut means this dessert is appropriate for most traditional eaters but is not suitable for vegan or gluten-free diets. Those with egg, dairy, or nut allergies (due to coconut) should also steer clear. Nevertheless, for guests who appreciate a decadent, tropical-influenced sweet course, this recipe is a true showstopper, perfect for passing around at any celebration.

name: Marshmallows dipped in chocolate
description: Kids will love making these sweet chewy lollipops decorated with melted chocolate and cake sprinkles
author: Caroline Hire
directions: Heat the chocolate in separate bowls over simmering water or on a low setting in the microwave. Allow to cool a little.

Put your chosen sprinkles on separate plates. Push a cake pop or lolly stick into a marshmallow about half way in. Dip into the white or milk chocolate, allow the excess to drip off then dip into the sprinkles of your choice. Put into a tall glass to set. Repeat with each marshmallow.
chief_review: This playful recipe offers an engaging and delightful treat for children, turning simple marshmallows into festive lollipops with a sweet chocolate coating and bright sprinkles. The combination of white and milk chocolate delivers a creamy, indulgent finish, while the sprinkles add a pleasing crunch and burst of color. Thanks to the absence of gelatin in many commercial marshmallow brands, this recipe may suit some vegetarian diets—though always check the specific marshmallow ingredients. With its fun assembly process and visually appealing results, it’s perfect for parties or playful kitchen projects. Note that it contains milk and may have common allergens, so consider ingredient labels for those with allergies. Easy and quick to assemble, these chewy delights are sure to be a favorite among young helpers and sweet tooths alike.

name: Seared scallops with sweet chilli sauce
description: Impress your friends with these stylish, healthy canapés
author: John Torode
ingredients: 4 tbsp vegetable oil, plus extra for cooking
sweet chilli sauce, to serve (recipe below)
directions: Place the ginger, coriander and garlic in a pestle and mortar, then pound to a paste. Add the oil and mix through. Pour over the scallops and rub in until they are covered with the mixture. Thread each scallop onto a skewer (see Know-how, below). Can be done up to 1 day in advance.

To cook, heat a non-stick frying pan until really hot. Place a couple of skewers in the pan and cook for 2 mins, until starting to turn golden. Turn over, drizzle with more oil if needed, then cook for another min. Serve with sweet chilli sauce.
chief_review: This canapé recipe brilliantly showcases the delicate sweetness of scallops elevated by aromatic ginger, coriander, and garlic. The quick sear in vegetable oil ensures a tender texture while retaining moisture, and the accompanying sweet chili sauce brings just the right hint of heat and tang. The preparation is straightforward, making it ideal for entertaining, but the flavors are complex and well-balanced, worthy of a fine dining appetizer. Notably, these canapés are gluten-free and dairy-free, as long as the sweet chili sauce is prepared or chosen accordingly. They're also a great option for those seeking low-carb, high-protein starters. A sophisticated yet approachable recipe that’s sure to be a conversation starter at any gathering.

name: Walnut & stilton orzotto with roasted squash & Port sauce
description:
It doesn't explain the strain through a sieve properly I don't think?
Are we straining and discarding the walnuts? If but what's the point of the strain, if so the stock doesn't taste of walnut enough? Anyone who's done this if they can shed some light for me please it'd be much appreciated.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 25g unsalted butter, plus a knob extra
85g stiltonor vegetarian alternative, cubed, plus extra to serve
1 small butternut squash, peeled, deseeded and cut into 1cm dice
directions: Soak the 100g walnuts in water overnight. Strain through a sieve, put in a pan and cover with 300ml water. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 15 mins. Strain again, return to the pan with the stock and bring to the boil. Pour into a blender, blend on medium for 5 mins, then strain back into the pan. Set aside until step 4.

Make the sauce: soften the shallot in the oil over a gentle heat for 10 mins. Stir in the spices and stock, increase the heat and reduce by three-quarters. Pour in the Port and gently simmer for 20 mins. Strain into a clean pan and reduce over a high heat until thickened, about 10 mins. Set aside. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

For the squash, heat the butter in an ovenproof pan. Fry the squash for 3-4 mins, then stir in the walnuts with the cinnamon, sugar and a pinch of salt. Roast for 15-20 mins or until tender. Keep warm.

Meanwhile, make the orzotto. Warm the walnut stock. Heat the oil and 25g butter in a large, deep pan, add the shallots and soften for 10 mins, but don’t colour. Stir in the garlic and cook 3-4 mins more. Remove from the pan, set aside, then wipe the pan clean. Increase the heat, tip in the barley and toast for 2-3 mins, keeping it moving so it doesn’t burn. Quickly stir the shallots and garlic back into the pan with the barley, then pour in the Champagne. Stir well and add a ladleful of warm walnut stock. Lower the heat a little and keep adding stock when the orzotto looks ‘thirsty’, stirring occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the pan. (You’ll need about 500ml stock in total. Make up the amount with vegetable stock if necessary.) Cook until the barley is tender – 35-40 mins (you have a lot more grace with this than with rice, as it retains its bite for longer).
When cooked, add another half ladle of stock (to stop the orzotto from thickening as it cools), then stir in the stilton and a knob of butter. Stir and season, remembering stilton can be very salty.

To serve, reheat the sauce, adding a little more Port if it is too thick, then stir in the redcurrant jelly until dissolved and finish with the butter. Spoon some sauce over each plate and top with a few spoonfuls of orzotto. Garnish with the roasted squash and walnut halves, a few small pieces of stilton and leaves.
chief_review: This recipe offers a beautifully complex flavor profile, balancing the earthiness of walnuts with aromatic spices and the creaminess of stilton. It's well-suited for a vegetarian diet (when ensured that the cheese is a true vegetarian alternative and rennet-free) and leans toward gourmet dining with the inclusion of champagne and tawny port. The use of walnuts both in the stock and as a garnish adds depth, but straining out the walnuts after steeping will mellow their influence, resulting in a subtler broth. For those who desire a more pronounced walnut flavor, consider blending and incorporating some soaked walnuts into the final dish. The orchestration of butternut squash and spiced wine sauce over hearty pearl barley creates wonderful texture and richness. This dish is perfect for an elevated vegetarian main course at a dinner party.

name: Roasted sprout gratin with bacon-cheese sauce
description: We all love this as a main course comfort food family dinner. Thankfully my kids love Sprouts so there are never any complaints
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Halve any large sprouts and toss them with the oil and some seasoning in a roasting tin or ovenproof dish. Roast for 20 mins until the sprouts are tender and turning golden.

Meanwhile, put the bacon lardons in a cold frying pan and place over a medium-low heat. Gently fry the lardons so the fat melts out into the pan as they crisp. When golden brown and crisp, remove from the pan with a slotted spoon. Add the breadcrumbs and crisp up in the bacon fat until golden and crunchy. Remove from the pan to cool, then clean the pan.

Melt the butter in the pan with 2 tbsp of the milk, then stir in the flour and mustard powder for 2 mins to make a paste. Gradually whisk in remaining milk, until you have a smooth sauce. Use a spoon again to stir and cook until the sauce comes to the boil and thickens. Turn off the heat and stir in the cheese until melted. Taste and season.

Tip the sprouts into a baking dish, scatter with the crisp bacon lardons, then spoon over the sauce and scatter with the crispy crumbs. Can be cooled, covered and chilled for up to 48 hrs before baking. Bake gratin for 10 mins (or 20 mins from chilled) at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 until piping hot and bubbling.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts gratin is a hearty, comforting main perfect for family dinners, with smoky bacon lardons and rich, creamy Gruyère and Parmesan enhancing the natural sweetness of the sprouts. The fresh breadcrumb topping, crisped with butter, offers an appealing contrast to the tender vegetables beneath. Enthusiasts of classic comfort dishes will appreciate the careful balance of flavors from the mustard and cheeses, while children and adults alike will enjoy the inviting texture. With no wheat substitutes, it does contain gluten, and the addition of bacon and traditional cheeses means it isn’t suitable for vegetarians or those avoiding dairy. Still, for those who can indulge, this recipe showcases Brussels sprouts at their addictive best—rich, savory, and deeply satisfying, especially when served bubbling hot from the oven.

name: Red cabbage with coriander seed
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1 red cabbage, around 900g, quartered, cored and shredded
2 Granny Smith apples, peeled, cored and chopped
directions: Heat the oil in a large saucepan or casserole dish over a medium heat. Add the cabbage, onion, garlic, coriander seeds and bay leaves, and cook, stirring occasionally, for 15 mins until the cabbage begins to wilt.

Stir in the apple, vinegar and maple syrup and season well. Cover the pan and cook gently for 1 hr until the cabbage is tender and wonderfully sticky and caramelised. Remove the bay leaves before eating. Can be made in advance and frozen or kept chilled for up to two days. Use up any leftovers in our
chief_review: This vibrant dish celebrates the robust, earthy flavors of red cabbage paired with the bright tang of Granny Smith apples, delicately lifted by the aromatic warmth of coriander seeds and bay leaves. The use of vegan white wine vinegar and maple syrup brings a sophisticated balance of acidity and sweetness, making for a nuanced side that’s both refreshing and satisfying. Sautéed simply with olive oil, onion, and garlic, the recipe is a triumph of plant-based cooking, showcasing how seasonal vegetables can be transformed with thoughtful seasoning. It is ideally suited for vegan and vegetarian diets, with the added benefit of being naturally gluten-free and dairy-free. Perfect alongside a hearty grain or as a festive accompaniment, this dish will please those who appreciate wholesome, allergen-friendly cooking without sacrificing depth of flavor.

name: Turkey bubble & squeak
author: Joe Wicks
directions: Peel the potato and parsnip, grab a bowl and grate them both into it. Grate or finely slice the sprouts and chuck them into the bowl too. Put the veg in a sieve and squeeze out as much liquid as you can. Return the mixture to the bowl and crack in the egg. Mix and season, then add your rosemary and garlic.

Now it’s time to get your hands messy. Shape the mixture into three rösti patties, equal in thickness. Slice the leftover turkey breast. Put it in a pan with the gravy on a low heat and simmer until the turkey is warm. Heat the coconut oil in a separate frying pan. Cook the röstis for 3 mins each side until golden brown, then put them on a plate, layer with the sliced turkey and add a dollop of cranberry sauce on top. Voilà – a lovely, lean Christmas leftover meal!
chief_review:
This recipe brings together a hearty mix of root vegetables and Brussels sprouts, creating a satisfying and rustic dish. The inclusion of cooked turkey and a poached or fried egg delivers a protein boost, while fresh rosemary and garlic infuse it with aromatic depth. The coconut oil adds a subtle richness, nicely balancing the savory notes from the leftover gravy. Cranberry sauce on the side provides a tangy sweetness that contrasts well with the earthy vegetables and savory turkey. 

This dish is particularly suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain gluten-containing grains (assuming your gravy is gluten-free). It also caters to individuals looking for a high-protein meal with plenty of vegetables. Overall, it’s a perfect recipe for reinventing holiday leftovers into a comforting, well-balanced plate.

name: Meringue kisses & icicles
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: decoration, depending on the final cake you have chosen
edible glitter (available from cakecraftcompany.com) or lustre powder (optional)
directions: Heat oven to 120C/100C fan/gas ½. Line two-three baking sheets with parchment. Beat the egg whites until they are foamy and doubled in size. Add the sugar, 1 tbsp at a time, while you continue to
. The meringue will become thick and glossy and should hold up in stiff peaks on the beaters when it is ready.

For the meringue kisses, fit a disposable piping bag with a 1cm round or star nozzle. Hold it vertically to the baking sheet and gently squeeze, pulling the bag up and away to make a peak. If you are making frosty icicles, make some meringue dots as well.

For colour-striped meringues, fit a disposable piping bag with a round nozzle, paint red food colouring paste in stripes onto the inside of the bag, then fill with meringue and pipe as before. Bake for 1 hr. Once cool, you can drizzle some of the meringues with melted chocolate and sprinkle with edible glitter or lustre powder, if you like.

For the icicles and snowflakes, scoop the meringue into a disposable piping bag and snip off a tiny opening. Pipe spiky icicle shapes onto the trays, making them thicker one end and thin at the other. Pipe crossed lines to make snowflakes.

Bake for 50 mins, then leave to cool on the tray for a few mins, then carefully loosen them off the parchment. Sprinkle with edible glitter or lustre powder, if you like. If left to cool completely, they may stick and break when you try to lift them off. If you are storing these, leave to cool completely, then layer in an airtight container between pieces of baking parchment.
Now use the meringue kisses to make our
chief_review: This recipe creates a classic meringue-based treat, likely intended for decorative or showstopper cakes. The combination of egg whites and caster sugar promises a crisp, airy texture, while the optional addition of red food colouring and edible glitter offers visual flair. Drizzling with melted dark chocolate will add a sophisticated, bittersweet element that balances the sweetness of the meringue. The absence of dairy, flour, or nuts makes this recipe naturally suitable for those on a gluten-free diet and for vegetarians. Its simplicity allows for creative customization with different decorations or flavour infusions. Overall, this is a versatile base recipe that yields both elegance and adaptability for bakers seeking to impress.

name: Chocolate nut butter cups
description: Filled with hazelnut, pistachio or peanut butter, these lovely little bites are a perfect after-dinner treat to share with coffee
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 140g nut butter(I used smooth peanut butter, hazelnut butter and pistachio nut butter – but you can use just peanut butter if you prefer)
25g nuts(I used peanuts, hazelnuts and pistachios)
gold leafand a paintbrush, to decorate (optional - see tip)
directions: Tip half the chocolate into a bowl set over a pan of simmering water. Once melted, remove from the heat and stir in the rest of the chocolate. Put the petit four cases into the holes of the mini muffin tins. Put 1 tsp of the melted chocolate in each one, then pick up a petit four case in your hand and swirl it gently to get the chocolate to coat the sides. Repeat with all the cases, leaving about a third of the chocolate in the bowl. Pop the tins in the fridge to firm up while you make the fillings.

Put the butter in a large bowl with the icing sugar. Beat well with electric beaters or a wooden spoon until light and creamy. Divide the mixture into three bowls, then stir the peanut butter into one, hazelnut butter into the second and pistachio butter into the third (if using). Transfer the fillings to three piping bags.

Take the chocolate cups out of the fridge and fill with the nut mixtures. If your reserved chocolate has hardened, melt again as before. Once melted, carefully spoon it over the top of each cup to seal in the nut butters.
Top each cup with with a whole nut (or a nut coated in gold leaf, a pinch of coarse sea salt – or any combination). Chill for at least 2 hrs. Will keep in the fridge for 1 week (see tip).
chief_review: A delightful blend of rich chocolate and creamy nut butters, these bite-sized confections offer a luxurious finish to any meal. The recipe’s flexibility—allowing you to choose from peanut, hazelnut, or pistachio butters—invites creativity and caters to a range of nut lovers. Textural contrast comes from the chopped nuts, while a sprinkle of flaky sea salt elevates the flavor, balancing sweetness and earthy richness. For those observing a vegetarian diet, this treat is an ideal choice; its ingredients are free from animal gelatin and rely solely on plant-based nut butters and dairy. The use of gold leaf for garnish adds an elegant touch, perfect for impressing guests over coffee. However, take note: this recipe contains a variety of common allergens, particularly nuts and dairy. Overall, these chocolate nut butter bites make for a decadent, satisfying finish to any gathering.

name: Sizzled sprouts with pistachios & pomegranate
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Heat the oil in a large frying pan over a medium-high heat. Put the sprouts in the pan, cut-side down, and leave them to fry for 10-15 mins, tossing occasionally. If they’re just lightly brown, carry on cooking for a further 5 mins until blistered.

Scatter over the pistachios and stir-fry until toasted. Remove from the heat and stir through the pomegranate seeds. Season with salt and tip into a serving dish. Drizzle with a little pomegranate molasses, if you like.
chief_review:
This vibrant dish brings together roasted Brussels sprouts with the crunch of pistachios and the burst of fresh pomegranate seeds, finished with a drizzle of tangy pomegranate molasses. The combination is both visually striking and flavorfully complex, balancing earthy, nutty, and sweet-tart elements. The use of olive oil keeps it light, while the optional molasses adds a sophisticated touch of acidity without overpowering the main ingredients. 

This recipe is an excellent choice for both vegan and vegetarian diets, as it relies solely on plant-based ingredients. It is also naturally gluten-free and dairy-free, and should be safe for most common food allergies, provided there is no nut sensitivity (pistachios). Served as a side or a hearty salad, it's a nutritious and dazzling addition to any table.

name: Marmalade carrots
description: Sticky, buttery and sweet - this versatile side dish is simple yet glorious
author: Good Food
directions: Put everything except the parsley in a pan and pour over 250ml water. Simmer over a low heat for 20 mins until the liquid has evaporated and the carrots are tender and coated in a sticky glaze. If they are still a little raw, add a splash of water and cook for a few mins more. Transfer to a serving platter and serve sprinkled with parsley.
chief_review: This sticky, buttery carrot side dish is a celebration of simplicity and sweet richness. The fine-cut marmalade enhances the natural sweetness of the carrots, while the butter creates a glossy finish and a touch of indulgence. Sprinkling chopped curly-leaf parsley on top provides a fresh, herbal brightness that completes the dish beautifully. Perfect for vegetarians, this recipe avoids any hidden meat or fish ingredients, making it suitable for those following a meat-free diet. It’s an excellent addition to festive feasts or weeknight dinners, transforming humble carrots into a show-stopping accompaniment.

name: Giant smoked salmon & beetroot blini
description: These super-sized buckwheat pancakes make a great dinner party or festive starter for sharing
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: zest 1 lemon, juice of ½, plus wedges to serve
140g cooked beetroot(not in vinegar), drained and finely diced
1 tsp rapeseed oil, plus a drizzle
1 tbsp small capers, drained and rinsed
25g butter, melted, plus extra for cooking
directions: First, make up the blini batter. Put the flours, baking powder, ½ tsp salt, the milk, egg yolks and melted butter in a bowl and whisk until smooth. In another bowl, whisk the egg whites until they hold stiff peaks. Stir a good spoonful of the whisked whites into the batter to loosen the mixture, then add the remaining egg whites and carefully fold everything together with a big metal spoon.

Heat a small knob of butter and a drizzle of oil in a large frying pan, roughly 23cm wide across the base. Pour a third of the blini mixture in the pan, using your spoon to encourage the batter towards the edge of the pan. Leave to cook for a few mins, until the blini starts to set around the edges and the underside is golden brown. Slide onto a plate, then carefully flip back into the pan and cook for a further 1-2 mins until golden. Repeat with the remaining mixture. Leave the blinis to cool on a wire rack, then place on a plate, separated by a layer of baking parchment and covered with cling film. The blinis will keep like this for 24 hrs.

Mix the crème fraîche, horseradish, most of the lemon zest, a good squeeze of lemon juice and some seasoning in a bowl. In a second bowl, toss the beetroot, oil and a squeeze of lemon juice. Set aside until ready to serve.

Place each blini on a board or large plate. Spoon on dollops of crème fraîche, arrange slices of salmon over and scatter beetroot, capers and the remaining lemon zest on top. Finish with a few rocket leaves and a drizzle of oil. Cut and serve with lemon wedges.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers an elegant, crowd-pleasing starter, perfect for special occasions or dinner parties. The substantial buckwheat pancakes provide a nutty, hearty base for a vibrant topping of smoked salmon, beetroot, and rocket, complemented by the tangy brightness of crème fraîche mixed with horseradish and lemon. The addition of capers lends a welcome briny punch, while the combination of both buckwheat and self-raising flour ensures a light yet satisfying texture.

Buckwheat, while naturally gluten-free, is combined here with wheat-based flour, making the pancakes unsuitable for gluten-free needs. The use of smoked salmon and dairy means this dish is not vegetarian or vegan. Those with dairy or egg allergies should also avoid this dish. Overall, these pancakes are a deliciously creative and impressive starter, offering a lovely balance of flavors and textures for your guests.

name: Stuffing sprouts
description: Brilliant! Takes a bit of effort but it's really two parts of Christmas dinner in one and tastes so good (I hate boiled sprouts!)
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Melt the butter over a low heat in a large, non-stick frying pan. Add the onion and cook for 10 mins until soft. Increase the heat to medium and stir in the bacon, sage and sausagemeat. Cook for 6-8 mins, breaking up the sausage with a wooden spoon, until starting to brown.

Tip in the sprouts and chestnuts, cover with a lid and cook, stirring occasionally, for 10 mins until the sprouts are tender. Keep them warm over a low heat until you are ready to serve. Just before serving, take off the lid, season, stir in the breadcrumbs and fry on high for 2 mins to toast them and get some colour on the sprouts.
chief_review: This festive dish creatively combines classic Christmas elements into a single, flavorful side. The caramelized onion and smoked bacon provide a rich base, complemented by aromatic sage and juicy pork sausages for depth. Brussels sprouts gain robust character here—roasting and tossing them with chestnuts brings textural contrast and nutty sweetness that’s perfect for those who shy away from boiled varieties. The finishing touch of buttery breadcrumbs adds crunch and ties the dish together. With the inclusion of breadcrumbs and sausages, note it contains both gluten and meat. Overall, it’s a show-stopping accompaniment—heartwarming, indulgent, and certain to win over even reluctant sprout eaters at your holiday table.

name: Sweet potato & chestnut roast with tangy tomato sauce
description: The mixture was tasty enough but didn't bind together. Perhaps I should have added another egg?
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 tbsp rapeseed oil, plus a dash for greasing
1 large sweet potato, about 325g, coarsely grated
2 tbsp fresh thyme leaves, plus extra for sprinkling
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease and line the base and sides of a 1lb (500g) loaf tin with baking parchment. Heat the oil in a large non-stick sauté pan and fry the onions for 10 mins until golden, stirring every now and then. Add the grated potato and garlic and cook for 5 mins more until the potatoes have softened.

Tip into a bowl, (reserve the pan) and add two-thirds of the chestnuts crushing them up as you go, then stir in the thyme, tamari and egg. Press into the loaf tin, roughly break the remaining nuts and arrange them on top then bake for 45 mins.

For the sauce mix the flour with a little of the bouillon to make a very wet paste. Return the pan to the heat and add all the ingredients, including the flour mix and stir over a high heat until well mixed and thickened. Keep simmering for a good 10 mins then taste as it should now be tangy rather than vinegary. If it is too sharp return to the heat and boil a little longer.

Carefully take the loaf from the tin and remove the paper. Scatter with thyme. If you're doing the Healthy Diet Plan, serve half in 2 thick slices with half the tomato sauce and chill the rest for another day, otherwise serve the whole recipe as a meal for four people.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful blend of sweetness from the sweet potato, earthiness from chestnuts, and aromatic depth from onions and thyme. The use of tamari instead of soy sauce makes it suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided the wholemeal flour is replaced with a gluten-free alternative. With a strong base of vegetables and plant-based ingredients, it caters well to vegetarians, though the inclusion of egg makes it unsuitable for vegans. The reliance on whole foods and healthy fats (rapeseed oil) gives this dish a nutritious profile. However, as noted in the description, binding may be an issue; increasing the egg or adding a binding agent like gluten-free breadcrumbs could improve texture. Overall, this is a hearty and flavorsome option for those seeking a satisfying vegetarian meal with potential for gluten-free adaptation.

name: Blitz 'n' blend mincemeat
description: A traditional boozy mincemeat that's ready in 20 minutes - make a big batch, bottle up and give as gifts
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 Bramley apple, peeled, cored and chopped into large chunks
50g stem ginger, plus 2 tbsp syrup from the jar
¼ tsp each powdered ginger/mixed spice/nutmeg
grated zest and juice of 1 orange
directions: In your food processor, pulse the almonds, peel, apple, ginger, cherries and pineapple together until finely chopped (but not mushy), then tip into a large bowl. In batches, pulse the sultanas, raisins and currants until just chopped a little bit then add to the bowl.

Sprinkle the suet and sugar, salt and spices over all the chopped fruit and mix well. To mix, squelch through fingers. Pour over the ginger syrup, orange juice and zest and alcohol, then mix again. Spoon the mixture into sterilised jars and keep until needed.
chief_review:
This traditional boozy mincemeat is a vibrant blend of dried and fresh fruits, candied peel, and warming spices, elevated by a generous splash of brandy or dark rum. The richness from suet and muscovado sugar gives the mixture a luxurious, velvety character, while apple and ginger provide a fresh, zesty contrast. The recipe’s inclusion of almonds, glacé cherries, and pineapple brings texture and bright flavors—perfect for festive bakes or as a thoughtful homemade gift.

Vegetarians can enjoy this recipe if vegetable suet is used in place of traditional animal-based suet (ensure you check your suet type). However, it's not suitable for nut-free or alcohol-free diets due to its ingredients. Overall, this mincemeat offers depth and tradition in every spoonful, ready in just 20 minutes—delightful for those seeking a homemade twist on a classic holiday staple.

name: Zesty mincemeat
description: This coarse traditional mincemeat doesn't require any cooking- just throw in your nutmeg, brandy and suet and leave to soak
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: zest and juice 1 orange and 1 lemon
175g coarsley grated Bramley appleand 100g finely grated Bramley apple
up to 1 tbsp ground almond, optional
directions: Tip all the ingredients, except the suet and ground almonds, into a large bowl and stir really well. Stir in the suet, cover with a plate or cling film and leave overnight for the fruit to plump up in the juices and brandy.

Next day, stir thoroughly again, and if the mixture still looks very juicy, add a sprinkling of ground almonds to absorb some of the liquid. Now it is ready to jar. The mincemeat will keep for 6 months, but once open, store in the fridge.
chief_review: This no-cook mincemeat recipe offers a wonderfully rich and aromatic filling, perfect for festive bakes. The blend of mixed dried fruit, candied peel, warming nutmeg, and fresh citrus zest creates vibrant layers of flavor, while brandy adds a classic depth. The addition of both grated and coarsely grated Bramley apple enhances texture and freshness. Using either beef or vegetarian suet allows this recipe to suit both traditional and vegetarian diets—just ensure you select the vegetarian suet as needed. Inclusion of optional ground almond provides extra nuttiness for those who enjoy it. This recipe is ideal for those seeking a straightforward, flavorful mincemeat with the flexibility for vegetarian adaptation.

name: Port & cranberry sauce with juniper
description: Ten minutes and four ingredients are all you need to whip up a homemade accompaniment for roast dinners, cheese and meat
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Tip all the ingredients into a pan and bring to the boil, stirring every now and then. Simmer for 5 mins, until the berries soften but still look whole. Tip into a bowl and leave to cool – it really is as simple as that.
chief_review: This quick and elegant cranberry sauce recipe expertly balances the robust sweetness of port with the tangy brightness of cranberries, accentuated by the aromatic depth of juniper berries. Its rich, jammy consistency makes it an ideal match not only for roast dinners but also as a sophisticated complement to cheese boards or charcuterie. With just four ingredients and minimal preparation, it delivers maximum flavor for minimal effort. This sauce is naturally gluten free and suitable for vegetarians, ensuring versatility for diverse dinner tables. The use of fresh or frozen cranberries makes it convenient year-round, while the absence of common allergens like nuts and dairy adds to its broad appeal. Perfect for elevating festive meals or adding a gourmet touch to everyday dishes.

name: From-the-freezer mince pies
description: Keep these festive favourites nice and simple or spice things up with some imaginative twists
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 500g pack sweet or dessert shortcrust pastry
directions: Roll out a little over half the pastry on a flour-dusted surface to about the thickness of a £1 coin. Stamp out circles of pastry to line the holes of a 12-hole bun tin – an 8cm cutter should be about right. Re-roll the trimmings until all 12 holes are lined.

Spoon a little mincemeat into each, then roll out the remaining pastry with a little more flour. Use a 6cm fluted or plain round cutter to cut out 12 lids. Top the mincemeat with the pastry lids, push around the edges to seal, then poke 1-2 small holes into each to allow steam to escape. Wrap the whole tray well in cling film.

To cook, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Remove the mince pies from the freezer and brush the top of each with a little milk. Bake for 20-22 mins or until the pastry is golden and crisp and the filling piping hot.
chief_review: This classic mince pie recipe is festive simplicity at its best. With ready-made sweet shortcrust pastry and rich, fruity mincemeat, it captures traditional holiday flavors with minimal effort. The use of shop-bought pastry ensures a tender, crumbly texture, while a milk glaze guarantees a beautifully golden finish. For those seeking an egg-free treat, this recipe is naturally suitable, as it doesn’t use any eggs. However, check the pastry and mincemeat ingredients to ensure they meet specific dietary needs—some brands are vegan-friendly. For adventurous bakers, adding spices or citrus zest to the pastry can elevate these mince pies even further. With just a handful of ingredients, this recipe delivers impressive results—perfect for a festive gathering or a cozy evening treat.

name: Tasty make-ahead gravy
description: Make the base for this gravy up to two days ahead, then simply add your roasted meat juices and heat before serving
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 850ml homemade or bought chicken or turkey stock
juices from the turkey(see 'goes well with', right)
directions: Heat the oil in a non-stick pan, then fry the onion, carrot and bay, stirring frequently, until the onion is golden. Stir in the flour, then pour in the stock while stirring. Simmer for 15 mins. Discard the bay leaf, then purée the contents of the pan with a hand blender until completely smooth. Cool, then chill. Can be made 2 days ahead.

When you take the turkey from the oven (see 'goes well with', right), pour the juices from the tin into a deep but narrow jug or bowl. Leave to stand so that excess oil from the turkey rises to the top. Skim off as much fat as you can and discard, then pour the juices into a pan with the gravy base and stir over the heat until bubbling. Season to taste.
chief_review: This gravy recipe showcases a classic technique, beginning with sautéed aromatics for a rich foundation. The blend of sunflower oil, onion, carrot, and bay leaf develops notable depth, complemented by flour for body. Using good quality chicken or turkey stock is advised, as it forms the backbone of flavour, while roasted meat juices add a final dimension. Preparing the base ahead streamlines your timing during a busy meal. Note that this recipe is not suitable for gluten-free diets due to the use of plain flour. For best results, simmer slowly to allow the flavours to meld and finish with a straining step for a velvety texture. Ideal for roast dinners, this gravy aligns well with traditional festive dishes.

name: Crayfish cocktail with horseradish cream
description: Give the classic prawn cocktail a twist by pairing crayfish tails with tangy horseradish and creamy avocado in this delicious dinner party starter
author: James Martin
ingredients: 140g pack crayfishtails, see tip below left
directions: First, make the horseradish cream by mixing together the crème fraîche, horseradish sauce and half of the lime juice. Keep the sauce covered and chill until needed.

Take two glass serving dishes and put 1 chicory leaf in each. Finely shred the rest of the chicory and divide it between the dishes. Stone, peel and thinly slice the avocado, toss in the remaining lime juice and put on the shredded chicory. Lay the crayfish tails over the top.
Add the horseradish cream and a light sprinkling of cayenne pepper to serve.
chief_review: This innovative starter elevates the classic prawn cocktail by substituting crayfish tails, which pair beautifully with the zesty lime juice and subtle heat of horseradish. The addition of creamy avocado adds richness, while fresh chicory brings a delicate crunch and mild bitterness to balance the flavours. The crème fraîche lends a luxurious texture without being overly heavy, creating a harmonious base for the seafood. A dusting of cayenne pepper gives just the right kick to round out the dish. With its balanced combination of tangy, creamy, and spicy notes, this recipe is perfect for pescatarians and those seeking a nut-free option. Presented elegantly, it makes a sophisticated dinner party starter sure to impress guests with both flavour and presentation.

name: Clementine possets with cranberry compote & cinnamon palmiers
description: These citrus set puddings are deliciously creamy and zesty, topped with a boozy compote and puff pastry palmiers to dip
author: Cassie Best
directions: Put the cream, sugar and both zests in a saucepan and bring to a simmer. Measure all the juice – you should have 100ml. Turn up the heat and bubble for 3 mins exactly, then stir in the juice. Sieve the mixture into a jug, then divide between 4 glasses. Chill for at least 4 hrs or until set.
To make the compote, put all the ingredients in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer, then bubble for 10 mins until thickened and syrupy. Cool, then chill until ready to serve.

Now make the palmiers. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line 2 baking trays with baking parchment. Unroll the pastry. Mash the butter, cinnamon and sugar until combined, then spread over the surface of the pastry. Roll the pastry up from each of the longer sides until the rolled-up edges meet in the centre. Slice the pastry into 1cm pieces, then place, cut-side up, on the baking trays, flattening a little with the palm of your hand. Bake for 20 mins until golden and puffed up, then cool on a wire rack. Serve each posset with a spoonful of compote and a palmier or two.
chief_review: This citrus set pudding is a delightful showcase of bright, zesty flavors balanced by a satisfyingly creamy texture. The clementine and lemon bring an uplifting freshness, which pairs beautifully with the tart cranberry and brandy compote for a boozy kick. The golden caster sugar keeps the sweetness well-rounded rather than overpowering, making each spoonful a pleasure. Paired with cinnamon-scented puff pastry palmiers, this impressive dessert provides both rich and crisp textures—a real treat for the senses. The inclusion of double cream and butter is integral for the luxurious mouthfeel, while the ready-rolled puff pastry ensures a fuss-free yet elegant finish. This recipe is vegetarian friendly, making it a great choice for those seeking an indulgent but meat-free dessert suitable for festive occasions or dinner parties.

name: Vegan 'cheesy’ leek crumble
description: Found the sauce way to thick, despite watering down with 4 oz of water - 5 Tbsp of nutritional yeast is a lot, yes it makes it cheesy but it makes the sauce claggy. I would half the carrot and potato ratio to be blended which would still provide the sauce with enough substance. Not a fan of the topping, I put it in the fridge to firm up as suggested but found it was rock hard and unappetising even when grilled to give it color.
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 1 tsp good-quality vegan white wine vinegar
directions: The night before, soak the cashew nuts in water and leave overnight.

To make the crumble, tip the oats and flour into a bowl, make a well in the centre and pour in the coconut oil. Draw the dry ingredients in until everything is well coated and resembles chunky breadcrumbs. Tip the mixture onto a baking sheet and put in the fridge to firm up – this will make your topping extra crunchy.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Steam the carrots and potatoes together for 5 mins until softened, then transfer to a
. Drain the cashews and add them too, along with 2 tbsp oil and the rest of the sauce ingredients except for the leeks. Blitz the mixture, season and set aside.

Heat the remaining oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat. Add the leeks and a large pinch of salt, then fry for 15 mins until softened. Spoon in the cheese sauce – if it is very thick, add a splash of water to thin it. Transfer the mix to an ovenproof dish, top with the crumble and bake for 30 mins until piping hot. For a crispy topping, put under the grill to finish. Can be assembled in advance and kept in the fridge to cook when needed.
chief_review: This recipe offers a creative, plant-based twist, utilizing cashews and nutritional yeast for a "cheesy" flavor, making it ideal for vegan diets. The combination of potatoes, carrots, and olive oil contributes creaminess, though five tablespoons of nutritional yeast can overpower and thicken the sauce excessively, as mentioned. Reducing the potato and carrot quantities would help prevent a claggy texture, striking a better balance. The topping, composed of oats, flour, and coconut oil, is inventive but may become too dense after chilling—consider omitting refrigeration or reducing coconut oil for a lighter, crumblier finish. The use of leeks and thyme provides fresh, aromatic notes, nicely rounding out the dish. Free from dairy and eggs, and easily adaptable for gluten-free needs by substituting a different flour, this recipe suits both vegan and dairy-free diets when minor adjustments are made for improved texture and balance.

name: Savoy cabbage with almonds
description: A superhealthy side dish with lightly toasted almonds to give your cabbage some crunch
author: Good Food
directions: Steam or microwave the cabbage until just cooked. Melt the butter with the oil in a large frying pan or wok, then add the garlic, rosemary and almonds. Cook, stirring the almonds for about 2 mins or until they start to brown. Tip onto a plate. Add the cabbage to the pan, stir in the leftover buttery juices, then return the almond mixture to the pan. Season well and tip into a serving dish.
chief_review: This recipe elevates humble Savoy cabbage into a standout side dish, thanks to the addition of crunchy toasted almonds and aromatic rosemary. The use of both butter and olive oil brings a rich, rounded flavor and balances the earthiness of the cabbage. Garlic adds a subtle kick, while the almonds provide texture and a delightful nuttiness. This dish is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, and could easily complement both simple and more elaborate mains. With minimal ingredients, it delivers maximum flavor and freshness—perfect for those seeking a healthy, satisfying side.

name: Brussels sprouts with chestnuts & sage
description: As we had guests for Christmas who prefer a plant based diet, I substituted walnut stir fry oil for the goose fat - tasty!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g pack whole, cooked and peeled chestnuts
directions: Boil a pan of water, add the sprouts and blanch for 6 mins. Drain and cool quickly under the cold tap or in iced water. To get ahead, pack into a plastic food bag and chill overnight.
On the day, heat the goose fat in a large wok and add the sage and chestnuts. Cook for a few mins over the heat, add the sprouts, season and stir-fry until piping hot.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts recipe is a festive delight with a clever plant-based twist. By replacing goose fat with walnut stir fry oil, the dish gains a pleasant nuttiness that enhances the earthiness of the sprouts and sage. The addition of chestnuts offers a satisfying crunch and subtle sweetness, balancing the flavors beautifully. With simple, wholesome ingredients—Brussels sprouts, sage, walnut oil, and chestnuts—this preparation caters perfectly to both vegetarian and vegan diets. It’s also a good fit for those seeking a dairy-free side that doesn’t compromise on holiday indulgence. A thoughtful, flavorful update to a classic that will impress plant-based diners and omnivores alike.

name: Crunchy roast potatoes
description: Soggy roasties? Follow Sara's directions for crispy spuds every time
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 20 even-size potatoes, such as King Edwards, peeled and halved if large
directions: Boil the potatoes for 10 mins, then drain. Rough up their surfaces with a fork or by shaking them in the pan with the lid on.

Melt the goose fat in a large, thickbottomed roasting tin on top of the stove. Tip in the potatoes carefully and turn them until they are evenly coated in the fat. Place on the top shelf of the oven (move the turkey down a shelf if necessary) and roast for 1-1¼ hrs, turning every now and then, until crisp and golden. Sprinkle with salt to serve.
chief_review: Sara’s method for roast potatoes is a classic and reliable approach to achieving that coveted crisp exterior with a fluffy center. Using King Edward potatoes ensures an ideal texture, while goose fat lends a distinct, rich flavor and exceptional crunch. The generous use of goose fat produces a deeply golden, shatteringly crisp crust, taking these roasties well beyond the ordinary. A final seasoning of salt enhances their savory profile, making for an irresistible accompaniment to any roast dinner. This recipe is particularly suited to low-carb and gluten-free diets, since it contains no gluten or wheat-based ingredients. However, it is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the use of goose fat. With just a few quality ingredients and precise technique, Sara's roast potatoes promise consistent, crowd-pleasing perfection every time.

name: Sugar-dusted passion cake
description:
This is a cross between a carrot cake and a
hummingbird cake – a very popular fruity bake
Down Under
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 250ml sunflower oil, plus a little extra for greasing
4 eggs, lightly beaten with a fork
432g tin crushed pineapple, drained, reserving 50ml juice (from Sainsbury's, or see Know-how, below)
icing sugarand doilies, mascarpone and natural yogurt, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Grease and line a deep, 20cm square tin with baking paper. Sift the muscovado until it’s lump-free. Tip into the largest bowl you have with the flour, coconut, mixed spice, baking powder and walnuts, then mix well. In a jug, whisk together the oil, eggs and 2 tsp of the vanilla extract, then pour over the dry ingredients. Add the carrot, pineapple, reserved pineapple juice and lime zest to the bowl, then give everything a really good mix until combined. Scrape into the tin, then bake on a low to middle shelf for 1 hr, until a skewer inserted comes out with just moist crumbs clinging to it and no sticky mix. Once cool, the cake can be frozen for up to 3 months, then soak with the syrup once defrosted.
Meanwhile, make a lime syrup by gently heating the caster sugar, lime juice and final tsp of vanilla in a small pan. Once dissolved, boil for a few mins until syrupy.

Leave the cake in its tin until cool enough to handle, then turn upside-down onto a wire rack. Using a skewer, poke holes all over the cake and drizzle over the syrup a little at a time, waiting for the last addition to soak into the cake before pouring over any more. Cool completely, then trim the edges. Will keep for a few days in an airtight tin.

To serve, return the cake to a serving plate, right side up, and place a doily, or a few doilies, over the top. Dust liberally with icing sugar, then very carefully lift off the paper without disturbing the sugar. Serve immediately, as the icing sugar will begin to melt after a while, with a dollop of something creamy on the side – try mixing equal amounts of mascarpone and natural yogurt with a little more icing sugar.
chief_review: This delightful bake is an inspired fusion of carrot cake and the tropical charm of a hummingbird cake. The generous use of carrot and pineapple imparts a moist crumb, while lime zest and juice beautifully balance sweetness with a bright, zesty edge. Walnuts and desiccated coconut add pleasing crunch and flavor complexity. The inclusion of wholemeal flour and minimal processed ingredients make it feel rustic yet indulgent. Its structure should hold well, thanks to a sturdy combination of eggs and baking powder. Dolloping with mascarpone and natural yogurt brings a luscious finishing touch that isn’t overly sweet, letting the fruit sing. This recipe is particularly suited for vegetarians and is nutty, tangy, and satisfyingly rich—perfect for an afternoon treat or special occasion.

name: Roast crispy pork
description: This moreish crispy-skinned roast is best served with stir-fried pak choi
author: Ken Hom
ingredients: 1½ kg boneless shoulder or belly of pork, with rind
2 tbsp Sichuan peppercorns, roasted and freshly ground
directions: Pierce the rind side of the pork (a roasting fork is good for this) until the skin is covered with fine holes. Put the joint rind side up on a rack over the sink. Bring a pot of water to the boil and, using a large ladle, pour hot water over the rind side of the pork several times. Set the pork aside.

Heat a wok or large frying pan until it is very hot. Add the salt, peppercorns and five-spice and stir-fry for about 30 seconds until hot and well mixed. Remove from the heat, stir in the sugar, then allow to cool slightly. When it is warm enough to handle, rub this mixture on the flesh side of the pork. Leave, flesh side up, on the rack at room temperature for a minimum of 3 hours (overnight is ideal).

To roast Sichuan peppercorns: heat a wok or heavy frying pan to a medium heat. Add the peppercorns (you can cook about 140g/5oz at a time) and stir-fry them for about 5 minutes until they brown slightly and start to smoke. Remove from the heat and let them cool. Grind the peppercorns in a pepper mill or using a mortar and pestle. Seal tightly in a screw-top jar until required. Alternatively, keep the whole roasted peppercorns in a well-sealed container and grind them when required.

Preheat the oven to 200C/gas 6/ fan 180C. Turn the pork rind side up on the rack and put the rack over a roasting tin with 2-3cm hot water in the bottom. Roast for 15 minutes, then reduce the heat to 180C/gas 4/fan 160C and continue to roast for 2 hours, checking every now and then that your tin is not dry – splash in some hot water from the kettle if it is. Increase the heat to 230C/gas 8/fan 210C for the last 15 minutes. Remove the pork from the oven and leave it to rest (about 20 minutes). Serve carved into large cubes.
chief_review: This recipe for crispy-skinned roast pork delivers superb flavor and texture, perfectly pairing the succulence of pork with the aromatic depth of Sichuan peppercorns and five spice. The salty, spicy rub ensures a crackling that’s beautifully crispy, while the meat stays tender and juicy. Serving it with stir-fried pak choi adds a refreshing, light balance to the richness of the pork. Suitable for gluten-free diets, provided the five spice powder contains no wheat-based fillers. With only pork and a handful of spices, it’s naturally free from dairy, nuts, and eggs, making it ideal for those with common allergies. An impressive dish for entertaining or a special family meal, celebrating the best of Chinese-inspired flavors.

name: Sprout & spring onion champ
description: Try an updated version of mashed potatoes with greens by trying out Brussels sprouts, spring onions, nutmeg and a healthy knob of butter
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1kg potato(King Edward or Maris Piper work well), cut into chunks
400g Brussels sprout, halved and finely sliced
directions: Put the potatoes in a large pan of salted water, cover with a lid and bring to the boil. Simmer for 15 mins or until cooked through. Drain and leave to steam-dry for 5 mins.

Heat the butter in a large pan, add the spring onions and cook for 3 mins, stirring regularly. Tip in the Brussels sprouts and cook for a further 8 mins until soft. Add the milk and warm through for 1 min more.
Tip the potatoes back into their pan, mash, then add the milk and sprout mixture. Add the nutmeg, season and stir.
chief_review: This inventive twist on classic mashed potatoes combines the creamiest varieties—King Edward or Maris Piper—with vibrant Brussels sprouts and spring onions for a fusion of flavor and texture. The addition of nutmeg elevates the dish with subtle warmth and complexity, while a generous knob of butter ensures a luxuriously smooth and rich mash. The use of milk and butter makes it best suited to a vegetarian diet, and it avoids common allergens like nuts and gluten, making it a versatile choice for dinner parties or family meals alike. The greens not only add a pop of color but also bring in extra nutrients and freshness. Serve this as a standout side for roasted mains or as a hearty vegetarian centerpiece.

name: Iced choca-mocha terrine
description: This striking dessert is based on a classic tiramisu, but uses chocolate mini rolls as sponges, and is set in an ice cream loaf to be served in slices
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 15 chocolate mini rolls, 12 halved down the middle, 3 left whole
directions: Grease a 900g loaf tin with oil and line with a double layer of cling film. Put the coffee, sugar and 125ml water in a pan, and bring to the boil. When the sugar has dissolved, remove the syrup from the heat. Add the coffee liqueur and set aside to cool.

Whisk the double cream until it just holds its shape. Fold through the mascarpone, and then the coffee syrup. To assemble the terrine, press half the halved mini rolls into the tin, cut-side down, trimming them to fit. Tip half the cream into the terrine, then line the whole mini rolls down the middle. Top with the rest of the coffee cream and press the other half of the cut mini rolls into the cream, cut-side up. Wrap with the cling film and press down gently to push the top layer of rolls into the cream, then freeze.
Before serving, remove the terrine from the freezer and place in the fridge for 1 hr, then turn out onto a chilled serving dish. Dust heavily with cocoa powder before cutting into slices.
chief_review:
This inventive tiramisu-inspired dessert reimagines tradition by swapping the usual sponge for chocolate mini rolls, adding playful texture and a delightful chocolate twist. The assembly in an ice cream loaf tin is a clever touch, giving impressive, sliceable results perfect for entertaining. The mascarpone and double cream set to a rich, silky finish, while the optional coffee liqueur deepens the flavor profile. Dusting with cocoa powder is a classic nod that ties the flavors together beautifully.

With no nuts and only optional alcohol, this dessert is suitable for vegetarians and those avoiding nuts or alcohol. However, always check the mini rolls for specific allergy information and ensure they are vegetarian-friendly. This recipe offers a fresh, crowd-pleasing centerpiece for any sweet table, sure to impress both classic tiramisu lovers and fans of creative desserts.

name: Red cabbage with juniper & pears
description: Swap apple for wedges of pear, which go beautifully with the garlic, juniper and cinnamon in this colourful side dish
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 red cabbage(about 1kg), quartered, cored and shredded
600ml vegetable stock, made with 2 stock cubes
2 firm pears, peeled, cored and each cut into 8 wedges
directions: Heat the oil in a large heavy-based pan. Add the onions and sauté for about 8 mins. Stir in the garlic and juniper and cook for 1 min more. Add as much cabbage as you can and cook, stirring, until it starts to soften, then make room for more and add the rest with the cinnamon, vinegar, sugar and stock.
Give everything a good stir, then cover the pan and leave to cook over a low heat for 35 mins, stirring occasionally and checking it isn’t catching on the bottom of the pan.
Add the pears and cook for 10-15 mins more, depending on their ripeness. If freezing, cook for just 5 mins. Leftovers will keep in the fridge for 1 week.
chief_review: This vibrant side dish masterfully combines the sweetness of pears with the warm, aromatic notes of cinnamon and juniper, balanced by a touch of muscovado sugar and tangy red wine vinegar. The shredded red cabbage absorbs the fragrant stock, resulting in a beautifully tender and deeply flavorful accompaniment. The absence of dairy, eggs, and animal-derived ingredients means this recipe is perfectly suited for vegan and vegetarian diets. Furthermore, there are no common allergens such as nuts, soy, or gluten-containing grains present, making it a considerate choice for those with food allergies or gluten sensitivities—just ensure your vegetable stock cubes are certified gluten free if required. Overall, this dish is not only a feast for the eyes but a celebration of contrasting flavors and textures, ideal for elevating any festive or everyday meal.

name: Peas with roasted shallots
description: This flavoursome side dish of peas with caramelised onions from James Martin is healthy and versatile
author: James Martin
directions: Turn oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the shallots in the sugar. Heat a large ovenproof frying pan until hot, and add the shallots. Cook for a few mins to caramelise the outside to a nice golden colour, then transfer to the oven for 5 mins to cook through.
Cook the peas in boiling salted water for 2 mins until tender, drain and mix with the shallots, mint, olive oil and lemon juice. Season and serve with your favourite roast.
chief_review:
James Martin’s peas with caramelised onions is a delightful side that balances the natural sweetness of caramelised shallots with the freshness of mint and lemon. The golden caster sugar intensifies the shallots' flavor, marrying wonderfully with vibrant peas and aromatic mint. Using extra-virgin olive oil adds richness without heaviness, while the lemon juice brings a bright finish, making the dish exceptionally refreshing.

This recipe is a great fit for both vegetarians and vegans, thanks to the absence of animal products. It also accommodates gluten-free diets, as none of the ingredients contain gluten. The ingredient list is free of common allergens like nuts, dairy, eggs, and soy, making it broadly suitable. Overall, this is a well-balanced, healthy, and crowd-pleasing side dish that pairs beautifully with a variety of mains.

name: Simply stunning chocolate fridge cake
