description: The beauty of this pudding is the simplicity of the ingredients, put together stylishly. Use chocolate biscuits and a Baileys mascarpone cream
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 200g bar dark chocolate, broken into chunks
5 boxes good milk chocolate biscuits, 48 biscuits in total (we used Marks & Spencer's All butter Fairtrade double chocolate chip cookies), or to make your own see tip, below
directions: Melt the chocolate and 150ml of the cream together in a small pan. Cool until spreadable, then use to sandwich pairs of the cookies together.

Choose a cake stand or flat plate to assemble your cake. Tip the remaining cream, the mascarpone, Baileys and icing sugar into a big bowl, and use an electric hand whisk to beat until thick and the mixture is just holding its shape.

Arrange some of your cookie sandwiches to make a base that almost covers the plate. Dot a little of the cream under each, and stick into position. Spread or dollop over a good layer of cream, then add another layer of cookies, a little smaller than the first. To get a neat finish, choose a front to your cake – and always start by arranging the outside ring of cookies from there (then you can snap cookies in half to fill in the middle). Repeat, making the layers smaller each time, until you finish with a single cookie and a dollop of cream on top! Chill in the fridge overnight.
chief_review: This chocolate biscuit pudding delivers decadent layers of texture and flavor, combining rich dark chocolate with luscious Baileys mascarpone cream. The use of high-quality milk chocolate biscuits ensures a satisfying crunch that contrasts beautifully with the velvety mascarpone and double cream blend. The splash of Baileys adds a sophisticated, festive note without overwhelming the dessert. Presentation is key here—layering the ingredients in a clear dish showcases the pudding’s elegant simplicity. Given the inclusion of mascarpone, double cream, and butter-rich biscuits, this recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, provided the biscuits are free of animal-derived gelatin and rennet. For optimal success, use room-temperature mascarpone for a smoother cream and chill the assembled pudding before serving to allow the flavors and textures to meld. A showstopper for any occasion, this pudding is indulgent yet straightforward, sure to impress guests with minimal effort.

name: 'Panforte' pies
description: The traditional Italian dessert is turned into a pretty hand-held nutty pie with chocolate and figs, plus an orange liqueur cream topping
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 140g mixed shelled and blanched nutsuch as pistachios, hazelnuts, almonds and cashews
50g soft dried fig, chopped to a paste in a food processor
1 tbsp icing sugar, plus extra to dust
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toast the nuts on a small baking tray for 5-8 mins until golden. Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured work surface and stamp 12 circles with a 7.5cm plain round cutter. Use to line the wells of a 12-hole bun tin. Chill until step 3. (You will only use around half of the pastry.)
Turn the oven down to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Melt the butter, sugar, syrup and chocolate together in a small pan, then beat in the egg, orange zest, figs and cinnamon. Stir in the toasted nuts.

Spoon the nutty mixture into the pastry cases and bake for 18-20 mins until the pastry is pale golden. Cool for 10 mins in the tin, then remove to a rack until just warm. Whip the cream with the sugar and booze, then dust the pies with a little icing sugar and finish with a dollop of cream and a scattering of orange zest just before eating. Good with strong coffee or mint tea.
chief_review:
This delightful twist on a classic Italian dessert combines a medley of nuts, rich chocolate, and figs enclosed in a crisp sweet shortcrust pastry, elevated by a zesty orange liqueur cream. The inclusion of pistachios, hazelnuts, almonds, and cashews offers a wonderful depth of flavor and texture, while the maple syrup and muscovado sugar add warmth and complexity. The whipped Cointreau cream adds a luxurious finish, balancing the earthiness of nuts and figs with citrusy brightness.

This recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish. However, it does include nuts, dairy, and eggs, making it unsuitable for those with nut or dairy allergies, or vegans. The use of ready-made shortcrust pastry means it is likely to contain gluten, so it’s not ideal for gluten-free diets.

Overall, a sophisticated dessert—perfect for festive occasions or as an elegant end to a meal.

name: Smashed roasties
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1½ kg floury potatoes(Maris Piper or King Edward), smaller potatoes kept whole, larger ones chopped in half
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180Cfan/gas 6. Put the potatoes in a large pan filled with cold salted water. Bring to the boil and cook for 15 mins until a cutlery knife can be inserted into the centre of a potato with only a little resistance, then drain and steam-dry.

Arrange the potatoes in a large roasting tin, leaving enough space between each one so that they have room to spread once smashed. Using a fish slice, push down on each of the potatoes to break them up slightly. Don’t worry if some break up completely, it just means more crispy bits. Season well and drizzle over the oil. Roast for 1 hr, turning once, until golden and crispy.
chief_review: This classic roast potato recipe is a triumph of simplicity, relying on floury potatoes and sunflower oil to deliver exceptionally crisp and fluffy results. The choice of varieties like Maris Piper or King Edward ensures the interior turns beautifully soft, while the exterior blisters into golden shards. Sunflower oil’s neutral flavor and high smoke point are perfect for roasting, yielding potatoes that are evenly cooked and never greasy. With only two core ingredients and no animal products or gluten-containing additives, this dish is ideal for both vegan and gluten-free diets, as well as being naturally nut- and soy-free. It’s a versatile side suitable for any celebratory table or Sunday roast, where pure potato flavor takes center stage. Attention to cutting the potatoes uniformly ensures even roasting, making this recipe accessible for cooks at any skill level. An essential roast potato, done properly.

name: Cocktail truffle selection
description: I made these as Christmas gifts for family & friends and had really positive comments. I couldn't really taste the difference between the Cosmopolitan and Pisco sour chocolates so the second time round I added a bit more of the flavourings (including alcohol!). They didn't look dull or melt as Jo suggests. Will definitely make again.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 100g espresso-flavoured dark chocolate(I used Green & Blacks espresso), chopped
gold food colouringbrush pen (we used a Rainbow Dust bright gold food pen from hobbycraft.co.uk)
3 x 10-hole silicone chocolate mouldtrays (you can use different shapes) or a 30-hole silicone chocolate mould tray
directions: Start by placing half the white chocolate in a heatproof bowl over a pan of simmering water. Once melted, take the bowl off the heat and add the rest of the white chocolate and the food colouring, if using (just use a tiny amount as the gel colours are quite strong). Stir occasionally to allow the chocolate to melt in the residual heat. Sprinkle a pinch of meringue into 10 of the holes of your chocolate mould. Once the chocolate has melted, use half to coat the insides of the holes where you have sprinkled meringue. Use the end of a teaspoon to spread the chocolate up the sides of the moulds so that the the inside is coated. Leave to set for 45 mins-1 hr.

Meanwhile, melt the other chocolates in separate bowls using the same directions, then use each to coat a further 10 holes of the mould. Keep back half of each chocolate mixture, as you will need this to seal the truffles.

While the chocolate sets, make the fillings. For the Pisco sour filling, beat the softened butter together with the icing sugar until pale and smooth. Add the Pisco, Angostura Bitters and lime zest and stir well. Transfer to a piping bag and store in a cool place until needed.

To make the espresso martini filling, melt the dark chocolate and butter in a bowl set over a pan of simmering water (or in the microwave). Remove from the heat and mix in the double cream, vodka and Kahlúa. Leave to cool for 5 mins. Transfer to a piping bag and store in a cool place until needed.

For the Cosmopolitan filling, Put the dried cranberries in a bowl with the orange liqueur and leave to soak for 15 mins. Beat the butter with the icing sugar, then stir in the cranberries and liqueur, bit by bit. Mix in the lime zest and cranberry jelly. Transfer to a piping bag and store in a cool place until needed.

Once all the chocolate has set in the moulds, pipe the Pisco sour filling into the green/white chocolate shells, the espresso martini filling into the espresso chocolate shells (saving a bit for sticking the beans on later) and the Cosmopolitan filling into the dark chocolate shells. Leave 2mm of space at the top of each one.

Bring the pan(s) of water back to simmering, then set the reserved bowls of chocolate over to melt them again if they have set. Use this remaining chocolate to fill up the moulds and seal in the filling. Try to fill the moulds level or just under – if they go over, they won’t sit flat when the chocolates are turned out.
Leave your truffles somewhere cool to set completely for at least 2 hrs (ideally overnight). If you put them in the fridge they will set more quickly, but they will lose their shine.

Once set completely, pop the chocolates out of the moulds carefully. Add a brush stroke of gold to the Cosmopolitan truffles using your brush pen. Stick a chocolate- coated coffee bean on each of the espresso martini truffles using a bit of the filling. Arrange in a box lined with baking parchment and tissue paper. Will keep in a cool place for up to 1 week.
chief_review:
This festive chocolate truffle recipe delivers an impressive blend of spirits and flavors, perfect for gifting or a luxurious treat. The combination of white and dark chocolates, espresso notes, and vibrant touches from lime zest, cranberry, and coffee beans results in a sophisticated mix. The addition of Pisco, vodka, Kahlúa, and orange liqueur brings cocktail-inspired elegance, while meringue and cranberries add enjoyable texture.

Be aware that this recipe is not suitable for a vegan or dairy-free diet, as it includes butter, double cream, and white chocolate. It is also not appropriate for those with egg allergies due to the meringue, and it contains alcohol, making it an adult-friendly indulgence. The gluten-free aspect depends entirely on the brands chosen (notably for the chocolate and liqueurs), so ingredient labels should be checked. Overall, a decadent, festive confection for the adventurous palate.

name: Cranberry fools
description: James Martin's Christmassy cranberry fools are quick to prepare and the recipe is easily increased to serve a crowd
author: James Martin
ingredients: 200g caster sugar, plus 3 tbsp extra to decorate
directions: Put the cranberries in a pan with 150g of the sugar. Gently heat until the sugar begins to melt, then cover and cook for 5-10 mins until the berries are soft. Mash with a potato masher and transfer to a large mixing bowl. Stir in 200ml of the cream and chill until cool.

In a bowl, whip the remaining cream with the remaining 50g sugar until soft peaks form. Scrape onto the cranberry mixture and fold 1-2 times to very lightly marble. Spoon between 5 small bowls – the fool will marble more as you spoon into the dishes. Cover and chill for at least 2 hrs or up to 24 hrs.

Froth the egg white with a fork. Put the extra 3 tbsp sugar on a small plate. Tip the extra cranberries for decoration into the egg white, then drop into the sugar. Shake the plate to roll and coat the berries. Repeat a few times, leaving the sugar to set for a couple of mins between each. Chill until ready to serve.
To serve, top each fool with a few sugared cranberries and serve with Cinnamon shortbread (see 'Goes well with').
chief_review: James Martin's Christmassy cranberry fools are a vibrant and approachable dessert, perfect for festive gatherings. The tartness of cranberries is beautifully balanced by the sweetness of caster sugar and the rich creaminess of double cream, resulting in a light yet indulgent treat. Whisked egg white brings a delightful airiness, making the fool incredibly smooth and mousse-like. The assembly is straightforward, allowing for easy scaling if you’re hosting a crowd. This dessert is a good option for those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no gelatin or animal rennet. The fresh cranberries with sugared decoration add a festive flair, making this a stunning centerpiece for a holiday table. Overall, it’s a winning recipe for both taste and presentation.

name: Squashed baby potatoes with rosemary
description: Lighter than your average roastie, these roasted new potatoes make a healthy addition to your Christmas plate
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1½ kg unpeeled salad or new potatoes- you want about 40
directions: Boil the potatoes for 10 mins until tender, then drain. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Drizzle half the oil over a flat, sturdy baking tray or baking dish. Using a potato masher, squash a sprig of rosemary into each potato on the tray so the masher leaves its mark and the potato splits around the edges. Drizzle the potatoes with the remaining oil, season with sea salt and roast for 50 mins or until golden around the edges.
chief_review: This recipe delivers perfectly crisp, golden roasted new potatoes with a wonderfully aromatic rosemary flavor. Using unpeeled salad or new potatoes retains more nutrients and fiber, and the olive oil keeps things light while enhancing the earthy notes of the rosemary. The absence of butter or animal fats makes these potatoes a great option for both vegetarians and vegans. Since no wheat or gluten-containing ingredients are present, it’s also naturally gluten-free, provided cross-contamination is avoided in preparation. The simplicity of the seasoning lets the natural sweetness of the potatoes shine, making this side dish an ideal, healthier, and satisfying choice for a festive table or any comforting meal throughout the year.

name: Edamame & chilli dip with crudités
description: Party food doesn't have to be fattening. Dip in to this fresh, healthy snack as many times as you like
author: Good Food
ingredients: halved radishes, sticks of carrots, celery and peppers, to serve
directions: Cook the soya beans in boiling salted water for 4 mins. Drain and cool under cold running water. Blitz with the yogurt, chopped red chilli, lime juice and crushed garlic clove until smooth. Fold in the finely chopped red onion and a handful chopped coriander. Serve with halved radishes and sticks of carrots, celery and peppers.
chief_review: This vibrant soya bean dip is a fresh, guilt-free addition to any party spread. The blend of creamy low-fat yogurt and protein-rich soya beans creates a smooth, satisfying base, elevated by the zing of lime, aromatic garlic, and fiery red chilli. The finely chopped red onion and coriander add a burst of freshness, while serving it with crunchy raw vegetables keeps things light and lively. This dip is perfect for vegetarians and is a great option for those looking for a high-protein, lower-fat snack. The recipe is also nut-free and low in sugar, making it suitable for a wider range of dietary needs while still delivering bold flavors and a satisfying crunch from the assorted raw veggies. A simple, health-conscious choice that doesn’t sacrifice taste!

name: Sticky chipolatas
description: These mini sausages with honey mustard glaze work as a roast accompaniment, canapé or on a party buffet
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line a baking tray with foil. Mix honey and both of the mustards in a bowl. You can make the glaze 2-3 days ahead.

Add the sausages and toss well to coat them. Arrange the sausages, spaced apart, on the baking tray. Smooth any remaining glaze left in the bowl on top of the sausages to make them extra sticky. Bake for 20 mins until golden.
chief_review: These mini sausages with honey mustard glaze are a delightful choice for entertaining. The pairing of sweet honey with the tang of both wholegrain and English mustards creates a well-balanced, flavorful coating that elevates the classic cocktail sausage. They are perfect as a canapé, party buffet addition, or even a creative complement for a roast dinner. Considering the ingredients, this recipe is suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided the sausages and mustards used are certified gluten-free. The simplicity of preparation makes it easy to scale the recipe for larger crowds, and the sticky, aromatic glaze ensures these sausages will be a hit with guests. The combination of sweet and savory makes them irresistibly moreish—an essential in any entertainer’s repertoire.

name: Crunchy nut cake decoration
description: This easy almond cake topping makes for a beautiful golden decoration suitable for any special occasion fruitcake
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Bake the Apricot & almond fruitcake (see recipe to the right of this one) or any other 20-23cm fruitcake but bring out of the oven 10 mins before the end of the cooking time. Increase oven temperature to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Gently heat the golden syrup and butter in a saucepan.

When it is all melted and runny, stir in toasted flaked almonds, whole blanched almonds and plain flour. Use a couple of teaspoons to dot the mixture all over the top of the cake, and pop back in the oven for 12-15 mins until the topping is nicely golden. Cool, then remove from the tin and cover the sides with pretty ribbons. Lightly dust the cake with icing sugar to finish.
chief_review: This almond cake topping delivers a fantastic golden crunch, elevating any celebratory fruitcake with both texture and rich nutty flavor. The combination of toasted flaked and whole blanched almonds creates visual appeal and satisfying bite. The golden syrup and butter bind the nuts beautifully while imparting a subtle caramel note, and the dusting of icing sugar adds a delicate finish. The use of plain flour means it’s not gluten free, but nut lovers will relish the abundance of almonds—those with nut allergies should take caution. Versatile and quick to prepare, this topping is especially suited to vegetarian diets. Perfect for adding a luxurious touch to holiday or special occasion cakes.

name: Any-roast apricot & pecan stuffing
description: You can't quite beat homemade stuffing- mix pork mince with fruit and nuts and freeze until you need it
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Melt the butter in a large pan, add the onions and celery, and briefly cook until they start to soften. Stir in the apricots and garlic, and cook a few mins more. Add the pecans and nutmeg, and cook, stirring until the nuts are lightly toasted. Leave to cool.
Stir in the breadcrumbs, mince, egg and herbs with 1 tsp salt and lots of pepper, then divide the mixture into 4, pack into bags and freeze. Will keep for 3 months.

One batch will make 12 stuffing balls or can be used to stuff roast pork or chicken. Two batches will fill a 1lb loaf tin, lined with streaky bacon that can be sliced, while 2 - 3 will stuff a medium-to-large turkey.

Cook at 200C/180C/gas 6 for 30 mins if rolling into balls, 45 mins if cooking in a loaf tin, or use to stuff the neck of your favourite roast bird, cooking for the same time as indicated in the recipe.
chief_review:
This homemade stuffing recipe offers a delightful combination of savory pork mince, aromatic herbs, and the natural sweetness of apricots, wonderfully complemented by the crunch of pecans. The foundation of butter-sautéed onions and celery creates a rich base, while the blend of nutmeg and fresh parsley adds depth and vibrancy. It's a hearty, flavorful dish that shines as a holiday side or a festive roast accompaniment.

Ideal for those following a nut-inclusive diet, it is also suited to egg and dairy eaters. However, due to the inclusion of pork, it fits well with traditional omnivorous diets. The use of fresh breadcrumbs makes this recipe unsuitable for gluten-free requirements, and the combination of meat, egg, and butter also disqualifies it from vegetarian or vegan diets. For those seeking a classic, satisfying stuffing, this recipe delivers both in taste and texture.

name: Little clementine & cranberry syrup cakes
description: These sticky individual cakes are inspired by rum babas- fruity, boozy and delicious. Serve with our stem ginger cream
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2-3 clementines, very thinly sliced (you need 8 nice slices), plus zest 4 clementines or 1 large orange
175g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
200g golden caster sugar, plus extra for sprinkling
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease 8 ovenproof dariole moulds and line the bases with a disk of baking parchment. Sprinkle each slice of clementine with a little sugar and place 1 in the bottom of each dariole, line up on a baking tray and set aside.

Put the butter and sugar in a large bowl. Mix with an electric hand whisk until smooth and fluffy. Add the eggs, one at a time, whisking until well incorporated. Add the flour, almonds and baking powder, whisk until smooth, then add the zest, milk and cranberries. Give everything a good final mix with a spatula, then divide the mixture between your dariole moulds. Bake for 30 mins until risen, golden, and an inserted skewer comes out clean. Leave to cool in their tins for 10-15 mins while you make the syrup.

Heat the clementine juice, orange liqueur and sugar in a small pan, swirling until the sugar has dissolved. Increase the heat and boil for a few mins, until the liquid has reduced by about half. Pour into a shallow dish and leave to cool for 5 mins.

When cool enough to handle, turn the cakes out of their tins and peel away the parchment. Stand in the dish of syrup, spooning it over the little cakes until completely absorbed. Transfer the cakes to a baking parchment-lined tray and leave to cool completely before serving with stem ginger cream (see tip below for recipe).
chief_review:
This vibrant, indulgent recipe is an excellent choice for a special occasion dessert, offering a delightful balance of zesty citrus, tart cranberries, and a boozy Cointreau syrup. The use of ground almonds imparts a pleasant moistness and a subtle nutty depth to the cakes. The sticky topping and the stem ginger cream take these cakes into gourmet territory, reminiscent of a classic baba au rhum but with a fruity twist.

Suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin, these cakes also pair well with festive menus thanks to their rich flavors and aromatic profile. However, the recipe includes gluten (flour), eggs, dairy, almonds, and alcohol, so it’s important to check for possible allergies among diners. For those who can indulge, this dessert promises a wonderfully aromatic and texturally pleasing finale to any meal.

name: Creamy bread & shallot sauce
description: This hearty roast dinner accompaniment is flavoured with cloves, bay leaves and nutmeg- great with chicken or turkey and smothered in gravy
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 100g crustless white bread(ideally cut from a loaf), cubed
directions: Melt the butter in a deep non-stick pan. Add the shallots, cloves and bay leaves, and gently cook for 10 mins over a low heat until the shallots are soft and colouring a little. Pour in the milk, then part-cover the pan and leave to simmer on a very low heat for 10 mins.

Remove the cloves, then add the bread and cream to the shallot mixture. Grate in half the nutmeg, then cook for 5 mins, or until the bread absorbs the milk and starts to break down a little but still has a texture. Can be made 1 day ahead (you may need to thin with a little milk). Grate over the remaining nutmeg to serve.
chief_review: This bread sauce recipe is a classic, embodying the warmth and aromatics of cloves, bay leaves, and freshly grated nutmeg. The richness from butter and double cream, combined with the subtle sweetness of shallots and soft texture of crustless white bread, creates a decadent, perfectly smooth accompaniment to roast chicken or turkey. Its simplicity allows the aromatic spices to shine, elevating even the most straightforward roast dinners. This sauce is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish. However, it includes dairy (butter, milk, cream) and gluten (white bread), so it isn’t appropriate for vegan or gluten-free diets. Serve generously, and don’t be shy with the nutmeg or a final seasoning adjustment–this old-fashioned classic always impresses.

name: Sticky sausage & rosemary skewers
description: Our version of pigs in blankets uses a decorative herb sprig and a drizzle of sweet maple syrup to really bring the traditional side dish to life
author: Cassie Best
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Grease a large baking tray with a little oil. To prepare your skewers, remove most of the leaves from each rosemary sprig, keeping a few leaves at the end. Sharpen the other end to a point by cutting it at an angle.

Stretch the bacon by placing it on a chopping board and running the back of a knife along the length. Cut each piece in half across the middle. Thread 3 sausages onto each skewer, weaving a piece of bacon around them as you do.
Arrange the skewers on the baking tray and bake for 20 mins. Turn them, brush with maple syrup and return to the oven for 10 mins more until really sticky.
chief_review: This inventive take on pigs in blankets elevates a beloved classic with thoughtful touches—aromatic rosemary sprigs add visual flair and an herbaceous note, while the finishing drizzle of maple syrup introduces a welcome hint of sweetness that beautifully balances the saltiness of bacon and sausage. The use of sunflower oil for roasting helps achieve an even, satisfying crispness. As the recipe includes pork-based cocktail sausages and streaky bacon, it is not intended for vegetarian or vegan diets, nor is it suitable for those avoiding pork. However, the clever use of fresh herbs and maple syrup gives a festive lift, making it a standout on any holiday table. For best results, ensure your rosemary sprigs are sturdy enough to skewer, and serve immediately for optimal texture and flavor contrast.

name: Golden crunch potatoes
description: We've used some top tricks to come up with the perfect roast potatoes with crisp coatings and fluffy middles
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: large pinch of paprika(not hot or smoked)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Peel the potatoes and cut into large chunks or, if they are small enough, keep them whole. Place in a pan of salted water, add most of the turmeric, stir and bring to the boil. Turn down the heat and simmer the potatoes for 6 mins until the sides are fluffy. Drain well and leave to cool slightly. Mix the flour, polenta, paprika and remaining turmeric together in a large bowl, then toss through the potatoes until evenly coated in the flour mix.

Put the oil and fat in a large roasting tin – you want a layer of fat about 5mm deep, and put in the oven for 10 mins until shimmering hot. Carefully tip the potatoes into the hot fat and use a fish slice to turn them until evenly coated. Place in the oven and leave for 40 mins. Remove, turn the potatoes and return to the oven for another 20 mins until golden. Serve sprinkled with the salt.
chief_review: This recipe delivers classic roast potatoes with a delightful golden crust and pillowy interiors, thanks to clever use of polenta and a touch of turmeric for both texture and hue. The mixture of sunflower oil with duck or goose fat imparts rich flavor and an irresistibly crisp finish, while coatings of flour and polenta ensure superb crunch. Paprika adds subtle warmth without overpowering the dish. Ideal for meat lovers and festive gatherings, this recipe is not suited to vegetarian or vegan diets due to the inclusion of animal fat. The use of plain flour means it’s not gluten-free, so it may not be suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. Technically sound and crowd-pleasing, these roast potatoes are a fantastic side for traditional roasts, providing the right balance between robust flavor and textural contrast.

name: Chestnuts in Cointreau & orange syrup
description:
This looks lively (especially as I picked up plenty of fresh chestnuts) for Xmas gifts, but how many jars does it make?
Thanks in advance for your answer.
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 1½ kg chestnutsin shells, or 800g prepared chestnuts (vacuum-packed or from a jar)
directions: To peel the chestnuts, cut a nick in each one on the flat side. Put 6 on a plate and microwave for 1 min on High. Then, wearing rubber gloves, peel off the outer skin and inner brown membrane. Continue until all the chestnuts are peeled. (If you don’t have a microwave, you can roast the chestnuts in the oven at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 15-20 mins.) Put them in a pan, cover with water and bring to the boil, then simmer for 25 mins. Drain well.

Pare thin strips of zest from the orange using a vegetable peeler. Cut the vanilla pod in half lengthways. Put the orange strips, vanilla pod, sugars and 400ml water in a pan and bring slowly to the boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Simmer for about 15 mins until syrupy. Remove from the heat and stir in the Cointreau.
Pack the prepared chestnuts into sterilised jars (see below) and pour over the syrup to cover. Seal the jars. The chestnuts will keep in a cool, dry place for up to 6 months.
chief_review: This chestnut spread recipe bursts with festive flavors, combining earthy chestnuts with zesty orange, fragrant vanilla, and a warming dash of Cointreau. The blend of granulated and light brown sugar creates a rich, balanced sweetness that pairs beautifully with the other ingredients. It’s especially appealing as a homemade holiday gift, bringing a luxurious touch to breakfast or dessert. Since the recipe contains no gluten, dairy, or eggs, it’s ideal for those following a vegetarian or gluten-free diet, as long as alcohol is permitted. The use of prepared chestnuts also offers convenience without sacrificing quality. Expect the batch to yield around 3–4 standard (250ml) jars, making it perfect for sharing.

name: Brined roast turkey crown & confit legs
description: I have made this twice now and it has been rated as the best turkey ever, this is after cooking many, many Christmas dinners. I used half oil and half goose fat fir the legs as I don't like potatoes roasted entirely in goose fat. Worked perfectly. I got my butcher to cut the legs and wings off.
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: 5kg turkey, legs and thighs removed, wings cut from the breast (ask your butcher to chop the neck and backbone into pieces for the gravy)
directions: Up to four days before, make the brine by combining the salt, peppercorns, bay, sage and sugar using a pestle and mortar, or crush with the end of a rolling pin in a bowl. Stir through both zests and spoon roughly 1/ 3 into a large resealable bag and the rest in another bag to chill.
Put the turkey legs and wings in the bag with 1/ 3 of the brine and shake well to coat the skin, then leave overnight in the fridge.

The next day, heat oven to 120C/ 100C fan/gas 1. Rinse the brine from the legs and wings and pat dry. Put the duck fat in a roasting tin, melt in the oven for 5 mins, then add the turkey pieces (they should be submerged in the fat). Cook in the middle of the oven for about 4 hrs or until the legs are tender. Leave to cool, then cover and chill overnight, or up to three days.
On Christmas Eve, cover the turkey crown in the remaining dry brine and chill in the fridge overnight.

In the morning, take the crown out the fridge 1 hr before roasting, rinse off the brine and pat dry with kitchen paper. Take the confit legs, thighs and wings out the fridge and leave to come to room temperature so they are easily released from the fat. Take out and put on a baking tray ready to reheat later. Strain the fat and set aside ready to cook the potatoes.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5 and line a large shallow roasting tin with foil. Set a wire rack on top, scatter the herbs and onion across and sit the crown on top. Rub the butter all over the skin and season well. Roast, uncovered, for 40 mins, then cover with foil and cook for another 30 mins. Remove the foil, and cook for a final 15-20 mins. To test if the turkey is cooked, insert a skewer into the thickest part of the breast – the juices should run clear. Transfer to a platter, cover with foil and leave to rest for at least 30 mins.
Meanwhile, reheat the confit legs and wings in the oven for 30 mins or until the skin has crisped up. Add to the platter with the crown and carve.
chief_review:
This turkey recipe is a masterstroke of festive cookery, yielding tender, flavorful meat that impresses even seasoned Christmas hosts. The method of separating the legs and breast allows for optimal roasting and easier carving, ensuring perfect texture throughout. The aromatic blend of bay, thyme, and sage infuses the bird with depth, while the combination of duck or goose fat with oil achieves wonderfully crisp skin without overpowering richness. Citrus zest brightens the savory notes, making each bite lively yet balanced. 

While this recipe delivers classic holiday indulgence, it accommodates gluten-free diets, as there are no grains or wheat-based products among the ingredients. Likewise, it avoids common allergens like nuts and soy. For those seeking a traditional, show-stopping centerpiece that highlights impeccable technique and bold flavor, this turkey is highly recommended. A true chef’s delight.

name: Slow cooker mulled wine
description: Does this wine need to be drunk as soon as it is made or could it be bottled up and gifted to people?
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: peeled zest and juice of 2 large oranges
directions: Put all the ingredients (except the slices of orange) in a slow cooker on low for 1 1/2 - 2hrs until hot. Ladle into heatproof glasses and serve with slices of orange.
chief_review: This recipe creates a beautifully aromatic mulled wine, ideal for cozy gatherings or gifting during the festive season. The inclusion of red wine and Cointreau ensures a bold, warming base, while citrus zest and juice brighten each sip. Whole spices like cinnamon, star anise, and cloves infuse complexity and seasonal charm, balanced by golden caster sugar for a touch of sweetness. Notably, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients. For best results, the mulled wine is meant to be enjoyed fresh, as the infusion of citrus and spices is most vibrant soon after preparation. If gifting, bottle and seal soon after mulling, but note that the flavors may evolve and diminish over time. Overall, this recipe is a festive treat, delivering depth and character perfect for sharing or gifting during the holidays.

name: Festive celeriac koshari
description:
What an enormous amount of effort and cleaning for a totally under-par dish!
1 thing in the oven, 2 pans and then you bring it all together and wonder why you bothered. I am a bit baffled by this recipe as the ingredients are all ace. I had to add lots more lemon and spices to try and 'zhuzz' it up but it was still boring and bland! Disappointing. Oh and also looks rubbish as it is totally brown!
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 2 small celeriac, peeled and chopped into small cubes
2 garlic bulb, split across the middle
150ml rapeseed oilor extra virgin olive oil
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Rinse the lentils and rice together under cold water until the water runs clear. Soak them in water for 30 mins, then drain. Meanwhile, toss the celeriac and garlic halves in 4 tbsp of the rapeseed oil and season. Cover with foil and roast for 20 mins, tossing occasionally. Remove the foil and return to the oven for 10 mins until soft and caramelised.

Heat 4 tbsp of the oil over a medium heat, season and fry the onions for about 12 mins until starting to caramelise. In the meantime, cook the macaroni until al dente, then drain. Tip into the onions along with the pine nuts, fry until the nuts and pasta are starting to brown, then remove from the heat.

Heat the remaining 2 tbsp oil in a heavy-bottomed frying pan and add the ground cinnamon, cumin and coriander seeds. Stir until they sizzle, then add the lentils and rice. Stir-fry for 1 min, then add the stock and cranberries. Cook for about 25 mins, stirring occasionally, until the stock is absorbed and the cranberries have swelled up.

Tip the lentil mixture into the onion mixture along with the celeriac, and heat over a medium heat to warm it all through. Squeeze the roasted garlic cloves out of their skins and mash with the lemon zest and juice, then stir into the rice.
In a separate container, stir the harissa into the yogurt. To serve, divide the koshari between bowls and top with the spiced yogurt and coriander.
chief_review: This recipe brings together a variety of textures and hearty flavors, combining lentils, rice, macaroni, celeriac, and richly caramelized onions. The inclusion of rose harissa, dried cranberries, and aromatic spices like cinnamon, cumin, and coriander adds layers of Middle Eastern-inspired complexity. However, the effort-intensive preparation—multiple pans and oven time—does not quite translate to bold results, as the dish risks turning out visually monotone and underwhelming on the palate. I recommend upping the citrus (as you did) and perhaps finishing with a fresh herb oil or a punchy spice blend for vibrancy. The Greek yogurt topping brings welcome creaminess, but makes it unsuitable for vegans; omit or use a plant-based alternative for a vegan-friendly version. This dish is perfect for vegetarians, and could be adapted to accommodate gluten-free diets by substituting gluten-free macaroni. Overall, a dish with potential but requires tweaks for excitement.

name: Harissa & marmalade roasted roots
description: Couldn't find rose harissa so sprinkled chilli powder on instead before roasting. Quick and easy to do and tasty.
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 500g unpeeled baby parsnips(or small parsnips), ends trimmed, any larger ones cut in half lengthways
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180Cfan/gas 6. Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Add the parsnips and carrots, cook for 2 mins, then drain and empty into a large roasting tin. Drizzle over the oil and season.
Mix together the harissa and marmalade, then spoon over the veg and toss to coat. Roast for 45-50 mins until sticky and caramelised.
chief_review: This recipe showcases beautifully roasted baby parsnips and carrots, enhanced with a delightful blend of rose harissa (or a simple substitute of chilli powder) and thin-cut marmalade. The use of sunflower oil keeps the dish light, while the sweet-and-spicy glaze adds an unexpected brightness that complements the earthiness of the vegetables. Preparation is quick and fuss-free, making this a practical side for weeknights or festive tables alike. The ingredient list is naturally vegan and gluten-free, appealing to a broad range of dietary needs. The minimal, wholesome additions also mean this dish is nut-free and suitable for typical food-allergy concerns, barring any specific citrus allergies related to the marmalade. Overall, these roasted vegetables deliver on both flavor and versatility, and can easily stand alone or accompany a main course.

name: Sticky bourbon BBQ wings with blue cheese dip
description: Super tasty recipe!
author: Gizzi Erskine
ingredients: 4 celery sticks, each cut into 4 small sticks (keep some with their leaves)
bunch French breakfast radishes(with their leaves if you can get them)
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/ gas 7. Cut the chicken wings into winglets by slicing through each of the joints. Keep the two meaty pieces and discard the wing tips, or freeze for stock.
Put the winglets on a large baking sheet, drizzle with the olive oil, then season. Roast in the oven for 20 mins, then reduce the temperature to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4 and cook for a further 25 mins.

Meanwhile, make the barbecue sauce. Put all the ingredients, except the butter, in a pan and mix together with plenty of black pepper. Let it bubble away for 3-5 mins to thicken up a little, then add the butter and stir until it has melted and made the sauce nice and shiny. Season to taste.

Half an hour before the chicken wings are ready, take them out of the oven and brush over three-quarters of the barbecue sauce. When they’re fully cooked, toss them in the rest of the sauce so that they become sticky.

In a small bowl, mash the blue cheese dressing ingredients together with some seasoning, until combined. The barbecue sauce and dip can be made a day ahead, covered and chilled. Serve alongside the wings with the celery sticks and radishes for dipping.
chief_review:
This chicken wings recipe delivers bold, smoky flavors balanced by tangy undertones and a refreshing assortment of vegetables. The bourbon-infused glaze, enhanced with spices, dark brown sugar, and hot chilli sauce, achieves a memorable depth—sweet, spicy, and slightly tangy. The combination of crispy, oven-baked wings and the vibrant crunch of radishes and celery adds complexity and freshness to each bite.

The standout Gorgonzola dip—a velvety blend of cheese, soured cream, and mayonnaise, with a touch of lemon juice—complements the wings masterfully, offering a cool, creamy contrast to the heat of the glaze. Perfect for gatherings or an indulgent game day, this dish is a true crowd-pleaser.

This recipe is ideal for a gluten-free diet, provided you ensure the Worcestershire sauce and other condiments are certified gluten-free. It is also nut-free, making it suitable for those with nut allergies.

name: Spiced pea & courgette fritters with minty yogurt dip
author: Gizzi Erskine
ingredients: 1 tbsp good-quality extra virgin olive oil
3 tsp mint sauce(or 2 tbsp freshly chopped mint leaves)
2 courgettes, grated and the moisture squeezed out
1 green chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
3 spring onions, thinly sliced on a diagonal
directions: In a large bowl, mix together all the fritter ingredients, except the oil, until combined. For the yogurt dip, simply mix all the ingredients together in a small bowl with plenty of freshly ground black pepper and 1 tsp salt. The dip can be made in the morning and chilled.

When you’re ready to cook the fritters, heat the oil over a high heat (you want to make sure the oil is really hot, so be brave!). Carefully drop 1 tbsp of batter into the pan – add only 4-5 tbsp at a time so you don’t overcrowd the pan – and fry for about 2 mins each side until nicely crisp and golden. Remove from the pan and place on kitchen paper to absorb the excess oil. The fritters can be fried a couple of hours before serving, then reheated in the oven.

To reheat the fritters ready for serving, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the fritters on a baking tray and bake for 10 mins or until crispy and hot. Serve on a platter with the feta and spring onions scattered over, with the minty yogurt dip on the side.
chief_review: This recipe offers a vibrant combination of fresh vegetables, aromatic spices, and herbs, brought together with a creamy Greek yogurt and feta topping. The use of gluten-free flour ensures it is well-suited for those adhering to a gluten-free diet, while the abundance of courgettes, peas, and mint provide freshness and color. Greek yogurt and feta lend tang and richness, and the gentle heat from green chilli adds a subtle kick without overpowering. The texture is light yet satisfying, thanks to the eggs and baking powder, while the olive oil adds a hint of fruitiness. Beautiful for a light lunch or as an appetizer, this dish balances healthfulness with satisfying flavor and is especially fitting for those seeking gluten-free options or wishing to increase vegetable intake.

name: Rainbow yule log
author: Mima Sinclair
ingredients: 100g caster sugar, plus extra for sprinkling
food colouringpastes (red, yellow, pink, green, purple, blue)
directions: Heat oven to 180C /160C fan/gas 4. Grease and line a 23cm x 33cm Swiss roll tin with baking parchment.
Beat together the eggs and caster sugar with an electric hand whisk until pale, thick and doubled in volume. Working quickly, divide between 6 bowls and stir a colouring paste into each portion.

Sift the flour and baking powder into a separate bowl and combine evenly. Sprinkle 3 tbsp of the flour mixture over each portion of the egg mixture. Drizzle with a little of the melted butter. Fold together very gently, taking care not to knock out the air.

Gently spoon each mixture into separate piping bags, then cut off each tip to create a 2cm hole. Pipe lines of the mixture diagonally across the Swiss roll tin in a rainbow pattern, making sure the lines touch each other. Continue until the tin is full and the mixture is used up. Bake for 12 mins, or until springy and dry to the touch.

Place a large piece of baking parchment onto a clean surface and sprinkle with caster sugar, then turn the cake out onto it. Remove the lining paper and loosely roll up the sponge from the short side, with the sugared paper rolling along with it. Cover with a damp tea towel and leave on a wire rack to cool completely.
For the whipped cream filling, beat the cream with an electric hand whisk until soft peaks form. Add the icing sugar and vanilla extract and whisk briefly until just combined.
Gently unroll the cake and remove the paper. Spread the cream filling evenly across and reroll. Trim the ends if any cream leaks. Dust with icing sugar before serving.
chief_review:
This recipe offers a delightful combination of airy sponge and creamy filling, reminiscent of classic European cakes. The use of eggs, sugar, flour, and baking powder ensures a light, tender crumb, while whipped cream with vanilla provides a rich yet balanced contrast. Food colouring adds an inviting visual element, making this an ideal treat for festive occasions or celebrations. 

The absence of nuts makes it suitable for those with nut allergies, but it’s important to note the inclusion of dairy, eggs, and gluten. For vegetarians, this recipe works beautifully, as all ingredients are plant-friendly aside from the eggs and dairy, which aren’t excluded from a typical vegetarian diet. For best results, ensure the eggs are at room temperature and the whipped cream is chilled before assembly to achieve the ideal texture and flavor.

name: Carrot & caraway crackers
description:
I made this for a cocktail party for 30 - it was fantastic.
I made the puree the day before, and to be honest I didn't like it. But, once on the crackers, with the crips and the scattering of dill...really, really terrific.
Use a pastry bag or similar if you have to make a lot - it's too fiddly/messy to do properly with a spoon.
I paired this pass-around hors d'oeuvres with the Feta & Cucumber Bites, also on this site. A great pairing, and everyone thought I was the most fantastic hostess ever ;-)
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 20 crunchy vegan crackers(such as an olive oil toast)
½ small pack dill, leaves picked, to serve
20 veg crisps(we used a small bag of Tyrells), to serve
directions: Heat the oil in a saucepan over a medium heat. Add the shallot and a pinch of salt, and cook for 6 mins until softened. Stir in the garlic and caraway seeds and cook for 1 min more, then add the carrot and veg stock, bring to a boil and simmer for 12 mins.
Once the carrots are completely soft, drain them (reserve the liquid) and

to a smooth purée – add a tbsp of the reserved stock initially, but use more if necessary to get the desired consistency. Season and leave to cool. The purée can be made a day ahead and kept in the fridge.
To serve, spoon the purée – or, if you want to be extra fancy, transfer it to a piping bag and pipe it – onto the oatcakes and top each with a little dill and a veg crisp.
chief_review: This vibrant hors d’oeuvre showcases carrots, caraway, and dill, creating a perfectly balanced topping for vegan crackers. The use of vegan vegetable stock and crunchy vegan crackers makes it entirely plant-based, suitable for vegan and vegetarian diets. It also works beautifully for a dairy-free crowd. The puree, while unimpressive on its own, transforms atop the cracker with fresh dill, making for an elegant and texturally interesting bite. The recommendation to use a pastry bag is spot-on for efficiency and presentation—particularly for larger gatherings. Pairing this with Feta & Cucumber Bites offers visual and flavor contrast, highlighting your attention to detail as a host. The tidy list of ingredients avoids common allergens like nuts and soy, and the choice of gluten-free crackers would also make this suitable for gluten-sensitive guests. Overall, a simple yet sophisticated cocktail party offering with broad appeal.

name: Baked camembert dough ball platter
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 7g fast-action dried yeast, plus another ½ tsp
drizzle of olive oilor rapeseed oil, for greasing
toppingsfor the cheese (optional) - use woody herbs such as rosemary and thyme
directions: Warm 350ml water in a saucepan until steaming, then remove from the heat, add the butter and set aside to cool until you can comfortably put your finger in the liquid. Combine the flour, yeast, sugar and 1 tsp salt in a large bowl or the bowl of a tabletop mixer. Add the cooled liquid and combine to make a soft dough. Knead for 10 mins by hand, or 5 mins in a mixer, until the dough feels stretchy and smooth. Return to a clean, oiled bowl and cover with oiled cling film. Leave somewhere warm to rise for 11/2-2 hrs or until doubled in size.

Grease and line your largest baking tray (ours was 42 x 33cm) with baking parchment. Grease the parchment too, then scatter over the polenta. Remove the cheeses from their boxes and place on the tray, spaced well apart. Brush each one with a little oil, slash the tops a few times with a sharp knife and poke in some fresh herbs, if you like.

Pour the egg into a shallow dish, the poppy seeds in another and the sesame in a third. Knock the air out of the dough and knead again for several mins. Take a small piece of dough (about the size of a whole walnut ) and roll it into a ball. Dip the top in egg, then into one of the dishes of seeds, and place on the baking tray, seeded-side up. Continue rolling and dunking the dough, leaving every third piece seedless, filling the tray but leaving a little space between each ball of dough. When you have used all the dough, you may need to reposition the dough balls to ensure the baking tray is evenly covered.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4. Cover the tray with a few sheets of oiled cling film and leave for 30 mins-1 hr until the dough has doubled in size and the balls are touching. Bake for 25-30 mins until the dough balls are cooked through and the cheese is oozy and melted. Leave to cool for 5 mins, then serve.
chief_review:
This recipe creates an indulgent tear-and-share bread featuring gooey, baked Camembert—a perfect centerpiece for festive gatherings. The strong white bread flour ensures a robust, airy loaf, while polenta or cornmeal adds a pleasing crunch. Enriched with butter and egg, the bread is luxuriously soft, and the addition of poppy and sesame seeds brings nutty depth. Melted Camembert elevates the dish with creamy decadence, beautifully complemented by fragrant rosemary and thyme.

With its dairy and egg content, this recipe is suitable for lacto-ovo-vegetarians, but not for vegans. It includes wheat and is not gluten-free. Overall, it’s a show-stopping bake that’s as fun to share as it is delicious to eat—a brilliant choice for cheese lovers and celebratory occasions.

name: Brussels sprout, bacon & stilton pizzettas
author: Emily Kydd
ingredients: 6 rashers smoked streaky bacon, roughly chopped into large pieces
250g Brussels sprout, trimmed and thickly sliced
small handful sage leaves, large leaves torn
directions: Make the pizza dough: put the bread mix in a large bowl, pour over ½ tbsp olive oil and 175ml lukewarm water. Stir until a dough is formed, then tip out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 5-10 mins until smooth. Rub the bowl with a little oil, pop in the dough, cover with cling film and leave to rise in a warm place for 45 mins or until doubled in size.

Meanwhile, make the pizza topping. Heat 1/2 tbsp oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat. Add the bacon and cook until just starting to crisp. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on kitchen paper. Add another drizzle of oil to the pan, then tip in the sprouts, season and cook for 3-4 mins until softened and starting to caramelise around the edges. Set aside.

For the white sauce, melt the butter in a small pan, add the garlic and let it sizzle gently for 30 secs. Pour in the cream, grate over some nutmeg, season and simmer for 5 mins until thickened and reduced.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and pop in 2 large trays. Carefully remove the dough from the bowl and, without punching out all the air, divide into 4. Using your hands or a rolling pin, shape each quarter into a rough circle 18-20cm in diameter. Transfer to the hot trays and cook for 4 mins. Remove from the oven, spread over the white sauce, then scatter with the sprouts, bacon and stilton. Toss the sage leaves with the remaining oil and divide among the pizzas. Cook for 5-10 mins until the dough is golden brown and the top is bubbling. Grind over some black pepper before serving.
chief_review: This hearty recipe brings together the rustic flavors of ciabatta bread with the savory notes of smoked bacon, Brussels sprouts, and crumbly stilton, finished with a rich cream sauce and perfumed with sage and nutmeg. The use of a bread mix anchors the dish with chewy, satisfying texture, while the combination of double cream and stilton creates an indulgently creamy, tangy sauce. Bacon adds a punch of umami, perfectly balanced by the slightly bitter Brussels sprouts. Sage and garlic offer aromatic depth. This dish is wonderfully suited to those who follow a nut-free diet, provided the bread mix and cheese are checked for potential allergen cross-contamination. It is best served warm, ideal for a comforting brunch or lunch. Creativity in presentation—such as individual portions or a rustic family-style bake—will truly elevate this recipe's robust, wintry charm.

name: Microwave bread sauce
description: This super-quick sauce for meat frees up your hob and is much better than the shop-bought instant variety
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 blade mace, or ¼ tsp ground mace
directions: Combine the milk, onion, cloves, bay leaf, peppercorns and mace in a medium-sized microwaveable bowl. Place in the microwave and cook for 2 mins on High. Remove, cover with cling film and stand for 15 mins, or chill for up to 2 days if the milk’s sell-by date allows.

When you’re ready to serve, strain the sauce, then return to the bowl. Add the breadcrumbs, place in the microwave again and cook for 3 mins on High. If the sauce is a bit lumpy, whisk until smooth, then stir in the cream, nutmeg and seasoning. Finish with a knob of butter.
chief_review:
This bread sauce recipe is a classic, elevating any meat dish with its rich, aromatic profile. The infusion of whole milk with onion, cloves, bay leaf, peppercorns, and mace lends a deep, comforting warmth, while the breadcrumbs and double cream create a creamy, luscious texture far superior to store-bought versions. The finishing touch of nutmeg and butter adds just the right amount of complexity and silkiness. 

Perfect for those following a vegetarian diet (provided the bread and butter are vegetarian-friendly), this sauce is also suitable for individuals who can tolerate dairy and gluten. The use of staple pantry ingredients makes this recipe both convenient and impressive. An excellent accompaniment to roasted meats, this sauce will undoubtedly be a crowd-pleaser at any gathering.

name: Roast turkey with pecan, sausage & chestnut stuffing & roast shallots
description: This traditional bird is served with classic sage & onion flavours and given a glossy finish with a sweet glaze
author: Good Food
ingredients: sprig each sage and thyme, plus extra for serving
25g softened butter, plus 1 tbsp for the glaze
2 medium onions, each cut into 6 thick wedges
12 shallots, halved lengthways, or left whole if small
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Rinse the turkey inside and out, then pat dry with kitchen paper. Weigh it to calculate the cooking time, allowing 40 mins per kg for the first 4kg, then 45 mins for each 1kg over that weight. Finely grate 1 tsp zest from the lemon and set aside for the stuffing. Cut the lemon into 4-6 wedges and tuck into the turkey cavity with the shallots and herb sprigs. Rub the turkey all over with the butter, then season with salt and pepper. Put the onion wedges in the middle of a large roasting tin and sit the turkey on top. Cover with a loose tent of foil, then roast following your calculated time.

Make the stuffing. Chop just over half the pecans and reserve the remaining. Line the base of a baking tray or sheet (big enough to take 16 stuffing balls) with baking parchment. Heat the oil and butter in a frying pan, tip in the shallots and garlic, and fry for a few mins until softened. Stir in the chestnuts and chopped pecans, then tip into a large bowl and cool. Squeeze the sausages from their casings and add to the bowl with the nut mixture. Add the remaining stuffing ingredients, including the reserved lemon zest, and season with salt and pepper. Shape the stuffing mixture into 16 balls. Break the remaining pecans into big pieces and press a piece into top of each ball. Arrange balls on the prepared tray, cover with buttered baking parchment and chill until ready to cook. Can be made 1 day ahead and chilled.

Make the glaze. Mix the honey, mustard, remaining 1 tbsp butter and soy sauce in a small bowl and set aside. Thirty mins before the end of the cooking time, remove the turkey and increase oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the foil, then return the bird to the oven for a further 10 mins. Remove again, brush the turkey with the glaze, then roast for another 20 mins until golden. If you are roasting potatoes, put them in now. To test if the turkey is cooked, pierce the fattest part of the thigh with a skewer – the juices should run clear, not pink. If they are pink, continue to roast, checking at 10 min intervals.

Remove the turkey from the oven, transfer to a warm serving platter and rest, covered loosely with foil so it doesn’t stick to the glaze, for up to 1 hr before carving. Meanwhile, cook the stuffing balls and shallots. Increase oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Bake stuffing balls in the oven for 25-30 mins, removing the paper for the last 5 mins if they need browning.

Make the shallots. Put the shallots in a small roasting tin, toss in the oil, scatter over a few thyme and sage sprigs, and season with salt and pepper. Roast for 25-30 mins, turning half way, until shallots are nicely caramelised.

Make the gravy. Pour off any excess fat from the roasting tin but leave the juices and onions. Sprinkle in the flour, set tin over a medium heat and cook, stirring for a couple of mins to cook the flour, scraping up any sticky bits from the bottom of the tin. Gradually pour in the stock, along with any resting juices from the turkey, and continue to stir until slightly thickened. Simmer gently for about 10-15 mins or until reduced to your liking. Season with salt and pepper if needed. Strain gravy into a pan, warm through, pour into a jug and serve with the turkey. Serve the turkey surrounded with stuffing balls, roasted shallots, and thyme and sage sprigs.
chief_review: This festive turkey recipe, enriched with sage and onion flavors and finished with a honey-mustard glaze, is a showstopper for holiday gatherings. The succulent bird is stuffed with a hearty mixture of pork sausage, chestnuts, pecans, fresh herbs, and breadcrumbs, imparting depth and texture. Gently roasted shallots and onions add sweetness and savor, while the crisp skin takes on a beautiful sheen from the glaze. The buttery, nutty stuffing stands out—even without the addition of fruit—so it pairs well with traditional sides. As it contains gluten (breadcrumbs, plain flour), dairy (butter), eggs, nuts (pecans, chestnuts), and meat, it best suits those without specific dietary requirements and is ideal for traditional omnivorous feasts, especially during the holidays seeking classic flavors with a sophisticated twist.

name: Cranberry & pomegranate sauce
description: Adding pomegranate juice takes this sauce to a different dimension, plus it's super-quick and easy to make ahead
author: Good Food
directions: Tip all the ingredients into a pan and stir well to combine. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer until the cranberries start popping (about 5 mins for fresh cranberries or 8-10 mins for frozen) and turn into a runny sauce. Leave to cool before serving.
chief_review:
This cranberry and pomegranate sauce is a delightful twist on the traditional, bringing a vibrant depth from the pomegranate juice that beautifully complements the tartness of the cranberries. The demerara sugar lends a subtle caramel note, balancing the flavors without overwhelming the fruit's natural brightness. I admire its simplicity and efficiency—just three ingredients and a process that welcomes make-ahead preparation, making it an excellent choice for busy cooks.

Notably, this recipe is well-suited for both vegan and vegetarian diets, as it relies solely on fruit and plant-based sweetener, free from animal products. It's also naturally gluten-free, accommodating those with gluten sensitivities or allergies. With its jewel-like hue and layered flavors, this sauce promises to elevate any festive table or accompany roasted dishes with grace and ease.

name: Gingerbread man party cake
description: Follow our step-by-step guide to icing a fruitcake with white fondant and marzipan, then decorate with smiling gingerbread men and cute candy canes
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 1 20cm-wide Christmas cake(see 'goes well with' for recipe)
200g icing sugar, mixed with enough water to make a smooth runny icing, plus a little extra for rolling
icingbag and thin nozzle or plastic sandwich bags
directions: Make sure your cake is completely cooled, remove from its tin and peel off the baking parchment. Spread a little icing over a cake board or cake stand, then invert your cake onto it, so the bottom now becomes the top.

On a clean surface lightly dusted with a little icing sugar, roll out the marzipan to a circle large enough to cover the cake – use a piece of kitchen string to help you check. Melt the apricot jam in a small pan with 1 tbsp water, then sieve and brush a little all over your cake. Cover the cake with the marzipan, smoothing it over the surface. Trim the edges.

Brush the marzipan all over with the remaining apricot jam, then roll out 1kg of the fondant icing and, using the same directions as for the marzipan, cover your cake with the icing. Trim the edges. (See our step-by-step guide on how to cover your cake, above.)

Split the remaining icing into 3 equal lumps. Dye 1 ball of icing bright red and another gingerbread brown. Cover the icing tightly with cling film until needed. Roll out the brown icing and, using your cutter, stamp out 5 gingerbread men. Use a little of your runny icing to glue the gingerbread men to the top of the cake in a circle.

Roll your red icing and white icing into 20cm sausage shapes, squeeze them together, then continue rolling, twisting the sausage as you roll to give you a candy-cane effect. Use a piece of string to measure around the base of the cake, then cut a candy cane-coloured strip long enough to run around the base and stick it with a little runny icing. Roll the remaining candy cane-coloured icing out a little thinner, then cut into 5 short pieces and bend the ends over to make candy canes. Stick 1 of these between each gingerbread man.

Pour the remaining icing into a piping bag fitted with a small nozzle, or a sandwich bag and snip off the end – if the icing is a little runny, thicken it with extra icing sugar first. Use the icing to pipe a smiley face, eyes and 2 dots in the middle of each gingerbread man – stick edible gold balls on the dots to make buttons.
chief_review: This festive fruitcake, beautifully adorned with marzipan, fondant, and charming gingerbread decorations, is a classic choice for holiday celebrations. The recipe shines in its attention to presentation, guiding bakers through layering smooth marzipan beneath flawless white fondant, then delightfully topping with playful touches. While the result is a true showstopper, filled with nostalgic flavors and textures, it does include common allergens such as nuts (marzipan), wheat (in the fruitcake and gingerbread), and possibly eggs (depending on the base cake and gingerbread recipe used). The use of marzipan and fondant makes it suitable for a vegetarian diet, provided the food colorings are plant-based. This cake is perfect for those who appreciate a hands-on, decorative baking project and will certainly steal the spotlight on any festive table.

name: Pistachio & raspberry pithiviers
description: Frangipane and berry individual puff pastry parcels - for a special touch decorate with your guests' initials
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 tbsp plain flour, plus extra for dusting
red edible glitterand gold spray to decorate (optional)
directions: Whizz together the pistachios, sugar, butter, 1 egg and the flour in a food processor to an almost smooth frangipane.

Roll the pastry into a ball (to break up some of the layers), then roll out very thinly on a flour-dusted surface. Cut out 4 x 11cm circles and 4 x 13cm circles – you’ll probably need to re-roll once. Save all the trimmings.

Put 6 raspberries in the centre of each of the 4 smaller circles, then dollop on some pistachio frangipane. Using a small palette or round-bladed knife, spread and smooth the mixture into a dome, covering and enclosing the raspberries – leave a good 1cm of pastry clear around the edge. Beat the second egg and brush a little around the pastry edges. Carefully lay the larger circles of pastry on top, easing and pressing them over the filling bit by bit, all the way around, to squeeze out any air. Reshape the pithiviers to give a nice round dome shape, press the edges to seal, then trim any excess pastry around the edges if you need to. Brush egg over all the pithiviers.

Decorate the tops by lightly scoring a pattern with the tip of a sharp knife. Pinch the edges to seal, then crimp to give a fluted edge. If you like, brush egg over some of the rolled-out trimmings, then brush with edible glitter. Use letter cutters to cut out the initials of your guests, or any other shapes you like. Spray other trimmings with gold spray and stamp out more shapes. Decorate with the shapes and cover loosely with cling film. Chill for at least 2 hrs, but more if you can. Can be made 1 day in advance.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bake the pithiviers for 20-25 mins until golden and crisp. Serve immediately.
chief_review:
This recipe for frangipane and berry individual puff pastry parcels delivers a delightful balance of nutty richness from pistachios and the tart sweetness of raspberries. The frangipane, enriched with butter and eggs, creates a classic creamy filling nestled inside crisp, buttery puff pastry. Personalizing each parcel with your guests' initials adds a charming, bespoke touch—perfect for special occasions. 

It's worth noting these parcels are suitable for a vegetarian diet, as all ingredients are plant-based or permitted in vegetarian diets. However, due to the use of butter, eggs, wheat flour, and nuts, they are not suitable for vegan, gluten-free, or nut-free diets. Overall, a show-stopping dessert both in flavor and presentation, guaranteed to impress guests with minimal effort and maximum elegance.

name: Butternut, chestnut & lentil cake
description: A healthy meal but not worth the effort to make. I totally agree with the other user: This was bland and fairly tasteless. Having read Kiwitifosi's review, I even added smoked paprika, nuts, caramelised onions and a layer of roasted butternut squash under the thin slices on the top. This was all in vein as it was still not great - too many lentils and chestnuts.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 3 tbsp sunflower oil, plus extra for greasing
15g pack of sage, 12 leaves reserved, rest finely chopped
2 sprigs rosemary, leaves stripped and chopped, plus a few springs to serve
2 x 400g cans brown lentils, rinsed and drained
directions: First, use a veg peeler to peel the butternut squash and heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Then using, a large, sharp knife cut a few 1cm thick ring-slices from the bulbous end, and a few small solid slices from the top end. Set aside the slices, and dice the rest into 1-2cm chunks. Toss the chunks with 1 tbsp of the sunflower oil on a baking parchment-lined tray and roast for 20-30 mins until tender and golden.

Meanwhile prepare the tin. It’s worth taking some time to do this, as it’ll be the top of your cake in the end – and the bit you want to look impressive! Line the base of a deep, round, 25cm tin with a sheet of baking parchment. Brush the new base and sides with some oil, then start to arrange the rings in the base. You want to get in as many as you can, overlapping a bit like the Olympic rings. Snuggle in as many flat as you can, then sit your overlapping ones on top, cutting out bits of the squash, so they’ll also sit flat too. Any leftover trimmings, put in a microwave-proof bowl with a splash of water, cover with cling film and microwave on High at 2 min intervals until tender – around 5-6 minutes.

In a separate pan, soften the onion in the last 2 tbsp of sunflower oil, over a very low heat so it doesn’t brown. Stir in the chopped sage, half the rosemary, and the garlic and mace, and cook for another few mins until fragrant. Mix the ground chia seeds or linseeds with 4 tbsp of water, and set aside with the cooling onions, until gluey.

Meanwhile, roughly chop half the chestnuts but keep them chunky. Put the other half in a food processor with half the lentils, the microwaved squash and one-third of the roasted squash. Pulse to a mashed mixture. Tip this into a large mixing bowl with the softened onions, breadcrumbs, ground seed mixture and 1 tsp salt. Mash everything together really well to thoroughly mix, then more gently stir in the chopped chestnuts, followed by the whole lentils, and finally the remaining roasted squash chunks. Carefully press this mixture around and over the squash rings in the prepared tin. Level off the top, making sure it is tightly packed, then cover with foil.
To bake, heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the cake (still foil covered), into the oven on a middle shelf and bake for 1 hr.

To serve, heat the rapeseed oil in a small frying pan and sizzle the reserved sage leaves with the remaining rosemary sprigs for a minute. Loosen around the sides of the cake with a round-bladed knife, then sit a serving plate inverted on top, and carefully flip the plate to turn out the cake. Spoon over the sizzled sage and rosemary leaves and herby oil, and serve at the table – for cutting into wedges in front of everyone.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a bounty of wholesome ingredients, including butternut squash, lentils, chestnuts, and a fragrant blend of fresh herbs. It’s hearty and well-intentioned, offering ample fiber and nutrients. The absence of animal products makes it suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Utilizing ground chia or flaxseeds as a binder brilliantly accommodates those avoiding eggs, and the omission of wheat flour caters to dairy-free needs—though it’s not gluten-free due to the wholemeal breadcrumbs. However, despite the nutrient profile, the resulting dish struggles with blandness, even after layering in additional flavors like smoked paprika and caramelized onions. Texture-wise, the dominance of lentils and chestnuts creates a dense bite that could use contrast. For those seeking a robust centerpiece for a plant-based menu, it holds merit, but, as noted, the flavor payoff may not justify the preparation involved.

name: Cider-braised cabbage & leek hotpot
description: Add a bit of colour to this versatile and healthy side with some sliced carrots
author: Good Food
directions: Melt the butter in a large pan, tip in the leeks and sweat for 5 mins, stirring to break up, until they soften. Stir in the cabbage, then pour over the cider. Turn up the heat and wilt the cabbage for a few mins. Season, and serve immediately.
chief_review: This vibrant and hearty side dish balances the sweet earthiness of leeks and carrots with the gentle bitterness of Savoy cabbage, all brought together by the richness of butter and the subtle tang of dry cider. It’s a wonderful accompaniment to roasted meats or as part of a larger vegetable spread. The use of butter gives a silky finish, and the cider provides a pleasing depth of flavor that brightens the dish. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe delivers both on nutrition and taste, offering ample fiber and vitamins from the vegetables. For those seeking a classic, comforting side with a contemporary twist, this recipe stands out as a colorful and satisfying addition to the table.

name: Sticky roasted parsnips, Chantenay carrots & apples
description: Glaze your Christmas root vegetables with honey and coriander seeds, then add apple quarters and roast for an extra-special side dish
author: Jenny White
ingredients: 12 small parsnips, peeled and halved lengthways
4 red eating apples, cored and quartered
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the parsnips and carrots in a large roasting tin. Mix the oil, honey and coriander seeds together with some seasoning and spoon over the vegetables, turning them to coat, then roast for 20 mins.
Add the apples to the tin and cook for a further 20 mins until the vegetables are golden and just tender.
chief_review: This festive side dish elevates classic root vegetables with a sophisticated glaze of honey and crushed coriander seeds. Roasting parsnips and Cantenay carrots with olive oil ensures tender interiors and caramelized edges, while the addition of apple quarters introduces a subtle sweetness and tart balance. The coriander seeds add aromatic complexity that complements both the earthy roots and fruit. Suitable for vegetarians and naturally gluten-free, this recipe makes for an elegant and colorful accompaniment to any holiday table. The harmonious blend of sweetness, spice, and texture is sure to impress guests and brighten your seasonal spread.

name: Mango & passion fruit pavlova roulade
description: A slightly wicked dessert packed full of fruit and cream - best served half-frozen
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 2 tsp white wine vinegar or cider vinegar
small handful of pistachios, sliced lengthways
directions: Heat oven to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1. Line a 33cm x 23cm Swiss roll tin with baking parchment. For the meringue, mix together the cornflour, coffee and vinegar, and set aside. Whisk the egg whites to stiff peaks, then gradually beat in the sugar, a spoonful at a time, until quite thick. Whisk in the coffee mix.
Spoon the meringue onto the paper and gently spread, giving the top a few swirls. Scatter over the pistachios. Bake for 35-40 mins until it feels crisp.

Meanwhile, make the filling. Slice the mango either side of the stone, peel, then finely chop the flesh. Beat the mascarpone, then stir in the mango. Whip the cream until thick and fold into the mango mix. Halve the passion fruit, scoop out the inside and set aside.

When the meringue is cooked, leave in the tin for 10 mins, then lift out and put on a cooling rack, paper-side down. Dust a sheet of baking parchment with icing sugar and, when the meringue is cold, tip it on, paper side up. Peel off the lining paper and spread the cream over. Drizzle over the passion fruit and roll up using the paper as a guide. Open-freeze (see 'Try' below) on a board, wrap in foil and freeze for up to 1 month.
To serve, unwrap and thaw in the fridge for about 1 hr. Sift with icing sugar and serve in slices.
chief_review: This indulgent dessert harmoniously balances the sweetness of tropical mango and passion fruit with the richness of mascarpone and double cream, while a hint of coffee adds unexpected depth. The cracked meringue base, given lift by whipped egg whites and a touch of vinegar, creates a delightfully airy texture. Pistachios scattered atop provide a pleasing crunch and a subtle nuttiness. Half-freezing enhances the contrast between the velvety cream layer and crisp meringue, making every bite a pleasure. This recipe caters generously to gluten-free requirements, as there are no wheat-based ingredients. However, it’s best avoided by those with nut or dairy allergies. A beautiful, elevated dessert—perfect for impressing guests on a special occasion.

name: Black olive & goat's cheese tartlets
description: Stylish veggie bite-sized treats for a posh party
author: John Torode
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Unwrap the puff pastry and, using a 5cm cutter, cut out 20 rounds (you may need to re-roll the pastry trimmings to get 20 circles). Now use a slightly smaller cutter to make a light dent in the pastry, creating a rim. Use a fork to make a few pricks in the centre of the pastry; this will stop it from rising, while letting the outer rim puff up.

Place the pastry discs on a baking sheet and brush all over with the egg. Crumble the goat’s cheese in the centre of each tartlet and scatter over the olives. Can be made up to this point up to 2 days ahead and kept in the fridge. Cook for 15-18 mins until the pastry is puffed and golden brown. Sprinkle with parsley before serving.
chief_review: These stylish veggie bite-sized treats showcase an elegant combination of creamy goat's cheese and briny black olives atop flaky, golden puff pastry. The use of fresh parsley adds a welcome brightness and color to each morsel. With the puff pastry providing delicate layers and the cheese a luxurious tang, these are perfectly balanced for a sophisticated party spread. As the recipe is meat-free, it is well-suited for vegetarians. The preparation is simple yet delivers impressive results, making it ideal for entertaining or special occasions.

name: Scandinavian roast turkey with prune & juniper stuffing & caramelised apples
description: Adding lingonberry jam or redcurrant sauce to your Turkey cooking juices gives traditional gravy a touch of sweetness
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g butter, plus extra for the tray and paper
2 eating apples, peeled, cored and finely chopped
1 heaped tbsp lingonberry jam or redcurrant jelly
2 eating apples, cored and each cut into 8 wedges
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Rinse the turkey inside and out, then pat dry with kitchen paper.
