Weigh the turkey to calculate the cooking time, allowing 40 mins per kg for the first 4kg, then 45 mins for each 1kg over that weight. Cut 1 onion into quarters and the other into 6 wedges. Finely grate 1⁄2 tsp orange zest from the orange and set aside for the stuffing. Quarter the orange and tuck it with the onion quarters into the turkey cavity. Rub the turkey all over with the butter, then season with salt and pepper. Put the onion wedges and carrot chunks in the middle of a large roasting tin and sit the turkey on top. Cover with a loose tent of foil, then roast following your calculated time.

Make the stuffing. Butter a 28 x 18 x 3cm deep baking tray and crush the juniper berries using a pestle and mortar. Melt the butter in a large frying pan, tip in the onions, garlic and celery, and fry for about 12-15 mins until softened and just starting to turn golden. Stir in the crushed juniper berries, then remove the pan from the heat. Stir in the breadcrumbs, apples, prunes, most of the parsley (reserve a small handful, to garnish), the reserved orange zest and the beaten eggs. Season with salt and pepper. Spoon the stuffing loosely into the baking tray, pat it down gently (don’t pack it down) then lay a piece of buttered baking parchment on top. Set aside. Can be made 1 day ahead and chilled.

Thirty mins before the end of the cooking time, remove the turkey and increase oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the foil, baste the turkey, then return to the oven for a further 30 mins until golden. If you are roasting potatoes put them in now. To test if turkey is cooked, pierce the fattest part of the thigh with a skewer – the juices should run clear, not pink. If they are pink, continue to roast, checking at 10 min intervals.

Remove the turkey from the oven, transfer to a warm serving platter and rest, covered loosely with foil, for up to 1 hr before carving. Meanwhile, cook the stuffing, and make apple wedges and gravy. Increase oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Bake the stuffing for 30 mins, then remove paper and bake for a further 10 mins to brown the top.

Make the gravy, pour off any excess fat from the roasting tin, leave the juices and onions, and discard the carrot. Stir the wine and lingonberry jam or redcurrant jelly into the tin, scraping up any sticky bits from the bottom. Set the tin over a high heat and bring to the boil, then boil rapidly for 8-10 mins until reduced by half. Pour in the stock along with any resting juices from the turkey, and simmer for 10-15 mins or until reduced to your liking (this makes a slightly thinner gravy). Season, if needed.

Make the apple wedges. Melt the butter in a large non-stick frying pan. Tip in the almonds and apples, and fry over a medium heat for about 5-8 mins, moving them around often, until the almonds are toasted and the apples golden and softened, but still holding their shape. Don’t worry if the butter starts to turn a nutty brown, it just adds to the flavour.

To serve, strain the gravy into a pan, warm through, then pour into a jug. Scatter the stuffing with the reserved parsley and cut into squares or wedges. Garnish the turkey with the apples, nuts and flat-leaf parsley sprigs, and serve everything together.
chief_review:
This recipe elevates the classic turkey roast with a Scandinavian twist, infusing the gravy with the unique tartness of lingonberry jam or redcurrant jelly. The combination of juniper berries, apples, parsley, and prunes in the stuffing offers a pleasing contrast of savory and sweet notes, while whole almonds provide a delightful crunch. Using turkey as the centerpiece makes it a great choice for festive gatherings.

The use of fresh white breadcrumbs means this recipe is not suitable for gluten-free diets, but it will suit those following a standard omnivorous diet. Nuts (almonds) and eggs are present, so care should be taken for those with allergies. The layers of fruit, aromatic vegetables, and herbs bring complexity to both flavor and texture, making this dish a well-rounded and memorable addition to any celebratory table.

name: Roast Parmesan parsnips
description: For a twist on a favourite side dish, coat parsnips in corn and grated Italian cheese to ensure a tasty, crunchy finish
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Mix together the polenta, Parmesan and nutmeg, and set aside. Bring a pan of salted water to the boil, tip in the parsnips and cook for 6 mins or until just tender. Drain. While parsnips are still hot, toss with the Parmesan mixture to coat.

Set a roasting tin over the hob and heat the oil. Add the parsnips and turn to coat in the oil. Put the tin in the oven and roast for 15 mins, then turn the parsnips over and cook for 15 mins more until golden.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a delightful, elevated take on classic roasted parsnips. Coating the parsnips in polenta and parmesan creates a satisfyingly crisp crust, while the nutmeg lends subtle warmth and depth. Using olive oil keeps the dish light and allows the natural sweetness of the parsnips to shine through. The inclusion of polenta instead of wheat flour makes this recipe suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided the polenta is certified gluten-free. It’s also a great fit for vegetarians, as parmesan (make sure it’s a vegetarian version) brings a rich, savory flavor without the need for meat. Serve as an impressive side for a holiday feast or alongside simple roasted meats for a comforting meal.

name: Bok choi with oyster sauce & chilli
description: John Torode's speedy side makes the most of Oriental cabbage, served with fragrant spices
author: John Torode
ingredients: 6 heads bok choi, split in half lengthways, or 16 baby bok choi
1 long red chilli, deseeded and finely sliced
directions: Heat the oil in a wok, add the garlic and fry for 2 mins. Tip in the bok choi and stir well over the heat for 4 mins until it wilts. Pour in the oyster sauce, soy and 50ml water. Simmer for a further 3 mins, then scatter over the chilli to serve.
chief_review: John Torode’s bok choi side is a vibrant celebration of texture and flavor, perfectly balancing tender greens with pungent garlic and the subtle heat of red chilli. The stir-fry approach maintains the vegetable’s crispness, while the blend of oyster and soy sauce creates a glossy, umami-rich finish that complements the sweetness of bok choi. The use of vegetable oil keeps the dish light, and the cook time is minimal—a bonus for those seeking a speedy, flavorful addition to any meal. This recipe would suit pescatarian lifestyles, as it avoids meat and the oyster sauce is generally made from shellfish. However, it’s not vegan or vegetarian due to the presence of oyster sauce. For a gluten-free option, ensure the soy sauce used is certified gluten free. In all, a delightful, quick Asian-inspired side with well-balanced flavors and pleasing visual appeal.

name: Salted fruit ’n’ nut bark
description: This super-simple slab of swirled dark and white chocolate is studded with chopped mixed nuts and dried fruit - break into chunky shards and pop in a homemade hamper as an edible gift
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 50g mixed nuts(we used pecans, cashews, pistachios and macadamia nuts), chopped into chunky pieces
50g dried fruit(we used sultanas, cranberries and chopped apricots)
directions: Melt the dark and white chocolate in separate bowls suspended over pans of gently simmering water, stirring every now and then. Meanwhile, line a large baking tray with baking parchment. Leave the chocolate to cool for 10 mins.

Pour the dark chocolate onto the tray and spread it into a rectangle, roughly 20 x 25cm. Drizzle over the white chocolate and create a swirled pattern by dragging a cocktail stick back and forth across the chocolate. Scatter over the nuts, fruit and sea salt, then leave somewhere cool to set.
Break into shards or leave whole, wrap in cellophane or pack into a box, then tie up with ribbon. Will keep for 2 weeks.
chief_review:
This elegant chocolate slab is a visually striking and effortlessly impressive treat. The deep, bittersweet notes of the dark chocolate blend beautifully with the creamy sweetness of white chocolate, while the chunky mixed nuts add both crunch and a savory, buttery dimension. The freeze-dried raspberries and assorted dried fruits bring bursts of tanginess and chew, making each bite complex and satisfying. A sprinkle of sea salt flakes heightens all the flavors, balancing sweetness and elevating the overall profile. 

With no animal-derived gelatin or obvious gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians and can suit a gluten-free diet with careful selection of dried fruit brands. Its nut content, however, makes it unsuitable for those with tree nut allergies. Perfect for gifting or as a festive centerpiece, this recipe is as practical as it is luxurious.

name: Dressed crab cups
description: A simple, stylish canapé of shellfish with Dijon mustard and lemon, served in individual lettuce cups
author: Good Food
directions: Mix the crabmeat with the mayonnaise, mustard, lemon juice, salt and a good grinding of black pepper. Chill for up to a day.
To serve, arrange the leaves from the lettuce to form a cup on your board and pile the crab in the centre of the lettuce cup.
chief_review: This canapé brilliantly showcases delicate white crabmeat, lightly bound with creamy mayonnaise and lifted by the gentle heat of Dijon mustard and brightness of fresh lemon juice. Serving it in crisp Little Gem lettuce cups adds a refreshing crunch and an elegant touch, making this dish as visually appealing as it is delicious. The use of lettuce instead of bread makes the dish naturally gluten-free, while the absence of meat other than shellfish ensures it is suitable for pescatarians. With its minimal ingredients, this canapé is straightforward to prepare and celebrates the fresh flavours of the sea without distraction—a sophisticated starter or party bite that will impress guests with both flavour and presentation.

name: Steamed leeks & peas with herby vinaigrette
description: Honey, mustard and herbs add flavour to simple steamed vegetables - a healthy side dish that's low fat and easy to make in just 15 minutes
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Trim the outer leaves from the leeks and cut off the top down to where the leaves split. Cut the leeks into 3-4 chunks, then wash really well to remove any grit. Heat a steamer, add the leeks and cook for 8 mins. Tip in the peas and cook for 2-3 mins more until both are tender.
Meanwhile, whisk the oil, vinegar, honey, mustard and seasoning together in a serving bowl to make the vinaigrette. Add the hot vegetables and herbs, and mix well.
chief_review: This vibrant recipe brings a fresh twist to simple steamed vegetables. The combination of honey and Dijon mustard creates a balanced dressing that lifts the sweetness of leeks and peas, while parsley and mint add a bright, aromatic finish. Olive oil lends richness without overwhelming the dish, keeping it light and heart-healthy. With no dairy or meat, it’s ideally suited for vegetarians and those seeking gluten-free options, provided the Dijon mustard used is gluten-free. This side dish is an excellent choice for anyone desiring a low-fat, nutrient-packed addition to their meal. Quick to prepare and elegant on the plate, it’s a testament to how simple ingredients can deliver outstanding flavor.

name: Roast parsnips with maple syrup & rosemary
description: Bring out the sweetness of this classic roast accompaniment with maple syrup and sprigs of rosemary for a low-fat yet delicious side dish
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Halve the parsnips down their length (as they are not too big, the cores shouldn’t be woody so there is no need to remove them), then cut each half into 3 equal pieces. To do this, cut off the bottom and halve the top down the length. Boil for 5 mins, then drain well and toss with the flour.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the oil in a large roasting tin and heat in the oven for 5 mins. Add the parsnips, turn them in the oil and give the tin a shake so that all the parsnips are in contact with the base of the tin. Roast for 30 mins, turning once, until golden. Tip onto a platter, drizzle with the maple syrup and scatter with rosemary and salt.
chief_review: This roasted parsnip recipe is a delightful, low-fat side dish that balances natural sweetness with herbal notes from rosemary. The maple syrup caramelizes beautifully in the oven, complementing the earthy flavor of the parsnips, while the flour helps develop a crisp, golden exterior. The use of olive or rapeseed oil ensures a healthier fat profile, making the dish heart-friendly. It’s a vegetarian option that can easily be made vegan, as it contains no animal products. Additionally, as long as a gluten-free flour is substituted for plain flour, it slides seamlessly into a gluten-free diet. Overall, this is a beautifully simple, nutritious side perfect for autumn and winter roasts.

name: Lasagne recipe kit
description: Package up a homemade lasagne kit to give as a gift to those who need a culinary confidence boost or keen cooks who need a break from the kitchen
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 2 x 400g tin whole cherry tomatoes(I used Biona organic)
gift tagsand a pen, for labelling
directions: Open the pack of lasagne sheets and divide between two large pieces of greaseproof paper. Wrap into 2 parcels and secure with sticky tape then wrap in wrapping paper and tie with string or ribbon, adding a label, if you like. Place each parcel into a lasagne dish along with a tin of tomatoes and a bottle of wine.

To make the seasoning sachet, place the dried mushrooms into a small food processor. Blitz until finely chopped then transfer to a small bowl. Stir in the remaining sachet ingredients and mix well then divide between 2 pieces of tin foil. Fold the foil parcels up to contain the mushroom and spice mix inside then wrap each one in wrapping paper. Label and place into the lasagne dishes.

Sterilise your jars and keep warm until needed (see tip). Heat the olive oil in a saucepan over a low heat then add the onion and cook gently for 20 mins until really soft. Stir in the garlic and heat for a further 5 mins. Divide the hot onions between the smaller jars, seal and leave to cool.

Now make the béchamel sauce. In a large saucepan, melt the butter over a medium heat. Add the flour and mix really well. Add the milk gradually until you have a smooth sauce then add the bay leaves. Simmer gently and allow to thicken, then season well with salt, black pepper and nutmeg. Divide between the large jars making sure a bay leaf goes into each one. Seal, leave to cool then label as ‘Béchamel sauce’. Once cool, refrigerate the jars until needed then add one to each lasagne dish along with a pack of Parmesan. Write or print out the recipe below and fix to a gift tag.
chief_review:
This lasagne kit is a thoughtful gift for anyone who loves comforting Italian classics, effortlessly combining convenience with gourmet flair. The recipe uses rich tomato and red wine for depth, complemented by wild mushrooms and spices for an aromatic, nuanced ragù. The classic béchamel is creamy thanks to whole milk and butter, while generous parmesan ensures a savory finish. 

Vegetarian-friendly, this kit contains no meat, providing robust flavor with plant-based ingredients. However, note that it includes dairy (milk, butter, parmesan) and gluten (wheat flour, lasagne sheets), making it unsuitable for vegans and those with dairy or gluten sensitivities. Parmesan may not always be strictly vegetarian due to rennet, so select a vegetarian cheese if needed. 

Overall, this lasagne kit delivers a balanced, warming meal, perfect for cozy evenings and sure to delight any home cook seeking a touch of culinary confidence.

name: Chinon apple tarts
description: These little French tarts are wonderfully buttery and crisp, glazed with a red wine jelly - the perfect end to a special supper for two
author: Alex Hollywood
ingredients: ½ split vanilla pod, seeds scraped out
3 tbsp red wine jelly(see above recipe)
3 cardamom pods, pods discarded and seeds ground
directions: To make the red wine jelly, put the red wine, jam sugar, star anise, clove, cinnamon stick, allspice, split vanilla pod and seeds in a medium saucepan. Stir together, then heat gently to dissolve the sugar. Turn up the heat and boil for 20 mins until reduced and syrupy. Strain into a small, sterilised jam jar and leave to cool completely. Will keep in the fridge for up to 1 month.

Take the pastry out of the fridge and leave at room temperature for 10 mins, then unroll. Heat the grill to high and heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Cut out 2 x 13cm circles of pastry, using a plate as a guide, and place on a non-stick baking sheet. Sprinkle each circle with 1 tbsp sugar and grill for 5 mins to caramelise, watching carefully so that the sugar doesn’t burn. Remove from the grill. Can be done a few hours ahead, and left, covered, out of the fridge.

Peel, quarter and core the apples, cut into 2mm-thin slices and arrange on top of the pastry. Sprinkle over the remaining sugar and pop in the oven for 20-25 mins until the pastry is cooked through and golden, and the apples are softened. Remove and allow to cool slightly. Warm 3 tbsp of the red wine jelly in a small pan over a low heat with 1 tsp water to make it a little more runny, then brush over the top of the tarts.
Tip the crème fraîche into a bowl, sift over the icing sugar and cardamom, and mix together. Carefully lift the warm tarts onto serving plates and serve with the cardamom crème fraîche.
chief_review: This elegant French tart is a celebration of classic pâtisserie technique and refined flavors. The deep spiced notes of red wine jelly pair beautifully with the sweet-tart Pink Lady apples, while the all-butter puff pastry delivers the shattering crispness one expects in a well-crafted tart. The addition of aromatic spices, like star anise and cardamom, elevates the jelly glaze to a sophisticated complement for the fruit. Crème fraîche, delicately sweetened and peppered with ground cardamom, adds a luscious and tangy finish. This recipe is a fine choice for vegetarians, as it contains no gelatine or animal-based thickeners, using only fruit, spices, dairy, and pastry. For dinner parties or intimate suppers, this tart provides both visual elegance and satisfying complexity on the palate.

name: Snowman cake
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 225g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
ready-to-roll icing(we used a mixed pack green, blue, orange and black, or you can use white fondant icing mixed with food colouring)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter and line the bases of two 18-19cm cake tins with baking parchment.
Beat the butter and sugar with an electric

until pale and fluffy. Add the eggs, one at a time, and beat well, scraping down the sides of the bowl after each addition. Add the lemon zest, vanilla, flour, milk and a pinch of salt and blend until just combined, then evenly divide the mixture between the tins.
Bake in the centre of the oven for 25-30 mins until a skewer inserted into the middle of each cake comes out clean. Cool the cakes in their tins for 10 mins, then turn out onto a
and leave to cool completely.

To make the buttercream, put the butter in a large bowl and beat with an electric whisk until fluffy. Add the icing sugar 2-3 tbsp at a time until it is all incorporated, adding the vanilla and milk halfway through. Sandwich the cakes together with a little of the buttercream and put on a board. Use the remaining buttercream to cover the sides and top of the cake. Chill for 30 mins.
To decorate,

the white fondant icing on a surface lightly dusted with icing sugar until large enough to cover the top and sides of the cake. Drape the fondant icing over the cake and carefully mould to fit. Trim off any excess, wrap and set aside.

Roll out the green icing and cut out a semi-circle, using the base of the cake tin as a guide; this will be the snowman’s hat. Brush one side with a little water and stick on the cake. Cut a strip of green icing and make some markings to make it look like the band of a hat, then trim to the correct length and stick on.

To make the nose, shape a round, flat lump from the orange icing. Mark a smile by gently pressing the rim of a water glass into the fondant. Cut out two circles from the black icing for the eyes, then add a small circle of white icing (from the offcuts) to make the eyes appear to sparkle. To make the scarf, wrap a strip of the blue icing around the base of the cake, then use a knife to add cuts for the fringe. Will keep for up to a week in an airtight container in a cool place.
chief_review:
This recipe creates a classic, indulgent cake layered with both buttercream and fondant icing, showcasing a delightful balance of tender sponge and sweet decoration. With wholesome butter, rich eggs, and a hint of lemon zest, the flavor profile is traditional yet refreshing, while the vanilla extract brings warmth and depth. The inclusion of self-raising flour ensures a light, airy crumb. Ideal for celebratory occasions, this bake demands precision but rewards with impressive results.

Suitable for vegetarians, the recipe does not contain meat, fish, or animal-derived gels. However, it does include dairy and eggs; those following a strict vegan or dairy-free diet would need substantial substitutions. Those with gluten intolerance or allergies should note the use of wheat-based self-raising flour, and those with nut allergies will find this recipe generally safe, provided all added decorations are nut-free.

name: Bloody Mary scrambled eggs & smoked salmon
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: ½ tsp Tabascoplus extra to serve, (optional)
½ tsp Worcestershire sauce, plus extra to serve (optional)
4 slices wholemeal bread, toasted and buttered
directions: Beat together the eggs, milk, Tabasco, Worcestershire sauce and some seasoning in a jug. Heat the oil in a large non-stick pan over a low heat and pour in the egg mix. Cook, stirring, until it is done around the edges and slightly runny in the middle. Then tip in the tomatoes and warm through for 1 min until the eggs have finished cooking.

Top the toast with the scrambled eggs and chives, and place the smoked salmon on the side with a wedge of lemon to squeeze over. Drizzle over extra Tabasco and Worcestershire sauce, if you like it with an extra kick.
chief_review:
This recipe offers a delightful, protein-packed breakfast or brunch, elegantly balancing creamy scrambled eggs with the savory richness of smoked salmon and the zing of cherry tomatoes, chives, and a hint of spice from Tabasco. Wholemeal toast provides a hearty base and fiber, while optional lemon wedges add freshness. 

Thanks to its emphasis on eggs, salmon, and bread, this dish is well-suited for pescatarians and can be a nutritious choice for those seeking heart-healthy omega-3s from the salmon. It is not suitable for a vegan or dairy-free diet due to the inclusion of eggs, milk, and buttered toast. Additionally, the use of wholemeal bread means it is unsuitable for those requiring gluten-free options. For vegetarians, consider omitting the salmon or replacing it with a non-meat protein. Overall, an easy yet sophisticated dish that would impress at any brunch table.

name: Membrillo, chorizo & cheddar toastie
description:
Very good, easy & quick, served with some salad.
However, a bit greasy for our tastes: you definitely don't need that much mayo.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 thick slices sourdoughor good-quality white bread
50g mature cheddar, grated (or another strong, hard or melty cheese leftover from the Christmas cheeseboard)
directions: Heat a large frying pan. Spread the membrillo paste over one slice of bread (you might need to mash it first with 1 tsp water if it’s very firm), top with the chorizo and cheese, and sandwich with the other slice. Spread the outside of both pieces of bread with mayo, and press on the sage leaves.

Heat the oil in the pan and cook the toastie for 2-3 mins each side, squashing with a fish slice every now and then, until the bread is crisp and golden and the cheese has melted. Cut in half to serve.
chief_review: This sandwich recipe is a quick and flavorful choice for a savory meal. The combination of membrillo and strong cheese adds a delightful sweet-salty balance, while chorizo and sage lend depth and aromatic richness. Using less mayonnaise would help cut the richness, allowing the other ingredients to shine without being overpowered by grease. Serving it with a salad provides a refreshing contrast and some needed lightness. Given the inclusion of chorizo and dairy, this recipe suits a standard omnivorous diet, but it's not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. Those with gluten or dairy allergies should also avoid it due to the bread and cheese. Overall, it makes for an indulgent, satisfying treat when prepared with moderation—especially perfect for using up leftover cheese.

name: Teriyaki tempeh with peanut dip
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 1 lime, ½ juiced, ½ cut into wedges to serve
directions: First, make the dipping sauce. Mix all the ingredients except for the lime wedges, adding a splash of water to loosen if it is too thick. Season and set aside. Can be made up to a day in advance and kept in the fridge.

Cut the tempeh into 16 slices. Heat the oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat. Fry the slices of tempeh for around 3 mins each side. Add the teriyaki sauce to the pan, and turn the slices to coat them. Let it bubble away for 1-2 mins – you’re looking for the tempeh to be well covered and sticky.

Tip the sesame seeds into a cup. Take the sticky slices of tempeh and push a wooden skewer into each (don’t push them down too far). Dip one end of the tempeh into the sesame seeds, then transfer to a serving platter with the dipping sauce in a bowl and the lime wedges on the side.
chief_review: This recipe showcases tempeh as the star ingredient, marinated in teriyaki and paired with a creamy peanut-coconut sauce, accented by a touch of lime and chili. The use of soy or tamari allows flexibility for those requiring gluten-free options. Its reliance on plant-based proteins and dairy-free coconut milk makes it highly suitable for both vegans and vegetarians. Toasted sesame seeds add a lovely crunch and depth, while the peanut butter enriches the dish with a nutty savoriness. The balance of spicy, sweet, and tangy notes results in a vibrant and satisfying meal, perfect for those following plant-based diets or looking for a robust, protein-forward alternative. Serve with fresh lime wedges to elevate the flavors just before eating.

name: Simple snow sparkle cake
description: This crunchy, sugar-snow topping is an easy way to transform a humble fruitcake into a celebration centrepiece
author: Cassie Best
directions: Once the cake has been removed from the oven, increase the heat to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Leave the cake in its tin. Put the sugar cubes in a large bowl and crush with the end of a rolling pin to a sugary rubble. Mix in the preserving sugar, pearly balls and egg white – it should have the texture of wet sand. Tip the mixture on top of the cake and level the surface. Bake the cake for 5 mins to set the sugary crust, then remove and leave to cool.

Once completely cooled, remove from the tin and peel off the baking parchment. Sprinkle the top with edible glitter, tie ribbons around the side and decorate with your favourite figurines, if you like.
chief_review: This dazzling sugar-snow topping turns any basic fruitcake into a festive masterpiece. The combination of white and preserving sugar creates both crunch and sparkle, while edible pearly balls and silver glitter add a striking, celebratory finish. Using a lightly whisked egg white helps the decorative sugar elements adhere, producing an elegant texture. The ribbon and optional decorative accents make presentation effortless, perfect for impressing guests during the holidays. Notably, this recipe contains no wheat or dairy, making it suitable for gluten-free and lactose-free diets, though it does include egg, so it’s not vegan or egg-free. This transformation is quick, visually impressive, and easily adaptable for creative expression—ideal for busy holiday hosts seeking to elevate a traditional cake without fuss.

name: Braised sea bass with spinach
description: This simple but festive recipe will see you cooking sea bass in no time at all
author: Curtis Stone
ingredients: 2 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, plus extra for drizzling
250g cherry or baby plum tomato, halved
12 large black olives, stoned and roughly chopped
2 whole sea bass, about 600-700g/1lb 5oz-1lb-9oz each, gutted, scaled and cleaned (get your fishmonger to do this)
directions: Heat the grill to high. Put the peppers, skin side up, on a baking tray, then pop them under the hot grill for about 10 mins until the skins blister and blacken. Drop them into a bowl, cover with some cling film and leave until cool enough to handle. Peel away and discard the skins, then roughly chop the peppers.

Heat the oil over a low-ish heat in a sturdy roasting tin or in a shallow pan that has a lid and is large enough to fit both fish. Throw in the shallots and garlic and sweat briefly until soft. Stir in the tomatoes, peppers, capers, olives and half the basil leaves, then sweat for a few mins until the tomatoes soften. Pour in the wine and tomato juice. Stir and gently simmer for 10-15 mins, adding a splash of water if the sauce becomes a bit dry.

While the sauce is simmering, slash each side of the fish a few times. When the sauce is ready lay the fish on top, season if you want to and cover with a lid (cover with foil if you are using a roasting tray). Leave to cook on a low heat for 12-15 mins until the flesh feels firm when pressed.

While the fish is cooking, melt the butter in a large pan, then fry the spinach until wilted, season if you like and divide the spinach between two serving dishes. Lift the fish carefully from the pan and place on top of the spinach, neatly drizzle some of the sauce round the fish, scatter the remaining basil on top and drizzle everything with extra-virgin olive oil. Serve with some ribbon shaped pasta, like tagliatelle or pappardelle, with the remaining sauce in a bowl or side dish.
chief_review:
This sea bass recipe is a vibrant celebration of Mediterranean flavors, pairing perfectly cooked fish with a colorful medley of roasted peppers, tomatoes, olives, and capers. The use of aromatic shallots, garlic, and basil, alongside a splash of white wine and tomato juice, creates a beautifully balanced sauce that enhances the delicate sea bass without overpowering it. The inclusion of spinach adds both texture and a lovely earthy note, making the dish both visually appealing and satisfying. 

With no gluten-containing ingredients and a reliance on fresh vegetables, olive oil, and fish, this recipe is ideal for gluten-free diets and those seeking nutritious, wholesome meals. It’s also well-suited for pescatarians. The method is straightforward, festive, and sure to impress both at a weeknight dinner or special occasion.

name: Salmon, fennel & lime plates
description: This is a fresh and light way to serve up smoked salmon - ideal as a last minute starter
author: Good Food
directions: Divide the smoked salmon between 4 plates. Toss the fennel, red onion, lime juice, white wine vinegar, olive oil and a little black pepper. Arrange over the salmon and serve.
chief_review:
This smoked salmon starter is a thoughtful balance of freshness and elegance. The natural richness of smoked salmon pairs wonderfully with the crisp, aniseed notes of finely sliced fennel and the subtle bite of red onion. The dressing—lime juice, white wine vinegar, and olive oil—cuts through the oiliness, infusing the dish with brightness without overpowering the main ingredients. The black pepper serves as a simple yet effective seasoning, elevating the overall flavor profile.

Ideal for pescatarians and those following a gluten-free diet, the recipe contains no wheat, dairy, or eggs—making it suitable for some common food allergies. It's light and refreshing, perfect as a quick starter when guests arrive unexpectedly. Preparation is hassle-free and the result is visually appealing, showcasing a modern approach to classic smoked salmon.

name: Fruity mincemeat with almonds
description: Give your mince pies an edge this year with a nutty filling - ready in just 20 minutes
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 4 Bramley apples, peeled, cored and grated
100g shredded suetor light shredded vegetable suet
directions: Put the grated apple and any juices, sugar, and orange and lemon zests and juices into a large saucepan. Bring gently to a simmer, stirring until the sugar has melted. Turn off the heat and stir in the spices, dried fruit and brandy. Set aside until cool.
Once cool, stir in the almonds and suet. Divide between sterilised jars or plastic containers for the freezer.
chief_review: This festive mince pie recipe offers a delightful twist with its nutty filling and aromatic spices. The use of Bramley apples brings a pleasant tartness, while the combination of orange and lemon zest adds fresh, citrusy notes. Dried cranberries, sultanas, raisins, and currants deliver contrasting textures and natural sweetness, beautifully balanced by the deep, caramel tones of light muscovado sugar. The inclusion of flaked almonds provides a wonderful crunch and elevates both flavor and mouthfeel. With the addition of brandy, the filling exudes a classic richness fit for holiday celebrations. Opting for light shredded vegetable suet makes this recipe suitable for vegetarian diets, while still achieving the traditional luscious texture. Quick to prepare and bursting with festive flavors, these mince pies will surely be a holiday crowd-pleaser.

name: Mustard Yorkies
description: Fluffy Yorkshire puddings are a comfort food classic, perfect as a side for roast dinner - give yours a kick with wholegrain mustard
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 12 tsp sunflower oil, for the tin
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put 1 tsp oil in each well of a 12-hole muffin tin and heat in the oven for 6 mins. Meanwhile, tip the flour and some seasoning into a large, wide jug or a bowl. Beat the eggs with the milk and mustard, then gradually beat into the flour mixture until it makes a smooth batter.

Pour or ladle the batter into the tin, taking care that it doesn’t splatter up and burn you. Bake for 25-30 mins until well risen and golden – try to keep the door closed, as this will help you get a good rise on the Yorkies.
chief_review: This recipe delivers impressively fluffy Yorkshire puddings, with the wholegrain mustard adding a subtle, tangy depth that elevates the classic side dish. The balance between soft centers and crisp, golden edges is spot on, ensuring each bite is satisfyingly light yet flavorful. These puddings rely on staple ingredients—plain flour, eggs, milk, and sunflower oil—making them straightforward to prepare for any Sunday roast. Notably, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or animal-derived rennet. The addition of wholegrain mustard is a clever twist that complements hearty roasts and gravies, bringing a mild heat without overpowering. Serve these alongside your favorite roast meats or vegetarian mains for a delightful, crowd-pleasing accompaniment.

name: Brussels sprouts pad Thai
description: This tasted good, and was easy and quick. It looked a bit boring so I think I'd add some different coloured veg if I cooked it again.
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 250g flat rice noodles (check the packet to make sure they’re vegan)
2 tsp palm sugar(or soft brown sugar)
2 spring onions, thinly sliced on a diagonal
200g charred Brussels sprouts left over from Christmas Day, or cook from raw
30g salted peanuts(or any other nuts you might have), roughly chopped, to serve
directions: First, put the noodles in a large heatproof bowl, cover in boiling water and leave for 10 mins. Drain and rinse with cold water, then set aside. In a bowl, mix the soy sauce or tamari, tamarind or lime juice and sugar.
Heat the oil in a large frying pan or

. Fry the garlic, spring onions, chilli and the cooked or leftover sprouts for around 2 mins (to cook the sprouts from raw, boil for 8-10 mins until tender). Then, add the noodles and beansprouts and fry for 1 min more. Pour over the sauce and toss well, working quickly to coat all the vegetables and noodles. Once everything is heated through, season and divide between four bowls. Scatter with the nuts and serve with lime wedges to squeeze over.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a quick, satisfying noodle dish with a bright, tangy flavor profile from tamarind (or lime), balanced by a gentle sweetness and a mild heat from red chilli. The charred Brussels sprouts add depth and a hint of smokiness, while beansprouts bring freshness and crunch. The salted peanuts on top contribute texture and a pleasant savoriness. Visually, the dish could benefit from more colorful vegetables—adding bell peppers, carrots, or purple cabbage would make it even more appealing. It's a great vegan and dairy-free option (just ensure your noodles, sugar, and sauces are compliant), and it can be made gluten-free by using tamari instead of soy sauce and verifying your rice noodles. Overall, this recipe is an easy weeknight meal, nutritious and robust in flavor, with plenty of room for adaptation.

name: Flash-fried courgettes
description: A dusting of flour and a sprinkling of rosemary are the secrets of this crisp and fragrant side dish
author: Ruth Watson
directions: Slice the courgettes in a food processor, using the fine disc, and pat dry on a clean tea towel. Toss the slices in a plastic bag with the flour, well seasoned. Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan with the rosemary, discarding the herb when the oli is hot, and add 1⁄4 of the courgettes. Fry the courgettes in batches on medium high heat for 2-3 minutes until light golden. Drain on kitchen paper, serve hot.
chief_review: This recipe for crisp, rosemary-scented courgettes is a delightfully simple yet sophisticated side dish. The thin dusting of plain flour creates a golden, delicate crust that locks in the courgettes’ tenderness, while a sprinkling of fresh rosemary infuses each bite with aromatic flavor. A splash of olive oil encourages even crisping without overwhelming the vegetables. It’s a wonderfully light and fresh option, especially suitable for vegetarians. As there are no animal products other than plant-based ingredients, this dish is also compatible with a vegan diet. For those seeking a quick and elegant accompaniment to a main course, this recipe showcases how a handful of quality ingredients and smart technique can elevate the humble courgette.

name: Festive fondant fancies
description: Turn a simple traybake into magical mouthfuls with these fun and easy decoration ideas
author: Good Food
ingredients: 20cm square, or a 30 x 20cm traybake cake
decorate with sprinkles, sugared almonds, mini marshmallows and small gingerbread men (we used Marks & Spencer Gingerbread men, 99p for 9)
directions: Put your ready-to-roll icing block in a large bowl and pour over boiling water to cover. After 10-15 mins the icing should be soft. Pour off water, and mix icing in bowl, adding a dribble more hot water until you get a smooth, runny but thickish icing. Divide evenly in 3 and add a little blue colouring to one third, and a little blue and green colouring to another third.
Slice a 20cm square, or a 30 x 20cm traybake cake into roughly equal, portion-sized squares, and sit them on a wire rack above a large tray.
Spoon some icing over each cake to cover, then decorate with sprinkles, sugared almonds, mini marshmallows and small gingerbread men.
chief_review: This traybake recipe transforms a basic cake into a playful masterpiece, perfect for parties or family gatherings. The use of ready-to-roll icing, vibrant food coloring, and whimsical toppings like sprinkles, sugared almonds, mini marshmallows, and charming gingerbread men ensures a festive finish with minimal effort. Creativity is at the forefront, inviting personalization with color and decoration. The recipe appears suitable for a vegetarian diet, assuming no gelatine or animal rennet in the marshmallows or icing (always check labels if strict vegetarian requirements). Note that sugared almonds and some decorations contain nuts and gluten, so this recipe should be avoided by those with nut or gluten allergies. Fun, visually appealing, and delicious—a delight for both kids and adults.

name: Beef & mozzarella meatballs
description: Use ready-made meatballs and stuff a piece of mozzarella in the middle for a quick and clever canapé
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Wet your hands, push a piece of mozzarella into the centre of each meatball, then re-form the meat into a ball. Place on a baking tray and cook for 15-20 mins until they’re browned and cooked through.
Meanwhile, tip the sauce into a pan. Gently heat, letting it bubble and reduce a little. Once the meatballs are cooked, pop a mini skewer in each one and serve with the sauce to dip.
chief_review: This inventive canapé takes humble, ready-made meatballs and elevates them by hiding a luscious center of mozzarella, giving each bite a delightful pull of creamy cheese. The fresh tomato & basil sauce adds brightness and a herby depth that balances the richness, making for an inviting party snack or a crowd-pleasing appetizer. This recipe is a good fit for a gluten-free diet, provided the meatballs and sauce are certified gluten-free, as many mass-produced options may contain breadcrumbs or thickeners. With its straightforward assembly and reliance on simple ingredients, it’s ideal for busy hosts who want impressive flavors with minimal fuss. The dish is sure to be a hit at any gathering, delivering savory satisfaction in every mouthful.

name: Crunchy almond panettone French toast
description: The panettone was almost disintegrating after 2 mins of soaking (even though they were good chunky slices) so I cooked it straight away without almond coating but it was quite soggy even once crispy on the outside. I put the almonds and clementines on when serving and they were nice. Overall was an ok dish but wouldn't buy panettone especially for it!
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 3 clementines, 1 zested, 2 peeled and sliced horizontally
drizzle of flavourless oil, such as sunflower or vegetable
maple syrupand Greek yogurt, to serve (optional)
directions: In a wide, shallow bowl, whisk the eggs, milk, cinnamon and clementine zest. Add the sliced panettone to the mixture and leave to soak for 5 mins, turning occasionally until all the liquid has been absorbed (alternatively you can wrap the bowl in cling film and chill overnight.)

Scatter the almonds over a plate and carefully dunk in the soaked panettone, pressing to help the almond flakes stick, then turn and stick more to the other side. Heat the butter and oil in a large frying pan (you may need to use two pans if the pieces are quite large.)

When the butter is bubbling, add the panettone and cook over a medium heat for 3-4 mins each side until golden. Serve with pomegranate seeds, clementine slices, and maple syrup and yogurt, if you like.
chief_review: This dish brings a festive twist to classic French toast by using panettone and a medley of fruit and nuts. The eggs and milk create a rich custard, complementing the panettone’s sweetness and spice. The addition of clementines and pomegranate seeds provides refreshing citrus and tart notes, while flaked almonds offer texture. The recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish. Those with nut allergies should avoid or modify the almond topping, and the bread choice means it’s not suitable for a gluten-free diet. The suggestion to top with Greek yogurt and maple syrup offers a creamy and sweet finish. Overall, it’s a pleasant breakfast or brunch dish, though the panettone’s delicate texture may not withstand prolonged soaking—brief dipping and immediate cooking are best to maintain structure.

name: Spiced meat rub
description: This quick and simple herb rub can be put into a mill and used to marinade or season meat and vegetables
author: Good Food
directions: Mix all the ingredients together in a bowl, then carefully transfer to a pepper mill or an airtight jar. Simply grind over your favourite meat before cooking, or over veg before roasting, for extra flavour.
chief_review: This herb rub is a vibrant and aromatic blend, perfect for infusing depth into both meats and vegetables. The mixture of dried thyme, rosemary, bay, and a punch of chilli flakes offers a classic, Mediterranean-inspired flavor profile with a pleasant heat and earthy undertones. Crushing bay leaves ensures a more even distribution of flavor, while the celery salt introduces an additional savory layer often missing from standard rubs. The inclusion of whole peppercorns provides a sharp, fresh bite when ground. This seasoning is suitable for vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free diets, provided you check that your celery salt is certified gluten-free. Versatile and free of common allergens like nuts and dairy, this rub is an excellent staple for anyone's spice collection, adding complexity to simple dishes with minimal effort.

name: No-cook spiced apple chutney
description: This storecupboard relish has all the flavours of a classic cooked chutney but with more bite. It makes a great last minute accompaniment to a cheese board or ham
author: Caroline Hire
ingredients: 2 large Braeburn apples(or similar), peeled, cored and diced
directions: Mix all the ingredients together in a bowl. Give them a good stir and season generously with salt and pepper.
Pour into a sterilized jar and refrigerate. Leave for 2 – 3 days, shaking once a day, before eating. Keep for up to a week more.
chief_review: This lively relish balances the sweetness of Braeburn apples and sultanas with warming spices and a gentle tang from red wine vinegar. The raw preparation keeps a pleasing crunch, providing contrast to creamy cheeses or rich ham. The ground ginger and cumin create subtle warmth without overpowering, while the dark brown sugar delivers mellow depth. Quick to assemble, this chutney is a brilliant last-minute addition to a cheese board or charcuterie spread. Thanks to its ingredient list, it’s suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, as well as being naturally gluten-free. Perfect for seasonal entertaining, the vibrant flavors and textures of this relish will elevate any platter.

name: Mulled red cabbage with clementines
description: Skip the red wine and mull your veg with mixed spice, brown sugar and an orange studded with cloves
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 4 clementines(or satsumas or mandarins), 1 left whole, zest and juice from 3
directions: Stud the whole clementine with the cloves and set aside.

Mix the remaining ingredients in a big saucepan or flameproof casserole. Cover and cook for 30 mins, then snuggle in the studded clementine, cover again and cook for 30 mins more until the cabbage is tender. Season and eat hot or at room temperature.
chief_review: This inventive take on classic red cabbage brings festive warmth to the table by infusing the shredded veg with zingy citrus, aromatic spices, and a gentle sweetness from brown sugar. The process of studding an orange with cloves and simmering it amid red onions, red wine vinegar, and mixed spice imparts a fragrant depth reminiscent of mulled wine, but without the alcohol. The result is a beautifully balanced side: tangy, subtly sweet, and highly aromatic, perfect for complementing rich roasts or holiday spreads. With no animal-derived ingredients, this recipe is ideal for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Additionally, as it contains no gluten ingredients, it's suitable for a gluten-free diet. A seasonal triumph that celebrates the vibrant crunch of cabbage while dressing it up with bold, festive flair.

name: Chestnut fool
description: An autumnal accompaniment to cakes and puds, this nutty cream goes particularly well with spiced friands
author: Maria Elia
directions: Whisk the cream, chestnut purée, sugar, Grand Marnier and cinnamon together until it forms soft peaks. Fold through the yogurt and spoon into a serving dish. Chill until ready to serve with the friands (see 'Goes well with').
chief_review: This luxurious nutty cream is a decadent addition to any autumn dessert table. The combination of velvety double cream and Greek yogurt offers richness, while sweetened chestnut purée and a hint of brown sugar lend depth and subtle sweetness. A dash of Grand Marnier or brandy introduces a sophisticated warmth, beautifully complemented by a touch of cinnamon. The result is a silky, subtly spiced cream that balances sweetness with complexity. It pairs excellently with spiced cakes, particularly friands, enhancing both flavor and texture. Vegetarians can enjoy this recipe, as all the ingredients are plant and dairy-derived without the inclusion of animal-based gelatin or rennet. For celebrations or a simple autumn treat, this chestnut cream elevates any dessert to a memorable indulgence.

name: Baked camembert kit
description: I love the look of this, how do I buy it?
author: Good Food
ingredients: 5 tbsp Calvados, PX Sherry, rum or brandy
small jar, string or ribbon and a label
directions: Heat sultanas and alcohol together until just simmering, then turn off the heat and cool completely. Spoon into a small jar and seal. Put the jar on top of the cheese and tie together with string or ribbon.

Keep in the fridge for up to a week until you are ready to give them away, then add a label with these instructions: ‘Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Unwrap the camembert, take off the wax wrapper and any other packaging. Put it back in the box but leave the lid off. Cook for 10 mins or until the centre of the cheese feels very soft. Cut a slashed cross in the centre of the cheese then tip in and over as many of the sultanas as you like. Serve with chunks of crusty bread.’
chief_review: This recipe brings an inventive twist, showcasing boozy sultanas paired with a creamy camembert. The luxurious blend of dried fruit soaked in your choice of Calvados, sherry, rum, or brandy adds a festive, indulgent character perfect for cheeseboard aficionados. The inclusion of only dairy and dried fruit means this recipe is ideal for lacto-vegetarians. It’s also naturally free from gluten, provided your spirit of choice is gluten-free. Packed in a jar and finished with ribbon and label, it makes an elegant, thoughtful edible gift or a sophisticated addition to your own table. The texture contrast and flavor depth between tangy, spirit-soaked sultanas and soft, ripe camembert is truly special—simple ingredients, exquisite results.

name: Lobster, green bean & radicchio salad
description: This festive seafood starter, finished with a garlicky basil dressing, can be prepared ahead - ideal for a fuss-free dinner for two
author: Alex Hollywood
ingredients: ½ small radicchio(about 100g/ 4oz), leaves separated, washed and patted dry
directions: To prepare the lobster, separate the claws from the tail. Crack the claws with a rolling pin and pick out the meat. Remove the shell from the lobster tail, cut the tail in half and discard the intestine. Break off the legs then roll a rolling pin over them to push out any meat. Cut all the meat into bite-sized pieces, cover and put in the fridge.

Put a small saucepan of salted water on to boil. Add the potatoes and simmer for 15 mins until cooked but not broken up. Lift the potatoes out of the water and leave to one side to cool. Add the green beans to the hot water and boil for 3 mins until just cooked. Drain the beans and run under cold water. Put the cooled potatoes and beans in the fridge to chill.

To make the basil dressing, blitz the pine nuts, most of the basil (saving a few leaves to finish), the garlic and red wine vinegar in a small food processor. With the motor running, slowly drizzle in the olive oil. The dressing should be fairly smooth but still have some texture. Season and set aside.

When you are ready to serve, cut the potatoes into 1cm-thick slices, put in a bowl and mix with half the dressing. Arrange the radicchio and green beans on two serving plates, top with the potato slices and finally the chilled lobster. Drizzle over the rest of the dressing, top with the reserved basil leaves and serve.
chief_review: This elegant seafood starter is an excellent choice for special occasions, showcasing the delicate sweetness of lobster paired with crisp green beans, tender new potatoes, and slightly bitter radicchio for contrast. The garlicky basil dressing, brightened with red wine vinegar and extra virgin olive oil, marries the elements beautifully, while toasted pine nuts add a satisfying crunch. The ingredients make it suitable for pescatarian diets, offering a well-balanced, nutrient-rich plate with both protein and vegetables. The absence of wheat or dairy allows those with gluten or lactose sensitivities to enjoy it, though always verify ingredient sources to avoid cross-contamination. Make-ahead preparation adds convenience, freeing up time for the host. A refined, refreshing dish worthy of a celebratory dinner.

name: Sweet party bites
description: Add a bit of glamour to your party with these sweet yet sophisticated party bites
author: Good Food
ingredients: Lemon fancies(all ingredients for recipes below)
directions: Split 6 scones. Sandwich them together with a 227g tub of clotted cream and ½ a jar of strawberry jam. Cut into quarters and serve like triangular sandwiches, pointy-side up (makes 24).

Use a melon baller to scoop 25 small balls of vanilla ice cream from a 500g tub. Freeze on a tray for 1 hr until solid. Melt 200g dark chocolate and spread 100g finely chopped pistachios on a tray. Dip the balls in the chocolate using a cocktail stick, then roll in the nuts and freeze for 30 mins or until serving (makes 25).

Buy 2 x 350g Madeira sponge cakes. Trim, then cut into 20 x 3cm cubes. Freeze until solid. Heat 200ml double cream, then remove from heat and stir in 200g chopped white chocolate until melted. Cool a little. Spread 2 cups of desiccated coconut on a tray. Dip each frozen cake completely into the chocolate, then roll in the coconut to coat all sides (it might help to hold each cake on a skewer). Firm up on baking parchment for at least 30 mins before serving (makes 20).

Thinly roll out a 375g pack puff pastry. Divide into squares (roughly 20 x 5cm), then prick each all over with a fork. Spread onto baking sheets. Peel, core and slice 2 Bramley apples into 2cm pieces. Place a small slice of marzipan on each square (you’ll need about 200g), top with some apple and bake at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 10 mins until crisp. Dust with icing sugar to serve (makes 20).
Use a 4cm pastry cutter to cut out 20 circles from bought lemon tarts (you’ll need 2 large tarts). Top each with a raspberry and dust with icing sugar.
chief_review: This selection of party bites offers a delightful array of flavors and textures, perfect for elevating any gathering. The cream teabites and lemon fancies provide a classic British touch with their delicate sweetness, while the mini choc ice balls add a rich, chocolatey indulgence. Cheat’s lamingtons bring a taste of Australia with their coconut coating, and the apple & marzipan tarts introduce a subtle nuttiness that complements the fruit beautifully. Given the presence of dairy, eggs, gluten, and nuts—particularly marzipan and likely wheat flour—these treats are tailored for those without dietary restrictions. Each bite is thoughtfully crafted for maximum visual appeal and taste sophistication, making them an excellent choice for an elegant dessert spread.

name: Persian pudding with whipped rose & honey butter
description: Orange and rose flavours are incorporated into this alternative steamed pudding. Sweet spiced butter makes the perfect accompaniment
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 175g melted butter, plus extra for greasing
2 tbsp icing sugar, plus extra to serve
directions: Tip the dates into a bowl with the raisins, cover with 200ml hot water from the kettle and set aside. Meanwhile, grease a 1.5 litre pudding basin and line the base with a disk of parchment paper. Put the dry ingredients and orange zest in a large bowl. Stir in the dates and raisins (and soaking liquid), the rose and orange water, with the eggs and butter. Mix until everything is combined. Tip into the basin and cover with a circle of parchment paper, then foil, then tie the rim with string.

Place the pudding on an upturned jar lid in a large pan and pour in hot water from the kettle until it comes halfway up the bowl. Cover the pan and gently steam for 4 hrs, topping up with more water if needed. The pudding can be eaten straight away, chilled and kept for up to a week, or frozen for 1 month. To reheat, defrost completely or remove from the fridge and steam pud again for 30 mins until piping hot.
To make the butter, whisk the ingredients together. Serve the pudding in wedges with a spoonful of the butter melting over it.
chief_review: This alternative steamed pudding is a delightful twist on traditional desserts, featuring a vibrant combination of orange and rose aromas. The use of dates, raisins, mixed peel, and a medley of nuts delivers a rich texture and depth of flavor, while the addition of sweet spiced butter elevates the experience with aromatic warmth. The muscovado sugar and honey provide natural sweetness that balances beautifully with the citrus zest and floral notes. The breadcrumbs and self-raising flour create a moist but structured crumb—perfect for steaming. This recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets, as it contains no meat or animal-derived gelatin. However, it does include nuts, gluten, eggs, and dairy, so consideration should be taken for common allergens. Overall, this pudding is a sophisticated and festive choice, ideal for those seeking a complex and aromatic dessert.

name: Chocolate chip mince pies
description: Get the kids involved with BBC Good Food food editor Barney's child-friendly chocolate mince pies
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 400g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: ADULTS the rest is for you.
Get your children to weigh out the mincemeat in a bowl and mix in the chocolate chips (if a few get eaten, not to worry, it is Christmas!). Set aside.

To make the pastry, tip the butter, flour and spice into a bowl. Get them to rub it together until combined to the texture of breadcrumbs. Add the sugar and squidge together to make a dough – don’t be tempted to add any liquid. Tip the dough onto a floured surface and knead.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Halve the dough (discuss with your child how half makes two, etc), and get them to roll half into 12 balls – another counting opportunity. Get them to gently press the balls into the holes of the tin so that they come up the sides with a little overlap.
Spoon the filling into the pies – try to be as neat as you can, as you don’t want to get any on the sides.

Make 12 more balls (again counting) and pat them out flat (cue the Pat-a-cake song), so that they are large enough to cover the pies. Top and press the edges together. You don’t need to worry about sealing them or being too neat.
Brush the tops of the pies with egg. Put the tray in the oven and bake for 20 mins or until golden brown. Remove from the oven and leave to cool slightly.
If you want neat-looking pies, you can use a 7cm round cutter to trim the edges. This is easiest done while the pies are still warm.

For some extra learning fun, you can now dust the work surface with icing sugar, press some marzipan out flat and use letter cutters to create letters of your choice. Brush the letters with a drop of water and gently press them onto the pies.

Leave to cool a bit more, then gently slip the pies out of the tin. Put some icing sugar in a fine sieve and give the pies a snowy dusting. Eat straight away, give to neighbours and friends, or keep in an airtight container for up to 3 days.
chief_review:
Barney’s chocolate mince pies are a playful twist on the classic, with gooey chocolate chips adding a crowd-pleasing richness. The pastry, enriched with cold butter and a touch of marzipan (if used), promises a melt-in-the-mouth texture and delightful almond undertones. The mincemeat filling, married with chocolate, offers a festive depth that will satisfy both traditionalists and adventurous palates. The recipe’s straightforward method makes it ideal for little helpers in the kitchen.

While not vegan or gluten free due to the butter, eggs, and flour, these mince pies are vegetarian-friendly—there’s no suet or meat in the mincemeat, only dried fruits and spices. Be mindful if serving anyone with nut allergies, as marzipan contains almonds. Overall, these mince pies deliver festive cheer and sweet comfort in every bite, making them a fantastic centerpiece for family baking sessions.

name: Passion-mango delight with coconut whip
description: These individual pudding pots are a taste of the tropical. The light fruit mousse is topped with a creamy whip laced with coconut liqueur
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 6 really ripe passion fruits, nice and wrinkled on the outside
directions: First collect 8 glasses to serve your mousses in, and put to one side. Put the coconut and granulated sugar in a bowl and, using a hand blender, whizz together until finely chopped. In another bowl, froth the egg white using a fork. Dip each glass rim into the egg, shake off any excess, then dip into the coconut mixture. Leave to set and dry.

To make the mousse, cut all the flesh from the mangoes. Put the fruit into a blender or food processor with the pulp from the passion fruit and lime juice. Blend to a smooth purée, then set a sieve over a large bowl and sieve to remove any passion fruit seeds. Put the gelatine leaves in a bowl of cold water to soften.

Heat the cream in a small saucepan until it’s just about to start bubbling. Turn off the heat. Squeeze out the softened gelatine leaves to remove excess water, then stir into the cream. When they have completely melted and no gelatine streaks remain, stir this into the mango mixture.

Beat the egg whites until stiff. Add the sugar and beat to a thick, shiny meringue mixture. Fold a little of the mango mixture into the meringue with a big metal spoon or spatula. Gently fold in the rest (you’re trying to get rid of all the meringue streaks, while retaining as much air in the mousse as possible . Ladle into a jug and divide between the glasses. Chill overnight to set.

To serve, beat the egg whites until stiff. Add the sugar and beat to a shiny, thick meringue, then beat in the Malibu. Spoon into a piping bag (or food bag with the corner snipped off) and pipe a blob onto each mousse. To save time, do this 1 hr ahead and pop them back into the fridge.
chief_review:
This recipe for individual tropical pudding pots beautifully balances the sweetness of ripe mangoes and passion fruits with the richness of coconut and cream. The mousse achieves a lovely lightness thanks to whipped egg whites, while Malibu liqueur in the creamy whip adds a delightful, aromatic finish. The use of gelatine provides a pleasing set, making the texture both smooth and airy. 

For those observing a gluten-free diet, this recipe is suitable as all the ingredients used are naturally gluten-free, assuming care with cross-contamination and with ingredient packaging. However, it is not suitable for those with egg or dairy allergies due to the use of egg whites and double cream. It's ideal for an elegant dinner party dessert or a special treat for those craving bright, tropical flavors.

name: Rudolph’s carrot patch cakes
description: These chocolate carrot loaf cakes with edible vegetable decoration can be left as a present for Santa's reindeer - or enjoyed all year round
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: few parsleysprigs and edible green glitter (optional)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Arrange 6 mini loaf cases (8 x 4 x 4cm) on a baking tray. In a large bowl, mix the sugar, flour, cocoa, bicarbonate of soda, spices, orange zest and ¼ tsp salt. In a jug, whisk the eggs, oil, milk and carrots. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry and mix thoroughly. Divide the mixture between the cases and bake for 30 mins until risen and cooked through. Transfer to a wire rack to cool.

While the cakes are cooking, make the carrot decorations. Mix the orange food colouring into the fondant icing until evenly coloured, then divide into 6 pieces. Roll each piece into a cyclinder, about 5cm long, then roll one end a little thinner to create a carrot shape. Use a cocktail stick to make indentations along the sides. Set aside, standing them on their fattest end, to firm up for 30 mins. Now make the chocolate icing. Put the butter, cocoa, icing sugar and milk into a saucepan, and bubble for a few mins, stirring with a small whisk until smooth and shiny. Set aside to cool for 20 mins. For the green coconut ‘grass’, tip the coconut into a small bowl, add a little green food colouring and mix until evenly coated.

To assemble the cakes, first cut a little hole, about 1cm, into the centre of each to ‘plant’ your carrot later. Stir the icing and spread over the cakes to cover the surface. Push your carrot into the centre, then scatter the green coconut around the edges. Stick a sprig of parsley into the top of each carrot and sprinkle the coconut grass with green edible glitter, if you like. Can be stored in a sealed cake tin for up to 3 days.
chief_review: This inventive chocolate carrot loaf cake brings together the natural sweetness of carrots with the richness of cocoa, accented by spices and a bright note of orange zest. The moist crumb is achieved with sunflower oil and grated carrot, ensuring a delightful texture. Decorated with homemade fondant 'vegetables,' this recipe is playful, making it an ideal project for family baking sessions or festive gifting. The use of self-raising flour means it’s not gluten-free, but the recipe is nut-free, catering to those with nut allergies. It suits a vegetarian diet, as no meat, fish, or animal rennet are present, but it’s not vegan due to eggs, milk, and butter. The inclusion of edible glitter and parsley sprigs adds whimsical flair. Overall, it’s a visually appealing, delicious loaf cake that balances tradition and creativity for any occasion.

name: Pomegranate-braised pork belly
description: Very rich but good as a once in a blue moon recipe!
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 1 lemon, juiced and zest peeled into strips
green vegetablesor a fresh grain salad, to serve (optional)
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/ gas 3. Heat the oil in a wide, shallow ovenproof dish (or use a roasting tin that can go on the hob). Mix the pomegranate juice, cinnamon, allspice, lemon juice, honey and red wine vinegar together in a large bowl. Brown the pork for 2-3 mins each side, then add all the other ingredients, season and bring to a simmer. Cover with a lid, or wrap the dish in foil, then transfer to the oven for 1 hr.

Uncover the dish, remove the pork and set aside. Skim off the fat and place the dish on the hob. Reduce the sauce to a sticky glaze before returning the pork to the dish and basting. Increase the temperature to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and return the dish to the oven. Continue cooking for another 45-50 mins until the pork is really tender. Scatter with the pomegranate seeds and serve with green veg or a fresh grain salad, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe offers a decadent twist on pork belly, featuring the deep, tangy notes of pomegranate juice and the warm spice of cinnamon and allspice. The honey and red wine vinegar create a beautifully balanced glaze, enhancing the richness of the pork without overpowering it. Strips of lemon zest bring a fresh, aromatic brightness, while the scattered pomegranate seeds add bursts of juicy sweetness and visual appeal just before serving. The suggested accompaniments of green vegetables or a grain salad round out the dish, adding texture and contrast. This dish is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided that all vinegars and additional sides are checked for hidden gluten-containing ingredients. It is sure to impress at special occasions or as a luxurious treat, though its richness makes it best enjoyed in moderation.

name: Orecchiette with cavolo nero, anchovies & pangrattato
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 slices crusty bread(stale if possible), crusts removed and blitzed into breadcrumbs
2 fat red chillies, deseeded and thinly sliced
200g cavolo nero, stalks removed, finely shredded
directions: Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil and cook the pasta following pack instructions. Meanwhile, heat 1 tbsp oil in a large frying pan and add the breadcrumbs. Toast until they are golden and crispy, then tip out onto a plate and set aside. Wipe the pan clean with kitchen paper.

Heat another 2 tbsp oil in the pan and add the chilli, garlic and anchovies. Sizzle for 1-2 mins but don’t let the garlic brown. Add a drizzle of the oil from the anchovies, stir and set the pan aside.

When the pasta has 2 mins to go, add the cavolo nero. Remove a cup of cooking water before draining the pasta, then tip it into the frying pan and return to the heat. Add a splash of cooking water, the remaining 1 tbsp oil (along with another drizzle from the anchovies if the pasta looks dry) and the lemon zest and juice. Season well and cook for 1-2 mins, tossing everything together and adjusting the seasoning if necessary. Serve in bowls scattered with the pangrattato.
chief_review: This vibrant pasta dish brings together the robust flavors of cavolo nero, anchovies, garlic, and chili, all elevated by the crunch of homemade olive oil-toasted breadcrumbs and a lively lemon finish. The recipe offers a harmonious balance between savory, spicy, and bright notes, with orecchiette’s cupped shape perfect for catching the bold, garlicky sauce. It's a fantastic choice for pescatarians, anchovy lovers, and anyone seeking a quick, flavorful meal full of texture. Since it’s naturally free from dairy and can easily be made with gluten-free pasta, it's adaptable for certain dietary needs. The anchovies provide a depth of umami that makes this dish incredibly satisfying for a weeknight supper or casual gathering. Serve immediately to maintain the delightful contrast between silky greens and crisp breadcrumbs.

name: Make-ahead Prosecco & wild mushroom gravy
description: Was unable to rate, but would give 5 stars!
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 500g chicken wings, chopped into pieces (you can ask your butcher to do this for you)
turkeybackbone and neck, hacked into pieces
2 celery sticks, cut into small chunks
directions: Heat the oil in a large shallow saucepan or flameproof casserole dish. When it’s shimmering, add the wings and the turkey pieces, and spend a good 20 mins browning them well in the oil – sticky bits of meat in the pan will add flavour.

Tip in the vegetables, herbs and porcini, scatter over the sugar and stir everything in. Turn down the heat and brown the vegetables for another 10 mins. Stir in the flour, then pour in the Prosecco and simmer down to a paste.

Stir in the stock and bring to the boil, scraping the bottom of the pan as you stir. Skim any scum off with a ladle and simmer steadily for 30 mins until thickened and reduced by about a third. Season to taste with salt and stir in a squeeze of lemon. Leave to cool slightly, then strain through a sieve into a container and chill. Can be made three days ahead, or frozen for up to three months.
On the day, simply reheat or pour into the turkey roasting tin and reheat with the roasting juices. If not serving to children, finish with a splash more Prosecco just before serving, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe masterfully layers depth of flavor, combining chicken wings, turkey backbone, and aromatic vegetables to form a robust base. The use of dried porcini introduces an earthy complexity, while prosecco adds brightness and subtle acidity that elevates the stock further. The bouquet of thyme and bay leaves perfumes the dish, and a touch of golden caster sugar creates balance against the savory notes. A squeeze of lemon at the finish provides a clean, refreshing lift. The inclusion of flour as a thickener is conventional but effective, producing a rich, velvety texture. This recipe is suitable for those following a classic omnivorous diet, and is best enjoyed by those without poultry or mushroom allergies, or gluten sensitivity. The method showcases classic techniques, and the result is a comforting, full-bodied broth—ideal as a soup starter or as a base for more elaborate dishes.

name: Mini port-spiked Eccles cakes
author: Cassie Best
directions: At least 2 hrs before baking, wrap the butter for the pastry in foil and freeze it.

Tip the flour into a big bowl with 1 /2 tsp salt. Hold the butter block in the foil (peeling back a little at a time as you need), then coarsely grate straight into the bowl of flour, dipping the end of the butter into the flour every so often – this helps to stop all the butter clumping together. Use a cutlery knife to lightly stir together. Stir in about 120ml cold water to bring the dough together, then wrap in cling film and chill for 30 mins.

To make the filling, mix the butter, brown sugar, currants, mixed peel, lemon zest, cloves and port in a saucepan over a medium heat. Cook until the butter has melted and the port has become thick and sticky, then leave to cool at room temperature for 1 hr.

Remove the pastry from the fridge 10 mins before rolling. Roll out to the thickness of a £1 coin and stamp out into circles using a 10cm cutter. Bring the pastry trimmings together and re-roll to make a few more circles. Divide the filling between the pastry and brush the edges with a little water. Pull up the sides and pinch together to seal. Flip the cakes over and press each one down with the palm of your hand to make a puck. Arrange over two baking sheets.

Whisk the egg white until a little foamy, then brush over the cakes and sprinkle over the granulated sugar. Slash the top of each one a few times with a sharp knife, then chill for at least 20 mins. You can also freeze the cakes for up to two months at this point.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Bake the Eccles cakes for 20-25 mins until golden and crisp. If baking from frozen, add another 5 mins. Cool for at least 10 mins before serving. Will keep in an airtight container for up to three days.
chief_review: This recipe makes a delightful, rich pastry treat, packed with currants, mixed peel, and a hint of lemon zest, all gently spiced with cloves and elevated by ruby port. The buttery crust is perfectly complemented by a crisp granulated sugar topping, thanks to the egg white wash. It is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat, poultry, fish, or gelatin. However, it does include wheat flour, egg, and dairy, making it unsuitable for gluten-free, vegan, or dairy-free diets. The flavors are harmonious: the sweetness of the fruit, the warmth of the spice, and the kick from the port bring a festive quality. This recipe is ideal for a special afternoon tea or celebration, offering a nostalgic, comforting bite with every mouthful.

name: Buttermilk caramel puddings
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1 vanilla pod, split and seeds scraped out
directions: You’ll need 6-8 dariole moulds or small individual pudding basins. Tip 150g of the sugar into a shallow pan and place over a medium heat. Cook the sugar until dissolved and turning to a light amber caramel. While it is still hot, carefully pour the caramel over the base of the moulds, tipping them around so some caramel also sticks to the sides. Set aside.

Soak the gelatine in very cold water for about 10 mins to soften. Tip the cream, remaining sugar and the vanilla pod and seeds into a saucepan. Place on the heat, stirring to combine and dissolve the sugar. Bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally, then remove from the heat. Add the drained, squeezed gelatine leaves and stir to dissolve, then leave to cool. When tepid, remove and squeeze out the vanilla pod, stir in the buttermilk, then strain everything into a jug. Share the mixture between the moulds, then place in the fridge for at least a couple of hours, or preferably overnight to set.

To serve, dip the bases of the moulds briefly into very hot water until the fillings just come away from the sides. When you are confident that it will turn out, place a serving plate over the mould and carefully turn, allowing the contents to drop out onto the plate, scooping out any caramel sauce left in the mould and drizzling over the puddings. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe offers a classic, luscious panna cotta with a delightful balance of sweetness from white caster sugar and subtle complexity from real vanilla seeds. The use of double cream and buttermilk results in a rich, silky texture complemented by a refreshing tang. Leaf gelatine ensures a delicate set, yielding a dessert that’s elegant in both flavor and presentation. As it contains dairy and gelatine, it's best suited for a vegetarian diet but not for vegans or those with dairy or gelatine allergies. This panna cotta would shine with seasonal berries or a simple fruit coulis for added freshness. A beautifully executed, straightforward recipe ideal for impressive entertaining.

name: Dark & stormy coffee cocktail
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Fill a highball glass with ice and pour in the rum and tequila. Stir then top with ginger beer. Slowly pour in the espresso.
chief_review: This creative cocktail brings together the deep notes of dark rum, the punch of tequila, and the boldness of freshly brewed espresso, all enlivened by a lively splash of ginger beer. Served over ice, the result is a surprisingly harmonious drink with layers of complexity—earthy coffee tones mingle with sweet spice and a subtle kick from the ginger beer. With no cream, dairy, or animal products, this recipe is naturally vegan and vegetarian. It's also gluten-free, assuming the ginger beer is certified gluten-free. The drink’s robust character makes it a unique after-dinner option or a conversation-worthy twist for cocktail hour.

name: Turkish coffee sour
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put the coffee grounds in a pan with 250ml water. Add the cardamom pods, lemon peel, cloves and cinnamon stick. Bring to the boil, then strain though a sieve lined with 2 pieces of kitchen paper. Leave to cool.

Pour 50ml of the coffee mixture into a cocktail shaker filled with ice then add the egg white, spiced rum and lemon juice. Shake hard for 1-2 mins then double strain into 2 coupe or martini glasses. Decorate with another cardamom pod and a few drops of Angostura bitters if you like.
chief_review: This inventive spiced coffee cocktail is a harmonious blend of warming aromatics and bright citrus, perfect for adventurous palates. The combination of coffee grounds, cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon infuses the drink with complex depth, while the strip of lemon peel and fresh lemon juice provide a lively, refreshing lift.
