Spiced rum introduces a layer of sweetness and heat, beautifully balanced by the silky texture from egg whites, which ensure a velvety mouthfeel. A dash of Angostura bitters adds subtle herbal notes, enhancing the bouquet. This recipe is an enticing option for those following a vegetarian diet, though not suitable for vegans due to the use of egg whites. Ideal as an after-dinner drink, it’s both sophisticated and bold—a true showcase of creative mixology.

name: Hot toddy
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 1 lemon, half juiced and half sliced
directions: Whisk the whisky and honey together and split between 2 heatproof glasses. Add half of the cinnamon stick to each, then top up with 200ml boiling water.
Add a splash of lemon juice to each, then taste and add more to your preference. Finish each with a slice of lemon, studded with a clove, and serve immediately.
chief_review: This warming drink brings together whisky, honey, cinnamon, lemon, and cloves for a classic concoction with deep, spiced notes and a subtle citrus tang. The honey balances the sharpness of the lemon and the boldness of the whisky, while the cinnamon and cloves provide aromatic complexity ideal for soothing or celebratory moments. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe is free from animal-derived ingredients except for honey, making it vegetarian-friendly but not vegan. There are no common allergens such as nuts, dairy, gluten, or eggs present, which increases its accessibility for a wider range of guests. Quick to prepare and packed with comforting flavors, this recipe is an excellent choice for chilly evenings or as a palate-warming after-dinner serve.

name: Jasmine & ginger tea
description: I used frozen cranberries and a quarter clementine - delicious!
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put the jasmine tea and frozen berries into a large teapot. Add the cinnamon stick, star anise, cloves,  ginger and orange. Fill the teapot with up to 1 litre water.
Let it steep for 3-4 mins, then strain into teacups to serve.
chief_review: This vibrant infusion brings together the fragrant elegance of jasmine tea with a medley of bold, warming spices and bright citrus notes. Using frozen cranberries and a touch of clementine adds a delightful tartness balanced by the subtle sweetness of orange. The ginger’s gentle heat harmonizes beautifully with the aromatic depth of cloves, cinnamon, and star anise, resulting in a soothing yet lively brew. The absence of dairy, animal products, and gluten makes this recipe perfectly suited for vegan and gluten-free diets. It’s also a wonderful caffeine-light option for an afternoon pick-me-up or a comforting evening treat.

name: Black pepper hasselback potatoes
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 2½ kg medium potatoes, scrubbed (choose a variety that roasts well like Maris Piper)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Rest each potato on a large serving spoon and cut widthways at 3mm intervals – cutting the potato on a spoon stops you slicing all the way through. Repeat with all the potatoes. Roughly grind the peppercorns with a

Melt the butter and oil in a large roasting tin. Once sizzling, add the potatoes and pared lemon zest. Toss well so that all the potatoes get coated in the fat, then season well with salt and three quarters of the freshly ground black pepper. Roast on the bottom shelf of the oven for 1 hr-1 hr 15 mins until golden and tender. Discard the lemon zest and scatter over the remaining pepper to serve.
chief_review: This roasted potato recipe is a celebration of simple, bold flavors and thoughtful technique. Maris Piper potatoes, known for their fluffy interiors, are paired with aromatic black peppercorns and the brightness of fresh lemon zest. The combination of butter and olive oil creates a rich base, ensuring golden, crisp exteriors and tender centers. The use of both fats adds depth while the lemon zest lifts the dish with a hint of citrus. This recipe is particularly well-suited to a vegetarian diet, offering luscious comfort without the need for meat or animal rennet. Ideal as a standout side for festive roasts or as a showstopping vegetarian centerpiece, these potatoes deliver on both texture and taste. The recipe's straightforward ingredient list keeps the focus on quality, seasonal produce and mindful seasoning—a testament to classic, satisfying cookery.

name: Honeyed almonds with cinnamon, nutmeg and five spice
author: Claire Thomson
ingredients: good pinch of flaky sea salt
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line a baking tray with lightly oiled baking parchment. Mix the sugar and salt in a large bowl and set aside.

Melt the honey in a frying pan over a low heat. Add the almonds and spices and stir to coat. Transfer the nuts to the baking tray and spread them out in a single layer. Bake for 10-15 mins until golden brown, scraping the nuts from the side to the centre from time to time so they cook and colour evenly.
Remove from the oven and cool slightly for 5 mins until the nuts become sticky, then toss them in the sugar and salt mixture. Cool completely, then divide them between cellophane bags.
chief_review: This recipe blends the warmth of cinnamon, nutmeg, and five spice with the natural sweetness of honey and the crunchy richness of almonds, creating a delightfully aromatic snack. The demerara sugar adds a charming caramel note, while a good pinch of flaky sea salt balances and highlights the flavors. The use of raw, skinned almonds ensures a crisp texture once roasted, and the spice combination marries beautifully with the honey’s floral sweetness. This recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians and is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for a range of diets. It is also a great option for those seeking a refined yet simple snack with minimal ingredients and maximum flavor. Serve these spiced almonds as an elegant accompaniment to cheese boards or as a satisfying treat on their own.

name: Chocolate stirrers
author: Claire Thomson
ingredients: 3 whole cardamom pods, husks removed and seeds ground to a powder
1 small unwaxed orangeor tangerine, finely zested
4 squares white chocolate, finely grated or shaved
¼ whole star anise, finely ground
small wooden spoons or ice lolly sticks
directions: Lightly oil the ice lolly moulds. Melt the chocolate in a bowl set over a pan of just-simmering water, stirring occasionally – take care to not scald the chocolate, as this will make it waxy and granular. Alternatively melt the chocolate in short, sharp bursts in a microwave on a medium heat. Put the spoons or lolly sticks into the holes of the lolly mould.

Divide the melted chocolate into four separate bowls. Now work quickly to add the different flavours. Stir the ground cardamom into one bowl and fill two lolly moulds to the top of the spoon, then sprinkle on the chopped pistachios. Mix the orange zest into the next bowl, then fill two moulds to the top of the spoon and top with candied peel. Mix the nutmeg into the next bowl, then fill two moulds as before and top with white chocolate. Add the star anise to the final bowl of chocolate, mix, then fill the remaining moulds and top with the freeze-dried raspberries.

Chill the moulds in the fridge for at least 2-3 hrs. When the chocolate has completely set, ease the stirrers out of the moulds, wrap each spoon in cellophane and secure with string. Add a label that reads ‘Stir me into hot milk’, if you like. Keep cool until you need them.
chief_review: This recipe presents a delightful blend of rich chocolate with aromatic spices and vibrant citrus, resulting in a sophisticated and flavorful ice lolly. The combination of cardamom, star anise, and nutmeg provides depth, while pistachios, candied peel, and freeze-dried raspberries deliver both texture and bursts of brightness. Using dark chocolate as the base not only gives a more intense cocoa flavor but also lends itself well to those on a vegetarian diet, provided the chocolate itself does not contain any animal-derived additives. The use of citrus zest and white chocolate shavings elevates both taste and appearance. These lollies are well-suited for entertaining or as a special treat. Be sure to check the chocolate ingredients if catering for specific allergies or restrictions, but overall this recipe wonderfully balances elegance and indulgence.

name: Stuffed saddle of venison with prunes & brioche
description: Absolutely delicious. Followed the recipe to the letter and the result was excellent and enjoyed by all the family.
author: Rob Taylor
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. To make the stuffing, melt the butter in a shallow pan, then fry the onion, garlic, prunes and bacon until the onion is translucent and the bacon is slightly coloured. Add the brioche and cook until combined and broken down, then add the sage, season and remove from heat.

Put a sheet of baking parchment on a sheet of foil (both should be larger than your venison). Arrange four pieces of string across the kitchen counter and put the foil and parchment on top – this will help the venison to keep its shape. Lay another four pieces of string across the parchment. Lay the pancetta on top of the paper and string, slightly overlapping the slices so that they cover an area roughly the size of your opened-out venison.
Lay the venison on top of the pancetta, skin-side down, then spoon the stuffing down the centre, patting it with your hands to make it into a sausage shape.

Fold in the sides of the venison, along with the pancetta, so they touch or slightly overlap – use the foil and baking parchment to help you. Tie the strings around the venison, making sure that the foil and parchment enclose the meat but stay outside it. Fold in the ends and tie the other pieces of string tightly around the outside of the parcel to hold it in shape.

Put the venison on a baking sheet or in a roasting tin. Roast for 40-50 mins or until a meat thermometer pushed into the joint reaches 60C, for medium rare meat. Rest for 10 mins, then remove and discard the foil and parchment. Brush the venison all over with butter and return to the oven for a final 10 mins. Leave to rest for 10-15 mins before removing the string and slicing.
chief_review: This recipe offers a beautifully rich and decadent centerpiece, perfect for an impressive dinner. The saddle of venison wrapped in pancetta delivers deep, gamey flavors, heightened by the subtle smokiness of streaky bacon. The stuffing, featuring prunes and sage, adds a sweet and herby note, while brioche lends a delicate, buttery texture. The careful layering of ingredients shows solid technique, resulting in a succulent, flavour-packed dish. Due to the presence of brioche, this recipe contains gluten, and it features both meat and dairy, making it unsuitable for vegetarian or vegan diets, but ideal for those looking to indulge in a classic, hearty main course with complex flavors. Serve with a robust red wine and simple sides to let the main shine.

name: Vegan nut roast
description:
Hello, what could I use instead of mushrooms?
Thanks
Janet
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 vegan vegetable stock cube(check the packet)
330g parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks
3 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
1 rosemarysprig, leaves stripped, plus extra to decorate if you like
small pack flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
handful parsnip crispswith sea salt & black pepper (optional)
directions: Cook the pearl barley with the stock cube according to pack instructions. Reserve 4 tbsp of the cooking stock, then drain the grains well.

Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, then add the parsnips, and cook until really soft. Drain well, tip back into the pan to steam dry for a few minutes, then roughly mash. Mix the ground linseeds with the reserved stock water, and leave to go gluey.

Put 2 tbsp of the oil in your largest frying pan with the onions and garlic. Fry gently until soft and golden, then stir in the mushrooms, rosemary and sage. Fry the mushrooms until they're golden too, and any liquid that comes out has evaporated. Scrape into a big mixing bowl and set aside to cool.
Grease a 22-24cm savarin or ring tin generously with oil. If it's not a non-stick tin, line it with thin strips of overlapping baking parchment.

Add the mashed parsnip, cooked pearl barley, gluey seed mix, grated vegan hard cheese (if using), chopped parsley and whole hazelnuts to the fried mushroom mixture. Season generously with salt and nutmeg, then mix everything together really well.
Spoon the filling into the tin, and press down firmly to fill the tin and flatten the top. Keep in the fridge for up to 24 hrs before baking.
Heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and cover the tin with foil. Bake for 45 mins, until a skewer poked into the centre of the mixture comes out piping hot.

Use a small palette knife or cutlery knife to release the filling all the way around, then sit a serving plate on top and flip over. Carefully lift off the tin, and top the wreath with some parsnip crisps if using and whole pumpkin seeds to serve – plus some extra rosemary sprigs if you like. Slice into wedges and enjoy.
chief_review: This hearty, vegan-friendly recipe masterfully showcases earthy flavors with a satisfying texture, thanks to ingredients like pearl barley, ground linseeds, and parsnips. The mushrooms contribute umami depth, but for those seeking an alternative, diced eggplant or zucchini could provide a similar meaty texture and absorb the aromatic sauté of onion, garlic, rosemary, and sage beautifully. The addition of toasted hazelnuts and pumpkin seeds enhances both crunch and nutty flavor, while optional vegan cheese adds a touch of richness. It’s suitable for both vegan and dairy-free diets, and, omitting barley or substituting with gluten-free grains like buckwheat or quinoa, can be adapted for a gluten-free menu. This dish is ideal for anyone seeking a plant-based, allergen-aware centerpiece with complexity and seasonal charm.

name: Wild mushroom Yorkshire puddings
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Tip the milk into a saucepan with the mushrooms and bring to the boil. Simmer for 1 min, then remove from the heat and leave to cool completely. Strain the milk well, pressing down on the mushrooms to squeeze out any excess liquid, then set both the milk and the mushrooms aside.

To make the batter, tip the flour into a bowl and beat in the eggs until smooth. Gradually add the flavoured milk and carry on beating until the mixture is completely lump-free. Stir in the soaked mushrooms and season.

Heat oven to 230C/210C fan/gas 8. Drizzle a little oil evenly into two four-hole Yorkshire pudding tins (or two 12-hole non-stick muffin tins to make 24 small puddings) and put in the oven for around 10 mins to heat through. Pour the batter into a jug and remove the hot, oiled tins from the oven. Carefully and evenly pour the batter into the holes. Put the tins back in the oven and leave for 20-25 mins until the puddings have puffed up and browned. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe, featuring whole milk, eggs, flour, and a generous addition of dried porcini mushrooms, creates a batter ideal for savory pancakes or crepes. The use of whole milk and eggs ensures a rich, creamy texture, while the umami depth from the porcini mushrooms elevates the dish's flavor profile. The simplicity and balance of the ingredients allow the earthiness of the mushrooms to shine through, making it appealing for those who appreciate robust savory notes. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe excludes meat, fish, and poultry, making it a versatile option for a meatless main or side. For best results, ensure a smooth, lump-free batter and allow the mushrooms to hydrate fully. The dish pairs excellently with a light herbed salad or a dollop of crème fraîche.

name: Triple pigs in blankets
author: BBC Good Food team
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Pile the sausages in groups of three and wrap a piece of bacon around each trio. Arrange on a baking tray and brush or drizzle with the oil. Roast in the oven for 30-35 mins until the chipolatas are golden and the bacon is crisp.
chief_review: This recipe is a classic, crowd-pleasing finger food featuring miniature chipolatas wrapped in crispy smoked streaky bacon, brushed with a touch of sunflower oil to achieve a perfectly caramelized finish. The combination of savory sausages and smoky bacon creates an irresistible flavor and appealing texture that is sure to be popular at gatherings. Preparation is straightforward, requiring minimal ingredients yet delivering maximum taste—a testament to the appeal of traditional British fare. Thanks to the absence of flours or breadcrumbs, this dish can also be enjoyed as part of a gluten-free diet, provided all packaged ingredients are checked to ensure no hidden gluten-containing additives. Serve these warm as an appetizer or alongside roasted meats for a festive accent.

name: Herb-infused roast potatoes
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 2½ kg Maris Piper potatoes, peeled and halved or quartered (depending on size)
large handful of mixed woody herbs(bay, thyme, rosemary) and parsley stalks
directions: Place the potatoes in a large pan of cold, salted water with the herbs. Bring the water to the boil and simmer gently for 8-10 mins until the potatoes are cooked through but not about to collapse. Gently drain the potatoes in a
, but don’t shake or ruffle up. Leave to drain and cool. If making ahead, place on a tray in a single layer and leave in the fridge, uncovered, until ready to roast.
Heat oven to 200C/180C/gas 6. Pour the oil into a deep
(the oil should be about 0.5cm deep) and put in the oven for 5 mins. Remove from the oven and gently tip the potatoes and herbs into the oil. Use a spoon or
to turn the potatoes until they’re completely coated in oil, then return the tin to the oven and roast for 40 mins.

Remove from the oven and turn the potatoes in the oil again. Return to the oven for 20 mins, then turn the potatoes in the oil once more. Turn the oven up to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and cook for a final 20 mins, or until golden and crunchy. Sprinkle with a little sea salt to serve.
chief_review: This classic roast potato recipe celebrates the noble Maris Piper, delivering crisp exteriors and fluffy interiors thanks to the generous use of sunflower oil. The infusion of mixed woody herbs—bay, thyme, rosemary, and parsley stalks—brings an aromatic depth that elevates the simple potato to a festive showstopper. Pure sunflower oil ensures a light, golden crunch and makes the dish suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Additionally, with no wheat or common allergens present, it’s ideal for gluten-free cooking and for those avoiding dairy and eggs. These potatoes would be a versatile side, complementing a wide array of mains from roast meats to hearty plant-based dishes, and are sure to please any crowd around the table.

name: Snowman biscuits
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 250g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
100g pack mixed red, yellow, black and blue ready-to-roll icing
directions: Heat the oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Cream the butter and sugar until pale and fluffy, then beat in the egg and vanilla. Stir in the flour and mix to a fairly soft dough. Tip onto a lightly floured surface and knead gently. Put the dough on a plate, cover and chill for at least 2 hrs.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to a thickness of around 0.5cm. Use a cookie cutter or water glass to stamp out 7cm rounds. Re-roll the trimmings and repeat.
Transfer the biscuits to two lined baking trays and bake for 8-14 mins until the edges turn lightly golden in colour. Leave to cool.

To decorate, roll out the white fondant icing on a surface lightly dusted with icing sugar. Stamp out 7cm circles using the same cookie cutter or glass as before, then use a dab of the white tube of icing to stick a fondant round on each biscuit.

Knead together some of the yellow and blue icing to make green icing, then do the same with the red and yellow icing to make orange (alternatively, buy separate packs of each colour). Roll out one icing colour at a time. Stamp out a 7cm circle of icing, cut in half and stick on for a hat. Cut a strip of another colour and make some markings to make it look like the elasticated band of a hat, then trim to fit and stick on. Repeat with all the biscuits, mixing and matching colours.

Decorate the hats with icing spots and stripes, if you like. Roll out balls of coloured icing, poke holes all over with a cocktail stick and stick on as pom poms. Mould lumpy balls of the orange icing for noses and roll out balls of the black icing for eyes. Press down to flatten, then stick on with white icing. Use the tube of black icing to pipe rows of dots for the smiles. Leave to set.
chief_review: This recipe yields classic butter-based cookies with a beautiful finish from fondant and ready-to-roll icing decorations. The dough comes together easily with pantry staples like butter, sugar, egg, vanilla, and flour, resulting in a tender crumb. The use of fondant and colored icing makes these cookies ideal for creative decorating—perfect for festive occasions or themed parties. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients except dairy and eggs. However, those with gluten intolerance or dairy or egg allergies should avoid this recipe, due to the presence of wheat flour, butter, and eggs. The end result is a delightful, visually stunning treat that balances sweet icing with a soft, buttery base—a crowd-pleaser for both kids’ parties and elegant gatherings.

name: Irish cream tiramisu
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 100ml Irish cream liqueur(we used Baileys coffee flavour)
300ml strong coffee, made with 2 tbsp coffee granules and 300ml boiling water
directions: Separate the egg whites and yolks into two large

the whites until stiff. Add the sugar to the yolks and whisk again (no need to clean first) until thick and foamy – this will take about 5 mins. Whisk the mascarpone and cream liqueur into the egg yolks until you can’t see any streaks of cheese. Carefully fold the whites into the mascarpone mixture with a large metal spoon to keep in as much air as possible.

Get your serving dish ready (ours was 20 x 15 cm). Pour the coffee into a shallow dish and dip in a few sponge fingers at a time, turning them for a few seconds until they are nicely soaked, but not soggy. Layer these into the dish until you have used half the biscuits, then evenly spread over half of the creamy mixture. Using the coarse side of the grater, grate over most of the chocolate, then repeat the sponge and cream layers (you should use up all the coffee). If you want a pretty finish, you can pipe on the final cream layer.
Cover and chill for a few hours or overnight.
To serve, dust with cocoa powder and grate over the remaining chocolate.
chief_review: This recipe is an indulgent take on a classic tiramisu, enriched with Irish cream liqueur and lush mascarpone. The clever layering of coffee-soaked sponge fingers and the creamy mascarpone mixture creates a textural contrast that is both pleasing and satisfying. The addition of Baileys elevates the flavor profile, adding warmth and a sophisticated note of coffee liqueur to each bite. The topping of grated dark chocolate and a dusting of cocoa powder delivers a pleasantly bittersweet finish. This dish is best suited for those who enjoy rich, coffee-infused desserts. Note that it contains both gluten and dairy, and is not suitable for those following a vegetarian or alcohol-free diet. Presented chilled, it's a show-stopping dessert perfect for festive gatherings or special occasions.

name: Brown sugar brandy cream
description: This simple brandy cream can be made in five minutes and is lighter than some traditional brandy butters
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 tbsp light muscovado sugar, plus a little extra for sprinkling
directions: Mix together the crème fraîche, vanilla seeds, brandy and sugar. This can be chilled for up to 2 days – just give everything a good stir. sprinkle on a little extra sugar before serving.
chief_review: This brandy cream is a delightful, lighter alternative to classic brandy butters, offering a tangy richness thanks to the crème fraîche base. The addition of real vanilla seeds enhances the depth of flavor, while the light muscovado sugar introduces a subtle caramel note that pairs wonderfully with the warmth of the brandy. It’s a quick, five-minute recipe that yields an elegant topping, perfect for drizzling over festive desserts like Christmas pudding or fruitcake. As the recipe contains only dairy and excludes eggs and gluten, it is well-suited for those following a vegetarian or gluten-free diet. The simple preparation makes it ideal for entertaining, providing a sophisticated touch with minimal effort.

name: Festive fruit & spice decoration
description: Decorating a simple iced cake with herbs, spices, nuts and fruit works to great effect and is especially easy for beginners to try
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 18-23cm fruit cake covered with marzipan and ready-to-roll white icing
cinnamon sticks, gold dragees, gold candles and a wide gold ribbon
directions: Line a baking sheet with non-stick baking paper and heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Cut the orange into thin slices and space out in a single layer. Sift over a thin layer of icing sugar and bake for 40-45 mins until dry but not over-browned. Allow to cool completely.

Meanwhile, make the frosted rosemary. Beat the egg white with a fork until lightly frothy, then spread the caster sugar over a large, flat plate. Dip the tips of the rosemary into the egg white, shake off the excess and roll in the caster sugar. Set aside to dry on a sheet of baking paper or a plate, for at least 30 mins.

Meanwhile, make the royal icing. To decorate, spoon almost all of the royal icing onto the centre of the cake. Arrange the frosted rosemary, a couple of orange slices and the rest of the decorations on top, pressing them into the icing to secure. Position the candles last. Tie the ribbon around the base and fix with a dot of leftover icing.
chief_review: This festive cake decoration recipe brings vibrant color and texture to a classic fruit cake, making it an approachable project for beginners. The combination of fresh orange, aromatic rosemary, and winter spices such as star anise and cinnamon gives the cake a visually stunning finish while enhancing the sensory experience. The addition of gold dragees and ribbon offers an elegant touch appropriate for celebratory occasions. Since the cake is already covered with marzipan and white icing, there's no complex construction involved—making this an ideal adornment for those seeking showstopping results without advanced pastry skills. The use of egg white in both the royal icing and for sugaring adds a delicate finish, though this means the recipe is not suitable for vegans or those avoiding raw eggs. Overall, it’s an accessible yet beautiful way to present a classic holiday cake.

name: Savoy cabbage with shallots & fennel seeds
description: Soften shallots before stir-frying with cabbage and fennel seeds for a low fat, healthy side dish - perfect with a hearty roast dinner
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 Savoy cabbage(outer leaves discarded) quartered, cored and shredded
directions: Boil the shallots in their skins for 10-15 mins until they are soft but still hold their shape. Leave to cool then slip the skins from the shallots and halve them. Can be prepared a couple of days in advance, then chilled.
Heat the oil in a large non-stick wok, and stir-fry the garlic, fennel seeds and shallots for a couple of mins until the shallots are golden. Remove from the pan.

Add the cabbage to the pan and stir-fry until it starts to wilt a little, then pour in the stock, cover the wok and cook for 3 mins until just tender. Test to see if the cabbage is done to your liking; if not, cook a little longer, then add the shallot mixture, heat through and serve.
chief_review: This cabbage and shallot side dish demonstrates a delicate balance of flavors, with the natural sweetness of softened shallots blending beautifully with aromatic fennel seeds. The addition of garlic and a gentle braising in vegetable stock enhances the cabbage's natural texture, resulting in a tender, flavourful accompaniment that won't overpower the main event. The use of olive oil and fresh vegetables keeps the dish light, healthy, and satisfying. This recipe is a stellar choice for those following vegetarian and vegan diets and is also gluten-free as written—making it an exceptionally versatile side for a variety of dietary needs. It pairs particularly well with hearty mains and is a thoughtful addition to any wholesome meal.

name: Deep-fried Brussels with black pudding & apple
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1 Granny Smithapple, cored, peeled and cubed
directions: Heat the butter in a small frying pan over a medium heat. Once foaming, add the apple. Fry for 2 mins until beginning to caramelise, then remove with a slotted spoon onto a plate. Add the black pudding to the butter and cook for a further 2 mins, turning halfway until crispy. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside with the apple.
Whisk the mustard, honey and vinegar into the butter and cook for 30 secs. Taste for seasoning and set aside on a very low heat to keep warm

Heat the oil in a large, heavy-bottomed saucepan until it reads 190C on a thermometer, or a piece of bread browns in it within 15 secs. Carefully drop in the sprouts and cook for 3 mins until deep golden brown. Drain on kitchen paper, then scatter with flaky sea salt. Divide the sprouts between two plates, along with the watercress, apple and black pudding, then drizzle over the warm dressing.
chief_review: This recipe balances rich and earthy flavors with freshness, thanks to the black pudding paired with tart Granny Smith apple and peppery watercress. The Brussels sprouts, fried to crisp perfection, add robust texture while the honey-mustard and sherry vinegar dressing introduces a sweet-sharp complexity that lifts the whole dish. The use of butter enhances the overall depth, making it a truly indulgent starter or small plate, especially suited to autumn or winter menus. This dish is not suitable for vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free diets, but it can be an excellent choice for those seeking a hearty, flavorful appetizer rooted in traditional British ingredients. The combination of contrasting textures and flavors demonstrates thoughtful composition and would stand out in a contemporary bistro setting.

name: Quick pickled onions
description: These colourful, spiced sweet and sour onions add piquancy to a ploughman’s, or a sharp finish to Mexican food - an ideal edible gift to make ahead and pop in a homemade hamper
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 3 small red onions, sliced into rings
directions: Pour the vinegar into a pan, add the sugar, sea salt, the spices and bay leaf, and bring to a simmer. After 1 min, check that the sugar and salt have dissolved. Remove from the heat.

Boil the kettle. Put the onion slices in a sieve or colander. Pour over the hot water from the kettle and drain well. When cool enough to handle, pack the onion rings into a 500g sterilised jar (see tip below). Pour over the warm vinegar and seal. Cool, then chill and leave to pickle for 2 hrs. Will keep for 6 months unopened, or 2 weeks in the fridge once opened.
chief_review: This recipe for spiced sweet and sour onions is a delightful condiment, delivering complexity and a vibrant kick to a variety of dishes, from traditional ploughman’s platters to lively Mexican fare. The aromatic combination of cider vinegar, spices, and sugar beautifully balances sweetness with acidity, enhancing the natural flavor of red onions. Star anise and coriander seeds lend a subtle warmth, while black peppercorns and bay leaf add depth and a fragrant finish. Impressively, this recipe is both vegan and gluten-free, making it suitable for those with such dietary preferences or intolerances. The simplicity of the ingredients ensures broad appeal, and the absence of common allergens like dairy, nuts, and wheat makes it an excellent pantry staple or edible gift. Ideal for making ahead, these onions bring a gourmet touch to any homemade hamper.

name: Panettone muffins
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 50g golden caster sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Mix the flour, yeast, milk and a pinch of salt in a tabletop
with a dough hook. Mix in two eggs and the vanilla, then knead until you have a smooth, springy dough. Cover and leave to rise for at least 2 hrs, or overnight in the fridge, until doubled in size.

Start the mixer again and add the sugar, butter and yolk from the remaining egg. Keep mixing and kneading until the dough is smooth again. Tip in the fruit and knead again quickly. Cover and leave to rise somewhere cool or in the fridge (so the butter doesn’t melt out of the dough) for at least two hours, or overnight in the fridge, until doubled in size.

Line a large six-hole muffin tin with paper cases. Divide the dough into six portions and roll into neat balls. Put a ball in each paper case, cover the tin with a tea towel and leave the dough to rise for 20 mins. Alternatively, chill in the fridge overnight, then leave the dough balls to warm up for 30 mins before baking.

Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Brush the tops of the muffins with the egg white and dust with caster sugar. Bake for 15-20 mins, or until the muffins have risen and are golden brown in colour. Leave to cool on a
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful, enriched bread with a tender crumb and rich flavor profile, thanks to the combination of butter, whole milk, eggs, and the fragrant hint of orange zest. The inclusion of raisins, sultanas, and mixed peel infuses the loaf with bursts of sweetness and chewiness, making it reminiscent of classic festive breads. The soft dough, lightly spiced with vanilla, yields a satisfying, golden crust when dusted with caster sugar. Vegetarians can enjoy this bread as it contains no meat or gelatin-based ingredients. However, note the presence of gluten (from the flour), dairy (milk and butter), and eggs, making it unsuitable for those with related allergies or following vegan or gluten-free diets. Overall, this bread is perfect for a festive breakfast or as a sweet treat with tea.

name: Buttery shallot bread sauce
description: This bread sauce has flavour layered up from the very start ,with almost-melting shallots, herbs and spices
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1 bay leaf, plus extra to serve
100g fresh white breadcrumbs, from a good-quality loaf
5 tbsp single or double cream, plus more to serve, if you like
¼ tsp freshly grated nutmeg, or to taste
directions: Heat the butter and oil in a pan, then add the shallots, cloves, thyme and bay and cook very, very gently for 15 mins until soft, translucent and pale golden.

Remove the cloves, add the milk and pepper, then bring to a gentle simmer for 10 mins. Stir in the breadcrumbs, give it another 5 mins or so over a very low heat until the bread has plumped up nicely, then stir in the cream and nutmeg. Fish out the stalks from the thyme – the leaves will have fallen off. Season to taste. To serve, grate over a little more nutmeg, drizzle with a little more cream and decorate with a bay leaf.
chief_review: This bread sauce recipe excels in both depth of flavor and luxurious texture. The slow-cooked shallots, gently sweated in butter and olive oil, lay a sweet, mellow base beautifully complemented by aromatic cloves, thyme, and bay. Full-fat milk and cream deliver a rich, comforting mouthfeel, while fresh breadcrumbs lend the traditional, velvety body to the sauce. White pepper and freshly grated nutmeg finish everything with just the right amount of warmth and spice. The method thoughtfully develops robust flavor, making this sauce a superb accompaniment for celebratory roasts. Suitable for vegetarians, provided the bread chosen is free of animal-derived additives, it's a classic that brings indulgence and elegance to the table.

name: Pork rillettes
description: A French dish of potted meat with garlic, juniper and brandy. Slow-cook pork until tender then set into individual ramekins for a sensational starter
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1kg rindless, boneless pork belly(it pays to use the best-quality pork you can find for this dish), cut into roughly walnut-sized cubes
10 juniper berries, roughly crushed, plush extra to decorate (optional)
large splash of brandy or Calvados
directions: Reserve 1 bay leaf, then tip everything except the duck fat and serving suggestions into a bowl and season generously. If you have time, cover and leave the meat to marinate overnight in the fridge – however, this isn’t essential.

Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1. Tip the meat and all the juices into a flameproof casserole dish with a lid. Pour over 250ml water, or enough to just cover the meat, and place the pan on a low heat. As soon as it starts to bubble, pop on the lid and put in the oven for 2½-3 hrs, removing it once to give it a good stir.

The meat should now be very tender. Leave it to cool slightly in the pan, then drain over a bowl to catch the fat and juices. Shred the pork by hand or put in a food processor and pulse a few times to shred, but don’t overwork it into a paste. Taste, add extra seasoning if needed, then press meat into 2 small or 1 large serving dish, or pack into individual ramekins. Pour the juices and fat back over the meat, and put in the fridge for at least 2 hrs for the fat to harden. (To keep the rillettes for a week or so, cover with a layer of duck fat, and lay a bay leaf and a couple of juniper berries on top for decoration.)
Serve with sourdough toast, cornichons and a few bitter leaves (such as curly endive, rocket and radicchio), in a sharp mustardy dressing.
chief_review: This traditional French potted meat presents pork belly slowly cooked with aromatic juniper, fragrant thyme, and a whisper of garlic, then lifted with the subtle warmth of brandy. The addition of duck or goose fat delivers rich, velvety depth and preserves the meat’s succulence, while a touch of Chinese five-spice powder adds an intriguing complexity. Presented in individual ramekins, the dish makes for a sophisticated and indulgent starter. Serve with crisp sourdough toast, tart cornichons, and dressed bitter leaves for a balanced plate that excites the palate. This recipe is well-suited to those following a gluten-free diet if served without the sourdough toast or with gluten-free alternatives. It is also a fitting centerpiece for anyone seeking a classic charcuterie-style appetizer, capturing the essence of rustic French cuisine.

name: Spicy prawn poppadoms
description: These are some of the quickest canapes to make, but are best made to order to prevent the poppadoms from going soft
author: Good Food
ingredients: 24 cooked and peeled extra large tiger prawns, thawed if frozen
24 ready-to-eat mini poppadums, plain or assorted
directions: Dry the prawns on kitchen paper and keep covered in the fridge. Lay out the poppadums on a serving platter.
Before serving, spoon a little tzatziki into each poppadum. Stand a prawn on top, then finish with a scattering of coriander and a light dusting of paprika.
chief_review: This canapé recipe is a delightful fusion of crisp mini poppadums topped with succulent tiger prawns and a dollop of creamy tzatziki, all brightened by coriander and a sprinkle of paprika. The interplay of textures—crunchy base, juicy prawns, and cooling yogurt—creates a balanced bite bursting with refreshing and savory flavors. The assembly is straightforward and rapid, making it ideal for last-minute entertaining. While the tzatziki provides a Mediterranean twist, the use of prawns keeps the dish light yet satisfying. Perfect for pescatarian guests, this recipe avoids red meat and is free of nuts—a thoughtful touch for allergy-sensitive eaters. Be sure to assemble just before serving to preserve the poppadums’ crispness. A sophisticated yet simple canapé, sure to impress with minimal effort.

name: Passion fruit cream
description: Simple and delicious!
author: Thomasina Miers
ingredients: 1 tbsp Cointreauor triple sec, plus some to serve
directions: Whisk the yolk and sugar until light and fluffy and doubled in size, about 3 mins. Beat in the Cointreau, lemon and the flesh of 2 passion fruits. Softly whip the cream until it just holds some shape (it stiffens quickly towards the end so whip slowly as it gets thicker). Chill 2 dessert glasses.

To assemble, gently fold the egg mix into the double cream, having first given the eggs another brisk whisk. Spoon the cream into little glasses and top them with the seeds from the remaining passion fruit and a drizzle of Cointreau.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful blend of creamy richness and tangy passion fruit, balanced by the subtle orange notes of Cointreau or triple sec. The method is straightforward, making it accessible for both amateur cooks and those with more experience. The use of fresh passion fruit elevates the dessert, adding freshness and a hint of exotic flavor. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin, this dessert is indulgent and elegant—perfect for a dinner party or special occasion. The finish with an extra splash of liqueur is a nice touch, enhancing the flavor complexity without overpowering the other ingredients. Enjoy chilled for maximum effect.

name: Herby root vegetable gratin
description: Layer thinly sliced potato, swede and parsnip then bake with a cream, garlic and Parmesan sauce for a decadent side dish
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Melt half the butter in a large saucepan, add the onion and cook until soft. Pour in the cream and milk, and add lots of seasoning. Add the sliced vegetables and gently simmer for 10 mins until the potatoes start to soften.
Meanwhile, blend the herbs, garlic, most of the Parmesan and some seasoning in a food processor. Add the oil and blend again to form a paste.

Tip a third of the creamy veg into a buttered baking dish, dollop over half the herb mix and spread out a little. Top with another third of the veg, followed by the remaining herb mix, then the rest of the vegetables. Dot the surface with the remaining butter and scatter over the reserved Parmesan. Bake for 1-1½ hrs until bubbling and golden, covering with foil for the final 30 mins if it’s becoming too brown. Leave to rest for 10-15 mins before serving.
chief_review: This root vegetable bake is a luxurious and comforting side dish, perfect for elevating any dinner table. The combination of potato, swede, and parsnip, sliced thin and baked in a rich cream and garlic sauce, brings out the natural sweetness and earthy flavors of the vegetables. Onion and fresh herbs add aromatic depth, while Parmesan cheese lends a savory finish. Notably, this dish can be easily adapted for a vegetarian diet by using a vegetarian Parmesan alternative. With its hearty and indulgent texture, this recipe is ideal for festive occasions or when you want to impress your guests with a dish that feels both rustic and refined. Serve alongside roasted meats, poultry, or as part of a larger vegetarian spread.

name: Clementine, cranberry & pistachio meringue wreath
description: This stunning dinner party dessert makes a showstopping centrepiece - the individually portioned pieces make serving really simple
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 small clementines, zested, then peeled and sliced
100g pistachios(slivered ones look nice, but use chopped if you can’t find them)
directions: Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 2 and cut a piece of baking parchment large enough to line your biggest baking sheet. Using a plate as a template, draw a circle roughly 28cm in diameter onto the parchment, then flip it over onto the baking sheet so the pencil marks don’t come into contact with the meringue.

Put the egg whites in a large, clean bowl and beat with an electric whisk until doubled in volume and holding soft peaks. Add the sugar 1 or 2 tbsp at a time, whisking continuously, until the meringue is stiff and shiny, and the sugar has been used up.

Dab a blob of meringue on each corner of the parchment to stick it to the baking sheet. Using the circle as a guide, spoon 10 mounds of meringue onto the parchment in a wreath shape. Create a little divot in the centre of each one with the back of a teaspoon. Bake for 1 hr 30 mins, then leave in the oven to cool completely (overnight if you can).

Put the cranberries and sugar in a saucepan and bring to a simmer. Turn up the heat and boil for 1-2 mins, until you have a sugary syrup, but the cranberries are still whole. Leave to cool completely.

When you’re ready to serve, place the meringue wreath on a large board or plate. Pour the cream into a bowl, and add the zest and liqueur, if using. Whip until the cream just holds soft peaks. Fill each meringue crevice with a spoonful of cream, then top with 1-2 slices of clementine and some cranberries. Drizzle some cranberry syrup and sprinkle generously with pistachios, then let everyone dive in.
chief_review: This elegant dessert is both visually striking and convenient for entertaining, thanks to its individual portions. The light meringues—crafted from egg whites and sugar—perfectly complement the tangy cranberries and fresh clementines, offering a balance of sweetness and acidity. The addition of orange liqueur brings a refined citrus depth, while the pistachios add a lovely texture and appealing color. Whipped cream ties it all together for a rich, indulgent mouthfeel. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat, poultry, or fish. However, those with nut allergies or dairy intolerances should take note of the pistachios and cream. All in all, this dessert would make a memorable finish to any special meal, delighting guests with both flavor and presentation.

name: Duck satay with peanut sauce
description: Easy to do, tasted delicious will be making again
author: John Torode
ingredients: 1 long red chilli, split down the centre
directions: Place the sugar, soy, Shaohsing or sherry, star anise, cinnamon, chilli and 100ml water into a pan. Bring to the boil, then remove from the heat and cool. Slice the duck into thin strips, about 5mm wide, and place in the marinade. Leave in the fridge overnight.

Remove the duck from the marinade. Pour 100ml of the marinade into a small pan along with the peanut butter. Finely chop half the marinated chilli, or pound to a paste using a pestle and mortar, and place in the pan. Cook over a low heat, letting it bubble for at least 5 mins. Add a little water if it starts to dry out. The sauce can be made up to 2 days ahead and kept in the fridge.

To cook the satay, thread the duck strips onto 20 wooden skewers that have been soaked in water for 1 hr. Mix 4 tbsp of the peanut sauce with the oil and brush all over the duck. Heat a griddle pan until really hot, then cook the duck for about 10 mins, turning until golden all over. You will have to do this in batches, so keep some warm in a low oven or make a day ahead and reheat in the oven. Serve with peanut dipping sauce.
chief_review: This recipe masterfully blends sweet, salty, and aromatic notes for a restaurant-worthy dish that's surprisingly simple to execute at home. The combination of palm or dark brown sugar, soy sauce, and Shaohsing wine creates a rich, umami-forward marinade, elevated by the warmth of star anise, cinnamon, and chilli. Duck breast remains juicy and flavorful, complemented by an indulgently creamy peanut butter sauce. The recipe is well-suited for lactose-free diets since it contains no dairy. Those following a gluten-free diet should opt for tamari or certified gluten-free soy sauce, and ensure the Shaohsing wine or sherry is gluten-free as well. Take note of the peanut butter for anyone with nut allergies. Overall, these flavors are both bold and balanced, delivering a gourmet experience with minimal effort—a definite repeat for any dinner rotation.

name: Caramelised cranberry relish
description: Homemade cranberry sauce with port is the little finishing touch to set off a festive dinner - it goes well with cheese and ham too
author: Good Food
ingredients: small piece ginger, finely shredded into matchsticks
directions: Use a zester to zest the orange or use a peeler to peel off the zest, then finely shred it with a knife and set aside with the ginger. Halve and juice the orange.

Tip the orange juice and sugar into a shallow saucepan and boil gently until you get an amber-orange caramel. Scatter the zest and ginger into the caramel, cook for 1 min, then tip in the cranberries and Port, if using. Cook everything on a high heat for 5 mins until the cranberries are starting to split but still have texture. Leave to cool and serve with the turkey.
chief_review: This homemade cranberry sauce with port is a delightful addition to any festive table, balancing tart cranberries with the sweet depth of golden caster sugar and subtle warmth from fresh ginger. The orange provides a bright citrus note, elevating the sauce’s complexity and freshness. A splash of port, though optional, adds a luxurious, grown-up richness that pairs beautifully with both cheese and ham. Impressively, this recipe is well-suited for vegetarian and vegan diets—simply ensure the port used is vegan-friendly. Additionally, it contains no gluten, dairy, or nuts, making it accessible for a range of dietary needs. Easy to prepare and deeply flavorful, this vibrant sauce promises to set off your meal with a memorable, artisan touch.

name: Herby mustard Yorkies
description: These quick, easy, fluffy Yorkshire Puddings can be prepared ahead - but make sure you leave the oven door closed while cooking!
author: Good Food
ingredients: large bunch rosemary and thyme, leaves picked
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. In a bowl, beat the flour and mustard powder with the eggs until you have a smooth, thick batter. Gradually beat in the milk until the batter is the same consistency as single cream, then stir in the herbs, and season.

Pour a drizzle of oil into each hole of a sturdy 12-hole muffin tin. Put the tin in the oven and heat for 5 mins. Working quickly, remove the tin and pour enough batter into each hole so that it comes two-thirds of the way up the sides. Carefully place the tin back in the oven and cook the puddings for about 20 mins until they are puffed up and brown.
chief_review: This Yorkshire Pudding recipe yields impressively fluffy results with a pronounced savory depth from English mustard powder and fragrant notes from fresh rosemary and thyme. The combination of five eggs and ample milk ensures an airy, rich interior with a beautifully crisp exterior—quintessential to the classic pudding. With only pantry staples and fresh herbs, execution is straightforward, making it ideal for both everyday meals and special roasts. While traditional, the use of plain flour means gluten is present, but the absence of meat suits a vegetarian diet. These puddings are best enjoyed fresh, but you can prepare the batter ahead for convenience. For perfect lift, resist opening the oven!

name: Easy mince pies with crunchy crumble tops
description: These individual pies with a twist are great for using up storecupboard staples such as nuts and dried fruit, they're budget-friendly too
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 25g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Put the dried fruit and jam in a small pan, heat until melted together, then stir in the brandy and cool. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

For the pastry, set aside 2 tbsp flour and put the rest plus the butter in a food processor. Whizz until there are no lumps of butter. Pulse in the egg yolk, followed by a tbsp of water at a time, until the dough comes together – you’ll probably need 2 tbsp. (If you don’t have a food processor, rub butter into the flour with your fingers, then stir in the yolk and water with a round-bladed knife.) Use the reserved flour to roll out the pastry to just over the thickness of a £1 coin. Stamp circles with an 8cm cutter and press into holes of a bun tin – you should get 15 from re-rolling the trimmings.

Divide the fruit amongst the pies, then bake for 5 mins while you rub together all the crumble ingredients with your fingers. Top each pie with crumble, then return to the oven for 15 mins until pastry and crumble are golden. Eat warm or cold dusted with icing sugar.
chief_review: This inventive take on individual pies leverages pantry staples like dried mixed fruit, apricot jam, and nuts, delivering a pleasing combination of sweet and nutty flavors. The recipe's simplicity, with a buttery pastry enriched by egg yolk and topped with chopped almonds, makes it accessible and budget-conscious without sacrificing taste. Its touch of brandy elevates the filling, rounding off the fruitiness with subtle warmth. Suitable for vegetarians, this dessert offers both texture and depth, making it an excellent addition to a festive or everyday spread. The use of icing sugar and apricot jam ensures a glossy, inviting finish. These pies are a delightful treat, ideal for making ahead, sharing, or presenting as a casual dinner party finale.

name: Dazzling beetroot-cured salmon
description: This salmon needs to be made at least three days ahead, which means very little work to do on Christmas day
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 85g fresh horseradish (little finger-length piece) peeled and finely grated, or grated horseradish from a jar
3 medium raw beetroot (about 250g/9oz), coarsely grated (no need to peel)
1 frisée, or oak leaf lettuce, leaves separated
4 medium beetroot, cooked, peeled and diced
2 tbsp freshly grated horseradish or grated horseradish from the jar
directions: Lay the salmon fillets, skin side down, on a board and brush your hand along it. If you feel any little pin bones pinch them out with your fingers or tweezers. In a bowl, mix all of the other ingredients for the salmon together to make the cure.

Stretch two large sheets of cling film over a work surface and spoon over some of the cure. Lay one of the fillets, skin side down, on the cure, then pack over most of the cure, and sandwich with the remaining fillet, skin side up. Top with the last of the cure and wrap both fillets together tightly with lots of cling film. Place in a container with sides, like a large roasting tray, put a smaller tray on top and weigh it down with a couple of tins. Leave in the fridge for at least three days or up to a week. Don’t be alarmed by the amount of liquid that leaks out, this is normal. Once a day, pour away the liquid, turn the salmon and re-apply the weights.

To serve, unwrap the salmon from the cling film and brush off the marinade. Slice the salmon into thin slivers. Make the dressing by mixing all the ingredients together with some salt and pepper. Toss all the salad ingredients together and serve each guest with a few slices of salmon, a handful of salad and drizzle with the dressing. Once made the salmon will sit happily in the fridge for up to a week and can be used just like smoked salmon.
chief_review: This vibrant cured salmon recipe offers an impressive centerpiece with minimal last-minute effort—ideal for festive occasions. The blend of beetroot, horseradish, dill, and lemon infuses the fish with both color and a bright, earthy flavor profile. The use of sea salt and sugar provides a classic cure, ensuring a luscious yet firm texture. Served atop a bed of crisp lettuce and complemented by crème fraîche, this dish is particularly suitable for pescatarians and those following a gluten-free diet, given the absence of wheat or gluten-containing ingredients. The simple preparation makes it approachable for cooks of all skill levels, while the flavors are sophisticated enough to impress any guest. Perfectly balanced, and well thought out for advance prep, this dish captures festive luxury with minimal fuss.

name: Calvados-glazed apples
description: Match Gordon Ramsay's wonderfully appley sauce with roast goose, pork or Christmas turkey
author: Gordon Ramsay
directions: Quarter the apples, cut out the cores and trim the ends. Heat the butter in a frying pan and toss in the apple wedges and sage. Cook for 2 mins, then sprinkle in the golden caster sugar and continue cooking for about 5 mins, stirring gently until golden and softened. Pour in the Calvados and cautiously flambé. Season lightly and keep warm until ready to serve.
chief_review: This apple sauce recipe is a delightfully aromatic accompaniment that brings a vibrant, tangy sweetness to rich meats like roast goose, pork, or turkey—just as Gordon Ramsay recommends. The use of Granny Smith apples ensures a tart freshness, while sage adds an earthy flourish and the Calvados lends a sophisticated, boozy note. Golden caster sugar provides balanced sweetness, and the butter enriches the sauce, resulting in a luscious mouthfeel. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly, making it a versatile addition to festive tables. Simple to prepare yet bursting with complex flavors, it elevates classic roast dishes with finesse and seasonal flair.

name: Ginger cookie sandwiches with lemon mascarpone
description: Delicious biscuits. Great consistency, texture and amazing flavour. I had no problems rolling although did chill them for 2 nights so not sure if that's why. Will definitely be making these again.
author: Edd Kimber
ingredients: ¼ tsp ground cardamom(the seeds from 3 pods, crushed – see tip)
directions: To make the cookies, put the butter, sugars, treacle, egg and vanilla in a large bowl and mix together with an electric whisk until smooth and combined. In a separate bowl, mix together the remaining ingredients except the demerara. Add the dry ingredients to the egg mixture and mix until a very sticky dough is formed. Cover with cling film and chill for at least 4 hrs.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and line two baking trays with baking parchment. Roll the cookie dough into balls, about a tablespoon in size, then roll in the demerara sugar. Place on the lined trays, leaving about 2.5cm space between cookies.

Bake for about 14 mins or until just lightly browned around the edges, swapping the trays over halfway through cooking. Allow to cool on the trays for 10 mins before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

To make the filling, beat together the mascarpone and lemon curd in a bowl until smooth and creamy. Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a plain round piping tip. Pipe a layer of the cream onto the base of half the cookies and sandwich together with the other half. Will keep for 3-4 days in a sealed container in the fridge – the texture will turn soft and cakey (this is no bad thing).
chief_review: These biscuits impress with a beautifully balanced mix of warming spices and a rich, tender crumb. The use of black treacle and brown sugar gives them a deep, caramelized note, while ground ginger and subtle hints of cardamom deliver aromatic complexity. Rolling them in demerara sugar adds a delicate crunch to each bite. The mascarpone and lemon curd topping creates a luscious and zesty finish, making these biscuits truly memorable. Thanks to the gluten-free flour blend, this recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, and the inclusion of eggs and dairy provides a rich, indulgent texture. Chilling the dough ensures easy handling and enhances the final texture, making them perfect for bakers seeking reliable results. An excellent choice for a special treat or festive platter.

name: Winter crunch salad
description: A crispy, fresh vegetarian salad to use up those winter vegetables
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 celery sticks, cut into thin diagonal slices
1 bunch of radishes, trimmed and quartered
50g shelled walnut or pecans, toasted and roughly chopped
2 red-skinned eating apples, cored and cut into slim wedges
4-5 tbsp ready-made honey and mustard dressing, to serve
directions: Preheat the oven and cook the garlic bread according to packet instructions.
While the bread is in the oven separate the chicory into leaves and toss in a large bowl with the celery, radishes, nuts and apples. Crumble the stilton in large chunks over the top.

To finish the salad, cut half the garlic bread into the marked slices. Cut the remainder into chunks and toss into the salad with as much dressing as you like. Serve with the remaining garlic bread on the side.
chief_review: This vibrant winter salad brings together the crunch of chicory, celery, and radish, with the sweetness of apple and the richness of blue cheese, perfectly complemented by toasted nuts. The addition of garlic bread adds a satisfying, hearty element, making it more substantial than a typical side salad. The honey and mustard dressing ties the flavors together with a pleasant tang and sweetness. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and offers plenty of texture and taste contrasts in every bite. The use of seasonal produce makes it especially appealing during colder months, transforming humble winter vegetables into a sophisticated, well-balanced dish. Perfect as a light lunch or a lively appetizer.

name: Crumbled top mince pies
description: Shortcrust pastry mincemeat pies with a twist - an extra crunchy and nutty crumble on top
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: satsuma, grated zest and juice of
directions: To make the pastry tip the flour into a large bowl and rub in the chilled butter using your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar and the satsuma zest.

Spoon out 4 tbsp of the pastry mixture and set aside. Add approximately 4 tbsp of the juice from the satsumas to the main pastry mix to make a fairly soft dough, kneading gently until smooth. Wrap in cling film and chill for 30 mins.

Lightly flour a surface and roll out the pastry to a £1 coin thickness. Using a 9cm fluted cutter, stamp out 12 circles of pastry. Gently press these into individual tartlet tins, the pastry should just protrude above the tins to allow for shrinkage when cooked. Spoon the mincemeat into the pastry cases being careful not to overfill.

Sprinkle the pastry crumble mix over the mincemeat to cover lightly, top with the flaked almonds and drizzle over the stem ginger syrup. At this stage you can cover them with cling film and freeze the whole tray ready for baking.

When you're ready to bake the mince pies, heat the over to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Remove the cling film from the tray and bake the mince pies straight from the freezer for 25 mins until golden and cooked through. Cool on a wire rack and serve dusted with icing sugar. Bake unfrozen pies for 18-20 mins.
chief_review: This inventive take on classic mincemeat pies brings a delightful texture contrast with its nutty almond crumble topping. The shortcrust pastry is beautifully tender, and the addition of satsuma zest and juice adds a bright, citrusy lift that balances the sweetness of the mincemeat. The stem ginger syrup imparts a subtle warmth, pairing nicely with the muscovado sugar for deep, caramel undertones. Flaked almonds provide welcome crunch and a hint of nuttiness that works exceptionally well with the rich filling. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat products or gelatine. However, it does include wheat (plain flour), butter (dairy), and nuts (almonds), so it’s best avoided by those with gluten, dairy, or nut allergies. Overall, this recipe offers a festive twist on a traditional favorite, making it perfect for holiday gatherings.

name: Cranberry, fresh pear & cinnamon bubbles
description: The cinnamon wasn't too popular and tends to just sit on top but overall it was a nice start to the evening.
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
directions: In a blender, purée the pears until smooth. Pour into a jug, then add a small splash of cranberry juice to stop the pear discolouring.

When your guests arrive, put a few tsps purée in the bottom of each flute or glass, then add a splash more juice. Add a pinch of cinnamon, then top up with chilled Cava. Serve immediately, before making another batch with the leftover purée.
chief_review: This refreshing recipe artfully combines the crisp sweetness of ripe pears with the tartness of cranberry juice and the celebratory fizz of cava. While the ground cinnamon adds aromatic complexity, it’s worth noting it may remain somewhat separate if not well incorporated—consider stirring thoroughly or infusing for a smoother blend. The simplicity and elegance of this dish make it a delightful palate opener for an evening gathering. With no animal-derived ingredients, it is suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets, and its use of naturally gluten-free ingredients also makes it an excellent option for those with gluten sensitivities.

name: Prawn cocktail crostini
description: Turn a classic into bite-sized, party pieces with this simple recipe
author: Good Food
ingredients: large ciabatta, diagonally cut into 8 slices
cayenne pepperand lemon wedges, to serve
directions: To make the sauce, mix all ingredients in a bowl, season well and set to one side. If you’re making this the day before, cover and place in the fridge until needed. Peel, then chop the avocados into small chunks, tossing in lemon juice as you go, so they don’t discolour.

Mix the prawns with half the sauce, add the avocados and stir gently to coat everything. Heat a griddle pan. To make the crostini, rub a little olive oil onto each slice of ciabatta and grill on each side for 2 mins until toasted.
To serve, spread a little cocktail sauce on each crostini, top with a lettuce leaf and add a spoonful of the prawn cocktail mix. Sprinkle with a little cayenne pepper and serve with lemon wedges.
chief_review: This prawn and avocado crostini recipe is a delightful reinterpretation of the classic prawn cocktail, perfect for parties and gatherings. The creamy avocado, zesty lemon juice, and succulent tiger prawns create a harmonious topping, while the ciabatta base offers satisfying crunch. The sauce—mayonnaise enlivened with tomato ketchup, a hint of brandy, and a dash of Tabasco—brings a well-balanced tang and richness. Crisp Baby Gem lettuce adds freshness, and a sprinkle of cayenne delivers gentle heat. This recipe is ideal for pescatarians and can accommodate a gluten-free diet if gluten-free bread is used instead of ciabatta. Those with dairy or nut allergies will also find this preparation suitable, provided the mayonnaise is free of such allergens. Overall, it’s a refined yet accessible bite bursting with vibrant flavors and contrasting textures—a guaranteed crowd-pleaser.

name: Smoked fish & potato latkes sharing platter
description: Pan-fry potato patties until golden, then serve with smoked salmon, mackerel and a creamy sauce as part of a sharing seafood platter
author: Jenny White
ingredients: 1 onion, grated and excess moisture squeezed out
2 tbsp chopped herbs(we used parsley, dill and basil)
2 lemons, cut into wedges, to serve
directions: Soak the potatoes in cold water for 1 hr, drain, then cut into quarters. Cook in boiling salted water for 5 mins, drain and set aside until cool enough to handle. Coarsely grate and transfer to a bowl.

Stir in the onion, garlic, flour, egg and plenty of seasoning. Divide the mixture into 24 and shape into small patties (known as latkes). Heat a little of the butter and oil in a large non-stick frying pan and fry the latkes over a medium heat for 3-4 mins each side until golden brown (you will need to do this in batches, add more butter and oil each time). Drain on kitchen paper and keep warm.

Mix the crème fraîche, herbs and horseradish sauce together and season. Spoon the mixture into a serving bowl. Slice the smoked salmon into strips and break the smoked mackerel into bite-sized pieces. Arrange on a serving platter with the potato latkes, herby crème fraîche and some lemon wedges.
chief_review: This seafood sharing platter is a delightful mix of crisp, golden potato patties paired with the distinctive flavors of smoked salmon and mackerel. The recipe is both indulgent and balanced, using crème fraîche, fresh herbs, and horseradish sauce for a zesty, creamy finish. The fritters—a blend of potatoes, onion, and garlic—offer hearty texture, while the smoked fish introduces a sophisticated, briny note to the dish. The platter benefits from a squeeze of lemon, brightening the palate and tying all components together beautifully. This recipe is ideal for pescatarians and contains no nuts, making it a thoughtful choice for some allergy considerations. Serve as an impressive appetizer or as a centerpiece for a relaxed, luxurious brunch.

name: Apple & clementine Bircher
description: The servings are very large. This bircher was very citrussy and not really to our taste. Tasted better when it was freshly made.
author: Chelsie Collins
directions: The night before, mix the oats with the cinnamon in a large bowl. Stir in the apple juice and grated apple, cover with cling film and leave overnight in the fridge.
In the morning, stir through the clementine segments, divide between four bowls, then scatter over the almonds and pomegranate seeds.
chief_review: This bircher recipe offers a refreshing and tangy twist, thanks to the bright notes from clementines and apple juice. The generous serving sizes make it suitable for a hearty breakfast, though the pronounced citrus flavor may not appeal to all palates. The oats and grated apples create a pleasing texture, while toasted almonds and pomegranate seeds add both crunch and visual appeal. I found that the bircher is at its best when freshly prepared, as the fruit flavors diminish over time if left to sit. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and is dairy-free, making it a fine choice for those with lactose intolerance or seeking plant-based options. Additionally, with no added sweeteners, it relies solely on the natural sweetness of the fruit, resulting in a wholesome, invigorating meal.

name: Peppermint & rose cream napkin decorations
description: These elegant edible adornments really finish off a beautifully set dinner table on those special occasions
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: few drops blue and pink food colouring- or whatever colours you like
directions: Divide the icing in half. Knead the peppermint essence and blue food colour in to one half, in drips, until you have a flavour and colour you like. Repeat with the rosewater and pink colouring in the other half.

Roll the two icings out on a lightly sugar-dusted surface to around ½ cm thick. Use a small biscuit cutter to stamp out shapes – we used hearts and stars in two sizes, then re-roll trimmings to get as many shapes as you can. If you want to use as decorations, stamp a hole out of the centre using the tip of a small piping nozzle or poking with the end of a skewer. Dry on a sheet of baking parchment for a couple of days. Store in airtight containers, layered between more sheets of baking parchment.
To make decorations or napkin rings, thread some ribbon through the holes and tie around a rolled up napkin, or to the tree.
chief_review: This recipe presents a charming way to adorn any celebratory table with edible decorations, marrying aesthetics with subtle flavours. The use of ready-to-roll regal icing allows for effortless shaping, while hints of peppermint and rosewater provide a delicate, aromatic lift. By incorporating food colouring, the decorations can be tailored to fit any occasion or palette theme. The absence of eggs and dairy makes this recipe suitable for vegan and vegetarian diets, provided the food colouring used is plant-based and free from animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, the recipe contains no gluten, making it a safe choice for those on gluten-free diets. Overall, these enchanting, softly flavoured confections offer a versatile, allergen-friendly finishing touch to your festive settings.

name: Fresh herb sauce
description: This fresh green purée is a light alternative to traditional heavy sauces and goes well with an Italian-style roast turkey or chicken
author: Good Food
directions: Place the watercress, parsley and walnuts in a blender and pulse until finely chopped. Add the oil, lemon juice and sugar, and season well. Blend for 1 min until everything has combined into a thick green sauce. Can be made several hours ahead.
chief_review: This vibrant green purée is a refreshing take on classic sauces, delivering a burst of herbaceous flavor from watercress and parsley complemented by the rich, earthy note of walnuts. The olive oil creates a smooth and luscious texture, while a touch of lemon juice brightens the blend and a hint of sugar balances the natural bitterness of the greens. It’s a versatile accompaniment, especially well-suited to Italian-style roast poultry. Notably, this recipe is vegetarian and gluten-free, making it an inclusive option for a variety of dietary preferences. For those avoiding dairy or seeking a vegan alternative, this purée entirely forgoes animal products, relying solely on fresh, plant-based ingredients. The use of walnuts adds both nutritional value and depth, elevating this sauce beyond a simple herb blend. Simple, quick, and full of flavor, this purée is a delightful addition to modern menus.

name: Chunky roast potatoes
description: Keeping your roasties nice and big makes it much easier to keep them crisp and warm
author: Good Food
ingredients: 16 medium-size Maris Piper potatoes, peeled and halved down the middle so they are still very large
140g lard or goose fat, or sunflower oil for vegetarians
directions: Place the potatoes in a pan of cold, salted water and bring to the boil. Turn down the heat and simmer for exactly 5 mins. Tip into a colander, then leave to drain for a good 10 mins to ensure they are really dry, before gently tossing in the colander to rough them up slightly.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Heat the fat in a sturdy, roomy roasting tin on the hob until it starts to shimmer. Carefully lay the potatoes in a single layer in the fat and leave for 1 min to start to crisp. Turn them until completely coated in fat, then transfer the tin to the oven. Leave undisturbed for 40 mins to crisp up, then turn them again, adding the garlic if you like, before returning them to the oven for 20 mins or until completely crisp and golden.
chief_review: This roast potato recipe brilliantly embraces larger potato pieces to ensure a perfect, crispy exterior while locking in warmth and fluffiness inside. The choice between lard, goose fat, or sunflower oil means the dish can effortlessly suit both vegetarian and omnivorous preferences—just opt for sunflower oil to keep it vegetarian-friendly. The use of Maris Piper potatoes guarantees a creamy, fluffy texture after roasting. Including garlic adds a fragrant, savory depth, though it remains optional for those wanting a purer potato flavor. The recipe is straightforward, relying on quality ingredients and careful preparation rather than excessive embellishment. These roasties would shine on any table, delivering simple but robust comfort with every bite, and fit well into a vegetarian diet when made with plant-based oil.

name: Turnip, potato & mustard gratin
description: This creamy, comforting side dish makes an indulgent accompaniment for roast pork
author: John Torode
directions: Fill a saucepan with 500ml water, the milk, a good pinch of salt and a grinding of black pepper, then bring to the boil. Add the turnips and potatoes and cook for 2 mins. Strain, drain well and pat dry.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter a baking dish and rub the sides with garlic to just add a hint of flavour. Mix the cream and mustard in a large bowl, add the potatoes and turnip, mix until well coated and season really well. Layer into the baking dish, flattening the top level. Can be assembled and chilled a day ahead.
Bake for 30-40 mins or until golden brown and the turnip and potato are cooked through – check with the point of a sharp knife.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a luxurious and velvety gratin that beautifully balances the earthy flavor of turnips with the mild creaminess of potatoes. The combination of milk and double cream results in a rich, decadent texture, while the touch of Dijon mustard provides just the right amount of sharpness to cut through the richness. The use of garlic subtly perfumes the dish without overpowering the other flavors. This decadent side dish is naturally gluten-free and fits well within a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal-derived rennet. It's an ideal companion for roast pork, but is equally satisfying alongside other hearty mains. Prepare for a crowd-pleaser that is bold, aromatic, and irresistibly creamy.

name: Mini baked Alaskas with boozy cherry centres
description: A much-loved favourite with a modern-day twist - and all the components can be prepared in advance
author: Good Food
ingredients: 500 ml tub good vanilla ice cream - one with real vanilla is nice
100g butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
2 eggs, lightly beaten, plus 3 egg whites
directions: Line 4 individual pudding moulds with cling film – brushing with oil first will help. Divide the ice cream between them, shaping so an even thickness covers the base and sides with a hollow in the middle. Mix the jam with 2 tsp of the kirsch, spoon into the ice-cream hollows, cover and freeze overnight.

For the base, heat oven to 180C/ fan 160C/gas 4. Butter and line a 20cm square cake tin. Reserve 2 tbsp of the almonds, then whizz the rest in a food processor until finely chopped and tip into a bowl with the flour, butter, beaten whole eggs and 100g caster sugar. Beat until smooth, then spread into the tin and bake for 15-18 mins until golden and springy. Cool on a wire rack. This cake will sit quite happily in a tin for 24 hrs, but stamp out the bases on the day or the edges will dry overnight.

For the meringue, whisk the egg whites until stiff, then add the remaining sugar and continue whisking until the meringue is thick and glossy. Can be chilled for up to 5 hrs. With a 7cm round cutter or rim of a pudding mould, cut 4 bases from the almond sponge. Drizzle with the rest of the kirsch, then sit them on a baking sheet lined with baking paper.

When you’re ready to serve, heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Turn 1 ice cream out onto each round of cake, peeling off the cling film, then spread over meringue using a knife or small spatula until completely covered. Scatter with remaining almonds and bake for 3 mins until the tips of the meringues are just browning. Lift onto serving plates with a fish slice and serve immediately.
chief_review: This Black Forest-inspired dessert brings together classic flavors with a clever twist, showcasing the pairing of creamy vanilla ice cream, cherry jam, and a light almond sponge. The addition of kirsch adds a fragrant lift, while toasted flaked almonds contribute a delightful textural contrast. With the components suitable for advance preparation, this recipe is an excellent choice for entertaining. While it contains eggs, dairy, wheat, and nuts, it is gluten-free adaptable if self-raising gluten-free flour is substituted. The recipe is also suitable for a vegetarian diet, as all ingredients are free from meat, fish, and gelatin. Its balance of rich, fruity, and nutty notes makes it a refined but approachable dessert that will impress at any gathering, especially when time management is essential.
