name: Herby cheese roulade
description: Very tasty recipe, and the step by step images helped. I used spinach instead of the spring greens, and the result was very pleasing.
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Oil a 23 x 33cm Swiss roll tin. Cut a rectangle of baking parchment 4cm larger all round than the tin. Fold in a 2cm strip all round, making a diagonal cut into each corner.

For the roulade, melt the butter in a large pan. Add the garlic and fry for 1 min. Add the flour and cook for 1 min, stirring constantly. Gradually beat in the milk. Bring to the boil, stirring constantly, until the sauce is thick and smooth. Remove from the heat and stir in half the cheese. Season, then allow to cool slightly. Beat in the egg yolks and parsley. Whisk the egg whites to stiff, but not dry peaks, then gently fold into the cheese sauce. Pour into the tin, tipping the tin so that the mixture fills all the corners. Bake for 15 mins until risen and golden.
Meanwhile, heat the oil and butter in a large wok or frying pan and stir-fry the spring greens and garlic for 4-5 mins until tender. Season.

Sprinkle the remaining cheese over a sheet of baking parchment just larger than the tin. Turn the roulade out onto the parchment, then peel off the lining paper. Trim the crispy edges off the roulade. Use a slotted spoon to remove the spring greens from the garlicky butter, then spread over the roulade leaving a 2.5cm space at one short end uncovered. Roll up the roulade from the short end with no filling on it, using the paper to help. Serve the roulade immediately, drizzled with any remaining garlicky butter.
chief_review: This recipe shines as a delightful vegetarian dish, featuring eggs, plenty of greens, and a luscious cheese sauce brought together with well-executed steps. The suggested substitution of spinach for spring greens worked beautifully, maintaining the dish’s freshness and vibrancy. The combination of garlic, parsley, and vegetarian parmesan-style cheese delivers a nuanced flavor profile, while the use of separated eggs promises a light, airy texture, reminiscent of a classic soufflé or a decadent gratin. The methodical approach and clear visual instructions make this accessible to home cooks, ensuring a rewarding result. This is an excellent choice for vegetarians, as all ingredients are plant-based apart from the eggs and dairy, and the specified cheese does not contain animal rennet. Ideal for brunch, lunch, or a lighter dinner.

name: Duck with red cabbage & madeira gravy
description: Used the slow cooker on low for10 hrs as suggested. Meat fell off one of duck legs making next step difficult. Will try again using shorter slow cooker time.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 tsp fresh thyme leaves plus 2-4 sprigs
2 large or 4 small ducks legs (550g/1lb 4oz total weight)
directions: At least 24 hours before serving, mix the salt, pepper and herbs, except the thyme sprigs, in a large bowl. Add the duck legs and rub in the herby salt until well coated. Cover and leave overnight or up to 24 hours in the fridge.

Next day, wipe the salty mixture from the duck legs and place them in a single, tight-fitting layer in the base of a pan. Add the bay leaves from the bowl and pour over the goose fat. If it doesn’t cover the duck, top up with the groundnut oil. Cook over the lowest possible heat for 2½ hours, so the fat barely bubbles. The duck skin should be creamy rather than golden once cooked. Transfer the legs to a bowl and strain in the fat, pushing the duck under until fully submerged. (The duck can now be chilled and refrigerated for up to 1 month.)

While the duck is cooking (or up to 2 days ahead of the meal), make the madeira gravy and cabbage. For the gravy, melt the butter in a small pan, add the shallots and cook for 6-8 minutes, stirring until golden. Stir in the flour and cook, stirring all the time, until the flour browns – take care not to let it burn. Whisk in the stock and continue whisking over the heat until slightly thickened. Add the madeira and cook for 2 minutes more. Strain through a sieve into a bowl. (The gravy can now be cooled and chilled for up to 2 days.)

For the cabbage, scoop 2 tbsp of the goose fat from the duck as it cooks (if making at another time use olive oil) and put into a medium pan. Add the shallots and cook, stirring, until softened. Tip in the juniper berries and cabbage and cook over a fairly high heat until the cabbage starts to soften. Stir in the vinegar, orange juice, raisins and redcurrant jelly. Cover and leave to cook for 15 minutes, stirring now and then until tender. (Cool and chill for up to 2 days if making ahead.)

On the day, preheat the oven to fan 180C/ conventional 200C/gas 6. Remove the duck legs from the fat and wipe away any excess with kitchen paper. Put the duck on a wire rack in a roasting tin and top each leg with a sprig of thyme. Roast for 10 minutes, then add the creamy wild mushroom potatoes to the oven (see recipe, below) and cook with the duck for 30 minutes, or until the duck skin is golden. Meanwhile, reheat the cabbage and gravy in separate pans until piping hot.

To serve, put a generous spoonful of cabbage on serving plates and sit the duck legs on top. Spoon round the gravy and serve with the potatoes. For a green vegetable, quickly stir fry some sugar snaps.
chief_review: This slow-cooked duck leg recipe is a showcase of deep, aromatic flavors and rich, comforting textures. The long, gentle cook delivers exceptionally tender meat, but care is needed: 10 hours may be excessive, as the meat risks becoming so tender it falls apart, making handling tricky. Reducing cooking time should yield a better balance between succulence and structure. The blend of spices, fresh herbs, and a luxurious base of goose fat and butter contribute to a restaurant-quality finish. The addition of shallots, juniper berries, and Madeira wine adds both earthiness and complexity, perfectly complemented by a tangy, fruity red cabbage side. The use of flour and chicken stock makes it unsuitable for gluten-free diets, but it suits those enjoying a classic meat-based dish. Overall, a rewarding, elegant recipe with thoughtful attention to flavor layering—just watch your timing for optimal results.

name: Glazed sprouts with caramelised red onions
description: This is an excellent recipe. Try it without changing a thing and you won't be disappointed!
author: Jenny White
ingredients: 700g Brussels sprouts(small ones if you can get them)
directions: Heat the butter in a large, heavy-based frying pan and add the onions. Cook over a medium heat for 6-8 mins, turning occasionally, until golden and caramelised. Meanwhile, cook the sprouts in a pan of boiling salted water for 3-4 mins until just tender.
Stir the sugar and vinegar into the onions and allow to bubble for a few secs. Remove from the heat, drain the sprouts thoroughly and toss through the onion mixture to serve.
chief_review: This recipe is a wonderful celebration of Brussels sprouts, elegantly paired with the sweetness of caramelized red onions and a touch of demerara sugar, all balanced by the gentle acidity of sherry vinegar. The use of butter adds a luxurious richness, helping to bring out the best in the vegetables without overpowering their flavors. This dish is suitable for a vegetarian diet and is also naturally gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for those with specific dietary needs. It would work beautifully as a side dish for festive meals or as part of a vegetable-focused menu. The concise ingredient list lets each flavor shine, and the straightforward technique ensures great results even for less experienced cooks. Highly recommended for anyone seeking to elevate humble sprouts to a centerpiece side.

name: Sparkling snowflake cake
description: This stylish, shimmering cake is ideal if you've had some practice at cake decorating before
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 18-23cm fruit cake (see link below) covered with marzipan and ready-to-roll white icing
edible silver lustre, edible silver balls and edible sparkles, fine writing tube and small piping bag
directions: Knead the ready-to-roll icing until smooth, then roll out to approx 1cm thickness. Using snowflake cutters of various sizes, stamp out 3 snowflake shapes. Lay the snowflakes on baking parchment on a flat surface and leave overnight to harden. Keep any trimmings and wrap up in cling film.

Next day, make the royal icing. Drop a writing tube into a piping bag and spoon in a third of the icing. Spread the rest around the base of the cake to create a snowdrift effect. Pipe snowflake outlines over the cut-out snowflake shapes and pipe snowflakes all over the surface of the cake in different sizes and designs. Leave for 1 hr until the icing has hardened slightly, then sprinkle silver lustre over the cake, snowdrift and snowflakes.

Using the leftover ready-to-roll white icing, mould thimble-sized supports for your snowflakes to lean against. Position the snowflakes on the top of the cake. Finally, fix the silver balls to the icing with a little more of the royal icing. Finish by scattering sparkles over.
chief_review: This shimmering cake is a showstopper, perfect for those comfortable with advanced cake decorating. The combination of smooth marzipan and ready-to-roll white icing creates a polished base, ideal for the application of edible silver luster, balls, and sparkles—lending the cake both elegance and visual drama. Soft royal icing allows for intricate piping work, especially when paired with a fine writing tip. This cake would complement vegetarian diets, as standard marzipan, royal icing, and decorative elements are typically vegetarian-friendly—be sure to verify the use of pasteurized egg white in the royal icing for strict adherents. Overall, this is a decadent centerpiece that’s as spectacular to present as it is to enjoy, making it a fitting choice for festive occasions or any celebration where a touch of glamour is required.

name: Glazed baby veg
description: A simple way to cook veg to serve alongside your favourite main
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Boil carrots and turnips for 3 mins until starting to soften then cool completely under cold running water. Can be blanched up to a day ahead.
When you’re ready to serve, heat butter and caster sugar in a pan until the butter melts, add the veg and seasoning, then toss for 2 mins until just tender and glossy.
chief_review:
This recipe is a delightful, straightforward approach to preparing vegetables, allowing the natural sweetness of baby carrots and turnips to shine through. The addition of a touch of butter enriches the texture, while a sprinkling of caster sugar enhances the vegetables’ inherent flavors without overpowering them. The result is a gently glazed medley that pairs beautifully with both rustic and refined mains.

Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this dish also works well for those seeking nut-free and soy-free options, provided none of the diners have dairy allergies. For those following a gluten-free diet, all listed ingredients are naturally free of gluten. Overall, this is a versatile and appealing side that balances simplicity with flavor, making it an excellent staple for any cook’s repertoire.

name: Ballotine of pheasant
description: We talk you through the technique of preparing poultry to create an impressive, easy-to-carve roast - ours is a boned and stuffed pheasant
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: First, make the stuffing. Fry the onion in the butter for 5-10 mins until softened, then leave to cool completely. Thoroughly mix the remaining ingredients in a large bowl, including the cooled onions.

If the wings are attached, cut at the first joint (on most butchered birds they will have been removed). Find the wishbone between the neck and the breast, then use a sharp knife to scrape away the flesh around it. Gently pull it out, trying to keep it as one, cut it away and discard.
Place the pheasant, breast side down, on the board. Using a sharp boning knife, see tip, left, cut through the skin to the backbone along the length of the bird.

Working down the length of the pheasant, slowly run your knife down against the ribcage, keeping close to the bone and scraping the flesh away from both. Twist out the thigh joints when you get to them.
Very carefully cut away the main carcass. This is where the skin is at its thinnest, so cut carefully as you don’t want to nip or pierce the skin.
Open the bird out like a book and lay it, skin-side down, on the board.
Season the bird’s flesh with salt and pepper then arrange half of the stuffing down the middle of each of the birds in a sausage shape.
Re-form the bird by lifting the sides up and around the stuffing. After you’ve done one, repeat with the other pheasant.
Wrap each pheasant tightly and neatly with bacon so that the bacon goes all the way round the bird and joins on the underside.
Using butcher’s string, tie the pheasant at regular intervals around the width. Then tie it once around the length to hold the stuffing in.
Finally, tie the legs together. The pheasant can be prepared to this stage and chilled up to a day ahead.

Heat oven to 200C/ 180C/gas 6. Transfer the pheasant to a roasting tin. Roast for 45-50 mins, basting regularly with the juices from the tin. Finally, cover with foil and rest for about 15 mins. Serve in thick slices with the juices from the pan.
chief_review: This boned and stuffed pheasant recipe showcases classic techniques, resulting in an elegant centerpiece perfect for special occasions. The use of brandy-soaked prunes brings a rich sweetness that balances the savory depth of sausagemeat and bacon. Fresh thyme and parsley lend fragrant, herbal notes, while pistachios add texture and a subtle earthiness. The butter and breadcrumbs achieve a succulent, tender filling, ensuring every slice is flavorful. While the preparation requires some skill, the payoff is a roast that's both easy to carve and visually stunning. This dish is well-suited to those following a gluten-containing, nut-tolerant, and omnivorous diet, particularly those who appreciate game meats and festive presentations.

name: Cheeseboard sticks
description: Create a canapé out of a classic cheeseboard, then thread on to skewers with quince paste and grapes
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 grapes, a mix of red and green
75g soft goat's cheese(we used an ash-covered one)
directions: Slice the grapes in half, then cut the cheeses and quince paste into 12 pieces.
Thread a grape half onto a mini skewer, followed by a piece of each of the cheeses and a piece of quince paste. Repeat, then arrange the sticks on a serving platter.
chief_review: This sophisticated canapé brilliantly distills the essence of a classic cheeseboard into bite-sized skewers, offering a harmonious blend of flavors and textures. The sweet juiciness of red and green grapes refreshes the palate, pairing beautifully with the creamy tang of goat's cheese and the assertive character of blue cheese. Comté or cheddar contributes a nutty depth, while membrillo (quince paste) ties everything together with a touch of fruitiness. Perfect for elegant gatherings, this recipe is a crowd-pleasing option for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish. It is best enjoyed served chilled or at room temperature to allow the cheeses' flavors to shine. Overall, this canapé delivers a balanced, intriguing bite that captures the delight of a full cheeseboard in miniature form.

name: Really good roast potatoes
description: Boil, fluff then crisp up in goose fat and oil for perfect roast potatoes - if you're vegetarian, sunflower oil works just as well
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 3kg King Edward potatoes, cut into large chunks
4 tbsp sunflower oil(or 8 tbsp if you’re not using goose fat)
directions: Boil the potatoes for 5 mins in salted water until the outside of the potatoes starts to soften. Drain well, return to the pan and shake to fluff up the outsides – alternatively, you can scratch them with a fork. (This process will make them crispier.)

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the goose fat (if using) and oil in a large shallow roasting tin and heat for 8-10 mins until the goose fat has melted and the mixture is really hot. Remove from the oven, carefully tip in the potatoes and stir well to coat them in the fat. Spread them out as much as the space allows and roast underneath the turkey for 45 mins, turning frequently and adjusting the positions so that they brown evenly.

When the turkey comes out of the oven, turn up the heat to 220C/200C fan/gas 7, season the potatoes with the flaky salt and roast for another 30 mins, turning halfway through the cooking time, until beautifully golden.
chief_review: This roast potato recipe yields an exceptional result: crisp exteriors with soft, fluffy interiors, thanks to the double cooking method and the generous use of either goose fat or sunflower oil. King Edward potatoes, renowned for their starchy content, roast beautifully. The option to use only sunflower oil provides a satisfying vegetarian alternative without sacrificing texture or deep flavor. The finishing touch of flaky salt heightens the overall taste and creates a memorable crunch in every bite. This dish is a classic side, perfect for any special occasion or Sunday roast, especially appealing to vegetarians when made with sunflower oil.

name: Partridge in cider with apples & celery
description: Serve a partridge as an individual portion for one in this seasonal stew with smoked bacon, Bramley apples, thyme and sage
author: Tom Kerridge
directions: Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Place a large frying pan over a medium heat and pour in 1 tbsp of the oil. Dust the partridges in the flour and fry until evenly browned all over. Remove from the pan and drain on a piece of kitchen paper.

Put a large casserole dish on the heat. Pour in the remaining oil, add the lardons and cook until the fat has rendered out and the lardons are crisp. Add the onion and celery to the pan and sweat down until soft. Stir in the apples to soften a little. Add the thyme, sage and the partridges, then pour over the cider and chicken stock and bring to the boil. Cover and transfer to the oven for 25 mins or until the thigh meat is cooked through and will come away from the bone, and the sauce has reduced and thickened. Remove from the oven and serve with the Smoked butter mash (see 'Goes well with').
chief_review: This rustic partridge stew is a celebration of seasonal British produce. The combination of tender partridge, smoky bacon lardons, and tart Bramley apples is both earthy and complex, while thyme and sage impart a robust herbal fragrance. The cider brings a gentle acidity and depth, complemented by the sweet-savoury balance of the apples and onions. Dusting the partridge in flour helps the sauce thicken beautifully, resulting in a glossy, inviting stew. The recipe is not suitable for gluten-free diets because of the flour, nor for vegetarians or vegans due to the partridge and bacon; however, it offers a superb option for those seeking a hearty, comforting meal that showcases game. Serve with crusty bread or creamy mash to soak up every last drop of the cider-infused sauce.

name: Whisky cream & jelly with toasted oat crumble & tea sorbet
description: This make ahead, grown-up dessert layers up sweet cream, boozy jelly and crunchy oats - finished with earl grey sorbet
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 1 leaf gelatine, soaked in cold water for 5 mins
1 leaf gelatine, soaked in cold water for 5 mins
directions: To make the sorbet, bring the tea, sugar and liquid glucose to the boil in a pan. Make sure the sugar and glucose have dissolved, then strain into a jug and leave to cool completely. Pour into an ice cream machine and churn until frozen, then transfer to a freezer-proof container and freeze until needed.

To make the cream layer, pour the cream into a heavy-based pan and bring to the boil. In a bowl, whisk together the egg and sugar, then pour over the cream and whisk until combined. Rinse out the cream pan and pour in the mixture. Return to the heat and cook gently, whisking all the time, until it reaches 88C – you’ll need a digital thermometer to test this. When it reaches this temperature, it will have thickened and the egg will be cooked. Pass the mix through a fine sieve into a clean bowl. Pour in the whisky, then squeeze any excess water out of the soaked gelatine and add to the bowl. Stir until all the gelatine has melted, then leave to cool a little. Pour into 4 small or 2 large glass dishes, leaving enough room for the jelly, and place in the fridge for at least 4 hours until set.

Make the jelly when the cream layer is almost set, put the whisky and sugar in a small pan and bring to the boil, making sure the sugar has dissolved. Remove from the heat, squeeze out any excess water from the gelatine, add to the pan and stir until melted. Pass the jelly through a fine sieve into a jug and place to one side to cool completely.

Once the cream layer has set, remove from the fridge and pour over the cooled jelly. If you have some left, don’t worry, just leave it to set in the fridge and eat it on its own. Return to the fridge and chill until the jelly has set. Can be made up to 2 days in advance; once set, cover with cling film and store in the fridge.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. To make the crumble, rub the butter into the flour until it resembles crumbs, then mix in the remaining ingredients. Tip onto a baking tray and bake for 15-20 mins or until golden brown. You will need to stir it a few times to ensure it cooks evenly. Remove from the oven and leave to cool. When cool, bash to a semi-fine crumble. Store in an airtight container until ready to serve.
Remove the set creams from the fridge and sprinkle over a generous layer of the crumble mix. Serve topped with a scoop of tea sorbet. Perfect with a shot of whisky!
chief_review: This dessert expertly balances sophistication and texture: fragrant Earl Grey tea forms the base for a refreshing sorbet, contrasted with luscious sweet cream and a robust, whisky-laced jelly. The addition of crunchy oat streusel brings a delightful textural component. The delicate use of whisky throughout adds depth without overpowering the other flavours. A wonderful make-ahead treat for dinner parties, it showcases classic British ingredients with a contemporary twist. Notably, this dessert is suitable for vegetarians, as gelatine leaf is the only gelling agent and can be replaced with a vegetarian substitute if desired. It does contain gluten (flour and oats), dairy (cream, butter), and egg, so those with allergies should take care. The balance of creaminess, crunch, and aromatic tea makes this a memorable ending to any meal.

name: Crunchy confit roast potatoes
description: How is this confit? It isn't - it's roasted potatoes.
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: 2kg floury potatoes(we used Maris Piper), cut into chunks
200g duck fator goose fat (reserved from the confit turkey - see 'goes well with' opposite)
directions: On Christmas Eve, put the potatoes in a large saucepan and cover with cold salted water. Bring to the boil, reduce the heat to a simmer and cook for 2-3 mins until slightly tender. Drain and give them a good shake in the colander. Tip into a large roasting tin lined with baking parchment and leave, uncovered, in the fridge overnight.

When your turkey crown goes in, put the duck fat in your largest roasting tin and heat in the oven. After 10 mins, transfer your cold potatoes to the hot duck fat – you should hear them sizzle as they hit the tin. Toss to coat in the fat and season well with flaky sea salt, then spread them in a single layer so they crisp up better. Roast for about 1 hr 30 mins, turning a few times, to evenly brown. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a superb version of classic roasted potatoes, making perfect use of duck or goose fat for exceptional flavor and a beautifully crisp exterior. Using floury potatoes like Maris Piper ensures a fluffy interior, while the generous coating of rich poultry fat elevates these roasties to a holiday-worthy level. The flaky sea salt finish accentuates the savory depths. These potatoes are ideal for a traditional roast dinner or festive feast, though it’s worth noting they aren’t suitable for vegetarian or vegan diets. The method is straightforward and the result is deeply satisfying: crispy, golden, and deeply savory potatoes that are sure to be the highlight of any meal.

name: Buttered baby carrots
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Wash and peel the baby carrots, keeping the green tops intact. Put them in a medium saucepan and half-fill with salted water. Bring to the boil and cook for 4 mins or until just tender. Drain, then transfer to a serving dish, season and stir in the butter.
chief_review: This simple dish of baby carrots sautéed in butter highlights the natural sweetness and texture of the carrots while adding a touch of richness from the butter. The minimal ingredient list allows the freshness of the carrots to shine through, creating a side dish that’s both comforting and elegant. The recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal rennet. For those seeking a gluten-free option, there are no gluten-containing ingredients present. The straightforward cooking process and classic flavor combination make this dish both accessible for home cooks and pleasing for diners looking for light, wholesome fare.

name: Persian pilaf & roasted root loaves
description: Why is this called 'Persian'? Throwing pistachios and saffron into any dish does NOT make it Persian. If anything, it's closer to Moroccan flavours than Persian.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 200g carrots, peeled and cut into 1-2cm chunks
200g sweet potatoes, peeled and diced like the carrots
200g parsnips, peeled and diced like the carrots too
3 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
400g can chickpeas, drained - optional (good for bulking the mixture if you want to feed another mouth)
2 large eggs, beaten with a fork
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Toss the carrot chunks, sweet potato and parsnip with 2 tbsp of the oil on a baking sheet. Roast in the oven until golden and tender – about 20-25 mins.

Meanwhile put the last tbsp of oil in a deep frying or sauté pan with the onion, and cook gently for around 8-10 mins to soften. Stir in the saffron and rice, then stir in the stock. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat so the rice is gently simmering and cook, stirring occasionally for 25 mins or until the rice is tender and stock just absorbed – like a paella. Stir in the cinnamon, coriander and both types of cumin, plus the chopped apricots and take off the heat. Leave to cool with the roasted veg while you get the rest of the ingredients and tins ready.

Roughly chop the pistachios. Grease 8 small loaf tins with a little oil, then cut long strips of baking parchment to line the base and ends of each tin – with overhangs to help you lift out the loaves when they’re done.

Scrape the cooled rice into a big mixing bowl and stir through the beaten eggs with salt and pepper. Scatter over chickpeas if using, plus the roasted veg and 100g of the pistachios and fold through. Divide the mixture between the loaf tins, and use your hands to neatly round the tops.
Make the sauce by combining all the ingredients with a little salt and pepper in a saucepan. Simmer for 20 mins until thickened and rich.

An hour before you want to serve, heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. For the roasted pomegranate roots, mix the carrots, beetroot, shallots and oil in a big roasting tin with some seasoning. Roast on the top shelf for 15 mins, with an empty tray heating on the bottom shelf.

Stir the cumin seeds, pomegranate molasses, orange juice and zest through the veg and put back on the top shelf. Sit the Persian rice loaves on the preheated tray, and bake for another 30 mins together. Finally, stir the pomegranate seeds through the veg, and swap the shelves – so the loaves sit on the top, for a last 5 mins of cooking. Meanwhile gently reheat the sauce.

Carefully lift the loaves out of their tins onto a platter, and scatter with the last 50g of chopped pistachios plus some coriander leaves. Let guests help themselves, sitting the Persian loaves in a pool of tangy tomato sauce – with spoonfuls of the roasted pomegranate roots, couscous, salad leaves and Greek yogurt alongside.
chief_review: This vibrant dish layers earthy root vegetables, fragrant spices, and sweet-tart accents for a hearty, flavor-packed centerpiece. The use of paella rice, saffron, pistachios, dried apricots, and pomegranate molasses brings together Middle Eastern and North African influences, creating a complex interplay of texture and taste. Greek yogurt and eggs add protein richness, while couscous, green salad, and roasted vegetables keep the meal balanced and satisfying. With chickpeas as an optional addition, this recipe is particularly nourishing and well-suited for vegetarians. It can also be adapted for those seeking a gluten-free meal by substituting rice or quinoa for the couscous. The thoughtful use of aromatic spices and a variety of plant-based ingredients makes this an excellent choice for those looking to explore vibrant, meatless cuisine without sacrificing depth or satisfaction.

name: Mulled rosé wine
description:
I made this and it was delicious. I did change it up a bit though because I was going for more of a fall flavor.
Added 3 cinnamon sticks to the spice mix.
An extra ball of ginger.
Extra Star of Anise.
Extra splash of crema de cassis (just because I love that stuff).
And the biggest change, I did 1 apple instead of 1/4 grapefruit.
It created the perfect warm fall beverage. After adding the crema de cassis I poured the entire concoction, spices and all, into my slow cooker on low so it would stay warm for the evening. I just dumped the entire mix in there and after sitting in the wine, the apples made a really delicious treat.
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour the rosé wine into a large saucepan with the star anise, stem ginger, black peppercorns, allspice berries and pink grapefruit. Bring to a simmer over a medium heat then stir in the crème de cassis, strain into a jug then serve in heatproof glasses or cups.
chief_review:
This recipe is a delightful twist on traditional mulled wine, swapping out the usual red for rosé and introducing warming fall flavors. The combination of rosé, star anise, stem ginger, and autumnal apples—enhanced by cinnamon sticks and a generous splash of crème de cassis—offers a fragrant and complex beverage perfect for cooler evenings. Slow-cooking the mix allows the spices to infuse beautifully, with the softened apples adding a sweet, edible bonus. 

This drink is well-suited for those on a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal products. Be mindful, however, that the recipe includes alcohol, so it's best enjoyed responsibly and kept away from anyone avoiding alcohol in their diet. Overall, this mulled rosé is inventive, festive, and brimming with seasonal warmth.

name: Celeriac & comté fritters
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 1 tbsp rapeseed oil, plus extra for frying
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the quail's eggs in a bowl of warm tap water to get them used to the change in temperature. Then bring about an inch of water to the boil in a saucepan and prepare a bowl with some iced water. Gently lower the quail's eggs into the boiling water and boil for 2 mins, then drop them into the iced water. Leave them in there until chilled. Carefully peel and set aside.
Toss the celeriac, apple, herbs and cheese together with the pumpkin seeds, chilli flakes and season. Combine the egg yolk with the Dijon and stir into the celeriac mixture.
the egg white to stiff peaks and fold into the celeriac fritter mix.

Heat a little rapeseed oil and butter in a non-stick frying pan. Put two dessertspoonfuls of fritter into the hot fat and fry for 1 min or until a caramelised crust has formed. Turn carefully and cook for a further 2 mins. Place on a lined baking sheet and bake for 5 mins. Remove from the oven and allow to settle on the sheet for a couple of mins. Dress the parsley and red onion with a little of the vinegar and rapeseed oil. Divide between plates and top with the quail's eggs and celery salt. Serve with the parsley salad.
chief_review: This recipe brings together earthy celeriac, tangy green apple, and the nutty richness of comté cheese, balanced by fresh herbs and a hint of chilli. The addition of pumpkin seeds gives it an appealing crunch, while quail's eggs add a touch of luxury. The use of rapeseed oil and butter for frying adds depth without overwhelming the delicate flavours. Separating the eggs likely lends lightness—perhaps in a fritter or rösti format. The combination of ingredients is well-thought-out, offering a satisfying interplay between creamy, crunchy, and aromatic elements. With its reliance on eggs and dairy, the dish is suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, and the careful use of apple and herbs elevates it beyond the ordinary. This is a refined yet approachable recipe that would make an excellent starter or light lunch for those looking to enjoy seasonal produce and bright, fresh flavours.

name: Mulled cider
description: nice to me re if u have any tips!!
author: Good Food
directions: Pour the cider, Calvados, apple juice and sugar into a large saucepan, and gently heat to mull.
Add the orange zest and spices, bring to a simmer, then turn down and keep on a low heat for 20-30 mins. Ladle into glass mugs to serve.
chief_review:
This recipe creates a warmly spiced cider punch, perfect for festive gatherings and chilly evenings. The combination of dry cider, Calvados, and apple juice brings depth and natural sweetness, elevated by the dark brown sugar and a fragrant blend of orange zest, cloves, cinnamon, and allspice berries. The balance of tart cider and aromatic spices makes for a complex and inviting beverage. 

Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this punch contains no animal products or by-products. However, please note that strict vegans or those with specific allergies should ensure the cider and sugar used meet their required standards, as some sugars may be processed with animal products, and certain ciders can use animal-based fining agents. Enjoy this mulled delight warm, perhaps garnished with a twist of orange or a cinnamon stick for extra flair.

name: Tuscan sausage, kale & ciabatta stuffing
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 3 large handfuls cavolo neroor kale, de-stalked and shredded
8 x good-quality pork sausages, meat removed from their skins
directions: Soak all but one handful of the bread chunks in the milk and set aside. Heat the oil in a large non-stick pan and cook the onions with the fennel and chilli flakes (if using) for 10 mins until softened. Add the garlic and the cavelo nero or kale and cook for 5 mins until softened, adding more oil if needed. Leave to cool.

Tip the onion mixture and the remaining ingredients (aside from the handful of bread) into a large bowl, season generously and use your hands to scrunch everything together really well. Scatter the stuffing into a shallow roasting tin or baking dish.
. Top the stuffing with the remaining torn bread. To cook, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and bake for 30-35 mins until the top is crispy.
chief_review:
This hearty dish is a celebration of rustic Italian flavors, combining savory pork sausage, earthy greens like cavolo nero or kale, and aromatic herbs such as rosemary and fennel seeds. The addition of ciabatta chunks soaked in milk creates a wonderfully moist texture, while toasted pine nuts offer delightful crunch. Grated parmesan and a touch of lemon zest lift the dish with umami and brightness, making each bite satisfying and balanced.

This recipe is best suited for those without major dietary restrictions. Note that it contains gluten (ciabatta), dairy (milk and parmesan), eggs, and nuts (pine nuts), making it unsuitable for gluten-free, vegan, nut-free, or dairy-free diets. The inclusion of pork means it is not vegetarian or halal/kosher-friendly. Overall, a comforting recipe perfect for a cozy family meal or casual entertaining, with a pleasing depth of flavor and texture in every bite.

name: Chilli cranberry sauce
description: A tiny hint of chilli lifts this cranberry sauce to a whole new tastebud-tingling level
author: Good Food
ingredients: ½ mild red chilli, chopped, seeds left in
directions: Gently heat sugar and wine in a saucepan. Once sugar has dissolved, bring to the boil.

Tip in the chilli and cranberries, return to the boil, then turn the heat down and simmer for about 10 mins until the berries have popped but not completely collapsed. Take off the heat. The sauce will continue to cook with the heat from the pan, then thicken as it cools.
chief_review: This cranberry sauce recipe delivers a vibrant balance of sweet, tart, and subtle heat, elevating a traditional condiment into something special. The use of white wine adds depth and a gentle acidity that beautifully complements cranberries, while golden caster sugar brings a delicate caramel note. The touch of finely chopped red chilli, seeds included, adds just enough warmth to intrigue the palate without overpowering the sauce. This recipe is naturally suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, with no gluten-containing components, it can be enjoyed by those following a gluten-free regimen—provided that all processed ingredients (like wine) are verified gluten-free. Perfect as a festive side or a bold pairing with roasted dishes, this sauce is bound to enliven any meal.

name: Potted ham
description: This simple starter is a great way to use up leftover ham and you can freeze it ahead
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: bunch curly parsley,leaves picked and finely chopped
rustic country bread toast, cornichons, chutney or red onion marmalade to serve
directions: Gently melt the butter in a small pan and leave it to settle. Slowly pour the clear yellow fat from the melted butter into a small bowl or jug, leaving the milky liquid in the pan. Discard the milky bit. Pull apart and shred the ham as finely as possible into stringy strips – use a knife to help if you need to.

Mix the ham with the parsley, spices, vinegar, two-thirds of the butter and a little crunchy sea salt. Divide between 8 small ramekins or pots. Press down and flatten the surface with your fingers, then spoon or pour over the remaining butter. Chill until butter is solid, then wrap in cling film. Will freeze for up to 3 months.
To serve, defrost the pots overnight in the fridge if frozen. Serve with toast, cornichons and chutney, or dip pots briefly in a bowl of hot water and turn the potted ham out onto plates first.
chief_review: This ham pâté starter is a clever use of leftovers, yielding a rich, savory spread balanced by the brightness of parsley and subtle warmth from ground cloves and mustard seeds. The addition of cider vinegar sharpens the flavors, while pairing with rustic country bread toast and tangy cornichons or chutney offers welcome contrast in texture and taste. It’s an excellent dish for those following a gluten-free diet—simply serve with gluten-free bread or crispbreads—and is also nut-free, making it a safe starter for nut-allergic guests. The generous use of butter ensures a smooth, decadent pâté, and the make-ahead, freezer-friendly aspect adds convenience for entertaining. This is a classic, crowd-pleasing appetizer with rustic charm.

name: Roast turkey with sage & onion butter and Marsala gravy
description: This is a really tasty and easy roast recipe that won't let you down on the big day
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 170C/150C fan/gas 3-4 and place the turkey in a large roasting tin. Tuck 3 of the onion halves and the lemon quarters into the cavity and season. Cover with foil, make sure there’s plenty of space between the turkey and foil for the air to circulate and seal the edges tightly so that no steam escapes. Roast for 4 hrs.

Meanwhile, finely chop the remaining onion half, and mix with the butter and sage. Take the turkey out of the oven and raise the temp to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Brush the sage and onion butter all over the turkey and return to the oven, uncovered, for 45 mins until crisp and dark golden. If you’re making the roasties, then start them in the oven when the turkey goes back in, uncovered.

Transfer the turkey to a warm serving plate, cover loosely with foil and leave to rest for 30 mins. Tip the juices out of the pan into a bowl, leave for a moment to settle, then scoop the buttery oil from the surface into a separate bowl. Spoon 2 tbsp of this oil back into the tin and return to the heat.

Stir the flour into the tin using a wooden spoon, scraping the residue off the bottom of the tin as you go. Cook for 2 mins, then stir in the Marsala or Madeira and bring to the boil. Make the reserved turkey juices up to 500ml using hot chicken stock and pour into the tin. Bring to the boil and simmer for a few mins, then add cranberry jelly. Keep warm until ready to serve.
chief_review: This roast turkey recipe is a classic choice for festive occasions, delivering rich, savory flavors and aromatic notes from fresh sage, lemon, and onions. The butter rubbed under the skin ensures a moist bird with golden, crisp skin, while the marsala or Madeira wine deepens the pan gravy with a luxurious touch. The addition of cranberry jelly to the sauce brightens the flavors, creating a balanced, layered gravy to complement the tender meat. This recipe is suitable for a gluten-free diet if you substitute the plain flour with a gluten-free alternative and ensure the stock and wine are gluten-free. It fits a nut-free diet as written and can be enjoyed by those without dairy restrictions or who consume poultry. Overall, an impressive, approachable centerpiece for any celebratory meal.

name: Game terrine
description: John Torode shows how to prepare classic coarse set terrine with duck and mixed game of your choice
author: John Torode
ingredients: 140g mixed game, such as skinless pheasant breast, pigeon or additional duck
directions: Carefully cut the duck skin from the duck breast, then very finely chop the skin. Reserve 12 bacon rashers for lining the tin. Cut all the meat and remaining bacon into 1cm pieces, keeping the different meats separate (Step 1). Put all the best bits to one side.
Reserve the chopped bacon and, from the best bits, reserve 100g chopped chicken, 250g chicken livers, half the mixed game, half the duck and half the duck skin.

Put all the remaining meat and duck skin into a food processor (include any fattier pieces) and blend to a mince. Transfer to a bowl and add the garlic, allspice, juniper berries, parsley, Armagnac or brandy, wine and stock. Mix in the reserved chopped meat and marinate in the fridge overnight.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a 1.5-litre loaf tin or terrine mould with butter. Lightly stretch the reserved bacon rashers (Step 2) and use most of them to line the tin or mould, overlapping slightly and leaving plenty of overhang at the top (Step 3). Pack the meat mixture into the tin (Step 4), then fold over the bacon overhang and lay the reserved rashers on top.

Cover the terrine with baking parchment, then cover tightly with foil. Put a folded tea towel in a roasting tin and set the terrine on top (Step 5). Pour enough hot water into the roasting tin to come just below the rim of the terrine tin.
Put in the oven, then reduce heat to 160C/140C fan/gas 3 and bake for 1½ hrs. Take from the oven and leave to cool for 1 hr in the water bath, then remove and leave to cool completely.
Once cool, cut a strip of foil or card to fit the top of the tin, put it on top of the terrine and weigh it down with a few heavy cans (Step 6). Chill overnight.
Carefully remove the terrine from the tin, wipe off all the jelly and serve in slices with the toasts and cornichons.
chief_review: John Torode’s classic coarse set terrine is a masterful celebration of rich, gamey flavors, showcasing duck, mixed game, and a sumptuous blend of chicken liver and thigh. The layering of smoked streaky bacon provides a compelling smokiness, while the inclusion of allspice and juniper berries amplifies the aromatic profile, lending depth and warmth. The spirit of Armagnac and a splash of white wine add brightness and complexity, expertly balancing the earthy notes of game. Texturally, the terrine is robust and rustic, perfect for slicing and serving on crisp toasts alongside tangy cornichons. This recipe is ideal for those following a low-carb or gluten-free diet, provided gluten-free toast is used for serving. Additionally, there are no nuts, making it potentially suitable for some individuals with nut allergies, though care should be taken for any cross-contamination. A showstopper entrée for festive gatherings or elegant starters.

name: Chorizo & prawn skewers
description: Create a simple, crowd-pleasing canapé by spearing Spanish sausage and harissa shellfish then serving oven-baked with a garlic mayonnaise
author: Good Food
ingredients: 12 mini chorizosausages (for cooking chorizo cut into 12 pieces)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and cook the chorizo on a tray for 12 mins. Meanwhile, mix together the prawns and harissa. In a bowl, combine the garlic, mayo and yogurt to make a dip.
Turn the chorizo, add the prawns to the tray and cook for 3 mins more. Sprinkle the parsley over the prawns, then thread each onto a skewer, followed by a sausage. Serve with the dip.
chief_review: This canapé offers a bold fusion of Spanish and North African flavors, perfect for entertaining. The smoky chorizo pairs beautifully with harissa-marinated prawns, delivering a satisfying bite of spice and umami. The garlic mayonnaise, lightened with Greek yogurt and enhanced by fresh parsley, adds a cooling, creamy dip that balances the heat. This recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it a safe option for those avoiding gluten. However, it’s not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or individuals with seafood or dairy allergies. Overall, it's a quick, robust, and crowd-pleasing appetizer that shines at any gathering with its vibrant flavor profile and attractive presentation.

name: Smoked salmon rice salad
description: Have some leftover smoked fish on your hands? Create this light and fresh Asian-style salad with a chilli and sesame dressing
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: 1 tsp chilli sauce(optional), we used sriracha
directions: Whisk the dressing ingredients and set aside. Toss together the salad ingredients in a large bowl with the dressing. Serve from the bowl or pile onto a serving platter.
chief_review:
This Asian-style smoked salmon rice salad is a refreshing option for those seeking a light yet flavorful meal. The combination of cooled rice, crisp cucumber, spring onion, and peppery rocket provides a vibrant base, while the smoked salmon adds rich umami depth. The chilli and sesame dressing, brightened with lemon zest and juice, delivers a punchy contrast that elevates the salad. 

With no dairy or nuts in the ingredient list, this recipe is suitable for pescatarians and dairy-free diets. It also fits well into a gluten-free lifestyle, provided you confirm your chilli sauce and rice vinegar are certified gluten-free. Vegetarians and vegans would need to skip or substitute the smoked salmon. Overall, this salad is an excellent use of leftovers and brings together balanced textures and flavors for a delightful meal.

name: Freeze-ahead chocolate & chestnut parfait
description: This make-ahead festive dessert is deliciously different and incredibly simple to make, with amaretti biscuits, fresh oranges and double cream
author: Jenny White
ingredients: 2 oranges, peeled,, segmented and roughly chopped, plus zest 1 orange
50g dark chocolate, coarsely grated, to decorate
directions: Rinse a 22 x 10 x 7cm deep loaf tin (about 1.5 litres in volume) with cold water, but don’t dry it. Line the tin with cling film, smoothing out as many of the wrinkles as you can.

Stir the chocolate, chestnut purée and amaretti biscuits together, then stir through the orange and zest. Gently fold in the cream until combined, then spoon the mixture into the tin. Smooth the top and cover with cling film. Freeze for 3-4 hrs until just firm.

Take the parfait out of the freezer 20 mins before serving. To serve, dip the tin briefly in hot water, then turn out onto a serving plate and remove the cling film. Scatter over the grated chocolate and slice.
chief_review: This festive dessert is a delightful combination of Italian inspiration and seasonal flair—perfect for impressing at gatherings. The richness of milk chocolate and double cream is artfully balanced by the sweet zestiness of fresh oranges, while amaretti biscuits add a pleasing crunch and subtle almond flavor. The sweetened chestnut purée gives depth and an earthy sweetness that sets this dish apart from typical holiday treats. Grated dark chocolate on top enhances the overall look and sophistication. This recipe suits a vegetarian diet, as all ingredients are plant-based or dairy, with no gelatine or meat derivatives. Be sure to chill in advance for best texture and flavor melding. A simple, luxurious dessert that delivers both in taste and festive presentation.

name: Cheese with pickled pear salad
description: A contemporary alternative to the traditional cheeseboard, the hardest part will be selecting your favourite cheeses
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 Conference pears, peeled, cored and thinly sliced
8 thin wedges stiltonsor another British cheese
biscuits, crackers and whole walnuts, to serve
directions: In a large bowl, mix the mustard and vinegar. Add the oils, mustard seeds, tarragon, spring onion and salt and pepper. Add the pears to the dressing, toss well, then cover and chill for up to 4 hrs until ready to serve. Place a wedge of each cheese on small serving plates, then divide the pear salad between the plates. Serve with biscuits, crackers and walnuts.
chief_review: This modern take on the cheeseboard brings together a delightful combination of flavors and textures. The pairing of crisp Conference pears with robust British cheddar and stilton offers a refreshing contrast, while the Dijon mustard, tarragon, and walnut oil dressing elevates the fruit beautifully. The addition of mustard seeds and spring onion adds a mild zing that complements the cheeses. Whole walnuts provide crunch and earthiness, and the assortment of biscuits and crackers ensures variety in every bite. This recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, provided that the cheeses are made with vegetarian rennet. Overall, it's an elegant, easy-to-assemble option perfect for entertaining or as an impressive finale to a meal.

name: Root vegetable & mustard mash
description: Make the most of cheap and tasty seasonal root vegetables in this low fat and super healthy side
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2kg mixed root vegetable, cut into small chunks, we used 1 swede, 1 celeriac and 6 carrots
directions: Put the veg in a large pan of salted water. Bring to the boil and cook for 15 mins until tender. Drain well, then mash adding the butter, oil and mustard. Season generously. Mix together until the butter has melted, and serve piping hot. This can be made a day ahead and reheated in the pan with a touch more butter, or in the microwave.
chief_review: This vibrant root vegetable medley highlights the natural sweetness and robust flavors of seasonal swede, celeriac, and carrots. The combination of butter and extra-virgin olive oil creates a luscious, silky texture, while wholegrain mustard lends a gentle tang and depth to the dish. It’s an excellent choice for vegetarians and those seeking gluten-free options, as the ingredients are naturally free from gluten and meat products. The recipe is low in fat and packed with nutrients, making it an ideal side to accompany lean proteins or hearty stews. For vegans or those with a dairy allergy, simply substitute a plant-based butter to keep all the richness without sacrificing any of the flavors. Overall, this dish brings comfort, nutrition, and versatility to the table—a must-try for anyone wanting to celebrate the best of root vegetables.

name: Crunchy crab parcels
description: The combination of crispy filo pastry & crabmeat makes this a wonderfully indulgent dish
author: John Torode
ingredients: 2 spring onions, plus extra for serving
directions: Boil the potato for 15 mins until soft. Meanwhile, place 25g of the butter and all of the cream in a heavy-based pan and bring to the boil. Slice the spring onions, separating the green and white parts, then add the white slices to the boiling liquid and cook for 1-2 mins to soften. Pass the cooked potato through a ricer or sieve to a really fine mash, then add to the pan and mix everything together. Set aside to cool.

Add the crabmeat and sliced green bits of spring onion to the potato mixture and stir together. Melt the remaining butter. Unwrap the filo pastry and cover with a clean, damp tea towel to prevent it drying out. Brush melted butter over one sheet, place another on top and brush again with butter. Then add a final sheet of filo.

Cut the filo sheets lengthways into 3 long strips. Then cut each strip in half across the middle. Place a teaspoon of the crab onto the bottom right-hand corner of each filo strip. Fold the filo over to make a triangle, then fold again, rolling up the strip. When the mixture is enclosed and you have a neat triangle shape, place on a baking sheet and brush with more butter. Can be made ahead up to this point and frozen for up to 1 month.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Cook the rolls for 15-20 mins until golden and crisp. To serve, pile the parcels up on a plate or bowl, then scatter over with extra sliced spring onion, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe brings together the delicate sweetness of crabmeat and the crisp, golden crunch of filo pastry in an irresistibly rich combination. The addition of potato and cream provides a luxurious creaminess that complements the briny freshness of the seafood, while spring onions add a subtle lift of flavor. The filo sheets ensure a satisfyingly light texture without overwhelming the filling. Suitable for pescatarians, this dish is ideal as a special appetizer or an elegant main. For those mindful of gluten, be aware that traditional filo contains wheat. Perfectly balanced and indulgent, this is a sophisticated recipe for entertaining or treating yourself to something exceptional.

name: Chipolatas wrapped in sage & pancetta
description: Update festive favourite trimming pigs-in-blankets by covering sausages in Italian bacon and herb
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put 1 slice of pancetta on a chopping board and stretch out using the back of a knife. Put 1 sage leaf and 1 sausage on top, and roll the sausage up on the diagonal, covering all of it. Put on a lightly greased baking sheet and repeat with the remaining sausages.
Cook for 20-25 mins until crisp and cooked through.
chief_review: This recipe elevates the classic pigs-in-blankets by wrapping chipolata sausages in fragrant sage leaves and silky pancetta. The combination of Italian bacon’s saltiness with aromatic sage beautifully complements the juicy sausage, creating a savoury, upscale bite perfect for festive occasions or as an appetizer at any gathering. The recipe uses pork-based chipolatas and pancetta, so it's ideal for those following a standard omnivore diet. The simplicity of the ingredients allows for quick assembly, with the herbs lending a subtle depth that balances the richness of the cured meat. Serve these straight from the oven for the best flavour and texture, and consider offering a tangy relish or mustard dip alongside to cut through the richness. This twist on a festive staple impresses with minimal effort and maximum taste, making it a must-try for your next celebration.

name: Bay, popcorn & cranberry strings
description: These thrifty decorations look pretty and seasonal - but don't eat them! Great for making with older kids
author: Good Food
directions: Cut a 3m length of kitchen string and tie a fat knot 10cm from one end. Thread the other end onto a big, blunt needle, such as a tapestry needle. Thread on bay leaves, popcorn and cranberries, in a random pattern. Tie off when you get to the other end, leaving enough string to hang it up with.
chief_review: This festive craft recipe cleverly uses bay leaves, popcorn, and fresh cranberries to create decorative garlands that evoke a classic holiday charm. The choice of natural, plant-based ingredients means the recipe is suitable for vegan and vegetarian households, making it a delightful project for those following plant-based diets. With no wheat or dairy included, it also caters well to gluten-free and lactose-free homes. While these garlands are not intended for consumption, their use of common, minimally processed foods makes the activity accessible for families mindful of food allergies, provided individual sensitivities to cranberries or popcorn are considered. Overall, this is a sustainable and inclusive holiday craft, perfect for involving older kids in the joyous preparations, and resulting in beautiful, eco-friendly decorations.

name: Rabbit & pork terrine with peppercorns
description: This rich terrine, with thyme, allspice and brandy, can be pressed and mature overnight for a perfect make-ahead starter or light lunch
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: meat from 3 wild rabbits, 500g brown meat from the back legs and trimmings, 200g from the loins
500g boneless pork belly, cut into chunks
about 100g/4oz small cornichons, plus extra to serve
directions: Ask your butcher to remove the meat from the rabbit, or do it yourself. The leg meat can be as roughly prepped as you like, but keep the loins as neat as you can.

Put the leg meat, trimmings and pork belly in a processor, finely chop, then tip into a large bowl. Melt the butter and cook the garlic, shallots and thyme together gently for 8 mins or until the shallots are soft but not coloured. Tip onto the minced meat, add the allspice, peppercorns and 3 tbsp brandy, then mix well. Leave to mingle for 1 hr, or longer if you like, in the fridge.

Add the oil to the pan and quickly brown the loins; you don’t need to cook them through. If you fancy, add 1 tbsp brandy to the pan and flambé them to finish. Set aside on a plate and tip any pan juices into the minced mixture.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Remove the garlic from the mince and season generously. It’s a good idea to fry a small ball of the mixture, let it cool, then taste to check the seasoning. Line a 900g loaf tin with a strip of foil. Stretch each piece of bacon a little with your knife. Arrange the rashers so that the base of the tin is covered with overlapping bacon and the rashers come neatly up the sides in a single layer and overhang generously. Boil a kettleful of water.

Press a third of the mince into the tin. Make a lengthways channel along one side, then poke in a line of loin pieces, so that they meet end-to-end. Scatter half the cornichons over the other side. Add the next third of mince and repeat, this time with the loins and cornichons on the opposite sides. Cover with the remaining mince, then bring the bacon over to seal. Wrap tightly in foil and put in a deep roasting tin. Pour in enough hot water to come halfway up the terrine and bake for 2 hrs or until a skewer comes out hot from the middle of the terrine, and the juices run clear. Top up the water if needed.

To press the terrine, sit the loaf tin on a rack in a roasting tin. Tear some cardboard to fit the top of the loaf tin as neatly as you can (we used egg box lids). Add a few layers and sit something extremely heavy on top to press the cardboard and terrine down (we used a cast-iron dish). Cool to room temperature, then chill completely, ideally overnight. Remove the weight and re-wrap the terrine in clean foil or cling film. Ideally, let it mature for 2 days in the fridge before eating. Serve with the pickle salad, below, and remaining cornichons.
chief_review: This rustic terrine impresses with its deeply savory blend of wild rabbit and pork belly, enhanced by aromatic thyme, allspice, and a splash of brandy. The dish requires careful attention to layering and seasoning, resulting in a mosaic of tender meats interlaced with fragrant shallots and green peppercorns. Pressing and maturing overnight allows flavors to meld beautifully, making this an exquisite make-ahead starter. Cornichons provide a bright, tangy contrast while bacon adds richness and ensures a picture-perfect finish. This recipe is best suited to traditional diets—it contains a variety of meats and animal products, along with alliums and dairy—so consider your guests’ preferences. Serve with crusty bread and extra cornichons for maximum enjoyment.

name: Chicken terrine with leeks & apricots
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1kg chicken thighson the bone, skin removed
500ml fresh chicken stock(you can buy this ready-made)
2 bay leaves, plus more to decorate
30g butter, plus more for the tin
1 large or 2 smaller banana shallots, finely chopped
50g smoked streaky baconor pancetta, finely chopped
2 chicken breasts, on the bone if possible, skin removed
toastdrizzled with olive oil, to serve (we used Crosta & Mollica Pane Pugliese)
directions: Put the chicken thighs into a pan with the stock and a string-tied bundle of 2 bay leaves, a few of the thyme sprigs and a little of the parsley. Add a few leek trimmings, the peppercorns and ½ tsp salt. Add water to just cover the meat, if needed. Bring to the boil, then cover and gently simmer for 30 mins.
Meanwhile, lightly butter a 900g loaf tin (ours was 12cm x 22cm x 7cm) and line with cling film, leaving plenty of overhang. Melt the butter in a

, then add the leeks, shallots and some seasoning. Cook for 10 mins over a medium heat until starting to colour. Add the bacon and garlic and cook for 2 mins more until the bacon is cooked through. Leave to cool.

Add the chicken breast to the stock mixture and top up with hot water to cover. Bring to the boil, then cover and simmer gently for another 20 mins. When ready, the chicken breast will be cooked through and the thigh meat will pull away easily from the bones. Lift the meat from the pan, drain the stock and leave to cool until it is just warm.
Discard the bones and any knobbly bits, then roughly chop the chicken. Stir into the leek mixture, along with 2 tsp more thyme leaves, the apricots and the brandy.

Soak the gelatine in cold water for 5 mins until floppy. Squeeze out the excess water, stir into 300ml of the warm stock, then mix with the chicken. Put a few bay leaves in the base of the tin, then spoon the chicken mixture on top and press down well. Cover with the cling film. Leave to cool, then chill thoroughly – overnight is best.

To serve, slice the terrine while it's still wrapped in cling film, then carefully peel the cling film off each slice. Drizzle the toast slices with olive oil and grill until golden brown and crisp, then sprinkle with a little salt. Serve the terrine with the toast and our yogurt piccalilli & crisp kale salad.
chief_review:
This recipe presents a rich, savory dish centered around tender chicken thighs and breasts, simmered in fresh chicken stock with aromatic herbs, leeks, and smoked bacon or pancetta. The addition of diced apricots introduces a subtle sweetness that beautifully balances the smokiness, while brandy offers depth and warmth. Leaf gelatine is used to set the mixture, ensuring a pleasing texture, and it's all served with toasted, olive oil-drizzled Pane Pugliese for a satisfying finish.

Ideal for those enjoying a traditional, protein-rich diet, this recipe is best suited for omnivores, with pork and poultry as key ingredients. The inclusion of alliums and dairy (butter) adds aroma and richness, making the dish hearty and comforting. The fresh green herb garnish adds brightness. A perfect centerpiece for a Sunday lunch or special gathering, this dish is a testament to classic European country cooking.

name: Red potatoes with horseradish & crème fraîche
description: An ideal side for ham, this salad gets added kick from the horseradish and vinegar
author: Good Food
directions: Cook the potatoes in a large saucepan of boiling salted water until tender. Drain, then place back in the warm pan to dry out a little.

Pour the vinegar over the potatoes and add a few pinches of salt. Let sit for 10 mins to cool, then add the remaining ingredients and toss gently. Taste and add a little more salt if necessary, then pour into a serving dish.
chief_review: This vibrant potato salad brilliantly balances creamy and sharp flavors, making it a delightful companion to ham or other mains. The baby red potatoes offer heartiness, while the combination of creamed horseradish and white wine vinegar adds an invigorating tang that elevates the dish beyond a traditional potato salad. The crème fraîche imparts silky richness, complemented by the fresh lift of lemon zest and garden-fresh notes from spring onions and chives. As it contains no meat, this salad is suitable for a vegetarian diet. Additionally, its absence of nuts, eggs, and gluten-containing grains means it caters well to common allergies and gluten-free needs—provided care is taken to choose certified gluten-free versions of horseradish and crème fraîche. The lively flavors and creamy texture ensure this side will be a talking point at any gathering.

name: Lettuce, chicory & apple salad with poppy seed dressing
description: Make the dressing for this super healthy salad in a jar and keep leftovers in the fridge for during the week
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 heads purple or white chicory, trimmed and separated into leaves
directions: Arrange the salad ingredients on a large platter or big salad bowl. Pour the dressing ingredients into a glass jar with a fitted lid, add some seasoning and shake well. When ready to serve, pour the dressing over and toss everything together.
chief_review:
This vibrant salad-in-a-jar offers a delightful interplay of flavors and textures, combining crisp salad leaves, chicory, juicy apples, sweet cherry tomatoes, and toasted walnuts. The dressing—a harmonious blend of vegetable oil, honey, lemon juice, Dijon mustard, shallot, and poppy seeds—brings a subtle zing and a touch of sweetness that compliments the freshness of the greens beautifully. 

With no animal-derived ingredients apart from honey, this recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet. Additionally, the absence of wheat-based products makes it a naturally gluten-free option, provided the Dijon mustard is verified gluten-free. The inclusion of nuts adds richness, though those with nut allergies should take note. This salad is not only delicious and satisfying but also makes meal prep effortless, as the dressing can be stored for convenience throughout the week.

name: Ginger & sesame sprouts
description: Try out this new side dish, which adds fresh and light Asian flavours to traditional winter favourite, Brussels sprouts
author: Good Food
directions: Blanch the sprouts in boiling water and drain well. Heat most of the oil in a wok and add the ginger. Sizzle for a moment, then add the sprouts and stir-fry until hot. Scatter over the sesame seeds and drizzle with a touch more oil. Season with salt, if you like, and serve.
chief_review: This inventive side dish beautifully elevates Brussels sprouts with the nutty depth of sesame oil and the zing of fresh ginger. The generous sprinkle of toasted sesame seeds delivers an appealing contrast in texture and a subtle earthiness, while the absence of animal products makes this a thoughtful offering for both vegan and vegetarian diets. With no gluten-containing ingredients, it’s also suitable for gluten-free diners. The flavors strike an impressive balance—bright and aromatic with a warming, toasty finish. This dish is ideal for anyone seeking a vibrant, healthful twist on a classic winter vegetable, and its simple ingredient list makes it easy to incorporate into a variety of dietary routines.

name: Reindeer & snowman chocolate bark
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 1 red jelly shoe lace, cut into lengths
directions: Line a baking tin with baking parchment. Heat both chocolates in separate bowls in the microwave in 30-sec blasts, or over pans of simmering water. Pour the dark chocolate into the baking tin, then pour the milk chocolate on top in a trail. Spread the chocolate out to make a reasonably thick slab.

Arrange the red smarties over the slab at intervals – these are the reindeer noses. Cut a marshmallow in half and press above the smarties to make eyes. Snap a pretzel in half for each set of antlers, snapping off any excess pretzel, then push into the chocolate near the noses.

To make the snowmen, arrange the rest of the marshmallows in lines of three. Use pieces of pretzel for the arms and a piece of shoe lace for the scarf. Sprinkle over the stars and sprinkles, then leave the chocolate to set completely.

Once the chocolate is hard, use an icing pen or small brush dipped in black food colouring to add pupils to the reindeer eyes, and faces and buttons for the snowmen. Use a knife to cut the bark into pieces around the reindeer and snowmen. To give them as gifts, put the chocolate shards in cellophane bags and tie with a pretty ribbon.
chief_review: This playful no-bake chocolate treat combines both milk and dark chocolate for a lovely balance of sweetness and depth. The addition of pretzels introduces a delightful crunch, complemented by the soft texture of marshmallows, while the playful use of Smarties and jelly shoe lace adds vibrant color and fun, making it especially appealing for children. Sprinkles and edible stars complete the festive presentation, and the black food pen is a nice touch for detail work. Ideal for those who enjoy sweet-and-salty combinations, this recipe would suit a vegetarian diet, as all included ingredients are typically free from animal-derived gelatin or additives. However, always double-check the specifics of your marshmallows and Smarties to ensure the absence of gelatin or non-vegetarian colorings. This treat is perfect for parties, celebrations, or an afternoon of baking with kids.

name: Juniper-glazed sprouts
description: Juniper berries aren't just for making gin, they perk up sprouts too
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tsp juniper berries, roughly ground with a pestle and mortar
directions: In a large frying pan, gently cook the shallots, garlic and juniper in the oil and half the butter until soft and golden – about 10 mins.
Add the sprouts and stock and simmer for 10 mins until sprouts are just tender and syrupy. Stir in the remaining butter with some seasoning and serve.
chief_review: This recipe transforms Brussels sprouts into a dish with surprising depth, thanks to the aromatic lift of juniper berries. The finely sliced shallots and crushed garlic sautéed in olive oil and butter add a rich base, while the juniper berries introduce a subtle, woodsy sharpness that sets the dish apart from typical preparations. Braising the sprouts in vegetable stock ensures tenderness and infuses them with layered flavor. As it contains only plant-based ingredients apart from butter, this recipe is well-suited for vegetarians. For those seeking a vegan option, the butter could be easily swapped for a plant-based alternative without sacrificing taste or texture. Overall, it’s an elegant side that pairs beautifully with a variety of main courses, making seasonal vegetables truly shine.

name: Pomegranate mojito mocktail
description:
Really tasty non alcholic drink. Made sure I really bruised mint and lime in the glass first.
Used as non alcoholic punch for our party. Went down really well with the drivers.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 limes, quartered, plus slices to garnish
directions: A day ahead, divide the pomegranate seeds between the holes in an ice cube tray, top up with water and freeze.

Reserve half the mint for serving, and tear the rest into a large jug with the lime quarters. Using a rolling pin, bash the mint and lime to release the flavours. Add the pomegranate juice and lemonade. Put ice cubes in each glass, then strain over the pomegranate mix through a small sieve. Garnish with lime slices and more mint.
chief_review: This refreshing non-alcoholic punch is a standout option for parties, offering a vibrant blend of pomegranate juice, zesty lime, and aromatic mint. The effort to bruise the mint and lime intensifies the flavors, making each sip lively and fragrant. Pomegranate seeds add a burst of texture, while the lemonade provides a gentle fizz, ensuring a balanced and easy-drinking beverage. With no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is well-suited for vegan and vegetarian diets, as well as those needing a gluten-free option. Perfect for designated drivers or anyone seeking a festive, alcohol-free alternative.

name: Beetroot-cured salmon with citrus salad & caramelised walnuts
author: José Pizarro
directions: Finely grate the beetroot and mix with the lemon zest, tarragon, sugar and salt.

2 Line a shallow dish with several layers of cling film in different directions, so it hangs over the edges. Spoon in half the beetroot mixture, drizzle with half the gin and put the salmon fillet on top. Spread the rest of the beetroot mix on top of the salmon, drizzle over the rest of the gin, then wrap as tightly as possible in the cling film. Leave to cure in the fridge for 48-72 hrs, turning the salmon occasionally (the longer you leave it, the firmer it becomes). Drain off any liquid as it escapes.
When the salmon is cured, scrape off the salt mixture really well, then rinse with cold water and dry well.

For the salad, put the sugar in a pan with 2 tbsp water and melt over a low heat. Bring to the boil and bubble until you have a golden caramel. Add the walnuts and mix together to coat. Tip onto a baking sheet lined with greased baking parchment and leave to cool.

Segment the citrus fruits over a bowl to catch the juice. Cut each segment into two or three pieces. Mix 4 tbsp of the juice with a pinch of salt and sugar, and plenty of black pepper. Whisk in the oil.
Finely slice the salmon. Divide the watercress and fruit segments between eight plates, then top with salmon. Scatter over the walnuts, drizzle over the dressing and serve.
chief_review: This recipe beautifully showcases vibrant ingredients, pairing earthy raw beetroots and aromatic tarragon with citrus notes from lemon, orange, and grapefruit. The use of flaky sea salt and sugar to cure the salmon, enhanced by gin, results in a delicate, flavorful gravlax-style fish. Toasted walnuts add a pleasant crunch, while peppery watercress and extra virgin olive oil lend freshness and balance to the finished dish. This recipe suits pescatarian diets and is naturally gluten-free, provided the gin used contains no additives with gluten. It also accommodates those avoiding dairy, as no milk or butter is present. Care should be exercised regarding nut allergies due to the walnuts. Overall, this is a refined, colorful cured salmon dish, perfect for a special brunch or light lunch.

name: Classic snowball
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Add the advocaat and lemonade to a tall glass filled with ice. Stir gently until the outside of the glass feels cold.
Garnish with the maraschino cherry.
chief_review: This playful cocktail combines the creamy, custard richness of advocaat with sparkling lemonade, resulting in a delightfully effervescent and indulgent drink. The maraschino cherry not only adds a touch of color but an elegant, sweet finish. The use of advocaat—a liqueur made with eggs, sugar, and brandy—means this drink is not suitable for vegans, but it does work for vegetarians. With no wheat, barley, or other gluten-containing ingredients, it’s also gluten-free, provided your advocaat and maraschino cherries are sourced from reputable gluten-free manufacturers. The recipe is simple and quick to assemble, ideal for festive occasions or as an after-dinner treat. Serve well chilled over ice for best results.

name: Bay & orange roast turkey
description: Brushing the turkey with a last-minute sticky glaze means your bird will be golden and looking its best when you bring it to the table
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Remove giblets, then wash and dry the turkey, removing any remaining feathers. Mix half the butter with the orange zest and plenty of seasoning. Lift up the skin at the neck end of the turkey and use your fingers to ease the skin away from the breasts. Gently smear some of the zesty butter over the breasts and under the skin. Pack the stuffing into the neck opening and secure the skin closed with skewers or cocktail sticks. Weigh the turkey at this point and write it down so you can work out your timings, then rub the rest of the zesty butter all over.

Stuff the 2 whole oranges into the cavity with some bay leaves. Pile the sliced shallots and a few more bay leaves into a large roasting tin and sit the turkey on top. Pour 500ml of the stock around, cover with foil to make a tent over the turkey, then roast for 20 mins per 450g/1lb.

Meanwhile, bubble the remaining butter, orange juice and sugar together until syrupy. With 30 mins cooking time to go, remove the foil, brush the turkey liberally with the syrup, then return to the oven to brown at 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Brush once or twice more while roasting. To test that the turkey is ready, pierce the thigh in its thickest part and make sure the juices run clear. Lift the turkey out, brush again with syrup and leave to rest, covered loosely with foil, for 20 mins or so while you make the gravy and finish cooking the veg.

Pour the tin juices into a jug (keeping shallots and bay in the tin), then put the roasting tin over a flame. Stir in the flour, then gradually stir in the remaining stock Marmite and reserved turkey juices – skimmed of any fat. Bubble until a nice consistency, then strain into a saucepan, squishing the shallots with a masher to squeeze out all the flavour. Keep the gravy warm while you carve the turkey to serve.
chief_review: This festive roast turkey recipe is a true showstopper, showcasing a beautiful, golden skin thanks to a last-minute, sticky glaze. The combination of orange zest and juice imparts a fresh citrus aroma that elegantly balances the savory richness of the butter and the subtle umami from Marmite. Bay leaves and shallots deepen the flavor base, while a generous amount of chicken stock in the roasting process ensures moistness throughout. The use of flour to thicken the gravy is something to note for those on a gluten-free diet, as a substitute may be necessary. The recipe, centered around turkey and chicken stock, is well-suited for those following a traditional, omnivorous diet but is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. Overall, this turkey recipe promises a moist, flavorful centerpiece with visually impressive results—ideal for holiday gatherings.

name: Mini Paris-Brest with white chocolate & crystallised fruit
description: This gorgeous confection was invented to celebrate the Paris-Brest cycle race – it's meant to resemble a bicycle wheel
author: Mary Cadogan
