directions: Heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line a large baking sheet with baking paper and mark 8 circles about 8-9cm across using a glass or mug. Turn the paper over. Sift the flour onto a sheet of baking paper. Put the butter and 150ml water into a pan, then bring slowly to the boil until the butter has melted. When the water is bubbling, remove quickly from the heat, tip in the flour all at once and beat quickly with a wooden spoon until it forms a dough that leaves the side of the pan clean. Remove from the heat and cool for 3 mins.

Lightly beat the eggs with a fork. Add the egg to the dough gradually, beating well with each addition until the dough is smooth and glossy. Put this dough into a piping bag fitted with a large plain nozzle (about 2cm across) or use a large food bag with the corner snipped off. Pipe 8 thick rings onto the baking sheet using the marked circles as a guide.

Bake the buns for 20-25 mins until crisp and golden, then split them carefully in half through the centre using a sharp knife in a sawing action; return to the oven for 5 mins. Transfer to a cooling rack, taking care to keep the tops and bottoms together, and leave to cool. Whip the cream to soft peaks and stir in the vanilla. Melt 100g of the chocolate for 1-2 mins in a microwave. Leave to cool slightly, then fold into the cream.

Stir half the crystallised fruit and the almonds through the cream. Fill the choux rings with the mixture using two teaspoons. Melt the remaining chocolate and drizzle over the choux rings. Scatter with crystallised fruit and leave to set. Dust with icing sugar before serving.
chief_review: This Paris-Brest-inspired confection is a showstopper with its beautiful wheel shape and rich, indulgent flavors. The choux pastry, made with butter, eggs, and flour, provides a delicate, airy base that’s perfectly balanced by a smooth, vanilla-scented white chocolate cream filling. The addition of crystallised fruit brings delightful bursts of sweetness, while toasted flaked almonds add a satisfying crunch and contrast. A light dusting of icing sugar gives the pastry a refined finish. This recipe is ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat-based ingredients. It’s a luxurious dessert that would impress at any celebration, marrying texture and flavor in each bite. Overall, a delicious, inventive nod to a classic French pastry.

name: Oysters with oriental dressing
description: John Torode's seafood dish with a kick makes a spicy addition to a Chinese banquet
author: John Torode
ingredients: 12 oysters, shucked (see directions for tips on preparing your oysters)
bunch chives, finely chopped, to serve
directions: Shuck your oysters if not already prepared. Watch our
To make the sauce, mix all the ingredients together in a small bowl. Drizzle the sauce over the oysters, then sprinkle with chopped chives and serve straight away.
chief_review: John Torode’s seafood creation delivers an alluring blend of heat and umami, highly evocative of a bustling Chinese banquet. The oysters form the dish’s delicate centrepiece, their briny sweetness amplified by the punchy mix of ginger, garlic, and red chilli. Mirin adds a touch of gentle sweetness, balanced by the savoury depth of soy sauce and a fragrant layer of sesame oil. Spring onions and chives offer a crisp, herbal finish that keeps the flavours bright. This recipe is a superb choice for pescatarians and naturally fits gluten-free diets if tamari replaces traditional soy sauce. It’s an elegantly simple dish that showcases fresh seafood with contemporary vibrancy—perfect as a starter or as part of a celebratory spread.

name: Coconut & cinnamon place-name cookies
description: Personalised biscuits are an impressive finishing touch when you're setting a table for dinner with friends and family
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 300g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
writing icing pens, sprinkles, to decorate (see Tip below)
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Beat butter, sugar, egg and vanilla together with a pinch of salt until smooth. Stir in the flour, cinnamon and coconut with a wooden spoon.

On a floured surface, roll out the dough to a just a bit thinner than 1/ 2 cm. Make a two templates out of card of roughly 10 x 5.5cm and 8 x 3cm. (If you can find cutters even better). Place the larger template on the dough and use a pastry wheel, pizza cutter or knife to cut out the shape. Repeat until all the dough is used. Lift onto baking sheets, then bake for 10-12 mins until pale golden. Cool for a few mins, then transfer to a cooling rack to finish cooling. Biscuits can now be frozen, see tip.
Roll out the ready-to roll icing on an icing sugar dusted surface. Use the smaller template, cut out the icing in the same way.

Sift the icing sugar into a bowl and stir in enough water to make runny. Brush the biscuit with a little of the runny icing. Stick an icing rectangle in the centre and scatter the sprinkles around the edges. Repeat with the rest. Pipe guests names onto biscuits and set aside to set. Will keep in an airtight tin for up to 3 days.
chief_review:
These personalised biscuits delight both the eye and the palate, making them an excellent way to add a bespoke touch to your next dinner gathering. The combination of softened butter, golden caster sugar, and vanilla delivers a classic biscuit base that is elevated by warm cinnamon and a hint of coconut for texture and depth. Ready-to-roll icing creates a smooth canvas for creativity, and the use of writing icing pens and sprinkles means each guest can have a unique treat.  

The recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatine-derived ingredients. Note that these biscuits contain common allergens such as wheat (gluten), egg, coconut, and dairy.  

Overall, these biscuits are a charming, crowd-pleasing addition to any celebratory table setting, striking a perfect balance between appearance and taste.

name: Pineapple sorbet with fresh mango
description: John Torode's refreshing, Asian ice will finish off your meal with a zing
author: John Torode
ingredients: 1 pineapple, peeled, cored and cut into chunks
1 ripe mango, peeled and thinly sliced, to serve
1 vanilla pod, split in half lengthways
directions: Put the pineapple into a blender or food processor and blitz to a purée. To make the stock syrup, put all the ingredients in a large pot with 500ml water, slowly bring to the boil and stir until the sugar has dissolved, then remove from the heat.

Tip the pineapple purée and the lime juice into the syrup and stir well. Leave to cool, then strain and churn in an ice-cream maker following manufacturer’s instructions. Place in a container and freeze. Alternatively, tip the syrup into a large tray and freeze until it starts to set, then every hour or so break up the ice with a fork. Serve the sorbet scooped into dessert glasses with a few slices of mango.
chief_review: John Torode’s Asian ice is an invigorating finale to any meal, delivering vibrant tropical flavors with a touch of aromatic spice. The blend of pineapple and lime juice offers a tart-sweet base, elevated by the warmth of cinnamon and subtle vanilla. The mango slices provide both color and creamy contrast. This recipe is naturally vegan, dairy-free, and gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for guests with these dietary preferences. The absence of common allergens such as nuts or eggs is a further advantage for inclusive entertaining. Prepare this ahead to allow the flavors to meld and serve well-chilled for maximum refreshment. An impressive, palate-cleansing dessert that is as stunning to look at as it is delightful to eat.

name: Whiskey marmalade
description: Add a kick to a classic. Marmalade lovers won't be able to resist
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Wash the oranges and put in a large pan with the water and lemon juice. Bring to the boil, partly cover and simmer for 21/2 hours, until the oranges are very soft. Remove from the heat and scoop the oranges out into a large bowl. When they are cool enough to handle, cut them in half and scoop the flesh and seeds back into the pan using a dessertspoon. Bring back to the boil and simmer uncovered for 30 mins.

Meanwhile cut the orange peel into strips(either using a sharp knife or knife and fork for a chunkier style). Press the contents of the pan through a sieve into a preserving pan, pressing though as much pulp as possible. Add the peel, sugar and treacle or molasses to the pan. Put a couple of saucers in the freezer.

Bring slowly to the boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar, then raise the heat and boil rapidly until setting point is reached. This should take around 6-10 mins. To test this turn off the heat under the marmalade, take a saucer out of the freezer and spoon on a little blob of marmalade. Leave for a moment, then push the marmalade with your finger. If the surface wrinkles it is ready, if not boil for a few more minutes and test again.

Stir the whiskey into the marmalade, then leave it to cool for 10 mins. Give it a stir to distribute the peel, then spoon into clean warm jars(put them through the dishwasher and leave to dry or wash and drain, then wash well, then warm in the oven for 10 mins) cover and label.
chief_review: This marmalade recipe offers an invigorating twist to the classic, blending the robust bitterness of Seville oranges with the complex depth of treacle and a generous splash of Irish whiskey. The addition of lemon juice brightens the flavor, creating an engaging balance with the natural sweetness from the preserving sugar. The method is traditional, delivering a preserve with vivid citrus notes complemented by subtle, warming undertones from the whiskey and molasses. Vegan-friendly and naturally gluten-free, this recipe is ideal for those mindful of such dietary preferences. Its ingredient simplicity also makes it suitable for dairy-free diets. Perfect spread on toast or scones, this marmalade will elevate any breakfast table or afternoon tea. A delightful choice for both marmalade purists and adventurous palates alike.

name: Spicy courgettes with saffron risotto
description: Simple and satisfying - perfect for impressing friends
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 large red chilli, halved and deseeded
fresh basil leaves and vegetarian parmesan-style cheese shavings, to garnish
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a large frying pan, then add the courgettes and fry for 3-4 mins until browned. Sprinkle with paprika, drain, then transfer to a shallow ovenproof baking dish.
Add the remaining oil to the frying pan and fry the onion and garlic for 5 mins, stirring occasionally, until softened and lightly browned.
Add chopped tomatoes, chilli, sugar and seasoning, then cook for a further 2 mins. Spoon sauce over the courgettes, then put in the oven on a low shelf.
Put the risotto rice into a casserole dish with the boiling water, then season. Cover and cook in the oven, above the courgettes, for 20 mins until the rice and courgettes are tender.
Fluff up the rice with a fork, then spoon onto warmed serving plates. Top with the courgette mixture and garnish with fresh basil leaves and cheese.
chief_review:
This vibrant courgette and tomato risotto is a delightful dish that balances simplicity with depth of flavor. The generous use of olive oil, fresh vegetables, and aromatic garlic offers a light yet satisfying base, while a whisper of chilli and paprika adds a gentle warmth. The use of saffron-flavoured Arborio rice infuses luxurious colour and subtle fragrance, making the presentation as striking as the taste. Finished with fresh basil and vegetarian parmesan-style cheese, the risotto feels indulgent yet fresh. 

This recipe is particularly well-suited for a vegetarian diet, thanks to the use of vegetarian parmesan-style cheese and a lack of any meat or fish. Those with gluten sensitivities will also appreciate that all ingredients are naturally gluten-free, provided the cheese and risotto rice are certified as such. A crowd-pleaser that doesn’t sacrifice on nutrition or elegance.

name: Smoked salmon & easy blinis
description: Can you make these in advance - a couple of days say.
author: James Martin
directions: For the blini mix, tip the flour into a bowl, then season. Make a well in the middle, then add the egg yolk and half the milk. Whisk until smooth, gradually add the rest of the milk, then the butter and chives. Whisk the egg whites until starting to stiffen, then fold into the batter. To cook, lightly grease a frying pan, then sizzle spoonfuls for 2-3 mins on each side until golden, flipping them over when bubbling. Set aside and keep warm.
Make a dressing in a large bowl with the mustard, vinegar and olive oil. Add the leaves, then toss. Serve the salad, salmon and blinis with some beetroot on the side.
chief_review:
This vibrant recipe beautifully combines the earthiness of beetroot, the smokiness of salmon, and the freshness of garden leaves for a delightful dish that impresses both visually and in flavor. The inclusion of wholegrain mustard and red wine vinegar in the dressing lends a pleasant punch, while the chives add a gentle herbal note. The method appears to involve making light, savory pancakes using plain flour, egg, milk, and butter—perfect as a base for the topping. These can certainly be made a couple of days in advance and assembled just before serving, making them ideal for entertaining or meal prep.

Suitable for pescatarians, this recipe also caters to anyone seeking a high-protein, nutrient-dense meal. With no nuts or shellfish, and adaptable for some common food sensitivities, it’s a versatile addition to any modern cook’s repertoire.

name: Hazelnut, pancetta & orange stuffing
description: This recipe makes enough smoked pancetta, orange zest and sage stuffing for a 4.5kg turkey - or roll into balls and bake
author: Jenny White
directions: Heat a large frying pan and add the pancetta. Cook for 2-3 mins until just starting to turn golden. Remove from the pan with a slotted spoon and set aside. Add the butter, onions and garlic to the pan, and cook for 4-5 mins, stirring occasionally. Remove from the heat and transfer to a bowl with the pancetta. Leave to cool.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Stir the orange zest, breadcrumbs, sage and nuts into the onion mixture and mix well. Season, then stir in enough of the beaten egg to bind the mixture but not make it sloppy. Use to stuff the turkey or shape into balls, place in a roasting tin and cook for 30 mins.
chief_review: This stuffing recipe delivers a rich, aromatic blend perfect for accenting turkey or served as standalone baked balls. The smoked pancetta infuses the stuffing with a savory depth, while the orange zest and sage add a vibrant, herbaceous lift. Toasted hazelnuts provide a subtle crunch and nutty note, elevating the overall texture. The butter, onions, and garlic round out the flavor profile with warmth and sweetness. Using fresh white breadcrumbs keeps the mixture light yet cohesive, bound together effortlessly by the beaten egg. This recipe is well-suited for those following a nut-inclusive, ovo-vegetarian-friendly (with pancetta omitted) diet, though, as written, it is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. The thoughtful combination of flavors and textures makes it a standout choice for holiday gatherings.

name: Cheese stars
description: These are divine, although true to my Mothers recipe I used cheddar, swiss and parm! They are so good I have had to just keep making them because they get eaten so quickly, no time to save for guests or as gifts!
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: mugful of grated cheese(we mixed 60g cheddar with 25g parmesan)
toppings of your choice(optional) - we used poppy seeds, dried oregano and sesame seeds
directions: Unroll the pastry and sprinkle most of the cheese over one half of the sheet. Fold the pastry in half to cover the cheese and seal it in.
Dust your rolling pin and work surface with a little flour and put your pastry sheet on it. Roll it out until doubled in size.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line two baking sheets with baking parchment.

Using cookie cutters, cut the pastry into shapes and put them on the prepared baking sheets. (Put the cutters on the dough close together so that less pastry is wasted. You can fold the trimmings back on themselves and re-roll to cut out more shapes.)
Brush the shapes with milk and add a pinch of cheese and a sprinkling of your chosen topping, if using.
Bake in the oven for 10-12 mins or until risen and golden, then transfer to a serving plate. Will keep in an airtight container for 3 days.
chief_review: This cheese straw recipe is a delightful crowd-pleaser, boasting a golden, flaky exterior thanks to the puff pastry and a deeply savoury, satisfying blend of cheddar and parmesan. The milk helps achieve that desirable sheen atop each twist, while your choice of toppings—poppy seeds, sesame, dried oregano—adds both texture and aromatic complexity. The recipe is quick to assemble, making it ideal for impromptu gatherings or as an impressive party snack. Importantly, it is suitable for vegetarians if you select vegetarian cheese for both cheddar and parmesan. However, those with gluten or dairy allergies should note that both the puff pastry and cheese are integral to the dish. Overall, these cheese straws are a classic example of simple ingredients coming together to create something delectable and crowd-pleasing.

name: Melting cheese with poppy & apricot bread wreath
description: Fabulous recipe. I made the bread without the poppy seeds as I didn't have any and it was delicious. Rather than making a whole loaf which I thought would be rather clumsy to serve I made the dough into 16 small balls which I arranged fairly close together around the cheese in a double ring to give a tear & share bread. It went down very well and I would make it again. The bread could also be used with any type of soup, cheese or cold meats.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1-2 soft cheeses in boxes, like brieor camembert
directions: Tip the bread mix into a food processor, add the walnuts and whizz until fully incorporated. Transfer to a bowl and stir in the apricots and most of the poppy seeds. Warm the milk to hand temperature, then stir into the flour mix with a wooden spoon. Knead in the bowl until smooth. Cover with oiled cling film and leave somewhere warm-ish to rise for 1 hr.
Find a heatproof dish the same size or a bit bigger than your cheese box. Sit it in the middle of a big baking tray.
Shape the risen dough into a long, thin log that will wrap around the dish on the sheet, like a wreath. Press the ends together, loosely cover with oiled cling film and leave to rise for 20-30 mins.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Brush the egg all over the loaf, then sprinkle with the remaining poppy seeds. Using kitchen scissors, randomly snip into the dough, to give a spiky finish. Bake for 35-40 mins until golden and crusty, and the bottom sounds hollow when you tap it. Remove the dish from the middle.

To serve, unwrap the cheese and put it back into the box. Stab a few times, add the wine and tie kitchen string around the box to secure it in case the glue comes undone. Sit the cheese in the middle of the bread, without its lid, and bake for 10-15 mins until molten. Serve straight away and, if you like, pop another cheese in the oven so you can finish off the bread when the first cheese box is wiped clean.
chief_review: This inventive bread recipe shines as a showstopping centerpiece, especially when shaped into tear-and-share rolls encircling creamy soft cheeses. The addition of walnuts and dried apricots provides a delightful texture and nuanced sweetness, elevating the bread’s flavor and pairing beautifully with brie or camembert. The use of prepared bread mix streamlines the process, while milk and egg contribute to a tender, rich crumb. This bread suits a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish. Its versatility makes it an excellent companion for soups, cheese platters, or charcuterie boards. Using poppy seeds is optional, offering a subtle crunch if included. The recipe’s flexibility in presentation enhances its appeal for entertaining. Serve warm for best results and enjoy the harmonious contrast of molten cheese and subtly sweet, nut-studded bread.

name: Chocolate & walnut Pavlova with madeira & tangerines
description: Delicious flavour combinations. I think I would go for the smaller diameter circle rather than the huge one as the meringue does cook quite crisply if you spread it to the larger circle but a bigger one could be good if you were trying to feed lots of people. I would also have done more tangerines as I loved the tang and contrast with the sweet meringue. I agree with the previous comment though - guessing you could use whatever alcohol you have - I had a bit of Marsala left over so used that.
author: Rosie Birkett
directions: Roughly chop the tangerines. In a bowl, toss the tangerines with the madeira until thoroughly coated, then set aside to macerate.
Heat oven to 110C/90C/gas
. Line two baking sheets with baking parchment.

the egg whites in a clean bowl or stand mixer until soft peaks form. Without stopping whisking, gradually add the sugar and whisk until thick and glossy, then whisk in the vinegar too. Toss the walnuts in the melted chocolate, then fold into the egg so the meringue is marbled with chocolate.

Spread a circle of the chocolate and walnut meringue about 20-25cm in diameter on each baking sheet. Bake for 2 hrs until crisp but slightly soft in the middle – don’t worry if it cracks; it will still taste delicious. Remove from the oven and carefully lift the meringues and parchment onto wire racks to cool. Peel the parchment from the meringues, then use a wide palette knife to lift one meringue onto a serving platter or cake stand.

Whip the cream to soft peaks, being careful not to over whip. Fold in half the tangerines and the madeira used to soak them. Spread just over half the cream mixture onto the meringue, then top with the other layer of meringue, the remaining cream and the rest of the tangerines. Sprinkle over the grated dark chocolate and serve. Can be made a day ahead and chilled in the fridge.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful interplay between crisp meringue, rich chocolate, buttery walnuts, and tangy tangerines. The suggestion to opt for a smaller diameter circle is practical, ensuring the meringue remains crisp yet tender. Elevating the tangerine quantity would indeed enhance the citrus vibrancy, which balances the sweetness beautifully. Marsala, or any favorite fortified wine, adds a sophisticated boozy depth—feel free to substitute Madeira with any similar tipple you have on hand. The walnuts add an earthy crunch and the grated dark chocolate finish brings a touch of bitterness, complementing the sweetness and cream. This dessert is ideal for gatherings and would suit a vegetarian diet. Those with gluten sensitivities will be pleased, as there are no gluten-containing ingredients. However, nut and dairy allergies should be noted. Overall, an elegant, crowd-pleasing dessert with captivating textures and flavors.

name: Turkish delight
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: ½ tsp rosewater(or 2 tbsp rose syrup)
pink food colouring, if not using the rose syrup
directions: Oil a shallow square metal or silicone baking tray, about 18 x 18cm. Put the sugar in a pan with the cream of tartar and 500ml water and heat gently at first, stirring so that the sugar melts. Then, turn up the heat and boil for 10-15 mins until the mixture is a little more syrupy. If you have a sugar thermometer, it should reach 115-118C.
Stir the cornflour into 150ml water, then,
all the time, pour it into the sugar syrup. Keep whisking, until everything combines to make a smooth, gloopy mix. Take out the whisk and start to stir with a

or spoon over a medium heat. Keep stirring until the mixture is thick enough to see a clear line drawn through it with the spoon and it starts to leave the sides of the pan. It will be very thick and make big bubbles that burst as it cooks, so be careful. This can take up to an hour. Test the mix by dropping a small amount into very cold water; it should form a ball that can be pressed gently when cold and that will feel a little springy.

Stir in the rosewater or rose syrup and the food colouring, if using, then pour everything into the tray and level the top. Leave to cool and set completely. Sieve some cornflour and icing sugar together over a board and carefully turn out the Turkish delight. Cover it with more icing sugar and cornflour and cut it into cubes with a sharp
. Dust with yet more of the icing sugar mixture and move the pieces apart so they can dry.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a classic, delicately flavored rose Turkish delight with a satisfyingly chewy texture. The combination of granulated sugar, cornflour, and rosewater (or rose syrup) creates an enchanting, fragrant sweet that’s beautifully finished with a dusting of icing sugar and cornflour. The use of oil for the tray ensures an easy release, maintaining the integrity of each cube. This confection contains no animal products or gluten, making it a delightful option for both vegan and gluten-free diets, provided the food coloring used is also vegan. Its simple ingredient list also avoids common allergens such as nuts, dairy, and eggs. The result is a sophisticated treat perfect for afternoon tea or as an edible gift, sure to impress with its floral aroma and melt-in-the-mouth consistency.

name: Marzipan & mincemeat apples
description: With only four ingredients, this is a great use for leftover mincemeat
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 small lemon, finely grated zest and juice
directions: Cut the apples in half widthways. Remove and discard cores, then stand the apples in a microwave-safe dish. Break the marzipan into small chunks and mix with the mincemeat and lemon zest. Spoon into the centre of the apples and pour over the lemon juice.
Cover the dish with cling film, pierce several times and microwave on High for 4½ minutes. If you don't have a turntable and the apples are not cooking evenly, turn the dish halfway through.
Remove the cling film and leave to stand for 5 minutes before serving.
chief_review: This delightful dessert makes the most of leftover mincemeat, pairing it with tart Bramley apples and rich marzipan for a harmonious balance of flavors. The addition of lemon zest and juice brightens the dish, lifting the sweetness with a touch of citrus. With just four ingredients, the preparation is refreshingly simple, allowing the natural flavors of the apples and mincemeat to shine. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin and relies solely on fruit, marzipan, and mincemeat—provided the mincemeat chosen is suet-free or made with vegetarian suet. The dish’s rustic charm and straightforward technique make it both accessible and satisfying—a wonderful option for those seeking to minimize food waste while presenting a charming dessert.

name: Simple snowflake cake
description: A simple, but sophisticated decoration for a homemade or bought cake - it'll only take half an hour
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 1 x 20cm round Christmas cake, homemade (see 'Goes well with' recipe) or bought
approx 65cm wide silver ribbon(available from cake decorating suppliers or stationers)
approx 65cm clear snowflake ribbon(available from Paperchase)
directions: Brush the top of the Christmas cake with honey. Roll out the marzipan, then trim to fit the top of the cake, using the cake itself or the cake tin as a template. Lay the marzipan on top of the cake, then press down lightly.

Lightly beat the egg whites with a fork, just to break them up, then gradually beat in the sifted icing sugar until you have an icing that forms soft peaks. Beat in the glycerine to stop the icing from getting too hard. Spread and thickly swirl the icing over the marzipan, then scatter with silver dragees. Decorate by wrapping round a silver ribbon and then the clear snowflake ribbon.
chief_review: This elegant cake decoration recipe beautifully elevates a classic Christmas cake with a smooth marzipan layer, glossy royal icing, and sparkling embellishments. The combination of honey, marzipan, and egg-white-based royal icing creates a luxurious finish, while the silver dragees and decorative ribbons add a festive, professional touch. Notably, this recipe suits a vegetarian diet, as it avoids gelatine and animal rennet. For those focusing on nut allergies, keep in mind that marzipan is almond-based, so it is not suitable for those sensitive to nuts. The method is straightforward, making it accessible even for beginner decorators while delivering results worthy of celebration.

name: Beef Wellington
description: Absolutely delicious! Cooked for 45 minutes after the initial 10 and was still nicely pink in the middle!
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1kg beef fillet- ask your butcher to cut it from the middle of the fillet and say you don't want the tail end or the head (chateaubriand) of the fillet
1 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
400g chestnut or button mushroom, roughly sliced
directions: First soak the dried porcini in 400ml of kettle-hot water and set aside. Pat the beef fillet with kitchen paper to dry it of any blood then season with salt and then heavily with black pepper. Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan until very hot then spend 8-10 mins searing and turning the fillet with tongs until it’s well browned on all sides. Hold it up to sear both ends as well. Set the beef aside on a tray to catch any juices and turn the heat off the pan but don’t clean it.

Drain and squeeze out the dried porcini but reserve the juice and tip the porcini into a food processor with the other mushrooms and thyme. Season everything with salt and pepper and pulse until finely chopped but not completely smooth. Place the beef pan back on the heat with the butter and when it starts to sizzle add the shallot and cook for 2 mins until softened. Turn the heat up and tip in the mushrooms, add a splash of Worcestershire sauce and cook everything for 10-12 mins until you have a paste that comes away from the side of the pan. Tip into a bowl to cool, stir through the parmesan if using and set aside. Turn off the heat from the pan but don’t clean it. The beef can be seared and the mushroom mixture can be made several hours in advance.

For the first stage of assembly get a large sheet of cling film and overlap the prosciutto slices on it in a row, tip the mushroom mix on top then cover with another sheet of cling film. Either with your hands or a rolling pin, pat it down or roll it out to a thin layer that just covers the prosciutto. Remove the top sheet of cling film and sit the fillet down the centre of the mushrooms. Using the edge of the cling film lift and roll the prosciutto and mushrooms to encase the beef then use the cling film to roll everything into a tight sausage. For the best results now place the sausage in the freezer for 30 mins to firm up – do not leave for longer of cooking times will be affected.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the pastry to a rectangle a little larger than a magazine, trim the edges to neaten and save the trimmings. Lightly brush the pastry all over with beaten egg. Carefully unwrap the prosciutto parcel and lay in the middle of the pastry. Like wrapping a parcel or making a spring roll fold the shorter edges over the fillet then roll the whole thing around the fillet to encase. For a really neat finish get another clean sheet of cling film and roll the Wellington into a sausage tight sausage again. Place in the fridge and chill for at least 30 mins or up to a day.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 with a sturdy, lightly oiled baking tray in it. Re-roll the pastry trimmings and use to make 6 leaves. Unwrap the Wellington, brush all over with egg then decorate with the leaves. Brush the leaves with more egg. Sprinkle with flaky sea salt and transfer, sealed side down to the heated baking tray. Bake the for 10 mins then reduce the heat of the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and continue to bake for 25 mins for rare meat, 30 mins for medium rare, 35 mins for medium and about 45 mins for well-done, making sure the pastry doesn’t burn (you can cover it with foil if it starts to become too dark. Remove from the oven and leave for 10 mins to relax.

To make the gravy, heat the butter in the mushroom pan and fry the shallot, thyme and bay, scraping the crispy bits of the pan with a wooden spoon. Scatter over the flour and brown then splash in the brandy, sizzle for a minute, then add the red wine and boil to a purple paste. Pour in the mushroom soaking liquid, avoiding the gritty bits at the bottom, crumble in the stock cube and any juice from the resting beef and simmer for 5 mins until you have a tasty gravy, season to taste.
Using a very sharp knife carefully carve the Wellington into 6 thick slices. You can trim the pastry ends and serve them separately. Serve on heated plates with a jug of gravy.
chief_review: An indulgent, classic Beef Wellington with a rich, earthy flavor profile thanks to dried porcini and fresh chestnut mushrooms, aromatic thyme, and a splash of brandy and red wine. The beef fillet remains tender and beautifully rare at the center, while the prosciutto and all-butter puff pastry provide a crisp, savory exterior with a buttery finish. Parmesan adds a subtle umami complexity to the mushroom duxelles, and shallots lend sweetness. The recipe celebrates fine ingredients and careful technique, making it perfect for special occasions or festive gatherings. Suitable for those following a diet that excludes seafood or nuts, this dish can also be enjoyed by those without dairy, egg, or gluten sensitivities. Notable allergens in this recipe include gluten (from flour and pastry), dairy (from butter and parmesan), and eggs (for glazing), so individuals with allergies to these ingredients should avoid or appropriately modify the recipe.

name: Tangerine curd ice cream with marshmallow meringues
description: A light and refreshing dessert that melds the fluffiness of meringue with the tartness of tangerine curd
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 150g unsalted butter, chopped into small dice
50g orange candied peel, cut into 5mm/¼in dice (optional)
directions: To make the tangerine curd: place the tangerine zest and juice in a saucepan and bring to the boil, reduce by half before mixing in the caster sugar and chopped butter. Once the butter has melted, let it cool for a few minutes then gradually mix in the egg yolks. Stir over a low heat for 3-4 minutes until thickened. This stage can also be achieved in a bowl set over a pan of simmering water, stirring continuously for 20-25 minutes until thickened. Once thickened transfer to a clean bowl and leave to cool slightly before covering with cling film or greaseproof paper. Alternatively, store in a sterilised jar.

To make the ice cream: whisk the crème fraîche and yogurt into the curd and flavour with Grand Marnier. The mix can now be churned in an ice cream maker for 20 minutes before freezing. An alternative directions is to freeze the mix for several hours without churning, but you do need to stir it every 20 minutes to break up the crystals until it sets properly. If this second directions is followed, remove the ice cream from the freezer about 20-30 minutes before serving to loosen its consistency.

To make the syrup: boil together the tangerine zest and juice with the caster sugar and allow to reduce by a third before adding the Grand Marnier. Mix the arrowroot or cornflour with the orange juice or water and whisk into the simmering syrup. Once returned to a gentle simmer, cook for just 2 minutes before removing from the heat. The candied orange peel, if using, can be added while the syrup is warm. Allow to cool. An alternative directions is to reheat the syrup just before serving, adding the peel while the syrup is warming.

To make the meringues: preheat the oven to 120C/Gas ½/fan oven 100C. Whisk the egg whites to soft peaks, then gradually whisk in two-thirds of the caster sugar. Continue to whisk to reach stiff peaks. The remaining sugar can now be added. Continue to whisk until the meringue has a good thick creamy consistency. The cornflour and lemon juice can now be whisked in, whisking for another minute.

The meringues can be kept naturally shaped by spooning individual portions on to lightly oiled parchment paper on a baking tray. Or spoon the meringue into a piping bag fitted with a 1cm/½in plain tube and piping large domes onto the paper. Whichever choice is made, it is important to leave ample space between the meringues to allow them to swell and rise. These can now be baked for 45-50 minutes, about 1 hour maximum. During this time they will take on a light colour, forming a crisp shell that coats the marshmallow centre. The meringues can be cooked at a higher temperature - 150C/Gas 2/fan oven 130C - to give slightly more colour. If so, cooking time will be slightly less, around 40-45 minutes.

When assembling the dish there are two options: if dome-shaped meringues have been made, it is best to crack the tops, placing five or six tangerine segments on top of each if using. The ice cream can now be scooped or scrolled using a warm tablespoon, before sitting on top of the meringue. The syrup with candied fruit can now be drizzled over to finish. The alternative is to simply sit the ice cream and meringue side by side, decorating with segments, if using, and drizzling over the syrup. Whichever you choose, either can be finished with a light dusting of icing sugar, if desired, and perhaps a leaf or sprig of holly.
chief_review: This dessert is a celebration of citrus, showcasing the vibrancy of tangerines and the ethereal texture of meringue. The combination of creamy tangerine curd, pillowy meringue, and a hint of Grand Marnier creates layers of flavor that are both elegant and satisfying. The inclusion of crème fraîche and yogurt provides richness while balancing the sweetness, resulting in a harmonious, not-too-heavy finale. Texture comes in from the candied peel and segmented tangerines, each bite refreshing the palate. As this recipe relies heavily on eggs and dairy, it's suitable for vegetarians but not for vegans or those with dairy or egg allergies. The use of arrowroot or cornflour gives flexibility for those avoiding wheat, making it ideal for a gluten-free diet if you ensure all products used are certified gluten-free. Overall, it’s a sophisticated dessert, perfect for showcasing seasonal citrus.

name: Green beans with shallots
description: Jazz up your green beans with the addition of buttery shallots
author: Lucy Netherton
directions: Cook the green beans in boiling, salted water for 3-4 mins, until just tender. Drain and cool under cold running water. This can be done the day before – just keep the beans covered in the fridge.

When you’re ready to eat, heat the butter in a large frying pan until foaming, add the shallots and cook for 4-5 mins, until soft but not coloured. Throw in the beans and toss to coat. Cook for 1-2 mins until heated through, then season. Serve with the pork.
chief_review: This green bean and shallot dish is a delightful celebration of simplicity and fresh flavors, ideal for showcasing quality produce. The buttery shallots provide a rich, aromatic base, perfectly complementing the green beans without overpowering their natural sweetness and crunch. The preparation is straightforward, making it an excellent choice for a quick side that feels elegant enough for any occasion. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe offers a satisfying, flavorful option for those abstaining from meat while still desiring depth in their vegetable dishes. For even greater flexibility, the butter can be swapped for a plant-based alternative, making the dish vegan-friendly as well. Overall, this is a versatile, crowd-pleasing side that’s as nourishing as it is delicious.

name: Winter slaw with maple candied nuts
description: A fresh and crunchy seasonal slaw served with sweet pecans, cashews, almond and peanuts in a sweet, spicy glaze
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g mixed shelled nut(we used cashews, almonds, pecans and peanuts)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toast the mustard seeds in a dry pan on the hob for a few mins until they begin to pop. Carefully (as it will spit) add the vinegar, sugar and seasoning, then stir to dissolve. Leave to cool, then drizzle the dressing over the vegetables and give everything a stir. Can be stored in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 7 days.

Toss the nuts with the rest of the ingredients, except the rosemary, and season generously. Spread out on a baking tray and roast for 15 mins, stirring once. Add the rosemary and roast for 5-10 mins more until the nuts are golden – keep an eye on them as they burn easily.
Allow to cool completely, stirring occasionally to stop them from sticking. Can be stored in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 7 days. Sprinkle over the slaw before serving.
chief_review: This vibrant seasonal slaw delights with its fresh crunch and harmonious balance of sweet, tangy, and spicy notes. The mustard seed-cider vinegar dressing adds a punchy brightness that beautifully complements the natural sweetness of carrots and celeriac. The highlight is the generous mix of glazed nuts—pecans, cashews, almonds, and peanuts—coated in brown sugar, maple syrup, cayenne, and rosemary, providing a satisfying, sweet-spicy crunch. This dish is an excellent option for vegetarians and is also gluten-free, as all ingredients steer clear of animal products and gluten-containing grains. Be mindful of nut allergies, as this recipe is heavily nut-based. Perfect as a stand-alone salad or a unique side dish, this slaw is sure to impress at any table with both flavor and texture.

name: Winter greens with bacon butter
description: We used kale in this sumptuous side dish, but any winter green would work well. Try cavolo nero or chard.
author: Cassie Best
directions: Heat grill to a medium-high setting. Cook the bacon under the grill until really crisp, turning halfway through cooking. Remove, drain on kitchen paper and leave to cool.

Put the bacon in a food processor and whizz until finely chopped. Add the butter and some black pepper, and blend again until combined. Transfer to a dish, or roll in cling film and chill for up to 3 days, or freeze for 2 months.
Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Add the kale and cook for 3-4 mins until tender. Drain well, then top with half the butter (see tip, below), and toss to help it melt and coat the kale.
chief_review: This recipe makes excellent use of seasonal winter greens, marrying their hearty flavor with the smoky richness of streaky bacon and the luxurious texture of softened butter. The sautéed bacon infuses the greens with a depth that compliments their earthy notes, while the butter rounds out the dish, offering a silky finish. Quick to prepare, this side dish is perfect alongside roasted meats or as a standout component in a cozy winter supper. Due to its absence of gluten-containing ingredients, it is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet. Bacon can contain allergens in cured forms, so it's advisable to ensure the product is free from additives for those with sensitivities. For a truly indulgent winter accompaniment, this dish balances robust, savory flavors with ease.

name: Jewelled cranberry & juniper red cabbage
description: This dish is simplicity itself. The sweet-sharp fruit flavours add a bit of drama to the earthy flavour of red cabbage - pair it with your roast turkey
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat the oil in a large lidded pan, then gently cook the onion and juniper for 10 mins until the onion has softened, but not coloured. Tip in the cabbage and fry for 10 mins, stirring, until it just starts to cook down. Pour in the apple juice, season to taste, then cover and leave to simmer for 45 mins, stirring occasionally, until the cabbage is tender and the liquid has almost all gone.
Add the cranberries, turn up the heat a little and continue to cook for about 5 mins until they have burst. Check the seasoning and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant red cabbage dish is a masterclass in balancing sweet, tart, and savory notes. The pairing of apple juice and cranberries brings brightness and a touch of acidity, which contrasts beautifully with the earthy undertones of red cabbage and the slight pine aroma from juniper berries. The gentle sauté of onions adds depth without overpowering the dish. It’s a standout side, ideal not just for turkey, but also for roast pork or as part of a larger vegetarian spread. With only plant-based ingredients, it is suitable for vegetarians and vegans alike. Additionally, since the recipe is naturally gluten-free and free from common allergens like nuts and dairy, it offers a wide appeal at the festive table. Simple to prepare, yet striking on the plate, this is a must-try for those seeking a robust, flavourful vegetable accompaniment.

name: Rum & coconut treacle tart
description: Add some Caribbean sunshine (and rum) to your dessert with this recipe for a delicious tart
author: Good Food
ingredients: finely grated zest and juice of 1 lime
directions: Preheat the oven to 190C/gas 5/fan 170C. Roll the pastry out to a 5 mm thickness (as thin as you can for a delicate crust). Use to line a 23cm shallow loosebottomed flan tin and leave the pastry hanging over the sides. Prick the base and chill or freeze for at least 30 minutes.

In a large bowl, mix the treacle with the golden syrup, lime zest and juice, and rum. Stir in the breadcrumbs and coconut. Put the flan tin on a baking sheet. Spread the syrupy filling over the pastry base. Bake for 15 minutes, then turn the oven down to 160C/gas 3/fan 140C (to stop the mixture bubbling over) and bake for another 15 minutes, until the filling is just set and the pastry starting to brown at the edges.

Meanwhile, whisk the rum, cream and icing sugar together until the mixture stands in soft peaks and the whisk leaves a trail. Transfer to a bowl, cover and chill until needed. Cool the tart slightly before trimming the pastry edges with a sharp knife. Serve warm with the rum cream.
chief_review:
This Caribbean-inspired tart is a true celebration of bold flavors, blending black treacle, golden syrup, fresh lime, and a generous splash of dark rum for a luscious, fragrant filling. The sweetened coconut and brown breadcrumbs create a pleasing texture, while the creamy double cream topping, lightly sweetened with icing sugar, adds a luxurious finish. The citrus zest brightens the richness beautifully. 

The use of shop-bought shortcrust pastry and breadcrumbs makes this recipe unsuitable for those following a gluten-free diet, while the double cream rules it out for vegans and the dairy-intolerant. Similarly, eggs are not present, making it friendly for those with egg allergies, but given the inclusion of wheat-based products and dairy, it’s best enjoyed by those without specific dietary restrictions. This tart is perfect for adventurous dessert lovers looking to add tropical flair to their repertoire.

name: Sharing potted shrimp
description: Potting shellfish in a cayenne and mace-flavoured butter is a surprisingly simple fish starter that's great as part of a sharing platter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 280g cooked and peeled small brown shrimp
directions: Melt the butter with the bay leaf in a pan or in a bowl in the microwave for 1 min. Add the shrimps, mace, a good pinch of cayenne pepper, the lemon juice and some seasoning. Mix everything together well.
Tip the mixture into a shallow soufflé or gratin dish, or a jar, put the bay leaf on top and sprinkle with a pinch extra cayenne. Chill for at least 2 hrs, or up to 3 days before serving.
chief_review: This shellfish pot leverages the subtle sweetness of small brown shrimp, elevated by fragrant mace and the gentle kick of cayenne pepper. Slowly infusing unsalted butter with bay leaf infuses the dish with a warming herbal note, while a squeeze of fresh lemon balances richness with a lift of acidity. The finished preparation is lush and deeply flavoured, perfect for spreading on warm toast or crispbread as a refined starter or centerpiece for a seafood platter. Its straightforward technique ensures the delicate shrimp remain the star. This recipe is suitable for pescatarian diets and is naturally gluten-free, depending on your choice of serving bread. However, it contains shellfish and dairy, making it unsuitable for those with related allergies. A truly classic, elegant dish that’s deceptively easy—a testament to the power of simple, quality ingredients handled with care.

name: Smoked trout pâté & pitta crisps
description: Cheaper than smoked salmon, this smoked trout dip makes a smart party nibble or simple starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tbsp chopped dill, plus extra for sprinkling
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 8. Halve the pittas and cut into wedges. Brush with 2 tbsp olive oil; sprinkle with salt and chopped dill. Cook for 10-12 mins until crisp.
Flake the hot smoked trout fillets and mix with soured cream, chopped gherkins and chopped dill. Serve with the crisps.
chief_review: This smoked trout dip is a delightful, cost-effective alternative to smoked salmon spreads, perfect for gatherings or as an elegant starter. The smokiness of the trout pairs beautifully with the tangy soured cream and zesty notes from chopped gherkin and dill, resulting in a fresh, balanced flavour profile. The homemade pitta crisps, lightly brushed with olive oil, add a satisfying crunch and make ideal vehicles for the creamy dip. The recipe is naturally pescatarian-friendly. For those with an eye on nutrition, the use of reduced-fat soured cream keeps it lighter without sacrificing texture or taste. Be mindful, however, as gluten from the pitta bread and dairy from the soured cream are present. Overall, this recipe impresses with its confident flavours and simplicity, making it a durable favourite for entertaining.

name: Two-part pheasant
description: Try this faff-free directions of cooking pheasant and produce a sensational roast
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 dried bay leaf, crumbled (or finely sliced, if fresh)
3 garlic cloves, crushed and roughly chopped
directions: THE DAY BEOFRE: Take a pheasant, fully extend one of its legs, and cut through the skin attaching it to the breast. Note where it's hinged to the carcass and sever between the two joints. Repeat with the other leg. Turn the bird over on to its breast and cut away the backbone where it's attached to the breast. Poultry shears are best for this, but strong scissors or a knife will do. Reveal the wishbone and cut it free, then break away as much of the carcass as you can, leaving the whole two-sided breast (the crown) intact. You will need to sever two more little joints to free the crown entirely and trim off a few flappy, fine ribs from below the breasts, then remove any yellow fat, bits of skin, shot or bloody parts from the crown itself. Repeat with the other two pheasants, then wrap each crown in cling film and put in the fridge.

Preheat the oven to 140C/gas 1/fan 120C. Tidy up the legs, then wipe them with damp kitchen paper. Pack the legs skin-side down into a roasting tin or baking dish just large enough to take them in a single layer. Strew with the juniper berries, herbs, garlic and salt and pepper, then pour in enough oil to barely cover. Roast for about 2 hours or until very tender, turning the legs halfway through.
When the legs are cooked, remove them from the oven and leave to cool immersed in their cooking fat before refrigerating (still in the fat) overnight.

IN THE MORNING: When you are ready to finish the cooking, bring both crowns and legs to room temperature, and preheat the oven to 230C/gas 8/fan 210C. Season the crowns well with salt and pepper. Cut the wodge of pancetta in half widthways, separate the half slices, then drape them across the crowns to cover them completely. Scrape off all the gubbins from the legs and discard.

Put the crowns in a roasting tin, leaving enough space for the legs, and roast for 12 minutes. Add the legs and roast for 8-15 minutes more, depending on the size of the birds and how you like your game cooked. Leave the pheasants to rest in a warm place for 5-10 minutes before slicing the whole breast off each side of the crowns and serving with the legs and pancetta.
chief_review:
This recipe presents a straightforward approach to roasting pheasant, yielding a flavorful and aromatic result. The use of juniper berries and bay leaf imparts a subtle, woodsy note that complements the mild game meat, while the pancetta adds richness and moisture, preventing the pheasant from drying out during roasting. Garlic and thyme bring balance and lift, forming a harmonious seasoning blend. The process is accessible, making it well-suited for home cooks eager to try their hand at game without intimidation.

This dish is suitable for those on a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain wheat or gluten-based products (provided you confirm the pancetta is gluten-free). It also fits a low-carb or keto regimen due to its high protein content and minimal carbohydrates. Ideal for an elegant dinner, this recipe highlights the delicate flavor of pheasant with simplicity and finesse.

name: French bread sauce
description: Double cream gives this traditional bread sauce an extra touch of Christmassy indulgence
author: Tony Tobin
ingredients: 1 small onion, peeled and studded with 6 cloves
3 tbsp double cream, plus extra to serve
directions: Shave the light brown crust from the outside of the French stick with a bread knife and discard it. Cut the bready centre into cubes, about 5cm across.
In a saucepan, bring the milk, onion, bay leaf, butter, allspice and 3 tbsp of cream to the boil, reduce the heat then add the diced bread.

Gently simmer, uncovered, for 5 minutes. Add a little salt and freshly ground black pepper, then allow to cool and remove the onion and bay leaf. The sauce can be refrigerated in a covered container overnight.
To serve, warm through gently in a pan, adding extra double cream to give a light, creamy consistency. Grind over some black pepper and serve.
chief_review: This traditional bread sauce recipe is a true classic, elevated by the addition of double cream for a luxuriously rich and festive finish—perfect for a holiday table. The use of stale French stick ensures a rustic texture, while the whole milk, buttery base, and gentle aromatics from onion, cloves, and bay leaf offer a comforting warmth. Allspice adds subtle depth without overpowering the other flavors. The creamy richness makes this sauce an excellent companion for roast poultry, delivering both nostalgia and indulgence. It's naturally vegetarian, making it a versatile side for a variety of gatherings. The method is straightforward yet yields a result that feels special and celebratory, making it a reliable recipe for cooks of any level seeking to impress during festive dinners.

name: Shaved pear, cheese & bresaola salad
description: A rustic salad with cured beef, blue cheese and chicory teamed sweet pears, and dressed in a red wine vinaigrette
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 2 crisp pears, blushing pink if possible
2 heads red chicoryor radicchio, broken into leaves
140g dolcelatteor your favourite local soft blue cheese, sliced
1 tbsp virgin olive or rapeseed oil
directions: Toast the nuts and make the dressing first as they will need to cool. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the walnuts onto a baking tray and toast for 5 mins or until dark golden. Cool. Put the wine or Port in a small saucepan with the vinegar and sugar. Boil for 3 mins or until slightly syrupy (it will thicken as it cools, so don’t get carried away), then take off the heat and set aside.

When ready to serve, shave thin slices from the pears using a large sharp knife, mandolin or potato peeler. Mingle them together with the leaves, bresaola, cheese and nuts on a large platter. Season the dressing, then drizzle over the salad, followed by the oil. Enjoy straight away.
chief_review: This vibrant rustic salad offers an elegant interplay of sweet, earthy, and tangy flavors. The cured beef (bresaola) brings a savory depth, offset by the creamy dolcelatte blue cheese and the assertive bitterness of chicory or radicchio. Toasted walnuts provide a delightful crunch, while blushing pears offer a juicy, fragrant sweetness that balances the dish. The red wine vinaigrette, accented by balsamic and a hint of sugar, ties the ensemble together with subtle acidity and complexity. This dish is suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided all packaged ingredients are certified gluten-free. It’s also an excellent option for those seeking a low-carb, high-protein meal, given the cured beef and nut content. Perfect as a sophisticated starter or a light lunch for discerning palates.

name: Salted caramel parsnips
description: Don't reserve salted caramel for desserts - it works perfectly with earthy roasted root vegetables too
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Halve the parsnips, then cut the thicker end in two lengthways. Boil for 5 mins, then drain well and leave to steam-dry for a few mins. Meanwhile, pour the oil into a shallow roasting tin or a lipped baking tray and heat in the oven for 3 mins.

Remove the tin from the oven and carefully add the parsnips to the hot oil. Turn them to coat, and make sure they aren’t overcrowded (otherwise they won’t crisp up). Roast for 30-35 mins or until golden and crisp, turning them halfway through the cooking time.

About 10 mins before the parsnips are ready, tip the sugar and 2 tbsp water into a small frying pan. Heat very gently until the sugar has dissolved. Turn up the heat and bring the liquid to the boil. Measure 3½ tbsp cold water into a jug. Keep swirling the pan around until the sugar reaches a rich, dark-reddish caramel colour, then remove from the heat. Stand well back and add the water (it will splutter!). Return to the heat, add the butter and the salt, and stir to remove any lumps. The caramel should be runny, so add a splash more water if needed. Pile the parsnips into a serving dish, then drizzle over the salted caramel.
chief_review: This inventive recipe marries the natural sweetness of roasted parsnips with the depth of salted caramel, enhancing the earthy flavors of the root vegetables beautifully. The use of rapeseed oil adds a subtle nuttiness, while the golden caster sugar and sea salt create a balanced, glossy glaze. The butter brings richness, ensuring a luxurious finish. This dish is an excellent choice for those following a vegetarian diet. While simple in preparation, the end result is complex and indulgent—perfect as a stand-out side or a unique twist for holiday spreads.

name: Green beans with wholegrain mustard
description: A versatile side dish that can be prepared at the last minute - simply mix your beans with crème fraîche, mustard, shallots and lemon
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Bring a large pan of water to the boil, then drop in the green beans and cook for 4-5 mins until they are just cooked but still bright green and with a slight crunch.

While the beans are cooking, heat the butter in a large shallow pan and soften the shallot. Add the mustard and crème fraîche, and bring to a simmer to combine. Add the drained beans and lemon juice, stir until evenly coated, then serve straight away.
chief_review:
This French bean side dish offers a delightful balance of textures and flavors with just a handful of ingredients. The beans remain crisp-tender, while the creamy crème fraîche and tangy lemon juice create a luxurious yet refreshing coating. Wholegrain mustard adds depth and gentle heat, and shallots contribute a subtle sweetness. As a chef, I appreciate the quick assembly and sophistication—ideal for last-minute entertaining. This recipe shines as an accompaniment to poultry, fish, or a rich vegetarian main course. Notably, it’s vegetarian-friendly, though not suitable for vegans or those with dairy allergies due to the crème fraîche and butter. It’s an elevated alternative to classic buttered beans, providing both comfort and flair with minimal effort. 

A perfect addition to both weeknight meals and festive tables.

name: Jewelled wild rice with almonds
description: A simple rice salad makes a great side dish. Add cranberries and orange for sweetness, nuts for crunch and herbs for lots of fresh flavour
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Heat the butter or oil in a flameproof casserole dish and gently cook the onion for 15 mins until just starting to turn golden. Add the rice and cranberries, and stir a few times until coated. Season well and pour over the stock.

Float the bay leaves and thyme on top of the stock, and put a circle of baking parchment on top of that. Cover with a lid and put in the oven for 45 mins until the rice is tender. Stir through the parsley, almonds and orange zest. Serve hot, or leave to go cold and serve as a salad, dressed with olive oil and lemon juice.
chief_review: This vibrant rice salad is a celebration of textures and flavors—sweetness from dried cranberries and orange zest, crunch from toasted almonds, and freshness from a generous amount of herbs. The blend of wild and brown basmati rice provides a hearty base, while the gently sautéed onions infuse the dish with depth. Using olive oil instead of butter makes this recipe entirely plant-based and suitable for vegans and vegetarians. Furthermore, with vegetable stock and naturally gluten-free rice, it fits a gluten-free diet (provided the stock is certified gluten-free). The combination of nuts, fruit, and fresh herbs makes this salad both satisfying and lively—a perfect side dish for festive gatherings or summer spreads.

name: Salmon & cucumber twists
description: Get creative with your canapés. These fresh and light smoked fish bites are easy to make and even easier to eat
author: Good Food
ingredients: ½ cucumber, halved lengthways and deseeded
100g beetroot-cured smoked salmon, cut into thin strips
squeeze of lemon juiceand a little zest
directions: Cut the cucumber on the diagonal into slices about 0.5-1cm thick. Twist the strips of salmon around the cucumber slices, then arrange on a serving plate.
Mix together the crème fraîche, lemon juice and a little salt, then dollop a little on top of the salmon. Sprinkle over some black pepper and lemon zest before serving.
chief_review: This canapé recipe offers a delightful interplay of flavors and textures, with crisp cucumber serving as a refreshing base for the richly colored beetroot-cured smoked salmon. The touch of crème fraîche and a hint of lemon juice brighten the dish, bringing a satisfying balance of creamy, tangy, and smoky notes in every bite. Exceptionally quick to assemble and visually appealing, these bites make for an elegant appetizer at any gathering. The absence of bread or crackers makes this recipe naturally gluten-free, and the ingredients are suitable for pescatarian diets. All in all, an impressive, light, and convenient addition to the appetizer repertoire.

name: Cheesy sprout fondue
description: This versatile recipe can be altered to transform your leftover cheese into a help-yourself starter - perfect served with crusty bread
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 500g Brussels sprouts, any damaged outer leaves removed
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the sprouts on a large baking tray, drizzle with oil and season, then roll around the tray to help the seasoning stick. Tear each slice of pancetta in half and wrap each piece around a sprout - you won't have enough to wrap each one. Roast for 20 mins.

Meanwhile, whizz the cheese (only 1 tbsp of the Parmesan), milk and cornflour together in a food processor. Stir through the mustard, then transfer to a shallow baking dish or an ovenproof pan (ours was 15cm across and 3cm deep) and scatter with the remaining Parmesan. Reduce oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3 after the sprouts have had their initial cooking time. Place the cheese dish on the top shelf of the oven and bake for 15 mins, with the sprouts on the tray below.
Remove the sprouts and turn on the grill. Cook the fondue under the hot grill for 2-3 mins until golden brown. Serve the fondue with skewers for dunking the sprouts and chunks of bread.
chief_review: This inventive starter is a cheese-lover’s dream, making clever use of leftover cheeses and infusing rich flavors with the addition of pancetta and Brussels sprouts. The combination of brie, cream cheese, Gruyère, and parmesan creates a complex, melty dip that’s both comforting and indulgent, while the Brussels sprouts add a satisfying, slightly bitter counterpoint. The crisp pancetta lends a savory crunch, and the wholegrain mustard gives a pleasing tang. Served with crusty bread, it’s an ideal sharing dish for gatherings. With no gluten-containing ingredients in the cheese mixture, this dish—minus the bread—can accommodate gluten-free diets when paired with gluten-free bread or crackers. It also fits comfortably into a low-carb approach by omitting the bread altogether. Cheesy, hearty, and crowd-pleasing, this is an adaptable recipe perfect for cold-weather entertaining.

name: Mimosa
description: Fantastic way to start my Xmas. Will be making again this year.
author: Good Food
directions: Half-fill each of 6 glasses with champagne, then carefully pour in the orange juice until the glass is full.
chief_review: This festive recipe is a classic mimosa—a timeless brunch cocktail that effortlessly blends the bright acidity of fresh orange juice with the delicate bubbles of chilled champagne or prosecco. The choice of freshly squeezed juice elevates the drink, ensuring vibrant, zesty flavors that balance the sparkling wine’s effervescence. This combination is wonderfully simple yet elegant, perfect for celebratory occasions like Christmas morning. As there are no animal-derived ingredients or gluten-containing components, this mimosa is suitable for vegan and gluten-free diets. Additionally, its short ingredient list minimizes common allergens, making it broadly accessible. Overall, this recipe delivers a refreshing, crowd-pleasing beverage with minimal preparation—ideal for festive gatherings.

name: Crunchy winter salad
description: Here's a seasonal, vegetarian salad which will complement any festive menu perfectly
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 50g chopped mixed nuts, walnuts, hazelnuts or pecans are good
directions: Peel the carrots and celeriac and grate in a food processor. Mix together with the onion and nuts. Whisk the oil and vinegar with some mustard, salt and pepper and toss with the salad immediately to stop the celeriac going brown. Cover and keep in the fridge for up to a day.
chief_review: This vibrant salad masterfully balances sweetness from roasted carrots and earthy celeriac with a bright tang from red wine vinegar and Dijon mustard. The olive oil dressing is light, allowing the fresh flavors of the vegetables to shine through. Chopped nuts such as walnuts, hazelnuts, or pecans add a delightful crunch and richness. As a vegetarian dish, it provides a wholesome, satisfying side, perfect for festive occasions. It’s also a great option for gluten-free diets, provided all ingredients are checked for cross-contamination. Additionally, with a few simple swaps—like omitting the nuts—it can be made suitable for those with nut allergies. The recipe is simple to prepare but delivers complex flavors and textures, making it an excellent addition to a holiday spread or any seasonal gathering.

name: Golden spiced roast potatoes
description: Add a golden glow to your roast potatoes by par-boiling them first with a touch of turmeric
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 2¼kg floury potatoes, preferably Desiree or King Edward
6 tbsp light olive or sunflower oil
directions: Preheat oven to 190C/gas 5/fan 170C. Peel the potatoes and cut into big chunks. Put them in a large saucepan of boiling salted water, sprinkle in the turmeric and give a good stir. Bring back to the boil, then cover and simmer the potatoes for 4 minutes.

Pour the oil into a roasting tin and put in the oven to heat through for 5minutes. Drain the potatoes well in a colander and give a gentle shake to rough up the surfaces a bit – but not too much or they’ll break up. This rougher surface will give you crisper potatoes.

Carefully tip the potatoes into the hot fat in the roasting tin, tossing with a big metal spoon to coat. Scatter with a light sprinkling of paprika and roast, without turning, for about 11⁄4 hours or until golden and crisp. Sprinkle the potatoes with Maldon sea salt flakes and freshly ground black pepper and serve immediately
chief_review: This recipe elevates classic roast potatoes with a clever twist—par-boiling the spuds with turmeric for extra color and subtle earthy notes, then finishing them in a generous slick of light olive or sunflower oil for maximum crispiness. The final touch of paprika and Maldon sea salt adds depth and crunch to each bite. It's a straightforward yet refined approach that lets quality ingredients shine. The absence of animal products or gluten makes this dish naturally suitable for both vegan and gluten-free diets, and it’s also free from common allergens like dairy, nuts, and eggs. Ideal as a vibrant, crowd-pleasing side for any occasion.

name: Maple-roasted squash with pecans
description: Squash makes a great accompaniment to a roast main course. Flavour with earthy rosemary and add some nuts for crunch
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 large butternut squash, peeled, deseeded and cut into wedges
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Finely chop the leaves from 2 rosemary sprigs and mix with the oil, maple syrup and plenty of seasoning. Toss with the butternut squash on a large baking tray and roast for 20 mins.

Roughly chop the pecans so they stay pretty chunky. Break the remaining rosemary sprig into shorter sprigs, then scatter with the pecans over the squash, and toss together, turning over the squash wedges. Return to the oven for another 20 mins until the squash is tender and caramelising at the edges. Serve straight away, or at room temperature.
chief_review: This roasted butternut squash recipe delivers a pleasing contrast of textures and flavors. The squash, caramelized with maple syrup, takes on a subtle sweetness that’s elevated by aromatic rosemary, while the salted roasted pecans contribute a savory crunch. Sunflower oil ensures even roasting and a delicate finish. This side dish is naturally vegetarian and vegan-friendly, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, it is gluten-free, suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. With a short list of wholesome ingredients and minimal preparation, it's a delightful accompaniment to a variety of main courses, bringing both elegance and robust flavor to the table.

name: Winter leaf salad
description: Salads work in both summer and winter. This rustic colder-weather mix contains fennel, apple, dill and a honey, mustard and poppy seed dressing
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g mixed leaf(we used rocket, watercress and spinach)
1 large or 2 small fennel bulbs, thinly sliced
finely grated zest ½ orange, plus 1 ½ tbsp juice
directions: Mix all the ingredients for the dressing together with some seasoning. Combine the salad leaves, fennel, apple and dill in a large bowl. Just before serving, pour over the dressing and toss together.
chief_review: This salad is a vibrant and refreshing option that cleverly marries the crispness of apple and fennel with the aromatic lift of dill and orange zest. The honey, mustard, and poppy seed dressing adds a balanced sweet-tangy note, enhancing the freshness of the greens (rocket, watercress, and spinach). The dish is both visually appealing and texturally satisfying, making it ideal as a light main or a bright side. Notably, it's vegetarian and gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. For those catering to a vegan diet, replacing the honey with maple syrup or agave would make this salad entirely plant-based without sacrificing flavor. Overall, it's a sophisticated yet straightforward salad perfect for cold or warm days alike, with an emphasis on clean, seasonal flavors.

name: Polenta & prosciutto chips
description: Wrap ready-made polenta in Italian ham and bake for a stylish, dippable party bite
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut the polenta into 18 chunky chips and the prosciutto into 18 strips. Put the polenta in a bowl along with the oil and a good grinding of pepper, and mix together. Wrap a strip of prosciutto around a polenta chip, then pop onto a baking tray. Repeat with the remaining chips and sprinkle over the Parmesan.
Bake for 25-30 mins until golden, turning them over after 15 mins. Serve with tomato ketchup, if you like.
chief_review: This baked polenta and prosciutto bite is a delightful nod to Italian flavors, perfect for an elegant party snack. The creamy polenta contrasts beautifully with the salty, savory prosciutto, and a light brush of olive oil helps achieve a crisp exterior without frying. A sprinkle of parmesan enhances the umami, while a side of tomato ketchup adds a playful, tangy touch—though a homemade tomato relish would be a step up. This dish caters well to those following a gluten-free diet, provided the polenta and prosciutto are certified gluten-free. While simple to prepare, the result is visually appealing and deliciously moreish, ideal for impressing guests or elevating your appetizer spread.

name: Potato rösti cakes with sage leaves
description: These pan-fried, golden potato patties with onion and sage make a delicious side dish for two
author: Alex Hollywood
ingredients: 2-3 Maris Piper potatoes(about 400g/ 14oz), peeled and coarsely grated
3 tbsp sunflower or vegetable oil, for frying
directions: Squeeze any excess water out of the grated potatoes, then tip into a bowl and mix well with the egg, flour, baking powder, onion and chopped sage leaves. Season well. Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large non-stick frying pan over a medium heat, and spoon the mixture in to make 4 röstis, flattening them down with the back of a spoon into disc shapes. Cook for 5 mins each side until golden brown and crisp, then drain on kitchen paper. Can be made up to 8 hrs in advance and kept in the fridge (see tip).

When ready to serve, heat the remaining 1 tbsp oil in the frying pan over a medium heat. Add the whole sage leaves and cook for 20 secs until crisp but still green. Drain on kitchen paper and top each rösti with a fried sage leaf.
chief_review: These pan-fried potato patties are a comforting side dish that elegantly combines earthy Maris Piper potatoes with aromatic sage. The inclusion of onion adds a subtle sweetness, complementing the fresh herbaceous notes. Golden and crisp on the outside with a tender center, the patties are uncomplicated yet packed with flavor. They use only a minimal amount of flour—great for those who need to watch their gluten intake rather than avoid it completely—but not strictly gluten-free. With no meat or fish, this recipe is well-suited to vegetarians. For those limiting nuts or dairy, you'll be pleased to find neither present. The simple technique delivers a rewarding texture and taste, making these patties a versatile accompaniment to mains or as part of a hearty brunch. Perfect for showcasing the humble potato with a chef’s touch.

name: Beetroot & rye tartines
description: I did the smoked mackerel tartines. They were lovely and very filling.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 4 slices German three-grain bread(rye, oats and barley)
4 cooked beetroot, about 230g, very thinly sliced
50g skinless smoked mackerel, flaked into 16 pieces
½ small red onion, thinly sliced
directions: Mix the yogurt and mustard together, then spread over the bread and top with the beetroot slices, overlapping them to make an even base.
For the pastrami tartines, cover the beetroot completely with the pastrami slices, then cut each into six fingers and top each one with a sliver of gherkin.
For the mackerel tartines, cut each piece of bread into eight squares. Top with the mackerel and red onion, then snip over some of the dill. Keep them chilled until ready to serve.
chief_review: These smoked mackerel tartines present a delightful balance of creamy, tangy, and smoky flavors, elevated by the freshness of dill and beetroot. The combination of Greek yogurt and mustard creates a zesty base, pairing beautifully with the robust smoked mackerel and savory pastrami. Layered atop hearty German three-grain bread, these tartines are both satisfying and nourishing. This recipe is suitable for pescatarians, as it includes both fish and dairy. However, it is not appropriate for those following gluten-free or vegetarian diets due to the bread and pastrami. The assortment of ingredients delivers a wonderful contrast in textures and flavors, making these tartines not just filling but also vibrant and appetizing—a commendable choice for a wholesome lunch or light dinner.

name: Sticky maple-glazed ham with baked apple sauce
description: Slow-roast a whole leg of gammon with apple juice, then cover in a sticky spiced glaze for a Christmas treat - perfect sliced hot or cold
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 1 whole unsmoked leg of gammon(about 4½ kg-5kg), on the bone
directions: If your gammon needs to be soaked to draw out some of the salt (ask your butcher), place in a clean bucket or a preserving pan and cover with cold water. Chill overnight, or for up to 3 days.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. If the ham has been soaking, drain it well and place in a large, deep-sided roasting tin. Pour in the apple juice and top up with 400ml water. Add the spices, bay leaves and orange zest. Cover the ham tightly with a few large sheets of foil, scrunching it around the edges of the tin so no steam can escape, then bake for 5 hrs. Meanwhile, mix together the ingredients for the glaze in a saucepan, then bubble until reduced to a sticky glaze. Score the apples around their equator with a small, sharp knife.

Remove the ham from the oven and increase the temperature to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Carefully transfer the ham to a board – the easiest way to do this is to leave it to cool for 10 mins, then pop on clean washing- up gloves to lift it. Pour away the cooking liquid and discard the aromatics. Use a small, sharp knife to cut and peel away the rind, leaving a thin layer of fat attached to the meat. Line your roasting tin with a few sheets of foil and place the ham in the middle, fat-side up. Use a sharp knife to lightly score the fat in a criss-cross pattern. Return the ham to the oven and bake for 30 mins until the fat starts to crisp and caramelise.

If the glaze has become a little thick, splash in a drop of water to loosen it, then brush all over the ham. Place the whole apples in the tin too, and return to the oven for another 20-30 mins, basting the ham every now and then, until dark and sticky all over.

Before serving, mash the whole apples (discard the stalks, skin and pips) with a little of the sticky sauce from the roasting tin.
