We decorated our ham with star anise, sprayed with edible gold spray, and arranged bay leaves and orange peel around the board. Serve warm slices of the ham with the apple sauce, or cold in sandwiches. Will keep for up to 1 week in the fridge, or slice and store in the freezer for up to 2 months.
chief_review: This festive slow-roasted gammon is a show-stopping centerpiece, infused with aromatic spices and apple notes that complement the meat’s natural sweetness. The poaching liquor—with cinnamon, star anise, and citrus—adds depth, while the maple syrup glaze brings a glossy finish and rich, sticky flavor. The addition of wholegrain mustard lends a gentle tang, balancing the sweetness of apples and maple. Sliced hot or cold, the gammon remains succulent, making it ideal for a celebratory meal or sandwiches afterwards. While the recipe may not cater to common dietary restrictions, the harmonious blend of spices, fruit, and meat exemplifies traditional holiday fare, served with decorative touches for a festive presentation.

name: Truffled crushed potatoes
description:
Truffle oil adds
a touch of luxury
to potatoes, perfect for a special occasion
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 400g floury potatoes, cut into large chunks
½-1 tsp truffle oil, depending on how much you like the taste
directions: Put the potatoes and milk into a medium pan, add water to just cover, season, then bring to the boil. Simmer for 15 mins or until tender. Add the rosemary a few mins before the end of cooking to infuse. Drain off all but a few tbsp of the cooking liquid.

Roughly crush the spuds, fold in the truffle oil and cream, then tip into a small baking dish, adding a few rosemary leaves to decorate. Flash under the grill for a few mins to colour the top. If making ahead, reheat in the oven at 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 for 15 mins until just bubbling and starting to turn golden.
chief_review: This recipe elevates classic mashed potatoes with the subtle elegance of truffle oil and a hint of rosemary, making it a wonderful choice for an indulgent side dish during festive meals or dinner parties. The use of floury potatoes ensures a light, fluffy texture, while the addition of single cream and milk brings extra richness and a smooth finish. The aromatic rosemary complements the earthy truffle flavor beautifully, without overwhelming the dish. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, ideal for those seeking refined yet simple comfort food. The key is restraint with the truffle oil—start with less and adjust to taste, as its distinctive flavor can easily dominate. Serve alongside roasted vegetables or as a luxurious companion to your main course for a truly memorable dining experience.

name: Clotted cream & stem ginger ice cream
description: Add a zing to your ice cream with Rick Stein's spicy suggestions
author: Rick Stein
ingredients: 100g stem ginger, finely chopped, plus 6 tbsp syrup from the jar
directions: Put the milk and clotted cream into a non-stick pan. Scrape out the seeds from the vanilla pod, add pod and seeds to the milk and cream, and bring almost to the boil. Set aside for 20 mins.
Cream the egg yolks and sugar together in a bowl. Bring the milk and cream back to the boil, remove the vanilla pod, then pour the mixture onto the egg yolks, stirring all the time.

Strain the mixture back into the cleaned-out pan and cook over a gentle heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture has thickened and lightly coats the back of a wooden spoon. Do not let the mixture boil or it will curdle. Pour back into the bowl and leave to cool, then cover and chill overnight. The next day, churn in an ice-cream maker, stirring the stem ginger and syrup into the mixture just before freezing. If you do not have an ice cream machine, you can pour the mixture into a shallow container, cover and freeze until firm but not rock hard, then whizz in a food processor until smooth. Re-freeze and repeat the process 2-3 times more. Store in the freezer until needed.
chief_review: Rick Stein’s ice cream recipe is pure indulgence, combining the luxuriousness of clotted cream and the warming kick of stem ginger. The use of a real vanilla pod adds aromatic depth, while the ginger and its syrup deliver a spicy-sweet zing that balances the rich dairy base. The method mirrors that of a traditional custard ice cream, ensuring a silky, creamy texture. This dessert is perfect for those seeking an elevated homemade ice cream with unique flavor complexity. It’s well-suited to a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, it is not suitable for dairy-free or vegan diets, nor for those with egg allergies, due to its reliance on both clotted cream and egg yolks. Serve solo or alongside a poached pear for a decadent finale.

name: Prosciutto & celeriac twists
description: This recipe is based on a classic French combination and always goes down well at parties
author: John Torode
directions: Whisk together the mustard, vinegar and oil in a small bowl until well combined. Stir in the double cream. Peel the celeriac and cut into really fine strips using a mandolin or very sharp knife. Then cut into matchsticks about 5cm long. Mix into the dressing along with the parsley.

Cut each prosciutto slice in half down the middle, then cut each piece lengthways so that you have 4 small strips. Place 1 tsp of the celeriac mixture onto each strip, then roll them up tightly. Secure each strip with a toothpick, place on a plate and leave in the fridge for at least 20 mins to firm up. Can be made a few hours ahead and kept in the fridge until ready to serve.
chief_review: This recipe is a refined nod to classic French flavors, combining the earthy crunch of celeriac with the silky richness of double cream and the tang of Dijon mustard. The addition of white wine vinegar balances the dish with a bright acidity, while walnut oil adds an intriguing nutty depth. The prosciutto or Bayonne ham brings a delicate saltiness and sumptuous texture, making this recipe ideal as a sophisticated party starter. The freshly chopped parsley lifts the dish with a hint of freshness. As prosciutto is naturally gluten free, and with no presence of bread or flour in the recipe, it caters nicely to a gluten-free diet. Overall, this is a wonderful starter that delivers balance, elegance, and impressive depth of flavor—sure to make an impression at any gathering.

name: Orange crème caramel cheesecakes
description: These individual cheesecakes are better made a couple of days ahead so the caramel in the ramekin dissolves into a sticky sauce
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2. In a small pan, bring the cream to the boil with the orange peel, then set aside to infuse. Tip 140g/5oz sugar into another saucepan with just enough water to make it sludgy. Bring to the boil, then turn the heat down to a simmer and boil to make a darkish caramel. Add 2 tbsp of the orange liqueur (watch out as it will splutter). Leave it to settle slightly, then pour the caramel over the base of 6 x 250ml ramekins and set aside.

Beat the cream cheese and the remaining 85g/3oz sugar together in a large bowl, then beat in the eggs and the remaining orange liqueur. Strain in the infused cream, then beat everything together to make a custard. Skim off any froth and set aside.

Boil the kettle. Place the ramekins in a deep roasting tin. Divide the custard between them – it will only come to halfway – then bring the tin to the oven and fill with hot water from the kettle so it comes halfway up the outside of the ramekin dishes. Bake the cheesecakes for 40 mins or until just set, then remove from the oven and the tin. Leave to cool, then chill at least overnight. These can be made up to 2 days ahead and left to chill.

Up to 2 days before serving, make the bases. Crumble the biscuits into a food processor, then blitz to fine crumbs. Add the melted butter and pulse until everything is mixed. Line a flat baking tray with greaseproof paper, tip the base mix onto it, then top with another sheet of greaseproof paper. Gently roll the mix out until large enough to cut 6 bases the same size as the ramekins out of it. Chill.

To make the caramel squiggles, heat the sugar with a little water in a saucepan and boil to make caramel, then set aside to cool slightly. Line a tray with baking parchment and grease with a little oil. Drizzle the caramel up and down so that all the strands of caramel stick together to create stars, then leave to set.

To serve, use a cutter the same diameter as the ramekin to cut out 6 bases from the biscuit mix. Lift the bases onto 6 plates. Unmould the cheesecakes, saving the caramel sauce in the ramekin. Top the bases with the crème caramels, drizzle the sauce over and around the plates, garnish with a star and serve.
chief_review: This recipe delivers an indulgent twist on classic cheesecake, elevated by the infusion of orange liqueur and a sticky caramel sauce developed over time. The creamy filling, complemented by the zesty brightness of orange peel, is perfectly balanced against the crunchy digestive biscuit base. Allowing the dessert to rest for a couple of days enables the caramel to meld beautifully, creating irresistible depth and a luxurious sauce. As prepared, this recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet, since it contains no gelatine or animal-derived rennet. Care should be taken with the choice of orange liqueur to ensure it is vegetarian-friendly. Additionally, note that it contains dairy, gluten, eggs, and citrus, and thus is not suitable for those with relevant allergies or intolerances. Serve chilled for maximum enjoyment—perfect for making ahead and impressing guests with minimal last-minute effort.

name: Peppermint candy canes
description: These sweet treats are a great last-minute gourmet addition to a homemade gift hamper and are fun to make with kids
author: Good Food
directions: Mix a few drops of peppermint into the white, red and green icing. Divide the white icing in 2 and wrap half in cling film along with the green icing.

Roll the remaining half of white icing into a long, thin sausage shape, then do the same with the red icing. Lay the 2 sausages next to each other, and twist together. Gently roll the twisted length with the palm of your hand until the 2 sausages are joined and smooth. Slice into 12cm lengths, then bend the end of each one to make a hook. Line a baking sheet with baking parchment, then spread out the candy canes. Repeat with the remaining white icing and green icing, then leave the canes to dry out for at least 24 hrs before packaging.
chief_review: This delightful recipe offers a playful twist on sweet confections, ideal for festive occasions or gift hampers. The use of regal icing and a hint of peppermint essence creates a vibrant, aromatic treat with a satisfyingly smooth texture and a pop of color. Made entirely from icing and flavoring, the recipe is naturally vegetarian and gluten-free, accommodating those with gluten sensitivities and vegetarian preferences. Its simplicity makes it perfect for engaging children in the kitchen, and the customizable colors lend themselves well to creative designs and themed celebrations. An excellent choice for a quick, eye-catching homemade sweet.

name: Crunchy parsley croutons
description: Try this recipe from Gordon Ramsay - it's a crunchy alternative to traditional stuffing
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 200g slightly stale country-style bread, cut into small cubes
directions: Heat the goose fat in a frying pan and toss in the bread, with a the parsley sprigs, turning until golden and crisp. Drain on kitchen paper, season well and keep warm, uncovered.
chief_review: Gordon Ramsay’s crunchy stuffing offers a rustic twist on the classic, making use of simple, quality ingredients for bold flavor. The use of stale country-style bread absorbs the rich, savory depth from goose fat, resulting in a golden, crisp texture that contrasts nicely with tender roasts. Fresh parsley adds a welcome brightness, cutting through the luscious richness. This recipe is particularly well-suited for vegetarian diets if the goose fat is substituted with olive oil or a plant-based alternative, and also provides a delicious way to repurpose leftover bread. The straightforward ingredient list and quick preparation make it an ideal addition for holiday tables or Sunday roasts, emphasizing both tradition and refined simplicity.

name: Noisette potatoes
description: These offer a sautéed roast flavour and are simply shaped from potatoes
author: Gary Rhodes
directions: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6/fan oven 180C. Scoop the potatoes into balls, rinsing well once all are cut. The potatoes can now be dried on a clean tea towel ready for pan-frying.

Heat 2 tablespoons of cooking oil in large frying pan and pan fry 2-3 handfuls of potatoes on a medium to high heat until golden brown, then transfer to a roasting tray. Repeat until all are coloured. The potatoes can now be finished in the oven for 15-20 minutes until they're tender.
Once the potatoes are cooked, remove the tray from the oven, add the butter and season with salt and pepper. The Noisette potatoes are now ready to serve.
chief_review: This straightforward recipe highlights the humble potato, delivering a beautifully sautéed, roasted flavour with minimal ingredients. The technique allows the natural earthiness and creamy texture of the potato to shine, enhanced by a rich note from the butter and the crisp finish from the oil. The dish is naturally vegetarian and can be easily adapted for vegan diets by substituting the butter with a plant-based alternative. Furthermore, the absence of wheat and other common allergens (aside from dairy in butter) makes it a fitting option for those following gluten-free or dairy-free regimens with simple swaps. It’s ideal as a side dish for a variety of main courses, offering both versatility and mass appeal. The simplicity of the ingredients ensures accessibility and ease of preparation, making it a staple for any home cook seeking comfort and classic taste.

name: Griddled leeks with hazelnut dressing
description: A light, citrussy vegetarian starter - it's just as good at room temperature if you don't want to do last-minute griddling
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 20-24 baby leeks, about 5-6 per person depending on size, trimmed
4 tbsp olive oil, plus a little extra for griddling
small bunch parsley, leaves picked and chopped
directions: Arrange the leeks in a wide, lidded pan, so they’re no more than 2 leeks deep at any point, then pour over enough boiling water to cover. Cover the pan and cook for 4-6 mins until just tender. Drain, refresh in cold water, then drain again. Now set aside until you are ready to serve.
Whizz the nuts in a food processor until finely chopped but not powdery, or chop by hand. Mix with the oil, citrus juices and vinegar. Season well.

To serve, heat a griddle or frying pan and toss the leeks in some oil. Griddle batches for 1 min on each side until slightly charred and warmed through, then put onto 4 plates. Stir the parsley into the nutty dressing, spoon over and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant starter is a showcase of fresh, zesty flavors—perfect for awakening the palate. The gentle char of griddled baby leeks pairs beautifully with the rich crunch of toasted hazelnuts. A lively dressing of orange, lemon, and sherry vinegar brings brightness, while parsley offers a fragrant herbal lift. The use of olive oil keeps the dish light and heart-healthy. This recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians and—thanks to the absence of dairy, eggs, or animal-derived products—fits seamlessly into a vegan diet as well. Since it contains no gluten-based ingredients, it's also naturally gluten-free, provided cross-contamination is avoided. Serve warm or at room temperature for a stylish, effortless appetizer that celebrates simplicity and fresh produce.

name: Sticky liquorice carrots
description: Aniseed flavours work well with earthy, sweet vegetables. Use soft black liquorice combined with creamy butter
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 50g soft black liquorice(we used Panda natural liquorice sticks from ocado.com)
directions: Finely chop the liquorice and put in a small pan with about 5cm water. Boil for 30 mins, topping up with water to keep the liquorice covered at all times, mashing and stirring occasionally, until nearly all the lumps of liquorice have disappeared and you’re left with black, syrupy water. Sieve into a new pan, add the butter, and gently bubble until you have a consistency between clear honey and gravy.

Boil a big saucepan of water. Add the carrots and cook for a couple of mins until just tender. Drain well, then tip back into their pan and add the hot liquorice syrup. Toss to coat, season, and tip into a dish to serve.
chief_review: This recipe seamlessly marries the distinct, aromatic notes of aniseed-rich black liquorice with the sweetness of carrots, brought together by the luxurious creaminess of salted butter. The liquorice introduces a nuanced depth that enhances the natural earthiness of the root vegetables, creating a flavour pairing that feels both inventive and elegant—a sophisticated update on classic glazed carrots. The technique is simple yet yields a complex profile, ideal as an adventurous side dish for dinner parties or holiday tables. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this dish also works well for those looking to add unexpected flair to familiar produce. The choice of high-quality natural liquorice is wise; its subtlety avoids overpowering the carrots while imparting a lingering herbal warmth. A bold recipe for the curious palate.

name: Mashed peppered roots with toasted hazelnuts
description: Combine sweet potatoes, carrots, parsnips and celeriac in this creamy mash with a lovely nutty finish - drizzle with optional hazelnut oil
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 2kg mixed root vegetable, including sweet potatoes, carrots, parsnips and 1 celeriac
directions: Peel and dice all the vegetables and put in a large pan of water. Bring to the boil and simmer for 20-25 mins until soft enough to mash. Drain, then add the milk and butter to the dry pan, and heat until the butter has melted. Tip the veg back into the pan, season with lots of cracked black pepper and mash over a low heat.
Remove from the heat and spoon into a serving bowl. Scatter with hazelnuts, drizzle with the oil (if using) and sprinkle the chives over.
chief_review: This root vegetable mash impresses with its velvety texture and naturally sweet, earthy flavors. The combination of sweet potatoes, carrots, parsnips, and celeriac creates depth and complexity, while the addition of toasted hazelnuts and hazelnut oil lends an enticing nutty aroma and crunch. Full-fat milk and butter elevate its creaminess, making it a decadent side dish. The scattered chives add a bright, fresh finish. This recipe is ideal for vegetarian diets and can cater to gluten-free requirements, provided all ingredients are checked for hidden gluten. Additionally, it’s suitable for those avoiding gluten but isn’t for anyone with nut or dairy allergies. Overall, it’s a comforting, elevated take on traditional mash—excellent for festive meals or as a luxurious accompaniment to any main.

name: Hot herb butter prawns
description: Entertaining? Treat your guests to flash-fried shellfish with a garlic butter, capes, chilli and zesty lemon. It's ready in 15 minutes too
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 20 large king prawns, peeled but with the tails left on
1 tsp caper, drained and finely chopped
1 lemon, zested then cut into wedges, and Mediterranean-style flatbreads (or gluten-free alternative), to serve
directions: Butterfly the prawns, removing the black thread that runs through the body. Beat the butter until smooth, then mix in the harissa, parsley, capers, lemon zest and some ground black pepper. Can be made 2 weeks in advance, then chilled.
Open out each prawn and smear 1 tsp of the butter into the middle. Can be made 1 day ahead and chilled.

When ready to eat, heat the grill to as high as it will go. Put the prawns on a baking tray and grill for 5 mins until they are pink through. Toast the flatbreads, then serve with the hot prawns and lemon wedges for squeezing over.
chief_review: This vibrant prawn dish is a true show-stopper for entertaining, packing bold Mediterranean flavors into a quick 15-minute recipe. The flash-fried king prawns remain succulent, absorbing the aromatic kick of garlic butter and the smoky heat from rose harissa. Capers lend a briny punch balanced perfectly by the freshness of parsley and the zest of lemon. Serving with Mediterranean-style flatbreads gives guests a perfect vehicle to mop up the irresistible juices; offering a gluten-free flatbread option makes this recipe effortlessly suitable for gluten-free diets. It’s also naturally pescatarian, celebrating the purity of shellfish and fresh herbs. A lively, crowd-pleasing dish that brings a taste of the seaside to your table.

name: Winter leaf, date & olive salad
description: Combine rustic flavours in this colourful salad with feta cheese, fruity dates and sweet honey
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1 tbsp sunflower or other mild oil
1 tbsp white or red wine vinegar
handful green olives, stoned removed, torn in half
10 plump dates(we used hadrawi), stoned and cut into long slivers
2 large or 4 small heads chicory(red or white) separated into leaves
directions: Thinly slice the peel and pith from the lemons, then segment. Squeeze 1 tbsp of the juice into a bowl. Whisk in the oils, vinegar, honey and seasoning.
Put the lemon segments, olives, dates and feta into a large bowl, and put the leaves on top. Cover and chill until ready to eat. Toss with the dressing to serve.
chief_review: This vibrant salad brings together a delightful mix of Mediterranean flavours and textures—creamy feta, sweet dates, tart lemon, and crisp greens. The dressing balances zingy citrus and honey, while olives add an earthy note. The simplicity of the ingredients lets each component shine, making it visually appealing and satisfying. This recipe is ideal for a vegetarian diet, as it avoids all meat and fish yet provides ample protein and richness from the feta cheese. Those seeking a gluten-free option will also appreciate this salad, as it is naturally free from grains containing gluten. Serve as a refreshing starter or a side for grilled dishes—this salad’s sweet-savoury contrast will impress any guest.

name: Lemon & elderflower fizz
description: This tastes divine. But agree with tcunnane - it froths up a LOT when you add the sorbet so make sure you use a really big jug because you won't want to waste a drop.
author: Good Food
ingredients: juice and strips of zest from ½ lemon
directions: To decorate the glasses with a sugar rim, tip the sugar onto a flat plate and the lemon juice into a bowl. Dip the rim of each glass in the juice, then the sugar.

Put the gin, lemon juice, sugar and elderflower cordial into a large jug. Stir until the sugar has dissolved. Add the prosecco, then the sorbet, and give it a good stir. Pour into the prepared glasses and pop in a few strips of lemon zest.
chief_review: This refreshing and vibrant cocktail blends the botanical notes of gin with the brightness of lemon and the floral sweetness of elderflower cordial, all finished with the effervescence of prosecco and the icy zing of lemon sorbet. The result is a luxurious, elegant drink perfect for summer gatherings or celebratory occasions. The dual use of caster sugar heightens the citrus profile, while lemon zest adds an aromatic lift. Be warned: adding the sorbet creates a dramatic froth, so a large jug is essential to avoid overflow and savor every drop. The ingredients list makes this recipe suitable for a vegetarian diet, as no animal-derived ingredients are used. Additionally, it is gluten-free, provided the gin and prosecco are verified as such, making this an inclusive and crowd-pleasing cocktail centerpiece.

name: Chocolate, mint & chilli truffles
description: Make these easy homemade truffles as an edible gift or after dinner treat - balance heat from the chilli with cooling mint extract
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 50g blanched almonds, finely chopped and toasted
directions: Pour the cream into a pan and heat until just steaming, but not boiling. Put the chopped chocolate and butter in a bowl, pour over the hot cream, and stir until smooth. Add the golden syrup, mint extract and chilli. Chill until firm, about 2 hrs.
Using a melon baller roll into 1 tsp balls. Roll the balls in chopped almonds and set on a tray. Cover and chill until serving.
chief_review: These homemade truffles deliver a delightful mix of creamy, rich chocolate balanced with a subtle kick from red bird’s-eye chillies and a refreshing hint of mint. The double cream and butter create a luscious ganache, while golden syrup adds a gentle sweetness that rounds out the flavors. Finely chopped, toasted blanched almonds lend a delicate crunch, providing textural contrast. With the inclusion of both milk and dark chocolate, the truffles achieve a sophisticated depth. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, making it a versatile treat to prepare for a wide range of guests. Perfect as an elegant after-dinner nibble or thoughtful edible gift, these truffles are sure to impress with their unique flavor profile and decadent finish.

name: Smoked butter mash
description: Give plain mashed potatoes a twist by using smoked butter for an indulgent, comforting side dish
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 50g smoked butter, cubed (we used Lune Valley Smokehouse butter)
directions: Put the potatoes in a saucepan, cover with cold salted water and bring to the boil. Cover and simmer for 10 mins until tender. Meanwhile, heat the cream, milk and butter in a saucepan on a medium heat for 5-8 mins until the liquid has reduced by half, then stir through the smoked butter.

Drain the potatoes, tip back into the pan and return to the heat to remove any further moisture. Sieve or mash the potato until really smooth, or put through a potato ricer if you have one. Add the warm smoked butter-cream to the mash until you have a good consistency – you may not need to add all of the cream. Season and add the mustard to taste.
Spoon the mash onto serving plates, scatter over the crispy sausage crumble and add a few pinches of smoked salt.
chief_review: This smoked butter mashed potato recipe elevates a classic comfort dish with luxurious depth and a subtle smokiness. The use of floury potatoes ensures a fluffy texture, while the smoked butter adds a rich, complex flavor that pairs beautifully with the creamy double cream and milk. English mustard provides a gentle kick, enhancing the overall savoriness without overwhelming the palate. A final drizzle of olive oil and a sprinkle of smoked salt amplify both richness and aroma. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, making it an indulgent choice for those seeking a sophisticated yet cozy side. The balance of textures and flavors is impressive—indulgent yet refined, and destined to impress at any table.

name: Easy turkey gravy
description: This simple gravy compliments delicately flavoured turkey meat and is quick enough to make at the last minute
author: Jenny White
directions: Spoon all but about 4 tbsp turkey fat from the roasting tin, leaving behind as much of the turkey juices as possible. Set the tin over a low heat on the hob and stir the flour into the juices to make a paste.

Gradually add the turkey stock to the pan, scraping up any bits stuck to the bottom of the tin. Once all the stock has been added, keep stirring until the gravy comes to the boil, then add the Marsala, if using. Reduce the heat and simmer gently for 5 mins or until thickened to your liking.
chief_review: This straightforward gravy recipe is an excellent finishing touch for delicately flavored turkey, providing rich depth and a silky texture in just minutes. Using turkey stock ensures savory authenticity, while the optional Marsala brings subtle sweetness and complexity for those who wish to elevate the flavor. The use of plain flour means it does contain gluten; however, the absence of milk, cream, or butter makes it suitable for those avoiding dairy, and its simplicity highlights the pure umami of the turkey. A perfect companion to your holiday roast, this gravy is both classic and remarkably quick to prepare for a refined yet effortless table.

name: Quick-to-mix mincemeat
description: Why settle for a shop-bought jar of this traditional, festive fruit filling when you can make your own in minutes?
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 2 large Bramley apples, peeled, cored and finely chopped to give 450g/1lb
100ml Armagnac or brandy, plus more if needed
directions: Put everything except the suet into a large mixing bowl and mix well using your hands. Leave for at least 2 hrs, or overnight if you can. Add the suet, mix again, then spoon into sterilised jars (see tip, bottom left) while they are still warm. Will keep for up to 1 year in a cool, dark place. If the mincemeat starts to look dry as it matures, add a little more brandy.
chief_review: This homemade festive fruit filling is a delightful upgrade from store-bought alternatives, bursting with robust flavors from Bramley apples, assorted dried fruits, candied peel, and aromatic spices. The balance of citrus zest and dark muscovado sugar brings both brightness and depth, while the generous hit of Armagnac or brandy adds a sophisticated warmth. Preparing your own filling allows for customizable richness, particularly with the choice of either beef or vegetable suet. Opting for vegetable suet makes this recipe suitable for vegetarians, and it can be easily adapted for vegans by ensuring all processed ingredients are free from animal derivatives. The texture is luxuriously moist, making it perfect for mince pies or festive tarts. For those observing vegetarian or vegan diets, confirm your suet and candied peels are plant-based to fully enjoy this sumptuous seasonal treat.

name: Grainy coconut ice cream
description: Pack a triple hit of coconut into this exotic homemade iced treat, which can be made with or without an ice cream maker
author: Shivi Ramoutar
directions: Put the coconut milk, double cream and coconut cream in a saucepan and bring almost to the boil. Meanwhile, whisk the sugar and the egg yolks in a bowl until thick. Pour the coconut milk mixture in a slow stream over the egg yolks and sugar, whisking constantly.

Rinse out the saucepan and return to a low heat. Pour in the custard mixture and stir in the desiccated coconut. Continue to stir constantly for 5-10 mins until the custard thickens slightly and you can trace a line through it with a wooden spoon. Pour into a bowl, then cover the surface of the custard with cling film, allow to cool, then chill for 30 mins.

Transfer the chilled custard to an ice cream maker and freeze according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Alternatively, transfer the mixture to a small freezable container with a lid and freeze for 1 hr, then use a fork or electric whisk to really churn through the ice cream to break up the ice crystals so that the mixture is the same consistency. Pop it back into the freezer for another 2-3 hrs, whisking it about every half hour, then cover the surface with a sheet of cling film and freeze with the lid on until as firm as ice cream. Take out of the freezer 10 mins before serving so it’s easy to scoop.
chief_review: This coconut ice cream recipe delivers a luxurious blend of creamy textures and deep coconut flavor, perfect for fans of this tropical ingredient. The combination of coconut milk, double cream, and coconut cream ensures a rich, velvety mouthfeel, while toasted desiccated coconut adds a delightful crunch and aroma. Egg yolks lend the base a classic silky structure, elevating it to professional quality whether or not you use an ice cream maker. The recipe does contain eggs and dairy, so it's best suited for vegetarians who consume dairy and eggs. However, it naturally avoids gluten, making it appropriate for gluten-free diets. The use of golden caster sugar allows for a balanced sweetness that doesn't overpower the coconut essence. Garnish with extra toasted coconut for enhanced flavor and presentation—an impressive, crowd-pleasing dessert with minimal fuss.

name: Buttered Jerusalem artichokes
author: Tom Kerridge
directions: Peel and finely slice 1kg Jerusalem artichokes, adding to a bowl of water and lemon juice. Heat 75g butter in a large frying pan over a medium heat and, once foaming, add the artichokes, 1 crushed garlic clove and 3 thyme sprigs.

Cook for 20 mins or so, adding another 75g cubed butter gradually, cube by cube, basting frequently so that the artichokes are always covered in foaming butter, until they’re a rich roasted colour. Just before serving, toss with the juice 1 lemon and season to taste.
chief_review: This recipe showcases the earthy, nutty flavor of Jerusalem artichokes, highlighting them with butter, garlic, thyme, and a bright splash of lemon. The technique brings out a wonderful balance between creamy richness and fresh, aromatic notes. The substantial use of butter gives the dish a luxurious texture, while the thyme and garlic provide depth. Suitable for vegetarians, this preparation makes an excellent side or a feature ingredient in a hearty vegetarian meal. Ensure the Jerusalem artichokes are thoroughly scrubbed to capitalize on their delicate texture. For those concerned with dairy, substitute a plant-based butter to suit vegan or lactose-free diets. Overall, it’s a beautifully composed dish that allows the main ingredient to shine with minimal fuss and maximum flavor.

name: Truffled Jerusalem artichoke soup
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: a few drops of truffle oil, to taste, plus extra to serve
directions: Heat the butter in a large saucepan. Fry the onions and artichokes for 10 mins or until the onions are cooked and the artichokes have softened. Add the stock and bring to the boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer, cooking for 15-20 mins until the artichokes are very tender.
Tip everything into a food processor with the cream and purée until smooth. Season with the truffle oil and some salt.Transfer to a saucepan to keep warm (or reheat later when needed).
Heat the olive oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium heat. Add the shredded goose and slowly fry until crispy and golden.
Ladle the soup into bowls and top with a drizzle more truffle oil and the crispy goose, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a luxurious, earthy soup with the natural sweetness of Jerusalem artichokes complemented by silky double cream and the distinct depth of truffle oil. Butter-sautéed onions add sweetness, while chicken stock forms a rich base; the optional addition of shredded goose introduces further complexity and savoriness. The soup’s velvety texture and aromatic finish are refined—ideal for an elegant starter or a comforting main on a cold day. Suitable for gluten-free diets and those without lactose intolerance (as dairy is present), and the goose is strictly optional, making this recipe easily adaptable for vegetarians by switching to a vegetable stock and omitting the poultry. The flavor balance between root vegetables, creamy mouthfeel, and aromatic truffle oil is admirable—a thoughtful dish for those seeking comfort with a touch of indulgence.

name: Charred Brussels, beetroot & bulgur salad
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: ½ small pack parsley, roughly chopped
directions: Put the bulgur in a small saucepan and cover with 300ml water. Bring to the boil, reduce to a simmer, cover and cook for 5 mins or until tender. Drain.
Meanwhile, heat a griddle pan over a high heat until very hot. Cook the sprouts until char lines appear, then set aside.
Make the dressing by combining all the ingredients in a small bowl with 1 tbsp water and a little seasoning.
In a large bowl, combine the bulgur with the Brussels, beetroot, onion, tomatoes, parsley and some seasoning. Divide between bowls and drizzle with the dressing, serving extra on the side.
chief_review: This inventive salad combines nutty bulgur wheat with earthy roasted Brussels sprouts and sweet beetroot, balanced by the acidity of cherry tomatoes and the aroma of fresh parsley. The use of creamy blue cheese and a buttermilk-mayonnaise dressing lends richness and tang, effectively tying the diverse vegetables together. The inclusion of whole grains, fresh produce, and dairy makes this dish particularly well-suited for vegetarian diets. Those seeking to boost fiber and flavor in their meals will find this recipe satisfying and lively, perfect as a hearty lunch or a unique side dish. The interplay of textures—from chewy bulgur to creamy dressing—illustrates a thoughtful composition and a clever use of leftovers, making it an appealing and practical option for any home cook.

name: Spiced home-cured salmon
description: How long after curing does this last for in the fridge? For example if I was to unwrap after stage one and then only use half, could I then rewrap it and leave it for a couple more days before using?
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: 400g/14oz whole piece of skinless, boneless salmon fillet
1 star anise, seeds removed and crushed
1 small red chilli, deseeded and diced
small handful each dill, coriander and mint leaves
½ mouli(Japanese radish), peeled and shaved into ribbons with a potato peeler
directions: Put the salmon fillet into a small tray on a double layer of cling film. In a bowl, mix the salt and sugar with the spices, coriander stalks and ginger, then scatter the mix over both sides of the fish and pat it down. Drizzle over the sherry and wrap the fish in the cling film. Place another tray on top, weight it down with a few tins, then chill for 2 days, flipping the fish over each day.
Mix all the dressing ingredients and stir until the sugar has dissolved. If the flavour is too strong, dilute it slightly with a drop of water, then set aside.

To serve, unwrap the salmon and wipe it clean, then briefly rinse it and pat dry with kitchen paper. Using a sharp knife, slice the fish quite thinly and arrange on plates with the mouli, then sprinkle with the herbs and drizzle over the dressing.
chief_review: This recipe is an aromatic cured salmon, layered with vibrant flavors from star anise, ginger, coriander, and sherry, complemented by fresh herbs and crisp mouli ribbons. The curing process intensifies the salmon’s taste while giving it a wonderfully firm texture, ideal for thin slicing and serving as an appetizer or light main. Due to the omission of wheat, dairy, and eggs, this dish is suitable for gluten-free and dairy-free diets—just be sure to use a gluten-free soy sauce. It's also perfect for pescatarians. The marriage of spice, sweetness, and herbaceous notes is beautifully balanced, and the mouli adds a refreshing crunch that cuts through the richness. Be mindful when rewrapping the salmon to ensure it stays tightly sealed for maximum freshness and best food safety practices. This is a stylish, flavorful dish fit for elegant gatherings or gourmet home dining.

name: Smoked ham & cheese pancakes
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: ½ tbsp vegetable oil, plus extra for frying
directions: Put the flour and ½ tsp salt in a bowl. Combine the eggs with the milk and oil, then gradually pour into the dry ingredients, whisking constantly until it’s a smooth batter. Transfer to a large jug.

Swirl a little oil around a large, non-stick pan over a gentle heat. Pour a quarter of the batter into the pan, tilting to coat the entire base. Cook for 1 min, flip over and cook for a further 30 secs. On one half of the pancake, add ¼ of the butter and sprinkle over ¼ of the ham and cheese. Grind over some black pepper and fold the pancake over the fillings. Fold in half again and transfer to a plate to serve. Repeat until you have four pancakes. Serve scattered with the chives.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a classic savory pancake with a delightful French twist. The batter, made from plain flour, egg, and your choice of milk, yields a tender, golden crepe. Sautéed smoked ham and nutty Gruyère provide satisfying richness, while fresh chives offer a subtle herbaceous lift. The use of both butter and vegetable oil ensures crisp edges and a soft center. This dish is ideal for a comforting brunch or a light dinner, pairing beautifully with a simple green salad. With both dairy and wheat present, it’s perfect for those seeking a traditional, protein-rich meal with a balance of fats and carbohydrates. Elegant in its simplicity, the combination of flavors and textures makes this recipe a reliable favorite for any home cook.

name: Crab fritters with cheat's chilli & crab mayonnaise
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: sea saltflakes and cayenne pepper, to serve
directions: Put the butter in a large saucepan with 225ml water, heating slowly so that the butter melts but the water doesn’t evaporate. Remove from the heat and quickly add the flour. Mix until fully incorporated and comes away from the pan, then leave to cool to room temperature. Use a wooden spoon to beat in the eggs, one at a time, until smooth, glossy and the mix drips off the spoon after 3 secs. Beat in the cheese until combined, before folding in the chives, crab and some seasoning.
Meanwhile, mix the mayonnaise ingredients together, season and set aside. Can be made a day ahead.

Heat the oil in a deep-fat fryer or large heavy-based saucepan (no more than half full) to 160C or until a piece of bread browns in 40 secs. Using a dessertspoon, scoop spoonfuls of the batter and carefully drop them straight into the hot oil (you will need to cook them in batches so that you don’t overcrowd the pan). Fry each batch for 3-4 mins until golden brown, then drain on kitchen paper. Season with sea salt flakes and cayenne pepper. Serve hot with the mayonnaise.
chief_review: This recipe is a sophisticated blend of French technique and coastal flavors, featuring crisp choux-based gougères enriched with Gruyère, chives, and delicate white crabmeat. The combination creates a refined, savory pastry that is ideally paired with a bold, crab-enriched sriracha mayo for dipping. The interplay between the creamy cheese, aromatic chives, and sweet crabmeat is masterful, while the spicy, tangy dip heightens the palate. This dish especially suits pescatarian diets, as the primary protein comes from crab. However, note the inclusion of butter, eggs, cheese, and mayonnaise, making it unsuitable for vegans and dairy-free regimens. The recipe is also not gluten-free, as it relies on plain flour for its structure. Overall, this is an impressive appetizer or canapé for those who appreciate seafood-forward, indulgent bites.

name: Vegan ‘smoked salmon’ toasts
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: slices of toasted baguette, sliced and toasted
directions: Cut the carrots into ribbons with a vegetable peeler and set aside. Pour 500ml water into a large saucepan with the salt and bring to the boil. Add the carrot ribbons and teabags and remove from the heat. Leave to steep for 20 mins until the mixture is cold and the ribbons have softened. Pour into a smaller container and chill until needed. Once cold and ready to serve, strain the carrot ribbons, discard the brine and pat dry with kitchen paper or a clean tea towel.
Spread the baguette slices with the cream cheese. Top each toast with a few carrot ribbons and a pinch of the dried seaweed, then season and serve.
chief_review: This inventive recipe transforms humble carrots into a smoky, savoury delight reminiscent of classic smoked salmon, thanks to the clever use of lapsang souchong tea and seaweed. The combination of marinated carrot ribbons atop toasted baguette slices, slathered with vegan cream cheese, delivers complexity in both flavor and texture. The umami notes from dried seaweed and the depth from smoky tea infuse the carrots beautifully, making this dish not only a conversation starter but also a flavor-packed bite. It’s an excellent choice for vegans and vegetarians seeking sophisticated appetizers, and all main ingredients are dairy-free. The absence of animal products and the use of plant-based cream cheese cater well to those with lactose intolerance or egg allergies. This recipe offers bold flavors and a satisfying, elegant presentation—ideal for gatherings or as a refined snack.

name: Date, blue cheese & pancetta polenta stacks
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1 tbsp olive oil, plus a little for the tin and for brushing
500ml vegetable stockmade with 2 tsp bouillon powder
120g creamy but sharp blue cheesesuch as Saint Agur or gorgonzola
8 large medjool dates, pitted and cut in half lengthways
handful baby spinach leaves(you’ll need 32 leaves)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. On a

, sandwich a single layer of pancetta rashers between two pieces of parchment, then weigh it down with a second tray (this will stop it wrinkling as it cooks). Bake for 10-15 mins until the fat is crisp and golden. Pat with kitchen paper to absorb any excess fat.
Oil a 20cm round tin. Boil the stock in a saucepan, then slowly stir in the polenta and simmer for 5 mins,

, until thick and smooth. Stir in 1 tbsp oil, the rosemary and parmesan, if using, and season. Spoon the mixture into the tin, level the top, then set in the fridge for at least 1 hr in the fridge or until very firm.
When ready to eat, heat a
or non-stick frying pan until hot. Cut the set polenta into 16 wedges, brush with a little oil, then cook for 4 mins on each side or until golden and marked. Transfer to a serving plate or board.

Meanwhile, use a cutlery knife to push about 1 tsp cheese into the middle of each date half. Thread a cocktail stick through each stuffed date, then add a piece of pancetta, two spinach leaves and a wedge of hot polenta. To serve, drizzle with a little of the pomegranate molasses.
chief_review:
This inventive recipe blends sweet, savory, and creamy elements, making for an intriguing appetizer or canapé. The combination of blue cheese, dates, and baby spinach wrapped in crisp pancetta delivers both textural contrast and bold flavors, while the drizzle of pomegranate molasses adds a bright, tangy finish. The quick-cook polenta base, infused with rosemary and finished with parmesan, grounds the dish with earthy undertones. 

This recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, but will work for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the bouillon powder and other ingredients are certified gluten-free. Watch for dairy sensitivities, as both parmesan and blue cheese contribute significant flavor and richness. Overall, this dish is a refined and festive bite, ideal for cocktail parties or as a starter to impress guests.

name: Rosy quince & cranberry jelly
description: This tangy jelly makes a fantastic accompaniment to your Christmas roast turkey, pork pie, ham or cheeseboard - or a gorgeous gift
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 450g Bramley apples, roughly chopped – don’t worry about coring
1kg bag preserving sugar(not with added pectin)
a few small, fresh bay leaves, to decorate the jars (optional)
directions: Put the quinces, apples and cranberries in a large pan. Cover with water and bring to the boil, then turn down the heat and cook more gently for about 1 hr until the fruit is really soft.
Hang a jelly bag over a large mixing bowl, tip the fruit in and let it drip overnight – don’t be tempted to squeeze the bag, or the pulp will come through and your jelly will be murky.

The next day, measure the amount of juice you have and, for every 1ml of liquid, match with grams of the sugar (so for 500ml you’d need 500g sugar). Tip both into a preserving pan, or large pan, and bring slowly to the boil, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Increase the heat once the sugar has gone and boil until it reaches 110C on a sugar thermometer.

Skim any scum off the surface of the liquid, then stir in the rosewater. Ladle into sterilised jars (see below left), adding a bay leaf to each one, if you like, and cover with lids – or wax discs, cellophane and elastic bands.
chief_review: This vibrant quince, apple, and cranberry jelly is a delightful addition to festive spreads, perfectly balancing tartness and subtle floral notes from rosewater. The use of preserving sugar (without added pectin) allows the natural fruit flavors to shine through, making it ideal for pairing with both savoury and sweet dishes—think roast turkey, ham, or a cheeseboard. As the recipe contains only fruit and sugar, it is naturally suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, and is also free from common allergens like nuts, eggs, gluten, and dairy. The optional bay leaves add an aromatic touch when gifting. Its jewel-like color and bright, tangy flavor will elevate any holiday table, making this jelly as beautiful to look at as it is delicious to eat.

name: Shooting star celebration cake
description: For a stunning Christmas centrepiece, this cake is perfect. Get the kids to help out making the stars and celebrate in style
author: Good Food
ingredients: 280g icing sugar, plus extra for rolling out
20cm round cake with marzipan (see 'Goes Well With')
gold edible lustre (we used Squires Kitchen)
red food colouring paste, we used Christmas red
directions: Knead 700g of the icing until smooth. Dust work surface with icing sugar, then roll icing into a circle 5mm thick and 40cm wide. Brush cake with cool, boiled water. Roll icing over the rolling pin, then place onto the marzipan, smoothing any folds. Cut away any excess, then use a glass to smooth sides of the cake.

Knead the trimmings with the remaining 300g icing and roll out to 5mm thick. Using an 8cm star cutter, cut one large star. Roll the rest of the icing a little thinner, then cut out 20 stars with a small cutter. Lift stars onto greaseproof paper and leave overnight. Once dry, mix some of the gold lustre with a drop of water then paint the large star and half the small stars gold. Leave to dry for 30 mins.

Squash trimmings together and colour with the red colouring paste. For the star’s tail, shape half the icing into a rectangle and roll out to a long strip about 3mm thick. Cut a length, 40cm long and 10cm wide at one end, tapering to about 5cm wide. Cut a ‘V’ in the wide end (see picture, below left). Cover with cling film, then roll the rest of the icing into a 20cm circle. Cut a scroll shape, ensuring one end is the same width as the thinner end of the first piece.

Brush the sides of the cake with water, then wrap the tail around. Lift the scrollshaped piece onto the cake, dampening underneath so it sticks, and join the scroll and tail ends together. Brush away excess icing sugar with a damp brush and leave to dry. Roll a walnut-size ball of icing and put on top of the cake where the tail ends.

Beat the egg white with the icing sugar to make a smooth paste. Spoon into an icing bag fitted with a fine writing nozzle. Use this to stick the large star onto the ball of icing and the small stars to the tail, and to pipe graduated dots to decorate. Leave to dry.
chief_review: This Christmas centrepiece cake is visually spectacular, with vibrant red stars and a touch of gold lustre that add elegance to any holiday table. The recipe is interactive and fun—perfect for involving kids in the kitchen while making decorative icing stars. The cake itself is covered with marzipan and finished with rich, sweet fondant, ensuring a classic flavor profile. It's suitable for a vegetarian diet, as none of the listed ingredients derive from animal flesh. However, it does contain egg white and marzipan (which includes almonds), so be aware if serving those with egg or nut allergies. The ready-to-roll icing simplifies the decoration process, and the edible gold lustre lifts the whole presentation. This recipe is the definition of festive indulgence, offering showstopping appeal and delicious taste in every slice.

name: Cranberry & Champagne sauce
description: Add a bit of bubbly and give this Christmas classic a fresh new taste
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: splash champagne or sparkling white wine
directions: Tip the sugar into a medium saucepan and place over a medium heat. Cook without stirring until the sugar has dissolved and turned into a bubbling, light-brown caramel.
Throw in the cranberries and let them cook in the caramel, stirring until they start to burst, then simmer everything for about 10 mins until you have a harmonious, thick, jammy sauce.
Pour in the Champagne or wine, bring the sauce to the boil, then remove and pour into a bowl to cool completely.
chief_review: This festive twist on classic cranberry sauce beautifully balances tart fruitiness with a delicate hint of champagne. The golden caster sugar sweetens the cranberries just enough without overpowering their natural zing, while the splash of sparkling wine adds brightness and a celebratory note, making it perfect for special occasions. With only three ingredients, this recipe is remarkably simple yet delivers impressive flavor complexity. It is naturally gluten-free and vegan, as it contains no animal-derived products or gluten-containing ingredients. The result is a vibrant, jewel-toned sauce that pairs beautifully with roasted dishes or can be used as a topping for desserts. A creative and refreshing addition to any holiday table.

name: Stir-fried festive cabbage
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: ½ red cabbage, quartered and core removed
200g bag shredded kale, or cavolo nero, sliced and woody stalks removed
directions: Finely shred the cabbage – the quickest way to do this is in a
with a shredder attachment or using a mandoline.
Heat the oil in a

or large frying pan, then add the cabbage and kale. Stir-fry over a high heat for 3-4 mins or until the cabbage starts to wilt, then add the rest of the ingredients. Toss everything together really well, continue to cook for a further 4 mins and season before serving. Keep warm in a low oven if needed or leave to cool, cover, chill and reheat in a pan or microwave the following day.
chief_review: This vibrant dish brings together the earthy crunch of red cabbage and kale, gently sautéed in a blend of oil and butter. The addition of cranberry sauce, red wine, and orange zest creates a sophisticated balance of sweet, tart, and citrus notes, elevating the vegetables to a star side. The cooking method helps soften and marry the flavors beautifully, while the hint of fruitiness from the cranberry and orange makes this perfect for festive occasions or as a bright companion to rich mains. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe can easily be adapted for dairy-free or vegan diets by using a plant-based butter alternative. With its nutrient-dense greens and creative flavor profile, it stands out as both healthful and delicious.

name: Cranberry & orange meringue pie
description: The creamy, citrus filling in this pie contrasts wonderfully with the sweet, fluffy meringue - a sure-fire showstopper
author: Good Food
ingredients: 250g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: For the pastry, put the butter and flour in a food processor and whizz to fine crumbs, then pulse in the sugar. Mix the egg yolks with 2 tsp cold water and, with the blade running, pour in the liquid to bring the pastry together. If it doesn’t come together, add 1-2 tsp more water until it does.

Tip the pastry onto a lightly floured surface and bring together to make a flat disc, then roll out to line a 23cm loose-bottomed tart tin. Leave the pastry overhanging the tin and prick the bottom of the pastry case with a fork. Chill for 30 mins.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line the pastry case with some crumpled baking parchment, fill with baking beans, then blind-bake for 15 mins. Carefully remove the parchment and beans, and bake for a further 10 mins or until the pastry looks golden and biscuity. Remove the case from the oven and trim the edges of the pastry with a sharp knife. Can be done the day before. Lower oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.

While the case is baking, make the filling. Cook the cranberries in a shallow pan over a medium heat with 2 tbsp water for 15 mins until pulpy. Push the fruit through a sieve over a bowl; discard the seeds and skins.

Put the cornflour in a clean pan and whisk in the lemon and orange juice until smooth. Add the sugar and cranberry purée, and heat until the mixture has bubbled and thickened, stirring constantly. Remove from the heat, add the butter and beat until melted. Add the egg yolks and whole egg to the pan, beat well and return to a medium heat. Keep stirring vigorously for 5 mins until the mixture thickens and drops off the spoon. Remove from the heat and set aside.

Meanwhile, make the meringue. Put the egg whites in a large clean bowl and whisk to stiff peaks. Add half the sugar, a spoonful at a time, whisking between each addition until stiff again. Whisk in the cornflour and remaining sugar until shiny and thick.

Pour the filling into the pastry case. Put spoonfuls of meringue around the edge of the filling so it just touches the pastry and pile the rest into the centre, spreading so that it covers the filling. Bake for 18-20 mins until the meringue is crisp and slightly coloured. Let the pie sit in the tin for 30 mins, then remove and leave for at least another 30 mins before slicing.
chief_review: This Cranberry Citrus Meringue Pie is a striking dessert, marrying the tartness of cranberries with bright citrus notes and a marshmallowy meringue crown. The shortcrust pastry is richly buttery, providing an indulgent, crumbly base for the silky, fruit-forward filling. The interplay of lemon and orange juices elevates the cranberry's natural zing, while the meringue topping is billowy and sweet, expertly balancing the pie’s acidity. With both eggs and dairy prominent throughout, this recipe is suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians. However, it is not appropriate for vegans or those avoiding eggs or dairy. Note that the use of wheat flour means it is not gluten free, so substitutions would be required for a gluten-sensitive diet. All in all, this pie is a celebration of texture and flavor, perfect as a festive centrepiece that delivers both visual appeal and delicious complexity.

name: Chicken liver pâté
description: James Martin's luxuriously rich dinner party starter can be made up to two days in advance for fuss-free entertaining - serve with toasted brioche, cornichons and chutney
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2 large garlic cloves, 1 crushed, 1 finely sliced
directions: Heat 1 tbsp of the butter in a non-stick frying pan over a medium heat. When the butter is foaming, add the chicken livers and fry for 2 mins each side.

Stir the crushed garlic, some of the thyme and Madeira into the pan with the livers. Fry for 2 mins, letting the Madeira simmer. Transfer the mixture to a food processor, reserve 200g of the butter and add the rest to the processor. Blend everything to a smooth paste. Season to taste, then spoon into 4 x 70ml clip-top jars.

Melt the reserved butter in a medium frying pan and add the sliced garlic. Turn the garlic in the butter until slightly golden. Pour into the 4 jars of pâté, ensuring a few slices of garlic and the remaining thyme leaves go in each jar, and chill in the fridge for at least 4 hrs, or until set. Can be made up to 2 days in advance.

Before serving, toast the brioche, then cut into triangular quarters for serving. Stir the diced apple through the chutney. Serve the pâté on small wooden boards with the toasted brioche, cornichons and chutney.
chief_review: James Martin’s chicken liver pâté offers a decadently smooth starter, perfect for impressing dinner guests. The blend of chicken livers, unsalted butter, and a touch of Madeira yields an exceptionally rich, silky spread, elevated by the aromatic notes of thyme and just enough garlic. Preparing this dish ahead of time not only develops its flavors but also brings ease to entertaining. The brioche delivers a light, buttery crunch, ideal for scooping up the pâté, while tangy cornichons and sweet Bramley apple onion chutney provide a delightful balance to the richness. This recipe is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet if paired with gluten-free bread instead of brioche. However, please note the use of butter and chicken liver excludes it from vegan and vegetarian diets. As a sumptuous, make-ahead dish, this pâté is an elegant way to start a special meal.

name: Sautéed potatoes with bacon lardons & persillade
description: Simple to make and really tasty! Easy to adapt as well, as I only had rosemary and thyme to go with the parsley, but it tasted great nonetheless. Made it without the lardons as I had other pork on the menu already but will definitely give that a try next time.
author: Raymond Blanc
directions: In a large saucepan on a high heat, simmer the potatoes for 5 mins in enough water to just cover them, then drain in a colander and leave for 1 min for the steam to escape.

In a small bowl, mix all the ingredients for the persillade together and set aside. Heat the oil in a large frying pan on a high heat, add the lardons and cook for 8-10 mins until lightly caramelised. Add the potatoes, then the butter.

Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper and cook for 10 mins, stirring regularly, until golden brown all over. Spoon out any excess fat and stir in the persillade. Taste and adjust the seasoning if necessary.
chief_review: This rustic yet refined potato dish impresses with its aromatic blend of fresh herbs—parsley, chervil, tarragon—and the distinctive sweetness of banana shallot. The rapeseed oil and unsalted butter create a beautifully rich base, while the smoked bacon lardons lend depth and a gentle smokiness. It’s a flexible recipe, easily adapted with whatever herbs you have on hand, as demonstrated by swapping in rosemary and thyme without losing flavor. The preparation suits those seeking gluten-free options, as all ingredients are naturally free from gluten. The classic combination of earthy potatoes, savory pork, and vibrant herbs makes this a satisfying accompaniment or even a main with a green salad. I appreciate that the dish isn’t overly complicated but delivers substantial flavor—excellent for both weeknights and special gatherings.

name: Carbonara cabbage
description: Give your side dish an Italian twist by mixing tender Savoy with smoked bacon, garlic, cream and Parmesan
author: Good Food
ingredients: 12 rashers streaky bacon, chopped into small pieces
directions: Bring a large pan of water to the boil. Tip in the cabbage and boil for 10 mins. Drain and keep warm.
Meanwhile, heat a large frying pan and cook the bacon for 7-8 mins until golden and crisp, adding the garlic for the final 3 mins.

In a bowl, mix together the cream and Parmesan with some freshly ground black pepper. Add the cream mixture and the cabbage to the bacon pan. Toss everything together until well coated. Return to the heat to warm through for a few mins before serving.
chief_review: This hearty Italian-inspired side dish brings together the subtle sweetness of tender Savoy cabbage with the deep, smoky flavor of bacon. The addition of sliced garlic infuses a gentle warmth, while single cream and a generous grating of Parmesan create a luxurious, velvety sauce. The combination of fresh vegetables, rich dairy, and savory bacon produces a balanced and satisfying result, making this recipe a delightful complement to robust mains. Its reliance on cabbage makes it suitable for low-carb and keto diets, while the absence of gluten-containing ingredients caters to gluten-free needs. The dish requires minimal preparation and offers maximum flavor, making it a valuable addition to any cook’s repertoire seeking both comfort and a touch of Italian flair.

name: Tropical coconut rum punch
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Put all the ingredients in a jug, mix well and chill. To serve, add ice to glasses, pour over the rum punch and decorate with pineapple & lime skewers.
chief_review: This tropical-inspired cocktail blends pineapple juice, mango juice, coconut milk, and Malibu rum for a refreshing and creamy drink reminiscent of a beachside escape. The use of pure juices and coconut milk offers a dairy-free option, making the recipe suitable for those who are lactose intolerant or following a dairy-free diet. The garnish of fresh sliced pineapple and lime on skewers adds both aroma and a striking visual appeal. The marriage of fruit juices with coconut milk balances sweetness and acidity, while Malibu rum brings a gentle coconut undertone, enhancing the overall experience. This cocktail is best served chilled and is sure to be a hit at summer gatherings or festive occasions.

name: Stollen wreath cake
description: The sweet German fruit and marzipan loaf recipe is adapted into a gorgeous wreath cake with decorative fondant holly icing and almond marzipan
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 50g red glacé cherry, sliced, plus about 9 left whole to decorate
about 100g green Regal-Ice Ready to Roll icing(or use white mixed with green food colouring)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease and lightly flour a 1.4-litre Bundt tin. Beat the butter and sugar until very light and fluffy. Add the eggs with a handful of flour and beat in, followed by the vanilla and almond extract. Tip in half the remaining flour, half the ground almonds, half the soured cream and all of the baking powder and beat in.

Mix the rest of the flour with the pistachios, sultanas, remaining ground almonds, the flaked almonds, cherries and mixed peel, then stir into the cake mixture with the remaining soured cream. Spoon into the tin, spread to level and bake for 50 mins until a poked-in skewer comes out clean. Remove from the oven and leave to cool for 10 mins in the tin, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

To decorate, first roll the marzipan into a sausage shape long enough to sit on top of the cake in a ring. Position it on top and squeeze the two ends together, then press down a little to help it stick in place. Mix the fondant icing sugar with enough water to make a thick but spreadable icing – add the water little by little, so you don’t end up with a really runny icing. Spoon the icing over the marzipan ring, letting it dribble down the sides a little. Shape the Regal-Ice Icing into holly leaves and dust with green glitter or press on green sprinkles. Arrange on top of the cake, using the whole glacé cherries as the berries.
chief_review:
This luxurious adaptation of the classic German fruit and marzipan loaf transforms its rich, aromatic flavors into an eye-catching wreath cake, perfect for festive occasions. The cake’s soft crumb is enhanced by soured cream, lending a pleasant tang, while golden caster sugar and a generous dose of vanilla and almond extract amplify its sweet, nutty undertones. Studded with sultanas, glacé cherries, pistachios, mixed peel, and toasted flaked almonds, every slice bursts with texture and festive fruitiness. The inclusion of marzipan infuses distinct almond notes, which marry beautifully with the crowned holly-shaped fondant icing and festive sprinkles, giving it a stunning presentation. 

Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this cake does not contain any meat or animal rennet. However, do note the presence of several common allergens, such as eggs, nuts, and dairy, for those with sensitivities.

name: Stuffed Peppadews
description: These low-fat, gluten-free canapés can be put together in just 10 minutes - perfect as a last-minute party nibble
author: Jennifer Joyce
directions: Finely chop the artichokes and a handful of rocket. Mix together with the crumbled feta. Spoon the mixture into the Peppadews and serve.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful option for anyone seeking a quick, fuss-free canapé with vibrant Mediterranean flavors. The tender grilled artichokes pair beautifully with the peppery bite of rocket, while the feta adds a creamy, salty contrast that perfectly complements the gentle heat and sweetness of peppadews. With only four ingredients and a preparation time of 10 minutes, it’s ideal for last-minute entertaining. Notably, these canapés are naturally gluten-free, making them suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. The use of low-fat components and fresh vegetables also caters well to individuals looking for lighter, health-conscious appetizers. Serve these at your next gathering for a guaranteed crowd-pleaser.

name: Beef fillet with red wine sauce
description: Luxuriously tender meat, soaked in a herby, garlicky marinade makes for a mouthwatering main course, fit for a feast
author: Marcus Wareing
ingredients: ½ small pack thyme, leaves picked and roughly chopped
3 rosemarysprigs, leaves picked and roughly chopped
1 whole garlic bulb, top third cut off and discarded
140g beefscraps (ask your butcher for these) or braising steak, chopped
directions: Put the beef in a container just big enough to fit snugly. Mix the marinade ingredients in a bowl and tip over the beef. Cover and chill, turning and basting as often as possible. Leave for 24-72 hrs.

Pour the Port and wine into a large pan and simmer until reduced to a glaze. – this will take about 20 mins. Heat the oil in a separate large pan and, when almost smoking, add the beef scraps and cook until dark golden. Add the shallots, garlic, peppercorns and herbs. Fry for a few mins until starting to brown, then add the reduced alcohol and stock. Bring to a simmer and cook for 25 mins. Strain into a clean pan, then simmer for 8-10 mins until thickened. Season to taste and chill until needed.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the fillet from the marinade and brush off the herbs, reserving them and the garlic for later. Heat the vegetable oil in a large pan. When almost smoking, add the fillet, season with 2 tsp salt and fry for 5-7 mins, turning every so often.

Add the butter, cube by cube, and – when foaming – baste the fillet, turning regularly. When the fillet is caramelised, put in a roasting tin with the reserved herbs and garlic, and cook in the oven for 8-12 mins, turning every 4 mins and basting. To check that the beef is done, insert a probe thermometer into the centre – it should read 55-60C for medium rare. Transfer to a board, wrap loosely in foil and rest for 20 mins.
Return the tin to the oven until the butter is hot. Before serving, roll the fillet in it. Serve with the sauce, croquettes, carrots and garlic.
chief_review: This recipe exemplifies classic luxury, centering on a well-aged beef fillet marinated and basted with a rich combination of herbs, garlic, and butter. The infusion of port and red wine, reduced and blended with aromatic shallots and beef stock, yields an intensely flavoured sauce that elevates the tender meat. The use of both fresh herbs—thyme and rosemary—and generous amounts of garlic offers an aromatic complexity. Port and red wine create depth and a subtle sweetness, perfectly balanced by the robustness of beef. While the recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or those avoiding alcohol, it is naturally gluten-free, making it an appealing choice for those on a gluten-free diet. Ideal for a festive occasion or an impressive dinner, this dish delivers a refined culinary experience for beef aficionados seeking bold, harmonious flavours.

name: Goat’s cheese, pear & candied pecan salad
description: This extra-special vegetarian starter is bursting with contrasting flavours and textures, such as spiralized pear, crunchy roasted nuts and creamy cheese
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2 red-skinned pears, cut into long, thin strips (use a spiralizer, or julienne them)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and put the pecans on a non-stick baking sheet. Sprinkle over the sugar and maple syrup, and toss to combine. Roast for 5-7 mins until golden, then leave to cool completely before roughly chopping.
Meanwhile, make the dressing by combining the ingredients and seasoning well. In a large bowl, combine the pear with the rocket, and toss with a little of the dressing.

Just before serving, blowtorch or grill the goat’s cheese rounds until golden. To serve, put the remaining dressing in a squeezy bottle and swirl around the edge of the plate. Put the pear and rocket salad in the middle, scatter over the nuts and top with the goat’s cheese.
chief_review: This vibrant vegetarian starter stands out with its interplay of sweet, tangy, and creamy flavors. Spiralized pear and wild rocket bring freshness and crunch, while candied pecans add a delightful sweetness and texture. The star is the goat’s cheese—rich and velvety, perfectly balanced by the acidity of the mustard and white wine vinegar dressing. The extra virgin olive oil rounds off the salad for a wholesome mouthfeel. Free from gluten and suitable for vegetarians, this dish is an ideal choice for dinner parties or festive occasions. The inclusion of nuts and dairy should be noted for those with allergies, but otherwise, the ingredients harmonize beautifully for an elegant, nutritious starter.

name: Ice cream bombe
description: Use up leftover fruitcake or Christmas pudding in this ice cream basin bombe with dark rum, raisins and caramel sauce
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Brush a pudding basin with a little sunflower oil, then line with cling film. Spoon the ice cream into a food processor (or a bowl if you have a handheld blender). Crumble in the cake or pudding, add the mixed spice and 4 tbsp of the rum, and whizz together until nearly smooth. Stir in the raisins.
Scrape the ice cream mixture into the basin and smooth the top. Cover with cling film and freeze overnight until solid.

Take the pudding basin out of the freezer 15 mins before serving. Turn the pudding out onto a serving plate and peel off the cling film. Mix the caramel sauce and remaining 2 tbsp rum together and warm gently, if you like (it’s still lovely cold). Serve with the Ice cream bombe.
chief_review: This festive ice cream bombe is a clever way to elevate leftover fruitcake or Christmas pudding. The vanilla ice cream base is enlivened with the warmth of mixed spice and dark rum, while plump raisins add extra bursts of sweetness. The star here is the gooey caramel sauce, which rounds out the flavors with indulgent richness. Preparation is straightforward, making it an ideal dessert for holiday gatherings or when you need to impress with minimal fuss. Thanks to its composition, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and nut-free diets, provided the fruitcake and ice cream are free from hidden animal products and nuts. Serve sliced, with extra caramel sauce drizzled over for a showstopping finish—an inventive treat that transforms festive leftovers into a luxurious finale.

name: Mini Mont Blancs
description: This sweet chestnut, cream and chocolate tart filling is perfect spooned into pre-baked tartlet cases for a no-bake alternative to mince pies
author: Good Food
directions: Mix the chestnut purée with the icing sugar and vanilla extract. Divide between 12 baked tartlet cases. Whip the double cream, spoon onto the tarts, then grate over dark chocolate to finish.
chief_review: This sweet chestnut, cream, and chocolate tart filling offers a luxurious twist on classic festive treats. The chestnut purée brings a naturally earthy sweetness that pairs beautifully with the rich double cream, while a hint of vanilla and a dusting of grated dark chocolate lend depth and a touch of indulgence. The mixture is airy yet decadent, perfect for those seeking a simple dessert with elegant flavours and minimal fuss. Easily spooned into tartlet cases, it saves on baking time while delivering maximum impact—a real treat for dinner parties or holiday gatherings. Notably, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no gelatine or animal-based thickeners. To ensure the recipe remains gluten-free, simply choose gluten-free tartlet cases.

name: Aperol & limoncello cocktail
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Mix together all the ingredients in a jug. Chill until ready to serve. Pour into 4 highball glasses with ice. Decorate with citrus skewers.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail recipe is a citrus-forward twist perfect for those who love bold, refreshing flavors. The blend of vodka, limoncello, and triple sec infuses the drink with bright lemon and orange notes, while Aperol or Campari adds a sophisticated bitterness. Freshly sliced oranges and lemons on skewers not only elevate the presentation but also subtly enhance the drink’s aroma. This recipe suits a vegetarian and vegan diet, as all the listed ingredients are derived from plant sources and free from animal products. Additionally, the cocktail is naturally gluten-free, provided you choose certified gluten-free spirits. Serve chilled for a lively aperitif or as a celebratory punch at gatherings; just be mindful of the alcohol content—this is a strong, zesty concoction sure to become a favorite for fans of Italian-inspired cocktails.

name: Korean beef bulgogi skewers
description: Sweet pineapple is combined with salty soy sauce in a delicious marinade for these sirloin steak canapés - great for a party buffet
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: thumb-sized piece ginger, peeled and sliced
1 tsp chilli flakesor Korean chilli powder
1 tbsp sesame oil, plus extra for frying
spring onions, thinly sliced, to serve
2 tbsp sriracha or other chilli sauce
2 tbsp kecap manis(Indonesian sweet soy sauce)
directions: Put the steak in the freezer for 30 mins – it will firm up and be much easier to slice thinly. Meanwhile, make a marinade. Put the soy, sugar, mirin, ginger, garlic, pineapple, chilli flakes and oil in a food processor. Blitz until smooth, then pour into a bowl.

When the meat is semi-frozen, thinly slice into 25 pieces and add to the marinade. Chill until ready to use, but don’t leave for longer than 2 hrs or the pineapple juice will break down the meat too much.

Meanwhile, soak small wooden skewers in water for 10 mins. When ready to serve, thread a piece of meat onto each skewer. Heat a griddle pan, or frying pan, and brown skewers for 1-2 mins each side or until grill marks appear. Add a little more oil to the pan if needed.
Mix together the dipping sauce ingredients in a small bowl. Serve the skewers with lettuce, sesame seeds, spring onions and dipping sauce.
chief_review: This sirloin steak canapé recipe beautifully balances sweet pineapple and salty soy sauce in a vibrant marinade, creating a succulent bite-sized treat perfect for party buffets. The addition of mirin, ginger, and garlic infuses the steak with depth, while a touch of chilli flakes provides gentle heat. The finishing touches of sesame oil, fresh lettuce leaves, spring onions, and toasted sesame seeds add refreshing crunch and aroma, making each canapé visually appealing and texturally satisfying. The sriracha and kecap manis lend complexity and a lingering umami richness. This recipe is a great fit for those following a dairy-free diet, provided the soy sauce used is also gluten-free if necessary. The dish is best enjoyed fresh, and its harmonious combination of flavors is sure to impress guests.

name: Mini saltimbocca sandwiches
description: A tasty morsel to whet your appetite as a canapé or nibble with a glass of fizz- perfect bite-sized party food
author: James Martin
ingredients: 4 thin slices from a small baguette, cut on the angle
1 heaped tsp fig chutney(we used Marks & Spencer Fig & Balsamic)
