directions: Spread each slice of baguette with butter. On an un-buttered side, spread over half the chutney, top with a piece of prosciutto and 2 bocconcini halves. Top with a second slice of bread, buttered-side up, then top with a sage leaf and press down slightly. Repeat to make a second sandwich.
Add a drizzle of oil and a knob of butter to a small pan. Fry the sandwiches over a low heat, turning, until golden and crisp, and the cheese is just melting. Eat immediately.
chief_review: This canapé is a delightful fusion of savory, sweet, and creamy notes, making it an exceptional party nibble. The crusty baguette forms a sturdy base, delicately enriched with a touch of butter. Fig chutney provides a luscious sweetness, beautifully offset by the salty prosciutto, while bocconcini adds a fresh, milky creaminess. Sage leaves offer an aromatic lift, and a final drizzle of olive oil ties the flavors together. This recipe is well-suited for those following a gluten- and nut-free diet (providing gluten-free bread is used and all ingredients are verified), but does contain dairy and pork, making it unsuitable for vegans, vegetarians, and those with dairy allergies. The balance of contrasting textures and the easy assembly make this canapé an outstanding choice for sophisticated entertaining.

name: Smoked salmon taramasalata
description: This Greek dip is an original way to use up leftover smoked salmon and works well on a sharing mezze platter
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: drizzle of olive oil, to serve
black kalamata oliveand toasted pitta bread, to serve
directions: Tip the salmon, soft cheese, crème fraîche and lemon juice into a food processor. Blitz everything until smooth, then stir in a very large pinch cracked pepper. Spoon the mix into a large bowl, drizzle with olive oil and serve with toasted pitta bread and olives.
chief_review: This smoked salmon Greek dip is a clever and delicious way to repurpose leftover fish, offering a creamy yet tangy profile thanks to the blend of low-fat soft cheese, crème fraîche, and fresh lemon juice. The smokiness of the salmon is pleasantly balanced by the freshness of the lemon, while the olive oil drizzle adds a velvety richness. Presented alongside black Kalamata olives and toasted pitta bread, the dish shines as part of a mezze platter—ideal for sharing. It's particularly suitable for pescatarians, as it omits meat but features fish. The recipe is also nut-free, making it appropriate for many with nut allergies. The simplicity of preparation, combined with its sophisticated flavors, makes this dip an excellent choice for casual gatherings or as an elegant appetizer.

name: Butternut soup shots with crispy pancetta soldiers
description: Serve squash soup in individual espresso cups with bacon toast for dipping as a cute party canapé
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2cm-thick slice white bread, cut into 8 chunky soldiers
850ml-1 litre butternut squash & sage soup soup(see 'goes well with')
drizzle cream and a few snipped chives, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Wrap a pancetta slice around each soldier. Toss with a little olive oil and bake for 5-8 mins until crisp, turning halfway through cooking.
Reheat the soup, then divide evenly between 8 espresso cups or large shot glasses. Serve drizzled with cream and sprinkled with chives, with a crispy pancetta soldier for dipping.
chief_review: This delightful canapé brings together the earthy sweetness of butternut squash and sage soup, served charmingly in espresso cups for a touch of sophistication. The pancetta-wrapped bread soldiers are a clever, indulgent companion—crispy, salty, and perfectly suited for dipping. The finishing drizzle of cream and chives adds freshness and elegance, balancing the richness of the soup and pancetta. While this recipe is not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or those avoiding gluten or dairy, it shines as a comforting, crowd-pleasing appetizer. The assembly is straightforward for an elevated presentation, making it a standout at any gathering.

name: Luxury bread & onion sauce
description: This thick white sauce makes the perfect accompaniment to roast chicken or turkey- flavour with cloves, bay and anise
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g good-quality white bread, crusts removed, chopped into chunks
directions: Heat the butter in medium pan until just starting to sizzle. Cook the onion over a very low heat with the thyme and bay for 15-20 mins until soft and just lightly golden. Pour the milk into the pan, add the star anise and ground cloves, season and bring to the boil. Turn off the heat and leave to infuse for at least 10 mins.

Remove the star anise and bay, and add the bread chunks to the pan. Bring back to the boil, then remove from the heat and blitz using a hand blender. Return to the heat, stir in the crème fraîche and simmer gently for 2 mins until thickened.
Tip into a bowl, sprinkle with cracked pepper, and add the bay leaf, if you like.
chief_review: This classic white sauce impresses with its depth and aromatic complexity, using cloves, bay leaf, and star anise to complement roast poultry exquisitely. The slow-cooked onions and thyme provide a rich base, while the infusion of spices into a creamy milk reduction elevates the sauce's profile. Incorporating good-quality white bread for thickening results in a velvety, luxurious texture. The addition of crème fraîche lends a tangy finish, balancing richness without overpowering the dish. With no meat, this sauce is an excellent accompaniment for vegetarians when served with vegetables or plant-based proteins. Bread as a thickener makes this sauce naturally wheat-based, so not suitable for gluten-free diets, but ideal for those seeking comforting, traditional flavors. Overall, a refined, aromatic sauce perfect for festive occasions or elevating everyday roasts.

name: Sticky maple-glazed parsnips with pecans
description: Spruce up your roots by adding crunchy nuts and caramelise with sweet maple syrup
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1kg parsnip, cut into long pointy batons
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. On a large baking tray, toss the parsnips with the oil and plenty of seasoning. Cook on a low shelf in the oven for 30 mins.
Remove from oven, drizzle with maple syrup, scatter over the pecans and toss everything together. Cook for a further 5-10 mins until the parsnips start to caramelise and crisp up at the ends.
chief_review: This recipe offers a vibrant twist on roasted parsnips by incorporating the crunch of pecans and a glossy caramelized finish from maple syrup. The choice of vegetable or sunflower oil, combined with the sweetness of maple syrup, enhances the natural earthiness of the parsnips, while the pecans provide an additional layer of texture and a subtle nutty depth. The method is straightforward: roast until golden, drizzle with syrup, and finish with toasted nuts for a pleasing contrast in every bite. This dish is an excellent option for vegetarians and a delightful addition to festive or everyday meals. As it’s free from animal products and uses plant-based ingredients exclusively, it’s also suitable for vegans. For those with gluten intolerance, there are no sources of gluten, making it a versatile side for multiple dietary needs.

name: Crunchy potato squares with herby salt
description: Cut spuds into uniform little cubes then sprinkle liberally with rosemary, thyme and sage salt - they'll crisp up a treat
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 tbsp vegetable, sunflower or rapeseed oil
directions: To make the herby salt, put all the ingredients in a small food processor (or use a pestle and mortar) and grind to a fine salt.
Tip the potatoes into a large roasting tin and toss with the oil, polenta, 2 tbsp of the herby salt and some black pepper. Any leftover salt will keep for up to 5 days in a small sealed container.

Bake underneath a joint of meat, if cooking, at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 30 mins. When the meat comes out, turn up the heat to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and cook on the top shelf for another 45 mins, shaking the tin halfway through the cooking time.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful take on herbed roasted potatoes, showcasing aromatic rosemary, thyme, and sage. The use of fine polenta or cornmeal adds a subtle crunch, setting these crisp spuds apart from more conventional roast potatoes. With only oil, potatoes, fresh herbs, and coarse sea salt, these are ideal for vegan and vegetarian diets. The absence of wheat or animal products also makes this recipe suitable for those who are gluten-free and dairy-free. The herbs infuse wonderful flavor, while the high-heat oil helps achieve a golden, crunchy exterior. Serve these as a show-stealing side or a satisfying snack—simple, delicious, and inclusive for many dietary requirements.

name: Mini meatball sliders
description: Serve American-style mini burgers with Italian meatballs, barbecue sauce and cheddar cheese
author: Good Food
ingredients: 12 large beef or British veal meatballs
few tbsp smoky barbecue sauce- chipotle if you can get it
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Space the meatballs in a baking tray and squash each slightly with the palm of your hand. Roast for 15 mins until cooked through, then press some cheese into the top of each. Put back in the oven for 20 secs-1 min until the cheese starts to melt.

Meanwhile, split the rolls in half and very lightly toast. Spread each half with a little barbecue sauce, then top each with a cheesy meatball, some onion and some cornichon. Skewer with a cocktail stick or mini skewer to hold everything together.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a playful twist on classic sliders, merging robust American flavors with a nod to Italian tradition through the use of hearty beef or veal meatballs. The smoky barbecue sauce adds depth and a gentle heat, while the sharp cheddar melts beautifully atop, balancing richness with a hint of tang. Red onion rings offer subtle bite and freshness, complemented by the piquancy of sliced mini cornichons for a satisfying finish. The use of mini rolls keeps the portions light and approachable, making these sliders ideal as an appetizer or party snack. This recipe is a solid choice for those following a gluten-free diet if gluten-free rolls are substituted. Likewise, the absence of nuts makes it suitable for nut-free diets, provided all packaged ingredients are verified as safe. Overall, these mini burgers are a flavorful crowd-pleaser with thoughtful textural contrast and bold taste.

name: From-the-freezer Yorkies
description: You can't have a roast dinner without Yorkshire puddings! These fluffy, crispy beauties can be made ahead and frozen
author: Good Food
directions: Mix together the milk, eggs, flour and a pinch of salt in a food processor or blender until you have a smooth batter. If you don’t have a food processor or blender, whisk the eggs into the flour and salt, then gradually whisk in the milk until smooth. Transfer to a jug, cover and leave for 15 mins.
Meanwhile, heat oven to 240C/220C fan/gas 9. Pour ½ tsp oil into the holes of a Yorkshire pudding or muffin tin and put in the oven for 10 mins to get hot.

When the oil is hot, pour the batter into each hole a third of the way up. Quickly put in the oven, then turn it down to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and cook for 12-15 mins. Remove the Yorkies, turn them upside down in the tin and return to the oven for another 2-3 mins to brown the bottoms.
Allow to cool completely on a wire rack, then put in a tight-sealing freezer bag or container and freeze for up to a month.
When ready to cook, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Put the frozen Yorkies on a baking sheet and cook for 6-8 mins until golden and hot.
chief_review:
This classic Yorkshire pudding recipe delivers beautifully crisp and airy results, perfect for complementing any roast dinner. The combination of whole milk, eggs, and plain flour ensures a tender yet sturdy puff, while the sunflower oil helps achieve the golden, crunchy exterior essential to a proper Yorkshire. 

Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe avoids any animal fats or meats, and uses a neutral oil for baking—ideal for those who don’t consume butter or lard. The straightforward ingredient list also makes it easy to prepare ahead and freeze, which is a great boon for busy cooks aiming for efficiency without sacrificing tradition or quality. 

Serve piping hot straight from the oven for best results, or reheat from frozen for a no-fuss addition to Sunday lunch. A reliable, crowd-pleasing staple for any festive table.

name: Healthy stuffing balls
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 2 sticks celery, stringed and finely chopped
100g wholemeal bread, crusts removed and roughly torn (about 6 slices)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Gently heat the oil in a shallow saucepan then add the onion, celery and garlic. Keep everything sizzling on a medium heat for 15 mins until soft. Tip into a food processor with the rest of the ingredients, except the egg, plus a small pinch of salt, if you like. Pulse until everything is chopped, then add the egg and pulse until combined. Use wet hands to roll the mixture into walnut-sized balls, then place on a baking sheet lined with baking parchment.
Bake in the oven for 25-30 mins until golden and hot through.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful medley of flavors and textures, balancing the earthiness of chestnuts and almonds with the subtle sweetness of dried apricots. The inclusion of aromatic vegetables like onion, celery, and garlic builds a savory foundation, while fresh parsley and dried sage add herbal brightness. The use of wholemeal bread gives the mixture heartiness and an appealing rustic quality. With olive oil as the primary fat and a single egg acting as binder, the recipe is well-suited to a vegetarian diet. It’s also rich in fiber, nuts, and wholesome grains, making it both satisfying and nutritious. This dish would work beautifully as a vegetarian stuffing or loaf, providing robust flavor without the need for meat.

name: Festive date & pecan pudding
description: Not your traditional Christmas pud, but a winner with our food team. A cross between sticky toffee and Christmas pud with a lighter feel
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 pieces stem ginger, cut into thin shreds
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Pour 300ml boiling water over the chopped dates and set aside. Butter a 1.4-litre pudding basin and put a disc of baking parchment in the base. Put the butter, sugar, flour, bicarbonate of soda, mixed spice and eggs into a large bowl, then beat with an electric hand whisk until really well blended. Add the cooled date mixture, then beat again to make a sloppy batter.

Stir in the fruits, nuts and ginger, then pour into the pudding basin and place on a baking tray. Bake in the oven for 1 hr, cover the top lightly with foil, then return to the oven for 25 mins more until a skewer inserted into the pudding comes out clean.

Meanwhile, make the brandy syrup. Put the sugar and 50ml water in a pan and stir over the heat until syrupy. Stir in the brandy and remove from the heat. When the pudding is ready, remove from the oven and push a skewer into it in several places. Pour over the brandy syrup so it soaks into the pudding, then cover until ready to serve.
Turn out onto a plate, scatter with the pecans and top with the holly sprig, dusted with icing sugar. Serve with good-quality vanilla ice cream.
chief_review: This festive dessert is a delightful twist on traditional Christmas pudding, artfully blending the rich, caramel depths of sticky toffee with classic holiday flavors. The use of dates, raisins, and candied peel infuses warmth, while pecans add a welcome crunch. Stem ginger enlivens each bite, and the brandy sauce brings indulgence without being overwhelmingly heavy. Its lighter texture makes it more approachable than the usual Christmas pud, perfect for those seeking a satisfying yet less dense finale to their holiday meal. This recipe contains eggs, butter, wheat (gluten), nuts, and ginger, so it’s well-suited to vegetarians, but not for those needing dairy-free, nut-free, or gluten-free options. The visual touch of a holly sprig and a dusting of icing sugar elevates the festive appeal, making this an elegant crowd-pleaser on any holiday table.

name: Zabaglione trifle slice
description: This dish is inspired by trifle and tiramisu, taking some of the best elements of each
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 425g can pitted black cherry, well drained
directions: For the zabaglione cream, put the egg yolks and sugar into a large bowl. Whisk with an electric hand beater for 2 mins until lighter in colour and falling in thick ribbons. Continue to beat while gradually pouring in the wine, then the marsala. Pour this into a medium, preferably non-stick saucepan. Stir over a lowish heat until it thickens. It takes 5-7 mins, by which time it should thickly coat the back of the spoon and be light and frothy. Pour into a bowl and chill for 45 mins, or better still, overnight.

Meanwhile, slice the panettone and lay it in overlapping slices on the bottom (not up the sides) of a 20cm loose-bottomed, round cake tin (5.5cm deep), pressing the slices down so they completely line the base (you are creating a panettone layer). Drizzle over the 3-4 tbsp of marsala, so each slice gets a little bit, and let it soak in. Tip the drained cherries onto kitchen paper and pat dry (if they are too wet the panettone will go soggy when it thaws), then halve each one to make it easier to cut later.

Whip the cream into soft peaks and fold it into the cold marsala mixture. If it all seems a bit lumpy, give it a quick beat with a wire whisk. Pour the zabaglione cream over the cherries and give it a few swirls so it is slightly undulating on top.
Open-freeze until firm, then cover with cling film and foil, and freeze for up to 1 month.
When ready to use, unwrap and thaw in the fridge for about 2-2½ hrs (it should be quite moussey), then serve, generously dusted with sifted cocoa powder and topped with holly. Serve cut in wedges.
chief_review: This innovative dessert brilliantly marries the richness of tiramisu and the layered indulgence of a trifle. The creamy zabaglione made from egg yolks, sugar, white wine, and marsala gives a luxurious, velvety base, while whipped double cream adds lightness and body. The use of panettone in place of traditional sponge introduces a buttery, festive note, pairing beautifully with the tart sweetness of black cherries. Marsala adds depth and a gentle warmth, complementing the fruity acidity. Finishing with a dusting of cocoa balances the flavors with a touch of bitterness. This recipe is a treat for those who enjoy sophisticated desserts, though it contains both gluten and dairy and is not suitable for those avoiding eggs or alcohol. An inspired and show-stopping end to any celebration, guaranteed to impress.

name: Parsnip & celeriac bake
description: This has become an absolute staple fall/winter side in our house since I first made it 4-5 years ago. We don't have double cream in the Netherlands so I use a lighter cream (slagroom), and it's fine. I also generally use slightly smaller portions of the veggies (300-400g parsnip and 600-800g celeriac) and more sage, but it always turns out delicious no matter how the portions vary.We love it so much!
author: Cathryn Evans
ingredients: 5 tbsp parmesan(or vegetarian alternative), coarsely grated
directions: Cook parsnips in a pan of boiling salted water for 2 mins, then tip in the celeriac and boil together for 8 mins. Drain well, then mash with butter and cream. Season, then add a grating of nutmeg, stir in the sage and spoon into a buttered ovenproof dish. Make up to this stage 1 day ahead or freeze for one month. Defrost in fridge overnight.

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Mix breadcrumbs, Parmesan, almonds and oil together. Season, scatter over the mash, then bake for 35-40 mins from cold, 25-30 mins if not, until topping is crisp and golden.
chief_review: This cozy parsnip and celeriac bake is a brilliant winter side dish, balancing earthy roots with the bright lift of fresh sage and nutmeg. The use of olive oil and a touch of butter create a rich, comforting base, while flaked almonds and coarse breadcrumbs provide delightful texture. Parmesan lends a deeply savory note, but the possibility of substituting with a vegetarian alternative ensures this dish suits vegetarian diets. The absence of meat, fish, and eggs also makes it ideal for lacto-vegetarian options. Those avoiding gluten or dairy should look to swap out breadcrumbs and dairy for suitable alternatives if desired, but as written, this bake offers a warming, rustic addition to festive meals. It’s a perfect showcase for root vegetables, easily adaptable, and sure to become a seasonal favorite.

name: Caramelised carrots & onions
description: The perfect caramelised carrots to accompany any roast - try them alongside your Christmas turkey
author: Cathryn Evans
ingredients: 500g carrot, peeled and cut into long chunks
8 red onions, peeled and quartered with root intact
directions: Blanch carrots in a pan of boiling salted water for 3 mins, drain well, then pat dry. In a large pan, melt the butter and oil, then fry the carrots, onions and thyme over a low heat for 30 mins until golden.

Stir in the sugar and red wine and bubble for a few mins to boil off the alcohol. Add the vinegar, then continue to cook until syrupy, about 5 mins. Remove the sprigs of thyme and serve. Make up to 2 days ahead, stored in a covered container. Tip back into a pan and reheat or use a microwave.
chief_review: This recipe transforms humble carrots into a standout side dish, thanks to a rich blend of butter, olive oil, and gentle caramelisation. The inclusion of both red wine and balsamic vinegar elevates the sweetness of the carrots and red onions, while the brown sugar creates a glossy, flavour-packed glaze. Thyme lends an aromatic note that balances the dish’s sweetness. Though indulgent with butter, this recipe is naturally gluten-free and suitable for vegetarians, making it an excellent choice for most festive tables. Serve these caramelised carrots and onions alongside roast meats or as a centrepiece for a vegetarian spread—they deliver festive flair with minimal effort.

name: Chocolate & chestnut truffle torte
description: This glamorous dessert makes the perfect festive centrepiece for a posh Christmas party
author: Good Food
ingredients: 50g butter, melted, plus a little extra
435g can unsweetened chestnut purée(we used Merchant Gourmet)
2 x 200g/7oz bars plain chocolate, broken (don't use one with a very high cocoa content)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Grease a 25cm springform tin, then line the base and sides with baking paper. Whisk eggs and sugar until pale and thick.

Sift the flour and cocoa together onto the mixture, then gently fold in, followed by the butter. Pour into the tin, ease to the edges, then bake for 8-10 mins until risen and firm to the touch. Cool in the tin.

Meanwhile, beat the chestnut purée and egg yolks until as smooth as possible. Melt the chocolate in a bowl over a pan of simmering water with half the cream. Remove from the heat, then beat into the chestnut mixture.

Whisk the egg whites until stiff. In a separate bowl, whip the remaining cream until it holds its shape. Fold into the chocolate mixture, then carefully fold in the egg whites. Drizzle the brandy, if using, over the sponge base, then pour the chocolate mix on top. Level the surface and chill for 5 hrs or overnight until firm. Chill for 2 days, or freeze for 2 months. Thaw overnight in the fridge.
To serve, carefully remove from the tin, strip off the paper and slide onto a cake stand. Dust heavily with cocoa.
chief_review: This dazzling dessert is truly a showstopper, ideal for an elegant festive gathering. The rich combination of chestnut purée, dark chocolate, and double cream creates an indulgent, velvety texture, with subtle brandy notes elevating the complexity. The recipe delivers layers of deep cocoa and smooth chestnut, perfectly balanced by the creamy finish. For preparation, careful folding of the egg whites ensures a light, airy mousse structure, while the flour keeps the base delicate. Suitable for vegetarians, this dessert avoids gelatine and other animal products beyond dairy and eggs. However, be mindful of potential allergens such as eggs, dairy, and chestnuts. It’s a true chef’s delight, both in flavor and presentation—certain to impress guests and make a memorable statement on your festive table.

name: Butternut squash & sage soup
description: Delicious, easy and comforting. Will make this again.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1.4kg peeled, deseeded butternut squash- buy whole squash and prepare, or buy bags of ready-prepared
bunch chives, snipped, and cracked black pepper, to serve
directions: Melt the oil and butter in a large saucepan or flameproof casserole. Add the onions and sage, and gently cook until really soft – about 15 mins. Tip in the squash and cook for 5 mins, stirring. Add the honey and stock, bring to a simmer and cook until the squash is tender.

Let the soup cool a bit so you don’t burn yourself, then whizz until really smooth with a hand blender, or in batches in a blender. Season to taste, adding a drop more stock or water if the soup is too thick. Reheat before serving, sprinkled with chives and cracked black pepper.
chief_review: This butternut squash soup brings a wonderful balance of sweetness and savoriness, with onions and sage infusing deep aromatic flavors. The use of both olive oil and butter adds richness, while the honey enhances the natural sweetness of the squash. Finished with fresh chives and a dash of black pepper, this recipe delivers a comforting, velvety texture perfect for cooler months. The reliance on vegetable stock keeps it suitable for a vegetarian diet, and the absence of flour or cream makes it gluten-free as well. Ideal for those seeking a cozy, wholesome bowl that’s simple yet elegant.

name: Snow-capped fairy cakes
description: Mary Cadogan’s fairy cakes are a treat for the whole family and they really do taste as good as they look
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: fruit jellies and silver balls, to decorate
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Line 18 holes of a 2 x 12-hole bun tins with paper cake cases. Melt butter and cool for 5 mins, tip into a large bowl with all the cake ingredients, then beat together for 1-2 mins until smooth.

Spoon the cake mixture into the cake cases, filling them three-quarters full (a heaped tablespoon is about right). Bake for 15-18 mins until lightly browned and firm to the touch. Cool on a wire rack.

To make the icing, put the egg white and orange juice into a heatproof bowl, sift in the icing sugar, then set over a pan of simmering water. Using an electric hand whisk, whisk the icing for 7 mins until it is glossy and stands in soft peaks. Remove from the heat, then whisk for a further 2 mins until it is slightly cooled.

Thinly slice the fruit jellies. Spoon the icing onto the cakes, swirling it with a knife, then decorate with slices of jelly fruits and a few silver balls. Leave to set. The cakes will keep for up to 3 days in the cake tin.
chief_review: Mary Cadogan’s fairy cakes are a delightful classic, showcasing a light, buttery crumb lifted by the brightness of orange zest and a hint of vanilla. The use of self-raising flour and eggs creates a beautifully aerated sponge, perfect for tea-time or children's parties. The orange juice in the icing provides a zesty counterpoint to the sweet decorations, with fruit jellies and silver balls adding a playful finish. This recipe suits a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin and relies on dairy and eggs for richness and structure. Overall, these fairy cakes offer a nostalgic yet vibrant flavor profile that is sure to please both young and old.

name: Black & white rice salad with cumin-roasted butternut squash
description: This vibrant Persian side salad is studded with dried fruit, nuts and seeds and finished with crumbled feta - ideal to take along to a Christmas buffet
author: Sabrina Ghayour
ingredients: 1 small butternut squash(about 375g/13oz), peeled and cubed
small pack dill, leaves and stalks finely chopped
small pack flat-leaf parsley, leaves and stalks finely chopped
zest and juice 1 large unwaxed orange
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and line a baking tray with baking parchment. Put the squash on the baking tray, drizzle over the olive oil, scatter on the cumin seeds and season generously – use your hands to ensure each piece is evenly coated with oil and seasoning. Roast for 30-35 mins until the edges are caramelised, then remove from the oven and leave to cool.

Meanwhile, bring a large saucepan of water to the boil. Cook the rice for 20-25 mins or according to pack instructions, then strain and rinse well with cold water until all the starch is washed off and the rice is cold. Allow to drain well.

Put the cranberries, pomegranate seeds, hazelnuts, herbs, onion and rice in a large bowl and mix well. Make the dressing by combining all the ingredients in a bowl with a generous amount of seasoning to taste. Once the squash is completely cool, gently mix it into the bowl of other ingredients. Pour over the dressing, mix well and serve on a large platter with the feta crumbled over the top.
chief_review: This Persian-inspired salad is a well-balanced medley of flavors and textures, combining the natural sweetness of roasted butternut squash, cranberries, and pomegranate seeds with the earthiness of cumin seeds and rice. Toasted hazelnuts impart a pleasing crunch, while abundant fresh herbs brighten the entire dish. The feta crumbles serve as a creamy counterpoint, tying all elements together. The orange zest and honey in the dressing add citrusy acidity and sweetness, elevating the salad with a festive flair—perfect for a Christmas buffet. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet and is naturally gluten-free when prepared with certified gluten-free wild and basmati rice. Its vibrant colors and layered flavors make it a standout side, easily prepared ahead for holiday gatherings.

name: Banana pancakes with crispy bacon & syrup
description: Treat yourself to a lazy brunch with these American-style fluffy pancakes with pancetta and maple drizzle
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 8 rashers smoked streaky bacon(or pancetta strips)
25g butter, melted, plus a little extra
directions: Heat the grill to high. Arrange the bacon on a baking tray lined with foil. Cook for 5-7 mins until crisp, then turn off the grill but leave the tray inside to keep warm. In a bowl, mix the flour, baking powder and sugar with a pinch of salt. Make a well in the centre and add the mashed banana, eggs, butter and milk. Whisk to a smooth batter without any flour lumps.

Heat a little butter in a large frying pan. Once sizzling, ladle in small dollops of the pancake batter, leaving a little space between each, as they will spread out. Put 2 or 3 slices of banana onto the surface of each pancake and cook for 2 mins over a medium heat. When you see bubbles appear between the banana slices, flip the pancakes over and cook for 1 min more, until puffed up and golden. Transfer to a plate and keep warm with the bacon while you cook the rest. Serve the pancakes with the crispy bacon and a drizzle of maple syrup.
chief_review: This brunch recipe brings together classic American-style fluffy pancakes with the savory richness of pancetta and the sweetness of maple syrup—a perfect balance of flavors and textures. The use of self-raising flour and baking powder yields a beautifully light and airy pancake, while the ripe banana adds natural sweetness and moisture. The contrast between the crisp, salty pancetta and the soft, sweet pancakes is delightful, elevated further by the maple drizzle. This dish contains gluten (from flour), dairy (from milk and butter), and eggs, so it's not suitable for gluten-free, dairy-free, or egg-free diets. The inclusion of pancetta makes it unsuitable for vegetarians and vegans. Altogether, this recipe is ideal for those seeking an indulgent brunch with a mix of sweet and savory notes—a real crowd-pleaser for weekend mornings.

name: Chocolate & pecan tart
description: Pecan pie crossed with chocolate tart with a dash of maple syrup - we can't argue with that
author: Matt Tebbutt
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Roll the pastry out on a lightly floured surface and use to line a 20cm loose-bottomed tart tin. Fill the tart with baking paper and baking beans, bake for 25 mins, then remove the baking paper and beans. Continue to cook for 10 mins more until golden. Remove from the oven and cool.

Melt the chocolate and butter together in a large bowl over a pan of simmering water. Whisk the eggs and maple syrup together, then stir into the chocolate with most of the nuts. Pour into the tart shell, top with the remaining nuts and bake for 30-40 mins until set. Cool and serve with vanilla ice cream or double cream.
chief_review: This decadent dessert marries the rich flavors of pecan pie and chocolate tart, elevated by a generous pour of maple syrup. The shortcrust pastry provides a crisp, flaky base, perfectly complementing the dense, chocolatey filling enriched with butter and a custardy blend of eggs and syrup. Whole pecans add a delightful crunch, while their nutty notes play well with the sweetness of maple and the slight bitterness of dark chocolate. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin. While indulgent, balance is key: the salt in the butter enhances flavors, ensuring each bite is satisfyingly complex. Serve this tart slightly warm, perhaps with a dollop of cream or a scoop of vanilla ice cream, for a truly irresistible finish to a special meal.

name: Creamy chicken & mango curry
description: Use korma paste, turmeric and black onion seeds as the base for this mild, Indian spice-pot, made creamy with coconut milk
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp black onion seed(kalonji or nigella)
few coriandersprigs, basmati rice, naan bread, mango chutney, lime pickle and our sides (see 'goes well with'), to serve (optional)
directions: Toss the chicken thighs with 1 tsp of the turmeric and some salt. Heat the oil in a big frying pan or wide flameproof casserole, and brown the thighs well on both sides. Remove from the pan. Add the chopped onion and cook for 5 mins until softened.

Roughly cut all the flesh from one of the mangoes, scraping as much as you can from the stone. Put into a food processor with the korma paste, ginger and quartered onion. Whizz to a paste, then tip into the pan and gently cook until softened.

Stir in the remaining turmeric, cumin and onion seeds and turn up the heat for a couple of mins. Return the chicken to the pan. Stir in the coconut milk and stock. Bring to a gentle simmer, then cover and cook for 20 mins.
Uncover the pan and cook for another 25-30 mins until the chicken is really tender, adding a few drops of water to keep it saucy.

Slice the remaining mango and stir in to heat through while you shred the chicken with two forks. Season and serve scattered with the coriander, with basmati rice, naan bread, chutney, lime pickle and our sides, if you like.
chief_review: This rich, aromatic korma is a masterclass in balancing gentle spices and sweet, creamy notes. The chicken thighs become meltingly tender, absorbing the fragrant base of turmeric, ginger, and korma paste, while coconut milk brings a silky texture without heaviness. Black onion seeds add a subtle, earthy crunch, and ripe mango infuses a delicate sweetness that complements the dish’s mild heat. Fresh coriander finishes the curry beautifully, adding brightness against the warm spices. It pairs perfectly with fluffy basmati rice and accompaniments like naan and chutneys, creating a well-rounded meal. This recipe is gluten-free (if served without naan bread) and dairy-free, making it suitable for those with gluten or lactose intolerances. Overall, it’s an impressive yet approachable curry ideal for family dinners or relaxed entertaining, striking the right chord between comfort and sophistication.

name: Pork & ham pie
description: Gordon's delicious pork pie recipe is perfect for a buffet, picnic or grown-up lunch box
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 140g cooked ham meat (see know-how), chopped into small chunks
450g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, then boil the eggs for exactly 7½ mins. Cool in cold water, peel and set aside. Tip the pork, sausagemeat, ham, sage and onion into a large bowl. Season generously and add a few shakes of Tabasco. Mix well with your hands until completely combined. Take about 1 tbsp of the mix, shape into a small burger and fry in a pan. Taste for seasoning. Slightly over-seasoned is perfect.

Melt a few tbsps lard, brush a 1-litre terrine dish with an even layer of the melted fat, then dust with flour. To make the pastry, tip the flour into a bowl with 2 tsp salt. Put the lard and milk into a pan with 150ml water, then heat until the lard has completely melted. Pour into the flour and beat with a wooden spoon until combined. Tip onto the surface and knead until it all comes together.

Cut a piece of baking parchment to fit the bottom and long sides of the terrine dish with some hanging over the edge. Take about two-thirds of the pastry dough and shape it into a rectangle roughly the width and length of the dish. Lay the dough into the terrine and, using your fingers, press it into the bottom, the corners and up the sides of the dish until it comes to the top and hangs over the rim a little.

Take half the meat mixture and pat it into a shape that will fit the terrine dish, then lay it in. Use your fingers to make a trench down the middle of the meat. Trim the tops and bottoms off the eggs, lay them, in a row, along the trench, then season. Trimming the eggs like this ensures that each slice of pie will contain both egg white and yolk.

Take the rest of the meat mixture, pat it out to a rectangle that will fit over the eggs, and press it over the top. Brush the overhang of the pastry with the beaten egg, then roll out the rest of the pastry to fit over the pie.

Pinch edges together to fix the top. Brush top generously with egg and pierce three holes along the top. Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Place pie on a baking sheet and bake for 30 mins. Lower the heat to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4, then continue to cook for another hour. Leave to cool. Carefully turn dish upside-down onto a board and use the sides of the paper to pull the pie out of the dish. If sides aren’t brown enough, return it to the oven on a baking tray at 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 until coloured. Cool, then chill in the fridge.

If you want to fill the pie with jelly, soak the gelatine in cold water and warm the stock until hot, but not simmering. Remove the gelatine from the water and squeeze to remove excess liquid, then stir into the stock to dissolve. Leave to cool to room temperature, then transfer to a squeezy bottle. Pour the jelly into one of the holes until it comes to the top. Place the pie on a dish in the fridge until the jelly has set, then repeat twice more, so the jelly has filled each hole. Leave to set in the fridge overnight.
chief_review: Gordon’s pork pie is a classic British treat, offering robust, savory flavors with a tender homemade crust. The combination of minced pork, sausagemeat, and chunks of ham creates a rich, meaty filling, beautifully complemented by aromatic sage and a gentle kick of Tabasco. The hot water crust pastry, enriched with lard and made flaky with plain flour and milk, encases the filling perfectly—producing a satisfying contrast in texture. The addition of gelatine, while optional, adds that traditional, jelly-like finish found in the best pork pies. This recipe is ideal for those seeking a protein-filled, wholesome main for a picnic or buffet, though it is not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, gluten-free, or dairy-free diets due to the inclusion of eggs, lard, plain flour, and milk. Overall, it’s an excellent choice for pork lovers craving authentic British fare.

name: Creamed sprouts
description: Go on, add a touch of crème fraîche and some juicy bacon to your sprouts and give them a wicked edge, it's Christmas
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 750g Brussels sprout, trimmed and halved if large
8 rashers smoked streaky bacon, cut into small chunks
directions: Cook the Brussels sprouts in a saucepan of boiling salted water for 8-10 mins until tender, then drain and cool in iced water or under the cold tap. Drain well.

Fry bacon gently in a large frying pan for 4 mins until starting to crisp, then throw in the chestnut pieces and cook until toasted. Add the sprouts and crème fraîche, season, then turn the heat up to boil the cream until it coats the sprouts. Tip into a serving dish and serve straight away.
chief_review: This festive Brussels sprouts recipe elevates the humble vegetable to new heights with the addition of smoky bacon and earthy chestnuts, finished with a rich dollop of crème fraîche for creaminess. The bacon imparts a savory depth and a pleasant chew while the chestnuts add sweetness and texture, making every bite delightful. The crème fraîche balances the ensemble, lending tang and silkiness without overpowering the natural flavor of the sprouts. This dish is a crowd-pleaser, perfect for holiday festivities and pairs beautifully with roasted meats. Suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided all ingredients are checked for hidden gluten. The combination of flavors and textures ensures that even sprout-skeptics will come back for seconds. A seasonal side worth repeating well past Christmas.

name: Crab, avocado & herby hollandaise tarts
description: These versatile crab tarts are perfect for Christmas or celebratory meals
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 8 slices white bread (medium sliced white works best)
400g white crabmeat(we used 2 x 200g tubs Hebridean crab meat from the Waitrose chiller cabinet)
small handful chervil or tarragon, roughly chopped
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Punch out a circle from the centre of each slice of bread using a 10cm round cutter and roll flat with a rolling pin. Brush circles with the melted butter on each side, then press into 8 individual tart tins. Lift onto 2 baking sheets and bake for 10 mins or until tinged with gold at the edges. Carefully flip the cases out from the tins so they are upside down on the trays, then put back into the oven for 5 mins or until crisp and dry. Leave to cool. Can be kept in an airtight tin for up to 3 days.

To start the sauce, put the vinegar, peppercorns and bay leaf into a small pan and bring to the boil. Simmer for about 5 mins or until reduced to about 1 tbsp. Take off the heat, then strain out bay leaf and peppercorns. Will keep covered in the fridge for up to a week.

Halve avocados, stone and peel. Thinly slice avocado, put into a bowl and gently toss with a squeeze of lemon juice. Can be kept covered in the fridge for up to 2 hrs before serving. When ready to serve, put the avocado and a little rocket into each case, then top with crabmeat. Tip vinegar reduction into a tall, narrow jug, then add the egg yolks. Melt the butter in a pan over a medium heat (don’t boil), then add to the jug. Put a stick blender right to the bottom of the jug, turn on and draw very slowly up through the butter. The sauce will thicken as the yolks and butter meld together. Add herbs, season, then add a dash of lemon juice to bring out the herby flavour and cut through the butteriness. Spoon the hollandaise generously over each tartlet so it oozes over the crab. Serve at once.
chief_review: These crab tarts deliver an elegant blend of creamy avocado, delicate white crabmeat, and a subtle herbal lift from chervil or tarragon—ideal as an indulgent starter for festive occasions. The bread base offers a pleasing contrast in texture to the silky filling. The use of fresh egg yolks and butter in the sauce lends a luxurious richness, while lemon juice brightens the flavors. While not suitable for gluten-free or dairy-free diets, nor vegetarians or vegans, this recipe does cater for pescatarians and doesn't include nuts, making it an option for nut-allergy sufferers. It’s best served immediately to enjoy the freshness of the crab and the crispness of the rocket. A refined dish worthy of a holiday celebration.

name: Roast sirloin of beef
description: Gary Rhodes' delicious, succulent roast beef dish is perfect for Boxing Day lunch or an alternative Christmas Day roast. Just four ingredients
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 2 tbsp vegetable oil or beef fat
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Heat the oil or fat in a large fl ameproof roasting tin in the oven for 5-10 mins. Season the beef all over.

Place the joint fat-side down in the roasting tin and put it on the hob. Sizzle to release some of the fat, then turn the beef in the fat to seal and colour it all over, about 5 mins. The joint can now be roasted, fat-side up, allowing 10-15 mins per 450g for medium-rare, 15-20 mins per 450g for medium, 20-25 mins for medium-well and 25-30 mins for well done. Turn the joint halfway through its cooking time for an even roast. Once roasted, remove the beef from the pan and leave to one side, loosely covered with foil, to rest for 15-20 mins.

Meanwhile, pour off any excess fat from the roasting tin, then put the tin on a medium heat on top of the stove. Once it begins to sizzle, pour in the red wine, allowing it to boil rapidly until almost completely evaporated. Tip in the consommé and allow to simmer for 4-5 mins. This will give a light sauce, rather than a gravy (see tip, below). Simmer for a few more mins before straining through a sieve for the smoothest of fi nishes. Carve the beef into thick slices, offering the gravy separately.
chief_review: Gary Rhodes' roast beef recipe celebrates simplicity, relying on quality ingredients and classic technique. The recipe calls for sirloin beef, enhanced with a modest glaze of red wine and enriched with beef consommé, resulting in deeply flavorful, succulent roast meat. Using vegetable oil provides a neutral base, though beef fat amplifies the richness for traditionalists. This minimal-ingredient approach puts the spotlight on the natural taste of premium beef, making it a superb main for festive occasions. This dish fits perfectly into low-carb and paleo diets, as it avoids starchy fillers. However, those with dairy, gluten, or soy allergies can take comfort, as the ingredients are naturally free of these common allergens—assuming the consommé used is pure and additive-free. Serve with simple sides to let the meat shine—a true centerpiece for any celebration.

name: Stollen sour
description: I was really looking forward to this but it was way too sweet for me. Bit disappointing but I should have expected it with what was in it!
author: Miriam Nice
directions: First, make the spiced syrup. Put all the ingredients in a saucepan with 100ml water. Heat gently until boiling, then turn the heat off and allow to cool. Strain through a fine sieve into a jug and chill until needed. Can be made 1 week ahead.
While the syrup is cooling, tip the sultanas, apricot, cherries and cranberries into a small bowl and add the orange liqueur. Leave to steep for around 30 mins (or up to 24 hrs).
When you’re ready to serve, take 4 cocktail sticks and thread 2 sultanas, a piece of dried apricot, a cherry and cranberry onto each one. Fill 4 tumblers with crushed ice.

Pour the amaretto, lemon juice, madeira and 50ml of the spiced syrup into a cocktail shaker (along with any leftover orange liqueur) with a handful of ice. Shake well until the outside of the cocktail shaker feels cold, then strain into the prepared glasses. Add the dried fruit cocktail sticks and serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe offers a boozy and spirited twist, layering dried fruits and aromatic spices with the bold flavors of amaretto and madeira. The combination delivers an intense sweetness, amplified by a generous 100g of golden caster sugar and candied cocktail cherries. The fresh lemon juice and citrus zests endeavor to balance the sweetness, though for some palates it may still be too syrupy. The inclusion of dried fruits and liquor crafts a festive, almost dessert-like cocktail with deep aromatic complexity from the cinnamon, mixed spice, and nutmeg. This drink could appeal to those with a sweet tooth who appreciate rich, vibrant flavors in their beverages. It is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal products apart from the optional cocktail cherries, which are typically vegan/vegetarian but could be checked for additives. Perfect for special occasions, though those favoring drier drinks may want to adjust the sugar.

name: Creamy Savoy cabbage with carrots
description: Savoy cabbage at its best, a great accompaniment to any meal - particularly the Christmas turkey or part of your Hogmanay meal
author: Nick Nairn
directions: Pull off any tough outer leaves from the cabbage and discard. Cut in half, then remove the hard inner core. Rinse the leaves, then shred as finely as you can. Cut the carrots into fine, thin strips or grate in the food processor.

Bring a pan of water to the boil and add the cabbage and carrots. Boil for 6 mins until just tender, then drain. Return to the hot pan and add the butter and cream. Season with pepper, and salt if you like, add the nutmeg and stir well to coat. Pile into a serving dish and serve immediately.
chief_review: This dish celebrates the natural flavors of Savoy cabbage and carrots, elevated by the richness of butter and double cream, with a subtle warmth from nutmeg. The simplicity of the preparation lets the vegetables shine, making it a delightful side for festive roasts or hearty winter meals. The use of dairy introduces a silky texture and depth, beautifully complementing the sweetness of the carrots and the gentle crunch of cabbage. This recipe is gluten-free and suitable for vegetarians, making it a versatile addition to your holiday table. The hint of nutmeg ties everything together, adding a festive aroma without overpowering the dish. For best results, use fresh vegetables and high-quality butter and cream.

name: Blue cheese pasta
description: A great pasta dish that uses up your Christmas storecupboard faves
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp fresh chopped sage, or 1 tsp dried
directions: Boil the pasta according to pack instructions. In a saucepan, melt the butter, then gently fry the onion until golden. Add the garlic and sage, fry for a further 2 mins, then remove the pan from the heat. Drain the pasta and reserve some cooking water. Stir through the buttery onions, stilton and 2 tbsp cooking water, then sprinkle with the toasted walnuts to serve.
chief_review: This festive pasta dish is a clever way to repurpose Christmas staples, combining penne with creamy Stilton, sweet sautéed onions, and earthy sage for a rich, aromatic flavor profile. The toasted walnuts add a delightful crunch and depth, elevating the overall texture. The recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or fish. Make sure the Stilton is vegetarian if needed, as some blue cheeses use animal rennet. The dish strikes a perfect balance between creamy and nutty notes, with the sage adding an herby, seasonal finish. It's comforting, elegant, and quick to prepare, making it ideal for holiday gatherings or an easy weeknight meal.

name: Celebration fish platter with spiced cucumber salad
description: This indulgent sharing platter makes an impressive dinner party starter with trout pâté, crisp coated mackerel fillets and smoked salmon
author: James Martin
ingredients: 1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
50g pickled ginger(I used Clearspring Sushi Ginger)
directions: Start making the pâté by putting the smoked trout, crème fraîche and lemon juice into a food processor. Pulse briefly to bring everything together without the mixture becoming a purée. Season to taste, and put in a bowl or ramekins, cover and chill until ready to serve.

For the spiced cucumber salad, put the chilli in a large bowl, and add the ginger and lime zest and juice, and slowly whisk in the olive oil. Once thoroughly combined, add the cucumber, mix well to coat in the dressing, then set aside in the fridge.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Put the oatmeal on a plate. Lightly brush the mackerel fillets all over with beaten egg, and dip them in the oatmeal, turning to coat them on both sides. Lay the mackerel fillets on a baking sheet that has been lightly greased with olive oil and bake for 15-20 mins or until golden.
To serve, arrange slices of smoked salmon and the warm cooked mackerel on large platters with the ramekins of trout pâté and the cucumber salad, breads, crispbreads, butter and lemon wedges.
chief_review: This impressive seafood platter brings together the richness of hot-smoked trout pâté, the crunch of oatmeal-coated mackerel fillets, and the silky texture of smoked salmon. The clever use of crème fraîche and citrus juices brightens and balances the fish, while pickled ginger and red chilli add zing and subtle heat. Fresh cucumber lends refreshing crispness. Served with a selection of breads and crispbreads, it’s ideal as a luxurious starter for sharing at dinner parties. This dish is a natural fit for pescatarians, and it’s also nut-free, making it accessible for those with nut allergies. The use of oatmeal for the mackerel coating is a creative touch, and the variety of textures and flavors ensures that each bite is distinctive and memorable. Pair with chilled white wine or champagne for a truly special experience.

name: Chocolate, orange & hazelnut cake
description: Do not put all the dry ingredients in as it says to in step 3, as you need the sugar for mixing with the eggs. I made that mistake, so ended up just mixing all the ingredients together as I no longer had a egg/sugar base to fold anything into and no ingredients to start again. It is in the oven, so we will have to see how it turns out. DInner party tonight so I may need to shop for dessert this afternoon!
author: Edd Kimber
ingredients: 175ml light-coloured olive oil, plus extra for greasing
directions: Make the candied orange slices a day ahead if you can. Put the sugar and 300ml water in a medium saucepan and bring to the boil. Reduce to a gentle simmer, add the orange slices and cook for 1 hr-1 hr 10 mins or until the pith is translucent, turning occasionally. Line a baking tray with parchment. Carefully remove the slices from the syrup, place on the prepared tray and set aside to dry (at least 8 hrs) before cutting in half. Reserve the syrup.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Lightly grease a loaf tin (mine was 900g) with olive oil and line with a strip of baking parchment.

Grind the hazelnuts in a food processor until they resemble coarse breadcrumbs (do not blitz them too much or they will become oily), then add to a bowl along with the orange zest, a pinch of salt and the rest of the dry ingredients. Mix together until evenly combined.

Pour the oil and the orange juice into a jug and mix together. Put the eggs and sugar in a tabletop mixer or large bowl and whisk together for 5-10 mins or until the mixture has tripled in volume and holds a ribbon on the surface when the beaters are lifted out. Slowly pour the oil mixture into the egg mixture and fold together until combined.

Add the flour mixture to the egg mixture in 3 or 4 additions, folding together until combined. You can’t sieve this mixture over the eggs because of the hazelnuts, but try not to dump the flour in one place – you need to be careful and fold the batter to retain its lightness. Once fully combined, pour the batter into the prepared loaf tin and bake for 50-55 mins or until a skewer inserted into the centre of the cake comes out clean.

Prick the top of the cake all over, then pour over 5 tbsp of the reserved orange syrup. Cool in the tin for 15 mins, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely. Trim the top of the cake (keep this for a mini trifle) and turn out, cut-side down, onto a serving platter.

To decorate, pour the orange juice into a small pan and bring to a simmer. Put the chocolate in a small bowl, pour the orange juice over and stir together to form a smooth ganache. Set aside in the fridge until thickened, about 20-25 mins. Tip the hazelnuts into a small bowl and add the gold powder with a dash of water, stirring together to coat. Put the ganache in a piping bag fitted with a small round piping tip. Pipe in peaks over the top of the cake, decorating with the golden hazelnuts and the orange slices. Will keep for up to 3 days in an airtight container.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a delightful combination of orange, hazelnut, and dark chocolate—delivering a sophisticated dessert with both nutty and citrus notes. Using olive oil instead of butter and dairy-free dark chocolate makes it suitable for a dairy-free diet. The absence of any meat or animal-derived gelatin ensures it aligns with a vegetarian lifestyle. However, the inclusion of eggs means it is not vegan. The use of hazelnuts is worth noting for those with nut allergies. Golden caster sugar, orange zest, and the touch of edible gold powder elevate the visual and flavor profile, making it ideal for a festive dinner party. Technique-wise, remember to separate sugar and eggs for creaming, preserving cake structure. Overall, this dessert delivers both in presentation and flavor, suitable for those seeking dairy-free and vegetarian options.

name: Apricot, bacon & sausage skewers
description: An easy yet impressive dish that gives a contemporary twist on the traditional Christmas trimming
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 16-20 ready-to-eat dried apricots, soaked in port (soaking optional)
directions: Run a knife along the length of the bacon rashers so they stretch a little, spread lightly with the mustard, then cut in half. Use the bacon to wrap a sausage and apricot together, then spear onto short skewers with bay leaves, allowing 2 rolls per person. Roast skewers in the oven with the turkey for 30-40 mins until golden. Serve on the platter alongside the turkey.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a delightful modern take on classic Christmas trimmings, pairing savory streaky bacon with the sweet tang of port-soaked dried apricots and aromatic fresh bay leaves. The use of English mustard adds a sharp, vibrant note that complements the richness of the bacon and sausages perfectly. The assembly is straightforward, making it ideal for entertaining without fuss, yet the result is visually striking and full of complex flavors. Be mindful that this dish is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the inclusion of bacon and sausages, and it may not be ideal for those avoiding pork or with sensitivities to mustard. For a festive gathering where classic flavors are celebrated with a modern twist, this recipe stands out as a showstopper canapé or side.

name: Squidgy chocolate & pomegranate torte
description: This rich dark chocolate sponge makes a great alternative Christmas cake, or dinner party dessert
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 225g unsalted butter, plus extra for greasing
250g dark chocolate(70% cocoa), broken into squares
225g light muscovado sugar, squished through your fingers to remove any lumps
50g plain flour, plus an extra 1 tbsp
100g bar dark chocolate(70% cocoa), roughly chopped
directions: Generously grease a 23cm springform tin, then line the base with parchment. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the butter and chocolate in a medium bowl and gently melt together, either over a pan of simmering water or in the microwave. Stir until smooth, then set aside.

Crack the eggs into a large bowl, add the sugar, then whisk for 5-8 mins with electric hand beaters until thick, mousse-like and doubled in volume. Pour the chocolate mix around the edge of the bowl, then fold together using a large metal spoon until the batter is evenly brown with the odd ribbon of chocolate appearing. Don’t rush this bit, it’s important to preserve the bubbles you’ve so carefully made. Sift over the almonds, flour and ¼ tsp salt, then fold in until even. Slowly pour the batter into the tin, then use a spatula to get every last bit from the bowl. Bake on a middle shelf for 30-35 mins, or until the cake is risen and set on top. Cool the cake in its tin on a rack. The torte may sink and crack a little, which is fine.

For the topping, bring the cream to the boil. Put the chocolate in a bowl with the icing sugar, then tip the hot cream over it. Leave for a few mins, stir until smooth, then let it cool and thicken for 10 mins. Carefully remove the torte from its tin onto a plate, then spread the icing over the top, letting it drip down the sides. Leave to set for a few mins, then scatter with the pomegranate seeds and either chill for a few hours, or serve straight away.
chief_review: This dark chocolate sponge is a decadent dessert that balances intense chocolate flavor with a moist, tender crumb. The use of ground almonds adds a subtle nuttiness and ensures a soft, rich texture—perfect for those seeking an indulgent alternative to a traditional Christmas cake. Noteworthy is the absence of gluten-heavy ingredients; with a minor tweak—substituting the plain flour for a gluten-free blend—it can easily cater to gluten-free diets. Since the cake contains butter, cream, and eggs, it is suitable for vegetarians but not for vegan diets. The pomegranate seeds provide a pleasing burst of freshness and a festive touch, making this dessert as visually appealing as it is delicious. Ideal for dinner parties or special occasions, it’s sure to impress with both flavor and presentation.

name: Apricot & hazelnut stuffing
description: Fantasic as part of the meal - so much more than just a stuffing for the turkey
author: Good Food
directions: Fry onions in the butter. Stir in nuts; fry until golden. Remove from the heat, add apricots, breadcrumbs, parsley and lemon zest. Mix in the egg and season. Use half to stuff the neck end of the turkey; shape the rest into balls.
Put the balls in a buttered baking dish, then drizzle with oil. Bake for 30 mins until golden, or roast them around the turkey.
chief_review: This vibrant stuffing recipe stands out for its delightful mix of textures and flavors, featuring sweet apricots, crunchy hazelnuts, and zesty lemon. The fresh parsley adds an herbaceous lift to the rich base of sautéed onions and buttery breadcrumbs. The addition of an egg helps bind the mixture, creating a cohesive stuffing that can easily double as a savory side dish. Thanks to the absence of any meat products, this recipe is perfect for vegetarians. However, it does contain nuts, gluten (from the breadcrumbs), and egg, so those with respective allergies should be mindful. The use of olive oil for drizzling provides a lovely finish and enhances the aromatic profile. Overall, this is a fresh, modern stuffing ideal for elevating any festive table, and it works wonders beyond just filling a turkey.

name: Crisp honey mustard parsnips
description: Dried mustard adds a slight heat to this sweet parsnip vegetarian side dish
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1kg parsnip, peeled and cut into thumb-width batons
directions: Boil the parsnips for 5 mins, then drain well and let them steam-dry for a few mins. Mix the mustard powder with the flour and plenty of seasoning. Toss the parsnips in the mix, then shake off any excess.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 – you can do this while the turkey is resting. Put the oil into one large, or even better 2, non-stick baking trays (the parsnips mustn’t be crowded if they’re to become really crisp), then heat in the oven for 5 mins. Carefully scoop the parsnips into the fat, turn them a few times, then roast for 30 mins or until golden and crisp. Drizzle the honey over the hot parsnips, give them a little shake, then scatter with flaky sea salt and tip into a serving dish.
chief_review: This sweet parsnip side dish strikes an appealing balance between earthy and piquant, thanks to the gentle heat of English mustard powder contrasting with the honey's delicate sweetness. The use of rapeseed oil maintains a subtle background note that allows the parsnip’s natural flavor to shine. The recipe is vegetarian-friendly and can be adapted for gluten-free diets by substituting the plain flour with a gluten-free alternative. Those following a vegetarian diet will appreciate its hearty, meat-free profile, while the absence of nuts, eggs, and dairy broadens its appeal for guests with common allergies (always check flour and mustard powder labels to ensure allergen safety). Overall, this is an accessible, crowd-pleasing side that's easy to prepare, making it a smart addition to any winter table.

name: Cheeseboard macaroni cheese
description: I've tried lots of recipes for macaroni cheese. This is a good one. It has a good depth of flavour which I think is down to the garlic and mustard flavours. I used apricot stilton, cheddar and brie. Would recommend this recipe.
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 250g mix of cheesesyou have around (we used Cheshire, cheddar and camembert), plus extra hard cheese for the topping
directions: Cook the pasta according to pack instructions, drain and set aside.

Melt the butter in a saucepan, add the garlic and cook for a min until softened, then add the mustard powder and cayenne pepper and cook for 1 min more. Add the flour and stir to make a paste, cooking for about 1 min, until the mix starts to bubble a little. Take off the heat and gradually pour in the milk, whisking with every addition so the sauce doesn’t go lumpy. Return to the heat and cook for 5 mins until thickened, then add the cheeses, stir until melted, and fold in the pasta.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tip the pasta into a baking dish, and top with additional cheese, preferably some hard cheese such as cheddar or parmesan, then bake for 25-30 mins, until golden and bubbling. Allow to cool for 10 mins or so then serve.
chief_review:
This macaroni cheese recipe stands out for its depth of flavour, achieved through the clever addition of garlic and mustard powder. The combination of cheeses—Cheshire, cheddar, and camembert—adds a rich, creamy complexity, while a hint of cayenne pepper offers a subtle warmth. The recipe’s flexibility allows you to use whatever cheese you have on hand, making it easy to personalize.

For those following a vegetarian diet, this dish can be made suitable by ensuring all cheese used is made with vegetarian rennet. It's also a good option for those avoiding nuts, as there are none in the ingredients. However, this recipe does contain gluten, dairy, and is not vegan-friendly. Overall, it’s a classic comfort dish with a gourmet twist, perfect for a hearty, flavorful meal.

name: Easy chocolate truffles
description: I wouldn't say these are easy, but with practice they would be. They are lovely, I made separate dark ones with orange juice and zest, our homemadebyoliver Plum & Brandy Jam and Plum & Amareretto Jam. I also made white chocolate with homemade Gin Rhubarb & Raspberry Jam, I used various toppings, the white chocolate were the favourite, I think because they are sweeter.
author: Good Food
directions: Chop the chocolate and tip into a large bowl. Put the cream and butter into a saucepan and heat gently until the butter melts and the cream reaches simmering point. Remove from heat, then pour over the chocolate. Stir the chocolate and cream together until you have a smooth mixture. Add any flavourings to the truffle mix at this stage (divide the mixture between bowls and mix in liqueurs or other flavourings, a tsp at a time, to taste. Try bourbon, Grand Marnier, coconut rum or the zest and juice of an orange), or leave plain. Cool and chill for at least 4 hrs.

To shape the truffles, dip a melon baller in hot water and scoop up balls of the mixture, then drop the truffles onto greaseproof paper. Or lightly coat your hands in flavourless oil (such as sunflower) and roll the truffles between your palms. You could also use a piping bag to pipe rounds onto greaseproof paper.

Coat your truffles immediately after shaping. Tip toppings into a bowl and gently roll the truffles until evenly coated, then chill on greaseproof paper. Try: crushed, shelled pistachio nuts; lightly toasted desiccated coconut; or roll a truffle flavoured with orange zest and juice in cocoa powder. To coat in chocolate, line a baking tray with greaseproof paper. Melt 100g milk, dark or white chocolate for 10 truffles. Allow chocolate to cool slightly. With a fork, pick up one truffle at a time and hold over the bowl of melted chocolate. Spoon the chocolate over the truffle until well-coated. Place on the baking tray, then chill.

Store in the fridge in an airtight container for 3 days, or freeze for up to a month. Defrost in the fridge overnight. To give as presents, place 8-10 truffles in individual foil or paper cases inside small, lined boxes tied with ribbon. Keep in the fridge until you’re ready to give them.
chief_review: This delightful recipe is a sophisticated take on chocolate truffles, suited for those who enjoy experimenting with flavors and a touch of homemade creativity. The use of premium 70% dark chocolate complements the rich double cream and unsalted butter, creating a decadent and velvety base. Incorporating fruit jams such as Plum & Brandy or Gin Rhubarb & Raspberry, as well as hints of orange zest, brings a playful balance of sweetness and acidity. The addition of white chocolate and varying toppings makes this a versatile and crowd-pleasing treat, with the white chocolate version particularly appealing for those with a sweet tooth. This recipe fits well within a vegetarian diet, as all ingredients are plant-based and free from gelatin or other animal-derived additives. For best results, use high-quality chocolate and fresh dairy. An impressive option for homemade gifts or special occasions.

name: Charred Brussels sprouts with Marmite butter
description:
Just polished off a dish of this on its own for supper.
Outstanding! But then I love marmite and I love sprouts so it's not surprising. I think marmite haters might enjoy this too though, as the taste is savoury rather than marmitey.
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Beat the butter and Marmite together until smooth, then form it into a log on a piece of baking parchment, roll up and twist the ends like a Christmas cracker. Chill in the fridge until you need it.
Boil the sprouts for 3-4 mins, then drain and leave to steam-dry. Heat a

, then add the sprouts and dry-fry them for 4-5 mins or until they start to blacken on the cut sides and at the edges. Take the pan off the heat, then add a chunk of the Marmite butter (keep the rest for another day). Sizzle until the butter has melted and shake the pan gently to coat the sprouts. Season with pepper, but taste before adding salt.
chief_review: This dish of Marmite-glazed sprouts is a bold and comforting combination that will delight lovers of umami flavors. The softened unsalted butter creates a rich, silky coating, while Marmite lends depth without overpowering the palate—a clever touch that tempers its usual intensity. The halved sprouts roast up tender yet crisp, absorbing the savory glaze beautifully. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet but contains dairy, making it inappropriate for vegans or those with dairy allergies. For anyone seeking to impress with something unique and deeply flavorful that still feels homely, this simple preparation is an inspired winner.

name: Honey & spice cookies
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Rub the butter into the flour in a large bowl until you have fine crumbs. Stir in the beaten egg, our
, golden caster sugar, honey and cream of tartar. Stir unil a soft dough forms, then wrap in cling film and chill for 20-30 mins.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Roll out the dough, cut into festive shapes and bake for 10-12 mins on lined baking trays. Dip in melted dark chocolate, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe yields a rich, aromatic biscuit with festive spices creating a warming, fragrant base. The pairing of butter and a touch of honey ensures a tender crumb and subtle sweetness, balanced by the bittersweet finish of dark chocolate. The inclusion of cream of tartar gives a gentle lift, helping to achieve a light, melt-in-the-mouth texture. It’s well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal rennet. However, it is important to note the presence of wheat (gluten), dairy, and egg, which may not suit those with related allergies or intolerances. The combination of spice and chocolate makes this a sophisticated treat for holiday gatherings or as an after-dinner nibble with coffee.

name: Brie, apple & onion tart
description: This was an excellent tart and used up the end of the Christmas cheese. If you only have two onions, then that would be fine. You don't really need three. Just be sure to cook the onions down well so they are very soft and caramelised to go on the tart.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 320g pack ready-rolled all-butter puff pastry, defrosted at room temperature if frozen
1 tbsp olive or rapeseed oil, plus a drizzle
2 tbsp white wine vinegar, plus a splash
small bunch of thyme, leaves picked, plus a few sprigs to serve
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Unroll the pastry sheet onto a large baking tray (leave it on the paper from the pack). If the edges are not straight, trim them with a sharp knife. Score a border, about 1cm in from the edge. Score a criss-cross pattern over the central piece of pastry (this will prevent it from rising too much) and around the border, if you like. Bake for 15 mins.

Meanwhile, heat the oil in a large pan. Add the onions and cook for 10-15 mins until softened and starting to caramelise. Stir in the vinegar, bubble for 1 min more, then add the Dijon mustard and thyme, season well and set aside. Slice the apple thinly through the core so a few slices have a nice star in the middle, and remove any seeds. Toss the slices in a splash of vinegar to prevent them from browning.

The pastry should be puffed and starting to colour. Push down the centre, then spread over the onions. Add blobs of cranberry sauce, then top with the apple slices and brie, overlapping them to cover the tart. Add a few more thyme sprigs, drizzle with a little oil, then put back in the oven for a further 25 mins until the cheese is bubbling and the apple slices are soft. Serve warm or cold.
chief_review: This festive tart is a delightful way to make use of leftover cheeses, with brie lending a rich creaminess that pairs beautifully with the sweetness of caramelised onions, apple, and cranberry sauce. The addition of Dijon mustard and thyme brings an aromatic depth, balancing the richness and cutting through with a hint of sharpness. The all-butter puff pastry forms a crisp, golden base, elevating the dish to elegant simplicity. Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, this recipe excludes meat and fish while embracing the full flavour profile of dairy and eggs present in the cheese and pastry. A perfect centerpiece for a vegetarian holiday spread or as a comforting weeknight main when served with a crisp salad. Just be sure to caramelise the onions thoroughly for the best result—this step is not to be rushed!

name: Mulled wine brownie surprise
description: Has the Wow factor when served at a dinner party!
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 150g unsalted butter, plus extra for the tin
directions: First, make the chocolate domes. Melt the chocolates in the microwave or over a pan of simmering water, then leave to cool slightly. Meanwhile, blow up the balloons to around the size of a honeydew melon. Sit the base of each balloon in a glass and spray the top half with oil – this will ensure the chocolate dome comes off easily.

One at a time, dip the sprayed end of the balloon into the cooled melted chocolate, turning the balloon to get an even coverage of chocolate. Sit the balloons chocolate half up in the glass. Repeat the process with the remaining balloons then leave to chill in the fridge for at least 4 hrs or overnight.

Next, make the brownies. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Butter and line the base of a 20 x 20cm baking tin with baking parchment. Melt the chocolate in the microwave or in a glass bowl over a pan of simmering water. Mix the flour and cocoa powder together with the spices and a pinch of salt, then set aside.
Using an electric

, beat the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy, then whisk in the egg and yolk. Pour in melted chocolate, wine and flour mixture and whisk until just combined. Pour the batter into the tin and bake for 15 mins until just set. Don’t worry if there’s a wobble in the centre – it will set as they cool. Put in the fridge to firm up.

For the butterscotch sauce, melt the butter in a heavy-based saucepan then tip in the sugar and cream, then whisk until well combined. Simmer for 5 mins, whisking occasionally, then remove from the heat and whisk in the vanilla and sea salt. Set aside to cool. All of these elements can be made the day before and kept in the fridge.

To assemble, carefully pop each of the balloons with a pair of scissors, unravelling the balloon so that you are left with a chocolate dome. Carefully put them on a baking tray lined with baking parchment. Cut the brownies into nine portions. Put a piece of brownie on each plate, top each with a ball of ice cream, then top with a chocolate dome. Gently reheat the butterscotch sauce. At the table, pour the hot sauce over the dome for extra pizazz, to reveal the brownie inside.
chief_review: This decadent dessert is a true showstopper for a dinner party, combining the creamy richness of vanilla ice cream with the intense flavors of spiced chocolate and a hint of red wine. The use of both dark and milk chocolates yields depth, balanced with warming spices like cinnamon, ginger, and cloves, making each bite complex and memorable. The addition of a homemade salted caramel sauce, highlighted by a delicate touch of sea salt and vanilla, elevates the dish further. Texturally, the dish shines thanks to clever presentation elements such as chocolate balloons. Ideal for those who appreciate classic desserts with a sophisticated twist, this recipe suits a vegetarian diet, as no meat or gelatin is used. Be mindful, however, of potential allergens such as dairy, eggs, and gluten. Overall, it’s a luxurious combination of flavors and textures, perfect for impressing guests.

name: Butternut, sage & hazelnut quiche
description:
Agree with the other comments regarding vague ingredient amounts for this recipe.
IF IT HELPS - I decided to do this filling with a shop bought pastry case (20cm diameter), and used the following:
2 eggs plus one yolk
150ml milk
150ml double cream
approx 10g sage
250g butternut squash - chunk into 2cm (ish!) chunks and pre roasted
60g feta.
I could've done with reducing the butternut squash amount, as i had egg mixture leftover which I couldn't fit in the case!
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 250g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
50g roasted and chopped hazelnuts, plus 2 tbsp
1 small butternut squash, peeled and cut into chunks
