directions: To make the pastry, put the flour, 50g hazelnuts and ½ tsp salt into a

. Give it a quick pulse to disperse the nuts through the flour, then add the butter and blitz until the mixture resembles rough breadcrumbs. Add the egg and 3 tbsp ice-cold water, and blitz again until the pastry is just coming together – if the pastry feels dry, add a tbsp more water and pulse again. Flatten into a disc, wrap in cling film and chill in the fridge for 30 mins until firm.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Melt the butter in a frying pan. Once foaming, add the sage leaves and fry for a min or so until crisp. Transfer to a plate with a slotted spoon and set aside. Mix the oil with the butter in the pan. Put the squash chunks in a roasting tin, sprinkle over the chilli flakes and some seasoning, then pour over the butter mixture. Toss together so that all the pieces of squash are coated, then roast for 35 mins until tender but holding their shape. Set aside to cool.

Roll the pastry into a circle roughly 3mm thick on a floured surface, then use it to line a deep 25cm tart tin. Prick the base all over with a fork, then return to the fridge for 20 mins to firm up, or chill it in the freezer for a few minutes.
Meanwhile, chop three-quarters of the sage leaves.
the cream with the milk and eggs in a bowl until combined, add a good grating of nutmeg, season well, then stir through the feta, cooled squash and chopped sage.

Line the pastry with baking parchment, fill with baking beans or dried rice and bake for 15 mins until the sides of the pastry are holding their shape. Remove the paper and beans and bake for 10 mins more until the pastry is lightly golden. Reduce the oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3.

Pour the quiche filling into the pastry case, then scatter over the rest of the hazelnuts and sage leaves. Return to the oven for 40-50 mins or until the filling is just set. Cool to room temperature before serving.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a rich, flavorful tart, perfect for autumn with its roasted butternut squash, earthy sage, and creamy feta. The roasted hazelnuts in the pastry add an elegant texture and depth. The combination of double cream and eggs creates a sumptuous custard base that envelopes the filling beautifully. However, the recipe does produce a generous amount of filling—consider reducing the butternut squash as suggested, or reserve some of the egg mixture if using a standard 20cm case. This dish is ideal for vegetarians, as it uses vegetarian feta and contains no meat or fish. Just be aware of hazelnuts and dairy if serving guests with allergies. Overall, a refined tart that would shine as a centerpiece for brunch or a light dinner paired with a crisp salad.

name: Turkey, bacon & chorizo bombe
description: Does the chorizo need cooking first to release the oil before it goes inside the turkey? I'm worried it will make the inside very greasy and oily if it goes in uncooked
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1.6kg boneless, skinless turkeybreasts (1 large or 2 small breasts)
directions: Squeeze the sausages into a bowl or tip in the sausagemeat. Add the garlic, parsley and egg, and squish through with your fingers to mix everything well.

Lay a large sheet of baking parchment on your work surface. Use the bacon to make a large rectangular lattice, weaving the rashers in and out of each other. Place a piece of baking parchment on top, then use a
to roll over the bacon and seal the rashers together.

Butterfly the turkey breast by cutting into one side of it so you can open it like a book. Cover with cling film and use a meat mallet or rolling pin to gently bash it out into a rectangle that fits inside the bacon, with a 2.5cm border of bacon on each side.

To build the bombe, peel the top layer of parchment off the bacon, leaving it lying on the bottom sheet. Arrange the turkey, skinned-side down, on the bacon, then pat the sausage mixture on top. Trim the rounded ends off the chorizo and line them, ends touching, along the middle of the sausage meat mixture. Use the edge of the baking parchment to lift and roll the bacon and turkey into a tight log. Tie the bombe at intervals with string to keep it together, then wrap well in cling film and put in the fridge. Can be prepared, up to this point, and chilled two days ahead.

To cook, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the cling film, then brush the bombe with a little oil, put it seam-side down on a baking sheet, and roast for 30 mins until the bacon has crisped up, then reduce oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 6.

Brush with the maple syrup to give it a sticky finish and continue to roast for another 45 mins or until the middle of the bombe reaches 75C on a digital cooking thermometer (check after 30 mins as oven temperatures do vary). Leave to rest for at least 15 mins before carving into thick slices. Any leftovers are delicious cold. Save the juices from the tin to make gravy.
chief_review: This recipe is rich, hearty, and perfect for those who enjoy bold flavors, especially with the inclusion of chorizo and smoked streaky bacon. The stuffed turkey breast is beautifully complemented by the seasoning from the sausagemeat, garlic, and herbs, resulting in a festive centerpiece. Cooking the chorizo beforehand is advisable, as it helps render out excess oil, ensuring the stuffing remains flavorful without making the dish excessively greasy. This method focuses on maximizing flavor while maintaining a pleasant texture in the filling. The recipe is best suited for omnivores and will be especially appreciated by those who love robust, meaty roasts. It can be a delightful addition to celebratory tables. If you're seeking a special roast with deep savory notes and a touch of sweetness from the maple syrup, this is a dish to try.

name: Brummie bacon cakes
description: These brunch cakes from Birmingham are similar to savoury scones, with cheese, tomato ketchup and Worcester sauce - perfect with eggs
author: Marcus Wareing
ingredients: 225g self-raising flour, plus extra for dusting
25g butter, cold and cut into small pieces
150ml milk, plus 2 tbsp extra for glazing
directions: Heat grill to high and grill the bacon for 10 mins, turning halfway, until crisp. Cool for a few mins. Meanwhile, heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and line a baking sheet with parchment. Sift the flour and ½ tsp salt into a bowl, add the butter, then rub in to the texture of fine breadcrumbs. Cut the bacon into small pieces and add to the bowl with a third of the cheese.

Mix the milk, ketchup and Worcestershire sauce in a jug. Pour into the bacon mixture, stirring briefly, to make a soft dough. Flour the work surface, turn the dough onto it and shape into an 18cm round. Brush with milk, then cut into 8 wedges with a large knife.

Arrange the wedges on the baking sheet and sprinkle with the remaining cheese. Bake for 20-30 mins or until risen and golden brown, and serve warm (or cool on a wire rack, and store in an airtight container). Warm the bacon cakes through in a low oven (140C/120C fan/gas 1) if you’ve made them in advance.
chief_review: These Birmingham brunch cakes offer a delightful savoury twist on scones, with smoky bacon, mature cheddar, and a hint of tang from Worcestershire sauce and tomato ketchup. The bacon adds both texture and depth of flavour, while the self-raising flour base ensures a light, tender crumb. The melted cheese pairs beautifully with the rich, buttery dough, making these an indulgent treat ideal for pairing with eggs at brunch. The recipe contains gluten (flour), dairy (butter and cheese), and eggs may be served alongside as suggested, but not included in the dough. Meat lovers and fans of classic British flavours will especially appreciate these hearty cakes. The preparation is straightforward and suitable for home bakers looking to elevate their brunch repertoire with a comforting, savoury bake.

name: Bubble & squeak cakes
description: Gordon Ramsay's scrumptious potato cakes are perfect for serving with your Boxing Day ham
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 1kg floury potatoes, quartered (I use King Edward)
50g plain flour, seasoned with salt and pepper
directions: Boil the potatoes for 12-15 mins or until tender, then drain and return to the pan over a low heat for 1-2 mins to dry out. Add the butter and mash well. Meanwhile, boil the sprouts for 3-5 mins until just tender. Drain and cool quickly under cold running water. Shake dry, then shred as finely as you can.
Mix the sprouts with the potatoes and season to taste. Leave until cool enough to handle, then shape into 8 round cakes. Tip the flour onto a plate, then coat the cakes, tapping off the excess.

Heat a 5mm depth of oil in a large frying pan and shallow-fry the cakes in 2 batches for 2 mins each side, turning carefully. Drain on kitchen paper and transfer to a baking sheet lined with greaseproof paper. Cool, cover and chill or freeze. Will keep in the fridge for up to 3 days or freeze for up to a month.
Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5 (or if you’ve roasted the ham, leave the oven on while it rests) and reheat the cakes for 15 mins until hot through and crisp on the outside.
chief_review: Gordon Ramsay’s potato cakes are a classic, comforting side: crisp on the outside with a fluffy, flavorful interior. The combination of King Edward potatoes and Brussels sprouts brings a delightful earthiness, while butter enriches every bite. With a basic flour-and-seasoning dredge before pan-frying in olive oil, the result is golden and irresistible—an ideal pairing for Boxing Day ham or any roast. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and can easily please a crowd looking for hearty, meatless dishes. However, take note: with both butter and flour, it’s not suitable for vegan or gluten-free diets. All in all, this is an accessible, well-balanced dish highlighting seasonal vegetables in a simple, yet refined presentation.

name: Baked potato skins with brie & truffle
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 5 large jacket potatoes, cooked, cooled and cut into wedges, or 10 large roast potatoes from Christmas Day, cut in half
drizzle of truffle oil, to serve (optional)
fresh truffleshavings (available from Waitrose), to serve (optional)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 6. Put the potatoes in a large roasting tin and drizzle with the melted butter. Roast for 30 mins or until they start to crisp up and become golden brown.

Scatter the brie and thyme over the wedges and return to the oven for another 15 mins until molten and bubbling. Remove the cheesy potatoes from the oven, drizzle with truffle oil and finish the dish with loads of grated truffle, if you can get your hands on some.
chief_review: This decadent potato dish is a luxurious take on leftover potatoes, combining the earthiness of thyme and the richness of ripe brie with the simple comfort of jacket or roast potatoes. The melted butter adds an indulgent touch, and the optional truffle oil and shavings elevate the flavor profile with a sophisticated umami note. It’s an excellent option for a festive side or a standalone treat. With no meat or fish present, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians but is not vegan due to the butter and brie. Those with gluten sensitivities can enjoy this dish, provided no cross-contamination with gluten-containing items. The creamy texture of brie pairs beautifully with the crispiness of reheated potatoes, creating a delightfully balanced mouthfeel. Overall, this recipe is an elegant, comforting way to reinvent classic holiday leftovers.

name: Sirloin with herby mustard crust & shallot gravy
description: If you're tired of turkey by the time Christmas Day arrives this joint of beef is just the ticket
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1½ kg piece of sirloin, trimmed but not rolled
300g bag of small shallots, trimmed and peeled
directions: Up to 2 days ahead, make the crust. Blitz the bread into crumbs in a food processor, then add the herbs and blitz again until chopped as finely as possible. Tip in the mustard powder, cheese and some seasoning, then pulse until all the ingredients come together. Tip out and knead well, until it’s the texture of crumbly pastry. Flatten with your hands, then lay on a piece of greaseproof paper. Cover with another piece of paper, then roll out to about the thickness of a £1 coin. Remove the top piece of paper, then trim the crust to a rectangle that is just a bit larger than the top of the joint of beef. To store, place on a tray, cover with cling film and keep in the fridge until needed.

Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. To cook the beef, season generously, then heat the oil in a frying pan until very hot. Sear the beef well on all sides, turning it with a pair of tongs when needed. Scatter the shallots for the gravy over the base of a roasting tin with the thyme. Sit the beef on a rack above the shallots, then roast for 1hr, shaking the pan occasionally to turn the shallots. This timing will give you beef still pink in the middle – if you prefer your meat more cooked give it another 15 mins.

When the beef has had its time, remove from the oven. Lay the crust over the fat and peel the paper away like a transfer, then pat the crust down slightly. Return the beef to the oven for 10 mins to crisp up the crust. When the beef is done, leave it on a board for 20 mins to rest.

Meanwhile, make the gravy. Place the roasting tin on a low heat and stir in the flour. Let the flour sizzle and become brown, then pour in the wine and bubble down to a purple paste. Stir in the stock and simmer until you have a good consistency. Season to taste and tip into a small bowl. 5 Slice the beef into thicker slices than normal (the thickness of a finger is perfect) and serve with the gravy and veg (see 'Goes well with').
chief_review:
This sirloin joint offers a festive centerpiece bursting with robust flavors. The crust, composed of white bread, thyme, parsley, English mustard powder, and Gruyère, lends a fragrant, savory crunch that beautifully complements the tender, juicy beef beneath. Shallots add a subtle sweetness, while the red wine and beef stock sauce anchors the dish in rich, umami depth. 

This recipe is suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians to a point—while it does contain cheese and eggs, the primary ingredient is beef, making it best suited for carnivores. It is not gluten-free due to the bread and flour. The use of Gruyère adds a luxurious finish, balancing sharpness and creaminess. Altogether, a refined alternative to turkey, perfect for those seeking a classic, showstopping main course.

name: Sloe gin cranberry sauce
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put all the ingredients in a saucepan. Bring up to a simmer and cook for 5 mins, then take off the heat and leave to cool.
Serve at room temperature.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful celebration of festive flavors, pairing the tartness of fresh cranberries with the aromatic depth of sloe gin and the subtle perfume of juniper berries. The light brown sugar balances the sharpness of the cranberries, resulting in a fragrant compote or sauce that will elevate any roast or dessert. As the ingredients contain no animal products, this dish is both vegan and vegetarian friendly, making it a versatile option for diverse holiday tables. Additionally, the absence of wheat-based ingredients renders it naturally gluten-free. The simple preparation allows the seasonal ingredients to shine, with the sloe gin and juniper echoing classic winter flavor profiles. I’d recommend serving this alongside a nut roast, cheesecake, or even as a sophisticated topping for breakfast pancakes. An elegant yet easy seasonal recipe that will impress both casual and discerning diners alike.

name: Mince pie baklava
description: This 'British baklava' was a huge success with a pretty diverse crowd and I keep getting asked to make it again, so thanks!
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Mix the mincemeat with the pistachios, almonds, orange zest and a good pinch of salt, then set aside. Melt the butter, then use a little to brush the bottom and sides of a 20 x 30cm baking tin. Cut the sheets of filo so they’re the same size as the tin, then cover with a damp tea towel to stop them from drying out.

Press one sheet of filo pastry into the tin and brush with the melted butter. Continue to layer the pastry in this way until you have used up one pack of pastry (around 10 sheets). Evenly spread the mincemeat mixture over. Top with the remaining pastry, continuing to brush the layers with melted butter as you go. Brush the final layer generously with melted butter. Using a very sharp knife, cut deep, diagonal lines all the way through the pastry to form a diamond pattern. Bake in the oven for 1 hr until golden.

Meanwhile, make the syrup. Put the sugar and 75ml water into a saucepan, and cook over a low heat until the sugar has dissolved. Simmer until the syrup is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon. Remove from the heat and stir in the Grand Marnier or brandy. Once the baklava has baked, remove from the oven and increase the temperature to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Pour the syrup over the baklava, then return it to the oven for 5 mins or until the syrup has been absorbed. Leave to cool completely in the tin, then slice into pieces along the diagonal lines. Will keep for up to one week in an airtight container.
chief_review: This inventive ‘British baklava’ offers a delightful Anglo twist on the Mediterranean classic, blending the festive richness of mincemeat with the crunch of pistachios and almonds. The orange zest brings a fresh citrus lift, perfectly complementing the heady depth of brandy or Grand Marnier in the sticky syrup. The flaky filo layers ensure a crisp contrast to the nutty, spiced filling, while the buttery aroma permeates each bite for ultimate indulgence. With no meat products and relying on plant-based ingredients aside from butter, this recipe is an excellent choice for ovo-lacto vegetarians. It’s also naturally alcohol-optional, as the liqueur can be omitted or swapped for orange juice for those abstaining. Serve warm with a dollop of cream or enjoy as a decadent teatime treat. A crowd-pleaser that stands out both for its originality and exquisite balance of flavors.

name: Spicy turkey noodles
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 2 spring onions, thinly sliced on a diagonal
30g salted peanuts (or any other nuts you have left over), roughly chopped coriander and lime wedges, to serve
directions: Cook the noodles according to pack instructions, then drain and rinse with cold water. Set aside. Mix the soy, lime juice and sugar together.
Heat the oil in a large frying pan or

and add the garlic, chilli, turkey and spring onions, fry for around 2 mins, then tip in the noodles and the beansprouts and fry for 1 min more. Pour the sauce into the pan and toss everything together well, working quickly to coat all the vegetables and noodles. Once everything is heated through, season, and tip into bowls. Scatter over the nuts and coriander, and serve with lime wedges for squeezing over.
chief_review: This vibrant noodle dish elegantly balances sweet, sour, and spicy flavors, thanks to the interplay of brown sugar, lime juice, and fresh red chilli. The stir-fried turkey pairs beautifully with crisp beansprouts and the crunch of peanuts, while spring onions and coriander add a burst of freshness. The use of vegetable oil keeps it light, and the soy sauce enhances the savory profile without overpowering. Quick to prepare and keenly satisfying, this recipe is well-suited for those following a dairy-free diet. By substituting the egg noodles with gluten-free rice noodles and opting for tamari instead of regular soy sauce, it can be made gluten-free as well. Likewise, for a nut allergy, simply omit or replace the peanuts with toasted seeds. An inviting, flexible dish sure to become a go-to for a midweek meal.

name: Cumin-spiced roast chicken with pork & pistachio stuffing
author: Stosie Madi
ingredients: 5 cardamom pods, seeds removed and lightly crushed
125g salted roasted pistachios, finely crushed (you can toast pistachios in a pan with a sprinkle of salt to make these)
directions: Make the stuffing by blending the ingredients with 1 tsp salt in a
, taking care not to purée it – a little bit of crunch here and there makes it all the more satisfying. Check the seasoning by frying a tsp of the stuffing and tasting – adjust if you need to.

Put a piece of cling film on a chopping board and dollop on the stuffing, patting it out to rough circle just smaller than the surface of the breast meat to be covered. Make the layer thicker at one end, for the bottom end of the breasts where the meat is thinner – the extra thickness will help to keep it juicy and cook evenly. Cover with cling film and chill for 30 mins to set.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Pat the chicken dry all over using kitchen paper. From the neck end, push your fingers under the layer of skin on the breasts and wriggle them gently to release the skin and open up the pocket for the stuffing. Push right down – you will need to cover the entire breast meat area with the stuffing – but be careful not to tear the skin.

Make the spice rub by combining all the ingredients. Rub it generously over the chicken and inside the cavity, then insert the aromatics into the cavity. Unwrap the stuffing, halve it, then push half under the skin of each of the breasts, thin end first. Cover the chicken loosely with foil so the spices don’t burn.

Roast the chicken for 1 hr 10 mins. Mix 3 tbsp grape molasses with 1 tbsp hot water, brush over the skin, then increase oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and return the chicken for 20 mins to crisp up the skin. Baste twice more with molasses at 5-min intervals. Test the chicken in the thigh and breast to make sure it is cooked – the juices should run clear. Take the cavity aromatics out of the chicken and set aside (don’t worry if you can’t get them all). Leave the chicken to rest for 45 mins somewhere warm, but don’t cover the skin so it stays crisp.

Meanwhile, pour the fat out of the roasting tin (there will be lots, which you can sieve and keep in the fridge for up to a week to use for cooking), leaving the juices behind. Add a little chicken stock and the cavity aromatics to the tin and bring to a boil, then sieve into a pan. Add the rest of the stock, simmer until reduced by half, then stir in 1 tsp grape molasses. Just before serving, add the resting juices from the chicken to the pan and bring the sauce back to the boil. Taste for seasoning and stir in the butter.
chief_review:
This recipe showcases a beautifully complex, spice-forward whole chicken enriched with the sweetness of grape molasses and aromatic accents from cinnamon, cardamom, and cloves. The blend of green grapes and pistachios brings texture and subtle acidity, while the inclusion of pork mince and generous amounts of butter provide depth and richness. The dish leans towards a Middle Eastern-inspired flavor profile, perfect for an adventurous palate. 

This recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, as none of the listed ingredients contain wheat or gluten-containing grains. However, it is not appropriate for vegetarians or vegans due to the use of chicken and pork, nor for those with tree nut allergies because of the pistachios. Overall, this is an indulgent, celebratory dish ideal for lovers of layered flavors and succulent roast meats.

name: Hazelnut & mustard carrots
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Toast the hazelnuts in a dry, non-stick pan until golden. Leave to cool a little, then roughly chop or crush using a
the mustard with the vinegar and sherry, then slowly pour in the oil, whisking all the time. Season and set aside.

Boil the carrots for 3-4 mins or until just tender, drain and tip back into the pan. Pour over the dressing, stir to coat, cook over a low heat for 1-2 mins, then tip into a serving dish. Scatter over the hazelnuts and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant carrot salad is a delightful medley of sweet and tangy flavors, brought together by crunchy hazelnuts and a sherry-mustard vinaigrette. The steps are straightforward, making it a reliable side dish for both home cooks and professionals. The balance of earthy carrots with the richness of hazelnuts and the zip of Dijon and vinegar elevates the humble root into something elegant. The use of vegetable oil keeps the dressing neutral and allows the nutty and sharp notes to shine. Since all the ingredients are plant-based, this recipe is perfectly suited for vegetarians and vegans alike. It’s also naturally gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for those with gluten intolerance. Ideal as an accompaniment to heartier mains or as a refreshing stand-alone dish, this salad showcases how thoughtful ingredient pairing transforms simple produce into refined fare.

name: Turkey & chestnut gravy
description:
This recipe is in the "make ahead" section.
It starts with "Once the turkey has cooked and is resting on a board".
Fail.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: pan juices from the turkeyroasting tin or 2 tbsp goose fat or butter
directions: Once the turkey has cooked and is resting on a board, carefully pour the juices from the roasting tin into a large heatproof jug. Leave to settle, then pour all of the fat into a separate jug. Put 2 tbsp fat in a saucepan and carefully dispose of the rest. If you have lots of pan juices left after skimming the fat off, substitute this for some of the chicken stock. Alternatively, put the goose fat or butter in a saucepan.

Put the saucepan with the fat in on the heat and add the giblets. Cook for 10 mins or until golden, then add the flour. Cook for 2-3 mins, then add the white wine and stir well. Pour in the chicken stock, then add the thyme and bay. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 25-30 mins or until reduced by half, then stir in the chestnut purée.
Strain the gravy into a jug, discard the herbs and giblets, season and serve with turkey.
chief_review: This make-ahead turkey gravy recipe is a classic, rich in flavor thanks to the use of pan juices or goose fat, turkey giblets, white wine, and chestnut purée for extra depth. Aromatics like thyme and bay leaves elevate the taste, while the use of chicken stock creates a silky, robust base. It’s perfect for holiday gatherings where prepping ahead is a must. The recipe does contain gluten (from the plain flour) and is not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or those with poultry or tree nut allergies (chestnut purée). The instructions cleverly maximize flavor by integrating both the cooked turkey’s essence and fresh, earthy notes from the chestnuts, giving you a sophisticated, restaurant-quality gravy that will impress any guest at the table.

name: Turkey Bánh mì
description: Use up leftovers from a Sunday roast such as turkey and red cabbage in this vibrant Vietnamese sandwich
author: Emily Kydd
ingredients: ¼ cucumber, thinly sliced on the diagonal
1 red chilli, ½ finely chopped, ½ finely sliced
directions: To make the pickled slaw, tip the carrots and cabbage into a large bowl. In a small bowl, combine the ginger, rice vinegar, sugar and a few pinches of salt. Pour over the vegetables and toss together. Set aside for at least 15 mins.

Halve the baguettes lengthways and spread the pâté over the bottom half. Top with the pickled slaw, cucumber and turkey. Mix the mayonnaise with the chopped chilli and dollop over the top. Scatter over the mint leaves and sliced chilli. Sandwich together and dig in.
chief_review: This inventive Vietnamese-inspired sandwich cleverly repurposes Sunday roast leftovers, notably turkey and red cabbage, delivering a vibrant balance of flavors and textures. The use of chicken liver pâté and mayonnaise adds a luscious richness, while fresh cucumber, mint, and carrot lend crunch and brightness. The pickled red cabbage and ginger bring a subtle zing, elevated by the heat of red chilli. The baguette provides a satisfying, crusty vessel, typical of a classic Bánh mì. This recipe would suit those following a dairy-free or nut-free diet, given the conventional ingredients, though always check labels for hidden allergens. Overall, this sandwich offers a delightful twist, perfect for an adventurous palate keen on minimizing food waste.

name: Next level Dauphinoise potatoes
description: Excellent dish - best we've ever had
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 50g butter, plus extra for the dish
2½ kg Maris Piper potatoes or Desirée potatoes, all roughly the same size, peeled
directions: the bay and thyme, then put into a
with the cream, crème fraîche, nutmeg and one half of the garlic clove. Season generously. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 2 mins. Set aside to cool and infuse.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 6. Sprinkle the cut side of the remaining half of garlic with salt and use it to rub the inside of a large rectangular gratin dish. Lightly butter the dish. Melt the remaining butter in a saucepan.

Thinly slice the potatoes using a mandoline and stack them in piles. Tightly pack the stacks widthways in the dish, standing on their side, using only as many as will snugly fill the dish. Strain the warm cream over the potatoes, pressing down on the herbs as you do so. Bake for 1 hr or until the potatoes are cooked through and crisp on the top, brushing with the melted butter halfway through. Leave to cool for about 10 mins, then serve scooped straight from the dish.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a luxurious and comforting potato dish, perfect for special occasions or as a hearty side. The combination of double cream and crème fraîche creates an exceptionally rich and silky texture, while aromatic bay leaves, thyme, and a hint of nutmeg elevate the flavor profile beyond the classic gratin. Using quality potatoes such as Maris Piper or Desirée ensures a creamy yet structured result after baking. The inclusion of butter adds another layer of indulgence, and the subtle garlic notes balance the overall richness beautifully. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal-derived rennet. It’s an excellent choice for impressing guests or treating yourself to a refined classic—simple ingredients, expertly executed, yield sumptuous results.

name: Hasselback potato gratin
description: A Scandinavian bake with herbs and butter - cutting the spuds really thin helps them to crisp up nicely
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1kg medium potato, such as Maris Piper
50g butter, melted, plus extra for greasing
2 tbsp each of thymeand rosemary, finely chopped
directions: Lightly grease a large oval baking dish. Using a mandolin or sharp knife, slice the potatoes into thin slices, about 3mm thick. Tip into a bowl and coat with the melted butter, oil, herbs and some seasoning.

Tightly pack the potatoes upright into the dish. Wedge some bay leaves throughout and pour over the remaining butter mixture from the bowl over the top. Cover with foil and bake for 30 mins at 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Remove the foil and cook for a further 45 mins at 220C/200C fan/gas 7, until the potatoes are cooked through.
chief_review: This Scandinavian-inspired bake elevates the humble potato with a delightful blend of fresh herbs and rich butter. Slicing the potatoes thinly ensures irresistibly crisp edges, complemented by the earthy flavors of thyme, rosemary, and aromatic bay leaves. Using a mix of olive oil and melted butter adds both depth and silkiness to the dish. The simplicity of the ingredients highlights the natural flavor of the potatoes, making it a perfect choice for a hearty side or a comforting centerpiece. Suitable for vegetarian diets, this recipe is an excellent addition to any table, especially for those who appreciate classic techniques with a herby twist.

name: Juniper & apple red cabbage
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 1½ kg red cabbage, quartered, tough core removed
4 red apples, peeled, cored and chopped
directions: Thinly slice the red cabbage, then put in a large saucepan along with the rest of the ingredients.
Bring to the boil, stirring regularly, then cover and cook over a low heat for 1 hr or until tender and the liquid has been absorbed, stirring occasionally. Season to taste.
chief_review: This braised red cabbage recipe beautifully balances sweet, tangy, and earthy flavors, making it a standout side for winter roasts or holiday tables. The combination of red onion, apples, orange zest, and juniper berries infuses the cabbage with complexity, while cider vinegar and apple juice add brightness and depth. The light brown sugar enhances natural sweetness, and a touch of butter enriches the final dish. This recipe is naturally vegetarian and gluten-free, provided that the cider vinegar and apple juice are certified gluten-free, and it’s wonderfully suited to most diets except those that avoid dairy. Its straightforward preparation and flexible nature allow it to pair well with both traditional meats and plant-based mains. An excellent choice for festive gatherings or as a vibrant accompaniment to everyday meals.

name: Parmesan roasties
description: The best roast potatoes! They were perfect side dish for Christmas lunch
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 2kg floury potatoes, peeled and cut in half, or quarters if large
directions: Boil the potatoes in a large pan of water for 12 mins, drain, leave to cool, then put into the fridge until you’re ready to roast them. Can be done a day ahead.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Pour the oil into a large, deep roasting tin, then put in the oven. Tip the polenta into a large casserole dish and season well. Add the potatoes, and turn them over to coat.
Take the tin of oil out of the oven and, using tongs, carefully add the potatoes. Turn them over and sprinkle any remaining polenta over the top, then return the tin to the oven for 30 mins.
Scatter the parmesan over the potatoes, turn them to coat, then return to the oven for a further 20 mins, or until crisp and golden.
chief_review: These roast potatoes deliver a wonderfully crispy exterior thanks to the combination of sunflower oil and a light dusting of fine polenta, while the interior stays fluffy and tender—an ideal texture balance for a classic side dish. The addition of finely grated parmesan adds a deep savory note as well as extra crunch. This recipe is a fantastic choice for those seeking a vegetarian-friendly dish with bold flavor and simple ingredients. Using floury potatoes ensures absorbent, pillowy results, and the method is straightforward enough for even novice cooks. Perfect for holiday gatherings or enhancing any special meal.

name: Sourdough bread sauce
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 2 large shallots, peeled and root cut off
1 tsp dark rye flour or wholemeal flour
directions: Blitz the bread to crumbs in a

and stud the shallots with the cloves. Put the shallots in a saucepan with the bay leaves, peppercorns and milk. Heat gently for 20 mins, then pour the mixture through a sieve into a clean pan and discard the aromatics.
Heat the infused milk until simmering, then add the flour, breadcrumbs, butter and nutmeg. Add the cream and buttermilk, and season well. Cook for 6-8 mins more or until the sauce has thickened.
Reheat gently on the hob before serving, and sprinkle over the thyme leaves, if using.
chief_review: This recipe builds a beautifully aromatic dish thanks to infusions of shallots, cloves, bay leaves, and nutmeg within a creamy milk base. The addition of sourdough bread lends a rustic texture and depth, while the blend of double cream, buttermilk, and a touch of butter promises richness and smoothness. Using wholemeal or rye flour instead of refined white flour offers a slight nutty note and some extra fiber. The finished dish, optionally garnished with fresh thyme, would be a sumptuous accompaniment to roasted meats or vegetables. Suitable for vegetarians (provided no animal rennet in the dairy) and those seeking a comforting, indulgent side, this recipe is a testament to the elevation of simple ingredients through careful layering of flavor.

name: Refried roasties
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 10 small pickled onions, cut in half
a few thyme sprigs, leaves picked
500g leftover or defrosted frozen cooked roast potatoes
directions: Heat 1 tbsp oil in a large

over a medium heat, add the pickled onions and fry for 3-4 mins until they get nicely caramelised. Add the cayenne and thyme leaves, then tip the roasties into the pan along with another 1 tbsp oil. Use the back of a wooden spoon to squash each one slightly. Leave alone for 3-4 mins to fry and get extra crisp on one side, then give them a good toss.

Add the remaining oil, toss and fry again for extra crispiness. Don’t worry if they fall apart a little, the scuffed bits will get extra crisp. Season to taste and serve warm with your Christmas leftovers.
chief_review: This simple yet flavorful recipe combines the richness of olive oil with the tangy sharpness of pickled onions and a gentle heat from cayenne, all lifted by aromatic thyme. Using leftover or previously frozen roast potatoes is not only efficient but provides a satisfying texture contrast between the crispy exterior and fluffy interior. The dish is naturally suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, as it contains no animal products. Additionally, it is gluten-free, making it an appealing option for those avoiding gluten. The bold flavors work wonderfully as a side or a hearty addition to brunch. Overall, an excellent way to transform leftovers into a dynamic, crowd-pleasing plate.

name: Gratin of fresh & smoked salmon, beetroot, potatoes & dill
description: We really enjoyed this gratin as it wasn't as creamy as a lot of them are. It was easy to make although it did take a lot longer than 25 mins to prepare. We thought it needed more smoked salmon next time we cook it but overall a great dish to serve anytime! 8/10
author: Diana Henry
directions: Using a sharp knife, cut the salmon into slices about ½cm thick (if there's skin on your salmon, leave it behind as you cut each slice). Tear the smoked salmon into pieces.
Cut the potatoes into wafer thin slices as if you were making Dauphinoise potatoes. It’s best (and certainly quickest) to do this with a mandoline.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and put in a baking sheet to heat up. Mix the creams and the milk in a large saucepan, and bring to just under the boil. Add the potatoes and cook gently for 5 mins, carefully turning the potatoes over from time to time. Cut the beets into slices about 2mm thick.

Season the potatoes and cream and butter a 22 x 30cm baking dish. Spoon half of the potatoes into the dish and spread them out. Put half the beetroot on top of that, then half the fish. Season and add half the dill. Now add the rest of the beetroot and fish, seasoning again and adding the dill. Spoon the rest of the potatoes on top. You don’t need to arrange the top layer of potatoes nicely unless you really want to.

Bake for 1 hr, or until the potatoes are completely tender and the top is bubbling (it may need an additional 10 mins). Serve with a green salad or, if you want something more comforting, warm cabbage.
chief_review: This salmon and potato gratin delivers a comforting, hearty flavor profile while steering clear of the overly rich consistency typical of traditional gratins. The duo of fresh and smoked salmon imparts a subtle but enticing smokiness that could be amplified with a bit more smoked salmon, as suggested. The beetroot adds earthiness and vibrant color, and the dill brings freshness that balances the creamy base. Preparation is straightforward, though expect to spend more time than the recipe states—patience pays off here. This dish aligns well with pescatarian diets and is naturally gluten-free, making it a versatile main course option. Serve with a crisp green salad or cabbage for welcome contrast in texture. A solid 8/10—elevated home cooking at its best.

name: Prosciutto & rosemary potatoes
description: These simple canapés are small but perfectly balanced
author: Good Food
directions: Cook the baby new potatoes in salted boiling water until just tender. Cut the prosciutto slices in half lengthways and wrap one length around each new potato, tucking small sprigs of rosemary underneath, then secure with a toothpick. Place in a baking tray, drizzle with olive oil, then season well. Bake at 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 for 25-30 mins until very crisp and golden. Serve warm or at room temperature.
chief_review: This canapé recipe beautifully balances earthy baby new potatoes with the saltiness of prosciutto and aromatic rosemary, all brought together by a light olive oil drizzle. The method allows the potatoes to absorb the flavors fully, resulting in bite-sized appetizers with great texture—a satisfying contrast between the soft potato and crisped prosciutto. This dish is tailored for a gluten-free diet, as it omits wheat and common gluten-containing ingredients. The use of simple, whole foods also makes it suitable for those following a clean-eating approach or looking to minimize processed ingredients. In terms of presentation, the rosemary sprigs add a touch of elegance and an extra note of fragrance, making these canapés an excellent choice for sophisticated gatherings.

name: Bao buns with spicy pork
description: This is a great recipe and the filling was absolutely on point, thanks :)
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 tsp cornflour, dissolved in 1 tbsp rice wine
directions: First, make the filling. Finely dice the pork. Heat the oil in a frying pan and brown the meat until cooked through (about 6 mins). Add the spring onions and sauté for 1 min, then add the hoisin and soy sauces and the honey, five-spice powder, chilli flakes and cornflour mix. Simmer for 5 mins, then transfer to a bowl and chill.

In a measuring jug, mix 200ml warm water with the yeast and oil. To make the dough by hand, put the dry ingredients in a mound on your work surface with a good pinch of salt. Make a hole in the middle, pour in the yeast mixture and slowly stir until it comes together. Knead on a floured surface for 10 mins or until the dough is soft. Or to use a standing mixer, put the dry ingredients in the bowl with a good pinch of salt. Turn on and pour in the yeast mixture. When the dough comes together in a ball, keep the speed on medium and knead for 8-10 mins until smooth and soft. Put in an oiled bowl and cover with cling film. Keep in a warm place until doubled in size (about 2-3 hrs).

Take the dough out, knock it back and knead for 1 min, then put on a floured surface. Cut into 2 pieces and roll each into a fat cylinder. Cut each into 16 pieces. Press a couple of pieces flat (about 7.5cm wide). Put a disc in the palm of your hand and add 1 tsp of the filling. Bring the sides up and pinch together at the top. Repeat with the remaining dough and filling.
Cut circles of baking parchment and put under each bun. Arrange the buns on a baking tray so they don’t touch each other. Leave to rise for another 30 mins.

Make sure your steamer fits snugly over a pan or use a regular steamer with a pan and lid. Fill the bottom pan with water and bring to a boil. Set the steamer with the buns and their liners over the pan and cook for 10-12 mins. You will need to do this in batches. Remove and eat straightaway with chilli sauce.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a wonderfully balanced filling, harmoniously blending the sweet, savoury, and spicy notes so essential in great Asian-inspired dishes. The pork fillet emerges tender and flavorful, absorbing the hoisin, soy, and honey sauce beautifully, while the five-spice powder and chilli flakes add an aromatic lift. Use of spring onion brings a necessary freshness that cuts through the richness of the filling. The slightly sweet, fluffy bun complements the robust filling perfectly. This dish is suitable for dairy-free diets if the milk powder is omitted or replaced, and it can work for those avoiding nuts, as no tree nuts or peanuts are present. However, it does include gluten, so it is not suitable for gluten-free diets. Overall, an excellent and satisfying recipe, ideal for a homemade take on a classic favourite.

name: Bourbon cocktail
author: Jennifer Joyce
directions: Put all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with some ice. Shake together, then pour into Martini glasses, add the zest, and serve. Alternatively, serve over ice in highball glasses.
chief_review: This spirited cocktail offers a sophisticated balance of flavors, marrying the warmth of bourbon with the rich depth of crème de cacao and a bright citrus kick from lemon juice. The addition of grenadine and golden caster sugar rounds out the profile with a hint of sweetness, while pared orange zest provides an aromatic flourish. The absence of dairy, eggs, and wheat-based ingredients makes this drink suitable for a vegan and gluten-free diet, provided that each alcohol used is certified vegan and gluten-free by the manufacturer. It’s an excellent choice for those seeking a refined, dessert-inspired tipple that’s as visually appealing as it is delicious. Serve well-chilled in a coupe glass for a truly elegant presentation.

name: Honey-crushed swede
description: This sweet and spiced side dish pairs beautifully with meats such as glazed ham, roast chicken or sausages
author: Tom Kerridge
directions: Put a pan of salted water on to boil. Add the swede and simmer for 20-25 mins until tender. Drain the swede, tip back into the pan and add the mace, butter and honey. Season and crush everything together gently with a potato masher.
chief_review: A splendidly simple yet deeply flavorful dish, this sweet and spiced swede mash showcases the vegetable’s earthy character, uplifted by warm mace and a luxurious sweep of butter. Honey lends a gentle sweetness that beautifully offsets the mild bitterness of swede, making it a harmonious companion to robust meats like glazed ham or roast chicken. The use of butter and honey means this recipe is ideal for those following a vegetarian diet, though it would require substitutions for vegans or dairy-free guests. The minimal, naturally gluten-free ingredient list also makes it appropriate for those avoiding gluten. The overall effect is rustic comfort with a subtle, aromatic twist—a delightful side to enrich any hearty meal.

name: Beetroot & blackberry cured salmon
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 800-1kg side of salmon, pin-boned and scaled
directions: In a

, combine the ingredients for the beetroot and berry cure. Unravel some cling film but keep it attached to the roll. Spoon a bit of the cure on the cling film then lay the salmon, skin-side down, on top and pack the rest of cure over the flesh. Roll the fish tightly in cling film to create a package. Put the package in a shallow baking dish or shallow-sided tray and lay another tray on top. Weigh the tray down with a couple of tins and put in the fridge for two days, turning the salmon over occasionally.

On the second day, remove the salmon from its wrapping and scrape off any excess cure. Gently rinse the remaining cure off the salmon and pat dry with kitchen towel. In a bowl, combine the chopped dill with the peppercorns, horseradish and gin. Prepare another piece of cling film for the salmon and cover all over with the herb mix. Wrap the salmon up again as before. Put it in the baking tray, weigh it down, and leave, for at least another 8 hrs. Remove the salmon from its wrapping and transfer to a board. Finely slice and serve with sourdough crackers and pickles. Will keep in the fridge for up to three days.
chief_review: This berry and beet-cured salmon recipe is an elegant showcase of Nordic-inspired flavors, perfect for impressing at festive gatherings or refined brunches. The blend of brown sugar and sea salt creates a classic cure, while the addition of blackberries or elderberries and raw beetroots imparts a vivid, jewel-toned color and subtle earthy sweetness. Juniper berries and gin infuse a fragrant, sophisticated botanical note, harmonizing beautifully with fresh dill and the gentle heat of horseradish. White peppercorns add a light, aromatic spice, balancing the overall flavor profile. The recipe suits pescatarians and is naturally gluten-free and dairy-free, making it an inclusive option for guests with diverse dietary needs. Serve thinly sliced, paired with rye bread or simple greens, to let the nuanced flavors shine. This dish is a testament to how curing elevates salmon with both taste and striking visual appeal.

name: Duck liver parfait, cherry compote & sourdough croutes
description: How long can this be done in advance?
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 400g duck livers, trimmed of sinew and roughly chopped
8 slices of sourdough, cut into bite-sized pieces (if making canapés)
directions: Heat a piece of the butter in a frying pan. Once melted and sizzling, add the shallots, thyme, peppercorns and coriander seeds with a pinch of salt. Cook, stirring, for 3-4 mins, until the shallots begin to colour, then turn up the heat slightly, add the livers and cinnamon and cook for 3-4 mins. Splash in the madeira and bubble until reduced by about half. Transfer to a bowl to cool and grate over some fresh nutmeg.
Once cool, transfer the mix to a

, add the butter and Grand Marnier and blitz. Check for seasoning, then pass through a fine sieve. Pour into ramekins or small bowls, leaving a gap for the cherry topping, and place in the fridge to set.

To make the cherry glaze, very gently melt down 80g of the cherry compote with the vinegar and a pinch of salt. Allow to cool slightly, then top the parfait with the cherry mix. Return to the fridge to set for a couple more hours. Can be made up to two days in advance.

To make the sourdough croutes, heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Toss your sourdough with a really generous pinch of salt, a good drizzle of olive oil and the thyme leaves. Roast in the oven for 15-20 mins until crisp and golden. The croutes can be made a day ahead and kept in an airtight container. Let guests spread the parfait over of the croutes and enjoy.
chief_review: This duck liver pâté recipe is a sophisticated appetizer that shines with layers of flavor—aromatic shallots and thyme, subtle spice from coriander seeds and cinnamon, heightening savory-sweet duck livers, and finished with a touch of Grand Marnier and Madeira for depth. The cherry jam with sherry vinegar brings acid and fruit to balance the richness, while crisped sourdough offers delightful texture. Given the presence of both butter and duck livers, this recipe is suitable for a standard omnivorous diet. It’s also ideal for making in advance—prepare the pâté up to two days ahead, allowing the flavors to develop, and toast the sourdough just before serving for best results. Serve as elegant canapés at your next gathering; the harmony between earthy, sweet, and subtly spiced is sure to impress.

name: Sprout remoulade
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Trim the bottoms off the sprouts, discard any damaged outer leaves and cut them in half. Chop the sprouts in a food processor until they are finely shredded – you can use a grater attachment if you have one, but it’s not essential. Tip into a large bowl, pour over the lemon juice and give the sprouts a good toss with your hands to combine.
Mix together the mayo, crème fraîche and mustard with some seasoning. Just before serving, tip into the bowl with the sprouts, along with the parsley. Mix well and season to taste.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts salad is a refreshing and creamy dish that highlights the natural earthiness of the sprouts with a zesty lemon tang. The dressing, made from mayonnaise, crème fraîche, and wholegrain mustard, creates a rich, velvety texture balanced by the bright acidity of citrus and the freshness of chopped parsley. It’s an excellent option for a quick side or light lunch, especially for those following a vegetarian diet. The recipe is naturally gluten-free, provided all condiments used are certified gluten-free. Its straightforward ingredient list caters well to family meals or entertaining, delighting guests with both flavor and texture.

name: Rocky road cheesecake pudding
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 x 200g ready-made chocolate loafor marble loaf cakes
edible glitter, chocolate truffles, sprinkles and sparkles, to decorate (optional)
directions: Line a 2 litre pudding bowl with cling film, leaving some overhanging to cover the top later. Thinly slice the cakes lengthways (8-9 slices per cake) and use the slices to line the base and sides of the bowl, making sure there are no gaps.
Mix the ingredients for the filling with an electric hand
until thick and smooth. Fill the lined bowl with it, leaving some space for the rocky road to go on. Set aside.

Break the chocolate for the rocky road into pieces in a heatproof bowl. Add the butter and golden syrup. Set over a pan of simmering water and leave for a few mins until melted – turn the heat off if the water boils, the residual heat will be enough to melt it. Stir until smooth and glossy.
Tip the biscuits into a food bag and crush to a rubble with a

, creating some fine crumbs and some bigger pieces. Tip into the chocolate mix with the pretzel pieces and marshmallows. Mix until everything is coated in chocolate. Spoon it all over the cheesecake, covering the surface. Wrap the bowl in cling film and place a plate on top with a can to weigh it down.

Decorate the cheesecake on the day you want to serve it. Heat the cream, chocolate and golden syrup in a pan over a low-medium heat until the chocolate has melted and you have a pourable mixture – don’t let it boil. Unwrap the cheesecake and turn onto a
with a tray underneath. Pour over the chocolate glaze to cover the entire cake. When it stops dripping, use a fish slice to transfer to a plate. Chill until the glaze has set (about 10 mins).
Meanwhile, melt the white chocolate in shorts bursts in the
. Drizzle it over the top of the cake, then decorate as you like. We used edible glitter, gold sprinkles and chocolate truffles.
chief_review:
This indulgent recipe is a showstopper for chocolate lovers, featuring layers of rich loaf cake, creamy ganache, and a decadent cream cheese filling. The use of double cream, full-fat cream cheese, dark and white chocolate, and toppings like truffles and marshmallows make it a wonderfully luscious dessert—perfect for special occasions or festive gatherings. The orange zest adds a subtle brightness that balances the chocolate’s intensity, while pretzel and biscuit pieces introduce delightful texture and a hint of saltiness. 

Please note, this recipe contains dairy, gluten (from cakes, biscuits, and pretzels), and possibly gelatin in marshmallows, making it unsuitable for those with dairy, gluten, or gelatin restrictions. The decorative flexibility with sprinkles and glitter allows personalization for celebrations, making this dessert both visually spectacular and deliciously satisfying.

name: Glazed apples & pears with sticky shallots
description: Proving apples don't just go with pork, this side will complement your Christmas turkey perfectly
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Put the lemon juice into a large bowl. Peel the apples and pears, leaving the stalks on, then toss in the juice. Meanwhile, bring a medium saucepan of water to the boil. Lower in the apples and pears, then cover and poach for 30 mins or until the fruit just gives to a sharp knife. Peel the shallots while you’re waiting.

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Add the oil and butter to a smallish roasting tin, then add the drained apples, pears and the shallots. Brush the fruit with a layer of the jelly or jam and roast for 1 hr until softened and golden. Turn the pears and apples around in the fat a few times during cooking, brushing twice more with the glaze. Serve spooned around the turkey, decorated with bay leaves.
chief_review: This festive side dish cleverly balances the sweetness of apples and pears with the gentle acidity of lemon and the subtle savor of shallots. The addition of quince or redcurrant jelly provides a beautiful sheen and a vibrant, tangy lift that would elegantly cut through the richness of Christmas turkey. The gentle sauté in olive oil and butter lends a luxurious mouthfeel, while finishing with a bay leaf brings a whisper of herbal aroma. Ideal for a vegetarian table, this recipe makes use of fruit-forward ingredients and dairy, making it suitable for those enjoying a meat-free feast but not for vegans or the lactose intolerant. A delightful harmony of flavors and textures, this side is sure to enliven any holiday spread with both color and taste.

name: Star anise meringues with mango coulis & raspberries
description: These meringues are utterly delicious and go really well with them ago coulis and coconut yogurt. When I make them again I will useless slightly less of the star anise as it is quite a strong flavour. They make quite large meringues and one is enough per person. Yummy!
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 1½ tsp ground star anise(you will need a spice grinder or use suggested alternative)
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Tip the egg whites into the bowl of an electric mixer and beat until soft peaks form (or whisk in a bowl with an electric whisk). Add the sugar, a spoonful at a time, mixing continuously until fully incorporated – about 10 secs between each addition. Keep whisking until glossy, stiff peaks form, about 1-2 mins. Sift in the cornflour and 1 tsp of star anise, and add the vinegar. Give everything a final whisk to incorporate.

Line two large baking trays with baking parchment. Place approx 12cm dollops of meringue on the lined trays, making 12 in total. Sprinkle over the remaining star anise. Reduce oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2 and bake for 35 mins. Turn off the oven and let them cool inside for about 2 hrs. This is important – if you take them out at this point, they will be soft. The cooling process makes them crisp yet chewy in the centre.

In a food processor, purée the mango flesh with the icing sugar until smooth. When ready to serve, swirl the mango coulis through the yogurt, then dollop on top of the cooled meringues. Decorate with the raspberries.
chief_review: These star anise-spiced meringues offer a sophisticated twist on the classic dessert, pairing delightfully with mango coulis and coconut yogurt for a fresh, tropical note. The meringues achieve a lovely crisp exterior and a marshmallowy center, though I recommend moderating the ground star anise to avoid overpowering the delicate sweetness. The fruit and coconut yogurt toppings create a bright, light finish, making each serving feel decadent yet refreshing. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and is naturally gluten-free, provided you confirm your cornflour is certified gluten-free. With careful plating and ripe fruit, these meringues elevate any dessert table while catering to a variety of dietary needs.

name: Ham & crackling
author: Sophie Godwin
directions: Sit the gammon in a large pot with the onion, bay leaves and vinegar. Pour over enough water to completely cover the gammon. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 45 mins. Remove the gammon from the pot and allow to cool.
Once cool enough to handle, carefully cut away the skin, leaving a layer of fat attached. Pat the skin dry with a clean tea towel, then transfer to a
and leave to dry out completely.
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line one small

with foil and two small baking trays with baking parchment. Put the gammon in the foil-lined tin, fat-side up, and rub all over with the mustard, then the sugar. Put the skin onto one of the baking trays, then place the other piece of parchment on top, followed by the second baking tray. Find a weight to go on top (a heavy pan works well) then put both the gammon and skin in the oven. Roast for 30 mins, basting twice, until the gammon is golden.

Take the ham out the oven and turn it up to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Continue cooking the crackling for 10 mins until it is deep golden and crisp. To serve, carve into slices and break the crackling into shards to serve alongside.
chief_review:
This recipe revolves around a classic smoked gammon, enhanced by the subtle aromatics of onion and bay leaves. The briny punch of white wine vinegar, sharp English mustard, and the molasses depth of dark brown sugar deliver a well-balanced glaze, resulting in a succulent and flavorful centerpiece. The method allows the gammon to retain its juiciness while the glaze forms a sticky, tangy-sweet crust—a delight for any carnivorous feast.  

As it contains only meat and basic seasonings, it is suitable for gluten-free diets, provided the mustard and vinegar are verified as gluten-free brands. The absence of dairy, eggs, nuts, and soy makes it generally allergy-friendly, though those with sensitivity to mustard should avoid. It’s a satisfying choice for traditional holiday meals or hearty Sunday roasts.

name: Bread & walnut sauce
description: Inspired by Turkish walnut sauce recipe called tarator, this flavoursome sauce has the taste of Christmas
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Pour the milk into a pan, add the onion, butter, nutmeg, bay and garlic, then bring to the boil. Turn the heat to its lowest setting and infuse the milk for 30 mins. If you have time, do this the day before, leave to cool completely, then chill overnight.
To make the sauce, bring the milk back up to the boil and break the bread into large chunks. Fish out the bay leaves, then add the bread and most of the walnuts to the sauce.

Blitz everything in a food processor or with a hand blender, then season to taste. Serve the sauce piping hot, scattered with the rest of the walnuts, one of the bay leaves and a little butter melting over the top, if you like.
chief_review: This creative take on the Turkish tarator infuses classic holiday flavors into a luscious walnut sauce. The combination of full-fat milk, butter, and a generous grating of nutmeg creates a beautifully rich base, while the addition of bay leaves and garlic adds depth and complexity. Finely sliced onion brings sweetness, and soft white bread acts as a wonderful thickener, allowing the walnuts' earthy taste to shine through. This sauce would elevate roasted vegetables, chicken, or even fish, offering a creamy, festive note to any dish. For those seeking nut-free, dairy-free, or gluten-free options, modifications would be required. Vegetarians can enjoy this recipe as is—it's both comforting and refined, making it a standout accompaniment for a festive table.

name: White Russian
description: While some of us really enjoyed it, others found it a bit much. The ice is a must for a drink with such a kick to it.
author: Good Food
directions: Mix together all the ingredients. Put some ice cubes in a small tumbler and pour the cocktail over the top.
chief_review: This recipe creates a classic White Russian, a cocktail known for its rich, velvety texture and bold coffee undertones. The pairing of vodka and Kahlúa delivers a robust flavor with a lively kick, while the cream tempers the strength, making it smooth and approachable. Serving over ice is indeed essential to balance the potency and add refreshing chill. This drink is not suitable for those seeking a vegan or dairy-free option, as cream is a primary ingredient. It's also an indulgent choice for adult gatherings, ideal for after-dinner sipping. The simplicity of the preparation highlights the importance of quality ingredients for the best result. Overall, it’s a deeply satisfying cocktail for those who appreciate a spirited, creamy drink.

name: ‘Cheesy’ vegan scones
description: Made these last night. The texture was good but they were really bland, no flavour at all to them. I'll put a heaped teaspoon of mustard powder and paprika next time, and loads more thyme.
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 3 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for the tray
300g self-raising flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and lightly oil a baking tray. Mix the vinegar with the almond milk and set aside. Bring a saucepan of water to the boil, add the cauliflower stalk and cook for 5 mins until almost tender. Drain well, leave to cool, then finely chop.

Mix the flour, baking powder, nutritional yeast, spices, thyme leaves and 1 tsp salt in a large bowl. Add the cauliflower, then add the oil and pour in 230ml of the soured almond milk. Working quickly, bring the mixture together with a wooden spoon; if there is any dry mixture in the bowl, add more almond milk to make a soft but not sticky dough. Tip the dough onto a floured work surface and pat to a thickness of about 2.5cm. Cut out rounds with a 6cm fluted cutter and transfer to the baking tray. Gather together any offcuts and cut out more rounds.
Bake on the top shelf of the oven for 10-12 mins until golden. Serve warm with onion chutney.
chief_review: This recipe offers a creative, plant-based take on savory baked goods, with cauliflower and almond milk lending moisture and a subtle nutty note. The use of nutritional yeast and olive oil ensures a dairy-free richness, making it ideal for both vegan and dairy-free diets. The ingredients also cater to those seeking egg-free options. However, as noted, the flavor can fall flat—upping the mustard powder, paprika, and thyme would enliven the dough significantly. Serving with vegan onion chutney is a smart finish, providing much-needed tang and sweetness. Overall, a versatile vegan base recipe begging for punchier seasoning and herbs.

name: Vegan rainbow spring rolls
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 12 spring roll wrappers(we used Blue Dragon)
½ small pack mint, leaves picked
½ small pack Thai basil, leaves picked (optional)
4 spring onions, cut in half then cut lengthways into strips
1 courgette, peeled lengthways, halved and cut into thin strips (or use julienne peeler)
1 large carrot, halved and cut into thin strips (or use julienne peeler)
1 red chilli, deseeded and cut into thin strips
directions: Have all your ingredients prepared and ready to go before you start assembling the rolls. Dip a spring roll wrapper into a shallow bowl of water until it just softens (don’t leave it too long or you’ll be left with a gluey mess). Put the wet wrapper on a chopping board, then top with a couple of mint and basil leaves (if using), and some spring onion, courgette, carrot, mango, chilli and peanuts (if using).

Starting with the edge nearest to you, fold the wrapper into the centre so that it covers half the filling. Fold in both of the shorter ends, then, rolling away from you, fold the wrapper over so that the entire filling is encased. Repeat with the remaining wrappers and fillings to make 12 spring rolls. Can be made in the morning and kept in the fridge for later.
To serve, cut the spring rolls in half on the diagonal. Serve with sweet chilli dipping sauce on the side.
chief_review: This vibrant spring roll recipe is a celebration of fresh, crisp flavors and striking textures. The combination of aromatic mint and Thai basil elevates the simple medley of vegetables, while the addition of sweet mango brings a delightful burst of juiciness. The peanuts add a welcome crunch and savory depth, though they can easily be omitted for a nut-free alternative. The use of spring roll wrappers makes this dish naturally gluten free (always check packaging, as brands may vary), and the recipe is well-suited to both vegetarian and vegan diets. The sweet chilli dipping sauce pairs beautifully with the refreshing filling, making these rolls an excellent appetizer or light snack. Overall, this is an approachable, healthful recipe packed with color and flavor—all in a wonderfully portable package.

name: Sour cherry & marzipan chrysanthemum pastry
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 4 tbsp sloe ginor port (or cherry juice)
500g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
75g butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
directions: First, make the dough. Put all the ingredients and a pinch of salt into a stand mixer and mix on low. When it forms a dough, knead for a couple of mins, then cover with a damp cloth. Leave it overnight or at least 8 hrs in a cool place. If you want to speed up the process, knead for about 10 mins until you have a smooth, pliable dough, then cover and leave to rise for 1 hr.
Put the cherries in a pan with the sloe gin and cherry jam, then bring to a simmer. Leave to cool. Cut the marzipan into 36 thin slices.

Butter a 24cm pie dish with sloping sides or shallow cake tin. On a lightly floured surface, cut the dough into four sections and very briefly knead each one. Keep the pieces you’re not using covered and, one at a time, roll out one piece until it’s about 4mm thick. Cut out circles using a 7cm cutter. Save all the off-cuts in case you need to re-roll them. You’ll need 30-36 circles.

Lay a piece of marzipan on each circle of dough and add a small spoonful of cherry mixture. Fold the circles in half, then bring the two points together like a fortune cookie. Arrange them in the tin, around the edges with the points facing in. Make a second, smaller circle, then, finally, fill the centre. Cover with buttered cling film and leave for 1 hr.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Brush the top of the dough with the egg and scatter with the sugar. Bake for 35-40 mins (turn the oven down if the dough browns too much). Cool a little and eat warm. Can be frozen once baked for 2 months. Wrap in foil and reheat from frozen in the oven.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on a classic brioche-style bread, beautifully layered with the tartness of dried sour cherries and the richness of marzipan. The inclusion of sloe gin or port adds depth, though cherry juice keeps it alcohol-free if desired. The use of both milk and eggs creates a luxurious, tender crumb, while a sprinkle of demerara sugar delivers a wonderful caramelized crunch. This bake is best suited for those following a vegetarian diet, as there are no animal-derived ingredients besides dairy and eggs. The use of marzipan and cherry accents makes this bread a standout, perfect as a teatime centerpiece or a unique brunch offering. The balance of flavors and textures is thoughtfully constructed, marking this as a recipe that’s both indulgent and festive.

name: Cheese & garlic pull-apart loaf
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 50g butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
directions: Butter a 900g loaf tin and line with baking parchment that comes well above the longer sides. Make up the bread following the pack instructions. Leave the dough to rest under a cloth for 10 mins. Shape into a log on a lightly floured surface and divide it into six pieces. Mix the cheese, garlic, parsley and butter together.

Roll each piece of dough out into a rectangle, or as near to a rectangle as you can, the width should be just shorter than the width of the tin and the length about twice the depth of the tin, and lay the rectangles out side by side. Divide the cheese mixture between them (reserving 1 tbsp) and spread it out as much as possible. Fold each rectangle in half and then put them into the tin one after the other, starting at one end. You may need to squeeze them a bit to fit them all in. Don’t worry about the dough sticking out of the top of the tin. Cover the dough and leave to rise for about 30 mins or until risen. Crumble the remaining cheese mix over the top.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Bake for 40-45 mins or until golden and puffed (don’t under-cook it or it may be squidgy in the middle). Leave the loaf in the tin for 10 mins, then lift it out with the parchment. Serve it whole, ready to be pulled into pieces.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers a delightful, savory bread, rich in cheesy depth from cheddar and parmesan, with aromatic notes of garlic and fresh parsley. The inclusion of butter adds a luxurious, tender crumb, while the use of a white bread mix ensures a satisfying texture with minimal effort. The combination of garlic and fresh herbs elevates the bread, making it an excellent accompaniment to soups or salads, or a standout snack on its own.

Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe offers a great way to enjoy a homemade specialty bread without the need for advanced baking skills. Cheese lovers in particular will appreciate the pronounced flavors in every slice.

name: Spinach & squash salad with coconut dressing
description: Roasted butternut squash, lime-marinated onions and spinach leaves dressed with coconut cream make the perfect winter buffet salad
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1 large butternut squashor pumpkin, deseeded but skin left on
1 large red onion, sliced into thin rings
2 limes, zest of 1, juice of both
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut the squash into bite-sized pieces, toss with the oil and seasoning, then roast for 30-40 mins until golden and tender. Leave to cool.
Toss the onion rings with the juice of 1 lime and set aside while the squash roasts.

Make the dressing. Whisk together the remaining lime juice, the zest, coconut cream, fish sauce and sugar. Cover and leave to infuse in the fridge for 10-15 mins, or until ready to serve. When ready to eat, toss together the squash, spinach and onions, and serve with a generous drizzle of the dressing.
chief_review:
This vibrant winter buffet salad brings together sweet roasted butternut squash, zesty lime-marinated onions, and fresh spinach leaves, all tied together with a silky coconut cream dressing. The combination of coconut cream and fish sauce creates a subtle Thai-inspired flavor profile, while the lime zest and juice add refreshing acidity. The salad’s hearty squash and spinach base provides a robust texture, balanced by the creamy, slightly sweet dressing. 

Thanks to the absence of gluten and dairy, this dish is well-suited for gluten-free and dairy-free diets. However, the inclusion of fish sauce makes it unsuitable for strict vegetarians or vegans, but it can easily be adapted by substituting with soy sauce or a vegan fish sauce alternative. Overall, this salad is both bold and comforting, perfect as a show-stopping centerpiece at any winter gathering.

name: Mai Tai
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp orgeat or almond syrup(we used Monin almond syrup, available online)
directions: Stir all the ingredients together in a jug or shake them in a cocktail shaker. Put a few cubes of ice in a tumbler, pour over the liquid and garnish with a cherry.
chief_review:
This Caipirinha-inspired cocktail offers a vibrant, citrus-forward experience, balancing the sharp acidity of Tahiti lime with the deep character of cachaça or white rum. The muddled lemon (lime) releases essential oils, giving a bold, aromatic note that pairs well with the raw sweetness of sugar. The result is a refreshing drink that shines on hot afternoons or as a lively aperitif.

This recipe is naturally gluten-free and suitable for vegans, as all ingredients—cachaça/rum, citrus, and sugar—contain no animal products or gluten-based additives. The simple preparation makes it accessible, yet it’s the quality of the spirit and freshness of the citrus that elevates the final result. A classic for a reason, the Caipirinha is the soul of Brazilian conviviality in a glass.

name: Aubergine & chickpea bites
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 3 large aubergines, halved, cut side scored
1 lemon, ½ zested and juice, ½ cut into wedges to serve (optional)
1 tbsp harissa(we used Belazu rose harissa)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Spray the aubergine halves generously with oil, then put them cut-side up in a large roasting tin with the garlic, coriander and cumin seeds. Season, then roast for 40 mins until the aubergine is completely tender. Set aside to cool a little.
Scoop the aubergine flesh into a bowl and discard the skins. Use a

to scrape the spices and garlic into the bowl. Add the chickpeas, gram flour, lemon zest and juice, roughly mash together and check the seasoning. Don’t worry if the mix is a bit soft – it will firm up in the fridge.

Shape the mixture into 20 balls and put them on a baking tray lined with baking parchment, then leave to chill in the fridge for at least 30 mins. Swirl the harissa through the yogurt and set aside. Can make ahead to this point the day before and kept covered in the fridge.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tip the polenta onto a plate, roll the balls in it to coat, then return them to the tray and spray each one with a little oil. Roast for 20 mins until crisp, hot and golden. Serve with the harissa yogurt and lemon wedges, if you like.
chief_review: This inventive aubergine recipe showcases a delicious interplay of earthy spices and vibrant textures. The use of coriander and cumin seeds delivers a gentle heat and aromatic depth, brilliantly complemented by the creamy richness of coconut yogurt and the fiery kick of rose harissa. Chickpeas and gram flour add both structure and a boost of plant-based protein, making this dish substantial and satisfying. The lemon zest and juice brighten the flavors, while polenta provides a pleasant, subtle crunch. This recipe is well-suited to vegan and gluten-free diets, as all ingredients are plant-based and free from wheat or traditional flour. Additionally, the absence of dairy and eggs makes it ideal for those with common food allergies. Overall, it’s a delightful, wholesome main or side that appeals to flavour enthusiasts and health-conscious diners alike.

name: Pineapple & rum cake
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 160g unsalted butter, at room temperature, plus extra for the tin
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tip the pineapple onto a non-stick baking tray and roast for 20 mins – this concentrates the flavour. Leave the pineapple to cool before roughly chopping into smaller chunks.
Melt the chocolate in a microwave or in a
set over simmering water, then tip onto a piece of baking parchment and spread it out in a thick layer. Leave to set.

Butter a 20 x 30cm baking tin and line with baking parchment. Beat the butter and sugar together until light and creamy. Add the five spice, milk and rum, and mix together. Beat in the eggs, one at a time, adding the flour in three batches between the eggs, and fold in the pineapple. Scrape the cake mixture into the baking tin and bake for 20 mins, or until just cooked through and lightly browned. Leave in the tin for 10 mins, then lift out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

Cut the cake in half widthways. Beat the butter for the icing until soft, then stir in the icing sugar, followed by the lime juice. You should end up with a soft, spreadable buttercream. Add a little more icing sugar if it’s too soft.

For the meringue, put the sugar, 65ml water and the glucose in a heavy pan on a medium heat and stir to dissolve the sugar. Bring to the boil, and use a sugar thermometer to keep an eye on the temperature. Put the egg whites in a stand mixer and whisk over a medium speed. When the temperature of the syrup reaches 118C, steadily pour it in a thin stream into the stiff egg whites, and continue
until completely cold. Scoop the meringue into a piping bag fitted with a plain round nozzle. Can be made up to three days in advance and kept in the fridge.

Put one half of the cake on a flat ovenproof serving plate or baking sheet. Spread a little of the icing over the cake and sandwich the other half on top. Now, imagine you are looking down onto a pineapple that is lying down and cut each corner off the cake to make it look like a barrel – a bread knife works best here.
