Trim off the sharp top edges to round the top, then coat the cake with a thin layer of the remaining icing

Pipe dots of meringue all over the cake so it looks like a pineapple. Brown the meringue with a blowtorch or put it in an oven, turned up as high as it will go, and keep an eye on it until it starts to brown. Cool completely. Cut the cooled chocolate into shards about 5-10cm long, and push them into one end of the cake so they look like pineapple leaves.
chief_review:
This cake is an intriguing fusion of tropical and spiced notes, balancing the caramelized sweetness of pineapple with the depth of dark chocolate and aromatic five spice. The addition of dark rum and lime juice adds welcome complexity, cutting through the richness of the buttery crumb and sweet icing. Multiple elements—such as the glossy chocolate and pineapple, as well as a sophisticated meringue—showcase both technique and creativity.

Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe avoids meat and fish, relying on eggs and dairy for structure and richness. However, those with dairy or egg allergies, or seeking a gluten-free option, should take note of the key ingredients involved. Overall, it's a showstopping, flavor-packed dessert that will appeal to lovers of bold and unique bakes.

name: Oysters with apple & horseradish dressing
description: Well I served this between the 2 of us. We like to keep it simple with oysters, adding nothing at all, occasionally some lemon, but I made this sauce and it was nice to add it to some of them. I'd happily 2 dozen myself
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 2 tbsp finely chopped appleflesh (a sharp-tasting variety is best)
directions: Mix the vinegar and shallots for the dressing in a small bowl and leave this to sit, covered, for an hour or so, so that the shallots can infuse the vinegar. Add all the other ingredients, stir and put into a serving bowl.

– make sure you have an oyster knife; don’t try to do this with a regular kitchen knife. Rinse the oysters under cold running water. Throw away any that are open and don’t close if you tap them against the side of the sink. Place an oyster rounded-side up on a work surface. Grip the oyster with a tea towel to help protect your hand, leaving the narrow hinged end exposed. Place the tip of the knife between the top and bottom shells just next to the hinge. Carefully push it into the shell, twisting and wiggling the knife tip, to release the top shell. At first, it may seem like you aren’t getting there, but keep going with gentle pressure until the shell pops open. Try to keep the oyster level, so the delicious liquor (the briny, salty sea water) stays inside the deeper bottom shell.

Wipe your knife, then pry open the shell by inserting the knife tip in a few other spots, twisting it to release the shell completely. Keeping the oyster level, run your knife along the inside of the upper shell to cut the muscle that attaches the oyster to it. Remove the top shell. Run your knife along the inside of the lower shell and gently cut the oyster free. Leave the oyster nestled in its shell. (If you open an oyster that has a strong, sulphurous smell, chuck it out: it’s dead.)

Transfer the oyster in its bottom shell to a bed of crushed ice or rock salt that will keep the shell level, while you repeat the process with the remaining oysters. Serve immediately with the dressing; each person should use about ¼ tsp of the dressing for each oyster (you can dress each one in advance yourself if you prefer, and add a dill sprig to the tops).
chief_review: This oyster recipe showcases fresh shellfish at their best, elevated by a creative sauce. The topping—a blend of white wine vinegar, shallots, honey, rapeseed oil, tart apple, horseradish, and crushed white pepper—delivers a vibrant balance of acidity, heat, and mild sweetness that enhances the oysters' natural brininess without overpowering them. The use of honey and apple introduces subtle complexity, while the rapeseed oil gives an elegant finish. Served beautifully on crushed ice or rock salt, this dish is perfect as an appetizer. The recipe is suitable for pescatarians and, thanks to its absence of dairy, nuts, or gluten-containing ingredients, is also friendly for those avoiding these common allergens. For true oyster lovers, this simple yet flavorful sauce is a delightful alternative to the classic lemon wedge.

name: Chip shop curry sauce
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: thumb-sized piece ginger, peeled and sliced
500ml chicken stockor vegetable stock for vegetarians
directions: Heat the butter in a large

over a medium-low heat and tip in the onions, garlic and ginger and fry for 12-15 mins until soft but not coloured. Stir in the curry powder, turmeric, raisins, vinegar and star anise, and fry for 1 min more, then pour in the chicken stock, bring to the boil and simmer very gently for 30 mins, stirring so it doesn’t catch on the bottom.
Lift out the star anise, mix the cornflour with 2 tbsp water and stir into the sauce. Simmer for 5 mins, stirring constantly until you have a thickened silky sauce. Pour into a
and blitz until smooth, or use a

. Squeeze in lemon juice to taste. Use this sauce to make a curry for your Christmas leftovers whether its sprouts, turkey, or simple roast potatoes. If freezing the sauce, leave to cool, pour into a container and freeze, then defrost and reheat when you’re ready to eat.
chief_review:
This recipe offers a harmonious blend of savory and sweet with the addition of raisins and aromatic spices like curry powder, turmeric, and star anise. The slow-cooked onions, garlic, and ginger build a comforting depth, while a touch of malt vinegar and lemon juice brings a lively acidity to brighten the dish. The use of cornflour ensures a smooth, slightly thickened sauce, perfect for layering with rice or vegetables.

With the inclusion of butter and the option of vegetable stock, this recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet. It is also gluten-free, relying on cornflour as a thickener rather than wheat-based ingredients. The absence of dairy aside from butter and no obvious allergens like nuts or shellfish makes it broadly accessible, though those with dairy allergies should consider using a plant-based butter alternative.

name: Shakshuka flatbread bake
author: Dan Doherty
ingredients: 1 red chilli, finely chopped (deseeded if you don't like it very hot)
small handful coriander, half finely chopped
2 flatbreads, roughly 20cm diameter (Turkish pide are good)
directions: Heat the oil in a medium pan and fry the onions, garlic, bay leaf and chilli for 3 mins. Add the cumin, paprika and cayenne, season, then cook for a further 3 mins. Add the pepper and cook for 5 mins until it starts to soften.
Add the chopped tomatoes and stock, lower the heat and simmer for 20-25 mins until you have a thick ragu, then stir in the finely chopped coriander.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Lay each flatbread on a baking tray. Put half the vegetable mix in the centre of each and spread it out a bit, keeping at least an inch spare all the way around as a border. Make a small well in the centre and crack an egg on top of each flatbread. Crumble over the feta and put in the oven for 12-15 mins until the egg is set and the cheese melted slightly. Scatter over the remaining coriander and serve.
chief_review:
This recipe showcases a vibrant Mediterranean-inspired blend of flavors with smoky paprika, cumin, and chili complementing the sweetness of red pepper and tomatoes. The combination of onions, garlic, and bay leaf develops a deep aromatic base, while the fresh coriander lifts the dish with a hint of brightness. The eggs, gently cooked and paired with crumbled feta, add richness and protein, making this a satisfying meal at any time of day. The use of Turkish pide or similar flatbreads provides both texture and a vehicle for soaking up the flavorful sauce.

Thanks to the absence of meat and the reliance on eggs and feta for protein, this dish is ideal for lacto-ovo vegetarians. However, it contains gluten from the flatbread and dairy from the feta, so it is not suitable for vegan or gluten-free diets without modifications.

name: Honey-mustard steamed green medley
description: Serve up an all-in-one side dish of broccoli, green beans, peas and leeks, glazed with sweet vinaigrette
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 leeks, trimmed and sliced into chunky rings
140g thin-stemmed broccoli, cut into smaller pieces
directions: Bring a large pan of water to the boil. Whisk the oil with the mustard, honey and vinegar in a large bowl and season.

Put the leeks in the water, bring back to the boil, then simmer gently for 1 min. Add the beans and cook for 2 mins, then add the broccoli and simmer everything for 4 mins. Finally, add the peas, bring back to the boil and simmer for 1 min more. Drain really well, then tip into the large bowl and toss through the dressing. Serve straight away.
chief_review: This vibrant side dish beautifully celebrates fresh green vegetables with the crunch of green beans, tender broccoli, sweet peas, and mellow leeks, all glazed in a honey-mustard vinaigrette. The combination of extra-virgin olive oil, wholegrain mustard, honey, and cider vinegar creates a light yet flavorful dressing that complements the inherent sweetness and earthiness of the vegetables. This recipe is naturally vegetarian and gluten free, making it suitable for a wide range of dietary preferences. The dish is also dairy free and nut free, accommodating those with common allergies. Serve warm or at room temperature alongside grilled mains or as part of a buffet for a colorful, healthful addition that will please a crowd. Its simplicity allows the produce to shine while the vinaigrette brings everything together with balance and brightness.

name: Proper turkey gravy
description: This simple Christmas gravy can be made a few days ahead or you can freeze it for up to a month
author: Good Food
directions: Put the onions and carrot in a large pan with the turkey neck (optional). Pour in stock and simmer for 1 hr. Strain to remove the vegetables and turkey, then return the liquid to the pan. (For a textured gravy, remove the turkey and, using a stick blender, blitz carrot and onion into the stock until very smooth.)

Blend the flour with the white wine or water, then blend this into the stock, stirring over the heat until thickened. Cool, then chill. Will keep for several days or freeze for 1 month. Thaw in the fridge a day ahead. Heat in a pan until piping hot, then add the juices from the turkey and season to taste.
chief_review: This Christmas gravy recipe is both practical and delicious, offering a make-ahead option that saves time on busy festive days. The combination of onions, carrot, and a rich turkey or chicken stock provides a depth of flavor, while a splash of white wine adds a subtle brightness. The optional turkey neck enhances savoriness, but it can be omitted for a vegetarian-friendly version—just use vegetable stock instead. With no dairy or eggs, it’s suitable for those avoiding these allergens. However, as it includes plain flour, it’s not gluten-free, but a simple swap with a gluten-free alternative flour would make it suitable for that diet as well. Overall, this gravy is a versatile and flavorful addition to your holiday table, adaptable for various preferences with just minor adjustments.

name: Candied roast ham with cranberry & star anise sauce
description: Lovely flavoured ham! I cooked a 3kg boned joint as Tom says you can in the comments but it did fall apart a bit with that length of boiling - think I could have reduced the cooking time a little. Also, with that size joint, you can reduce the amount of sugar to glaze because there is less surface area of fat to cover - wish I'd thought of that before I mixed the sugar and mace together!! Last point - when I put the honey on over the first layer of sugar, it had a real tendency to roll straight off! Don't know what I was doing wrong!
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 4kg smoked bone-in hamtrimmed and skin left on
500ml ham stock(from the soaking liquid in step 1)
directions: Put the ham in a large, deep pan and cover with cold water. Bring to the boil and skim off any impurities. Add the bay leaves, star anise, thyme, peppercorns, white wine vinegar and orange zest. Simmer for 3 hrs, then turn off the heat and leave the ham to cool in the water.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Remove the ham from the pan, reserving the stock. Using a sharp knife, carefully cut away the skin, leaving a good layer of fat. Score the fat all over with as many long, fine cut marks as you can fit in. Mix the sugar and mace together. Put the ham in a large roasting tin and cover with half the mace-sugar mix, pressing it into the score marks. Drizzle over the honey, then press the rest of the mace and sugar on top. Roast in the oven for 30 mins, basting every 10 mins to form a dark caramel crust. Remove from the oven and rest for 30 mins.

To make the sauce, pour the ham stock through a fine sieve until you have 500ml. Pour into a medium saucepan, add the star anise and reduce until thick and glossy. Add the butter and reduce until it emulsifies and becomes a thick sauce. Remove from the heat, stir in the cranberries, orange zest and juice, and check the seasoning. Slice the ham into thick slices and spoon over the sauce.
chief_review:
This ham recipe delivers deeply aromatic flavors with a festive twist, thanks to the star anise, thyme, and orange zest. The glaze—a delightful combination of demerara sugar, ground mace, and honey—caramelizes beautifully, adding sweetness and spice that perfectly complements the saltiness of the smoked ham. The cranberries and orange offer a pleasing brightness, cutting through the richness, while butter infuses the sauce with luxurious depth.

Ideal for celebratory occasions, this dish is suitable for gluten-free diets, given that none of the ingredients contain gluten or wheat-based additives. However, those with dairy sensitivities should note the inclusion of butter. If you wish to experiment, consider adjusting the sugar and honey to taste and watch the glaze closely to prevent it from running off. Overall, this ham joint is a joyous centerpiece, marrying traditional and contemporary flavors superbly.

name: Beetroot, bacon & spring onions
description: Beetroot and horseradish work brilliantly with beef - serve alongside Matt's spiced beef recipe
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: 1 bunch spring onions, sliced on the diagonal
100g cubetti di pancetta or diced streaky bacon rashers
2-3 tbsp freshly grated horseradish, or horseradish sauce from a jar
directions: Cut the beetroot into quarters and toss in a serving bowl with the spring onions. Fry the pancetta or bacon in a little oil until just golden. Remove from the heat and immediately tip over the beetroot. At this point the dish can either be served or chilled. If making ahead, remove 1 hr or so ahead of time.

To serve, mix the crème fraîche with the freshly grated horseradish, lemon juice and seasoning. Taste and adjust to be as fiery as you like. Spoon a little of the dressing over the beetroot and serve the rest on the side.
chief_review: This vibrant side dish cleverly balances earthy beetroot with the fiery kick of horseradish and the creamy richness of crème fraîche. The inclusion of crispy pancetta or streaky bacon introduces a delectable savory depth, while spring onions add freshness throughout. The squeeze of lemon juice brings a subtle brightness that ties the flavors together beautifully. This recipe is well-suited for gluten-free diets—as none of the ingredients contain gluten—making it an excellent accompaniment for those sensitive or intolerant. Its compatibility with beef, especially spiced cuts, showcases a chef’s understanding of complementary tastes and textures. Serve as a lively side to elevate any roast or festive meal.

name: Homemade gravy
description: A rich sauce for roast poultry - use chicken wings, bacon and white wine for added flavour
author: Lucy Netherton
ingredients: 1 onion, unpeeled and cut into quarters
bunch herbssuch as bay, thyme, parsley stalks (just use whatever you have, don't buy especially)
directions: Dry-fry the bacon in a large pan until golden. Remove, then fry the wings (add a splash of oil if they start to stick), turning until browned all over. Tip into a pan with the remaining ingredients (apart from the butter and flour) and the bacon. Simmer, skimming off any froth, for about 2 hrs.

Strain through a sieve, then heat the butter in a saucepan and, when foaming, add the flour. Cook, stirring constantly, for 1 min. Gradually pour in the stock, stirring all the time, to get rid of any lumps. Simmer until you have a thin gravy, taste and season.
chief_review: This sauce recipe is a masterclass in building deep, complex flavor—perfect for elevating roast poultry. The combination of chicken wings and bacon creates a robust base, while white wine brings brightness and acidity. Vegetables like onion, carrot, and leek—paired with aromatics such as garlic and fresh herbs—layer in earthy sweetness. The finishing touch of butter and flour gives the sauce a silky, luxurious texture. This is an excellent choice for those following a traditional omnivorous diet, though it is not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or those with gluten sensitivities, as flour is used as a thickener. The method encourages flexibility with herbs, making it approachable for home cooks. Overall, this sauce delivers restaurant-quality depth and would make an outstanding accompaniment for any classic roast poultry dish.

name: Spiced turkey burgers
description: Turkey isn't just for Christmas you know! The kids will love these, and for the grown ups, they're low fat, too
author: Good Food
ingredients: salad and mango chutney or lime pickle, to serve
directions: In a large bowl, mix together the turkey mince, onion, garlic, curry powder, coriander and egg yolk with a little salt and pepper. Combine well with your hands, then shape into 4 flat burger patties.

Heat the oil in a frying pan over a high heat, then cook the burgers for 5 mins each side or until cooked through. Toast the cut sides of the burger buns. Place the salad on the bottom halves of the warm buns, then top with the burgers and chutney or lime pickle.
chief_review: This turkey burger recipe is a delightful twist on the classic burger, blending lean turkey mince with aromatic Madras curry powder and fresh coriander for a vibrant burst of flavor. The use of grated red onion and garlic adds depth, while a single egg yolk helps to bind without excess fat, keeping the dish light—great for those following a lower-fat diet. Served in burger buns with salad and a touch of mango chutney or lime pickle, it’s a fusion treat that’s perfect for family meals. The simple yet bold ingredients make it accessible for home cooks, while the flavors are nuanced enough to satisfy adults. This recipe is also a practical choice for anyone seeking a high-protein, lower-fat meal option.

name: Snowball truffles
description: Festive fun for the kids, these snowy truffles are great to give as gifts and fun to make in school holidays
author: Tana Ramsay
ingredients: 200g good-quality dark chocolate (at least 70% cocoa solids)
directions: Pour the cream into a saucepan and bring just up to the boil. Chop the chocolate into small pieces and place in a large bowl. Pour over the boiling cream, then stir until the chocolate and cream are well blended and smooth. Cool, then set aside in the fridge until the mixture is solid, about 2 hrs.

Scoop out teaspoons of the mixture and roll into small walnut-size balls with your hands. Sprinkle the coconut onto a plate and roll the truffle in the coconut until evenly covered. Will keep in a cool place for 3 days or freeze for up to 1 month.
chief_review: These snowy truffles are a delightful treat, perfect for festive occasions or as homemade gifts. The combination of rich dark chocolate and creamy double cream creates a luxuriously smooth ganache, while the desiccated coconut offers a wonderful contrast in both texture and flavor. Their simplicity makes them an excellent, interactive activity for children during the holidays. Ideal for a vegetarian diet, this recipe relies on basic, easily sourced ingredients and delivers a decadent bite with every truffle. To get the best result, use high-quality dark chocolate and be sure to chill the ganache thoroughly before rolling. The coconut coating not only adds a snowy touch but also prevents stickiness, making them easy to package and share. These truffles are a festive essential for anyone who enjoys a classic chocolate-coconut pairing.

name: Bubble & squeak
description: Mine didn't look anything like the picture and it didn't stick together. However it was absolutely delicious and just like my mum used to make even with the garlic. We had it with grilled sausages and a fried egg on top.
author: Paul Merrett
ingredients: 1 tbsp duckfat, goose fat or butter
15-20 cooked Brussels sprouts, sliced, or leftover boiled cabbage, shredded
400g cold leftover mashed potato, or cold crushed boiled potatoes
directions: Melt 1 tbsp duck fat, goose fat or butter in a
, allow it to get nice and hot, then add 4 chopped streaky bacon rashers. As it begins to brown, add 1 finely sliced onion and 1 chopped garlic clove.
Next, add 15-20 sliced cooked Brussels sprouts or shredded boiled cabbage and let it colour slightly. All this will take 5-6 mins.
Add 400g cold mashed potato. Work everything together in the pan and push it down so that the mixture covers the base of the pan.

Allow the mixture to catch slightly on the base of the pan before turning it over and doing the same again. It’s the bits of potato that catch in the pan that define the term ‘bubble and squeak’, so be brave and let the mixture colour.
Cut into wedges and serve.
chief_review: This recipe is a comforting, rustic dish that brings out the nostalgic flavors of home cooking. The use of duck fat, goose fat, or butter as a base adds a rich depth, while the inclusion of streaky bacon provides a wonderful smoky undertone. Sautéed onions and garlic layer in savory notes, perfectly complementing the hearty mix of Brussels sprouts or cabbage and potatoes. It's an excellent way to use up leftovers and delivers a satisfying, well-rounded flavor profile. The dish pairs beautifully with grilled sausages and a fried egg for a simple, fulfilling meal. Suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided all ingredient choices are free from gluten. With its straightforward technique and familiar ingredients, this recipe offers both comfort and taste in every bite.

name: Indian cucumber salad
description: Turn down the heat with this palate-cleansing, accompaniment to curry, flavoured with mustard seeds
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp black or brown mustard seed
directions: Halve the cucumber lengthways, then scoop out the seeds and slice. Mix with mustard seeds, vinegar and sugar.
chief_review: This cucumber salad offers a crisp, refreshing complement to spicy curries, with the sharpness of red wine vinegar and aromatic bite of whole mustard seeds. The minimal ingredient list allows the cucumber’s freshness to take center stage, while the sugar balances acidity for a subtle sweetness. With no animal products, dairy, or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is ideal for vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free diets. The method is straightforward yet delivers bold flavors and an invigorating zing, making it a quick, palate-cleansing side suitable for a range of dietary preferences.

name: Crispy golden spuds
description: Crunchy roast potatoes that work every time - use a touch of turmeric for colour and bay and stock for flavour
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1½ kg potato, such as Maris Piper or King Edward, cut into large roastie size
2 tbsp vegetable bouillon powder or 2 vegetable stockcubes
6 tbsp vegetable, sunflower or rapeseed oil
directions: Put the potatoes in a large pan, cover with cold water and add the bouillon powder or stock cubes, turmeric and bay leaves. Cover with a lid, bring to a boil and simmer for 10 mins until the potatoes start to soften on the outside but remain whole.

Drain the potatoes well and give them a shake in the colander to rough up the edges, then leave to steam-dry in the colander for 5 mins. Meanwhile, pour the oil and duck or goose fat, if using, into your largest baking tray (the spuds will need plenty of space to really crisp up) and put in the oven underneath the turkey to heat for a few mins. Once the potatoes are dry, sprinkle with the flour and plenty of seasoning, then toss to coat.

Remove the hot tray from the oven. Carefully tip in the potatoes and coat in the hot fat. Cook for 30 mins at 200C/180C fan/gas 6, on the lower shelf of the oven underneath the joint of meat, if making. When you take the joint or main meal out, turn the oven up to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Turn the potatoes over in the tray and continue cooking for 45 mins-1 hr longer on the top shelf, until golden and crispy.
chief_review: This roast potato recipe delivers a reliably crisp exterior and fluffy interior, with aromatic undertones from turmeric and bay leaves. The addition of vegetable bouillon and stock infuses the potatoes with savory depth, making them especially flavorful without being overpowering. The choice to use vegetable, sunflower, or rapeseed oil with optional duck or goose fat gives flexibility for both vegetarians and those seeking richer taste. Use only plant oils to keep the dish vegetarian. The turmeric beautifully enhances the golden color, while the plain flour helps achieve that coveted crunch. This dish is well-suited for a vegetarian diet if you skip the duck or goose fat. Gluten-free diners should note the inclusion of plain flour, but a gluten-free alternative can easily be substituted. These potatoes make an excellent side that could complement a variety of main courses, adding both flair and flavor to any meal.

name: Orange & coconut salad
description: Cool down a curry with this fresh and light fruity salad with toasted creamy coconut, parsley, onion and lime
author: Good Food
directions: Cut away the peel and pith from the oranges, then thinly slice the flesh. Mix with coconut, parsley, red onion and lime juice.
chief_review: This vibrant fruity salad is a refreshing accompaniment to a spicy curry, delivering a lovely balance of sweet, tangy, and creamy notes. The oranges provide a juicy burst of flavor, complemented beautifully by the richness of toasted coconut. Parsley adds a fresh herbal undertone, while the sharpness of red onion and brightness of lime juice tie everything together. The ingredient list is naturally free from gluten and dairy, making it suitable for vegan and vegetarian diets. With no nuts, animal products, or common allergens present, this salad is a safe, light, and zesty side that will elevate any meal with minimal prep and maximum flavor contrast.

name: Chunky mince pie slices
description: Inject some Christmas spirit into the workplace with these easy to share slices
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 25g pecan, mix of broken and whole
finely grated zest 1 lemon, plus 2 tsp juice
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Combine the mincemeat with the nuts, cranberries, apple and lemon zest.

Unroll the pastry and lay it on a lightly floured work surface. Slice off a strip across one end to leave a 23cm square of pastry. From the strip, cut out 15-30 star shapes (depending on whether you want 1 or 2 stars per slice). Thinly re-roll the pastry trimmings until it is all used up. Lay the pastry square on a baking sheet and scatter over the ground almonds. Carefully spread the mincemeat mixture over so that it comes right to the edge of the pastry (the mincemeat shouldn’t spread when baked). Lay the stars in lines across the mincemeat, slightly overlapping them if necessary to fit, so you can cut out 15 slices when baked. Brush the stars with egg to glaze, if you like.
Bake for 15 mins or until the pastry is golden. Leave to cool. Meanwhile, mix the icing sugar with 2 tsp lemon juice. Drizzle over the cool pastry and cut into 15 slices.
chief_review:
This festive recipe is a delightful way to bring the flavors of Christmas into a shareable workplace treat. The combination of mincemeat, nuts, dried cranberries, and a hint of apple creates a rich, fragrant filling, beautifully balanced by the zest and juice of lemon. The ready-rolled puff pastry offers a crisp, golden base that pairs well with the soft, juicy center. The scatter of whole and broken nuts provides an appealing texture, while a dusting of icing sugar adds a finishing touch of sweetness. 

Thanks to its absence of meat, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians, although those with nut allergies should be aware of the prominent use of pecans, pistachios, and almonds. It’s a straightforward recipe to prepare and perfect for sharing at holiday gatherings, bringing a warm, seasonal touch to any table.

name: Pear & mincemeat crumble cake
description: With a hint of spice and little pockets of mincemeat, this is a lovely post-Christmas cake, great with warm custard
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 4 firm pears, peeled, cored and cut into thumb-size pieces
250g pack salted butter, softened (use a tiny bit for greasing)
directions: Put pears into a non-stick frying pan with 2 tbsp sugar and 2 tbsp water. Cover, then cook over a medium heat for 10 mins until just tender, stirring every so often. There shouldn’t be juices once the pears are cooked. Add the spice; leave to cool.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Butter then line the base and sides of a 20cm round, deep cake tin. Put butter, sugar, vanilla and ¼ tsp salt into a large bowl. Beat with an electric hand whisk until pale and fluffy. Add eggs and flour, beat until smooth, then fold in almonds with a spoon. Remove 85g batter and put into a small bowl. Into this add the plain flour and chop into the mix with a cutlery knife to make a soft, crumbly-looking mix.

Spoon half the cake mix into the tin, top with half the pears, dot over half the mincemeat, then dollop the rest of the cake mix on top. Scatter with remaining pears, mincemeat, then the crumble mix. Sprinkle with final 1 tbsp sugar. Bake for 1½ hrs, covering with foil after 1 hr, until golden, risen and a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean. Cool in the tin for 10 mins, then cool on a rack. Keep it in the lining paper, as this will help it stay moist. Will keep, well wrapped in an airtight tin, for 5 days. Freeze for 1 month.
chief_review:
This post-Christmas cake is a delightful fusion of warm spices, juicy pears, and bursts of festive mincemeat, perfect alongside a ladle of warm custard. The addition of ground almonds enriches the crumb with a pleasant nuttiness, while the use of both self-raising and plain flour results in a balanced, tender texture. Salted butter gives a deeper flavor, nicely complemented by the subtle warmth of mixed spice. The pears retain their shape and texture, offering juicy, tart contrasts to sweet, aromatic notes.  

This recipe contains flour with gluten, eggs, butter, and ground almonds, making it best suited to traditional diets without specific restrictions. With no meat, it is appropriate for a vegetarian diet, provided the mincemeat is vegetarian-friendly (many are, but double-check your brand). A pleasing, comforting cake for chilly days and family gatherings.

name: Creamy smoked salmon, leek & potato soup
description: Creamy and low-fat aren't words you often hear together, but that's exactly what you get with this freeze-ahead starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 large leeks, halved and finely sliced
directions: Heat the butter in a large saucepan and add the leeks and bay leaf. Cook over a low heat for 8-10 mins or until the leek is really soft, then stir through the potatoes until coated in the butter. Pour over the stock and cream and bring to the simmer, then gently bubble for 10-15 mins until the potatoes are really tender.
Add two-thirds of the smoked salmon, stir through and season. Serve the soup in deep bowls with the remaining smoked salmon and snipped chives on the top.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers an impressive balance of indulgence and lightness, making it a refined yet approachable starter. The use of double cream creates a velvety texture without overwhelming richness, while the smoked salmon infuses a delicate, savory depth. The foundation of leeks and floury potatoes results in a brilliantly smooth and subtly aromatic base, elevated by the freshness of chives.

Opting for vegetable stock transforms this dish into an excellent option for pescatarians, and its gluten-free composition suits those avoiding wheat-based ingredients. However, due to the inclusion of butter, cream, and salmon, it's not vegan or vegetarian. The freeze-ahead detail is a thoughtful touch for hosts seeking convenience without compromise on flavor. A sophisticated soup, perfect for a celebratory meal or entertaining, where simplicity meets elegance.

name: Lemon & honey chicken
description: This dish is best served cold, so you can make it a day in advance - it's also low in fat
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 6-8 skinless boneless chicken breasts, (about 1kg/2lb 4oz in total)
grated zest of 2 lemonsand the juice of 1
1 curly lettuce, such as Batavia or Webb’s
directions: Preheat the oven to 190C/gas 5/fan 170. Arrange the chicken in a shallow ovenproof dish. Mix together the honey, lemon zest and juice, oil, salt and pepper, then pour over the chicken breasts and turn them around until well coated.

Roast the chicken breasts for 40-45 minutes, turning them halfway through the cooking time, and basting occasionally, until they are golden brown and shiny and the marinade has almost evaporated. Leave to cool, then wrap in foil and chill until ready to eat. (The chicken may now be frozen for up to 1 month. Defrost before serving.)
On the day, spread the lettuce over a large platter, tearing up any large leaves. Slice the chicken breasts, keeping them together, then arrange over the lettuce.
chief_review: This refreshing chicken salad is a superb option for those seeking a light yet flavorful meal, perfectly suited for preparing in advance. The combination of succulent, lean chicken breasts marinated with honey, lemon zest, and olive oil delivers a vibrant, subtly sweet, and citrusy profile, balanced beautifully by the fresh crunch of curly lettuce. As it’s low in fat and free of gluten and dairy, this dish fits well into gluten-free and lactose-intolerant diets. Additionally, using simple, whole ingredients keeps it both clean and wholesome, ideal for health-conscious diners. Serve chilled for maximum refreshment and convenience.

name: Halloumi & bacon rolls
description: Impress your friends with these tasty gluten-free nibbles - ideal finger food for a buffet
author: Good Food
ingredients: 10 rashers pancetta or smoked streaky bacon
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Cut the halloumi into 20 sticks. stretch each rasher of pancetta with the back of a knife, then cut in half. season the pancetta with just black pepper, then sprinkle with the chopped chives.
Roll the pancetta around the halloumi in a spiral and arrange on a baking sheet. Bake for 10-12 mins or until the pancetta is brown and beginning to crisp.
chief_review: This simple yet flavorful recipe offers a delightful blend of salty halloumi wrapped in smoky pancetta, elevated by fragrant chives. The result is a crunchy, savory bite that's sure to be a crowd-pleaser at any gathering. The use of halloumi gives a firm texture and a satisfying chew, while the pancetta crisps perfectly under heat. These nibbles are naturally gluten-free, making them an excellent option for guests with gluten sensitivities. Quick to prepare and even quicker to disappear, these bites showcase how a few quality ingredients can create standout finger food.

name: Brussels sprouts with bacon & chestnuts
description: My husband said these were the best tasting brussels sprouts he's ever eaten and I must say they were delicious. Followed the recipe to the letter and we weren't disappointed. Will be making again.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1¼kg Brussels sprouts, trimmed (or if buying pre-trimmed, buy 1 kg)
6 rashers smoked streaky bacon, cut into bite-sized pieces (or use more, if you like)
directions: Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, then tip in 1 ¼ kg trimmed Brussels sprouts. Once back to the boil, cook for 5 mins. Drain, run under the cold tap until cold, then drain again.
Heat a large frying pan, add 6 rashers smoked streaky bacon, cut into bite-sized pieces, and gently fry for 10 mins until crisp and golden.
Tip out of the pan, leaving the fat behind, then add 200g chestnuts and fry over a high heat for about 5 mins until tinged. Tip out of the pan.
Add the Brussels sprouts to the pan with a splash of water, then cover and finish cooking over a medium heat for about 5 mins, stirring now and again, until just tender.
Uncover, turn up the heat, then add most of the 50g butter and sauté the sprouts for 2 mins more.
Tip in the bacon and chestnuts, season generously with salt and pepper, then serve with the last knob of butter on top.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts dish combines smoky bacon, earthy chestnuts, and rich butter for a deeply satisfying flavor profile—an ideal pairing for festive or wintery meals. The bacon infuses the sprouts with a subtle savoriness, while the chestnuts introduce a pleasing sweetness and texture that balances the dish. Using butter adds a luxurious finish, ensuring each sprout is well coated and tender. This recipe would appeal particularly to those following a gluten-free diet, as none of the listed ingredients contain gluten. Be mindful, however, to confirm that the bacon and chestnuts are free from any added gluten-containing preservatives or seasonings. Overall, the balance of textures and flavors makes this a standout side that could convert even reluctant sprout eaters into fans.

name: Mum's leek & potato soup with mustard toasts
description: Mary Cadogan says 'This soup is still a favourite of mine and always goes down a treat'
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Melt the butter in a large pan, add the bacon and fry it until it is just starting to colour. Add the leeks and potatoes, then stir well until they are glistening.

Add the stock and bay leaves, season and bring to the boil. Partly cover and simmer for 15 mins, until everything is cooked. Fish out the bay leaves, then purée the soup in batches in a food processor or blender. Return to the pan and stir in the milk. Reheat gently and season to taste. Add more stock or water if the soup seems too thick (this will depend on the size of your potatoes). Sprinkle with parsley to serve.

Make the toasts: heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Cut the baguette into thin diagonal slices. Mix the oil and mustard together, then brush over both sides of the bread. Spread them on a large baking sheet and bake for 10 mins. Serve with the soup for dipping. They can be baked earlier in the day and served cold or warmed through in the oven.
chief_review: Mary Cadogan’s soup brings together the comforting, earthy flavors of leeks and potatoes with the deep, savory notes from streaky bacon. The use of butter and milk lends a creamy richness, while bay leaves and fresh parsley offer aromatic freshness. The vegetable stock provides a subtle base, ensuring a perfect harmony in flavors. The inclusion of a long baguette, crisped in olive oil and enlivened with wholegrain mustard, adds delightful texture and contrast, turning the soup into a hearty meal. This recipe is a robust offering for those who enjoy classic, comforting fare, and is especially suitable for a gluten-free diet if gluten-free bread is substituted for the baguette. Ideal for cooler weather, this soup promises both warmth and satisfaction, making it a well-rounded dish for sharing.

name: Spiced pork & potato pie
description: This budget-friendly French-Canadian speciality, known as tourtière, is traditionally served at Christmas, but with salad it makes a perfect spring supper
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: ¼ tsp each ground cinnamon, allspice and nutmeg
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Boil the potato until tender, drain and mash, then leave to cool. Heat the oil in a non-stick pan, add the mince and onion and quickly fry until browned. Add the garlic, spices, stock, plenty of pepper and a little salt and mix well. Remove from the heat, stir into the potato and leave to cool.

Roll out half the pastry and line the base of a 20-23cm pie plate or flan tin. Fill with the pork mixture and brush the edges of the pastry with water. Roll out the remaining dough and cover the pie. Press the edges of the pastry to seal, trimming off the excess. Prick the top of the pastry case to allow steam to escape and glaze the top with the beaten egg.
Bake for 30 mins until the pastry is crisp and golden. Serve cut into wedges with a crisp green salad. Leftovers are good cold for lunch the next day, served with a selection of pickles.
chief_review:
This classic tourtière delivers a comforting blend of spices with lean minced pork, enriched by the subtle sweetness of onion and earthy potato. The warmth of cinnamon, allspice, and nutmeg adds a signature depth, reminiscent of traditional French-Canadian holiday tables. The ready-made shortcrust pastry provides a crisp, golden shell, perfectly contrasted by the moist filling. Minced pork ensures robust flavour without excessive fattiness. With minimal oil and straightforward steps, this recipe is accessible for home cooks seeking a hearty yet elegant main. 

This dish is ideal for those following a diet that includes meat but seeks a leaner protein source with moderate carbohydrates. However, please note that the inclusion of shortcrust pastry means the dish contains gluten, and the presence of egg makes it unsuitable for those with egg allergies. The ingredients list does not reveal any potential nuts or dairy, which may suit some common dietary needs.

name: Walnut & raisin oatcakes
description: Quick and easy to make, these biscuits will add a flourish to the final Christmas course
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Dissolve the baking powder in the milk. Beat the butter and sugar until pale and creamy, then mix in the oats, flour, raisins, walnuts and milk to make a stiff dough.

Tip the dough onto lightly floured surface and roll out until about 1cm thick. Cut into circles with a 5cm pastry cutter, place on an oiled baking sheet, then bake for 15 mins until lightly golden. Leave to cool, then serve with cheese. Can be baked up to 2 days ahead and kept in an airtight container until serving.
chief_review: These festive biscuits showcase a delightful harmony of textures—oats and wholemeal flour provide a hearty, rustic base, complemented by the sweetness of raisins and the earthy crunch of walnuts. The use of butter and milk lends richness and keeps the crumb tender, while a dash of baking powder ensures lightness. Their preparation is refreshingly straightforward, making them ideal for quick assembly during the holiday hustle. Notably, these biscuits are suitable for vegetarians, given the absence of animal meats or derivatives beyond dairy. Nut lovers will appreciate the robust walnut presence, though those with nut allergies should be cautious. Perfect for pairing with a post-dinner coffee or tea, they’ll round out your Christmas feast with a wholesome flourish.

name: Coconut ice squares
description: This recipe was re-tested and updated on 05 April 2011. It now uses 250g of sweetened condensed milk and works beautifully.
author: Lesley Waters
ingredients: 250g icing sugar, sifted, plus extra for dusting
directions: Using a wooden spoon, mix together the condensed milk and icing sugar in a large bowl. It will get very stiff. Work the coconut into the mix until it’s well combined – use your hands, if you like.

Split the mix into two and knead a very small amount of food colouring into one half. Dust a board with icing sugar, then shape each half into a smooth rectangle and place one on top of the other. Roll with a rolling pin, re-shaping with your hands every couple of rolls, until you have a rectangle of two-tone coconut ice about 3cm thick.

Transfer to a plate or board and leave uncovered for at least 3 hrs or ideally overnight to set. Cut into squares with a sharp knife and pack into bags or boxes. These will keep for up to a month at least, if stored in an airtight container.
chief_review: This delightful recipe delivers a soft, chewy treat with a pleasing sweetness and a subtle coconut aroma. Using desiccated coconut as the base, blended with icing sugar and sweetened condensed milk, the texture comes together lusciously without the need for baking—a boon for a quick dessert fix. The optional pink food colouring adds a playful visual element, perfect for festive occasions or afternoon tea trays. Since there are no eggs or wheat-based ingredients, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian and gluten-free diet, making it accessible for a broad range of guests. The method is straightforward, with the sifted icing sugar ensuring a smooth finish, and a light dusting before serving for an extra touch of finesse. An excellent choice for coconut lovers seeking a charming, crowd-pleasing confection!

name: Simple port & cranberry sauce
description: The big occasion just wouldn't be the same without a colourful cranberry sauce on the side.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 x 250g/9oz packs fresh or frozen cranberries
directions: Tip the port and sugar into a pan and bring to the boil. Add the cranberries, then cook for 5 mins for frozen and 8-10 mins for fresh until tender, but holding their shape. The sauce will thicken as it cools. Will keep in the fridge for 1 week or freeze for up to 6 weeks. Thaw for 2 hrs or overnight before serving.
chief_review: This cranberry sauce recipe is a delightful addition to any festive table, bringing a balanced harmony of tart and sweet notes thanks to the fresh cranberries and light muscovado sugar. Simmered in rich port, the sauce develops a deep, complex flavor that's both sophisticated and comforting—a true classic for celebratory meals. The vibrant color makes it visually appealing, while its lively acidity is perfect for cutting through richer dishes. As the ingredients are naturally gluten-free and suitable for a vegetarian or vegan diet (assuming the port is vegan-friendly), this sauce caters well to a variety of dietary preferences. It's also free from common allergens like dairy, eggs, and nuts. Ideal for those wanting a crowd-pleasing, versatile condiment that elevates the meal with minimal effort but maximum flavor.

name: Sticky pork with cranberries
description: Use up leftover Christmas cranberry sauce in this quick pork braise, lovely with a dollop of mash
author: Good Food
directions: Season the flour and dust the pork slices. Heat the oil in a large frying pan, then cook the pork for 3-4 mins each side until browned and cooked through. Transfer to a plate and set aside.

Add the red onion wedges to the pan and fry for 5-8 mins until soft and starting to turn golden. Stir in the stock, cranberry sauce and honey and simmer for 10 mins. Return the pork with any resting juices and gently cook for 1-2 mins until hot through. Serve with some mash or jacket potatoes and vegetables.
chief_review: This pork braise recipe is a clever and delicious way to use up extra cranberry sauce. The pork tenderloin cooks quickly to remain tender, while the red onions and sweet-tart cranberry sauce create a rich, balanced sauce that complements the meat beautifully. The hint of honey deepens the glaze, tying the flavours together. Served with a generous helping of mashed potatoes, this dish is hearty and comforting—a perfect winter warmer that brings new life to holiday leftovers. This recipe is ideal for those on a standard or dairy-free diet, but is not suitable for vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free diets due to the inclusion of pork and flour. The recipe's simplicity makes it accessible for weeknight cooking, yet it's elegant enough for a festive meal.

name: Spiced parsnip & ham soup
description: Use up your Christmas roast leftovers in this creamy soup
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100ml double cream, plus extra to drizzle
directions: Heat the oil in a saucepan and fry the curry powder for 1 min until fragrant. Stir in the veg, cover with three-quarters of the stock and simmer for 5-10 mins.

Blend the soup until very smooth with a hand blender or food processor, adding more stock if the soup is too thick. Stir in the cream and ham, then return to the pan and gently reheat. Season and serve with a drizzle of cream on top.
chief_review: This leftover Christmas roast soup is a clever and comforting way to reimagine festive flavors. The use of olive oil and mild curry powder adds an inviting warmth and subtle spice, pairing beautifully with the sweetness of roast potatoes and parsnips. Incorporating chicken or turkey stock lends depth, while a swirl of double cream gives the soup a luscious, velvety finish. The addition of shredded ham brings savory, smoky notes that round out the dish. This recipe is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the stock used is certified gluten-free. Ideal as a post-holiday meal, it showcases resourcefulness and culinary finesse in transforming leftovers into a nourishing, elegant soup.

name: Giant jaffa orange cake
description: Give the classic flavour combo of chocolate orange even more wow factor in this cake with zingy jelly and luxurious chocolate ganache
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 250g pack butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
zest 4 large orange(use the oranges below)
juice 5 large oranges(about 500ml), save the zest of 1 orange to finish
directions: First make the jelly. Grease a 20cm round cake tin and line with cling film (you can use the 23cm tin that you will bake the cake in, but you’ll have to make this the day before so that you can remove it before making the cake). Remove the zest from 4 of the oranges and set aside for the cake. Tip the orange juice and sugar into a saucepan and gently heat to dissolve the sugar. Meanwhile, soak the gelatine leaves in cold water for a few mins until soft. Remove the gelatine from the water, squeeze out any excess and add to the warm orange juice, stir until the gelatine has dissolved. Pour the liquid into the lined cake tin and chill for at least 4 hrs or preferably overnight.

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3 and line a 23cm round cake tin with baking parchment. Tip all the cake ingredients into a large mixing bowl and combine with an electric hand whisk until smooth. Spoon into the tin and smooth over the surface. Bake in the centre of the oven for 55 mins, or until a skewer inserted comes out clean. Cool in the tin for 15 mins, then invert onto a wire rack and leave to cool completely.

Now make the ganache. Heat the cream in a small pan until hot. Put the chocolate in a small bowl and pour over the cream, leave for 10 mins, then mix well – you should be left with a smooth chocolate sauce. Leave at room temperature until the ganache cools and thickens a little (you can put it in the fridge to speed this up, but keep an eye on it, as it will set quickly).

To assemble the cake, place it on a cake stand and trim the top to give you a flat surface. Warm the apricot jam in the microwave until a little runny. Paint it over the top of the cake, then flip the orange jelly out of its tin, and position on top. Using a palette knife, swirl the chocolate ganache over the orange jelly, letting it dribble down the sides of the cake a little. Serve straight away or within 24 hours.
chief_review:
This Chocolate Orange Cake is a showstopper, perfectly balancing rich chocolate ganache with vibrant, fresh orange notes. The use of both milk and dark chocolate creates depth, while the homemade orange jelly adds a playful, citrusy zing that’s both refreshing and elegant. The crumb is tender from the addition of yogurt and butter, ensuring moisture without heaviness. The apricot jam glaze and final zesting of orange elevate the presentation with a glossy, aromatic finish.

Suited to vegetarians, as all ingredients are plant-friendly with no gelatine made from animal rennet, this cake makes a luxurious centrepiece for any festive or celebratory occasion. However, note the inclusion of dairy (butter, yogurt, cream) and gelatine, so it's not vegan. With its careful layering of textures and flavours, this recipe is a masterful update on a much-loved classic.

name: Guinness pudding with Whisky cream
description: Soaking the fruit in Guinness really plumps it up and gives a rich, dark pudding without the bitterness of brandy or rum
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 1 large Bramley apple (about 125g), peeled and finely chopped
100g cold butter, plus extra for the basin
directions: Mix the dried fruit and apple, then add the Guinness, orange and lemon zests and stir. Cover and leave overnight to soak. Butter a 1.25 litre/2 pint pudding basin, then spoon in 2 tbsp dark muscovado sugar. Turn the bowl at an angle, jiggling the sugar around as you go to coat the inside of the bowl.
Mix the remaining dry ingredients in a large bowl. Grate the butter, then add to the bowl along with the eggs and fruit, and stir well. Spoon into the basin and level the top.
Take a sheet of foil about 30cm long, cover with a same-size sheet of greaseproof paper and butter the paper. Fold a 3cm pleat in the

Sit the pudding on a heatproof saucer in a saucepan, then pour in just-boiled water to come halfway up basin. Cover and steam for 6 hrs, topping up water occasionally. Re-cover with fresh paper and foil and store in a cool place. To reheat, steam for 1 hr or microwave, without foil, for 10 mins on Medium.
chief_review: This pudding recipe brings a wonderful depth of flavor by soaking an assortment of dried fruits in Guinness Extra Stout, lending a nuanced richness that sets it apart from traditional brandy or rum-based Christmas puddings. The combination of Bramley apple, aromatic spices, and citrus zest elevates the fruitiness, while dark muscovado sugar and butter provide a moist, indulgent texture. The use of self-raising flour and breadcrumbs gives the pudding a delightfully light crumb. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians and those looking to avoid nuts, as it contains only fruit, dairy, eggs, and grains, with no animal-derived gelatin or nut ingredients. The clever use of Guinness in place of stronger spirits results in a sophisticated, crowd-pleasing dessert with a remarkable depth and warmth, making it a festive centerpiece for any holiday table.

name: Chinese braised red cabbage
description: Add a zing to your red cabbage with this great accompaniment to cold meats at Christmas
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 3 red chillies, halved, deseeded and chopped
large piece fresh root ginger, peeled and finely sliced
directions: Tip all the ingredients, except the spring onions, sesame seeds and oil, into a large pan with a lid, and bring to a simmer. Cook over a low heat for 25-30 mins until all the liquid has evaporated and continue to cook, stirring regularly, until the juices become really sticky and glaze the cabbage.
Stir through half the spring onions and sesame seeds and pile into a bowl. Serve scattered with rest of the spring onions and sesame seeds and drizzled with the sesame oil.
chief_review: This vibrant red cabbage dish offers a delightful balance of heat, acidity, and umami, making it a standout accompaniment, especially for cold meats or festive spreads. The crunch of fresh cabbage pairs beautifully with aromatic ginger, fragrant star anise, and a pleasant kick from red chillies. The rice wine vinegar and soy sauce bring depth and a tangy sharpness, while the sesame oil and seeds layer in nutty undertones and a satisfying finish. The lack of animal-derived ingredients makes this recipe naturally suitable for vegans and vegetarians. Additionally, as long as gluten-free soy sauce is used, it caters well to gluten-free diets. The method is straightforward, ensuring bold flavors without fuss. Overall, this is a festive, versatile side that lifts any holiday table with freshness and complexity.

name: Spaghetti with walnuts, raisins & parsley
description: Use up leftover Christmas fruit and nuts in this superhealthy and super quick meal
author: Good Food
ingredients: small bunch flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
directions: Cook the pasta in boiling water, following pack instructions. Meanwhile, heat the oil in a frying pan and cook the onions until soft and golden brown – about 8-10 mins. Add the raisins and stock and cook for 2-3 mins until hot through. Toss with the pasta, Parmesan, walnuts and parsley.
chief_review: This inventive recipe cleverly transforms leftover festive fruit and nuts into a vibrant, wholesome pasta dish. The sweetness from raisins or sultanas beautifully offsets the savoriness of onions and umami notes from parmesan, while walnuts add a delightful crunch. A splash of either chicken or vegetable stock makes the sauce lush without overwhelming the ingredients' natural flavors. Finishing with fresh parsley lifts the entire dish with bright, herbal notes. The use of vegetable stock makes this a great option for vegetarians, while the simple list of common allergens (gluten, milk, tree nuts) can be easily adjusted to suit further dietary needs. A perfect weekday meal: fast, flavorful, and resourceful—a chef’s ideal way to elevate leftovers.

name: Spiced parsnip bubble & squeak
description: A good Sunday side dish, or veggie main, great served with a chunky tomato chutney
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1⁄2 Savoy cabbage or 300g Brussles sprouts, finely shredded
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Tip the parsnips into a pan of cold water with the turmeric and a little salt and boil for about 12 mins until they are on the brink of collapsing. While the parsnips are cooking, blanch the cabbage or sprouts in another pan of boiling water for 3 mins until tender, adding the peas for the final min, then drain well.

Drain the parsnips well, then tip back into the pan and roughly mash with the lemon juice and half the butter. Then beat in all the other ingredients except the remaining butter, and season with salt. Heat the remaining butter in a non-stick frying pan about 28cm in diameter, and press the parsnip mixture into the pan. Cook until crisp underneath, then turn over with a fish slice. (Don’t worry if it breaks at this point, it will hold eventually.) Keep cooking until crisp on the other side, then slide onto a plate and flip back into the pan again. Keep on doing this until you have a crisp, puck-shaped cake. Serve on a plate or board, cut into wedges.
chief_review: This vibrant vegetable dish stands out for its clever blend of warming spices and comforting textures. The parsnips, spiced with turmeric and cumin, provide an earthy sweetness balanced by the lemon's freshness and a hint of chilli heat. The cabbage or Brussels sprouts and peas bring crunch and color, making this both hearty and visually appealing. Butter adds mellow richness, though a simple swap for a plant-based alternative can transform this into a vegan-friendly option. The dish is naturally gluten-free and suitable for vegetarians. Served with a robust tomato chutney, it’s a satisfying Sunday side or a main course for those seeking a flavorful, plant-forward meal. The finishing touch of fresh coriander elevates the aroma and taste beautifully.

name: Lemon & herb stuffing
description: Add a citrus zing to your Christmas turkey this year with this zesty, fresh stuffing
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 smoked, dry-cured streaky bacon rashers, halved across the middle
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Heat the oil in a large frying pan, then soften the onions for 10 mins with the pan covered. Put the bread and herbs into a food processor and pulse until you have herby breadcrumbs. Stir into the onion pan along with the lemon zest and juice and plenty of seasoning. Set aside 250g to stuff the turkey, then press the remainder into a well buttered baking tin or dish, about 20 x 30cm, or use 2 smaller tins if that’s all that you have.

Wrap half a bacon rasher around each sausage. Score the stuffing into 8 rectangles, then sit a sausage on top of each. Cover with foil and cook for 20 mins. Uncover, then roast for 20 mins more or until the sausages and bacon are golden and the stuffing golden and sizzling.
chief_review: This festive stuffing brings a lively citrus twist to the classic Christmas turkey. The combination of sautéed onions, fresh parsley, and sage provides a fragrant herbal backbone, while lemon zest and juice add brightness that cuts through the richness of the traditional bread base. The addition of cocktail sausages and smoked bacon gives it depth, savouriness, and a satisfying texture contrast. Perfect for those seeking an imaginative spin on familiar flavors, this recipe is well-suited to those without gluten or meat restrictions, as it contains bread, sausage, and bacon. The generous use of herbs and lemon ensures the stuffing remains vibrant and light, complementing heavier main courses beautifully. For best results, use good-quality sourdough and well-cured bacon for maximum flavor impact.

name: Baked buffalo chicken wings
description: Sticky spiced wings make great finger food or canapés, and this version skips the deep-fried stage so they're healthier
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 tbsp peppersauce (we used Frank's hot sauce)
1½ kg chicken wing, halved at the joint
directions: In a large bowl, mix together the garlic, olive oil, cider vinegar, paprika, Worcestershire sauce, celery salt, hot sauce, honey and a couple of cracks of black pepper. Add the chicken wings and toss around to make sure they’re fully covered in the marinade. If you have time, leave the wings to marinate for a couple of hrs in the fridge or ideally overnight.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Drain and reserve the marinade, then spread the wings out on a very large baking tray. Bake for 30 mins, then pour off the excess oil, add the reserved marinade and toss well. Increase oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Return to the oven and cook for a further 30 mins, tossing a few times to coat in the glaze as they cook. They should be sticky and glazed with most of the marinade evaporated. Serve on a large platter alongside other party snacks.
chief_review: These sticky spiced chicken wings strike an excellent balance between flavor and health, skipping the deep-frying for roasting or baking. The combination of garlic, paprika, and Frank’s hot sauce delivers a bold, bright heat, while honey and cider vinegar introduce a pleasant tang and sweetness. Worcestershire sauce deepens the umami, rounding out the marinade. They're perfect for gatherings, serving well as canapés or finger food at parties. This recipe is naturally gluten-free, provided you verify your Worcestershire and hot sauces are certified gluten-free, making it a great option for those with gluten sensitivities. The use of olive oil keeps the dish lighter than traditional wings, making them a guilt-free indulgence. These wings are a crowd-pleaser, perfectly sticky, spicy, and satisfying.

name: Strawberry jam
description: James Martin's step-by-step guide to making homemade preserve - the resulting jars are ideal for gift hampers
author: James Martin
directions: Prepare the strawberries by wiping them with a piece of damp kitchen paper. (Wiping the strawberries rather than washing them ensures the fruit doesn’t absorb lots of water – too much water and the jam won’t set easily.) To hull the fruit, use a knife to cut a cone shape into the strawberry and remove the stem. Cut any large berries in half.

Put the strawberries in a bowl and gently toss through the sugar. Leave uncovered at room temperature for 12 hrs or overnight. This process helps the sugar to dissolve, ensures the fruit doesn’t disintegrate too much and helps to keep its vibrant colour.

Before starting the jam, put 2 saucers in the freezer. Tip the strawberry mixture into a preserving pan with the lemon juice. Set over a low heat and cook very gently. If any sugar remains on the sides of the pan, dip a pastry brush in hot water and brush the sugar away.

When you can no longer feel any grains of sugar remaining, turn up the heat to start bubbling the jam and bringing it to the boil. (The sugar must be completely dissolved before increasing the heat, otherwise it will be difficult for the jam to set, and it may contain crystallised lumps of sugar.)

Boil hard for 5-10 mins until the jam has reached 105C on a preserving or digital thermometer, then turn off the heat. If you don’t have a thermometer, spoon a little jam onto one of the cold saucers. Leave for 30 secs, then push with your finger; if the jam wrinkles and doesn’t flood to fill the gap, it is ready. If not, turn the heat back on and boil for 2 mins more, then turn off the heat and do the wrinkle test again. Repeat until ready.
Use a spoon to skim any scum that has risen to the surface and discard this. Do this only once at the end, rather than constantly during the boiling stage, to reduce wastage.

Add a knob of butter, if you like, to the finished jam, and stir in to melt. This will help to dissolve any remaining scum that you haven’t managed to spoon off the top. Leave the jam to settle for 15 mins – this will ensure that the fruit stays suspended in the mixture and doesn’t all float to the top of the jam jar. Meanwhile, sterilise your jars.

Ladle into warm jars, filling to just below the rim. Place a wax disc on top of the jam (this prevents mildew forming), then cover with a lid or a cellophane circle and elastic band. Pop on a label (include the date), plus a pretty fabric top, if you like.
Refrigerate after opening.
chief_review:
James Martin’s strawberry preserve recipe is a delightful classic, ideal for both beginner and experienced home cooks. The use of jam sugar ensures a reliable set, while lemon juice brightens the flavor and helps balance the sweetness. The optional knob of butter is a useful tip to reduce foaming, resulting in a clear, glossy jam. With its straightforward ingredients and simple technique, this preserve is perfect for transforming seasonal strawberries into something special. 

It’s naturally vegetarian and gluten-free, making it suitable for a range of diets. For those with dairy allergies or seeking a vegan option, simply omit the butter—its exclusion won’t impact the final result significantly. Overall, this jam is delicious on toast, scones, or as a thoughtful homemade gift.

name: Ham with boozy cranberry & mushroom sauce
description: An easy and decadent way to use up leftover Christmas ham
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 clementines, satsumas or mandarins, juice only
1 tsp bouillon powder or ½ chicken stock cube, crumbled
about 350g leftover cooked ham, cut into chunky slices
directions: To fry the mushrooms, heat the oil and butter in a frying pan over a high heat until the butter is foaming. Add the mushrooms and fry for 4-5 minutes until they're golden.

To make the sauce, pour in the port or wine to deglaze the pan, then lower the heat and stir in the cranberry sauce until dissolved. Pour in the hot water and fruit juice and sprinkle in the bouillon powder or stock cube. Splash in a spoonful or so of soy sauce and stir well. Turn up the heat and boil the sauce rapidly for a few minutes until it reduces slightly.
Slide in the ham and heat through for a minute or two. Taste for seasoning and serve.
chief_review: This festive leftover ham dish brings rich, comforting flavors together with minimal fuss. The combination of chestnut mushrooms sautéed in olive oil and butter, deglazed with port or red wine and lifted by the zing of citrus juice and cranberry sauce, delivers a beautifully balanced sauce. The splash of soy sauce and addition of bouillon or chicken stock reinforce umami depth, perfectly complementing the chunky slices of succulent ham. This recipe suits those who appreciate robust, savory profiles with hints of sweetness and acidity. Ideal for omnivores, it deftly reimagines Christmas leftovers into a new, mouthwatering main course. The method is straightforward, ensuring the ham remains tender while the sauce coats each bite luxuriously. Pair with buttery mash or a simple green vegetable for a complete meal.

name: Creamy risotto layer cake
description: A perfect veggie main that goes brilliantly with traditional Christmas accompaniments
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 300g shallot, half chopped, the rest thinly sliced
100g vegetarian parmesan-style cheese, finely grated (we used Twineham Grange Itlaian-style cheese)
1 large butternut squash (about 1.2kg/2lb 10oz unprepped weight), peeled and cut into small cubes
2 Savoy cabbages (you only need the outside leaves)
directions: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large pan and fry the chopped shallots over a low heat for 10 mins until well softened. Add the garlic, cook for another min, then tip in the rice. Stir the rice until coated in the oil, and keep stirring until the grains are really hot and starting to hiss. Pour in the wine and stir. Once it’s almost all been absorbed, start adding the stock, a ladle at a time, allowing each ladleful to absorb before adding the next. Stir in a good knob of butter and 25g of the vegetarian Parmesan and season to taste. Tip onto a large baking tray and spread out so that it cools quickly (see Know-how, below). Once cool, keep covered in the fridge. Can be cooked and cooled up to 2 days ahead.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Tip the squash into a roasting pan. Toss with 1 tbsp oil and roast for about 30 mins until softened and golden, turning it occasionally. Meanwhile, melt another knob of butter in a frying pan, add 1 tbsp oil, then fry the sliced shallots until softened and dark golden, about 15 mins. Stir in the chestnuts, pine nuts and herbs, season, then cook for another 2 mins until heated through. Mix with the roasted squash. Can be made up to 2 days ahead.

Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Remove any tough outer leaves from the cabbage, then separate the large green leaves from the heads. You’ll need about 10. Blanch for 2 mins or until just tender, then plunge into cold water and drain.

Line a 23cm springform cake tin with cling film (or, if reheating in the oven, just butter the tin liberally), then line with most of the cabbage leaves, overlapping slightly and leaving an overhanging edge. Mix the remaining vegetarian Parmesan and the mascarpone together, seasoning well with salt and pepper. Spoon half the risotto into the tin (if you’ve chilled the risotto overnight, it’ll need breaking up a little with a fork), then top with the squash mix. Spoon the mascarpone mix over the top, then finish with a second layer of risotto, pressing in firmly.

Fold the overhanging edges of the cabbage over the risotto and then ‘seal’ it in with the remaining leaves. Cover with the overhanging cling film; weight down with a dinner plate. Can be made up to 2 days ahead (if risotto is cooked, cooled and layered on the day).

To reheat, turn the cake (still in its cling film) out of the tin onto a microwave-proof plate and cook on Medium for 10 mins or until piping hot throughout. (Microwaving will give you the best results as it keeps the cabbage green and vibrant.) To reheat in the oven, leave the cake in its tin, cover with buttered foil and heat for 30 mins at 180C/fan 160C/gas 4 until hot through.
chief_review:
This festive veggie main is a standout dish, showcasing a beautifully balanced risotto brimming with robust flavors and textural contrasts. The combination of roasted butternut squash, chestnuts, and toasted pine nuts delivers a sweet, nutty richness, complemented by fragrant sage and rosemary. The creamy mascarpone and vegetarian parmesan-style cheese ensure a luscious, indulgent finish. The use of Savoy cabbage leaves adds a rustic touch, visually elevating the presentation.

Notably, the use of vegetarian parmesan guarantees this dish is suitable for vegetarians, as traditional parmesan contains animal rennet. With its reliance on naturally gluten-free risotto rice and absence of wheat-based ingredients, this recipe is also appropriate for gluten-free diets, provided the stock and other processed ingredients are certified gluten free. This is a hearty, satisfying centerpiece, perfect for anyone seeking a luxurious meatless option at a festive table.

name: Cranberry pecan & ginger loaf
description: Impress your family with Mary Cadogan’s lighter alternative to the traditional Christmas cake
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: grated zest and juice 1 large orange
2 tsp each baking powder and ground ginger
extra pecans, dried apricots, vanilla pod, cinnamon sticks, sliced ginger, glacé cherries and cranberries, to decorate
directions: Heat oven to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2. Butter and double line the base and sides of a 20cm square deep cake tin with baking parchment. Grind 100g of the pecans in a food processor.

Chop up the butter and put in a large heavy-based pan with the sugar, cranberries, apricots, orange zest and juice and brandy. Bring slowly to the boil, stirring until the butter is melted, then simmer for 10 mins until the fruits are plump and glossy. Remove from the heat and cool for 30 mins.

Beat the eggs lightly. Sift together the flour, baking powder, ground ginger and cinnamon. Stir the eggs, ground pecans, remaining pecan halves, flour mixture and crystallised ginger into the pan, stirring until well mixed.

Spoon into the prepared tin and smooth the top. Bake for 1 hr, then reduce the temperature to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1 and cook for a further 1½-2 hrs, until the cake feels firm and a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean. Cool in the tin for 10 mins, turn out, then remove the paper and leave to cool completely on a wire rack.

Warm the jam with 1 tbsp water, then press through a sieve into a bowl. Put the cake on a board and brush the top with a thin layer of jam, reserving some for later. Lightly dust a surface with icing sugar, then roll out the marzipan to slightly larger than the top of the cake. Lift onto the cake, press on lightly, then trim to meet the edges. Cut in half.

Brush the remaining jam over the marzipan, then decorate the tops with dried fruits, nuts and other ingredients of your choice. Wrap each cake first in baking parchment, then in foil. Store in the tin for up to 3 weeks. Can be frozen for up to 2 months.
chief_review: Mary Cadogan’s lighter Christmas cake is a delightful twist on tradition, packed with vibrant flavors from dried cranberries, apricots, and aromatic ginger. The inclusion of pecans offers a pleasant crunch, while the orange zest and brandy infuse the cake with a festive warmth. The marzipan layer provides classic richness, offset by the light muscovado sugar for a subtle caramel note. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and suits those looking for a lighter yet still indulgent centerpiece. Carefully arranged glistening fruits and nuts make for a showstopping presentation. A well-balanced, beautifully textured cake perfect for holiday celebrations.

chief_review: This festive vegetable risotto is a show-stopping main that offers a luxurious balance of flavors: creamy arborio rice enriched with mascarpone and vegetarian parmesan-style cheese, sweet bursts of butternut squash, earthy chestnuts, and the aromatic lift of sage and rosemary. The addition of crunchy pine nuts and tender Savoy cabbage leaves provides compelling textural contrast. With a base of olive oil and an abundance of vegetables, this dish is ideal for vegetarians, making it a superb centerpiece for those seeking an alternative to the traditional Christmas roast. The use of gluten-free ingredients like rice and naturally gluten-free cheeses also makes it a potential choice for gluten-free diets, provided the stock and mascarpone are certified gluten-free. Ultimately, this comforting yet elegant risotto perfectly captures the warmth and generosity of the holiday table.

name: Saffron roast turkey
description: Classic roast turkey not your thing? Add a bit of spice and some special sausages and make a meal to remember
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 3 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
2 x 20g packs flat-leaf parsley, chopped, plus generous sprigs to garnish
directions: Peel the zest from the lemon, then cut into strips, finely chop and set aside. Now cut the lemon in two, squeeze its juice into a bowl with the saffron and mix together. Fry the sliced onions in the oil until soft and starting to colour, then add the coriander, cumin and lemon zest and cook for 1 min more. Remove from the heat, stir in the cranberries, nuts, couscous and chopped parsley, then season well. When cool, beat in the eggs.

Wash and dry the turkey, removing any feathers with tweezers. Pull out the giblets and neck and discard, or use to make stock for the gravy. Lift up the skin that covers the neck opening, then push some stuffing into the cavity, packing it in well. Secure tightly underneath with a skewer or two cocktail sticks. Shape the rest of the stuffing firmly into balls and chill until ready to bake. Put the onion quarters in the turkey cavity with any leftover stalks from the parsley. Can chill at this stage up to 1 day ahead.

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Weigh the stuffed turkey and calculate the cooking time, allowing 40 mins per kg (20 mins per lb). Put the turkey in a roasting tin. Mix the butter with the saffron mixture and brush generously onto the turkey. Pour 500ml water into the tin, then roast for 1 hr. Brush with the buttery mixture again, then loosely cover with foil and roast until 15 mins before the time is up. Mix the honey into the remaining buttery mix, brush over the turkey and cook uncovered for 15 mins more until golden.

Pierce the turkey thigh through its thickest part – the juices should run clear. If not, return to the oven for another 20 mins and test again. Leave to rest on a platter, covered with a clean tea towel. Reserve the juices in the roasting tin to make the gravy.

Meanwhile, twist the sausages in half and snip to separate. Toss with the harissa, oil and onions in another roasting tin, then roast for 1 hr until golden. After 40 mins roasting, add the stuffing balls to the tin.

To make the gravy, drain the juices from the tin into a jug and skim off the excess oil. Put the roasting tin over heat, pour in the stock and loosen the savoury bits on the base with a wooden spoon. Add any juices from the resting bird to the mixture along with the onions from the sausages, then simmer for about 10 mins. Blitz with a hand blender until smooth and thick. Taste and season, or add a little redcurrant jelly to sweeten, if you like.
To serve, put the turkey on a platter and surround with the sausages and stuffing balls. Garnish with parsley sprigs and bay.
chief_review: This inventive twist on a holiday roast turkey is brimming with Middle Eastern flair, courtesy of vibrant spices like coriander, cumin, saffron, and harissa.
