The addition of quality pork sausage adds remarkable depth and succulence, while pistachios and cranberries bring delightful bursts of texture and tang. The couscous stuffing, brought together by fresh parsley and a hint of sweet honey, is aromatic and well-balanced, though care is needed to avoid overcooking and drying the grains. With both eggs and a generous dose of olive oil, the mixture is luxuriously moist. The use of both turkey and pork makes this dish flavorful and hearty—ideal for a festive centerpiece sure to please adventurous palates. Note: Contains nuts, gluten, and eggs.

name: Perky turkey soup
description: A warming winter treat, this spicy turkey soup is a great use of Christmas leftovers - happy Boxing Day!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 large onion, halved and sliced into thin strips
1 red pepper, seeded and sliced into thin strips
3 tbsp basmati riceor long grain rice
1½ l hot turkey or chicken stock
250g 9oz turkey meat, cut into thin strips (leg meat will have the most flavour)
a handful of fresh coriander or flatleaf parsley, roughly chopped (optional)
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan, add the onion and fry for 5 minutes or so, stirring every now and then until it starts to soften.

To make the soup, add the red pepper, ground coriander, chilli and rice and stir round the pan for about a minute. Pour in the hot stock, stir in the turkey and chickpeas and season well. Bring to the boil, cover and simmer for 8-10 minutes, until the vegetables and rice are tender. Stir in the coriander or parsley and it’s ready. (The soup may now be cooled and frozen for up to 1 month.)
chief_review: This Spicy Turkey Soup is a deliciously hearty and aromatic way to repurpose Christmas leftovers, particularly turkey. The use of fragrant ground coriander and a kick of chilli flakes add depth and warmth, perfect for winter days. Chickpeas boost the soup’s protein and texture, while rice thickens the broth and creates satisfying body. The inclusion of both turkey and chicken stock, alongside turkey meat itself, makes this soup unsuitable for vegetarians or vegans, but it is a strong option for those following a high-protein or dairy-free diet. Notably, basmati or long grain rice ensures the soup remains naturally gluten-free, ideal for those with gluten sensitivities. Garnishing with fresh coriander or parsley brightens the flavors and adds color. Overall, this soup is a nourishing, flavorful bowl that brings comfort and excitement to your holiday table.

name: Broccoli soup with cheese toasties
description: Nice soup but I added an onion and a garlic clove, softened in a little oil at the start. Also only used 1L of stock and stirred through a tablespoon of herby Philadelphia at the end, very tasty!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g cheese, grated – cheddar, red leicester or any blue cheese
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the potato and stock in a saucepan and bring to the boil, turn down to simmer for 10 mins until the potato is tender, then add the broccoli and some seasoning and cook for another 4-5 mins. Blend the soup until smooth, then return to the pan and keep warm while you make the toasties.

Whizz 1 slice of bread to make crumbs, then stir in the cheese, egg and onions. Spread over 3 slices of bread, add a dash of Worcestershire sauce, and sandwich each one together with the remaining slices. Brush with oil and bake for 10 mins, turning halfway through, until the outside is crisp and golden and middle melted. Cut into triangles and serve with the soup.
chief_review: This broccoli and cheese soup offers a comforting, well-balanced depth of flavor, especially with the addition of softened onion and garlic. The herby Philadelphia stirred in at the end adds a satisfying creamy finish, complementing the robust cheese mix. Using either chicken or vegetable stock and omitting meat, the recipe is well-suited for lacto-ovo vegetarians. Cheese and egg enrich the soup’s protein profile, while diced potato brings heartiness. The bread rounds out the meal, perfect for dipping. Those preferring a gluten-free variant could substitute gluten-free bread. The soup’s flexibility with cheese types—from sharp cheddar to pungent blue—invites personal expression. It’s a wholesome and inviting dish, ideal as a nourishing lunch or dinner centerpiece for the vegetarian table.

name: Smoked salmon carbonara
description: If you've got leftover smoked salmon trimmings, use them up in this creamy, indulgent pasta dish
author: Good Food
directions: Cook the spaghetti. Meanwhile, melt the butter in a small pan, add the garlic and gently sizzle for 1 min. Remove from the heat.
Lightly beat the cream, eggs, softened garlic and half the Parmesan in a bowl. Stir in the smoked salmon trimmings.

Drain the pasta well and return to the pan. Add the salmon mixture and the chives, then toss well so the heat from the pasta lightly thickens the sauce. Serve scattered with the remaining Parmesan and plenty of black pepper.
chief_review: This smoked salmon pasta is a luxurious twist on classic carbonara, perfect for transforming leftovers into an elegant meal. The rich blend of double cream, eggs, and freshly grated Parmesan creates a lusciously creamy sauce, while the smoked salmon trimmings add depth and an irresistible smoky note. Chives provide a fresh, subtle lift to cut through the richness. The recipe is a standout for pescatarians and works beautifully for those on a fish-inclusive diet. Note that it contains gluten and dairy, making it unsuitable for gluten-free or lactose-free requirements. The preparation is swift thanks to quick-cook spaghetti, making it an ideal midweek indulgence. A well-executed, satisfying dish with balanced flavors.

name: Lime semifreddo cheesecake
description: Mine didn’t make the ice cream consistency and we found it had no sweetness. For me this just didn’t work unfortunately. We used dried cranberries which also added to the fail.
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: finely grated zest 3 limes, plus extra to serve
directions: Line a 900g loaf tin with a large piece of foil. Press down well into the base and sides of the tin, and leave plenty overhanging the edges. Put the biscuits in a freezer bag and bash to crumbs with a rolling pin. Mix with the melted butter and tip the crumbs into the prepared tin – press firmly into the base to create an even layer. Chill while the filling is made.

Use an electric whisk on a medium setting to beat the condensed milk, cheese and cream together until smooth and thickened – this will take around 2 mins. Add the grated zest and juice, and beat slowly until the cheese mixture forms soft peaks.

Spoon the lime mixture over the biscuit base. Cover lightly with the overhanging foil and seal firmly to keep out as much air as possible. Wrap in a second layer of foil, pop into a large freezer bag and freeze overnight.

To make the cranberry compote, put the cranberries, sugar and 150ml cold water in a saucepan and bring to a simmer. Cook for 5 mins, stirring occasionally, until the cranberries are softened but holding their shape. Mix the arrowroot or cornflour with 2 tbsp cold water until smooth, then stir into the fruit. Cook for another 2 mins, stirring regularly. Leave to cool, then cover and chill. Can be frozen at this stage.
Turn out the frozen cheesecake onto a platter or board and leave to thaw for 30 mins, then carefully peel off the foil. Warm the cranberry compote gently and serve with the sliced semifreddo.
chief_review: This recipe presents a rich and creamy dessert with a tangy twist from lime and cranberries. The crust, made from digestive biscuits and butter, pairs delightfully with the luxurious filling of condensed milk, cream cheese, and double cream, while the lime zest adds freshness. The cranberry topping brings a vibrant color and a subtle tartness, balanced by golden caster sugar. Using ground arrowroot or cornflour helps achieve a thick, glossy finish. This dessert is ideal for festive occasions or when you crave a zesty sweet treat. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin, but relies on dairy for its creamy base. The flavors are well-balanced, though the recipe could benefit from adjusting sugar levels for personal taste or adding a touch of vanilla for extra depth.

name: Chocolate orange & Grand Marnier truffle cake
description: This naughty pudding is the perfect way to use up all those Christmas Chocolate Oranges. A definite winner
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 dark Terry's chocolate oranges, seperated into segments
grated dark chocolate or chocolate curls
directions: Line the base and sides of a 1kg loaf tin with cling film. Squeeze the juice from the orange and mix with 3 tbsp of the Grand Marnier. Cut away the bitter white pith from inside the orange shell, then cut the peel into fine strips and boil it in a covered pan with 300ml water for 20 mins until soft. Add the sugar, then simmer uncovered for a bit longer until you have a soft, sticky peel.
Melt the chocolate over a pan of water, then take from the heat and beat in the butter and egg yolks, followed by the rest of the Grand Marnier.
Whisk the egg whites until they hold their shape, then whip the cream until softly stiff. Fold both of them into the chocolate mixture.

Spoon 5 large tbsp of the chocolate mixture into the tin, then dip the finger biscuits in the orange and Grand Marnier mixture one by one and arrange over the chocolate layer – don’t soak them too much or they will fall apart. Scatter over some of the sticky peel, then spoon on another 5 tbsp of the chocolate mixture.

Carry on layering up the biscuits and chocolate mixture until you have 4 layers of biscuit, finishing with a chocolate layer. You should only need to use half the peel. Lightly cover with cling film and freeze until ready to serve. Freeze the remaining peel separately.

To serve, take the cake and orange peel out of the freezer no more than 1 hr before serving and strip off the cling film. Top with whipped cream and the remaining peel, and scatter with the grated chocolate. Keep chilled until ready to eat.
chief_review: This indulgent pudding takes the iconic Terry’s Chocolate Orange and transforms it into a festive delight, elegantly balanced with tangy orange zest and aromatic Grand Marnier. The combination of whipped cream, softly creamed butter, and egg yolks ensures a decadent, silky texture, while the crushed rich tea biscuits add a pleasant, nostalgic crunch. Separating the eggs and folding in the whipped whites lends a lightness that offsets the richness of the chocolate and cream. Finished with a flourish of grated dark chocolate or chocolate curls, this dessert delivers multiple layers of flavor and texture—each spoonful laced with citrus and sophisticated notes of liqueur. This recipe contains no meat or gelatin, making it suitable for a vegetarian audience, though it does feature dairy and eggs. An excellent end to a celebratory meal, it’s a showstopper sure to impress at any holiday table.

name: Canapés & cocktails
description: The chicken poppadoms are lovely! Highly recommend, flew off the plate! Ideal before a Indian meal :O)
author: Good Food
directions: Marinate 150g cooked prawns in zest and juice 1 lime, 1 tbsp soy sauce, ½ finely chopped chilli, 2 tsp grated fresh root ginger and 1 tsp clear honey for 20 mins-1 hr. To serve, lay each prawn on a baby spinach leaf and thread a cocktail stick through (makes 28).

Mash 100g feta with ½ finely chopped chilli, 2 tsp chopped mint and zest and juice ¼ lemon. Roll into 24 small balls. Quarter 6 prosciutto slices lengthways, then wrap each prosciutto strip around a feta ball (makes 24).

Cut 1 large cucumber into 20 thick slices and scoop out some of the seedy middle, leaving a dip. Mix 200ml crème fraîche with zest 1 lemon and freshly ground black pepper, then spoon 1 tsp into each dip. Top with a piece smoked salmon, lemon zest and some black pepper (makes 20).

Take 20 small crackers (we used Morrisons Gouda cheese & mixed seeds cracker bites) or 20 homemade crostini. Spread 1 tsp red pesto onto each cracker, top each with a piece of mozzarella from a 125g ball and garnish with basil leaves (makes 20).

Arrange a 75g tub mini poppadums on a plate and slice 85g cooked chicken so there’s 1 piece per poppadum. Mix together ½ tsp curry powder, 100ml crème fraîche and zest ½ lemon, put 1 tsp in each poppadum with ½ tsp mango chutney, then finish with a slice of chicken and some chopped coriander. Best assembled just before serving so the poppadums stay crisp (makes 20).

Put 140g fresh or frozen cranberries, a handful mint and 2 tbsp brown sugar in a bowl. Crush with the end of a rolling pin, then add a couple of handfuls of crushed ice and stir to mix. Add a shot of vodka to 6-8 tall glasses, divide the cranberry crush between them, then top up with cranberry juice and sparkling water (serves 6-8).
chief_review: An impressive array of vibrant appetizers, this selection promises a lively start to any festive Indian-inspired gathering. The curried chicken poppadoms are the star, offering bold flavors and an inviting crunch that pairs beautifully with the zesty tang of the spicy prawn skewers. The cucumber salmon provides a refreshing, light counterpoint, while the stuffed prosciutto balls and red pesto & mozzarella festive crackers contribute satisfying savory notes and a pleasing variety in texture. The Christmas cranberry mojitos add a festive flourish, balancing tartness and sweetness. This platter is best suited for omnivores and those without specific food allergies, as it contains seafood, dairy, and processed meats. Overall, it’s a fun and delicious way to kick off an evening, guaranteed to disappear quickly from any party table.

name: Eccles cake
description: A new take on the traditional pastry, this cake will go down well on any occasion
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 250g pack butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
2 eating apples, peeled, cored and diced to about 1cm pieces
a few sugar cubes, roughly crushed
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease and line a deep 20cm cake tin with baking parchment. Mix together the filling ingredients and set aside.

Put butter, sugar and vanilla in a bowl and whisk until pale. Beat in the eggs, then fold in the flours, buttermilk and apples. Spoon half the mixture into the tin. Scatter over filling, leaving a 2.5cm clear border all around the edge. Spoon remaining mixture on top, starting by dolloping round the edges, then moving into the middle. Bake for 1 hr 25 mins or until a skewer poked in comes out clean. Cool in the tin.
Mix the icing sugar with enough lemon juice to make a runny-ish icing. Remove cake from the tin, drizzle over the icing, then scatter with crushed sugar cubes and lemon zest.
chief_review: This delightful cake reinvents the pastry tradition with an aromatic blend of spices, fresh apple, and citrus zest for a beautifully moist crumb and sophisticated flavor. The addition of buttermilk ensures tenderness, while the dual use of plain and self-raising flours strikes a lovely balance in structure and lightness. Apples provide sweetness and texture, harmonizing with currants, raisins, and mixed peel for a subtle richness. The fragrant spice medley of cinnamon, cloves, and mixed spice delivers depth, ideal for autumn or festive gatherings. A zesty lemon icing, with a playful hint of sugar crunch, crowns the bake for extra freshness and visual appeal. The recipe contains eggs, dairy, and wheat, making it suitable for vegetarians but not for those seeking dairy-free or gluten-free options. Perfect as a centerpiece for tea or celebration, this cake brings classic comfort with a tasteful twist.

name: Pickled pears & cheese platter
description: This stunning prepare-ahead starter can be served on individual plates, or just gather everyone around for drinks in the kitchen
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp white or yellow mustard seed
large loaf of walnut or other nutty brown breadwith a good crust
good wedge (about 700g) of strong cheese, like stiltonor Stichelton or a firmish goat's cheese
directions: Put the vinegar, sugar and spices into a large saucepan with 500ml of water. Heat gently to melt the sugar. Meanwhile, peel the pears, halve, then scoop out the core with a teaspoon or melon-baller. Add the pears to the pan, they should be just about covered with the liquid, then bring to a simmer for 25-30 mins. Test the pears with a tip of a knife – they should be just tender. Lift out with a slotted spoon and put into a large Kilner jar or a few smaller ones. Boil the liquid down to about 600ml, then pour over the pears to cover. Seal and store in the fridge for up to a week, before serving.

On Christmas Day, remove the pears from the fridge so they come up to room temperature. To serve, thickly slice and toast the bread and slice the cheese into thin wedges. Lift the pears from the jar and layer up with the cheese on a large platter or board, then scatter with some leaves. Serve with the bread.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful celebration of autumnal flavors, perfect for a sophisticated starter that pairs sweet, tangy pears with robust cheese and hearty nut bread. The poached pears, briefly pickled in a fragrant cider vinegar syrup with pink peppercorns and mustard seeds, add complexity and brightness that beautifully complement strong cheeses like Stilton or goat’s cheese. The use of nutty brown bread provides a rustic, satisfying base, while a handful of winter salad leaves bring the dish freshness and balance. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, provided a vegetarian cheese is chosen. For those mindful of gluten, substituting the nut bread with a gluten-free alternative will suit dietary needs. It’s ideally served as an elegant, make-ahead starter—inviting guests to gather, share, and savor bold, seasonal flavors.

name: Spinach & feta falafel bites
description: These simple canapés can be made ahead of time and served up at your Christmas party
author: Good Food
directions: Pour a kettle of boiling water over baby spinach in a colander. When cool enough to handle, squeeze out any water – do this really well or your falafels will be too soft. Pulse in a food processor with drained chickpeas, feta, cumin and plain flour until just combined. Roll into tbsp-sized balls with wellfloured hands, then flatten into patties.

Fry in batches in vegetable oil for 2-3 mins each side, then leave to cool. Place on a baking tray, cover with cling film and freeze. To serve, defrost in the fridge overnight and cook at 180C/160C fan/ gas 4 for 5-10 mins. Serve with tzatziki.
chief_review: These spinach and chickpea canapés are a delightful addition to any party spread, bringing together Mediterranean-inspired flavors with minimal fuss. The combination of creamy feta, earthy chickpeas, and aromatic cumin offers a balanced bite that’s both satisfying and memorable. The pan-fried exterior delivers a subtle crispness, while the tender, flavorful interior is complemented perfectly by a dollop of refreshing tzatziki. Notably, these canapés cater well to vegetarian guests, making them an inclusive and popular choice for gatherings. Prepping ahead ensures ease during the event, while their compact size makes for effortless nibbling. Serve warm or at room temperature for maximum versatility.

name: Creamy porridge with spiced apple & cranberry
description: Just made the compote and had some if it with ice cream for dessert, looking forward to putting the rest on my morning porridge. I used dried cranberries which may be why mine didn't turn out as red and juicy as in the picture - will double the water next time. Will definitely make again, very tasty.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 eating apples, peeled, quartered, cored and diced
directions: Put the apples in a pan with 100ml water and cook gently until almost softened. Turn up the heat. Add the cranberries, mixed spice and 3 tbsp of the caster or granulated sugar and bubble until saucy.

Tip the oats, milk, vanilla and remaining sugar into a big saucepan. Bring to the boil, stirring constantly, and simmer for 4-5 mins until creamy. Divide between 6 bowls and top with the warm or cold fruit mixture.
chief_review: This fruit compote, featuring apples and cranberries, offers a delightful balance of sweetness and tartness, enhanced by the fragrance of mixed spice and vanilla. The recipe excels as a versatile component—perfect over ice cream for dessert or spooned onto porridge for breakfast. Using dried cranberries absorbs more liquid, so doubling the water as suggested will help achieve the desired juicy texture. The use of whole milk and the absence of eggs or nuts make this dish suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians, but it is not vegan or dairy-free. Thanks to its use of oats rather than wheat, the base is a good choice for those seeking an alternative to wheat-based grains, though celiacs should ensure their oats are gluten-free certified. Overall, the flavors are warming and comforting—a great way to use seasonal fruit in a dish that’s both satisfying and simple to prepare.

name: Coffee cocktails & star biscuits
description: Can you bend this recipe and serve the coffee hot so it's like an Irish coffee?
author: Good Food
ingredients: 280g plain flour, plus a little extra for rolling
directions: Stir together the butter, sugar, egg yolk and vanilla using a wooden spoon. Stir in the flour – you might need to get your hands in at the end. Tip onto a floured surface and bring together into a smooth dough.

Roll out the dough – half at a time if you like – and stamp out 5-6cm stars. Keep re-rolling trimmings, and you should get about 40 biscuits. Cut out a thin triangle about 2cm long and ½cm wide at one of the indents of each star. Arrange on trays lined with baking parchment, cover with cling film and chill for 30 mins.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Remove cling film and bake the biscuits for 8-12 mins until golden. Cool, then dust with icing sugar.

Mix the coffee and Kahlúa in a Martini glass. Slowly pour in the double cream over the back of a teaspoon so that it gently settles on the top of the coffee. Dust with a little cocoa and serve with a star biscuit slotted onto the glass and a plateful of Mint chocolate truffles, if you like (see 'Goes well with').
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on classic shortbread cookies, infused with rich coffee and a touch of Kahlúa for an indulgent treat. The coffee and liqueur add depth without overpowering the buttery, tender crumb. The double cream provides a smooth, luxurious finish, while a dusting of cocoa powder ties the flavors together elegantly. It’s suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish products. For those considering dietary restrictions, note the presence of gluten, dairy, and egg. Perfect as a sophisticated accompaniment to an after-dinner coffee, these cookies showcase a harmonious blend of classic and modern flavors.

name: Pepper & honey-roasted roots
description: The perfect warming veggie dish for any roast dinner
author: Good Food
ingredients: 5 medium carrots, peeled and cut into long slices
1 large celeriac, peeled and cut into chunks
5 parsnips, peeled and cut into long sticks
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Heat oil in a roasting tin on top of the stove, then throw in the vegetables and fry for 5-8 mins until they begin to brown. Place the tray in the oven for 40-50 mins, shaking pan occasionally until golden brown and soft.
Stir the honey, pepper and a sprinkling of salt into the vegetables, then return to the oven for 5 mins to warm the honey through.
chief_review: This roasted root vegetable medley offers a beautiful harmony of flavors and textures, making it an excellent addition to any roast dinner. The combination of carrots, celeriac, and parsnips brings a natural sweetness and earthiness, amplified by the caramelizing effect of honey. Olive oil ensures each piece roasts to perfection with a subtle richness, while cracked black peppercorn introduces a warming spice that balances the sweetness. The absence of dairy, eggs, and gluten-containing ingredients makes this dish suitable for vegetarians and those avoiding gluten. The recipe’s straightforward technique and minimal seasoning let the freshness of the produce shine through. A satisfying, wholesome side well worth a place at your table.

name: Tarte tatin
description: Excellent recipe. Rather than leave the tarte to cool to room temperature, I switched the oven off, left the door open whilst we ate our Sunday lunch and turned the tarte out when we were ready to eat it. Delicious with salted caramel ice cream!
author: Raymond Blanc
ingredients: 6 dessert apples(about 900g/2lb), such as Braeburn, Cox’s Orange Pippin or Adam’s Pearmain
85g unsalted butter(60g/2¼oz chilled and diced, 25g/1oz melted)
crème fraîche(full-fat please!) or high-quality vanilla ice cream, to serve
directions: Roll the pastry to a 3mm-thick round on a lightly floured surface and cut a 24cm circle, using a plate as a guide. Lightly prick all over with a fork, wrap in cling film on a baking sheet and freeze while preparing the apples.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Peel, quarter and core the apples. Put the sugar in a flameproof 20cm ceramic tatin dish or a 20cm ovenproof heavy-based frying pan and place over a medium-high heat. Cook the sugar for 5-7 mins to a dark amber caramel syrup that’s starting to smoke, then turn off the heat and stir in the 60g diced chilled butter.

To assemble the tarte tatin, arrange the apple quarters very tightly in a circle around the edge of the dish first, rounded-side down, then fill in the middle in a similar fashion. Gently press with your hands to ensure there are no gaps. Brush the fruit with the melted butter.

Bake in the oven for 30 mins, then remove and place the disc of frozen puff pastry on top – it will quickly defrost. Tuck the edges down the inside of the dish and, with a knife, prick a few holes in the pastry to allow steam to escape. Bake for a further 40-45 mins until the pastry is golden brown and crisp.

Allow to cool to room temperature for 1 hr before running a knife around the edge of the dish and inverting it onto a large serving plate that is deep enough to contain the juices. Serve with crème fraîche or vanilla ice cream.
chief_review: A classic tarte appealingly executed, this recipe delivers a truly indulgent French dessert. The all-butter puff pastry lends a delicate, flaky foundation, while the caramelized apples offer depth and natural sweetness, brought to life by the golden caster sugar and just the right amount of butter. Letting the tarte finish in the residual oven heat encourages the apples to soften further and sets the caramel beautifully—an excellent tip for achieving the ideal texture. Serving with crème fraîche or premium vanilla ice cream adds a luxuriously creamy contrast, although salted caramel ice cream is a worthy upgrade for those seeking extra decadence. This dish is suitable for vegetarians, provided the puff pastry contains no animal-derived rennet. Overall, a masterful, crowd-pleasing dessert perfect for Sunday lunches or special occasions alike.

name: Nutty chocolate crunch
description: Turn all those nuts, biscuits and chocolate from Christmas into these delicious tiffin bites, great for gifts
author: Good Food
ingredients: 250g assorted nuts, or a mix of nuts and dried fruit
300g milk or plain chocolate, or a mixture of both, chopped
directions: Butter and line a 20cm square tin with non-stick baking parchment. In a large bowl, combine the biscuits and nuts, halving any larger nuts. Melt the chocolate, butter and golden syrup in a bowl set over a pan of simmering water, stirring occasionally until smooth and glossy, then pour this over the biscuit and nut mixture.
Tip the mixture into the tin, then flatten lightly – it doesn’t need to be completely smooth. Chill for at least 2 hrs or overnight before cutting into squares.
chief_review: This festive tiffin recipe cleverly repurposes leftover biscuits, nuts, and chocolate into delightful no-bake bites, perfect for holiday gifting or snacking. The mixture of crunchy biscuits and nuts enrobed in a rich, buttery chocolate layer offers both texture and deep flavor. The recipe is highly customizable—using dried fruit in place of some nuts can add extra chew and a touch of natural sweetness. Suitable for vegetarians, it’s free from gelatin and eggs, relying on the chocolate and golden syrup for binding. With no flour added, these tiffin bites can potentially be made gluten-free by choosing gluten-free biscuits, though as written, they typically contain gluten. For nut allergies, substitute with seeds or more dried fruit if needed. Overall, this is a satisfying, crowd-pleasing treat that makes excellent use of holiday surplus ingredients.

name: Brussels sprouts with chestnut bacon butter
description: The perfect recipe to make Brussels sprouts irresistible (trust us)
author: Cathryn Evans
ingredients: 6 rashers streaky bacon, cut into pieces
1kg small Brussels sprout, trimmed of outer leaves
directions: Fry bacon in a hot pan without any oil for 10 mins until crisp. Add chestnuts and fry until they are beginning to colour and coated in the fat. Pour away excess fat, then tip bacon and chestnuts into a bowl to cool.

Beat butter to soften with a spatula, then stir in the bacon and chestnuts. Season with black pepper, then store in fridge. This can be made up to 3 days ahead or frozen for 1 month. Defrost in fridge overnight.

To serve, place sprouts in a microwaveable bowl, pour in 100ml water, cover with cling film and pierce a few times. Microwave on High (850W) for 16-18 mins, stirring twice during cooking, or cook in a pan of boiling water for 5 mins. Drain and tip into a warm serving dish, then dot the butter over to melt. Toss through and serve.
chief_review: This Brussels sprouts recipe brilliantly combines salty, crispy bacon with nutty chestnuts and a generous amount of butter, elevating the natural sweetness of the sprouts. The inclusion of chestnuts adds texture and a subtle earthiness that pairs exceptionally well with the richness of bacon. This dish is particularly suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain gluten. It’s a fantastic side for festive occasions, delivering bold flavors and making Brussels sprouts truly irresistible. The balance of smoky, sweet, and savory notes ensures this recipe will convert even the most hesitant sprout eaters.

name: Classic potato salad
description: Team with Christmas leftovers or summer BBQ favourites. Either way, Matt Tebbutt's Classic potato salad is hard resist
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: small handful parsley leaves, roughly chopped
directions: Boil the potatoes in salted water for 20 mins until just cooked, drain, then cool.

Cut the potatoes into chunks, then throw into a bowl with the shallots, capers and cornichons, if using. Add enough mayonnaise to bind, then mix together the olive oil and vinegar and add just enough to give a little sharpness to the salad. Stir in the finely chopped parsley and serve.
chief_review:
Matt Tebbutt’s Classic Potato Salad is a versatile dish, perfect for both festive leftovers and summer BBQ spreads. The combination of creamy new potatoes, tangy capers, cornichons, and fragrant parsley creates a refreshing salad with distinct layers of texture and flavor. The dressing, featuring mayonnaise, extra-virgin olive oil, and white wine vinegar, adds richness and zing without overpowering the delicate potatoes. 

This recipe is vegetarian-friendly, making it ideal for those abstaining from meat, and easily adaptable for gluten-free diets as all the listed ingredients are naturally gluten-free. For those with egg allergies or following a vegan diet, substituting traditional mayonnaise with plant-based or egg-free alternatives will tailor the salad accordingly. A classic, crowd-pleasing side that can welcome everyone to the table.

name: Mini mincemeat crumble pies
description: Red grapes add moistness to these mince pies with a quirky crumble topping
author: Good Food
ingredients: 140g ready-washed luxury mixed fruit (cut any cherries into quarters)
85g butter, chilled and cut into cubes
175g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
finely grated zest of 1 small orange
directions: Make the mincemeat by mixing all the ingredients together in a large bowl. Set aside for 30 minutes so the fruit absorbs some of the liquid. Make the pastry in a large bowl or food processor by blending the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar and orange zest and then 2 tbsp water. Bring the mixture together with your hands, adding a few more drops of water if it feels a little dry. Preheat the oven to fan 160C/ conventional 180C/gas 4.

Roll out half the pastry (keep the other half wrapped in the fridge) on a lightly floured surface. You want the pastry to be very thin, so it is crisp when cooked. Cut out 12 circles of pastry with a plain 6cm cutter (you will need to re-roll the pastry a couple of times) and use to line a 12-hole, non-stick mini muffin tin. It is quite a soft pastry, so any little gaps that form as you are lining the holes can easily be patched up. Chill while you make the topping.

In a small bowl, make the crumble topping by rubbing the butter into the flour until the mixture looks like breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar and almonds. With a teaspoon, fill each pastry case with mincemeat, gently pressing it down to leave room for the topping. Sprinkle the topping over each pie, place the tin on a baking tray and bake for 20 minutes.

Leave the pies to cool in the tin before taking them out carefully. They are fragile when hot, so use a small knife to help lift them out. Unless you have two mini muffin tins, repeat the process with the second batch of pastry, filling and topping. Eat the mini mince pies warm or cold, lightly dusted with icing sugar.
chief_review:
This inventive twist on classic mince pies brings a lovely burst of freshness thanks to red grapes, while maintaining that festive richness with luxury mixed fruit, almonds, and brandy. The crumble topping is a delightful departure from the traditional pastry lid, lending a rustic charm and additional texture. The inclusion of both lemon and orange zest elevates the filling with bright, citrus notes that balance the sweetness.

This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or gelatin-based ingredients. However, as it does use butter, it is not vegan-friendly. The addition of nuts (almonds) makes it unsuitable for those with nut allergies. This bake is perfect for a holiday spread, especially for those seeking a fruit-forward, buttery treat with charming homemade appeal. Serve slightly warm with a dollop of cream or custard for added indulgence.

name: Chicory, pomegranate & feta salad
description: A no-cook, zingy vegetarian salad to serve alongside winter dishes
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: 1 pomegranate, halved and seeds bashed out
directions: In a large serving bowl, throw together the salad leaves. Push a quarter of the pomegranate seeds through a fine sieve over a bowl to catch the juice.
Stir the olive oil, vinegar and some seasoning into the juice to make a dressing, then add to the leaves with the remaining seeds and feta.
Toss and serve immediately.
chief_review: This vibrant winter salad brings together the crunch of chicory, peppery watercress, and bursts of tart pomegranate seeds, all beautifully balanced by creamy feta. The red wine vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil dressing adds a lively acidity that cuts through the richness of the cheese, making it a perfectly refreshing accompaniment to heartier winter mains. The recipe is well suited for vegetarian diets. The absence of gluten-containing ingredients and reliance on fresh produce also makes it ideal for a gluten-free menu, provided the feta and vinegar are certified gluten free. A celebration of contrasting flavors and textures, this salad is quick to assemble and sure to impress with its jewel-like appearance and palate-cleansing zest.

name: Chestnut & butternut risotto
description: This comforting Italian rice supper is a great way to use up leftover chestnuts
author: Silvana Franco
ingredients: 4 tbsp freshly grated parmesanor vegetarian alternative, plus extra to serve
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan. Add the onion and garlic, and cook for 5 mins. Add the squash, sage and rice, and cook for a further 2 mins.
Pour in the stock and cook, stirring regularly, for 15 mins. Add the chestnuts and cook for a further 5 mins or until the rice is tender and the stock has been absorbed.
Stir in the butter, parsley and Parmesan. Divide risotto between bowls, scatter with extra Parmesan, season and serve.
chief_review: This Italian rice dish masterfully balances creamy carnaroli rice with tender butternut squash and the nutty sweetness of chestnuts—a clever use of leftovers. The addition of sage and fresh parsley elevates the flavor profile, while the finishing touch of grated Parmesan brings luxurious depth. The use of vegetable stock and the absence of meat make it well-suited for a vegetarian diet, especially if you choose a vegetarian Parmesan alternative. Additionally, the recipe is naturally gluten-free, provided the stock and all other components are certified as such. For those seeking a hearty, crowd-pleasing supper that fits specific dietary needs, this risotto delivers both comfort and thoughtful, wholesome ingredients.

name: Herby fondant potatoes
description:
No, this didn't work for me. All was well with the frying on both sides, but just a mess at the 'pour enough stock to go halfway up the side of the potatoes'. The crispy bottom comes off when you try to turn it over thus undoing all the previous frying to achieve the golden brown look. You are left with a half boiled potato in mush which has one lovely golden side.
I popped it in the oven at this point to try and salvage something. I wouldn't bother with this recipe again, I'm sure others can make a better job of it. As far as I'm concerned 'Go straight to roast potatoes'.
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1½ kg small floury potato, like Desirée or Maris Piper, peeled
pared zest 1 lemon, peeled with a vegetable peeler
about 600ml gluten- and wheat-free chicken or vegetable stock(check the label)
directions: Trim the top and bottom of each potato so that they lie flat on both sides. Heat the oil in a large frying pan or flameproof casserole and fry the potatoes on both sides until dark golden, 10-15 mins.

Poke in the garlic, thyme, rosemary, bay leaves and zest, then pour in enough stock to go halfway up the side of the potatoes. Simmer for 20-30 mins, then turn the potatoes and cook the other side for a further 20-30 mins, topping up with more stock if it evaporates. Continue cooking until the potatoes are really tender and most of the stock has gone. Season well and serve.
chief_review: This potato recipe ambitiously seeks to capture both crispness and rich flavor by pan-frying, then braising in stock. The choice of floury potatoes like Desirée or Maris Piper is spot on for a light, fluffy interior, but the transition from frying to braising risks sacrificing that carefully achieved crispiness, especially when adding a generous amount of stock. Although the dish is aromatic—with lemon zest, garlic, and assorted fresh herbs imparting plenty of depth—the technique may leave you with unevenly textured potatoes: half golden, half mush. The addition of gluten- and wheat-free stock and pure olive oil makes this recipe a suitable side for gluten-free and vegetarian/vegan diets (if using vegetable stock). Overall, while the flavors are promising, roasting or simply sticking to classic methods may yield more consistent and satisfying results.

name: Garlicky green beans
description: A simple sauté of fresh beans with lightly fried garlic and a touch of olive oil makes a healthy, versatile side
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Cook the green beans in boiling water for 2-3 mins until just tender, then drain well and steam-dry for a min.
Meanwhile, gently fry the garlic in the oil until pale golden – no further. Toss with the beans, season and serve.
chief_review: This sautéed green bean dish is a testament to the beauty of simplicity. The fresh beans retain a satisfying crunch, lightly kissed by the fragrant aroma of golden fried garlic and the rich notes of olive oil. It's a minimalistic approach that brings out the natural sweetness and vibrancy of the beans. The use of olive oil in place of butter makes this recipe compatible with vegan and vegetarian diets, and the absence of grains or processed products means it’s also suitable for gluten-free eaters. Additionally, with no nuts, dairy, or eggs, it’s ideal for those with common allergies. Serve this as an elegant side, or bolster it with toasted almonds or a squeeze of lemon for a refreshing twist. A versatile, healthful addition to any table, this dish allows seasonal produce to shine.

name: Bitter chocolate truffles
description: These bitesize chocolate treats are an impressive way to end a meal and also make a great gift
author: Good Food
ingredients: cocoa and grated white chocolate, for dusting
directions: Put the chocolate, cream and vanilla in a pan and heat very gently until melted. Cool, then chill for 90 mins until firm.

Use a mini ice cream scoop or teaspoon to make 24 truffles, then dust with cocoa or grated white chocolate. Chill until ready to eat. You can make these 4 days ahead or they will freeze for 1 month. Thaw in a cool place and, if needed, dust with a little more cocoa.
chief_review: An excellent recipe for those seeking an elegant and simple confection, these bitesize chocolate treats showcase deep cocoa notes balanced by the smoothness of double cream and a subtle hint of vanilla. The dusting of cocoa and white chocolate adds texture and visual appeal, making these truffles ideal as after-dinner petit-fours or as a thoughtful homemade gift. The use of 70% dark chocolate ensures a rich, adult flavor profile that isn’t overly sweet. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, provided the double cream and white chocolate are free from animal-derived rennet. With minimal ingredients and a straightforward process, these treats offer impressive results with very little fuss.

name: Squash & blue cheese Wellington
description: Great recipe, went down really well with everyone, non-vegetarians went for seconds and it was finished pretty quickly. Easy to make and all the flavours come together wonderfully. I used one medium-sized butternut that gave a few smaller pieces that I layered on the pastry. Used crumbly blue cheese, maybe 140 grams and that was really enough. Prepared the ingredients the day before and it was really easy to assemble. Will definitely make this again!
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 850g from the long end of a large butternut squash, to give you a solid piece, peeled (you may need to use the ends of 2 squashes)
400g pack shallot, peeled and halved if large
200g blue Wensleydale cheese, diced (or vegetarian alternative)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut the squash lengthways into 8 long chunky pieces and put in a large roasting tin with the shallots. Toss in a little oil, season and roast for 20 mins. Add the pecans and roast for 10 mins more, or until the squash is cooked but still firm.

Leave the squash to cool completely, but tip the nuts and shallots into a non-stick pan. Add the maple syrup, balsamic vinegar and plenty of seasoning, and stir over the heat until the shallots start to caramelise. Leave to cool.

Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface to a rectangle about 32 x 38cm. Trim 2cm from one of the long edges and set aside. Transfer the pastry to a baking tray. Place 4 of the pieces of squash down the longest length in the middle to make a rectangular block, keeping a generous border of pastry all the way round. Place another 2 pieces of squash on top. Trim the remaining 2 pieces and put crossways at the end. Scatter over the sage and blue cheese, then top with the shallots and pecans. Lightly press to compact everything together.

Brush round the pastry edges with the egg, then draw the 2 long edges up to meet and pinch together to seal – as you would a Cornish pasty. Tuck under the pastry at both ends, then brush all over with egg. Cut leaf shapes from the pastry trimmings and use to decorate the top of the Wellington. Glaze again and make a couple of small air holes with the point of a knife.
Open-freeze on a baking tray until solid, then wrap in cling film then foil. It will keep for 2 months.

, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and put a baking tray in to heat up. Unwrap the Wellington and place on the hot tray. Bake for 30 mins. Cover lightly with foil and bake for 35-40 mins more, taking off the foil for the final 10 mins. Leave to settle for 10 mins before thickly slicing, or the cheese will be too melty and run out. (If cooking from fresh, chill the Wellington for at least 30 mins before cooking – it then needs only 30-40 mins in the oven.)
chief_review: This recipe is a true delight for those who appreciate the harmonious blend of sweet, earthy, and tangy flavors. The combination of roasted butternut squash, caramelized shallots, and pecans delivers both texture and depth, while the blue cheese brings a bold, creamy note that lingers beautifully on the palate. The use of all-butter puff pastry ensures a rich, flaky base, tying the savory filling together with elegance. Preparation is straightforward, and assembling ahead makes it convenient for entertaining. It’s an excellent choice for a vegetarian crowd, especially when made with a vegetarian blue cheese. Ideal for festive gatherings or as a luxurious vegetarian centerpiece, this recipe proves that meat-free dishes can be just as crowd-pleasing. A must-try for anyone seeking refined comfort food.

name: Pumpkin & parsnip cassoulet
description: This warming dish is perfect for a weekend get-together
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Heat the oil in a large pan or wok, add onions, then fry for 5 mins until golden. Add pumpkin, parsnips and garlic and cook for a further 3 mins. Stir in beans, tomatoes, wine, stock, thyme, sugar and plenty of seasoning. Bring to the boil, then transfer to a large casserole dish, pressing the beans and vegetables beneath the liquid.
Sprinkle the top with breadcrumbs and grated cheese. Cover, then cook for 40 mins. Uncover, stir well and cook for a further 40 mins. Serve with garlic bread and stir-fried cabbage.
chief_review: This hearty, vegetable-forward bake is a standout for autumn or winter gatherings. The blend of pumpkin, parsnip, and a medley of beans brings both sweetness and earthiness, complemented by aromatic thyme and a splash of red wine for depth. The tomato base ensures a rich, comforting sauce, while the topping of fresh breadcrumbs and vegetarian parmesan adds a pleasing crunch and touch of umami. With no animal products (assuming the parmesan-style cheese is truly vegetarian), this dish caters well to vegetarians. It’s also naturally gluten-free if you substitute gluten-free breadcrumbs, and suitable for those avoiding nuts, eggs, and soy. A robust, filling centerpiece that’s both nourishing and crowd-pleasing.

name: Seeded oatcakes
description: These quick biscuits make a great addition to a cheeseboard or gourmet homemade gift hamper
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Melt the butter in a small pan, then allow to cool slightly. Tip all the dry ingredients into a bowl, with ½ tsp salt, then pour in the butter. Add 5-6 tbsp boiling water and combine to make a firm dough.

Turn out the dough onto a lightly floured surface, then roll out until about 0.5cm thick. Cut into small squares, then bake for 12-15 mins until golden. Leave to cool for a few mins, then transfer to a wire rack and cool completely.
chief_review: These quick biscuits are a delightful companion to a cheeseboard, offering a crisp texture and a subtle nuttiness from poppy and sesame seeds. The butter and oatmeal create a rich, hearty base, while plain flour provides structure and a delicate crumb. The touch of bicarbonate of soda ensures a light result, making these biscuits perfect for pairing with strong cheeses or even jams. Their make-ahead nature also lends them well to inclusion in a gourmet gift hamper. Suitable for vegetarians, these biscuits contain no animal-derived ingredients apart from dairy-based butter. However, those with gluten or seed allergies should take note of the recipe’s contents. Overall, this recipe offers a simple yet refined addition to any appetizer spread, balancing savory and toasty notes with an attractive, homemade appeal.

name: Amaretto fizz
description: Dangerously delicious!!
author: Good Food
directions: Mix Disaronno, orange juice and sparkling wine in a jug. Add a strip orange zest to each glass, if you like.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail marries the rich almond notes of Disaronno with the brightness of fresh orange juice and the effervescence of sparkling wine, all finished with aromatic orange zest. A festive choice for lively gatherings, it offers a balanced, citrus-forward flavor profile that’s both refreshing and indulgent. The recipe is naturally gluten-free, as it avoids wheat-based spirits and mixers, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. Those following a vegetarian diet can also indulge, as all ingredients are plant-based. For best results, serve well-chilled in flute glasses to preserve the sparkle and visualize the enticing zest garnish. An exceptional, celebratory drink that’s quick to assemble and certain to impress!

name: Cauliflower & onion cream
description: Soft, creamy purée that'll add lots of flavour to any roast - perfect for a Boxing Day lunch, by Gary Rhodes
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 1 large cauliflower, cut into small florets
directions: Put the cauliflower and onions in a large pan, then pour in enough milk to almost cover. Bring to a simmer and cook for 15-20 mins, or until the cauliflower is completely tender.

Using a slotted spoon, transfer the cauliflower and onion to a blender with a ladleful of milk, and blitz until smoothly puréed. Add more milk if you like, mixing to soften to your preferred consistency. Season with salt and pepper. (Can be made to this stage a day ahead. Keep chilled and reheat before serving.) Serve with a knob of butter melting on top.
chief_review: Gary Rhodes' cauliflower purée is a testament to how simple ingredients can deliver exceptional flavor and texture. The combination of cauliflower and onion simmered gently in milk results in a wonderfully smooth and creamy base, with the subtle sweetness of the vegetables shining through. The addition of a knob of butter adds lusciousness and depth, while the white pepper brings mild warmth without overpowering the dish. This recipe is naturally vegetarian and gluten-free, making it an excellent choice for a variety of dietary preferences and those with gluten sensitivities. It's an ideal, elegant accompaniment to roasted meats or as part of a festive spread, adding both comfort and sophistication to the table.

name: Dark chocolate & cranberry roulade
description: This is a fantastic cake to serve as a dessert or at teatime over the festive season and can be made up to a day in advance
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 25g good-quality cocoa powder (we used Green & Black's)
100g caster sugar, plus extra for turning the cake out
300g jar good-quality cranberry sauce (or use homemade)
200g good-quality dark chocolate, broken into pieces
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Butter a large (approx 30cm x 40cm) Swiss roll tin and line the base and sides with baking parchment. Lightly butter the parchment, dust with the plain flour and tip out any excess.

Sift the self-raising flour, baking powder and cocoa into a bowl and mix in the ground almonds. Put the eggs and caster sugar in a large mixing bowl and beat, using an electric hand-whisk or tabletop mixer, for 5-10 mins until pale, thick and trebled in volume. The mixture should leave a trail when the beaters are lifted out.

Fold the dry ingredients into the egg mixture using a large metal spoon. Pour into the prepared tin, then tip the tin from side to side until it is covered in an even layer of batter and the corners are filled. Bake on the middle shelf of the oven for 12-15 mins or until firm to the touch. Meanwhile, lay a sheet of baking parchment on the work surface and sprinkle with caster sugar.

Allow the sponge to cool for 1 min before turning out onto the sugared paper. Peel away the backing paper and, with the short side facing you, roll the sponge away from you so that the sugary parchment is rolled inside the roulade. This will help you to fill and roll it later. Set aside until completely cold.

To make the filling, beat the mascarpone with the orange zest. Unroll the sponge, discard the inside paper and evenly spread the mascarpone over, leaving a finger-width border around the edges. Cover with the cranberry sauce. Using the outside baking paper to help, roll the sponge away from you as tightly as possible. Transfer to a serving platter, cover loosely and chill while you prepare the frosting.

For the frosting, melt the chocolate in a heatproof bowl over a pan of just-simmering water, or microwave on High for 2 mins, stirring halfway through. Set aside for about 10 mins until cooled, but still soft.

Meanwhile, beat the butter and icing sugar together until pale and smooth. Pour in the chocolate and stir thoroughly to combine. Set aside for 20 mins to firm up slightly before using a palette knife to cover the roulade in frosting. Mark with a fork to create a log effect. To decorate, arrange the cranberries and bay leaves along the length of the log. Dust with a little icing sugar just before serving. Cut into slices, removing cranberries and bay leaves to serve. The roulade can be made up to a day ahead. Take it out of the fridge at least 30 mins before you want to serve it, to allow the filling and icing to soften.
chief_review: This festive cake recipe is a true showstopper, perfect for dessert or teatime gatherings. The harmonious blend of rich cocoa, tangy cranberry sauce, and creamy mascarpone creates a sophisticated balance of flavors, while orange zest adds an unexpected brightness. Ground almonds contribute subtle depth and a tender crumb, making the texture especially pleasing. The use of both dark chocolate and butter ensures a decadent mouthfeel, and finishing touches like cranberries and bay leaves lend a celebratory appearance. Notably, this recipe contains no meat or fish, making it suitable for vegetarians. However, it does rely heavily on dairy products—mascarpone, butter—and eggs, which means it's not appropriate for vegan diets. For those without dietary restrictions, this cake offers a luxurious and crowd-pleasing centerpiece for any festive occasion, and its make-ahead nature is an added bonus for stress-free entertaining.

name: Raspberry & coconut trifle cake
description:
This towering beauty will make the perfect sweet centrepiece for a buffet,
or a lighter option if you’re not into Christmas pudding
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 200g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
50g unsweetened desiccated coconut, soaked in water for 1 hr then squeezed dry
2 tbsp from a 200 ml/7 fl oz pack coconut cream (keep the rest for the filling)
600ml good-quality ready-made custard from the chiller
4 tbsp Malibu (or you could use white rum)
300g pack frozen raspberries, defrosted, or use fresh
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Butter and line a deep 20cm loose-bottom cake tin. Beat all the cake ingredients together until smooth, pour into the tin, then smooth the top. Bake for 40-45 mins until golden and risen. Cool completely on a rack; once cold, put into the fridge. Meanwhile, prepare the custard – whisk the cornflour and 1 tbsp icing sugar into the remaining coconut cream until smooth. Bring the custard to the boil, then whisk in the coconut mix. Keep whisking until it’s boiling and fairly thick. Tip into a bowl, cover with cling film straight away, then cool.
Mix the Malibu, lime zest and juice and 2 tbsp icing sugar. Trim off the top of the cake if it’s domed, then cut into three horizontally using a bread knife or serrated knife.

Line the cleaned cake tin with plenty of cling film (a little oil helps it to stick), then put a circle of cake back in the bottom. Sprinkle with some of the Malibu mix. Crush 100g of the raspberries and mix well into the jam, then fold in 100g whole raspberries. Spoon onto the sponge in the tin but don’t go right to the edges.

Top with the second piece of cake, sprinkle with more of the Malibu mix, then spoon the custard over and spread it out. Top with the final layer of cake, sprinkle with remaining Malibu, then chill for at least 4 hrs, covered with cling film, to let the layers firm up and the flavours mingle.

Once set, remove the cake from the tin, then slide it onto a serving plate. Softly whip the cream with the final 1 tbsp icing sugar, then spread over top of the cake. Scatter with the remaining whole raspberries and decorate with fresh shredded coconut, if you like.
chief_review: This showstopper dessert is a delightful alternative to traditional Christmas pudding—a lighter, fruit-forward centerpiece that balances rich coconut layers with tangy raspberry notes. The combination of custard, coconut cream, and double cream creates a luscious texture, while the Malibu or white rum and lime zest lend a tropical vibrancy that feels festive and fun. Finished with fresh (or defrosted) raspberries and raspberry jam, every bite is bursting with fruity freshness. This recipe will suit a vegetarian diet, as it does not contain any meat, fish, or gelatine-based products. However, those with coconut or dairy allergies, or an intolerance to gluten, should avoid this bake due to the presence of coconut, cream, milk, butter, and self-raising flour. Overall, this coconut and raspberry trifle is sure to impress with its flavor and presentation, perfect for celebratory buffets.

name: Festive stuffed chicken
description: Went down well in our house. My husband loved them. A very quick way to make a dinner with all the flavours of Christmas!
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 85g pack of stuffing (we used Paxo sage & onion stuffing for chicken), cooked following pack instructions
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the potatoes in the stuffing mix, tip into a roasting tin, drizzle over the olive oil, season and roast for 30 mins.

Cut the chicken breasts in half horizontally, carefully cutting halfway through, and open them out like a book. Spread 1 tbsp Boursin cheese and ½ tbsp cranberry inside each chicken breast. Close the breasts, then wrap each in a slice of Parma ham. Line a baking tray with foil and put the chicken breasts on top. Once the potatoes have been cooking for 10 mins, put the chicken tray in and cook for the remaining 20 mins.
Remove the chicken and potatoes, and toss the potatoes with the lemon juice and rocket. Serve the oozing chicken breasts with the potatoes on the side.
chief_review: This festive chicken dish is delightfully simple yet packed with holiday flavors. The Boursin cheese paired with cranberry jelly brings a creamy tang and sweet contrast to the tender chicken breasts, while the Parma ham provides a crisp, savory wrap that seals in moisture and infuses a subtle saltiness. Using ready-made stuffing and frozen roast potatoes streamlines prep without sacrificing comfort or flavor. The addition of a rocket salad dressed with olive oil and lemon juice refreshes the plate and balances richer elements. This recipe is great for those without major dietary restrictions, but it notably excludes gluten-free and vegetarian guests due to the inclusion of stuffing and poultry. Perfect for a quick, satisfying Christmas-themed dinner that feels special with minimal effort.

name: Maple & pecan carrots
description: Sweet maple syrup and pecan nuts go brilliantly with roasted carrots in this festive vegetarian side dish
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. You can do this while the turkey is resting. Place the carrots on a large baking tray, toss with the oil and plenty of salt, then spread out in an even layer. Cover with foil and roast for 10 mins, then remove the foil and cook for 20 mins more.
Drizzle with the syrup and scatter over the nuts, then return to the oven for a final 10 mins until the carrots are soft and golden and the pecans toasted.
chief_review: This delightful roasted carrot dish strikes a perfect balance between the natural sweetness of carrots, the rich depth of maple syrup, and the crunchy texture of toasted pecans. Olive oil brings it all together, making for a side that feels festive yet refreshingly simple. With no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, it fits beautifully into vegan and gluten-free diets, while also being suitable for those with dairy and egg allergies. The use of maple syrup adds a luxurious glossy finish and enhances the earthy flavors of the carrots, while pecans provide a satisfying contrast in each bite. This recipe is sure to add both color and vibrant flavor to the holiday table.

name: Smoked salmon gateau
description: Layer fish with lemon cream cheese and a gravadlax dressing of brandy, dill and mustard for a sensational centrepiece
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 1 heaped tsp mignonette pepper (coarsely ground black peppercorns)
1 heaped tbsp very finely chopped shallot
leaves from a few sprigs of fresh dill
directions: Wrap the base of a loose-bottomed, 20cm non-stick cake tin with cling film, twizzling it into a knot on the underside, then slot base back in the tin. Cut the salmon into pieces about 15cm long and make a neat layer of slices, presentation side down, on the base of the tin. Start at the outside and push the slices right to the edge; after going all round the edge, fill in the centre with straight pieces of salmon.

Mash the cream cheese until smooth (a rubber spatula is good for this), working in the mignonette pepper and a pinch of salt at the same time. Pour in two-thirds of the cream, a little at a time, and keep stirring and beating until a smooth, lightly whipped cream consistency is achieved. Now work in the lemon juice. If slightly too firm (it should be spreadable), work in the remaining cream and then recheck for seasoning.

Dollop about a quarter of the cream cheese in the centre of the salmon and spread to the edge with the spatula or a palette knife; slowly turn the tin to get an even thickness of about 3mm. Top this with a salmon layer, continuing until both salmon and cheese have been used, finishing with a salmon layer. Press the top down with your hands. Stretch cling film over and refrigerate for at least four hours – or preferably overnight.

Make the dressing. Simmer the shallots, sugar and brandy in a small pan until almost dry and a deep brown colour – about 5 minutes. Tip into a bowl and leave to cool. Whisk the crème fraîche in a bowl with the mustard and lime juice, and whisk in the cold shallots.Whisk in the olive oil, trickling it slowly as if making mayonnaise. Season, cover the bowl with cling film and chill in the fridge for 2 hours or overnight.

To turn the salmon gateau out, dip a knife into a jug of warm water and run it carefully around the inside of the tin, between the gateau and the sides, to release the salmon from the tin. Invert a flat serving plate or board on top, then turn the gateau out upside down and lift off the tin and the cling-filmed base. You will now be left with a perfectly flat top to the salmon-layered gateau.

The gateau is best cut into wedges while set firm, then left to reach room temperature for 20-30 minutes before serving – it will soften slightly and have more flavour being less cold. Just before serving, chop the dill and whisk it into the dressing, which is best served straight from the fridge. Serve the gateau with watercress sprigs drizzled with olive oil and lime wedges for squeezing. Serve the dressing in a jug.
chief_review:
This luxurious layered smoked salmon dish embodies elegance and rich flavor, making it an impressive centrepiece. The creamy filling, marrying whipped cream cheese, crème fraîche, and a bright hint of citrus, harmonizes beautifully with the intensity of the salmon. The gravadlax dressing, spiked with brandy, dill, Dijon, and shallots, lends both sharpness and aromatic depth, while watercress and lime provide fresh, peppery contrast. 

Ideal for pescatarians, the recipe is naturally gluten-free, as it contains no wheat-based products. However, it's dairy-rich, so unsuitable for those with lactose intolerance. The use of mustard and egg-free ingredients makes it safe for those with egg allergies. 

Overall, this recipe is perfect for special occasions, delivering sophisticated flavors and pleasing presentation, particularly for guests following pescatarian or gluten-free diets.

name: Glamorgan cheese sausage rolls
description: These melt in the mouth festive party nibbles provide a tasty alternative for your vegetarian guests - they're also gluten-free
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g gluten-free flour (we used Doves Farm, widely available)
1 egg yolk mixed with 3 tbsp cold water
100g gluten-free breadcrumbs (we used Dietary Specials Gluten-Free bread)
directions: To make the pastry, put the flour, butter and cayenne pepper into a food processor, then whizz into fine breadcrumbs. sprinkle the egg and water mixture onto the flour and pulse again until the mixture begins to come together. Tip the mixture onto a board, then gently squeeze the pastry until it begins to come together in a ball, adding more water if it feels dry. Divide the mixture in half, roll each piece into a 12 x 30cm rectangle and slip onto a baking sheet. Do not chill.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Mix the filling ingredients together, except one egg yolk, which you need for glazing, in a food processor. Divide in two and roll each into a 30cm-long sausage shape. Lay a cheese sausage on one side of the pastry. Brush the sausage and pastry with egg yolk and fold the pastry over the top to encase the sausage. Seal the two edges, trim the ends, then cut into 2cm pieces. Arrange on a baking sheet and chill for 30 mins.
Brush the rolls with a little more egg yolk, place herbs on top, if you like, then bake for 12-15 mins until golden brown.
chief_review: This delightful recipe is a real gem for festive gatherings, offering a sophisticated melt-in-the-mouth nibble that's both vegetarian and gluten-free. The use of gluten-free flour and breadcrumbs ensures it caters perfectly to those with gluten sensitivities, while the omission of meat makes it suitable for vegetarians. The combination of Caerphilly cheese and aromatic leeks, uplifted by mustard seeds and a hint of fresh herbs, creates a savoury, moreish bite with just the right balance of richness and spice. The crumbly, buttery pastry contrasts beautifully with the creamy filling, resulting in an irresistible party snack. A clever, allergy-conscious option that doesn't compromise on flavour or texture—these nibbles are sure to become a festive favourite.

name: Mulled apple juice
description: Delicious; was even chosen by some adults who weren't driving so definitely a decent alternative to mulled wine. I left out the sugar after reading the previous comments but also the cloves (because I hate them).
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 1 cinnamon stick, plus extra to garnish, if you like
directions: Simmer the apple juice with the strips of orange peel, cinnamon stick and cloves for about 5-10 mins until all the flavours have infused. Sweeten to taste.
Serve each drink with a little orange peel and a piece of cinnamon stick, if you like.
chief_review: This warming apple juice-based drink is an inviting, non-alcoholic alternative to mulled wine, ideal for both adults and children. The infusion of orange peel, cinnamon, and cloves complements the natural sweetness of the apple juice, creating a well-rounded, aromatic beverage. Adjusting the sugar or honey level allows you to tailor the sweetness, making it suitable for a range of palates. For those following a vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free diet, this recipe is a great fit—just opt for sugar instead of honey for vegan guests. The absence of common allergens like nuts, dairy, or eggs makes it widely accessible. Omitting the cloves is a flexible touch for those with specific spice preferences. Garnished with a cinnamon stick, it’s both festive and comforting, perfect for holiday gatherings or cozy evenings.

name: Crisp potato cake
description: This side dish is one to bring to the table with pride - it looks as good as it tastes!
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1.3kg medium-sized roasting potato, such as King Edwards or Maris Pipers
1 tbsp thyme leaves and 1 thyme sprig
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Peel the potatoes and place them in a pan of cold, salted water. Bring to the boil, simmer for 3 mins and drain. When cool enough to handle, slice a few very neatly. Coat the bottom of a round, ovenproof, non-stick pan with butter, then place a sprig of thyme in the middle. Cover with a slice of potato in the middle, then arrange the rest of the slices over the base of the pan, overlapping the slices in concentric circles. Slice the rest of the potatoes and tip into a bowl, then pour over the rest of the butter, the nutmeg and the thyme leaves and season with salt and pepper. Toss everything together, then tip the seasoned potatoes over the arranged slices and press down gently to flatten. The potato cake can be prepared up to a day ahead and kept covered in the fridge.

Cook the cake in the oven below the beef. Every now and then, remove it, press it down with a fish slice and drizzle the surface with a little olive oil. Cook for 1hr-1hr 15mins, until the sides look brown and crispy. Carefully invert the cake onto a serving dish or board, scatter with sea salt and serve cut into wedges.
chief_review: This beautifully simple side dish elevates the humble roasting potato to star status. The combination of melted butter and olive oil ensures the potatoes achieve a supremely crisp exterior while remaining fluffy inside. Fresh thyme and a whisper of nutmeg provide aromatic depth, perfectly complementing the natural sweetness of the potatoes. A final sprinkle of sea salt adds just the right touch of savoriness. Suitable for a vegetarian diet, this recipe is wonderfully versatile and sure to impress whether served at a family gathering or a festive occasion. Simple to prepare, visually appealing, and brimming with flavor—this is a potato dish you’ll turn to again and again.

name: Venison Wellington
description: Did this for a Sunday lunch today and apart from looking amazing it tasted absolutely amazing. I ran out of time to put the whole thing once wrapped in pastry back in the fridge but I thought with everything having been in the fridge (including the pastry) before being wrapped I might get away with it and I did ☺️ I can definitely recommend.
author: James Martin
ingredients: 1 tbsp olive oil, plus a little extra
400g chestnut mushroom, very finely chopped in a food processor
directions: Firstly, dry the venison with kitchen paper, then season well. Heat the oil in a frying pan and sear the meat all over for about 8 mins. Brush with mustard, leave to cool, then chill for 20 mins. Reserve any juices for the gravy.

Melt the butter and soften the shallot and garlic. Add the mushrooms, herbs and seasoning, and cook for 10 mins until you have a paste-like mixture. Add the brandy and cook until it’s evaporated. Leave to cool.

Overlap 2-3 sheets of cling film on a clean surface and lay the prosciutto in 2 rows, slightly overlapping each slice. Spread the cooled mushroom paste all over the prosciutto, creating a thin, even layer.
Place the fillet in the centre of the mushroom mixture. Using the edge of the cling film, carefully draw the layer of prosciutto and mushroom around the meat.
Roll into a sausage shape, twisting the ends of the cling film as you do, to form a tight log. Chill for 30 mins to firm up.
On a lightly floured surface, roll the pastry to a rectangle a little larger than a magazine, and trim the edges to neaten.
Carefully unwrap the prosciutto parcel and lay in the middle of the pastry.
Fold over the bottom half of the pastry. Lightly brush the rest of the sheet with beaten egg.
Roll the whole thing around the meat to encase. Neatly fold under the shorter edges to create a parcel.
Transfer to a baking sheet and, using your hands, smooth the pastry around the meat, pressing it firmly to avoid any air being trapped. Brush the pastry all over with beaten egg yolk.
Chill for at least 30 mins or up to 24 hrs. Then, using the back of a knife, mark the pastry, being careful not to cut all the way through. Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7.
Lightly oil a non-stick baking tray and heat until hot. Put the Wellington on the tray and bake for 30 mins (35 mins for well done). Remove from oven, brush with extra egg and rest for 20 mins.

To make venison gravy, melt a large knob of butter in a medium pan, add 1 finely chopped shallot, 1 crushed garlic clove and 1 thyme sprig, and cook until soft. Add 1 tbsp flour, brown for about 1 min, then pour in 250ml Port and reduce by two-thirds. Add 400ml beef stock and any reserved juices from the venison, then reduce again by two-thirds until syrupy. Season, add 1 tbsp redcurrant jelly, if you like, and strain before serving.
chief_review: This venison Wellington is a real showstopper—succulent, perfectly cooked venison enveloped in an earthy mushroom duxelles and wrapped in crisp, golden all-butter puff pastry. The addition of prosciutto lends a subtle saltiness that beautifully balances the richness of the filling, while the aromatic shallots, garlic, and herbs create impressive depth of flavor. English mustard adds a punchy layer that cuts through the richness, keeping the dish lively. Paired with creamy mashed root vegetables and a glossy homemade gravy, this makes for an indulgent yet elegant main course. Note that this recipe contains both gluten (from the puff pastry and flour) and dairy (from butter), and includes eggs, so it is best suited to omnivorous diets without these restrictions. For those who enjoy game meats and classic French technique, this dish is sure to impress both in taste and presentation.

name: Beetroot & squash salad with horseradish cream
description: A rustic and warm root vegetable salad with creamy dressing and lots of healthy watercress leaves - great for a buffet
author: John Torode
ingredients: 1¼kg large butternut squash, peeled and deseeded
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Peel the beetroot and cut each into 8 wedges. Cut the onions and butternut squash into roughly the same size. Spread out in a large roasting tin. Mix the vinegar and sugar until dissolved, then whisk in the oil. Pour over the vegetables, toss and roast for 40-45 mins until charred and soft, stirring halfway through cooking.
To make the horseradish cream, mix together the soured cream, horseradish, lemon juice and some seasoning.
To serve, put the roasted veg in a large bowl or on a platter, followed by the watercress, then drizzle over the horseradish cream. Serve warm or cold.
chief_review: This root vegetable salad is a beautifully rustic dish, celebrating the earthy sweetness of beetroot and butternut squash, counterbalanced by the tang from red wine vinegar and lemon juice. Roasted onions lend additional depth, while the creamy horseradish and soured cream dressing adds a lush, piquant finish, livened up with peppery watercress. The balance of textures and flavors makes it a standout option for any buffet or autumnal gathering. With its hearty vegetable base and absence of meat, it’s perfectly suited for a vegetarian diet. The robust use of watercress provides a peppery freshness that cuts through the richness of the dressing. This salad offers both comfort and sophistication in every bite—an excellent choice for those seeking a filling, flavorful vegetarian dish for entertaining.

name: Cheese & ham souffléd omelette
description: This fluffy and filling meal for one uses up leftover ham or gammon and makes a great brunch served with baked beans
author: Silvana Franco
directions: Mix most of the cheese with the ham or gammon, egg yolks, mustard, herbs and some seasoning. Whisk egg whites until stiff. Using a rubber spatula, gently fold the whites into the yolk mixture until evenly mixed.

Heat a splash of olive oil in a small non-stick frying pan. Pour mixture into the pan and cook for 4 mins until the underside is set and browned. Sprinkle over the remaining cheese and grill for 2 mins until cheese is bubbling and golden.
chief_review: This recipe is an excellent option for anyone looking to create a quick, satisfying brunch from leftovers. The combination of torn ham or gammon and the richness of Gruyère or cheddar brings a delightful savory character, while Dijon mustard and fresh herbs contribute complexity and a burst of freshness. Separating the eggs creates an impressively fluffy texture, giving the dish a soufflé-like quality with minimal effort. Serving it with baked beans adds heartiness and a touch of sweetness that balances the flavors. This dish would be suitable for a gluten-free diet, as long as care is taken to use gluten-free Dijon mustard. It's an ideal single-serving meal—well-balanced, flavorful, and perfect for using up ingredients you may already have on hand.

name: Smoked salmon carpaccio
description: James Martin's stunning seafood starter is guaranteed to impress at any dinner party - layer with beetroot, orange and tangy horseradish cream
author: James Martin
ingredients: 400g smoked salmon, cut into long slices
100g cooked beetroot, finely sliced into rounds
drizzle of extra virgin olive oil, to serve
directions: First, lightly pickle the radish slices by putting them in a small bowl with the vinegar for at least 30 mins. Meanwhile, mix the horseradish with the whipped cream in a small bowl and season with salt.

Lay 100g of the long salmon slices on 4 rectangular plates in a neat rectangle shape. Put 3 discs of beetroot on top of the salmon in different places. Arrange about 6 slices of the pickled radish around the salmon too. Add a few orange segments and some of the preserved lemon.

Next, shape the horseradish into quenelles by using 2 teaspoons to scoop and roll it. Put 3 quenelles on each plate. Finally, scatter with the pea shoots, and drizzle over a little oil before serving.
chief_review: James Martin's seafood starter offers a vibrant medley of flavors, beautifully balancing the smokiness of salmon with earthy beetroot and refreshing orange segments. The horseradish cream adds a lively kick, while preserved lemons and radishes provide subtle tang and crunch. Layered artfully and finished with pea shoots and quality olive oil, this dish shines both in taste and presentation.
