It's an excellent choice for pescatarians and suits a gluten-free diet, as well as being free from nuts and eggs. The variety of textures and bursts of citrus ensure an elegant start to any meal.

name: Glazed orange carrots
description: These carrots have a zesty kick, for pepping up roast dinner
author: Good Food
directions: Trim the carrots and cook in boiling water for 4-6 mins until just tender, then drain. Melt the butter in a large frying pan, add the drained carrots, then fry over a high heat for 1 min. Pour over the orange juice and cook for a further 2-3 mins, bubbling the sauce and stirring to thoroughly coat the carrots. Finally, stir in the chopped parsley and serve.
chief_review: These zesty carrots offer a delightful burst of flavor, balancing the natural sweetness of baby carrots with fresh orange juice and a touch of butter. The parsley adds a vibrant, herbaceous note, lifting the entire dish. The use of minimal ingredients allows the quality of the produce to shine, making this a perfect side to liven up a roast dinner or to complement a variety of mains. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe avoids common allergens like nuts and gluten, and can be prepared easily for weeknight meals or special occasions. The buttery glaze ensures the carrots are tender and glossy, while the citrus provides a refreshing tang, making each bite lively and satisfying. A simple yet sophisticated addition to any table.

name: Passion fruit soufflés with passion fruit sauce
description: Use ready-made custard in these tropical desserts, for all the 'wow' factor but less of the effort
author: James Martin
ingredients: knob of butter, plus extra for greasing
75g caster sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put a baking tray on the top shelf to heat up. Grease 4 x 150ml ramekins with butter and dust the insides with caster sugar to coat.

Whisk the egg whites in a bowl until stiff. Add 1 tbsp of the sugar and whisk for 30 secs more until thick and glossy. In a separate bowl, scoop the pulp from 1 passion fruit into the custard, then fold in the whisked egg white. Spoon the mixture into the prepared ramekins and put on the hot baking tray. Bake for 15 mins until risen and golden on top.

While the soufflés are cooking, make the sauce. Scoop the remaining passion fruit pulp into a saucepan, add the remaining sugar and simmer gently for 5 mins. Finally add a knob of butter and stir until melted. Pass through a sieve and serve in a jug with the hot soufflés as soon as they come out of the oven. Let your guests break a hole in the centre of their soufflé, then pour in the sauce.
chief_review: This tropical dessert recipe cleverly elevates ready-made custard with minimal effort, delivering an impressive finish with delicate passion fruit flavor. Whipping the egg whites to soft peaks and carefully folding in sugar ensures the soufflés achieve a light, airy texture, while the combination of tangy passion fruit and creamy custard brings a welcome freshness and depth. The use of everyday ingredients—egg whites, sugar, butter, and pre-made custard—makes for an approachable dish even for the home cook. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, offering a luscious sweet treat without gelatin or animal rennet. Best enjoyed straight from the oven, these soufflés capture the 'wow' factor and are sure to delight at any gathering.

name: Baked Swiss chard
description: Try baking leafy greens with garlic, cream and Parmesan for an indulgent side dish - perfect with your Sunday roast
author: Theo Randall
ingredients: 1kg Swiss chard, stems cut into 1cm pieces and leaves into quarters
1 garlic clove, crushed to a paste with sea salt
directions: Put a pan of salted water on to boil and cook the chard stalks for 2 mins until tender. Remove the stalks with a slotted spoon. Add the leaves and cook for 30 secs-1 min. Drain and reserve 200ml of the cooking water. In a saucepan, bring the cream to a simmer, then add the garlic and cook for 2 mins. Whisk in the water, egg yolks and 140g Parmesan, and let them all melt together and bubble for 3 mins.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Add the chard to the saucepan, season, mix well and tip into a greased baking dish. Top with the breadcrumbs, thyme and remaining Parmesan. Cover with foil and bake for 15 mins. Removethe foil and cook for 15 mins more until golden and bubbling.
chief_review: This Swiss chard gratin is a luxurious, indulgent side dish that shines with layers of creamy texture and savory depth. The combination of double cream, egg yolks, and generous Parmesan creates a rich, velvety base, while the Swiss chard offers a subtle earthiness, balanced by aromatic garlic and thyme. The crispy topping of breadcrumbs adds welcome contrast to the tender greens beneath. For vegetarians, opting for a vegetarian Parmesan alternative ensures the dish is meat-free while retaining its cheesy character. Those looking to avoid gluten can substitute gluten-free breadcrumbs seamlessly. This gratin is a show-stopping addition to any Sunday roast or festive spread, offering both comfort and sophistication with every mouthful.

name: White chocolate trifle
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 350g white chocolate, plus extra to serve
directions: To make the custard, put the milk, cream and caster sugar in a saucepan and bring to the boil. Meanwhile, set a glass bowl over a pan of gently simmering water. Snap the white chocolate into the bowl and leave to melt. Put the egg yolks in a separate bowl.
Once the cream mixture is up to the boil, pour into the bowl with the yolks,

continually. Return the mixture to the pan and cook over a gentle heat, whisking until the mixture reaches 85C on a digital thermometer, or the custard has thickened enough to coat the back of a spoon and you can draw a line through it with your fingertip. Pour the custard through a sieve into the melted chocolate and quickly whisk to combine. Pour the white custard into a bowl, cover with cling film and chill in the fridge overnight.

The next day, crumble the cake into the bottom of a trifle bowl or individual glasses and pour over the rum and half the passion fruit pulp. Leave to soak for 10 mins, then spoon over the white chocolate custard. Put in the fridge while you whisk the cream.

Whisk the cream, vanilla, sugar and lime zest to soft peaks, then spoon into a piping bag with a star nozzle. Pipe on top of the custard, then top with the remaining passion fruit, coconut and a grating of white chocolate. Chill until needed. Can be made a day ahead and decorated just before serving.
chief_review:
This recipe offers a lush, tropical twist on a classic dessert, combining lemon drizzle cake soaked in white rum with vibrant passion fruit and toasted coconut. The rich custard base, made with whole milk, double cream, golden caster sugar, white chocolate, egg yolks, and vanilla, delivers a decadent, creamy texture. The lime zest adds a final burst of zesty freshness. The dessert is indulgent and well-balanced, using quality ingredients to play up sweet, tangy, and aromatic notes.

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat, poultry, fish, or their derivatives. However, it does include dairy, eggs, and gluten (from the cake), so keep this in mind for other dietary needs. Overall, it’s a sophisticated, crowd-pleasing finish perfect for special occasions or dinner parties.

name: Puff pastry mince pies
description: Great Recipe :)
author: Elena Silcock
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and lightly butter and flour a 12 hole fairy cake tin. Lay a sheet of puff pastry on a floured surface and use a rolling pin to roll it out a little, so it's 5 cm bigger than your fairy cake tin.

Lay the sheet onto the tin, pushing it into the holes. Spoon 1½ tbsp of mincemeat into each hole, then use some of the beaten egg to brush around all of the holes. Lay the other sheet of pastry on top and press to seal. Lightly dust the top with flour.

Use an 8cm cookie cutter to cut circles around each of the holes, peeling away the excess puff pastry. You will be left with 12 flat-topped pies. Place a flat baking tray over the pies and flip the fairy cake tin upside-down. The pies should slip out of the tin, leaving you with 12 puff pies on a baking tray.

Press each one around the edges to make sure they're well sealed. Brush them with more of the beaten egg, sprinkle with demerara sugar. Bake for 20 mins, until risen and golden. Allow to cool a little, then serve warm.
chief_review: This recipe offers a classic, indulgent take on festive baking with its use of all-butter puff pastry and rich mincemeat filling. The inclusion of butter and eggs makes it suitable for a vegetarian diet, provided the mincemeat does not contain suet or other animal products—always worth a quick check. However, this treat is not appropriate for vegan or gluten-free diets due to the presence of eggs, butter, and wheat flour. The combination of a golden, crisp pastry and fragrant, spiced mincemeat makes for a delightful seasonal treat. The dusting of demerara sugar adds an appealing crunch and a touch of sweetness. For best results, focus on even greasing and gentle flouring to ensure the pastry lifts beautifully in the oven. Serve warm for a comforting, crowd-pleasing dessert or snack.

name: Brandy snaps
description: Making these homemade crispy biscuits is easier than you think - best served with vanilla ice cream or piped cream
author: Caroline Hire
ingredients: half a lemon, zest and 1 tsp juice
sunflower or vegetable oil, for greasing
directions: Preheat the oven to 180C/ 160 fan/ gas mark 4 and two baking trays with baking parchment.

Put the butter, sugar and golden syrup in a saucepan and heat gently until the butter and sugar have melted. Put the flour and ginger in a bowl and make a well in the centre. Add the lemon zest and juice and the brandy. Pour in the butter mixture and gradually beat it into the flour until the mixture is thoroughly combined.

Use a teaspoon to dollop 3 - 4 heaps of mixture onto the prepared baking tray. A heaped tsp is enough for a cigar and two heaped teaspoons is enough for a basket. Space them well apart as they will spread. Cook in batches for 8 – 10 mins until set, golden brown and lacy in appearance. Do not allow to go too dark as they will taste bitter. Leave for a minute before shaping – the snaps should still be pliable but set enough to move without tearing.

You can shape the brandy snaps into cigars or baskets. To make cigars, oil the handle of a wooden spoon and wrap the brandy snap around. If you have a long handle or more than one spoon, you can do a few at a time. The base of the biscuits should be the bit that touches the spoon so that the top ‘presentation’ side of the biscuit is seen. Transfer to a cooling rack. To make baskets, oil the base of small ramekins or narrow tumblers and drape the biscuits over them. The top of the biscuit should touch the base this time as this is the bit you’ll see.
Pipe whipped cream into the cigars or use the baskets or cones for ice cream and berries. If not using straightway, store in an airtight container for up to 5 days.
chief_review: This delightful recipe for homemade crispy biscuits yields a treat that is sweet, delicately spiced with ginger, and brightened up by a hint of lemon zest and juice. The addition of golden syrup and brandy lends depth and warmth to the flavor profile, while the use of butter ensures a rich, tender bite. These biscuits are simple to prepare and bake to a beautiful, crisp texture—perfectly complementing a scoop of vanilla ice cream or a swirl of piped cream. As the recipe contains no eggs and can easily be made with gluten-free flour, it can suit some vegetarian diets and those with egg allergies, provided a plant-based butter is substituted for vegans. However, it does contain gluten and dairy as written. Overall, these biscuits offer a classic, crowd-pleasing finish to any meal.

name: Honeyed carrot salad
description: Gordon Ramsay's carrot salad is the perfect accompaniment to your Boxing Day feast.
author: Gordon Ramsay
directions: Blanch the carrot in boiling water for 2 mins, then drain and cool. Whisk together the honey, lemon and oil and season to taste. To serve, toss the carrots in a bowl with the chicory and rocket. Pour the dressing over, toss well. Pile in a serving bowl, scatter with pinenuts.
chief_review: Gordon Ramsay’s carrot salad is a vibrant, refreshing addition to any festive table. The thinly sliced carrots pair beautifully with the bittersweet chicory and peppery rocket, offering a lovely variety of textures and flavors. The dressing balances sweetness from clear honey with the bright acidity of lemon juice and the richness of olive oil, elevating the humble carrot. Toasted pine nuts add an essential nutty crunch, tying the salad together. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and works well for gluten-free diets, as none of the ingredients contain gluten. The use of honey over other sweeteners makes it unsuitable for strict vegans, but otherwise, it’s a wholesome, eye-catching dish. It’s a perfect palate cleanser that can cut through the richness of heavier holiday fare.

name: Rhubarb & custard cocktail
description: A winner every time! DELICIOUS!!!
author: Good Food
directions: To make the rhubarb syrup, put the caster sugar in a saucepan with 75ml water. Heat very gently, so the sugar disappears but the water doesn’t bubble. Tip in the chopped rhubarb, cover with a tight-fitting lid and increase the heat a little so it begins to boil. Simmer, covered, for about 5 mins until the rhubarb is very tender but not disintegrating.

Turn off the heat, and tip the pan’s contents into a fine sieve over a bowl. Use a wooden spoon to gently squeeze the rhubarb so that you get all the juices, but no pulp. Tip back into the pan and boil rapidly for a few mins until just syrupy. Pour into a jug – you should have about 125ml. Leave to cool completely.

Chill 4 cocktail glasses with ice or in your freezer. Shake the vodka and 100ml of the rhubarb syrup together with ice until mixed and chilled down. Make small shreds of rhubarb using a vegetable peeler and place into iced water – this will make them curl up.
In a separate jug, whisk together the advocaat and lemonade with more ice to lighten. Divide the vodka and rhubarb mixture between the glasses, straining through a small sieve to catch the ice.

Carefully pour 25ml of your advocaat mixture into each glass over an upsidedown spoon (the mixture should float on the surface of the vodka syrup mixture). Drain the rhubarb shreds well and use to garnish your cocktails.
chief_review: This refreshing rhubarb cocktail strikes a delightful balance between sweet and tart, showcasing the bright flavors of fresh rhubarb and a playful splash of lemonade. The careful blend of vodka and advocaat adds depth without overpowering the fruitiness. The inclusion of homemade rhubarb syrup ensures the cocktail is infused with genuine rhubarb character, making each sip interesting and satisfying. While a touch of caster sugar provides sweetness, it doesn’t overshadow the vibrant notes. This recipe suits vegetarians, as no animal-derived gelatins or by-products are included in the ingredients. Overall, this is a vibrant and well-executed drink, ideal for summer gatherings or a special treat, and sure to impress with its unique use of both rhubarb and advocaat.

name: Miso-glazed roast ham
author: Tommy Banks
ingredients: 1 uncooked ham, on the bone (about 5-6 kg)
3 tbsp heather honey(you can use regular honey if you can't find this)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Sit the ham in a large roasting tin and scatter all the veg, herbs and spices around it. Pour over 750ml boiling water, then cover with a couple of layers of extra-wide foil, sealing around the edges of the tin to make a tent that will trap the steam. Roast for 4 hrs, reducing the temperature to 160C/140C fan/ gas 3 halfway through. Remove the foil, then leave the ham to rest in the tin for at least 30 mins or until it is cool enough to handle.
Meanwhile, tip all the glaze ingredients into a small pan and bring to a simmer, stirring until everything is mixed. Set aside.

Reheat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Lift the ham into a clean roasting tin – reserve the stock for soup. Cut off the skin, leaving a layer of fat all over, then use a knife to score the fat with a diamond criss-cross pattern. Roast for 10 mins to allow some of the fat to render, then use a pastry brush to paint the ham evenly with the glaze. Roast the ham for 15 mins more, then add a second layer of glaze and roast for another 15 mins until sticky and caramelised. Rest the ham for another 30 mins before serving in thick slices. You should have leftovers to enjoy cold over the next few days.
chief_review:
This ham recipe showcases a robust mix of aromatics and warm spices, resulting in a deeply flavorful centerpiece perfect for festive occasions. The use of dark miso paste and honey in the glaze brings a beautiful umami-sweet balance that complements the rich, slow-cooked meat. The aromatic base, featuring celery, onion, carrots, and herbs, gently infuses the ham with understated earthy notes. The glaze, layered with demerara sugar, cider vinegar, sherry, mustard, and Chinese five spice, lends a glossy finish with sweet, tangy, and subtly spicy complexities.

Given the use of miso paste and the absence of gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe could be suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the miso used is certified gluten-free. It's also nut-free and dairy-free, making it accessible for those with common allergies. This ham is sure to impress at any gathering with its balanced flavors and inviting aroma.

name: Steak & stilton bruschetta
description: Delish! Was completely devoid of ideas for last night's supper and this fitted the bill. Like EmSmith, I also used gorgonzola and upped the quantity of cheese a bit! Served with potato wedges.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 large steak, such as sirloin, rib-eye or rump
directions: Heat a griddle pan. Rub the steak with the olive oil, season, then cook for 2-4 mins on each side or until done to your liking. Put the steak on a plate to rest.
Put the roll halves cut-side down in the pan for 2 mins to soak up the meat juices and toast until golden brown. Spread the toasted side with the mustard and pile the watercress on top.
Cut the steak in half, sit on top of the watercress, then crumble over the stilton. Drizzle with a splash of balsamic vinegar, tip over any steak resting juices and serve.
chief_review: This steak sandwich recipe is a rich and hearty option, perfect for a quick but indulgent supper. The use of quality steak cuts, complemented by tangy Stilton or gorgonzola, creates a luscious combination with the fresh bite of watercress and a hint of balsamic acidity. Dijon mustard and the crusty ciabatta add layers of flavor and texture, making the meal satisfying and well-balanced. While the recipe contains gluten (ciabatta) and dairy (Stilton), its straightforward preparation makes it accessible for cooks at any level. Serving it with potato wedges brings an extra comfort factor, rounding out a meal that is both impressive and achievable on a weeknight.

name: Leeks & peas in lemon butter
description: You get two veg for the price of one pan with this veggie side dish, and it's a good source of vitamin C
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 leeks, each one cut on the angle into 5-6 pieces
directions: Boil the leeks in salted water for 6 mins until tender, but still holding their shape. Drain, leaving a little water in the pan, then return the leeks to the pan. Place over a low heat and stir in the peas and butter, cooking until the butter has melted and the peas are hot. Add the lemon juice, season with salt and pepper and serve straight away.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful ode to simplicity, marrying the gentle sweetness of leeks with the vibrant pop of petits pois, all brought together in a single pan. The use of cold butter imparts a classic richness, which, when paired with a bright splash of lemon juice, balances the dish beautifully. Suitable for vegetarian diets and gluten-free needs, it’s a versatile side that provides a good boost of vitamin C. The process respects the natural flavors of the vegetables, and the minimal ingredient list keeps preparation fuss-free, making it ideal for both busy weeknights and elegant dinners. For best results, ensure the butter emulsifies smoothly with the lemon juice to coat the leeks and peas evenly, delivering a silky, tangy finish.

name: Lemon & herb-basted simple roast turkey
description: Roast your Christmas turkey with a classic lemon, parsley and thyme butter for juicy, delicately flavoured meat
author: Jenny White
ingredients: Hazelnut, pancetta & orange stuffing(optional, see 'Goes well with')
directions: Remove any giblets from the turkey and save for stock, if you are making your own (see 'Tip'). Remove the bird from the fridge 1 hr before cooking to allow it to come to room temperature. Wipe the turkey inside and out with kitchen paper.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Starting at the neck-end of the bird, carefully push your fingers between the skin and flesh on the breast, loosening the skin. Mix the butter, lemon zest, herbs and garlic together and season. Push the flavoured butter under the skin and spread over the flesh. Smooth the skin back over the breast.

You can now stuff the neck-end of the bird with the stuffing, if you like, and secure the skin underneath with a skewer. Weigh the turkey and calculate the cooking time – it will need 40 mins for every 1kg.

Transfer the bird to a roasting tin, cover loosely with foil and place in the middle of the oven. Cook for 20 mins, then reduce the temperature to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 for the rest of the cooking time. Remove the foil for the last 30 mins. Check if the turkey is cooked by piercing the thickest part of the thigh with a skewer. If the juices run clear, it’s cooked. If they are pink, return it to the oven for another 15 mins, then test again. If using a meat thermometer, it should read 80C for the thighs, and the breast should be 75C.
Remove the cooked turkey from the tin, and place on a serving platter (use the tin to make the gravy – see 'Goes well with'). Cover with foil and leave to rest for 30-45 mins before carving.
chief_review: This roast turkey recipe is a masterclass in achieving tender, succulent meat with a fragrant, herby finish. The blend of softened butter, lemon zest, parsley, thyme, and garlic creates a beautifully aromatic butter, perfect for infusing the turkey with subtle citrus and herbal notes that complement—not overpower—the natural flavor of the bird. Using a free-range turkey ensures a superior texture and taste, while the option to pair with hazelnut, pancetta, and orange stuffing adds festive richness. This dish is suitable for gluten-free diets (so long as the optional stuffing is excluded or made gluten-free) and is nut-free if the hazelnut stuffing is omitted. Overall, this classic turkey promises to be a centerpiece worthy of your holiday table, delivering timeless flavors and a moist result every time.

name: Honey-glazed spiced roast goose & confit potatoes
author: Tommy Banks
ingredients: 1 garlic bulb, halved, plus 2 cloves, finely chopped
1½ kg Maris Piper potatoes, peeled and thickly sliced
3 tbsp good-quality honey(lavender honey works well)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. For the glaze, mix the honey with the spices and lots of cracked pepper, then set aside. Remove all the fat from inside the bird and, using the point of a small

or skewer, prick the skin all over, paying particular attention to the areas under the wings and around the legs. Sit the goose in an empty sink and slowly pour over a kettleful of boiling water. Repeat the process a few more times (the more the better) until the skin is tight and glossy. Leave the goose to cool, then pat dry with kitchen paper.
Season the inside of the goose and stuff with the onions, halved garlic bulb, rosemary and orange. Rub the goose all over with the oil and season generously with salt. Sit the goose on a
in a large
and tightly cover with a large piece of foil. Cook in the oven for 1 hr 30 mins.

Remove from the oven, discard the foil and use oven gloves to lift the rack (and the goose) out of the roasting tin. Pour all the fat from the tin into a bowl and set aside. Scatter the potato slices in the roasting tin, season with salt and mix with a small drizzle of the fat. Sit the goose back in the tin – on top of the potatoes – and cover with foil, then roast for 1 hr. Remove the foil, then brush the goose all over with the honey glaze and return to the oven for 15 mins. Transfer the goose to a large board or platter to rest, uncovered, in a warmish place for 30 mins.

Carefully pour away most of the fat from the potatoes. If your roasting tin is flameproof, finish browning the potatoes on top of the stove; if not, place the potatoes back in the oven until crisp and golden brown. Stir the parsley and the chopped garlic through the potatoes just before serving. Carve the goose at the table and serve with the potatoes.
chief_review: This roast goose recipe is a showstopper, pairing classic aromatics with a beautifully crisped bird. The use of onions, garlic, rosemary, and orange provides a fragrant foundation, while the honey, cinnamon, and cloves glaze the meat with a rich, gently spiced sweetness. Thick-sliced Maris Piper potatoes roasted in goose fat are the perfect accompaniment, turning gorgeously golden and infused with savory drippings. The finishing sprinkle of fresh parsley adds a burst of color and freshness. This dish is suitable for gluten-free diets, as all the ingredients are naturally gluten free—just be sure to use certified gluten-free honey if needed. The recipe is ideal for festive occasions and makes an impressive centerpiece, with both classic flavors and a touch of aromatic flair.

name: Chestnut & shallot tatins with mushroom & madeira sauce
description: Worked perfectly. Useful if cooking for both vegetarian and meat eaters as can prepare ahead and finish off whilst roasting potatoes.
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 2 tsp thyme leaves, plus extra to garnish
handful dried mixed mushrooms(you need around 3 tbsp)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Peel the shallots, cut in half lengthways and place in a single layer on a baking tray, cut-side up. Drizzle with the oil, season well and bake for 20-25 mins. Take the tray out of the oven and drizzle with the balsamic vinegar. Sprinkle with the sugar and return to the oven for 10 mins more or until golden brown and softened. Leave to stand for 10 mins.

Unroll the pastry onto a work surface lightly dusted with flour and cut out 4 x 13cm discs (or 6 x 11cm discs if making for starters), using a bowl or saucer as a guide, if you like. Divide the shallots between 4 x 12cm non-stick, preferably loose-based mini cake tins (or 6 holes of 2 x 4-hole non-stick Yorkshire pudding tins), arranging cut-side down, nice and snugly. Scatter the chestnuts on top and press down lightly. Sprinkle with the thyme leaves and season. Place a disc of puff pastry over the shallots and chestnuts in each tin and ease down the sides using a round-bladed knife. Prick with a fork all over. Can be frozen at this point (see tip, below left) or covered with cling film and kept in the fridge for up to 8 hrs before baking.

To make the mushroom sauce, put the dried mushrooms in a measuring jug and cover with 200ml just-boiled water. Leave to stand for 20 mins. Drain in a sieve and reserve the soaking liquor. Put the mushrooms on a board and roughly chop. Heat the oil in a medium frying pan and fry the chestnut mushrooms over a high heat for 2-3 mins until lightly browned. Reduce the heat, stir in the butter and, as soon as it has melted, add the flour and the soaked mushrooms and cook for a few secs, stirring.

Slowly add the mushroom liquor, taking care to avoid adding any gritty bits from the bottom of the jug, then add the madeira, stirring well between each addition. Bring the sauce to a simmer and cook for 2 mins, stirring. Adjust the seasoning to taste.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Place the cake tins on a baking tray and bake the tatins for 20-25 mins or until the pastry is golden brown and risen. Leave to cool for 5 mins, then turn out onto warmed plates. If the shallots stick to the tin, gently ease them out with a round-bladed knife and rearrange them on the pastry. While the tatins are resting, gently warm the sauce. Spoon the mushrooms on top of each tatin and allow the sauce to drizzle onto the plates. Garnish with more thyme and serve with the vegetables.
chief_review: This savory tart makes an excellent choice for a vegetarian-friendly main course, with a thoughtful blend of shallots, mushrooms, chestnuts, and thyme contributing rich, earthy flavors. The ready-rolled puff pastry provides a crisp, golden base, while the balsamic and brown sugar glaze adds a subtle sweetness that complements the umami of the mushrooms and madeira. It pairs beautifully with sides like roasted carrots and steamed cabbage, making it a balanced meal. Suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians, the recipe features dairy butter but no meat products. Those preparing for a mixed group of eaters will appreciate its ability to be prepped ahead of time and finished while roasting potatoes—a practical touch for stress-free entertaining. If catering for vegans or those with gluten sensitivities, the recipe would require adaptations such as dairy-free substitutes and gluten-free pastry/flour. A creative, well-executed dish ideal for festive or everyday occasions.

name: Chocolate orange cheesecake
description:
Very poor. Made exactly as recipe (used Solerno liqueur). Base was nondescript. Cheesecake itself was watery and lacking flavour with an unpleasant loose grainy texture. Topping becomes hard and cracks when sliced.
Nigella's key lime cheesecake uses the same directions and is divine. I'd tweak that recipe to use orange if I wanted an orange cheesecake again.
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 75g butter, melted, plus extra for greasing
4 tbsp orange liqueur, such as Cointreau
directions: Lightly grease and line a 20cm springform cake tin. To make the base, put the biscuits and butter in a food processor, pulse into fine crumbs, then tip into the tin. Spread evenly over the base and press down firmly with the back of a spoon. Put the tin in the freezer and leave to set for 30 mins.

Put a large piece of foil (extra-wide foil if possible) on the work surface, or criss-cross two pieces of small foil. Place the cake tin in the centre of the foil and bring up the sides to create a foil bowl around the cheesecake. Place in a medium-sized roasting tin.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. To make the filling, put the eggs and egg yolks in a food processor and blitz until well combined. Add the cheese, cream, sugar, orange zest and orange liqueur to the food processor and pulse until only just combined. Pour the cheesecake filling gently onto the chilled base.

Add enough just-boiled water to the roasting tin to rise roughly 2cm up the sides. Carefully place the roasting tin in the centre of the oven and bake for about 1 hr 15 mins. The cheesecake is ready when it is very lightly browned and only just set.

Take out of the oven and sprinkle with the grated chocolate. Leave to cool in the water bath for 15 mins. Lift the cake tin from the water and leave to cool for a further 1 hr. Cover with cling film and chill the cheesecake overnight before serving.

To serve, run a round-bladed knife around the cheesecake and carefully release it from the tin. Using a palette knife, slide the cheesecake onto a flat serving plate or cake stand and cut into wedges to serve.
chief_review:
This orange chocolate cheesecake combines a rich base of dark chocolate digestives with a creamy filling subtly infused with orange zest and liqueur. However, the texture suffers from excess moisture and turns out uncharacteristically grainy, rather than luxuriously smooth. The use of double cream and cream cheese does promise indulgence, but the flavour doesn’t shine through, leaving the cheesecake somewhat bland. The topping, despite the promise of grated orange and almond milk chocolates, becomes overly hard, making slicing and serving problematic.

For those following a vegetarian diet, this recipe is suitable as it contains no gelatine or animal-derived setting agents. However, the inclusion of wheat-based biscuits, dairy, eggs, and chocolates makes it unsuitable for gluten-free, vegan, dairy-free, or nut-allergy diets. With refinement and perhaps inspiration from a more successful citrus cheesecake, there’s potential to lift both the taste and texture of this creation.

name: Slow-cooked pork & red cabbage
description: A wonderfully seasonal dish for Christmas entertaining - serve with a big of mashed potato and a seasonal salad
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2 apples, peeled, cored and cut into eighths
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Cut the pork into thick slices, about 3cm thick. Coarsely crush the peppercorns and sprinkle over the pork along with the thyme and some salt and pepper.

Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large flameproof casserole, then add the onions and fry until lightly browned. Add the cabbage and stir well, then add the apples and wine and cook until the cabbage starts to soften. Finally, add the chestnuts, 1 tbsp of the jelly, salt and pepper, and bring to the boil. Cover and simmer for 5 mins.

Meanwhile, heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a frying pan, add the pork and fry on both sides until browned, then stir in the remaining tbsp of the jelly. Cook for a few mins until the pork is deeply browned and glistening. Arrange the pork over the cabbage. Pour a little boiling water into the frying pan, stir well to lift up all the pan juices, then pour over the pork.
Cover the pan tightly, then cook in the oven for 1¼-1½ hrs until the pork is very tender.
chief_review: This festive pork shoulder recipe is a delightful centerpiece for Christmas gatherings, marrying rich, tender meat with the sweetness of apples, red cabbage, and cranberry or redcurrant jelly. The inclusion of chestnuts adds a lovely earthy texture and seasonal flair, while the red wine imparts depth and richness. The use of olive oil and plenty of fresh thyme ensures an aromatic, herbaceous note that livens up the slow-cooked elements. This dish is gluten-free, making it suitable for those avoiding wheat-based products. It may also suit some dairy-free diets, as no butter, cream, or milk is used. However, those with nut allergies should be cautious due to the presence of chestnuts. Overall, this recipe balances savory and sweet notes beautifully, making it a standout option for a festive table.

name: Pickled red cabbage with walnuts & apple
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 1 small red cabbagequartered, cored and finely shredded (with a mandoline, if you can)
2 red onions, finely sliced (with a mandoline, if you can)
100g walnuthalves, toasted and lightly crushed with a pestle and mortar
3 Granny Smith apple, skin on, quartered, cored and sliced
directions: Tip the cabbage and red onion into a bowl and season with 2 tsp sea salt, then toss together. Set aside for to cure for 20 mins.

Meanwhile, pour 200ml water into a saucepan and add the chilli, juniper, allspice, vinegar and sugar, then bring to the boil. Tip the cured cabbage into a colander and rinse once under cold water to remove any excess salt. Pack into a large, clean container and pour over the warmed spiced pickling liquid. Put on the lid and leave in the fridge until needed. Can be made up to a week ahead.

When you are ready to serve, drain the pickling liquid from the cabbage and discard the dried chilli. Bring up to room temperature, then stir through the nuts, dill and sliced apple. Spoon the salad into a large salad bowl to serve.
chief_review:
This vibrant salad offers a delightful interplay of textures and flavors—crunchy red cabbage, tart Granny Smith apples, and earthy toasted walnuts, all brightened with a spiced red wine vinegar dressing. Aromatic dill lifts the dish, while allspice, juniper, and a touch of chili add subtle warmth and complexity. The use of vinegar and demerara sugar creates a balanced sweet-sour profile reminiscent of classic pickled salads.

Suited for vegetarian and vegan diets, this recipe is free from animal products and contains no gluten-based ingredients, making it accessible for gluten-free eaters. However, those with nut allergies should take note of the walnuts. Ideal as a fresh side or a stand-alone lunch, the salad’s combination of raw vegetables and fruit offers both nutrition and flavor interest, making it a thoughtful addition to any spread prioritizing plant-based whole foods.

name: Peach & chilli chutney
description: Preserve sweet juicy fruit in this spiced chutney with cardamom, chilli and ginger - great with cheese, cold meat or curry
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 700g (prepared weight) firm peach(about 8), peeled and cut into small dice
thumb-sized piece ginger, peeled and cut into fine matchsticks
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan, add the onion and cook for a few mins until starting to soften. Add the remaining ingredients, increase the heat and stir to dissolve the sugar. Reduce the heat and simmer, uncovered, until most of the liquid has evaporated and the peaches have softened – this will take about 45 mins. Meanwhile, sterilise your jars (see tip, below).
Transfer the chutney to the jars, seal and leave to cool before eating. The chutney can be stored in a cool dry place for up to 1 year.
chief_review: This peach chutney recipe is a delightful balance of sweet, spicy, and tangy flavors, thanks to the combination of ripe peaches, red chillies, aromatic ginger, and warming spices like cumin and cardamom. The use of cider vinegar and brown sugar ensures a glossy, well-preserved finish with a nuanced depth. It's remarkably versatile—perfect for pairing with cheese, cold meats, or as an accompaniment to curries, adding a vibrant punch to any platter. The absence of animal products and use of plant-based oil make it suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets, while the ingredient list is naturally gluten-free, fitting those with gluten sensitivities. This recipe also avoids common allergens such as nuts and dairy, providing a thoughtful, flavorful addition to many tables. A must-try for chutney enthusiasts seeking something just a little exotic!

name: Feed-a-crowd chunky beef chilli
description: The ultimate make-ahead dish, this chilli con carne can be frozen for up to 2 months - simply add more chillies to turn up the heat
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: 50g dried Mexican chillies, soaked in boiling water for 1-2 hrs
1½ kg chuck steak, beef shin or ox cheek
2 red peppers, deseeded and roughly chopped
240g can kidney beans, drained and rinsed
240g can black beans, drained and rinsed
directions: Drain the chillies and discard the seeds and stalks. Roughly chop and put in the small bowl of a food processor with the garlic, 2 tbsp of the oil, the red wine vinegar, cumin and oregano. Whizz to a paste.
Put the meat in a bowl or resealable food bag, pour on the paste and rub all over the meat. Leave to marinate overnight (or for at least 4 hrs).

Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Heat the remaining oil in a large, lidded flameproof casserole dish and cook the onions for a few mins until beginning to soften. Add the meat and all the paste to the dish and cook for about 5 mins, turning the meat until browned all over. Pour in the tomatoes and add the cinnamon. Stir everything together, then add 100ml water and bring to the boil. Put on the lid, transfer to the oven and cook for 1 hr 45 mins.

Remove the lid and stir in the red peppers, chocolate, sugar and all the beans. Return to the oven for another 20 mins. To serve, stir in the lime zest and juice, season to taste, and scatter over the coriander.
chief_review: This chilli con carne recipe is a robust, slow-cooked dish that expertly balances smoky Mexican chillies, aromatic spices, and the deep richness of beef cuts like chuck steak or ox cheek. The blend of dark chocolate and cinnamon offers complexity and warmth, while kidney and black beans bring earthiness and heartiness. The addition of lime zest and coriander at the end cuts through the richness, brightening each bite. As a make-ahead option, it freezes beautifully, making it perfect for busy cooks or meal prep. Gluten-free by nature, this recipe also fits well within a dairy-free diet. Serve on its own or with rice for a comforting, flavor-packed meal adaptable to your preferred spice level. This is a chef-worthy chili that will satisfy both traditionalists and adventurous eaters alike.

name: Sherried sprout & Savoy gratin
description: We had this with sliced gammon leftover from the weekend. The whole family enjoyed it but I am fortunate that my kids love sprouts, but we all agreed it would be too much to serve as part of a roast. Will definitely be making this again Leftovers taken to work for lunch
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1 large Savoy cabbage, cut into 10 wedges
60g hard cheese, grated (parmesan, comté or pecorino all work well)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the cabbage wedges and sprouts with the oil, garlic and thyme in a large gratin dish. Season well, then roast for 25 mins.

Meanwhile, melt the butter in a saucepan. Stir in the flour and cook for a couple of mins until it begins to turn golden. Remove from the heat then, whisking constantly, gradually pour in the sherry, followed by the milk and cream. Put the sauce back on the heat and cook for 3-4 mins,
constantly, until you have a thick sauce. Grate in a generous amount of nutmeg, season well and set aside. Mix the breadcrumbs with the cheese.

Take the sprouts and cabbage out of the oven, pour over the sauce and top with the cheesy breadcrumbs. Can be made a day ahead, and then reheated. Heat grill to 200C and grill the gratin for 15 mins until the top is golden and crisp. Leave to stand for 5 mins before serving.
chief_review: This comforting bake is a clever way to showcase winter greens, combining Savoy cabbage and Brussels sprouts in a rich, creamy sauce. The blend of sherry, whole milk, and double cream gives depth, while the baked breadcrumb and cheese top provides a golden, textural finish. The sharpness of parmesan or comté nicely offsets the butteriness and sweetness of the vegetables. The recipe is suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, provided you choose a vegetarian hard cheese (ensure it’s not made with animal rennet). Those avoiding gluten or dairy will need substitutions as it features both flour and multiple dairy components. This dish shines as a main with a crisp salad or as a decadent side. It’s filling, reheats well, and makes for a satisfying next-day lunch. An excellent winter warmer that celebrates veggies in a family-friendly format.

name: Bacon & pecan stuffing cornbread
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 75g butter, melted, plus extra for the tin
500ml buttermilk (or 500ml semi-skimmed milk with a squeeze of lemon juice)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Brush a 20 x 30cm roasting tin with melted butter. Combine the polenta, flour, baking powder, sugar and 2 tsp salt in a large mixing bowl. Mix the melted butter, buttermilk and eggs in a jug, then make a well in the centre of the dry ingredients and pour in the buttermilk mixture. Stir well until smooth.

Fry the bacon in a large frying pan until it starts to crisp, then add the onion and celery and cook for 5 mins. Add the rest of the stuffing ingredients and the cornbread mix, season well and stir together.
Scrape it all into the prepared tin and bake for 1 hr or until cooked through. Cut into squares to serve.
chief_review: This recipe is a wonderfully hearty and savory bake, clearly inspired by classic stuffing combinations and rustic bread pudding techniques. The use of polenta gives the dish a delightful crumb and gentle sweetness, while the blend of dried apricots and cranberries infuses pops of tartness and depth. The addition of pork mince and bacon lardons ensures a rich, meaty flavor profile, balanced by the aromatic mix of onions, celery, and thyme. Crunchy pecans add a well-placed textural contrast. However, note the inclusion of both plain flour and buttermilk (or a milk alternative), which means this recipe contains gluten and dairy. The blend of ingredients makes it unsuitable for vegetarians or vegans, but it will certainly please those who seek a comforting, flavor-packed dish with a satisfying, slightly sweet-savory character—perfect alongside roast meats or as a festive centerpiece.

name: Root vegetable tatin with candied nuts & blue cheese
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: 3 slim carrots, about 12-13 cm long, halved lengthways
3 slim parsnips about 12-13 cm long, halved lengthways plus 1 large parsnip, peeled and grated
5 banana shallots, 3 halved lengthways, 2 thinly sliced
small bunch sage, leaves picked and finely chopped
4 rosemary sprigs, leaves picked and finely chopped
2 garlic cloves, finely grated or crushed
100g blue cheese, crumbled (we used Cropwell Bishop)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
the pastry to just larger than a 30cm diameter ovenproof frying pan and use the pan as a template to cut out a round of pastry. Leave in the fridge, or a cool place while you prepare everything else.
Bring a

of water to the boil, add the carrots and parsnips and cook for 5 mins. Drain and set aside to dry off slightly. Heat the oil and 1 tbsp of the butter in your pan and cook the sliced shallots and grated parsnips for 1-2 mins over a medium-high heat until just starting to brown, then add a good splash of water to the pan, stir to scrape up any brown bits, turn the heat down slightly, cover and cook for 4-5 mins, stirring every so often. The parsnips should be tender. Add the herbs and garlic and cook for another minute, then tip into a bowl, scraping out as well as you can. Season a little and set aside.

Add the sugar and vinegar to the pan and bring to the boil. Cook for a few minutes until syrupy, then stir in the remaining butter. Set aside to cool slightly, then arrange the vegetables in the pan, fanning them out. Top with the herby shallot and parsnip mixture, pushing it into any spaces there may be. Lay the pastry over the top of the vegetables and push in the edges a little. Place in the oven and bake for 30-35 mins until puffed and deep golden brown.

While the tart bakes, put the nuts, sugar and butter in a small frying pan with a pinch of salt. Cook over a medium-high heat for about 5 mins, stirring, until the sugar has dissolved and coated the nuts. Add the rosemary for the last minute. Tip out onto a piece of baking parchment and leave to cool for a few minutes.

Once the tart is baked, remove from the oven and carefully turn out onto a serving board. Scrape out any bits that are left in the tin and add back to the tart. Bash the nuts to break them up and scatter over, along with the crumbled cheese.
chief_review:
This recipe is a sophisticated, vegetable-forward tart that showcases root vegetables and aromatic herbs in a flaky puff pastry base. The combination of carrots, parsnips, shallots, and sage brings sweetness and earthiness, balanced beautifully by the tangy hit of red wine vinegar and the creamy, umami-rich blue cheese. The addition of walnuts introduces a satisfying crunch, elevating the texture profile. The finishing touch of caramelized nuts with rosemary adds both savoriness and a hint of sweetness, complementing the vegetables perfectly.

Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, as the dish contains both butter and blue cheese but no meat or fish. Those following a nut-free or gluten-free diet should be cautious, as the dish includes walnuts and traditional puff pastry which typically contains wheat. Overall, this tart is an elegant centerpiece for a vegetarian feast and a delicious way to celebrate seasonal produce.

name: Sweet potato parcel
description: We really enjoyed this pie. The only thing I would say is that the sweet potato could spend less time in the oven before going in the pie as it will finish cooking in it. You just save some power from not having the oven on so long. I might make it as individual pies next time.
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: 4 sweet potatoes(about 750g), peeled and cut into 2-3cm chunks
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the potatoes on a
, toss with 1 tbsp of the oil, season and roast for 25 mins.

While the potatoes roast, heat another 1 tbsp oil in a frying pan and cook the onion over a medium heat for about 7-10 mins to soften. Stir in the garlic, chilli flakes and sage and cook for another minute or 2. Remove from the heat and add the chestnuts, cranberry sauce and the sweet potato cubes. Season a little.

Line a 20cm square tin with a rectangle of baking parchment that comes up two sides of the tin (this is to help you remove it later). Put 1 sheet of filo in the tin, brushing the bottom and sides with a little of the remaining oil, then add another piece of filo going in the other direction (like a cross). Brush with more oil on the bottom and sides, and repeat with another 2 sheets of filo.

Spoon the sweet potato mixture into the tin and fold over the filo to cover, brushing with a little more of the oil. Brush the last piece of filo with the remaining oil, then scrunch on top of the parcel. Put in the oven and bake for 30 mins. 5 To serve, use the baking parchment to lift the parcel out
of the tin and cut into four.
chief_review: This inventive pie combines the natural sweetness of sweet potatoes with earthy chestnuts, aromatic sage, and a vibrant hint of cranberry sauce—all encased in crisp filo pastry. Using rapeseed oil and omitting any animal-derived ingredients, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and, with careful choice of dairy-free filo, can be easily adapted for vegans as well. The lack of gluten-containing ingredients in the filling makes it ideal for those avoiding gluten if gluten-free filo is used. The use of chestnuts provides a lovely texture and protein boost, making this a satisfying main or side dish. The tip to par-cook sweet potatoes saves time and energy—a smart move for busy cooks. Overall, a thoughtfully balanced pie that can be served for diverse dietary needs with just minor adjustments.

name: Tilly's trifle
description: Gordon Ramsay's traditional trifle is the perfect treat to satisfy the whole family.
author: Gordon Ramsay
directions: First, make the jelly. Soak the gelatine leaves in cold water until floppy, then drain. Strain off the juice from the cherries into a jug – you should have around 350-400ml. Put the juice and the redcurrant jelly in a pan, stirring until it boils and the redcurrant jelly has melted. Take off the heat, cool for a few mins, then stir in the gelatine until it dissolves. Pour into a shallow pan or dish to cool, then chill until set.

For the custard, scrape the vanilla seeds from the pod into a large bowl. Add the egg yolks, 40g sugar and the flour, then whisk until pale and creamy. Pour the cream into a medium-size pan and bring just to the boil. Gradually whisk the cream into the yolk mix. Wipe out the pan, then return the mixture to it. Cook slowly over a low heat, stirring with a wooden spoon until thickened – take extra care to stir well at the edges of the pan. Cool, stirring every so often.
To assemble the trifle, slice the Swiss roll into 8 pieces and arrange on the base and around the inside of a large glass serving bowl. Sprinkle with the sherry, if using.
Turn the jelly out onto a board and chop with a sharp knife. Scatter the drained cherries and chopped jelly on top of the Swiss roll, then sprinkle over the crushed amaretti.

Pour the cooled custard over the biscuits, then return to the fridge until cold (about 2 hrs). For the topping, whip the cream to soft peaks with 1 tbsp sugar, then spoon or pipe it over the custard. The trifle can be covered and chilled for up to 2 days at this point.
To serve, sprinkle over the pistachios and remaining amaretti. Push back the leaves of the physalis and poke the fruit into the cream.
chief_review:
Gordon Ramsay's traditional trifle is a masterful layering of flavors and textures, offering a delightful indulgence for dessert lovers. The use of Morello cherries and redcurrant jelly adds a sharp, fruity contrast to the rich Swiss roll and velvety custard. Amaretti biscuits and pistachios provide a delightful crunch, while the physalis gives a fresh, vibrant finish. The inclusion of sherry is optional, making this trifle flexible for various occasions.

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it uses leaf gelatine, which is often derived from animal sources; however, vegetarians can substitute with a plant-based alternative if desired. Be aware of common allergens like eggs, nuts, dairy, and gluten present in multiple components. Overall, it’s a show-stopping dessert that balances tradition with refined flavors—perfect for celebratory gatherings.

name: Sausage & fennel seed slices
description:
I guess you could do it this way with any sausage roll recipe but this was really convenient for freezing and having it on stand-by. They were also really delicious! I had a couple of "rolls" in the freezer over Xmas and NY and I plan to do several more for the summer - I get houseful so of teenager and this is so handy to have around.
The instructions do look a bit daunting but actually it's very easy. It's worth doing because it's much easier to cut the pastry tidily before it's cooked than after!
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put the skinned sausages in a bowl and squish together with your hands, then divide into two balls. Place one ball of sausagemeat onto a long piece of cling film. Roll into a cylinder approx 30cm long. Wrap tightly in the cling film and place on a plate or tray in the fridge. Repeat with the other ball of sausagemeat.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Lay the pastry out on your work surface and cut it into four equal strips lengthways. Roll two of the strips out a little more with a rolling pin so that they are 40cm long and 10cm wide. Unwrap the sausagemeat, place each one in the middle of a rolled-out pastry length and sprinkle each with half the fennel seeds. On either side of the meat, cut regular slits from the edge up to the meat – do this all the way round to create 2cm tabs. Fold over the ends. Starting at one end, bring up one tab from one side and drape it over the meat, then do the same with one from the opposite side. Repeat with the other strip of sausagemeat. Brush both with egg, then lift onto baking trays.
Cut each of the remaining strips of pastry into three strips lengthways and plait together. Lay the plait on top of the sausage pastries and brush with more egg.
Bake in the oven for 40 mins or until risen and golden brown. Remove from the oven, transfer to a large board and slice – or allow your guests to serve themselves. Can be served hot or cold.
chief_review: This sausage roll recipe is a great option for busy households and makes for an excellent make-ahead snack or party food. The combination of pork sausages and the aromatic kick of fennel seeds wrapped in buttery puff pastry creates a savory treat teenagers and adults will both love. The tip to cut the pastry before baking is spot-on for achieving neat, bakery-style results. This recipe, however, isn’t suitable for gluten-free diets due to the puff pastry, nor is it compatible with vegetarian or vegan diets because of the pork and egg. The convenience of freezing and baking on demand is a winner, making it ideal for gatherings and last-minute entertaining.

name: Smoky sweet root vegetables
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 600g baby carrots, scrubbed (about 2cm of the tops left on), any larger ones cut in half lengthways
600g baby parsnips, scrubbed, any larger ones cut in half lengthways
directions: The day before, put the butter, sugar and 500ml water in a deep frying pan. Heat until the butter is melted, then bring the liquid to the boil and simmer until lightly syrupy. Drop in the parsnips and cook, covered, for 6-8 mins until just tender then, using tongs, transfer to a roasting tin. Repeat with the carrots then tip them, with the liquid, into the roasting tin with the parsnips. Leave to cool, then put in the fridge overnight.
When you are ready to eat, take the roots out the fridge, and lift out of the syrup. Discard the syrup. Heat a

or frying pan until searing hot then, in batches, put the roots cut-side down in the pan and cook for a min on each side until visibly charred. Sprinkle over the smoked salt, lemon juice and some parsley to serve.
chief_review: A delightful side dish showcasing the natural sweetness of baby carrots and parsnips, this recipe blends earthy root vegetables with a buttery glaze, enlivened by the brightness of lemon juice and the savory edge of smoked salt. The addition of fresh parsley adds a pleasant herbaceous note and a touch of color. This vegetable-forward preparation is well-suited for vegetarian diets, as it contains no meat or animal-derived rennet. The absence of wheat or gluten-containing additives also makes it a solid choice for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the smoked salt used is certified gluten-free. The simple, well-balanced flavors make this an excellent accompaniment to roasted mains or as part of a festive spread.

name: Brown rice canapé bowl
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: selection of leftover Asian-style canapés(we used 6 gyoza and 120g tempura prawns)
1 carrot, peeled into ribbons with a vegetable peeler
100g frozen edamameor peas, cooked and cooled
sesame seeds (optional) and pickled ginger or fresh ginger, cut into matchsticks, to serve
directions: Whisk the dressing ingredients together and set aside. Cook the rice following pack instructions, divide between two bowls and drizzle over half the dressing. Reheat the canapés.

Arrange all the remaining ingredients on top of the rice, making sections of carrot, cucumber, edamame, and canapés. Top with the coriander, sesame seeds and pickled ginger. Drizzle over the remaining dressing and serve.
chief_review: This creative rice bowl is a fantastic way to repurpose leftover Asian-style canapés like gyoza and tempura prawns, paired with vibrant fresh vegetables and aromatic garnishes. The combination of brown rice, edamame (or peas), carrot ribbons, and cucumber offers a pleasing balance of textures and flavors, while the coriander and optional sesame seeds enhance the freshness. The sweet chilli, soy sauce, and sesame oil make for a well-rounded dressing with both sweet and savoury notes. This dish is excellent for pescatarians, as it contains seafood (tempura prawns) and no red meat. It can also be made nut-free, provided your sauces and canapés don’t contain nuts. With the use of brown rice and a variety of vegetables, it’s relatively high in fiber. To make it gluten-free, ensure your soy sauce, gyoza, and tempura batter are gluten-free variants.

name: Chocolate Jaffa pots
description: I made this and i too found i needed double the jelly mixture, i didn't have enough so i had to use normal orange jelly but it was fine, would have preferred the original jelly, it had such lovely flavour. Would used tinned mandarins next time, far too much hassle peeling your own. Very popular though.
author: John Torode
directions: To make the clementine jelly, put the sugar, vanilla pod, cinnamon stick, clementine juice and 100ml water in a large pan and bring to a gentle simmer. Meanwhile, peel the clementines and remove all the pith and outside membranes. Put the broken-up segments into a bowl and pour over the spiced sugar syrup. Cover with cling film and allow to macerate for at least 30 mins.

Meanwhile, cut the madeira cake into 2cm-thick slices, trimming off and discarding the dark edges. Divide the slices between 12 glasses and push down in an even layer. Soak the gelatine leaves in cold water.

Drain the clementines, pouring the liquid into a small saucepan. Discard the vanilla and cinnamon stick. Divide the clementines between the glasses in an even layer. Gently warm the liquid. Once it is warm, squeeze the gelatine to remove the excess water and stir into the warm liquid until completely melted.
Pour a layer of the jelly over the clementines. Transfer the pots to the fridge and allow to set for at least 3 hrs.

To make the chocolate layer, heat the cream to just below boiling. Remove from the heat, add the chocolate and stir until melted and smooth. Add the liqueur and butter and mix until fully combined. Pour into a jug and allow to cool for 15-20 mins. Pour on top of the jelly and put back in the fridge for a few hours to set.
chief_review: This trifle recipe is a delightful citrus twist on a classic dessert, pairing soft madeira cake with a vibrant clementine jelly and lush layers of double cream and dark chocolate. Using tinned mandarins is a practical tip to save time, and the subtle warmth from cinnamon and vanilla pod infuses extra depth into the dish. The inclusion of orange liqueur and real butter rounds out the flavor profile beautifully. However, it contains dairy, gluten, alcohol, and gelatine, so it is not suitable for vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, or dairy-free diets. The recipe is rich and indulgent, making it an excellent showstopper for gatherings where a decadent, crowd-pleasing dessert is called for. The balance of citrus and chocolate works very well, delivering a memorable finish to any meal.

name: Pecan mince pie
description: Take this beautiful mincemeat, nut-topped tart along to a festive buffet or serve with an indulgent brandy cream as an alternative to the traditional Christmas pud
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 250g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
400g homemade mincemeat(see goes well with for recipe), or a 411g shop-bought jar
directions: To make the pastry, put all the ingredients in a food processor and pulse until it comes together, then tip onto a surface and knead into a ball. Wrap in cling film and chill in the fridge for 30 mins.
Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface and use to line a 23cm tart tin, leaving any excess pastry overhanging. Chill for a further 30 mins.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5 with a baking sheet on the middle shelf. Prick the pastry base with a fork and line the tin with baking parchment and baking beans or some dry rice. Place on the baking sheet and bake for 20 mins until golden around the edges. Remove the parchment and beans, and return to the oven for 10 mins more until the base is biscuit-brown.

While the pie case is baking, make the filling. Finely chop half the pecans by hand or by pulsing in a food processor, then tip into a bowl. Mix in the eggs, golden syrup and melted butter until completely combined, then stir in the mincemeat.
When the pie case is cooked, spoon over the mincemeat pecan filling and top with the reserved whole pecans. Bake for 20-25 mins until the top is just set, then remove from the oven to cool slightly.

To make the brandy cream, whisk together the cream and the icing sugar until holding soft peaks, then gently whisk in the brandy, vanilla and cinnamon. Serve the pie warm in slices with a dollop of the cream.
chief_review: This festive mincemeat and nut-topped tart is a delightful centerpiece for any holiday buffet, offering a rich, buttery pastry filled with aromatic, spiced mincemeat and toasted pecans. The addition of an orange zest pastry base brings a lively freshness, while the nutty topping adds satisfying crunch and depth. Paired with an indulgent brandy cream, this alternative Christmas pudding is especially appealing to those seeking a luxurious twist on tradition. The recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, provided the mincemeat used does not contain suet derived from animals. However, due to the inclusion of flour, butter, eggs, and cream, it is not aligned with vegan, gluten-free, or dairy-free diets. The tart’s flavors are rich, festive, and sure to impress, making it an excellent choice for special occasions.

name: Choc hazelnut truffles
description: Wrap these decorative chocolates in cellophane and pack in boxes to give as gifts or simply bring out after dinner to wow your guests
author: Good Food
directions: In a small saucepan, bring the cream to the boil. Remove from the heat and pour over the chopped chocolate. Gently stir the mixture until smooth, then add the alcohol or vanilla extract and hazelnuts. Cover and put in the fridge for 30 mins or until the mixture is thick but not solid.

Scoop out teaspoons of the mixture and roll into small balls with your hands. Put each of your sprinkles or glitters onto separate small plates or bowls. Roll each truffle into the sprinkles or glitter to coat, then chill again to firm up. Will keep chilled for 1 week, or freeze for up to 1 month without the decoration.
chief_review: This recipe delivers luxurious, visually stunning chocolates that impress both as a handmade gift and as a post-dinner finale. The combination of rich dark chocolate, silky double cream, and aromatic Frangelico or vanilla extract yields a decadent, balanced flavor. Hazelnuts add a satisfying crunch and earthy note, while the sprinkles and edible glitter deliver playful, festive flair. This recipe is especially suited for lacto-vegetarians as it contains no gelatine or animal rennet, only dairy and plant-based ingredients. Those with gluten sensitivities should choose gluten-free sprinkles to accommodate dietary needs. Overall, this recipe offers both elegance and a customizable, memorable treat.

name: Piña colada
description: Nice and strong! I used Coco Lopez as the coconut element (bought off Amazon).
author: Good Food
directions: Pulse all the ingredients along with a handful of ice in a blender until smooth. Pour into a tall glass and garnish as you like.
chief_review: This recipe is a classic Piña Colada—a tropical cocktail that balances the fruity sharpness of pineapple juice with the creamy richness of coconut cream and the punch of white rum. The use of Coco Lopez coconut cream provides a decadent, authentic flavor with just the right amount of sweetness. The texture is silky and indulgent, making each sip a true escape. For those following a vegetarian or vegan diet, check your coconut cream to ensure it's free from animal-derived additives, but Coco Lopez is generally vegan. This drink is also naturally gluten-free, as all primary ingredients typically contain no gluten. Serve over ice and garnish with a wedge of pineapple for a vibrant, visually appealing treat—ideal for summer parties or a simple evening refreshment.

name: Thai turkey filo dippers
description: Fill filo pastry parcels with turkey or chicken mince, spring onions and ginger for a buffet nibble or party canapé similar to a spring roll
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 3 sheets filo pastry, each about 24 x 48cm
Thai sweet chilli dipping sauce, to serve
6 spring onions, trimmed and finely sliced
25g piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated
directions: To make the filling, mix all the ingredients in a small bowl until thoroughly combined. Cut each sheet of filo pastry into 4 evenly sized rectangles. Make a pile of 12 rectangles and cover with a damp tea towel to stop them drying out.

Brush 1 of the rectangles lightly with oil. With one of the shortest sides facing you, spoon 1 level tbsp of the filling across the pastry 2cm up from the bottom of the rectangle and around 1cm in from both sides. Form into a sausage shape. Fold in the bottom over the filling, then fold in the 2 long sides all the way up the rectangle. Roll up from the short side close to you, fully enclosing the filling.

Place on a baking tray lined with baking parchment. Repeat as above to make a further 11 filo rolls. Brush with more oil and sprinkle with sesame seeds, if using. Can be covered with cling film at this stage and kept in the fridge for up to 8 hrs before baking.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bake the dippers for 10-15 mins or until the pastry is light golden brown and the filling is cooked thoroughly. Serve with Thai sweet chilli dipping sauce.
chief_review:
This inventive filo pastry parcel brings together aromatic Thai flavors in a light, crisp package. With juicy turkey or chicken mince as a base, accented by spring onions, fresh ginger, garlic, and zesty lime leaves, the filling is both punchy and balanced. The touch of Thai red curry paste and fish sauce lends an authentic Southeast Asian character, while the optional sesame seeds add a nutty crunch atop the flaky pastry.

Paired with sweet chilli sauce, these parcels are perfect as a canapé or party appetizer—delicate yet satisfying. The recipe is suitable for those seeking a dairy-free option, and using turkey or chicken keeps the bite leaner and lower in fat than traditional pork-based alternatives. Vegetarians and those with gluten sensitivities should note that adaptations would be needed, given the core ingredients in the filling and pastry. A clever, crowd-pleasing finger food.

name: Yule slice
description: Perfect for health-conscious people who still like a Christmas treat, this is dairy-free and full of fruit and nuts
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Heat oven to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2. Line the base and sides of a 1.5-litre loaf tin (a long thin one is best) with baking parchment. Mix the nuts and dried fruit thoroughly in a large bowl using your hands. Sift in the flour, spice and baking powder, then add the sugar and mix everything well. Beat the eggs with the vanilla, then add to the dry mix, turning everything together well until there is no dry mix visible.

Turn into the prepared tin and smooth the top. Bake for 1½-1¾ hrs, then cool in the tin for 15 mins. Turn out, peel off the paper and cool on a wire rack. Dust the top thickly with icing sugar, to serve.
chief_review: This festive fruit and nut cake stands out as an excellent option for those seeking a dairy-free treat during the holidays. With a dense medley of walnuts, hazelnuts, almonds, raisins, dates, apricots, and glacé fruit, it offers a robust, chewy texture and natural sweetness balanced by dark muscovado sugar and aromatic mixed spice. The use of plain flour and eggs gives the cake a satisfying crumb and structure, while the touch of vanilla extract rounds out the flavors beautifully. As there's no butter or milk, it's perfectly suited for a dairy-free diet. The abundance of fruit and nuts not only provides flavor but also ensures a healthier alternative to traditional Christmas cakes—making it suitable for anyone looking for a more wholesome holiday indulgence. Dust lightly with icing sugar for a simple, elegant finish.

name: All-the-trimmings roast potatoes
description: Save space and time by throwing everything together in the same bowl. Perfect for people without a four-doored oven
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 230C/fan 210C/gas 8. Tip the potatoes into a roasting tin and toss in oil. Place in the oven on the shelf below thepoussin and roast undisturbed for 30 mins.
Toss through the sausages and chestnuts, then cook 15 mins more until the sausages are brown. Scatter over the parsley to serve.
chief_review: This one-bowl wonder is a brilliant choice for busy cooks or anyone working with limited kitchen space. Chunky potatoes, savory cocktail sausages, and buttery chestnuts are tossed together with a drizzle of vegetable oil and finished with fresh parsley for a simple yet flavorful dish. The interplay of earthy chestnuts and herby parsley elevates the humble potato and sausage pairing, making it satisfyingly hearty. The recipe contains no dairy or gluten-based ingredients, making it a solid option for those following a gluten-free diet—just ensure your sausages are certified gluten-free. This dish is also nut-free (chestnuts are not botanical nuts) and suitable for omnivores looking for a quick, fuss-free meal with rustic charm.

name: Mustard-glazed roast chicken with Waldorf stuffing
description: A few extra vegetables will turn this recipe into a Sunday lunch spread - get ahead by making the stuffing in advance
author: Good Food
ingredients: roast potatoes and vegetables, to serve (optional)
2 red apples, cored and finely chopped
100g fresh breadcrumb, handful reserved for the topping
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. To make the stuffing, mix together all the ingredients, except the butter, in a large bowl with some seasoning. Scrunch with your hands until well combined.
Season the chicken all over and put in a roasting tin. Smear with the butter and put on the middle shelf of the oven for 50 mins.
Meanwhile, grease a 20 x 30cm roasting tin. Press in the stuffing, then sprinkle with the reserved breadcrumbs and dot with the butter.

Brush the chicken with the mustard, transfer it to a lower shelf and roast for 40 mins more until cooked through and the juices run clear. Put the stuffing on the top shelf at the same time and cook for 40-50 mins until golden and crisp.
Leave the chicken to rest for 10 mins, then serve with the stuffing, along with roast potatoes and veg, if you like.
chief_review: This classic roast chicken recipe, elevated with a hearty apple, walnut, and sausagemeat stuffing, brings rich flavors and satisfying textures to the Sunday table. The preparation is straightforward, and the stuffing can conveniently be made ahead—ideal for relaxed entertaining. Chopped apples and celery lend sweetness and freshness, while walnuts inject earthy crunch. Wholegrain mustard adds tang both to the chicken and the stuffing, tying the dish together. The stuffing’s buttery breadcrumb topping crisps beautifully in the oven, complementing the juicy roast chicken. Note that this recipe includes gluten (breadcrumbs), nuts (walnuts), and eggs, so it’s not suitable for those with related allergies. Serve with classic roast potatoes and your choice of vegetables for a complete meal. This is an impressive, comforting dish perfect for a communal feast.

name: Cheeseboard soufflé & seasonal salad
description: This luxuriously light soufflé is a good way to use up a selection of leftover cheeses
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 25g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
300g leftover hard cheese, cut into chunks
100g leftover blue or goat's cheese, crumbled
3 tbsp salad dressing(use your favourite), to serve
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Melt all the butter in a saucepan. Brush a 20cm soufflé dish with a little of it, then dust with flour. In the saucepan, stir the flour into the rest of the melted butter, then sizzle everything for 1 min. Gradually pour in the milk to make a white sauce, then add two-thirds of the cheese and carry on cooking to melt. Leave to cool slightly, then mix in the remaining cheese, the cream or crème fraîche and the egg yolks. Season, then add the nutmeg and cayenne pepper.
In a clean bowl, whisk the egg whites until stiff. Fold into the cheese sauce, then carefully tip into the soufflé dish. Bake the soufflé for 25 mins until puffed up and golden.
While the soufflé is cooking, toss the salad ingredients together. Once the soufflé is cooked, dress the salad and serve alongside.
chief_review: This cheese soufflé is a celebration of texture and rich flavor, making expert use of assorted leftover cheeses and nuts. The airy rise of the soufflé is well complemented by the tang from blue or goat’s cheese in the accompanying salad, while sliced pear adds a fresh, sweet counterpoint and a delightful crunch from nuts rounds out the dish. The gentle warmth of nutmeg and cayenne brings fragrance without overpowering the cheese. With its use of double cream, butter, eggs, and both wheat flour and a generous mix of dairy, this recipe is best suited to a vegetarian diet, provided the cheeses are rennet-free. It also cleverly repurposes leftovers, supporting a more sustainable kitchen. Best enjoyed hot from the oven with the salad providing vibrancy, this soufflé is a comforting, elegant centerpiece for a meat-free meal.

name: Crispy squashed baby roasties
description: Fennel seeds and flaky sea salt give these roasted new potatoes a crispy, flavoursome finish
author: Cassie Best
directions: Boil the potatoes for 10 mins until tender, then drain and leave to steamdry. While the pork is resting (see left), lower the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

Drizzle half the oil over a flat, sturdy baking tray and tip in the potatoes. Add the fennel seeds, and season with the flaky sea salt and some black pepper, tossing everything to coat. Gently squash the potatoes with a potato masher to just break the skins. Drizzle with the extra oil and bake for 45 mins until crispy and golden.
chief_review: This recipe transforms humble new potatoes into a truly delightful side, thanks to the aromatic depth of fennel seeds and the bright crunch of flaky sea salt. Roasting them in olive oil brings out a golden, crispy exterior while keeping the insides tender. The combination of earthy potatoes and toasted fennel creates a unique flavour profile with vibrant, almost sweet notes. The ingredient list is refreshingly simple—potatoes, olive oil, fennel seed, and sea salt—which makes this dish naturally suitable for vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free diets. It’s also an excellent choice for those with common food allergies, as it contains no dairy, eggs, nuts, or soy. Perfect as a side for a variety of mains, these crispy roasted potatoes are sure to impress with their texture and bold, savoury taste.

name: Rudolph’s carrot flapjacks
description: These moist oaty slices are packed full of fruits, seeds and spices - a great bake to make with the kids
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Line an 18cm square baking tin with greaseproof paper. Melt butter, golden syrup and sugar in a large pan. Mix in rolled oats, carrots, orange zest, apricots, cinnamon and pumpkin seeds. Stir everything well, then pack into the prepared tin, pushing down firmly. Bake for 40-45 mins, then cool in the tin before slicing into 16 squares.
chief_review: This oaty slice recipe brings delightful texture and flavor, marrying sweet golden syrup and brown sugar with earthy carrots and aromatic orange zest. The addition of apricots and pumpkin seeds introduces chewiness and crunch, complemented by a warm hint of cinnamon. With rolled oats as the base, these bars provide a hearty, fiber-rich snack—perfect for baking with children or serving as an on-the-go treat. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatin. However, those with dairy allergies should be cautious due to the inclusion of butter, and those with gluten sensitivities should ensure the oats are certified gluten-free. Overall, this bake offers a wholesome way to incorporate fruit, seeds, and grains into a delicious, easy-to-make snack.

name: Simple seafood platter
description: Raid your local fishmongers for a selection to suit your budget and you have an instant impressive starter
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: about 800g mixed seafood prawns, smoked salmon and gravadlax
directions: Whisk the lemon juice with the mustard, then mix into the mayonnaise with the dill. Prepare up to a day ahead and chill.
