Lay out the seafood on a platter with lemon wedges and a bowl of the mayonnaise in the middle so everyone can help themselves. Serve with plenty of fresh brown bread.
chief_review: This seafood platter showcases the freshest offerings from your local fishmonger—juicy prawns, smoky salmon, and buttery gravadlax—served alongside zesty lemon wedges and hearty brown bread. The creamy dressing, made from mayonnaise, Dijon mustard, lemon juice, and fresh dill, enhances the natural sweetness of the seafood without overpowering it. The dish is ideal for pescatarians and works well for a celebratory starter or a light main course. Every element on the plate is thoughtfully balanced, offering both vibrant flavors and elegant presentation, making it a crowd-pleaser for seafood lovers.

name: Stilton & chutney rarebit bites
description:
The chutney for this moreish canape can be
made in bigger quantities and stored in jars for a couple of
months – delicious with cheese and crackers
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
ingredients: 6 slices sourdough breador German rye bread
directions: Put the onions, sugar and vinegar into a large pan on a low heat. Cook for about 25 mins, stirring now and again, until gloopy and sticky. Cool. Mix together the cheeses, crème fraîche, eggs and mustard with some seasoning, then chill.

To serve, heat the grill, lightly toast the bread and cut each slice into chunks. Put onto a baking sheet, spread a tsp of chutney on each chunk, then pile on the rarebit mixture – as much as the little squares can hold. Grill for 3-5 mins until golden brown and bubbling.
chief_review: This recipe offers a wonderfully rich canape, pairing a tangy red onion chutney—sweetened with muscovado sugar and balanced by balsamic vinegar—with two punchy cheeses, Stilton and Parmesan. The blend is given silkiness by crème fraîche and body from eggs and wholegrain mustard, all served atop robust slices of sourdough or rye. The chutney’s make-ahead potential is a chef’s delight, perfect for effortless entertaining or adding zest to a cheese platter. Vegetarian diners can enjoy this recipe by choosing a vegetarian Parmesan alternative, as traditional Parmesan contains animal rennet. However, those following gluten-free or dairy-free diets will need to seek other options. Overall, it's a sumptuous treat, ideal for lovers of bold, layered flavors with a touch of tang and creaminess.

name: Jumbo turkey samosas
description: Use up leftover cooked potatoes and turkey in these spiced filo pastry parcels, then serve with tangy mango chutney
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 tbsp mango chutney, plus extra to serve
2 tbsp natural yogurtfrom a 150g pot (serve the remainder)
200g leftover cooked potatoes(roasted or boiled are fine), chopped into small chunks
250g cooked turkeyor chicken, chopped into small pieces
bunch coriander, chopped, plus a few leaves picked to serve
directions: In a large bowl, combine the curry paste, mango chutney and 2 tbsp yogurt, and mix well. Fold in the potatoes, turkey, peas and coriander, then season well.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut the sheets of filo in half lengthways so you have 12 strips – keep the pastry covered with a tea towel while you work so it doesn’t dry out. Layer up 3 sheets of filo, brushing a little oil between each sheet. Pile a quarter of the filling in the top corner of the pastry in a triangle shape. Fold the pastry over to encase the filling, then keep folding until the parcel is sealed and the filo is used up. Brush the final edge with a little beaten egg to help stick the pastry together. Repeat to make all 4 jumbo samosas.

Lay your samosas on a baking sheet and brush each one with more beaten egg, then sprinkle with sesame seeds. Bake for 35 mins or until the samosas are golden brown and the filling is piping hot. Serve with the remaining yogurt, some mango chutney and coriander leaves.
chief_review:
This inventive recipe elegantly transforms leftover potatoes and turkey into aromatic filo parcels, enriched with mild curry paste and a touch of mango chutney. The use of filo pastry ensures a crisp bite, while peas and fresh coriander add brightness and texture. The egg wash provides a golden finish, accented by sesame seeds for a subtle nutty aroma. These parcels pair beautifully with tangy mango chutney, balancing the gentle spice of the filling.

Suitable for those following a nut-free diet (provided the curry paste is free from nuts), this dish is a savvy option for repurposing holiday leftovers, but is not suitable for vegetarians or those requiring gluten-free or dairy-free fare. The combination of protein, vegetables, and spices provides a comforting yet vibrant dish, ideal as an appetizer or light main. Serve with extra yogurt and fresh coriander for added freshness.

name: Ham & veg crumble
description: Ham and root vegetables are coated in a creamy mustard and crème fraîche sauce, then topped with savoury crumble in this winter bake
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 400g cooked ham, cut into chunky slices from a joint, then shredded
directions: Melt 2 tbsp butter in a large frying pan, chop the remaining butter into small chunks and put in the fridge. Add the leeks, carrots, parsnips and celeriac to the pan with a splash of water, season, cover with a lid and cook for 10-15 mins, stirring now and then, until the veg is beginning to soften.
Stir in 2 tbsp plain flour, then add the stock bit by bit, stirring as you go, until all incorporated and smooth. Cover with a lid and simmer for 20 mins until the vegetables are tender.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 6. Add the ham, all but 2 tbsp of the crème fraîche, and the mustard, season with plenty of black pepper and transfer to an ovenproof baking dish. Put the remaining butter and flour in a bowl and season. Rub together with your fingers to a fine crumbly texture. Add the remaining crème fraîche and mix with a cutlery knife until the crumble clumps together in places. Sprinkle the crumble mixture over the filling, then bake for 35-40 mins until crispy and golden on top.
chief_review:
This hearty winter bake brings together tender root vegetables, succulent ham, and a rich, tangy sauce of crème fraîche and wholegrain mustard, all tucked beneath a buttery, savoury crumble. The leeks, carrots, parsnips, and celeriac impart earthy sweetness and vibrant texture, beautifully complementing the savoury ham. The sauce is balanced and creamy without being heavy, thanks to the low-fat crème fraîche, which melds well with the subtle piquancy of mustard. The crumble topping adds an irresistible contrast, turning this dish into true comfort food.

While not suitable for vegetarians or those avoiding dairy or gluten, this bake can be included in diets where pork is enjoyed. Ideal for feeding a crowd or offering as a centerpiece for a cozy family meal, it’s a delightful use of root vegetables and a clever way to make the most of leftover ham.

name: Warm greens & shallots with allspice dressing
description: Add some sweetness and spice to your Sunday lunch with this easy veggie side dish - perfect with roast lamb or chicken
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 400g mixed green vegetables(we used green beans, broccoli and peas)
directions: Cover the shallots with boiling water and set aside until cool enough to handle, then peel and discard the skins.

Heat the oil in a large pan, and add the shallots. Cover with a lid and cook over a low heat for 8-10 mins until starting to caramelise. Add the vinegar, honey and allspice to the pan along with some seasoning. Give everything a good shake in the pan, then bubble for 10 mins until the shallots are tender and sticky, adding a splash of water if the honey looks like it might burn.
Meanwhile, bring a large pan of water to the boil, add the greens and cook for 2 mins until they are just tender but still have a nice bite. Add to the shallots and toss through the sticky dressing.
chief_review: This vibrant veggie side dish is a delightful balance of sweet, tangy, and aromatic flavors that will elevate any Sunday roast. The caramelized shallots, infused with honey, allspice, and a splash of white wine vinegar, bring complexity to a medley of crisp green beans, broccoli, and peas. The gentle spice from allspice pairs exceptionally well with lamb or chicken, making it a versatile accompaniment. Using olive or rapeseed oil keeps the dish heart-healthy, and all ingredients are naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those avoiding gluten. Additionally, this recipe is vegetarian, ensuring it can be enjoyed at most tables where meat-free diners are present. Simple to prepare yet full of character, this side dish is sure to become a favorite for both everyday dinners and special occasions.

name: Buckwheat & spelt chrain blinis
author: Rosie Birkett
ingredients: 1 ready-to-eat beetrootblended with 30g horseradish, or 2 tbsp chrain (beetroot and horseradish purée)
soured cream, smoked trout, dill and salmon roe (optional), to serve
directions: Sift the buckwheat and spelt flours into a bowl with 1 tsp salt and scatter over the yeast. Heat the milk and yogurt very gently until tepid, then
in the egg yolks. Whisk this mixture into the flour mix and leave for 1 hr to ferment.
Whisk the egg whites to stiff peaks. Stir the beetroot and horseradish purée through the batter, then lightly fold in the egg whites. Leave for a further hour.

Heat the clarified butter in a non-stick frying pan, then add in dessertspoonfuls of blini mix. Fry for about 40 secs, or until they naturally come away from the pan when you shake it. They should puff up, and you’ll need to be careful when turning over as the middle might try and escape a bit – use a palette knife for this. Turn over and fry for another 20-30 secs, then transfer to kitchen paper. Continue with the rest of the mix. Leave to cool, then freeze the blinis for up to one month.
When your blinis are done, top with the soured cream, smoked trout, dill and salmon roe, if using, then serve.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a delightful use of buckwheat and spelt flours, offering a nutty, earthy base that pairs beautifully with the tang of yogurt and the richness of soured cream. The addition of beetroot blended with horseradish introduces a vibrant color and piquant flavor, harmonizing with the subtle smokiness of the trout. Egg separation ensures a light, airy texture—perfect for tempting blini or flavorful pancakes. This dish is a refined choice for brunch or entertaining, especially for those seeking an alternative to traditional wheat flours. Suitable for pescatarians and those comfortable with dairy. However, with both eggs and dairy present, this recipe is not vegan. The creative garnish of dill and salmon roe offers a luxurious finish. Overall, a sophisticated, well-balanced recipe that impresses both visually and on the palate.

name: Orange & spice wings
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C/gas 6. Put the chicken wings in a large bowl with plain flour and season well. Toss together to coat, then spread out over a large baking tray, drizzle with oil and cook for 40-45 mins, turning halfway through.
When the chicken wings are nearly done, put the
in a saucepan with the orange juice and honey. Warm gently, then pour over the chicken wings, toss together, and return to the oven for a further 10 mins or until sticky. Sprinkle with salt to serve.
chief_review: This recipe delivers flavorful, festive chicken wings with a delightful balance of sweet, citrusy, and spiced notes. The use of orange juice and honey creates a glossy, aromatic glaze that pairs wonderfully with the warming festive spice mix. The plain flour gives the wings a light coating, allowing the spices to adhere and creating a satisfyingly crisp texture when baked or fried. The dish is ideal for those following a dairy-free diet, as it contains no milk or cheese-based ingredients. However, it’s worth noting that this recipe is not suitable for those with gluten intolerance, as it uses plain flour. Overall, it’s a crowd-pleaser perfect for holiday gatherings, offering an appealing blend of seasonal flavors on tender, juicy wings.

name: Non-alcoholic mulled wine
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Put the pomegranate juice, sugar, blackberries and apple juice in a saucepan. Add the cinnamon, star anise, cloves, peppercorns and orange. Heat gently until simmering. Taste for sweetness, then strain into heatproof glasses.
chief_review:
This vibrant punch brings together pomegranate and apple juices with the subtle warmth of spices—cinnamon, star anise, cloves, and peppercorns—for a refreshingly aromatic beverage, highlighted by frozen blackberries and orange wedges. The use of pure fruit juices ensures a lively, balanced sweetness, with golden caster sugar adding a gentle enhancement rather than overpowering the natural flavors. Whether served chilled or gently warmed for a mulled effect, the result is juicy, spiced, and intoxicatingly fragrant, perfect for social gatherings or as a non-alcoholic centerpiece.

This recipe is naturally vegan and vegetarian, containing no animal products. It is also gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease. With no dairy, eggs, or nuts, it's appropriate for people with those common allergies as well.

name: Spiced piña colada mocktail
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 1 pineapple, a few strips of skin, plus leaves to garnish
directions: To make a mock rum syrup, put the dark brown muscovado sugar and 200ml water in a

, stir well and heat gently until the sugar has dissolved. Add a few strips of skin from the pineapple, add the black peppercorns, cloves and a cinnamon stick, then bring to the boil. Turn off the heat and leave to infuse until cold. Strain into a jug and set aside in the fridge until needed.

Pour the pineapple juice into a tall glass, and add the coconut milk and lime juice. Stir gently. Fill up the glass with a handful ice then slowly add 25ml of the syrup so it sinks to the bottom. Garnish with pineapple leaves and a tinned cherry.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful tropical beverage with rich flavors from pineapple juice, coconut milk, and lime, accentuated by aromatic spices such as cinnamon, clove, and black pepper. The use of fresh pineapple and creative garnishes elevates both presentation and taste. The muscovado sugar adds a deep molasses note, balancing the tartness of citrus and the creaminess of coconut milk. This beverage is ideal for vegetarians and vegans since it contains no animal products. Additionally, it is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. For best results, use high-quality coconut milk and fresh spices. The cherry and pineapple leaf garnish complete the festive touch, making this an excellent choice for summer gatherings or as a non-alcoholic drink option.

name: Faux fizz
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 1 sprig rosemary, plus extra to garnish (optional)
directions: To make the base syrup, put the sliced pear, dried apricots, golden caster sugar, honey, sprig of rosemary and a strip of lemon zest in a saucepan with 100ml water. Heat for 10 mins or until the sugar has dissolved and the pear is very soft, then leave to cool completely.

Strain the syrup into a jug, add the apple cider vinegar and chill in the fridge for at least 30 mins. Pour about 25ml of the syrup into a champagne flute and top with cold sparkling water. Garnish with a rosemary sprig, if you like.
chief_review: This refreshing pear and apricot cooler combines crisp apple cider vinegar, honey, golden caster sugar, and rosemary for an aromatic and subtly sweet drink. The use of sparkling water gives it a lively effervescence, while dried apricots and fresh pear bring natural fruitiness and texture. The lemon zest lifts the flavors with a citrus edge. This recipe contains no dairy, eggs, or gluten, making it suitable for a vegetarian diet and many with common dietary sensitivities, though it's not vegan due to the honey. The blend of ingredients highlights both sweetness and herbaceous notes, making it a sophisticated, non-alcoholic option ideal for summer gatherings or as a unique aperitif. Garnish with extra rosemary for a visually striking and fragrant finish.

name: Red cabbage with port, prunes & orange
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 1 large red cabbage, quartered, cored and thinly sliced
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Heat the butter in a casserole dish until sizzled to a nutty brown. Add the onion and fry for 15 mins over a medium heat until soft and starting to colour.

Tip the remaining ingredients into a large pan and cover with a tight-fitting lid. Put in the oven for 1 hr, then stir, cover and cook for a further 1 hr until the cabbage is tender. If it looks dry, add a splash of water; if there’s still liquid in the pan once cooked, turn the heat up until it evaporates. Season with a little salt and serve.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a deeply flavorful braised red cabbage, elevated by the richness of port and the bright, citrus zip of orange zest and juice. The addition of prunes imparts a subtle sweetness and complexity, brilliantly complemented by warming spices like cinnamon and cloves. The butter gives the dish a luscious mouthfeel, while the onion creates a savory base. It’s an excellent side for hearty winter mains, and it stands out as a festive accompaniment. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and works beautifully for those seeking a gluten-free dish, provided the port used is certified gluten-free. The absence of nuts and eggs makes it an accommodating choice for some common allergies as well. Highly recommended for holiday tables or any special dinner featuring robust, comforting flavors.

name: Cranberry & lentil bake
author: Katy Greenwood
ingredients: ½ garlic clove, crushed or finely grated
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Oil and line the base of a 200ml ovenproof ramekin with a circle of baking parchment. Put the cranberries in a small pan with the wine and cook for a couple of mins over a medium heat until the cranberries are plump and the wine syrupy. Pour into the base of the ramekin and set aside.

Put the lentils in a bowl and roughly mash about half of them with a fork. Heat the oil in a small pan and cook the onion for 6-8 mins over a medium heat until softened. Stir in the garlic, herbs, paprika and cloves and cook for another minute. Turn off the heat and add the lentils, tomato purée, soy and cornflour, stir everything together well, then spoon into the ramekin, pressing down gently with the back of a spoon.
Put the ramekin on a
and bake for 15 mins. Leave to cool for 1 min, then turn out onto a plate.
chief_review: This recipe offers a satisfying, flavor-packed vegetarian dish with a hearty base of Puy lentils, balanced by the sweetness of cranberries and the depth of red wine and smoked paprika. The addition of fresh herbs—sage and parsley—gives aromatic complexity, while the tomato purée and soy sauce round out the umami profile. Using olive oil as the cooking fat and cornflour for thickening makes this meal appropriate for vegans, provided a vegan-friendly red wine and soy sauce are chosen. The recipe is also gluten free if gluten-free soy sauce (tamari) is used, making it adaptable for various dietary needs. With no nuts, dairy, or egg, it caters well to those with common food allergies. Overall, it’s a creative, balanced dish perfect for a wholesome plant-based meal.

name: Giant jam tart
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 1 tsp cinnamonor a grating of nutmeg (optional)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and put a
in the oven to heat up. On a lightly floured surface,

two-thirds of the pastry to a circle about 0.5cm thick. If you’re adding a spiced flavour to your pastry, sprinkle with the cinnamon or nutmeg, fold in half and repeat, then roll it out again to a circle about 0.5cm thick.

Press the pastry into a 23cm metal pie tin or tart tin and trim off any excess pastry hanging over the edge. If you’re using a deep tin, roll the edges down a little to make a lip (you only want to make a shallow tart). Spread the jam over the pastry base.

On a lightly floured surface, roll out the remaining pastry to a thickness of 0.5cm and use small cookie cutters to stamp out shapes. Re-roll the trimmings and cut out more shapes if needed. Arrange the pastry decorations over the jam layer.
Put the tin on the hot baking tray and cook for 40 mins, then leave to cool for 15 mins. Dust the pastry toppings with icing sugar. Serve warm or cold with custard, cream or ice cream.
chief_review:
This recipe brings a delightful twist to classic sweet shortcrust pastry, elevated by a hint of warming spice from cinnamon or nutmeg and filled generously with fruit jam. The combination offers both texture and flavor contrast, enhanced by a light dusting of icing sugar. Ideal for an indulgent teatime treat or dessert, it’s quick and convenient, relying on a ready-made pastry base. 

While not suitable for gluten-free or vegan diets due to the likely presence of wheat and animal products in standard shortcrust pastry, it does cater to vegetarians, provided the pastry and jam are free from animal-derived additives like gelatin. The recipe is also nut-free by default, making it suitable for those with nut allergies, assuming the jam and pastry are checked for potential cross-contamination. Overall, it’s a simple yet satisfying bake, perfect for both casual and special occasions.

name: Super sausage rolls
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 2 tbsp apple sauce, pickle or chutney
directions: the pastry to a 35 x 30cm rectangle on a surface lightly dusted with flour. Trim the edges neatly, then cut in half lengthways to form two long strips. Spread with a thin layer of the apple sauce, pickle or chutney, leaving a border along the edges.
Tip the sausagemeat into a

, add 3 tbsp cold water and squash together. Divide the mixture in two and mould each half into a cylindrical shape. Put each portion of meat into the middle of a pastry strip, leaving a border at either side. Brush the pastry border and the top of the sausage mix with the beaten egg. Fold one edge of the pastry over the meat and roll to encase, then use a fork to press the pastry edges together. Cut the sausage rolls into 5cm lengths and arrange on a lined baking tray. Chill for 20 mins. Can be made a day ahead or frozen for up to one month; to bake from frozen, add an extra 10 mins to the cooking time.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Brush the sausage rolls with the rest of the beaten egg and sprinkle with the sesame seeds or nigella seeds (if using). Bake for 30-35 mins until the pastry is deep golden. Transfer the sausage rolls to a wire rack and leave to cool for 10 mins.
chief_review: This take on classic sausage rolls delivers a wonderful combination of flaky, buttery pastry and savory, juicy filling. The all-butter puff pastry assures a rich, melt-in-the-mouth texture, while the addition of apple sauce or chutney adds a subtle sweetness that balances the robust flavor of the sausage meat. The sprinkle of sesame or nigella seeds on top not only offers visual appeal but an extra layer of aroma and crunch. Ideal for picnics, parties, or a hearty snack, these rolls are sure to be a hit with anyone craving comfort food with a twist. This recipe is suitable for those following a nut-free diet.

name: Chocolate & almond croissants
description: Give your croissants an indulgent twist with this super simple brunch idea
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Slice into each croissant lengthways, but don’t go all the way through – they should open like books. Sprinkle or spread the bottom half of each with marzipan, followed by 1 tsp almonds and 1 tbsp chocolate.
Close up, put on a baking sheet and sprinkle the remaining chocolate and almonds on top. Bake for 5 mins or until the chocolate has melted. Serve warm.
chief_review: This brunch recipe elevates classic croissants with a rich almond and chocolate filling, perfect for a sweet weekend treat. The marzipan adds a delicate nutty sweetness, while toasted almonds provide a satisfying crunch and depth of flavor. Milk chocolate melts luxuriously into the layers, creating a lush, gooey center. This recipe is suitable for lacto-vegetarians, as it contains no meat or eggs but does include dairy and possibly butter in the croissants (depending on brand—check labels for strict vegetarians). The preparation is straightforward, making it accessible even for novice cooks, yet the end result delivers a bakery-quality experience. Serve warm for maximum enjoyment.

name: Ginger-spiced pears
description: Make and store preserved fruits for a month or so and serve alongside cold meats and cheeses
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: pared zest (use a vegetable peeler) and juice 1 orange
5cm piece ginger, thinly sliced (no need to peel)
directions: Put the sugar, vinegar, orange zest and juice, ginger, bay leaves and peppercorns in a large pan. Bring slowly to the boil, stirring constantly to dissolve the sugar, then boil for 5 mins.

Meanwhile, peel, core and halve or quarter the pears, depending on size. Add the pears to the pan and poach gently for 10-15 mins until they are just tender. Remove with a slotted spoon and pack into warm sterilised Kilner jars with rubber seals (see tip below).

Boil the vinegar mixture hard to reduce by a third, then pour over the pears, including the spices. The pears need to be completely covered with the liquid. Fit the rubber seal and clamp the jar tightly closed. Reserve any leftover syrup for topping up the jars later, as the pears will absorb the syrup over time.
chief_review: This preserved pear recipe brings a delightful balance of sweet, tangy, and aromatic flavors that pairs wonderfully with cold meats and cheeses. The infusion of orange zest and juice, ginger, bay leaves, and peppercorn lends complexity, elevating it well beyond a simple conserve. The method is straightforward, making it ideal for those who enjoy preparing homemade accompaniments for charcuterie boards or cheese platters. With no dairy, eggs, or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is well-suited for vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free diets. For those with food allergies, note that it is also nut-free. Overall, this preserve is an elegant and versatile addition to any spread, and the long shelf life makes it practical for advance entertaining.

name: Butter-basted pork loin with stuffing crust & cheesy polenta
description: Bring big flavours and contrasting textures to your Sunday lunch table with this juicy roast pork, crusted with crunchy sage and onion stuffing
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 1kg pork loin, bone out and skinned (see tip, below left), but with a good layer of fat
1 garlic bulb, cloves separated and bashed (save 2 for the stuffing)
2 large or 4 small thick slices sourdough bread
steamed Romanesco or broccoli, to serve
directions: First, make the stuffing crust, as this will keep. Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1. Place the slices of bread on a baking sheet, drizzle with the rapeseed oil and dust with the cayenne pepper. Bake in the oven until the bread is completely dry and browned just a little – this will take about 20 mins. Remove from the oven and rub with the garlic cloves while still warm. Use a whole clove on each slice, or half if you have small slices. Leave the toasted slices to cool, then put them in a food processor and blitz to rough but not too big breadcrumbs. Empty the crumbs into a mixing bowl and add the dried sage and onion, the parsley and a good pinch of sea salt. Mix together, then set aside in an airtight container. Can be made up to 2 days ahead without the parsley (see tip, below left).

Turn down the oven to 120C/100C fan/ gas ½. Score the layer of fat on the pork with a sharp knife, working diagonally along the length, then score again in the opposite direction. Tie the loin with butcher’s string to help keep its shape and cook evenly. Heat the rapeseed oil in an ovenproof frying pan and add the pork, fat-side down. Sear and brown the top layer of fat, then turn the pork over and throw in the butter, garlic, rosemary, thyme, pepper and 2 tsp table salt. Once the butter has melted, add the lemon zest and juice to create a fragrant cooking liquor. Roll the pork around in the buttery juices and baste so that it is well coated.

Place the pan with the pork in the oven and set your timer for 1 hr 15 mins. Baste the meat with the buttery juices every 15 mins. At the end of the cooking time, test the thickest part of the pork with a digital thermometer – it should read 70C when ready. If the meat hasn’t reached the temperature, return it to the oven for 5 mins, then check again. Once the pork is cooked, remove from the oven and leave to rest for 10 mins. If you don’t have a digital thermometer, cook the pork for 1 hr 20 mins.

While the pork is resting, pour the milk for the polenta into a saucepan and bring to the boil. Whisk in the polenta and cook over a medium heat until thickened, following pack instructions – it needs to be the texture of creamy mash. If your polenta is too thick, add a little more milk to loosen it. When it is ready, remove from the heat and whisk in the butter, Parmesan, lemon zest, truffle oil, fresh truffle (if using), salt and the cayenne to taste. Pour into a serving bowl and sprinkle over the chives.

Untie the rested pork loin and give it a final baste with the cooking liquor. Tip the crust into a roasting tin, then roll the pork loin in it, making sure it gets a good covering. Thickly slice the pork and serve with the soft polenta, Romanesco or broccoli sprinkled with toasted hazelnuts, and the buttery juices.
chief_review:
This roast pork recipe is a true showstopper, incorporating layers of flavor through its herby lemon zest, garlic, and sage crust, complemented by the creamy richness of parmesan polenta and a hint of truffle. The inclusion of sourdough adds welcome crunch and depth to the stuffing, while steamed Romanesco and toasted hazelnuts bring contrast and balance to the plate.

It is not suitable for vegetarian or vegan diets due to the pork, dairy butter, milk, and parmesan. Those with gluten intolerance should note the sourdough bread in the stuffing, which contains wheat. The use of hazelnuts also means this recipe is not appropriate for anyone with nut allergies.

Overall, this is a luxurious and indulgent centerpiece with plenty of classic and modern touches—perfect for an ambitious Sunday lunch. Each bite brings a harmonious mix of textures and well-developed flavors.

name: Orange, fennel & wild rice salad
description: Really delicious, everyone loved it. I use mixed nuts including almonds, hazelnuts and cashews and it gets even better when you caramelise them with honey, salt, and a pinch of chili.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 500g carrotswe used purple and orange ones), peeled, halved and cut into short batons on an angle
large fennel bulb, quartered, core removed, thinly sliced
1 red onion, halved and thinly sliced
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the carrots, oil and some seasoning on a large baking tray. Cook for 25-30 mins until tender. While the carrots cook, fill 2 large pans with salted water and bring to the boil. Add the rice to one pan and the lentils to the other. Cook following pack instructions, or until just cooked, then drain and set aside to cool.

Zest the oranges over a large bowl. Cut away the peel and pith, then cut along each piece of membrane to remove the segments, catching any juices in the bowl. Set the segments aside. Add the ingredients for the dressing to the orange zest and juice, season and whisk.
When the carrots have cooled a little, add to the dressing with the remaining salad ingredients, including the cooked rice, lentils and orange segments. Toss together and serve on a big platter.
chief_review: This vibrant salad is a masterclass in textures and flavors, blending tender batons of purple and orange carrots, nutty Puy lentils, and aromatic wild rice. The addition of caramelized nuts (almonds, hazelnuts, cashews, and pecans) with honey, salt, and chili delivers delightful crunch and a nuanced sweet-heat. Fresh fennel, juicy grapes, and sharp red onion balance perfectly with fresh herbs, while the citrusy dressing—brightened with lemon zest, orange, Dijon mustard, and a hint of maple syrup—ties everything together beautifully. This dish is not only visually stunning but also hearty enough for a main or a show-stopping side. Ideal for vegetarian diets, and with the swap of honey for maple syrup in nut caramelization, it’s easily adapted for vegans. It’s naturally gluten-free, making it an inclusive option for varied tables. A must-try for anyone seeking a nourishing, flavor-packed centerpiece.

name: Cheesy celeriac, leek & rosemary gratin
description: Heavenly. Followed the recipe to the letter (with one extra leek) and it was divine. Am making it again this weekend. Wonderful winter comfort food.
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 2 leeks, outer layer removed, washed of any grit and sliced into rings
small handful rosemary leaves, roughly chopped
1 celeriac(about 500g), peeled, quartered and thinly sliced
directions: Heat the butter in a saucepan. Add the leeks, rosemary and bay leaf, then cover and cook very gently over a medium-low heat for 15-20 mins until the leeks are soft. Pour over the milk and almost all of the cream, then season and bring to the boil. Remove from the heat and leave to cool a little, then scoop out the bay leaf.

Pour a little of the leek mixture into an ovenproof gratin dish. Arrange a layer of celeriac in the dish, then season. Spoon over some more of the leek mixture and scatter with a little cheese. Repeat the process, alternating between layers of the leek mixture, cheese and celeriac slices, then finish with a drizzle of cream and the last of the cheese.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Bake the gratin for 1 hr-1 hr 15 mins until the top is golden and the celeriac is tender when poked with a knife. If the gratin is browning a little too much, cover the dish in foil.
chief_review: This recipe is a true celebration of winter flavors, transforming simple vegetables and herbs into a luxurious, comforting dish. The addition of an extra leek amplifies the sweetness and earthiness, which pairs beautifully with the aromatic rosemary and creamy base. Celeriac brings a delicate, nutty nuance that sets this apart from the usual gratin. With a generous dose of double cream, milk, and robust cheddar or Gruyère, it delivers a rich satisfaction and an irresistibly golden crust. The use of butter and dairy makes it ideal for a vegetarian diet, provided you use a vegetarian cheese. This dish is perfect as a starred side or a cozy main event for chilly evenings.

name: Griddled chicory
description: This simple side dish of charred chicory pairs perfectly with indulgent main courses, adding a pop of colour to any dinner party plate
author: Ben Tish
ingredients: 1 small radicchio(rosso di Treviso), or extra chicory, cut into quarters
3 tbsp saba (reduced grape must, see tip below) or balsamic vinegar
directions: Heat a griddle pan over a high heat until nearly smoking. Rub the chicory and radicchio quarters with the olive oil and season. In batches, griddle on all sides until tender and the leaves have slightly blackened. Drizzle over the saba or balsamic vinegar to serve.
chief_review: This charred chicory side dish is a vibrant addition to any meal, its bitterness tempered by sweet, syrupy saba or balsamic, and a hint of fruitiness from the olive oil. The combination of white chicory, red chicory, and optional radicchio delivers complex flavors and stunning color contrast. The recipe is both vegetarian and vegan, making it a versatile choice for plant-based or dairy-free diets. Its naturally gluten-free ingredient list also makes it suitable for those avoiding gluten. Pair it with rich mains to cleanse the palate and elevate the overall dining experience. Simple, elegant, and health-aware, this side dish is sure to impress.

name: Mac ’n’ cheese sliders
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Cook the macaroni following pack instructions, then drain in a colander. Meanwhile, melt the butter in a large saucepan over a medium heat. Once melted, add the shallots and cook very gently for 10-15 mins until soft. Add the flour, mix well, then slowly add the milk, a splash at a time, mixing well after each addition to make a smooth sauce. Once all the milk has been added, keep cooking and stirring until the sauce thickens. Stir in the mustard, cream cheese, cheddar and egg. Season well.

Tip the cooked macaroni into a deep baking dish (ours was 28 x 18cm) and pour over the cheese sauce, making sure the macaroni is well coated. Bake for 20 mins until starting to turn lightly golden. Remove from the oven, leave to cool completely, then chill overnight.

The following day, heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5 and slice the macaroni cheese into 36 blocks. Transfer to 2 baking trays so the blocks have space around them. Gently press a piece of mozzarella into the middle of each. Bake for 10-15 mins or until starting to crisp at the edges and the cheese has melted. Put the blocks into the mini rolls with a few watercress sprigs and a squeeze of BBQ sauce, if you like. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful, indulgent twist on classic macaroni and cheese, featuring a richly creamy sauce, sharp cheddar, tangy Dijon mustard, and luscious chunks of mozzarella. The inclusion of mini breadrolls suggests these are turned into portable, pull-apart sliders—ideal for parties or casual gatherings. The addition of fresh watercress balances the richness with a peppery, crisp element, and a drizzle of barbecue sauce adds smoky depth. This dish is a hearty treat that will appeal to cheese-lovers and fans of comfort food alike. With its reliance on dairy and gluten-containing ingredients, it's a celebration of classic flavors and textures with a playful presentation.

name: Coconut custard tart with roasted pineapple
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 300g plain flour, plus a little for dusting
150g cold butter, cut into small pieces
2 tbsp rum(or use lime juice if serving to children)
small handful toasted coconut shavings, optional
directions: Rub the flour and butter together with your fingertips until the mixture looks like breadcrumbs. Add the sugar, egg yolks and 1-2 tbsp cold water, then mix until the dough starts to form clumps. Tip onto your work surface and knead a few times to bring any crumbs into the dough. Shape into a puck, wrap in cling film and chill for at least 30 mins.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and put a baking sheet on the middle shelf to warm up. Roll out the dough on a flour-dusted surface to line the base and sides of a 23cm round fluted tart tin. Drape it over a rolling pin and lift into the tin, keeping an overhang of about 1cm. Press into the corners, leaving no gaps. Save the pastry scraps.

Line the tart case with parchment and tip in baking beans or rice. Bake for 20-25 mins on the sheet, then remove the beans and parchment. Check for holes and patch them with the scraps. Put back in the oven for 5-10 mins to give it a nutty brown colour. Brush with the beaten egg and return to the oven for 2 more mins. While still warm, use a serrated knife to trim the pastry to the height of the tin. Leave to cool. Reduce oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1.

Put the cream and coconut cream in a pan and heat until steaming. Meanwhile, whisk the whole eggs, yolks and sugar until pale. Pour the hot cream over the eggs, whisking until the sugar has dissolved. Pour through a sieve into a jug.

Put the tart case on the baking sheet in the oven, with the shelf pulled out. Pour in the custard, using up as much as you can. Sprinkle nutmeg over the top generously and bake for 50-55 mins until the custard is set with a little wobble when gently shaken. Leave to cool.

When ready to cook the pineapple, heat oven to 240C/220C fan/gas 8. Peel it using a knife to carve away the skin, then cut into four wedges and remove the core. Slice lengthways into long slivers. Arrange over a baking tray lined with parchment. Mix the sugar, rum (or lime juice) and a grating of nutmeg, then paint this over the pineapple. Bake for 10 mins, or until caramelised. Serve warm with the cold tart. We served ours on top with coconut shavings.
chief_review:
This recipe showcases a lush blend of buttery pastry and a rich, creamy filling accented by the tropical brightness of pineapple and coconut. The double cream and coconut cream create an indulgent custard, enhanced by the aromatic touch of fresh nutmeg. The pineapple compote, caramelized with light brown sugar and a splash of rum (or lime juice for a family-friendly version), delivers a sweet-tart counterpoint, while toasted coconut shavings add texture and visual appeal.

For dietary considerations, this dessert is suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, it contains gluten (plain flour), dairy (butter, cream), and eggs, making it unsuitable for those with related allergies or intolerances. The coconut element adds a delightful layer of richness without overpowering the dish. Overall, a sophisticated dessert that balances classic patisserie with tropical flair.

name: Chocolate brownie & boozy cherry brûlées
description: These fondant-like crème pudding pots are studded with chocolate and fruit and have a crispy sugary crust
author: Maria Elia
ingredients: 1 vanilla pod, split and seeds scraped out
85g plain chocolate, 70% cocoa, broken into small pieces
3 ready-made chocolate brownies(up to about 200g), cut into chunks
50g cherry in kirsch (or about 3 cherries per brûlée), drained, plus more to serve if you like
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Put the cream into a saucepan with the vanilla seeds, then bring just to the boil. Take off the heat and stir in the chocolate until it has completely melted.

Boil the kettle. Meanwhile, whisk together egg yolks and 50g sugar for 20-30 seconds until thick and pale, then stir in the creamy chocolate. Divide the brownie pieces and cherries between six 200ml ramekins or dishes, drizzle with a little of the kirsch from the jar, then pour over the chocolate mix.

Line a roasting tin with a clean tea towel and stand the ramekins in the tin. Pour hot water halfway up the sides of the ramekins, cover the whole thing with foil, then cook for 40 mins until just set. Chill for at least 3 hrs. These can be baked and chilled up to 2 days in advance.

One hour before serving, make the sugary crust. Put the 6 tbsp sugar into a non-stick pan and melt evenly over a gentle heat. Once the sugar has turned a rich caramel colour, spoon it over the puddings and leave to set hard.
chief_review:
This decadent crème pudding pot is a celebration of rich textures and flavors, with dark chocolate and kirsch-soaked cherries complementing the velvety cream base. The addition of chocolate brownies adds delightful chewiness, while the brûléed sugar crust provides a satisfying crunch. Despite its elegance, this is a recipe best enjoyed as an occasional treat due to its indulgent use of double cream, sugar, and chocolate.

For those following a vegetarian diet, this dessert is suitable, as it contains no gelatin or animal-derived thickeners besides dairy and eggs. It is not gluten-free due to the brownies and also not nut-free without assurance from the brownie ingredients. The strong chocolate and cherry flavors, elevated by real vanilla, make this an impressive finish for a special meal, especially when paired with extra cherries on the side.

name: Brie & cranberry twists
description: Ooh, just seen this! I'd like to repeat Whirlwind's question ref freezing. When I get my kitchen back (extension) I'll test that theory and freeze uncooked and then prob cook from frozen so the filo doesn't dry out during defrost. Has anyone done this and can report back?
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Stack two of the filo sheets. With a widest edge facing you, brush with some melted butter. Put three brie fingers at even intervals across the bottom of the filo. Top each finger with 1 tsp cranberry sauce, then sprinkle over a few chopped walnuts.
Roll up the filo from the bottom. Cut into three parcels, and twist the ends to seal. Brush with more butter and sprinkle with poppy seeds. Repeat with the remaining ingredients. Bake for 10 mins.
chief_review:
This recipe combines creamy brie, tangy cranberry sauce, and crunchy walnuts, all wrapped in delicate filo pastry—a winning combination for a festive or special occasion appetizer. The crispy filo perfectly complements the softness of the cheese and tartness of the cranberry, while walnuts add a pleasant textural contrast. A light sprinkling of poppy seeds gives extra flavor and visual appeal.

For vegetarians, this recipe is a fantastic treat, as it contains no meat or fish. However, do check the source of your brie and butter if strict adherence to vegetarian rennet is required. It’s also worth noting that those with nut allergies should avoid the walnuts or substitute with seeds. This dish is not gluten-free due to the filo pastry, nor is it vegan because of the cheese and butter. Overall, it’s an elegant and flavorful dish that’s sure to impress your guests.

name: Artichoke & pecorino bruschetta
description: These simple and speedy antipasti-friendly toasts are perfect for when you want to spend less time in the kitchen and more with your guest
author: Bill Granger
ingredients: 1 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for drizzling
2 large or 4 small slices of crusty bread
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Halve or quarter the artichokes, if whole, and put them in a bowl with the chilli flakes, mint, zest and oil. Season lightly with salt and set aside.
Put the bread on a baking sheet and scatter over the garlic. Drizzle with olive oil and season with sea salt. Bake for 10 mins, or until golden and crisp. Set aside to cool.
Fold the pecorino through the marinated artichokes and spoon over the garlic bruschetta just before eating.
chief_review: This antipasti-style toast is a delightful balance of bold and fresh flavors—a true testament to the beauty of simple ingredients. The marinated artichokes provide a luscious base, lifted by zesty lemon and the invigorating scent of fresh mint, while a touch of chili flakes adds gentle warmth. Rubbing the toasted bread with garlic imparts an aromatic depth, and a generous drizzle of olive oil ensures richness throughout. The pecorino brings a salty, nutty finish—though swapping for a vegetarian cheese makes this dish suitable for vegetarians. This recipe is a great fit for anyone seeking a speedy yet elegant starter, and its ingredients are naturally nut-free, making it accessible for those avoiding nuts. Perfect for casual entertaining—serve with extra mint and lemon zest for a truly inviting platter.

name: Kipper pâté
description: Whizz up sustainable smoked fish with horseradish, lemon and cream cheese, plus a little spinach for colour, then serve with toast as a light starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: pair of kippersor 350g kipper fillets (once prepared you want to have 225g flesh)
sourdough toast(or gluten-free alternative) and lemon wedges, to serve
directions: Put the kippers in a bowl and pour over boiling water so that they are completely covered. Leave for 8 mins, then drain. Meanwhile, put the remaining ingredients, except the sourdough and lemon wedges, into a food processor. Add a good grind of black pepper and whizz until everything is chopped and combined.

Cut the heads off the kippers and remove the skin, then fillet and discard the bones. Add the kipper flesh to the processor and whizz again until you have a smooth pâté. Pack in a suitable container and chill. Serve with sourdough toast and lemon wedges.
chief_review: This smoked kipper pâté is a standout starter that brings together the robustness of sustainable fish with a lively burst of horseradish and lemon. The full-fat cream cheese lends a luscious creaminess, complemented by herbaceous parsley and the subtle, fresh note of spinach. Sourdough toast adds a perfect crunch, though a gluten-free substitute integrates seamlessly for gluten-sensitive diners. The dish’s balance between smokiness, tang, and freshness is well-considered, making it both satisfying and light. An imaginative recipe for pescatarians and those seeking an elegant, easy-to-share appetizer.

name: Rye & pumpkin seed crackers
description: Oh dear, I only read these previous comments when mine were in the oven. I turned mine over at 20 mins and they only had about half hour in the oven in total but unfortunately still too hard and overdone. Boo hoo.
author: Cassie Best
directions: Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 1 and line 2 baking trays with baking parchment. Mix the dry ingredients in a large bowl. Beat the egg with 250ml water in a jug, then pour into the dry mixture. Combine with a wooden spoon, then transfer to a lightly floured work surface and knead until you have a smooth, firm dough.

Roll the dough out as thinly as possible and cut into squares, about 7cm. Transfer the squares to your baking trays. Bake for 45 mins, then remove the trays from the oven. Flip each cracker over on the tray and return to the oven, swapping over the shelves, for a further 45 mins. Once cooked, remove from the oven and transfer to a wire rack to cool.
chief_review: This recipe produces a hearty, rustic bake thanks to the use of rye and wholemeal flours, complemented by the nutty crunch of pumpkin seeds. The inclusion of only one egg as the binding agent keeps the recipe relatively light on enrichments. As it contains no dairy, the recipe is suitable for those who are lactose intolerant, and it is a good fit for vegetarians. Additionally, the absence of common allergens like nuts (pumpkin seeds are seeds, not tree nuts) and the focus on whole grains make this a wholesome choice for health-conscious eaters. However, attention to baking time is crucial—these can easily become overdone. Check doneness early for a more tender result.

name: Peppermint candy biscuits
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 175g plain flour, plus a little extra for dusting
directions: Before you start, read the tips at the bottom of the recipe.

Tip the flour and butter into a bowl. Use your fingers to squash the lumps of butter into the flour, then rub together until the mixture resembles wet sand. Add the sugar and egg yolk and 1-2 tbsp cold water. Mix together with a blunt cutlery knife, then your hands, until it becomes a soft dough. (Or, get an adult to help you to do this in a food processor.) Wrap the dough in cling film and pop in the fridge for 20 mins to chill.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line 2 baking trays with baking parchment. Put the candy canes in a resealable plastic bag, then wrap in a tea towel. Use a rolling pin to bash them to a chunky rubble. Set to one side.

Dust your work surface with a little flour, then use a rolling pin to roll out the dough. Cut out heart shapes with your big cookie cutter. Put them on the baking trays, spaced a little apart. Use your small cutter to cut out a little heart in the centre of each big heart. Re-roll your cuttings to make about 20 hearts in total.

Bake for 8 mins. Carefully remove the trays from the oven, then fill each small heart with a little of the crushed candy cane. Return to the oven for 4 mins more, until the biscuits are just starting to turn golden and the candy cane has melted.

Once out of the oven, quickly sprinkle the gooey centre of each heart with a little extra crushed candy cane. Leave to set and cool completely on the trays. Once cool, the biscuits will peel straight off the trays. Wrap them in pretty boxes to give as a gift.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a classic buttery biscuit enriched with a festive twist from peppermint candy canes. The combination of plain flour, butter, caster sugar, and egg yolk results in a crisp, tender texture, while the crushed candy canes infuse a playful burst of cool mint flavor—perfect for holiday gatherings or as a delightful gift. The recipe contains no nuts, making it suitable for those avoiding nut allergens. However, it does include gluten, dairy, and egg, which should be noted for those with specific dietary needs. The simplicity and balance of flavors ensure these biscuits appeal to both children and adults, and the peppermint pieces also add an attractive visual flourish. Serve these treats alongside tea or coffee for a truly festive experience.

name: Moroccan turkey salad
description: Use up abundant roast meat in a healthy salad with aubergine, tomatoes, pomegranate and mint
author: Good Food
directions: Tear the pitta into pieces and fry in the olive oil until crisp. Tip into a bowl, then fry the aubergine for 10 mins until soft. Add to the pitta with the harissa, tomatoes, turkey and rocket. Toss well. Scatter over pomegranate seeds and mint leaves.
chief_review: This inventive salad is an excellent way to repurpose leftover roast turkey in a vibrant, healthy dish bursting with Mediterranean flavors. The diced aubergine, roasted with harissa, brings a lovely smokiness that pairs beautifully with the juicy cherry tomatoes and peppery rocket. Pomegranate seeds add a delightful sweetness and crunch, while fresh mint lifts the whole salad with aromatic notes. Toasted pitta pieces add satisfying texture. This salad is naturally dairy-free and can be easily adapted for gluten-free diets by swapping the pitta for a gluten-free alternative. Its lean turkey and vegetable base suit high-protein and low-fat diets, and the dish is brimming with antioxidants thanks to the colorful vegetables and pomegranate. A refreshing, hearty option for those looking to eat wholesome, balanced meals without sacrificing flavor.

name: Edible name place biscuits
description: This isn't really a recipe, is it? If the ingredients contain "4 large cookies"!
author: Good Food
directions: Mix icing sugar with peppermint extract and enough water to make a thick icing. Spread the icing over cookies and create a border around the edges using sweets and sprinkles. Leave for 10 mins for the icing to set. Then, using an icing pen, write a guest’s name in the centre of each cookie. When the icing is dry, wrap in cellophane and tie up with a pretty ribbon.
chief_review:
This playful dessert showcases a fun, customizable approach that will delight both children and adults with a sweet tooth. Using substantial cookies as a base, the recipe calls for a peppermint-infused icing—bringing a refreshing finish—and encourages creativity with a variety of sweets and sprinkles for decoration. It's an approachable project for parties or family gatherings, offering an interactive decorating experience.

From a dietary perspective, this recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets, provided the sweets and sprinkles do not contain gelatin or other animal-derived ingredients. However, those following vegan, gluten-free, or common allergy-friendly (such as nut-free or dairy-free) diets should closely examine store-bought cookie and candy labels, as these often contain non-vegetarian or allergenic ingredients. Overall, this dessert stands out for its adaptability and fun factor, making it a festive choice for casual celebrations.

name: Apple & grape chutney
description: Spice a garden glut of fruit with coriander, cumin and mustard seeds for this pickle that's perfect for hampers
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2 green chillies, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Toast the cumin and coriander seeds in a dry frying pan until aromatic. Tip into a mortar and coarsely grind with the pestle. Toast the mustard seeds in the same pan until they start to pop, then add to the other spices. Tip the spices into a large pan with the chillies, onions, ginger and vinegar. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 10 mins until the onions are softened.
Add the chopped apples, grapes, sugar and 1 tsp salt, and bring to the boil, stirring. Boil hard, stirring from time to time, for about 15-25 mins until the mixture is thick and pulpy.
Pot into warm sterilised jars (see tip, below), seal and label.
chief_review: This vibrant fruit pickle cleverly harnesses the late-summer bounty, melding apples and grapes with a warm blend of cumin, coriander, and mustard seeds. The cider vinegar base delivers a satisfying tang, while powdered ginger and green chillies infuse a gentle heat that lingers on the palate. The absence of animal products makes this recipe suitable for both vegetarian and vegan diets. Additionally, the pickle is naturally gluten-free, as none of the listed ingredients contain wheat or gluten derivatives. The result is a complex, aromatic condiment that pairs beautifully with cheese boards, cold meats, or crusty bread. The balance between sweet and spicy is expertly managed, making this an excellent homemade gift or a bright addition to everyday meals.

name: Almond florentines
description: Bake your own delicate nutty biscuits and keep them light as a feather with egg whites and icing sugar
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 2 tbsp melted butter, plus a little extra for brushing
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Line 2 baking sheets with baking parchment and brush with butter. Mix the butter, egg whites, sugar and flour until smooth, then add the almonds. With wet fingers or the back of a spoon, flatten tbsps of mixture into 16 biscuits on the sheets. Bake for 15-18 mins until golden. Cool.
chief_review: These nutty biscuits deliver a delightfully crisp texture and feather-light bite, thanks to the clever use of whipped egg whites and icing sugar. The toasted flaked almonds add an irresistible fragrance and crunch, balanced by a subtle richness from melted butter. With no raising agents, the recipe relies on careful folding of ingredients to maintain its delicate structure. These biscuits are a lovely choice for those following a vegetarian diet. However, they do contain nuts and eggs, so be mindful of common allergens. Best enjoyed freshly baked, these treats pair wonderfully with tea or a silky coffee.

name: Ricotta & spring onion dip
description: Have some leftover cream cheese? Whip it into a light dip with lemon and serve with cucumber or toast
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 3 roughly chopped spring onions, plus extra to serve
50g soured cream, crème fraîche or natural yogurt
directions: Whizz the ricotta, spring onions, lemon zest, juice, soured cream and some seasoning in a food processor. Scatter with more sliced spring onions to serve, and eat with cucumber sticks or toast.
chief_review: This recipe transforms leftover cream cheese into a refreshing, airy dip, balanced with ricotta and brightened by lemon juice and zest. The addition of fresh spring onions brings a pleasant sharpness, while the option of soured cream, crème fraîche, or natural yogurt adds a tangy creaminess to the mix. Served with crisp cucumber sticks, this dish is well-suited for vegetarians and those following a gluten-free diet—simply opt for gluten-free bread or stick to the vegetable dippers. The dip shines as a light appetizer or a healthy snack, perfect for gatherings or a casual bite. Its versatility and simplicity are commendable, offering both flavor and nutritional profile in just a few ingredients.

name: Semolina roast potatoes with garlic & thyme
description: Try this easy side dish for Sunday lunch - toss in semolina flour and roast with garlic and thyme until perfectly crisp and golden
author: Theo Randall
directions: Break the garlic bulb into cloves and place in a pan with the potatoes in their skins, then cover with cold salted water. Bring the potatoes to the boil, then simmer for 15 mins until you can put a knife through, but they still hold their shape. Drain in a colander and leave to cool.

Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. When the potatoes are cool enough to handle, peel off the skins. Cut into quarters and mix in a large bowl with 2 tbsp of the olive oil and some seasoning. Toss with the semolina flour until well coated.
Pour the remaining 3 tbsp olive oil into a shallow roasting tin and add the potatoes, garlic and thyme. Bake for 45 mins-1 hr until the potatoes are crisp and golden.
chief_review: This roast potato recipe is a masterclass in simplicity and texture. Tossed in fine semolina, the potatoes develop an irresistibly crisp, golden crust, beautifully complemented by the earthy aroma of whole garlic and aromatic thyme. Olive oil serves as both a flavour vehicle and a means to achieve even roasting, ensuring the insides remain fluffy and soft. The use of semolina and olive oil makes this dish naturally suitable for vegetarians and those seeking a dairy-free side—not to mention its appeal for anyone avoiding common allergens like eggs and nuts. A perfect accompaniment for Sunday roasts or festive meals, these potatoes strike a harmonious balance between elegance and comfort.

name: Turnip gratin
description: This rich side dish is similar to potato dauphinoise - turnips and potatoes are layered up with double cream and garlic and baked
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 600g potatoes, such as Maris Piper, peeled
large knob of butter, for greasing
directions: Preheat the oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Thinly slice the potatoes and turnips to about 2mm thick – you can use a Japanese mandolin if you have one – then toss together in a large bowl. Pour the cream in a pan, then add the garlic, plenty of salt and some white pepper – be generous when seasoning the cream as the potatoes and turnips aren’t seasoned separately. Bring the cream to the boil, then remove from the heat and put to one side. Grease a large gratin dish and layer a third of the potatoes and turnips in the dish, slightly overlapping each other as if you are building a wall. Pour over a third of the warm cream, then continue in this way with the remaining potatoes, turnips and cream.

Put the gratin in the oven and cook for 20 mins. Remove the dish from the oven and push the potatoes and turnips down with a fish slice. This will help to release the starches and the cream will eventually reduce and thicken. Put the gratin back in the oven and repeat the process every 10 mins until the potatoes and turnips feel tight and firm. Return to the oven for another 20 mins and cook until golden brown and tender – test by inserting a sharp knife through the potatoes and turnips. Remove from the oven and leave to cool slightly.
chief_review: This potato and turnip gratin is a decadent, comforting side, pairing the earthy sweetness of root vegetables with luscious double cream and aromatic garlic. The Maris Piper potatoes ensure a creamy texture, while turnips introduce a subtle tang that keeps the dish from becoming too heavy. Baking the layers in double cream intensifies richness, making it a perfect accompaniment to hearty mains. Since the dish is free from meat, it fits well into a vegetarian diet. However, it relies on dairy — butter and double cream — so it’s best suited for lacto-vegetarians. The absence of flour or bread makes it naturally gluten-free, catering to gluten-intolerant guests. The key is achieving thin, even slices and a slow bake for tender, melt-in-your-mouth layers. This gratin is wonderfully crowd-pleasing and guaranteed to elevate any meal with its classic French-inspired comfort.

name: Brie, ham & fig jam toastie
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 1 thick slice of ham(best from the deli counter, or leftover)
directions: Heat a toastie maker or a small griddle pan. Butter each slice of bread on one side, then spread the other side of one slice with fig jam, and one with mustard. Top the fig jam with brie and ham, sandwich with the remaining bread, butter-side up, then place in the toastie maker or the griddle pan. If cooking in a pan, squash down a little with the back of a fish slice while cooking, flip over after 2-3 mins when golden, then cook on the other side. Serve with a handful of salad leaves on the side, if you like.
chief_review: This indulgent sandwich pairs the creaminess of brie or camembert with the delicate sweetness of fig jam and the savory depth of ham, all embraced by buttery, crisped white bread. The touch of Dijon mustard adds just the right zing, balancing the richness of the cheese and the saltiness of the ham. The harmonious blend of flavors is reminiscent of a classic French croque-monsieur, but with a refined, sweet twist. While the salad leaves offer a refreshing counterpoint, they are optional and dependent on personal preference. This recipe is not suitable for vegetarian, vegan, dairy-free, or gluten-free diets, as it contains bread, butter, cheese, and ham. Ideal for a luxurious brunch or a satisfying lunch, this sandwich elevates simple ingredients into an elegant, café-worthy creation.

name: Quick plum crumble
author: Sarah Cook
directions: Simmer the plums, covered, with 200ml water and sugar until softened. Tip into a baking dish and scatter over the madeira cake.
Drizzle with double cream, scatter with the nuts and dust with icing sugar. Bake at 180C/160C fan/gas 4, just until browning.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful combination of sweet fruit, tender cake, and a creamy finish, accented by the crunch of nuts and a dusting of icing sugar. The use of plums or apples brings a fresh, tart element that balances the sweetness of the madeira cake and sugar. Double cream or custard adds a luxurious richness, making this dessert both comforting and indulgent. The final touch of flaked almonds or pistachios provides textural contrast and visual appeal. Suitable for vegetarian diets, this dessert is adaptable and perfect for gatherings or an elevated family treat. For optimal results, ensure the fruit is ripe and the cake is slightly stale for better absorption. Serve lightly chilled for a harmonious blend of flavors.

name: Chestnuts in Cognac & vanilla syrup
description: Steep nuts in brandy and cinnamon liqueur and store them in jars to serve with desserts like ice cream or fruit salad
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Put the zests, sugar, vanilla pod, cinnamon sticks and 400ml water in a large pan. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer gently for 20 mins. Leave to cool, then add the Cognac.

Pack the chestnuts into sterilised jars (see tip, below), then pour over the syrup to cover. Seal and label. Keep in a cool, dry place for at least 1 week before eating. Store in a cool, dry place for up to 6 months.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a decadent treat, infusing tender chestnuts with citrus zest, vanilla, and the warming notes of cognac and cinnamon. The combination of brandy, cinnamon liqueur, and aromatic spices creates a versatile syrup ideal for elevating simple desserts like ice cream or fruit salad. The use of vacuum-packed chestnuts ensures convenience and consistent texture. This recipe is suitable for gluten-free diets, as none of the ingredients contain wheat or gluten. Furthermore, it aligns with vegetarian diets, as it contains no animal-derived products beyond plant-based ingredients. The layering of flavors from citrus zest, vanilla, and spirits results in a complex, fragrant syrup that enhances both flavor and presentation. Recommended for anyone looking to add a luxurious accent to seasonal desserts.

name: Choc & ginger dippers
description: Have some leftover gingerbread dough? Bake it into biscuit fingers for dunking into hot drinks after a meal
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: gingerbreadtrimmings (from cottage in 'goes well with', or leftover from other gingerbread recipes)
tea, coffeeor hot chocolate, to serve
directions: Melt the chocolate and half dunk the baked trimmings from cutting out the sides of your gingerbread house. Leave to set, then serve with tea, coffee or hot chocolate after dinner.
chief_review: This simple recipe for gingerbread biscuit fingers is a creative way to use up leftover gingerbread dough. The combination of spiced biscuit and a dunk of rich dark or milk chocolate creates a classic flavor pairing, making these fingers perfect for enjoying with tea, coffee, or hot chocolate. The versatility of using either dark or milk chocolate caters to different preferences, and allows for further customization. The recipe does not require additional flour or eggs, making it quick and approachable even for beginner bakers. With no mention of animal-derived ingredients in the core gingerbread trimmings or chocolate (if non-dairy dark chocolate is used), this recipe can suit a vegetarian diet. Serve as a festive after-dinner treat, or present in small bundles as edible gifts for the holidays.

name: Mini hasselbacks with dill
description: Slash baby potatoes then bake with dill breadcrumbs for the perfect, crunchy accompaniment to a roast or stew
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. To slice, place a potato in a wooden spoon and carefully cut at 3mm intervals, slicing through the potato until your knife hits the spoon. In a bowl, mix the dill and breadcrumbs together.
Toss the potatoes with the oil and some seasoning, and arrange a large baking tray – cut-side up. Bake for 20 mins. Sprinkle with the dill breadcrumbs, then bake for a further 15 mins.
chief_review:
This recipe transforms humble baby new potatoes into a sensational, crispy side dish with just a handful of ingredients. The potatoes are slashed for maximum texture, then tossed with aromatic dried dill and crunchy fine breadcrumbs before baking in rapeseed oil—resulting in irresistible, golden edges. The combination of dill and the delicate, buttery potatoes evokes classic Eastern European flavors, making this an excellent pairing for roasted meats, vegetarian mains, or hearty stews.

Notably, the ingredients are all plant-based and free from dairy and eggs, so this recipe is naturally vegan and vegetarian-friendly. If you opt for gluten-free breadcrumbs, it easily caters to those with gluten intolerance as well. However, always check the breadcrumbs for potential allergens if serving guests with dietary restrictions. Ultimately, it's a simple, textural, and flavor-packed side that elevates any meal.

name: Yogurt piccalilli & crisp kale salad
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 280g jar sweet pickled baby silverskin onions
4 tbsp Greek-style yogurt(not the thick-strained type)
125g (or about 5 leaves) kaleor cavolo nero, any big stems removed, then shredded into 1cm strips
directions: Bring a pan of salted water to the boil and have a bowl of iced water ready. Add the cauliflower to the pan, return to the boil and cook for 30 seconds. Drain the cauliflower, then plunge into the ice water. Once cold, drain well.

Keep 3 tbsp of the onion vinegar aside, then mix the cauliflower with the onions and the rest of the vinegar from the jar in a large bowl. Cover and steep in the fridge for at least 2 hrs, or overnight if possible.
To make the dressing, heat 1 tbsp oil in a

, then add the garlic and ginger and cook for 1 min, stirring well. Stir in the turmeric and cook for 30 seconds, then remove from the heat. Add the mustard, 1 tbsp oil and the 3 tbsp pickling juice you reserved earlier. Cool for a few mins, then stir in the yogurt and season to taste.
Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 4. Tip the kale onto a large

. Season and rub 1 tbsp oil all over the leaves. Bake for about 6-8 mins till turning crisp at the edges. Once cooled, the kale will crisp up all over. Just before serving, drain the cauliflower and onion from the pickling juices and toss into the dressing, then fold the kale gently into it. Serve alongside our chicken terrine with leeks & apricots.
chief_review:
This vibrant dish offers a delightful fusion of textures, with crunchy cauliflower florets and tender kale or cavolo nero, balanced by the piquant sharpness of pickled baby silverskin onions. The olive oil base skillfully carries the aromatic warmth of ginger, garlic, and turmeric, while English mustard adds a distinctive tang. Greek-style yogurt contributes a creamy, slightly tangy finish, rounding out the flavors beautifully.

The recipe is well-suited for vegetarian diets and is gluten-free, making it accessible to a broader range of diners. However, those adhering to vegan diets will need to substitute the yogurt for a plant-based alternative. The absence of nuts, eggs, and major allergens aside from dairy means it may be appropriate for those managing certain food allergies, provided they are not sensitive to dairy. Serve this as a refreshing side or a light main for health-conscious and flavor-focused eaters alike.

name: Herb-studded roast loin of pork with apple & cider gravy
description: Boneless rolled pork with the scored skin will give you lots of delicious crackling - great for Sunday lunch
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1.8kg piece of rolled and tied pork loinwith the skin scored
2 garlic cloves, sliced into thin slivers
small bunch rosemary, broken into small sprigs
1 Bramley apple, peeled, quartered, cored and roughly sliced
directions: If you have time, rub salt in the pork skin 2 hours before cooking and leave it uncovered in the fridge. Heat the oven to 230C/210C fan/gas 8. Turn the pork rind-side down and with a small knife make about 6 deep incisions along the meat. Poke a sliver of garlic, a piece of rosemary and bay in each incision and turn the pork the right way up. If you didn’t salt the pork earlier salt the skin now.

Mix the carrot, onion and apple and scatter along the middle of a shallow roasting tray to make a bed for the pork to sit on. Sit the pork on the vegetables and rub the skin with the oil. Place the pork in the oven and leave for 15 mins then turn the heat down to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and continue to roast for 1hr 30 mins. If after this time you don’t have brilliant crackling turn the heat up again and check every 5 mins until the skin has crackled.

Remove the pork from the roasting tray to a board to rest and pour off all but about 2 tbsp of fat from the tray. If your tray is robust enough to go on the heat then do so, if not scrape the contents into a shallow saucepan and place on the heat. Stir the flour in with the veg and cook until you have a mushy, dark amber paste then splash in the cider and bubble down to a thick paste again. Pour in the stock and simmer everything for 8-10 mins until you have thickened gravy. Strain the sauce into another saucepan pushing as much puréed apple as you can through the sieve. Simmer again and season to taste.
Carve the pork loin with crackling attached into slices using a serrated knife and serve with your favourite vegetables and the apple and cider gravy.
chief_review: This boneless rolled pork recipe promises a showstopping centerpiece with its perfectly scored skin delivering satisfying, golden crackling—ideal for a celebratory Sunday lunch. Infusing classic aromatics like rosemary, garlic, and bay leaves delivers subtle herbaceous notes that deeply enhance the pork. The inclusion of Bramley apple adds a gentle tartness and melds beautifully with the richness of the pork and the heady cider-based gravy. Using both plain flour and cider ensures the sauce is luscious and tangy, while the layers of onion and carrot provide a sweet, caramelized base. This roast is best served freshly carved, and pairs well with simple vegetables or roasted potatoes to let the flavors shine. While not suitable for gluten-free diners due to the use of plain flour, this recipe is a traditional and rewarding dish for any home chef seeking classic British comfort.

name: Pan-fried camembert sandwich
description: Tried this with spinach in the sandwich instead of cranberry sauce and it was still delicious!
author: Silvana Franco
ingredients: a few drops of balsamic vinegar
directions: Butter the bread. Put a wedge of camembert or brie on the unbuttered side of one slice of bread. Top with a spoonful of cranberry sauce. Drizzle with a few drops of balsamic vinegar, if you have some.
Put the second slice of bread on top, buttered side out. Fry in a hot
, pressing down with a fish slice, for a minute or two on each side, until golden brown and melting. Cut in half and eat straightaway.
chief_review:
This sandwich brings together creamy camembert or brie and tangy cranberry sauce with a hint of balsamic vinegar, all tucked between thick slices of white bread. The richness of the cheese pairs beautifully with the sweet-sour cranberry, making each bite decadent yet balanced. Swapping in spinach offers a fresh, earthy spin that complements the cheese just as well—perfect for those who prefer greens over fruit preserves. Buttered bread, ideally griddled or toasted, delivers that irresistible golden crunch. 

This recipe is suitable for lacto-vegetarians but is not vegan due to the cheese and butter. Watch out for gluten in the white bread—opt for gluten-free bread if needed. The simple ingredient list makes it an easy-to-prepare option for a cozy lunch or quick supper.

name: Turkey laksa
description: Turkey isn't just for Christmas. Packed with protein, vitamins and lean too, it makes a great substitute for that other white meat
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1-2 tbsp Thai red curry paste, depending on taste
directions: Heat a large saucepan and fry the curry paste for 1 min, until fragrant. Tip in the stock and bring to the boil, then throw in the turkey and cook for 5 mins. Add the rice noodles and cook for 3 mins more.

Add the pepper and beansprouts and cook for 2 mins more. Add the coconut milk, bring to a simmer, season with the lime juice and sugar, then spoon into bowls, sprinkle with the coriander leaves and serve.
chief_review: This turkey curry noodle soup is an excellent choice for those following a gluten-free diet, thanks to the use of rice noodles instead of wheat-based alternatives. With lean turkey breast as the protein source, it’s also ideally suited for anyone seeking a high-protein, lower-fat meal. The recipe is dairy-free and, with its vibrant mix of Thai red curry paste, coconut milk, lime, and fresh coriander, offers a depth of flavor with a light, refreshing finish. The addition of plenty of vegetables—red pepper and beansprouts—adds both texture and nutritional value. Overall, it’s a robust, balanced dish that caters to gluten-free and dairy-free diners while delivering the warming, invigorating qualities of a great bowl of Asian-inspired soup.

name: Sticky marmalade ham
description: A Christmas classic from John Torode that will have all your guests wanting more
author: John Torode
ingredients: 1 raw gammon ham, smoked or unsmoked, approx 5-6kg/11-13lb 3oz with bone in
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/ gas 6. Put the ham into a large roasting tin, then tip in 500ml water. Cover the whole thing loosely with greaseproof paper, then cover with a large sheet of foil, scrunching and sealing it around the edge of the tin. Make sure you leave some room around the ham. Put it in the oven, then turn the heat down to 160C/140C fan/ gas 3 and leave to cook for 5 hrs. Meanwhile, mix the marmalade with the sugar and 50ml water in a small pan, bring to the boil, then set aside and leave to cool.

Take the ham from the oven. Be careful when you lift the foil as there will be a good amount of steam, which can burn. Once the ham has cooled just a little, remove the rind by gently prising the skin from the fat and lifting it away.
