Try to keep as much fat on the leg as you can as this will keep the ham moist as it roasts. Drain off most of the liquid (this is very good ham stock – keep it and use it for soup), leaving a little in the tin. Turn the oven up to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

Score lines into the fat with a knife to make large diamond shapes, with the lines about 4cm apart. Brush a third of the marmalade glaze over the joint, really pushing it into the creases and cuts. Now stud the ham with the cloves by poking a clove into the corner of each diamond.

Put a trivet into the roasting tin (if you don’t have one, a few halved carrots will do), then sit the ham on top. Roast the ham, uncovered, for 45-50 mins, brushing with the remaining glaze a few times during cooking, until caramelised and delicious. Carve hot or cold.
chief_review: John Torode’s festive ham is a masterclass in pairing robust, savoury meat with the subtle acidity and sweetness of orange marmalade. The gammon, slow-cooked to perfection, is glazed with marmalade and muscovado sugar, creating a shiny, caramelized crust studded with aromatic whole cloves. The result is a tender, flavour-packed centrepiece that balances sweet, smoky, and spicy notes—sure to delight any holiday gathering. This recipe would be suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided the marmalade doesn't contain barley malt or wheat-based thickeners. Its simplicity highlights the quality of the ham, making it ideal for those seeking a traditional yet show-stopping Christmas dish. Serve it hot or cold for maximum versatility and enjoy an easy win with minimal effort.

name: Watercress & celeriac soup with goat's cheese croutons
description: Feed your friends this simple freeze-ahead starter, topped with goat's cheese croutons for added crunch
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: a few sprigs watercress, to serve
directions: Gently cook the leeks in the butter and olive oil until soft but not coloured. Add the celeriac and stock, bring to the boil and simmer until the celeriac is soft. Add the bags of watercress and blend until smooth, then season. Cool.

To serve, defrost the soup in the fridge overnight, then tip into a saucepan and reheat. Top each toasted baguette slice with some goat’s cheese, then add a slice to each bowl with a sprig of watercress.
chief_review: This vibrant, make-ahead starter masterfully balances the delicate sweetness of leeks and earthiness of celeriac with the peppery freshness of watercress. The use of vegetable stock and vegetarian goat's cheese makes this dish entirely vegetarian-friendly, ideal for gatherings with diverse dietary needs. The creamy soup contrasts beautifully with the crisp, toasted baguette croutons, generously topped with tangy goat’s cheese for richness and depth. Garnishing with fresh watercress adds both visual appeal and a final hit of flavor. This recipe is exceptionally elegant yet approachable, offering both impressive taste and convenience for stress-free entertaining.

name: Creamy baked onions
description: Creamy onions that are perfect accompanying a roast dinner whether meat or veggie
author: Good Food
directions: Heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Peel and trim the roots of the onions but leave them whole. Cook in a large pan of boiling water for 25 mins until tender, then drain, reserving a little cooking water.

Season the cream and mix in 2 tbsp of the onion water. When the onions are cool enough to handle, slice each in half through the root. Lay the onion halves, cut side down, in a large baking dish with the bay leaves. Pour over the cream, scatter with the Parmesan, and bake for 25 mins until the cream is bubbling and the onions are just beginning to brown.
chief_review: This creamy onion dish is a superb accompaniment to any roast, delivering mellow sweetness and richness. Slowly cooked onions meld beautifully with double cream, infusing with the earthy, aromatic notes of bay leaves. The addition of parmesan brings a savory depth and a subtle tang, which can be easily tailored with a vegetarian cheese alternative, making the recipe suitable for vegetarians. Rich, comforting, and simple to prepare, this side is ideal for elevating a weekend roast. The velvety sauce complements both meat and vegetarian mains, and its minimal ingredient list allows the natural flavors of onion to shine, while remaining accessible and adaptable in any kitchen.

name: Gingerbread cake with caramel biscuit icing
description: This sumptuous Christmas bake is covered in a decadent icing, finished with gingerbread biscuits and dusted with desiccated coconut 'snow'
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 225ml vegetable oil, plus a little for greasing
3 tbsp dark rum(optional – replace with extra milk, if you like)
250g pack slightly salted butter, very soft
600g icing sugar, plus a little extra for dusting
200g smooth caramelised biscuit spread(I used Lotus Biscoff biscuit spread)
directions: Measure the milk and treacle into a saucepan (grease the measuring spoon with a little oil first and the treacle will easily slide off). Bring to a gentle simmer and stir until combined, then set aside to cool. Meanwhile, grease 3 x 20cm loose-bottomed cake tins with a little oil and line the bases with baking parchment (if you don’t have enough cake tins, see tip). If the tins are any shallower than 4cm, line the sides with a deep collar too. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.

Measure the flour, baking powder, bicarbonate of soda, sugar and spices into a large bowl, then add 1/2 tsp fine salt. Mix the dry ingredients together with a large whisk; if there are any large lumps of sugar, squeeze these through your fingers until you have an even, sandy-textured mixture.

In a jug, whisk the oil, buttermilk, eggs, rum and vanilla. Add the milk and treacle mixture, and mix well. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry, and whisk into a smooth batter. Divide between the tins and bake for 25-30 mins until a skewer inserted into the centre of the cakes comes out clean. You may have to swap the cakes over to cook evenly, but don’t do this until they’ve had at least 20 mins cooking. Cool the cakes in their tins for 10 mins, then transfer to a wire rack, peel off the parchment and leave to cool completely. Once cooled, you can wrap the sponges in cling film and store in a cool place for 4 days, or freeze for up to 2 months – the texture and flavour will be all the better for it.

To make the icing, put the butter and half the icing sugar in a large bowl. Mash together roughly with a spatula, then whizz with an electric hand whisk until smooth. Add the remaining icing sugar, the cream cheese, vanilla bean extract and biscuit spread. Mix again until smooth and evenly mixed. Transfer half the icing to another bowl and set aside. Use the remaining icing to stack the cakes and cover the entire outside in a thin layer – don’t worry about making the cake look too neat at this stage, as any crumbs trapped in the icing will be covered in the final coat. Chill the cake for 30 mins and the remaining icing for 20 mins (remove the icing from the fridge 10 mins before the cake to soften a little).

When the icing on the cake is firm, remove it from the fridge and use the remaining icing to cover the cake. Smooth the sides using a palette knife, but leave peaks and dips on top for your snow scene. Top the cake generously with desiccated coconut, a dusting of sieved icing sugar and some edible glitter, if you like, then decorate the top and sides with gingerbread shapes (see tip). If you’re not eating the cake within a few hours, store it in the fridge, but bring back to room temperature before serving. Wlll keep for 2 days.
chief_review:
This festive Christmas bake is an indulgent centerpiece, expertly layering warming spices like cinnamon, ginger, and cloves with the rich flavor from black treacle and dark rum. The crumb is moist thanks to buttermilk and oil, while the decadent icing, made with cream cheese, butter, and caramelized biscuit spread, adds a smooth, tangy sweetness. The gingerbread biscuit and desiccated coconut 'snow' decoration elevates both presentation and texture, making it a true showstopper for holiday gatherings.

Suitable for vegetarians, provided the rum (if used) is vegetarian-friendly and the icing sugar doesn’t contain animal-derived agents. However, with the use of wheat flour and cream cheese, this recipe contains gluten and dairy, so is not suited for gluten-free or dairy-free diets. Overall, this bake is a delightful treat for those seeking a nostalgic, crowd-pleasing dessert with classic holiday flavors.

name: Fruit-filled clementine cake
description: A beautiful, moist gluten-free cake packed with zingy citrus flavours, wonderful for Christmas
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
1 tsp baking powder (we used Fiddes Payne, which is gluten-free)
icing sugar, to decorate (most are gluten-free, but check the packaging)
directions: To make the cake, place the clementines in a small pan, cover with water and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat to a simmer and cook for 1 hr or until tender. Drain and cool.

Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Butter a 20cm springform cake tin and line the base with a disc of buttered baking parchment. Cut the cooked clementines in half and remove any pips. Place in the bowl of a food processor and pulse until finely chopped but not puréed.

Combine the raisins, sultanas, currants, cherries and brandy in a bowl. Add the clementine pulp and mix well. Cream the butter and sugar together until pale. Add the beaten eggs, a little at a time, mixing well between each addition. In another bowl, combine the spices, ground almonds, polenta and baking powder. Fold into the creamed mixture along with the dried fruit and clementine pulp.

Spoon into the prepared tin and smooth the top. Bake on the middle shelf of the oven for 30 mins. Reduce the oven temperature to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3 and continue to cook for a further 40 mins. You may need to loosely cover the top of the cake with a sheet of baking parchment for the final 20 mins to prevent it browning too quickly. Cool in the tin for 30 mins before turning out onto a cooling rack.

To make the topping, slice the clementines to a 5mm thickness. Tip the sugar into a saucepan with 140ml water and cook over a low heat, stirring often, until the sugar has dissolved. Put the clementine slices in the pan and stir through. To keep the clementines submerged in the syrup, cut out a circle of greaseproof paper to fit into the pan and place over the fruit. Cook over a low heat for 1 hr until glossy and translucent. Remove and spread out over greaseproof paper to cool.
To serve, dust the whole cake with icing sugar, then arrange the clementine slices, overlapping, over the top of the cake.
chief_review: This delightful gluten-free cake is a true celebration of citrus and festive spices, perfect for those who crave a moist, aromatic bake without wheat. The clever use of polenta and ground almonds ensures a tender crumb while keeping the cake naturally gluten-free—excellent for anyone following a gluten-free diet. The medley of dried fruits, glacé cherries, and a splash of brandy imbue the cake with classic holiday flavors, while the clementines provide a vibrant, fresh lift. Attention to using gluten-free baking powder and checking icing sugar packaging demonstrates thoughtfulness toward dietary restrictions. This recipe does contain butter and eggs, so it's not suitable for vegans or those needing a dairy-free option. Overall, it’s a sophisticated, festive centerpiece sure to please a crowd, especially those sensitive to gluten, without any compromise on taste or texture.

name: Silky celeriac soup with smoked haddock
description: A twist on celery soup. Leave out the haddock if you like (it's just flaked over the top)
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: 1 garlic bulb, cut through the middle
few thyme sprigs, plus extra to serve
directions: Heat the 50g of butter in a large saucepan until foaming, then lower the heat a little. Sweat the onion and leek with the clove of garlic, a few sprigs of thyme and 2 bay leaves. Add the celeriac and the 2 potatoes and cook for 10 mins more, stirring frequently so the vegetables don’t stick to the pan. Pour over the litre of stock to just about cover, bring to the boil, then simmer gently for 20 mins.

Meanwhile, in a deep frying pan bring the 500ml of milk and remaining bay leaves to the boil. Lower to a very gentle simmer, slide in the 2 haddock fillets and cover with baking paper. Cook for 3-4 mins until the fish flakes easily. Remove the fish from the milk and flake into a bowl; cover to keep warm.

When the celeriac is tender, pour in the 500ml of cream, bring back to the boil and remove from the heat. Remove the garlic and herb stalks, then blitz until silky smooth using a stick blender. If you want to freeze the soup, stir through the fish at this point. Serve scattered with the flaked haddock and thyme leaves.
chief_review: This celery soup reinterpretation delivers a beautifully rich, aromatic profile, underpinned by the harmonious sweetness of leek, celeriac, and onion. The infusing of thyme, bay, and whole garlic lends a deep and layered fragrance, while the smoked haddock – though optional – brings welcome umami and complexity as a final flourish. The use of chicken stock, butter, and double cream results in a luxuriant, velvety texture, making this soup hearty and truly comforting. This recipe is adaptable: simply leaving out the haddock creates a delicious vegetarian version. Ideal for those adhering to a vegetarian diet (when using vegetable stock), this soup caters to varied tastes while maintaining a restaurant-quality finish. Serve with crusty bread and an extra sprinkle of thyme for a sophisticated starter or satisfying lunch.

name: Cranberry mince pies
description: Gordon Ramsay's cranberry mince pies provide the all-important finishing touch to your celebration feast
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 250g 00 flour or plain flour, plus extra for rolling
finely grated zest 1 orange or lemon
1 egg yolk, beaten with 1tsp water, to glaze
directions: Whizz together the flour, icing sugar and butter until they form fine crumbs. With the blades running, add the zest, then the egg and process for a few secs until the mixture forms clumps. If you need to, work in a few trickles of ice cold water, but try and avoid it if you can for the shortest pastry.
Tip onto a very lightly floured surface, knead briefly until smooth, then chill in the fridge for 30 mins or until firm. Can be made up to 3 days ahead or frozen for up to a month.

Lightly dust the work surface with flour, then roll pastry out to approx £1 thickness. Cut out 12 x 8cm rounds with a fluted cutter and press into a 12-hole non-stick bun tin. Re-roll the trimmings to the same thickness and stamp out 12 x 5cm rounds for the tops. If you like, use a star cutter to cut out star shapes in the top of the pies, or simply cut crosses in the middle.

Spoon about 1 dessertspoon mincemeat into each base, sprinkle with cranberries, then press on the tops. Chill for 20 mins while you heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Can be frozen for up to 1 month at this point.

Brush the tops with the egg, then bake for 15-20 mins until golden and crisp. Cool for a few mins, then lever out of the tins with a table knife and cool on a wire rack. Store in an airtight container for up to 1 week. Warm gently to serve, dusted with sifted icing sugar.
chief_review: Gordon Ramsay's cranberry mince pies present a refined twist on the classic festive treat, incorporating dried cranberries for a burst of tangy sweetness. The pastry, enriched with butter and a hint of citrus zest, delivers a delicate texture and bright aroma. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians and those seeking a nut-free dessert, as no nuts or animal-derived gelatin are used. However, the use of flour means it's not gluten-free by default. The simple glaze adds a golden finish, while a dusting of icing sugar provides a light, elegant touch. Ideal as a centerpiece for holiday gatherings, these mince pies balance tradition with a refreshing twist, appealing to both classic and modern palates.

name: Clotted cream & ginger ice cream
description: This tangy ice cream is perfect for your ice cream maker but just as easy by hand
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 tbsp syrup from the stem ginger jar
2 x pieces stem ginger, finely chopped
1 x Roasted rhubarb(see 'Goes well with below)
directions: Fold the custard, clotted cream and ginger syrup together in a bowl until completely combined. Pour this into an ice-cream machine and churn according to machine instructions. (If you don't have an ice-cream machine, put the bowl in the freezer for about 11⁄2 hrs, or until the mixture starts to freeze around the edges. Give it a good stir to break it all up, then repeat.)
When the ice cream is completely churned, mix in the chopped ginger so it speckles the ice cream, then serve in scoops with the Roasted rhubarb.
chief_review: This rhubarb and stem ginger ice cream offers a delightful interplay of tart and spicy notes, balanced beautifully by the richness of clotted cream and custard. The syrup from the stem ginger jar imparts both sweetness and warmth, elevating the overall complexity of flavor. The recipe is wonderfully convenient, allowing preparation either with or without an ice cream maker, making it accessible for home cooks of all skill levels. The use of ready-made custard ensures a luxuriously smooth texture, while the roasted rhubarb adds bursts of tanginess. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, as it contains dairy but no animal-derived gelatin or eggs in its composition, assuming the ready-made custard is egg-free or uses free-range eggs if ethically considered. Ideal as a summer dessert, it pairs beautifully with poached fruits or a simple shortbread biscuit.

name: Red cabbage with balsamic vinegar & cranberries
description: This vibrant veggie Christmas side dish beautifully contrasts sweet and savoury, make it up to four days in advance or freeze it
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 large onions, halved and thinly sliced
1 medium red cabbage, quartered, cored and thinly sliced
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan. Add the onions and fry, stirring every now and then, for about 10 mins, until they start to caramelise. Stir in the cloves, then add the cabbage and continue cooking, stirring more frequently this time, until the cabbage starts to soften.
Pour in the stock, add the vinegar and sugar, then cover and cook for 10 mins.
Stir in the cranberries and cook for 10 mins more. Cool and keep in the fridge for up to 4 days, or freeze for 1 month. Thaw in the fridge overnight. Reheat until very hot before serving.
chief_review:
This festive vegetable side dish is a delightful celebration of contrasting flavors, perfect for adding depth and color to a holiday spread. The combination of caramelized onions, aromatic cloves, and tangy cranberries merges with red cabbage, creating a pleasing balance between sweet and savory notes. The technique of slow-cooking in balsamic vinegar and vegetable stock yields a tender, well-melded texture that holds its appeal whether served fresh, made ahead, or thawed from the freezer.

Notably, all the ingredients used—fresh vegetables, olive oil, cranberries, and plant-based flavorings—make this dish naturally suitable for vegan and vegetarian diets. With no gluten-containing ingredients, it also adapts well to a gluten-free table, provided the vegetable stock is verified gluten-free. Nut-free and dairy-free, it’s an inclusive option for diverse gatherings, packing festive color, flavor, and convenience into one vibrant bowl.

name: Roast vegetable tray
description: Seasonal roast veg couldn't be any easier - just peel and roast - perfect alongside your Christmas roast
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 1 small swede, cut into thick wedges
large knob of butter, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Pour 3 tbsp of the oil into a roasting tin, scatter and roll the vegetables in the oil and season with salt and pepper. Drizzle with the remaining oil. Can be prepared to this stage up to an hour ahead.
Roast the vegetables for 45-55 mins until tender and golden brown. Brush with butter before serving.
chief_review: This seasonal roast vegetable recipe is a celebration of winter produce, offering earthy sweetness from carrots, parsnips, onions, and swede. Simply tossed in olive or vegetable oil and roasted, the vegetables caramelize beautifully, resulting in a satisfying blend of crisp exteriors and tender interiors. The finishing touch of butter adds richness and enhances their natural flavors—an ideal complement to any festive roast. This dish fits well with vegetarian diets, and if you swap the butter for a plant-based alternative, it gracefully transitions to suit vegan requirements as well. Additionally, the use of root vegetables and absence of wheat-based ingredients makes this naturally gluten-free. A versatile and straightforward side, this recipe lets the ingredients' quality shine, perfect for both holiday feasts and everyday meals.

name: Slow roast honey & sesame duck
description: A delicious way to cook duck which is well worth the wait.
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 150ml chicken stock (or water with a small sprinkling of chicken stock cube)
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Score the duck breast skin with a sharp knife. This helps release excess fat from the skin as the bird roasts. Season the duck with the sea salt and pepper, then sit it on a rack set in a roasting tray and roast for 1½ hrs. Remove the bird from the oven and pour off the excess fat collected in the tray.

Return the duck to the roasting tray, then spoon 3 tbsp of the honey over to cover the breasts and legs. Roast the duck for a further hr, basting with the honey every 10-15 mins. Sprinkle the sesame seeds on top during the final 10 mins of roasting.
Once cooked, remove duck from the roasting tray, and allow it to rest for 10-15 mins. Spoon the remaining tbsp of honey over the duck as it rests.

Meanwhile, make the sauce. Pour off any excess fat from the roasting tin, leaving behind a couple of tbsp of the honey and duck juices. Heat the roasting tray on top of the stove. Once the contents sizzle and become well caramelised, pour in the red wine, then boil for a few mins to reduce by about a third. Pour in the chicken stock (or water and stock cube), then simmer for several mins, also allowing it to slightly reduce to strengthen the flavour. Finish off the sauce (which is quite loose) with the knob of butter (for thicker gravy see 'Try' below). Season with salt and pepper and strain through a fine sieve, if you like.

Now finsih it in style: Gary say's: I prefer to serve just the half duck on the plate. To do this, remove the duck breasts and legs from the breast bone by cutting either side of the breast bone, following its natural line. Drizzle any excess honey juices over and offer all accompaniments separately.
chief_review: This duck recipe delivers a gorgeously caramelized crust, thanks to the honey glaze, while the red wine and chicken stock lend richness and depth to the sauce. The use of coarse sea salt ensures a crisp skin, and the sesame seeds add a subtle, nutty crunch. The duck remains beautifully moist, with each bite balancing sweet, savory, and umami flavors. This dish is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, provided a gluten-free chicken stock or cube is used. As a main course, it’s an impressive centerpiece for any special occasion, offering restaurant-quality results at home.

name: Devilled tofu kebabs
description: A low fat vegetarian kebab to bring out the devil in you
author: Good Food
directions: Put the shallots or button onions in a bowl, cover with boiling water and set aside for 5 mins. Cook the potatoes in a pan of boiling water for 7 mins until tender. Drain and pat dry. Put tomato purée, soy sauce, oil, honey, mustard and seasoning in a bowl, then mix well. Toss the tofu in the marinade. Set aside for at least 10 mins.

Heat the grill. Drain and peel shallots or onions, then cook in boiling water for 3 mins. Drain well. Thread the tofu, shallots, potatoes, courgette and pepper on to 8 x 20cm skewers. Grill for 10 mins, turning frequently and brushing with remaining marinade before serving.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a vibrant, smoky kebab with a playful balance of sweet and tangy notes, thanks to the honey, tomato purée, and wholegrain mustard marinade. The combination of smoked tofu and colourful vegetables offers a satisfying texture and satisfying umami depth, while light soy sauce and sunflower oil help keep things lean and flavourful. The kebabs are ideal for vegetarians, and the absence of eggs and dairy makes them suitable for a lacto-vegetarian diet. As the recipe avoids most common allergens like nuts and gluten (provided a gluten-free soy sauce is used), it can be customized for gluten-sensitive diners. These kebabs shine as a centrepiece for healthy grilling, making them equally welcome at family dinners or summer gatherings.

name: Velvety duck liver parfait
description: A little parfait makes Christmas complete, try making your own with Barney's festive recipe
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 600g duck or chicken liver, or a mix of both
250g pack butter, diced and slightly softened
toast, gherkin and chutney, to serve
directions: Cut away and discard any large sinews from the livers, then set the livers aside. Heat about a third of the butter in a large frying pan, then gently fry the shallots and garlic for 3-4 mins unti l soft. Turn up the heat, add the livers, then fry until just browned on all sides. Add the brandy and port, boil down as quickly as possible – if the sauce catches light for an instant, then all the better. Remove the pan from the heat and leave to cool completely.

Season the livers generously, then tip the contents of the pan into a food processor with the tomato purée and remaining butter, and blitz until smooth. Push the mixture through a fine sieve into a bowl, taste for seasoning, then tip into a serving dish, banging the dish down on the tabletop to smooth out the surface. Place in the fridge to set.

Once the mixture has set, make the topping. Gently melt the butter in a small pan or in a bowl in the microwave, then leave for a min to settle and separate. Pour the yellow butter that has risen to the top into another bowl and discard the milky liquid. Leave the yellow butter to cool slightly, then mix in the thyme and peppercorns. Pour the mixture over the parfait and leave to set in the fridge. Serve with plenty of toast, sliced gherkins and chutney. Will keep for 2 days in the fridge.
chief_review: Barney’s festive parfait is a sophisticated addition to any Christmas table, offering a luxuriously smooth texture and rich depth from the combination of duck and chicken livers. The incorporation of butter lends a silky, indulgent finish, while shallots, garlic, and thyme provide aromatic undertones that balance the richness. A splash of brandy or port introduces a festive, warming note, and the seasoning of black peppercorn elevates the complexity. Served alongside crisp toast, sharp gherkins, and a dollop of chutney, this dish hits all the right notes: creamy, tangy, and robust. This recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet if paired with gluten-free toast and for vegetarians seeking a rich appetizer alternative. For entertaining, this parfait is both impressive and classic, sure to become a seasonal favorite with its luxurious mouthfeel and memorable flavor profile.

name: Apple & cranberry pancakes with cinnamon butter & syrup
description: These spiced, American-style pancakes make a deliciously decadent yet easy to make brunch
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 2 small-medium eating apples, peeled, cored and grated
a little more butter or sunflower oil, for frying
directions: To make the cinnamon butter, mix all the ingredients together, wrap in cling film, shape into a log and chill. You can make this up to 3 days ahead.

Mix the flour, bicarb and a pinch of salt in a bowl. Make a well in the centre, then gradually whisk in the eggs, followed by the buttermilk, milk and melted butter. Once the mixture is smooth, stir in the grated apples and cranberries.

Melt a little more butter in a non-stick pan or wipe with sunflower oil. When hot, add 1-3 small ladles of batter to the pan to make 1-3 small pancakes (depending on the size of your pan). Cook for 2-3 mins until bubbles appear and the underneaths are set and golden. Flip and cook for a few mins more. Transfer pancakes to a plate, cover with baking parchment and keep warm in a low oven. Cook the remaining pancakes.
To serve, stack pancakes on plates, top with a good knob of cinnamon butter and drizzle with maple syrup.
chief_review: These spiced American-style pancakes offer a delightful blend of warming cinnamon, tart grated apple, and pops of sweet cranberries, making them an irresistible brunch choice. The use of buttermilk lends them a tender, fluffy texture, while the melted butter and self-raising flour ensure richness and proper rise. The flavored cinnamon butter is a charming touch that pairs wonderfully with the maple syrup, adding decadence to every bite. These pancakes include eggs, dairy, and wheat, so they fit well within a vegetarian diet. The inclusion of fruit within the batter elevates their flavor complexity, balancing sweet and tart beautifully. Ideal for a cozy weekend treat, this recipe is straightforward but delivers gourmet results reminiscent of a classic American diner experience at home.

name: Herb & pepper crusted rib of beef
description: Fantastic and easy
author: James Martin
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Mix the rock salt, peppercorns, garlic, rosemary, parsley and olive oil. Rub this mixture all over the beef rib then place in a roasting tin. Put in the oven and cook for 30 mins, then turn the oven down to 160C/140C fan/gas 3 and cook for a further 1 hr 20 mins. Remove from the oven, transfer the beef to a board, cover with tin foil and rest for 30 mins before carving.

While the beef rests, make the gravy. Pour off all but 2 tbsp of fat from the roasting tin and reserve any juices. Fry the onions in the roasting tin over a medium heat for about 10 mins, then add the wine, stock and reserved juices. Keep cooking for a further 10 mins to reduce to a thick sauce, season well and serve alongside the roast beef.
chief_review: This rib of beef recipe delivers robust, classic flavors with a rustic charm. The black pepper and rock salt create a bold, savory crust, beautifully fragrant with garlic, rosemary, and parsley. Olive oil enhances both the meat and the herbal aromatics, while the combination of red wine and fresh beef stock forms a rich, luxurious jus. The sliced onions add subtle sweetness and depth to the finished dish. This recipe is naturally suitable for a gluten-free diet, provided the stock is certified gluten-free. Ideal for celebratory meals or Sunday roasts, its straightforward method lets the high-quality beef shine. This dish will surely impress with little fuss in preparation.

name: Goat's cheese & cranberry tartlets
description: These vegetarian tartlets make great finger food for a festive drinks party
author: Jo Pratt
ingredients: 375-425g pack ready-rolled puff pastryor 500g pack ready-made pastry rolled 5mm thick
3 tbsp cranberry sauce or a good-quality chutney
3 x 120g goat's cheese logs (such as Soignon Petit Sainte-Maure), at room temperature
directions: Preheat oven to fan 200C/conventional 220C/gas 7. Lay pastry on a floured work surface. Using a round 7.5cm round pastry cutter, cut out as many circles as possible.

Sit them on oiled baking sheets and score a circle about 2.5cm in from the edge of each disc by pressing gently with a 5cm cutter. Pierce the middle of each with a fork, brush with egg and top with a little cranberry sauce or chutney.
Slice the cheese 5mm thick so you have a slice per disc (discard end rinds). Lay a slice on each tartlet, then top with thyme leaves, a drizzle of oil and a twist of black pepper.
Bake for 10-15 minutes until the cheese is golden and the pastry crispy. Cool for 5 minutes and serve warm, garnished with rocket leaves.
chief_review: These vegetarian tartlets are a delightful addition to any festive gathering, boasting a harmonious blend of tangy goat’s cheese and sweet cranberry sauce perched atop crisp, golden pastry. The ready-rolled puff pastry keeps preparation fuss-free, while the fresh thyme adds a subtle aromatic note that elevates the filling. A drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil and a handful of peppery rocket leaves serve as the perfect finishing touch, bringing color and freshness to the plate. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, making it inclusive for diverse guests. The tartlets balance savory and sweet components exceptionally well, resulting in moreish bites that are as elegant as they are delicious.

name: Mincemeat & pecan palmiers
description: Mine did not quite turn out like this. I think I need pictures!
author: Good Food
directions: Mix the mincemeat, nuts, cinnamon and maple syrup together; set aside. Lightly flour a work surface, then roll pastry out to a rectangle measuring 40 x 30cm. Trim the edges with a sharp knife.

Carefully position the pastry with one of the long edges facing you. Spread two-thirds of the mincemeat mix over the pastry, then fold the two shorter edges over to meet in the middle. Spread the rest of the mincemeat over the folded pastry and bring the outside ends over again to join in the centre. Turn the pastry over, lift onto a non-stick baking sheet, then gently squeeze down the length to make an even-shaped log, with tight folds. Chill in the freezer for 10 mins. Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7.

Remove the baking sheet from the freezer. Cut the pastry into 1cm slices and arrange on baking sheets, spaced apart. Cook on the top shelf for 15 mins until risen and golden brown. Cool on a wire rack and serve dusted with icing sugar.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful combination of sweet and nutty flavors thanks to the use of mincemeat, pecan nuts, cinnamon, and maple syrup, all wrapped in buttery puff pastry. It’s an indulgent treat that beautifully captures classic holiday tastes, with the pecans adding a satisfying crunch and the cinnamon lending warmth. While the preparation seems straightforward, visual guidance would indeed help perfect the pastry’s golden finish. This dish would suit a vegetarian diet, assuming the mincemeat is the traditional fruit-based kind and not the historical meat-based version. Be sure to check your mincemeat ingredients to confirm. The addition of dusted icing sugar elevates the presentation, making this a lovely option for festive gatherings.

name: Homemade marzipan thins
description: Sweet treats for friends and family
author: Good Food
directions: Make the marzipan: mix the almonds and sugars until well combined. Add the egg and almond essence and mix to a stiff paste, using your hands to press the mixture together. Knead the marzipan briefly on a surface dusted with icing sugar, then roll out to a thickness of about 1cm.

Line a baking sheet with baking parchment, then carefully set marzipan on top. Leave to set for 1 hr. Beat royal icing and lemon juice together, then spread evenly over the marzipan. Leave to dry overnight.
Cut the iced marzipan with small cutters and press a piece of crystallised fruit into the centre of each. Pack into boxes interleaved with baking parchment.
chief_review:
This delightful sweet treat recipe brings together the rich nuttiness of ground almonds with the subtle aroma of almond essence, resulting in a wonderfully tender and fragrant bite. The addition of crystallised fruits on top offers a visually appealing, jewel-like finish, perfect for gifting or serving on special occasions. The royal icing delivers a soft, sweet shell that balances the dense interior.

Thanks to the absence of wheat or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet. However, always check labels on ingredients like royal icing mix to ensure they are certified gluten-free. The use of a single egg means this treat is not suitable for vegans, but it will appeal to many looking for a nut-forward, gluten-free confection. Ideal with afternoon tea or as a festive, elegant treat for the dessert table.

name: Leek, potato & ham flip-over pie
description: This warming winter recipe is a great way to use up the Christmas leftovers, and so easy to make. Perfect for Boxing Day
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g leftover cooked potato (roasted or boiled – see step 1)
100g cooked ham, chopped into small pieces
directions: To make the filling, preheat the oven to 220C/gas 7/fan 200C. Slice your potato leftovers as best you can, then blanch the leek in boiling water for 3 minutes and drain. If you don’t have any leftovers, peel, halve and thickly slice a baking potato, then boil for 8 minutes, adding the sliced leek for the last 3 minutes. Drain. In a large bowl, mix the potato, leek, horseradish sauce, crème fraîche, ham and thyme, mushing up the potato slightly, then season well.

To make the pie, unroll the pastry rectangle onto a baking sheet. Pile the filling along the length of one half of the pastry, leaving a small gap on the outside edge. Brush milk round the edges of the pastry. Fold the uncovered side over the filling, then press the pastry edges together well, using the prongs of a fork, to seal. Make a few 6cm diagonal slashes in the top. (The pie can now be frozen for up to a month.)
To bake the pie, brush the pie with the remaining milk and bake for 30 minutes until golden brown. Leave to relax for a couple of minutes then cut into slices and serve with a green salad.
chief_review: This hearty winter pie is a brilliant, no-fuss solution for revamping Christmas leftovers into a comforting meal. The combination of tender potatoes, sweet leeks, and the subtle kick of horseradish sauce creates a flavorful, creamy filling, accentuated by salty bites of ham and an herby touch of thyme. Ready-rolled puff pastry delivers a golden, flaky crust with minimal effort. The addition of crème fraîche lends a silky richness and binds the ingredients beautifully. This recipe is best suited to those following a vegetarian diet if the ham is omitted and a vegetarian puff pastry is used. Additionally, check for gluten-free pastry and dairy-free crème fraîche alternatives if accommodating those dietary needs. Easy to prepare and deeply satisfying, this dish is perfect for lingering holiday gatherings or a cozy Boxing Day supper.

name: Ultimate Gratin Dauphinois
description: An utterly irresistable creamy potato side dish with very few ingredients but oozing with flavour
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 2 sprigs of fresh thyme, plus extra for sprinkling
directions: Preheat the oven to 160C/Gas 4/fan oven 140C. Rub the butter all over the surface of a gratin dish, about 18x28cm/7x11in. Peel and slice the potatoes to a width of 3mm/1⁄8in. Lay the slices on a clean tea towel and pat dry. Keep them covered with the tea towel while you prepare the rest of the ingredients.

Pour the milk and cream into a saucepan. Add the garlic, thyme and shallot (if using). Slowly heat the milk and, just as it is about to reach boiling point and you see bubbles appearing around the edge of the pan, remove it from the heat. Strain the liquid into a large jug, sprinkle in the nutmeg and keep warm.

Layer half the potato slices in the dish, slightly overlapping the slices and sprinkling with a little salt and freshly ground pepper between each layer. You don’t have to be too neat with the lower layers, but keep some of your best slices for later, so the top looks good.

Pour half the hot milk and cream over the potatoes, then finish off layering the rest of the potatoes (arranging them a bit more carefully this time). Pour over the rest of the hot milk and cream. Scatter the cheese over the top and bake for about one hour, until golden and tender. Leave the dish to stand for about 5 minutes, then serve sprinkled with a few fresh thyme leaves.
chief_review: This creamy potato side dish exemplifies comfort and decadence, using minimal yet high-impact ingredients for maximum flavor. The Desirée potatoes become meltingly tender when bathed in the rich combination of double cream and full-fat milk, while the garlic and thyme bring a subtle aromatic depth. A hint of nutmeg adds warmth, perfectly complementing the richness of the dairy. The finishing touch of freshly grated Parmesan provides a savory, umami lift—feel free to use a vegetarian-friendly Parmesan alternative for a fully vegetarian dish. As there is no flour or gluten-based additive, the recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. Pair this luxurious side with a simple main to let its flavors shine.

name: Chocolate truffles
description: These truffles, from Good Food reader Jeanette Jones, make great gifts. Vary them with chopped walnuts, dried fruit or a splash of rum
author: Good Food
ingredients: cocoa and icing sugar, to decorate
directions: Melt the chocolate in a bowl over a pan of simmering water. Once melted, add the remaining ingredients.
Roll into walnut-size balls with your hands and pop into the fridge on a plate to chill and set. Once set, roll in cocoa or icing sugar. Will keep in the fridge for 1 week.
chief_review: These chocolate truffles offer a delightful fusion of rich chocolate and creamy condensed milk, enhanced by the subtle nuttiness of ground almonds and the soft texture of Madeiracake crumbs. The recipe is easy to adapt with additions like chopped walnuts, dried fruit, or a touch of rum for extra depth. Rolled in cocoa and icing sugar, each truffle delivers a perfectly balanced sweetness with a luxurious mouthfeel. Vegetarians can enjoy these treats, as there are no meat or gelatine products involved. However, note the inclusion of dairy (from condensed milk and chocolate), and gluten (from Madeiracake), making them unsuitable for those with lactose intolerance or gluten sensitivity. These truffles are perfect for gifting, bringing a personal and decadent touch to any celebration or festive occasion.

name: Parsnip hash browns
description: These crispy hash browns can be made ahead and reheated from frozen - ideal for unexpected Christmas visitors
author: Jenny White
ingredients: 1 small onion, halved and thinly sliced
6 rashers of streaky baconor slices of prosciutto
6 stems of cherry tomatoeson the vine
directions: Peel and coarsely grate the potatoes and parsnips – if you’re using a food processor, attach the medium grater. Squeeze out as much liquid as possible with your hands and put them in a bowl.

Stir in the onion, garlic, egg and season if you like. Divide the mixture into six and roughly shape into flat cakes. Heat 2 tbsp of the oil in a large non-stick frying pan and fry three of the cakes on a low heat for 4-5 mins on each side until golden and tender. Transfer to kitchen paper with a slotted spoon and leave to cool while frying the remainder, adding remaining oil as necessary. Meanwhile grill the bacon and tomatoes, poach the eggs and serve alongside.
chief_review: This festive hash brown recipe offers a comforting and crowd-pleasing breakfast option with a twist—melding waxy potatoes and parsnips for added flavor and texture. The addition of garlic and onion builds aromatic depth, while sunflower oil ensures a crispy, golden exterior. Topping with streaky bacon or prosciutto and perfectly roasted cherry tomatoes elevates both taste and presentation. With eggs used both in the hash mix and served alongside, this dish is high in protein and suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians if the bacon or prosciutto is omitted or substituted. The absence of flour makes it naturally gluten-free, catering to those with gluten sensitivities. Ideal for batch cooking, these hash browns can be frozen and reheated, ensuring a stress-free, impressive addition to any festive breakfast spread.

name: Red cabbage with apples
description: Vey easy and tasty (even though I used water and not stock). Didn’t have any star anise so used cloves but it worked very well. Probably cooked it longer than stated but not a problem. The flavours grew overnight and it was even better the next day.
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2 apples, cored and cut into wedges
directions: Place all the ingredients except for the apples in a large saucepan and season. Place over a medium heat, bring to the boil, then turn down the heat and simmer for 30 mins. Add the apples, then continue cooking for 15 mins until tender.
chief_review: This vibrant braised red cabbage recipe is both easy to prepare and bursting with warm, aromatic flavors from cinnamon, bay leaves, and star anise (or cloves as a clever substitute). The mix of apples and golden caster sugar adds a gentle sweetness balanced by tart cider vinegar, making each bite lively and satisfying. While water can successfully replace stock for a lighter version, the flavors are beautifully layered and deepen overnight, making this an excellent make-ahead dish. Since the ingredients are all plant-based and naturally gluten-free, this recipe is well-suited for both vegan and vegetarian diets, as well as those avoiding gluten. Its adaptability and robust taste make it a fantastic side dish for a variety of meals.

name: Classic winter fruitcake
description: This festive icing is easy to use, looks amazing and makes a lighter end to a meal. The perfect centrepiece for Christmas tea
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Lightly beat the egg white in a shallow bowl and spread out the caster sugar on a baking sheet or tray. Dip the grapes and the holly or bay leaves into the egg white, or use a paintbrush. Shake off the excess, then coat in the sugar. Set aside to dry for at least 10 mins, ideally about 30 mins.

When you’re ready to decorate, make the frosting. Put a large bowl over a pan of simmering water, making sure the bottom of the bowl does not touch the water. Put the egg whites and icing sugar into the bowl and whisk for 5-7 mins until you have a thick, very glossy frosting. Use a spatula to clean around the edges of the bowl every so often as you whisk. Scoop the frosting onto the top of the cake and spread it around with a flat-edged knife, swirling as you go to create a snowy effect (see Knowhow, below).

Halve the clementines, figs and kumquats, then arrange on top of the frosted cake with the physalis, frosted grapes and leaves. Fix a ribbon around the base and leave the cake somewhere cool – but not the fridge – until your guests arrive.
chief_review: This festive icing recipe offers a stunning, elegant finish—perfect for crowning a classic fruitcake as a Christmas centerpiece. The method of using egg whites for a snowy-sheen icing gives a refined texture that’s lighter than some traditional buttercream or royal icing. The addition of fresh fruits like black grapes, figs, kumquats, physalis, and clementines lends vibrant color and a touch of tartness, cutting through the sweetness and balancing the overall flavor profile. This recipe suits vegetarian diets, as it does not contain animal gelatin; however, be mindful of the use of egg whites. For those with gluten sensitivity, ensure the fruitcake underneath is gluten-free, as this recipe is only for the icing and decoration. All in all, a show-stopping, light, and fresh finale for any festive occasion.

name: Dundee cake
description: Tasty cake, but easy to overcook it.
author: Good Food
directions: Put the almonds into a small bowl and pour over boiling water to just cover. Leave for 5 mins then drain in a sieve and leave to dry.
Preheat the oven to 180C/160 C fan/Gas Mark 4. Line a deep loose-based 20cm cake tin with baking parchment.
Put the butter in a large bowl and beat well until soft. Add the sugar and beat until light and fluffy. Stir in the orange zest and apricot jam.

Sieve together the flour and baking powder. Add the eggs to the creamed butter and sugar, a little at a time, beating well between each addition. If the mixture starts to curdle, stir in a little flour.
Add the remaining flour and ground almonds and mix well. Mix in the milk and then add the dried fruit and cherries and mix gently together.
Spoon the mixture into the prepared tin and spread level using the back of a spoon. Arrange the whole almonds close together in neat circles on the top of the cake. Bake in the oven for 45 mins.

Lower the oven temperature to 160C/140 C fan/Gas Mark 3 and cook for a further 60–80 minutes. Check the cake after 50 minutes by inserting a wooden or metal skewer into the cake. When it’s done it should have just a few crumbs attached. Check every 10 minutes - it’s important not to overcook this cake so the centre will be a little soft.

When cooked, remove the cake briefly from the oven, put the milk and sugar into a small pan and heat gently until the sugar has dissolved. Brush over the top of the cake and return the cake to the oven for 2-3 mins. Remove and allow the cake to cool in the tin. When quite cold remove from the tin and wrap in foil and keep for at least 2 days before cutting.
chief_review: This delightful cake combines ground and blanched almonds with a generous helping of dried fruit and glacé cherries, offering a rich, moist crumb and a beautifully aromatic orange zest lift. The use of apricot jam adds an elegant, sweet glaze, complementing the muscovado sugar’s deep flavor. The key here is careful baking—easy to overcook, so keep a close eye and err on the side of caution for the perfect soft texture. With both ground almonds and flour, it’s not suitable for gluten-free diets, but it makes a wonderful treat for vegetarians, as there are no animal-derived ingredients apart from eggs and dairy. A fitting centerpiece for tea time, this cake rewards attention to detail and patience in baking.

name: Coronation turkey with homemade chapattis
description: A jar of homemade spicy mayo will brighten up your turkey leftovers - it makes a great sarnie filling too
author: Paul Merrett
ingredients: ½ tsp each ground cumin, ground coriander and turmeric
chopped tomato, sliced onion and lettuce leaves, to serve
350g wholemeal flour(or roti flour), plus extra for dusting
directions: Heat a saucepan and add a little vegetable oil. Fry the onion and garlic until both are lightly browned. Chuck in all the spices and let them sizzle for 1 min, then add the coconut milk and the stock. Allow this to reduce until you have a thick, rich, creamy, spicy onion mixture in the pan. Pour into a bowl, leave to cool, then stir through the mayonnaise. Can be kept in the fridge for up to a week.

To make the chapattis, put the flour and 1 tsp salt into a large bowl. Pour in the oil and rub into the flour with your fingertips. Pour in 250ml lukewarm water, mix to form a firm dough, then knead for about 10 mins until springy. Place back in the bowl and leave to rest for 30 mins. Cut into 8 walnut-size pieces and roll out into thin discs on a lightly floured surface. Pan-fry the discs in a dry heavy-based pan for about 1 min on each side. They should colour and blister – use a clean cloth to press flat in the pan while cooking.

To serve, mix the curried mayonnaise with the turkey. Toast the desiccated coconut in a dry pan until golden. Sprinkle over the turkey along with some coriander, then serve alongside the chapattis with some tomato, sliced onion and lettuce, if you like.
chief_review:
This inventive spicy mayo recipe breathes new life into turkey leftovers, delivering bold, aromatic flavors with a satisfying kick from curry powder, cumin, and coriander. The addition of coconut milk contributes both creaminess and subtle sweetness, while the mayonnaise base renders the sauce luxuriously smooth. Serve it with classic sandwich fixings like lettuce, tomato, and onion, and pair with homemade wholemeal rotis for a wholesome touch.

With its substantial protein from turkey and fiber from wholemeal flour, this dish is balanced and filling. The recipe is free from nuts, making it suitable for those with nut allergies, and provided a gluten-free flour blend is substituted for the wholemeal flour, it could be adapted for gluten-free diets. Overall, this versatile, flavor-packed mayo is an excellent condiment for sandwiches, wraps, or even as a dip for vegetable crudités.

name: Next level turkey & ham pie
description: Made this for Sunday dinner and it was fantastic - really delicious! I halved the recipe and used a ceramic pie dish instead of a spring form tin and it easily would have served 5-6 people (there was 4 of us and we all had a huge portion). I will definitely be making this again!
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: about 600g cooked turkey, breast meat carved into slices, brown meat chopped
about 600g cooked ham, carved into thick slices
2 leeks, cleaned, halved and finely sliced
500g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
directions: First, make the sauce. Heat the butter in a saucepan, add the leeks and thyme and cook very gently for 10-15 mins until soft but not coloured. Stir in the flour and cook to a sandy paste, then splash in the vinegar and bubble for a moment. Pour in the stock and bring to the boil, then add the cream and simmer until you have a thick sauce. Stir through the mustard, tarragon and chopped turkey, turn off the heat and leave to cool. Set aside.
To make the pastry, tip the flour into a

with the sage and 1 tsp salt. Add the butter and suet, and whizz to fine crumbs. With the motor running, slowly pour in 150ml cold water until the pastry just comes together. Tip onto a lightly floured surface and bring together into a dough. Cut just over a third of the pastry and cover while you roll out the rest to line an oiled 20cm springform tin, leaving an overhang.

Layer some sliced ham or turkey on the bottom, then spoon and spread over a thin layer of sauce and repeat the layers until you get to the top of the tin, finishing with a final layer of meat, then press down gently. Cut away another small ball of pastry from the remaining third.

the larger piece until big enough to cover the pie with an overhang. Brush the edge of the pie with egg yolk, then lift on the pastry lid and press the edges to seal before trimming. Crimp all the way round. Cut a little hole in the middle of the pastry to let steam escape. Brush all over with more yolk and use the last bit of pastry to decorate the top.

When you're ready to bake, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 with a baking sheet in it. Sit the pie on the hot sheet and bake for 45-50 mins. Leave until warm, remove from the tin and cut into thick wedges or cool and eat cold.
chief_review: This turkey and ham pie is a masterclass in hearty comfort cooking, perfect for a festive Sunday gathering. The generous mix of succulent turkey and ham is elevated by aromatic leeks, a hint of tarragon, and wholegrain mustard, all swaddled in an indulgent double cream sauce. The pastry, enriched with butter and suet, delivers a flaky, rustic crust that pairs beautifully with the rich filling. Use of both breast and brown meat highlights a resourceful approach to leftovers. This recipe suits those without specific dietary restrictions; it does contain gluten, dairy, eggs, and suet (which is not vegetarian). The balance of flavors with the subtle acidity of cider vinegar and depth from dried herbs enhances the dish’s complexity. Ideal for feeding a crowd, this pie brings both nostalgia and exceptional taste to the table—highly recommended for a family feast.

name: Marmalade glazed roast duck
description: it's Areet looking actually just doesn't taste very good.
author: Raymond Blanc
directions: Expose and cut out the wishbone. This makes the duck easier to carve once cooked. A butcher can do this for you.
Heat oven to 240C/220C fan/gas 9. Lightly score the skin on the duck all over, and make a deep cut from inside the body into each leg.
Season the duck well. Heat an ovenproof frying pan over a low heat. Place the duck on its side with the thigh touching the pan for 15 mins. Turn and cook on the other side for 15 mins more.
Turn the duck breast-side down, then transfer the pan to the oven and cook for 5 mins. Drain the fat from the pan, turn the duck onto its back and continue to cook for 15 minutes.

Remove the orange wedges from the pan and set aside. Squeeze the juice from the remaining orange halves into the hot pan and reduce by half. Add the marmalade, take off the heat, add 1 tbsp water and stir together.
After 15 mins of roasting, brush the marmalade glaze over and continue to roast for a final 10 mins. Rest for 20 mins.
Carve by cutting the leg and thigh away, then separating the leg from the thigh. Carve slices of breast and serve with the orange wedges to squeeze over.
chief_review: This oven-roasted duck accented with orange and Seville orange marmalade is visually striking, offering a golden, glossy finish that is sure to impress at the table. The simple ingredient list makes it accessible to most home cooks, and the pairing of rich duck with tangy citrus and sweet marmalade is a classic French-inspired combination. Suitable for gluten-free diets given the absence of wheat-based ingredients, and it can be enjoyed by those who do not consume dairy. However, the recipe’s success heavily depends on balancing the sweetness and bitterness of the marmalade with the fatty richness of the duck—overpowering sweetness or bitterness can detract from the overall flavor. Proper seasoning is crucial to elevate the dish and prevent it from tasting one-dimensional. With careful preparation, this recipe can be a showstopper main course for a festive dinner.

name: Red cabbage with beetroot
description: Add some colour and vitamins to your plate with this aromatic cabbage dish. Perfect with boiled Christmas ham
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1¼kg red cabbage, quartered, cored and thinly sliced
2 large onions, halved and thinly sliced
2 eating apples, such as Cox's, peeled quartered, cored and very thickly sliced
4 raw beetroot, peeled and cut into wedges
directions: 1 Mix the sugar with 1 tsp salt and plenty of black pepper. In a large, heavy-bottomed pan, layer up a handful of the cabbage, onions, apples and beetroot with the spices and sprinkle with some of the sugar, repeating with the layers until all the ingredients are used up.

Mix the wine, vinegar and stock cube, pour over the cabbage and dot the butter on top. Tightly cover the pan and bring to the boil over a medium heat. When you can hear it boiling, turn down the heat to low and simmer for 30 mins. Stir well – the mixture will have reduced and softened – then cover and simmer for 15-30 mins more depending on how soft you like it.
chief_review: This vibrant red cabbage dish is a delightful harmony of sweet, earthy, and aromatic notes—perfect as a festive accompaniment or a hearty side for any cool-weather meal. The combination of red cabbage, apples, beetroot, and a fragrant touch of cinnamon and star anise yields a rich, warming flavor profile, beautifully balanced by the depth of red wine and the subtle savory lift from a vegetable stock cube. The butter finish gives the dish a glossy, luscious texture without overpowering the natural sweetness of the vegetables. With no meat, dairy alternatives, or gluten-containing ingredients (assuming your stock cube is gluten-free), this recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians and those seeking gluten-free options. The absence of nuts, eggs, and major allergens further broadens its appeal. A visually striking and nourishing addition to any table!

name: Smoked salmon with horseradish crème fraîche & beetroot
description: This speedy salad can be whipped up as an impressive starter - the fish is completely lifted by contrasting flavours
author: Good Food
ingredients: 250g pack cooked beetroot(not in vinegar), finely diced
directions: Fold the crème fraîche with the horseradish and vodka, if using, with a little seasoning. Chill.
In a bowl, mix the vinegar, olive oil and honey. Toss half the dressing through the beetroot and chill until ready to serve.

Before serving, divide the slices of salmon between 8 plates, then top with a spoonful of the crème fraîche and bring up the sides of the salmon to make a ‘flower’. Arrange the salad and beetroot round the salmon, scatter with the dill. Grind over some black pepper, drizzle with the remaining dressing and serve with toast, if you like.
chief_review: This vibrant salad delivers a sophisticated mix of flavors and textures, making it an enticing starter for any dinner party. The creamy, tangy blend of crème fraîche and horseradish sauce perfectly complements the delicate smokiness of the salmon, while diced beetroot and crisp chicory provide freshness and crunch. A touch of vodka and honey balances the acidity from white wine vinegar, creating a harmonious dressing. Baby rocket and dill add peppery and aromatic notes, enhancing the dish’s complexity. The inclusion of smoked salmon and dairy means this recipe is ideal for pescatarians. Serve with toast fingers for added texture, or omit for a gluten-free option. Overall, it’s a quick, visually impressive appetizer that celebrates contrasting flavors and elevated simplicity.

name: Chestnut & bacon cake
description: Festive, flavoursome and filling, this chestnut and bacon stuffing is a winner
author: Good Food
ingredients: 8 smoked, dry-cured streaky bacon rashers, chopped
200g vacuum-packed chestnut, most roughly chopped, plus 100g more for the top, halved, if you like
450g pack good-quality pork sausage, meat squeezed out
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Heat the oil in a large frying pan, then fry the onions and two-thirds of the bacon, covered, for 10 mins until the onions are very soft. Once cool enough to handle, mix with the chopped chestnuts, sausagemeat, breadcrumbs, thyme leaves and egg, and season really well. Take out 250g for stuffing the turkey.
Butter a 23cm round tin, scoop in the remaining stuffing, press down a little, then top with the remaining bacon. Put onto a baking sheet, cover with foil and bake for 15 mins.

Uncover, grind over some fresh black pepper, then cook for 35 mins more until the bacon is turning golden. With 5 mins to go, top with the chestnut halves, if you like, brushing them with a little butter. Cut into wedges to serve.
chief_review: This chestnut and bacon stuffing delivers a classic combination of rich, smoky bacon and earthy chestnuts, elevated by aromatic thyme and the subtle sweetness of onions. The use of quality pork sausage guarantees savoury depth, while the egg and breadcrumbs bind the mixture into a moist, hearty consistency. The additional whole chestnuts on top provide a delightful texture contrast and holiday flair. Sunflower oil and melted butter add just the right amount of richness. Ideal for festive occasions, this recipe is perfect for those on a traditional diet, and will be especially appreciated as a luxurious side dish to roasted poultry or seasonal mains. Its robust flavours and satisfying balance of crunch and tenderness make it a standout stuffing for any celebratory table.

name: Caramelised passion fruit & lime tart
description:
This tart is absolutely delicious! I made the pastry from scratch with some sesame and poppy seeds - the texture of the pastry went perfectly with the passionfruit custard. Also reduced the sugar and thicken cream so that it would be healthier. Click on the link below for the recipe
http://tableforting.com/2015/03/31/passionfruit-lemon-tart/
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: finely grated zest and juice of 1 lime
directions: Roll out the pastry and use it to line a 23cm tart ring, then chill for at least 20 mins. Heat oven to 180C/fan160C/gas 4. Line the tart with baking parchment and baking beans, then bake for 15 mins. Remove the parchment, bake for a further 5-10 mins until golden, then remove from the oven and reduce the temperature to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1.

While the case is cooking, cut the passion fruits in half, scoop out the flesh into a bowl, then blitz with a hand blender. Push the pulp through sieve and mix the juice with the lime zest and juice. Beat the sugar and yolks together until pale, then beat in the cream and fruit juice. Carefully pour the custard into the tart case, then bake for 40 mins, until set with a very slight wobble. Remove the tart from the oven, then leave to cool completely.
You can now either serve the tart as it is, or try a chef’s tip and dust it with icing sugar, then caramelise the top with a blowtorch.
chief_review: This Passionfruit-Lemon Tart offers a delightful combination of crisp, seed-speckled pastry and a tangy, creamy custard. The addition of sesame and poppy seeds to the homemade pastry is a creative touch, adding both nutty flavor and extra texture. The passionfruit-lime custard is refreshingly tart, nicely balanced by a moderate sweetness, especially with the reduced sugar and cream for a lighter finish. The recipe relies on egg yolks and double cream, making it suitable for vegetarians, but not for vegans or those with dairy or egg allergies. The pre-made dessert pastry, if using traditional wheat flour, contains gluten, so take note for gluten-intolerant guests. Overall, this tart is a vibrant, elegant dessert ideal for occasions when a citrusy, less-sweet treat is called for.

name: Salmon & herby potato coulibiacs
description: An impressive addition to any buffet, this puff pastry parcel is filled with fish in a creamy parsley, dill and lemon sauce
author: John Torode
ingredients: 650g side of salmon, skinned and pin-boned, cut crossways into 3cm slices, then cut in half lengthways to get thick fingers
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Par-boil the potato slices for 2-3 mins. Drain and set aside in a large bowl.

Gently fry the onion in the oil for 10 mins until lightly golden. Cool slightly, then stir in the cream, crème fraîche, herbs, zest and plenty of seasoning. Pour over the potatoes and mix very gently.

Roll out one pack of pastry on a lightly floured surface to a 35 x 35cm, then lay on a large baking sheet. Pack ¼ of the potato mixture down one side of the pastry, leaving a 5cm border. Arrange ½ of the salmon on top to cover the potato. Cover the salmon with ¼ of the potato. Brush the pastry all the way round with beaten egg and fold over the pastry. Trim the edges and crimp with your fingers, or seal with a fork. Make decorative fish for the top, if you like.
Roll out the remaining pastry and repeat the process, using up the rest of the potato and salmon. Chill for 30 mins.
Brush the pastries all over with beaten egg. Bake for 40 mins. Leave to rest for 10 mins if serving hot, or serve cold.
chief_review:
This puff pastry parcel showcases a luxurious medley of salmon enveloped in a flaky, golden all-butter crust. The filling impresses with its harmonious blend of tender potatoes, sweet onions, and succulent fish, all brought together by a velvety sauce infused with crème fraîche, double cream, fresh parsley, dill, and a bright lift from lemon zest. The result is a dish with balanced richness and herbaceous freshness, beautifully suited as a centerpiece for festive gatherings.

For dietary considerations, this recipe is an excellent option for pescatarians, as it features fish as the main protein and omits meat or poultry. It’s important to note that with its inclusion of dairy-rich ingredients and all-butter pastry, it is not appropriate for vegan or dairy-free diners. The hefty use of all-butter puff pastry also makes it unsuitable for those following gluten-free diets.

name: Gratin of carrots & root vegetables
description: Serve as a tasty side for your favourite meat dish or as an impressive vegetarian main.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 500g waxy potatoes (we used Desirée), sliced wafer thin
directions: Preheat the oven to 180C/gas 4/fan 160C and butter a shallow ovenproof dish. Layer the potatoes, then the parsnip in the bottom of the dish with two of the sliced garlic cloves and sprinkle over a little salt and half the rosemary. It’s best to keep the potatoes buried under the other vegetables because they go black if they are on top of the gratin.

Pour the cream and milk into a large saucepan, add the rest of the rosemary and garlic, the carrots and a little seasoning. Bring to the boil, then turn the heat to the lowest it will go and simmer for 3 minutes.

Pour the carrots and cream over the other vegetables, and spread the carrots out. Sprinkle over the parmesan, cover with foil and bake for 40 minutes. Remove the foil and bake a further 20 minutes until golden and bubbly.
chief_review: This gratin-style dish is a delightful tribute to root vegetables, harmonizing the earthy flavors of potatoes, parsnips, and carrots. The addition of fresh rosemary and abundant garlic brings aromatic depth, while the double cream and full-fat milk render an irresistibly rich and velvety texture. Parmesan cheese adds a golden, savory crust. Perfectly suited for a vegetarian audience—provided the parmesan is made with vegetarian rennet—this recipe delivers both comfort and sophistication. The thin slicing of the vegetables ensures a uniform, tender bake, allowing the flavors to meld beautifully. Ideal as an impressive main course for vegetarians or a satisfying side with roasted meats, this dish stands out for its classic technique and balanced seasoning. Serve hot, garnished with a touch more fresh herbs, and enjoy its simple elegance.

name: Brown butter new potatoes
description: Roast your new season baby potatoes with golden butter until crisp. Flavour with bay leaves and serve as an accompaniment
author: James Martin
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, add potatoes and bay leaves, bring back to the boil and simmer for 10-12 mins until just tender.

Drain the potatoes and leave to steam in a colander. Return the pan to the heat, add butter and melt gently until it turns a nutty brown colour. Remove from the heat, stir through the potatoes (don’t worry if a few break up) and bay leaves, and leave to absorb for a few mins.

Meanwhile, heat a roasting tin in the oven, tip the potatoes in and season well. Roast for 30-35 mins until golden and crisp, turning and basting halfway through. Transfer to a dish and pour over any buttery juices from the tin.
chief_review: This recipe highlights the simple pleasure of new season baby potatoes roasted in rich, golden butter and delicately infused with bay leaves. The method allows the creamy texture of the potatoes to shine, with the butter lending a deep, nutty flavor while the bay leaves provide a subtle aromatic lift. Ideal as a versatile side dish, this preparation works beautifully with roasted meats or as an elegant addition to a vegetarian spread. The ingredients used here are naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. The straightforward technique ensures crisp edges and fluffy centers, celebrating the natural sweetness of freshly harvested potatoes. Overall, it’s a classic approach that allows top-quality ingredients to do the talking—a hallmark of great cookery.

name: Chicory & hummus bites
description: I make this as part of my pack lunch. I spread the houmous between two slices of wholemeal bread, and place the salad in a container, to give myself the option of sarnies or salad. Also as I work in an airport houmous on it's own is not allowed, as it is considered a liquid.
author: Merrilees Parker
directions: Up to 2 hrs ahead, separate the chicory into boat-shaped leaves and trim the ends so that they are all roughly the same size. You will probably get about eight or nine decent-sized leaves from each head of chicory. As the leaves get closer to the heart of the chicory, they will be too small to use for canapés, so save them to add to wintry salads.
Peel the carrot, then keep peeling off strips until you have as many as the number of chicory leaves.
Drop spoonfuls of hummus onto the chicory, then add a carrot curl and an olive to each. They’ll keep in the fridge for about 2 hours.
chief_review: This lunch recipe is a clever, nutritious solution for busy days, pairing the creamy richness of hummus with crunchy chicory, sweet carrots, and briny olives. The use of wholemeal bread introduces a wholesome, fiber-rich base, and the fresh salad ingredients keep things light and refreshing. The dish is naturally vegetarian and, provided the hummus is made without dairy, it's often suitable for vegans too. Additionally, with no obvious sources of common allergens like eggs or dairy, it can accommodate certain food sensitivities (though always check the hummus and bread ingredients for hidden allergens). This combination provides a balanced meal—ample protein from the hummus, a mix of vitamins and fiber from the vegetables, and healthy fats from olives. Overall, this is a practical, flavorful choice for anyone seeking a plant-based, convenient lunch.

name: Cucumber pappardelle
description: Gordon Ramsay shows how to make a light, elegant side dish
author: Gordon Ramsay
directions: Using a swivel vegetable peeler, remove the skin from a large, straight cucumber. Then cut long, thin strips of flesh using the same peeler, like flat noodles. Mix in a bowl with seasoning and a light sprinkling of rice wine vinegar.
chief_review: This recipe is a masterclass in simplicity, highlighting the crisp freshness of cucumber with the subtle tang of rice wine vinegar. The minimalistic approach lets the natural flavors shine, creating an elegant accompaniment to a variety of main dishes. The preparation is swift, requiring just a quick slice and toss, making it ideal for busy kitchens or as a last-minute addition to your table. This dish is perfectly suited for vegan and vegetarian diets, free from gluten, dairy, soy, and common allergens, making it an inclusive option for most guests. The light acidity of the vinegar balances the cucumber’s coolness, offering a palate-cleansing effect that elevates heavier courses. A sprinkle of fresh herbs, if desired, could further enhance its appeal without compromising dietary preferences. An outstanding example of how restraint in ingredients can produce a refined and refreshing dish.

name: Spiced roast beef
description: Made this twice now for dinner parties never had any leftover for sandwiches as everybody has loved it that much.really easy to make too
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: 2kg-3kg (4lb 8oz-6lb 8oz) topside joint of beef- depending on the amount of leftovers you want
directions: Combine all the spices and ½ tbsp salt together in a pestle and mortar. Give everything a good grind, keeping a little of its coarseness. Rub the oil and then the ground spices all over the beef and massage in well. Cover and chill overnight to marinate.

Next day, heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Weigh your joint and roast for 10 mins per 450g for rare meat and 15 mins per 450g for medium, plus an extra 20 mins. Cover and rest for 20 mins while you finish the salads, then slice and serve. Alternatively, roast the beef in the morning and serve at room temperature for dinner.
chief_review: This beef joint recipe is a delightful centrepiece, with aromatic notes from juniper, coriander, allspice, and black pepper beautifully infusing the beef during roasting. The simplicity of the spice rub and olive oil allows the quality of the meat to shine, providing a richly flavoured, succulent roast ideal for dinner parties. Its straightforward preparation makes it accessible even for home cooks new to large roasts. The absence of dairy, gluten, or eggs means this dish can comfortably fit into gluten-free and dairy-free diets, provided the beef is not processed or marinated with hidden allergens. While the portioning allows for impressive servings and generous leftovers, don’t expect any—this recipe’s crowd-pleasing appeal will have guests coming back for seconds. An effortlessly impressive classic.

name: Three-in-one braised vegetables
description: This dish is so handy - while the veg cook, you're making a tasty stock for the gravy, too
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 2 large carrots, sliced on the diagonal
directions: Tip the sprouts and carrots into a pan and cover with boiling water. Sprinkle in the stock cube, add the butter and bring to the boil.
Simmer for 8-10 mins until the veg are tender. Add peas and cook a few mins more.
Rest the veg in the stock until you want to make the gravy, then drain over the roasting tin.
chief_review: This recipe offers a quick and convenient way to enjoy a medley of vegetables, with the added depth of a homemade gravy made from chicken stock. The combination of Brussels sprouts, carrots, and peas results in a vibrant, colorful side dish that retains a pleasant crunch and loads of fresh flavor. The butter adds a satisfying richness, tying the vegetables together beautifully. Thanks to its use of only plant-based vegetables (excluding the chicken stock), this dish is naturally gluten-free, provided you use a gluten-free chicken stock cube. It’s also a good choice for those avoiding nuts and soy, assuming standard allergen-free butter and stock cube are used. Whether as an accompaniment or a light main, this recipe balances nutrition, simplicity, and flavor.

name: Spring greens with bacon
description: Combine rich greens with salty bacon and a little nutmeg to make a versatile side dish
author: James Martin
directions: Bring a large pan of water to the boil, add spring greens and cook for about 5 mins until tender, then drain well.
Meanwhile, heat a non-stick frying pan, add bacon and cook until crisp. Tip in the greens, toss and warm through. Grate over nutmeg, season, and serve.
chief_review: This recipe masterfully brings together the earthy freshness of spring greens with the savory depth of smoked bacon, all elevated by a hint of aromatic nutmeg. The greens retain a satisfying bite, providing a pleasing contrast to the crisp, salty morsels of bacon. The nutmeg adds a subtle warmth, enhancing the overall complexity without overpowering the dish. This side is both versatile and crowd-pleasing, complementing roasted meats or fish beautifully. It's particularly suitable for gluten-free diets, as none of the ingredients contain gluten. The balance of flavors and straightforward preparation make it ideal for weeknight dinners or special occasions alike.

name: Parmesan, poppy seed & caraway twists
description: These vegetarian and gluten-free twists are perfect to serve with festive drinks
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g gluten-free flour (we used Doves Farm, widely available)
1 egg yolk mixed with 3 tbsp cold water
3 tbsp freshly grated parmesan(or vegetarian alternative)
1 tbsp each poppy seeds and caraway seeds
directions: To make the pastry, put the flour, butter and cayenne pepper into a food processor, then whizz into fine breadcrumbs. sprinkle the egg and water mixture onto the flour, then pulse again until the mixture begins to come together. tip the mixture onto a board and gently squeeze the pastry until it begins to come together in a ball, adding more water if it feels dry.
