Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. roll the pastry into a large a4-sized rectangle, roughly 20 x 30cm. Brush the sheet with the beaten egg and cut in half widthways. Sprinkle one half with the Parmesan and the second half with poppy and caraway seeds. lightly run the rolling pin across the top to press the cheese and the seeds into the pastry. Cut each half into 12-15 sticks. arrange on a baking sheet and chill for 10 mins.
Bake for 8-10 mins until golden brown, then cool for 5 mins before lifting onto a wire rack.
chief_review: These twists are a delightful addition to any festive gathering, with a golden, crisp texture and a subtle hint of spice from the cayenne pepper. The combination of gluten-free flour and butter results in a tender, rich dough, while the egg wash ensures a glossy finish. Parmesan adds a savory depth—using a vegetarian cheese keeps the recipe suitable for vegetarians. The duo of poppy and caraway seeds provides an aromatic crunch, elevating the overall flavor profile. Perfect alongside drinks, they cater to both gluten-free and vegetarian diners.

name: Speedy spicy turkey rice
description: Put your leftover Christmas turkey and ham to good use with this super fast egg-fried rice
author: Good Food
ingredients: 300g cold cooked rice(or use a pouch of straight-to-wok rice)
2 tbsp each soy sauceand sweet chilli sauce, plus extra to serve
directions: Heat half the oil in a wok or frying pan. Add the eggs, swirl to coat the base of the pan and allow to set to an omelette, flip and cook for 1-2 mins. Once cooked, remove, shred and set aside. Add the remaining oil to the pan, then stir-fry the chilli, if using, and spring onions for 1 min.
Add the remaining ingredients and the egg, and heat through, stirring, until piping hot. Serve immediately with some extra soy and sweet chilli sauce, if you like.
chief_review: This quick egg-fried rice recipe ingeniously transforms leftover Christmas turkey and ham into a vibrant, satisfying dish. The combination of sesame oil, eggs, and a splash of soy and sweet chilli sauce imbues the rice with classic, umami-packed flavors, while the peas and spring onions brighten the profile. Using pre-cooked rice keeps the texture appealingly fluffy, and the optional red chilli adds a gentle heat for those who like a kick. The recipe is well-suited for anyone looking to repurpose holiday leftovers in a new, fuss-free way. Note for those with dietary needs: as written, this dish contains eggs, gluten (from soy sauce), and is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. For a gluten-free or vegetarian twist, easily substitute tamari and omit the ham and turkey. Overall, it’s a flavorful, efficient mid-week meal with plenty of room for customization.

name: Celeriac soup with scallops & black pudding
description: For a show-stopping dinner party, James Martin recommends this peppery soup, topped with luxurious seafood
author: James Martin
ingredients: 1 celeriac(about 1kg/2lb 4oz), peeled and cut into cubes
100g black pudding, crumbled into small pieces
12 scallops, coral removed, each halved into 2 discs
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan over a medium heat and add the celeriac, shallots and garlic. Gently fry for a few mins, until they soften without colouring. Add the white wine, bring everything to the boil and reduce the liquid by half. Add the chicken stock and nutmeg, bring to the boil again, then reduce the heat and simmer for 10-15 mins or until celeriac is tender. Remove from the heat and cool for 5 mins.

Transfer the soup to a food processor and blend until smooth. Pour the soup back into the pan, add the cream and generously season with salt and freshly ground pepper. Reheat gently while you finish everything else.
In a large frying pan, fry the black pudding until crisp. Set aside on kitchen paper to soak up any fat. Wipe out the pan.

Season the scallops. Heat the frying pan again until hot and add the butter. When it is foaming, add the scallops and sear for 1 min on each side, or until just cooked through, then place on a warm plate. To serve, pour the soup into 8 bowls, top each with 3 scallops and sprinkle with black pudding.
chief_review: This celeriac and scallop soup is a luxurious, restaurant-worthy dish perfect for impressing guests. The earthy celeriac and aromatic shallots create a velvety base, enriched with double cream and a gentle touch of nutmeg. The addition of white wine adds depth, while the chicken stock maintains classic savory notes. Black pudding contributes a robust, peppery accent that pairs unexpectedly well with tender, buttery scallops. The dish is suitable for a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain gluten, but be sure to verify the black pudding's label as some brands may use fillers. This recipe is ideal for seafood lovers who appreciate sophisticated flavors and textures. Serve piping hot for the ultimate dinner party centerpiece.

name: Prawn & fennel bisque
description: The end result is wonderful but no way this should be classified as 'easy'. It's the most effortful recipe I've ever done from Good Food and I've done a few 'more effort' ones.
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 450g raw tiger prawn in their shells
1 large fennel bulb, chopped, fronds reserved
8 tiger prawns, shelled, but tail tips left on (optional)
directions: Shell the prawns, then fry the shells in the oil in a large pan for about 5 mins. Add the onion, fennel and carrots and cook for about 10 mins until the veg start to soften. Pour in the wine and brandy, bubble hard for about 1 min to drive off the alcohol, then add the tomatoes, stock and paprika. Cover and simmer for 30 mins. Meanwhile, chop the prawns.

Blitz the soup as finely as you can with a stick blender or food processor, then press through a sieve into a bowl. Spend a bit of time really working the mixture through the sieve as this will give the soup its velvety texture.

Tip back into a clean pan, add the prawns and cook for 10 mins, then blitz again until smooth. You can make and chill this a day ahead or freeze it for 1 month. Thaw ovenight in the fridge. To serve, gently reheat in a pan with the cream. If garnishing, cook the 8 prawns in a little butter. Spoon into small bowls and top with the prawns and snipped fennel fronds.
chief_review: This seafood recipe delivers an impressively rich and layered flavor profile, testament to the deep, methodical cooking process. The use of tiger prawns in their shells, along with aromatic vegetables, builds a nuanced base that pairs beautifully with white wine and a splash of brandy. Cream adds a velvety finish, complementing the sweet prawn essence and fennel. While outstanding in result, this dish requires advanced prep and plenty of patience—definitely for an experienced home cook or a gastronomic enthusiast. The ingredient list makes it a luxurious option for pescatarians but is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans. Additionally, it is naturally gluten-free, provided care is taken with the brand of fish stock. Expect a refined, restaurant-quality seafood soup that’s perfect for impressing at special occasions.

name: Cauliflower & chestnut soup
description: This creamy, vegetarian soup, from Becky Lovatt, is a great way to use up leftover chestnuts, or use freshly roasted chestnuts for a more intense flavour
author: Good Food
ingredients: ½ tbsp olive oil, plus a drizzle to serve
25g grated parmesanor vegetarian alternative, to serve
directions: Heat the oil in a large saucepan and add the onion. Cook over a gentle heat for 8-10 mins until the onion softens. Add the cauliflower, milk and stock. Bring to a simmer, cooking for 10-12 mins until the cauliflower is tender.

Add the cream, season well and bring back to the boil. Take off the heat, throw in the chestnuts and blend with a hand blender until smooth. Taste and add more seasoning, if you like. To serve, top with shaved Parmesan, black pepper and a drizzle of olive oil.
chief_review: Becky Lovatt’s creamy chestnut and cauliflower soup is a wonderfully comforting dish, perfect for utilizing leftover or freshly roasted chestnuts. The recipe’s base of olive oil, onion, and cauliflower yields a velvety texture, complemented by richness from double cream and a gentle depth from vegetable stock. Chestnuts add a naturally sweet, nutty undertone that harmonizes beautifully with the freshness of cauliflower. Finished with a flourish of grated Parmesan (or a vegetarian alternative) and a drizzle of olive oil, this soup is ideal for vegetarians and those seeking a nut-forward, hearty starter. The absence of meat or fish ensures it fits well within a vegetarian diet, provided the Parmesan used is strictly vegetarian. Serve warm for a perfect autumn or winter dish—simple, elegant, and bursting with seasonal flavor.

name: Triple cheese & bacon Dauphinoise
description: Smoked bacon and a triple hit of gooey, melted cheese takes this classic dish of layered potatoes and double cream to the next level of indulgence - a showstopping side for a dinner party
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: 6 large (about 900g) Maris Piper potatoes, thinly sliced (use a mandolin if you have one)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and grease a shallow baking dish with butter (I used a 20 x 30cm dish). Pour the milk and cream into a large saucepan, add the garlic, tip in the potatoes and bring to the boil. Remove from the heat to let the garlic infuse and the potatoes cool a little while you cook the bacon.
Heat the oil in a frying pan and add the lardons. Cook on a low-medium heat for 10 mins until they are turning crispy.

Using a slotted spoon, start layering the potatoes onto the base of the dish until completely covered (remove the garlic cloves when you spot them). Spoon over some of the cream mixture, a little cheddar, Parmesan and Gruyère, and scatter on some of the bacon. Season well and repeat until you have used up all the potato. Pour over any remaining cream and scatter with the remaining cheese. Reserve some of the bacon for topping later.

Cover with foil and cook in the oven for 1 hr. Remove the foil and cook for a further 30 mins until the potatoes are cooked through (insert a skewer or knife and check there is no resistance) and the topping is golden. Scatter with the remaining bacon for the final 5 mins of cooking.
chief_review: This indulgent take on a classic gratin dauphinoise dazzles with layers of thinly sliced Maris Piper potatoes enveloped in a luxurious blend of semi-skimmed milk and double cream. The trio of cheddar, parmesan, and Gruyère guarantees a luscious, melty interior with a rich, deeply satisfying flavor profile. Smoky bacon lardons add a punch of umami and a pleasing textural contrast. Garlic infuses aromatic warmth throughout the dish, tying all the elements together beautifully. This recipe is particularly well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as it contains no wheat-based ingredients. Perfect as a showstopping side for a dinner party, this gratin promises both comfort and decadence in every bite.

name: Easter puddings
description: These cute oven-steamed puds with nutmeg custard are almost like blonde Christmas puddings
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Butter 6 individual puddings basins or dariole moulds and line the bottom of each with a small circle of baking parchment. Sit them in a deep roasting tin and boil the kettle.

Place the butter, flour, sugar and zests and eggs into a bowl with a pinch of salt. Whisk with an electric hand whisk until just combined. Stir in the dried fruit, then divide between the moulds. Carefully pour hot water from the kettle into the tin until it comes about one-third to halfway up the sides of the moulds. Bake for 25-30 mins until a skewer pushed in comes out clean. Serve straight away. If making ahead, leave the puds to cool, cover for up to a day, then turn out of the moulds into a microwave-proof dish and microwave, three at a time, for 1-2 mins on High until hot. Turn out the puddings, pour over some of the Nutmeg custard (see recipe, below) and add a grating of nutmeg, if you like.
chief_review: This delightful oven-steamed pudding is a charming twist on classic Christmas fare, delivering a light, moist crumb thanks to a well-balanced ratio of butter, eggs, and flour. The addition of lemon and orange zest provides a fragrant lift, harmonizing beautifully with bursts of glacé cherries, sultanas, currants, and mixed peel. The gentle grating of nutmeg atop the rich, homemade custard brings warmth and depth, evoking nostalgic holiday notes. The recipe is best suited for vegetarians, containing no meat or gelatin. However, those with egg, dairy, or wheat allergies should be aware of potential allergens. Serve these elegant puds with a generous ladle of nutmeg custard for an irresistibly festive dessert—perfect for winter gatherings or a yuletide afternoon tea.

name: Sesame beef wraps
description: The perfect Asian-inspired pre-dinner nibble, perfect for a Christmas get-together with friends
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 175g beef steak, cut into thin strips
1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced
2cm piece fresh root ginger, thinly sliced and cut into matchsticks
directions: Heat oil in a large frying pan. When the pan is really hot, tip in the beef and pepper, then cook for a few mins until lightly browned and the beef is cooked through. Tip in the garlic, ginger and sesame seeds, then cook for 1-2 mins more, stirring often until they start to turn golden.

Pour over the soy sauce and 2 tbsp water, let it bubble down a bit until it starts to look syrupy, then drizzle with the sesame oil. Separate the leaves from the lettuces and arrange on a plate. Spoon a little of the beef mixture into each leaf, drizzle with pan juices and serve warm.
chief_review: This Asian-inspired beef and vegetable lettuce wrap is a fresh, vibrant starter, ideal for any festive gathering. The thinly sliced beef caramelizes beautifully in the sesame oil, and mingles with fresh ginger, garlic, and sweet red pepper for a punchy, aromatic filling. Soy sauce adds umami depth, while toasted sesame seeds offer a final nutty crunch. Presentation in crisp Baby Gem lettuce leaves provides a cool, refreshing contrast—a clever touch reminiscent of classic Asian appetizers. This recipe is suitable for gluten-free diets if a gluten-free soy sauce is used and is naturally dairy-free. Those avoiding nuts or eggs will also find it accommodating. Quick to prepare and brimming with flavor, it’s a stylish, interactive nibble that will brighten any holiday table.

name: Potatoes cooked in bay-infused milk
description: The ultimate Sunday lunch side dish, these creamy potatoes add a powerful herbal note to the table
author: Matt Tebbutt
ingredients: 1kg small salad potato, scrubbed of their skins
directions: Melt the butter in a large saucepan and throw in the potatoes and some seasoning. Colour gently all over for 10 mins or so.

When the potatoes are nicely golden, add the bay leaves and milk, making sure potatoes are covered. Gently simmer for 20 mins until the potatoes are cooked through. Turn off the heat and leave to infuse in the milk until ready to serve. Drain and serve.
chief_review: This creamy potato side dish is a classic example of comfort food elevated by simple yet impactful flavors. The use of full-fat milk and a generous amount of salted butter creates an unctuous base, perfectly coating the tender salad potatoes. Bay leaves add a sophisticated, herbal aroma that cuts through the richness for a balanced bite. The absence of flour, breadcrumbs, or other wheat-based thickeners makes this recipe naturally gluten-free, and it’s an excellent choice for a vegetarian table. It’s ideal alongside roasted meats or as the star of a hearty vegetarian spread. The minimal list of ingredients also makes it safe for those avoiding egg and nut allergens. A straightforward yet impressive addition to any Sunday lunch.

name: Moroccan-spiced turkey pie
description: Transform leftover turkey in this spiced filo pastry parcel, inspired by a Moroccan pastilla - a perfect main course for Boxing Day
author: Chelsie Collins
ingredients: 2 peppers(any colours will do), deseeded and diced
500g leftover turkey(a mix of leg and breast is best), chopped
100g butter, melted, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat a large non-stick pan over a medium heat and toast the coriander and cumin seeds for 1-2 mins until fragrant. Add the cinnamon, olive oil, aubergine and shallots. Coat the veg in the spices and cook on a medium-low heat for about 10 mins until the aubergine has softened slightly.

Add the harissa and peppers. Give everything a good stir, then add the tomatoes and crumble over the stock cube. Simmer, uncovered, for 20 mins until the veg is tender and the mixture is nice and thick.
Stir through the turkey meat and season well. Set aside to cool.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and grease a 23cm springform tin with a little butter. Lay two sheets of filo over the base of the tin and brush with the melted butter. Cross over another two layers of filo and brush again with butter. Repeat once more, then put the cooled filling in the centre. Using the remaining four pastry sheets, cover the filling and brush with more melted butter. Scrunch the top of the pie together and bake for 30-35 mins.
Remove from the oven and scatter the pie with the flaked almonds. Cook for a final 10 mins until the pie is golden and piping hot. Serve straight away.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful way to reinvent leftover turkey, blending Moroccan flavors with the crisp, buttery texture of filo pastry. Toasted coriander and cumin deliver earthy spice, while harissa and cinnamon add complexity and warmth, complementing the diced aubergine and peppers beautifully. The addition of flaked almonds provides a pleasing crunch and a touch of sweetness—a clever nod to the classic pastilla. The use of a chicken stock cube and filo pastry means this dish is not suitable for gluten-free or vegetarian diets, but it’s a highlight for those who enjoy bold, aromatic main courses. Serve it as the centerpiece for Boxing Day—its fragrant filling and golden pastry are sure to impress and make the most of those festive leftovers.

name: Chocolate pudding with spiced berry syrup
description: James Martin serves his steamed chocolate sponge with whole cherries and a fruity sauce - perfect for a smart dinner party
author: James Martin
ingredients: 85g softened butter, plus extra for greasing
½ x 400g can pitted cherriesin syrup, drained
directions: Butter a 1lb pudding basin, then line the base with a circle of greaseproof paper. To prepare the steamer, place an upturned saucer into a large saucepan big enough to fit the pudding basin. This will act as a trivet to stop the base of the pudding coming into direct contact with the heat. Put the kettle on.

In a bowl, beat the butter and sugar until light and creamy. Slowly add the beaten eggs, mixing well between each addition. Add the vanilla and melted chocolate and mix everything well. Sieve the cocoa, flour and baking powder into the mixture, then fold in the ground almonds, milk and chocolate buttons.

Fill the pudding basin with the mixture. Cut out large circles of greaseproof paper and tin foil, big enough to fit over the basin with a 2-in overhang. Lightly butter the greaseproof and lay this on top of the foil, buttered side up. Make a pleat down the centre of the two, then place, paper side down, over the pudding. Turn the foil under to cover the paper. Secure well with string and lower the pudding into the steamer. Add enough boiling water from the kettle to come halfway up the basin but not touch the paper. Cover with a lid and turn the heat down to a gentle simmer.
After 1 hr 15 mins, remove the lid and check the pudding is cooked by inserting a metal skewer. There should be no raw cake mixture on the skewer.
Meanwhile, bubble the orange juice, jam, star anise and dried fruit together until syrupy. Stir in the maraschino and canned cherries.

Carefully turn the pudding out on to a serving plate. Pile some fruit from the sauce on top plus the star anise to decorate, then spoon over some warm syrup. Pour the remaining syrup into a jug and serve alongside.
chief_review: James Martin’s steamed chocolate sponge is an opulent dessert, perfect for impressing guests at a dinner party. The sponge is rich and moist, thanks to dark muscovado sugar and ground almonds, with an added depth of flavor from melted chocolate and cocoa. The inclusion of whole cherries, both dried and maraschino, punctuates each bite with bursts of fruitiness, while the raspberry and orange sauce, infused with star anise, offers a sophisticated, aromatic touch. The texture is luxurious—light yet substantial, complementing the silky sauce and tender cherries beautifully. This recipe contains flour, eggs, dairy, almonds, and chocolate, making it suitable for vegetarians and those who appreciate classic European desserts. Overall, it’s a show-stopping pudding that balances richness and fruit with finesse.

name: Squash, feta & pine nut tart
description: Ready-made puff pastry makes it easy to go meat free - top with spicy harissa paste, salty cheese, sweet pumpkin and mint
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: a little plain flour, for dusting
½ butternut squash, peeled, deseeded and very thinly sliced
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put a large baking tray on the middle shelf to heat up. On a floured surface, roll out the pastry to a 30cm square. Trim the edges, lightly score a 1cm border around the edge of the tart, and prick the centre all over with a fork. Transfer the pastry base to a sheet of baking parchment.
Mix the chutney and harissa, and spread over the middle of the pastry. Arrange the squash in one layer over the top, then season. Put the tart on the hot baking tray and bake for 30 mins.
Remove the tart, scatter over the feta and pine nuts, and bake for 20 mins more. Scatter over the mint and rocket to serve.
chief_review: This vibrant tart brilliantly combines the sweetness of butternut squash with the bold flavors of harissa and salty feta, all atop a flaky, golden puff pastry base. The addition of onion chutney provides a rich depth and subtle tang, while pine nuts add welcome texture and nuttiness. Fresh mint and rocket leaves lend brightness and a peppery finish, rounding out the dish. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians, offering a hearty main or impressive side. Just be mindful that store-bought puff pastry can contain butter, so check labels if you're cooking for vegans. Altogether, it's an easy-to-prepare yet elegant vegetarian centerpiece, with a satisfying blend of spicy, sweet, and salty tastes that highlight seasonal flavors.

name: Spinach & ricotta slice
description: Both vegetarians and non-veggies will love this puff pastry parcel with Italian cheese - great as a buffet centrepiece
author: John Torode
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Melt half the butter with the oil in a sauté pan. Add the onion and cook for 10 mins until softened. Remove to a bowl.

Add a few handfuls of spinach to the pan and cook for a few mins until it has wilted down. Remove from the heat and drain in a colander. Repeat until all the spinach is cooked. Press with the back of a spoon to remove any excess liquid. Now roughly chop and tip into the bowl with the onion. Stir in the nutmeg, ricotta, egg yolks, Parmesan and some seasoning and mix well.

Roll out one pack of pastry on a lightly floured surface to a 25 x 30cm rectangle, then lay on a large baking sheet. With the longest side facing you, pack the spinach mixture down the middle of the pastry, leaving a 5cm border all the way around. Brush the pastry all the way round with some beaten egg.

Roll out the second pack of pastry to a rectangle slightly larger than the first. Drape over the top and gently press down the edges to seal both pastry layers together. Trim the edges to neaten and crimp with your fingers, or seal down with a fork.

Brush all over with beaten egg and, if you like, lightly score the pastry with the back of a knife in a criss-cross fashion, making sure you don’t cut all the way through. Bake for 40 mins. Leave to rest for 10 mins before serving.
chief_review: This recipe is a show-stopping Italian-inspired puff pastry parcel, ideal for vegetarians thanks to its use of ricotta and the option of vegetarian parmesan. The filling of spinach, ricotta, and nutmeg brings a classic flavor combination, elevated by the richness of finely grated cheese and buttery pastry. The use of all-butter puff pastry adds a luxurious texture, while the egg yolks and beaten egg contribute to a golden, glossy finish. Perfect as a centerpiece for buffets or festive gatherings, this dish balances creamy, savory notes with a touch of spice from the nutmeg. Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarian diets, the recipe offers versatility and can be adapted by using vegetarian cheese alternatives to accommodate specific preferences. A decadent, crowd-pleasing option for vegetarians and cheese lovers alike.

name: Sprout & spinach baked eggs
author: Elena Silcock
ingredients: 1 green chilli, chopped (deseeded if you don’t want it very hot)
½ small pack coriander, yogurt, sriracha and thick slices of sourdough, to serve
directions: Heat the oil in a frying pan with high sides, scatter in the cumin seeds and toast a little, then add the onion and fry until softened, around 5 mins. Add the garlic and chilli and fry for 1 min. Tip the sprouts into the pan and cook for 5 mins until softened, then add the spinach – you may have to do this in batches. Cook until the spinach has wilted down, then squeeze in the lemon juice to taste. Season well.

Use a spoon to create six holes in the greens to crack the eggs into. Break the eggs into the holes, cover the pan with a lid and cook for 5-7 mins until the eggs have set, but the yolk remains runny. Sprinkle over the coriander and serve immediately, drizzled with natural yogurt and sriracha, and with sourdough on the side.
chief_review:
This vibrant, nutrient-packed recipe combines Brussels sprouts and spinach, delivering a colorful, flavorful base enhanced by aromatic cumin, garlic, and green chilli. The eggs add richness and protein, while a finishing squeeze of lemon brightens the dish. Coriander, yogurt, and a dash of sriracha bring freshness and heat, nicely complemented by hearty sourdough. The use of olive oil and fresh herbs keeps it light and engaging.

Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, this dish offers ample dietary fiber, protein, and healthy fats. It also fits those seeking a low-sugar meal, and can be made gluten free by serving without the sourdough. The yogurt and sriracha provide optional, customizable toppings, catering to varying tastes and spice tolerances. Perfect for brunch or a satisfying supper, this recipe balances wholesome greens with comforting, bold flavors.

name: Big ham salad
description: Peas and ham don't just partner well in soup - try them together in a fresh, minty salad platter, great for a buffet party
author: Good Food
directions: Cook peas in boiling water for 1 min. Drain and rinse under cold water. Toss with ham, leaves, spring onions, potatoes and two-thirds of mint. Mix remaining mint with yogurt and sugar. Drizzle over salad.
chief_review: This Peas and Ham Salad is a refreshing twist on classic flavors, pairing sweet peas and savory shredded ham with crisp lettuce and new potatoes. The addition of mint lifts the dish, adding a vibrant note that complements the creamy yogurt dressing. The ingredients create a light, yet satisfying platter, perfect for a buffet or spring gathering. The use of natural yogurt makes the dressing tangy without being heavy, and the hint of sugar rounds everything off. It’s ideal for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the ham is verified gluten-free, and can be enjoyed by anyone without restrictions to pork or dairy. This salad is straightforward to assemble and visually appealing, thanks to the layers of green and pink. A simple, flavorful choice for entertaining.

name: Moist turkey crown with chestnut truffle stuffing
description:
If you want succulent tasty Turkey this recipe delivers
We normally don't have turkey for Christmas - because we found it tasteless and dry -
Tried this this year and brined the turkey for 8 hours on 24th Dec - stuffed the crown as suggested and left overnight - so Christmas morning all we had to do was put it in the oven.
Yes the mushroom stuffing makes the Turkey look dark, however was very tasty
Turkey was held in a "Hostess trolley" for 2 hours ( late family arrivals) and still remained succulent and tasty.
Only thing slightly negative was the skin was not crispy - otherwise highly recommend this recipe
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 5 tbsp clear honey or brown sugar
directions: To make the brine, heat 200ml of the water, salt, honey or sugar and a couple of thyme sprigs in a small pan. When the salt has dissolved, stir together with the remaining water. Place the turkey in a bowl and pour over the brine. Cover and chill for 4-8 hrs.

For the stuffing, heat a knob of the butter in a frying pan. When melted, add the shallot and fry for a couple of mins until softened. Add the mushrooms and fry for 5 mins until they start to turn golden. Pour over the madeira, add the chestnuts and the leaves from 1 thyme sprig. Cook for 10 mins more until all the liquid has evaporated. Drizzle with the truffle oil and leave to cool, then mix together with the remaining butter.

Remove the turkey from the brine and discard the liquid. Use kitchen paper to gently pat the meat until it’s dry all over, then use your fingers or a spoon to gently ease under the skin of the bird, making a pocket between its flesh and skin. Smear the truffle butter all over the flesh, following the contours of the breast. Brush a little more butter over the skin, then place in a roasting tin. Can chill at this stage up to 1 day ahead.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Roast for 1 hr (about 40 mins per kg). Halfway through cooking, baste with the juices and loosely cover with foil if the skin is browning. Check that the turkey is done by piercing the thickest part with a skewer – the juices should run clear. Remove from the tin and leave to rest, covered loosely with foil, for 10 mins.

While the turkey is resting, make the gravy. Pour away any excess fat from the roasting tin, then place the tin over a medium heat on the hob. Tip in the shallot, then cook for a couple of mins, stirring often. When the shallot has softened, sprinkle over the flour and mix through. Slowly pour in the madeira, scraping up any caramelised cooking juices. If the gravy starts to turn lumpy, quickly whisk out any lumps. Bring to the boil and simmer until reduced by half, then pour in the chicken stock. Simmer for 5-10 mins until lightly thickened. Strain before serving, if you like.
chief_review:
This turkey crown recipe impresses with its succulence and depth of flavor, especially thanks to the clever use of a brine and umami-packed mushroom and chestnut stuffing. Brining ensures the meat remains juicy, even after holding in a warming trolley, and the blend of wild mushrooms, madeira, and truffle oil complements the turkey beautifully. The stuffing, though dark in appearance, is a highlight in both taste and texture.

The dish is well-suited to gluten-free diets if the flour is substituted with a gluten-free alternative. However, it is not suitable for those with mushroom or nut allergies, or for vegetarians/vegans, given its use of turkey and butter. The instructions are clear and practical, making advance preparation easy—a perfect recipe for any festive gathering where flavor and tenderness are paramount.

name: Stacked star cake
description: Turn a plain cake into a stunning centre piece. You need a steady hand so save the sherry for after the tricky balancing act!
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Cover the cake and set aside. Knead the 500g icing for the stars and roll out to 5mm thick on a surface dusted with icing sugar. Dust with edible lustre, then rub it in with your fingertips. Stamp 20 stars out of the icing using one 6cm cutter, or use two different-size cutters if you have them. Leave to dry overnight.

If you’re putting a ribbon around the cake, do this now. Start building up the hardened stars – start with three in a triangle shape, pushing the points into the icing on the cake for stability. Build on this basic frame, letting the stars support each other. Lay a few stars around the base of the stack. Cake can be iced up to a week ahead.

TO COVER THE CAKE: To cover a cake with marzipan, first brush the cake all over with a thin layer of warmed apricot jam. Dust the work surface with icing sugar, then roll out the marzipan evenly until you have a 5mm-1cm thick round, about 40cm across for a 20cm cake. Lift over the cake, using a rolling pin to help, then smooth with your hands and trim off the excess. Leave to dry overnight or for a few hours. Lightly brush the marzipan all over with cooled, boiled water. Roll the icing out as you did the marzipan, then smooth with your hands, trim off the excess and leave to dry.
chief_review: This decorative fruitcake recipe transforms a simple cake into an impressive centerpiece with the elegant use of marzipan, ready-to-roll icing, and gold or silver edible lustre. The method is ideal for those comfortable with intricate cake decorating, as it requires patience and precision. The ingredients are suitable for vegetarians, as there are no animal-derived gelatin or fats involved. However, it's important to check that the ready-to-roll icing and edible lustre are labeled vegetarian, as some brands may vary. The cake is nut-based due to the marzipan (almonds), so it's excellent for those seeking a nutty flavor but unsuitable for anyone with nut allergies. The visual impact, classic fruitcake base, and touch of edible shimmer make this a showstopper for special occasions.

name: Wedding cake - light fruit cake
description: This makes the top tier of a three tier wedding cake, or make it alone for christenings, Christmas, or whenever you need a good, lighter, fruit cake
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 50g (3 balls) stem ginger from a jar
directions: Heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Grease and double-line the base and sides of a deep, 15cm cake tin. Wrap a double layer of greaseproof or brown paper around the outside of the tin, too, then secure with string.

Using an electric whisk or a tabletop mixer, cream the butter and sugar together until fluffy and light. Beat in the eggs gradually. In a small bowl, mix the orange flower water with the zest and juice of the orange and lemon. Fold the flour, then dried fruit, pistachioes and ginger into the creamed mix, followed by the juice and zest mix.

Spoon the mix into the prepared tin and bake for 30 mins, then turn oven down to 150C/ fan 130C/gas 2 and bake for another 1 hr 45 mins until risen, golden and an inserted skewer comes out clean. Leave to cool for 15 mins before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.
The cake will keep well wrapped in a cool place for up to 1 month.
chief_review: This lighter fruit cake strikes a balance between traditional richness and fresh citrus notes, thanks to orange flower water, zesty orange and lemon, and a vibrant mix of dried fruits and nuts. The inclusion of golden sultanas, apricots, glacé cherries, and stem ginger creates delightful bursts of flavor and texture. Using unsalted butter and golden caster sugar keeps the crumb tender and light, while shelled pistachios contribute a pleasant crunch and subtle earthiness. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly, as it relies on eggs and butter for structure and moisture, but contains gluten and nuts, making it unsuitable for those with related allergies. It's an excellent choice for celebratory occasions, offering a less dense alternative to classic fruit cake while maintaining festive appeal. Serve as the crowning tier for special events, or enjoy on its own whenever you crave a refined, flavourful cake.

name: Baked carrot & sweet potato mash
description: Gorgeous, tastes wicked, probably is wicked, but sooooo good!!!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 800g sweet potato, peeled and chopped into 2½ cm pieces
500g carrot, cut to the same size as the sweet potato
directions: Put the veg in a large pan, cover with water and bring to the boil, then put a lid on the pan and cook for 15 mins until really tender. Drain and leave to steam-dry for a few mins. Once completely dry, return to the pan and mash with the cream, nutmeg, cinnamon and plenty of seasoning. Transfer the mash to an ovenproof gratin dish, sprinkle with the breadcrumbs and drizzle with a little olive oil.
Bake at 220C/200C fan/gas 7 for 35 mins until the top is golden and crunchy, and the mash is piping hot.
chief_review: This recipe showcases a delightful blend of sweet potato and carrot, brought together by the richness of double cream and a fragrant touch of nutmeg and cinnamon. The fresh breadcrumbs on top crisp up beautifully under a drizzle of olive oil, adding a satisfying textural contrast to the velvety vegetables beneath. The dish is hearty yet subtly spiced, making it a comforting side or a vegetarian centerpiece when paired with robust mains. Since it’s naturally gluten-free if you use gluten-free breadcrumbs and suitable for vegetarians, this bake can find its way into various dietary preferences. A simple, elegant dish that truly lets the sweetness of the root vegetables shine—perfect for festive gatherings or weeknight indulgence.

name: Filo triangles with artichoke, feta and mint
description: Try this stylish and quick canapé idea, perfect for a relaxed cocktail evening, or Christmas Eve, with friends.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 jar artichoke hearts, rinsed and roughly chopped
a small bunch of mint, chopped
directions: Mix the feta, artichoke, lemon and mint together.

Take a piece of the filo pastry, brush all over with melted butter and cut into 7cm-wide strips. Cover the remaining pastry with a damp tea towel to keep fresh. Put 1 tbsp of the mixture at the bottom of the sheet of pastry and fold this edge up to meet one side to start the shape of a triangle. Fold the bottom point of the pastry up, sealing in the filling, then complete the triangle by folding again in the opposite direction. Keep folding until you reach the top and lightly brush with more melted butter. Repeat until you have finished the filling. Chill the triangles until you are ready to cook.
Heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and put a baking sheet in the oven.
Put the triangles on the hot baking tray and cook for 15 minutes or until golden brown.
chief_review: This canapé recipe offers a delightful medley of Mediterranean flavours with creamy feta and artichoke accentuated by fresh mint and lemon zest. The use of filo pastry ensures a crisp, elegant bite—ideal for entertaining guests at a cocktail party or festive gathering. The combination of feta and vegetables makes this recipe suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, those with dairy or gluten sensitivities should note the inclusion of feta and filo pastry. The preparation is efficient yet impressive, making it well-suited for hosts seeking sophisticated, stress-free party fare. Serve warm for best results, and garnish with extra mint or lemon for added zing.

name: Clove sugar cookies
description: These sweet, nutty, spiced biscuits can be served after dinner, or packaged up as gifts for family and friends
author: Good Food
directions: Put the butter, hazelnuts, vanilla extract and 85g of the icing sugar in a food processor and whizz to a paste. Add 1 tsp of the ground cloves and the flour, and pulse together until a dough forms.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line a couple of baking sheets with baking parchment. Roll the dough into walnut- sized balls and arrange on the baking sheets. Use the back of a fork to lightly squash each ball, then bake for 12-15 mins until they turn a pale biscuit colour – if they get too brown, they will become dry.
Mix the remaining icing sugar and ground cloves, then sieve thickly over the hot biscuits. Leave to cool slightly before eating just warm, or cool.
chief_review: These sweet, nutty, and spiced biscuits deliver a delightful finish to any meal or make for an elegant edible gift. The rich blend of hazelnuts and butter creates a crumbly, melt-in-the-mouth texture, while ground cloves introduce a warming note that complements the subtle sweetness of vanilla and icing sugar. The balance of flavors is expertly layered, showcasing both the earthiness of hazelnuts and the aromatic spice. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and suitable for those wishing to avoid eggs, making it accessible for a range of diets. With straightforward preparation and a sophisticated taste, these biscuits promise to elevate your after-dinner spread or impress as a thoughtful, homemade gift.

name: Creamy cauliflower & broccoli bake
description: Instead of cauliflower cheese, try this alternative with broccoli, crème frâiche, mustard, white wine and nutmeg
author: Lucy Netherton
ingredients: 1 large head of cauliflower, broken into florets
1 large head broccoli, broken into florets
splash of white wine(if you have some)
2 slices stale bread, whizzed into crumbs
directions: Cover the cauliflower in cold water, add the stock cube, then bring up to the boil. Add the broccoli and cook for 1 min, then drain (reserving some of the stock) and allow to steam-dry for 1-2 mins. (The veg shouldn’t be tender.)

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Mix together the crème fraîche, mustard, wine (if using), nutmeg and some seasoning. Add the veg and mix well. Tip into an ovenproof dish, scatter with the breadcrumbs and bake for 30 mins until golden and crisp on the top.
chief_review: This creative twist on the classic cauliflower cheese swaps out the usual cheese sauce with a tangy, creamy mélange of crème fraîche, mustard, white wine, and nutmeg. The combination of broccoli and cauliflower provides a robust, earthy base, while the mustard and wine lift the flavors with subtle acidity and heat. The breadcrumb topping adds textural contrast, ensuring each bite is satisfyingly crunchy. The absence of traditional cheese makes this dish lighter, yet crème fraîche keeps it rich and indulgent. Suitable for lacto-vegetarians, this recipe can also cater to those avoiding gluten by substituting gluten-free bread for the crumbs. Its use of vegetable stock keeps it meat-free, making it a solid choice for those following a vegetarian diet. Enjoy as a centerpiece or a side dish; this bake stands out for its depth of flavor and approachable ingredient list.

name: Gingerbread gift jars
description: Layer a jar with ingredients for delicious ginger biscuits and present as a thoughtful homemade gift
author: Good Food
directions: Mix sugar with ginger, allspice and cinnamon. Spoon into a jar and pack down tightly. Add a layer of crystallised ginger. Mix flour with baking powder and bicarbonate of soda and spoon on top of the ginger. Put on the lid, decorate with ribbons and a cookie cutter.

Label with cooking instructions: Mix 150g melted butter with 1 tbsp golden syrup and 1 egg yolk. Add to the dry ingredients, mix well, then knead to a dough. Chill for 15 mins then roll out. Cut into biscuits and bake at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 8-10 mins. Cool on a wire rack.
chief_review: This ginger biscuit jar recipe offers a delightful blend of warming spices and sweet, chewy crystallised ginger, making it an excellent homemade gift for any baking enthusiast. The combination of soft light brown sugar and aromatic spices like ginger, allspice, and cinnamon promises a flavourful and comforting biscuit. With plain flour as the base, the biscuits are likely to be tender yet crisp. The addition of baking powder and bicarbonate of soda ensures a light texture. Notably, this recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets, as it contains no animal-derived ingredients in the dry mixture. For those on a dairy-free diet, it’s important to note that the recipient may need to add butter or egg when baking, so specify alternatives if required. Overall, this recipe strikes a wonderful balance between convenience and thoughtful gifting.

name: Marinated goat’s cheese
description: A refreshing alternative to a full cheeseboard, this zesty thyme and chilli treat can be made ahead and given as a gift - just wrap up and add a box of good-quality crackers and chutney
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 350ml good olive oilor rapeseed oil (not extra virgin), plus extra for greasing
3 pared strips lemonszest (white pith removed from the underside)
1 red chilli, pierced a few times with a sharp knife
directions: Sterilise a 500g jar (see tip). Oil your hands well, then break the goat’s cheese into 4 pieces and roll into balls. Place the cheese in the jar, then pack the lemon zest, thyme and chilli around the cheese. Scatter over the fennel seeds and pour over the oil. Chill and leave to marinate for 2 days. Store in the fridge, and eat within 2 weeks.
chief_review: This marinated goat’s cheese is a delightful, herbaceous treat that’s perfect for gifting or as a centrepiece for light entertaining. The combination of earthy thyme, bright lemon zest, and gentle heat from the pierced red chilli infuses the creamy goat’s cheese, while fennel seeds add a subtle aniseed lift. Opting for a mild olive or rapeseed oil (rather than extra virgin) ensures the flavours remain balanced and the cheese texture stays pillowy. This recipe is ideally suited to a vegetarian diet, as goat’s cheese provides a satisfying protein source without the inclusion of animal rennet. Paired with good-quality gluten-free crackers, it easily adapts to gluten-free needs. For an extra flourish, present the cheese in a pretty jar alongside artisan crackers and tangy chutney—a thoughtful, elegant gift that showcases gourmet simplicity.

name: Red cabbage & potato hash
description: With abundant brassicas, there's often leftovers - create a hash brown-like breakfast dotted with apple and walnut
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: fried eggs and leftover ham, to serve
directions: Boil potatoes until tender. Melt the butter in a shallow pan (ovenproof if you have it), then fry Festive red salad for a few mins to soften. Stir in the well-drained spuds with some seasoning, press down and carry on cooking to crisp the bottom and heat through.
If you like, dot the top with a bit more butter and grill to crisp it up. Eat with fried eggs and slices of leftover ham, if you like.
chief_review: This inventive breakfast hash brown brings together the earthy comfort of potatoes, the crunch of walnuts, and a subtle hint of sweetness from apple, resulting in a harmonious blend of textures and flavors. The recipe's use of butter ensures a rich, golden crust, while the addition of leftover festive ham and fried eggs makes it a hearty, protein-rich start to the day. Suitable for those following a gluten-free diet (provided the ham is free from gluten-containing additives), this dish is also adaptable to vegetarians when the ham is omitted and more salad or a vegetarian protein is added. The walnuts offer a pleasing nutty dimension, though those with nut allergies should omit them. Overall, it’s a clever way to reinvent leftovers into a balanced and satisfying breakfast, with plenty of room for customization.

name: Rudolph's snowball carrot muffins
description: Get the children to create their own Christmas magic with these fluffy muffins, perfect for Rudolph and Santa
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and line a muffin tray with 12 paper cases. Drain the pineapple, reserving the juice, then crush the flesh with a fork. Mix the dry ingredients in a large bowl. Beat the eggs, melted butter and yogurt together and pour into the bowl, along with the carrot and pineapple. Stir quickly, then spoon into muffin cases and bake for 18 mins or until risen and golden. Can be frozen at this stage for up to a month.

To decorate, mix the creamed coconut with 5 tbsp pineapple juice and stir in the icing sugar. Put the desiccated coconut onto a plate or tray. Peel the muffins from their cases and put on a rack. Spread the icing over until completely covered (this can get a bit messy), then roll in the coconut. Leave to dry for a few mins. Pipe a carrot on the top of each muffin using the writing icing, with strips of angelica as stalks.
chief_review: This festive muffin recipe is delightfully moist and packed with child-friendly flavors. The combination of pineapple, carrot, and coconut imparts natural sweetness and texture, while the rich aroma of butter and golden caster sugar creates that familiar Christmas warmth. The bio-yogurt adds tenderness, preventing dryness, and the inclusion of self-raising flour ensures fluffy, well-risen muffins. These treats are ideal as a fun holiday baking project for families, especially with the decorative elements like orange writing icing and crystallised angelica. Notably, the absence of nuts makes the muffins suitable for nut-free diets, and the use of natural ingredients appeals to those seeking less-processed options for children. Overall, this recipe skillfully balances flavor, texture, and festive charm for a memorable holiday bake.

name: Baked almond & date tart
description: A great recipe for using up leftover dates from Christmas to make a delicious fruity pud - by Gary Rhodes.
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 100g date, preferably Medjool, stoned and roughly chopped
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Lightly butter and flour a 23-25cm fluted flan dish or tin (not loose-bottomed). Crush half the digestive biscuits with a rolling pin. Cream the butter and sugar in a food processor until light and fluffy, 2-3 mins, scraping down the sides halfway through. Add the flour, baking powder, ground almonds and crushed digestive biscuits, along with the eggs, then process again just until smooth. Transfer the mix to a bowl.

Break the remaining digestive biscuits into chunky crumbs, (see step 1, left). Stir them into the mix (step 2) along with the chopped dates and almonds. Spoon the mix into the flan dish. Bake for 25-30 mins until golden and the tart is just beginning to come away from the sides.
Remove the tart from the oven and leave it to cool a little, before dusting over icing sugar. Serve warm with cream.
chief_review: Gary Rhodes’ festive date pudding is a delightful way to utilize any remaining Medjool dates, resulting in a rich, moist dessert with a gentle crunch from chopped blanched almonds and the buttery base from digestive biscuits. The use of ground almonds not only enhances the nutty flavor but also adds a lovely texture. This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it forgoes meat or gelatine, relying on eggs and butter for richness. Pairing the finished pud with clotted or pouring cream imparts a luxurious finish – perfect for indulgent occasions. A dusting of icing sugar adds just the right touch of sweetness. Whether served warm or cold, this dessert stands out for its inviting flavors and clever use of leftovers.

name: Herb-buttered turkey, roasties & cranberry sauce gravy
description: The potatoes and turkey crown cook together and there's no need to baste - and it's delicious. Easy and stress free
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1½ kg new potato, halved if large, quartered if huge
directions: Heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Tip the garlic, parsley and butter together in a bowl, season generously with black pepper and a pinch of salt, then beat with a wooden spoon or squish through your fingers until everything is combined. The butter can be prepared up to a day ahead and chilled or made two weeks ahead and frozen. Soften before using.

Place the turkey crown on a board with the thick part of the breast facing away from you. Use your hands to make two pockets between the skin and the meat, then smear the flavoured butter beneath the skin and all over the breast and work it down so that the breast is completely covered. 3 Tip the new potatoes into a large roasting tray. Sit the turkey on top, skin side up, then roast for 30 mins. Remove from the oven, sit the turkey on a board and give the potatoes a good shake. Then place the turkey back in the tin, spoon over some of the buttery juices and continue to cook for another 40-50 mins until the turkey is dark golden. Transfer the turkey to a board to rest, loosely covered in foil, then continue to cook the potatoes for 20 mins to brown. Use a slotted spoon to scoop the potatoes into a serving dish, reserving the buttery juices in the pan. Put the potatoes to one side and keep warm.

To make the cranberry gravy, place the roasting pan on a lowish heat and stir in the flour. Let everything sizzle and brown, then add the cranberry sauce and a splash of port. Sizzle everything for a few mins until really sticky, then stir in the stock, bring to the boil and cook until thick or to your liking, seasoning to taste. If the gravy is on the pale side or a bit too sweet, stir in a splash of soy sauce.
chief_review:
This recipe presents a beautifully streamlined approach to a classic turkey roast, marrying tender, juicy turkey crown with perfectly roasted new potatoes. The fusion of garlic, parsley, and butter creates a depth of flavor that infuses both the bird and the potatoes as they roast together, eliminating the need for stressful basting. The accompanying gravy—lifted by cranberry sauce, port, and a touch of soy—provides a festive, tangy-sweet complement. 

It's well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet if you substitute the plain flour with a gluten-free variety and ensure the soy sauce is gluten-free. The recipe also fits a nut-free diet and is ideal for anyone seeking an uncomplicated, crowd-pleasing main for special occasions or family gatherings. This dish shines in its simplicity and robust flavors, and is sure to become a holiday favorite.

name: Niçoise toasts
description: These bite-sized, crostini-like mouthfuls are packed with robust Mediterranean flavours including anchovies, capers and olives
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 1 x 150g part-baked baguette, cut into 24 slices (blitz the ends into breadcrumbs and freeze)
3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil, plus a little extra to drizzle
6 anchovy filletsin olive oil (from a jar or can), drained
½ medium red onion, finely chopped
12 pitted black olives, ideally Kalamata, drained and halved
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Place the bread slices on a large baking tray in a single layer and drizzle over 1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil. Bake for 10-12 mins or until dry, taking care not to let them burn or become too hard.

Heat the remaining oil in a medium non-stick frying pan and cook the anchovies, garlic and onion for 3-4 mins over a low heat until well softened, stirring until the anchovies break up. Add the tomatoes, purée, capers and chilli flakes, and cook over a low heat for 10-15 mins, stirring regularly, until the sauce is thick. Leave to cool for 15 mins.
Once cool, spread a little tomato sauce on each piece of bread and top with half an olive. Sprinkle with the Parmesan, then cover and chill for up to 24 hrs until ready to reheat.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the toasts on a parchment-lined baking tray (or two) and bake for 8 mins or until hot throughout. To serve, garnish with basil and a drizzle of extra virgin olive oil.
chief_review: This Mediterranean-inspired crostini recipe delivers intense flavor in every bite, highlighted by the saline punch of anchovies, briny capers, and rich olives. The crisp baguette base provides pleasing texture, while the combination of tomato, chilli, and parmesan rounds out a vibrant, umami-packed topping. Aromatic garlic and sweet red onion create a balanced foundation, enlivened by fresh basil at the finish. This recipe features no meat apart from anchovies, catering well to pescatarian diets. However, with bread as a main component, it's best served to those without gluten intolerance. The use of dairy (parmesan) and fish (anchovies) means it is not suitable for vegan or dairy-free eaters, nor those allergic to fish. Overall, this is an ideal starter for lovers of bold, Mediterranean flavors—simple to assemble yet sophisticated in taste.

name: Mini creamy mushroom pies
description: Individual party pies with vegetarian garlicky filling, flavoured with caraway for a Scandinavian feel
author: Good Food
ingredients: a little plain flour, for dusting
directions: Heat the butter and oil in a frying pan. Add the onion and fry until soft. Stir in the garlic and mushrooms, season and cook for 5 mins until the mushrooms are soft. Stir in the parsley and cream. Remove from the heat and allow to cool.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Grease a 6-hole muffin tin with butter, then line each hole with a long thin strip of baking parchment. Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface and stamp out 6 x 10 cm circles. Press a circle into each hole to line. Roll out the remaining pastry (you may need to re-roll trimmings) and stamp out 6 x 8cm circles.
Divide the mushroom mix between the pies. Brush the pastry edges with a little egg, top each with a pastry lid and carefully press the pastry edges together to seal.

Brush with the remaining egg and sprinkle with caraway seeds. Bake for 25-30 mins until golden. Allow to cool in the tin slightly before serving, or cool on a wire rack and keep in airtight containers for up to 1 day. Reheat before serving.
chief_review: These individual party pies offer a delightful vegetarian option, bursting with umami from mixed mushrooms and enriched by garlicky undertones and fragrant caraway seeds. The use of ready-rolled shortcrust pastry ensures consistency and a perfectly crisp shell, encasing a creamy filling brightened by fresh parsley. The subtle hint of onion melds seamlessly, while a glossy egg wash yields an inviting golden finish. Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, this recipe offers a Scandinavian twist on classic comfort fare, making it a welcome addition to any festive spread. The pies are hearty yet sophisticated, balancing earthy, herbal, and creamy flavors in a handheld treat.

name: Carrots with pine nuts, raisins & parsley
description: Bring out the sweetness of carrots with dried fruit, add texture with pine nuts and finish with fresh herbs
author: Good Food
ingredients: 800g carrot, halved and cut on the diagonal into 1cm pieces
directions: Put the carrots in a large pan and cover with water. Bring to the boil and cook for 6-8 mins until just tender, then drain. Can be done the day before; just chill the carrots until needed.

Melt the butter in the same pan, add the pine nuts and sultanas, and cook for 2 mins until the pine nuts start to lightly brown. Return the carrots to the pan with the sugar, parsley and plenty of seasoning. Toss everything to coat.
chief_review: This vibrant carrot dish beautifully balances natural sweetness and earthy notes. Roasting the carrots intensifies their flavor, while sultanas add a gentle chew and bursts of fruity sweetness. The pine nuts contribute a delicate crunch and rich nuttiness, making each bite texturally interesting. Finishing with fresh parsley brightens and lifts the dish, keeping it fresh and fragrant. The use of butter adds a luxurious richness, pulling together all elements in harmonious unity. This recipe is ideal for a vegetarian menu, easily serving as a standout side or a complementary dish at a festive table. The ingredient combination is thoughtful, resulting in a dish that is both satisfying and elegant.

name: Grilled ham, egg & spiced oven chips
description: Use up the leftovers from a delicious home-cooked ham with this simple but classic supper
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Cut the potatoes into chunky chips, place in a pan of salted water and bring to the boil. Simmer for 5 mins until softened slightly, then drain and leave to steam-dry for a few mins.

Pour 3 tbsp of the oil into a shallow baking tray and place in the oven to heat for 5 mins. Meanwhile, toss the chips with the paprika, cayenne pepper and some salt. Carefully tip the chips into the hot oil and return the tray to the oven to cook for 40 mins, tossing them halfway through cooking.

Ten mins before the chips are ready, heat a large griddle pan. Cook the ham slices for 3 mins each side until they are hot and have griddle lines on both sides. Transfer to a plate to keep warm. In a small frying pan, heat the remaining oil and fry the eggs to your liking. Top each slice of ham with an egg and serve with the oven chips, and ketchup if you like.
chief_review: This recipe skillfully transforms leftover ham into a comforting classic, pairing crispy, spiced baked potatoes with savory slices of ham and perfectly fried eggs. The use of paprika and cayenne lends a gentle warmth and depth to the potatoes, making them wonderfully flavorful. The preparation is straightforward, making it ideal for a quick supper. It’s well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients contain wheat or gluten. This dish is also nut-free and free from common allergens beyond eggs. For those seeking a satisfying, hearty meal that puts leftovers to good use, this recipe delivers familiar flavors and pleasing textures in every bite.

name: Passion layer torte
description: Get ahead for a dinner party or celebration with this indulgent, fruity cake which can be frozen for up to 2 months
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 225g softened butter, cubed, plus extra for greasing
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Grease 2 x 20cm loose-based sandwich tins and line the bases with discs of baking parchment. Put the butter, sugar, eggs, flour, coconut, orange zest and baking powder in a food processor or food mixer and blend or beat until well combined, thick and creamy. Do not over-blend or the cake will be tough rather than light. If you don’t have a food mixer, put all the ingredients in a bowl and beat hard with a wooden spoon until soft and creamy.

Spoon the mixture evenly into the prepared tins and smooth the surface. Bake on the same shelf in the centre of the oven for 25 mins or until well risen and just beginning to shrink back from the sides of the tin. Remove the tins from the oven and leave to cool for 5 mins before running a knife around the edge of the cakes and turning out onto a wire rack. Peel off the parchment and leave to cool completely.

When the cakes are completely cold, very carefully cut horizontally through each one with a serrated knife to make 4 thin sponges. To make the frosting, cut the passion fruits in half and scoop into a sieve. Press through the sieve to strain the juice – you should have 4 tbsp. Set aside and reserve the seeds. Put the butter, icing sugar and cheese in a food processor or mixer and blend until smooth. Do not overbeat or it will become runny. Slowly add the passion fruit juice and blend until just combined.

Place one of the sponges, cut-side down, on the metal base of the sandwich tin and put on an upturned bowl on a tray. This will help make frosting the cake easier. Spread with roughly a fifth of the frosting – just enough to cover the sponge. Use a paddling motion with a palette knife or soft spatula for the best result, trying to keep contact with the cake to prevent the sponge from lifting.

Cover with a second cake, spread with frosting and repeat the layers once more, ending with the last sponge, cut-side down. By this stage, you should have layered 4 cakes with passion fruit frosting between 3 of them. Use the remaining frosting to spread over the top and sides of the cakes to cover completely. Don’t worry if the sides are a little messy, as the grated chocolate should cover any imperfections.

Put the cake in the fridge for 30-60 mins to allow the icing to set a little. Coarsely grate the chocolate. Working your way slowly around the cake, scoop grated chocolate onto a palette knife and sweep up the sides of the cake, pressing into the soft icing.

Take the cake off the bowl, slide the palette knife between the cake and the metal base, and gently transfer to a plate or cake stand. (If the icing is too soft to do this, pop the cake in the freezer for 30 mins and then try again.) Chill until ready to serve. Before serving, drizzle over 1 tsp of the reserved passion fruit seeds over the top of the cake. If making a day ahead, cover with a cake tin or a bowl large enough to cover the cake without touching it, so the cake doesn’t get damaged in the fridge.
chief_review:
This decadent cake combines vibrant passion fruit with the richness of butter, coconut, and cream cheese for a truly indulgent dessert—ideal for special occasions. The balance of citrusy orange zest, sweet white chocolate, and tangy passion fruit within a moist sponge creates a delightful layering of flavors and textures. The inclusion of eggs, butter, cream cheese, and white chocolate provides a luxuriously creamy texture and a rich mouthfeel, while desiccated coconut adds a pleasant chewiness.

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat, fish, or gelatin-based ingredients. However, it does rely heavily on dairy and eggs, making it ideal for those who enjoy classic, full-flavored cakes.

Overall, this cake is a showstopper—sure to impress guests with its fruity freshness and luscious, creamy finish. Preparation ahead of time, with the option to freeze, makes it especially practical for entertaining.

name: Cranberry chicken salad
description: Use up leftover cranberry sauce in this healthy salad. Add a can of cannellini beans if you want to bulk it up
author: Good Food
directions: Slice each chicken breast in half horizontally to give 4 thin breasts, then rub with half the oil and season. Heat a non-stick frying pan and fry the chicken for 3 mins on each side until cooked through. Set aside on a plate.

Heat the remaining oil in the pan and fry the onions for 5 mins. Slice the chicken, collecting any juices, and layer up with the onions, leaves, cucumber and dried cranberries. Mix the cranberry sauce, lime juice, 2 tbsp water and any chicken resting juices, and drizzle over the salad.
chief_review: This vibrant salad is an excellent way to put leftover cranberry sauce to use, turning it into a tangy dressing mixed with fresh lime juice. The skinless chicken breasts, grilled or pan-seared with olive oil, provide a lean protein source, while the mix of fresh leaves and crunchy cucumber adds both texture and freshness. Red onions and dried cranberries give the salad depth and a touch of sweetness, perfectly balanced by the zesty cranberry-lime dressing. Optionally, adding cannellini beans would boost the dish with extra plant-based protein and fiber, making it even more filling. This recipe is well-suited for those looking for a light and healthy meal, and it’s naturally gluten-free. It's also a great choice for anyone following a high-protein or low-carb diet, provided the cranberry sauce is unsweetened or low in added sugars.

name: Chicken, kale & sprout stir-fry
description: Brussels sprouts aren't just for Christmas- add them to a healthy noodle pot for extra nutrition and crunch
author: Lucy Netherton
ingredients: 2 lean chicken breasts, skin removed and sliced into thin strips
25g piece fresh ginger, peeled and sliced into matchsticks
1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced
handful Brussels sprout, cut into quarters
2 tbsp rice wine or white wine vinegar
directions: Cook the noodles following pack instructions, then drain and set aside. meanwhile, heat a large wok or frying pan and add the kale along with a good splash of water and cook for 1-2 mins until wilted, with a little bite remaining, then cool under running water to keep the colour.

Add half the oil and cook the chicken strips until browned, then remove and set aside. Heat the remaining oil and fry the ginger, pepper and sprouts until softened a little. return the chicken and kale and add the noodles.
Tip in the soy, rice wine and lime zest and juice along with enough water to create a sauce that clings to the ingredients. Serve immediately.
chief_review:
This vibrant noodle pot cleverly showcases Brussels sprouts beyond their usual holiday role, combining them with crisp kale, sweet red pepper, and zingy ginger for a refreshing, nutrient-packed meal. The lean chicken strips add satisfying protein, while soba noodles (traditionally made with buckwheat, often wheat-blended—check your brand if gluten-free is needed) serve as a hearty base. Finished with a light dressing of sesame oil, lime, soy, and a splash of vinegar, the dish is balanced and lively, with bright acidity cutting through the earthy veg. 

Ideal for those seeking a high-protein, low-fat meal, this recipe is a great fit for a health-conscious, vegetable-rich diet. Its ingredients cater well to dairy-free diets, and with a simple substitution of tamari for soy sauce, it can be made gluten-free if pure buckwheat noodles are used. A delightful, wholesome twist for any time of year.

name: Sprouts with sesame & spring onions
description: Don't save sprouts for Christmas Day - enjoy this light, crunchy stir-fry throughout the winter months
author: Good Food
ingredients: thumb-size piece ginger, cut into matchsticks
small bunch spring onions, sliced diagonally
2 tbsp soy sauce, plus extra to serve
directions: In a wok or large frying pan, heat the oil. Fry the ginger and Brussels sprouts, tossing to coat them in the oil for 5-6 mins, until slightly browned. Add a few tbsp water during cooking to stop them sticking if needed.
Throw in the beansprouts, spring onions, honey and soy sauce, then stir-fry for 1 min. Sprinkle on the sesame seeds and serve immediately with extra soy sauce, if you like.
chief_review: This vibrant Brussels sprout and beansprout stir-fry is a refreshing take on winter greens. The sesame oil provides a rich base, while matchsticks of ginger enliven the dish with aromatic heat. The combination of halved Brussels sprouts and crunchy beansprouts delivers a delightful texture contrast, complemented by the fresh bite of diagonally sliced spring onions. A drizzle of honey and a splash of soy sauce impart a balanced sweet-savory glaze, finished with a scattering of nutty sesame seeds for extra crunch. This recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets and can cater to a dairy-free lifestyle, making it versatile for various dietary preferences. Opting for tamari instead of regular soy sauce will render the dish gluten-free as well. Quick to prepare and bursting with flavor, this stir-fry is a fantastic way to enjoy sprouts all season long.

name: Festive jammie dodgers
description: Another great gift idea from Tana Ramsay. These jammie dodgers get the nostalgia flowing and are great for the kids to help out with too
author: Tana Ramsay
ingredients: 200g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
100g strawberry or raspberry jam (about half a jar)
directions: Put the butter, sugar, flour and almonds into a food processor and whizz until the mixture just comes together and forms a ball. If making by hand, first beat together the butter and sugar, then add the flour and ground almonds. Wrap in cling film and leave in the fridge for at least 1 hr.

Remove the dough from the fridge and knead until it is soft enough to shape and roll. Divide into two even-size balls. Sprinkle a little plain flour over your work surface and roll out one ball of pastry. I find it best to start the rolling myself so that it’s even, then let the kids finish it off. The dough should be approximately 5mm thick. Using a star cutter (about 6cm wide) dipped in a little flour to stop it from sticking, cut out as many star shapes as you can. Then lightly knead the dough trimmings together and roll out again. Keep going until you have about 24 stars. Carefully place the stars on a baking sheet, making sure you keep them slightly apart.

Roll out the second ball of dough the same way. Cut out the same-size stars and place them on a baking sheet. Now cut out a small circle in the centre of each biscuit using a small cookie cutter or the end of a large piping nozzle.

Heat oven to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1 and cook the biscuits for 20-30 mins until just golden. Remove from the oven and place on a cooling rack to cool completely. Place a blob of jam onto the centre of the biscuits without the cut-out circle. Be generous – you want the jam to show at the edges as well as the centre. Place the top halves of the biscuits on and push down gently. These will keep in an airtight container for up to 3 days.
chief_review: Tana Ramsay's jammie dodgers evoke classic British nostalgia with a melt-in-the-mouth biscuit and vibrant jam centre. The use of ground almonds adds a pleasing richness and subtle nutty undertone, elevating the traditional shortbread base. The dough is yielding and workable, making this an inviting baking project for families, especially with children. These treats are well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as the ingredients avoid any animal-derived gelatin or fats. For best results, chill the dough before rolling and use high-quality, seedless jam for a glossy, flavoursome filling. The finished biscuits are delightfully crumbly with a bright, fruity pop—ideal for gifting or sharing over tea.

name: Fruity red cabbage
description: Rustle up your own, sweeter version of pickled sauerkraut with apple, redcurrant and cider flavours
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 4 eating apples, grated to the cores (cores discarded)
directions: Quarter the cabbage, cut away the tough stem and thinly shred each quarter. Put on a pair of clean rubber gloves, and peel and grate the beetroot.
Put all the ingredients in a large pan. Bring to the boil, then cover and cook over a low heat, stirring occasionally, for 45 mins-1 hr until tender. Cool to room temperature, then serve.
chief_review: This vibrant take on sauerkraut pairs sweetness and tang in perfect balance, delivering a medley of textures and flavors. The use of red cabbage, beetroot, and apples creates a robust base, while the addition of redcurrant jelly and sultanas infuses each bite with layers of fruitiness. Cider vinegar and apple juice bring gentle acidity, making the dish wonderfully refreshing. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians and vegans, as it is entirely plant-based and free from animal products. It’s also naturally gluten-free, given that none of the ingredients contain wheat or gluten derivatives. All in all, this pickled creation makes for an excellent accompaniment to roasted dishes or as a stand-alone salad for a lighter meal. The method is straightforward, and the finished product is as visually appealing as it is flavorful—a true celebration of seasonal produce.

name: Quince & rosewater jelly and quince paste
description: I have a quince tree (Meech's prolific) that regularly produces 100 quinces - so I've been making quince jelly and cheese and quince gin for 10 or more years. However, I'm interested in the use of the paste from the quince jelly - surely blitzing the remnants in a food processor won't get rid of the pips and peel? I tend to peel the quinces and take out the pip section before doing quince cheese and getting a good jelly as a sideproduct rather than vice versa. Please advise.
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2kg quince, peeled, cored and roughly chopped
pared zest and juice 1 lemon(use a vegetable peeler)
directions: Put the quinces and lemon zest and juice in a large heavy-based pan. Add enough water to cover the fruit. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for about 1 hr until the quinces are very tender. Strain through a jelly bag or muslin-lined colander. Do not press out the juice – just leave it for at least 4 hrs, or ideally overnight, until the juice has dripped through.

Put 3 saucers in the freezer. Measure the juice and return it to the pan (reserve the leftover fruit for the paste). For each 1 litre juice, add 750g sugar (or for each 100ml juice, add 75g sugar). Bring to the boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar, then boil hard until set. This could take between 5 and 20 mins. To test for set, spoon a little onto a chilled saucer, leave for 1 min, then push your finger through the juice. If it wrinkles, the jelly is set. If not, return to the heat and boil again for a few mins, then test again.
Remove from the heat and skim off any surface scum with a slotted spoon. Stir in the butter to dissolve any leftover sediment, then stir in the rose water. Pot into sterilised jars, seal and label.

Line a 16 x 24cm shallow oblong tin or tray with baking parchment. Tip the reserved fruit into a food processor and whizz to make a smooth-ish paste. Weigh the paste and for each 1kg paste, add 750g sugar (or for each 100g paste, add 75g sugar).

Tip the paste and sugar into a large heavy-based pan and heat gently, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Increase the heat and cook, stirring regularly, for 30-45 mins until the paste is thick and golden, and leaves a gap when you run a wooden spoon across the base of the pan. Be careful as the mixture will spit at you and can burn. Spoon into the tin or tray and smooth the top. Leave to cool, then chill overnight until it is very firm.
Wrap the paste in fresh baking parchment, then over-wrap in foil and store in the fridge for up to 6 weeks.
chief_review: This quince jelly recipe showcases the fragrant, floral notes of quince enhanced with lemon zest and a hint of rosewater. By peeling and coring the quinces prior to cooking, you ensure a smooth, elegant jelly free from gritty textures often retained when using whole fruit. The addition of rosewater brings an intriguing Middle Eastern touch that works beautifully with quince’s natural perfume. The recipe is naturally vegetarian and gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten intolerance or following a plant-based diet (though not vegan, due to the inclusion of butter). For a vegan alternative, consider substituting the butter with a plant-based equivalent. The method is practical and gives you a refined preserve with possibilities beyond breakfast spreads—try it alongside cheese boards or as a luxurious filling for pastries.

name: Cheeseboard pasta bake
description: I made this last night.. left out the nuts but the rest was as the recipe said. Was so nice and easy. Boyfriend was especially pleased with it. I used really low fat milk too and he didnt notice. Will be making this again soon.
author: Good Food
ingredients: half a nutmeg(or ¼ tsp ready ground)
85g mature cheddar, or other hard cheese
85g garlic and herb cheesesuch as Boursin or roulé
85g mixed nut, such as cashews, blanched almonds, and hazelnuts, roughly chopped
a handful of parsley, roughly chopped
directions: To cook the pasta, bring a large pan of water to the boil, add a generous measure of salt and tip in the pasta. Stir once and return to the boil, then boil rapidly for 12 minutes. Preheat the oven to 190C/gas 5/fan 170C.

To make the sauce, pour the milk into a pan and add the butter, flour and plenty of seasoning. Grate in the half nutmeg (or sprinkle in the ready ground). Bring to the boil over a medium heat, whisking all the time until it makes a smooth, creamy sauce.
