Drain the pasta and tip it into the sauce. Taste and add extra seasoning if necessary. Stir in the ham and grate in the cheddar, then tip into a shallow ovenproof dish. Dice the remaining cheeses and swirl into the pasta to make cheesy pockets.
Mix the nuts and parsley together, then scatter over the pasta. Bake in the oven for 30 minutes until the nuts are golden and crunchy and everything is piping hot.
chief_review: This creamy rigatoni bake is a true crowd-pleaser, offering a rich blend of cheeses—cheddar, dolcelatte, and a garlic herb variety—melded into a velvety béchamel sauce. The dish balances robust flavors with a subtle hint of nutmeg and freshness from parsley. Using low-fat milk maintains the creamy texture without sacrificing flavor, making it a lighter option. Omission of the mixed nuts is a smart adaptation for nut allergies, and can be left out without compromising taste. However, the inclusion of both dairy and ham means the recipe is best enjoyed by those following a traditional omnivorous diet. This recipe stands out for its simplicity and ability to satisfy, with a comforting, restaurant-quality finish that’s sure to delight both home cooks and their lucky guests.

name: Coffee & cream cocktail
description: Lovely recipe, just be careful when pouring the cream :)
author: Good Food
directions: Pour the Tia Maria into small cocktail or liqueur glasses. Carefully pour the cream into the glasses over the back of a teaspoon so it floats on the surface of the Tia Maria and makes a separate layer. Dust the cream with cocoa by shaking it through a tea strainer, and serve.
chief_review: This recipe presents a decadent and indulgent treat perfect for lovers of creamy liqueurs. The combination of chilled Tia Maria and generous double cream results in a silky, luxurious drink, with the final touch of cocoa dusting adding a hint of chocolatey aroma. It's an excellent choice for a dessert cocktail or a festive after-dinner drink. The ingredients are suitable for a vegetarian diet, but not for those avoiding dairy or alcohol. For service, carefully pour the cream over the back of a spoon to achieve a beautiful layered effect. This simple yet elegant recipe is sure to impress guests when served in small, chilled glasses.

name: Gingery treacle tart
description: If you find traditional treacle tart too sweet, try this lighter classic with lots of zingy ginger and the addition of lemon-poached pears
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 ball stem ginger, finely chopped, plus 1tbsp syrup from the jar
directions: Roll out the pastry with a little flour and use to line a loose-bottom 23cm round tin (it needs to be about 5cm high). Leave the excess pastry overhanging the sides, then chill for 30 mins.

In a large saucepan, melt the sugar with 800ml water and the zest of 1 lemon. Increase the heat until just simmering, drop in the pears, then cover and poach for 12-15 mins until almost tender. Lift out the pears, then set aside on some kitchen paper.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Line the pastry case with baking paper, fill with baking beans, then bake blind for 15-20 mins until a pale biscuit colour. Remove the paper and beans, then bake for a further 5 mins. Meanwhile, put the golden syrup in a small pan with remaining zest, juice of 1 lemon and the chopped ginger and syrup, then warm until runny. Tip the breadcrumbs into a large bowl, then stir in the warm syrup and eggs.

Reduce oven temperature to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Slice a little off the bottom of each pear so they stand upright, then space them out in the tin. Carefully spoon in the filling and bake for 50 mins-1hr until golden and set. Cool to room temperature, slice off the excess pastry to neaten the edges, then serve with cold cream or hot custard.
chief_review:
This reinvented treacle tart brings a delightful freshness to the classic, with zesty lemon and ginger giving welcome complexity. Lemon-poached pears lend a fruity note that nicely cuts through the golden syrup’s richness. The stem ginger adds warmth and depth, making each bite more intriguing. The sweet shortcrust pastry is traditional, and the use of breadcrumbs helps achieve the signature filling texture.

The recipe contains eggs and gluten (from both breadcrumbs and the pastry), so it isn’t suitable for vegan or gluten-free diets. It’s also not nut-free by default, as commercial pastries may contain traces. However, vegetarians can enjoy this dessert, as all ingredients are plant-based except for the eggs, and there are no animal-derived gelatins or fats. Serve slightly warm with a dollop of crème fraîche or Greek yogurt for contrast. This lighter tart is ideal for finishing a meal with style.

name: Crab cocktail
description: Swap prawn and iceberg lettuce for crabmeat, crunchy raw fennel and avocado, topped with classic Marie Rose sauce
author: James Martin
ingredients: 1 small fennel bulb, very finely sliced
500g cooked crabmeat(use a mixture of brown and white)
rustic bread, toasted and thinly sliced, to serve (optional)
large pinch of cayenne pepper, plus a little extra to finish
directions: Put the fennel in a large bowl of ice-cold water with a squeeze of lemon juice. Leave for at least 30 mins to crisp up. Drizzle more lemon juice on the avocados to stop them browning. Whisk together all the ingredients for the Marie Rose sauce in a bowl with seasoning. Set aside to chill in the fridge.

Just before serving, drain the fennel and toss with the remaining lemon juice, dill and some seasoning. Layer the lettuce, avocado, fennel and crab in 4 x half-pint glasses – or tumblers or jam jars. Add a spoonful of sauce to each, then repeat the layers until the glasses are full, finishing with the Marie Rose sauce. Sprinkle a pinch of cayenne pepper over each cocktail and serve with lemon wedges and toast, if you like.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on a classic seafood salad, marrying the sweet, delicate flavors of crabmeat with the refreshing crunch of fennel and creamy richness of avocado. The addition of Baby Gem lettuce brings a tender green note, while the lemon juice and fresh dill brighten the overall flavor profile. The Marie Rose sauce, with its subtle heat from Tabasco and cayenne, complements the crab beautifully without overpowering its natural sweetness. The dish can be served with rustic toasted bread or as a standalone salad, making it versatile for light lunches or elegant starters. With no gluten-containing ingredients (except for the optional bread, which can be omitted or replaced with gluten-free toast), this recipe is suitable for a gluten-free diet. The focus on fresh, whole ingredients also makes it an excellent choice for pescatarians.

name: Cranberry & blue cheese tart with pear salad
description: Use up the remains of the cheeseboard and your cranberry sauce in this sweet-savoury tart
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. In a non-stick frying pan, cook the onions in the olive oil with some seasoning for 12-15 mins until golden and soft.
Lay the pastry on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Spread over the cranberry sauce, leaving a small border. Scatter over the onions. Bake for 20-25 mins, sprinkling with cheese halfway through.
Toss the lettuce leaves and pear with the dressing and serve alongside the tart.
chief_review: This clever tart is a delightful way to transform cheeseboard leftovers into an impressive dish. The deeply caramelized onions pair beautifully with sharp blue cheese, all brought together by the sweet tang of cranberry sauce atop a crispy puff pastry base. Fresh pear and Little Gem lettuce tossed in a light dressing offer a crisp, refreshing contrast on the side. The use of ready-rolled puff pastry requires minimal effort, making this an ideal choice for a quick lunch or light supper. As written, this recipe is vegetarian, suitable for those avoiding meat. For utmost dietary clarity, ensure the puff pastry and blue cheese used are free from animal rennet. The flavor combination of sweet, creamy, and savory components in each bite make this tart a conversation starter and a crowd-pleaser.

name: Crab & avocado sesame toasts
description: This quick canapé can be prepared in minutes by simply assembling the fish and guacamole on crostini bread
author: Good Food
directions: Divide the guacamole between the crostini. Top each one with a spoonful of crabmeat. Toast the sesame seeds in a pan, then sprinkle over each crostini. Serve with lime wedges.
chief_review: This canapé recipe is a delightful marriage of creamy guacamole and fresh white crabmeat served atop crisp crostini. The addition of sesame seeds offers a pleasing textural contrast and a subtle nutty flavor, while lime wedges provide a bright, zesty finish. Perfect for entertaining, this dish delivers elegant flavors with minimal effort. As it contains no meat or poultry, it’s suitable for pescatarian diets, making it a crowd-pleaser for a variety of guests. Note that crostini typically contain gluten, and both crabmeat and sesame are common allergens. Overall, a sophisticated bite that balances freshness and richness beautifully for any gathering.

name: Cranberry vodka
description: Great using Cranberries .. even better with Raspberries (which don't need to be pricked as the shaking will break them up and release the juices) and could be ready sooner than stated if you shake the jar a couple of times a day. Make sure to squeeze all the Raspberries through the sieve though to get all that yummy juice!
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 250g fresh or frozen cranberriesor other berries
directions: Prick each cranberry a couple of times with a fork and layer up in a large sterilised Kilner jar with the sugar. Pour over the vodka and leave for 2 weeks, shaking the jar each day.
Strain and decant into decorative bottles. Seal and label.
chief_review: This vibrant berry-infused vodka recipe is a delightful way to capture the essence of fresh cranberries or raspberries. The process is straightforward, with just three ingredients—berries, vodka, and caster sugar—yielding a liqueur that’s both flavorful and strikingly colored. It’s also gluten-free and suitable for a vegan diet, as neither animal products nor gluten-containing ingredients are used. The tip to shake the jar frequently helps infuse the vodka more quickly and ensures maximum extraction of berry flavor. The final sieve step is essential for a smooth, richly hued spirit. This recipe is a festive homemade touch to cocktails or a wonderful edible gift, especially appealing for those looking for simple, allergen-friendly treats.

name: Grilled baby onions with cream & basil
description: Add tender, creamy baby onions to your roast beef this Sunday for a taste of comfort food heaven
author: Matt Tebbutt
directions: Simmer the onions in the stock for 30 mins, adding a little water if needed to keep them covered. Meanwhile, in a small pan, melt the butter, then add the flour and cook for 1-2 mins. Stirring constantly, gradually pour in the milk, then the cream, and bring to the boil. When you have a smooth white sauce, remove from the heat. Allow to cool a little before stirring in the egg yolks, spices and seasoning.

Heat grill to high. Drain the onions and lay them in a single layer in an ovenproof dish. Spoon over the cream sauce to cover. Grill for 5 mins until lightly browned, then scatter over the basil before serving.
chief_review: This recipe brings silky, caramelized baby onions to a decadent level, pairing beautifully with roast beef. The combination of butter, cream, and egg yolks yields an exceptionally rich texture, heightened by warming notes of nutmeg and a subtle cayenne kick. Basil adds freshness to this otherwise indulgent side. Using chicken stock and double cream, the dish leans into classic comfort food without apology. For those following a vegetarian diet, a simple swap to vegetable stock transforms it without compromising flavor. However, as written, it’s best suited to those without dairy or egg allergies. A wonderful side, particularly at a Sunday roast, where complexity and comfort meet.

name: Streaky stuffing parcels
description: Sage and onion stuffing balls wrapped in bacon makes a great alternative to devils on horseback
author: Good Food
ingredients: good knob of butter, plus extra for greasing
170g pack sage and onion stuffing(we used Paxo)
directions: Butter 12 holes in a muffin tin. Make up the stuffing mix with 520ml boiling water. Add the butter and stir well. Set aside to absorb the water and cool.

Meanwhile, criss-cross two bacon rashers, with a bay leaf if using, in each space in the muffin tin, allowing the excess to overhang the tin (see step-by-step guide). Spoon the cool stuffing mixture into the tin and fold the overhanging bacon over the top to make a parcel. Secure in place with cocktail sticks. Chill until ready to bake.
Bake at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 30 mins, until piping hot and the bacon is cooked. (Remove cocktail sticks before serving.)
chief_review: This recipe for sage and onion stuffing balls wrapped in bacon is a delightful twist, combining the aromatic depth of sage and onion with the richness of smoky bacon. The use of prepared stuffing mix streamlines prep without sacrificing flavor, while the bay leaves add a subtle herbaceous note if you choose to include them. The butter ensures a pleasingly moist and tender stuffing interior. These are an ideal accompaniment to roast dinners or as festive party bites—intensely savory, with a satisfying contrast between the crisp bacon and soft, herby stuffing. This recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-containing, omnivorous diet, but is not appropriate for vegetarians, vegans, or those avoiding gluten or pork. The method is straightforward, making it accessible for home cooks seeking maximum flavor with minimal fuss. Best served hot, with your favorite roast or as a holiday canapé.

name: Prawn cocktail salad
description: A seafood pot to whip up in a flash - the lettuce, avocado and tomatoes provide three of your 5-a-day
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: ¼ romaine lettuce, torn into pieces
1 large avocado, stoned, peeled and sliced
directions: Pile the lettuce, avocado, tomatoes and shallot into a bowl and toss together. Divide between 2 serving bowls, then top with the prawn cocktail. Lightly toss to mix the dressing into the salad, then eat with toast or crusty bread, if you like.
chief_review: This seafood pot is a vibrant medley of fresh textures and flavors. The crisp romaine lettuce, creamy avocado, and juicy cherry tomatoes create a refreshing base, making each bite light yet satisfying. The prawn cocktail adds a tangy seafood element with a classic touch, elevated by the gentle sharpness of thinly sliced shallots. With minimal preparation, this dish offers an ideal blend of creaminess and crunch, perfect for a quick lunch or elegant starter. Suitable for pescatarians, this recipe is also naturally gluten-free, provided the prawn cocktail sauce contains no gluten-based thickeners. The abundance of fresh vegetables ensures a healthy boost, delivering three portions of your daily vegetable intake. An excellent choice for those seeking speed, simplicity, and vibrant flavors in a single pot.

name: Asian cured salmon with prawns, pickled salad & dill lime crème fraîche
description: I really fancy making this for Christmas lunch this year, however, the fish van will be coming round on the 21st December. Could I freeze the salmon first for a couple of days then defrost and cure on the 23rd?
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 125g caster or granulated sugar, plus 2 tsp and another 2 tbsp
5 tbsp Japanese rice vinegar, plus a dash
2 fresh red Thai chillies, sliced (deseeded if you don’t like it too hot)
directions: Check the fish for bones and, if needed, remove with tweezers. To make the cure, put the lemongrass, 125g sugar, the salt, lime juice, zest of 1 lime, 1 tbsp rice vinegar, 1 garlic clove, half of the coriander and dill, including stems, into a
. Blitz until the lemongrass is finely chopped, then stir in a quarter of the sliced chillies.
Cross two large pieces of cling film in a

and spoon on a third of the cure, then top with the fish. Cover the fish with the rest of the cure. Wrap tightly and leave for 36-48 hrs, then scrape off the cure, rinse the fish in cold water and pat dry. The fillet will feel firm.

On the day of serving, start the other elements of the recipe. Shave the turnips into very thin slices using a mandoline, then plunge them into iced water with a dash of the vinegar. Leave for an hour, then drain well. Thinly slice the onion and mix with the turnip slices, 2 tbsp vinegar, 2 tsp sugar and a pinch of salt. Cover and steep for at least 1 hr, or chill for a few hrs.
Finely chop the remaining dill leaves and stir most of them into the crème fraîche with the remaining lime zest and a little seasoning, then chill.
For the dressing, stir together the remaining 2 tbsp sugar, 2 tbsp vinegar, another quarter of the sliced chillies and the crushed garlic and leave until the sugar dissolves.
Slice the fish into approx 20 slices, taking the
down to the skin, then easing the blade underneath each piece to remove it.

When ready to serve, spoon and swoosh the dill crème fraîche down the middle of each plate, then top with overlapping salmon slices. Add 3 prawns per serving. Lift the salad from its juices and mound to one side. Scatter with a little extra dill and the remaining sliced chillies, then drizzle the dressing over the fish and prawns (or let your guests do that bit at the table).
chief_review:
This vibrant cured salmon dish is a showstopper for any festive table, with zesty citrus, aromatic lemongrass, and fresh herbs creating a lively balance of flavors. The suggested combination of crème fraîche, prawns, and salmon offers a rich yet refreshing ensemble, ideal for a celebratory lunch. The pickled elements, powered by rice vinegar and baby turnips, add texture and sharpness, while mild chili and fresh coriander provide a subtle heat and fragrance.

This recipe is well-suited for pescatarians, as it features salmon, prawns, and an assortment of plant-based aromatics. However, it contains both seafood and dairy (crème fraîche), so those with shellfish or dairy allergies should be cautious. Gluten-intolerant guests can enjoy this recipe, as all ingredients are naturally gluten-free. Overall, this dish offers a sophisticated, fresh, and festive addition to any celebration.

name: Ivy House roast potatoes
description: A couple of tablespoons of semolina help make the perfect roast potato - serve with Sunday lunch or Christmas dinner
author: Good Food
directions: Peel potatoes and cut into even-size pieces (Ivy House used Marfona and allowed 4 pieces per person).
Put potatoes in boiling salted water. Bring back to the boil and simmer for 10 mins.
Meanwhile, melt lard in a thick roasting pan in the oven at 220C/fan 200/gas 7. (Ivy House tried both goose fat and butcher’s beef dripping, but found neither as successful as good old lard.)
Drain the potatoes and put back in the saucepan with a couple of tbsp of semolina. Cover the pan and shake it to rough up the potatoes.
Remove the baking tray from the oven and put the potatoes in the lard, turning to coat each one in the melted lard.
Return the tray to the oven and roast for 40 mins, turning the potatoes 2-3 times as necessary.
Remove tray from the oven and put the potatoes in a serving dish. Return the dish of potatoes to the hot oven for 10 mins to dry any fat off. Serve straight away – roast potatoes wait for no man!
chief_review: This recipe delivers beautifully crisp and golden roast potatoes, with semolina providing extra crunch. The use of lard ensures an irresistibly rich flavor and superbly textured exterior—a technique highly regarded among chefs for traditional Sunday roasts or festive dinners. However, it's important to note that this recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the use of lard (animal fat). Additionally, semolina—derived from wheat—means the dish is not appropriate for a gluten-free diet or those with wheat allergies. For an impressive and classic side, these roast potatoes are sure to become a favorite on any special occasion table.

name: Lamb & feta burgers with minty yogurt
description: Delicately spiced morsels with a cooling yogurt dip - perfect party food
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
ingredients: 1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
1 egg, lightly beaten with a fork
directions: First make the dip by mixing together the yogurt and mint with a little seasoning, then chill until ready to serve.

Tip the lamb mince into a big bowl with the spices, chilli, herbs, Worcestershire sauce and egg. Season, then get your hands in and mix well. Divide the mixture into 16. Shape into burgers, pushing a cube of cheese into the centre of each and sealing in. Chill until just before your guests arrive.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and heat the oil in a frying pan. Fry the burgers for 1-2 mins until brown on each side, then transfer to a baking tray. Put in the oven for 5-10 mins until cooked through and piping hot. Pile onto a big plate and serve with the dip on the side.
chief_review: This recipe for spiced lamb morsels with a cooling yogurt dip is wonderfully aromatic and perfect as party fare. The combination of ground coriander, cumin seeds, fresh herbs, and a hint of red chilli brings a well-balanced depth to the lamb, while the feta at the center of each bite adds a creamy, tangy surprise. The accompanying mint yogurt dip offers a refreshing counterpoint to the spices. This dish is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided that the Worcestershire sauce used does not contain gluten. It's an excellent choice for those who enjoy Mediterranean and Middle Eastern flavors, and the inclusion of fresh herbs elevates both the taste and presentation. Serve these warm to appreciate the melting feta and crispy exterior—guests are sure to enjoy every bite.

name: Tuna & red onion salad
description: This simple salad is perfect for a guilt-free, post-Christmas lunch - it makes the most of storecupboard ingredients too
author: Good Food
directions: Mix canned tuna (drained) with cooked new potatoes, red onion, capers and a handful of rocket or watercress, and toss with a bought fat-free dressing.
chief_review: This vibrant salad delivers a refreshing balance of flavors and textures, combining flaky tuna, tender new potatoes, sharp red onion, and briny capers atop a bed of peppery rocket or watercress. It’s a clever use of storecupboard staples, making it ideal for a quick, nourishing lunch after festive indulgence. The potato base adds heartiness without heaviness, while capers bring a delightful pop of acidity. This recipe is naturally gluten-free and dairy-free, making it suitable for those with gluten or lactose sensitivities. Additionally, it aligns well with pescatarian diets. Simple yet satisfying, this salad is a testament to how a few well-chosen ingredients can create a wholesome meal.

name: Jaffa sorbet
description: Make the most of your Jaffa Cakes with this low-fat dessert - ideal after a food-laden Christmas
author: Good Food
directions: Arrange a Jaffa Cake (a good low-fat choice) with a scoop of orange or mango sorbet, and drizzle with a little bought raspberry sauce.
chief_review: This clever dessert elevates store-bought Jaffa Cakes by pairing them with a scoop of zesty orange or mango sorbet and a drizzle of raspberry sauce, resulting in a refreshing, low-fat treat. The combination offers a delightful contrast of textures: cakey biscuit, creamy fruit sorbet, and tangy sauce. This recipe is especially suited to vegetarians and is mindful of those wanting a lighter ending after a large meal. The use of sorbet instead of ice cream keeps things vibrant and less heavy. The dessert comes together in minutes, making it a perfect option for effortless entertaining or a guilt-free sweet fix.

name: Spiced blackened prawns with clementine salsa
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 1 lime, cut into wedges to serve
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Start by butterflying the prawns. Using a small serrated knife, cut down the back of the prawns through the shells and the flesh from the heads to the tails, cutting just far enough that you can open it up, then remove the black entrails. Once all the prawns are butterflied, set aside.
Combine all the salsa ingredients in a bowl with some seasoning. Ideally leave the salsa at room temperature for 30 mins so that the flavours can infuse.

Mix all the seasoning ingredients together, along with 1 tsp fine salt and 1/ 2 tsp cracked pepper, in a bowl. Brush the prawns inside and out with the melted butter, then toss in the spice mix. Heat two large frying pans over a high heat, tip in the prawns and cook for 4-6 mins until they have just turned pink and the insides are opaque. Serve on a board with the salsa and lime wedges.
chief_review:
This prawn recipe offers an enticing blend of smoky, citrusy, and lightly spiced flavors that will impress any seafood lover. The use of giant tiger prawns as the star ingredient, complemented by a zesty clementine and lime salsa, brings a refreshing brightness that cuts through the richness of butter and olive oil. The combination of paprika, cayenne, cumin, and herbs creates a beautifully balanced marinade with just enough heat and depth without overwhelming the delicate prawns.

This dish is excellent for gluten-free diets, as none of the ingredients contain gluten. It also fits a pescatarian lifestyle and is naturally nut-free, making it suitable for those avoiding nuts or gluten in their meals. The freshness from coriander and cucumber elevates the overall taste, while the presentation with lime wedges makes for a vibrant plate—ideal for summer gatherings and as a standout appetizer or main.

name: Lobster with Thermidor butter
description: A luxury that has been prized by chefs for years, so make the most of it with this cheat's classic
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: First make the butter. Put the wine and shallot into a pan, then bring to the boil and simmer until nearly dry. Tip into a bowl to cool, mix all the ingredients together, roll into a log, using cling film or foil, then chill to harden. Can be frozen for up to 1 month.

Snap away the claws from the lobster. Using a large chef’s knife, cut the lobster in half and wash the head cavity under cold water, then dry with kitchen paper. Lay the lobsters, cut side up, on a baking tray. Crack the claws and remove the claw meat. Divide claw meat between the head cavities. This can be done the day before and the lobster kept in the fridge ready for grilling.

Heat grill to high. Slice the butter into thin rounds and lay it along the lobsters so all the meat is covered. Grill for 5-8 mins until the butter is bubbling and starting to brown. Put the lobsters on plates, pouring any butter from the tray over them. Serve with new potatoes and some dressed salad leaves.
chief_review: This recipe is a splendid tribute to classic luxury, allowing the natural sweetness of lobster to shine while building layers of complexity with fresh herbs, a dash of Dijon, and the subtle kick of Tabasco. The white wine reduction, enriched with lush butter and laced with lemon, tarragon, and parsley, promises a sauce with depth and fragrance. Topping it all with parmesan adds a decadent, umami-rich crust, lightly caramelized under the grill for irresistible texture and flavor. Dairy from butter and parmesan makes this a fine option for pescatarians seeking a celebratory dish, though it’s not suitable for those with dairy allergies. The careful balance of acidity, herbal notes, and gentle heat shows finesse, making this "cheat's classic" both approachable for the home cook and impressive enough for any special occasion. It’s refined, richly flavored, and beautifully showcases lobster’s natural elegance.

name: Richly spiced plum chutney
description: Make-ahead for special occasions or simply enjoy al fresco with your favourite cold cuts
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 1kg plum, halved, stoned and finely chopped
100g dried cranberriesor raisins, roughly chopped with an oiled knife
directions: Put all the ingredients, except the sugar, into a large pan and stir well. Bring slowly to the boil, then reduce the heat, cover and simmer for 10 mins, until the plums are tender.

Stir in the sugar plus 2 tsp salt and keep stirring until it has dissolved. Boil the chutney for 20-30 mins, uncovered, stirring occasionally to prevent it catching on the bottom, until it is thick and pulpy.
Pot into sterilised jars (see Know-how, below), seal, label and store for at least 2 weeks before eating. Will keep for up to 6 months in a cool dark place.
chief_review: This plum chutney recipe is a vibrant blend of sweet, tart, and warmly spiced flavors, perfect for elevating a charcuterie board or complementing an alfresco spread. The harmonious marriage of fresh plums, dried cranberries, aromatic ginger, and a well-balanced spice mix creates delightful depth. The use of red wine vinegar and light muscovado sugar ensures a glossy, sticky condiment with just the right tang and sweetness to cut through rich cold cuts or cheeses. This chutney is naturally vegetarian and vegan, containing no animal-derived products, and also gluten-free, making it an inclusive option for varied diets. Its make-ahead convenience means flavors only improve with time—ideal for entertaining or gifting. A thoughtful, well-rounded preserve that showcases both creativity and practicality.

name: Ham, cheese & mushroom turnovers
description: A puff pastry turnover is always a good way of using leftovers - adapt the recipe to whatever cheese you've got
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tbsp each butterand flour, mixed to a paste, plus extra for dusting
85g leftover cheese(amount will vary according to type - go with your taste buds), cut into small pieces
1 tbsp chopped herbs- tarragon, parsley and chives all work well
directions: The first thing to do is to make a thick white sauce that will be the base of the turnover filling. Bring the milk to a simmer, then add the butter and flour paste. Whisk the paste into the simmering milk and allow it to boil for 3-4 mins, whisking gently all the time to prevent it from catching. You should now have a very thick white sauce. Cool the sauce in a bowl. Fry the mushrooms in the oil for 3-5 mins until golden, then leave to cool.
Place the ham, cheese and mushrooms into a bowl, then gradually add the white sauce until everything is well coated. Finally, add the herbs.

Roll out the pastry on a floured surface to about the thickness of a £1 coin and cut out 4 saucer-size rounds (about 18cm wide), re-rolling the trimmings if you need to. Brush the edges of each round with beaten egg. Spoon the mixture onto 1 side of each round, then fold over and seal the edges well. The turnovers can now be frozen for up to 1 month. Brush the turnover with the remaining egg, then chill for 30 mins.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Place the turnovers on a baking sheet and bake for about 35 mins until puffed up and golden. Leave to cool slightly and enjoy warm.
chief_review: This puff pastry turnover is an excellent showcase for creativity with leftovers, particularly cheese. The recipe balances savory mushrooms, ham, and herbs enveloped in a golden, flaky pastry. The use of a classic roux (milk, butter, flour) lends a creamy texture, while fresh herbs brighten the filling. It’s a rich, indulgent option, perfect for a hearty lunch or casual dinner, especially when served with a crisp salad. The flexibility with cheese types ensures each batch can be unique. This recipe suits those following a vegetarian diet if the ham is omitted and replaced with extra mushrooms or vegetables. However, as written, it contains gluten, dairy, eggs, and meat, so it is not suited to a vegan or gluten-free diet. Overall, the flavors are comforting and satisfying, ideal for using up kitchen leftovers in style.

name: Fragrant Thai prawns
description: Add subtle Thai flavours to seafood in Curtis Stone's prawn recipe
author: Curtis Stone
ingredients: 1 fresh red chilli, halved, seeded and finely chopped
2½ cm piece of fresh root ginger, peeled and finely chopped
1 stem of lemongrass, tough outer leaves removed, finely chopped
a good handful of fresh mint leaves, finely chopped
a good handful of fresh coriander leaves, finely chopped
grated zest and juice of 1 lime
directions: Tip all the chopped ingredients into a bowl, add the olive oil along with the lime zest and juice and mix well. Set aside for 30 minutes to allow the flavours to mingle.

To make fragrant Thai prawns, remove heads and peel shells from 20 raw king prawns but leave tail sections on. Toss in the marinade and cook on a really hot barbecue for 45 seconds on each side until they turn from grey-blue to pink.
chief_review: Curtis Stone’s prawn recipe is an elegant dish that elevates seafood through a medley of fresh, bright Thai flavors. The blend of lemongrass, lime, ginger, mint, and coriander delivers a fragrant, zesty punch that enhances the natural sweetness of the prawns without overpowering them. Olive oil contributes a subtle richness, while garlic and red chili add depth and a gentle heat. This recipe is free from gluten and dairy, making it suitable for those seeking gluten-free or lactose-free options. As all the ingredients are plant-based aside from the prawns, it also fits a pescatarian diet perfectly. The simple preparation preserves the freshness of the aromatics, producing a dish that is both light and vibrantly flavorful—a superb choice for a summery starter or main course.

name: Pot-roast loin of pork with celeriac, shallots & pancetta
description: A chunky, comforting casserole that makes a wonderful Sunday lunch
author: Ruth Watson
ingredients: 6-8 garlic cloves, peeled and cut into thin slivers
1 x 130g twin-pack cubetti di pancetta(small cubes of Italian cured belly pork)
600ml full-bodied red wine– drink the remainder!
directions: Using a small, sharp kitchen knife, stab through the fatty side of the pork loin to make about 30 fairly deep, randomly spaced incisions. Insert a sliver of garlic into each stab mark, pushing the garlic well into the meat and smoothing over the fat to close up the entry points. Reserve a few slivers to push in cuts made on the flesh-side of the joint.

Put 5 tablespoons of the olive oil, the juice of the lemon, tbsp of fennel seeds and the leaves stripped from 4 oregano sprigs in a large non-reactive dish (a non-porous dish, such as glass or stainless steel, which won’t react with acidic foods and alter the flavour). Grind in plenty of black pepper, then swish everything into a sludge with one clean hand. Put the joint into the dish and massage the marinade into every nook and cranny. Leave the pork to marinade for 6-24 hours in a cool place or the fridge.

When you are ready to start cooking, preheat the oven to 170C/Gas 4/fan oven 150C. Put the 300g of shallots in a heatproof bowl and cover with boiling water. Leave for 2 minutes to loosen the skins, then tip the shallots into a large sieve or colander and rinse under cold water. Trim off the root end, then peel the shallots, breaking any large ones into their natural segments. Halve the 4 celeriac wedges, then cut into large, bite-sized chunks.

Heat the remaining oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat. Toss in the 130g pack of pancetta and fry for 2-3 minutes until slightly frazzled. Transfer the cubes to a large casserole big enough to take the pork, using a slotted spoon so the fat drains back into the pan. Throw the shallots and celeriac into the frying pan and sauté them for 3-4 minutes until coloured, turning frequently. Transfer them to the casserole, again draining off the oil.

Pull the frying pan to one side. Quickly scrape off any excess marinade from the pork loin, then season the meat with fine sea salt. Replace the frying pan over a medium-high heat and brown the pork on all sides, including the ends. Place the loin on the vegetables in the casserole. Stuff the remaining 4 sprigs of oregano around it.

Pour off and discard all the fat in the frying pan, raise the heat and pour in the 600ml of wine. Bring to the boil, scraping up all the tasty bits from the bottom of the pan. Let the wine bubble and reduce for 3 minutes, then pour into the casserole.

Place the casserole over a high heat and bring the juices up to a bubble. Immediately put the lid on the casserole and transfer it to the oven. Cook the loin for 1 hour 45 minutes, turning it halfway through. Remove the casserole from the oven and leave the pork to rest in a warm place for 15-30 minutes, still covered, before carving.
chief_review: This pork casserole is a robust and aromatic dish, perfect for a leisurely Sunday lunch. The combination of British pork loin with fragrant garlic, fennel seeds, and fresh oregano creates a deeply savory base, while cubetti di pancetta and shallots add sweet and smoky layers. Celeriac delivers earthiness and texture, with the richness balanced beautifully by a generous pour of red wine and a hint of lemon zest. The use of olive oil ensures the meat remains moist, and the overall result is succulent, with complex, well-rounded flavors. This recipe is well-suited for gluten-free diets, as there are no wheat-based ingredients involved. Allergy-wise, it is free from nuts and eggs but does contain pork. An excellent choice for those seeking hearty, classic comfort food with Mediterranean flair.

name: Slow-baked sticky gammon
description: Fancy a cross between a traditional roasted ham and pulled pork? Use pineapple, treacle and ginger marinade as a tropical glaze
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 3-4kg gammon(doesn't need to be 1 piece, just make up the weight with smaller joints)
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Fit the gammon, quite snugly, in a big, deep roasting tin or casserole. Reserve 150ml of the pineapple juice, then pour the rest over the gammon, plus enough water to fill the tin about three-quarters full. Cover tightly with a few sheets of foil, then put in the oven and bake for 4 hrs. About halfway through, check the liquid levels and turn the gammon.
Remove the gammon and pour off the liquid. Cut away the rind and most of the fat, leaving just a thin layer of fat on the joints.

Whizz the reserved pineapple juice, allspice, treacle, ginger, ketchup, sweet chilli and honey together to combine to a purée. Spoon all over the gammon and set aside until ready to serve (or, if you’ve made at home before taking to the host’s house, cover and chill for up to 48 hrs).
To serve, heat oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6. Roast for 30 mins until hot and sticky, then loosely break into large chunks to serve.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a vibrant fusion of tropical and traditional flavors, infusing gammon with a lively pineapple juice, black treacle, and fresh ginger marinade. The use of allspice, tomato ketchup, sweet chilli sauce, and honey crafts a balanced glaze: sweet, tangy, and aromatic, with the richness of slow-cooked pork. The final result is reminiscent of both a festive glazed ham and the succulent texture of pulled pork, making it a showstopper for celebratory gatherings or Sunday roasts. Notably, the absence of gluten-containing ingredients makes this dish suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided all condiments used are certified gluten-free. The recipe isn’t suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or those with pork or pineapple allergies, but for meat lovers seeking bold, tropical notes, it’s a crowd-pleaser.

name: Creamy pesto with prosciutto dippers
description: Barely any more effort than opening a bag of crisps - and your party guests will be so much more impressed with this
author: Good Food
directions: Mix the soft cheese with 2 tbsp basil pesto. Take the pack grissini (bread sticks) and halve each one. Cut the prosciutto into strips and wrap around the end of each grissini. Serve alongside the pesto dip. Scatter the pine nuts over dip and drizzle with extra virgin olive oil before serving.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful and sophisticated party snack, combining the creamy tang of light soft cheese with the herby punch of basil pesto. The crunchy grissini provide perfect texture, while the prosciutto lends a savory depth that pairs beautifully with the gentle bite of toasted pine nuts. A final drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil adds silkiness and elevates the flavors. Suitable for those following a gluten-free diet if gluten-free grissini are used, and ideal for anyone seeking a quick yet impressive appetizer for gatherings. The careful layering of flavors and textures here demonstrates an understanding of classic Italian antipasti—simple, elegant, and full of flavor. Serve on a rustic wooden board for maximum visual impact and enjoy the effortless sophistication this dish brings to any party spread.

name: Chocolate orange bombe Alaska with hot chocolate sauce
description: This twist on baked Alaska looks simply stunning – and the dark chocolate and orange flavours are just as good. Try it for Christmas, Hogmanay or New Year
author: Nick Nairn
ingredients: 100g/4oz bar dark chocolate (minimum 70% solids), broken into pieces
5 tbsp orange whisky marmalade(good-quality, fine cut)
600ml/1pint tub orange sorbet (you will only need approx 400ml), softened slightly
200g/7oz bar dark chocolate (minimum 70 per cent solids)
directions: First make the cake: heat oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Lightly butter a Swiss roll tin and line the base with non-stick baking parchment. Put the whole eggs, egg yolks and caster sugar in a bowl and whisk with an electric hand whisk for 8-10 mins until light and fluffy. Meanwhile, melt the chocolate and butter in a bowl over a pan of almost simmering water, stirring occasionally.

When the whisked egg mixture is light and fluffy, gently fold in the flour with a large metal spoon or the whisk blades, taking care not to lose too much volume. Beat a small amount of the egg mixture into the melted chocolate, then gently fold the chocolate into the remaining egg mixture. Pour into the prepared tin, then tilt the tin from side to side until even and the corners are filled. Bake for 10 mins until firm, then leave to cool completely.

Line a 1-litre freezer-proof pudding basin with cling film. Cut a small circle of sponge cake to fit the base then cut triangular pieces to line the sides. Fill any gaps with trimmings and save the remaining sponge for later. Place the bowl in the freezer to firm up the sponge.

Make the ice cream: slice the vanilla pod in half lengthways and remove the seeds. Put the milk, vanilla seeds and pod, orange zest, caster sugar and cream into a medium pan and bring to the boil. Meanwhile, whisk the egg yolks together in a large bowl. Pour the hot cream mixture slowly on to the eggs, whisking all the time. Return the mix to a clean pan and stir constantly over a gentle heat for about 5 mins until the mixture has just thickened. Pass through a sieve and leave to cool for 30 mins. Churn in an ice-cream machine (or make by hand, see 'Try' below). Add the marmalade and continue to churn for another 10 mins until thick.

Scoop the ice cream into the cake-lined bowl, leaving a central indent for the sorbet layer. Sit a small bowl in the top of the ice cream to make a smooth indent for the sorbet later to sit in. Freeze for at least 1 hr, until just firm.

Fill the centre of the bombe with orange sorbet, cover the entire base of the bowl with a layer of sponge, cover with cling film and return to the freezer until needed, or at least 8 hrs ahead. This can be done well in advance and that’s all the really hard work done.
, grate the chocolate into a bowl and add the golden syrup, butter and warm water. Melt over a pan of just simmering water until melted, stirring occasionally.

About 20 mins before serving, heat oven to 230C/fan 210C/gas 8. Whisk the egg whites and a pinch of salt in a large clean bowl until stiff but not dry. Whisk in the sugar, a little at a time, bringing it back to stiff peaks before each addition. Turn the bombe out onto an ovenproof serving dish and remove the cling film. Spoon the meringue all over the bombe to completely seal it. Using the back of the spoon or a palette knife, pull the meringue into dramatic swirls. Bake for 10-15 mins or until golden. Reheat the chocolate sauce over a pan as before or in a microwaveable bowl for 1 min on Low, stirring halfway through. Take the Chocolate orange bombe Alaska to the table immediately and serve sliced, drizzled with the hot chocolate sauce.
chief_review:
This elegant baked Alaska variation wonderfully marries intense dark chocolate with bright orange zest, creating a visually dramatic and festive centrepiece suitable for any celebration. Layers of rich dark chocolate sponge and silky orange-infused custard complement each other, while the orange sorbet adds a refreshing contrast. The flambéed meringue exterior provides an irresistible touch of theatre. 

The recipe includes dairy (butter, cream, milk), eggs, wheat (flour), and alcohol (orange whisky marmalade), making it a decadent choice best suited for those without dietary restrictions. However, it is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat, poultry, or fish products. Fans of bold citrus and chocolate pairings will particularly appreciate this showstopper dessert. The result is a harmonious balance of texture and flavour—perfect for a memorable holiday table.

name: Dolcelatte-stuffed figs
description: Simple yet impressive stuffed figs make lovely canapés and only take 15 minutes to make
author: Good Food
directions: Remove the hard core from the dried figs. Cut a pocket in each with the point of a knife, then stuff each pocket with ½ tsp dolcelatte cheese.
Cut the prosciutto in half lengthways, then wrap up each stuffed fig into a little parcel. Serve scattered with a small handful chopped parsley if you have it.
chief_review: These stuffed figs are a delightful bite-sized treat, combining the rich creaminess of dolcelatte cheese with the sweet chewiness of dried figs and the savory touch of prosciutto. The fresh chopped parsley adds a subtle herbal note to balance the flavors. The use of these ingredients makes this recipe suitable for a gluten-free diet, as none of the components contain gluten. However, the presence of dairy and cured meat means it's best enjoyed by those without related dietary restrictions. These canapés are easy to assemble and pack a punch in both flavor and presentation, making them perfect for entertaining. The contrasting textures and harmonious blend of sweet, salty, and creamy elements will surely impress your guests without taking up much of your time.

name: Turkey & parsnip curry
description: This post-Christmas curry is full of flavour and so easy to make - even better, it's all cooked in one pan, so there's very little washing up
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 onions, halved through the root and thinly sliced
500g parsnip, peeled and cut into chunks
500g/1lb 2oz boneless cooked turkey, cut into chunks
directions: Heat the oil in a saucepan, add the onions and fry gently for 10 minutes until they are softened and lightly coloured. Add the parsnips and stir well.

To make the curry, stir in the curry paste, then add the tomatoes with a little salt, and stir well. Add 1½ canfuls of water and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat, cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes, until the parsnips are just tender.

To finish, stir in the turkey chunks, cover the pan again and simmer for a further 5 minutes until the turkey is heated through. Remove from the heat. (The curry can now be cooled and frozen for up to 2 months.) Lightly swirl in the yogurt and serve with basmati rice.
chief_review: This post-Christmas curry is a clever and resourceful way to transform leftover turkey into a vibrant, one-pan meal bursting with flavour. The sweetness of parsnips pairs harmoniously with the robust Madras curry paste, while the chopped tomatoes bring a delightful freshness to the sauce. Finishing with a swirl of low-fat yogurt adds a creamy tang and balances the dish beautifully. The use of cooked turkey makes this recipe suitable for those looking for lean protein options, and it’s low in saturated fat thanks to the choice of low-fat yogurt. Served over fluffy basmati rice, it’s a warming, satisfying meal perfect for a relaxed family dinner. This curry is a practical, delicious choice for anyone seeking a straightforward, flavour-forward dish to make post-holiday.

name: Sautéed scallops with mushrooms & spinach sauce
description: A quick, impressive dish that's easy to prepare and cook, creating stacks of flavour within minutes
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 100g mushroom, sliced (button, chestnut or cleaned wild)
6 good-sized scallops, shelled and cleaned (with or without corals)
directions: Melt a knob of butter in a frying pan. Once sizzling, add the mushrooms and fry for just a min or two before adding the spinach. Cook on a high heat for about 1 min, allowing the leaves to wilt and soften. Drain the leaves and mushrooms in a sieve or small colander set over a bowl, pressing them gently in the sieve to release the juices (the juices will provide the base for the sauce, so don’t discard them). Keep warm to one side.

Heat the oil in a separate clean frying pan. When very hot, add the scallops. Sauté for a couple of mins without disturbing them at all, then add a knob of butter to the pan. Turn the scallops, season with salt and pepper, then baste with the sizzling butter. Continue to cook for a further couple of mins until the scallops are ready.

While sautéing the scallops, return the saved spinach juices to the pan the spinach and mushrooms were cooked in, then whisk in the remaining knob of butter to create the sauce. Season with salt and pepper and a grating of nutmeg.
Now finish in style: Arrange spinach and mushrooms on plates or in bowls, sit the scallops on top, then spoon the nutmeg spinach sauce around.
chief_review: This recipe delivers an elegant, restaurant-quality plate in a remarkably short time. The harmony of earthy mushrooms, sweet scallops, and vibrant spinach comes together beautifully, with the butter enriching every element and the freshly grated nutmeg offering aromatic warmth. The use of groundnut oil ensures a high smoke point for a golden sear on the scallops. This dish is an excellent fit for pescatarians, as it features seafood and vegetables without any meat or poultry. Additionally, the absence of wheat products makes it naturally gluten-free, suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. The recipe relies on simple techniques but produces complex, layered flavors—perfect for a quick yet impressive main course. Serve immediately to enjoy the buttery richness and delicate texture of the scallops at their best.

name: Crumble-topped mince pies
description: Gluten and egg-free diets are catered for with these crunchy mince pies. The perfect addition to a cup of tea or glass of mulled wine
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g gluten-free flour (we used Doves Farm), plus a little extra for rolling
200g gluten-free mincemeat (we used Sainsbury's luxury mincemeat)
directions: To make the pastry, rub the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Add the icing sugar and orange zest. Spoon in 4 tbsp water, mixing with a knife until the dough starts to come together. Knead lightly, flatten into a disc, wrap in cling film and chill for at least 30 mins.

Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. On a lightly floured work surface, roll the pastry out to a 2-3mm thickness. Using a 9-10cm fluted cutter, stamp out discs from the pastry. Re-roll any trimmings and stamp out more discs until the pastry is used up. Line two 8-hole muffin tins with the pastry discs, then fill each pastry shell with 1 heaped tsp mincemeat and spread out to smooth. Can be frozen, uncooked, in trays for up to 1 month.

Combine the crumble ingredients in a small bowl, then sprinkle a little over the top of each mince pie. Bake on the middle shelf of the oven for about 20 mins until the pastry is cooked and golden brown. Cool in the tins for 5 mins, then serve with brandy butter or crème fraîche.
chief_review: These gluten and egg-free mince pies are a thoughtful nod to inclusive baking, delivering classic holiday flavors without compromising on texture. The pastry, thanks to the chilled unsalted butter and the use of Doves Farm gluten-free flour, achieves a satisfying crunch and lightness. The hint of orange zest complements the Sainsbury’s luxury mincemeat, giving a fragrant depth. Almonds add both richness and a delightful contrasting crunch, while the cinnamon and brown sugar lend a classic festive warmth. This recipe is suitable for those following gluten-free and egg-free diets, making it perfect for gatherings with guests who have specific dietary needs. Serve with tea or mulled wine for a truly nostalgic seasonal treat.

name: Fried rice with egg & ginger
description: John Torode's delicious egg fried rice is dotted with juicy prawns and makes a great addition to a Chinese feast
author: John Torode
ingredients: bunch spring onions, whites and greens separated and sliced
directions: Heat the oil in a wok. Add the ginger and garlic, then stir-fry briefly until just coloured. Add the prawns and the whites of the spring onions, and cook for a further 3 mins. Pour in the beaten egg, let it set for a couple of secs, then break it up and stir well to scramble. Add the cooked rice and stir-fry everything together for 10 mins. Add the rest of the spring onions, rice wine and soy, then toss everything together well. Serve immediately.
chief_review: John Torode’s egg fried rice with juicy prawns is a lively, satisfying dish that brings authentic flavors and lovely textures to your table. The sharp freshness of ginger and the aromatic garlic infuse the rice beautifully, while the prawns add a subtle sweetness and a succulent bite. Fluffy scrambled eggs give the dish richness and color, complemented by the gentle crunch of spring onions. The finishing splash of rice wine and soy sauce creates a harmonious balance, tying together all the elements with umami depth. This recipe contains no gluten-based ingredients, provided you use gluten-free soy sauce, making it adaptable for a gluten-free diet. It's also ideal for pescatarians, as it highlights seafood and omits other meats. Serve as part of a larger Chinese meal or as a stand-alone centerpiece—it's bound to impress both family and guests.

name: Herby bean sausage stew
description: Great dish, I added all the suggested spices, halved brussels sprouts, zucchini, and finally large fresh spinach leaves. It was so good the next day.
author: Good Food
directions: Heat a large non-stick frying pan, then brown the sausages for 3-5 mins over a high heat. Drain the beans, then add to the pan with the chopped tomatoes, herbs and sugar. Season well and bring to the boil. Simmer for 10 mins until the sausages are cooked through and the sauce has thickened, coating the beans.
chief_review: This recipe offers a hearty blend of flavors, combining savory chipolatas with mixed beans and vibrant tomatoes, elevated by aromatic basil and oregano. The addition of zucchini, halved brussels sprouts, and fresh spinach lends freshness and texture, making the dish both comforting and wholesome. The balance of herbs and a touch of sugar enhance the sauce beautifully, while the use of canned beans adds protein and fiber. This dish would suit those looking for a balanced, protein-rich meal. It's particularly ideal for family-style dining or meal prepping, as the flavors deepen and improve with time, making delicious leftovers.

name: Red pepper, walnut & goat’s cheese palmiers
description: These mini French pastry swirls with soft cheese are a great cheat's canapé - quick, simple and stunning
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Roll out the puff pastry to a large rectangle. Spread the goat’s cheese over the pastry. Roughly chop the peppers and walnut pieces, then sprinkle over the cheese. Roll up one edge of the pastry into the centre, then repeat with the opposite edge to meet in the middle. Cut into 20 slices, place on a baking tray and bake for 10-12 mins until golden.
chief_review: This recipe for mini French pastry swirls with soft goat’s cheese makes a delightful canapé—elegant yet easy to prepare. The ready-made puff pastry ensures crisp, golden layers without the fuss, while soft goat’s cheese provides a creamy, tangy base. Roasted red peppers add a sweet, smoky dimension, complemented by the rich crunch of walnuts. This harmonious combination creates canapés that are visually appealing and bursting with flavor contrasts. Not only are these bites quick to assemble, but they’re also a winning option for vegetarian guests, thanks to the absence of meat and fish. For those seeking impressive party treats that balance taste, texture, and ease, these pastry swirls are sure to impress.

name: Courgette & tomato chutney
description: A chunky and vibrant homemade pickle flavoured with yellow mustard seeds- keep as an accompaniment or present as a gift
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g brown sugar(any brown sugar will work)
directions: Put the vinegar, 300ml water, sugar and spices in a very large pan. Heat, stirring, until the sugar dissolves then add the rest of the ingredients with a tsp of salt.
Bring back to a simmer then simmer uncovered for 2 1/2 hours until darkened, thick and chutney-like.
To sterilise the jars, wash thoroughly in very hot soapy water. Rinse in very hot water then put on a baking sheet in a 140C/fan 120C/gas 1 oven until completely dry.
Pour the chutney into the sterilised jars while still hot, seal and leave in a cool dark place for at least 3 weeks before opening.
chief_review: This vibrant homemade pickle is a delightful condiment, bursting with sweet and tangy flavors from the blend of cider vinegar, brown sugar, and aromatic spices. The yellow mustard seeds and cinnamon add depth, complementing the natural sweetness of onions, courgettes, tomatoes, apples, and sultanas. The recipe is suited to vegan and vegetarian diets as it contains no animal-derived products. It is also gluten-free if you ensure your vinegar has no additives containing gluten. With its chunky texture and bright, complex flavor profile, this pickle is perfect as an accompaniment to cheeses, curries, or roasted vegetables, and would make a thoughtful homemade gift. The generous amount of fruit and veg makes it robust and satisfying on the palate. Store in sterilized jars to ensure optimal freshness.

name: Slow roast shoulder of pork
description: If you're entertaining a crowd, keep the cooking laid-back but delicious with this tender roast pork and homemade apple sauce
author: John Torode
ingredients: 3kg piece of pork shoulder, bone in and rind on
directions: The day before, use a very sharp knife to score the skin of the pork in a criss-cross fashion at 1cm intervals. (Ask your butcher to do this if you prefer.) Combine the garlic, paprika, oil, lemon juice and 1 tsp salt in a mixing bowl. Rub this marinade all over the pork, cover and leave in the fridge for 12-24 hrs.

The next day, heat oven to 220C/ 200C fan/gas 7. Put the potatoes in a roasting tin to make a trivet for the meat, trimming them flat if you need to. Sit the pork on top, then pour any marinade plus ½ a cup of water over the pork. Cook for 30 mins to start the crackling crisping up. Now turn down the oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2, cover the tin with foil and cook for 3½ hrs. Remove from the oven and leave to rest for 30 mins. Serve with apple sauce, see below.
chief_review:
This roast pork shoulder recipe is a classic centerpiece for gatherings, combining rich, tender meat with the brightness of homemade apple sauce. The garlic and paprika lend aromatic depth, while a squeeze of lemon juice provides a welcome lift to the richness of the pork. Roasting with potatoes ensures a comforting, hearty side that absorbs the pork’s flavorful juices. The straightforward ingredient list makes this dish accessible and unfussy, ideal for laid-back entertaining. 

This recipe is naturally suitable for gluten-free diets, as there are no gluten-containing ingredients present. It’s also nut-free and dairy-free, making it appropriate for those with related allergies or intolerances. For best results, ensure the pork is properly seasoned and roasted to achieve a crisp rind and succulent meat, and serve with the apple sauce for a classic sweet-tart pairing.

name: Mussel, bacon & brie tartlets
description: Easy and tasty! I added grated courgette and cut back on cream and it worked perfectly.
author: Nick Nairn
ingredients: 1 medium egg, beaten with 1 tbsp milk
100g dry cure streaky bacon or pancetta, cubed
500g frozen cooked shelled mussels, thawed and drained, or 2kg/4lb 8oz fresh mussels
200g ripe brie, rind removed and cubed
2-3 tbsp bought or homemade vinaigrette, to serve
directions: Rub the butter, flour and parmesan together in a bowl until the mixture has the consistency of fine breadcrumbs. Add the egg mix and quickly bring it all together into a dough. Knead lightly a few times with floured hands until smooth. Shape into a flat ball, cover in cling film and chill for at least 1 hr.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Roll the pastry out to the thickness of a £1 coin and line eight 10cm x 3cm tartlet tins. Fill with greaseproof paper and baking beans, and bake for 7-10 mins until the pastry feels dry. Remove beans and paper, then bake for 2-3 mins, until lightly golden. Leave to cool.

Reduce oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Heat the olive oil in a frying pan and fry the onion for 3 mins until softened, but not coloured. Add the garlic and bacon, and cook for 2-3 mins. Allow to cool slightly. Meanwhile, whisk the eggs and cream with the chives, then fold in the onion, bacon and mussels. Season to taste. Set the cases on a baking sheet. Spoon the mix in and scatter the brie over the top, pushing into the mix here and there. Bake for 12-15 mins until the filling is just firm and golden. Serve warm with dressed leaves.
chief_review:
This sumptuous recipe offers a luxurious spin on a classic quiche, with brie, mussels, and crispy bacon combining for deep layers of flavor. The buttery pastry is enhanced by freshly grated parmesan, delivering a superbly rich base. Grated courgette adds moisture and a touch of freshness, effectively balancing the indulgence of the double cream and cheese. The salad leaves with vinaigrette lighten the plate and add a crisp finish.

Ideal for pescatarians who enjoy dairy and eggs, this dish is suitable for those following a pescatarian diet. However, it contains common allergens such as shellfish, eggs, dairy, and gluten, so should be served mindfully. Overall, it’s a showstopping main course perfect for brunch or a light lunch, sure to impress with its complexity and satisfying textures.

name: Sweet potato stackers
description:
For an added kick to these canapes, try
swapping the lemon juice for a teaspoon
of mustard in the mayo
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
ingredients: 2 large sweet potatoes, peeled and each cut into 8 chunky discs
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6, then toss the potato chunks with the oil and some seasoning on a baking sheet. Roast for 20-30 mins until golden and crisp on the outside, then leave to cool.
To serve, mix the mayonnaise with the lemon juice. Pile a scrunched up piece of ham on each potato, then top with a blob of the lemony mayo. Arrange on a platter with the watercress, then serve.
chief_review: These sweet potato canapés offer a delightful balance of flavors and textures. Roasted, caramelized sweet potato discs form a naturally sweet base, while the creamy, tangy mayonnaise—especially with the suggested upgrade to mustard—adds depth and zing. The prosciutto brings a satisfying savory note and a hint of saltiness, elevated by the fresh pepperiness of watercress. This recipe is well-suited for those following a gluten-free diet, as all components are naturally free from gluten. It's a sophisticated, crowd-pleasing dish ideal for entertaining, and the preparation involves simple steps with impressive results. Overall, these canapés stand out for their bold contrasts and elegant presentation.

name: Hot chocolate soufflé
description: Gordon Ramsay creates melt-in-the-mouth soufflés to impress a crowd
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 25g good-quality dark chocolatepreferably 70% cocoa solids, broken in pieces
single cream or ice cream, to serve
50g good-quality dark chocolatepreferably 70% cocoa solids, broken into pieces
directions: Take four 200ml soufflé dishes and brush them completely with softened butter. Chill the dishes for 5 mins, then, as an insurance policy so the soufflé doesn’t stick to the dish, apply a second coat as before. Tip a little grated chocolate into each dish, roll the dish around tilting it as you do so it is evenly lined all round.

For the crème patisserie, mix the flour, sugar and cornflour. Put egg yolk and whole egg into a bowl, stir, then beat in half of the flour mixture to give a smooth paste. Tip in the rest of the flour mixture and mix well.
Pour the milk and cream into a pan and bring just to the boil. Remove from the heat. Add the chocolate and beat until it is melted and smooth with no lumps.

Gradually stir hot chocolate mix into paste. Return to pan. Cook, stirring, over a medium-low heat for 5 mins to a smooth, thick paste. Remove from the heat. Leave until cold, beating occasionally with a wire whisk.

Make the ganache: slowly warm the cream in a pan. Just before it boils, take off the heat and add chocolate. Beat constantly to a velvety texture, gradually sprinkling in the cocoa as it dissolves. Allow to cool.

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Whisk the egg whites to soft peaks with an electric whisk. Sprinkle in the sugar as you are mixing. Keep whisking to give stiff, firm peaks to give volume to the soufflés.

Mix crème patisserie and ganache in a large bowl. Stir in 2 tbsp of egg white. Carefully fold in a third of the rest, cutting through the mixture. Fold in another third (take care not to lose the volume); fold in the rest.

Spoon the mixture into the dishes to fill them by three-quarters, then gently press a spoon in to make sure it fills all the gaps. Fill the dishes to the top with the mixture, then bang each dish on to the surface so the mixture fills the sides.

Take a palette knife and pull it across the top of each dish so the mixture is completely flat. Take a little time to wipe any splashes off the outside of each dish, or they will burn on while cooking.

So mixture won’t stick to the top of the mould, and to give a straight finish, go around the top edge of the mixture with your finger. Sprinkle a little grated chocolate in the centre, then bake the soufflés for 15-17 mins.

The soufflés should have risen by about two thirds of their original height and jiggle when moved, but be set on top. To serve, make a small dip with a spoon in the centre of each, then pour in single cream or add a spoonful of ice cream.
chief_review:
Chef Ramsay’s chocolate soufflés are the epitome of elegant French patisserie—light, airy, and with a deep chocolate flavor that’s sure to delight any chocolate lover’s palate. The technique, balancing whipped egg whites with a luxurious chocolate base, demonstrates classic culinary skill. The use of high-quality dark chocolate (70% cocoa) underscores the dessert’s sophistication, while double cream and egg yolk lend richness.

This recipe does contain both wheat (plain flour) and dairy (butter, cream, and chocolate with potential milk solids), so it's best suited for those without gluten or lactose restrictions. It’s ideal as a show-stopping dessert for gatherings, especially when paired with a scoop of ice cream or a drizzle of single cream. The dramatic rise and melt-in-the-mouth texture deliver a truly memorable finish—this is a soufflé to savor.

name: Wild mushroom & port brioche
description: Perfect for a dinner party
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Heat 1 tbsp oil in a large pan, then fry mushrooms for 4-5 mins, stirring occasionally, until lightly browned. Remove with a slotted spoon, then set aside. Add remaining oil to the pan, then fry the celery, onion and garlic over a low heat, stirring occasionally, for 5-6 mins. Add wine, stock and thyme and bring to the boil. Simmer for 30 mins.

Add the port and redcurrant jelly. Bring back to the boil, then boil for 10 mins until reduced by half and thick and syrupy. Season to taste, discard the thyme and stir in the mushrooms. Simmer for 5 mins.

Meanwhile, pull the tops off the brioche and reserve, then pick out dough from the centre to leave a thick shell. (Process remaining dough to make breadcrumbs, then freeze for future use.) Place rolls on a baking sheet, then bake for 5-7 mins until hot and crisp.
Spoon the mushroom mixture into the brioche rolls, then garnish with the flat-leaf parsley. Serve immediately with any remaining gravy, potato wedges and green beans.
chief_review: This recipe presents a sophisticated medley of mushrooms enriched with aromatic vegetables and deepened by the complexity of red wine and port—a truly elegant dish, perfect for a dinner party centerpiece. The inclusion of three types of mushrooms gives depth of texture and earthiness, balanced beautifully by celery and sweet redcurrant jelly. The glossy sauce, perfumed with thyme, elevates the umami to restaurant quality. The use of hot vegetable stock and omission of animal-based ingredients (aside from brioche rolls, which often contain butter and eggs) makes this versatile for vegetarians. Vegans should substitute the brioche with a plant-based alternative. The absence of wheat flour in the core mixture lends itself to gluten-free adaptation if gluten-free rolls are chosen. Aromatic and hearty, this recipe delivers bold flavors while remaining adaptable for plant-based and gluten sensitive guests—an impressive and thoughtful addition to any gathering.

name: Korean rice pot
description: A one pot rice dish is a fab way to use up leftovers - this one combines healthy veg and turkey, topped with fried egg
author: Silvana Franco
directions: Pour the chicken stock into a large pan and bring to the boil. Add the rice and turkey, bring back to the boil and simmer for 12-15 mins until the stock has been absorbed and rice is tender.
Meanwhile, put the spinach in a colander and pour over a kettle of hot water to lightly wilt. Keep the spinach and carrots separate, but dress both with the sesame oil and seeds.
Cover the cooked rice with a lid and leave to sit for a couple of mins. Meanwhile, heat vegetable oil in a non-stick pan set over a high heat. Fry eggs so the white crisps up nicely round the edges.
Spoon the rice into large bowls and arrange the spinach and carrots on top. Finish each with a fried egg and a dollop of chilli sauce. Serve immediately.
chief_review: This one-pot rice dish offers a satisfying balance of protein, vegetables, and grains, making it ideal for a wholesome midweek meal. The use of leftover turkey ensures the recipe is lean yet hearty, while fresh spinach and carrots bring color and nutrition. Layering the flavors with toasted sesame oil and topping with a fried egg elevates the overall aromatic depth. The addition of thick chili sauce introduces a pleasurable kick, complemented by the crunch of toasted sesame seeds. This dish is suitable for those following a nut-free and dairy-free diet, provided the chilli sauce and stock used are free from hidden allergens. It's also a great post-holiday option to minimize waste while maximizing flavor and nutrition. Overall, it’s a balanced and practical meal with plenty of room for customization.

name: Daube of beef with spiced beetroot
description: Serve Tony Tobin’s Christmassy casserole with a really good, creamy mash
author: Tony Tobin
ingredients: 2 medium onions, cut into small dice
1 small celery stick, cut into small dice
250ml beef stock, made from a cube
½ tsp fennel seed, crushed or ground
2½ cm/1in piece fresh root ginger, grated
1 red chilli, deseeded and very finely chopped
directions: Put the beef, bacon, carrots, onions, celery, garlic, thyme, bay leaf and orange zest into a large shallow bowl. Pour in the port, cover with cling film and leave in the fridge to marinate overnight.

Meanwhile, for the beetroot, pour the wine into a saucepan, then add the vinegar, sugar, fennel, garlic, ginger and chilli and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 30 minutes. Cut the beetroot into wedges and put in a large bowl. Pour the hot wine mixture over the beetroot. Allow to cool, then cover and leave in the fridge to marinate overnight.

Drain the meat and vegetable mixture, reserving the marinating liquid. Separate the meat from the vegetables as best you can and set the vegetables aside. Heat the oil in a large casserole dish or saucepan and fry the beef pieces in batches over a high heat for 3-4 minutes until just browned. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.

Add the reserved vegetable mixture to the casserole and cook for 3-4 minutes until the onion is softened. Add the flour and cook for 1 minute, stirring continuously. Return the beef to the pan with the reserved marinade and the stock and season well. Bring to simmering point, cover and gently cook for 11⁄2 hours until the beef is tender.

Carefully remove all the beef and vegetables from the pan, using a slotted spoon, and set aside. Drain the marinade from the beetroot and add it to the cooking juices in the pan. Bring to the boil and simmer for 5-6 minutes until the sauce has slightly thickened and has a coating consistency. Return the meat and vegetables to the sauce, then stir in the beetroot. Heat through for 2-3 minutes and serve.
chief_review: Tony Tobin’s festive casserole is a masterfully layered dish brimming with rich, bold flavors—the port and red wine lend a robust depth, skillfully offset by the brightness of orange zest and beetroot. The slow-cooked beef, combined with smoky bacon and aromatic vegetables, creates a truly comforting winter centerpiece. The touch of ginger and chilli introduces a subtle warmth, while muscovado sugar achieves a beautifully round sweetness. This recipe, however, is not suitable for gluten-free or vegetarian diets. It’s an ideal dish for those looking to elevate a classic festive casserole, especially when paired with creamy mash to soak up the luscious sauce. A perfect treat for the holiday table, promising both comfort and a touch of sophistication.

name: Winter Pimm's punch
description: Everyone agreed it had a lot of brandy...but no one was complaining :-) We warmed it as per fairy89's suggestion and I think this is the best way. We had this for bonfire's night, but all agreed that it's very Christmassy. I think this may replace the usual mulled wine we have.
author: Good Food
directions: Combine the Pimm’s and brandy with the apple juice in a jug filled with ice, cinnamon sticks and a sliced apple and orange.
chief_review: This festive punch is a delightful twist on traditional mulled wine, brimming with warming spices and citrus brightness. The generous measures of Pimm's and brandy give it a distinct, spirited character that pairs beautifully with the mellow apple juice and aromatic cinnamon. Serving it warm truly enhances the flavors, making it an ideal choice for chilly evenings or holiday gatherings. With no animal-derived ingredients, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and vegans. It also sidesteps common allergens such as dairy, eggs, nuts, soy, and gluten, provided your apple juice is certified gluten-free. Be mindful of the significant alcohol content—this is a celebratory drink best enjoyed responsibly. Overall, a crowd-pleaser that effortlessly fills the room with festive cheer.

name: Blinis with crème fraîche, roast beef & cornichons
description: Beautifully bite-sized canapés to hand round at your next party - just five ingredients and ready in 15 minutes
author: Good Food
ingredients: 36 canapé blinis(we used a 123g pack from Waitrose)
75g cold roast beef, thinly sliced and cut into strips
directions: Warm the blinis following the pack instructions. Mix together the crème fraîche and mustard and spoon onto the blinis. Fold the beef on top then add the cornichons. Arrange the blinis on a platter, grind over some black pepper and serve.
chief_review: This canapé recipe is a fantastic option for effortless entertaining, delivering elegance and bold flavors in just 15 minutes. The pillowy blinis serve as a perfect base, topped with the tang of crème fraîche mixed with wholegrain mustard, ribbons of tender roast beef, and crisp, zesty cornichons to finish. Each bite offers a balanced mix of creamy, sharp, and savory notes. With no nuts featured and a reliance on unprocessed, fresh ingredients, this recipe is nut-free, making it suitable for those with nut allergies. However, it does contain dairy and gluten. Overall, these canapés are an impressive addition to any party, offering gourmet taste with minimal effort.

name: Cranberry-crowned pud with white chocolate custard
description: We've wound back the years with this classic steamed pud, perfect for a cold winter's day
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Put 100g cranberries in a saucepan with the redcurrant jelly and sugar. Simmer for 5 mins, then leave to cool. Meanwhile, put a pan of water on to simmer and butter a 1.4 litre/2½ pint basin. Butter a large sheet of baking paper, sit on a same-size sheet of foil and fold a leat in the middle. Beat all the sponge ingredients together, then stir in the remaining cranberries. Spoon a third of the cranberry and redcurrant mix into the bowl, then spoon the sponge mix on top.

Cover with the paper and foil, tie with string and steam, lid on, for 1½ hrs. To serve, reheat the cranberry mix and pour over the top of the turned-out pudding. Can be made up to 2 days ahead and re-steamed for 30 mins or microwaved for 5 mins on High. 3 To make the custard, put the chocolate into a microwave-proof bowl, add the custard and heat according to pack instructions, stirring every 30 secs until the chocolate has melted.
chief_review: This classic steamed pudding is a delightful homage to traditional British desserts, boasting a moist, spongey texture and vibrant tang from cranberries and redcurrant jelly. Rich butter and the vanilla pod impart depth, while the decadent white chocolate and creamy vanilla custard elevate it to an indulgent winter treat. The use of self-raising flour means it's not gluten free, and with both butter and eggs included, it's not suitable for vegan or dairy-free diets. However, those following a vegetarian diet can enjoy this pudding without reservation. The flavors are beautifully balanced—tart fruit against sweet sponge and custard—making it a nostalgic yet sophisticated finale for any festive meal.

name: Caramel & orange mousses
description: This festive dessert makes the perfect end to a buffet party, and it can be made ahead too
author: Sara Buenfeld
directions: Soak the gelatine in cold water to soften it. Heat the orange juice in the microwave for 1 min. Squeeze the excess water from the gelatine, add to the hot juice and stir to dissolve. Set aside to cool.
