Put the egg yolks, sugar and orange zest into a bowl and whisk over a pan of hot water for 10 mins until thick and foamy. Remove from the heat and continue whisking until completely cool.

Fold the gelatine, orange mix and liqueur, if using, into the egg yolk mixture. In separate bowls, whisk the egg whites and cream until both are softly stiff, then gently fold into the orange mix. Spoon into 8 cocktail glasses and chill until set. Will keep, covered, for 2 days.

A couple of hrs before serving, make the caramel oranges. Heat the sugar in pan with 2 tbsp water. When the sugar has dissolved, turn up the heat and cook until pale golden. Add the oranges (take care as the sugar will splutter) and swirl them round the pan to coat them in the caramel. Allow to cool. Spoon a couple of orange segments and some caramel juice on top of each mousse and serve with crisp biscuits on the side.
chief_review: This dessert is a delightful finale for any buffet, offering a refreshing citrus punch balanced by the richness of double cream and the subtle warmth of Grand Marnier. The use of orange zest and juice ensures vibrant flavor, while the light, airy texture achieved with whipped egg whites adds sophistication. The ability to prepare it ahead makes this dish both practical and impressive for entertaining. As it includes neither flour nor wheat, it’s naturally gluten-free—an excellent treat for those avoiding gluten. However, do note the use of gelatin and dairy, which may not suit vegans or those with milk allergies. The layered components provide visual appeal, especially when garnished with the fresh orange segments. Overall, a well-composed dessert that marries elegance with practicality, sure to impress your guests.

name: Grilled goat's cheese with cranberry dressing
description: A smart veggie starter that will impress even the biggest foodie at your dinner table
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 3 x 100g Capricorn goat's cheese, halved horizontally
handful radish sprouts (available from larger supermarkets) or watercress
directions: Quarter, core, then thinly slice the apple into a bowl with the lemon juice and 1 tbsp water. Toss well, as this stops the apples going brown.
Heat grill to high, then line your grill rack with foil. Put the cheeses rind-side down on the foil, then set aside for a moment.

Drain 2 tbsp of the juice from the apple bowl into another small bowl and discard the rest. Add the cranberry sauce, oil and honey with some seasoning, and whisk to form a dressing. Grill the cheeses for 4 mins, then scatter the nuts on and around the cheeses and return to the grill to cook for a few mins more – but take care that the nuts don’t burn.
Arrange the apple, chicory and radish sprouts or watercress on 6 plates, then carefully top with the hot melted cheese. Scatter over the nuts, spoon over the dressing and serve straight away.
chief_review: This vibrant veggie starter marries the creamy tang of Capricorn goat’s cheese with the sweetness of cranberry jelly and honey, offset by crisp apples and pecan crunch. The addition of chicory and radish sprouts (or watercress) brings refreshing bitterness and peppery notes, balancing the dish perfectly. It’s light yet satisfying, ideal for opening a refined meal or serving as a sophisticated lunch. The recipe is suitable for vegetarian diets, as all ingredients are plant-based or dairy. Those seeking gluten-free options will appreciate the absence of bread or wheat products. The combination of fruit, nuts, and cheese is thoughtfully layered, delivering contrasting textures and flavors in every bite. This elegant plate will undeniably impress both food enthusiasts and health-conscious guests alike.

name: Chocolate biscuit truffles
description: Treat yourself with these creamy truffles, so good you won't want to share!
author: Lesley Waters
ingredients: 4 shortbreads fingers, or biscuits, crumbled roughly
85g dried fruit (chopped apricots and cranberries are good)
directions: Put the cream in a small pan, then bring just to the boil. Put chocolates in separate bowls, then divide the butter between each. Tip half of the cream over each bowl of chocolate. Leave for about 1 min then stir until melted and smooth. Allow to cool.
Divide the shortbread, fruit and orange zest between the bowls, stir, then chill for at least 4 hrs until firm.

Using a teaspoon, scoop out the mixtures and form into small truffles. Sift the icing sugar onto a plate and roll the white chocolate truffles in it. Do the same with the cocoa and the dark chocolate truffles, then chill until needed. Can be made up to a day ahead.
chief_review: These creamy truffles are an indulgent delight, balancing the richness of double cream and butter with the sweetness of white and dark chocolates. The addition of chopped dried fruit and fresh orange zest brings a lively burst of flavors that cut through the decadent base, while crumbled shortbread offers a delightful crunch. Rolling the truffles in icing sugar or cocoa powder adds a pleasing textural contrast. This recipe suits vegetarians, as it contains no meat, fish, or animal-derived rennet. However, be aware of potential allergens, as it includes dairy, gluten (from the shortbread), and possibly nuts (if biscuits contain traces). Overall, these truffles are a wonderful treat for special occasions or as an elegant homemade gift.

name: Cranberry & ginger sausages
description: This classic canapé gets a stylish upgrade with sweet cranberry sauce and fragrant ginger
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Place the chipolatas in a roasting tin with vegetable oil and cook for 15 mins. Mix cranberry sauce with ground ginger and 1 tbsp water. Pour over the sausages and return to the oven for a further 5 mins or until sticky and golden.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful twist on traditional canapés, marrying the savoriness of chipolatas with the bright, tangy notes of cranberry sauce and aromatic ground ginger. The use of vegetable oil helps keep the sausages moist while baking, and the glossy cranberry glaze with ginger brings a subtle warmth that elevates each bite. It’s a straightforward crowd-pleaser, ideal for festive gatherings or sophisticated snacks. Given the ingredients, this canapé accommodates those who are gluten-free (assuming the chipolatas are free from fillers containing gluten), making it a thoughtful choice for guests with gluten sensitivities. The flavors balance beautifully, and the preparation is simple enough for a quick assembly, yet striking enough to impress. A modern, flavorful take on a beloved party classic.

name: Pears in port with meringue cream
description: This festive make-ahead pudding is a great way to use up leftover port (or red wine)
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 8 ripe but firm pears, peeled with the stalk intact
2 meringuesshells, broken into pieces (bought ones are fine)
directions: Pour the port into a large pan with 600ml water, add the sugar and cinnamon, then heat until the sugar dissolves. Add the pears, bring to the boil, then cover and simmer for 20-30 mins until tender all the way through. They are ready when a cocktail stick can be easily pushed through each one. Depending on the size of your pan, you may need to cook the pears in 2 batches using the same port syrup, or turn the pears several times as they cook so they become an even colour. Let the pears cool in their syrup, preferably overnight to allow the syrup to really stain them. Will keep for 3 days in the fridge.
Check the consistency of the syrup. If it is very thin, boil it in a pan to reduce the amount and concentrate the flavour.

To serve, whip the cream with the sugar and vanilla until it holds its shape, then fold in the meringue. Sprinkle with the cinnamon. Arrange the pears in a shallow dish and spoon over the syrup. Allow guests to help themselves to both pears and cream.
chief_review: This festive pudding is a creative way to bring warmth and elegance to the dessert table, showcasing perfectly poached pears infused with port and cinnamon. The use of ripe pears keeps the texture luscious, while the double cream and vanilla-scented meringue add richness and contrast. The cinnamon infuses both the syrup and final sprinkle, lending a lovely spice note. This dessert is ideal for those seeking a gluten-free option, as all the ingredients are naturally free from gluten. The make-ahead aspect is a bonus for hosts, and the results are visually impressive and full of complex flavor. Perfect for winter gatherings.

name: Luxe fish pie
description: Salmon and smoked haddock are perfect partners in this creamy, cheesy fish dish - freeze ahead and thaw for a make-ahead dinner party main
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 500g thick white fishfillets, such as cod or haddock, unskinned
700ml full fat or semi- skimmed milk
1 medium onion, cut into thin wedges
½ small pack dill, roughly chopped
1½ kg potatoes(ideally Maris Piper), cut into even-sized pieces
directions: Place the fish fillets in a large, wide saucepan and pour over the milk. Add the onion wedges and bay leaves, tucking them in around the fish. Bring to a very gentle simmer, then cover with a lid and remove from the heat immediately. Leave to stand and infuse for 10 mins or until the fish is just cooked. Drain the fish in a colander over a large jug to reserve the infused milk, then tip the fish into a bowl. Set aside.

Meanwhile, make the topping. Put the potatoes in a large saucepan of cold water, bring to the boil, then simmer for 15 mins or until the potatoes are soft but not falling apart. Drain well, return to the pan and mash with the butter, half the cheese and the crème fraîche until smooth. Season to taste and set aside.

To finish the filling, melt the butter in a medium saucepan and stir in the flour. Cook for a few secs, then gradually add the infused milk, stirring over a medium heat for 3 mins until the sauce is smooth and thick. Stir in the spinach and wine or vermouth, if using, and cook for 2 mins more. Remove from the heat and stir in the dill. Season to taste.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Spoon a third of the sauce into the base of a 3-litre shallow rectangular dish. Scatter half the fish fillets over the sauce, breaking them into chunky pieces and discarding the skin, any stray bones, onion and bay leaves as you go. Pour over another third of the sauce, then top with more fish. Continue the layers once more, finishing with sauce.

Spoon the potato over the fish mixture, starting at the edges. Swirl the potato with the back of a spoon and sprinkle over the remaining cheese. Place the dish on a baking tray and bake in the centre of the oven for 45 mins or until the potato is golden and the filling is bubbling.
chief_review:
A luxurious dish bringing together salmon and smoked haddock, this creamy, cheesy fish recipe is the epitome of comfort food. The careful balance of fresh dill, white wine, and a rich base of crème fraîche highlights the delicate flavors of the fish, while the cheesy mashed potato topping adds a satisfying golden crust. The inclusion of spinach and onion lends depth and freshness to the overall profile.

This recipe is well-suited to pescatarians, as all proteins are derived from fish. However, it contains both dairy and gluten, so it is not suitable for individuals with lactose intolerance, dairy allergy, or gluten sensitivity. Using a blend of fish ensures a variety of textures and flavors in every bite, making this an excellent make-ahead centerpiece for a dinner party or special family meal.

name: Shimmering forest cake
description: Get the kids to help create this winter wonderland - just make sure you have enough Smarties to nibble on!
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 200g icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
2 Christmas tree cutters, about 5cm and 10cm tall
green Smarties and silver chocolate buttons (optional)
directions: Cover the cake with marzipan and white icing. (See step 5 for more information).

Knead the ready-to-roll icing, then split into three balls. Leave one ball white, and knead a little green colouring into the other two to give two different shades of green. Roll out each ball to about 5mm thick on a work surface lightly dusted with icing sugar. Stamp out about 15 tree shapes using tree cutters, then leave to dry for a few hours or overnight.

Once firm, lift half of the trees onto a cooling rack. Combine the 200g icing sugar and egg white to make an icing, then drizzle it over the trees with a teaspoon. Scatter with edible sparkles and leave to dry again until solid.

Put a little icing on the back of each tree and press the trees around the edge of the cake, overlapping some to give a 3-D effect. Scatter the sweets over the top of the cake to finish. Can be iced up to a week ahead.

To cover a cake with marzipan, first brush the cake all over with a thin layer of warmed apricot jam. Dust the work surface with icing sugar, then roll out the marzipan evenly until you have a 5mm- 1cm thick round, about 40cm across for a 20cm cake. Lift over the cake, using a rolling pin to help, then smooth with your hands and trim off the excess. Leave to dry overnight or for a few hours. Lightly brush the marzipan all over with cooled, boiled water. Roll the icing out as you did the marzipan, then smooth with your hands, trim off the excess and leave to dry.
chief_review: This festive fruitcake recipe is a visual delight and a joy for children to help assemble. The combination of a classic fruitcake base with apricot jam, layers of marzipan, and ready-to-roll icing delivers both flavor and a stunning wintry presentation. The decorative use of colored icing, edible sparkles, and Smarties adds playfulness and an interactive aspect to the baking experience. While the recipe is vegetarian-friendly, those with nut (marzipan), egg, or gluten allergies should take note, as well as those seeking a vegan option, due to the use of egg white and potential milk derivatives in Smarties and some icings. Overall, it’s an imaginative and charming cake, perfect for celebrations and family gatherings.

name: Salt beef on rye bread with mustard sauce
description: This quick canapé of traditional Jewish salt beef with a twist has the wow factor despite taking only minutes to make
author: Good Food
directions: Cut the rye bread into 18 squares in total. Mix the mustard and mayonnaise and spread a little on each square of rye. Cut the salt beef into 18 pieces and the cornichons in half. Top each rye square with a piece of beef and a cornichon half.
chief_review: This recipe delivers an elegant twist on traditional Jewish salt beef, transforming classic flavors into a refined canapé format. The deep, earthy notes of dark rye bread pair beautifully with the tangy bite of Dijon mustard, while creamy mayonnaise adds richness and balance. Thinly sliced salt beef provides a satisfyingly savory centerpiece, complemented by crisp, piquant cornichons for textural and flavor contrast. The assembly is straightforward, making it an ideal choice for entertaining when time is short. Notably, this recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet if you use a plant-based alternative to salt beef and mayonnaise. Rye bread, typically lower in gluten than wheat bread, is nonetheless unsuitable for those with gluten intolerance unless a certified gluten-free version is used. Overall, a sophisticated yet approachable canapé that brings both tradition and bold flavors to the party table.

name: Slow-roasted pork shoulder with leeks, apricots & thyme
description: Make your weekend roast really special with creamy leek and apricot stuffing, extra crispy crackling and tender meat
author: Gerard Baker
ingredients: 2½ kg/5lb 8oz piece boned and rolled pork shoulder- free-range or rare breed is best
85g chopped dried apricot, soaked for 2 hrs in boiling water to cover, then drained
directions: A few hours before you want to cook the pork, remove it from the fridge and dry the skin thoroughly. Leave unwrapped in a cool place to slowly come to room temperature while you make the stuffing.

Put a large saucepan over a medium heat and add the butter. When it begins to sizzle, add the leeks and cook until they are soft and most of their liquid has evaporated. Stir in the apricots and thyme, season well and transfer to a bowl to cool. When the mixture is cold, stir in the breadcrumbs. Taste and season again if required.

When you are ready to cook the pork, heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Spoon the stuffing into the pocket your butcher has left for you. Wipe any stuffing from the skin, put the pork in a roasting tin and season the skin well with salt. Put the celery, onion and carrot in the tin around the pork, place in the oven and cook for 30 mins.
Reduce heat to 140C/120C fan/ gas 1 and cook the pork for a further 2 hrs 30 mins. Transfer the pork to a warm serving dish to rest while you finish the gravy.

Tip out any fat from the roasting tin and reserve for another dish. Put the roasting tin on a medium heat, add the white wine or cider and, using a wooden spatula, scrape the caramelised juices from the bottom of the pan and allow them to dissolve. Let the juices reduce by half.

Add the stock and simmer for 5 mins. Add the flour and butter, mashed together, and whisk them into the gravy. Taste for seasoning, then strain into a warmed jug. If your pork skin has not crackled, put under a hot grill for a few mins, turning every 30 secs or so, until bubbled and crackling.
chief_review:
This pork shoulder roast recipe excels in both flavor and presentation, making it a standout for special weekends. The meat turns out impressively tender, thanks to the gentle braising with aromatic vegetables, white wine (or cider), and robust stock. The extra crispy crackling delivers that coveted textural contrast, while the creamy leek and apricot stuffing offers a delightful balance of sweetness from the apricots and herbal undertones from thyme. Incorporating leeks and dried fruit into the stuffing lends a modern twist to a classic dish, keeping it moist and interesting.

This recipe does contain gluten, so it suits neither gluten-free nor low-carb diets. The presence of butter and stock makes it unsuitable for dairy-free, vegetarian, or vegan preferences. However, for those looking for a hearty, celebratory pork centerpiece with sophisticated flavors, this recipe is a winning choice for any traditional Sunday roast.

name: Celery sticks with blue cheese dip
description: This tangy, creamy sauce makes a great centrepiece for a party platter but is versatile enough to go beyond crudités
author: Good Food
directions: In a medium-sized bowl, mix the soured cream, mayonnaise, blue cheese, white wine vinegar, Worcestershire sauce and some seasoning. Pour into a serving bowl and use as a dip for the celery sticks.
chief_review: This blue cheese dip delivers a luxurious blend of tang and creaminess, thanks to the combination of soured cream and mayonnaise as its base. The blue cheese offers a robust, savoury depth that is well balanced by the acidity of white wine vinegar, and a dash of Worcestershire sauce adds a subtle umami kick. Served with crisp celery batons, it’s ideal for sharing on a party platter, but just as suited to dressing salads, topping steaks, or pairing with chicken wings. The inclusion of dairy makes it perfect for a vegetarian diet, as Worcestershire sauce can be sourced in vegetarian versions to swap out the anchovy-containing original. This simple yet indulgent dip brings restaurant-level flair to casual entertaining and demonstrates how straightforward ingredients can yield a sophisticated, crowd-pleasing result.

name: Tangy chicory salad
author: Sophie Godwin
ingredients: 2 tbsp toasted pumpkin seedsand 30g shaved parmesan (or vegetarian alternative), to serve
directions: together the vinegar, honey, orange zest and juice and olive oil. Season to taste, then set aside.
Thinly slice the bottom third of each chicory heart, then separate the leaves. Put in a bowl and mix with the salad dressing. To serve, scatter over the pumpkin seeds and parmesan shavings.
chief_review: This refreshing salad brilliantly balances the bitter notes of chicory with the sweetness of honey and orange, all contrasted by the nutty crunch of toasted pumpkin seeds. The sherry vinegar and extra virgin olive oil create a light yet flavorful dressing that lets the fresh ingredients shine. The shaved parmesan adds a creamy depth; using a vegetarian alternative keeps the dish suitable for vegetarians. Gluten-free by nature, this recipe is ideal for those seeking a light, nutrient-dense offering with delicate citrus undertones and a good mix of textures. Perfect as a starter or a sophisticated side.

name: Cake of kings
description: Versions of this cake – a fruity Brioche-like bread – are eaten all over Europe on Twelfth Night. Buried inside is a trinket, and whoever finds it, is king for the day
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 1 trinket or dried bean(in greaseproof paper)
1 egg yolk, beaten with 1 tbsp water
directions: Soak citrus peel, raisins, pine nuts and cherries in the sherry or brandy overnight until plump. Measure 140g/5oz of the fl our in a large mixing bowl and mix with the yeast. Tip the remaining flour and salt into a separate bowl and set aside. Heat the milk until just warm, make a well in the centre of the flour mix, and gradually add the milk to form a batter, beating until smooth. Cover with a tea towel and leave for 20 mins, until frothy.

In another bowl, beat butter, sugar and zests until light and fluffy. Add the eggs, a little at a time, beating well after each addition. Don’t worry if it curdles, this won’t affect the final cake. Stir the mix into the batter, along with the remaining flour, to make a dough. Turn out onto a floured surface and knead for 5 mins, until smooth and elastic. Knead in the fruit mix, a bit at a time, kneading after each addition until evenly distributed. This bit is messy, but dust the dough and your hands with flour as you work.

Pop the dough into a clean bowl and cover. Leave for 2 hrs, until doubled in size. Butter a large baking sheet. Knead the dough again briefly, then shape into a sausage, about 50cm long. Curl onto the baking sheet to make a ring, pinching the ends to join. Tuck the trinket under the cake, cover and leave for 1 hr, until doubled in size. Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5.

Slice the candied fruits and crush the sugar lumps into small pieces (put them in a cup and use the end of a rolling pin). Brush the top of the ring with egg and decorate with candied fruits and sugar. Bake for 45 mins, then transfer to a wire rack and brush the top with jam. Leave to cool before cutting.
chief_review: This festive cake, reminiscent of brioche, boasts a tender crumb studded with candied peel, raisins, pine nuts, cherries, and a heady kick of sherry or brandy. The inclusion of milk, butter, and eggs yields a rich, airy texture, offset by zesty citrus. Crowned with candied fruits and a delicate apricot glaze, it’s a luxurious center­piece for celebrations. While not suited to vegan or dairy-free diets, this recipe is vegetarian-friendly, making it perfect for festive tables where dietary preferences vary. The traditional hidden trinket adds fun and ceremony. For best results, knead thoroughly and allow ample rising time for a light finish. Enjoy toasted with coffee or alongside dessert wine for an authentic taste of European Twelfth Night tradition.

name: Papas a lo pobre with chorizo
description: The simplicity of this recipe belies its' yumminess! Lovely recipe and very filling - feels like you're being naughty with fried chorizo, plus fried eggs - but overall a reasonable calorie count. We enjoy this as an evening meal and sometimes add chopped onion and sliced mushrooms to get some veg in and balance out the meal.
author: Tom Hunt
ingredients: garlic cloves, crushed in their skins
directions: Fry the chorizo in the olive oil with the crushed potatoes, garlic and rosemary. Allow the chorizo to form a crust before turning.

Meanwhile, fry the eggs the way you like them. Mix the potatoes with the parsley and a light dusting of smoked paprika. Serve the eggs on top of the potatoes with a further dusting of paprika, if you like.
chief_review: This rustic chorizo and fried egg skillet is a satisfying dish that beautifully balances bold flavors and comforting textures. The spicy, smoky notes of the chorizo permeate the tender, slightly crushed potatoes, while rosemary and garlic add aromatic depth. Runny fried eggs provide a luscious richness, perfectly complementing the hearty base. A finishing sprinkle of smoked paprika and fresh parsley brightens the plate. The recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it ideal for those avoiding gluten. With the option to add mushrooms and onions, it can be easily adapted for extra nutrients and complexity. This is a straightforward, quick-to-prepare meal that doesn’t compromise on taste, particularly well-suited for a cozy evening supper.

name: Spiced wine
description: A tasty gluhwein I was able to knock up when the parents visited on a chilly evening. I used light brown sugar rather than the muscovado, and ground nutmeg. It was just the thing, though it did cool quite quickly - perhaps I will microwave my mugs next time as the kitchen had got so cold!!
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 2 oranges, zest pared, juice squeezed from one, the other cut into chunks
1 apple, quartered, cored and thickly sliced
directions: Put the sugar, the orange zest, juice and chunks, cinnamon and nutmeg in a pan with 300ml/1⁄2pt water and bring to the boil. Simmer for 10 mins to infuse the spices, then add the wine and apple slices and bring to a simmer. Serve in heatproof glasses.
chief_review: This homemade gluhwein delivers a heartwarming blend, perfect for cold evenings, with citrus and spice harmonizing over a mellow red wine base. The light muscovado sugar adds a subtle depth, complementing orange zest, apple, and warming cinnamon. Ground nutmeg provides a fragrant finish. As a chef, I appreciate the balance of sweetness and spice—none overpowering, all contributing layers to the mug. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly and naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for a broad range of guests. For best results, serve in pre-warmed mugs to maintain its inviting heat. Simple, classic, and thoroughly comforting.

name: Ginger treacle sponge
description: We know how you love hot treacle sponge and sticky ginger cake, so this gorgeous pud is sure to become a favourite
author: Good Food
ingredients: 175g softened butter, plus extra for greasing
1 tbsp gingersyrup from a jar of stem ginger
6 balls stem ginger, chunkily diced, plus 3 tbsp syrup from the ginger jar
directions: Butter a 1 litre pudding basin. Mix the breadcrumbs, golden syrup and ginger syrup and place in the bottom of the basin.
To prepare the steamer, put a small, upturned saucer or trivet into a large saucepan big enough to fit the pudding basin. Put the kettle on.

In a large bowl, beat the butter and sugar until pale and creamy. Add the beaten eggs, vanilla and lemon zest, then sieve the flour and ginger into the mixture. Fold everything together with a big spoon or spatula. Fill the pudding basin with the sponge mixture.

Cut out large sheets of greaseproof paper and foil, big enough to fit over the basin with a 2in overhang. Sit greaseproof on foil, fold a pleat into the middle, then butter the greaseproof. Put, butter-side down, over the pudding, and tie tightly under the rim with string. Sit the basin in the saucepan, add enough water from the kettle to come halfway up the basin sides, cover with a lid and simmer gently for 1 hr 45 mins.

Meanwhile, candy your clementine slices by pouring 100ml water from the kettle over the sugar in a small frying pan. Heat until melted, then add the clementine slices and bubble until they are shiny and sticky with sugar. Lift out with tongs and set aside on baking parchment to dry.
Check the pudding is cooked by inserting a metal skewer – there should be no raw mixture on the skewer, but you may find a little sticky syrup from the bottom.

For the topping, put the syrups in a small pan and bubble to thicken for a few mins, then stir in the ginger chunks and a few clementine slices. Turn the pudding out onto a serving plate and spoon over some syrupy ginger topping. Serve with crème fraîche and custard.
chief_review:
This indulgent hot treacle and sticky ginger pudding offers a sublime marriage of warming spices and citrus brightness. The use of both stem ginger and ground ginger delivers a pleasingly robust kick, balanced beautifully by sweet golden syrup and a delicate hint of lemon zest. The clementine slices bring a zesty freshness, cutting through the richness of the sponge. The texture is light yet satisfyingly sticky—a testament to the careful creaming of butter and sugar and the inclusion of self-raising flour. 

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal-derived products other than eggs and dairy. However, those with gluten or egg allergies should avoid this dish. Serve warm with a dollop of cream or custard for a show-stopping dessert that truly comforts and delights.

name: Slow cooker gammon in coke
author: Cassie Best
directions: Set your
to medium. Place the gammon joint in and cover with the cola. Add 1 chopped carrot, 1 quartered onion, 1 chopped celery stick, 1 cinnamon stick, ½ tbsp peppercorns and 1 bay leaf.
Cook for 5½ hrs on low until the gammon is tender but still holding its shape, topping up with boiling water if necessary to keep the gammon fully covered.
Carefully pour the liquid away, then let the ham cool a little while you heat the oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Lift the ham into a
, then cut away the skin leaving behind an even layer of fat. Score the fat all over in a criss-cross pattern.
Mix the maple syrup, mustard, vinegar and ground cloves or five-spice in a jug. Pour half over the fat, roast for 15 mins, then pour over the rest and return to the oven for another 30 mins.
Remove from the oven and allow to rest for 10 mins, then spoon more glaze over the top.
chief_review: This recipe beautifully transforms a simple gammon joint by infusing it with the warming sweetness of cola, aromatic vegetables, and a hint of spice. The addition of maple syrup, wholegrain mustard, and red wine vinegar for glazing imparts a glossy, deep flavor with layers of subtle heat and tang, balanced perfectly by the cloves or five-spice. The use of cola as a poaching liquid tenderizes the meat while introducing an unexpected richness without being overly sweet. Vegetarians and vegans should note that the dish centers on pork, and those with allergies to mustard or celery should take caution. This recipe is a wonderful centerpiece for a festive meal, offering a creative twist on classic glazed ham that promises succulent results and a memorable flavor profile.

name: Celeriac & parsnip bake
description: This vegetable side dish is full of flavour with thyme, mustard seeds, red wine vinegar and chicken stock - perfect with a Sunday roast
author: Katy Gilhooly
ingredients: 500g parsnips, peeled and cut into thin rounds
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Heat a non-stick frying pan over a medium-high heat, add the onions, thyme leaves, mustard seeds and 1 tbsp water, and cook for 10-15 mins. If the onions start to catch, add a splash more water. Once the onions are soft, add the vinegar and bubble for 1 min.

Meanwhile, bring the stock to the boil in a medium pan. Add the celeriac and parsnips, and simmer for 6 mins, stirring occasionally. Layer the vegetables with the onions in a large ovenproof dish. Pour over enough stock to come halfway up the vegetables, then bake for 30 mins until golden and cooked through.
chief_review: This hearty vegetable side dish showcases earthy celeriac and sweet parsnips, beautifully layered with softly caramelized onions. The aromatic lift from fresh thyme and a subtle tang from red wine vinegar balance the sweetness perfectly, while crushed mustard seeds add a nuanced, peppery finish. Simmering the vegetables in chicken stock imbues them with rich, savory depth—making this an ideal companion for a classic Sunday roast. Since it’s naturally gluten-free, this recipe is a crowd-pleaser for those seeking wheat-free options. The technique is straightforward, allowing the root vegetables’ natural flavours to shine against robust seasonings.

name: Crunchy root & apple 'slaw
description: Serve Gordon Ramsay's stunning homemade coleslaw with your Boxing Day ham
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: ½ white cabbage (about 500g), cored and thinly shredded
½ small red cabbage (about 200g), cored and thinly shredded
½ bunch spring onions, shredded lengthways
3-4 tbsp seed & nut mixture from a pack, optional
directions: Shred the fennel thinly. Place in cold water for 1 hr until crisp, then drain and pat dry. Meanwhile, bring a large pan of water to the boil, then blanch the shredded cabbage, white cabbage first, in boiling water for 2 mins. Drain, then cool quickly under cold running water. Shake dry.

Slice the celeriac thinly, then cut into sticks. Blanch in boiling water with half the lemon juice for 2 mins, then drain and cool under cold water. The veg can be prepared up to 2 days ahead and kept bagged in the fridge.

When ready to serve, core and thinly slice the apple and toss with the remaining lemon juice. Beat together the mayonnaise, oil, vinegar and mustard and season to taste. Mix all the vegetables with the apple, parsley and spring onions in a big bowl, then mix in the dressing. Mound into a serving bowl and sprinkle with the seed and nut mix, if using.
chief_review:
This vibrant coleslaw marries crisp textures and fresh flavors, elevating any festive table. The combination of fennel, cabbage, celeriac, apple, and parsley gives a delightful crunch and bright notes, while the seed and nut mix adds richness and extra texture. The dressing—a blend of mayonnaise, olive oil, wine vinegar, and Dijon mustard—brings creamy sharpness that ties the slaw together beautifully. 

The recipe is vegetarian-friendly and suits gluten-free diets, provided your Dijon mustard and mayonnaise are certified gluten-free, as some brands may contain trace gluten. For an egg-free version, use vegan mayonnaise. Additionally, this salad can accommodate nut allergies by omitting the seed and nut mixture. 

Overall, this coleslaw is a refreshing, versatile side that complements richer main courses, especially ideal for holiday celebrations.

name: Winter cannellini bean soup
description: A freeze-ahead soup that's perfect for a festive meal - no more last minute panics
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1.4l chicken stock or vegetable stock (Kallo is good)
2 tsp chopped fresh oregano or marjoram or ½ tsp dried
2x 450g cans cannellini beans, drained and rinsed
a handful of flatleaf parsley, chopped
directions: Heat the oil in a large saucepan and tip in the shallots, garlic, carrot, celery, leeks and bacon. Cook over a medium heat for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until softened but not browned.

Pour in the stock, then add the bay leaves and oregano or marjoram. Season and bring to the boil, then cover the pan and simmer gently for 15 minutes. Tip in the beans, cover again and simmer for a further 5 minutes.
Pour the soup into a freezer container and leave it to cool completely, then seal, label and freeze for up to a month.
Defrost the soup at room temperature for 3 hours, (or overnight).

Tip into a saucepan, reheat gently until bubbling, and simmer for 5 minutes. Taste for seasoning. Swirl in the chopped parsley, ladle into warm bowls and top each with a drizzle of olive oil and a parsley sprig.
chief_review: This hearty, make-ahead soup is a brilliant addition to any festive spread. The combination of finely chopped vegetables—shallots, leek, carrot, celery—creates a flavorful, aromatic base, while the streaky bacon adds a subtle smokiness that enriches the broth. Cannellini beans provide a creamy texture and balanced body, making the soup both comforting and filling. Fresh herbs like oregano and flat-leaf parsley lift the flavors, and the finishing touch of extra-virgin olive oil adds silkiness. The recipe cleverly uses either chicken or vegetable stock, so by omitting the bacon and opting for vegetable stock, it can be made vegetarian-friendly. Additionally, with no wheat-based thickeners or pastas, this soup is naturally gluten-free if you ensure the stock is safe. Ideal for prepping ahead of time, the flavors develop beautifully as it freezes and reheats, banishing any last-minute kitchen stress.

name: Chicken liver & raisin pâté
description: This delicious, unashamedly rich starter is the sort of dish that makes entertaining stress-free, as it can be made up to three days ahead
author: Raymond Blanc
ingredients: 60g large blonde raisin, plus a few extra to garnish
200g chickenlivers, all traces of sinew removed
25g pistachioor hazelnuts, finely sliced, plus extra to garnish
salad leaves, dressed with walnut oil and wine vinegar
directions: A day ahead, put the raisins in a small bowl, pour over enough brandy to cover, then leave to soak for 1 hr. Pour the wine and port into a small, deep saucepan, tip in the shallots and garlic, then simmer until reduced by two-thirds – about 10 mins. Remove from the heat and pass through a fine sieve, pressing to extract all the juices. Allow to cool. Melt the 200g butter, then leave to cool slightly.

In a food processor, blend the chicken livers until smooth, then add the wine reduction followed by the eggs, the cooled melted butter, 1 tsp salt and ½ tsp black pepper. Pass through a fine sieve into a jug, stir in the nuts, then set aside. Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3.

Drain the raisins, then divide them between 6 x 125ml ramekins. Pour the chicken liver mixture over, leaving a small space at the top of each one. Stand the ramekins in a small roasting tin (or similar ovenproof dish with sides to make a bain-marie) then pour in enough hot water to reach two-thirds of the way up the sides. Cover with foil and bake for 35-40 mins. To check when cooked, push a fine knife blade into the centre and, if it comes out hot and clean, the pâté is ready. If not, continue to cook, but don’t overcook or let them soufflé up or the texture of the pâté will be grainy.

Remove from the bain-marie, then pour a thin layer of clarified butter over each dish to seal. Scatter over a few extra raisins and pistachios to garnish as the butter is setting. Leave to cool, then refrigerate for up to 3 days.
To serve, put each ramekin on a plate with toasted walnut bread and a few dressed salad leaves.
chief_review: This luxurious chicken liver pâté is a classic starter, perfect for make-ahead entertaining. The use of brandy, port, and white wine adds deep layers of flavor and richness, while the inclusion of large blonde raisins and toasted nuts gives subtle sweetness and texture. The clarified butter provides a beautiful finish, and pairing with toasted walnut bread and dressed salad leaves elevates the overall balance of the dish. This recipe suits gluten-free diets when served with gluten-free bread, as all primary pâté ingredients—chicken livers, eggs, butter, nuts, fruit, and aromatics—are naturally gluten-free. Additionally, it contains no added dairy aside from butter and is free from shellfish and soy. A refined dish, suitable for those seeking a sophisticated, crowd-pleasing appetizer with elegant flavors and textures.

name: Mini Mont Blancs
description: These bite-sized puddings are ideal for finger food and cocktail parties
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tbsp icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
directions: Trim the tops off the mini meringues. Softly whip the double cream with the icing sugar and divide this between the meringues. Top each with ½ tsp sweetened chestnut purée and dust with icing sugar before serving.
chief_review: These mini meringue puddings are a delightful treat, perfect for elegant gatherings or as bite-sized desserts at cocktail parties. The crisp shells of the meringue provide a light sweetness that pairs beautifully with the rich, lightly sweetened double cream and the unique, earthy flavor of sweetened chestnut purée. The recipe is free from gluten, making it an indulgent yet safe option for those on a gluten-free diet. It’s also suitable for vegetarians, as all the ingredients are plant-based or derived from dairy. The simplicity of the ingredient list allows the natural flavors to shine, and the extra dusting of icing sugar adds a festive touch. Serve these mini puddings chilled for the best texture and presentation.

name: Raspberry Martini fizz
description: This looks like a great recipe but does anyone know how much of the gin martini mix I should put into each glass?
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 bottles chilled proseccoor other sparkling wine
directions: Mix the Martini and gin together and chill or store in a bottle if making ahead. If you have room in your fridge or freezer, chill your Champagne glasses, too.

When your guests are due to arrive, spoon ½ tsp icing sugar into 8 Champagne glasses. Pour over the Martini mixture, mix with a spoon and add the frozen raspberries. Top up with the sparkling wine just before serving.
chief_review: This sparkling raspberry martini punch is a lively and elegant cocktail, perfect for celebrations or gatherings. The blend of Martini Rosso, gin, sparkling wine, and the natural sweetness from raspberries and icing sugar creates a balanced drink with botanically rich flavors and a refreshing finish. The frozen raspberries serve as both a flavorful garnish and a natural chiller, avoiding the dilution of traditional ice. While the recipe is not suitable for those avoiding alcohol or sugar, it is gluten-free and vegetarian, as none of the ingredients include gluten or animal-derived products. For best results, I recommend pouring about 100ml of the martini mix into each flute and topping up with sparkling wine. Cheers to a festive, beautifully crafted aperitif that delights the senses!

name: Double salmon roll
description: Make this posh starter ahead of time and serve up with salad and melba toast
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Flake the hot-smoked salmon into a bowl, discarding the skin. Add the horseradish, lemon juice, soft cheese, finely snipped chives and some seasoning and beat well until combined to a rough mousse texture.

Lay 2 sheets of cling film overlapping on your work surface, then lay the sliced smoked salmon out to make a rectangle about 20 x 50cm. Dollop the hot-smoked salmon mix over and gently spread over evenly. Use the edge of the cling film to roll the long side of the rectangle into itself, then roll up like a Swiss roll. Wrap in the film, twisting the ends like a cracker to secure and hold the shape. Freeze for up to a month.

Transfer the roll from the freezer to the fridge the day before you want to serve it. While still semi-frozen, cut into thick slices, lay on a tray, then leave to defrost completely in the fridge. Serve with leaves mixed with chives and a little dressing, and some melba toast.
chief_review: This sophisticated salmon starter is a true showstopper, perfect for preparing in advance for effortless entertaining. The creamy blend of hot-smoked salmon, soft cheese, horseradish, and lemon delivers a delightful balance of richness, heat, and freshness. An ample layer of smoked salmon wraps the creamy filling, providing luxurious texture and flavor. Fresh chives add a vibrant herbal note that elevates the dish further. Served with mixed salad leaves and crisp melba toast, this starter offers contrasting textures and satisfying depth. It's a lovely option for pescatarians and makes an elegant appetizer at dinner parties or festive gatherings. Those preferring gluten-free fare can easily substitute melba toast for a suitable alternative. The finished dish presents beautifully and is sure to impress guests with its harmonious flavors and inviting appearance.

name: Prawn, pomegranate & grapefruit salad
description: Bypass bread croutons and a heavy cream dressing and instead serve up a crispy, fruity salad with shellfish
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 2 pink grapefruits, zest and juice from 1, segments cut from the other
½ cucumber, halved lengthways, seeds scooped out with a teaspoon, diced
directions: Whisk together the grapefruit zest and juice, oil, vinegar, sugar and dill to make a dressing. Mix half with the prawns and allow to marinate for 10 mins.

Just before serving, gently toss the cucumber, shallots, frisée and rocket with the remaining dressing. Add a pile to each of 6 starter plates, along with the prawns and grapefruit segments. Scatter over the pomegranate seeds and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant salad is a delightful medley of crisp greens, succulent prawns, and the bright tang of grapefruits and pomegranate seeds. The dressing—a zesty blend of grapefruit juice, olive oil, and red wine vinegar, balanced with a touch of sugar and fresh dill—beautifully enhances the freshness of the prawns and the crunch of the cucumber and shallots. The combination of frisée and rocket introduces peppery and slightly bitter notes, which pair exceptionally well with the sweet, citrusy fruit. With no bread, dairy, or heavy ingredients, this dish remains light yet satisfying, making it perfect for a gluten-free and dairy-free diet. Additionally, the absence of common allergens like nuts or eggs makes it a safe, refreshing option for various gatherings. Overall, this salad is an elegant and healthful choice that celebrates the flavors of each season.

name: Cauliflower, rice & lentil salad
description: This earthy and vegetarian rice pilaf is good for feeding a crowd, so works well on a buffet table
author: John Torode
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Break the cauliflower into florets, drizzle with oil and toss with the paprika. Spread out in a roasting tin and roast for 40 mins until just tender. Allow to cool slightly.

Meanwhile, rinse the rice and lentils, then put them in a saucepan with twice their volume of water. Cover and bring to the boil, reduce to a simmer and cook for 25-30 mins. Drain and rinse under cold water.
To make the dressing, whisk together all the ingredients. Season and pour over the rice mixture while slightly warm, then stir in the cauliflower, raisins and parsley.
chief_review: This rice pilaf is a vibrant, earthy dish that brings together the sweet notes of raisins, the nuttiness of Puy lentils, and fresh herbs with a zesty lemon finish. Roasted cauliflower lends both heartiness and depth, pairing beautifully with wild and basmati rice for a range of textures. The generous use of olive oil and vinegar brightens the entire dish, making it wonderfully moreish in a buffet setting. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians and easily suits a vegan diet, as it contains no animal products. While substantial enough as a main, the pilaf also works well as an accompaniment to other dishes. The combination of ingredients ensures it’s both filling and healthy, appealing to diners looking for a savory yet refreshing crowd-pleaser.

name: Bread sauce stuffing
description: A great alternative to meat stuffing, or just an extra one for those special occasions
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 300g hunk crustless, unsliced white bread, torn into chunks
directions: Toss onion in 2 tbsp oil with thyme and seasoning; roast for 25-30 mins. Remove from oven, melt in crème fraîche, Add nutmeg, cloves and seasoning. Toss in bread and walnuts. Drizzle over remaining oil. Return to oven for 40 mins, until bread chunks are crisp. Toss through the parsley and serve.
chief_review: This inventive stuffing offers a robust, savory profile with a satisfyingly rich texture. The combination of slowly cooked onions and thyme creates an aromatic base, while crème fraîche introduces a creamy tang that pairs beautifully with earthy cloves and warming nutmeg. Torn white bread absorbs these flavors, and the walnuts provide delightful crunch and depth. Parsley lifts the final dish, adding vibrancy. This recipe is ideal for those seeking a vegetarian option at festive meals—although it does contain dairy and nuts, so isn't suitable for those with related allergies. The simplicity of the ingredients invites creative riffs; consider adding roasted mushrooms for an umami boost or swapping parsley for sage to complement autumn menus. A standout, meat-free stuffing that’s both hearty and elegant.

name: Smoked salmon parcels with fennel & walnut salad
description: Salmon and walnuts make an unusual marriage, but the flavours and textures work together really well. A great starter or light lunch
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: few crisp lettuce leaves, Batavia or Little Gem
directions: Select 4 slices of salmon and use to line four ramekins, allowing the slices to drape over the edges. Finely chop the remainder and put in a bowl. Trim the fronds from the fennel and finely chop. Add the chopped fronds to the chopped salmon along with the crème fraîche, 1 tbsp lemon juice and seasoning. Mix well, then divide between the lined ramekins. Fold over any overhanging salmon and cover with cling film. Chill until ready to serve.

Halve, quarter and core the fennel, then shred as finely as you can. Put in a bowl with the remaining lemon juice, 3 tbsp walnut oil and seasoning. Put a few lettuce leaves on each plate and scatter over the dressed fennel. Invert the salmon onto the plates, then scatter over the chopped walnuts. Drizzle with the remaining oil, season with black pepper and serve.
chief_review: This recipe elegantly pairs smoked salmon with crunchy walnuts and fresh fennel, resulting in a starter or light lunch that is both refined and satisfying. The creaminess of crème fraîche and the tang of lemon juice create a lively dressing, complemented by the nutty depth of walnut oil. Crisp lettuce and aromatic fennel brighten the plate, making each bite texturally dynamic. Notably, this dish is suitable for pescatarians and those following a gluten-free diet, as it contains no meat or wheat-based products. The combination of healthy fats from both salmon and walnuts also makes it an excellent choice for anyone seeking nutrient-rich light fare. Overall, a delightful balance of flavors and textures, perfect for a sophisticated yet simple meal.

name: Sweet potato dip with chorizo & chicory dippers
description: Cater for everyone at your party with this healthy canapé of paprika dip and Spanish sausage - it's gluten and dairy-free
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: small handful corianderor parsley, chopped, plus extra to serve
250g mini cooking chorizosausages (for special diets, see tip below)
few heads red and white chicory, leaves separated
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Put the potatoes on a baking tray and bake for 50 mins until really soft. Leave to cool.

Scoop the potato flesh into a food processor, discarding the skins. Add the oil, paprika, vinegar, coriander or parsley and some seasoning and whizz to a smooth paste. Transfer to a bowl, cover with cling film and chill until needed. The dip will keep for 2 days in the fridge – just bring to room temperature before serving.

Cook the chorizo in a small frying pan for 10 mins until cooked through. Drain on kitchen paper. Scatter extra coriander or parsley over the dip and serve with the chorizo and chicory leaves for dipping.
chief_review: This vibrant canapé recipe pairs a creamy, smoky paprika sweet potato dip with robust Spanish chorizo and crisp chicory leaves. It's a standout choice for gatherings, delivering both color and bold flavors. Impressively, the dish is gluten-free and dairy-free, making it ideal for guests with these dietary sensitivities. The sweet potatoes and smoked paprika lend a deep, earthy sweetness to the dip, while fresh herbs brighten the overall taste. Olive oil and red wine vinegar add richness and tang, perfectly complementing the spice from the chorizo. Using chicory leaves as edible scoops introduces crunch and a pleasant bitterness, balancing the sausage’s fattiness. For anyone seeking a flavorful, allergy-friendly appetizer, this canapé is a crowd-pleasing solution that doesn’t compromise on taste or presentation.

name: Spiced lamb skewers with pomegranate tzatziki
description: This tasty Greek-inspired canapé of grilled meat and sweet dip can be quickly whipped up for a party platter
author: Good Food
ingredients: ½ tsp each ground cumin, coriander, garam masala and cinnamon
directions: Mix the lamb with the cumin, coriander, garam masala and cinnamon. For the tzatziki, mix the Greek yogurt, shallot, garlic, mint, cucumber and honey. Sprinkle with pomegranate seeds. Cook the lamb under a hot grill for 8 mins, turning halfway. Thread each piece onto a cocktail stick. serve with tzatziki.
chief_review: This Greek-inspired canapé offers a delightful balance of spiced, grilled lamb and a refreshing yogurt dip, making it a vibrant choice for party platters. The blend of cumin, coriander, garam masala, and cinnamon on the lamb infuses rich, aromatic flavors, while the creamy dip of Greek yogurt, mint, cucumber, and a touch of honey and pomegranate seeds brings a cooling contrast. The recipe is naturally gluten-free, ideal for those avoiding wheat or gluten-containing ingredients. It also works well for low-carb diets, as it contains minimal carbohydrates. Be cautious if serving to guests with dairy sensitivities, as Greek yogurt is a key component. Overall, the canapé is a versatile, crowd-pleasing bite that beautifully marries savory and sweet, perfect for festive gatherings or as an appetizer at any Mediterranean-themed meal.

name: Chocolate brownie chunks with chocolate dip
description:
Pop these
tiny temptations into a low oven to warm
through quickly before serving
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
ingredients: 3 eggs, at room temperature and lightly beaten
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 6 and line the base of a 20cm square shallow baking tin with baking parchment. Melt 100g dark chocolate, all of the milk chocolate and the butter in a heatproof bowl over a pan of simmering water. Remove from the heat, then stir in the sugars. Cool a little while you prepare the rest of the ingredients.

Stir the eggs into the chocolate mixture, followed by the flour, walnuts and a pinch of salt until really well combined. Pour the mixture into the prepared tin, then bake for 25-30 mins until an inserted skewer comes out with sticky crumbs. Cool in the tin.
For the dip, gently melt the remaining chocolate as above, then stir into the yogurt and chill. To serve, cut the brownies into chunks, then spoon the dip into small bowls.
chief_review: This decadent recipe marries dark and milk chocolates with walnuts for a rich, irresistibly fudgy treat. Melting the chocolate and butter together yields a smooth base, beautifully complemented by the caramel notes of muscovado sugars. The lightly beaten eggs give rise to a tender, cakey texture, while the addition of natural yogurt ensures the result is moist without being heavy. Walnuts provide a satisfying crunch and earthy contrast to the deep chocolate flavors. Ideal for a crowd-pleasing dessert, especially when gently warmed before serving. This recipe contains gluten, dairy, eggs, and nuts, making it well-suited for vegetarian diets but not for those with common food allergies or dietary restrictions. Serve these bite-sized delights with a dusting of powdered sugar or a dollop of yogurt for extra flair.

name: Braised ox cheek Wellingtons with peppercorn gravy
description: Crisp puff pastry covers tender meat in these individual Wellingtons - the ultimate main course for a romantic Valentine's Day meal for two
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 1 tbsp rapeseed, vegetable or sunflower oil
1 ox cheek, about 350g trimmed of any sinew
1 tbsp plain flour, plus a little for dusting
1 tsp black peppercorns, crushed using a pestle and mortar
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Heat the oil in an ovenproof pan (one with a tight-fitting lid) or flameproof casserole dish over a high heat. Cut the ox cheek into 4 large chunks, then season well and toss in the flour and mustard powder. Place the pieces of meat in the hot oil – they should sizzle – and brown the meat all over. Add the onion to the pan and continue cooking until softened and starting to caramelise. Add the thyme, stock cube, porcini and some seasoning. Pour 450ml water into the pan, stirring to scrape any meaty bits off the bottom. Cover with a lid and place in the oven to cook for 3 hrs, turning the meat over in the liquid once while cooking, and topping up with a splash of water if the pan looks dry.

While the meat cooks, melt the butter in a pan. Add the garlic, stir for 1 min but don’t brown, then add the mushrooms and cook for 10-12 mins until the pan is dry and the mushrooms are turning golden. Season and set aside.

When their cooking time is up, scoop the ox cheeks out of the liquid and use 2 forks to shred the meat – discard any bits of fat or sinew. Strain the cooking liquid. Add 3-4 tbsp of the liquid back to the meat, along with the cooked mushrooms. Cool, then chill the meat mixture and the cooking liquid for 3 hrs, or up to 48 hrs.

Roll out the pastry on a floured surface to the thickness of a £1 coin. Cut out 2 x 12cm circles and 2 x 15cm circles – use 2 plates to cut around if you can. Arrange the prosciutto in pairs on top of the smaller circles of pastry, in a cross shape. Split the meat mixture in half and mount each portion on top of the prosciutto. Fold the prosciutto over the meat to encase it, then flip the little parcel of meat over, so the smooth side is facing up on top of the pastry. Brush the edge of each pastry circle with a little beaten egg, then place the larger circles of pastry on top. Use your hands to create a domed centre, then crimp the edges with a fork (or your fingers) to seal in the meat. Score the pastry in a criss-cross pattern, then brush all over with beaten egg.

Use any pastry scraps to cut out a heart for each pie, stick this on top and brush with egg too. Poke a steam hole on either side of each heart. Place each Wellington on a square of baking parchment and chill for at least 30 mins, or up to 24 hrs.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and put a baking tray in the oven to heat up. Slide the Wellingtons on their parchment onto the hot tray and bake for 30 mins. Meanwhile, reheat the cooking liquid, add the cream and peppercorns, and keep warm until ready to eat. Serve each Wellington with green veg and the peppercorn gravy for pouring over.
chief_review:
This individual Wellington recipe is a showstopper, perfect for a special occasion like Valentine’s Day. The star is a succulent ox cheek, slowly cooked for optimum tenderness, then encased in layers of finely chopped chestnut and porcini mushrooms, aromatic thyme, prosciutto, and crisp puff pastry. The dual use of fresh and dried mushrooms gives the duxelles a deep, earthy flavor that complements the rich meat beautifully. The touch of English mustard adds a subtle tang, while double cream creates a velvety sauce—classic touches of indulgence. 

Be mindful: this dish contains gluten (puff pastry, plain flour), dairy (butter, cream), eggs, and is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the meat and prosciutto. The complexity of the flavors and textures showcases impressive culinary technique, making it a stellar centerpiece for a romantic or celebratory meal.

name: Caramelised onion quiche with cheddar & bacon
description: Make quiche Lorraine to perfection every time with this easy recipe for a crisp pastry base and rich smoked bacon, cheese and thyme filling
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 large onions, halved and thinly sliced
1 tbsp fresh thyme leaves, plus a few sprigs
2-3 pinches of nutmeg, plus extra for the top
directions: Melt the butter in a large non-stick frying pan, add the onions and cook for 20 mins, stirring now and then, until they are soft and golden brown. Season, stir in the thyme leaves, then transfer to a plate to cool.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 with a large baking sheet inside. Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface until large enough to line a 25cm loose-bottomed tart tin, with a little overhang of pastry all the way round the top. This will stop the pastry shrinking in the oven later. If there is more overhang than you need, trim off the excess with scissors. Gently press the pastry into the sides of the tin and prick the base with a fork. Chill for 15 mins.

Line the pastry case with a sheet of baking parchment and fill with ceramic baking beans. Bake for 15 mins on the hot baking sheet (this helps to prevent a soggy bottom). Carefully remove the parchment and beans, then return to the oven for 10 mins more until the pastry looks cooked like shortbread, but is not too brown.

Meanwhile, put the bacon in the pan you cooked the onions in (there’s no need to wash it first or add any oil) and fry for 10 mins until golden. Lift from the pan onto kitchen paper to remove any excess fat. Beat the cream, milk and eggs with seasoning and nutmeg, then stir in the bacon and half the cheese.

Remove the pastry case from the oven and reduce heat to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Spoon the caramelised onions evenly over the base of the pastry case. Pour in the bacon mixture, then scatter with the remaining cheese, the thyme sprigs and a little nutmeg. Bake for 25-30 mins until golden and the filling is just set with a slight wobble in the centre.
Trim the excess pastry and leave to settle for 10 mins, then remove from the tin and slice.
chief_review: This Quiche Lorraine recipe showcases classic French flavors with a buttery pastry base, rich smoked bacon, caramelized onions, and a luscious, creamy cheese filling. The combination of mature cheddar and double cream creates a decadent texture, perfectly complemented by fragrant thyme and a hint of nutmeg. The crispness of the shortcrust pastry pairs beautifully with the savory, custardy interior. This recipe is ideal for those enjoying a vegetarian-free, hearty brunch or lunch—especially when served slightly warm alongside a green salad. Note that it contains common allergens, including dairy, eggs, and wheat, making it fitting for a standard diet but not for those with specific dietary restrictions. The method ensures even novice cooks can achieve a reliably satisfying, crowd-pleasing dish every time.

name: Roasted salt & paprika almonds
description: These nuts have a great kick of spice and can be whipped up quickly ahead of entertaining
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 x 150g packs whole almonds(skins on are fine)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Spread the nuts on a baking tray and roast for 15 mins. Tip the hot nuts into a bowl and toss with the butter, salt and paprika to taste, until coated. Tip the nuts back onto the tray and roast for 2 mins more to dry the coating onto them. Cool and store in an airtight container. The nuts will keep for 3 days.
chief_review: This spiced almond recipe is a delightful snack, perfect for entertaining or adding excitement to any cheese board. The combination of whole almonds with the warming depth of smoked paprika and the crunch of flaky sea salt creates layers of flavor, while a good knob of butter lends richness and helps the seasoning cling beautifully. The preparation is pleasantly straightforward and can be executed swiftly even on short notice. Notably, this recipe is naturally gluten-free, making it a great option for guests with gluten sensitivities. Additionally, with a simple substitution of plant-based butter, it can easily cater to a vegan diet. The use of whole almonds offers a satisfying texture and a dose of healthy fats, balancing the indulgence of butter and spices. Overall, these spiced nuts would be a memorable addition to any gathering or accompaniment to drinks.

name: Haricot bean & truffle mash
description: Give your mash a bit of texture with humble haricot beans and a hint of luxury with an optional splash of truffle oil
author: James Martin
ingredients: 2kg floury potato, such as Maris Piper, peeled and halved
2 x 400g tins haricot beans, drained and rinsed
directions: Boil the potatoes in salted water until tender, about 15 mins. Drain, replace the lid on the pan, then shake to break the potatoes up a bit. Add the beans, cream, butter and 2 tbsp truffle oil, then mash together well. Season liberally with salt, pepper and a good pinch of grated nutmeg, and drizzle with the remaining truffle oil.
chief_review: This mash is a delightful twist on the classic, bringing in haricot beans for an earthy bite and truffle oil for a touch of indulgence. The use of Maris Piper potatoes ensures a creamy texture, while the single cream and unsalted butter add rich smoothness. The subtle addition of freshly grated nutmeg lifts the flavor profile without overpowering the dish. This recipe is particularly suitable for vegetarians, as it contains no meat or animal-derived rennet. However, it is not vegan due to the dairy ingredients. The combination of beans and potatoes makes this mash heartier, perfect as a luxurious side for special occasions. Those with lactose intolerance or dairy allergies may want to consider alternatives, but for most, this dish offers a sophisticated take on comfort food.

name: Sticky Thai pork
description: This classic dish, called Mah Hor in Thailand, is served with wafer-thin slices of pineapple, ready to scoop
author: John Torode
ingredients: 2 fat green chillies, seeds left in
small bunch coriander, stalks finely chopped (or if you can find a bunch with the root intact, chop that instead)
50g dried shrimp, soaked in water for 10 mins, then drained
½ pineapple, peeled and sliced very thinly, to serve
directions: Put the ginger, garlic, chilli, coriander stalks (or root) and shrimp into a food processor and whizz to a paste.

Heat a wok, add the oil, then add the paste. Fry until fragrant. Add the pork, stir well and fry for 5 mins until cooked through. Stir in the fish sauce and the palm sugar, then cook for a good 10 mins more, until the meat becomes sticky, dark and caramelised. Can be made up to 2 days ahead, then reheated. Cool a little, top each pineapple slice with a teaspoon of the sticky pork and devour.
chief_review: Mah Hor is a delightful blend of sweet, spicy, and savory flavors, artfully balanced across pineapple slices that add refreshing acidity and texture. The use of minced pork, dried shrimp, and fish sauce grants the filling a deep umami complexity, while the aromatic kick from fresh ginger, green chillies, and coriander keeps the profile lively. Palm or muscovado sugar introduces just the right caramel note to complement the fruitiness of the pineapple. This dish is particularly well-suited to those on a gluten-free diet, as there are no wheat-based ingredients present. Additionally, the use of groundnut or vegetable oil makes it adaptable for those avoiding dairy. Classic, vibrant, and perfect for an elegant starter or canapé—Mah Hor brings Thai flavor to any feast with style.

name: Santa's mince pie diamonds
description: Get the kids to make them, then relax with a glass of sherry for you and one for Santa
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and grease an 18 x 28cm baking tray with melted butter. Brush a sheet of filo pastry with melted butter and lay buttered side up in the tray. Repeat with 4 more sheets, brushing each layer with melted butter. In a large bowl, mix all of the dried fruit, brown sugar, spices and honey together. Spoon a third of the filling into the tray in an even layer. Cover with 3 buttered sheets of filo. Continue until you have 3 layers of fruit, sandwiched and topped with 3 sheets of buttered filo.
Brush the top with melted butter, then, using a sharp knife, carefully cut into diamond shapes. Sprinkle with a little water (to prevent the corners curling) and bake for 30 mins until golden brown.
Warm the zest, honey and 2 tbsp water in a pan, then pour over the still-warm pastry. Leave to cool in the tray before loosening the pieces and arranging on a plate to serve.
chief_review: This festive recipe is an imaginative twist on traditional mince pies, utilizing filo pastry for a delightfully crisp texture. The combination of mixed dried fruit, berries, cinnamon, and spice, complemented by honey and lemon zest, creates a vibrant, aromatic filling bursting with holiday flavor. The use of filo sheets and melted butter provides a light, flaky base, ensuring a delicate contrast to the rich fruit mixture. This recipe is vegetarian-friendly, making it a great option for gatherings with diverse dietary needs. The approachable method makes it ideal for cooking with kids, adding a fun, family-friendly activity to your holiday traditions. Enjoy the sweet scent of baking spices as these treats crisp up in the oven—perfect alongside a glass of sherry for a well-deserved festive treat.

name: Duck with summer peas & beans
description: An elegant main course
author: Ainsley Harriott
ingredients: 450g new potato, scrubbed and halved or quartered if large
directions: Preheat the oven to 220C/gas 7/fan 200C. Score the duck breasts on their skin side with a very sharp knife, then press the cracked pepper on to the skin and sprinkle with the salt. Heat a heavy-based frying pan until it is very hot, then put the breasts skin-side down in the hot pan, without added fat. Cook for 5-6 minutes until the skin is crisp, then turn and cook on the other side for 2 minutes. Transfer the duck breasts, skin-side up, to a baking tray, pour the fat into a bowl and wipe the frying pan clean. Roast the duck for 8-10 minutes, depending on thickness.

While the duck is roasting, prepare the vegetables. Cook the potatoes in boiling salted water for 10 minutes. Remove the duck breasts from the oven and set aside to rest for about 10 minutes. After the potatoes have cooked for 10 minutes, tip in the broad beans and cook for 1 minute, then add the peas and cook for 3-4 minutes until all the vegetables are tender. Drain well.

Heat half the duck fat in the frying pan until hot, and cook the bacon until browned, about 4 minutes. Toss in the garlic and veg until piping hot and glossy. Pour in the vinegar, let it bubble, then stir in the parsley, and season with salt and pepper. Serve with the duck.
chief_review: This elegant duck breast main course showcases perfectly seasoned, seared duck paired with vibrant spring vegetables and a flavor boost from smoked bacon and tangy sherry vinegar. The use of new potatoes, broad beans, and peas creates a delightful textural contrast, all brought together with fresh parsley for a bright finish. The cracked black peppercorn and sea salt enhance the natural richness of the duck without overwhelming. With no gluten-containing ingredients, this dish is gluten-free, provided care is taken with any added condiments. However, it is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the inclusion of duck and bacon. The recipe may also suit those looking for a balanced meal, rich in protein and seasonal vegetables, making it as nourishing as it is sophisticated. In short, this is a refined, restaurant-quality dish that will impress at any dinner gathering.

name: Butternut soup with crispy sage & apple croutons
description: I made this today. It's delicious. http://fatburningsouprecipess.blogspot.com/
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 butternut squash, about 1kg, peeled, deseeded and chopped
500ml gluten-free vegetable stock, plus a little extra if necessary
1 tsp chopped sage, plus 20 small leaves, cleaned and dried
1 large eating apple, peeled, cored and diced
a few pinches of golden caster sugar
directions: Heat the oil in a large pan, add the onion and fry for 5 mins. Add the garlic and squash, and cook for 5 mins more. Pour in the Madeira and stock, stir in the chopped sage, then cover and simmer for 20 mins until the squash is tender.

Blitz with a hand blender or in a food processor until completely smooth. Allow to cool in the pan, then chill until ready to serve. Will keep for 2 days or freeze for 3 months. To make the crispy sage, heat some oil (a depth of about 2cm) in a small pan, then drop in the sage leaves until they are crisp – you will need to do this in batches. Drain on kitchen paper. Will keep for several hours.
Just before serving, reheat the soup in a pan. The texture should be quite thick and velvety, but thin it with a little stock if it is too thick.
For the apple croutons, heat the oil in a large pan, add the apple and fry until starting to soften. Sprinkle with the sugar and stir until lightly caramelised.
To serve, ladle the soup into small bowls and top with the apple, sage and a grinding of black pepper.
chief_review: This vibrant butternut squash soup recipe strikes a beautiful balance between savory and sweet, thanks to the combination of squash, apples, and a hint of sherry. The use of fresh sage adds subtle herbal notes, while the crispy sage leaves finish the soup with textural contrast. Olive and sunflower oils keep the richness light and heart-healthy. Notably, the use of certified gluten-free vegetable stock means this recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet. Additionally, it’s entirely plant-based, making it an excellent choice for vegetarians and vegans. With only common allergens like onion and garlic, it’s broadly accessible and perfect for a cozy lunch or elegant starter. Highly recommended for anyone seeking a comforting, flavorful, and diet-friendly soup.

name: Warm Mexican bean dip with tortilla chips
description: A quick and easy party dip which is superhealthy, freezable and counts towards your five-a-day - what more could you want?
author: Good Food
ingredients: 400g tin mixed beans, rinsed and drained
directions: Fry the chopped onion in olive oil until soft. Add soft brown sugar, wine vinegar and Cajun seasoning. Cook for 1 min then add the mixed beans and chopped tomatoes with garlic. Simmer for 10-15 mins until the sauce has thickened then season.

Scatter handful grated cheddar onto tortilla chips. Microwave on High for 1 min until cheese has melted. Serve alongside the dip (top with some chopped avocado if you like). Make ahead and reheat dip before guests arrive.
chief_review: This vibrant party dip is quick to prepare and packed with nutritious ingredients, making it a standout choice for casual gatherings. The combination of mixed beans and tomatoes delivers a punch of protein, fiber, and satisfying richness, while Cajun seasoning infuses a lively depth of flavor. Caramelized onion, a hint of brown sugar, and a splash of wine vinegar provide a delightful balance of sweetness and tang. Topped with melting cheddar and served with crunchy tortilla chips and optional fresh avocado, this dip is comforting, hearty, and conveniently freezable. It’s well-suited for vegetarians and can be made gluten-free if you choose gluten-free tortilla chips. The recipe is also nut-free, making it a great option for those with nut allergies. A versatile, crowd-pleasing dish that truly elevates any party table!

name: Almost-instant sweet wine ice-cream
description: This fruity treat will last for up to a month in the freezer
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 150ml sweet white wine, such as Orange Muscat and Flora
summer fruits to serve, such as blackberries, raspberries and redcurrants
directions: Tip the wine and sugar into a bowl and whisk together. Gradually whisk in the cream until it starts to thicken and just hold its shape.
Pour into a rigid container and freeze until firm, about 3-4 hours. Serve in scoops with seasonal summer fruits splashed with a little more sweet wine.
chief_review: This recipe delivers an elegant and refreshing frozen dessert, perfect for showcasing the vibrant flavors of summer fruits. The combination of rich double cream and sweet white wine creates a luxurious base, balanced by the tartness of blackberries, raspberries, and redcurrants. The use of caster sugar ensures a smooth, creamy texture and just the right level of sweetness. With minimal preparation and the convenience of a month-long freezer life, this treat is a practical make-ahead option for entertaining. Suitable for vegetarians, it can be paired with your choice of seasonal fruits for a personalized touch. An indulgent, yet simple, celebration of summer’s best bounty.

name: Pear, date & walnut salad with creamy stilton dressing
description: Works every time!
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 3 ripe pears, quartered and cored, peel left on
1-2 tbsp ginger syrup (from a jar of ginger in syrup)
12 dates (Medjool are good), stoned and chopped
directions: Cut the pear quarters into thin slices and toss in a bowl with the lime juice to help protect their natural colour. Blend the crème fraîche with half the stilton, ginger syrup to taste, and enough water (3-4 tbsp) to give a smooth, thick coating consistency. (Don’t add too much water or it may separate.)
Scatter the pear slices over six serving plates and follow with the walnuts, dates and remaining cheese. Can be prepared to this stage up to an hour ahead.

Drizzle each salad with a little of the dressing and some walnut oil. Season with a grinding of pepper – you shouldn’t need salt, as the cheese is salty. Mix the salad leaves and watercress very lightly with just a bit more dressing – some leaves should be touched by the dressing, some untouched. Gently pile the leaves on top of each salad.
chief_review: This vibrant salad recipe offers a delightful balance of sweet, tangy, and earthy flavors. The ripe pears pair beautifully with creamy Stilton, while the dates and ginger syrup add subtle layers of sweetness and spice. The crème fraîche provides a luscious texture that marries well with the sharpness of the cheese, and the walnuts deliver a satisfying crunch. Watercress and mixed salad leaves bring freshness and a peppery bite, enhanced by a finishing drizzle of walnut oil. This dish is an excellent choice for vegetarians and for those on a gluten-free diet, as all the ingredients are naturally free from gluten and meat. Ideal as a dinner party starter or a light lunch, this recipe brings sophistication to the table with minimal effort and maximum reward.

name: Naan dippers with fresh mint & coriander raita
description: The perfect start to an Indian buffet, this refreshing dip is sure to have your guests digging in - ideal for New Year's Day
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: a handful of fresh mint leaves
directions: Up to a day ahead, coarsely grate the cucumber into a bowl then squeeze it with your hands to remove as much juice as possible.
In a food processor, whizz the yogurt, mint and coriander together until well blended. Tip into a bowl and stir in the cucumber. Cover with cling film and chill until you are ready to serve.

To serve, preheat the oven to 200C/gas 6/fan 180C. Cut the naan into long triangles and arrange on 2 large baking sheets. Brush them with oil on one side and sprinkle over a little paprika and salt. Bake for 8-10 minutes until crisp and golden. Season the raita with up to 1 teaspoon of salt (see tip) and lemon juice to taste. Serve on a platter with fresh tomato chutney and dippers.
chief_review: This cucumber and herb Greek yogurt dip is a vibrant, cooling addition to any Indian buffet spread.
