The tangy yogurt base, enlivened by fresh mint, coriander, and a splash of lemon juice, pairs beautifully with crisped naan bread brushed in olive oil and finished with paprika and sea salt. The use of Greek yogurt provides a protein boost while keeping the dip creamy and luscious. It’s an excellent option for lacto-vegetarians, making it versatile for mixed gatherings. Simple yet full of character, this recipe elevates classic flavors with garden-fresh herbs and thoughtful seasoning. Serve chilled to highlight its refreshing qualities—your guests will keep coming back for more.

name: Sesame & chilli pancakes with tzatziki
description: A tempting and tasty gluten-free option for your party guests. These are a little like small blinis
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g gluten-free flour (we used Doves Farm, widely available)
1 green and 1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
1 bunch spring onions, finely sliced, plus extra to serve
directions: Whizz the flour, egg, yogurt and 2 tbsp water together in a food processor to form a smooth batter. tip into a bowl, then stir in the chillies, spring onions, coriander and sesame seeds. Cover and chill until required.
To make the tzatziki, mix the yogurt, cucumber and mint together, season to taste, then chill.

Heat a small frying pan with a splash of oil, wiping out excess oil with kitchen paper. fry the pancake mixture a dessertspoonful at a time, for 1 min on each side, until lightly browned. tip onto a plate and keep warm. pile onto a large platter, top with a dollop of tzatziki and some extra sliced spring onions and serve warm.
chief_review: This recipe delivers delightful gluten-free blinis with a vibrant punch from fresh chillies, spring onions, coriander, and sesame seeds. The use of gluten-free flour ensures it’s perfect for those with celiac disease or gluten intolerance, and substituting soya yogurt keeps the batter light and dairy-free. However, the addition of Greek yogurt in the dip means the dish is not entirely dairy-free or vegan, but vegetarians can enjoy it without concern. The refreshing cucumber-mint yogurt pairs beautifully with the warm, savory pancakes, and the garnish of extra spring onion adds the right touch of freshness. A wonderful, inclusive party snack that balances heat, herbaceousness, and creamy-cooled accompaniment—all packed into a bite-sized treat.

name: Sticky apple cups
description: These simple dessert cups are made in the microwave and are brilliant to use up leftover dates and prunes
author: Good Food
ingredients: 85g ready-to-eat prune, roughly chopped or raisins
0% Greek yogurtor fromage frais, to serve
directions: Halve each apple through the circumference and dig out the core with a dessert spoon from both halves, leaving bowl-shaped hollows behind.

Mix together all the remaining ingredients except for the orange juice and fill the apples with the mixture. Fit them into a microwaveable dish and pour the orange juice on top. Cover and cook on Medium (500w) for 5-7 mins until soft. Cool for a few mins before serving with the yogurt or fromage frais.
chief_review: This recipe for microwave dessert cups is an inspired way to utilize leftover dates and prunes, creating a naturally sweet and fibre-rich treat. The Bramley apples provide a tartness that balances the richness of the dried fruit, while the mixed spice and orange zest add warmth and freshness. Using 0% Greek yogurt or fromage frais for serving not only gives the dish a creamy finish but also keeps it low in fat, making it a suitable option for those following a vegetarian or low-fat diet. Additionally, this dessert contains no gluten ingredients and can fit into a gluten-free diet if served with certified gluten-free yogurt. The absence of eggs and nuts makes it a thoughtful choice for common food allergies. Overall, it’s a satisfying, nutritious dessert with minimal preparation and maximum flavor.

name: Citrus-cured salmon gravadlax
description: Gravadlax makes a stunning prepare-ahead starter or centrepiece for your New Year festivities
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 1 filleted side of very fresh salmon- weighing about 900g
100g mixed baby salad leavesand extra virgin olive oil, to serve
directions: Tip all the ingredients for the salt mix into a food processor and whizz until everything is combined and the spices are completely ground.
Stroke your hand along the salmon fillet to check for any stray bones. If you find any, pull them out with a pair of tweezers or small pliers.

To skin the salmon fillet, lay the fish skin-side down with the tail end closest to you. Insert your knife at an angle at the tail end and cut through the flesh to the skin. Turn the blade so it’s almost flat against the skin, then take hold of the skin with the other hand. Pull and wiggle the skin towards you so as to cut the fillet away. Halfway through removing the skin, hold the knife firmly and flip the fillet over. Gently lift the fillet away from the skin and discard the skin. Trim away the thinner part, plus any fat around the edges, so that the fillet has an even shape.

Scatter about a third of the salt mix onto a large tray in a line about the size of the salmon fillet. Lay the salmon, skinned-side down, over the salt and pack the rest of the salt on top. Cover with cling film, put another tray on top and weigh it down with a few cans or an empty casserole dish. Leave in the fridge overnight or for at least 10 hrs.

Under cold running water, wash the salt mix off the salmon fillet, then dry with kitchen paper. Finely chop the dill. Lay the salmon on a board and cover with the dill, pressing it down to pack it onto the salmon.
If serving as a plated starter, use a sharp carving knife to cut the salmon straight down into fine slices, allowing 6 slices for each plate.

To make the horseradish cream, whisk together the cream and crème fraîche. Add the horseradish, lemon juice and seasoning, then continue to whisk until thick. Dress the salad leaves in a little olive oil. You are now ready to plate up.

Arrange a neat pile of baby salad leaves in the centre of each plate. Curl slices of the salmon into bow shapes around the leaves. Continue all the way around the plate in a petal fashion. Use 2 teaspoons to make small quenelles of horseradish cream and spoon each into each bowl.
chief_review: This Gravadlax recipe is a showstopping choice for elegant festive gatherings, delivering a beautifully balanced interplay of flavors—fresh salmon cured with citrus zests, fragrant dill, and delicately spiced with star anise and coriander. The mix of Maldon sea salt and demerara sugar creates a perfect cure, keeping the salmon moist yet firm. Paired with a zesty horseradish cream and crisp salad leaves tossed in olive oil, this dish offers a refreshing and luxurious starter. It suits pescatarian and gluten-free diets, provided the horseradish used is gluten-free and free from additives. The recipe does include dairy, so is best for those who enjoy classic creams in their starters. Overall, the gravadlax’s vibrant presentation and make-ahead convenience make it perfect for celebratory occasions.

name: Jewelled fruit, nut & seed cake
description:
If you’re not keen on icing and marzipan, bake a crown of toasted nuts, seeds and juicy cherries onto
your cake instead
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 batch uncooked Hot toddy fruitcake mix (see link below)
directions: Make the Hot toddy cake (see link, right) in a loose-bottom tin, holding back about 2 tbsp of the mix for later. While it bakes, bake the fruit and nut topping. Melt the butter and golden syrup together, then toss with the nuts, dried fruit and seeds. Set aside; the butter mix will start to cool and thicken.

Take the cake out of the oven 30 mins before the end of cooking, then gently spread over the remaining cake mix with the back of a spoon. The cake will still be quite soft but will take the weight, don’t worry about it sinking. Scatter the fruit and nut mix over the top in an even layer. Bake for the remaining 30 mins until the cake is cooked and the nuts golden. Test for doneness by poking a skewer through the topping and into the cake. If it’s underdone, but the nuts are golden, just cover with foil and give it another 10 mins; then test again.

Leave the cake to cool completely in the tin, so that the nutty topping firms up. Loosen any obviously sticky edges, then push the cake out of the tin from the bottom. Transfer to a cake board or plate and fix the ribbon around the base before serving. Can be kept in an airtight tin for up to a week.
chief_review: This festive fruitcake offers a delightful alternative to traditional iced cakes, topping rich, boozy fruitcake with a vibrant crown of toasted nuts, seeds, and juicy cherries. The buttery glaze with golden syrup binds a medley of cashews, blanched almonds, pistachios, Brazil nuts, and pumpkin seeds, creating a crunchy contrast to the moist base. The addition of glacé cherries and dried cranberries delivers tang and sweetness, elevating each bite. Suitable for vegetarians, this recipe avoids marzipan and icing, letting the natural flavors and textures of fruits and nuts shine. The result is an elegant, jewel-topped centerpiece that will appeal to those seeking a less sugary, more textural twist on the classic holiday cake. Perfect for gatherings or as a homemade edible gift.

name: Berry semifreddo with warm chocolate sauce
description: An indulgent dessert with a hint of coffee that you can freeze for up to one month - perfect for festive entertaining
author: Good Food
ingredients: 140g dark chocolate (70% cocoa solids), broken into pieces
directions: Preheat the oven to fan 90C/ conventional 110C/gas 1⁄4 and cover a baking sheet with baking parchment. Tip the egg whites into a large bowl, sprinkle in the coffee powder and whisk until the whites are stiff. Add half the caster sugar and whisk in well, then tip in the remaining sugar and the chopped hazelnuts and whisk until blended and standing in stiff peaks.
Spread the meringue mixture to a depth of about 2cm on the baking parchment (any shape will do as you’re going to break it up later). Bake for 3 hours until crisp right through. Remove and cool.
Cut out a 28cm circle of baking parchment and make 10cm cuts towards the centre all the way round. Use this to line the bottom and sides of a loose-bottomed 20cm round cake tin.

Pour the cream from both cartons into a bowl and whip until it just holds its shape. Break the meringue into smallish pieces with your hands. Set aside about a third of the meringue for the top of the cake, and mix the rest into the cream. Spread out about a third of the cream mixture in the bottom of the tin and cover with half the frozen berries. Repeat these layers once more, then cover with the remaining cream mixture and top with the reserved meringue. Cover the cake with cling film and compress evenly with a small plate that fits inside the tin. Wrap in foil, label and freeze for up to a month.

Make the sauce. Put the cream and golden syrup in a small pan with 3 tbsp water. Heat until just bubbling, then turn the heat down to low and add the chocolate and butter. Heat gently, stirring occasionally, until the chocolate melts and the mixture becomes smooth and glossy. Pour into a freezer container, cool, seal, label and freeze for up to a month.

transfer the cake and the chocolate sauce from the freezer to the fridge 8 hours before you plan to serve. After 2-3 hours, take out the cake. Unwrap it and carefully balance the cake tin on a jam jar or can, then push down on the sides of the tin to release. Peel away the baking parchment from the sides. Now lift the cake off the base of the tin, discarding the parchment underneath (a wide palette knife or fish slice will help here) and stand the cake on a serving plate. Return to the fridge for 5 hours before serving with the chocolate sauce.
To warm the chocolate sauce, pour it into a heatproof bowl over a pan with a little hot water in the bottom and heat gently, stirring occasionally, until warm, smooth and glossy.
chief_review: This frozen coffee-hazelnut dessert is a showstopper, ideal for festive occasions and advance preparation. The coffee subtly elevates the sweetness, while toasted hazelnuts provide depth and crunch, contrasting beautifully with the velvety double cream and bittersweet dark chocolate. The mixed berries add a bright, tart note, balancing the richness and introducing a refreshing layer. The texture is luxurious yet light from the meringue base, making each bite both indulgent and airy. While the dessert isn't suitable for nut or dairy allergies and contains eggs, it is gluten free, making it a wonderful option for those avoiding gluten in their diet. Serve this semifreddo-style treat sliced straight from the freezer—its dazzling flavor and impressive presentation are sure to captivate your guests.

name: Piernik (Polish gingerbread)
description: A classic Polish honey gingerbread cake is adapted by Edd Kimber. It's layered with plum jam and coated in chocolate with sprinkles of edible gold
author: Edd Kimber
ingredients: 140g unsalted butter, plus extra for greasing
140g dark chocolate(70% cocoa solids), finely chopped
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Grease and line the base and sides of a deep 20cm cake tin with baking parchment. Put the honey, sugar and butter in a medium saucepan and cook over a medium heat until fully melted. Remove from the heat and allow to cool. Put the flour and spices in a large bowl and mix everything together.

Once the liquid ingredients have cooled, whisk in the eggs. Pour over the dry ingredients, whisking them together to form a smooth batter – be careful not to overmix as this can lead to a dry cake. Pour into the prepared tin and bake for 50-55 mins or until risen and a skewer inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean. Allow the cake to cool in the pan for 20 mins before turning out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

Once cooled, use a large serrated knife to slice the cake into 3 layers. Spread the jam across the 2 bottom cake layers, then reassemble the cake and set aside while you make the glaze. Put the cream, chocolate and honey in a medium pan and cook over a low-medium heat until the chocolate is melted and you have a smooth, pourable mixture. Put the cake on a wire rack set over a parchment-lined baking tray and pour over the glaze, making sure to cover the entire cake. Use a fish slice to carefully transfer the cake to a serving plate and allow the glaze to set. To decorate, dust with a little edible gold powder, if you like. Uniced, this cake will keep for up to 5 days.
chief_review: Edd Kimber’s adaptation of the classic Polish honey gingerbread cake is an indulgent treat, striking a delightful balance between warming spices and rich sweetness. The honey-forward sponge carries aromatic notes of ginger, cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg, offering complexity without overpowering. Layered with tart plum jam, the cake gains both moisture and a subtle, fruity tang, while the dark chocolate coating adds a luxurious finish. Edible gold dust is a playful, elegant touch. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or gelatine. While not dairy- or gluten-free, nor vegan, it delivers a refined, festive centerpiece for special occasions, worthy of any celebration.

name: Triple chocolate mousse
description: A trio of milk, dark and white chocolate combined in a delectable mousse
author: Gary Rhodes
ingredients: 75g each good-quality milk, white, plain chocolate, broken into pieces
icing sugar, single cream, chocolate curls
directions: For a 1.2 litre terrine, cut a strip of greaseproof paper as long as the tin and wide enough to cover the bottom and come up both long sides, with about 7.5cm to spare. Put the paper in the tin as if to line it, then draw a line across the paper on both sides where it meets the bottom edge, and the top edge, of the tin. Take the paper out of the tin and draw two lines at equal intervals between the bottom and top edge lines you have already drawn. (This will help you make each layer exactly the same depth when filling the tin.) Lightly grease the paper and use to line the tin.

Whip a third of the cream to just soft peak stage, then chill. Melt the milk chocolate in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of simmering water or microwave on High for 2 mins. Whisk 2 egg yolks and 25g/1oz sugar in a heatproof bowl over a pan of simmering water with a hand-held electric blender for about 2-3 mins until the mixture has at least doubled in volume. Once you have reached this stage, remove the bowl from the heat and keep whisking, adding the melted chocolate – this not only incorporates the chocolate, but also cools the mixture more quickly. Leave to cool for a few minutes, then carefully fold in the whipped cream.

Quickly whisk two egg whites into soft peaks, making sure the bowl and whisk are spotless to ensure the maximum volume is obtained. Using a large metal spoon, carefully fold the egg white into the chocolate mixture so you don’t knock out too much air.

Pour mixture into the terrine, filling it to first mark (any extra can be frozen), then freeze for 20-30 mins before starting the white chocolate mixture. Repeat process with white chocolate, then the plain; cover with plastic film and freeze completely. To guarantee a good set, make terrine at least 8-10 hrs or up to 2 days before.

Dip the tin briefly in a large bowl of hot water. Put a chopping board or flat plate on top and invert the mousse. Gently remove the paper and open freeze for about 10 mins to re-set. To decorate, pipe an outline of melted plain chocolate in a teardrop shape onto each plate. Dust the plates lightly with icing sugar, then carefully fill the teardrop with cream. Slice the mousse, wiping the knife after each cut, and put a slice on each plate. Decorate with chocolate curls and serve at once.
chief_review: This elegant three-chocolate mousse delivers a luscious, layered dessert with creamy textures and an indulgent blend of milk, white, and dark chocolate. The use of double cream and three types of chocolate results in a rich, velvety mouthfeel, while egg yolks lend body and the whipped whites provide lightness. It’s well-balanced in sweetness, with just enough sugar to enhance the chocolate flavors without overpowering them. Garnishes of icing sugar, single cream, and chocolate curls add visual appeal and a textural contrast. This recipe is a delight for any chocolate lover and is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or fish products. However, be mindful of the presence of eggs, dairy, and chocolate, which may pose issues for some allergies. This mousse would make a sophisticated finish to any meal or a luxurious treat for special occasions.

name: Redcurrant & red onion relish
description: Fantastic with goat's cheese, sausages or cold meats
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 medium red onions, peeled and cut into thin wedges
1 small red pepper, seeded and cut into small chunks
1 plump red chilli, seeded and chopped
directions: Toss the onions with the red pepper and the oil, then fry in a frying pan for 5-8 mins over a high heat until lightly charred and softened. Remove from the pan and set aside.

Put the chilli, garlic and ginger in the pan with half the vinegar. Bring to the boil then simmer for 2-3 mins. Add the onions and pepper plus the remaining vinegar, all the sugar, spice and 1 tsp salt.
Bring to the boil then bubble away for about 5 mins until thickened. Add redcurrants and simmer for about 5 mins more, or until they have burst, but still have some shape and the liquid is syrupy.
Remove and pour into a large heatproof jar. Cover and seal while hot. Keeps in the fridge for up to 3 weeks.
chief_review:
This vibrant recipe celebrates the tangy-sweet complexity of red onions and redcurrants, rounded out by the warmth of ginger, garlic, and five spice. The pairing of red wine vinegar and muscovado sugar creates a lush chutney-like condiment with a nice balance between acidity and sweetness, while the red chilli adds a pleasant, gentle heat. Its versatility makes it a fantastic companion to goat’s cheese, sausages, or cold meats, shining especially on a cheese board or charcuterie platter.

This recipe is naturally vegetarian and vegan, as it contains no animal products. It is also gluten-free, assuming standard red wine vinegar is used. However, those with allium allergies or sensitivities to nightshades should avoid it. Overall, a deftly balanced and delicious condiment that adds flair and color to a range of dishes.

name: Smoked salmon with Asian dressing
description: A mix of chilli, lime, sesame and soy turns a traditional smoked salmon starter into a spicy taste sensation
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 large just-ripe avocados, peeled, stoned and diced
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Mix the ingredients for the dressing. It will keep in the fridge overnight, although the flavours will get hotter as the chilli sits in the liquid.

To serve, arrange the salmon on plates – it works out at about 3 slices per person. Mix the avocado, cucumber and coriander, then pile or scatter on top. Spoon over a little of the dressing and serve.
chief_review: This vibrant smoked salmon starter takes a bold, modern turn with the addition of chilli, lime, sesame oil, and soy sauce—creating a dish that’s lively and full of contrasts. The creamy avocado and crisp cucumber balance the smoky richness of the salmon, while fresh coriander and zingy lime zest add a refreshing lift. A touch of sugar provides a subtle sweetness to round out the spice and acidity. This dish is an excellent choice for pescatarians and is also gluten-free if a gluten-free soy sauce is used. It’s fresh, light, and perfect for entertaining, especially when you want to impress with minimal fuss but maximum flavour. The interplay of textures and flavours makes it a stand-out appetiser for summer gatherings or special occasions.

name: Warm carrot salad with toasted cumin dressing
description: A simple and lightly spiced salad is the perfect accompaniment to your favourite lamb, chicken or fish dish
author: Good Food
directions: Put the cumin seeds in a dry frying pan set over a lowish heat. Cook for a few minutes, tossing in the pan, until they smell fragrant and have darkened slightly. Grind them in a spice or coffee grinder.
Put the carrots in a saucepan and cover with cold water. Add a few pinches of salt, then bring to the boil. Turn the heat to low and cook very gently for 3-4 minutes. Drain.

Whisk the oil, lemon juice and sugar, then stir in the garlic and 1⁄4 tsp salt. Stir in the cumin and paprika. Mix well with the carrots, then leave to cool, stirring occasionally. Toss in the coriander and lemon zest. Serve at room temperature.
chief_review: This vibrant carrot salad masterfully balances the earthy warmth of toasted cumin seeds with the bright, zesty lift of lemon zest and juice. The muscovado sugar adds a subtle molasses undertone, enhancing the natural sweetness of the carrots without overpowering them. Thinly sliced garlic and fresh coriander provide aromatic depth, while a touch of paprika rounds out the flavor profile with a gentle smokiness. The use of extra-virgin olive oil brings everything together, giving the salad a silky finish. Exceptionally fresh and light, this dish is naturally vegan, gluten-free, and nut-free—making it a versatile choice for a range of dietary preferences. It stands out as a refreshing accompaniment to meats or fish or can easily be enjoyed on its own as a satisfying, healthful starter.

name: Sticky ginger-nut cake
description: A wonderfully sticky dessert - perfect served with a dollop of cream
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 100g butter, room temperature, cut in pieces
85g stem ginger in syrup (from a jar), roughly chopped
directions: Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Butter a 23cm-round ring tin. Combine the flour, muscovado sugar and butter in a bowl, then rub in with your fingers until crumbly and completely blended. Stir in the grated orange zest and ground ginger.

Scatter half the nuts and half the chopped stem ginger into the bottom of the ring tin. Break up the rest of the nuts into small pieces and stir into the crumb mix with the rest of the stem ginger. Measure out 100g/4oz of the crumb mix and spoon it into the tin over the nuts. Stir the bicarbonate of soda into the rest of the crumb mixture. Mix the soured cream and egg together, then stir it into the remaining crumb mixture. The mixture will be very soft. Pour this batter over the crumbs (it will come quite high in the tin).
Bake for 35-40 mins or until risen and a skewer inserted in the centre comes out clean. Let the cake sit for 10 mins, then take it out of the tin and leave to cool on a wire rack.
Cool the cake completely, then wrap it in foil and freeze for up to 2 months.
When ready to use, thaw for about 2 hrs at room temperature. Serve in slim slices with dollops of Cointreau cream, orange segments and a drizzle of syrup from the jar of stem ginger.
chief_review: This sticky dessert delivers a delightful balance of warmth from ground and stem ginger, richness from muscovado sugar and butter, and a fresh citrus lift from orange zest. The addition of pecans or walnuts provides a welcome crunch, complementing the moist texture. Layering with Cointreau cream and fresh orange segments pushes this treat into the realm of indulgence, perfectly suited to a celebratory table or an after-dinner delight. With no use of meat or gelatine, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, it does contain gluten, dairy, and eggs, and includes nuts, so it’s important for those with food allergies to take note. Serving with ginger syrup completes the dessert with a sticky, aromatic finish.

name: Clementine martini
description: Fun and easy to do as well as tasty and refreshing. Lovely way to use up clementines if you have succumbed to how pretty they look and bought a boxful. Beware though - quite strong on the alcohol content!
author: Sarah Cook
ingredients: 1 bottle prosecco, Cava or Champagne, well chilled
directions: Put some Martini glasses (or champagne flutes) into the freezer. Mix the clementine juice, vodka and Cointreau in a jug, then chill for 1 hr (or up to 1 day). Thinly slice the 2 clementines to use as a garnish.
To serve, put a clementine slice into each frosty glass. Fill almost halfway with the chilled jug mixture, then open the bottle of fizz and top up the glasses.
chief_review: This lively and refreshing cocktail makes excellent use of seasonal clementines. The bright citrus juice balances beautifully with vodka and Cointreau, while a good dose of sparkling wine lifts the whole blend, making it ideal for celebrations or brunch gatherings. The recipe is straightforward—just mix, chill, and serve over more clementine slices for an attractive finish. Note that this cocktail is entirely plant-based and contains no animal products or dairy, making it suitable for those following a vegan diet. However, always double-check that your prosecco or Champagne is certified vegan if required, as some wines can be processed with animal-derived fining agents. The fresh flavor, combined with strong alcohol notes, means it’s a treat best enjoyed in moderation. Perfect for citrus lovers seeking an elegant adult beverage.

name: Pork shoulder braised in black vinegar & rice wine with pickled chillies
description: Simple and a nice balance of flavours. I thought it would be more like a Filipino adobo but, because of the wine, it's a more mellow flavour. I'm not a big pork eater, but I'd make this again for my parents who would enjoy it.
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 1½ kg pork shoulder, cut into 4cm/1½ in pieces
1 long or 2 bird's-eye red chillies, sliced
directions: Put the pork in a bowl and add 1 tbsp each of the soy sauce and rice wine. Toss to combine, then cover and chill for 1 hr, or overnight if time permits.
To make the pickled chillies, put the chilli, shallot and rice vinegar in a small bowl with a big pinch of salt, and let stand for 1 hr or more.

Heat the vegetable oil in a heavy- based saucepan over a medium heat, add the garlic and ginger, and sauté for 2-3 mins or until golden. Add the pork and all the remaining ingredients, and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat to low, cover and simmer for 45 mins. Remove the lid from the pan to allow the liquid to reduce, and cook for a further 45 mins or until the meat falls apart.
Serve scattered with the sesame seeds and spring onions, with steamed rice and the pickled chillies on the side.
chief_review: This pork shoulder recipe is a delightful interplay of sweet, tangy, and savory notes, thanks to clever use of Shaohsing rice wine, black vinegar, and light brown sugar. The slow braise in vegetable stock ensures meltingly tender meat, balanced by the gentle heat of red chillies and brightness from spring onions and sesame seeds as garnish. The inclusion of oyster sauce and soy sauce underscores its deep umami character, while hints of ginger and garlic add aromatic warmth. This dish is well-suited for those following a dairy-free diet and can be enjoyed by most, except for those with shellfish allergies due to the oyster sauce or those requiring a gluten-free or vegetarian/vegan meal. The pairing with steamed rice rounds it out perfectly, making it a comforting centerpiece for a family meal.

name: Cheesy spinach parcels
description: An impressive starter to your meal
author: Good Food
ingredients: 25g walnuts or pine nut, roughly chopped
12 squares filo pastry, each measuring 16cm x 16cm
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Place spinach in a pan and stir over a high heat until wilted. Strain, squeeze out as much liquid as possible, then roughly chop.
Heat oil in a frying pan, sauté shallot until softened. Add walnuts, then fry for 2-3 mins. Remove from heat, stir in spinach, cheese, nutmeg, cream and seasoning.

Mix walnut oil with butter. Brush a thin coating on a piece of pastry. Place another piece on top with corners at a different angle, brush with the butter and repeat with one more piece. Place a spoonful of spinach mix in the centre, bring up corners of pastry and pinch in the middle to form a parcel. Repeat to make remaining parcels, then transfer to a greased baking tray. Brush parcels with remaining butter and oil. Bake for 20 mins until golden.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a sophisticated starter with a delightful interplay of textures and flavors—earthy spinach, buttery nuts, and tangy vegetarian cheddar, all wrapped in crisp filo pastry. The addition of nutmeg and cream brings a luxurious richness that elevates the dish. Suitable for lacto-vegetarian diets, the use of vegetarian cheddar ensures no animal rennet is present, and the recipe contains no meat or fish. However, note the presence of dairy and nuts, which are important considerations for those with allergies. Using filo pastry keeps the starter light and elegant, perfect for opening a special meal. The clear instructions and balanced ingredients make it approachable for home cooks aiming to impress their guests.

name: Rhubarb crumble trifle
description: Two mighty desserts merge in this seasonal pud made from baked rhubarb, mascarpone laced with almond liqueur and a covering of oat and almond crumble
author: James Martin
ingredients: 100g caster sugar, plus 2 tbsp for the whipped cream
pared zest and juice ½ orange
a few splashes grenadine(optional) - this is to endure that the rhubarb has a lovely pink colour
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Arrange the rhubarb pieces in a large roasting tin. Sprinkle over the sugar, orange zest and juice, grenadine and 150ml water. Cover with foil and bake for 25-30 mins until tender but not mushy. Scoop the rhubarb out of the tin into a sieve and reserve any juices, then leave to cool completely. Tip the rest of the liquid into a saucepan, along with the collected juices, and bring to the boil. Simmer for 15-20 mins or until reduced and syrupy. Leave to cool completely.

To make the crumble topping, rub the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles fine crumbs, then stir through the demerara sugar, almonds and oats. Tip onto a baking tray lined with parchment and bake for 15 mins, shaking the tray every so often, until golden brown, then cool.

Mix the Disaronno and orange juice together in a shallow dish. Dip each sponge into the liquid, leaving it for about 15 secs on each side, then arrange them in the base of a large trifle dish. Tip the mascarpone into a bowl and whisk until soft and smooth, then add the custard, a little at a time, and mix until combined. Arrange half the rhubarb pieces on top of the sponges, discarding the orange zest. Drizzle over 2 tbsp of the rhubarb syrup and top with half the custard mix. Follow with another layer of rhubarb, 1 tbsp of the syrup, and the remaining custard.

Whip the cream and 2 tbsp sugar to soft peaks and dollop over the custard. Drizzle over the remaining rhubarb syrup, along with a scattering of the crumble topping. Tip any extra crumble into a bowl and pass around the table.
chief_review:
This dessert creatively marries a classic trifle with a seasonal rhubarb crumble, producing a lush, layered treat. The baked rhubarb, sweetened and delicately flavoured with orange and a hint of grenadine, brings both tartness and vibrant colour. The addition of Disaronno infuses the mascarpone with a rich almond aroma, nicely complementing the crunchy oat and almond crumble topping. Creamy vanilla custard and whipped double cream in ample measure ensure a luxurious mouthfeel, while trifle sponges add airy soakability.

With no meat, fish, or gelatine, this dessert is a solid option for vegetarians. However, it does contain nuts (almonds), gluten (trifle sponges, flour, oats), and dairy (mascarpone, double cream, custard, butter), so it may not be suitable for those with food allergies or intolerances. The play on textures, flavours, and seasonal ingredients makes this an impressive, crowd-pleasing pudding.

name: Prawn cakes with cucumber peanut relish
description: Flavours were not bad. I found the cakes didn't hold together very well though and needed a little more lime zest and seasoning. I would add a little flour to bind if I was making again and probably fry them too to get them to hold together a bit better, although this may not work as well. Relish was a little hot. Mint went well with them but coriander you could leave out of the salad. Not a bad recipe but needs some tweaking.
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: ½ red chilli, deseeded and diced
1 tbsp light brown soft sugarmixed with 1 tsp water
directions: To make the relish, put the sugar and vinegar in a small saucepan with a pinch of salt. Bring to the boil and simmer for 5 mins until syrupy. Remove from the heat and cool completely. When cool, add the chilli flakes, cucumber, peanuts and shallot, and stir together. Set aside.

Put the ginger, coriander, shallots, chilli, lime zest and half the prawns in a food processor and blitz until fine. Add the remaining prawns and the fish sauce and pulse again, this time keeping the mixture chunky. Season well with black pepper, then form into 18 flat cakes.

Heat the grill to high. Brush both sides of the cakes with a tiny bit of vegetable oil and place on a baking sheet. Cook for 2 mins on one side, turn over and brush with the sugar water. Cook for another 2-3 mins or until opaque and slightly browned at the edges. Serve the cakes with the lettuce leaves, herbs and the cucumber relish.
chief_review: This prawn cake recipe offers vibrant Southeast Asian flavors with ginger, lime, and fish sauce bringing aromatic complexity. The cakes themselves are juicy, though the mixture's binding is an issue; adding a touch of flour or frying could strengthen their structure. The inclusion of lime zest deserves emphasis, as it brightens the overall taste—don't skimp! The relish provides a bold, spicy kick, nicely tempered by the cooling cucumber and fresh mint, though those sensitive to heat may want to reduce the amount of chilli flakes. The coriander is optional in the salad, and its omission won't detract from the end result. With prawns and fish sauce as core ingredients, this recipe is not suitable for vegetarians or vegans, but it is well-suited for pescatarian diets and is naturally gluten-free. With a few minor tweaks, this dish could become a lively addition to any seafood lover’s repertoire.

name: Apricot & hazelnut mince pies
description: No gluten, no wheat - just plenty of Christmassy flavour
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 tsp each ground cinnamon, grated nutmeg and mixed spice
grated zest and juice of 1 orange
directions: To make the pastry: put the flour and cinnamon into the bowl of a food processor. Add the butter and pulse until it looks like very fine breadcrumbs. Sprinkle in the sugar and 3 tbsp cold water, and pulse until the mixture starts to clump together, about 30 secs. Tip the mixture onto a board and gently squeeze the pastry until it comes together into a ball – add water if it feels dry. Wrap the pastry in cling film and chill for 30 mins.

Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Roll the pastry on a lightly floured surface to the thickness of £1 coin. Using a 7cm cutter, cut out 10-12 discs and use to line a 12-hole bun tin with them. Use a 6cm cutter for the lids, or use a 6cm star cutter to make star shapes. Chill both.

Make the mincemeat: put all the ingredients into a food processor and pulse on and off until evenly chopped. Spoon 1-2 tsp into each tart, dampen the edge of the pastry bottom with water and sit a smaller pastry disc or star on top. Using scissors, snip a hole in the lid, if you’ve made round tops. Bake for 12-15 mins until golden brown. Lift onto a wire rack to cool and dredge with icing sugar.
chief_review: This festive treat delivers classic Christmas flavours with a thoughtfully gluten-free twist, making it ideal for those following a gluten-free diet. The combination of semi-dried apricots and figs offers natural sweetness and a chewy texture, while toasted hazelnuts add depth and crunch. Warming spices—cinnamon, nutmeg, and mixed spice—create an aromatic backdrop, enhanced by the bright citrus of fresh orange zest and juice. Butter and banana contribute moisture and richness, preventing dryness often found in gluten-free baking. A splash of brandy infuses the bake with a subtle, grown-up warmth, perfectly balancing the spice and fruit. Finished with a dusting of icing sugar, these bakes capture the essence of the season without sacrificing texture or flavour, proving that gluten-free can be genuinely crave-worthy. A perfect holiday indulgence for anyone avoiding wheat or gluten.

name: Pot-roasted vegetables
description: Slow-cooked, pot-roasted vegetables develop a sweet flavour and soft texture, lovely with braised beef
author: Raymond Blanc
ingredients: ½ small celeriac, cut into 2cm dice
150g baby turnip, halved, or 1-2 small turnips, cut into small wedges
150g butternut squash, deseeded and cut into 2cm dice
2 parsnips, quartered, cores removed, cut into 2cm dice
directions: Heat oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Melt the butter in a large heavy-based frying pan. Add all the vegetables (or do this in 2 batches if necessary rather than overcrowd the pan) and a little sea salt and freshly ground black pepper, then sweat them on a medium heat for 5 mins.
Transfer the veg to a large roasting tin, pour in 150ml water, cover with foil, then roast for about 2 hrs or until meltingly tender but still holding their shape. Taste and correct the seasoning.
chief_review: This slow-cooked, pot-roasted vegetable medley shines with an impressive depth of sweet, earthy flavor, achieved through gentle caramelization and skillful layering. The use of celeriac, squash, turnip, carrots, and parsnips creates a beautiful balance of textures and natural sugars, resulting in perfectly tender vegetables that pair wonderfully with rich braised beef or roast meats. The unsalted butter elevates each element, imparting a silky mouthfeel without overwhelming the individual characteristics of each vegetable. This recipe is ideal for vegetarians, and easily adaptable for a gluten-free diet as it contains only vegetables and butter. With minimal effort, you achieve maximum depth—a testament to the transformative power of slow cooking. Serve as a sophisticated side for autumn and winter dishes, or enjoy as a hearty standalone main when paired with grains or a simple salad.

name: Venetian-style scallops
description: A quick but impressive starter of plump scallops scattered with toasted breadcrumbs
author: Carmelita Caruana
ingredients: 12 large fresh scallops, separated from their shells (ask your fishmonger to do this for you)
4 concave scallops shells, as serving dishes
large handful fresh finely chopped flatleaf parsley
juice of a lemon, plus wedges to serve
directions: Rinse the scallops in cold water then pat dry with kitchen paper. With scissors, snip off the corals (the orange part) as closely as you can to the plump white scallop, and reserve. Scrub the scallop shells thoroughly and dry them.

Remove the crusts from the bread and discard. Break the bread into smallish pieces, then pulse in the food processor to make into fine breadcrumbs. Tip into a large non-stick frying pan and toast the breadcrumbs over a moderate heat, stirring every now and then. When they are evenly browned, set aside.

Brush any crumbs from the pan with kitchen paper then add the olive oil. When hot, add the scallops but not the corals. Fry over a moderate heat for 3 minutes on each side, then add the corals, chopped parsley and garlic and fry a further minute. If you have shelled your own scallops and saved some of their sweet juice, strain it through muslin to remove any sand then add it to the pan now and let it bubble over a high heat. Season to taste with salt and pepper, add the lemon juice and mix well.
Spoon three scallops and their corals with some of the pan juices onto each of the cleaned shells, then scatter with the dry toasted breadcrumbs. Serve with the lemon wedges.
chief_review: This elegant starter showcases the natural sweetness of fresh scallops, beautifully complemented by a crisp topping of toasted white breadcrumbs, garlic, and parsley. The use of extra-virgin olive oil gives a smooth richness, while the lemon juice provides a vibrant, zesty lift that cuts through the dish’s savoriness. The presentation in scallop shells is visually striking, perfect for impressing dinner guests. This recipe is suitable for pescatarians and can be made dairy-free as there are no animal dairy products involved. However, it contains gluten due to the use of white bread, which should be noted for gluten-free diets. Quick to assemble yet refined in flavor, this dish would make a delightful introduction to a special meal.

name: Snowflake biscuits
description: Does anyone know how long these would last for if made as a gift?
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: silver balls and white sprinkles, to decorate
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line a baking sheet with baking parchment. Put the butter in a bowl and beat it with electric beaters until soft and creamy. Beat in the sugar, then the egg and vanilla, and finally the flour to make a dough. If the dough feels sticky, add a little flour and knead it in. Chill for 20 mins in the fridge.
Roll the dough to about the thickness of a £1 coin on a lightly floured surface. Cut out snowflake shapes using a biscuit cutter, then re-roll the off-cuts and repeat.
Bake for 8-10 mins or until the edges are just beginning to brown. Leave to cool for 5 mins before trying to move them. Cool completely.

Roll out the fondant icing to the thickness of a 50p piece. Use the same cutter to stamp out the icing. If you have smaller cutter you can stamp out holes in the middles of some of them. Brush each biscuit with a tiny amount of honey and press an icing snowflake on top.

Mix the icing sugar with enough water to make a pipeable icing, and spoon it into a piping bag fitted with a straight piping nozzle. Pipe patterns onto the snowflakes and add silver balls and sprinkles as you decorate. Leave to dry completely.
chief_review: This festive snowflake cookie recipe yields beautifully decorated biscuits with a classic, buttery crumb and delicate vanilla aroma. The use of ready-to-roll fondant and royal icing allows for creative decoration, making them ideal as edible gifts. The ingredients list shows the recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal-based gelatin. However, it does include common allergens such as eggs, wheat (gluten), and dairy, so keep this in mind for recipients with dietary restrictions. Stored in an airtight container, these cookies should remain fresh for up to a week. The sugar and fondant ensure a sweet finish and a crisp texture, perfect for the holidays.

name: Bubble & squeak croquettes
description: John Torode's fried potato rostis are packed with turnip, cabbage and crispy streaky bacon
author: John Torode
ingredients: 8 rashers back or streaky bacon, chopped
½ large cabbage, or a few handfuls sprouts, shredded
500g leftover roast or boiled potato, mashed
200g leftover roast turnip, parsnips, carrots (or any veg really), roughly chopped, then mashed
200g plain flour, well seasoned, plus a little extra for shaping
2 eggs, beaten with a pinch of salt and a little water
sunflower or vegetable oil, for frying
directions: Melt the butter in a pan, then fry the onions and bacon together for 10 mins until the onions are soft and bacon has started to colour. Add the cabbage or sprouts to the pan with a good grinding of black pepper. Stir well, then add a splash of water and cook, covered, for 5 mins more until tender.

Tip the potatoes and cooked veg into the pan, then mash really well. Mix in the eggs, then season to taste. Turn onto a floured surface, flatten out, then cut into squares about the size of a scone. Roll each piece into a cigar shape about 10cm long and the width of a £2 coin. Cool.
Roll each croquette in the flour, then in the egg and finally in the breadcrumbs. Put onto a tray and chill for at least 1 hr.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Heat a 5mm depth of oil in a large frying pan; then, once a crumb turns golden within a few secs, shallow-fry the croquettes in 2 batches for 2 mins each side, turning carefully. Drain on kitchen paper and transfer to a baking sheet lined with baking paper. Bake for 15 mins or, if making ahead, cover and chill for up to 2 days. To reheat, give them 15 mins in the oven at 190C/fan 170C/gas 5 until hot through and crisp on the outside.
chief_review: John Torode's fried potato rostis offer a delightful fusion of textures and flavors, combining creamy mashed potatoes and turnip with the caramelized sweetness of onion and the savory punch of crispy bacon. The inclusion of cabbage (or sprouts) adds freshness and a subtle bite, rounding out the dish. The rostis are coated in flour and breadcrumbs, which ensures a satisfying crunch upon frying. This recipe is especially suited for those looking to use up leftover roasted vegetables, making it as practical as it is delicious. The dish isn’t suitable for gluten-free or vegetarian diets, but it stands out as a hearty and crowd-pleasing option for a brunch or comforting meal. Serve hot, preferably with a tangy sauce or through your preferred seasonal accompaniments.

name: Smoked mackerel loaded leaves
description: The smoked mackerel paste for these healthy canapes will keep in the fridge for a week - use it on jacket potatoes or toast
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
ingredients: 200g smoked mackerelfillets, skin removed and flaked
directions: Gently mix the mackerel flakes with the crème fraîche, lemon juice, half the herbs and some pepper (but no salt – smoked mackerel is salty enough). Chill until ready to serve.
Spoon a generous amount of the mixture into each leaf, then arrange on plates. Sprinkle each ‘scoop’ with the remaining fresh herbs and a pinch of the lemon zest, then serve.
chief_review: This smoked mackerel paste canape recipe is a flavorful and versatile appetizer, ideal for entertaining or a light snack throughout the week. The combination of rich, smoky mackerel with creamy crème fraîche, bright lemon zest, and fresh herbs creates a well-balanced spread that pairs beautifully with crisp radicchio and chicory leaves. The absence of bread or crackers makes this dish naturally gluten-free, while the simple ingredient list avoids common allergens like nuts and eggs. It’s a nutritious choice, rich in omega-3 fatty acids, and the use of leafy greens keeps it low-carb. Perfect for pescatarians and those seeking lighter, yet flavorful bites, this recipe stands out for its freshness and convenience, easily stored and repurposed to top potatoes or toast.

name: Tropical punch cups
description: A refreshing fruit salad to hand out to guests at the end of a party
author: Laura and Jess Tilli
ingredients: ½ fresh pineapple, cut into chunks
2 mangoes, peeled and cut into chunks
directions: Mix together all the fruit in a large bowl with the guava juice, then chill until ready to serve. At the last minute, pour over the ginger beer and serve with small cups or bowls on the side for spooning the drinks and fruit into.
chief_review: This fruit salad is a vibrant and invigorating end-of-party treat, showcasing the fresh sweetness of pineapple, mango, and starfruit. The addition of guava juice lends a fragrant tropical flair, while a splash of ginger beer provides an unexpected, spicy effervescence that elevates the entire dish. This recipe is a great choice for vegan and vegetarian diets, and is also naturally gluten-free and dairy-free, catering to a range of common dietary preferences. It’s light, hydrating, and simple to assemble, making it both crowd-pleasing and practical for entertaining. The use of only fresh fruit and juices ensures a crisp, clean finish, and the unique appearance of starfruit slices adds visual appeal. Serve chilled for optimal refreshment.

name: Lamb en croûte with redcurrant sauce
description: Teaming lamb with sage instead of mint is a clever idea for a festive feast - and you can freeze this dish for up to a month
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 lamb neck fillets, each weighing about 140-175g/5-6oz, trimmed
1 egg yolk, whisked with a fork
leaves of 6 fresh sage sprigs, chopped
1 egg yolk, whisked with a fork
directions: Season the lamb well. Heat the oil in a frying pan and fry three fillets over a high heat for 5 minutes until seared on the outside. Remove from the pan and repeat with the other 3 fillets. Set aside until cold.
Unravel the whole pack of pastry on a floured surface and cut into four rectangles. Cut the half pack to make two rectangles. Roll out each piece to make the rectangles 2.5cm larger all round.

Position one rectangle with a short side facing you, brush with egg yolk and sprinkle with a sixth of the chopped sage. Put a lamb fillet on the pastry close to the end facing you, then fold the long sides in to cover the ends of the meat; brush these with more egg yolk.
Freeze the lamb parcels on a tray until solid for 4 hours, then pack in a freezer container. Seal, label and freeze for up to a month.

To make the sauce, melt the redcurrant jelly in a pan over a gentle heat, add the port and rosemary and boil uncovered for 10-12 minutes until syrupy. Cool for 5 minutes, strain into a freezer container, then leave until completely cold. Seal, label and freeze for up to a month.
defrost the lamb seam-side down on a wire rack for 3 hours at room temperature. Defrost the sauce at room temperature.

Preheat the oven to fan 200C/ conventional 220C/gas 7. Put the parcels seam-side down on a nonstick baking sheet, brush with egg yolk, then snip four incisions in the top of each. Bake for 25 minutes until golden. Remove from the oven and rest them for 5-10 minutes. Reheat the sauce in a pan.
Slice each parcel and serve with the sauce and watercress salad.
chief_review: This inventive lamb and sage pastry dish stands out for its aromatic herbal twist, pairing fresh sage and rosemary with succulent lamb neck fillets—a delightful divergence from the classic mint. The redcurrant jelly and port reduction brings a luxurious, festive character that balances the savoury richness of the lamb, while the ready-rolled puff pastry creates a golden, flaky crust. The egg yolk glaze ensures a glossy, inviting finish. This recipe is ideal for anyone looking to elevate their holiday table with a dish that’s both comforting and refined. Additionally, the absence of dairy and nuts makes it a suitable option for those managing such allergies (always double-check your pastry ingredients); however, note that it is not gluten free nor vegetarian/vegan. Being freezer-friendly up to a month is another practical bonus, allowing you to prepare ahead for a stress-free celebration.

name: Redcurrant sorbet
description: Try this refreshing redcurrant sorbet for an alternative low fat dessert
author: Lesley Waters
directions: Remove redcurrants from stems, wash and put in a pan with 2 tbsp water. Bring to the boil, lower the heat, cover and simmer for 5 mins until softened. Push through a sieve to make a purée. Stir in the elderflower cordial and set to one side to cool.
Put the caster sugar in a pan with 300ml/½pt water and leave over a low heat for 5 mins until the sugar dissolves. Raise heat and boil for 10 mins.

Tip redcurrant mixture into syrup and mix. Return to the boil, turn down and simmer for 2 mins. Cool, pour into a container and freeze for 3-4 hrs until frozen. Scoop into glasses and top with redcurrants.
chief_review: This redcurrant sorbet recipe is a delightfully refreshing option, perfect for those seeking a light, low-fat dessert. The sharp tartness of the redcurrants is beautifully balanced by the subtle floral notes from the elderflower cordial and sweetness of golden caster sugar. Since it’s made entirely from fruit, sugar, and cordial, this sorbet is suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Additionally, as it contains no gluten or dairy, it can be enjoyed by those with gluten or lactose intolerances. Garnish with extra redcurrants for a vibrant touch and added texture—ideal for summer entertaining or as a palate-cleansing finish to a meal.

name: Nutty apricot & cinnamon pudding
description: A sticky, spicy and moreish pudding - brilliant way to round off a winter meal
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 medjool dates, stoned and roughly chopped (see try below)
directions: Put the dates in a small pan with the apricots, spice and honey, then pour over the orange juice. Bring to the boil and cook for 5 mins, until the dates have broken down and you have a thick, syrupy sauce. Stir in the nuts.

Cut the cake in half lengthways, on the horizontal. Use a 150ml ramekin to cut out 4 circles from the cake. Divide the date mix between the 4 ramekins, then top with the circles of cake, pressing them down gently. Cover with cling film and microwave on high for 3 mins, then turn out onto a plate and serve with cream or ice cream.
chief_review: This sticky, spicy pudding offers a delightful interplay of textures and flavors, marrying the caramel richness of medjool dates and apricots with the warm depth of ground spices. The honey and orange juice lend a fragrant sweetness and bright acidity, beautifully soaking into the soft slices of madeira cake. Chopped mixed nuts crown the dessert with a satisfying crunch, balancing its overall softness. While decadently comforting for winter, this pudding is naturally suitable for a vegetarian diet. However, those with nut allergies should note the inclusion of mixed nuts. As a chef, I appreciate how quickly this dessert comes together, making it an excellent choice for effortless entertaining—delivering both comfort and flair to the winter table.

name: Crunchy cauliflower cheese
description: This makes a hearty and satisfying side dish, perfect served with Sunday lunch
author: Good Food
ingredients: 100g Swiss cheese such as gruyère or emmental, grated
directions: Heat the grill to high. Fill a large saucepan with water and bring to the boil. Meanwhile, break the cauliflower into even-sized florets. Drop into the pan and boil for about 7 mins, or until very tender.
Heat the cheese sauce either in the microwave on High for 1 min or in a small pan until heated through, but not boiling. Place the cheese, hazelnuts and breadcrumbs in a bowl and mix together.

Drain the cauliflower and place in the bottom of a large, shallow, baking dish. Pour the warmed sauce over the cauliflower, covering it evenly, then sprinkle with the breadcrumbs. Put under the grill for 5 mins, or until the cheese is bubbling and the breadcrumbs are golden and crusty.
chief_review: This cauliflower bake is a classic, comforting side that brings together creamy cheese sauce and nutty Swiss cheeses for a rich, savory flavor. The golden breadcrumb and hazelnut topping adds a delightful crunch and depth, contrasting beautifully with the tender cauliflower beneath. The recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it relies solely on dairy for richness and uses no meat or fish products. Those seeking extra texture and flavor will appreciate the toasted hazelnuts. Serve alongside a Sunday roast or with a vegetarian main for a crowd-pleasing addition.

name: Pomegranate ice
description: 2 comments: 1) Wear some old clothes for the juicing. Fortunately I did coz my 'cooking' yellow vest now looks like a tie-dye thing from the 70s! 2) I think it would be useful to give an indication of qty of sugar syrup to juice yield. One man's pomegranate could be another man's watermelon! I got 400ml of juice so used an equal qty of sugar syrup. The result is delicious and will be perfect as part of a trio of sorbets on Christmas Day - the colour as well as the flavour.
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Tip the sugar into a bowl and pour over 600ml of boiling water from a kettle. Stir to dissolve, then set aside to cool.

Meanwhile, juice the pomegranates. Squeeze and press the skin of seven of the pomegranates vigorously to crush the seeds inside. Hold the squashed fruit over a bowl, slit the skin with a knife and the juice will pour out. Mix the juice with the syrup and churn in an ice-cream machine until set, then scoop into a plastic container and freeze. Serve the sorbet in scoops, scattered with a few seeds from the remaining fruit.
chief_review: This pomegranate sorbet recipe is a vibrant celebration of fresh, tart flavors and striking ruby hues—perfect for a festive table centerpiece. By combining the fresh juice of eight pomegranates with caster sugar to create a simple syrup, you achieve a silky-smooth texture and a balanced sweetness that highlights the fruit’s natural tang. The method is wonderfully straightforward, though juicing pomegranates can be messy—protective clothing is certainly warranted! With just two plant-based ingredients, this recipe is entirely vegan and vegetarian friendly. As there are no gluten-containing or dairy ingredients, it’s also suitable for both gluten-free and lactose-intolerant diets. The flexibility to adjust the sugar syrup to juice yield ensures the result isn’t overly sweet or tart. Serve as a refreshing palate cleanser or as part of a medley of sorbets—its jewel-like color and intense flavor promise to delight.

name: Tomatoes stuffed with fruity dhal
description: Make beef tomatoes extra fruity with this delicious stuffed recipe
author: Good Food
directions: Put the split peas in a pan with 600ml/1pt cold water. Bring to the boil and skim the surface to remove any scum. Reduce the heat and simmer for 20 mins. Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5.

Meanwhile, heat 2 tbsp of the oil in a pan and cook the onion and garlic for 4 mins until softened. Stir in the spices, then cook for a further minute. Stir this mixture and the raisins into the split peas, then cook for a further 10 mins until soft and creamy. Stir in the chickpeas, chutney and coriander and heat through. Season to taste.

Slice the tops off the beef tomatoes and reserve. Scrape out the insides and discard. Spoon the dhal mixture into the tomatoes and replace the tops. Place on a baking sheet and brush with the remaining oil. Cook for 20 mins until the tomatoes have softened.
chief_review: This vibrant stuffed beef tomato recipe is a delightful fusion of bold flavors and nourishing ingredients. The combination of yellow split peas, chickpeas, and raisins creates a satisfyingly hearty and mildly sweet filling, balanced by the gentle warmth of cayenne and turmeric. Mango chutney adds a tangy-fruity accent that lifts the dish, while fresh coriander brings a burst of freshness. With protein-rich legumes at its core, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians and offers a great gluten-free option, provided the mango chutney is confirmed gluten-free. The use of sunflower oil keeps the dish light, and the absence of dairy and eggs makes it a solid choice for those with lactose intolerance or egg allergies. Perfect as a centerpiece for a vegetarian meal or as a vibrant side, these stuffed tomatoes offer both robust taste and nutritional value.

name: Duck & beetroot toasts
description: A quick and simple chutney that's a great toast topper with pâté or cheese
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 1 small red onion, chopped, plus extra to serve
directions: Put the all the ingredients, except the pâté and baguette, into a food processor and work into a rough purée.

Slice a baguette thinly and brush slices on each side with olive oil. Arrange in one layer over a baking sheet and bake at 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 for 8-10 mins until the bread is crisp and golden. Leave to cool (this can be done the day before serving).
To serve, spread a little duck pâté onto each toast and top with a spoonful of beetroot relish. For a veggie option, substitute the pâté with goat’s cheese.
chief_review: This beetroot chutney recipe is a vibrant, tangy spread that pairs beautifully with both creamy goat’s cheese and rich duck pâté. The earthiness of the beetroot is lifted by the zesty orange and balanced with a touch of red wine vinegar, bringing freshness and depth to every bite. The quick preparation makes it a practical addition to your appetizer repertoire; simply spoon over toasted baguette and garnish with extra red onion for a burst of crunch and color. This chutney is a great fit for vegetarian diets when paired with goat’s cheese, and the core preparation itself contains no gluten, making it suitable for gluten-free diets if served on gluten-free bread. For a lighter snack or an impressive starter, this recipe is wonderfully adaptable, offering layers of flavor with minimal effort.

name: Really easy cheese fondue
author: Emma Freud
ingredients: small baguette, torn into chunks, to serve
directions: Heat the wine in a heavy-based saucepan, then add the cheese, a handful at a time, and keep stirring. When all the cheese has melted, add the kirsch, followed by the cornflour, stirring until completely smooth.
Serve the pan in the middle of the table on a wooden board with the chunks of baguette for dipping.
chief_review:
This cheese fondue recipe is a classic celebration of rich, melting cheeses enhanced by a splash of white wine and the subtle warmth of kirsch. The mix of Gruyère and cheddar delivers a deep, savory flavor with a delectably creamy texture, perfect for a cozy gathering. The cornflour ensures a silky smooth consistency, while torn baguette pieces serve as the ideal vehicle for scooping up the molten cheese. 

Vegetarians can enjoy this dish, provided the cheeses are confirmed to use microbial or vegetarian rennet. However, those with lactose intolerance or dairy allergies should avoid this recipe due to its high cheese content, and individuals with gluten sensitivity will need to substitute the baguette for a gluten-free option. Overall, this fondue is wonderfully simple yet indulgent—a timeless treat for communal dining.

name: Elderflower & raspberry spritzer
description: A fabulously boozy jelly pud - the perfect dinner party dessert
author: Good Food
directions: Soak gelatine leaves in cold water. Dissolve the gelatine in a measuring jug in the hot water from the kettle. Add the elderflower cordial and top up with sparkling white wine to make 450ml of liquid in total. Drop a few raspberries into six tall glasses and fill to about a third with the elderflower syrup. Leave to set completely, then add a few more raspberries and some more elderflower syrup. Repeat again until the glasses are nearly full to the top.
chief_review: This boozy jelly dessert is an elegant finale, ideal for impressing at a dinner party. The fragrant elderflower cordial pairs beautifully with fresh raspberries and sparkling white wine, while the delicate gelatine sets everything to a perfect wobble. Fruitiness and fizz combine for a refreshing palate cleanser that’s both sophisticated and light. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians if you substitute gelatine leaves with a vegetarian alternative such as agar-agar. It’s also gluten-free, provided that the sparkling wine is certified gluten-free. The preparation is straightforward, yet the result is striking—a clear jelly studded with jewel-like raspberries. Serve chilled in pretty glasses for maximum visual and flavor impact.

name: Elegant berry wreath cake
description: Simple, smart, but still reassuringly traditional
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 tbsp apricot jam, warmed and sieved
several eucalyptus sprigs (smaller-leaf varieties look best)
plenty of fresh bay leaves, in sprigs if possible
directions: MAKE A RING-SHAPED CAKE: Prepare Hot toddy fruitcake mix (recipe opposite), then grease and double-line a 23cm round, deep cake tin. Peel off the label from an empty 400g can and wash well. Butter the outside of the can and wrap in non-stick baking paper. Fill the can one-third full with baking beans, rice or dried pulses (to weigh it down), then position in the middle of the tin. Spoon the cake mix around the ‘ring’, then smooth the top. Bake at 160C/fan 140C/gas 3 for 1½ hrs, then turn down to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1 and bake for another hour or until a skewer comes out clean.

While the cake is still warm, use the skewer to pepper the cake with holes, poking it all the way down. Dissolve the sugar in the tea, add the whisky or orange juice, then spoon over the surface. If you’re making the cake ahead of time, feed it with a fresh swig of hot toddy every week, but take care not to make the cake soggy. Can be kept for a month well-wrapped in an airtight container in a cool, dry place. If short on time, the cake can be made the same day that you decorate it.

To decorate, lightly beat the egg white, then put the caster sugar on a flat plate or tray. Dip the tips of the leaves into the egg white, shake off any excess, then dip into the sugar to coat. Leave to dry while you cover the cake with marzipan. If your cranberries are frozen, leave them on a few sheets of kitchen towel at this stage to thaw and dry out, or the juice will run into the icing.

Roll the marzipan to a 23cm circle, shaping it into a round with your hands. Alternatively, roll the marzipan a little larger than you need, then cut a round using the cake tin’s base as a guide. Turn the marzipan over. Brush the top of the cake with jam, then put it, jam side down, on the marzipan.

Make the hole in the middle. Using the can, push through the hole in the centre of the cake and punch out excess marzipan – this is the easiest way to make sure the hole in the covering matches hole in the cake. Turn cake right way up and sit on a cake plate.

Sieve the icing sugar, then beat with the egg white until thick and smooth. Spread over the marzipan with a palette knife, then decorate the top with cranberries, bay leaves and the frosted eucalyptus sprigs. Leave to set overnight before cutting. Can be decorated up to a day ahead. Keep cake wrapped in foil up to the icing.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a classic charm with inventive use of fresh herbs and fruit, bringing a festive look and delicate flavor balance. The marzipan provides a dense, almond-rich base, complemented by a glossy layer of apricot jam for sweetness and tartness. The use of cranberries livens up the palate, while eucalyptus and bay leaves impart subtle aromatic notes—though largely decorative, their infusion elevates presentation. The double use of egg whites in the icing ensures a smooth finish, highlighting skilled traditional technique. This recipe is appropriate for vegetarian diets, as it contains no meat or animal rennet, but isn't suitable for those with nut or egg allergies. Overall, it’s a clever twist on tradition, maintaining familiar comfort while surprising with fresh, herbaceous details.

name: Yogurt & ginger creams with blowtorched satsuma
description: These set puddings are Tom Kerridge's version of panna cotta, and are sure to impress as a celebration dinner party dessert
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 4 satsumasor clementines, peeled, left whole but pith removed
directions: In a large bowl, beat together the yogurt and mascarpone with an electric or hand whisk for 2 mins until smooth. Soak the gelatine leaves in a bowl of cold water for 5 mins until softened. Meanwhile, warm the sugar, ginger wine and cream in a small saucepan on a medium heat, stirring until the sugar has completely dissolved. Drain and squeeze the excess water out of the gelatine and add it to the warm cream, stirring to dissolve. Fold the cream into the yogurt mix, then stir in the ginger. Pour the mixture into 4 dariole moulds or individual pudding basins, cover with cling film and put in the fridge for at least 4 hrs, or overnight, until set. Can be made up to 3 days ahead.

For the satsumas, combine 125ml water, the sugar and star anise in a pan and bring to the boil. Put the satsumas in the syrup and turn off the heat. Cover the pan with cling film and leave to cool for 15 mins. Turn the satsumas over, cover with cling film again, then leave to go completely cold. Can be done the day before.

To serve, turn out the set creams by placing each mould in hot water for 10 secs, release the sides gently and tip the creams onto your serving dishes. Remove the satsumas from the syrup and break into segments. On a baking tray, blowtorch all around the edges until charred. Serve the satsumas with the yogurt creams drizzled with a little syrup. Add a sprinkling of mint and put a couple of ginger biscuits on the side.
chief_review:
Tom Kerridge’s take on panna cotta is a luxurious treat, ideal for an elegant dinner party finale. The combination of natural yogurt, mascarpone, and double cream yields a delightfully rich and creamy base, while the ginger wine and stem ginger introduce subtle spice and warmth. The citrus from satsumas or clementines balances the richness with refreshing acidity, complemented further by fragrant star anise and mint. Served with crisp ginger biscuits, this dessert offers a harmonious play of textures and flavors. 

The inclusion of gelatine means this dessert is not suitable for vegetarians, but it fits well for those without specific dietary restrictions. The recipe celebrates classic techniques with inventive, modern flavors—a guaranteed showstopper for any celebratory gathering.

name: Porridge with beetroot, apple & cranberry compote & toasted hazelnuts
description: This is a glorious compote with a beautiful colour that made our porridge on New Year's Day very special. I will be making this again. Yum!
author: Alex Hely-Hutchinson
ingredients: 100g rolled oat, soaked overnight in 250ml/9fl oz water (for best texture, use an equal combination of porridge oats and jumbo oats)
250g almond milk, coconut milk or full-fat milk
1 eating apple, core removed and diced
cardamom pods(seeds only, pounded using a pestle and mortar)
directions: Put all the compote ingredients in a saucepan over a medium heat and bring to the boil, then lower to a simmer for 30 mins, adding a little water, 1 tbsp at a time, if needed.
Once the compote is cooked, put the soaked oats, milk, vanilla and a good pinch of flaked sea salt in a saucepan, and warm over a medium heat for 3-4 mins.
Divide the porridge between two bowls, add a heaped tbsp of compote, the yogurt and a scattering of crushed hazelnuts, to serve.
chief_review: This vibrant compote and oat porridge is a breakfast treat that dazzles both visually and in flavor. The use of cranberries and beetroot gives a natural, earthy sweetness and stunning color, complemented by the warm notes of cinnamon, vanilla, and cardamom. Maple syrup and orange juice add a refreshing brightness, and the diced apple provides fresh texture. With the option of almond or coconut milk and coconut yogurt, this recipe is easily adaptable for vegans and those avoiding dairy. Additionally, the ingredients are naturally gluten-free (if gluten-free oats are used), making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities. Topped with crunchy toasted hazelnuts, this nourishing bowl offers a symphony of textures, ideal for a festive morning or any cozy breakfast gathering. Highly recommended for plant-based and gluten-free diets.

name: Mini crostini with goat’s cheese & artichokes
description: Bite-sized pieces of crispy toast topped with cheese, artichokes and pesto make attractive canapés for a party or buffet spread
author: Jennifer Joyce
ingredients: 4 slices of white or sourdough bread
a small log (125g) of goat's cheese(you won't use it all)
8 grilled artichoke hearts, from a jar
directions: Cut the crusts off the bread. Cut diagonally in half, then cut each piece into 2 triangles. Press them into a mini muffin tin and brush with a little oil. Bake at 200C/180C fan/gas 6 for 7 mins or until golden. Leave to cool completely. Top each one with a piece of goat’s cheese, half an artichoke heart and 1 tsp pesto. Scatter over some rocket and serve.
chief_review: This canapé recipe brilliantly balances textures and flavors, ideal for party spreads. The crispy toast provides a sturdy base for the creamy tang of goat's cheese and the earthy, slightly smoky bite of artichoke hearts. Pesto adds a fresh, herbal brightness while the rocket leaves lend a peppery finish. The dish visually impresses with vibrant greens atop golden toast. Suitable for lacto-vegetarians, it eliminates meat entirely and spotlights high-quality dairy and vegetables. For best results, use a rustic sourdough for enhanced crunch and flavor, and opt for a vegetarian pesto (one without Parmesan containing animal rennet, for strict vegetarians). These canapés are a satisfying, sophisticated finger food—easy to assemble and sure to please a crowd seeking a fresh, savory bite.

name: Chicory salad with blue cheese dressing
description: This was very tasty but I think that I would use a little less vinegar next time.
author: John Torode
ingredients: 4 heads of chicory(it's nice to have a mix of 2 red and 2 white)
directions: Slice the base off each chicory and peel off the leaves until you reach the core, which you can either cut into quarters or leave whole. Arrange the leaves on a platter.

Drizzle the chicory with a little olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Crumble half the blue cheese over the chicory, then mix the remaining cheese with the vinegar, squashing with a fork to make it creamy. Add the cream, lemon juice and crème fraîche, then whisk together. Adjust the seasoning, spoon over the salad and serve.
chief_review: This chicory and blue cheese salad is a delightful combination of bold flavors and creamy textures. The bitterness of the chicory is beautifully balanced by the rich, tangy blue cheese and the smoothness of crème fraîche and double cream. A hint of acidity from the white wine vinegar and lemon juice brightens the dish, though adjusting the vinegar to personal taste is a wise note. The use of olive oil adds a pleasant, peppery undertone. Vegetarian-friendly, this recipe is ideal for those seeking a robust, satisfying salad that steers clear of meat. The choice of red and white chicory not only elevates the visual appeal but also adds depth to every bite. A great addition to any vegetarian table or as a standalone starter.

name: Mini Bakewells
description: Spoon this Bakewell tart filling into uncooked, mini tartlet cases for a great alternative to mince pies, or for an afternoon tea treat
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Divide the raspberry jam between 12 uncooked tartlet cases. Beat the softened butter with the golden caster sugar, then gradually beat in the eggs followed by the ground almonds and flour. Sprinkle with a few flaked almonds and bake for 15-20 mins.
chief_review: This Bakewell tart filling delivers a delightful blend of sweet raspberry and rich almond flavors—perfect to elevate any afternoon tea or holiday gathering. The frangipane mixture, enriched with ground almonds and a hint of flaked almonds on top, bakes up tender and aromatic with a pleasing texture contrast from the nuts. The use of raspberry jam provides a bright, tangy layer, complementing the buttery almond base beautifully. With ground almonds as a star ingredient and minimal flour, this recipe suits those looking for wheat-light options, though it's not suitable for a gluten-free diet due to the presence of flour. It fits wonderfully into a vegetarian regimen, as it relies solely on eggs for structure. The preparation is simple yet yields a sophisticated, quintessentially British treat perfect for festivities or a refined snack.

name: Crispy cubed roasties with garlic & thyme
description: Cut your potatoes smaller so that there's no need to par-boil to achieve perfectly crispy garlic and thyme flavoured spuds, with fluffy centres
author: Jenny White
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Peel the potatoes and cut them into cubes. Put the garlic, thyme and oil in a large roasting tin, and put it in the oven for 5 mins.

Tip the potatoes into the roasting tin, quickly turn them to coat in the oil, then spread them out in a single layer. Season well and roast for 1–11/2 hrs, turning occasionally during cooking, until golden and crispy.
chief_review: A beautifully simple approach to classic roasted potatoes, this recipe leverages small cuts and an aromatic blend of garlic and fresh thyme to deliver an irresistibly crisp finish and fluffy interiors. The choice of Maris Piper or baking potatoes ensures a delightful texture, while using olive oil introduces a subtle, savoury richness. Notably, the recipe is naturally vegan and gluten-free, making it an inclusive and versatile option for most guests. Fresh thyme offers a fragrant complexity, and the omission of dairy or animal fat means the dish remains light yet satisfyingly robust in flavour. A true staple for any well-rounded table, these potatoes pair effortlessly with a variety of mains, earning a well-deserved place in both casual and elevated meals.

name: Mint-chocolate bark with pretzels
description: These little triple chocolate bites make a great addition to a sweet party buffet, or an attractive edible gift
author: Jennifer Joyce
