directions: Use 2 glass bowls set over 2 saucepans of boiling water, making sure that the water doesn’t touch the bottoms of the bowls. Melt the dark and milk chocolates in 1 bowl and the white in the other. Stir both until smooth, then add the mint essence to the melted dark and milk chocolate.

Line a baking tray with baking parchment. First, pour a little of the dark and milk chocolate onto the paper, spaced apart, then pour the white chocolate on top. Using a knife, swirl the chocolates together to create a marbled effect. Arrange the pretzels on top of the chocolate and leave to harden. Break into pieces and serve. Will keep for 1 week in an airtight container.
chief_review: These triple chocolate bites deliver an indulgent fusion of dark, milk, and white chocolates, elevated with a subtle hint of mint and a playful crunch from salted pretzels. The layered chocolate flavors create lovely contrasts, while the mint essence adds a refreshing twist to each bite. The salted pretzels bring a delightful savory edge, balancing the sweetness and giving a satisfying texture. This recipe is ideal for a party buffet or as a homemade edible gift, appealing to both kids and adults alike. As there are no animal-derived gelatins or non-vegetarian additives, this recipe suits a vegetarian diet. However, those with dairy or gluten sensitivities should check their chocolate and pretzel selections for possible allergens. Overall, these chocolate bites are quick and easy to assemble, offering an impressive result with minimal effort—perfect for festive occasions or thoughtful foodie gifts.

name: Roast poussins with wild mushroom sauce
description: Impress any dinner party guests with Tom Kerridge's indulgent main dish - everyone is served their own little roast chicken
author: Tom Kerridge
ingredients: 8 garlic cloves, crushed with their skins on
25g dried morelsor dried porcini mushrooms (see Tip)
8 thyme sprigs, tied together with string
Baby Gem lettuce, blowtorched, to serve (see Tip)
directions: First, make the sauce. Bring the white wine to the boil and pour it on top of the dried mushrooms. Cover with cling film and leave to soak and rehydrate for 1 hr. After this time, pass the wine through a fine sieve into a saucepan and put the mushrooms to one side. Add the shallots and garlic to the wine. Put the pan on a medium-high heat until the wine has reduced by two-thirds, and the shallots are soft and translucent. Add the tied-up sprigs of thyme, the mushrooms and double cream. Bring the cream to the boil and gently simmer until it has reduced by a third. Remove from the heat, season, pour in the Sherry and turn off the heat until serving. Can be made 2 days ahead.

Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Stuff the cavity of each poussin with 2 garlic cloves, 4 sprigs of thyme and a piece of lemon peel. For neat presentation, you can now tie the poussin legs together, but this isn’t essential. Smear the butter over the poussins, put in a shallow roasting tin and cook for 30-35 mins until the legs easily come away from the bird, or until a digital cooking thermometer reads 75C when inserted in the breast. Take out of the oven, baste with the buttery cooking juices and leave to rest for 15 mins.
chief_review: Tom Kerridge’s poussin recipe is a showcase of sophisticated yet approachable cooking, with individual roast birds elegantly flavored by thyme, lemon, and oven-roasted garlic. The sauce, enriched with morels or porcini, double cream, and dry sherry, is deeply aromatic—luxurious without overwhelming the delicate meat. The interplay of textures, from the supple roast poussin to the lightly charred Baby Gem lettuce, makes each plate both visually striking and genuinely satisfying. This dish would delight guests at any dinner party, providing a restaurant-quality experience in a home setting. Notably, the recipe does contain dairy (butter, cream), mushrooms, and alcohol—factors that should be kept in mind when serving to guests with specific dietary needs or allergies. An excellent choice for those seeking a rich, restaurant-inspired poultry dish to elevate festive entertaining.

name: Antipasti skewers
description: Impress party guests with these simple, stylish canapés - thread olives, feta, Serrano ham and Peppadews onto long cocktail sticks
author: Jennifer Joyce
directions: Cut the feta into small cubes. Tear the Serrano ham into long pieces. Thread a cube of feta, a piece of ham, a drained Peppadew and an olive into 12 long cocktail sticks.
chief_review: This canapé recipe artfully combines bold Mediterranean flavors: creamy feta, silky Serrano ham, tangy peppadews, and savory olives. The balance of salt from the cheese and ham with the sweet, spicy bite of the peppadews makes for an elegant and satisfying party bite. The preparation is straightforward and the presentation is visually appealing, perfect for effortless entertaining. This dish is ideal for a low-carb or ketogenic diet, as it contains minimal carbohydrates and plenty of healthy fats from the cheese and olives. Those following a gluten-free diet will also appreciate that these canapés are naturally free of gluten-containing ingredients. For ease, ensure the cocktail sticks are sturdy enough to hold all elements. I recommend serving these chilled for optimal flavor and texture contrast.

name: Apple, cream & spiced rye crumble pots
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 5 tbsp icing sugar(or add to taste)
2 tbsp blanched hazelnuts, halved and toasted
directions: Peel and core the apples and cut the flesh into chunks. Put these in a large saucepan with the caster sugar and 3 tbsp water and cook over a gentle heat until the apples are completely tender. Stir every so often and mash the fruit down roughly with the back of a wooden spoon. The finished purée shouldn’t be too wet – if it is, simmer it over a low heat until it reduces and loses some of its moisture.

Check the apples for sweetness – they shouldn't be too sweet as it's being mixed with sweet cream and breadcrumbs – and tip into a bowl to cool. In Scandinavia, the stewed apples are usually puréed until smooth, but you can also keep them chunky.

Melt half the butter in a frying pan and add the brown breadcrumbs and half the brown sugar. Sauté, stirring constantly, over a medium heat until the breadcrumbs are golden. Add half the cinnamon and half the cardamom and continue to cook for about 1 min. Spread out on a tray – it cools quicker this way – and leave until it’s room temperature. Do the same with the rye breadcrumbs, then mix the breadcrumbs together in a bowl.

Whip the cream, adding the icing sugar and the lemon (add the lemon before the cream is too thick as the acid in the lemon has a thickening effect). If you are going to add the aquavit, do it once the cream has been whipped.

Layer the apples, breadcrumbs and whipped cream in a glass bowl (so you can see the layers) starting with the stewed apples and ending with a layer of cream. Scatter over the hazelnuts just before serving.
chief_review: This recipe celebrates classic Nordic flavors with tender apples, spiced crumbs, and a generous lashing of whipped cream. The combination of rye and traditional breadcrumbs offers a lovely rustic texture, while cinnamon and cardamom bring warmth and depth. The toasted hazelnuts add a pleasing crunch and nuttiness. The use of whipping cream for the topping creates a rich, indulgent finish, sweetened to taste with icing sugar and brightened by a squeeze of lemon. A splash of aquavit is an exciting optional twist, adding complexity and a hint of aromatics. This dish would be a delightful addition to a festive table or as an elegant end to a cozy meal. It’s suitable for a vegetarian diet, as all ingredients are derived from plant or dairy sources. However, do note that it contains gluten, dairy, and nuts, and is not vegan.

name: Klump
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 2 ripe pears, cored and chopped into chunks
directions: Halve the potatoes and cook them in boiling lightly salted water until tender, then drain and leave until cool enough to touch. Meanwhile, melt 15g of the butter in a saucepan. Add the bacon and sizzle until golden. Remove with a slotted spoon, then add the onion and pears. Cook until pale golden, then tip the bacon back into the saucepan.

Remove the kale leaves from their coarse ribs and blanch the leaves for 2 mins in boiling water. Drain and rinse in cold water. Chop the leaves and add to the bacon and onions. Pour in 2 tbsp water and some pepper, cover the pan and cook for about 15 mins, making sure the pan doesn’t become dry. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Peel the potatoes and put them back in the pan in which they were cooked. Add the remaining butter and seasoning, then mash together.

If the bacon mixture is too ‘wet’, then remove the lid, turn up the heat and boil off the excess moisture. Put the kale and bacon mixture into a gratin dish and spread the mash on top. Sprinkle over the cheese, if using, then bake in the oven for about 20 mins, or until the top is golden – you can crisp it up under the grill for 5 mins if you need to. Leave to rest for a few minutes before serving.
chief_review:
This hearty dish is a celebration of robust, seasonal flavors—ideal for comforting family meals. The use of floury potatoes creates a soft, fluffy base, while butter and cheddar (if using) add creaminess and depth. Bacon lardons introduce savoriness and subtle smokiness, beautifully balanced by the sweet juiciness of ripe pears. Kale provides both vibrant color and a pleasant earthy note, rounding out the nutritional profile.

While the dish isn’t suitable for vegetarians or vegans due to the inclusion of bacon, butter, and (potentially) cheddar, those without specific dietary restrictions will appreciate its rich, warming character. A thoughtful balance of textures—from silky potatoes to tender greens and juicy pears—adds to its appeal. Easily adaptable, it’s perfect as a main meal or a generous side, inviting home cooks to make it their own.

name: 15-minute mix & match salad
description: I dont want to sound daft here but are the sprouts raw or do you use cooked cold sprouts left over from dinner.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 red-skinned eating apple, cored, but with the skin left on
175g mixed nut, such as brazils, walnuts and roasted cashews
6 tbsp light olive oilor sunflower oil
directions: Fit your food processor with the slicing blade. Cut the hard white core from the cabbage, then shred the leaves and slice the celery, sprouts and apple in the processor. With the grating attachment, grate the carrots. Roughly chop the nuts, either in the processor or by hand.
In a small bowl, mix the oil with the cranberry sauce. It will look quite cloudy and thick, but don’t worry – add the orange juice next and it will all thin out into a fruity dressing.

Tip all the chopped veg and nuts into a big bowl, pour in the dressing and toss together. (The salad will keep in a covered container for up to a day in the fridge.) Season and serve with stilton crumbled over the top.
chief_review:
This vibrant salad is a delightful showcase of winter vegetables and festive flavors. The raw red cabbage, celery, carrots, and Brussels sprouts bring crunch and freshness, complemented by the natural sweetness of apple and cranberry sauce. The medley of mixed nuts provides a lovely, rich texture and healthy fats, while stilton adds a bold, creamy tang that ties all elements together. The dressing—light olive oil and orange juice—offers a zesty brightness without overwhelming the ingredients. 

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet and would appeal to those avoiding meat. However, with the inclusion of nuts and dairy (stilton), it's important for anyone with nut or dairy allergies to steer clear or modify accordingly. Perfect for a festive side or a hearty lunch salad, this dish balances flavors and textures with chef-worthy finesse.

name: Irish coffee
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Lightly whip the cream just so it’s very slightly thickened, then set aside.

Pour the hot coffee into a mug or heatproof glass, then add the whiskey and sugar. Stir until the sugar has dissolved. Gently float the cream on the top and sprinkle the nutmeg over the cream. Serve hot.
chief_review:
This recipe crafts a true classic: Irish coffee, made with rich black coffee, a splash of Irish whiskey, double cream, and a hint of brown sugar. The fresh grating of nutmeg adds an aromatic finish that elevates the drink. The combination of smooth cream and coffee is well-balanced by the whiskey, making it an excellent after-dinner treat. 

This recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no meat or animal-derived rennet. However, it is not vegan due to the presence of dairy cream. Also, it is gluten-free, provided the whiskey used is distilled (most commercial Irish whiskeys are). Those with lactose intolerance or dairy allergies should substitute a dairy-free cream alternative to enjoy this warming beverage.

name: Singapore sling
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour the gin, cherry brandy and Benedictine into a mixing glass or a jug. Add the ice and Angostura bitters. Stir well until the outside of the glass feels cold.
Pour the mix into a tall glass, then add the pineapple juice and lime juice and stir gently. Top up with sparkling water and garnish.
chief_review: This vibrant cocktail masterfully balances botanical gin, warming cherry brandy, and aromatic Benedictine with the tropical freshness of pineapple and lime juice. Angostura bitters deepen the flavor profile, while a splash of sparkling water ensures a refreshing finish. The drink’s complexity is elevated with the optional garnish of fresh pineapple and a cocktail cherry, adding visual appeal and a subtle fruitiness. Suitable for vegetarians and vegans, as the ingredients exclude any animal-derived products, and commonly avoid gluten-containing ingredients. This cocktail is an excellent choice for craft cocktail enthusiasts looking for a harmonious blend of sweet, tart, and herbal notes—perfect for summer soirées or as a sophisticated pre-dinner tipple.

name: Classic nougat
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 150g clear honey(use a floral-flavoured honey for extra flavour)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Scatter the nuts over a

and toast in the oven for 10 mins, then set aside (they don’t need to cool). Cut the two pieces of rice paper to fit a 20 x 20cm square tin. Line the tin with one sheet of rice paper, brush the sides of the tin with oil, then dust the tin with icing sugar.
Put the honey into a

, then in another saucepan tip in the sugar, glucose and 100ml of water. Put the egg whites in the very clean bowl of a tabletop mixer with a whisk attachment and whisk on a low speed. Heat and boil the honey until it reaches 121C on a digital cooking thermometer, then straightaway pour the honey over the egg whites and set the speed to medium. While the whites and honey are whisking, bring the sugar and water to the boil and keep boiling until the syrup reaches 145C exactly on a digital cooking thermometer. Pour the hot syrup in a slow, steady stream into the beating egg white mixture. Continue beating for about 10 mins until you have a thick, glossy, firm meringue. It’s hard to over-whisk at this stage but easy to under-whisk, so keep going until the meringue looks like sticky chewing gum.
Use a

to stir though the nuts (which should still be warm), the vanilla extract and a small pinch of salt. Scrape the mixture into the lined tin, then smooth over to spread the mixture out evenly (if you have an offset spatula, now is the time to use it). Finally, top with the remaining sheet of rice paper and press down. Leave the nougat to set for at least 2 hrs or overnight.
To turn out and portion, use a spatula to loosen the edges of the nougat away from the tin, then invert the tin on to a clean board and use a sharp serated, hot knife to portion into bars or squares.
chief_review: This recipe creates a classic nut-studded nougat, offering an inviting combination of blanched almonds, pistachios, and hazelnuts enveloped in a silky, honey-sweetened meringue. The careful balance between white caster sugar, liquid glucose, and floral honey delivers a delicate yet complex sweetness, while the edible rice paper ensures a fuss-free finish and professional appearance. The whipped egg whites provide a light, chewy texture essential to traditional nougat, and the vanilla extract adds aromatic depth. This confection is naturally gluten-free, provided the rice paper and other ingredients are certified as such, making it ideal for those avoiding gluten. With a generous quantity of nuts, it celebrates crunch and flavor, and the presentation is elevated by a dusting of icing sugar. Perfect as an elegant treat or gift, this recipe pays homage to artisan confectionery craft.

name: Pear & rose punch
author: Miriam Nice
directions: Pour the pear juice into a large pan. Add the vanilla pod, golden caster sugar, cardamom pods and root ginger, then bring to a simmer. Leave to cool completely, then strain into a punch bowl or jug.
Add the raw apple cider vinegar, rosewater and sparkling water. Garnish with rosemary sprigs, thyme, sliced red pear and a handful of frozen redcurrants. Add ice and serve.
chief_review:
This beautifully aromatic mocktail is a refreshing showcase of layered flavors, balancing the mellow sweetness of pear juice with the warmth of cardamom, vanilla, and ginger. The apple cider vinegar and rosewater introduce subtle tart and floral notes, making every sip intriguing. Fresh herbs like rosemary and thyme add a pleasant herbal aroma, while sparkling water delivers a lively effervescence. The sliced red pear and frozen redcurrants not only elevate the visual appeal but also contribute slight bursts of fruitiness.

With no animal products or gluten-containing grains in the ingredients, this recipe is perfectly suited for vegan and gluten-free diets. It’s also free from common allergens like dairy, eggs, nuts, and soy, making it a safe and sophisticated choice for a broad range of guests. This drink is a fragrant, elegant addition to any special occasion or afternoon gathering.

name: Gin-free G&T
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: ½ bunch mint leaves, plus extra to garnish
directions: Bruise the cardamom pods and slice the cucumber. Put them both in a large jug and add the chamomile teabag, mint leaves, lemon zest, cloves and rosemary. Top up with 500ml cold water. Leave to infuse in the fridge for 2-4 hrs. To serve, strain the infused water and pour 50ml of it into each glass. Top up with tonic water and lots of ice. Garnish each one with a few more mint leaves and pomegranate seeds, if you like.
chief_review: This refreshing, herbaceous beverage is a masterful blend of cooling cucumber, aromatic cardamom, soothing chamomile, and fragrant herbs like mint and rosemary. The addition of whole cloves and a strip of lemon zest offers a complex, spiced citrus note, balanced perfectly with tonic water for a brisk finish. Visually, the optional pomegranate seeds and extra mint garnish make for an appealing presentation. With no animal products or gluten-containing ingredients, this recipe is both vegan and gluten-free, and suits many common dietary restrictions. It’s ideal as a sophisticated mocktail or a palate-cleansing aperitif, allowing the fresh, natural flavors of the botanicals to truly shine. This drink is a creative, elegant alternative for non-drinkers and a standout at any gathering.

name: Fortune cookies
description: I was so pleased with how these came out!! Definitely took a couple of tries to make them perfect but is honestly so worth it once you see the final result. I do have a couple of tips from making these today- reduce the almond extract by a touch, maybe closer to 3/4 of a teaspoon. Also, when you spread the cookies out, do them thin- thinner than feels comfortable, and reduce the bake by a few minutes, closer to 8/9 minutes. This gives you a lovely ‘snap’. You definitely need to have asbestos hands to shape these too! I’d recommend wearing some kind of thin glove if you can. However, these were surprisingly easy and the flavour was almost identical to that of an authentic Fortune Cookie! Very impressed, thank you for the recipe!
author: Chelsie Collins
directions: Preheat the oven to 180C/160 fan/gas 4 and line a large baking sheet with baking parchment, or use a silicone baking sheet. Write or print fortunes on paper measuring 6cm long by 1cm wide.

Put the egg whites, vanilla, almond extract, oil and 2 tsp cold water into a bowl and whisk with an electric hand whisk until frothy, 20-30 secs. Measure the flour, cornflour, sugar and a good pinch of salt into a bowl, then sift into the egg white mixture. Whisk everything together until you have a smooth batter-like consistency. Chill the mixture for 1 hr.

Next, put a tbsp of mixture onto the prepared baking sheet. Oil a metal spoon, then use the back of it to swirl the mixture out into a 8-10cm circle. Repeat with another tablespoon of the mixture, to create 2 cookies. Make sure there is space between each cookie as they will spread in the oven. It is best to only bake 2-3 cookies at a time, as you will need to shape them whilst they are hot. Sprinkle 1 of the cookies with black sesame seeds, then bake for 10-12 mins until the edges of the cookies turn golden.

One at a time remove the cookies with a palette knife once they are out the oven. You want them to still be soft so you can shape them so work quickly. Turn the cookie over so that the sesame seeds are face down and put the fortune in the middle of the circle. Fold the circle in half to secure the fortune and pinch the 2 edges together to seal. Pop the cookie on the rim of a mug or cup and very gently pull the 2 corners down to get the fortune cookie shape. Hold for 10 secs, then transfer the cookies to muffin tins so that they hold their shape whilst cooling completely. Repeat with the remaining cookie mixture.
chief_review:
This Fortune Cookie recipe delivers on both flavor and texture, yielding a crisp, golden snap reminiscent of authentic versions. The use of sunflower oil contributes a light crumb, while the blend of vanilla and a touch less almond extract keeps the aroma balanced and inviting. A key tip: spreading the batter thinner than you’d expect and slightly reducing bake time (to around 8–9 minutes) achieves the ideal crispness without overbrowning. The incorporation of black sesame seeds adds a lovely visual appeal and a subtle nutty note.

For those with dietary considerations, this recipe is vegetarian-friendly. However, please note it utilizes eggs and wheat flour. Overall, these homemade fortune cookies impress with their ease, versatility, and spot-on flavor, making them an excellent treat for special occasions or fun kitchen projects.

name: Perfect roast potatoes
description: Excellent recipe! Goose fat is a must... I also added garlic powder to the oil (just a sprinkling) and a sprig of rosemary. Absolutely delicious, we were all fighting over the last roastie :)
author: Good Food
ingredients: 16 potatoesthe best ones to use are Desirée, as they hold their shape, but King Edward and Maris Piper are also good
140g goose fator duck fat or dripping
3 tbsp sunflower oil or vegetable oil
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Peel the potatoes and cut in half; if very large, cut into quarters, or leave whole if they are small. Tip into a saucepan, cover with cold water, then bring to the boil. Set the timer and boil for exactly 2 mins. Drain the potatoes well, then toss in the colander to fluff up their surfaces, sprinkling over the flour as you go.

Place a large, sturdy roasting tray over a fairly high heat, then tip in the fat and oil. When sizzling, lower in the potatoes carefully, then gently brown in the hot fat for about 5 mins so all the sides are covered with oil.

Roast undisturbed for 20 mins, then remove from the oven and gently turn them over with a fish slice. Place the tray on the hob to heat the oil, then return to the oven and cook for another 20 mins. Turn again, putting the tray back on the hob to heat the oil. Give them a final 20 mins in the oven, by which time you should have perfect roast potatoes.
chief_review: This roast potato recipe delivers on flavor and texture, thanks to the combination of goose or duck fat with just a touch of rosemary and garlic powder. The technique highlights classic British cooking, achieving crisp, golden exteriors with a fluffy inside—exactly what you want in a perfect roastie. The use of plain flour for dusting maximizes crunch, while sunflower or vegetable oil options offer some flexibility. This dish is naturally suitable for a vegetarian diet if vegetable oil is used instead of animal fats. However, it is not vegan due to the use of goose or duck fat in the original version. Additionally, it contains gluten from the flour, so is not suitable for gluten-free diets without modifications. Excellent as a centerpiece for Sunday roasts or festive occasions, this recipe will have everyone reaching for more.

name: Limoncello plum tart
description: A melt-in-the-mouth dessert that can be prepared ahead
author: Gino Di Campo
ingredients: zest and juice of 2 unwaxed lemons
6 plums, stoned and cut into wedges
directions: Roll out the pastry and use to line a loose-bottomed tart tin, 25cm diameter and about 3.5-4cm deep. Chill for at least half an hour.
Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Line the pastry with greaseproof paper, fill with baking beans and bake blind for 15 mins. Remove beans and paper.
Put the lemon zest and juice, cream, almonds, sugar, eggs and melted butter in a large bowl and whisk until smooth then stir in the limoncello.
Put the plums in the pastry case then pour the custard mixture over. Bake for about 20-30 mins until the custard is just set. Allow to cool then dredge with icing sugar before serving.
chief_review: This dessert effortlessly marries the tangy brightness of lemon and limoncello with the subtle nuttiness of ground almonds, creating a superbly balanced tart. The shortcrust pastry delivers a delicate, flaky base, while the combination of eggs, double cream, and butter ensures a custard-like filling that is both rich and airy. Plums add a pleasantly tart and juicy contrast to the sweet, aromatic interior. Ideal for preparing ahead, this dessert is particularly well suited to gatherings or special occasions where time is of the essence. Please note, with the inclusion of eggs and dairy, it is not suitable for vegan or dairy-free diets; however, it can delight those following a vegetarian diet. An excellent choice for an indulgent finish to a summer meal, especially for those who appreciate fruity, Italian-inspired treats.

name: Sweet potato & parsnip bake
description: A make-ahead vegetarian side dish that's high in fibre and provides a good source of vitamin C
author: Good Food
ingredients: 800g sweet potato, peeled and cut into chunks
800g parsnip, peeled and cut into chunks
directions: Boil the sweet potatoes and parsnips for 20 mins in salted water until tender. Drain really well, then roughly mash with half the crème fraîche and half the sage, the mustard and salt and pepper. Pile into a buttered ovenproof dish and smooth over.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Mix the breadcrumbs with the Parmesan, pine nuts and remaining sage. Spoon the remaining crème fraîche over the mash, scatter over the bread and cheese mixture, then bake for 35-40 mins from fridge-cold, 25-30 mins if not, until golden.
chief_review:
This vibrant side dish brilliantly combines sweet potato and parsnip for a high-fibre, vitamin C-rich addition to any table. The use of reduced-fat crème fraîche keeps it lighter, while the wholegrain mustard and shredded sage infuse subtle warmth and complexity. The crunchy breadcrumb, pine nut, and vegetarian-style parmesan topping brings texture and depth. 

As a vegetarian dish, it’s ideal for those avoiding meat but looking to enjoy robust, satisfying flavours. The absence of meat, reliance on vegetarian parmesan, and use of plant-based ingredients also make it suitable for lacto-vegetarians. However, note that crème fraîche is dairy-based, which precludes this recipe from being vegan. 

Overall, it’s a well-balanced, make-ahead side that will brighten up festive or everyday meals with both nutrition and flavour.

name: Poached pears in spiced tea
description: This low-fat, easy and fresh-tasting pudding is perfect for feeding a crowd on a budget
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 spiced fruittea bags (Pukka's 'revitalise' is good, or apple & cinnamon)
4 firm pears, peeled, halved and core scooped out with a spoon
yogurt or sweetened crème fraîchewith a little orange juice or zest, to serve
directions: Put the sugar, honey, jelly and tea bags into a big saucepan with 600ml water and bring to the boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Add the pear halves, then cover and simmer for 12-15 mins until the pears are just tender – poke them with a skewer or the tip of a knife.

Lift out the pears, then turn up the heat, throw in the cranberries and boil for a few mins until syrupy. Discard the tea bags. Serve the pears with the warm syrup poured over and a spoonful of crème fraîche or yogurt.
chief_review: This pudding is a delightful, budget-friendly option full of fresh, bright flavors—just the thing for a large gathering. The pears and cranberries offer a pleasant tartness, while the honey and spiced fruit tea bring a subtle warmth that complements the fruit beautifully. Using yogurt as the serving base keeps the dish light and lets the fruit shine, although sweetened crème fraîche with orange adds a luxurious touch. It is suitable for a vegetarian diet, and by choosing a plant-based yogurt or crème fraîche, this dessert can also easily be adapted for vegans. An excellent choice for a health-conscious crowd, this recipe is low in fat without sacrificing taste or visual appeal.

name: Raspberry ripple pavlova
description: This whipped-up ripply delight tastes as dreamy as it looks
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 large free-range egg whites, at room temperature
directions: Make the semi-freddo. Push 140g/5oz of the raspberries through a sieve, leaving behind the seeds. Stir in 25g/1oz of the icing sugar. Whip the cream until like thick custard. Whisk in the mascarpone until the mix thickens, then stir in the remaining icing sugar.

Drop spoonfuls of the cream mix into a deep, oblong plastic container, and fill in with a drizzle of sieved raspberries. Do not stir. Add another layer of cream and raspberries. Gently smooth the surface and press down lightly, then freeze for 2-21⁄2 hours until half frozen.

Heat oven to 140C/fan 120C/gas 1. Line a large baking sheet with non-stick baking parchment. Draw a 20-22cm circle on the paper. In a large bowl, whisk the egg whites until stiff peaks form. Slowly whisk in the caster sugar until thick and glossy. Beat in the cornflour. Pile the meringue in soft folds onto the circle on the baking parchment. Scatter over the pistachios. Bake for 11⁄4-11⁄2 hrs until crisp on the outside and dry underneath. Cool then gently peel off the paper.
Remove the semi-freddo from the freezer and pile in big spoonfuls on the pavlova. Finish off with a scattering of the remaining raspberries.
chief_review: This recipe offers a luscious, cloud-like raspberry dessert, balancing the tartness of fresh raspberries with rich double cream and mascarpone. The swirl of smooth cream and whipped egg whites creates an elegant, ripply texture, finished with a crunchy scatter of pistachios. The use of egg whites and cream ensures a light, airy consistency, while mascarpone adds a luxurious body. Perfect for impressing guests, the dessert is naturally gluten free, making it ideal for those with gluten sensitivities. Nut lovers will appreciate the pistachios, although these can be omitted or swapped to suit nut allergies. The result is a visually stunning and deliciously indulgent dessert that suits festive tables and summer gatherings alike.

name: Venison sausage & chestnut casserole
description: This warming sausage stew is a perfect make-ahead main, with a rich red wine sauce, chestnuts and a creamy mustard mash
author: Justine Pattison
ingredients: 3 celery sticks, trimmed and thinly sliced
200g chestnut mushrooms, halved (or quartered if large)
small pack parsley, chopped, to serve (optional)
1½ kg medium potatoes(ideally Maris Piper), cut into even chunks
directions: Heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a large non-stick frying pan and fry the sausages in two batches over a medium heat for 15 mins, turning regularly, until nicely browned. Transfer the sausages to a large flameproof casserole dish.

Tip the onions and celery into the frying pan and cook over a medium-high heat for 5 mins or until beginning to soften and lightly colour, stirring regularly. Add a splash more oil if needed. Tip the vegetables into the casserole dish.

Put the remaining oil in the pan, cook the mushrooms over a high heat for 4-5 mins until lightly browned, then add to the casserole. Pour the wine and 300ml water into the dish and crumble the stock cube over the top. Stir in the chestnuts, tomato purée and bay leaf. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat, cover loosely with a lid and simmer gently for 30 mins, stirring occasionally.

Meanwhile, make the mustard mash. Put the potatoes in a large pan of water, bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 15-20 mins or until the potatoes are soft but not falling apart. Drain well in a colander, then return to the pan and mash with the butter and cream until smooth. Beat in the mustard, season to taste, and set aside.

Mix the cornflour with 2 tbsp cold water until smooth. Stir into the casserole and cook for 2-3 mins, stirring regularly, until the sauce has thickened. Remove the dish from the heat, season and sprinkle with chopped parsley, if using. Serve with the mustard mash.
chief_review: This venison sausage stew delivers a robust, comforting flavor, perfectly complemented by the earthy chestnuts and hearty red wine sauce. The addition of mushrooms and onions enriches the dish with deep umami notes, while the creamy mustard mash adds a velvety, subtly sharp finish. The use of cornflour as a thickener makes this suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, provided the stock cube is also gluten free. The recipe's reliance on beef stock, venison sausages, and dairy (butter, double cream) means it isn’t suitable for vegan, vegetarian, or dairy-free diets. The dish’s make-ahead nature enhances the depth of flavors and makes it a fantastic option for entertaining. Overall, this is an impressive, cozy main that showcases seasonal ingredients and careful layering of flavors, ideal for cool evenings or festive gatherings.

name: Beetroot shots with tarragon yogurt ice cubes
description: Sounds weird - tastes delicious - perfect for those hard to impress guests
author: Cathryn Evans
directions: To make the ice cubes, mix the yogurt with a handful of chopped tarragon leaves, then half-fill 2 x 12-cube ice trays (the smallest you have) with the mix. Cover with cling film and freeze overnight.

Put the onions and sugar in a saucepan, cover with a lid, then cook over moderate heat for 10 mins, shaking the pan from time to time. Pour in the wine and vinegar and bubble away until syrupy. Now pour in the stock, add the beetroot and a handful of tarragon leaves. Bring to the boil, then cook for 15 mins.

Blend the soup until smooth, then pass through a sieve into a bowl, pushing as much of the puréed beetroot through as possible. Season with lots of black pepper, then serve hot in shot glasses with a yogurt ice cube on top
chief_review: This vibrant beetroot and red onion soup is a showstopper for the adventurous palate. The caramelized onions, enriched with golden caster sugar, add a gentle sweetness that balances beautifully with the earthy beetroot. Red wine and vinegar provide a subtle complexity, while vegetable stock ensures a robust, satisfying base. The final swirl of natural yogurt delivers luxurious creaminess and a tangy counterpoint, with fresh tarragon lending a fragrant, herbal note. This recipe is an inspired choice for vegetarian guests, and also fits a gluten-free diet, making it especially versatile when catering to varied dietary needs. A truly impressive and well-balanced starter.

name: Goat's cheese & onion pastries
description: Use a hearty shortcrust base then top with creamy cheese and crunchy walnuts and contrast with watercress salad
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 3 large onions, halved and thinly sliced
4 Capricorn goat's cheese, halved (keep the rind on)
directions: For the onions, heat the oil in a non-stick pan. Add the onions, stir well, then cover and cook for 15 mins, stirring every now and then. Stir really well and add the sugar, lots of seasoning and the walnuts, olives and rosemary. Cook for 5 mins more, until soft and very golden.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Thinly roll out the pastry, then stamp out 8 fluted rounds with a 10cm cutter. Prick with a fork, then bake for 10 mins. Mix the dressing ingredients together. This can all be prepared a few days ahead.

Pile the onions onto the pastry rounds, top with goat‘s cheese and place a walnut half on top of the cheese. Bake for 10 mins until the cheese is melty. Toss the watercress with the dressing, pile onto plates and serve the pastry on top.
chief_review:
This recipe expertly balances flavors and textures: the richness of all-butter shortcrust pastry, sweetly caramelized onions, and tangy goat’s cheese pairs perfectly with toasted walnuts and briny olives. The addition of rosemary imparts an aromatic lift, while the crunchy, peppery watercress salad with walnut oil and red wine vinegar provides a refreshing contrast—preventing the tart from ever feeling too heavy.

As there’s no meat here, this recipe is a fine choice for vegetarians. With nuts, dairy, and gluten present, those with allergies or intolerances should be mindful. The technique is straightforward, making it suitable for both novice and seasoned cooks. Served warm or at room temperature, this tart is impressive enough for a main at a luncheon, yet equally delightful as a starter. Overall, this recipe delivers a sophisticated, well-balanced vegetarian dish sure to please a crowd.

name: Home-churned butter
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 600ml double cream(the better quality the cream, the better the butter)
directions: Pour the cream into a jar with a clean marble inside. Screw the lid on tightly. Shake the jar continuously for 5 mins (you can take turns shaking with someone else). The movement of the marble acts as a whisk and helps the butter to churn. You can do it without the marble, it just takes longer. At first the cream will thicken to whipped cream, then it will get even thicker. After about 5 mins you will hear sloshing in the jar – give it a few more vigorous shakes, and that’s the butter churned.

Scrape out the contents into a sieve sitting over a bowl – the liquid that drains out is buttermilk (which can be kept and used for baking or in pancakes), and the fatty solid in the sieve is the butter.

With clean hands, squeeze the butter between your fingers over the sieve to squeeze out any more buttermilk, while working it into a ball. ‘Wash’ the butter in a bowl of ice-cold water to get rid of any residual buttermilk.
To make brandy butter, beat the sugar and a small pinch of salt into the butter, then work in the brandy 1 tbsp at a time. Will keep in the fridge for up to one week.
chief_review: This indulgent recipe delivers a rich, velvety cream enhanced by the depth of brandy or dark rum and a delicate sweetness from sifted icing sugar. The focus on high-quality double cream ensures a luscious texture and flavor, making it an excellent accompaniment to desserts or holiday treats. With only three ingredients, the method is straightforward yet results in a luxurious, festive finishing touch. Notably, this recipe is suitable for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no animal-derived gelatin or meat byproducts. However, be mindful of the dairy content for those with lactose intolerance. Overall, it’s an elegant, classic choice for elevating dessert occasions.

name: Healthy gravy
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 1l low-salt vegetable stock, or chicken stock if not making it vegetarian
directions: Heat the oil in a saucepan then add the vegetables and cook them over a medium-high heat for 10-15 mins to brown – if they burn at the edges, then all the better. Stir in the ketchup and dried mushrooms and cook together until everything becomes sticky, then splash in the vinegar. Stir in the stock and season with a pinch of salt, if you like. Bring to the boil, then simmer gently for 20 mins.

Using a hand blender, blitz to create a thin soup-like consistency, then pass through a sieve into another saucepan and bring to the simmer. Slake the cornflour with a splash of water, then pour into the liquid and continue to cook until thickened. Serve straightaway, chill, or freeze for reheating at a later date.
chief_review: This recipe is wonderfully suited for a vegetarian diet when prepared with low-salt vegetable stock. The combination of aromatic onions, sweet carrots, and earthy dried porcini mushrooms creates depth and richness, balanced with a hint of ketchup and a splash of balsamic vinegar for tanginess. The sunflower oil provides a neutral base, and the cornflour ensures a pleasing thickness without the need for dairy or gluten—making this dish gluten-free as well. The use of low-salt stock supports a lighter sodium profile, ideal for those mindful of their salt intake. Overall, this is a thoughtfully balanced, hearty, and flavorful choice for anyone seeking a comforting, plant-based, and allergen-friendly meal.

name: Salmon & lemon mini fish cakes
description: These fish cakes provide a tasty gluten-free alternative to your festive spread
author: Good Food
ingredients: grated zest and juice ½ lemon
140g smoked salmon trimmings, plus extra to serve
2 tbsp gluten-free flour mixed with 1 tsp coarsely ground pepper
directions: Microwave potatoes on high for 10 mins until tender. Leave to cool for 5 mins, scoop the flesh in a bowl, then mash and leave to cool. Season with olive oil, lemon zest and juice to taste, then mix in the egg, salmon and parsley. Shape into small rounds 3cm wide and 1cm deep. Chill for 15 mins.
Dust each cake with the peppered flour, then fry over a low heat in a little oil for 2-3 mins on each side. Drain on kitchen paper and serve garnished with salmon and parsley.
chief_review: These fish cakes deliver a delightful balance of smoky salmon and fresh herbs, brightened by lemon zest and juice. The use of olive oil and baked potatoes keeps the texture light, while the gluten-free flour makes this a welcome option for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. Smoked salmon trimmings add a satisfying depth, perfectly complemented by fresh parsley. The recipe requires only simple techniques and yields moist, flavorful cakes with a crisp exterior. Serve with a squeeze of extra lemon and a sprinkle of parsley for a festive, elegant touch that’s suitable for gluten-free diets.

name: Clementine & Cointreau marmalade
description: Give your marmalade a boozy twang by adding a dash of Cointreau
author: Good Food
directions: Scrub clementines in warm soapy water, rinse, then halve and squeeze juice into a large pan. Scoop out the pulp and any seeds, then tie in the muslin, as before. Shred the peel. Add both to the pan with the lemon juice and water, then leave to steep overnight.

Put the pan over a medium heat and bring up to a simmer. Cook, uncovered, until the peel is soft, about 30-45 mins. Squeeze as much liquid from the muslin bag as possible. Discard the bag. Weigh the mixture – you should have around 1.15kg.

Put the pan over a low heat, then add the sugar. Heat gently until sugar has dissolved, stirring occasionally, then bring up to a good rolling boil. Cook for 15 mins, then check for a set (see Step 5). If not at setting point, boil (see Know how) for a further 2 mins and check again. Repeat until setting point has been reached.
Add Cointreau, taking care, as marmalade will bubble up. Allow to stand for 15 mins or until beginning to thicken. Transfer to sterilised jars, then seal.

To test the setting point: take the pan off the heat and allow the bubbles to subside. Take a plate from the freezer and spoon a little liquid onto the plate, then return to the freezer for 1 min. Push the marmalade along the plate with your finger. If setting point has been reached then the marmalade surface will wrinkle slightly and the marmalade won’t run back straight away. If it’s not at setting point, return to the heat and boil again for 2 mins before re-testing. Repeat until setting point is reached. If you have a sugar thermometer, setting point is reached at 105C, but it’s good to do the plate test as well.
chief_review: This clementine marmalade, brightened with a splash of Cointreau, offers a delightful balance of citrus tang and subtle boozy notes. The combination of clementines and fresh lemon juice ensures a vibrant, refreshing flavor profile, while the Cointreau adds a sophisticated orange liqueur twist. With only fruit, sugar, and Cointreau, this recipe is well-suited for vegetarian and vegan diets, as there are no animal-derived ingredients. Additionally, the absence of gluten-containing grains makes it a safe option for those following a gluten-free diet. The method is straightforward for home cooks and results in a jewel-toned preserve perfect for morning toast or as a flavorful addition to desserts. An elegant upgrade to classic marmalade.

name: Hot chocolate milkshakes
description:
I'm going to make it.
It looks so yummy.
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: a nip of rumor brandy for the adults (optional)
directions: Break 200g plain chocolate (I used 70% cocoa) into cubes and put into a pan with 600ml full-fat milk. Gently heat until the chocolate melts, then bring almost to the boil, whisking regularly until even and smooth. Can be made ahead, then chilled for up to 2 days.
Re-heat if necessary, whisking, then ladle or pour into heatproof glasses or mugs. Top with scoops vanilla ice cream and mini marshmallows. Add a nip of rum or brandy for the adults, if you like.
chief_review:
This recipe is a luxurious treat, combining rich 70% cocoa chocolate with creamy full-fat milk, a scoop of vanilla ice cream, and topped with mini marshmallows. The optional addition of rum or brandy gives it an adult twist, perfect for cozy evenings. The use of real chocolate instead of powder adds depth and intensity, making this far superior to standard hot chocolate. 

Vegetarians can enjoy this recipe as all ingredients used are typically vegetarian-friendly. However, check the marshmallow packaging, as some brands contain gelatin, which is not vegetarian—opting for vegetarian marshmallows ensures suitability. For those with common food allergies, especially dairy and egg, care should be taken with both the milk and ice cream components. All told, it’s an indulgence sure to please any chocolate lover with an appetite for decadence.

name: Ginger & pear bread & butter pudding
description: Want a treat to keep for yourself? This gooey and spicy vegetarian pudding will hit the spot
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 slices day-old white bread, crusts removed
1 ripe pear, peeled, cored and diced
directions: Spread the bread with the butter, then the preserve. Cut each slice into 4 triangles. Arrange half the bread in the base of a 300ml microwave dish. Scatter over the pear and top with the remaining bread triangles.
Beat together the egg, half the sugar and the milk. Pour over the bread and leave to soak for 10 mins, pushing the bread down to soak up the milk mixture.
Cook the pudding in the microwave on High for 4 mins, then leave to stand for 5 mins. Cook on High for 1 min.
Heat the grill. Sprinkle over the remaining sugar, then cook under a hot grill until the top is bubbling and golden. Serve the pudding warm.
chief_review: This sumptuous vegetarian pudding is a delightful twist on classic comfort desserts, combining the warmth of ginger preserve with the sweetness of ripe pear. The use of day-old white bread creates a satisfyingly gooey base that absorbs the spiced custard beautifully. Butter and demerara sugar contribute to a rich, caramelized flavor, balanced by the fruit’s fresh brightness. Suitable for lacto-ovo vegetarians, this recipe is perfect for those seeking a comforting, egg-based treat. The ingredients, however, do include gluten, dairy, and eggs, so best suited for diners without specific allergen concerns. Serve warm for the ultimate indulgence—each bite is a balance of softness, spice, and sweetness, guaranteed to satisfy a dessert craving.

name: Chilli potato stack with squash & garlic butter sauce
description: Whether you make a cosy bake for a crowd or impressive individual portions, this smart veggie main is a tasty winter main
author: Angela Nilsen
ingredients: 1 tsp each, thyme and rosemary leaves, finely chopped, plus extra sprigs
1kg medium King Edward potato or Maris piper, very thinly sliced
2 small fiery red chillies, deseeded and finely chopped
600g acorn squash, deseeded and cut into small wedges
about 160g pack taleggio cheese, cut into 6 slices, then halved
about 24-30 fried sage leaves, to serve (see know-how below)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Line a baking tray with buttered baking parchment. Butter 6 x 10cm metal rings (2-3cm deep) and place on the tray. Melt the 50g butter with the stock, bubble briefly, then add the chopped herbs and a little pepper. Set aside for a few mins to infuse.

Place one-third of the potatoes in a couple of overlapping layers to cover the base of the rings. Brush with some of the butter mix, scatter over half the shallots and chilli, brush with a little more butter, then season. Continue layering and buttering, pressing down gently as you go. Finish with a layer of potatoes and a final brushing of butter. Cover loosely with foil, bake for 20 mins, remove the foil, then bake a further 25 mins or until the potatoes are tender and golden.

Meanwhile, tip the squash in a single layer into a roasting tin and toss with 2 tbsp oil, a few thyme and rosemary sprigs and black pepper. Roast with the potatoes for the final 20-25 mins until soft and starting to brown.

Make the sauce: simmer the shallot, garlic and sage with the vinegar and wine until the pan is almost dry (you should have about 1 tsp liquid left). Immediately add the butter, a piece at a time, over a low heat, stirring as you go until you have a creamy sauce. Sieve into a small pan and thin with about 1 tbsp of warm water, so it is a pouring consistency. Throw in a few thyme leaves and set aside.
When ready to serve, heat the remaining 2 tbsp oil in a frying pan. When hot, add the sliced mushrooms. Fry for 1-2 mins until golden on both sides, turning once only. Season with salt and pepper.

Heat the grill to high and remove the rings from the potatoes. Lay the mushrooms on top of the potatoes, then lay 2 overlapping slices of cheese on each. Grill until the cheese has just melted. Top with a pile of squash and a scattering of fried sage leaves, then gently lift onto hot plates. Briefly reheat the sauce and drizzle a little around each serving.
chief_review: This winter vegetable bake is a delightful and comforting vegetarian main, making it suitable for a meat-free diet. The combination of earthy chestnut mushrooms, creamy acorn squash, and the punch of fiery red chillies makes for a rich and balanced flavor profile. Adding Taleggio cheese on top offers a luxurious, melty finish, while the herbs—sage, thyme, and rosemary—add a wonderful aromatic quality. The fried sage leaves as a garnish bring both texture and elegance, perfect for special occasions or holiday gatherings. This dish does contain butter and cheese, making it unsuitable for vegan diets, but promises to satisfy vegetarians looking for a hearty centerpiece. The use of thinly sliced potatoes acts like a gratin base, absorbing the vegetable stock and olive oil for a luscious, layered texture. Ideal for cosy dinners or impressing guests at a dinner party.

name: Microwave boozy fudge
description: After reading the comments I was worried that it would be gritty so I beat the mixture after each 2 minutes in the microwave. I added Baileys at the end, then whisked the mixture for about 4-5 minutes. The result is creamy fudge. Perfect.
author: Cassie Best
ingredients: 2 tbsp coffee liqueur (or another alcohol of your choice - amaretto or brandyworks well)
directions: Grease and line a 20cm square baking tin with baking parchment. Put the sugar, condensed milk and butter in a large heatproof bowl (the mixture will bubble up as it cooks to roughly double its size), add a good pinch of salt and stir together.
Heat the mixture in the
on High for 10 mins, stirring every 2-3 mins. Keep an eye on the mixture, as it will bubble up and may go over the sides of the bowl.

Add the vanilla and liqueur to the mixture, whisk together and heat on High for another 2 mins. The mixture should be caramel-coloured and thickened. Scrape into the tin and set aside for 45 mins to 1 hr until cool and firm before cutting. Pack into a box and eat within 3 weeks.
chief_review: This fudge recipe delivers a wonderfully creamy texture, thanks to the method of beating between microwave intervals. The addition of Baileys (or other liqueur) introduces a decadent depth of flavor, pairing beautifully with the rich condensed milk and vanilla. Its ease of preparation makes it approachable for both novice and experienced cooks. This recipe is well-suited for a vegetarian diet, as it contains no gelatin or other animal-derived thickeners. However, those with dairy allergies or lactose intolerance should avoid it due to the butter and condensed milk. With a sweet, melt-in-the-mouth finish, this fudge is an indulgent treat perfect for special occasions or gifting.

name: Spicy squash & apple chutney
description: The sweet flesh of squash or pumpkin takes on a new character as it nestles down in the pan with onion, apple, spices, sugar and vinegar
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 4 tbsp rapeseed, vegetable or sunflower oil
100g piece of ginger, peeled and thinly shredded
1 fat red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
2 long cinnamon sticks, snapped in half
4 fat or 6 smaller garlic cloves, peeled and sliced
1kg butternut squashor pumpkin flesh, peeled and cut into sugar-cube size pieces
3 Bramley apples(about 500g), peeled and cut into sugar-cube size pieces
directions: Heat the oil in a large preserving pan, then gently fry the onions, ginger, chilli, cardamom, cinnamon, mustard and cumin seeds together for 5 mins, until the spices are aromatic.
Stir the garlic, squash and apples into the onions, then cook for 10-15 mins more, until the onions and apples are soft and the squash yields a little here and there.

Stir in the turmeric and sugar and let it melt around the vegetables. Simmer for 5 mins – this process almost candies the chunks of pumpkin, so that it doesn’t entirely break down during the next step.

Pour in the vinegar, season with 2 tsp salt, then bring the chutney back to a simmer. Cook, stirring regularly, for about 30 mins or until the apple has cooked down to make a squishy base for the chutney, with chunks of tender pumpkin here and there, and a little syrupiness at the bottom of the pan – you don’t want the chutney to be too dry as it will thicken as it cools.
Spoon the hot chutney into sterilised jars and seal. The chutney can be eaten straight away, or left to mellow in a dark place. You can store it for up to six months.
chief_review: This recipe is a vibrant celebration of autumnal flavors, blending the earthy sweetness of squash or pumpkin with the tartness of Bramley apples, balanced by warming spices like cardamom, cinnamon, and mustard seeds. The layering of aromatics—ginger, chili, garlic, and onion—creates a complex base, while the addition of cider vinegar and soft brown sugar delivers a delectable sweet-sour contrast reminiscent of classic chutney. The use of plant-based oils and omission of animal products make this dish entirely vegan and vegetarian, ideal for those following plant-based or dairy-free diets. Furthermore, it’s naturally gluten-free, as no wheat or gluten-containing ingredients are used. This versatile accompaniment would pair beautifully with roasted vegetables, cheeses, or cold meats, and promises to enliven any plate with its robust flavors and gently spiced warmth.

name: Winter slaw with warm celery seed dressing
description: This coleslaw uses a vinaigrette instead of mayonnaise to create a super healthy veggie salad dish
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g thick green bean, halved lengthways, then cut in 2
directions: Cook the green beans for 1 min in boiling salted water, then drain and rinse under a cold tap. Place in a large bowl with the cabbage, onion and carrot.
In a small saucepan, bring the dressing ingredients to the boil. Add a pinch of salt, remove from the heat, let cool for 5 mins, then toss with the salad before serving.
chief_review: This vibrant coleslaw offers a refreshing twist by substituting mayonnaise with a light vinaigrette, resulting in a crisp and tangy salad. The combination of cabbage, carrots, green beans, and onion delivers a satisfying crunch and a nutritious boost. The vinaigrette—made from sunflower oil, cider vinegar, wholegrain mustard, and celery seeds—adds depth of flavor without heaviness. The absence of dairy and eggs makes this coleslaw suitable for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Additionally, no gluten-containing ingredients are present, so it fits a gluten-free regimen, provided the mustard is certified gluten-free. Perfect as a side dish or a light lunch, this coleslaw not only delights the palate but also caters to a range of dietary preferences.

name: Prosecco cake
description:
After reading the comment that the cake was bland, I soaked the sponge with a few tbsp of prosecco syrup after cooling it down (boil a half pint of prosecco with ca. 300g sugar and a vanilla pod until thickened, add lemon juice and rose water to taste) and I think that did the trick, the flavour came through nicely. I also left out the sweets for decoration and replaced it with raspberries; you'll need lots of tart berries to balance the mountains of butter cream.
It turned out a very heavy cake. I would make it again, however, I will probably use less butter cream next time and maybe put some lemon in it as well as it's just too much of a good thing.
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 350g unsalted butter, plus a little for the tins
sprinkles, coloured sugar, mini meringues, Prosecco-flavoured sweets, popcorn and lollies
directions: Heat oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3. Butter the inside of 2 deep, loose bottomed 21cm tins. Cream the butter and sugar together with electric beaters until it is light and fluffy, then gradually beat in the eggs a little at a time. Fold in the flour and a pinch of salt, don’t worry if the mixture look like it has split, it will come back together when the flour is added. Pour in the Prosecco and stir until smooth.

Spoon the mixture into the tins, level the top and bake for 45-50 mins or until the cakes are well-risen and golden and a skewer inserted comes out clean. Leave to cool in the tin for 10 minutes and then turn them out onto a rack.
While the cakes cool, make the icing. Beat the butter with the icing sugar until it is smooth. Add the Prosecco and beat again until the frosting is fluffy and smooth.

Level the cakes if you need to and spread the raspberry jam on one of the cakes followed by some of the butter cream, sandwich the other cake on top. Roughly ice the cake all over in a very thin layer with a couple of tablespoons of buttercream, this will help all the crumbs stick to the cake and help make the outer layer of icing nice and clean. Ice the cake all over with the remaining buttercream, this can be quite rough because you are going to stick sweet all over it. Now stick sweets all over it. Go mad. Drink Prosecco with it.
chief_review: This indulgent cake is a showstopper with its prosecco syrup-soaked sponge and generous layers of buttercream. The syrup, enriched with lemon juice and rose water, beautifully lifts the cake’s flavors and keeps the crumb moist, while raspberries bring a welcome tartness that cuts through the sweet, rich buttercream. It’s a decadent bake—perfect for special celebrations—though the quantity of buttercream can overwhelm, so a lighter hand or extra lemon could offer better balance. The recipe contains gluten, dairy, and eggs, making it suitable for those without related allergies. The buttercream mountain, while luxurious, does make for a “heavy” cake, so serve in small slices. This cake is an excellent treat for those seeking a celebratory dessert with vibrant, nuanced flavors, but best enjoyed in moderation.

name: Right-every-time roasties
description: Goose fat, vegetable oil and polenta - the secrets to the perfect roast potatoes every time
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 2kg King Edward potato, or another roasting variety, peeled
directions: Cut the potatoes into quarters, or eighths if really large – you want to end up with even-size 5cm pieces. Put the potatoes in a large pan of salted water and boil for 5 mins, just until the outside of the potato starts to soften. To check, try scraping a potato with a fork – it should be easy to make a mark but you shouldn’t be able to slide it into the flesh. Drain really well.

Return to the pan and scatter over the flour and polenta (if using) and a little salt. Place a lid on top of the pan and give it a couple of good shakes, coating the potatoes in the flour and polenta and lightly crushing the sides.

Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Place the goose fat and oil in a roasting tin large enough to hold all the potatoes in one layer and heat in the oven for 5 mins. Quickly tip the potatoes in and return to the oven. Cook for 30 mins, turning once, then increase the heat to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Cook for 20 mins more or until crisp all over. Sprinkle with a little more salt, then serve.
chief_review:
This roast potato recipe delivers irresistibly crisp exteriors and fluffy, tender centers, thanks to the inspired combination of goose fat and vegetable oil. The inclusion of polenta adds a subtle crunch, elevating this dish above the usual Sunday roast fare. Flour ensures each potato chunk achieves the perfect golden coating. King Edwards, or another starchy roasting potato, absorb the rich fats beautifully while retaining their structure.

This recipe is ideal for those following a gluten-free diet if you swap the plain flour for a gluten-free alternative, and polenta is naturally gluten-free. However, it is not vegetarian or vegan due to the use of goose fat. Perfect for festive occasions or impressing dinner guests, this method guarantees a memorable side dish—the kind that disappears first from the table. A must-try for lovers of classic British roast potatoes with an extra crunch.

name: Potato cakes with smoked salmon & cream cheese
description: I made this for a Christmas party and the finished canapés looked amazing. It was interesting to make the potato farl from scratch, but I'm not convinced I'd bother again and perhaps would just buy some blinis or something similar. I found I needed to whip the cheese mixture for quite a while after the addition of the lemon and cream otherwise it would have been liquid. I thought the cheese ended up a bit too lemony, so if I made it again I'd just put the zest on top and skip the juice.
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 100g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
200g pack smoked salmonslices, cut into strips
directions: Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Prick the potatoes all over with a fork, then bake whole for 1 hr 20 mins or until crisp on the outside and fluffy inside. Set aside on a wire rack to cool. Reduce oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.

Once the potatoes are cool enough to handle, cut in half and scoop out the flesh into a large bowl, discarding the skins. Mash the potato really well, then mix in two-thirds of the melted butter, all the flour and the bicarbonate of soda. Season well.

Line a large (approx 35 x 25cm) baking tray with a piece of baking parchment and brush with half the remaining butter. Roll out the potato dough on a floured surface, then lay it on the lined baking tray – don’t worry if it breaks, just push the pieces back together once on the tray. Brush the dough with the remaining melted butter and bake for 45 mins or until golden brown on the outside.

Remove from the oven and allow to cool on the tray. Meanwhile, put the cream cheese in a large bowl and whisk until smooth and light. Stir in the double cream and lemon juice, and season well with black pepper. Spread the cream cheese mixture all over the surface of the cooled potato cake. Use a large, sharp knife to cut the potato cake into 30 squares, then top with the strips of salmon, the dill fronds, caperberries and lemon zest. Transfer to a serving platter and serve.
chief_review:
This canapé recipe offers an elegant combination of traditional elements with a homemade touch—making potato farl is a pleasant nod to classic technique, though prepared blinis are a worthy timesaver. The filling of whipped cream cheese, double cream, lemon, smoked salmon, dill, and caperberries delivers bright, creamy, and indulgent flavors; however, caution with the lemon juice is advisable to avoid overpowering the dish. Texture is critical—whipping the mixture thoroughly ensures a luxurious finish rather than a runny one. 

The recipe suits pescatarians, as it contains smoked salmon and dairy. It also avoids nuts, so it could be suitable for nut-allergic guests, assuming all packaging is checked for cross-contamination. With its festive flavor profile and impressive presentation, this canapé is a crowd-pleaser for holiday entertaining.

name: Rosti-filled onions
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 large onions, sliced into quarters, keeping root intact
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Place the onions on a baking tray, brush with olive oil, season, then cook for about 1 hr until golden and tender.
Meanwhile, mix the potato and carrot together, then stir in the mustard and seasoning. Divide the mixture between the onions, then dot the top of each one with a little butter.
Return the onions to the oven and cook for 15 mins until they are meltingly tender. Sprinkle with the cheese, then cook for a further 5 mins until the topping is golden and bubbling.
chief_review: This recipe is a delightful celebration of savory flavors and satisfying textures. The use of vegetarian gruyère-style cheese and the absence of meat make it fully suitable for a vegetarian diet. Wholegrain mustard brings an earthy depth to the dish, while grated potatoes and carrots add natural sweetness and a pleasant bite. Olive oil and butter create a rich base for roasting or sautéing the vegetables, and the quartered onions, kept intact at the root, ensure a visually appealing presentation and a gentle, mellow flavor profile. The combination of melty cheese and root vegetables promises a comforting, hearty result. This is an excellent choice for those seeking a nutritious, well-balanced vegetarian main or side, especially when aiming for both hearty sustenance and a flavorful profile in one dish.

name: Spiced prawns with coriander mayo
description: Add a touch of sophistication to your party with these spicy seafood treats
author: Good Food
ingredients: zest and juice 1 lime, plus wedges to serve
about 20 large prawns, shells off but tails still on
vegetable or groundnut oil, for frying
directions: Mix the breadcrumbs, chilli powder, cumin, crushed chillies, if using, and lime zest with ½ tsp salt and lots of black pepper. Spread over a plate. Toss the prawns in the flour, then dip them into the egg and then into the crumbs. Shake off excess crumbs. Can be chilled in one layer for up to one day ahead.

When ready to cook, heat a few centimetres of oil in a large, deep frying pan. The oil is hot enough when a few crumbs tipped into it sizzle and turn brown. Fry the prawns in batches for 2 mins, turning halfway, until the crumbs are crisp and golden all over. Lift them onto kitchen paper to drain (they will keep in a low oven for 15 mins if necessary), then serve on a warm plate, with lime wedges scattered around. Mix the lime juice and coriander into the mayonnaise and serve alongside.
chief_review: These spicy seafood treats offer a delightful fusion of zesty lime, aromatic cumin, and a punch of chilli heat, perfectly complementing the tender prawns. The coating—a mix of seasoned flour, egg, and crispy breadcrumbs—provides a satisfying crunch that contrasts beautifully with the juicy seafood within. A final flourish of fresh coriander and a side of creamy mayonnaise round out the flavors, while lime wedges add brightness. This recipe is ideal for pescatarians and those seeking a standout appetizer for parties or gatherings. Note: Contains shellfish, eggs, and gluten, so it's not suitable for those with related allergies or dietary restrictions. Serve hot for the best flavor and texture.

name: Aubergines filled with spinach & mushrooms
description: A hearty, slow-roasted dish that looks as stunning as it tastes
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Bring a large pan of water to the boil, add the aubergine halves and cook for 4-5 mins. Drain well and pat dry with kitchen paper.

Place the aubergines on a baking tray, brush with 1 tbsp of the olive oil and cook for 20-25 mins until tender and golden. Scoop out the flesh (leaving about 15mm of flesh attached to the skin), then roughly chop.

Meanwhile, heat remaining oil in a large frying pan, then cook the onion and garlic for 4-5 mins until the onion has softened. Add the aubergine flesh to the pan and fry for a few mins, add the mushrooms, then cook for about 5 mins until browned and tender. Add the spinach and cook for 3-4 mins until wilted, stirring frequently.
Remove the pan from the heat and stir in the cheese, fromage frais and seasoning to taste.
In a bowl, mix together the breadcrumbs, lemon zest, pine nuts, parsley and seasoning.
Spoon the spinach mixture into the aubergine halves and sprinkle the top of each with the breadcrumb mixture. Return to the oven and cook for 10-15 mins until the topping is golden.
chief_review:
This slow-roasted aubergine dish is a feast for both the eyes and palate, delivering layers of flavor and texture. The combination of earthy mushrooms and tender spinach mingles perfectly with the creaminess of fromage frais, while the lemon zest and parsley brighten every bite. A topping of vegetarian parmesan, toasted pine nuts, and crisp breadcrumbs brings irresistible contrast and richness.

Beautifully balanced, this recipe is an excellent choice for vegetarians, providing ample protein and nutrients through vegetables, cheese, and nuts. It would also suit those seeking dishes without red meat or fish. The use of vegetarian parmesan and fromage frais ensures the cheese is suitable for a vegetarian diet, making this dish both inclusive and impressive. Serve as a centerpiece or an indulgent side; its hearty character stands on its own.

name: Full English frittata
description: This recipe puts a British spin on the traditional Italian classic, but it's guaranteed to be a winner for brunch
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tsp olive oil, plus extra for greasing
4 leftover roast potatoes, cut into bite-size chunks
4 leftover cooked chipolatas, cut into bite-size portions
fresh breadand brown sauce, to serve
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. First of all, beat the eggs with a whisk in a bowl, then whisk in the soured cream and seasoning. Heat a non-stick pan, add the oil, then fry the bacon and mushrooms until caramelised and cooked through. Towards the end, toss in the leftover sausages and roast potato chunks and allow them to heat up in the pan alongside the bacon and mushrooms.

Tip the contents of the pan into a small, lightly greased roasting tin, then pour over the egg mixture. Bake until the egg has risen slightly and set. Serve with fresh bread and brown sauce (or tomato sauce to add a splash of colour).
chief_review: This inventive recipe delivers a satisfying British twist on the traditional Italian frittata, making it an excellent choice for a hearty brunch. The combination of eggs, soured cream, and olive oil ensures a creamy texture, while the addition of bacon, chipolatas, roast potatoes, and mushrooms brings both flavor and substance. The use of leftover potatoes and sausages not only enhances depth but also adds a practical, resourceful touch. Served with fresh bread and brown sauce, it’s a complete meal with nuanced, savory flavors evocative of a full English breakfast. This dish is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet if you opt for gluten-free bread on the side. It’s also ideal for anyone seeking higher protein content in their meal. Overall, this recipe is a comforting, crowd-pleasing option perfect for brunch gatherings or a weekend treat.

name: Cranberry sunrise
description: The ultimate treat for all the family
author: Good Food
directions: Soak the gelatine leaves in cold water. Drain, squeeze and dissolve the soaked gelatine in the hot water from the kettle. Add to the warm, smooth-style orange juice and set aside. Repeat the process using warm cranberry juice. Pour half of the orange juice into a large jelly mould and chill in the fridge until set completely – about 4 hours. Cover the orange jelly with half the cranberry juice and chill to set. Repeat the process until both juices are used. Leave to set overnight.
chief_review: This vibrant recipe brilliantly blends orange and cranberry juices with gelatine to create a refreshing, crowd-pleasing treat. The use of hot water and warmed juices ensures the gelatine dissolves smoothly, resulting in a beautifully set dessert with a silky texture. Its simple ingredient list means it’s free from common allergens like nuts, dairy, eggs, soy, and gluten, making it an excellent choice for those with food sensitivities. Since it contains no animal-derived fats or flours, it’s also suited to a vegetarian diet, provided the gelatine is plant-based or swapped for a suitable alternative like agar-agar. The natural fruit flavors shine through, delivering a deliciously tangy sweetness perfect for family gatherings. Serve chilled for a delightfully light yet satisfying finish to any meal.

name: Winter leaf & parsnip salad with walnuts
description: John Torode's bitter leaf salad and vinaigrette are a good foil to a creamy tart or rich ham
author: John Torode
ingredients: 3 large heads chicory or radicchio, leaves separated
200g mixed salad leaves, such as baby spinach and watercress
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Toss the parsnips with the oil in a roasting tin, then roast for 20-25 mins until golden and tender. Add the nuts and roast for 15 mins more until the nuts are coloured. Take from the oven and cool. Can be cooked up to 2 days ahead.
Put all the leaves, parsnips and nuts into a large serving bowl.
Make the vinaigrette according to the recipe below and serve on the side – this way your guests can add their own dressing, and your salad won’t go soggy if it’s not eaten straight away.
chief_review: This vibrant salad by John Torode combines earthy roasted parsnips and crunchy walnuts with the bitterness of chicory or radicchio, balanced by fresh spinach and watercress. The interplay of textures and flavors makes it a refreshing companion to rich mains like creamy tart or ham. The use of vegetable oil and absence of animal products means this dish is suitable for vegetarians and can also easily fit into a vegan diet if the vinaigrette is free from honey or dairy. With naturally gluten-free ingredients and no common allergens like eggs or shellfish, its versatility and bold flavors make it a smart, stylish addition to any modern table.

name: Poached pears in spiced red wine
description: A completely fat-free pud that isn't boring. It's not just Good Food, it's genius
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: fresh thyme sprig, plus sprigs to seve
6 pears, peeled, but kept whole with stalk intact
directions: Halve the vanilla pod lengthways, scrape out the black seeds and put in a large saucepan with the wine, sugar, cinnamon and thyme. Cut each piece of pod into three long thin strips, add to pan, then lower in the pears.

Poach the pears, covered, for 20-30 mins, making sure they are covered in the wine. The cooking time will very much depend on the ripeness of your pears – they should be tender all the way through when pierced with a cocktail stick. You can make these up to 2 days ahead and chill.
Take the pears from the pan, then boil the liquid to reduce it by half so that it’s syrupy. Serve each pear with the cooled syrup, a strip of vanilla, a piece of cinnamon and a small thyme sprig.
chief_review: This recipe transforms humble pears into an elegant dessert, beautifully poached in a spiced red wine syrup infused with vanilla and thyme. The absence of fats, dairy, and animal products makes it an excellent choice for both vegan and vegetarian diets. Its reliance on simple, fresh ingredients caters well to those seeking a light, guilt-free treat, while also accommodating anyone with dairy or egg allergies. The combination of cinnamon, vanilla, and thyme provides depth and complexity, lifting the natural sweetness of the pears. Serve with a sprig of thyme for an aromatic finish—perfect for dinner parties or a refined end to a meal.

name: Turkish-style sharing bread
author: Miriam Nice
ingredients: 1 red onion, cut into thin rings
directions: Make the ciabatta bread dough following pack instructions. Once it has risen, knock it back by punching some of the air out and kneading it a little. Roll into an oval shape (approx 35 x 25cm) and place on a large baking tray. Lightly brush the whole surface with olive oil and cover with cling film. Leave to prove for 30 mins while you make the topping.

Put all the topping ingredients, except the lamb, in a small food processor and blitz until finely chopped. Tip into a large bowl, mix in the lamb, season well, then squish everything together with your hands until thoroughly mixed. Chill until needed.
Heat oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. In a small saucepan, heat the red onion rings with the vinegar and 1 tbsp water until really soft, then leave to cool.

Dot the surface of the dough with the lamb topping – gently press it down with your fingers to spread it evenly over the surface, but try not to press too much air out of the dough. Bake in the oven for 15-20 mins or until the base is risen and golden, and the meat is cooked through and caramelised at the edges.
Meanwhile, make the dressing. Stir together the baba ganoush, lemon juice and olive oil, then pop in the fridge until serving.

Once the bread is baked, transfer to a wooden board. Drain the onions in a metal sieve and scatter over the bread. Drizzle over the baba ganoush dressing, leaving some on the side as a dip, then sprinkle over the pine nuts and parsley. Serve warm.
chief_review:
