This recipe brings together Middle Eastern flavors with tender lamb, aromatic spices, and a lovely finish of baba ganoush and pine nuts. The use of a ciabatta bread mix as the base provides a hearty, rustic touch, complemented by the smokiness of baba ganoush and the tangy brightness from lemon and pickled red onion. Fresh parsley adds a delightful herbal note, while sundried tomato paste intensifies the umami. The spiced lamb mince is perfectly balanced by the sweetness of cinnamon and the earthy cumin.

Ideal for those following a Mediterranean-inspired diet, this dish offers a satisfying blend of protein, healthy fats, and vibrant vegetables. However, it does contain gluten (from the ciabatta), nuts, and animal products, so keep this in mind when considering dietary preferences. Overall, a flavorful, well-balanced recipe that will impress with its depth and authenticity.

name: Really easy cinnamon rolls
author: Lulu Grimes
ingredients: 350g can ready-made croissant dough(we used Jus Rol)
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Line a 23cm cake tin with a square of baking parchment so the corners stick up (this will help you to lift the rolls out).
Unroll the croissant dough from the can and lay it out on your work surface. Cut it into three sections along the dotted lines, but don’t cut the diagonal line. Spread over a quarter of the butter.

Mix the cinnamon and sugar together. Using one square of dough at a time, sprinkle over 2-3 tsp of the sugar and roll up the dough. When you have three rolls, cut each one in half and then each half into three. Arrange the rolls in the tin in two circles – you need to spread them well apart as they will rise and spread. Stick the end bits in among fatter pieces from the centre of the rolls so they cook evenly. Bake for 15 mins or until the rolls are risen and cooked through.

Meanwhile, heat the remaining sugar mix with the remaining butter until you have a thick caramel (don’t worry if some of the butter separates out, it will soak into the dough). When the rolls are cooked, pour over the caramel. Leave to cool a little, then eat warm.
chief_review: This recipe showcases an indulgent, buttery treat reminiscent of a classic cinnamon roll, utilizing convenient ready-made croissant dough. The combination of soft light brown sugar and cinnamon, melded with the richness of unsalted butter, promises a sweet, aromatic pastry with a tender crumb and flaky layers. Thanks to the absence of eggs and direct dairy (apart from butter), this creation is suitable for vegetarians. Be mindful that store-bought croissant dough typically contains gluten and dairy, so it is not fit for gluten-free or vegan diets. The recipe’s straightforward approach and humble ingredient list make it perfect for a quick breakfast or an elegant brunch addition, providing both impressive flavor and appealing presentation without demanding excessive preparation time.

name: Roasted winter vegetables with smoked mayo
author: Diana Henry
ingredients: 500g beetroot(mixed colours if you can get them), small if possible
2 tbsp lemon juice(you may not need all of it)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Give the whole beets a really good scrub, and cut off the tufty tails, if they have any. Scrub the carrots and halve them lengthways if they’re fat. Wash the Jerusalem artichokes well (there’s no need to peel them).

Put the beets in a roasting tin and put the carrots in another (it’s best to cook them separately as their crimson juice can start to bleed). Toss the beets and carrots in a little oil and seasoning before roasting for 15 mins. Halve the artichokes lengthways, then add them to the roasting tin with the carrots, tossing them in the oil, then cook all the veg for a further 30 mins until tender – it may take a little longer, depending on the thickness of the carrots and the size of the beets.
Meanwhile, make the smoked mayo. Put the egg yolks in the bowl of a

with the mustard, garlic and a little seasoning. Turn it on and slowly add the oil (make sure the mixture is thickening and the oil is incorporated), until all the oil has been added and your mixture is thick. Add the lemon juice and adjust the seasoning to taste. If your mayo is too thick, add a splash of water.
Allow the beets to cool a little, then peel – the skins should just slip off – and cut them into pieces if you like. Put all the vegetables on a platter, and serve with the smoked mayo on the side.
chief_review: A vibrant medley of root vegetables—beetroot, carrots, and Jerusalem artichokes—takes center stage in this roasted dish, offering earthy sweetness and depth. Roasting with olive oil enhances their natural flavors while achieving a pleasing caramelization. The smoked rapeseed oil brings a subtle smokiness to the homemade mayonnaise, lifted by a touch of lemon juice, English mustard, and grated garlic. This sauce is delightfully creamy thanks to the egg yolks and pairs perfectly with the roasted vegetables. The recipe is well-suited to vegetarian diets and is naturally gluten-free, making it an inclusive option for many. With its colorful presentation and harmonious balance of savory, smoky, and fresh flavors, this dish would grace any festive table or be enjoyed as a standout vegetarian main course.

name: Cranberry-pistachio brownies
description: Moist, fruity and nutty - what more could you want from a brownie? Ready in under an hour
author: Good Food
ingredients: 200g butter, diced, plus extra for greasing
2 x 150g bars plain chocolate (about 40% cocoa solids is fine)
directions: Heat the oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Butter a non-stick baking tin (about 31 x 17 x 3.5cm) or line the base if you prefer. Break the chocolate into a saucepan, add the butter, sugar and juice or milk, then warm gently, stirring frequently until melted and evenly mixed. Allow to cool slightly, then beat in the eggs one at a time. Fold in the flour, cinnamon and cranberries.

Spread half the mixture into the prepared tin, scatter over the nuts, then gently spread the rest of the mixture on top. Bake for 25-30 mins. Cut into squares while still warm. Will keep in an airtight container for up to a week.
chief_review: This brownie recipe offers a delightful twist on the classic with the addition of tart dried cranberries and crunchy pistachios, delivering a lovely balance of flavors and textures. The use of muscovado sugar imparts a subtle caramel note, while a hint of cinnamon adds warmth. The brownies come together easily in under an hour, making them ideal for a quick yet impressive dessert. While the recipe does include dairy, eggs, wheat flour, and nuts, it's perfectly suited for those following a vegetarian diet. The optional icing sugar dusting provides a beautiful finish without overpowering the treat's natural flavors. Serve these brownies slightly warm for maximum enjoyment—an excellent bake for festive occasions or casual gatherings alike.

name: Apricot pancakes with honey butter
description: Perfect pancakes for a leisurely brunch and healthier than most bought versions
author: Good Food
ingredients: handful ready-to-eat dried apricots, finely chopped
directions: For the honey butter, beat the butter with the honey and spoon onto a large piece of cling film. Squeeze into a sausage shape, then wrap tightly and chill until ready to use. Will keep in the fridge for up to a month.

Sift the flour, bicarbonate of soda and a small pinch of salt into a bowl, then stir through the sugar and make a well in the centre. Beat together the egg and milk, then gradually pour into the well, stirring slowly, to avoid creating lumps. Stir in the apricots.

Heat a non-stick frying pan over a low heat and add a little oil. Drop in 4 tablespoonfuls of batter and cook for 1 min or until the surface of each pancake is covered in bubbles. Flip with a palette knife or fish slice, then cook for a further min. Repeat with the remaining batter. Serve warm or leave to cool, then toast and spread with the honey butter to serve
chief_review: These pancakes strike a satisfying balance between indulgence and a nod toward wholesomeness, making them a solid brunch option. The use of self-raising flour and bicarbonate of soda creates a reliably fluffy texture, while the honey and dried apricots lend natural sweetness and nuanced flavor—an elegant touch over plain sugar. With butter and a solitary egg, the recipe maintains richness without excess. Those seeking nut-free, vegetarian options will appreciate that the ingredients steer clear of animal rennet, nuts, and meat. For a lighter touch, you could consider reducing the butter or swapping in low-fat milk. Ideal for a weekend treat or a crowd-pleasing breakfast, these pancakes deliver both comfort and a subtle fruitiness without feeling overly decadent.

name: Stuffed mushroom bruschettas
description: The big mushrooms cook to a moist meatiness under their cloak of peppers and melting goat’s cheese, a veggie dish anyone will enjoy.
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 4 thick slices country-style loaves, white or brown
2 x 20g/1oz tubs garlic butter or 50g/2oz softened butter beaten with 1 chopped clove of garlic
200g jar roasted red peppers, either strips in oil or whole peppers in brine
directions: Preheat the oven to 190C/Gas 5/170C fan. Spread both sides of each slice of bread with garlic butter (no need to remove the crusts). Put the bread slices in one layer on a baking sheet. Put a mushroom on top of each and drizzle with a little olive oil. Sprinkle with salt and pepper.

Drain the peppers, slice if necessary, and divide between the mushrooms. Cut the goat’s cheese into four slices and put one slice on top of each stack. Bake for 25-30 minutes, until the mushrooms are cooked and the cheese golden. Serve with a mixed salad.
chief_review: This hearty mushroom dish is an inspired vegetarian option, combining meaty portobellos, sweet roasted peppers, and creamy goat’s cheese atop rustic garlic bread. The flavors meld beautifully—the mushrooms soak up garlicky richness and the cheese adds tangy depth, offset by the smoky peppers. Perfect for a satisfying lunch or lighter main, this recipe caters especially well to lacto-ovo vegetarians. Be mindful, as it contains dairy and gluten, so it isn’t suitable for those with lactose intolerance, dairy or gluten allergies. The preparation is straightforward, while the result is robust, savory, and wholly comforting. A great centerpiece for a vegetarian meal or elegant brunch.

name: Mustard-buttered chicken with tarragon, peas & carrots
description: An all-in-one roast that is ready in less than two hours. Roast two birds at once for a simple dinner party, or better still, great sandwiches the next day
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: whole garlic bulb, cut across the middle
small handful each chopped tarragon and parsley
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Beat the mustard and butter together, then season well. Put the chickens into a large roasting tin; then, starting at the neck end, pull the skin away from the breast and thigh meat with your fingers. Stuff the butter under the skin, saving 1 tbsp for later. Put half the garlic bulb into each cavity. Season generously, cover with foil, then roast for 1 hr, uncovering for the final 20 mins, until crisp and golden.

Lift the birds onto a board, then sit the pan on the hob and splash in the wine. Reduce for 5 mins, scraping up the meaty bits with a wooden spoon, then add the stock and bring to a simmer. Tip in the carrots, cover with a sheet of foil, then cook for 5 mins. You can do this ahead of time. Add the peas and simmer for a few mins until tender. Just before serving, whisk in the reserved mustard butter, chopped herbs and any resting juices, then season to taste. If you like, transfer everything to a platter and bring to the table – or simply return the chickens to the roasting pan.
chief_review: This all-in-one roast presents a beautifully orchestrated classic centerpiece, perfect for effortless entertaining or meal prepping. The use of two whole chickens ensures abundance, while the blend of Dijon mustard, softened butter, and fresh herbs elevates the flavor profile to a refined standard. Roasting alongside Chantenay carrots infuses the dish with natural sweetness and complementary texture. The addition of white wine and chicken stock creates a luscious, aromatic jus that ties everything together. This recipe is well-suited to a gluten-free diet, provided the stock and mustard are verified gluten-free. With a short, focused ingredient list and straightforward technique, this is a reliable and impressive option for any gathering.

name: Exotic avocado salad
description: my guests loved this!
author: Good Food
directions: Dry-fry the pumpkin seeds in a frying pan for a few minutes, tossing and turning them until they look toasted. Tip them out of the pan and let them go cold. Peel the papayas, halve them lengthways and scoop out the seeds. Cut the flesh into long, thin slices. Halve the avocados and remove the stones, then peel off the skin and slice the flesh lengthways into thin slices.
Put the papayas, avocados, pumpkin seeds and watercress into a large bowl. Chop about 1 tbsp of the mint leaves and set aside. Pick the remaining leaves from the stalks and tear them into the bowl.

Mix the lime juice and olive oil with the rest of the chopped mint to make a dressing, and season with salt and pepper to taste. Pour over the salad and gently mix all the ingredients together with your hands. Taste and add more salt and pepper if you think it needs it, then transfer to a serving platter.
chief_review:
This refreshing salad bursts with nutritious, vibrant flavors, making it a delightful option for warm-weather entertaining. The juicy sweetness of ripe papaya pairs elegantly with creamy avocado, while crunchy pumpkin seeds add texture and a nutty undertone. Peppery watercress and aromatic fresh mint keep the dish lively and well-balanced. The simple lime and olive oil dressing lets the ingredients shine, adding just the right zing.

This recipe is particularly suitable for vegan and vegetarian diets, as it contains no animal products. It's also naturally gluten-free, dairy-free, and nut-free (aside from the pumpkin seeds, which are generally safe for those with tree nut allergies). With its allergen-friendly profile and minimal ingredients, this salad is both easy to prepare and impressive on the table—a true crowd-pleaser for a variety of guests.

name: Honey-roast carrots
description: Slightly sticky yet succulent and sweet, honey and carrots are a classic combination that will never go out of style
author: Lesley Waters
ingredients: 1kg Chantenay carrot, or large carrots, cut into big chunks
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C/gas 6. Boil carrots for 5 mins till almost cooked, drain and cool. Mix the rest of the ingredients in a small roasting tray, tip in carrots, season and roast for 20 mins until cooked, but still with a little bite.
chief_review: This recipe beautifully showcases the natural sweetness of Chantenay or large carrots, enhanced by a glossy honey glaze and the bright acidity of fresh orange juice. Roasting with olive oil brings out the carrots’ earthiness, creating a tantalizing side dish with balanced flavor and a hint of zest. The methodology is simple yet effective, allowing the ingredients to shine. Suitable for vegetarians, this dish is also friendly for those seeking gluten-free options, as it contains no wheat or gluten-based additives. The finished carrots are vibrant, fragrant, and perfectly tender—an elegant complement to a variety of mains or a star on a vegetable-focused table.

name: Rare beef with mustard Yorkshires
description: Roast beef is always an impressive dish to bring to the table, make it extra special with Sara Buenfeld's recipe
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2.7kg rib of beef (mine was a large 2-rib), French trimmed and at room temperature
12-16 potatoes, peeled and halved, or quartered
2 large eggs and 1 large egg white
goose fat (from a can) or sunflower oil
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Using a large pestle and mortar, grind the garlic, thyme, peppercorns, mustard, anchovies and olive oil to a paste. Rub the mixture all over the beef and put in a large roasting tin. Roast for 25 mins, then turn down the oven to 160C/fan 140C/gas 3. Remove the pan from the oven, add the potatoes and toss in the fat, adding 4 tbsp sunflower oil. Return to the oven for another 90 mins for rare; 2 hrs for medium rare.

Meanwhile, make the Yorkshires. Make the milk up to 225ml/8fl oz with water. Beat the eggs, egg white, mustard and milk together, then gradually add the flour and ¼ tsp salt – the batter should be the consistency of thin double cream. Pour into a jug. Take the meat out of the oven, cover and leave to rest, then turn the oven up to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7.

Put 1 tbsp goose fat or oil in each of 8 large Yorkshire pudding tins and heat for 15 mins in the oven, with the potatoes on a lower shelf. Pour the batter into the tins, then cook for 15-20 mins, without opening the oven, until risen and golden. Serve with horseradish, gravy and your favourite veg.
chief_review:
Sara Buenfeld’s roast beef recipe is a masterclass in classic British cuisine, pairing perfectly seasoned, succulent rib of beef with crispy roast potatoes and Yorkshire puddings. The marinade of lemon thyme, garlic, anchovies, black peppercorns, and mustard delivers deep, aromatic flavors that enhance the meat without overpowering its natural richness. Anchovies provide a wonderful umami depth, blending seamlessly with the robust beef. The use of goose fat infuses the potatoes and Yorkshire puddings with an irresistible crunch and a savory richness that elevates this meal to celebration status.

This recipe is suitable for a gluten-free diet if the plain flour is substituted with a gluten-free alternative. It’s ideal for those who eat eggs and dairy, as the Yorkshire puddings rely on these ingredients for their airy texture. Designed for a grand occasion, it’s a sensational showpiece for family feasts or special gatherings.

name: Easy coq au vin
description: Didn't look like the picture at all but it was delicious!
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 1 x 1.3kg organic chicken, jointed into 8 (see steps and directions)
250g smoked streaky bacon, cut in pieces
2 leeks, trimmed, washed and roughly chopped
1 bottle red wine, preferably from Burgundy
250g fresh cep mushroom or large chestnut mushrooms, trimmed and thickly sliced
directions: Joint the chicken (for pictures of jointing, click on step by step link above or read the instructions below. Alternatively, ask the butcher to do it for you).

JOINTING THE CHICKEN: Pull out the wing joints and cut off the wing tip. Using a small knife, cut around the skin and flesh on the lower wing joint through to the bone, then scrape back the flesh. Using a heavier large knife, smash through the bone halfway along and detach. Repeat on the other side.

Detach the scaly leg bone at the drumstick with a hefty thump of the large knife. Slash through skin where the thigh joins the body and pull leg firmly from socket to dislocate the thigh bone. Press down and pull to expose the 'oyster' muscle underneath the bird. Slice the thigh away from the back of the body.
Lay the whole leg joint out on the board, find the mid-point socket joint and simply cut straight through it for neat thigh and leg joints. Repeat on the other side.
Cut through the skin and flesh halfway along to the drumstick and scrape back the flesh, then smash through the bone.

Using poultry scissors or heavy kitchen scissors, cut away the back half of the breast carcass, to leave a 'crown' of chicken breast and wing joint. Cut through the top of the crown to divide in half for two chicken breasts.
Lay each breast joint on the board, then cut in half again at right angles so you have one portion with a wing joint and one without. You should now have eight neat, joints of chicken.
Put the flour into a bowl with some salt and pepper, then toss in the chicken, shaking off the excess. Place the chicken on a plate and season again.

Heat 4 tbsp of oil in a large shallow pan and brown the chicken joints. (Do this in batches if your pan is not large enough, adding extra oil if necessary.) Tip the bacon into the pan along with the chicken, stirring until lightly browned and crisp. Using tongs, remove the chicken to a plate.

Add all the vegetables and herbs to the bacon with a splash more oil, if necessary, then cook for about 5 mins, stirring once or twice. Pour in the Cognac and bubble up, scraping the pan to deglaze, for 2-3 mins. Then pour in all the wine and bring to the boil.

Tip in the chicken joints; press into the pan so they are immersed in liquid and cook, uncovered, for 10 mins, until the wine has reduced by half. Pour in the stock, return to a simmer, season and cook, uncovered, for 1 hr until the liquid has reduced by half and the chicken is tender. Set aside for 10 mins before serving.

Heat another 4 tbsp oil in a large frying pan and, when hot, fry the mushrooms for about 8 mins, seasoning well and stirring frequently until nicely browned. Remove and drain on kitchen paper. Serve the chicken in bowls with vegetables and sauce spooned over, and top with the mushrooms.
chief_review:
This recipe delivers a comforting, rustic dish brimming with deep flavors and hearty textures. The combination of jointed chicken, smoky bacon, and a robust red wine sauce creates a rich and satisfying base. Fresh herbs like rosemary and thyme add aromatic complexity, while a medley of carrots, leeks, shallots, and mushrooms contribute natural sweetness and earthiness. The use of Cognac further enhances the sauce, offering a well-rounded finish.

This dish is well suited for those following a traditional omnivore diet and would be an excellent centerpiece for a cozy gathering or Sunday roast. However, it contains flour and smoked bacon, so while it's not gluten-free or vegetarian, it remains a classic, homestyle recipe rooted in French tradition. Expect deep comfort, vibrant flavors, and an impressive crowd-pleaser, even if the appearance doesn’t match the photo.

name: Partridge with wine & cinnamon
description: Partridge packs plenty of game flavour for its size and is perfect matched with these robust flavours
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for drizzling
2 oven-ready partridge, washed and patted dry
1 tsp concentrated chicken stock, such as Knorr Touch of Taste
directions: Heat the oil in a large deep frying pan and quickly brown the partridges all over, then remove. Add the garlic and fry until softened. Pour in the wine, bubble over a high heat, then add tomato purée, honey, stock, olives, cinnamon and seasoning, plus 150ml water. Return the birds to the pan, then cover and simmer over a low heat for 20 mins.
Stir in the rest of the ingredients (plus water if needed). Cover and simmer for 20 mins until tender. Sprinkle with parsley. Serve with toasts.
chief_review: This partridge recipe is a delightful showcase of game, pairing the bird’s robust flavor with Mediterranean elements like kalamata olives, cherry tomatoes, and a touch of cinnamon. The balance of honey and tomato purée lends sweetness and acidity, while the white wine and concentrated chicken stock enrich the sauce, creating depth and complexity. Garlic enhances the savoriness, and a finishing drizzle of olive oil brings it all together. This dish is most suitable for those following a gluten-free diet (provided the stock is gluten-free), making it a great option for anyone avoiding wheat. The combination of ingredients is sophisticated yet approachable, making it ideal for an impressive dinner that doesn’t compromise on comfort or rustic charm. A well-executed celebration of game that stands out for its thoughtful use of flavor contrasts.

name: Bresaola with rocket & artichokes
description: Produce a delicious bresaola starter to entertain friends in ten minutes
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 50g parmesan shavings, bought or shave your own
virgin or extra-virgin olive oil for drizzling
directions: Be a clever cheat and save time by picking up most of the ingredients at the deli counter or the chiller cabinet.

Arrange the bresaola slices on 4 large plates. Toss the rocket with the vinegar and pile in the centre of each plate. Tuck in 3 artichoke halves per portion, generously top with Parmesan shavings and finish with a drizzle of oil.
chief_review: This bresaola starter is a masterclass in simplicity and flavor, balancing salty cured meat with the peppery freshness of rocket and the richness of parmesan. The artichoke hearts introduce a pleasing tang, while a splash of balsamic vinegar and a drizzle of quality olive oil tie the elements together. The dish is executed in just ten minutes, making it perfect for last-minute entertaining. This recipe, focusing on high-protein and low-carb ingredients, suits a gluten-free diet as there are no grains or flours involved. Additionally, it’s well-suited to lactose-sensitive diners, provided parmesan is tolerated. For best results, use paper-thin slices of bresaola (or prosciutto) and shave your own parmesan over the top for extra aroma. Serve chilled, and let the quality ingredients speak for themselves—effortless, elegant, and sure to impress.

name: Blanquette of veal
description: From Gordon Ramsay, a blanquette is a stew made with pale-coloured meats which are not fried first
author: Gordon Ramsay
ingredients: 1l veal stock (see goes well with for recipe)
1kg boneless shoulder or back rib of veal
300g button mushroom, trimmed and halved if large
25g butter, plus a little knob extra for the pasta
large bunch flatleaf parsley, stalks trimmed, leaves roughly chopped
grated zest and juice ½ lemon
directions: Pour the stock and wine into a large saucepan, then add all the vegetables except the mushrooms. Add the garlic and rosemary and bring to the boil, then simmer, uncovered, for 10 mins.

Trim veal of any excess fat and cut into large bite-size cubes. Add to pan with the mushrooms. Return to a simmer, season well, then cook for 20 mins until meat is just tender; allow longer if it’s not. The stew can be cooled and chilled or frozen at this stage.

When ready to serve, beat together the yolks and cream. Return the stew to a simmer, stir in the horseradish or mustard, briskly mix in yolks and cream, then stir until it starts to thicken slightly. Take care not to overheat or the mixture will curdle. Stir in the butter, remove pan from the heat, then mix in the parsley, lemon zest and juice. Check the seasoning again.

Meanwhile, boil tagliatelle according to pack instructions – about 3 mins for fresh pasta, up to 10 mins for dried. Drain and toss with a little butter. Make into a ‘barrel’ of pasta (see above right) or simply divide between six warmed plates. Spoon the Blanquette of veal on top and serve.

Make a 'barrel' of tagliatelle Gordon's way: Pick up a few strands of pasta, digging a carving fork into the pot 3-4 times. Lift up the pasta so the strands hang free and press against the side of the pan. Then, holding with your (clean) fingers, start to twist the pasta into a barrel shape, pushing back against the pan side once or twice to neaten. When all the strands are wound, up-end the fork intothe centre of a plate and gently push the pasta off.
chief_review: This classic veal blanquette delivers an elegant French stew with delicately simmered veal, paired with earthy mushrooms, aromatic leeks, and a creamy white wine sauce. The use of double cream and egg yolks imparts a luxurious richness, while the horseradish or mustard adds a subtle tang that lifts the dish. Fresh tagliatelle makes an ideal accompaniment, soaking up the velvety sauce. The blanquette’s flavor profile is sophisticated yet comforting—perfect for a refined dinner. With its focus on veal and dairy, this recipe is best suited for those following a standard omnivorous diet, though its absence of nuts may appeal to those with nut allergies (verify all ingredient sources for allergens). The methodical layering of flavors pays homage to classic French technique, making this dish a delightful showcase of traditional culinary finesse.

name: Pecan toffee meringue with mulled pears
description: A great dinner party centre piece you can make ahead
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 600ml mulled wine, ready made from a bottle
6 small, ripe, shapely pears, peeled, quartered and cored
4 tbsp dulce de leche (we used Merchant Gourmet)
directions: Put the wine, pears and sugar in a pan and simmer for 10 mins.

Heat oven to 160C/140C/gas 3. Draw a 25cm circle on a sheet of baking parchment, then put on a baking sheet. Stir 225g sugar and cornflour together in a jug. Whisk the egg whites until stiff, then whisk in the sugar mixture, a tbsp at a time, until thick and glossy.

Fold in vinegar and half the nuts, then pile mixture onto the circle, building up the edges to make a ‘nest’. Scatter with rest of pecans then put in oven, turning the temperature down to 150C/fan 130C/gas 2. Bake for 1 hr, then turn oven off and cool inside for 1 hr.
chief_review: This show-stopping centerpiece is ideal for impressing dinner guests with minimal last-minute fuss. The mulled wine-poached pears infuse festive warmth, while the cloud-like meringue—enhanced by a hint of pecan—brings a delightful crunch and contrast. Greek yogurt offers a refreshing tang that cuts through the sweetness, while the luscious swirl of dulce de leche adds an extra layer of luxurious caramel flavor. The use of cornflour in the meringue helps create its signature chewy-in-the-middle texture. As the recipe is free from gluten-containing ingredients, it’s a wonderful dessert option for those following a gluten-free diet—though always ensure each packaged product specifies gluten-free. Nut lovers will appreciate the pecans, but those with allergies should be cautious. This elegant, make-ahead dessert combines texture, flavor, and presentation beautifully—perfect for holiday gatherings or special occasions.

name: Potato, parsnip & horseradish baked rosti
description: A trio of winter vegetables that are the perfect accompaniment to a meal.
author: Good Food
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Cut the potatoes and parsnips into matchsticks or grate them coarsely and place in a large bowl. Stir in the onion, creamed horseradish, chives and yogurt and mix until well combined. Season to taste.

Arrange the vegetable mixture in a 20cm shallow metal tin, cover with foil and bake for 1 hr. Remove the foil, dot the top with the butter and bake, uncovered, for a further 15 mins until the vegetables are tender and the top is crispy and golden. Serve hot.
chief_review: This winter vegetable trio is a delightful, comforting side dish that offers a balance of earthiness from potato and parsnip, sweetness from onion, and a gentle heat from creamed horseradish. The Greek yogurt adds a creamy tang that lightens the vegetables, while fresh chive elevates with herbal notes. The butter enriches the dish without overpowering the natural flavors. This recipe is suitable for vegetarians, and the use of Greek yogurt and butter ensures a luscious, satisfying mouthfeel without becoming too heavy. It pairs beautifully with a variety of main courses and is especially ideal for colder months when root vegetables are at their peak.

name: Toffee fig pies
description: Figs are delicious when in season and this easy recipe gives them a lovely sweet edge. Perfect with a touch of cream.
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 egg, beaten with a little milk
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Roll the pastry out thinly on a floured surface. Cut out 6 circles using a small saucer (about 11-12cm diameter) and 6 circles about half the size.

Cut the tops off the figs, squash them down gently with your hands and push a toffee into the centre of each fig. Place a fig in the middle of each large circle of pastry and brush the egg around the pastry border. Brush the top of the fig with a little egg and cover with the smaller circle of pastry. Pull the edges of the larger circle up and pinch to seal them over the fig to make a sort of purse. Place the little pies on a baking sheet. The pies can be prepared up to a day ahead and kept covered in the fridge or frozen for up to a month.

Brush with the egg and scatter over the sugar. Bake the pies for 30-40 mins until golden and sticky. Leave to cool for 10 mins and serve hot, so when you break into them you get a pool of toffee fig sauce - perfect with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
chief_review: This fig tart recipe is a celebration of seasonal produce, balancing the natural sweetness of fresh figs with the rich caramel notes of hard toffees. The shortcrust pastry bakes up crisp and buttery, creating a perfect contrast to the soft, almost jammy fruit. Brushing the pastry with egg and milk gives the crust a beautiful golden finish, with a final sprinkle of caster sugar adding delightful crunch. Serving with vanilla ice cream rounds out each bite with cool creaminess. This dessert suits vegetarian diets and is a crowd-pleaser for gatherings—simple to prepare yet elegant enough for special occasions.

name: Grilled duck breast with minted peas
description: A quick and utterly delicious version of a classic partnership, grilled duck breast with minted peas
author: Geraldene Holt
ingredients: 250g shelled garden pea, about 800g/1lb 12oz in their pods
2 ducks breasts, ideally Barbary or Gressingham
dried herbes de Provence or dried thyme or oregano
directions: Shell the peas and set aside. Chop the mint and blend into the butter. Pat the duck dry with kitchen paper and place on the oiled rack of a grill pan (or place a small cake rack in a roasting pan). Use a long sharp knife to score the skin of the duck in a diamond lattice pattern. Sprinkle the skin with salt and dried herbs. (If you wish, the duck, peas and mint butter can now be covered and set aside in a cool place for a couple of hours until ready to cook).

Preheat the grill to very hot. Grill the duck breasts skin-side up for 10 minutes (watch carefully as you do this because the hot fat can splatter) until the skin is browning and has yielded most of its fat – carefully pour this off and reserve for roasting potatoes. Turn the duck over and grill on the flesh side for 5-10 minutes, depending on how rare you like the meat. Turn off the heat and allow the duck to rest while you prepare the peas.

Cook the peas in boiling salted water for 3-5 minutes or until the peas are just tender and still bright green. Drain in a colander and return to the hot pan with the mint butter. Toss the peas until evenly coated with the butter.
Serve the duck breasts whole or sliced with the minted peas, accompanied by buttered new potatoes.
chief_review:
This recipe for grilled duck breast with minted peas is a refined yet approachable dish that celebrates classic flavor pairings. The richness of the duck breast, enhanced by aromatic herbs and a quick grill, is beautifully offset by the freshness of minted garden peas. The peas, quickly blanched and finished with butter and mint, provide a sweet, vibrant contrast and a hint of spring. Buttered new potatoes round out the plate, offering a mellow base for the bold flavors. 

With its focus on vegetables and herbs alongside high-quality duck, this dish fits well into a gluten-free diet, so long as care is taken to ensure contamination-free sides. It’s a perfect seasonal main course for anyone seeking a luxurious yet simple dining experience.

name: One-pan English breakfast
description: This combines all the best ingredients of a traditional English breakfast in one frying pan, with no need to chop anything
author: Good Food
directions: Heat the grill to high. Heat a medium non-stick frying pan, add the chipolatas and fry for 3 mins. Add the bacon, turning occasionally, until it starts to crisp, about 5 mins more. Tip in the mushrooms and continue to cook for a further 3-5 mins. Drain any excess fat and move the ingredients so they are evenly spread out.

Season the eggs, then add to the pan, swirling to fill the spaces. Gently move with a fork for 2 mins over a low-medium heat until beginning to set. Scatter over the tomatoes, cheese, if using, and chives, then grill for 2 mins until set. Cut into wedges and serve with your favourite sauces.
chief_review: This skillet English breakfast is a clever, fuss-free take on the classic fry-up, delivering all the essential flavors in one pan. The use of whole ingredients—chipolatas, smoky back bacon, button mushrooms, halved cherry tomatoes—gives a rustic, hearty texture, while the beaten eggs bring it all together into a rich, satisfying dish. The optional cheese adds a creamy note, and chives contribute a fresh, herbal finish. This recipe is well-suited to a low-carb or keto diet, thanks to its high protein and fat content and minimal carbohydrate sources. It also works well for a grain-free approach. The lack of bread or potatoes keeps things lighter yet still filling, making it perfect for a leisurely weekend brunch.

name: Warm stuffed avocados
description: Fresh flavours make a great alternative to salad as a starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 4 sundried tomatoes in oil, drained and chopped
2 spring onions, finely sliced on the diagonal
1 tbsp each freshly squeezed orange, lemon and lime juice
directions: Heat grill to hot. Halve the avocados and discard the stones. Brush each half with ½ tsp of the olive oil and arrange on a baking sheet. Grill for 5 mins.
In a small bowl, toss together all of the remaining ingredients. Season to taste, then divide between the hollows of each avocado. Serve immediately.
chief_review:
This vibrant dish is a refreshing alternative to a traditional salad, featuring creamy avocado paired with the tangy brightness of citrus juices and cider vinegar. The mix of plum and sundried tomatoes adds both sweetness and umami depth, complemented by briny black olives, capers, and the gentle bite of spring onions. Fresh basil provides an aromatic finish, while a touch of caster sugar brings all the flavors together. 

With entirely plant-based ingredients, this recipe is ideal for vegan and vegetarian diets. It is naturally gluten-free, making it suitable for those with gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. The absence of common allergens like nuts and dairy further broadens its versatility. It’s a wonderfully light, zesty starter, perfect for a summer menu or as an elegant first course at any gathering.

name: Lemony potato gratin
description: Dauphinoise can be a bit rich, so make it lighter by mixing stock with cream. It's just as creamy and indulgent, but a little less heavy.
author: James Martin
ingredients: 200ml vegetable or chicken stock(or gluten-free alternative)
1¼kg potato, peeled and very thinly sliced
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the lemon zest, thyme, nutmeg, cream, stock and plenty of seasoning into a large saucepan and bring to a simmer. Add the potatoes, stir well, and cook gently for 8 mins until beginning to soften, stirring every so often so they don’t stick.

Grease a medium casserole dish using a little of the butter. Spoon the potatoes and creamy liquid into the dish and dot the remaining butter over the surface. Cover with foil and bake for 30 mins. Remove the foil and return to the oven for a further 30-40 mins until the potatoes are soft and the surface is golden. Leave to rest and cool for 15 mins before serving.
chief_review: This take on dauphinoise offers a clever balance by lightening the traditional richness—combining double cream with vegetable or chicken stock rather than using only cream. The infusion of lemon zest and thyme lifts the dish beautifully, while nutmeg adds a classic, aromatic warmth. Thinly sliced potatoes absorb the flavors well, with butter providing a silky finish. Opting for vegetable stock and ensuring the stock is gluten-free also makes this suitable for vegetarian and gluten-sensitive diets. The absence of flour or breadcrumbs keeps it gluten-free, while the richness is tempered without sacrificing indulgence. A refined, lighter gratin that’s both comforting and full of flavor—recommended for family meals or as an elegant side.

name: Mulled wine kit
description: A lovely homemade gift for wine lovers
author: Good Food
ingredients: 25cm square butter muslin (available from department & hardware stores)
directions: Put the muslin on a flat surface and tip the sugar, ginger and nutmeg into the centre. Tie into a pouch with fine string and attach to the neck of the wine bottle. Then attach the cinnamon stick to the bottle with a little raffia.
Stick the cloves into the orange and pack into a box lined with raffia or shredded paper, with the wine.

Tie a label to the wine bottle with the following instructions: ‘Tip the contents of the muslin bag into a pan with the wine, orange, cinnamon stick and 300ml/½pt water. Simmer for 5 mins, then serve.’
chief_review: This recipe creates a charming homemade mulled wine kit, perfect for gifting during the festive season. The combination of warming spices—ginger, nutmeg, cinnamon, and cloves—infuses the red wine with aromatic depth, while demerara sugar adds richness and a hint of caramel. Fresh orange lends a bright, citrusy note that balances the spice. The use of butter muslin to bundle the spices shows thoughtful presentation and makes preparation simple for the recipient. This recipe is suitable for vegetarian and vegan diets, provided the wine used is certified vegan, as some wines may use animal products in processing. It is also naturally gluten-free, assuming the wine is free from additives containing gluten. Overall, this mulled wine kit is a thoughtful gift that delivers festive cheer in every sip.

name: Truffle-stuffed guinea fowl
description: See what all the fuss about truffles is with this indulgent Sunday lunch or special occasion dish
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Peel and very finely slice the truffle. Loosen the breast skin of the bird, smear most of the butter underneath, then place half the truffle slices under the skin. Heat the rest of the butter in a casserole dish, brown bird on all sides, place the bird, breast side up, in oven, then cook for 30 mins.
While the bird is roasting, tip the potatoes into a pan of water and bring to the boil. Tip in the shallots and bacon, simmer everything for 2 mins, then drain.

Remove bird from the oven and lift from the pan. Tip potatoes, shallots and bacon into the casserole dish and toss in the juices. Nestle the bird among the vegetables and return to oven for 30-40 mins. When the bird is done, remove from the oven to rest, but cook the vegetables for a further 15 mins. Scoop vegetables into a serving bowl and scatter with the rest of the truffle. Serve the bird with potatoes drizzled with truffle oil.
chief_review: This recipe is a luxurious showcase for the unique flavor of truffles, perfectly paired with tender guinea fowl. The truffle and truffle oil infuse the dish with deep, earthy aromas while the butter enhances succulence. Roasting the guinea fowl atop potatoes and shallots allows the bird’s juices to marry with the vegetables, and the diced bacon adds a delightful salty smokiness. The result is an elegant and memorable centerpiece, ideal for special occasions or an elevated Sunday meal. With its use of poultry, dairy, and bacon, this dish is best suited to omnivorous diets but would bring joy to any truffle enthusiast seeking a restaurant-worthy experience at home.

name: Butter bean pâté with melba toast
description: This speedy pâté is ready in 15 minutes, the perfect last minute starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tbsp chopped fresh parsley, plus sprigs to garnish
directions: Heat the oil in a pan, then gently cook the shallot and garlic for 5 mins until softened. Transfer to a large bowl. Add the butter beans, then mash together until roughly puréed. Stir in the soured cream, parsley and seasoning. Cover and chill until ready to serve.

Meanwhile, place the slices of bread under a medium grill and gently toast on both sides until light golden. Cut off the crusts and, using a long, sharp knife, split the bread in half, through the centre. Place the bread, untoasted-side up, under a low grill until it curls into a crisp, golden shell. Serve with the butter bean pâté and a sprig of parsley.
chief_review: This quick butter bean pâté is a delightful starter that punches above its weight in both flavor and texture. The earthy creaminess of butter beans pairs beautifully with the freshness of parsley and the subtle heat of garlic and shallot. A small amount of olive oil enriches the mix without overpowering it, while soured cream lends a tangy smoothness, making the spread irresistibly light. Serve on lightly toasted white bread for the ideal contrast in crunch and creaminess. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, delivering plenty of protein and fiber, and is naturally nut-free, catering to those with nut allergies. For an extra touch, garnish with fresh parsley sprigs. Perfect for entertaining or a simple, satisfying snack.

name: Mushroom & olive tatins
description: This is a versatile dish, starter, main, picnic or snack. It's smart enough for entertaining and easy enough for everyday
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 2 x 250g packs Portabellini mushroom, stalks removed
1 sheet puff pastry, from a 425g pack
few toasted pine nut and chopped olives
directions: Heat oven to 240C/fan 220C/gas 9. Spread the mushrooms, stalk side up, on 2 baking trays. Drizzle with oil, sprinkle with thyme, then season well. Roast for 12 mins until juicy.

Take two 15cm sandwich cake tins. Unravel the pastry, then using the tin as a guide, cut two circles. It’s best to put the tins on the pastry before cutting to get the best possible fit – you may need to patch one of the rounds slightly with some pastry trimmings.

Arrange the mushrooms, overlapping (one up, one down) in the tins and scatter with pine nuts and olives. Spread tapenade over one side of the pastry, then place, tapenade side-down, on top of the mushrooms.
Bake for 15 mins, then tip onto plates. To serve, combine the oil, vinegar, pine nuts, olives and rocket and pile on top of the tarts.
chief_review: This recipe showcases earthy Portabellini mushrooms contrasted with zesty tapenade and aromatic thyme, all encased in crisp, golden puff pastry. The use of olives and toasted pine nuts adds depth and texture, while a fresh finish of rocket leaves brightens the dish. Its straightforward preparation makes it suitable for casual meals, yet its vibrant flavors and elegant appearance can impress at gatherings. As puff pastry is often made with butter, but the recipe features vegetarian tapenade, this dish caters well to vegetarians. It’s a great option for anyone seeking a meat-free, flavor-packed centerpiece or snack. The combination of ingredients also provides a good dose of healthy fats and umami, making this both satisfying and wholesome.

name: Moreish mocha profiteroles
description: A classic profiterole recipe with an added kick for coffee lovers - pile up a batch as modern wedding cake!
author: Good Food
ingredients: 2 tbsp coffee essence (dissolve 2 tbsp instant coffee granules in 2 tbsp hot water - we used Nescafé Partners’ Blend)
1-2 tbsp coffee liqueur such as Kahlúa
directions: Sift the flour into a bowl and stir in a pinch of salt. Put butter and 200ml cold water into a pan, bring to a rolling boil, then take off the heat. Tip in the flour and salt and stir to form a smooth paste. Now beat the mixture until it starts to come away from the sides of the pan, then tip onto a plate and leave to cool.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Return paste to the pan, then gradually beat in the eggs, mixing well. Spoon walnut-sized balls onto a baking sheet, then bake for 20-25 mins until golden. Remove from oven, poke the underneath with a teaspoon, turn upside-down, then bake for 5 mins to dry out. Cool on a wire rack before filling.

For the filling, mix the custard powder and sugar with a splash of milk until you have a smooth paste. Heat the remaining milk, then stir into the paste. Pour the mixture into a pan and bring to the boil, stirring. Cook for 5 mins until you have a thick custard. Stir in coffee, then leave to cool. Softly whip the cream, sift in the icing sugar and mix, then fold into the custard. Pipe the cream into each choux bun.
For the sauce, melt chocolate and butter with the coffee in a bowl in the microwave on Medium for 1-2 mins. Pour in the liqueur, mix well, then pour over the filled buns.
chief_review: This coffee-infused profiterole recipe elevates the classic choux pastry with bold coffee notes both in the custard filling and the glossy chocolate-coffee glaze. The step-by-step inclusion of both instant coffee and coffee liqueur ensures a deep, aromatic flavor that coffee enthusiasts will adore. The filling, a luscious blend of custard, double cream, and coffee essence, comes together silky and rich, providing a beautiful contrast to the crisp pastry shells. The final drizzle of dark chocolate, butter, and coffee liqueur is decadent and sophisticated—perfect for special occasions like modern weddings or adult celebrations. With its combination of eggs, dairy, wheat, and liqueur, this recipe suits a classic dessert appetite, but is best enjoyed by those without food allergies or dietary restrictions. Overall, a sumptuous twist on tradition for those who appreciate nuanced flavors and a touch of culinary drama.

name: Melon granita
description: Cool off with this refreshing dessert
author: Good Food
directions: Tip the sugar and 125ml/4fl oz water into a saucepan. Scrape in the vanilla seeds and put in the pod as well, then heat gently until the sugar has dissolved. Bring to the boil and boil for 6-8 minutes to make a sugar syrup. Leave to cool and remove the vanilla pod.

Halve the melons, scoop out and discard the seeds, then scoop the flesh onto a board and chop to a slush with a sharp knife (or you can do this in a food processor). Mix the sugar syrup and melon slush together with the lemon juice in a large shallow baking dish. Freeze uncovered for about 1 hour until crystals form around the edges. With a fork, stir the edges into the centre and mash well, then return to the freezer until crystals form again. Stir and refreeze as often as you can (say every half an hour or so) until the granita is frozen all over – this should take about 3 hours. Fork it up roughly when you serve it.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a beautifully refreshing dessert that showcases the sweet, fragrant qualities of ripe charentais melon enhanced by a touch of vanilla and brightened with a splash of lemon juice. The use of caster sugar brings out the natural juiciness without overwhelming the palate. Its simplicity allows for the flavors of the melon to truly shine through, making it a perfect palate cleanser or a light finish to a summer meal. Since it contains only fruit, sugar, and vanilla, this dessert is naturally suitable for vegan and vegetarian diets, and it's also gluten-free. The absence of nuts, dairy, and eggs makes it a great option for those with common food allergies. For best results, serve well chilled, and consider a final flourish of fresh mint for added aroma and color.

name: Roast chicken with savoury sauce
description: Piquant and delicious Italian style roast chicken
author: Carmelita Caruana
ingredients: a small handful flatleaf parsley leaves, plus 1 tbsp extra chopped parsley to serve
50g Venetian soppressa or a soft tasty Italian salami, such as salami brianza, optional
1 lemon, finely grated zest and juice
directions: Preheat the oven to 200C/gas 6/fan 180C. Carefully loosen the skin over the breast of the chicken and ease a slice or two of the prosciutto and sprig of rosemary under the skin to cover each breast. Choose the fattiest parts of the prosciutto, as the idea is for it to baste the breast meat and keep it from drying out too much. Chop the remaining prosciutto and put it in the cavity of the chicken with the onion, sage and the rest of the rosemary. Use wooden cocktail sticks to close the cavity.

Choose a baking dish that will just hold the chicken comfortably, drizzle the base with 1 tbsp of the oil and put in the chicken, breast side up. Pour over the remaining oil and season thoroughly. Roast for 11⁄4 hours, basting from time to time with the white wine, until the juices from the chicken have no trace of blood in them when the thigh joint is pierced with a knife.

While the chicken is roasting, start the sauce. Tip the garlic, parsley leaves, livers and anchovies into the bowl of your food processor with the soppressa or salami, if using. Whizz until everything, including the parsley leaves, seems amalgamated.

When cooked, lift the chicken on to a carving board, cover with foil and let it rest for 15 minutes. Pour the olive oil from the juices left in the roasting pan into a small saucepan – you should have about 4-5 tbsp. Put the pan over a low heat and gradually add the liver mixture, stirring to blend with the oil. Cook, stirring continuously until the sauce changes from a raw to a cooked colour. Pour in the lemon juice, stir, then add the white wine, and when that has evaporated, add the vinegar. After 10-12 minutes cooking, taste and season with salt and freshly ground black pepper.

Return the sauce to the cleaned food processor bowl, give it all a second whiz and return to the pan. Back on the heat, continue to stir and cook the sauce, adding water, a little at a time, until you achieve a velvety texture and a thick pouring consistency. Keep the sauce warm over a pan of simmering hot water while you joint the chicken.

Discard the backbone, carve the legs into thighs and drumsticks, and cut each breast into two, so diners get a bit of each. Discard the flavourings from inside the cavity. Add half the chopped parsley and lemon zest to the sauce and pour into a serving bowl, scatter with the rest of the parsley and lemon zest and serve with the chicken.
chief_review: This Italian-style roast chicken recipe is a festival of bold flavors, pairing the succulence of maize-fed or free-range chicken with the punch of prosciutto, anchovies, and Venetian soppressa (optional). The fragrant backdrop of rosemary, sage, garlic, and zesty lemon lifts the dish to aromatic heights, while the generous splash of dry white wine and rich olive oil guarantee a moist, savory result. Chicken livers add a decadent earthiness, and the final sprinkle of fresh parsley brightens each bite. This recipe would be well-suited for low-carb or grain-free diets, and is naturally gluten-free, provided care is taken with wine and processed meats. It does contain potential allergens such as anchovies (fish), salami (pork, which could contain milk proteins), and prosciutto, so those with sensitivities should check labels. Overall, a robust crowd-pleaser that summons the spirit of a rustic Italian kitchen.

name: Hot spiced buttered rum
author: Emma Freud
directions: Heat all the ingredients in a pan until hot but not boiling, while stirring. Let it sit for a few mins, then strain into a flask.
chief_review: This aromatic drink is an intriguing blend of warming spices—cloves, star anise, and cinnamon—elevated by the vibrant zest and juice of blood orange. The addition of butter imparts a silky richness, while the maple syrup offers a delicate sweetness to balance the cocktail's robust rum base. The inclusion of bay leaf lends a subtle herbal note, resulting in a well-rounded, deeply flavorful concoction perfect for cool evenings. The recipe contains no gluten or animal-derived ingredients except for butter, making it suitable for vegetarians. However, it is not vegan due to the butter. The thoughtful layering of spice and citrus creates a sophisticated beverage that is both comforting and festive, ideal for sipping slowly and savoring each nuanced sip.

name: Spinach & artichoke filo pie
description: This makes a good main course for vegetarian friends and family
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 400g frozen leaf spinach, thawed and well drained and chopped
400g can artichoke heart, drained and halved
directions: Soften the leeks in the butter for a couple of mins. Add the spinach to the pan, cover and cook for 5-6 mins more until the spinach has just thawed.
In a separate bowl, beat the ricotta and eggs with the parmesan, spinach mix, nutmeg and plenty of seasoning. Stir in the artichokes and tomatoes.

Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Line the base and sides of a greased 23cm clip-sided or loose-based tin with the filo pastry. Brushing each sheet lightly with the oil, place in the tin, oil-side down, leaving excess to hang over the edge. Turn the tin a quarter turn after each sheet.
Tip filling into the tin, fold excess pastry onto the top of the pie, a sheet at a time, crumpling to give a ruffled effect. Bake for 11⁄2hrs until golden and firm.
chief_review: This recipe offers a delightful, hearty main course, particularly for vegetarians. The combination of leeks, spinach, and canned artichoke hearts brings depth and freshness, while ricotta, parmesan, and eggs provide richness and a satisfying texture. SunBlush tomatoes add a lovely sweet-tart accent that lifts the flavors. The use of filo pastry yields an appealingly crisp, golden crust encasing the filling. A touch of nutmeg ties the creamy and earthy notes together beautifully. It’s perfect for a festive table or a special meat-free meal. With its use of butter, cheese, and eggs, it’s best suited to a vegetarian diet and not suitable for vegans or those with dairy and egg allergies. The reliance on filo pastry also means it contains gluten, so it’s unsuitable for gluten-free diets. Overall, a well-balanced and flavorful dish for vegetarians and cheese lovers alike.

name: Poule au pot with stuffing balls & garlic cream
description: Loved this meal for our Sunday lunch yesterday here in France. This is a typical family meal and I was surprised at how much flavour there was when the meat has just been poached in water effectively! We loved the stuffing balls but not sure about the garlic cream. We'd eat the meal again and won't be frightened to invite our neighbours in and serve it to them either. Scored it 8/10
author: Mary Cadogan
directions: Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Put the chicken in a flameproof casserole dish and pour over 600ml water and the wine. Stud the onion with the cloves. Add to the pan with the bouquet garni, garlic and seasoning, then bring to the boil. Cover and put in the oven for 1½ hrs.

To make the garlic cream, simmer the unpeeled garlic cloves in a small pan of water for 30 mins until soft. When cool enough to handle, squeeze out into a bowl and mash with salt and pepper. Stir in the crème fraîche and tip into a bowl, then keep in the fridge until needed.

For the stuffing, mix the meats in a bowl. Heat the oil in a small pan and gently fry the shallots and garlic until softened but not browned. Add to the bowl with the egg, parsley, breadcrumbs, seasoning, then mix well. Shape into 18 balls and put in a shallow baking tray.

Remove chicken after 1½ hrs and put it on the hob on medium heat. Place the stuffing in the oven for 25-30 mins until browned and crisp. Add the vegetables to the chicken pot. Cook for 25-30 mins, then lift out the chicken to a plate and keep the veg warm in the stock.

Remove chicken’s skin, and break the flesh into chunks. Put on a warm platter with the stuffing and the veg. Add a ladle of cooking stock and the parsley. Serve the rest of the cooking juices in a jug.
chief_review: This traditional French family meal delivers delicate poached chicken with aromatic vegetables and standout stuffing balls that impress. The inclusion of chicken, pork, and bacon layers the dish with rich, savory notes, while the bouquet garni infuses subtle herbal nuances. The vegetables, gently simmered, absorb the broth's flavor beautifully. The stuffing balls—a mix of minced pork, bacon, chicken livers, egg, and fresh breadcrumbs—are moist and deeply flavorful, a highlight on the plate. Although the garlic cream divides opinion, it offers a robust finish for garlic lovers. The recipe suits those seeking a comforting, protein-rich dish with classic European techniques. Notably, it includes gluten (from breadcrumbs), dairy (crème fraîche), and various meats, so it best fits omnivorous diets. This is a hearty, flavorful centerpiece perfect for sharing with family or guests, certain to impress at a Sunday lunch.

name: Fresh Savoy, red onion & egg pie
description: A great vegetarian main - perfect pastry and a scrummy filling
author: Good Food
ingredients: 1 quantity shortcrust pastry (see 'Goes well with' below) made with 2 tbsp lightly crushed cumin seeds
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a large frying pan, then gently cook the potatoes and onion for about 10 mins until golden and tender. (You may need to do this in two batches.) Season, then set aside.

Heat the remaining oil in the pan. Add half the cabbage, garlic, cumin seeds, chilli, seasoning and 1 tbsp water, then cook for 3-4 mins until the cabbage is wilted and tender. Remove from the pan and repeat with the remaining ingredients.
Roll out half the pastry and use to line a 20cm pie plate. Place the potatoes and onions in the bottom, then top with the cabbage mixture. Make 4 wells in the cabbage and crack an egg into each.

Brush the pastry border with water. Roll out remaining pastry, then use to cover the pie, trimming the edges and pinching together to seal. Brush the pastry with milk. Make a hole in the centre to allow steam to escape. Place on a baking sheet and cook for 25-35 mins until crisp and golden.
chief_review: This savory main showcases a delightful harmony between perfectly crisp shortcrust pastry and a robust, aromatic filling. The mix of diced new potatoes, sweet red onion, and tender Savoy cabbage is elevated by cumin seeds and a touch of chilli, creating both warmth and earthy complexity. The olive oil sauté adds richness, while the four eggs provide structure and heartiness, making this tart a complete meal. As a vegetarian dish, it’s ideal for those pursuing a meat-free diet. However, it is not vegan due to the inclusion of eggs and milk in the glaze. The interplay of pliant vegetables with flaky cumin-laced pastry delivers on both texture and flavor. All in all, a skillful and satisfying recipe—an excellent centerpiece for a vegetarian dinner.

name: Mini chilli beef pies
description: Perfect party nibbles to impress your guests with
author: Cathryn Evans
ingredients: 1 large potato (about 250g/9oz), peeled and cut into chunks
directions: To make chilli, heat oil in a pan and fry onion for 5 mins until soft. Add spices; fry for 1 min. Stir in beef and cook for a few mins. Add tomato purée, stock and cinnamon. Give it a stir, bring to the boil, then simmer for 15-20 mins until very little liquid is left. Add beans 5 mins before the end of cooking. Check seasoning and cool.

Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Using a 7cm pastry cutter, stamp out 12 circles from the pastry. Use to line a 12-hole mini muffin tray, prick the base of the pastry with a fork, and bake for 10 mins. Remove from oven and cool on a wire tray. Repeat with remaining pastry.

Meanwhile, cook the potato in boiling water until tender. Drain, mash with soured cream and seasoning, then stir through chives. Spoon 1-2 tsp of chilli mix into the pastry cases and top with a tsp of mash. Ruffle mash with a fork; return to the oven for 15 mins or until golden.
chief_review:
These party nibbles are a delightful crowd-pleaser, combining the savory richness of minced beef, aromatic spices, and creamy kidney beans wrapped in buttery shortcrust pastry. The clever addition of cooked potato lends a hearty texture, while the hot chilli powder and cumin elevate the filling with a warming depth. Soured cream and chive provide a refreshing contrast, cutting through the spices and ensuring each bite is balanced. 

This recipe suits those following a nut-free diet, as no nuts are present in the ingredient list. However, check all packaging for cross-contamination if allergies are a concern. Vegetarians and vegans would need significant adaptations, but as presented, the flavors and textures are sure to impress your guests and disappear quickly from any party platter.

name: Chocolate & coffee truffle pots
description: What better way to finish a meal than rich chocolate truffles and coffee? This easy dessert combines the two
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 4 tbsp favourite spirit, such as rum, brandy, Disaronno
directions: Break the chocolate into small chunks and tip into a bowl with the coffee and alcohol. Bring 250ml of the cream to the boil, then pour over the chocolate mixture and stir until the chocolate has melted and the mixture is smooth. Divide the mix between 6 coffee cups and leave to set overnight in the fridge.
To serve, whip the remaining cream with the sugar until just set. Spoon the cream onto the chocolate pots and serve dusted with cocoa powder so each cup looks like a cappuccino.
chief_review:
This chocolate and coffee truffle recipe is indulgent and sophisticated, perfect for ending a meal on a high note. The marriage of bittersweet dark chocolate and robust coffee creates a deep, complex flavor profile, while the addition of your chosen spirit adds a subtle warmth and aromatic lift. The double cream ensures the truffles are luxuriously smooth, and dusting with cocoa powder rounds out the experience with a classic finish. 

As it contains no wheat or gluten-based ingredients, this dessert is naturally gluten-free, provided your chocolate and spirit are as well. However, since double cream is a key component, this recipe is not suitable for those with dairy allergies or who follow a vegan diet. For vegetarians, this treat is entirely appropriate, as none of the ingredients are animal-derived beyond the dairy, making it a lovely vegetarian-friendly option.

name: Low-fat roasties
description: Enjoy these guilt-free roast potatoes - they contain around 6g fat compared to the usual 14g!
author: Emma Lewis
ingredients: 200ml vegetable stock (from a cube is fine)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Put the potatoes and garlic in a roasting tin. Pour over the stock, then brush the tops of the potatoes with half the olive oil. Season, then cook for 50 mins. Brush with the remaining oil and cook 10-15 mins more until the stock is absorbed and the potatoes have browned and cooked through.
chief_review: These roast potatoes impress with their clever use of vegetable stock to significantly reduce fat content, making them an excellent choice for those seeking lighter comfort food options. The addition of garlic infuses gentle, aromatic flavor, while a restrained amount of olive oil ensures a crisp, golden exterior without excess greasiness. As this recipe relies solely on plant-based ingredients, it’s perfectly suited for vegetarian and vegan diets. Additionally, with no inclusion of wheat or gluten-containing items, it accommodates gluten-free requirements, assuming a certified gluten-free stock cube is used. These potatoes make a versatile, healthier side dish, balancing taste and nutrition.

name: Roast pheasant with ricotta & Parma ham
description: For a really special Sunday lunch pheasant is a good choice. The parma ham crisps us beautifully in the oven and gives the pheasant an eye-catching edge
author: Sara Buenfeld
ingredients: 1 tbsp thyme leaf, plus some sprigs
directions: Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Separate the layers of Parma ham and chop two slices finely. Mix the ricotta, chopped ham, thyme and Parmesan with some seasoning.

Carefully ease the skin away from the breast meat of each pheasant and use half the stuffing per bird, pressing it to the contours of the breasts through the skin. This protects the meat from the heat and will stop it drying out. Poke some sprigs of thyme into the body cavity to add flavour.
Put the pheasants in a roasting tin and top each one with the remaining ham. Season with pepper, then pour over the vermouth and drizzle with oil.

Roast for 20 mins, then turn down the heat to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4 and cook for 40 mins more, basting every now and then with the pan juices until the legs are no longer pink. Cover with foil and a tea towel and leave to stand for 10 mins before carving. Serve with wilted spinach and potatoes prepared however you like them.
chief_review: This roast pheasant recipe creates an impressive and sophisticated main course, perfect for a celebratory Sunday lunch. The parma ham delivers a crisp, savory contrast to the tender pheasant, while the ricotta and parmesan filling adds a creamy, aromatic richness enhanced by thyme. The use of dry vermouth subtly lifts the flavors and lends elegance without overpowering the dish. The recipe is ideal for low-carb or ketogenic diets, given its emphasis on protein and minimal use of carbohydrates. Dairy lovers will appreciate the abundance of cheese, but those with lactose intolerance should take note. The result is a visually appealing and flavorsome centerpiece that will satisfy discerning palates and make any Sunday feel truly special.

name: Boozy berry & elderflower trifle
description: Taste the essence of summer with berry & elderflower trifle
author: Merrilees Parker
directions: With an electric whisk, whip together the mascarpone and custard in a bowl. Cover and chill until ready to use. Roughly mash most of the raspberries with the elderflower cordial.

Cut up the sponge cake and use to line the bottom of four glasses. Drizzle each one with a little kirsch, and spoon over half of the raspberry mixture. Cover with half of the whipped mascarpone and custard, then repeat the layers with the remaining berries and mascarpone and custard. Decorate with the rest of the raspberries and chill for at least 30 mins before serving.
chief_review: This berry & elderflower trifle brilliantly encapsulates the fresh, floral notes of summer. The combination of creamy mascarpone and velvety custard gives each spoonful a luxurious mouthfeel. Plump raspberries add a tart juiciness, perfectly complemented by the subtle sweetness of elderflower cordial and a spirited drizzle of kirsch. The ready-made sponge absorbs the kirsch and elderflower beautifully, creating a soft, boozy base under the creamy layers. This recipe is well-suited for vegetarians, as it features dairy and eggs but no meat or gelatine. While effortless to assemble, the trifle delivers a sophisticated medley of flavors sure to impress for any summer gathering. For the perfect finish, chill thoroughly to allow the flavors to meld together.

name: Mushroom & tarragon pâté
description: This low-fat, easy pâté is a perfect vegetarian starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 3 tbsp chopped fresh tarragon, plus extra to garnish
1 French stick; extra vigin olive oil; mixed salad leaves, to serve
directions: Heat butter in a large frying pan. Add shallots, leek and garlic, then gently fry for 7 mins until softened.

Increase the heat, add the chestnut and the shiitake mushrooms, then cook for 10 mins, stirring, until the juices have evaporated and the mushrooms are tender. Stir in the mustard and crème fraîche, then season well. Cook for a further 2 mins then stir in the chopped tarragon.

Preheat the grill. Cut the French stick into diagonal slices, drizzle with a little olive oil, then grill until golden. Spoon the hot pâté on to the toasts, garnish with the extra tarragon, then serve with salad leaves.
chief_review: This vegetarian pâté offers a sophisticated yet simple starter, boasting earthy chestnut and shiitake mushrooms complemented by fragrant tarragon and a tangy lift from wholegrain mustard and crème fraîche. The use of shallots, leek, and garlic provides a gentle aromatic base, while finishing with extra virgin olive oil and serving alongside a French stick and fresh salad leaves lends both texture and freshness. It’s well-suited for vegetarian diets and, thanks to low-fat ingredients and a focus on vegetables, it can be an excellent choice for those seeking lighter appetizers. While still indulgent with butter and crème fraîche, their quantities are modest, keeping the dish balanced. Perfect as an elegant introduction to a meal or as part of a shared spread.

name: Spicy prawn cocktail with tomato & coriander dressing
description: An entertaining favourite with light and fresh flavours - make it a feature of a retro dinner
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: Italian flatbread or toasted pitta breads, to serve
directions: Prepare Ahead: Pat the prawns dry with kitchen paper. Peel the garlic and finely chop. Halve the chilli, discard the seeds and finely chop. Mix the garlic, chilli and prawns. Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a pan, add the prawns and stir fry for 2-3 minutes, until pink. Tip into a bowl and leave to cool, then chill for up to 8 hours.

Quarter the tomatoes and discard the seeds. Finely chop the flesh and tip into a bowl with the lemon juice, honey and remaining oil. Add coriander, season and whisk until slightly thickened. Cover and chill for up to 8 hours.

On The Day: Tear the gem leaves into small pieces. Chop the avocado flesh. Fill six glasses with lettuce, avocado and rocket leaves. Pile the prawns on top and spoon over the dressing. Serve with Italian flatbread or toasted pittas.
chief_review:
This vibrant prawn dish is a nod to classic retro entertaining, delivering fresh, zesty flavours with a modern twist. Plump tiger prawns are quickly sautéed with garlic and chilli, complemented by juicy tomatoes and a drizzle of lemon and honey for subtle sweetness. The salad base—Little Gem lettuce, creamy avocado, and peppery rocket—adds a refreshing crunch. A final flourish of coriander brightens the composition, while Italian flatbread or toasted pitta on the side makes it perfect for sharing. 

Thanks to its emphasis on vegetables, healthy fats, and lean protein, this recipe is an excellent choice for pescatarians. It's naturally gluten-free if served without the bread or with a gluten-free alternative, and is dairy-free, making it suitable for a range of dietary preferences. Overall, it’s a visually appealing and light recipe ideal for a stylish starter or a summery main.

name: Classic prawn cocktail
description: This classic retro starter packed with juicy prawns will never go out of fashion
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: 4 Little Gem lettuces, washed and trimmed
directions: Peel all but 4 of the prawns (reserve these for the tops). Break the lettuces into individual leaves, then divide the leaves evenly between 4 small glass bowls.
Sprinkle the prawns over the lettuce and season with black pepper.

Mix the mayonnaise, tomato chutney, Worcestershire sauce, horseradish and Tabasco together. Season to taste with lemon juice and salt and pepper, then spoon sparingly over the prawns. Dust the top with a little paprika and sprinkle with chives. Top with the remaining prawns and serve immediately. Delicious with brown bread.
chief_review: This prawn cocktail recipe is a timeless starter, bursting with the freshness of Atlantic prawns and crisp Little Gem lettuce. The sauce—a blend of mayonnaise, tomato chutney, Worcestershire, creamed horseradish, and a dash of Tabasco—delivers a creamy, tangy profile with a subtle kick, beautifully complementing the sweetness of the prawns. The squeeze of lemon juice adds essential brightness, while a dusting of paprika and a sprinkle of chives finish the dish with a vibrant, aromatic flair. Suitable for pescatarians, this elegant appetizer makes a stunning begin to any meal, especially when seeking a nostalgic taste done right.

name: Squash with rice, sage & goat's cheese
description: Slow-roasted for maximum flavour this vegetarian main will thrill family and friends
author: Good Food
ingredients: 25g sundried tomato in oil, drained and chopped
directions: Heat oven to 190C/fan 170C/gas 5. Cut squash in half lengthways, then scoop out seeds and membranes. Brush insides with a little oil and place in a roasting tin filled to 1cm with water. Roast for 20-30 mins until almost tender when tested with a sharp knife. Scoop out some of the flesh and roughly chop.

Meanwhile, heat remaining oil in a pan, then cook onion and garlic for 5 mins until the onion is tender. Stir in the rice and fry for 1 min. Add the vegetable stock and cook for a further 10-12 mins until the rice is tender and the liquid has all been absorbed.
Stir in chopped squash flesh, sun-dried tomatoes, goat's cheese, half the sage leaves and seasoning.
Stuff the squash with the filling, top with remaining sage leaves and cover with foil.
Return to the oven and cook for a further 15 mins until the cheese is melted and all is heated through. Stand for 5 mins before serving with a green salad.
chief_review: This slow-roasted butternut squash dish is a standout vegetarian main, perfect for family gatherings or festive occasions. The combination of sweet, caramelized squash with aromatic sage, creamy goat’s cheese, and umami-rich sundried tomatoes makes for a deeply flavorful and satisfying centerpiece. The use of basmati rice adds substance without overpowering the delicate flavors, while olive oil and garlic bring a Mediterranean touch. This recipe is wonderfully suitable for a vegetarian diet, and can also be enjoyed by those seeking a gluten-free option, as all ingredients are naturally free from gluten. To sum up, this is a thoughtfully balanced, hearty dish that highlights the best of seasonal produce and simple yet effective flavor pairings.

name: Rustic chestnut stuffing
description: If you love stuffing don’t just stop at one. Cook one inside the turkey to give it flavour and help keep it juicy, then cook another separately
author: Good Food
ingredients: 6 rashers smoked streaky bacon, each rasher cut into 6-8 pieces
140g oatmeal breadcrumbs (we used an Allinson sliced oatmeal loaf) or white breadcrumbs
directions: Fry the onion in the butter for 5 mins. Add the mushrooms, then fry for 5 mins more.

Tip into a bowl, then lightly stir in the other ingredients with plenty of seasoning. Stuff into the neck end of the turkey, or spoon into oiled muffin tins (half-fill to make 8 servings) and bake for 30 mins alongside the turkey.
chief_review: This stuffing recipe is a delightful celebration of rich, earthy flavors—mushrooms, chestnuts, Ardennes pâté, and smoky bacon unite for an indulgent side that pairs perfectly with roast turkey. The use of both oatmeal breadcrumbs and white breadcrumbs offers pleasant texture, while the fresh herbs lift the profile from simply savory to aromatic. Sautéing the onions and mushrooms in butter creates a deep, inviting base. The inclusion of eggs helps to bind the mixture, resulting in a moist yet well-structured stuffing. This recipe contains eggs, gluten (from breadcrumbs), and dairy (butter), so it’s not suitable for those with related allergies or intolerances. The hearty bacon and pâté give a luxurious depth, making this stuffing a memorable centerpiece for festive occasions or holiday meals. Assemble in advance for convenience—the flavors continue to meld beautifully as it rests.

name: Sticky clementine & ginger puddings
