description: These sweet little puddings make terrific dinner party desserts, or you can make one big one for the family
author: Barney Desmazery
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Juice one of the clementines and set aside. Peel the other two, reserving the peel. Slice the clementines into thick rounds. Using a teaspoon, scrape away the pith from the reserved peel, then finely chop the peel.
Grease 6 individual pudding basins, drizzle 1 tbsp golden syrup into each, add a slice of clementine, then set aside.

In a bowl, cream the butter and sugar together until pale, then add the eggs. Fold in the flour, almonds, ground ginger and chopped peel, then fold through the juice and chopped ginger. Divide the mixture between the basins, then cover each tightly with a greased hat or foil.

Place the puddings in a roasting tray, half fill the tray with boiling water from the kettle, then cook in the oven for 30 mins until puffed up. The puddings can be made up to 2 days ahead and reheated in a steamer or in the microwave. Turn out onto plates and serve with cream or custard.
chief_review:
This delightful pudding recipe brings together the vibrant citrus of clementines and the warmth of ginger for an elegant yet comforting dessert, perfect for dinner parties or a cozy family gathering. The use of ground almonds imbues the sponge with a lovely moist texture and subtle nutty undertone, while stem ginger adds aromatic complexity. Served with cream or custard, it achieves that classic, rich British pudding indulgence.

Thanks to the absence of meat or gelatin, this recipe is suitable for vegetarians. However, do note that it contains eggs, butter, and ground almonds, making it unsuitable for those with egg, dairy, or nut allergies, and not appropriate for a vegan or nut-free diet. This dessert will shine with the freshness and zest of quality clementines.

name: Hash browns with mustard & smoked salmon
description: This brilliant brunch dish is especially sensational served with poached eggs
author: Good Food
ingredients: soured cream or crème fraîche, to serve
directions: Grate the unpeeled potato onto a clean tea towel. Bring up the edges of the towel, then squeeze over the sink to remove any excess water in the potatoes. Tip into a bowl and add the flour and mustard or horseradish. Season well and mix together.

Divide the mixture into 8 balls and flatten between your hands. Heat a large frying pan with the butter and oil, then add the potatoes to the pan. Cook for 2-3 mins on each side, over a medium heat, until golden.
Stack a couple of hash browns on each serving plate and top with a slice of smoked salmon, a dollop of soured cream or crème fraîche and some chives to serve.
chief_review: This brunch dish is a delightful combination of crispy, pan-fried potato—a riff on rösti or hash browns—with the luxurious pairing of smoked salmon and cool soured cream or crème fraîche. The inclusion of wholegrain mustard or horseradish brings a lively kick that cuts through the richness, while fresh chives add a welcome herbal note. It’s a well-balanced plate, pleasing in both flavor and texture, and particularly suited for pescatarians. Light, yet deeply satisfying, it shines when topped with a poached egg, whose runny yolk blends beautifully with the creamy and tangy components. Ideal for an elegant weekend brunch.

name: Pecan & maple syrup sticky pudding
description: The perfect family desert
author: Good Food
directions: First make the topping. Put the butter, double cream and maple syrup together in a small pan and stir over a low heat until well mixed. Bring to the boil, simmer for 1 min, then pour into the base of a buttered 900ml pudding basin.

Sift the flour into a bowl with the cinnamon and nutmeg. In a separate bowl, beat the butter with the sugar and maple syrup until light and fluffy. Beat in the egg a little at a time. Fold the dry ingredients into the creamed butter and egg mixture, adding the milk to give a soft dropping consistency. Stir in nuts and raisins.
Spoon the mixture into the basin, then cover with greased greaseproof paper and foil, making a pleat in the centre of both. Tie securely with string.
Steam the pudding for 1½ hrs, checking regularly to make sure that the pan doesn’t boil dry. Turn out and serve with extra warmed maple syrup and a generous helping of double cream.
chief_review: This dessert is a delightful, warmly spiced treat—the cinnamon and nutmeg shine through, complemented by the richness of dark muscovado sugar and maple syrup. The use of pecans and raisins adds a wonderful texture and bursts of sweetness, making this a crowd-pleasing family option. The combination of butter, egg, and double cream ensures a decadent, moist result, while the self-raising flour provides a lightness that balances the richness. Its ingredient profile makes it suitable for lacto-vegetarians, as it omits gelatin and other animal-derived thickeners, relying instead on dairy and eggs. Serve warm for maximum comfort and satisfaction—a satisfying finish to any family meal.

name: Lemon meringue ice cream
description: This zesty ice cream is the perfect summer treat
author: Merrilees Parker
ingredients: zest and juice of 3 juicy lemons, unwaxed if possible
6 good quality meringues, crushed (we used Sainsbury's Meringue Nests)
directions: In a large bowl, mix the custard and the single cream.
Whip the double cream until it forms soft peaks, then stir in the lemon zest and juice. Fold this into the custard mixture.

Pour into an ice cream machine and churn according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Gently fold in the meringue, then spoon into a freezer container and freeze. Remove from the freezer at least half an hour before serving. To serve, scoop into the ice cream cones and eat immediately.
chief_review: This zesty ice cream recipe masterfully balances the richness of custard and creams with the brightness of fresh lemon zest and juice, resulting in a refreshing, indulgent summer dessert. The addition of crushed meringues introduces delightful texture—a sweet, airy crunch that perfectly complements the creamy base. Served in quality cones, this treat is both nostalgic and elevated. While the ingredients make it best suited to those without dairy or egg allergies, it can be considered suitable for vegetarians, given the absence of gelatin or animal rennet in standard custard, creams, and most commercial meringues. The recipe relies on fresh, simple components, ensuring a straightforward yet impressive dish for gatherings or casual summertime enjoyment. Pair with seasonal berries for an extra flourish.

name: Salted almond brittle
description: A surprising topping for desserts - makes them that little bit extra special. Also delicious dipped in chocolate
author: Jane Hornby
directions: Lightly butter a lipped baking tray and spread the almonds over it in a thin, even layer. Put the sugar, butter, salt and 4 tbsp water into a smooth-bottomed frying pan and heat gently, stirring, until the sugar dissolves. Increase the heat and boil for about 5 mins, or until it starts to turn light golden brown. Stir every now and again as some patches will start to caramelise faster than others. Carefully tip the caramel over the nuts and leave to cool completely.

Once cold, shatter the caramel. An easy way to get clean sharp pieces is to put the point of a sharp knife vertically onto the caramel and bash the handle with a rolling pin, like a hammer and chisel. Serve on top of the Chocolate amaretti puddings. Keep for up to 2 days in an airtight container, interleaved with non-stick paper, in a cool, dry place (not the fridge).
chief_review:
This almond brittle topping adds a delightful crunch and nutty sweetness to a variety of desserts. The combination of toasted flaked almonds and golden caster sugar creates a rich, caramelized flavor enhanced by a touch of salt for balance. The use of butter lends the brittle a smooth, melt-in-the-mouth finish while helping it set perfectly atop creamy desserts or dipped in dark chocolate. 

Due to its nut content, this recipe caters well to gluten-free diets, as none of the ingredients contain gluten. However, it’s important to ensure that your almonds and sugar are certified gluten-free, as cross-contamination can occasionally occur. This topping would make an elegant finish for ice creams, cakes, and mousses, providing a professional touch with minimal effort.

name: Smoked wild Irish salmon with chive pancakes
description: A sophisticated salmon starter that your guests will adore...
author: Good Food
ingredients: 12 slices of smoked salmon, preferably wild Irish salmon
directions: To make the dressing, place the wholegrain mustard in a bowl, then using a whisk, add the olive oil slowly. Add a squeeze of lemon, season to taste, then set aside.
To make the pancake mixture, mix together the eggs, flour, milk and chopped chives until smooth. Season with pepper and salt, if you want

Heat a medium non-stick frying pan over a highish heat. Using a piece of kitchen paper wipe the pan with some vegetable oil. Pour a ladleful of the pancake batter into the pan and swirl to cover the base. Cook for about 1 min, then flip, cook for 30 secs more, remove and place on greaseproof paper. Repeat until you’ve made all six pancakes, then set aside.

To serve, arrange handfuls of salad leaves in piles on the side of each of six plates. Fold pancakes into four and sit next to the leaves. Loosely drape two slices of smoked salmon over the leaves and pancakes. Tuck two slices of lemon and a few chives under the salmon, then drizzle the mustard dressing over everything and serve.
chief_review: This elegant salmon starter is a harmonious balance of smoky, tangy, and herbaceous notes. The combination of smoked salmon with a zingy wholegrain mustard and lemon dressing provides a fresh burst of flavor, beautifully complemented by the soft crepe base enriched with chives. Mixed salad leaves lend needed texture and brightness. While this recipe is ideal for pescatarians, it’s also suitable for a vegetarian diet that includes fish and eggs. However, those seeking gluten-free or dairy-free options should note the use of plain flour and milk. Perfectly suited for an upscale dinner party or special occasion, this dish delivers both sophistication and a pleasing array of textures and flavors.

name: Herb rolled pork loin with crackling
description: We recommend you make a trip to your butcher for this dish based on an Italian classic for suckling pig, good meat equals good crackling
author: Emma Lewis
directions: Tip the rosemary and garlic into a mortar along with the fennel seeds, olive oil and a good pinch of salt. Pound everything together with a pestle until you get a rough paste. Unfold the pork loin, spread the herb mixture all over the cut side, then fold the loin back over. You need to keep the loin together during cooking, so tie pieces of string around it at 2cm intervals. Tuck any leftover rosemary sprigs under the string.

Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Lightly oil a baking tray and place the pork on top, sprinkling a little salt over the skin. Cook in the oven for 20 mins until crisp and browned all over. Reduce oven to 190C/fan 170C/ gas 5 and cook for 45 mins per kg more, which will be just under 2 hrs for this amount of meat. When ready, take the pork out of the oven and cover tightly with tin foil. Leave for at least 15 mins before eating, or leave to cool and keep in the fridge for up to 2 days. To serve, loosen the crackling, then carve the pork into thick slices, handing out pieces of crackling if people wish.
chief_review: This recipe is a true celebration of Italian simplicity, allowing quality ingredients to shine. The combination of rosemary, garlic, and fennel seed delivers a fragrant, robust marinade that infuses the butterflied pork loin with authentic Mediterranean flavors. The generous use of olive oil helps keep the meat succulent while promoting beautifully crisp crackling—a hallmark of expertly prepared pork. Given its reliance on quality meat and fresh herbs, this dish is perfect for those following a gluten-free diet. It’s a showstopper for special occasions or Sunday roasts, rewarding the cook who sources excellent pork from a trusted butcher. A timeless classic done right.

name: Bay & potato sticks
description: Perfect potatoes to accompany a special joint of meat
author: Lesley Waters
ingredients: 16 cocktail sticks, soaked in cold water for 20 minutes
directions: Heat oven to 200C/180C/gas 6. Boil the potatoes for 10 mins until almost cooked through, drain well, then allow to cool a little. Carefully push 2 potatoes and 1 bay leaf onto each skewer and rub each with a little olive oil. Can be prepared up to a day ahead.
Put potatoes on a roasting tray, then season. Roast for 10-15 mins, till golden and tender.
chief_review: This recipe for perfect potatoes is a delightful accompaniment to any special meal, featuring the aromatic touch of fresh bay leaves and subtle richness from olive oil. The method of skewering the potatoes with bay leaves infuses each bite with herbal notes, elevating the humble new potato to something worthy of a celebration table. The use of olive oil keeps the dish light yet flavorful, while the straightforward ingredient list allows the natural qualities of the potatoes and bay leaves to shine. Furthermore, this dish suits vegetarian and vegan diets, and is naturally gluten-free, making it a versatile choice for guests with varied dietary needs. Easy to prepare yet visually appealing, these potatoes are sure to impress alongside your favorite roast.

name: Bloody Mary recipe
author: BBC Good Food team
ingredients: 1 tbsp lemon juice, plus 2 slices to serve
few shakes Tabasco(smoked Tabasco is nice)
directions: Place the ice in a large jug. Measure the vodka, tomato juice and lemon juice and pour it straight onto the ice.

Add 3 shakes of Worcestershire sauce and Tabasco (or more if you like it very spicy) and a pinch of celery salt and pepper. Stir until the outside of the jug feels cold, then strain the cocktail into 2 tall glasses.
Top up with fresh ice, add a celery stick and lemon slice to both glasses and enjoy.
chief_review: A classic Bloody Mary shines through in this recipe, balancing the robust flavor of tomato juice with the bite of vodka and aromatic notes from Worcestershire sauce, lemon juice, and celery salt. The intensity of Tabasco brings a satisfying heat, while fresh lemon and crunchy celery provide brightness and texture. This cocktail is traditionally enjoyed as a brunch staple and is especially well-suited for a vegetarian diet, provided you choose a vegetarian-friendly Worcestershire sauce (as standard varieties can contain anchovies). Served chilled over ice, it’s an invigorating and savory beverage, perfect for those seeking bold, complex flavors in a glass.

name: Charred tomatoes
description: Try charred tomatoes for a change from the usual veg
author: Ruth Watson
ingredients: 3 tbsp olive oil, plus a drizzle
1 scant tbsp balsamic vinegar, plus extra
a small handful fresh basil leaves, finely sliced
directions: Preheat the oven to 160C/gas 3/fan 140C. Put a griddle pan or heavy cast iron frying pan (not non-stick) over a high flame and leave it to heat.
Cut the tomatoes in half around the equator. Brush the cut surfaces with 1 tbsp of oil and place cut side-down on the hot griddle. Cook undisturbed for 1 minute, then take the pan off the heat.

Transfer the tomatoes, cut side-up, to a shallow baking dish. Brush cut surfaces with the vinegar, then with about 2 tbsp of oil. Place a sliver or two of garlic on each tomato, and sprinkle with the sugar.

Bake for about 1 hour until the tomatoes are deep brown and sticky-looking. Cool a little, then finish with a sprinkling of balsamic vinegar, extra oil and a scattering of basil. Serve warm or at room temperature.
chief_review: This delightfully simple recipe brings out the natural sweetness of vine tomatoes by charring them, then elevates their flavor profile with a drizzle of olive oil, a splash of balsamic vinegar, and a hint of muscovado sugar. The inclusion of freshly sliced garlic and basil adds aromatic depth and freshness. It’s a vibrant dish, perfect as a side or a warm salad component. The ingredients are all plant-based, making this an excellent choice for both vegetarian and vegan diets. The absence of gluten-containing ingredients also makes it naturally gluten-free. For those mindful of allergens, there are no common triggers present. The interplay of sweet, tangy, and smoky notes captures summer in every bite, offering a refreshing alternative to conventional vegetable preparations.

name: Purple sprouting broccoli with garlic & sesame
description: Purple sprouting broccoli with a hint of garlic and sesame...perfect with your Sunday roast
author: Ruth Watson
ingredients: 2 tbsp groundnut oil or vegetable oil
5 garlic cloves, peeled and very finely sliced
directions: Trim off any hard ends from the broccoli stalks as well as any very coarse leaves. Bring a large quantity of salted water to the boil in a very large saucepan and plunge in the broccoli. With the lid on, quickly bring the water back to the boil, then remove the lid and briskly simmer the broccoli for about 2 minutes. Drain thoroughly.

Meanwhile, heat both oils in the pan over a medium heat. Fry the garlic for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the slices are light golden. Throw in the broccoli and fry it for 2-3 minutes, tossing frequently, until the stalks are piping hot and imbued with the garlicky oil.
Serve immediately with the sesame seeds sprinkled over the top.
chief_review: This dish of purple sprouting broccoli is a vibrant, aromatic addition to any meal, bringing a delightful balance of nuttiness from toasted sesame oil and seeds with a subtle punch of garlic. The choice of groundnut or vegetable oil keeps the flavors clean and lets the freshness of the broccoli shine. The recipe is naturally vegan and vegetarian, with no animal-derived ingredients in sight. It's also gluten-free, making it suitable for a wide range of dietary needs. The absence of common allergens like dairy, eggs, or wheat further broadens its appeal. Serve it alongside your Sunday roast, or as a centerpiece in a plant-based spread; its texture and bold character won’t disappoint.

name: Chocolate amaretti puddings
description: A dream pudding that words can't explain. Make it for yourself and share it if you can!
author: Jane Hornby
ingredients: 200g butter, plus extra for the tins
25g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
Salted almond brittle (see 'Goes well with' below)
directions: Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6 and put on a full kettle. Have a large roasting tin ready. Butter 10 squares of foil, each about 15 x 15cm. Butter 10 x 200ml mini pudding tins, dust with flour, then tap out the excess. Cut 10 small circles of baking paper to fit the bottoms and drop one into each tin.

Melt the butter and chocolate together in a pan, heating gently and stirring every so often. Set aside to cool. Meanwhile, put the eggs and sugar into a large bowl and whisk with electric beaters for 10 mins, or until the mix is thick and foamy and holds a trail for a few seconds.

Mix the ground almonds, flour and baking powder together. Splash 1 tbsp amaretto over the biscuits. Fold the cooled chocolate mix into the whisked egg and sugar using a large metal spoon. Follow with the flour mix, then work in the amaretto.

Fill the tins one-third full, then drop in an amaretti biscuit and top up with mix, leaving a 1cm gap between the top of the mix and the edge of the tins. Loosely scrunch a foil square over the top of each tin. Put the tins in the roasting pan and pour hot water around – it should come about halfway up the sides of the puddings. Bake for 30 mins, then insert a skewer into one; a few damp crumbs should stick to the skewer – you don’t want the puds to be totally dry.

Meanwhile, make the fudgy sauce. Melt all of the ingredients together in a heavy-based pan, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Set aside. Keep in the fridge for up to 2 days,then reheat on the hob or in the microwave on High for 1 min. To serve the puddings, turn onto plates and spoon over some of the sauce, allowing it to ooze over the edges. Sprinkle with shards of Salted almond brittle and serve straight away.
chief_review: This pudding is a decadent showcase of rich chocolate and almond flavors, enhanced by the sophisticated notes of Amaretto liqueur. The use of ground almonds and amaretti biscuits adds texture and a gentle nuttiness, while muscovado sugar brings a satisfying depth. The addition of double cream and golden syrup ensures a luxuriously smooth finish. This recipe contains both flour and eggs, making it unsuitable for gluten-free or vegan diets, but it is an excellent choice for those following a vegetarian lifestyle. The impressive combination of ingredients results in a lush, celebratory dessert perfect for special occasions. Pairing with salted almond brittle not only elevates the presentation but also adds a delightful crunch that contrasts beautifully with the pudding’s softness. Serve warm for maximum indulgence.

name: Tomato & pepper dip
description: A delicious filling yet low-calorie starter
author: Good Food
ingredients: 375g jar of Peppadew sweet piquante peppers
directions: Drain and rinse a the jar of Peppadew sweet piquante peppers and tip them into a food processor or blender. Add the tomatoes, roughly chopped, sundried tomato paste and most of the bunch of chives, snipped.

Whizz together until blended, but still chunky. Season with pepper and spoon half into a serving dish, sprinkle over the remaining chives and serve with lots of crisp, fresh, raw veg sticks. You can also grill a few soft flour tortillas until crisp, then snap them into pieces. Pop them under a hot grill – they take about a minute each, turning once. The other half of the dip will keep refrigerated for three days.
chief_review: This vibrant starter combines the sweet tang of Peppadew piquante peppers with juicy tomatoes and an umami-rich sundried tomato paste, finished with a fresh chive garnish. Its bold flavors belie its low-calorie content, making it a satisfying beginning to any meal. The recipe is naturally vegan and gluten-free, catering to both plant-based and gluten-avoidant diets. With minimal ingredients and clean preparation, it’s also ideal for those with common food allergies, as it contains no dairy, nuts, or eggs. The interplay of sweet, savory, and herbal notes showcases the freshness of the produce, and the dish’s simplicity lets these ingredients shine. It’s a wonderful choice for anyone looking for a light, flavorful, and allergy-friendly appetizer that can easily be prepared ahead of time.

name: Flavoured butters
description: Flavoured butters are great to have to hand, make a batch and keep them in the freezer for meat and fish dishes
author: Mary Cadogan
ingredients: 4 tbsp freshly grated parmesan(or vegetarian alternative)
½ a 400g can red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
directions: Take 100g of butter out of the fridge for an hour to soften. Flavour is key, so use good-quality semi-salted or unsalted butter. Beat the butter with a wooden spoon until it is soft and creamy, then beat in any of the flavourings you fancy. See each below.

Tip the flavoured butter onto a square of baking parchment or cling film, roll it around the butter to form a sausage shape, then twist the ends to seal. The butter is now ready to be stored for up to 3 days in the fridge or up to a month in the freezer.
chief_review: This recipe for flavoured butters offers a versatile way to elevate meat and fish dishes, delivering layers of vibrant, aromatic flavors. The inclusion of fresh herbs, garlic, sun-dried tomato, and zesty lime ensures a delightful balance, while the parmesan (or vegetarian alternative) adds a savory richness. The use of horseradish cream and crushed peppercorns introduces a subtle heat that will complement red meats especially well. Provided you use a suitable vegetarian cheese, this recipe easily adapts for lacto-vegetarian diets. It is also a handy make-ahead option—prepare in batches, freeze, and slice as needed. This butter elevates simple proteins with little effort, bringing both convenience and gourmet flair to your cooking repertoire.

name: Apricot stilton pots
description: Treat your guests to an extra special cheese course or give these away as little gifts
author: Good Food
directions: Crumble or grate the stilton into a small bowl. Beat the softened butter until creamy, then stir in the stilton.
Pack into three 150ml/¼ pt ramekins and smooth the tops. Mix the walnuts and apricots and press on top of the cheese. Wrap in cling film and chill for up to a week or freeze for up to 2 months.
chief_review: This recipe delivers a luxurious twist on the classic cheese course, combining creamy vegetarian Stilton with softened butter, nutty walnuts, and tangy dried apricots. The rich blue cheese sets a bold foundation, beautifully offset by the sweetness and texture of the dried fruits and nuts. With its vegetarian ingredients—specifically the vegetarian Stilton—this cheese spread suits a vegetarian diet and makes an ideal choice for gatherings where meat-free options are valued. The recipe is thoughtfully balanced, easy to prepare, and visually appealing, making it perfect for entertaining or gifting. Serve with seeded crackers or crusty bread to let these vibrant flavors shine.

name: Classic vinaigrette
description: This classic dressing is easy to make at home, and stores in the jar for up to a week
author: Good Food
directions: Put the mustard, vinegar and olive oil in a jar and season. Shake vigorously to mix. Store in a cool place (not the fridge) until ready to use. Use for all your salads or try one of our recipes, right. Vinaigrette will keep for a week.
chief_review: This classic dressing is a beautifully simple concoction, balancing the tang of red wine vinegar with the slight sharpness of Dijon mustard and the smooth body of light olive oil. Its silky texture and vibrant flavor make it an ideal accompaniment for green salads or drizzling over roasted vegetables. With no animal-derived ingredients, this vinaigrette is naturally vegan and vegetarian friendly. The absence of gluten-containing elements means it also suits a gluten-free diet. The short ingredient list keeps the flavors clean and allows the punchy mustard to shine without overpowering. Best made fresh, it does hold well for up to a week in the refrigerator, developing its character over time. This recipe is a staple for those seeking a quick, versatile, and nutritious salad enhancer.

name: Flavoured butters
description: Try these different flavoured butters melted over new potatoes, grilled fish, chicken or steak
author: Maxine Clark
ingredients: 2-3 tbsp chopped fresh mixed herbs ( parsley, chervil, dill, marjoram, basil)
salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
1 tsp chopped fresh tarragon (remember this is very strong)
salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
½ tsp crushed, dried chilli flakes
2 tbsp finely chopped pickled dill cucumber or gherkins
salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
directions: Take100g/4oz softened butter and beat until creamy, then for...
Herby butter: stir in 2-3 tbsp chopped fresh mixed herbs (parsley, chervil, dill, marjoram, basil) and salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
Tarragon and wholegrain mustard butter: stir in 1 tsp chopped fresh tarragon (remember this is very strong) and 1-2 tbsp wholegrain mustard, plus salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
Mint and cider butter: gradually beat in 1 tbsp cider vinegar, then 2 tbsp chopped fresh mint and salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
Chive and shallot butter: stir in 1 tbsp finely chopped shallots and 2 tbsp chopped fresh chives, plus salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
Parsley, lemon and chilli butter: stir in 3 tbsp chopped fresh parsley, 2 tsp finely grated lemon zest, salt to taste and ½ tsp crushed, dried chilli flakes.
Dill butter: stir in 2 tbsp finely chopped pickled dill cucumber or gherkins and 3 tbsp chopped fresh dill, plus salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.

After mixing, have the flavoured butters handy in the fridge or freezer ready for slicing. Roll them into logs in wet greaseproof paper and chill until firm. Rewrap in cling film and twist each end to seal. Will keep in the fridge for 4-5 days or in the freezer for up to 3 months.
chief_review: A testament to classic French technique, these flavoured butters are a chef’s essential for adding depth to a variety of dishes. The use of fresh herbs such as parsley, chervil, dill, marjoram, and tarragon ensures vibrant, layered flavours, while additions like mustard, cider vinegar, gherkins, and lemon zest introduce complexity and brightness. The butter delivers creaminess that effortlessly enriches new potatoes, grilled fish, chicken, or steak. The versatility shines in the suggested combinations – be it herb-centric, zesty, or with a subtle kick from chilli flakes. Suitable for ovo-lacto vegetarians, this recipe is also a useful tool for prepping ahead, as compound butters store well and elevate the simplest ingredients. Perfect for those seeking a quick yet refined accompaniment.

name: Crispy Roast Duck
description: Duck basted to perfection, ideal for a Sunday lunch or special occasion
author: Ruth Watson
directions: Remove the duck’s giblets and wash them. Cut off any greenish parts from the livers and discard, then roughly chop the rest. Quarter the crops (the gullet), slicing any very red flesh away from the white sinew, which should be discarded. Put all bits and pieces into a large roasting tin.

Cut off the parson’s nose from each duck and add to the tin. Remove the wings: hold and pull on a wing, turning the skin back so you can see inside to where the wing is attached to the shoulder bone. Cut between the bones to release the wing, then cut around it from the skin side to remove it. Repeat with all wings and add them to the tin.

Turn one of the ducks on to its breast. Cut down each side of the backbone, using a very sharp, sturdy kitchen knife and/or game scissors. Remove the backbone, then turn the duck the other way up and cut down each side of the breastbone, keeping the blade close to the bone so you don’t cut away any breast meat. Put all the bones into the tin and repeat with the other ducks.

Remove any lumps of fat from inside the duck and set aside. Cut off any flappy bits of skin and discard. Wash the duck halves then pat very dry. Prick the skin all over, especially the thick, fatty areas, then sprinkle with fine sea salt.

Preheat the oven to 230C/Gas 8/fan oven 210C. Arrange the duck halves skin-side up on a rack set inside a large roasting tin. Roast for 11⁄4-11⁄2 hours, or until the skin is crisp and dark golden. You will need to drain off the fat that accumulates once or twice: pour it straight into the tin if you’re going to roast potatoes, otherwise into a heatproof bowl.
Leave the duck to rest for 10-15 minutes, serve with the gravy and veg (see 'Goes well with' recipes, right).
chief_review: This roasted duck recipe is a classic showcase of crisp, flavorful skin and succulent meat, with simplicity at its heart—just duck and fine sea salt. The focus on quality protein and minimal seasoning allows the natural flavors to shine, making it perfect for highlighting duck’s luxurious texture and rich taste. It’s an excellent centerpiece for a family Sunday lunch or a celebratory meal. Notably, its straightforward ingredient list makes it suitable for gluten-free diets and those avoiding common allergens like dairy, nuts, or soy. Serve with roasted root vegetables or a tangy fruit sauce to complement the savory notes. Simple, elegant, and deeply satisfying.

name: Smoked salmon kedgeree
description: This kedgeree is totally delicious. Treat everyone to an extra special brunch.
author: Barney Desmazery
ingredients: large knob of fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
1 tsp each fennel and cumin seeds
large bunch coriander, leaves reserved, stalks chopped
directions: To make the sauce, heat the butter in a large pan, then tip in the onions, garlic, ginger, spices and bay. Fry over medium heat for 8-10 mins until the onions colour. Stir in the purée, curry powder and coriander stalks, then cook for a few mins until everything is sticky. Pour in the stock and cream, season, stir well, then bring to the boil. Gently simmer for 15 mins until reduced by half. Strain through a sieve into a container. Keep covered in the fridge for up to two days.

Rinse the rice in several changes of water, then put in a pan with enough cold water to cover it by 1.5cm. Cover the pan, then place over a high heat. Bring to a fast boil, stir, return the lid, turn heat to minimum, then leave the pan for 2 mins. Turn the heat off; leave for a further 10 mins. If making ahead, cool quickly, then refrigerate.

On the day, poach the eggs, then set aside. Roughly chop the salmon and coriander leaves. Reheat rice until piping hot. Heat sauce until simmering, then stir in the rice. Stir though salmon and most of the coriander. Spoon into bowls
chief_review: This sumptuous take on kedgeree elegantly balances smoky salmon with aromatic spices and creamy richness. Basmati rice absorbs flavor from fennel, cumin, cardamom, and bay leaves, while ginger, onion, and garlic add piquancy. The addition of double cream brings luxuriously velvety texture, complemented by the silkiness of scrambled egg. Fresh coriander lifts the dish, adding brightness against the heady mix of curry powder and tomato purée. This recipe is suitable for pescatarians, but do note it includes dairy and eggs. The use of chicken stock can be swapped for a quality vegetable stock to adapt for ovo-lacto vegetarians. Serve for brunch as a centerpiece—it’s hearty, fragrant, and deeply satisfying, sure to impress guests with its blend of classic British and South Asian flavors.

name: Spicy potted crab
description: An ideal elegant starter for a wedding
author: Merrilees Parker
ingredients: 2 tsp hot chilli powder (or use ¼-½ tsp pure chilli powder - cayenne)
950g fresh (well picked over) or frozen (thawed) white crabmeat
juice of 2 lemons and zest of one good pinch of freshly grated nutmeg
1 white medium sliced loaf of bread
2 lemons for garnish, cut into 20 wedges
directions: Heat the butter in a pan until melted. Turn up the heat a little to separate most of the milk solids (the creamy white looking part) to start clarifying, but be careful it doesn’t burn. It is clarified when there are a few nutty brown “bits” at the bottom and the remaining liquid is a clear golden colour. Cool slightly and carefully pour into a jug, leaving the nutty “bits” behind.
Pour the clear butter back into a clean pan and tip in the chilli powder. Heat very gently for 1-2 minutes. (The butter will cloud up again.)
Put the rest of the ingredients in a bowl and season. Carefully fold together with a spatula, trying not to break up the plump flesh. Taste and adjust seasoning.

Loosely spoon the mixture into 20 100ml ramekins or into one larger shallow serving dish. Ensure you leave a nice level top. Now pour over the chilli clarified butter to give a thin covering. Stir the butter to distribute the spice each time before you pour. If the butter cools too much, microwave it for 30 seconds. Cover the ramekins and put in the fridge for 2 hours, or overnight, until the butter is set.

Make the melba toast: lightly toast the bread. Cut off the crusts, then slice the bread through the centre so you have ultra thin slices. Put the toast, cut-side up, under a medium to hot grill to toast until the edges curl. Be careful as it burns easily. Cool, and store in sealed plastic bags.

Remove the potted crab from the fridge an hour before serving, but keep in a cool place. You want the mixture to be soft enough so that all the delicious buttery flavours blend into the toast. Put each ramekin or a spoonful of spicy crab on to a serving plate with a lemon wedge.
Crisp the melba toast, if necessary, in the oven for 5 minutes. Place a couple of slices on each plate and serve.
chief_review: This elegant crab starter is a luxurious choice, perfect for a wedding reception. The combination of fresh white crabmeat, abundant herbs, and a subtle kick from chilli powder showcases clean, bright flavors. The addition of lemon juice and zest provides the right acidity to balance the richness of unsalted butter, while nutmeg adds a gentle warmth in the background. Serving with sliced white bread offers a comforting contrast in texture and makes for convenient, attractive presentation when garnished with lemon wedges. This recipe is particularly well-suited for pescatarians, and could accommodate a vegetarian diet if the crab were substituted with a suitable plant-based alternative. Note, however, that bread selection is key if gluten-free options are required; otherwise, the main ingredients focus exclusively on seafood and fresh herbs. Overall, it’s refined yet approachable—an excellent start to a celebratory meal.

name: Sage and Onion Sauce
description: A great accompaniment to roast duck that can be made in advance
author: Ruth Watson
ingredients: all the innards, wings and bones from the ducks
1 large leek, trimmed, washed and chopped
2 medium onions, peeled and finely diced
6 large fresh sage leaves, finely chopped
directions: Preheat the oven to 230C/Gas 8/fan oven 210C. Brown the duck bits in the oven for about 30 minutes. Transfer to a stockpot. Discard the fat and place the tin over a medium-high flame. Pour in the Marsala and 200ml/7fl oz cold water, bring to the boil and scrape any stuck-on bits into the liquid. Boil for 2 minutes then scrape everything into the stockpot.
Add 2.25 litres/4 pints cold water to the pot and bring to the boil over a medium heat, uncovered. Scoop off any scum, then add the vegetables and herbs. Bring back to the boil, de-scum again.

Now very gently simmer for 2 hours, adding cold water if the liquid falls below the level of the bones. Remove from the heat and drain through muslin-lined colander (or use a clean tea towel) into a heatproof bowl. Cool, then refrigerate until jellied.

Heat the butter and oil in a large, nonstick frying pan over a low-medium heat, then tip in the onions. Cook for about 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until meltingly soft. Turn heat to high, add the Marsala and boil for 3-4 minutes, stirring often, until onions are syrupy. Set aside.

Meanwhile, remove the solidified fat from the stock and discard. Boil the stock in a saucepan, uncovered, until reduced to 500ml/18fl oz. Add the white wine and boil for 10 minutes, uncovered. Add the onions and sage and bring back to the boil. (Prepare in advance up to this point.)
To finish the sauce, pour in the cream and boil furiously for 4-5 minutes, season to taste. Serve in a warmed jug.
chief_review:
This sauce recipe, rich and complex, is a classic French-inspired accompaniment ideal for roast duck. The combination of duck offal, marsala, dry white wine, and aromatic herbs (bay leaf, thyme, parsley, sage) delivers deep, layered flavors that complement the richness of the poultry. The use of double cream provides a velvety texture, beautifully binding all flavors together. The infusion of both butter and olive oil adds depth and silkiness to the finished product. 

This recipe is suitable for those following a gluten-free diet, as none of the ingredients listed contain gluten. Dairy allergies or lactose intolerance should be noted due to the inclusion of butter and double cream. Make it ahead of time for ease of entertaining—its flavor only improves as it rests. Pair generously with roast duck or other game for an indulgent, restaurant-quality finish to your meal.
